paragraph: Philosophy (from the Greek word φιλοσοφία,philosophy, meaning "love of wisdom" ) is the study of general and fundamental questions, such as questions of existence, reason, values, reason, and language. This term is probably first used by Pythagoras (c. 570–495SM). The methods used in philosophy include asking questions, critical discussion, dialectics, and systematic presentations. Classical philosophical questions include: Is it possible to know everything and prove it? What's the most real? Philosophers also ask more practical and concrete questions such as: Is there a best way to live? Is it better to be fair or unfair (if one can get away with it)? Do humans have free will? Historically, philosophy encompasses the core of all knowledge. From the time of Ancient Greek philosophers such as Aristotle until the 19th century, natural philosophy encompassed astronomy, medicine, and physics. For example, Newton's Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy in 1687 is later classified as a physics book. In the 19th century, the development of modern university research ushered in professionalized and specialized academic philosophy and other disciplines. In the modern era, several investigations that were traditionally part of philosophy have become separate academic disciplines, some of which are psychology, sociology, linguistics, and economics. Other investigations closely related to art, science, politics and several other fields remained part of philosophy. For example, is beauty objective or subjective? Are there many scientific methods or is there only one? Is political utopia a hopeful dream or a vain delusion? The main sub-fields of academic philosophy include metaphysics (dealing with the nature of reality and being), epistemology (concerning "the origins and fields of knowledge and] ... their limits and validity" ), ethics, aesthetics, political philosophy, logic, philosophy of science , and the history of western philosophy.

Since the 20th century, professional philosophers have contributed to society primarily as professors, researchers, and writers. However, many of those who study philosophy in undergraduate or postgraduate programs contribute to the fields of law, journalism, politics, religion, science, business and various arts and entertainment activities. The word philosophy or philosophy in Indonesian is an absorption word from Arabic: فلسفة‎, which is also taken from Greek; Φιλοσοφία philosophia. In this language, this word is a compound word, and comes from the words (philia = friendship, love, etc.) and (sophia = wisdom, س** ایرانی citation needed], so its literal meaning is a "lover of wisdom". which is taken from the Dutch language is also known in Indonesia. This last form is more similar to the original. In Indonesian a person who studies philosophy is called a "philosopher". knowledge. In this sense, philosophy is closely related to religion, mathematics, natural science, education, and politics. "Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy", Newton's work in 1687 was classified in the 2000s as a physics book; he used the term "philosophy nature" because the term was used to cover disciplines later associated with science such as astronomy, medicine, and physics. In classical times, Philosophy t is traditionally divided into three main branches: This division is not obsolete but has changed. Natural philosophy has divided into various natural sciences, especially astronomy, physics, chemistry, biology, and cosmology. Moral philosophy has given birth to the social sciences, but still includes value theory (including aesthetics, ethics, political philosophy, etc.). Metaphysical philosophy has given birth to formal sciences such as logic, mathematics and philosophy of science, but still includes epistemology, cosmology and others.

Utilitarianism is a normative ethical theory that dictates that kindness is the act that maximizes the happiness and well-being of all affected individuals. Although there are forms of utilitarianism with different characteristics, the basic idea of ​​ethical utilitarianism is to maximize utility, or what is often defined in terms of welfare. Jeremy Bentham, founder of utilitarianism, defines utility as "the character in any object that produces benefit, gain, pleasure, good, or happiness ... or] prevents harm, pain, evil, or unhappiness to those whose interests are considered. ” Utilitarianism is a version of consequentialism, an ethical theory that holds that the consequences of an action are the only standard by which right and wrong are judged.Unlike other forms of consequentialism, such as egoism and altruism, utilitarianism considers the interests of all humans to be equal.Proponents of utilitarianism Opinions differ on several issues, such as whether an action should be chosen on the basis of its probable consequences (action utilitarianism), or whether an agent should act according to a utility-maximizing rule (rule utilitarianism). ), the average utility (average utilitarianism) or the utility of the poorest people that must be maximized. Although the origins of ethical utilitarianism can be traced and found in the hedonic philosophy of Aristippus and Epicurus, who view happiness as a the only good, and in the work of the medieval Indian philosopher Śāntideva, the tradition of modern utilitarianism begins with Jeremy Bentham, and continues with such utilitarian philosophers as John Stuart Mill, Henry Sidgwick, RM Hare, and Peter Singer. The concept of utilitarianism has been applied to social welfare economics, the global poverty crisis, the ethics of raising animals for food, and the importance of avoiding existential risks to humanity. Utilitarian philosophy founded by Jeremy Bentham was substantially modified by his successor, John Stuart Mill, who popularized the term utilitarianism.

In 1861, Mill wrote in a footnote that although Bentham claimed "himself to be the first to use the word "utilitarian", he was not the one who coined the term. Mill stated that Bentham had adopted the term utilitarian from an expression in John Galt's 1821 novel , Annals of the Parish. Mill seems to have been unaware, however, that Bentham had used the term utilitarian in his 1781 letter to George Wilson and his 1802 letter to Étienne Dumont. The importance of happiness as the ultimate goal for humankind has long existed. hedonism has been argued by Aristippus and Epicurus; Aristotle argued that eudaimonia is the highest human good; and Augustine wrote that "all men agree in desiring the ultimate end, which is happiness." Happiness is also discussed in depth by Thomas Aquinas, in his Summa Theologica. Meanwhile, in India Medieval, 8th-century Indian philosopher Shantideva was one of the earliest proponents of utilitarianism. He wrote that we must "end all pain and suffering of all living beings now and in the future, and produce pleasure and happiness in the present and in the future." Forms of consequentialism also existed in the ancient and medieval world, such as the state consequentialism of Mohism or the political philosophy of Niccolò Machiavelli. Mohist consequentialism advocates the moral virtues of communitarianism, including political stability, population growth, and wealth, but does not support the utilitarian idea of ​​maximizing individual happiness. Utilitarianism as a separate ethical position emerged only in the 18th century. Although it is generally thought that utilitarianism began with Jeremy Bentham, there have been earlier authors who presented very similar theories. Francis Hutcheson first introduced the central utilitarian phrase in his work, An Inquiry into the Original of Our Ideas of Beauty and Virtue (1725): when choosing the most moral act, the amount of virtue in an action is proportional to the amount of happiness people derive from it.

Søren Aabye Kierkegaard (5 May 1813 – 11 November 1855) was a Danish 19th-century philosopher and theologian. Initially, Kierkegaard himself saw himself as someone who tended to be religious rather than philosophical and somewhat distanced himself from philosophy, but later he became known as the father of existentialist philosophy. Kierkegaard bridged the gulf that existed between Hegelian philosophy and what would later become existentialism. Thus, Kierkegaard became a critic of Hegel in his time and characterized what he saw as the pseudo-formalism of the Danish Church. His philosophy is a reaction against Hegel's dialectics. Many of Kierkegaard's works deal with issues of religion such as the nature of faith, the institutions of the Christian Church, Christian ethics and theology, and the emotions and feelings of individuals when faced with existential choices. Kierkegaard's work has often been described as Christian existentialism and existential psychology. Because he wrote much of his early work under various pseudonyms, often commenting on and criticizing his other works written under other pseudonyms, it is difficult to distinguish between what Kierkegaard really believed and what he advanced as arguments. from the position of a pseudo-author. Ludwig Wittgenstein argues that Kierkegaard was "by far, the most profound thinker of the 19th century". Søren Kierkegaard was born into an affluent family in Copenhagen, the capital of Denmark. His father, Michael Pedersen Kierkegaard, was a very devout man. He believed that he had been cursed by God, and because of that he believed that none of his children would reach the age of Jesus Christ, which was 33 years. He believed that his personal sins, such as cursing God's name in his youth and possibly impregnating Kierkegaard's mother out of wedlock, caused him to deserve this punishment.

Though many of his seven children died young, his prediction was disproved when two of them surpassed this age. This early introduction to the notion of sin and its connection from father and son laid the foundation for much of Kierkegaard's work (particularly Fear and Trembling). Kierkegaard's mother, Anne Sørensdatter Lund Kierkegaard, is not directly referred to in his books, although she too affected his later writings. Despite his father's occasional religious melancholy, Kierkegaard and his father shared a close bond. He learned to use his imagination through a series of exercises and games they played together. Kierkegaard's father died on 9 August 1838 at the age of 82. Before he died, he asked Søren to become a priest. Søren was deeply influenced by his father's religious and life experiences and felt burdened to fulfill his will. Two days later, on 11 August, Kierkegaard wrote: "Father passed away Wednesday. I sincerely wish that he had lived a few years longer, and I consider his death to be the last sacrifice he made out of love for me; ... he died because of me so that, if possible, I could still be something.All that I have inherited from him, his memory, his transfigured portrait ... are precious to me, and I will try to preserve ( memories) to be safely hidden from the world." Kierkegaard attended the Citizen Virtue School, obtaining excellent grades in Latin and history. He continued his studies in theology at the University of Copenhagen, but while there he became increasingly interested in philosophy and literature. At university, Kierkegaard wrote his dissertation, On the Concept of Irony with Constant Reference to Socrates, which the university panel considered important and well thought out, but a bit too flowery and literary to be a philosophy thesis.

Poverty is a state of inability to meet basic needs such as food, clothing, shelter, education and health. Poverty can be caused by scarcity of means of meeting basic needs, or difficulty accessing education and employment. Poverty is a global problem. Some people understand this term subjectively and comparatively, while others see it from a moral and evaluative point of view, and still others understand it from an established scientific angle, and so on. Poverty is understood in different ways. The main understanding includes: Poverty can be grouped into two categories, namely absolute poverty and relative poverty. Absolute poverty refers to a consistent set of standards, regardless of time and place/country. An example of an absolute measure is the percentage of the population that eats below the amount sufficient to sustain the human body's needs (approximately 2000-2500 calories per day for an adult male). The World Bank defines absolute poverty as living with an income below United States Dollars (USD) $1/day and middle poverty for an income below $2 per day, with these limits it is estimated that in 2001 1.1 billion people in the world consumed less than $1/day and 2.7 billion people worldwide consume less than $2/day." The proportion of the population of developing countries living in extreme poverty has fallen from 28% in 1990 to 21% in 2001. Looking at the period 1981-2001, the percentage of the world's population living below the poverty line $1 dollar/day has been halved. However, the value of $1 has also decreased over this period. Although poverty is most severe in the developing world, there is evidence of poverty in every region. In developed countries, these conditions present the wandering homeless and impoverished suburbs and ghettos.

Poverty can be seen as the collective condition of the poor, or groups of poor people, and in this sense entire countries are sometimes considered poor. To avoid this stigma, these countries are usually referred to as developing countries. Poverty cannot be understood using one dimension or one indicator only. Poverty is very complex, so multidimensional indicators or measures are needed. The indicators that are widely used are global indicators using a monetary approach such as the poverty line used by the World Bank with a limit of USD 1.25 Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) or through the basic consumption approach (basic need) which is also used in Indonesia. Meanwhile, this approach only looks at indicators of income or consumption by the community and according to Sen (2000) is considered not to have captured the real root causes of poverty. To look at the problem of poverty holistically, IKM (Multidimensional Poverty Index) was developed. The concept was first developed by the Oxford Poverty and Human Initiative (OPHI) in collaboration with the Nation Development Program (UNDP) in 2010. The main objective of developing the concept is to map poverty indicators more comprehensively and clearly. As a result, when adopted in Indonesia, there are three indicators that are used to understand the problem of poverty, namely health, education, and quality of life standards. These indicators show that monetary and consumption approaches alone are not enough to provide a clear picture of poverty, other indicators are needed such as health, education, and quality of life standards. Debates related to the state of human capital and one's individual capital tend to focus on access to instructional capital and social capital which are available only to those who are educated in the formal system. The Copenhagen Declaration defines absolute poverty as "a condition characterized by severe deprivation of basic human needs, including food, safe drinking water, sanitation facilities, health, housing, education and information."

Immanuel Kant (UK /kænt/, US /kɑːnt/, German: ɪˈmaːnu̯eːl ˈkant, -nu̯ɛl]; 22 April 1724 – 12 February 1804) was a German philosopher and one of the principal intellectuals of the Age of Enlightenment. Kant's comprehensive and systematic work in the fields of epistemology, metaphysics, ethics, and aesthetics has made him one of the most influential figures in modern Western philosophy. In his account of transcendental idealism, Kant argued that space and time are simply "intuitive forms" that shape all experience. Therefore, although the "thing-in-itself" exists and contributes to experience, it is still distinct from the object of experience. From this it can be concluded that the object of experience is only what appears, and the nature of things in themselves (an sich) cannot be known by humans. In an effort to counter the skepticism he found in the writings of the philosopher David Hume, he wrote Critique of Pure Reason (1781/1787), one of his most famous works. In that work, he developed a theory of experience to answer the question whether synthetic a priori knowledge is possible. This in turn will make it possible to define the limits of metaphysical inquiry. Kant equated his idea with the Copernican revolution to determine sense objects as something that is in accordance with our spatial and temporal intuition forms, so that we have a priori cognition about these objects. a] Kant holds that reason is the source of morality, and aesthetics arises from the ability of impartial judgment . Kant's views continue to have a major influence on contemporary philosophy, especially post-modern epistemology, ethics, political theory, and aesthetics. He sought to explain the relationship between reason and human experience and moved beyond what he believed to be the failings of traditional philosophy and metaphysics.

He wanted to end what he saw as the era of the futile and speculative theory of human experience and rejected the skepticism of thinkers like Hume. Kant is considered to have shown the way past the impasse between rationalism and empiricism, and to have broadly synthesized the two traditions in his thinking. Kant supported the idea that lasting peace could be achieved through universal democracy and international co-operation, and perhaps this could be the pinnacle of world history. Kant's religious views have continued to be the subject of scholarly debate, ranging from the suggestion that he shifted from an ontological argument for the existence of God to principled agnosticism, to a more critical view exemplified by Schopenhauer, who criticized Kant's ethical imperative form as "theological morals", to Nietzsche who claimed that Kant had "theological blood" and was only an expert defender of traditional Christianity. b] Outside of his religious views, Kant has been criticized for racism in several of his papers such as "On the Use of Teleological Principles in Philosophy" and "On the Differences of Races" Man". Although he was a supporter of scientific racism for most of his career, Kant's views on race changed significantly in the last decades of his life. Ultimately, Kant rejected racial hierarchies and European colonialism in his Towards Lasting Peace: A Philosophical Concept (1795). During his lifetime, Kant also published other important works on ethics, religion, law, aesthetics, astronomy, and history. These include Universal Natural History (1755), Critique of Practical Reason (1788), Criticism of Judgment (1790), Religion within the Limits of Pure Reason (1793), and Moral Metaphysics (1797). Immanuel Kant was born on April 22, 1724 in a small town in East Prussia, namely Königsberg. His family was a devout Protestant, thus influencing Kant's thinking about morals.

Pharmacy is the science that studies all the intricacies of medicine. Pharmaceutical science is the application of (at least) three fields of science, namely medicine, chemistry, and biology. The scope of pharmaceutical science does not only focus on the exact sciences, but also on the social sciences such as Pharmaceutical Management and Pharmacoeconomics. In accordance with the regulations stipulated in Government Regulation no. 51 of 2009 concerning Pharmaceutical Work, pharmaceutical work is manufacturing including quality control of pharmaceutical preparations, security, procurement, storage and distribution or distribution of drugs, drug management, drug services on doctor's prescription, drug information services, as well as development of drugs, medicinal ingredients and traditional medicines . It is also regulated in the regulation that pharmaceutical work is only entitled to be carried out by pharmaceutical staff consisting of: Pharmacists in Indonesia are marked by the title of apt. in front of the proper name. In pharmaceutical work, only pharmacists can be responsible for all pharmaceutical work performed. In contrast to doctors who wear bone-white coats, pharmacists' official attire when carrying out their practice is an ivory white coat. Overseas (in English) pharmacists are referred to as "pharmacists", which are Indonesianized to become pharmacists. The term pharmacist is rarely used and is not official to refer to pharmacy staff, but is often used to represent all pharmacists produced by various levels of education (SMK Pharmacy, Diploma in Pharmacy, Bachelor of Pharmacy, and Pharmacist). "Pharmacy" is an absorption word from the English word "pharmacy". Meanwhile, the word "pharmacy" itself is rooted in the word "pharmacon" which is the name of the Ancient Greeks for "medicine". "Farmacie" (French) and "pharmakeia" (Latin) are other early forms of the historical word "pharmacy". The history of pharmacy and medicine has been heavily influenced by figures such as Hippocrates (450-370 BC), Dioscorides (1st century AD), and Galen (120-130 AD).

Buddhism (Sanskrit: बुद्ध, /ˈbʊdɪzəm/, known as Buddhism in Indonesia) is a non-theistic philosophical view originating in the eastern part of the Indian subcontinent, based on the teachings of Siddhartha Gautama. The spread of Buddhism in India started from the 6th century BC to the 4th century BC. Buddhism is the world's fourth largest religious group with over 520 million followers, or over 7% of the world's population, known as Buddhists.web 1] Buddhism also encompasses a wide range of knowledge, traditional values, philosophies, beliefs, meditation, and spiritual practices, some of which are largely based on the early teachings attributed to Siddhartha Gautama and produced an interpreted philosophy. Buddhism arose in ancient India as a Sramana tradition sometime between the 6th and 4th centuries B.C., spreading through much of Asia. The Buddha is known by Buddhists as the enlightened or enlightened Supreme Master who shared His insights to help sentient beings end their suffering by eliminating ignorance/ignorance/delusion (moha), greed (lobha), and hatred/anger ( sin). The ending or extinction of moha, lobha and sin is called Nibbana. To attain Nibbana one performs right actions, abstains from wrong actions, practices meditation to keep the mind always in a good or pure state and is able to understand mental and physical phenomena. The two main extant schools of Buddhism that are generally accepted by scholars: Theravada ("School of the Elders") and Mahayana ("Great Vehicle"). Vajrayana, a form of teaching associated with Indian siddhas, can also be considered a third school or only a part of Mahayana. Theravada has a widespread following in Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia. Mahayana, which includes the Pure Land, Zen, Nichiren, Shingon, and Tiantai (Tiendai) traditions can be found throughout East Asia.

Tibetan Buddhism, which preserves the Vajrayana teachings from 8th century India, is practiced in the region surrounding the Himalayas, Mongolia, and Kalmykia. The number of Buddhists worldwide is estimated to be between 488 millionweb 1] and 535 million, making it one of the world's major religions. In Theravada Buddhism, the ultimate goal is the attainment of the supreme bliss of Nibbana, which is achieved by practicing the Noble Eightfold Path (also known as the Middle Path), thereby breaking free from what is known as the cycle of suffering and rebirth. Mahayana Buddhism, on the other hand, aspires to attain buddhahood through the bodhisattva path, a state in which one remains in the cycle of helping other beings attain enlightenment. Each school of Buddhism adheres to the Tipitaka as the main reference because it contains the words and teachings of Gautama Buddha. His followers then recorded and classified his teachings into three books, namely the Sutta Piṭaka (discourses of the Buddha), Vinaya Piṭaka (rules or regulations of monks) and Abhidhamma Piṭaka (teachings of metaphysical and psychological laws). All texts of the Theravada school use Pali, the language spoken in parts of India (especially the North) at the time of the Buddha. It is interesting to note, however, that there are no other philosophical or writings in the Pali language apart from the sacred texts of Theravada Buddhism, which are called the Tipitaka, and thus the term "Pali Buddhist teachings" is synonymous with Theravada Buddhism. Theravada Buddhism and several other sources argue that the Buddha taught all of his teachings in Pali, in India, Nepal and beyond for the last 45 years of his life, before he attained Parinibbana. All of the Mahayana texts were originally in Sanskrit and were known as the Tripitaka. Therefore the term Buddhism in Sanskrit is synonymous with Mahayana Buddhism.

Revisions asked to hide include: Feminism (derived from the French word feminine) is an adjective meaning "female" or denoting female characteristics. Feminism is a flow of women's movement that fights for women's rights. Movements and ideologies that aim to reach the level of gender that is under the auspices of human rights. Feminism is a series of social movements, political movements and ideologies that have the goal of fighting for women's rights by establishing equality in the political, economic, personal and social aspects of the two sexes. a] Feminism incorporates the position that society prioritizes the male point of view and that women are treated unfairly in that society. Efforts to change this include fighting gender stereotypes and working to build equal educational and professional opportunities with men. The feminist movement has campaigned for and continues to campaign for women's rights including the right to vote, hold political office, work, earn fair wages, equal pay and close the gender pay gap, to own property, to receive an education, to enter into contracts, to have equal rights in marriage and to have maternity leave. Feminists seek to protect women from acts of social integration violence, to protect women from rape, sexual harassment and domestic violence. Changes in dress and acceptable physical activity are often part of the feminist movement. Some scholars consider feminist campaigns to be the main force behind major historical social changes to women's rights, particularly in the West, where they were almost universally credited for achieving women's suffrage, gender-neutral language, reproductive rights for women (including access to contraception and the right to enter into contracts and own property.Although feminist advocacy focuses mainly on women's rights, some feminists, including Bell hooks, argue to include male liberation in the goals of feminism because they believe that men are also harmed by the role of their traditional gender.

Feminist theory, which emerged from the feminist movement, aims to understand the nature of gender inequality by examining women's social roles and life experiences; it has developed theories in various disciplines to respond to issues of gender. Many feminist movements and ideologies have developed over the last years and represent different viewpoints and goals. Some forms of feminism have been criticized for taking into account only white, middle-class, and highly educated perspectives. This critique has led to the creation of ethnically specific and multicultural forms of feminism, including black feminism and intersectional feminism. The feminist movement started at the end of the 18th century and developed rapidly throughout the 20th century which began with the voice of equal political rights for women. Mary Wollstonecraft's writing entitled A Vindication of The Rights of Woman is considered as one of the earliest feminist writings containing criticism of the French Revolution which only applies to men but not to women. A century later in Indonesia, Raden Ajeng Kartini contributed to her thoughts on criticizing the condition of Javanese women who were not given the opportunity to receive an education equal to that of men, apart from criticizing Dutch colonialism. At the end of the 20th century, the feminist movement was widely seen as an offshoot of the Critical Legal Studies movement, which essentially provided a lot of criticism of the logic of law that had been used so far, the manipulative nature and dependence of law on politics, the economy, the role of law in shaping patterns of social relations, and the formation of hierarchies by statutory provisions is not fundamental. Even though feminist opinions are pluralistic, one thing that unites them is their belief that society and the legal order are patriarchal. Rules of law that are said to be neutral and objective are often only a cover for political and social considerations driven by decision-making ideologies, and these ideologies are not in the interests of women.

Sramana (Dewanagari: श्रमण; ,IAST: Śramaṇa,; Pali: समण samaṇa) is a non-Vedic based religious movement from India, similar to but distinct from Brahmanism. The Sramana tradition led to the emergence of Yoga, Jainism, Buddhism, and several nastika schools in Hinduism such as Carwaka and Ajiwika, as well as popular concepts such as saṃsāra (the cycle of birth and death) and moksa (freedom from the cycle) in Indian religions. note 1 ] The Pali words Samaṇa and Śramaṇa in Sanskrit refer to an ascetic tradition dating back to the middle of the 1st millennium BC. This movement is individual, experience-based, free-form tradition, and does not depend on the common people; competing with brahmin priests—as opposed to sramanas—who place more emphasis on mastering the scriptures and performing rituals. The words Samaṇa and Śramaṇa are thought to have originated from the root śram, meaning "to exert effort, exertion, or strain". So "Śramaṇa" means "one who works hard" or "labor" in Sanskrit and Pali. The Śramaṇa tradition is more properly used with the term parivrajaka, meaning a homeless wanderer. The history of wandering monks in ancient India is rather difficult to trace. The term 'parivrajaka' could perhaps be applied to all the wandering monks of India. Several Sramana movements are known to have existed in India, even before the 6th century BC, and were influenced by the astika or nastika traditions of Indian philosophy. The Sramana movement began to gain prominence during the time of Mahavira and Gautama Buddha, when Vedic ritualism had become the dominant tradition in several parts of India. Sramana adopted alternative methods that replaced the Vedic ceremonies in order to achieve liberation of life and leave the household life. This movement usually involves three kinds of activities: mindfulness, meditation, and related theories. As a spiritual authority, the Sramana is a variant on the traditional Brahmin authority.

Soul (derived from Sanskrit: jiva which means "seed of life") In various religions and philosophies, the soul is the part that is not physical (immaterial) of a person. Usually the soul is believed to include the mind and personality and is synonymous with the spirit, mind, or self. In theology, it is believed that the soul lives on after a person dies, and some religions teach that God is the creator of the soul. In some cultures, inanimate objects are said to have souls, a belief called animism. The terms soul and spirit are often used interchangeably, although the first word relates more to the world than the second. Jiwa and psyche can also be used synonymously, although psyche has a more physical connotation, while soul is closely associated with metaphysics and religion. Meanwhile, according to the Big Indonesian Dictionary, the word soul means the human spirit (which is in the body and causes a person to live or life. The soul is also interpreted as the entire human inner life (which occurs from feelings, thoughts, dreams, and so on). The human soul is different from the souls of other creatures such as animals, trees, etc. The human soul is like the universe, or the universe itself, which is hidden in the human body and is constantly moving and rotating. by the spirit. The first philosopher who studied and gave a definition of the soul was Plato. In his thinking, Plato defined the soul as something that is not visible but is the real world that does not change. The nature of the soul is eternal and does not change. The body and soul are considered different. Each each has a function for human existence.The soul acts as a regulator of rational action which then controls it human desires or passions.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health sciences Climatology or climate science (derived from Ancient Greek κλίμα, klima, "place, region, zone"; and -λογία, -logia "science") is the study of climate, scientifically defined as the weather conditions that averaged over a long period of time. This field of study is categorized as a branch of atmospheric science and a subfield of physical geography, which is one of the earth sciences. Climatology also includes aspects of oceanography and biogeochemistry. Basic knowledge of climate can be used in weather forecasting using analogous methods in the case of ENSO, Madden-Julian Oscillation, North Atlantic Oscillation, and so on. Climate models are also used to study weather dynamics and the climate system to project climate in the future. The Chinese scholar Shen Kuo (1021-1095) suggested that the climate naturally shifted over time, after observing weather-preserved bamboo near Yanzhou (Yan'an, Shaanxi province), because a dry area would be impossible for bamboo to grow. Early climate researchers, such as Edmund Halley, published maps of wind movement in 1686 after his trip to the Southern Hemisphere. Benjamin Franklin (1706-1790) first charted the path of the Gulf Stream to use as a method of postal delivery from the United States to Europe. Francis Galton (1822-1911) coined the term "anticyclone". Helmut Landsberg (1906-1985) developed the use of statistical analysis in climatology which sparked the drastic development of climatology into a physical science. Climatology is done in various ways. Paleoclimatology reprojects past climates by examining records such as ice cores and tree growth rings (dendroclimatology). Paleotempestology uses the same records to determine the frequency of hurricanes over thousands of years. Contemporary climate studies involve meteorological data accumulated over a period of several years, such as data on precipitation, temperature, and composition of the atmosphere.

Knowledge of the atmosphere and its dynamics is also collected in models, such as statistical modeling or mathematical modelling, which integrate various observations and test their fit. Modeling is used to understand climate in the past, present climate, and future climate. Historical climatology is the study of climate as a factor influencing the development of human history and focuses only on periods of hundreds or tens of thousands of years. Research on climate is quite difficult to do because it involves a very large area, a very long period of time, and a complex process. Because it is the result of averaging weather parameters over a very long period of time, climate can be described by differential equations. These equations are connected nonlinearly so that approximate solutions can be obtained by using numerical methods to create climate models. Climate is often modeled as a stochastic process. However, it is generally accepted as an approximation of climate processes that are too complex to analyze. Scientists use climate patterns based on multiple climate patterns (known as variability modes) in their attempts to characterize and understand the various climatic mechanisms that culminate in everyday weather. Climate patterns are generally designed simply as two objects that complement each other in that period, which oscillate like the El Nino phenomenon which is then followed by La Nina, then returns to El Nino. The most commonly discussed is the El Niño Southern Oscillation, but other climate phenomena such as the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO), North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), Northern Annular Mode (NAM) or Arctic Oscillation (AO), Pacific Index North, Pacific Decade Oscillation (PDO), Interdecade Pacific Oscillation (IPO) El Nino is a global atmosphere-ocean phenomenon. As the characteristics of the Pacific Ocean, El Nino and La Nina are important temperature fluctuations in surface waters in the tropical area around the Pacific Ocean.

Ānanda (Pali and Sanskrit: आनन्द; 5th–4th century BC) was the Buddha's main attendant and one of his ten chief disciples. Among the Buddha's many disciples, Ānanda stood out for having the best memory. Most of the early Buddhist texts of the Sutta-Piṭaka (Pāli: सुत्त पिटक; Sanskrit: सूत्र-पिटक, Sūtra-Piṭaka) are associated with his recollection of the Buddha's teachings during the First Buddhist Council. As such, he is known as the Treasurer of the Dhamma, where Dhamma (Sanskrit: धर्म, dharma) refers to the teachings of the Buddha. In early Buddhist texts, Ānanda is the first cousin of the Buddha. Although the early texts disagree on many parts of Ānanda's early life, they agree that Ānanda was ordained as a monk and that Puṇṇa Mantānīputta (Sanskrit: पूर्ण मैत्रायणीपुत्र, Pūrṇīat Maitr's son) became his guru. Twenty years in the Buddha's service, Ānanda had become the Buddha's servant, when the Buddha selected him for this task. Ānanda performed his duties with great devotion and care, and acted as an intermediary between the Buddha and the laity, as well as a saṅgha (Sanskrit: संघ, translit. saṃgha, lit. 'monastic community'). He accompanied the Buddha for the rest of his life, acting not only as an assistant, but also secretary and spokesman. Scholars are skeptical about the historicity of many events in Ānanda's life, especially the First Council, and a consensus on this point has not been established. Traditional accounts can be drawn from early texts, commentaries, and post-canonical chronicles. Ānanda has an important role in building the order of monks (Sanskrit: भिक्षुणी, translit. Bhikṣuṇī, Har. 'Female Beggars'), when he asked the Buddha to allow his last foster mother Mahāpajāpati Gotamī (Sanskrit: महाप्रजापती गौतमी गौतमी गौतमी गौतमी गौतमी गौतमी महाप्रजापती to be ordained. Ānanda also accompanied the Buddha in the last years of his life, and was therefore a witness to many of the teachings and principles the Buddha imparted before his death, including the well-known tenets that the Buddhist community should take his teachings and discipline as their protection, and that he would not appoint a leader. new.

The last period of the Buddha's life also shows that Ānanda was very attached to the person of the Buddha, and he looked at the Buddha's death with great sorrow. Shortly after the Buddha's death, the First Council was convened, and Ānanda was able to attain enlightenment just before the council started, which was a requirement. He had a historical role during the council as a living memory of the Buddha, reciting many of the Buddha's discourses and checking them for accuracy. However, during the same council, she was punished by Mahākassapa (Sanskrit: महाकाश्यप, Mahākāśyapa) and by the saṅgha for allowing women to be ordained and for failing to understand or respect the Buddha on key moments. Ānanda continued to teach until the end of his life, passing on his spiritual heritage to his students, including the Sāṇavāsī (Sanskrit: शाणकवासी, Śāṇakavāsī) and Majjhantika (Sanskrit: मध्यान्तिक), who later took major roles in the Third Council and Madhyāक. Ānanda died 20 years after the death of the Buddha, and stupas (monuments) were erected at the river where he died. Ānanda is one of the most beloved figures in Buddhism. He was known for his memory, knowledge and compassion, and was often praised by the Buddha for these. He serves as a protector for the Buddha, although he still has worldly attachments and is not yet enlightened, unlike the Buddha. In the Sanskrit textual tradition, Ānanda is considered the patriarch of the Dhamma who stood in a spiritual lineage, receiving teachings from Mahākassapa and passing them on to his own disciples. Ānanda has been honored by nuns since the early Middle Ages for his services in founding the nuns' order. In contemporary times, composer Richard Wagner and Indian poet Rabindranath Tagore have drawn inspiration from the story of Ānanda in their works. The word ānanda (आनन्द) in Pāli and Sanskrit means 'bliss, joy'.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Germany (German: Deutschland, German pronunciation: ˈdɔʏtʃlant]), officially known as the Federal Republic of Germany (German: Bundesrepublik Deutschland) is a federation in Europe. This country has a very important economic and political position in Europe and in the world. With an area of ​​357,021 square kilometers and a population of around 82 million, the country with 16 states (Bundesland, plural: Bundesländer) is a key member of the European Union organization (most populous), a hub for the transportation of goods and services between countries in the region, as well as being a country with a population the third largest immigrant population in the world. Although the modern German nation-state was only formed in 1871 after the Franco-Prussian War, political units in this region have long played an important position in the monarchical era in Europe from the time of rule by the Roman Empire towards the modern era (AD) until the end of the Napoleonic Wars. The unification of Central Europe under Charles the Great (Charlemagne), leader of the Frankish Empire, in the 8th century paved the way for the formation of a nearly 1000-year-old confederative empire known as the Holy Roman Empire. This empire deeply colored feudal culture throughout Europe and became the center of the Reformation of the Christian church in the 16th century which gave birth to Protestantism. When the Holy Roman Empire was dissolved in 1806 as a result of the divisions caused by the Napoleonic wars, a sense of one nation had grown as a people with a common language (German). However, the modern state that was formed later was unable to unite these national ideals because Austria formed an ally with Hungary to become a separate state from the modern German state. In 1949, Germany, with its territory greatly reduced by the two major wars in Europe, was divided into two separate countries: West Germany and East Germany.

This separation ended on 3 October 1990 (now Germany's national day) when East Germany formally reunited with West Germany. Germany (West) is the founding country of the European Economic Community (later to become the European Union in 1993). This country is also a member of the Schengen zone and a user of the Euro currency since 2002. As an important country, Germany is a member of the G8, G20, ranks fourth in Gross Domestic Product and fifth in Purchasing Ability Balance (2009), second in exporting country and second in exporting countries. both importing countries (2009), and ranks second in the world in the value of development assistance in its annual budget (2008). Germany is also known as a country with a good social safety net system and has a very high standard of living. Germany is known as a country with mastery of advanced science and technology in various fields, both natural and social sciences and humanity, apart from being a country that has made many achievements in the field of sports, such as Formula One, football, and others. Germany is considered a country that really revives the world. In other words, Germany is also a country that influences the state of the world economy/stock market. Because of its location in the center of Europe and its long history as different clans before being united, Germany has many nicknames. The name "Germany" used in Malay is taken from the English name German which means "German people" or German. The name of this country in English, Germany, comes from the Latin name used by the Romans for the area around the Rhine, namely Germania since the 3rd century BC. The etymology is unclear, but it is possible that the Romans adopted the Celtic title of Gaul for the people there which means "neighbor".

The atom is a basic unit of matter, consisting of an atomic nucleus and a cloud of negatively charged electrons that surrounds it. The atomic nucleus consists of positively charged protons and neutrally charged neutrons (except in the atomic nucleus of Hydrogen-1, which has no neutrons). The electrons in an atom are bound to the nucleus by electromagnetic forces. A collection of such atoms can also bond with each other, and form a molecule. Atoms containing the same number of protons and electrons are neutral, while those containing a different number of protons and electrons are positive or negative and are called ions. Atoms are grouped based on the number of protons and neutrons contained in the atomic nucleus. The number of protons in an atom determines the chemical element of that atom, and the number of neutrons determines the isotope of that element. The term atom comes from the Greek (ἄτομος/átomos, α-τεμνω), which means indivisible or indivisible. The concept of the atom as an indivisible component was first proposed by Indian and Greek philosophers. In the 17th and 18th centuries, chemists laid the foundations for this idea by showing that certain substances could not be broken down any further by chemical methods. During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, physicists discovered subatomic structures and components within atoms, proving that the 'atom' was not indivisible. The principles of quantum mechanics used by physicists then succeeded in modeling the atom. In everyday observation, relatively atom is considered a very small object that has a proportionally small mass. Atoms can only be monitored using special equipment such as an atomic force microscope. More than 99.9% of the atomic mass is centered in the atomic nucleus,note 1] with protons and neutrons having almost the same mass.

Every element has at least one isotope with an unstable nucleus, which is subject to radioactive decay. This can result in transmutation, which changes the number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus. Electrons bound to atoms contain a number of stable energy levels, or orbitals, and can undergo transitions between them by absorbing or emitting photons that match the energy differences between the levels. The electrons in an atom determine the chemical properties of an element, and influence the magnetic properties of that atom. The concept that matter is composed of discrete units that cannot be subdivided into smaller units has been around for a millennium. However, these thoughts are still abstract and philosophical in nature, rather than based on empirical observations and experiments. Philosophically, descriptions of the properties of atoms vary depending on the culture and school of philosophy, and often contain spiritual elements in them. Nevertheless, the basic ideas about atoms could be accepted by scientists thousands of years later, because they could elegantly explain new discoveries in the field of chemistry. The earliest reference to the concept of the atom can be traced back to ancient India in 800 BC, which are described in Jain philosophical texts as anu and paramanu. The Nyaya and Vaisesika schools of thought developed theories that explained how atoms combined to form more complex things. A century later, references to atoms in the West appeared by Leucippos, who later systematized this view by his student Demokritos. Around 450 BC, Democritus coined the term átomos (Greek: ἄτομος), meaning "uncut" or "undividable". Democritus's theory of atoms is not an attempt to describe a physical phenomenon in detail, but a philosophy that tries to provide answers to the changes that occur in nature.

Untranslated articles can be quickly deleted according to criteria A2. Quantitative titrations are commonly used in laboratories to determine the concentrations of reactants. Since volume measurement plays an important role in titrations, this technique is also known as volumetric analysis. Titrimetric analysis is one of the main parts of analytical chemistry and its calculations are based on the stoichiometric relationship of chemical reactions. Analysis of the titrimetric method is based on chemical reactions such as: aA + tT → results with information: (a) analyte A molecules react with (t) reactant molecules T The T reagent, called the titrant, is added in small increments, usually from a burette, in the form of a solution of known concentration. The latter solution is called the standard solution and its concentration is determined by a standardization process. The addition of the titrant is continued until an amount of T equivalent to A has been added. Then it is said that the titrant equivalence point has been reached. In order to know when adding titrant has stopped, the chemist can use a chemical, called an indicator, which responds to the presence of excess titrant by changing color. Acid-base indicators are made of weak organic acids or bases, which have a different color when in a dissociated state or not. This color change may or may not occur at the exact equivalence point. The titration point when the indicator changes color is called the end point. It is certainly a hope, that the end point is as close to the equivalence point as possible. Choosing an indicator to make the two points coincide (or making corrections for the difference between the two) is an important aspect of titrimetric analysis. The term titration concerns the process of measuring the volume of titrant required to reach the equivalence point. Over the years the term volumetric analysis has been used instead of titrimetric. From a strict point of view, however, the term titrimetric is preferable, because volume measurements need not be limited by titrations.

In certain analyses, for example, one can measure the volume of a gas. A reagent, known as a titrant, of known concentration (standard solution) and volume is used to react a titrated solution of unknown concentration. By using a calibrated burette to add the titre, it is possible to determine the exact amount of solution needed to reach the endpoint. The end point is the point at which the titration is completed, which is determined by an indicator. Ideally the indicator will change color at the equivalence point—where the volume of the titrant added with a given mole equals the value of the moles of solution titrated. In strong acid-base titrations, the end point is the point at which the pH of the reactants is nearly 7, and usually when the solution turns pink due to the presence of the pH indicator phenolphthalein. Apart from acid-base titrations, there are also other types of titrations. Many methods can be used to indicate the end point in a reaction; titrations usually use a visual indicator (a solution of a reactant that changes color). In simple acid-base titrations, pH indicators can be used, an example being phenolphthalein, where the phenolphthalein turns pink when the solution reaches a pH of about 8.2 or exceeds it. Another example of a pH indicator that can be used is methyl orange, which turns red in acids and yellow in alkaline solutions. Not all titrations require an indicator. In some cases, both the reactants and products already have contrasting colors and can be used as "indicators". For example, a redox titration using potassium permanganate (pink/purple) as a titrant does not require an indicator. When the titer is reduced, the solution will become colorless. After reaching the equivalence point, there is excess titer remaining in the solution.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Czech Republic, Czech Republic, Czech, or Czech] (Czech language: Česká Republika, Česko hear (help·info)), or Czech or Czechia for short ( /ˈtʃɛkiə/ listen (help·info)) is a country in Central Europe that was formed after the dissolution of the Czechoslovak state. The country is bordered by Germany to the west and north, Poland to the north, Slovakia to the southeast and Austria to the south. In this country lies the Sudetenland where ethnic Germans used to live, but after World War II, most of them were deported although there are still many Czech people who bear German names. At that time, around 3.5 million Germans were expelled. In the Sudeten land there are many industries, especially crystal and beer craft industries. The Czech land appeared at the end of the 9th century when it was unified by the Přemyslids. The Kingdom of Bohemia was its ruler, but religious conflicts such as the 15th century Hussite Wars and the 17th century Thirty Years' War were especially damaging. Later these lands came under Habsburg influence and became part of Austria-Hungary. After the collapse of this country after World War I, the Czechs and neighboring Slovakia merged and formed the independent republic of Czechoslovakia in 1918. This new country had a large ethnic German minority, which led to the dissolution of Czechoslovakia when Germany successfully annexed this minority through the Munich Agreement in 1938, and Slovakia received greater autonomy, with the country being named "Czecho-Slovakia". Slovakia further broke away again in 1939 and the rest of the Czech country was occupied by Germany. After World War II, Czechoslovakia fell under the influence of the Soviet Union. In 1968, an invasion by Warsaw Pact forces ended efforts by the country's leaders to liberalize the ruling party and create "socialism with a human face" during the Prague Spring.

In 1989, Czechoslovakia gained independence through the Velvet Revolution. On 1 January 1993 the country peacefully split into two, creating the independent Czech Republic and Slovak Republic. The Czech Republic joined NATO in 1999 and the European Union in 2004. The Czech Republic has no maritime borders as it is bordered by Poland, Germany, Austria and Slovakia. In the Bohemian region, the river Elbe or Labe in Czech and the River Vltava flow, surrounded by low mountains. In Sudeten, there is the highest point in Czech, Mount Sněžka with a height of 1602 m. The eastern part of the Czech Republic, Moravia, is also hilly and is fed by the Morava River and is a spring of the Oder or Odra River. These rivers flow into the North Sea, Baltic Sea, and Black Sea. The climate in Czechia is temperate with warm summers and wet, cloudy and cold winters and is influenced by the sea and land climates. Based on the constitution, the Czech Republic is a parliamentary democracy with a president who is elected by parliament for a 5-year term as head of state. The president has veto power over legislation, immunity, and can dissolve parliament under certain circumstances. He also selects the prime minister as well as members of the cabinet based on proposals from the prime minister. The Czech Parliament (Parlament) is a bicameral parliament consisting of the Poslanecká sněmovna consisting of 200 seats with a term of 4 years and the Senát consisting of 81 seats with terms of 6 and 2 years. Czechia is divided into thirteen administrative regions (kraje, singular - kraj) and one capital region (hlavní město), which are marked with *. As of the 2020 census, the Czech population is 10,701,777 people. The fertility rate in 2019 is 1.71 births/woman.

Persecution (English: persecution) is systematic ill-treatment or persecution by individuals or groups against other individuals or groups. The most common forms are religious persecution, racism, and political persecution, although there is sometimes some overlap between these terms. Causing suffering, harassment, imprisonment, exile, fear or pain are all elements that can be categorized as persecution, but not all suffering is something that is caused by the act of persecution. The threshold for the severity of persecution has been a much debated topic. As part of the Nuremberg Principles, crimes against humanity are part of international law. Principle VI of the Nuremberg Principles states that: Crimes which are further determined to be punishable as crimes under international law: ... (c) Crimes against humanity: Murder, extermination, enslavement, deportation and other inhumane acts committed against any civilian population , or persecution on political, racial or religious grounds, when the act was committed or the persecution was committed in the commission of or in connection with any crime against the peace or war crime. Telford Taylor, who is Prosecution Counsel at the Nuremberg Trials wrote "in] the Nuremberg war crimes trials, the court dismissed several attempts by prosecutors to bring such 'domestic' atrocities within the scope of international law as 'crimes against humanity". Several subsequent international agreements incorporated this principle, but some parties have dropped the limitations "in respect of any crimes against the peace or any war crimes" that existed in the Nuremberg Principles. Under Article 7.1 of the Rome Statute, the persecution of a group is considered a form of crime against humanity: (h) Persecution of an identifiable group or collectivity on grounds of politics, race, national, ethnicity, culture, religion, gender as defined in paragraph 3, or on other grounds that are universally recognized as impermissible under international law, relating to any act referred to in this paragraph or any crime within the jurisdiction of the Court. This article on the topic of sociology is a stub.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Law is a collection of regulations consisting of norms and sanctions. Law is something that is closely related to human life referring to the most important system in the implementation of a series of law enforcement powers by law enforcement institutions because all human life is limited by law. The law regulates sanctions for abuse of power in the political, economic and social fields in various ways and acts as the main intermediary in social relations between communities against violations of individual rights in civil law, and criminal law which seeks the state's way of prosecuting perpetrators of public law violations. Administrative law is used to review from the government, while international law regulates matters between sovereign countries in activities ranging from trade, environment, regulation or military action. The philosopher Aristotle declared that "a rule of law is far better than tyrannical rule." The word law comes from the Arabic al-hukmu which means judgment, decree, order, government, power, and punishment. Experts and legal scholars try to provide a definition or legal definition, but no single expert or legal scholar has been able to provide a legal understanding that can be accepted by all parties. The absence of a legal definition that can be accepted by all experts and jurists, in turn, mutates the problem regarding disagreements in the legal definition, so is it possible to define the law or is it possible for us to make a legal definition? Then it develops again into whether we need to define law? The absence of a legal definition is clearly an obstacle for those who just want to study law. Of course, an initial understanding or understanding of law is needed in general before starting to study what law is with its various aspects.

For ordinary people, the meaning of law is not so important. More important is the enforcement and legal protection given to the community. However, for those who want to learn more about law, of course it is necessary to know the meaning of law. In general, the formulation of the legal definition at least contains the following elements: In order to carry out the function of law as a tool of social engineering. Law as a means of development, according to Michael Hager, law can serve 3 (three) sectors, namely: Given the very strategic function and role of law in the development of today's society, law must guarantee legal certainty, justice and usefulness for society. Law can be divided into various fields, including: criminal law/public law, civil law/private law, procedural law, constitutional law, state administrative law/state administrative law, international law, customary law, Islamic law, general law, agrarian law, business law, and environmental law. Criminal law is included in the realm of public law. Criminal law is the law that regulates the relationship between legal subjects in terms of actions that are required and prohibited by laws and regulations, norms and result in the imposition of sanctions in the form of punishment and fines for violators. In criminal law, there are 2 types of acts, namely crimes and violations. In Indonesia, criminal law is regulated in general in the Criminal Code (KUHP), which is a relic from the Dutch colonial era, previously named Wetboek van Straafrecht (WvS). The Criminal Code is a lex generalis for setting criminal law in Indonesia in which general principles are contained and form the basis for all criminal provisions regulated outside the Criminal Code (lex specialis). One area of ​​law that regulates the relationships between individuals in society with certain channels.

United States of Mexico or Mexico (Spanish: Estados Unidos Mexicanos or México) is a country located in North America and is bordered by the United States, Guatemala and Belize to the southeast, the Pacific Ocean to the west and the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea to the east. It is the third largest country in Latin America and also the country that speaks the most Spanish. The name of this country is taken from the name of the capital which comes from the name of the ancient Aztec capital, namely Mexico-Tenochtitlan. Mexi is part of the name Mexitli, namely the name of the god of war while co means 'place' and ca means 'people'. For nearly 3,000 years, Mexico was home to several advanced civilizations such as the Amerindian, Mayan and Aztec civilizations. The arrival of the Spanish conquistadors under the sage Hernan Cortes in the early 16th century, and their victory over the Aztecs in 1521, marked the beginning of the era of colonizing Mexico as New Spain. On September 15, 1810, independence from Spain was declared by Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla in Dolores, a small town. This was the starting point of the war for independence known as the Mexican War of Independence which ended with independence in 1821, and the formation of the First Mexican Empire. After independence, all the countries of Central America except Chiapas, agreed not to become part of this empire. After the Empire fell to republican forces led by Antonio López de Santa Anna, the first Republic was formed with Guadalupe Victoria as its first President. Under Santa Anna, residents of the Texan section of Coahuila and Texas had revolted, demanding independence from the Mexican government. The people here, especially English explorers, formed the Republic of Texas.

This rebellion has sparked the famous war that is the war at the Alamo between the Mexican military, and Texas. Finally in 1836, Texas gained independence, and the Mexican Republic dwindled. In the 1840s, the country was invaded by the United States which resulted in massive territorial losses, including Alta California, Arizona, Nevada, Utah and New Mexico. In the 1860s the country was once again attacked, this time by the French army, which wanted to install the Austrian Archduke Ferdinand Maximillian as Emperor of Mexico, backed by the Catholic clergy and conservative Creole groups. However, his reign ended in bloody events, where Benito Juarez, the former president of Mexico, was reinstated as President. At first, General Ignacio Zaragoza killed French soldiers on May 5 (or Cinco de Mayo, in Spanish) 1862 in the Battle of Puebla but was eventually forced to relent, and Napoleon III of France, Emperor of France, had installed Ferdinand Maximillian of Austria as King of Mexico in 1864. But within a short period of just three years, Maximillian's empire was overthrown by Juárez, and he was executed. After Juárez's death, anarchy had set in, and dragged on for 30 years starting with the Mexican Uprising led by Porfirio Díaz in 1910. Notable figures during the Mexican Uprising included Francisco I. Madero, Venustiano Carranza, Pancho Villa, Alvaro Obregon , Victoriano Huerta, and Emiliano Zapata. The rebels had killed allied soldiers, but they were forced to face internal upheaval, and the country was in a state of conflict for another two decades. The rebellion ended in the 1930s, the Revolutionary Institutional Party (PRI) took over the helm of government, and ruled for 70 years until the end of the 20th century.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health science Astrobiology (sometimes called exobiology, exopaleontology, bioastronomy, and xenobiology) is the study of the origin, evolution, distribution, and future of life in the universe. This interdisciplinary field of science includes the search for habitable environments both within and outside the Solar System, the search for evidence of prebiotic chemistry, life on Mars and other bodies in the Solar System, laboratory and field research on the origin and early evolution of life on Earth, and studies of the potential of life on Earth. live to adapt on Earth and in outer space. Astrobiology makes use of molecular biology, biophysics, biochemistry, chemistry, astronomy, physical cosmology, exoplanetology and geology to investigate the possibility of life on other worlds and help identify biospheres that may differ from those on Earth. The origin and early evolution of life is an integral part of the discipline of astrobiology. Astrobiology is concerned with the interpretation of existing scientific data. Astrobiology is concerned with itself primarily with hypotheses that conform to existing scientific theories. This interdisciplinary field includes research on the origin of planetary systems, the origin of organic compounds in outer space, rock-water-carbon interactions, abiogenesis on Earth, planetary habitability, research on biosignatures for the detection of life, and studies on the potential for life to adapt to challenges on Earth and in outer space. Biochemistry may have started shortly after the Big Bang, 13.8 billion years ago, during the habitable age when the universe was only 10-17 million years old. According to the panspermia hypothesis, microscopic life — distributed by meteoroids, asteroids, and other small Solar System bodies — may exist throughout the universe. According to research published in August 2015, very large galaxies may be more favorable for the creation and development of habitable planets than smaller galaxies like the Milky Way.

Nonetheless, Earth is the only place in the universe known to man to harbor life. Estimates of the habitable zone around other stars, sometimes referred to as the "Goldilocks zone" have coincided with the discovery of hundreds of exoplanets and new insights into extreme habitats. here on Earth, suggest that there may be more habitable places in the universe than was thought until recently. Current studies of the planet Mars by the Curiosity and Opportunity probes are underway to look for evidence of ancient life as well as plains associated with ancient rivers or lakes that may have inhabited it. The search for evidence of habitability, taphonomy (associated with fossils), and organic molecules on the planet Mars is now a major goal of NASA and ESA. Even if extraterrestrial life is never discovered, the interdisciplinary nature of astrobiology, and the cosmic and evolutionary perspectives it brings, could still yield a variety of benefits on Earth. The term was first proposed by the Russian (Soviet) astronomer Gavriil Tikhov in 1953. Astrobiology is etymologically derived from the Greek ἄστρον , astron, "constellation, star"; βίος , bios, "life"; and -λογία, -logia, study. Synonyms of astrobiology vary; However, synonyms are structured in relation to the most important sciences implied in their development: astronomy and biology. A close synonym is exobiology from the Greek Έξω, "external"; Βίος, bios, "live"; and λογία, -logia, study. The term exobiology was coined by molecular biologist and Nobel Prize winner Joshua Lederberg. Exobiology is considered to have a limited scope limited to the search for life beyond Earth, whereas the subject area of ​​astrobiology is broader and investigates the relationship between life and the universe, which includes the search for extraterrestrial life, but also includes research on life on Earth, its origins, evolution and limits.

Bullying, bullying, bullying or intimidation (English: bullying) is the use of violence, threats or coercion to abuse or intimidate others. This behavior can become habitual and involve an imbalance of social or physical power. This can include verbal abuse or threats, physical violence or coercion and can be directed repeatedly against particular victims; it may be on the basis of race, religion, gender, sexual orientation, or ability. There are four types of bullying, namely emotional, physical, verbal and cyber media. Habits of bullying can develop anywhere while there is interaction between humans, for example, starting in government, organizations, schools, workplaces, families, and the environment. Acts of bullying by physical contact that cause feelings of physical pain, injury, injury, or other physical suffering. For example hitting, slapping, or kicking another person. Acts of bullying that cause psychological trauma, fear, depression (psychology), anxiety, or stress. In addition, it also causes confusion/irritation due to incitement from other people. In adolescents, one of the psychological factors of bullying behavior is the upbringing of parents, blood descendants or parental substitutes. Parenting styles of parents, authoritarian and permissive-indulgent bloodlines both shape the tendency of children to become actors of oppression. In contrast, authoritative parenting styles prevent youth from being involved as perpetrators or victims of bullying. Other psychological factors that can increase a person's chances of becoming a perpetrator or victim of bullying are a person's past personal history as a victim/perpetrator of violence, low assertiveness by spectators of bullying to stop bullying, the trap of playing identity politics, maladaptive personality, lack of empathy, lack of skills to resolve civilized problems are caused by the interference of other people, low feelings of responsibility in the use of social media due to a lack of insight in understanding the conclusions contained in social media, the habit of throwing offensive humor, to public policies that do not open up space for auditing power.

Chemistry is a branch of the physical sciences that studies the composition, structure, properties and changes of matter. Chemistry covers topics such as the properties of atoms, how atoms form chemical bonds to produce chemical compounds, the interactions of substances through intermolecular forces that give matter the general properties of matter, and the interactions between substances through chemical reactions to form substances. different. Chemistry is sometimes referred to as the central science because it bridges the natural sciences, including physics, geology, and biology. Experts differ on the etymology of the word chemistry. The history of chemistry can be traced back to alchemy, which was practiced for millennia in various parts of the world. The word chemistry comes from alchemy, a designation for a series of ancient practices that included elements of chemistry, metallurgy, philosophy, astrology, mysticism, and medicine. Alchemy is often thought of as having to do with turning lead or other common raw materials into gold, but in ancient times it studied many issues of modern chemistry. Alchemy was defined by the early 4th century AD Greco-Egyptian alchemist, Zosimos, as the study of the composition of water, its movement, growth, appearance, disappearance, expulsion of the spirit from the body, and bonding of the spirit within the body. The word alchemy comes from the Arabic word al-kīmīā (الکیمیاء). The word al-kīmīā is derived from the Greek word χημία (chemistry) or χημεία (kemeia). Al-kīmīā may come from Ancient Egypt because the word al-kīmīā may be derived from the Greek word χημία (kemia), which is also derived from the word Kemi or Kimi, which is the ancient name of the country of Egypt in Egyptian. It is also possible that the word al-kīmīā is derived from the word χημεία (kemeia), which means "to be poured together" (into mold). Chemistry is often referred to as the "central science" because it connects many other disciplines, such as physics, materials science, nanotechnology, biology, pharmacy, medicine, bioinformatics, and geology.

This connection arises through various sub-disciplines that utilize concepts from various disciplines. For example, physical chemistry involves applying the principles of physics to matter at the atomic and molecular level. Chemistry deals with the interactions of matter which can involve two substances or between matter and energy, especially in relation to the first law of thermodynamics. Traditional chemistry involves interactions between chemical substances in chemical reactions, which change one or more substances into one or more other substances. Sometimes these reactions are driven by enthalpy considerations, as when two highly enthalpy substances such as elemental hydrogen and oxygen react to form water, the substance with lower enthalpy. The chemical reaction can be facilitated by a catalyst, which is generally another chemical that is involved in the reaction medium but is not consumed (an example is sulfuric acid which catalyzes the electrolysis of water) or an immaterial phenomenon (such as electromagnetic radiation in a photochemical reaction). Traditional chemistry also deals with the analysis of chemical substances, both inside and outside of a reaction, as in spectroscopy. All normal matter is composed of atoms or subatomic components that make up atoms; protons, electrons, and neutrons. Atoms can be combined to produce more complex forms of matter such as ions, molecules or crystals. The structure of the world we live in every day and the properties of the matter with which we interact are determined by the properties of chemical substances and the interactions between them. Steel is harder than iron because the atoms are bonded together in a more rigid crystalline structure. Wood burns or undergoes rapid oxidation because it can react spontaneously with oxygen in a chemical reaction if it is above a certain temperature. Substances tend to be classified based on energy, phase, or their chemical compositions. Matter can be classified into 4 phases, the order of which has the lowest energy is solid, liquid, gas, and plasma.

Horní náměstí 1771 27 Olomouc Olomouc (English: /ˈɒləmoʊts/ OL-ə-mohts, US: /ˈoʊloʊ-/ OH-loh-, Czech: ˈolomouts) locally Holomóc or Olomóc; German: Olmütz; Polish: Ołomuniec ɔwɔˈmuɲɛts]; Hungarian: Alamóc; Latin: Olomucium) is a city in Moravia located in the east of the Czech Republic. The city of Olomouc is the administrative center of the Olomouc Region (Olomoucký kraj) and the sixth largest city in the Czech Republic. The city has 100,523 inhabitants (2019) and in its urban zone lives a population of approximately 480,000 people. Olomouc is known for its historical monuments, for example the Column of the Holy Trinity has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2000. In the Middle Ages Olomouc was the third largest city in the Bohemian Crown Territory (after Prague and Wroclaw) and competed with Brno for the status of center of Moravia. This situation changed after the city of Olomouc was occupied by the Swedish Empire from 1642 to 1650. Then, in the mid-18th century, the city was rebuilt and became a very strong and important stronghold. Because of this, Olomouc was a principal and important center of defense and also the seat of a large military garrison. Since 1968 the city of Olomouc was occupied by the occupying garrison of the Soviet Army. Palacký University in Olomouc founded in 1573 is the oldest university in Moravia and the second oldest in the Czech Republic. Universities play a very important role in city life. With over 25,200 students (including those at Moravian College Olomouc), Olomouc has the highest student density in Central Europe. Most of the university's buildings are located in the city's heritage centre. The university has eight faculties. Geographically, the city of Olomouc and the rest of the Ceho Republic are located in a temperate zone and there are four seasons (spring, summer, autumn and winter).

Metaphysics is a branch of philosophy concerned with the analytical process of the fundamental nature of being and the reality that accompanies it. The study of metaphysics generally pivots on fundamental questions regarding the existence and properties that pervade the reality being studied. The meaning of metaphysics varies and each period and philosopher certainly has a different view. In general, the topic of metaphysical analysis includes discussions about existence, actual existence and accompanying characteristics, space and time, relations between existences such as discussions about causality, possibility, and other metaphysical discussions. Given the range of studies it focuses on, metaphysics becomes a fundamental discipline in the study of philosophy. Throughout the history of philosophy, metaphysics reaches out to classical problems in theoretical philosophy. In general, the study of metaphysics becomes a "stepping stone" for the structure of more complex philosophical ideas and principles to explain other problems. Thus, in the understanding of classical metaphysics, metaphysics discusses fundamental questions whose answers can be used as the basis for more complex questions. References are needed] For example: is there a primary purpose in the existence of this world? Then is its existence limited to existence that "exists" or is it dependent on other existences? ; Does god/gods exist? Then, if so, what are the things that humans know/don't know about it? ; Is it true that there is such a thing as an intellectus, especially in discussions of the distinction between the problem of the separation of soul-body entities? ; Is the soul a real thing, and is it free will? ; Is everything fixed or changing? Are there things or relations that are always constant at work in various phenomena? ; and other similar questions. The object of discussion of metaphysics is not merely empirical things or things that can be reached by individual observations, but things or aspects that form the basis of reality itself.

Claims on the method and object of metaphysical study have become a perennial problem of philosophy. The discussion of metaphysics has various sub-discussions. For example, the central discussion of metaphysics is ontology, namely the analytical process and exploration of classification based on the principles of category existence and the relations between them. Another central topic is metaphysical cosmology, which is an in-depth study of the principles of the world's existence, reality, origins, and the meaning of its existence. The word "metaphysics" is recorded from Aristotle's set of 14 works on philosophical problems.
