At first there was no name to refer to this philosophical study, until Andronicus of Rodesia compiled the works of Aristotelian philosophy with eight books outside the "Physics" label named τὰ μετὰ τὰ φυσικά βιβλία (tà metà tà Physika biblia; book/work (which is) after/beside Φυσικὴ ἀκρόασις (Phusike akroasis)). There are various understandings of the true meaning of the word Metaphysics and it has become a problem for philosophers and historians to this day. So the true meaning is still unclear, considering that Aristotle did not use the term to name his metaphysical theories. The word "Metaphysics" was never—even if it ever existed in Aristotelian times—used by Aristotle himself, but he often referred to it as "early philosophy". for the suitability of the name given to him. The activities of several 20th century scholars helped to direct alternative meanings to metaphysics itself. Renaissance understandings gave rise to new ideas such as 'meta-language' or 'support for the philosophical corpus' and led to metaphysics being understood as "the science of the world beyond physis (φύσις, usually translated 'nature')."

Nanotechnology is the manipulation of matter on an atomic and molecular scale. Atomic diameters range from 62 picometers (Helium atoms) to 520 picometers (Cesium atoms), while combinations of several atoms form molecules with a nano-size range, that is, the size of objects that are: one billionth of a meter (0.0000000001 m) or one meter divided by one billion. The term Nanotechnology was first used in a scientific speech by Professor Nario Taniguci in 1974. The initial description of nanotechnology referred to the purpose of using technology to manipulate atoms and molecules to manufacture macro-scale products. A more general description is the manipulation of matter with a maximum size of 100 nanometers. Because of the wide range of potential applications (including industrial and military), governments of various countries have invested billions of dollars in nanotechnology research. Prior to 2012, the US invested US$3.7 billion using the National Nanotechnology Initiative, the European Union invested US$1.2 billion, and Japan invested US$750 million. More than sixty countries created nanotechnology research and development (R&D) programs between 2001 and 2004. In 2012, the US and EU each invested US$2.1 billion in nanotechnology research, followed by Japan with US$1.2 billion. Global investment totaled US$7.9 billion in 2012. Government funding was surpassed by corporate R&D spending on nanotechnology research, which totaled US$10 billion in 2012. The largest corporate R&D expenditures came from the US, Japan and Germany which combined amounted to US$7. 1 billion. As of August 2008, the Project on Emerging Nanotechnologies estimates that there are around 800 publicly available nanotechnology products, with 1 new product appearing every 3-4 weeks. Most applications are limited to the use of "first generation" passive nanomaterials which include titanium dioxide in sunscreens, cosmetics, surface coatings, and some food products, among others; carbon allotropes used in gecko tape; silver in food packaging, clothing, disinfectants, and household appliances; zinc oxide in sunscreens and cosmetics, surface coatings, paints, and furniture varnishes; and cerium oxide as a fuel catalyst.

Other applications include tennis balls which can last longer, golf balls which can fly straight, and bowling balls which can be more durable and have a harder surface. Trousers and socks have also been infused with nanotechnology so they can last longer and stay cooler in the summer. The bandage is infused with nano silver to heal wounds faster. Video game consoles and personal computers are cheaper, faster and have higher memory thanks to nanotechnology. Nanotechnology makes existing medical equipment cheaper and easier to use. Cars are made with nanomaterials so they need less metal and are more fuel efficient in the future. Scientists are currently developing nanotechnology for diesel engines with cleaner exhaust gases. Platinum is currently used as a catalyst in diesel engines. The reduced catalyst will bind the nitrogen atoms of the NOx molecule thereby releasing oxygen. Then the catalyst oxidizes the hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide to carbon dioxide and water. Platinum is used in reduction and oxidation catalysts. However, using platinum is inefficient because it is expensive and non-renewable. The Danish company Innovationsfonden is investing DKK 15 million to find new catalysts for substitution with nanotechnology. The goal of this project was to maximize surface area and minimize material requirements. If the surface area of ​​the catalyst exposed to exhaust gas is greater, the catalyst efficiency increases. If successful, the use of platinum can be reduced by up to 25%. Nanotechnology also plays an important role in the development of tissue engineering. When designing the scaffold, scientists try to mimic the nanoscale characteristics of a cell. For example, when creating a scaffold to support bone growth, scientists can mimic osteoclasts. Scientists have successfully used DNA origami-based nanobots that can carry out logical functions to achieve drug target delivery in cockroaches.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health sciences Archeology or archeologynote 1] is a science that studies past human (human) cultures through a systematic study of material data left behind. Systematic studies include discovery, documentation, analysis, cultural values, norms, customs, customary law and interpretation of data in the form of artifacts (material culture, such as stone axes and temple buildings) and ecofacts (environmental objects, such as rocks, features of the earth's surface, and fossils) or features (artifacts) that cannot be separated from their place (archaeological sites). A typical research technique is archaeological excavations, although survey techniques are still being carried out. Archaeologists are a term for scholars, practitioners, or experts in the field of archeology. Archeology is diverse and becomes a long-standing debate. Among them is the so-called archaeological paradigm, namely compiling cultural history, understanding human behavior, and understanding the process of cultural change. Because it aims to understand human culture, this science is included in the humanities science group. Thus, there are various auxiliary sciences used, including history, anthropology, geology (with n the science of earth-forming layers which are a reference for the relative age of an archaeological find), geography, architecture, paleoanthropology and bioanthropology, physics (among others with carbon c-14 to obtain absolute dating), metallurgy (to obtain the elements of a metal object ), as well as philology (studying old manuscripts). Archeology today encompasses many related fields. For example, the discovery of a buried corpse will attract the interest of experts from various fields to study about the clothing and types of materials used, the shape of the ceramics and the way they were distributed, beliefs through what was buried with the corpse, chemists who are able to determine the age of excavations through such methods of measurement. carbon 14.

Meanwhile, geneticists who want to know the movement of ancient humans, examine their DNA. In particular, archeology studies past cultures, which were old, both in prehistoric times (before writing was known), and in historical times (when there was written evidence). In its development, archeology can also study contemporary culture, as popularized in the study of modern material culture (modern material culture). Because it relies on objects from the past, archeology really needs the preservation of these objects as a source of data. Therefore, another discipline was developed, namely management of archaeological resources (Archaeological Resources Management), or more broadly, management of cultural resources (CRM, Culture Resources Management). Purbawanism is a combination of the word 'purbawan' and the English suffix '-ism'. According to the Dictionary of the Language and Library Council, a purveyor has the intention of being a person who studies, collects and sells antiques, while '-ism' means character and behavior. It can be concluded that 'ancientism' refers to the attitudes and behavior of people who study, collect and sell antiquities. The more popular term used in English is antiquity or antiquarianism. The term first appeared in the 15th century as a historical branch of Renaissance Humanism. The first ancient activities of antiquity were carried out by Nabonidus (555–538 BC), the last king of Babylon before being conquered by Cyrus the Great. He was very interested in the history of the Babylonian civilization and had discovered the Naram-Sin temple which was built 2200 years before his reign. During the reign of Julius Caesar, artifacts such as jars, ancient weapons and bronze were some of the findings of Roman troops when searching ancient graves in their colonies such as Greece and Italy. Suetonis noted that the activity of collecting ancient goods by Maharaja Augustus Caesar.

Jupiter or Jupiter is the fifth closest planet to the Sun after Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars. This planet is also the largest planet in the Solar System. Jupiter is a gas giant with a mass one thousandth that of the Sun and two and a half times the mass of all the other planets in the Solar System. This planet and the other gas giants in the Solar System (namely Saturn, Uranus and Neptune) are sometimes called the Jovian planets or outer planets. Jupiter has been known to astronomers since ancient times, and is associated with the mythology and religious beliefs of many civilizations. The Romans named this planet after the god Jupiter in Roman mythology. When viewed from Earth, Jupiter's apparent magnitude can reach −2.94, which is bright enough to cast shadows, and also makes it the third brightest object in the night sky after the Moon and Venus, although Mars can rival Jupiter in brightness at times. Jupiter is mostly composed of hydrogen and helium. A quarter of Jupiter's mass is helium, although it makes up only a tenth of Jupiter's composition. The planet may have a rocky core made up of heavy elements, but it doesn't have a solid surface like the other gas giants. As a result of its fast rotation, the planet has an oblate spherical shape (there is a bulge around Jupiter's equator). The outer atmosphere is divided into several layers at different latitudes, and interactions between the layer boundaries produce storms. One of these impacts is the Great Red Spot, a massive storm that has been known to exist since the 17th century with telescopes. Around Jupiter there are thin rings and a strong magnetosphere. In addition there are at least 67 natural satellites, including four large moons called the Galilean moons which were first discovered by Galileo Galilei in 1610.

Jupiter's largest satellite, Ganimede, has a larger diameter than the planet Mercury. Jupiter has been explored several times by robotic probes, such as the Pioneer flyby, Voyager and Galileo missions. The last probe to visit Jupiter was the New Horizons probe at the end of February 2007 while on its way to Pluto. The spacecraft uses the help of gravity from Jupiter to help increase its speed. In the future, some of the satellites surrounding Jupiter may be explored, such as the Europa satellite which may have a liquid ocean beneath its icy layer. Jupiter consists mostly of gas and liquid matter. It is the largest of the four gas giants and the largest in the Solar System with a diameter of 142,984 km (88,846 mi) at its equator. Jupiter's density, which is 1.326 g/cm3, is the second largest among the gas giants, but lower than the other four terrestrial planets. Jupiter's upper atmosphere is composed of 88–92% hydrogen and 8–12% helium by volume percent or molecular fraction. Since the atomic mass of helium is four times that of hydrogen atoms, the composition changes when described in terms of mass proportions. Thus, Jupiter's atmosphere is composed of 75% hydrogen and 24% helium by mass, with the remaining one percent being the mass of other elements. Jupiter's interior contains denser matter so its distribution by mass is approximately 1% hydrogen, 24% helium and 5% other elements. Jupiter's atmosphere contains methane, water vapor, ammonia and silicon-based compounds. There is also carbon, ethane, hydrogen sulfide, neon, oxygen, phosphine, and sulfur. The outermost layer of the atmosphere contains frozen ammonia crystals. Through infrared and ultraviolet measurements, the presence of benzene and other hydrocarbons was also discovered. The proportions of hydrogen and helium in the atmosphere are about the same as the theoretical composition of the primordial solar nebula.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health sciences Ecology is a branch of biology that studies the interactions between living things and other living things and also with the surrounding environment. In environmental science, ecology is used as a basic science to understand interactions in the environment. The components involved in this interaction can be divided into biotic (living) and abiotic (non-living) components. Ecological systems are formed from the unity and interaction between components that make up an ecosystem that are interconnected with one another. Ecological analysis is used by humans to create a sustainable living environment in an accountable way for security and sustainability, and well-being. Ecological principles are used in analyzing the human environment, population growth, increased food production, greening, erosion, flooding, preservation of germplasm and endangered animals, collection of rare fruits, and environmental pollution. Ecology is a science with a broad and complex topic, which includes hierarchy and biodiversity, number and distribution of organisms, roles and interactions between organisms, habitats and niches, food webs, nutrient and biogeochemical cycles, and various other processes. Various approaches can be used to classify ecology into a number of sub-disciplines, both according to spatial (place) and temporal (time) patterns, subjects studied, and links to other fields of science. There are no clear boundaries regarding the beginnings of ecology as a scientific discipline. Nonetheless, ecological principles have been studied since ancient Greece by Aristotle. Aristotle's student Theophrastus then observed and explained the relationship between organisms and their environment. He focused on the reasons certain species prefer certain environments. As early as the 19th century AD, Alexander von Humboldt described the correlation between plant associations (such as grasslands, rainforests, and tundra) and environmental factors (such as temperature, rainfall, and topography) to understand the number and distribution of animal and plant species.

The term ecology was first put forward by Ernst Haeckel as ecologic in 1866; the Greek word oikos itself is the root for the terms economics (managing of the household) and ecology (the study of the household). Three years after publishing this term, Haeckel defined ecology as the whole science of the relationships of organisms to the external world around them and those that can be accounted for in a broader sense under all conditions of existence. It is partly organic, partly inorganic. Experts view the definition of ecology presented by Haeckel as part of physiology. Charles Krebs then separated ecology from the study of physiology. He explained that ecology is a science that examines the interactions of living things which explains the distribution and diversity of living things. In environmental interactions, ecology remains inseparable from physiology. Krebs' definition of ecology is then used as the core of ecological studies. George Evelyn Hutchinson (1903–1991) has been called the father of limnology and the father of modern ecology. He comprehensively observes and empirically measures organic and environmental factors that can affect the biota of a lake, and lays the foundations of ecological niches. Ecology then became popular around the 1960s when environmental issues started to get public attention. The development of ecological science and its relationship with other sciences occurred in 1968 and 1970 with the emergence of the environmental awareness movement. People are starting to think about the problems of pollution, nature conservation, population and food and energy consumption. Prior to the 1970s, ecology was still viewed as part of biology. After that, ecology became a scientific discipline separate from biology. Ecological studies are concerned with physical and biological processes and link the natural and social sciences. At present, ecology is associated with various other fields of science because of its high complexity, ranging from philosophy to mathematics.

The Republic of Maldives is an island nation consisting of a group of atolls (a coral island surrounding a lagoon) in the Indian Ocean. The Maldives is located south-southwest of India, about 700 km southwest of Sri Lanka. This country has 26 atolls which are divided into 20 administrative atolls and 1 city. The Maldives is a country with the smallest population and area in the Asian region and is 100 percent Muslim. The average ground level in the Maldives is 1.5 meters above sea level, making it the country with the lowest sea level in the world. The highest peak of the Maldives is only 2.3 meters above sea level, so it is also known as the country with the lowest highest peak in the world. The Maldives' economic situation depends on two main sectors, namely tourism and fisheries. This country is very well known for its many beautiful beaches and underwater scenery which attracts ± 700,000 tourists every year. Catching and processing fish makes the Maldives one of the exporters of fish to several Asian and European countries. The name Maldives may come from the Sanskrit mālā (garland) and dvīpa (island), or මාල දිවයින Maala Divaina ("String of Islands") in Sinhala. Maldivians are called Dhivehin. The terms Dheeb/Deeb (Old Dhivehi, related to the Sanskrit dvīpa (द्वीप)) meaning "island", and Dhives (Dhivehin) meaning "island people" (as is the case with Maldivians). During the colonial period, the Dutch referred to the inhabitants of this country as the Maldivische Eilanden in their notes, while the Maldive Islands were a British tongue version, which later became the commonly used name "Maldives". Reference needed] Chronicle of Sri Lanka the ancient Mahawamsa refers to these islands as Mahiladiva ("Island of Women", महिलादिभ) in Pali, which may be a mispronunciation of the Sanskrit term meaning "garland".

Hogendorn theorizes that the name Maldives comes from the Sanskrit term mālādvīpa (मालाद्वीप), meaning "strand of islands". In Malayalam, it is pronounced as Maladweepu (മാലദ്വീപ്). In Tamil, it is pronounced as MalaiTheevu (மாலைத்தீவு). Although these names are not mentioned in any literature, classical Sanskrit texts dating from the Vedic period mention the "Thousand Thousand Islands" (Lakshadweepa), a generic name that includes not only the Maldives, but also the Laccadives, Aminidivi Archipelago, Minicoy and Chagos Islands. Some ancient explorers such as Ibn Batuta called the islands Mahal Dibiyat (محل دبيأت) from the Arabic Mahal ("place"), which must have been derived from the way the Berber travelers pronounced the place name, across Muslim North India, where the terms Perso-Arabic is known in the local vocabulary. This name is now included in the official state symbol of the Maldives. The classic Persian/Arabic name for Maldives is Dibajat. Since the 6th - 5th centuries BC, the Maldives already had their kingdom. This country has a history of more than 2,500 years according to historical evidence and legends. The earliest settlers in the Maldives were probably the Gujaratis, who reached and settled Sri Lanka around 500 BC. Evidence of cultural influence from North India can be seen in shipbuilding methods and silver coins. The Mahāvaṃsa (300 BC) has records of people from Sri Lanka emigrating to the Maldives. Assuming that cowrie skins originated in the Maldives, historians believe that there may have been people who lived in the Maldives during the Indus Valley civilization (3300-1300 BC). A number of artefacts show the presence of Hinduism in the country before pre-Islamic times. According to the book Kitāb fi āthār Mīdhu al-qādimah (كتاب في آثار ميذو القديمة) (On the Ancient Ruins of Meedhoo) written in the 17th century in Arabic by Allama Ahmed Shihabuddine (Allama Shihab al-Din) from Meedhoo in Addu Atoll, the first settler Maldives is a human known as Dheyvis.

Laboratory (abbreviated as lab) is a place where scientific research, experiments, measurements or scientific training is carried out. Laboratories are usually made to enable these activities to be carried out in a controlled manner. Scientific laboratories are usually distinguished according to their scientific disciplines, for example physics laboratories, chemistry laboratories, biochemistry laboratories, computer laboratories and language laboratories. Laboratories used for scientific research vary in form because of the different requirements for specialists in various fields of science and engineering. A physics laboratory may contain a particle accelerator or vacuum vessel, while a metallurgical laboratory may have equipment for foundry or metal processing or equipment for testing its strength. A chemist or biologist might use a wet lab, while a psychologist's lab might be a room with one-way mirrors and hidden cameras to observe behavior. In some laboratories, computers (sometimes supercomputers) are used for simulation or analysis of data collected elsewhere, such as those used by computer scientists. Scientists in other fields will use other types of laboratories. Engineers use laboratories to design, build, and also test technological devices. Scientific laboratories can be found as research and learning spaces in schools and universities, industrial, government, or military facilities, and even aboard ships and spacecraft. The earliest recorded examples of "laboratory" in English involve alchemy and the preparation of medicines. 18th century chemistry laboratory, used by Antoine Lavoisier and scientists of his day. Thomas Edison in his laboratory, in 1901 A laboratory in the 1970's Laboratory technique is a set of procedures used in natural sciences such as chemistry, biology, physics to carry out an experiment, all following the scientific method. While some of these involve the use of complex laboratory equipment from laboratory glassware to electrical devices, others require more specific or more expensive supplies.

Laboratory equipment refers to the various equipment and tools used by scientists working in laboratories: Classical equipment includes equipment such as Bunsen burners and microscopes as well as special equipment such as operant cooling chambers, spectrophotometers and calorimeters. Laboratory equipment is generally used to carry out experiments or measurements and collect data. Larger or more sophisticated instruments are generally called scientific instruments. Both laboratory equipment and scientific instruments are increasingly being designed and used in conjunction with open hardware principles. The term laboratory is also used for certain other facilities where the process or equipment used is similar to that of a scientific laboratory. These include: In some laboratories, conditions are no more hazardous than in others. However, there are dangers in many laboratories. Laboratory hazards vary as much as the subject of research in the laboratory, and may include poisons; infectious substances; flammable, explosive or radioactive materials; moving machines; extreme temperatures; lasers, strong magnetic fields or high voltages. In laboratories where hazardous conditions exist, safety precautions are important. Rules exist to minimize individual risk, and safety equipment is used to protect laboratory users from injury or to assist in an emergency response. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) in the United States, has adapted standards for occupational exposure to hazardous chemicals in the laboratory by recognizing the unique characteristics of the laboratory workplace. These standards are often referred to as "Laboratory Standards". Based on this standard, laboratories are required to produce a Chemical Hygiene Plan (CHP) that addresses the specific hazards found at the site, and the steps to approach them. In determining the appropriate Chemical Hygiene Plan for a particular business or laboratory, it is necessary to understand the requirements of the standard, evaluate current safety, health and environmental practices, and assess hazards.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark gray)– in the African Union  (light blue) Algeria or Algeria (Arabic: الجزائر, translit. al-jazā'ir‎, /al-jaza-ir/, Berber: ⴷⵣⴰⵢⴻⵔ, / Dzayer/, French: Algérie), officially the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, is a country on the Mediterranean coast of North Africa. The name of this country which means archipelago (al-jazā'ir, in Arabic) probably refers to the 4 islands that are located close to the capital city as well as the seat of government of this country, Algiers. Algeria is a semi-presidential republic consisting of 48 provinces and 1,541 communes. With a population of over 37 million people, Algeria is the 34th most populous country on Earth. With the economy relying on oil resources, the manufacturing sector has suffered from the Dutch disease. Sonatrach, the national oil company, is the biggest company in Africa. Algeria has the second largest army and the largest defense budget in Africa. Algeria has had a peaceful Nuclear Program since the 1990s. With a total area of ​​2,381,741 square kilometers, Algeria is the 10th largest country in the world and the largest in Africa, and in the Mediterranean. The country is bordered by Tunisia to the northeast; Libya to the east; Morocco to the west; Western Sahara, Mauritania, and Mali to the southwest; Niger in the southeast; and the Mediterranean Sea to the north. Algeria is a member of the African Union, Arab League, OPEC and the United Nations, and a founding member of the Union of the Arab Maghreb. The area that is now Algeria was home to many ancient prehistoric cultures, including the Aterian and Kapsian cultures. The region is known to have had many empires and dynastyes, including Berber Numidians, Carthaginians, Romans, Vandals, Byzantines, Arab Umayyads, Berber Fatimids, Berber Almohads, and finally the Ottomans. The country's name is derived from the name of the city, Algiers.

The most common etymology connects the city's name to al-Jazā'ir (الجزائر, "The Islands"), a severed form of the city's old name, Jazā'ir Banī Mazghanna (جزائر بني مزغنة, "The Islands of the Mazghanna Tribe"), used by geographers medieval times, al-Idrisi. Other etymologies trace this name to Ldzayer, Maghrib Arabic and Berber for "Algeria" possibly related to King Ziri bin Manad of the Zirid dynasty and founding father of the city of Algiers. In the region of Ain Hanech (Saida Province), remains have been found of early hominid occupation (200,000 BC) of North Africa. Tool makers, the Neanderthals, produced hand axes in the Levaloisia and Musteria style (43,000 BC), similar to those found in the Levant. The indigenous Berber people of Algeria have been under foreign rule for the last 3000 years. The Phoenicians (1000 BC) and the Roman Republic (200 BC) were the most important, until the arrival of the Arabs in the 8th century. However, the flow of conquest was not entirely one-way; in the Middle Ages the Fatimid Berbers, originally from Algeria, took over Egypt, although soon thereafter they left North Africa. Algeria was incorporated into the Ottoman Empire by Khair ad-Din and his brother Aruj who made its coast a corsair base; privateering] which peaked in Algiers in the 1600s, after which the center of activity moved to Tripoli in Libya. Under the pretext of ignoring their consuls, the French attacked Algiers in 1830; however, the formidable resistance of figures such as Emir Abdelkader which made for a gradual conquest of Algeria, did not technically end until the early 1900s when the last Tuareg were conquered. Meanwhile, however, France had made Algeria an integral part of its metropolis, a status that would end the fall of the Fourth Republic. Tens of thousands of settlers from France, Italy, Spain, and Malta moved across the Mediterranean Sea to farm the Algerian coastal plains and occupy the most valuable parts of Algeria's cities, benefiting from the confiscation of joint lands owned by the French government.

The Sahara Desert (Arabic: الصحراء الكبرى‎, aṣ-ṣaḥrāʼ al-kubrá, 'The Greatest Desert') is the name of the largest desert in the world. The name "Sahara" is taken from Arabic which means "desert". The Sahara is located in northern Africa and is 2.5 million years old. This desert stretches from the Atlantic Ocean to the Red Sea. From the Mediterranean in the north to the Sahel in the south. From Mauritania in the west to Egypt in the east. This desert divides the continent of Africa into North Africa and "true" Africa. These two parts of the continent are very different, both climatically and culturally. The area of ​​this desert is around 9,200,000 km2. reference needed] Several thousand years ago, the Sahara was a savanna inhabited by humans. In the 3rd century BC, the climate changed to make the savanna arid. The settlers then moved to the previously swampy banks of the Nile. This is known through several ancient paintings found in several caves in the Sahara. In one of his paintings, there are pictures of animals that are not usually found there, such as elephants, giraffes, and some grass-eating animals such as horses. Natural conditions mean that there are no surviving archaeological remains in the Sahara apart from inscriptions. Inscriptions found in 2007 indicate that the Sahara was once a trade route in Africa. Average annual rainfall ranges from lowest in the northern and southern fringes of the desert to almost nonexistent in the central and eastern parts. The desert's thin northern edge receives more winter clouds and rain due to the arrival of a low pressure system over the Mediterranean concurrent with the polar opposites, although it is greatly attenuated by the mountain rain shadow effect and the average annual rainfall ranges from 100 millimeters (4 in) up to 250 millimeters (10 in).

in ASEAN (dark gray)  – Legend] Brunei Darussalam or Brunei is a sovereign country in Southeast Asia which is located on the north coast of the island of Borneo. This country has an area of ​​5,765 km² which occupies the island of Borneo with the entire coastline touching the South China Sea. Its territory is separated into states in Sarawak, Malaysia Currently, Brunei Darussalam has the second highest Human Development Index in Southeast Asia after Singapore, so it is classified as a developed country. According to the International Monetary Fund, Brunei has the fifth largest per capita gross domestic product in the world in terms of purchasing power balance. Meanwhile, Forbes places the Kingdom of Brunei as the fifth richest country out of 182 countries because it has extensive oil and natural gas fields. In addition, Brunei is also famous for its prosperity and firmness in carrying out the Islamic Religion, both in the field of government and social life. In 2020, it is recorded that Brunei has a population of 460,345 people. The royal genealogy of Brunei is found on the Tarsilah Stone which writes the Genealogy of the Kings of Brunei starting from Awang Alak Betatar, the king who first converted to Islam (1368) to Sultan Muhammad Tajuddin (19th Sultan of Brunei, ruled between 1795-1804 and 1804-1807). Brunei is the oldest state among the kingdoms in the Malay lands. The existence of Old Brunei was obtained based on Arabic, Chinese and oral traditions. In Chinese historical records known as Poli-li, Polo-lo, Poni or Puni and Bunlai. In Arabic records known as Dzabaj or Randj. An oral tradition note was obtained from Syair Awang Semaun who said that Brunei came from the words, “Baru-nah”, after the group of clans or the Sakai tribe led by Pateh Berbai went to the Brunei River looking for a place to establish a new country.

After getting the area which has a very strategic position, namely flanked by hills, water, easy to identify as well as for transportation and rich in fish as a source of food for many in the river, they also said the new word nah which means the place is very good, pleasing and appropriate in their hearts to establish the country as they wish. Then the new words, eventually changed to Brunei. A replica of a stupa that can be found at the Brunei Historical Center explains that the Hindu-Buddhist religion was once embraced by the people of Brunei. Because it has become the custom of these religious travelers, when they arrive at a place, they will erect a stupa as a sign and notification of their arrival to develop the religion in that place. Replicas of P'u Kung Chih Mu's tombstone, Rokayah bint Sultan Abdul Majid ibni Hasan ibni Muhammad Shah Al-Sultan's tombstone, and Sayid Alwi Ba-Faqih's (Mufaqih) tombstone also describe the arrival of Islam in Brunei brought by travelers, traders and preachers of Islam, so that Islam is influential and has a place for both the local population and the Brunei royal family. Islam began to develop very rapidly in the Sultanate of Brunei since Syarif Ali was appointed the 3rd Sultan of Brunei in 1425 AD because the sultan had previously married his daughter to Syarif Ali. Sultan Syarif Ali is an Ahlul Bait from the descendants of the grandson of Rasulullah Shalallahualaihi Wassallam namely Amirul Mukminin Hasan / Syaidina Hasan as stated in the Tarsilah Stone / inscription from the 18th century AD which is located in Bandar Sri Begawan, Brunei. The descendants of Sultan Syarif Ali later also developed to produce Sultans around the territory of the Sultanate of Brunei, namely the Sultans of Sambas and the Sultans of Sulu.

Tripiṭaka (Pali: Tipiṭaka; Sanskrit: Tripiṭaka) is the term used by Buddhism to describe their various canonical texts. In accordance with the meaning of the term, Tripiṭaka originally meant "three baskets" or "three groups" of teachings: Sūtra Piṭaka (Sanskrit; Pali: Sutta Pitaka), Vinaya Piṭaka (Sanskrit & Pali) and Abhidharma Piṭaka (Sanskrit; Pali: Abhidhamma Piṭaka ). The Sutta Pitaka contains Buddhist discourses for 45 years expounding the Dharma totaling 84,000 suttas. The Vinaya Pitaka contains Bhikkhu/ni rules, while the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the philosophy and metaphysics of Buddhism. A few weeks after the Buddha's death (483 BC) an old, undisciplined monk named Subhaddha said: "Don't be sad, friends, don't weep, now we are free from the Great Ascetic who will no longer tell us what is appropriate to do and what to do. no, that made our lives miserable, but now we can do whatever we like and not do what we don't like" (Vinaya Pitaka II,284). Thera Maha Kassapa upon hearing these words decided to convene a great Council (Council) at Rajagaha. With the help of King Ajatasattu of Magadha, 500 Arahants gathered at the Sattapanni Cave near Rajagaha to collect the teachings of the Buddha that had been preached so far and arrange them in a systematic way. Venerable Ananda, the Buddha's closest disciple, had the honor of repeating the Buddha's discourses and Venerable Upali recited the Vinaya (rules). It was in this First Great Assembly that all the teachings that are now known as the Tipitaka (Pali) Scriptures were collected. Those who follow the teachings of the Buddha as mentioned in the Tipitaka (Pali) Scriptures are called the Preservers for the Purity of the Teachings as the last words of the Buddha: "Take Dhamma and Vinaya as a lamp and protector for yourself".

At first the Tipitaka (Pali) was passed down orally from one generation to the next. A century later there was a group of monks who wanted to change the Vinaya. Faced with this endeavor, monks who wanted to defend the Dhamma - Vinaya as handed down by Lord Buddha Gotama organized the Second Great Council with the assistance of King Kalasoka at Vesali, where the contents of the Tipitaka (Pali) Scriptures were recited by 700 Arahants. This group of monks who adhered to the purity of the Dhamma - Vinaya called themselves the Sthaviravada, who would later be called Theravada. Meanwhile, a group of monks who wanted to change the Vinaya called themselves the Mahasanghika, which later developed into the Mahayana school. Thus, a century after the death of the Buddha Gotama, Buddhism split into the two major schools of Theravada and Mahayana. The Third Great Council was held in Pattaliputta (Patna) in the third century after the Buddha's death (249 BC) under Emperor Asoka Wardhana. This emperor embraced Buddhism and with his influence helped spread the Dhamma throughout the empire. At that time, thousands of impostors (smugglers of dark teachings) entered the Sangha with the intention of propagating their own teachings to mislead the people. To put an end to this situation, the Emperor convened a Great Assembly and purged the Sangha of interlopers and planned to send Dhamma Ambassadors to other countries. In this Third Great Assembly 100 Arahants repeated their recitation of the Tipitaka (Pali) for nine months. It is from the starting point of this Community that Buddhism can spread to all corners of the world and avoid disappearing from the land of its origin. The Fourth Great Council was held at Aluvihara (Sri Lanka) under the patronage of King Vattamani Abhaya at the beginning of the sixth century after the death of the Buddha (83 BC).

In chemistry, conformational isomerism is a form of stereoisomerism in which molecules with the same structural formula but different conformations are caused by the rotation of atoms in chemical bonds. Different conformers can be exchanged with each other by rotating single bonds without breaking chemical bonds. The existence of more than one conformation, usually with different energies, is due to the hindered rotation of sp3 orbital hybridization of carbon atoms. Conformational isomerism only occurs in single bonds because double and triple bonds have pi bonds that hinder bond rotation. Comparison of the stability of different conformers is usually explained by differences in the combination of steric repulsion and electronic effects. A simple example is seen in the butane molecule viewed using the Newman projection as shown above. Rotamers are conformers that differ only in single bond rotation. The rotational barrier is the activation energy required to change from one conformer to another. There are two important forms of conformational isomerism: Another example of conformational isomerism is molecular folding, in which some forms of folding are stable and functional, but others are not. Conformational isomerism is also seen in atropisomers. The different populations of conformers follow the Boltzmann distribution: The approximate side of the equation is the equilibrium ratio of conformer i to the total conformers. Erel{\displaystyle E_{rel}} is the relative energy of the ith conformer of the minimum energy conformer. R is the gas molar constant of 8.31 J/K/mol and T is the temperature in Kelvin (K). The denominator on the right is the partition function. If the overlapping conformation of an isomer has a high enough potential, it can be prevented from rotating into another conformation. This will lead to conformational racemic mixtures which may have different reactivity (eg in enzyme reactions which usually depend on the shape of the molecule).

For other synonyms, look at The Plant List. Taro, taro, or fiber (Colocasia esculenta L.) are important tuber-producing plants. This plant comes from the taro tribe or Araceae. Allegedly native to Southeast Asia or southern Central Asia, taro is thought to have been cultivated by humans since ancient times, even in the days before rice was planted by people. Now taro has spread to various parts of the world, including India, China, West and North Africa, and the West Indies. Taro is a staple food, apart from breadfruit, in several islands in Oceania. In Indonesia, popular taro is grown in almost all regions. Many names in regional languages ​​refer to this tuber, for example talé, kĕladi, sukat, suhat, seuhat, suwat (Bat.); taros (Nias); taléh, kaladi, kuladi (Min. ); talos, kĕladi (App. ); talĕs, keladi, cleaver, luèh (Day. ); taleus, ballang (Sd.); tales, janawari (Jw.); tales, kaladi (Md.); talĕs, cladi (Bl. ); talé, koladi, kolai, kolei, korei, kore (various dialects in North Sulawesi); aladi, suli, kosi, paco (South Sulawesi); lole, ufi lole (Timor); inane, inano, inan, ina wuu, ronan, kětu, etu, hakar, wakal, gwal (various islands in Maluku); bètè, ota, dilago, komo (North Maluku); ifen (Biak) omo, uma, warimu, hèkérè, sekéré, yéfam (Papua). While taro in English is called taro, old cocoyam, dasheen, and eddoe. Herbs, with a kind of tuber called a weevil (English: corm, corm) that grows underground; height 0.4-1.5 m. Leaves 2-5 strands; with green stalks, streaked with dark green or purplish, 23-150 cm, frond-shaped base; leaf blade 6.60 × 7.53 cm, ovate, oblong, or oval, with a tapered tip, sometimes purplish in color around the stalk, the underside is waxy, the taju at the base is rounded.

Inflorescence occurs inside the cob in the axils, 15–60 cm long. Flower sheath 10–30 cm, consists of two parts, the upper one is longer, yellow-orange and falls off. Cob butter-colored on male parts. Buni fruit is green, lk. 0.5 cm. Spindle-shaped seeds, grooved lengthwise. Taro is primarily grown for its edible tubers, which are an important source of carbohydrates. However, this tuber contains an itchy sap, which varies in sharpness according to the type, so it must be cooked before it can be consumed. Eating taro should not be excessive, because it contains sap which causes itching. Eating too much taro causes a feeling of bloating and indigestion. Taro tubers can be processed by steaming, boiling, baking, frying, or processing into flour, porridge, and pastries. In some areas of Indonesia where rice cannot grow, including the Mentawai Islands and Papua, taro is eaten as a staple food, by roasting, steaming, or cooking it in bamboo tubes. In Hawaii and parts of the Islands. In Polynesia, taro tubers are steamed and pounded to make a paste which can then be fermented to produce pudding. In Java as well as in other places in Indonesia, taro tubers are steamed or fried to be enjoyed as a snack. In addition to the tubers, young taro leaves and petioles can be used as vegetables. Sayur lompong from West Java is a type of curry that uses the young taro shoots and leaf stalks, cooked with or without coconut milk. Its young leaves are known as the preferred buntil wrappers. Taro leaves, old or young, are also used as feed for carp. The leaves, petioles and tubers are used as a mixture of animal feed, especially for pigs.

Literature (Sanskrit: शास्त्र, IAST: śāstra, IPA: /ʃɑstraː/) is an absorption word from the Sanskrit language, namely shaastra, which means "text containing instructions" or "guidelines". Shaastra comes from the basic words śās- or shaas- (Sanskrit: शास्) which means to direct, teach, give instructions or instructions, and tra (Sanskrit: त्र) which means a tool or means. Literary texts are also not only texts that contain teaching instructions, more than that in Indonesian this word is commonly used to refer to "literature" or a type of writing that has a certain meaning or beauty. It is also necessary to know that there is the use of literary and literary terms. Literary segmentation refers more according to its definition as just text. Meanwhile, literature is more directed to literature with a strong poetic or abstract nuance. The term writer is one example, defined as a person who is engaged in literature, not literature. Because, a writer is someone who likes poetic and abstract nuances, not just texts. In addition, in a literary sense, literature can be divided into written literature or oral literature (oral literature). Here literature has little to do with writing, but with language which is used as a vehicle for expressing certain experiences or thoughts. Sugiantomas, stated that literature is the result of human creative activity which is poured into language media, both spoken and written. A work of art can be said to be a work of literary value not only because the language is beautiful, square, full of rhythm and imagery, but must be seen as a whole; of aesthetic values, moral values, and conceptual values ​​contained in the literary work. Eagleton, gives the opinion that literary works of beautiful writing (belle letters) which record something in the form of language which is condensed, deepened, convoluted, shortened and twisted, made odd or other ways of aesthetic composition through language tools.

The sun or Surya is the star at the center of the solar system. It has an almost spherical shape and consists of hot plasma mixed with a magnetic field. It has a diameter of about 1,392,684 km, about 109 times the diameter of Earth, and its mass (about 2×1030 kilograms, 330,000 times that of Earth) represents approximately 99.86 % of the total mass of the solar system. The sun is the largest celestial body in the Milky Way galaxy, which is even 10 times the size of the largest planet in the solar system, Jupiter. Chemically, about three-quarters of the sun's mass is composed of hydrogen, while the remainder is predominantly helium. The rest of the mass (1.69%, equivalent to 5,629 times the mass of Earth) consists of heavy elements such as oxygen, carbon, neon, and iron. The sun formed about 4.6 billion years ago due to the gravitational decay of a region within a large molecular cloud. Most of the matter gathered in the center, while the rest flattened out into the circulating disk that would become the solar system. Its central mass gets hotter and denser and eventually starts thermonuclear fusion in its core. It is thought that nearly all other stars formed by a similar process. The classification of sun stars, based on their spectral class, is a main sequence G star (G2V) and is often classified as a yellow dwarf because its radiation appears to be more intense in the yellow-red portion of the spectrum. Although the color is white, from the surface of the Earth, the sun looks yellow due to the mixing of blue light in the atmosphere. According to the spectrum class label, G2 indicates a surface temperature of around 5778 K (5505 °C) and V indicates that the sun, like other stars, is a sequence star. main, so its energy is created by the nuclear fusion of hydrogen nuclei into helium. At its core, the sun fuses 620 million metric tons of hydrogen every second. Based on estimates that all the hydrogen in the sun will be used up in about 4.5 billion years, and the sun will die into a white dwarf.

In the past, astronomers saw the sun as a small and insignificant star. Today, the sun is thought to be brighter than about 85% of the stars in the Milky Way galaxy which are dominated by red dwarfs. The sun's absolute magnitude is +4.83. However, as the star closest to Earth, the sun is the brightest object in the sky with an apparent magnitude of −26.74. The sun's hot corona continues to expand in space and creates the solar wind, which is a stream of charged particles that travels up to the heliopause at about 100 au. The bubble in the interstellar medium formed by the solar wind, the heliosphere, is the largest continuous structure in the solar system. The Sun is currently moving through the Local Interstellar Cloud (near the G Cloud) in the Local Bubble zone, within the innermost rim of the Orion Arm of the Milky Way galaxy. Of the 50 closest star systems within 17 light years of Earth (the closest star is a red dwarf named Proxima Centauri about 4.2 light years away), the sun has the fourth largest mass. The sun orbits the center of the Milky Way at a distance of approximately 24,000–26,000 light years from the galactic center. When viewed from the galactic north pole, the sun completes one orbit clockwise in about 225–250 million years. Since the Milky Way is moving relative to the cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation towards the constellation Hydra at a speed of 550 km/s, the sun's speed relative to the CMB is about 370 km/s in the direction of Crater or Leo. The sun's average distance from Earth is about 149.6 million kilometers (1 au), although this distance varies as the Earth moves from perihelion in January to aphelion in July. At this average distance, light travels from the sun to Earth in 8 minutes and 19 seconds.

The kelvin (symbol: K; English and French: kelvin) is the base unit for thermodynamic temperature units in the International System of Units (SI). After being redefined in 2019, the definition of the kelvin unit, as stated in the ninth edition of the SI Brochure, is as follows. The kelvin, which is designated by K, is the SI unit of thermodynamic temperature. This unit is defined by obtaining a fixed numerical value from the Boltzmann constant k of 1.380649×10−23 when expressed in units J⋅K−1 which is proportional to kg⋅m2⋅s−2⋅K−1, by definition the kilogram, meter, and seconds defined with respect to h, c, and ΔνCs. The Kelvin scale itself is an absolute thermodynamic temperature scale, meaning the kelvin unit uses absolute zero (when molecular motion stops, in the field of thermodynamics) as the point 0 K. Previously, the kelvin scale was defined by two facts, namely that zero kelvin is absolute zero and that one a kelvin is a fraction of 1273.15 from the thermodynamic temperature of the triple point of water (0.01°C). After redefinition, the definition of one kelvin becomes the thermodynamic temperature change T resulting in a change in kT heat energy of 1.380649 × 10−23 J. The Celsius temperature scale is also now defined in terms of the kelvin. Kelvin was named after the English physicist and engineer William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin (1824–1907). Unlike the Fahrenheit and Celsius scales, the kelvin does not use degrees (°). The name of the kelvin as an SI unit begins with a lowercase letter (except at the beginning of a sentence), and is never followed by the word degree or the symbol °, unlike the Fahrenheit and Celsius scales. This is because kelvin is the unit of measurement for the "Kelvin scale", while Celsius and Fahrenheit are just the "measurement scale", while the units for both scales are actually degrees of temperature.

Das Lied der Deutschen or Deutschlandlied (meaning the German Nation's Song) is the national anthem of the Federal Republic of Germany which has been used since the founding of the Weimar Republic (1922). The lyrics to this song were composed before the German Revolution of 1848, namely in 1841 on the Isle of Helgoland (then controlled by the British) by August Heinrich Hoffmann von Fallersleben to convey the mood of the German-speaking people at that time regarding a common "homeland" that they did not have, due to the breakup of the Holy Roman Empire of the Germanic nation. (Vaterland, Germany is not an archipelago so it refers to land, while in Indonesia land is associated with women: "motherland"). He wanted the German people to give priority to a united Germany over kingdoms and various political units that competed with each other. The second verse (strofe) is intended as a lullaby of beer. These lyrics were created to play over a melody composed by Joseph Haydn which was first composed in 1797 as a tribute song to Emperor Franz II, emperor of Austria. Haydn later included the song as part of his No. 1 String Quartet. 62 in C major, Op. 76, No. 3 of his works. Since the end of World War I, the government of the Weimar Republic adopted this song as the national anthem. At that time, the song was popularly known as Deutschland über alles, taking the first line from the first verse of the lyrics. The meaning of the phrase (meaning "Germany above all") is often misinterpreted as a desire for world domination, although its real intent is to indicate that there are various Germanic peoples and nations that are still divided and not yet united. But this misunderstanding was actually exploited by Hitler's Nazi regime as a political justification for its expansion. In 1952, the melody was reused as the national anthem of the Federal Republic of Germany (West Germany) based on correspondence between German President Theodor Heuss and German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, but only the third verse was sung.

Existentialism is a tradition of philosophical thought primarily associated with several 19th- and 20th-century European philosophers who agreed (despite deep doctrinal differences) that philosophical thought begins with the human subject—not just the human subject who thinks, but also the human individual who doing, who feels, and who lives. The main value of existentialist thought is usually considered to be freedom, but in fact the highest value is authenticity. In an existentialist sense, an individual begins with what is known as an "existential stance," namely a kind of feeling of disorientation, confusion, or fear in the face of a world that seems meaningless or absurd. There are also some existentialist philosophers who think that the content of traditional systematic or academic philosophy is too abstract or far from concrete human experience. Soren Kierkegaard is generally considered the first existentialist philosopher, although he did not use the term existentialism. He argues that each individual—not society or religion—is responsible for giving meaning to life and living, and to live out that meaning honestly and passionately (in an "authentic" way). Existentialism became popular after World War II and has greatly influenced fields outside philosophy, including theology, drama, art, literature, and psychology. The term "existentialism" (French: L'existentialisme) was coined by the French Catholic philosopher Gabriel Marcel in the mid-1940s. At first, when Marcel applied this term to Jean-Paul Sartre at a colloquium in 1945, Sartre refused. Sartre then changed his mind and on 29 October 1945 publicly adopted the existentialist label, in a public lecture delivered to the Club Maintenant in Paris. This public lecture was later published as a short book which greatly popularized existentialist thought entitled L'existentialism est un humanisme (Existentialism Is a Form of Humanism).

Marcel himself soon rejected the term in favor of Neo-Socratic, in honor of Kierkegaard's essay "On the Concept of Irony with Continuous Reference to Socrates" (Danish: Om Begrebet Ironi med stadigt Hensyn til Socrates). There are scholars who argue that the term should only be used for the cultural movement in Europe in the 1940s and 1950s and is associated with the works of philosophers Jean-Paul Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir, Maurice Merleau-Ponty, and Albert Camus. Other scientists have extended this term to Kierkegaard, and some have extended it to Socrates. However, this term is often used to refer to the philosophical views of Jean-Paul Sartre. The labels existentialism and existentialist are often seen as historical conveniences because the two terms were first used by some philosophers long after they died. Although existentialism is generally thought to have started with Kierkegaard, the first major existentialist philosopher to use the term to introduce himself was Jean-Paul Sartre. Sartre put forward the idea that "what all existentialist philosophers have in common is the fundamental doctrine that existence precedes essence", as Frederick Copleston explained. According to the philosopher Steven Crowell, defining existentialism is a little difficult, and he says that the term is better understood as a general approach that can be used to reject a particular systematic philosophy, rather than using it to refer to a systematic philosophy. It has been claimed that Kierkegaard adopted the term "existentialism" (or at least the term "existential" as a description of his philosophy) from the Norwegian poet and literary critic Johan Sebastian Cammermeyer Welhaven. This claim stems from two sources. A Norwegian philosopher, Erik Lundestad, remembers the Danish philosopher, Fredrik Christian Sibbern. Sibbern is said to have had two conversations in 1841, the first with Welhaven and the second with Kierkegaard.

Stupa (Sanskrit: स्तूप) is a symbol of Buddhism in the form of an inverted bowl. At the top of the top of the inverted bowl there is a rectangular or octagonal shaped stick above it. Stupa is an identity that signifies a Buddhist sacred building. In some areas of the world, stupas serve as markers for burial places for precious relics. These treasures can include parts of the Buddha, his bowls and robes, replicas of footprints, and various other materials that are important and related to the Buddha. The shape of the stupa is half a ball made by humans. The stupa form of pre-Buddhist India is an earthen burial place roofed with wooden pillars. The shape symbolizes the relationship between heaven, earth, and the underworld. In Ceylon and Sri Lanka, there is another mention of a stupa, namely dagob. In Thailand, the mention of the name of the stupa is called a cedi. A researcher named Nitin Kumar said that the stupa was made with the five cosmic elements that make up the universe, namely earth, water, fire, air and space. Apart from the cosmic element, the physical form of the Buddha is also represented in the form of a stupa. The stupa depicts the base of the stupa which represents the Buddha's feet, the dome of the stupa is part of the Buddha's body, and the head is shown in the form of a cube between the dome and the top of the stupa's cone. In ancient India, the stupa building was used as a tomb, a place to store the ashes of nobles or certain figures. Among Buddhists, a stupa is a place to store relics of the Buddha. After death and then cremated, the remains in the form of crystals which are also known as relics or sarira are kept in eight separate stupas which were erected in North India. During its development, the stupa became a symbol of Buddhism.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health science Gerontology (English: Gerontology) comes from the Greek, namely: geros which means elderly and logos which means science. So etymologically gerontology can be defined as the science of the elderly (elderly). Although it sounds simple and short, this definition has a very broad scope because the problem of aging is motivated by various factors and aspects and affects many areas and aspects of life. Because of this, gerontologists (gerontologists) have very diverse scientific backgrounds. They are researchers and practitioners in the fields of biology, medicine, psychology, criminology, sociology, economics, anthropology, law, social politics and various other disciplines. Gerontologists apply their knowledge and all the knowledge they have to help the elderly live a good, prosperous and happy life. They conduct training for the elderly; educating the general public to participate in encouraging and facilitating the elderly to remain active and productive; Conduct counseling on good ways to care for the elderly; advocating the creation of public policies that accommodate the rights of the elderly and the creation of laws that guarantee protection for the elderly. The term gerontology was first introduced by a Russian scientist, Ilya Ilyich Mechniko around 1903. Mechniko used the term to refer to the studies he produced through scientific research to understand the aging process. However, long before Mechniko was born, the aging process has become a topic of discussion, study and learning material for thinkers but with less scientific approaches when viewed from the perspective of modern scientific disciplines. Aristotle, for example, more than 2000 years ago on various occasions raised the topic about life expectancy and the theory of aging of various species of living things. One of the important questions he asked about this theme was “why is there death”?

He tried to answer this question by studying the physical morphological components of plants and animals so he came to the conclusion that death was caused by the loss of the ability to develop from these morphological components with increasing age. Apart from Aristotle, it is also worth noting the names of Galen and Roger Bacon who published writings on the aging of living things. Galen (129-216 AD) in his book entitled De Sanitate Tuenda explained that the aging process lasts a lifetime, starting from conception to death. Gelen explained that the aging process occurs due to an imbalance in body heat that will be experienced by each organism. Body temperature will get colder from time to time. Whereas the right body temperature is vital for producing tissues and organs. In contrast to Galen, Roger Bacon (1220-1292 AD) in his book Opus Magi reflected on death and the short lifespan of humans within the framework of the teachings of the Christian faith. He explained that the short human lifespan is accidental, so it is possible to improve it. Roger Bacon explained, basically humans can live hundreds of years but because of the fall of humans into sin (the Eden event) their life span is shortened. This, according to him, is evidenced by the human soul which is eternal (immortal). In addition, according to Roger Bacon, the decline in life expectancy also occurs because humans are not sensitive to hygienic factors. Furthermore, Francis Bacon during the Renaissance seriously reviewed the human life cycle in his History of Life and Death and gave several suggestions for overcoming the decline in body strength in order to extend life. One of the suggestions he gave was to take care of the soul/spirit. Towards the 20th century, empirical studies and the scientific method began to be introduced and promoted intensively as a means of obtaining scientifically justifiable truths.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark gray)– in the African Union  (light blue) Somalia (Somali: Soomaaliya; Arabic: الصومال, translit. aṣ-Ṣūmāl‎), officially the Somali Federal Republic (formerly the Somali Democratic Republic ), is a country located in the Horn of Africa. The country is bordered by Djibouti to the northwest, Kenya to the southwest, the Gulf of Aden and Yemen to the north, the Indian Ocean to the east, and Ethiopia to the west. The land of Somalia was known as the "Land of Aromatics" in ancient Egypt. However, the Somalis believe that their ancestors are now Arabs who migrated to Somalia in the 7th century when the spread of Islam was being intensively carried out by Muslim Arabs. Most of them settled and assimilated with the local nomadic population which eventually gave birth to the Somali people today. Somalia's modern history can be traced back to British and Italian colonization in the mid-1880s. The region of Zeila, Berbera was administered by the British as British Somaliland from the 1880s to 1960, while the southern region was Italian Somaliland. After World War II, Somalia became a UN trust territory and finally gained its independence in 1960 under the name of the Somali Republic. The Somali Republic was a parliamentary democracy until 1969 before the armed forces took leadership and transformed Somalia into a socialist state with the name the Somali Democratic Republic. The new constitution was passed in 1979 and elections were held to elect the People's Assembly. In addition, Somalia also has a regular legal assembly and one based on Islamic sharia. Somalia has six administrative regions which include Mijirtein, Mudugh, Benadir, Hiran, Upper Juba and Lower Juba.

Somalia is now led by a president and prime minister, namely president Sharif Ahmed and prime minister Omar Ali. In 1977, Somalia was involved in a conflict with Ethiopia because Somalia wanted the Ogaden region which was traditionally Somali territory because there were so many Somali tribes living there. With the help of the Soviet Union, Ethiopia managed to defend the territory and caused more than 1,000,000 families to flee to Somalia. This creates a huge refugee problem in Somalia. Somalia itself has a very small number of troops, because this country has always been hit by protracted conflicts and civil wars as well as the problem of piracy which has recently become very rife in the Somali sea area. Somalia is located from 12` North Latitude to 39` South Latitude and from 41` East Longitude to 51` East Longitude. Its north coast faces the Gulf of Aden and its east coast faces the Indian Ocean. Somalia is bordered by Kenya, Djibouti and Ethiopia. The territory of Somalia covers an area of ​​637,657 km2, slightly larger than that of France. Somalia has a dry, tropical climate with an annual rainfall of less than 50 cm. Somalia is mostly an arid semi-desert area, although there are still mountains and low-lying areas in the southeast. Somalia has a coastline of about 2,600 km, but because of the Pelintang reef off the coast, the supply of imported materials is somewhat hampered. Somalia has three main rivers namely the Nagal River in the north, the Shibeli River in the middle and the Giuba River in the south. For the last two mentioned, the area through which the river flows is always fertile because every year this river always has water. In many areas, the land of Somalia is overgrown with bushes and grass, especially in the south.

Woman is a term for the human gender that is different from men. In Sanskrit the word woman is taken from the word per + empu + an. Per, means creature, and empu, which means noble, master, skilled. Thus women can be interpreted as beings who have nobility or ability. Women have organs of the female reproductive system, namely the ovaries, uterus and vagina, and are capable of producing gamete cells called eggs. Women also have the ability to menstruate, get pregnant, give birth, and breastfeed. The term "woman" is generally used for people of all ages. The general term for female adults is called a woman. Meanwhile, the term for a child who is female is called "daughter", "girl", or "girl". In Indonesia, a more polite greeting or address for respected or older women is "mother", or other greetings according to the local language of each region. The opposite sex of women is men. According to popular theory, the word "female" comes from the word "empu" in Old Javanese, which was later absorbed into Malay, meaning "lord, noble, respect". The word master was affixed with the addition of "per-" and "-an" which then formed the word "female". Some sources also state that the word empu in women is related to the word ampu which means "support, support". The word "woman" comes from the Sanskrit word vanita, which literally means "to be desired". Certain religious doctrines have specific provisions relating to gender roles, social and personal interactions between the sexes, appropriate clothing for women, and various other issues affecting women and their position in society. In many countries, these religious teachings influence the criminal or family law of those jurisdictions (see Islamic law, for examples).

in ASEAN (dark gray) – Legend] The Philippines, with the official name referred to as the Republic of the Philippines (Filipino: Republika ng Pilipinas) is an island nation and unitary state with a presidential system with a constitutional republic in Southeast Asia, north of Indonesia, and northeastern Sabah. The Philippines is an island nation located in the West Pacific Rim, this country consists of 7,641 islands. Over thousands of years, these hardworking, Filipino islanders have developed a highly developed system of rice cultivation, which provides the staple food of their people. The Philippines was the most developed country on the Asian continent after World War II, but has since lagged behind other countries due to weak economic growth, government expropriation of wealth, widespread corruption, and neo-colonial influences. Even so, currently the Philippines is experiencing moderate economic growth, which is largely contributed by remittances by Filipino workers abroad, and the rapidly growing information technology sector. The Philippines is often considered to be the only country on the Asian Continent where Western cultural influence is felt most strongly. The country's major problems include the Bangsamoro separatist movement in the south of the Philippines, namely in the Mindanao region, rebels from the communist New People's Army (New People's Army) in rural areas, government policies that are often inconsistent, the level of increasing crime, and environmental damage such as deforestation, and marine pollution. The Philippines also suffers from the problem of overpopulation in urban areas due to a lack of jobs in rural areas, and a high birth rate. Filipino written records begin around the 8th century based on discoveries of copper plates near Manila.

From the writing on the plate it is known that the Philippines was under the influence of Srivijaya. However, this written evidence is so scanty that even Filipino historians still think that Philippine history began in the colonial era. Before the arrival of the Spaniards in the 16th century, in the Philippines there were small animist kingdoms influenced by Indian culture, and Islamic ones in the southern part of the archipelago. These Muslim kingdoms received strong influence from the Malacca Kingdom. For 265 years, the Philippines was a colony of the Spanish Empire (1565-1821), and for the next 77 years it was made a Spanish province (1821-1898). The country got the name of the Philippines after being ruled by the ruler of Spain, King Felipe II. After the Spanish-American War in 1898, the Philippines was ruled by the United States. It then became a commonwealth under the United States from 1935. The Commonwealth period was cut short by World War II when the Philippines was under Japanese occupation. The Philippines finally gained its independence (de facto) on July 4, 1946. This period of foreign colonialism greatly influenced Filipino culture and society. The country is known for having a strong Roman Catholic Church, and is one of two predominantly Catholic countries in Asia besides Timor Leste. The Philippines consists of 7,107 islands with an estimated total land area of ​​343,448 km2. The country is located between 116° 40', and 126° 34' E, and 4° 40', and 21° 10' N. To the east it is bordered by the Philippine Sea, to the west by the South China Sea, and to the south by the Celebes Sea. The island of Borneo lies a few hundred kilometers to the southwest, and Taiwan to the north. Maluku, and Sulawesi to the south, and to the east is Palau. The Philippines has a coastline of 36,289 km (22,549 mi), which makes it the fifth longest coastline in the world.

Mitosis is a cell division through the stages of prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. The purpose of mitosis is for growth and regeneration which results in two daughter cells that are identical to the original parent cell. Mitosis occurs only once and lasts only during somatization. Mitosis is generally followed by cytokinesis which divides the cytoplasm and cell membrane. This process produces two identical daughter cells, which have nearly the same distribution of organelles and cell components. Mitosis and cytokenesis are the mitotic phase (M phase) of the cell cycle, in which the initial cell divides into two daughter cells that have the same genetic makeup as the initial cell. Mitosis occurs only in eukaryotic cells. In multicellular organisms, somatic cells undergo mitosis, while sex cells (which become sperm in males or eggs in females) divide by a different process called meiosis. Prokaryotic cells that do not have a nucleus undergo division called binary fission. Because cytokinesis generally occurs after mitosis, the term "mitosis" is often used to refer to the "mitotic phase". It should be noted that many cells carry out mitosis and cytokinesis separately, forming a single cell with multiple nuclei. This is done for example by fungi and slime molds. In animals, cytokinesis and mitosis can also occur separately, for example at certain stages in the development of the fruit fly embryo. The main outcome of mitosis is the division of the original cell's genome into the two daughter cells. The genome is made up of a number of chromosomes, which are tightly coiled DNA complexes that contain genetic information vital for the proper functioning of a cell. Because each daughter cell must be genetically identical to the parent cell, the starting cell must duplicate each chromosome before it can go through mitosis.

The process of DNA doubling occurs in the middle of interphase, which is the phase before the mitotic phase of the cell cycle. After doubling, each chromosome has identical copies, called sister chromatids, which are attached to a region of the chromosome called the centromere. Sister chromatids themselves are not considered chromosomes. See also Meiosis and Mitosis Mitotic division is a type of cell division in which 2 genetically similar daughter cells are produced. This means that the two daughter cells that are formed have the same genetic makeup as their parents. Almost all living things go through the same process of mitosis, except for prokaryotes (living things that do not have a true nucleus) such as bacteria, viruses and blue algae. The mitotic cycle of a cell can be distinguished into two stages, namely interphase (resting stage) and mitosis (division stage). Interphase is the period between one division and the next in the cell division cycle. This period occurs when a cell's DNA molecule in the nucleus will replicate or make derivatives like itself. The nuclear membrane is connected to the inner skeleton of the cytoplasm, where there are dark colored granules called ribosomes. These ribosomes are rich in ribonucleotide acid (ARN) and have an important role in protein synthesis. In the interphase nucleus, 2 main components can be distinguished, namely karyolymph (nuclear fluid which appears clear, colorless and colloidal) and nucleolus (core of the nucleus). The rest consists of chromatin, in the form of fine threads composed of deoxyribonucleic acid (ADN) and protein to form nucleoproteins. In the cytoplasm, mitochondria appear, which are organelles where respiration takes place from the cell. The interphase stage is divided into several phases: 1.G1: specifically, in the G¬1 stage the cell size increases due to cell growth. 2.S: In the G1 stage, the cell size increases due to cell growth. S, chromosomal duplication and DNA synthesis (DNA replication) occur.

Teleology comes from the Greek roots τέλος, telos, meaning end, aim, purpose, and λόγος, logos, speech. Teleology is a teaching that explains that everything and all events lead to a certain goal. The term teleology was put forward by Christian Wolff, a German philosopher of the 18th century. Teleology is a study of phenomena that show order, design, goals, ends, aims, tendencies, goals, directions, and how these things are achieved in a process of development. In a general sense, teleology is a philosophical study of evidence for planning, function, or purpose in nature as well as in history. In other fields, teleology is a religious-philosophical teaching about the existence of goals and objective "wisdom" outside of humans. In the world of ethics, teleology can be interpreted as a moral consideration of whether an action is good or bad. There is a big difference between teleology and deontology. In simple terms, we can see this from the difference in principle between the two. In deontology, we will look at a principle of right and wrong. However, in teleology it is not that which is the basis, but good and evil. When law plays an important role in deontology, it does not mean that teleology ignores it. Teleology understands what is right and what is wrong, but it is not the ultimate criterion. What is more important is the goal and the result. No matter how wrong an action according to the law, but if it has a good purpose and results, then the action is considered good. Teleological teaching can pose the danger of justifying any means. Thus a good purpose must be followed by a lawful act. This proves that the teleological point of view is not always separate from the deontological. Discussion of "good" and "evil" must be balanced with "right" and "wrong".. More profoundly, this teleological teaching can create hedonism, when "what is good" is reduced to "what is good for me".

Nicaragua (Spanish: nikaˈɾaɣwa] ( listen)), officially the Republic of Nicaragua (Spanish: República de Nicaragua), is a republic in Central America bordered by Honduras to the north, Costa Rica to the south, and the Pacific Ocean to the west. , and the Caribbean Sea to the east. This country is the largest in the area and the least densely populated. The name Nicaragua is taken from the word Nicarao, the name of a tribe on the shores of Lago Nicaragua and the word agua which means water in Spanish. The Nicaraoans came from the north after the fall of Teotihuacán at the suggestion of their religious leaders. Nicaragua became famous when a gigantic earthquake devastated the country on December 23, 1972. Injured 20,000 people and destroyed 5,000 people. With an area of ​​around 129,500 km², Nicaragua is almost the same area as New York. This country has 7% of the world's biodiversity and the second largest rainforest in America; nearly 20% of its territory is protected as a national park or nature reserve. The country is bordered by Costa Rica to the south, Honduras to the north, and the Caribbean Sea to the east. Its territory is divided into three regions: the Pacific Lowland, the North Central Range, and the Atlantic Lowland. Nicaragua is divided into 15 departments (departamentos) and 2 autonomous regions. Nicaragua is one of the poorest countries in America. Gross domestic product (GDP) in purchasing power parity (PPP) in 2008 was estimated at US$17.37 billion. Agriculture represents 15.5% of GDP, the highest percentage in Central America. Remittances account for more than 15% of Nicaragua's GDP. Nearly a billion dollars was sent to the country by Nicaraguans living abroad. The economy grew at a rate of around 4% in 2011.

In 2019, with tax restrictions and civil conflict, negative growth was recorded at -3.9%; International Monetary Fund forecasts for 2020 saw a further decline of 6% due to COVID-19. According to the United Nations Development Programme, 48% of Nicaragua's population live below the poverty line. 79.9% of the population live on less than $2 per day. According to UN figures, 80% of the indigenous population (which is 5% of the population) live on less than $1 per day. According to the World Bank, Nicaragua is ranked 123 out of 190 best economies to start a business. In 2007, Nicaragua's economy was labeled "62.7% free" by the Heritage Foundation with high levels of fiscal, government, labor, investment, finance, and trade freedom.
