Nicaragua ranks 61st as the freest economy in the world and 14th (out of 29) in America. In March 2007, Poland and Nicaragua signed an agreement to write off $30.6 million borrowed by the Nicaraguan government in the 1980s. Inflation was reduced from 33,500% in 1988 to 9.45% in 2006, and foreign debt was cut in half. Nicaragua is primarily an agricultural country; agriculture accounts for 60% of its total exports which annually generates around US$300 million. Nearly two-thirds of the coffee crop originates from the northern part of the central highlands, in the area north and east of the city of Estelí. Tobacco, grown in the same northern highland region as coffee, has become a cash crop of increasing importance since the 1990s with annual exports of leaves and cigars of around $200 million annually. Soil erosion and pollution from overuse of pesticides have become serious concerns in the cotton district. Yields and exports have both declined since 1985.

Stars are celestial bodies that emit light caused by nuclear fusion reactions that produce energy that occurs in their cores. It should be noted that 'pseudo stars' are not stars, but planets that reflect light from other stars and appear to glow in the sky like a star. According to astronomy, the definition of a star is: All massive objects (with a mass between 0.08 and 200 solar masses) that are and have carried out energy generation through nuclear fusion reactions. Therefore, white dwarfs and neutron stars that do not produce constant energy are called stars. The closest star to Earth is the Sun at about 149,680,000 kilometers, followed by Proxima Centauri in the constellation Sentaurus, about four light years away. The stars have been a part of every culture. The stars are used in religious practices, in navigation, and in farming. The Gregorian calendar, which is used in almost all parts of the world, is the solar calendar, basing itself on the position of the Earth relative to the closest star, the Sun. Early astronomers such as Tycho Brahe were able to identify 'new stars' in the sky (later called novae) indicating that the sky is impermanent. In 1584 Giordano Bruno proposed that the stars were actually other Suns, and might have Earth-like planets in their orbits, ideas that had been suggested earlier by ancient Greek philosophers such as Democritus and Epicurus. In the following century, the idea that the star was the distant Sun gained agreement among astronomers. To explain why the stars do not exert a gravitational pull on the solar system, Isaac Newton proposed that they are spread evenly in the sky, an idea originating from the theologian Richard Bentley. The Italian astronomer Geminiano Montanari recorded a change in the luminosity of the star Algol in 1667.

Edmond Halley published the first measurements of the apparent motion of a pair of nearby "fixed" stars, showing that they had changed positions since those made by Ptolemy and Hipparchus. Direct measurement of the distance to the star 61 Cygni was carried out in 1838 by Friedrich Bessel using the parallax technique. William Herschel was the first astronomer to try to determine the distribution of stars in the sky. During the 1780s he carried out enumerations of some 600 different regions of the sky. He then concluded that the number of stars increased steadily in one direction of the sky, namely the center of the Milky Way galaxy. His son John Herschel repeated the same work in the southern celestial hemisphere and found the same result. In addition, William Herschel also found that several star pairs were not stars that coincidentally were in one direction of the line of sight, but they were indeed physically paired to form multiple star systems. The idea of ​​constellations has been known since Babylonian times. The ancient sky watchers imagined certain patterns formed by a prominent arrangement of stars, and related them in some way from nature or their mythology. Twelve of these arrangements lie on the ecliptic and form the basis of astrology. Many of the prominent individual stars were given their own names, especially with Arabic or Latin names. Like certain constellations and the sun, some stars also have their own mythology. To the ancient Greeks, several "stars", known as planets (Greek: πλανήτης planētēs], wanderer), represented their various important gods from which the planets Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn were named. Uranus and Neptune were also Greek and Roman gods, but were unknown in ancient times because of their dim radiance. Its second name was given by later astronomers.

Humans (Homo sapiens) are the primate species that originated and lived on earth with the largest population, the most widespread distribution, and are characterized by the ability to walk on two legs, as well as a complex brain capable of making tools, culture, and language complex. Most humans live in a social structure consisting of certain groups which in turn can compete with or help one another, ranging from small family groups with kinship ties to large political groups or countries. Social interaction between humans creates a diversity of values, norms, and rituals in human society. The human desire to know and influence the world around him led to developments in philosophy, science, mythology, and religion. Other classifications are based on age, starting from fetuses, infants, toddlers, children, adolescents, puberty, youth, adults, and the elderly. In addition, there are many other classifications, based on physical characteristics (skin color, hair, eyes; nose shape; height; gender), socio-political-religious affiliation (adherents of XYZ religions/beliefs, XYZ citizens, XYZ party member), kinship (family: immediate family, distant family, stepfamily, adoptive family, foster family; friends; enemies), and so on. Character is a term for people who are famous and influential, for example 'political figures', 'figures who appear in films', 'characters who receive awards', and others. In biology, humans are usually studied as one of several species on Earth. The study of human biology is sometimes also extended to psychological and physical aspects, but usually not spiritual or religious. Biologically, humans are defined as hominids from the species Homo sapiens. The only remaining subspecies of this Homo sapiens is Homo sapiens sapiens. They are usually considered the only surviving species in the genus Homo.

Humans use their perfect bipedal locomotion (two legs). With the two feet to move the body, the two forelimbs can be used to manipulate objects using the thumb (thumb). The average height for adult American women is 162 cm (64 inches) and the average weight is 62 kg (137 pounds). Men are generally larger: 175 cm (69 inches) and 78 kilograms (172 pounds). Of course these figures are only averages, the physical form of humans varies greatly, depending on factors of location and history. Although body size is generally influenced by heredity, environmental and cultural factors can also influence it, such as food nutrition. Human cubs are born after nine months in the womb, and typically weigh 3-4 kilograms (6-9 pounds) and 50-60 centimeters (20-24 inches) in height. Helpless at birth, they continue to grow for several years, generally reaching sexual maturity around 12-15 years of age. Boys will still continue to grow for several years after this, usually stopping around 18 years of age. Human skin color varies from almost black to reddish white. In general, people whose ancestors came from sunny areas have darker skin than people whose ancestors came from areas where there was little sunlight. (However, this is of course not an absolute standard, there are people who have ancestors who came from areas that are less hot, and these people can have different skin colors within the scope of the spectrum). On average, women have slightly lighter skin than men. Estimated human longevity at birth is approaching 80 years in affluent countries, this can be achieved thanks to the help of science and technology.

Ghana, officially the Republic of Ghana, is a country in West Africa bordered by Ivory Coast to the west, Burkina Faso to the north, Togo to the east, and the Gulf of New Guinea to the south. Its area is almost twice the size of the island of Java. Ghana is one of the largest cocoa producing countries in the world besides the largest aluminum producer in Africa. Formerly known as the Gold Coast, the name "Ghana" comes from the Ghanaian Empire (although its area was not as large as modern-day Ghana). Before colonial times, Ghana was ruled by several ancient empires, including the inland empire of Ashanti and the various Fante states along the coast. Trade with European countries thrived after contact with the Portuguese in the 15th century. Ghana was the first black African country to achieve independence from colonial rule. The country achieved independence from the United Kingdom in 1957. As of 2020, the estimated population of Ghana is 31,072,940. The Republic of Ghana is named after the medieval Ghanaian Empire in West Africa. The original name of this empire was Ouagadouogu. Ghana is the title of the king who rules over the kingdom concerned. The land was ruled by Sundiata in 1240, and was incorporated into the larger Mali Empire. (The Mali Empire reached its peak under Mansa Musa around 1307.) Until March 1957, Ghana was known around the world as the Golden Coast. The Portuguese who arrived in Ghana in the 15th century found a lot of gold between the Ankobra and Volta rivers and named the place Mina, which means "mine". The Gold Coast was then received by the British colonialists. The French, who were interested in the decorative items worn by coastal residents, named the area west of Ghana as Ivory Coast.

Before the year 500, much of central sub-Saharan Africa saw the expansion of agriculture. Agriculture began in the southernmost areas of the Sahara Desert, then villages arose. Towards the end of the classical period, larger regional kingdoms were established in West Africa, one of which was the Ghana Empire located in the north of present-day Ghana. After falling in the early 13th century, the Akan tribe moved south and established several states including the first great Akan empire named Bono which is now known as Brong Ahafo in Ghana. The Akan states that followed such as the Ashanti federation and the Fante states are believed to have emerged from Bono's original territory in Bono Manso. Most of its territory was united under the Ashanti Empire until the 16th century. The Ashanti government began as a loose network and gradually became a centralized government with a developed bureaucracy centered in Kumasi. Geographically, ancient Ghana was located about 500 miles north of present-day Ghana, and occupied the area between the Senegal River and Nigeria. Some of the people of modern Ghana are descended from ancestors associated with medieval Ghana. It can be traced back to the Mande and Volta peoples in Northern Ghana—Mamprussi, Dagomba and Gonja. Anecdotal evidence links the Akan tribe to this empire. The evidence lies in names such as Danso which is dominated by the Akan tribe in present-day Ghana and Mandinka in Senegal/Gambia which are strongly related to this empire. Ghana was also the site of the Ashanti Empire which was perhaps the most advanced black state in sub-Saharan African history. It is said that in his golden age, the King of Ashanti was able to mobilize 500,000 soldiers. In 1481, King João II of Portugal commissioned Diogo d'Azambuja to build the complete Kastel Elmina the following year.

Death is the permanent and irreversible cessation of all biological functions that sustain living things. Brain death is sometimes used as a legal definition of death. The remains of living things that were previously alive usually begin to decompose soon after death. Death is a universal process that is inevitable and will eventually occur in all living things. A similar process that occurs in the building blocks of living things, such as cells or tissues, is called necrosis. Something that is not considered a living organism, such as a virus, can be physically destroyed but cannot be said to be dead. At the start of the 21st century, more than 150,000 people died every day. Many cultures and religions have ideas about life after death. Some religions and beliefs also have the idea of ​​evaluating good and bad deeds in one's life (heaven, hell, karma). The concept underlying death is key to human understanding of the phenomenon. There are many scientific approaches and various interpretations of the concept of death. It is difficult to come up with a single definition of death. Especially with the emergence of life-sustaining therapies and the many different criteria for defining death, from both a medical and a legal perspective. One of the challenges in defining death is distinguishing it from life. As a point in time, death seems to refer to the moment at which life ends. It is difficult to determine when death has occurred, because cessation of life functions often does not occur simultaneously in all organ systems. Therefore, such a definition requires delineating definite conceptual boundaries between life and death. This is difficult, because so far there is little consensus on how to define life. Life can be defined in terms of consciousness. When consciousness ceases, the living organism can be said to have died.

Dhamma comes from the Pali language (Sanskrit: Dharma) which means Law or Order in Buddhism. Dhamma means Absolute Truth, Absolute Truth or Eternal Law. Dhamma exists not only in the human heart and mind, but also in the entire universe. The entire universe is pervaded by it. If the moon rises or sets, rains fall, plants grow, seasons change, this is due to Dhamma. Dhamma is the Eternal Law that pervades the universe, which makes everything move as stated by modern science, such as physics, chemistry, life, astronomy, psychology and so on. Dhamma is the universal truth of all form and formlessness. Meanwhile, the nature of the Dhamma is eternal. It cannot be changed or changed. Thus the Buddha Dhamma is the Dhamma realized and expounded by the Buddha Gotama. Whether or not there is a Buddha, the Eternal Law (Dhamma) will remain throughout the ages. The Buddha said: "O monks, whether Tathagatas appear (in the world) or not, the Dhamma will still exist, it is an eternal law" (Dhammaniyama Sutta). When man is in the Dhamma, he will be able to rid himself of suffering and will attain Nibbana, which is the end of all suffering. Nibbana cannot be attained by praying, performing ceremonies or invoking the Gods. The end of suffering can only be achieved by promoting mental development. Dukkha can also be divided up as follows: The source of suffering is tanhä, that is, craving that has no end. The more he pushed, the harder he gripped. One who surrenders to tanhä is like a person drinking salty water to quench his thirst. The thirst does not go away, it even increases, because the salty water contains salt.

A volcanic eruption is an event that occurs as a result of magma deposition in the bowels of the earth which is pushed out by high pressure gas. This event is associated with the rise of magma from the bowels of the earth. Magma activity that has a very high temperature in the bowels of the earth tries to get out so that cracks and shifts in the earth's crust can occur. Magma that comes out of the belly of a volcano is an erupting volcano or volcanism. Magma is an incandescent liquid that is found in the earth's layers with a very high temperature, which is estimated to be more than 1,000°C. The liquid magma that comes out of the earth is called lava. The temperature of the released lava can reach 700-1,200°C. Volcanic eruptions carrying rocks and ashes can erupt up to a radius of 18 km or more, while the lava can flood up to a radius of 90 km. The types and shapes of volcanoes vary because the degree of viscosity and depth of magma that forms volcanoes is different. Volcanic eruptions occur due to magma deposits in the bowels of the earth which are pushed out by high pressure gas. It is from these eruptions that volcanoes are formed. The results of volcanic eruptions are: volcanic gas, lava and sand flows and hot rock, lava, landslides, earthquakes, eruption ash, hot clouds. The eruptions, which carry ash and rock, can erupt violently up to a radius of 18 km or more, while the lava can flood areas as far as a radius of 90 km. Volcanic eruptions can cause great loss of life and property up to thousands of kilometers away and can even affect the rotation of the climate on this earth. Not all volcanoes erupt frequently. A volcano that frequently erupts is called an active volcano.

The type of volcano refers to its shape: Based on the source of volcanic eruptions it can be classified into : Eruption through the main crater. Eruption of the body slope of the mountain. Eruptions that appear in cracks / faults that can extend up to several kilometers. Lateral eruptions, namely the magma that comes out does not come from the central crater which deviates to the side, but directly from the magma chamber through the crater. Based on the type of volcanic eruption, it can be classified into several types, namely: Explosive eruptions of basaltic magma or basaltic incandescent rock. Usually in the form of incandescent lava flakes and, often, simultaneously, followed by lava flakes, which occur in simple trenches or craters. The eruption is almost the same as the Hawaiian Type but in the form of a superficial magma explosion. Usually occurs in active volcanoes on the edge of the continent or the center of the continent. This eruption is strongly influenced by magma with high viscosity or acidic magma with composition of andesitic magma with rhyolitic properties. The material absorbed is a certain amount of pumice. Explosive volcanic eruptions of magma (rhyolitic). The effusive eruptive stage produces a rhyolitic lava dome. Subplineal eruptions can lead to inflammatory formation. The highly explosive eruptions produced larger deposits of rock than the typical Plinian. The magmatic eruption consists of basaltic andesite within dacite. In general, volcanic bombs or chunks near craters and are often accompanied by bomb crust or surface cracks. The absorbed material does not only come from magma, but is mixed with lateral rock in the form of boulder. Both types are eruptions that occur on volcanic islands, undersea volcanoes or volcanoes with craters. Surtseyan is an eruption of interaction between basaltic magma and surface or ground water.

Amitābha (Sanskrit: अमिताभ, Amitābha, Hindi pronunciation: əmɪtaːbʱə]; Amitābho; Mandarin: 阿彌陀佛, ēMítuó fó; Japanese: 阿弥陀 如 来, amida nyorai; Tibetan language: འོད་ མེད ། ། ö ö ö ö ; Mongolian: Одбагмэд Odbagmed, Аминдаваа Amindavaa, Аюуш Ayush; Javanese: ꦄꦩꦶꦠꦴꦨ) is a celestial Buddha described in the Tripiṭaka scriptures of the Mahāyāna school of Buddhism. Amitābha is the principal buddha in the Pure Land sect which flourished mainly in East Asia. According to this scripture, Amitābha became the Buddha because of his good deeds in countless past lives as a Bodhisattva named Dharmakāra. "Amitābha" can be translated as "Infinite Light", thus Amitabha is often referred to as "The Buddha of Infinite Light". According to the Sutra of Infinite Lives or the Great Sutra of Infinite Lives (Mahāyāna Amitāyus Sūtra), Amitābha was, in a very distant past and possibly in other solar systems, a monk named Dharmakāra. In some versions of the sūtra, Dharmakāra is described as a former king who, after hearing teachings from Buddha Lokesvararaja, renounced his throne. He then resolved to become a Buddha and take possession of a buddhakṣetra ("Buddhist pure land", a realm existing in the primordial universe beyond ordinary Time and Space, resulting from the accumulated merits of the Buddha) where everything is perfect. This resolve is contained in the 48 Vows of Amitabha, describing what kind of Buddhist pure land Dharmakāra aspired to, what conditions were required to be reborn there, and the form of every being reborn there. In the versions of the sutra widely known in China, Vietnam, Korea and Japan, Dharmakāra's 18th Vow is that any being in any universe desiring to be reborn in Amitābha's Pure Land and chanting his name even as little as 10 times will be assured of rebirth there. there.

The 19th Vow promises that, along with other Bodhisattvas and holy beings, will appear before those who chant his name at the moment of death. This openness and acceptance of all human beings without exception made Pure Land School a major influence on Mahāyāna Buddhism. Pure Land Buddhism initially became popular in northwestern India/Pakistan and Afghanistan, then spread to Central Asia and China. The sūtra also explains that Amitābha, after accumulating enormous merit over an innumerable number of lifetimes, finally attained Buddhahood and is still residing in his pure land of Sukhāvatī, which is described as having much goodness and joy. The basic doctrine regarding Amitābha and his vows is found in all three canonical Mahāyāna texts: Through his efforts, Amitābha created the "Pure Land" (净土, pinyin: jìngtŭ; Japanese: jōdo; Vietnamese: tịnh độ) called Sukhāvatī (Sanskrit|Sanskrit) or " Land of Happiness"). Sukhāvatī is located in the far west beyond our solar system. By the power of his vows, Amitābha made it possible for anyone who chanted his name to be reborn into his realm, receiving dharma guidance from him to attain bodhisattvahood and ultimately buddhahood (the ultimate goal of Mahāyāna Buddhism). From there, those Bodhisattvas and Buddhas will return to earth to help more beings. Amitābha is the Buddha of infinite love. He lives in the west (represented in the meditative position) and seeks to enlighten every being (represented in the position of bestowing blessings). The most important technique he taught was visualizing the entire surrounding realm as pure land. Anyone who sees his world as a pure land will awaken his enlightenment energy. The world can be seen as a paradise by a corresponding positive thought enlightenment thought or by sending light to all beings wish all beings to be happy.

Misan or cousin or cousin (brother or sister) is a relative and grandfather. Cousin comes from the word "pupu" which means ancestor. Two siblings who each have children, their children call each other as brother or sister cousin. For cousins ​​who are children of uncles from the father's side (child of father's brother) or children of maternal aunt (child of mother's sister) are called Sejajar Sejajar (Parallel Cousin) while cousins ​​who are children of aunt of the father's side (son of the father's sister) or the child of the mother's uncle (child of the mother's brother) is called Cross Cousin (Cross Cousin). There are types of cousins: 1. Close cousins ​​(cousin) are relatives who are children of our uncles/aunts (siblings of our parents, have the same grandparents) 2. Second cousins ​​are relatives who are children of our parents' cousins ​​(grandchildren of our grandparents' siblings, have the same grandparents). The count is already a distant cousin. 3. Third cousins ​​are relatives who are the grandchildren of our grandparents' cousins ​​(our great-grandfathers and great-grandfathers are siblings). The description of cousins, for example, Adit and Andi are siblings. Adit has a son named Raisa, Andi has a son named Sukma. So, Raisa and Sukma are close cousins ​​(cousin). Raisa has a child named Sandi, Sukma has a child named Bunga. So Passwords and Flowers are second cousins. Sandi has a son named Tari, Bunga has a son named Fahmi. The relationship between Tari and Fahmi is third cousins.

Zen is one of the schools of Mahayana Buddhism. The word Zen is a Japanese origin from the Chinese "Chan" (禪, Pinyin: Chán). The word "Chan" itself comes from the Pali "jhana" or the Sanskrit dhyana ( ध्यान ). In Vietnamese, Zen is known as "thiền" and in Korean, it is known as "seon". Jhana or Dhyāna is a focused state of mind encountered in meditation. Although semantically, the word Chan itself comes from the word 'dhyāna' (Sanskrit) or 'jhana' (Pali) or 'Chan-na' 禪那 (Chinese). Zen does not aim at attaining the jhanas. This simply shows that Zen teachings place great emphasis on the meditation or samadhi aspect. When it came to China from India, Buddhism was originally adapted to Chinese culture and understanding so that it was exposed to the influence of Confucianism and Taoism. Goddard quotes D.T. Suzuki by calling Chán a "natural transformation of Buddhism in a Taoist environment". Judging from the reception by Han Hinayana's work and from early comments, it appears that Buddhism was perceived and assimilated through religious Daoism (Taoism). Buddha was seen as a foreign immortal who had attained some form of Daoist immortal. Buddhists' careful breathing is considered an extension of the Daoist breathing practice. Taoist terminology was used to express Buddhist doctrines in the oldest translations of Buddhist texts, in a practice called ko-i, which means "according to concepts", when the newly emerging Chinese version of Buddhism had to compete with Taoism. and Confucianism. The first Buddhists recruited in China were Taoists. They developed a high appreciation for the newly introduced Buddhist meditation techniques, and combined them with Taoist meditation. Early members of the Chinese version of Buddhism such as Sengzhao and Tao Sheng were heavily influenced by the foundational works of the Taoist faith written by Laozi and Zhuangzi.

Against this background, the concept of the nature of the Tao was inherited by the early disciples of Chán: they paralleled the ineffable nature of the Tao and Buddha to a certain extent. As such, they do not feel attached to the abstract "wisdom of the sutras" or the emphasized Buddha-nature that can be found in "everyday" human life, the same is true of the Tao. Zen school is considered to have originated from Bodhidharma. He is originally from India and is a student of the 28th generation after Mahakassapa (in Pali; Sanskrit: Mahakasyapa). Around 520 he went to South China in the Liang kingdom. He then meditated for 9 years facing a stone wall at the temple in Luoyang. It is also believed that the Shaolin temple (少林寺) was founded here. The original Zen flow was then passed on to the 6th generation of Hui Neng. After that Zen flow spread in China, and Japan. Although the Zen narrative states that it is a "special exposition outside the scriptures" that is not composed of words, Zen does have a rich doctrinal background. The most important thing is that "the most fundamental teaching is that we are enlightened from the start." ", and Bodhisattva idealism, which complements insight with Karunā, compassion for all living beings. It is almost impossible to pinpoint "which Zen teachings are important", given the many different schools of thought, the history conveyed over 1500 years, and what emphasis on understanding reality, as it should be, should be expressed in everyday life, not in words. But common to most schools and teachings is the emphasis on understanding as it is, Bodhisattva idealism, and the priority of zazen. Zen's teachings can be likened to “finger pointing to the moon.” Zen teachings point to the moon, awakening, “realization of the interpenetration of dharmadha That's not happening soon."

The Commonwealth of the Bahamas or the Bahamas is a country consisting of ± 700 islands in the Caribbean region. Florida, United States lies to the west, and Cuba to the south of the Bahamas. Although Paleo-Indians had inhabited this place before, the Taino Indians from Hispaniola and Cuba moved to the southern Bahamas around the 7th century and became the Lucayan people. There were around 40,000 Lucayans at the time of Columbus' arrival. Christopher Columbus' first landfall in the New World was on the island of San Salvador, also called Watling Island, in the southern part of the Bahamas. There, Columbus came into contact with the Lucayans and traded goods with them. The Bahamian Lucayans were brought to Hispaniola as slaves, and in the following 2 decades, many of the Lucayans became extinct, as the population became forced laborers, suffered from disease, emigrated, and married outsiders. After the Lucayan population was decimated, the islands of the Bahamas were virtually uninhabited until English settlers arrived from Bermuda in 1650. So-called Eleuther Adventurers established settlements on the island of Eleuthera. The Bahamas became a British colony in 1718. About 8,000 loyalists and slaves moved to the Bahamas in the late 1700s from New York, Florida and the Carolinas. The United Kingdom made the island self-governing in 1964 and in 1973, the Bahamas gained full independence while remaining a member of the Commonwealth of Nations. Since the 1950s, the Bahamian economy has thrived on the 2 pillars of tourism and financial services. Nonetheless the island still faces significant challenges such as education, healthcare, public services, and illegal immigration. Urban renewal projects have been launched in recent years to assist poor urban areas in social decline on the mainland. Today, the country enjoys the 3rd highest per capita income in the western hemisphere.

Some say the name 'Bahamas' is derived from the Spanish for "shallow sea", baja mar. Others trace it to the Lucayan word for Grand Bahama Island, ba-ha-ma ("big upper midland"). Abaco Island is to the east. The southeasternmost island is Inagua. Other notable islands are Eleuthera, Cat Island, Bahamas, San Salvador, Acklins, Crooked Island, Exuma and Mayaguana. Nassau is the capital and largest city, located on New Providence. The island has a subtropical climate, fed by the Gulf Stream. To the southeast, the Turks and Caicos Islands, and 3 wider underground features called Mouchoir Bank, Silver Bank, and Navidad Bank, are geographically a continuation of the Bahamas, but not part of the Commonwealth of Bahamas. The climate of the Bahamas is subtropical to tropical, and is significantly altered by the waters of the Gulf Stream, especially in winter. On the other hand, it proves dangerous in the summer and fall, as typhoons flow near or through the islands. Hurricane Andrew hit the northern islands in 1992, and Hurricane Floyd hit most of the islands in 1999. Hurricane Frances in 2004 was expected to be the worst for the islands. Also in 2004, the northern Bahamas was hit by the less potent Hurricane Jeanne. In 2005 the northern islands were again hit by Hurricane Wilma. The hurricane destroyed homes, schools, cemeteries and left about 1,000 people homeless. The homeless people lack food, drink and supplies depending on the government. The Bahamas is an independent country and a member of the Commonwealth of Nations. Political and official traditions follow those of Great Britain. The Queen of the United Kingdom is the ceremonial head of state, represented by the governor general of the Bahamas. The PM is the head of government and leader of the party with the most seats in the elected DPR.

The Vinaya (a Pali and Sanskrit word, meaning 'to rule', education', 'rules') is the basic code of conduct of the Buddhist monastic body, or Sangha, based on texts such as the Vinaya Pitaka. The teachings of the Buddha, or "Buddhadhammas" as they are also called, can be divided into two broad categories: 'Dhammas' or beliefs (doctrines), and Vinaya, or rules. Another term for Buddhism is "dhammavinaya". The Patimokkha (in Pali), or Pratimoksha (in Sanskrit) are the sets of rules that form the heart of the Vinaya. The Vinaya was imparted orally by the Buddha to his disciples. Finally, many different Vinayas arose within Buddhism, based on geographic location or cultural differences and the Buddhist schools that developed. Only three of the many Vinaya are in use today. All the Vinaya are of the same nature and meaning and there are only minor differences. In Burma, Cambodia, Laos, Sri Lanka and Thailand following the Theravada Vinaya rules, there are 227 rules for monks and 311 for nuns (although the rules for nuns died out centuries ago and some attempts at restoration of Chinese traditions are still controversial). China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Vietnam follow the Dhammaguptaka Vinaya/Vinaya Mahayana (Hanyu:四分律), which has 250 rules for monks and 348 for nuns. In Tibet and Mongolia follow the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya/Vinaya Tantrayana, which has 253 rules for monks and 364 for nuns (although rules for nuns were never introduced in Tibet, the Dalai Lama recently granted permission). Besides the patimokkha rules, there are many additional rules. The Buddha always reminded his listeners that it is enthusiasm that matters most. However, the rules themselves are made in such a way as to ensure a life full of happiness, and to serve as a stepping stone to the highest attainment.

Geography is the study of relationships, similarities, and differences between spaces on Earth. The center of the study of geography is the relationship between humans and their environment. In general, geography is divided into two branches of science, namely physical geography and human geography. After 1945, geography was more directed to social sciences and prioritized the study of human geography. Geography has important concepts that are used to understand the relationship, form, and function of natural events and social events. Erastothenes was the first to use the term geography. The word geography comes from a combination of words in Greek, namely the words geo and graphein. Geo means earth and graphein means writing or painting, so geography is defined as writing about the earth. In a broader sense, geography is defined as the study of the earth. The earth in question is not only related to its physical form, but includes all natural phenomena and processes that occur along with the symptoms and processes of life. The symptoms and processes of life also discuss the life of the inhabitants of the earth, namely plants, animals and humans. The term geography became known and spread widely among scholars in the 1st century AD. Knowledge of geography has been known since the days of Ancient Greece. At that time, mythology still had a lot of influence on knowledge about the earth. The influence of mythology diminished after natural sciences began to develop from the 6th century BC. The basis of natural sciences and exact sciences began to form knowledge about the earth. The investigation of the earth began to make use of logic. In the pre-Christian era, philosophers and historians became the shapers of views and understanding of geography. Explanations about geography are still historical, while explanations about history are geographical. In addition, writing about making earth maps or paintings is still limited to certain areas.

In pre-Christian times, knowledge of geography was only given to things that could be measured using mathematics. Explanations of space on earth are mostly drawn by travelers. The concept given is based on historical events experienced directly or through direct observation. In addition, the explanation of geography also begins to discuss the symptoms and characteristics of nature and humans as natural inhabitants. The explanation given by travelers is still in character to compare their origin area and other areas which have clear differences. In the late Middle Ages, accounts of geography were still the result of travel reports. This report is divided into land travel reports and sea travel reports. Knowledge of geography is obtained from the travel records of traders who trade between countries and between continents. In addition, knowledge of geography was also obtained through war troops who expanded into other countries or kingdoms. A road record that gives quite a lot of information about geography is the travelogue of Via Appia. This record describes the overland travel route between Rome and Capua in 950 AD. Another record that also provides information about geography is the Silk Road travelogue. This note describes the overland route from China to the Middle East during the Middle Ages. These travel notes were then disseminated to various countries or kingdoms, resulting in various activities aimed at discovering new areas that were not yet known at all. During the renaissance, knowledge of geography experienced rapid development because of the renewal movement in the fields of art and philosophy. The emergence of Protestantism is also the cause of the development of geographical knowledge related to humanism in religion.

Babylon (Greek: Βαβυλωνία, Babylon), full Babylonian Empire or Babylonian State, was an ancient Akkadian-speaking state and cultural region located in central southern Mesopotamia (now Iraq and Syria). In 1894 B.C.E., the Amorites established a small sovereign state that also included the administrative city of Babylon. During the time of the Akkadian Empire (2335–2154 BC), Babylon was just a small city in one of its tributaries. This situation changed during the time of the Old Babylonian Empire. Babylon During Hammurabi's reign, Babylon was enlarged and made the capital. Throughout and after Hammurabi's reign, Babylonia was called "Land of the Akkadians" (Akkadian: Māt Akkadī) in memory of the former glory of the Akkadian Empire. In the Christian Bible and the Hebrew Bible/Tanakh, the two countries of Babylon and the capital city of Babylon are referred to as Babylon, or simply the Land of Babylon. The term "Babylon" (Hebrew: בָּבֶל‎ Bavel, Tib. בָּבֶל Bāḇel; Syriac: Hirjik Bāwēl, Aramaic: בבל Bāḇel; Arabic: بَابِل‎ Bābil) is interpreted in Genesis as "confusion", from the verb bilbél (בלבל, "toss about"). Babylonia was often involved in rivalry with the Assyrian Empire in the north and the Elamite Kingdom in the east. Although it did not last long, Babylon became a major power in the Mesopotamia region after Hammurabi (acting ca. 1792–1752 BC according to the Intermediate Chronology or ca. 1696–1654 BC according to the Short Chronology) a new empire, following in the footsteps of the glorious Akkadian Empire, the New Sumerian Empire , and the Old Assyrian Empire. Not long after Hammurabi died, the Babylonian Empire went into decline and returned to being a small kingdom. Like Assyria, the Babylonian Empire preserved written Akkadian (the language of the native peoples) for official affairs, although the founding kings were Amorites who spoke a Northwest Semitic language and the successor kings were Kasi speakers of one of the isolated language.

The Babylonian Empire also preserved the Sumerian language for religious matters (as well as the Assyrian Empire), although Sumerian was no longer the spoken language at the time the Babylonian Empire was founded, having been completely replaced by Akkadian. The customs of the Akkadians and the Sumerians from ancient times became a major element in Babylonian and Assyrian culture. The Babylonian region remained a major center of culture, even after the Babylonian Empire was colonized by other countries. The oldest written record mentioning the existence of the city of Babylon is a clay tablet from the reign of King Sargon the Great (2334–2279 BC) around the 23rd century BC. At that time Babylon was only a city of religion and culture, not yet a big city, let alone an independent city-state. The city of Babylon was then subject to the Akkadian Empire, a state that united all Akkadian and Sumerian-speaking peoples under one government. After the fall of the Akkadian Empire, southern Mesopotamia was under the control of the Gutians decades before the founding of the New Sumerian Empire, which ruled over all of Mesopotamia (except for the northern region of Assyria), including the city of Babylon. The history of Mesopotamia has been going on for a long time before Babylon was born. The Sumerian civilization emerged in the area around 3500 BC, while Akkadian-speaking societies emerged in the 30th century BC.[citation needed] In the 3rd millennium BC, an intimate cultural symbiosis developed between Sumerian and Akkadian speakers, which includes the expansion of bilingualism. The influence of the Sumerian language on Akkadian and vice versa is evident in all aspects, from the massive absorption of vocabulary, to the combination of syntax, morphology, and phonology. This fact has led scholars to call the Sumerian and Akkadian languages ​​in the 3rd millennium a sprachbund.

Molybdenum is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Mo and atomic number 42. Its name is taken from the Neo-Latin molybdaenum, from the Ancient Greek Μόλυβδος molybdos, meaning lead, because its ore was confused with lead ore. The mineral molybdenum has been known throughout history, but the element was discovered (in the sense of distinguishing it as a new entity from salts of other metallic minerals) in 1778 by Carl Wilhelm Scheele. The metal was first isolated in 1781 by Peter Jacob Hjelm. Molybdenum does not occur naturally as a free metal on Earth; it is only found in various oxidation states in minerals. The free element, a silvery metal with gray stains, has the 6th melting point of all the elements. It readily forms stable and hard carbides in alloying metals, and for this reason, a large part of the element's world production (about 80%) is used in steel alloys, including high-strength alloys and superalloys. Most molybdenum compounds have low solubility in water, but when molybdenum minerals are exposed to oxygen and water, the resulting MoO molybdate ion is moderately soluble. On an industrial scale, molybdenum compounds (about 14% of world production) are used in high pressure and high temperature applications as pigments and catalysts. Molybdenum fixing enzymes are by far the most common bacterial catalysts for breaking chemical bonds in atmospheric nitrogen molecules in the nitrogen fixation process. At least 50 molybdenum enzymes are now known in bacteria and animals, although only bacterial and cyanobacterial enzymes are involved in nitrogen fixation. These nitrogenases contain molybdenum in a form different from the other molybdenum enzymes, which all contain fully oxidized molybdenum in a molybdenum cofactor. These molybdenum cofactor enzymes are essential for organisms, and molybdenum is an essential element for life in all higher eukaryotic organisms, though not in all bacteria.

In its pure form, molybdenum is a silvery-gray metal with a Mohs hardness of 5.5. Mo has a melting point of 2,623°C (4,753°F; 2,896K); Of the natural elements, only tantalum, osmium, rhenium, tungsten and carbon have higher melting points. The weak oxidation of molybdenum begins at 300°C (572°F; 573K). It has one of the lowest coefficients of thermal expansion of the metals used commercially. The tensile strength of molybdenum wire increases about 3 times, from about 10 to 30 GPa, as the diameter decreases from ~50-100 nm to 10 nm. There are 35 known isotopes of molybdenum, with atomic masses ranging from 83 to 117, as well as four metastable nuclear isomers. Seven isotopes occur naturally, with atomic masses of 92, 94, 95, 96, 97, 98, and 100. Of these naturally occurring isotopes, only molybdenum-100 is unstable. Molybdenum-98 is the most abundant isotope, making up 24.14% of all molybdenum. Molybdenum-100 has a half-life of about 1019 years and undergoes a double beta decay to become ruthenium-100. Molybdenum isotopes with mass numbers 111 to 117 all have half-lives of about 150 ns. All the unstable isotopes of molybdenum decay into niobium, technetium, and ruthenium. As also noted below, the most common isotopic molybdenum applications involve molybdenum-99, which is a product of fission. It is the parent radioisotope to the short-lived, gamma-emitting daughter radioisotope technetium-99m, a nuclear isomer used in a variety of imaging applications in medicine. In 2008, Delft University of Technology applied for a patent for the production of molybdenum-99 based on molybdenum-98. Molybdenum is a transition metal with an electronegativity of 2.16 on the Pauling scale and a standard atomic weight of 95.95 g/mol.

The intestine is part of the digestive system that starts from the stomach to the anus. The intestine consists of two parts — the small intestine and the large intestine (colon). The small intestine is further divided into the duodenum, empty intestine, and absorption intestine, while the large intestine is divided into the appendix, large intestine, and rectum. Macroscopically, the divisions of the small intestine are continuous with each other and basically have almost the same histological structure. The small intestine begins in the duodenum and has a tubular structure, usually between 6 and 7 m in length. The mucosal area of ​​an adult human is about 30 m2. Its main function is to absorb the products of digestion (including carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, and vitamins) into the bloodstream. The small intestine has three main parts: The large intestine, also called the colon, consists of the appendix, large intestine, and rectum. It also includes a worm root, which is added to the cecum. The large intestine is further divided into: The main function of the large intestine is to absorb water. The mucosal area of ​​the adult human large intestine is about 2 m2. Some signs of inflammation in the intestine are intestinal villi becoming longer, the intestinal wall thickening, and the amount of lymphatic tissue becoming more numerous. Based on the histopathological picture, in acute inflammation there is edema in the lamina propria accompanied by a mild leukocyte infiltration and dominated by neutrophils. In addition, the space between the villi and crypts becomes wider. In chronic infection, the infiltration of inflammatory cells is dominated by lymphocytes and plasma cells, and the spread of the crypts becomes wider because they contain leukocytes and cell debris. In some cases, there can be acute and chronic inflammation together with tissue death, thrombosis, and mineralization.

Tibet (Tibetan: བོད་, Bod, pronounced pö in the Lhasa dialect; Chinese: 西藏, pinyin: Xizang) is a province of the People's Republic of China, a Special Autonomous Region of China also named China Xizang, located in the Himalayas. which is often said to be the top of the world, is bordered by Nepal, Bhutan and India as well as Xinjiang, Qinghai and Sichuan in China. The majority of the population is Buddhist, with Lhasa as the capital. Years ago, before it was opened by China, Tibet was an area that was said to hold a mystery for adventurers, bearing in mind that at that time not all adventurers could enter the area and it was a closed area, like Mecca in Saudi Arabia which was only entered by Muslims. Tibet used to be an independent kingdom that experienced interactions and clashes, especially politically, with dynasties in mainland China. The King of Tibet is given the title Dalai Lama where the current Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso is the 14th Dalai Lama. The Dalai Lama is the leader of the Tibetan state and at the same time the religious leader of Tibet which became a province of China. After the Chinese Red Army invaded this region in 1950, in the fall of 1951 Chinese troops succeeded in controlling the capital city of Lhasa and removed the Dalai Lama from power. The pretext, the Dalai Lama rejected the cooperation agreement entitled "Tibet Peace Liberation Plan" whose theory seemed to benefit Tibet, but in practice China carried out the suppression and massacre of tribal chiefs and a number of priests (Lamas) who were considered disobedient, another reason China was "abolishing the practice of feudalism-style oppression " in Tibetan. However, according to some international analysts, China is eyeing the mineral deposits contained in the earth of Tibet. On March 17, 1959, the Dalai Lama managed to escape from being captured by the Chinese army in India by a fugitive led by Gampo Tashi, and established a kind of runaway government in Dharamsala, northern India until now.

Pharmacology is a term derived from the Greek words pharmakos which means medicine and logos which means science. So literally, pharmacology can be interpreted as a science that studies drugs and how they work in biological systems. Especially regarding drugs related to the response of the body's parts to the properties of drugs, the effect of their physico-chemical properties on the body, the use of drugs for healing and the fate that drugs experience in the body. This means that pharmacology will examine the effects of chemical compounds on living tissues of living things. In pharmacology, living systems must be influenced by drugs, thus giving rise to the basic principle that drug molecules must be able to chemically affect one or more cell contents in order to produce a pharmacological response. Drug molecules must approach the molecules that make up the cell in sufficient numbers to seal tightly so that the function of the cell's molecules changes. Medicines in ancient times were made from plants, animals and minerals. Records of medicinal use have been made since 2700 BC in the Middle East and China. Drugs that were often used at that time were emetics to induce vomiting. In 1550 BC, Egyptians wrote empirical observations into drug therapy in the Ebers Medical Papyrus. They suggest castor oil as a laxative and an opiate for pain. They also advocated using moldy bread for cuts and bruises (3500 years before Alexander Flemming discovered penicillin) Roman physician and writer Galen (131 201 AD considered to be influential in medicine and pharmacy for hundreds of years. They started the general use of recipes and using several mixtures to treat certain diseases.Pharmacology of the ancient period began before 1700, marked by empirical observations made by humans on the use of drugs.

Copper is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Cu and atomic number 29. Its symbol comes from the Latin Cuprum. Copper is a good conductor of heat and electricity. In addition, this element has a very fast corrosion. Pure copper is smooth and malleable, with a reddish-orange surface. Copper is mixed with tin to make bronze. Copper(II) ions can leach into water, where they function at high concentrations as anti-bacterial agents, fungicides, and wood additives. In high concentrations, copper will be toxic, but in small amounts copper is an essential nutrient for human life and lower plant life. In the body, copper is usually found in the liver, brain, intestines, heart, and kidneys. Copper is one of the most important metals and played a major role in human history and was one of the first metals to be mined. Copper has been used since 10,000 years ago. A copper necklace found in Iraq is thought to have been made in 9500 BC. Copper (Cuprum) derives its name from the Latin, Cyprium, which derives from the name of the island of Cyprus where it was first produced. Cyprium was later shortened to Cuprum. Copper played a major role in human civilization, especially during the Bronze Age (3000-1000 BC). At that time copper was combined with tin to make bronze. Bronze is then processed into various tools, weapons, coins, musical instruments and jewelry. Copper, silver, and gold are in group 11 elements on the periodic table and share the same properties: they have one electron in the s-orbital in the d shell with good electrical conductivity. Copper's malleability can be explained by its high electrical conductivity (59.6×106 S/m) and therefore also its high (second highest) thermal conductivity of all pure metals at room temperature.

Along with cesium and gold (both yellow) and osmium (a bluish color), copper is one of four metals with a natural color other than gray or silver. Pure copper is red-orange and turns reddish on contact with air. Copper does not react with water, but it reacts slowly with oxygen from the air to form a brown-black layer of copper oxide. In contrast to the oxidation of iron by air, this oxide layer then stops corrosion from continuing. Green verdigris (copper carbonate) coating can be seen on old copper constructions, such as on the Statue of Liberty. Copper reacts with sulfide to form copper sulfide. Copper has 29 isotopes. 63Cu and 65Cu are stable isotopes, with the highest percentage of 63Cu in nature, about 69%. Both of these isotopes have a spin number of 3/2. The other isotopes are radioactive, with the most stable being 67Cu with a half-life of 61.83 hours. Seven metastable isotopes have been identified, 68mCu being the isotope with the longest half-life, 3.8 minutes. Isotopes with mass numbers above 64 decay with β-, while those with mass numbers below 64 decay with β+. 64Cu (half-life 12.7 hours), decays in both ways. 62Cu and 64Cu have many uses. 64Cu is a radiocontrast agent for X-ray images, along with chelates it can be used for radiation therapy for cancer. 62Cu is used in 62Cu-PTSM which is a radioactive tracer for positron emission tomography. Copper is synthesized in massive stars and present in the Earth's crust at a concentration of 50 parts per million (ppm), or it can be in native copper form or minerals in the form of copper sulphide chalcopyrite and chalcocite, copper carbonate azurite and malachite and the minerals copper(I) oxide cupprit. . The purest copper mass ever discovered, weighing 420 tons, was discovered in 1857 on the Keweenaw Peninsula in Michigan, USA.

Dialectic (Dialectics) comes from the word dialogue which means two-way communication, this term has existed since ancient Greece when the understanding that everything changed (panta rei) was introduced. Then Hegel perfected the concept of dialectics and simplified it by interpreting dialectics into the trilogy of thesis, anti-thesis and synthesis. According to Hegel there is no one absolute truth because dialectical law applies, the only thing absolute is the revolutionary spirit (the change/opposition of the thesis by the anti-thesis to become a synthesis). "Dialectic" is a term used to describe a method of philosophical argument that involves some kind of conflicting process between opposing parties. In what is possibly the most classical version of "dialectics", the ancient Greek philosopher, Plato, for example, he introduces his philosophical argument as a two-way or back-and-forth dialogue or debate, generally between the character Socrates, on the one hand, and some person or group of people to whom Socrates is speaking (his interlocutor), on the other hand. In a series of dialogues, Socrates' interlocutors propose definitions of philosophical concepts or express views that Socrates questions or opposes. The back-and-forth debate between opposing parties results in a kind of linear development or evolution in philosophical views or positions: During the dialogue, Socrates' interlocutors change or correct their views in response to Socrates' challenges and come to adopt more advanced views. The dialectic back and forth between Socrates and his interlocutors thus becomes Plato's way of arguing against earlier, less advanced views or positions and for more advanced ones later. "Hegel's dialectic" refers to a particular method of dialectical argument used by the 19th-century German philosopher, G.W.F. Hegel, which, like other "dialectical" methods, relies on processes of conflict between opposing parties. Whereas on the "opposites" according to Plato it depends on the person like (Socrates and his interlocutors), However, what is in the "opposites" in Hegel's work depends on the subject matter he is discussing.

Electronegativity or electronegativity (Symbol: χ) is a chemical property that describes the ability of an atom (or less commonly a functional group) to attract electrons (or electron density) towards itself in a covalent bond. The concept of electronegativity was first introduced by Linus Pauling in 1932 as part of the development of valence bond theory. Electronegativity cannot be calculated directly, but must be calculated from the properties of other atoms and molecules. Several calculation methods have been proposed. Although within each method there is a slight difference in the numerical value of the electronegativity, all methods share the same period trend among elements. Electronegativity is one of the periodicity properties of elements, in addition to electron affinity, atomic radius, and ionization energy. The method that is generally used is the Pauling method. The results of this calculation produce a dimensionless value and are usually referred to as the Pauling scale with a relative scale ranging from 0.7 to 4.0 (hydrogen = 2.2). When other methods of calculation are used, there is a convention (although not required) to use the same scale range as the Pauling scale: this is known as electronegativity in Pauling units. Electronegativity is not a property of atoms, it is only a property of atoms in molecules. The property of a single atom that is equivalent to electronegativity is electron affinity. The electronegativity of an element will vary depending on the chemical environment, but is usually considered a transferable property, that is, a value of electronegativity is assumed to hold true in a variety of situations. Pauling first proposed the concept of electronegativity in 1932 as a description of the phenomenon that the covalent bond between two different atoms (A–B) is stronger than would be expected by taking the average strength of the A–A and B–B bonds. According to valence bond theory, this "additional stabilization" of the heteronuclear bond is due to the contribution of the canonical form of the ion to the bond.

The difference in electronegativity between the two atoms A and B can be calculated by: with the dissociation energies (Ed) of the A–B, A–A and B–B bonds expressed in electronvolts. The factor (eV)−½ is inserted to produce a dimensionless value. With this method, the electronegativity difference between hydrogen and bromine is 0.73 (dissociation energies: H–Br 3.79 eV; H–H 4.52 eV; Br–Br 2.00 eV) Therefore only the electronegativity difference can be calculated , we need to choose a reference point to build the scale. Hydrogen is used as a reference because it forms covalent bonds with almost all elements. Its electronegativity value was first determined as 2.1, but later revised to 2.20. In addition, we also need to decide which element (of the two elements) has the greater electronegativity. This breaking can be done using "chemical intuition", for example in hydrogen bromide dissolving in water to form H+ and Br−, we can assume that bromine is more electronegative than hydrogen. To calculate the Pauling electronegativity of an element, we need data on the dissociation energies of at least two types of covalent bonds formed by that element. Allred updated Pauling's electronegativity values ​​in 1961 to incorporate thermodynamic data. It is these revised Pauling electronegativity values ​​that are often used. Mulliken proposed that the arithmetic mean of the first ionization energy and electron affinity must be a measure of the tendency of an atom to attract electrons. Because this definition is independent of any relative scale, it is also referred to as relative electronegativity, with units of kilojoules per mole or electronvolts. But usually we use a linear transformation to transform the absolute value into a value that is more similar to the Pauling value. For ionization energies and electron affinities in electronvolts, and for energies in kilojoules per mol,n 1] Mulliken's electronegativity can only be calculated for elements whose electron affinities are known.

Magnesium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Mg and atomic number 12. It is a shiny gray solid that bears a physical resemblance to the other five elements in the second column (group 2, or alkaline earth metals) of the periodic table: all group elements 2 has the same electron configuration in the outer electron shell and a similar crystal structure. Magnesium is the ninth most abundant element in the universe, usually accumulating in igneous rocks. Magnesium is produced in the aging of massive stars from the sequential addition of three helium nuclei to carbon nuclei. When such a star explodes as a supernova, most of the magnesium is ejected into the interstellar medium where it can be recycled into new star systems. Magnesium is the eighth most abundant element in the Earth's crust and the fourth most common element on Earth (after iron, oxygen and silicon), making up 13% of the planet's mass and most of the planet's mantle. Magnesium is the third most abundant element dissolved in seawater, after sodium and chlorine. Magnesium occurs naturally only in combination with other elements, and it always has an oxidation state of +2. The free elements (metals) can be produced artificially, and are highly reactive (even in the atmosphere, they are immediately coated with a thin layer of oxide which partially inhibits their reactivity — see passivation). The free metal burns with a characteristic brilliant white light. The metal is now obtained primarily by electrolysis of magnesium salts obtained from brine, and is used primarily as a component of aluminum-magnesium alloys, sometimes called magnalium or magnelium. Magnesium is less dense than aluminum, and its alloy is prized for its combination of light weight and strength. Magnesium is the eleventh most abundant element, by mass, in the human body and is essential for all cells and for about 300 enzymes.

Magnesium ions interact with polyphosphate compounds such as ATP, DNA and RNA. Hundreds of enzymes require magnesium ions to function. Magnesium compounds are used medicinally as a general laxative, an antacid (eg, milk of magnesia), and to stabilize abnormal nerve excitation or vascular spasm in conditions such as eclampsia. Elemental magnesium is a gray-white light metal, with a density two-thirds that of aluminum. It dulls slightly on exposure to air, although, unlike other alkaline earth metals, it does not need to be stored in an oxygen-free environment because magnesium is protected by a thin layer of oxide which is quite impermeable and difficult to remove. Magnesium has the lowest melting point (923 K (650 °C)) and lowest boiling point (1.363 K (1.994 °F)) of all the alkaline earth metals. Magnesium reacts with water at room temperature, although it reacts much more slowly than calcium, a similar group 2 metal. When submerged in water, hydrogen bubbles form slowly on the surface of the metal—although in powder form it reacts more quickly. The reaction occurs more rapidly at higher temperatures (see Safety precautions). The reversible reaction of magnesium with water can be utilized to store energy and run magnesium-based machines. Magnesium also reacts exothermically with most acids such as hydrochloric acid (HCl), producing metal chloride and hydrogen gas, similar to the reaction of HCl with aluminum, zinc, and many other metals. Magnesium is highly flammable, especially when powdered or sliced ​​into thin strips, although it is difficult to ignite in bulk or bulk form. The flame temperature of magnesium and its alloys can reach 3,100°C (5,610°F), although the height of the flame above the burning metal is usually less than 300 mm (12 in).

Qatar, officially the State of Qatar (Arabic: دولة قطر‎, Daulah Qatar), is an emirate in the Middle East located on a small peninsula on the Arabian Peninsula in Western Asia. Its only land boundary is Saudi Arabia to the south and the rest is bordered by the Persian Gulf. This bay is also what separates Qatar from the island nation of Bahrain. After being under Ottoman rule, Qatar became a British protectorate in the early 20th century until independence in 1971. Qatar has been ruled by the Thani Family since the early 19th century. Sheikh Jassim bin Mohammed Al Thani is the founder of Qatar. Qatar is a monarchy and its current head of state is Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani. Qatar can be called a constitutional monarchy or an absolute monarchy depending on opinion. In 2003, the new constitution was approved by 98% of the population. At the start of 2017, Qatar's total population reached 2.6 million: 313,000 Qatari nationals and 2.3 million expatriates. Qatar is a country with high economic income, supported by natural gas and oil reserves which are the third largest in the world. This country is one of the countries with the highest per capita income in the world. Qatar is classified as a country that has a very high human development index and is the best among other Arab countries. Qatar has considerable influence in the Arabian Peninsula, supporting several rebel groups during the Arab Spring both financially and through their global media group Al Jazeera Media Network. For its size, Qatar holds significant influence in the world. Qatar will host the 2022 FIFA World Cup, becoming the first Arab country to do so. In 2017, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates and Egypt cut diplomatic ties with Qatar and labeled it a terrorist state, causing the 2017 Qatar diplomatic crisis.

After the domination of the British and the Ottoman Empire in Qatar, Qatar finally became an independent country on September 3, 1971. In the past, Britain controlled Qatar as a transit point for merchant ships before heading to India. Qatar then acquired status as dependent on Britain, then British protectorate status which was discontinued in 1916. After the Second World War, Qatar tried to gain its independence, especially after India achieved its independence in the 1950s. Qatar intensified after the British gave independence to Kuwait in 1961. The British government said it would stop political control but continue to control the economy in Qatar. This was not allowed by Qatar to form the Arab Gulf Federation together with Bahrain. The plains of Qatar are only 160 km and smaller than the US state of Connecticut. The Qatar plain consists of desert. The highest point in Qatar is at Jabal Dukhan. This area contains enormous amounts of natural gas. Qatar can be considered as a constitutional monarchy as well as an absolute monarchy headed by the Al Thani family. The Al Thani dynasty has ruled Qatar since 1825. In 2003, Qatar adopted a constitution that directly elected 30 of the 45 members of the Legislative Council. This constitution was approved unanimously in a referendum with a rate of 98%. The eighth Emir of Qatar is Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani, his father Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani who handed power to him 25 June 2013. The supreme chancellor has exclusive powers to select and remove the prime minister and cabinet ministers who all form the Council of Ministers. The Council of Ministers is the highest executive authority in the country. The Council of Ministers also initiates legislation. Laws and decrees proposed by the Council of Ministers will be referred to the Advisory Council (Majilis Al Shura) for discussion and then given to the Emir for ratification.

Ur (Sumerian: Urim; Sumerogram: 𒌶𒆠 URI5KI, 𒋀𒀕𒆠 URIM2KI or 𒋀𒀊𒆠 URIM5KI; Akkadian: 𒋀𒀕𒆠, translit. Uru; Arabic: أُوْر, translit. ʾūr‎; Hebrew: ‎‎‎ אוּר, transliterated site. ancient that was once an important city-state of the Sumerians located in the region of ancient Mesopotamia. The modern location of the site is "Tel al-Muqayyar" (Arabic: تل ٱلْمُقَيَّر‎) in Dhi Qar Governorate in southern Iraq. The city of Ur is thought to be the same as the Chaldean city of Ur, which is mentioned in the Hebrew Bible and the Old Testament of the Christian Bible, and is the place of origin of Terah, Abraham's father, from where Abraham later departed for the land of Canaan at God's command. This place is also thought to have been the center of the worship of the moon god, Sin. The city has two harbors connected to the Persian Gulf by the Euphrates river, so the city has a high culture and a prosperous history. Ur became rich thanks to his trade with foreign countries. Since about 4300 BC, the city of Ur has been inhabited by people. In the following time (until about 3400) parts of the city were damaged by a prolonged deluge ("the deluge"). The king list of ancient Babylon lists three ruling dynasties. The third dynasty (c. 2047-1939) is among the most important: Ur takes over the political leadership in southern Mesopotamia (with the head of the central government, the peak of the development of Sumerian literature, the buildings of worship). The immigration of the Amorites and the devastating attacks by the Elamites rendered Ur worthless. Ur is thought to be the same as the Chaldean city of Ur which is the birthplace of the forefather of Judaism, Islam and Christianity, namely Abraham or Abraham. Ur is mentioned 4 times in the Hebrew Bible, with the additional caption "Chaldeans", referring to the Chaldeans who were in it.

Swami Vivekananda (Bengali: স্বামী বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ বিবেকানন্দ West. He is the brother of Shri Bhupendranath Dutt, a revolutionary in India. Vivekananda is a person who is well known to the world as a spiritual leader who has great influence from the teachings of Vedanta and Yoga. He was the first Hindu Swami to come to the West, to introduce Hinduism, Yoga and Vedanta to the World's Parliament of Religions, in connection with the holding of the World's Fair in Chicago in 1893. Here his name began to soar and became widely known throughout Chicago, followed later throughout America . He was the leader of the students who studied at the Ramakrishna Paramahamsa and also the founder of the Ramakrishna Mission Turban which was worn by Vivekananda believed to be on the advice of Maharaja Khetri. However, some historians and researchers are of the view that Vivekananda visited Swamithope Pathi during his visit to Kanyakumari in December 1892 and believes that he was impressed by the principle behind the religious rituals of the monistic faith, in which monists wear a kind of headband during worship at the temples, in in front of mirrors etc., and Vivekananda started wearing the turban from that time on. Some people think that Vivekananda received spiritual enlightenment from Ayya Vaikundar. But all this is never listed in his works or biography. It is also said that when he was a child he was impressed by the turban worn by the train driver, who carried his father to work every day. Later after he announced to the world and took the path of a sanyasin, he started wearing a turban for himself.

Christianitynote 1] is a monotheistic Abrahamic religion based on the life history and teachings of Jesus Christ, which is the essence of this religion. Christianity is the largest religion in the world, with more than 2.5 billion adherents, or around 2.6 billion people or nearly a third of the world's population, who are called "Christians". note 2] Christians believe that Jesus is the Son of God and The Savior of mankind who came as the Messiah as prophesied in the Old Testament Bible. Christian theology is embodied in confessions such as the Confessions of the Apostles and the Confessions of Nicea. These confessions of faith contain statements that Jesus suffered, died, was buried, descended to hell, and rose from the dead, to give eternal life to anyone who believes in him and relies on him to obtain forgiveness for the sins they have committed. These confessions also state that Jesus physically ascended into heaven, where he reigns with God the Father in the fellowship of the Holy Spirit, and that he will return one day to judge the living and the dead, and grant eternal life to his followers. . His incarnation, ministry, crucifixion, and resurrection are often called "gospels", which means "good news". , and the Gospel of John—considered canonical (valid) and made part of the Christian Bible. Christianity is an Abrahamic religion that began as a sect of Second Temple-era Judaism in the middle of the first century of our Common Era. This sect originated in Judea, then spread rapidly to Europe, Syria, Mesopotamia, Anatolia, Transcaucasia, Egypt, Ethiopia and India, and by the end of the 4th century had become the official religion of the Roman Empire.

After the Age of Discovery, Christianity also spread to the Americas, Australasia, Sub-Saharan Africa, and to all corners of the world through missionary work and colonialism. Christianity has played a major role in the formation of Western World Civilization. Throughout its history, Christianity has experienced schisms and theological disputes that have given rise to various churches and denominations. The three largest branches of Christianity in the world are the Catholic Church, the Eastern Orthodox Church, and the major Protestant Christian denominations. The Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church broke off from each other in the East–West Schism in 1054, while Protestant Christians emerged during the 16th century reformation as a breakaway from the Catholic Church. Early Christians who were Jewish by nationality called themselves followers of the way (Greek: τῆς ὁδοῦ, tês hodoû), possibly referring to the passage of Isaiah 40:3, "prepare in the desert the way for the Lord." note 4] Based on the text of the Acts of the Apostles 11:26, the term "Christians" (Greek: Χρῑστῐᾱνός, Krīstiānós) means "followers of Christ", referring to Jesus' disciples, and was first used in the city of Antioch by non-Jews. The term "Christianity" (Greek: Χρῑστῐᾱνισμός, Krīstiānismós) was first used by Ignatius of Antioch in his letters written around 100 AD. There are many different interpretations and views regarding the Bible and the Sacred Traditions which are the foundation of Christianity. Irreconcilable theological differences, as well as a lack of agreement on the main points of the Christian faith, have caused Catholic, Orthodox and Protestant Christians to often not recognize people from certain Christian denominations as fellow Christians. The summary of the doctrinal declarations or expressions of Christian religious beliefs is called the shahada (from the Arabic: الشهادة‎‎, asy-syahadah, which means "testimony") or the credo (from the Latin credo, which means "I believe"); Protestant Christians in Indonesia usually use the term "confession of faith" (a translation of the typical Protestant term in Latin, confessio fidei).

Temperature shows the degree or size of the heat of an object. Simply put, the higher the temperature of an object, the hotter it is. Microscopically, temperature shows the energy possessed by an object. Every atom in an object moves, both in the form of displacement and movement in place, vibration. The higher the energy of the atoms making up the object, the higher the temperature of the object requires reference]. Temperature is also called the temperature measured by a thermometer. The four best known types of thermometers are Celsius, Reaumur, Fahrenheit and Kelvin. The comparison between one type of thermometer and another follows: Because from Kelvin to degrees Celsius, Kelvin starts at 273 degrees, not from -273 degrees. And degrees Celsius start from 0 degrees. The Kelvin temperature is the same as degrees Celsius, which is 5:5, therefore, to change that temperature to another temperature, you should use or change it to degrees Celsius first, because if we use Kelvin it will it is more complicated to change it to another temperature. Example: For example: Qualitatively, we can know that temperature is the sensation of coldness or warmth of an object that is felt when touching it. Quantitatively, we can know it by using a thermometer. Temperature can be measured by using a thermometer which contains mercury or alcohol. The word thermometer is taken from two words, namely thermo which means heat and meter which means to measure (to measure). Several types of thermometers include: Thermometers that are usually used as follows: Infrared thermometer, detects the temperature optically as long as the object is observed, infrared radiation energy is measured, and presented as temperature, by knowing the amount of infrared energy emitted by the object and its emission, object temperature can be distinguished. There are two types used in processing, namely thermocouple and resistance thermometer.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union  (light blue) The Union of Comoros (Arabic: الاتحاد القمري) until 2002 was named the Federal Islamic Republic of the Comoros (Arabic: جمهورية القمر الإتحادية الإسلامية) is an island nation in the Indian Ocean .Comoros is the second smallest Arab country after Bahrain. The Comoros shares maritime borders with Madagascar and Mayotte to the southeast, Tanzania to the northwest, Mozambique to the west and the Seychelles to the northeast. Its capital and largest city is Moroni. The religion of the majority of the population as well as the official state religion is Sunni Islam. As a member of the Arab League, Comoros is the only country in the Arab world that is located entirely in the Southern Hemisphere. The country is also a member state of the African Union, Organization internationale de la Francophonie (International Organization of French-Speaking Countries), Organization of Islamic Cooperation, and the Indian Ocean Commission. Comoros has three official languages: Comoros, French and Arabic. The name Comoros is taken from the Arabic word qamar (قمر) which means "moon". The Comoros is located at the northern end of the Mozambique Channel, between Madagascar and Mozambique. Officially the country of Comoros consists of four islands in the volcanic Comoros archipelago, namely: Mayotte, Greater Comoros, Anjouan and Moheli, as well as many smaller islands. The capital city is Moroni which is located on the island of the Greater Comoros. The entire Comoros archipelago was a French colony until 1975 when a referendum for independence organized by France in 1974 was announced. The results of the referendum showed that three of the four main Comoros islands: Greater Comoros, Anjouan and Moheli voted for independence and formed the Union of Comoros. Mayotte or Maori Island is the only island in the Comoran archipelago that voted against independence from France to become part of the Comoros Alliance; the 1974 and 1976 referendums consistently showed that the people of the Mayotte archipelago preferred to remain a French colony rather than join the Comoros.

This difference of opinion is more towards the political and economic side because the Mayotte people have the same culture as the other Comoros and the majority also adhere to the same religion, namely Islam. Even so, the Comoros government still claims Mayotte as part of the Comoros and denounces the presence of the French government there. The United Nations has determined that Mayotte is part of the Comoros, but France has vetoed a UN Security Council resolution that would have affirmed Comoros sovereignty over the island.
