In addition, on March 29, 2009 the citizens of Mayotte approved a referendum passed in 2011 to change Mayotte's status as an overseas department of France and part of the European Union. The President of the Comoros himself rejected the results of this referendum. The first inhabitants to occupy the Comoros Islands are thought to have been residents, fishermen, and traders from Africa and Austronesia, who traveled by boat. They came to the Comoros around the sixth century AD, the earliest recorded history in the form of known archaeological traces found in Anjouan. So that the Comoros is occupied by residents from various regions on the coast of Africa, the Persian Gulf, Indonesia and Madagascar. In the 10th century, the first Arab traders had brought Islamic influence to the islands of the Comoros. One of the most powerful facts is the sale and purchase of slaves from Africa, and increased the spread and dominance of Arab culture throughout the world. Arab settlers lived with a population of Indonesian-Malaysian origin, as well as indigenous people who spoke Bantu, Swahili and languages ​​of East Africa. Despite its great distance from the coast of Africa, the Comoros lies along the main strait between Africa and Mozambique. The Comoros Islands, like other coastal areas in the region, were important transit areas on trade routes during the early days of the spread of Islam.

Vulva or puki or pharynx is the external genitalia of female mammals. This article deals with the human genitalia, although their structure is similar for other mammals. The vulva (Latin: covering, covering) consists of the external female sex organs. The parts of the vulva include the mons pubis, labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, bulb of vestibule (vestibulum bulge), vulvar vestibule, urinary meatus, Bartholin's glands (which are larger) and Skene's glands (lesser vestibular glands), and vaginal opening. The urinary meatus (opening of the urethra) is also visible as it opens to the vulvar vestibule. Other features of the vulva include: pudendal fissures, sebaceous glands, urogenital triangle (anterior part of the perineum), and pubic hair. The vulva is the entrance to the vagina that leads to the uterus, and provides the vagina with multiple layers of double protection by folds of the outer and inner labia. The vulva can be affected by many disorders which can often cause irritation. Maintaining Vulvovaginal Health is one of the measures to prevent many diseases. The main structures of the vulva are: the mons pubis, labia (major and minor) including the frenulum labia minor, the outside of the clitoris - the clitoral hood (also known as the prepuce) and clitoral sheaths, the urinary meatus, the vaginal opening and hymen, and the Bartholin's and Skene's glands. Other parts include: the pudendal fissure, the sebaceous glands, the vulvar vestibule, and the urogenital triangle (anterior part of the perineum). The mons pubis is a soft mound of fatty tissue at the front of the vulva, in the pubic area that covers the pubic bone. Mons pubis is Latin for "pubic mound" and is present in both sexes. Sometimes the term variant is used specifically for women—namely mons veneris' ("the mound of Venus"). Below, the mons pubis is divided by the pudendal fissure, which separates the mons pubis from the labia majora.

The pudendal fissure is also known as the Venus (Roman goddess of love) fissure. The labia majora and labia minora protect the vulvar vestibule. The clitoral hood and labia minora protrude into the pudendal cleft to a lesser or greater degree. The outer portion of the folds are the labia majora (New Latin: greater lips) which are divided by the pudendal fissures, containing and protecting the other, more delicate structures of the vulva. The labia majora meet again at the urogenital triangle (anterior part of the perineum) between the pudendal slit and the anus. The outer skin color of the labia majora usually approximates the overall skin tone of an individual, although considerable variation exists. The inner skin and mucous membranes are often pink or brownish in color. The labia minora (lesser lips) are the two soft folds of the labia within the labia majora, and contain many sebaceous glands. The labia majora and labia minora meet at the frenulum of the labia minora which is a fold of restrictive tissue at the posterior end of the vulva. Despite being called small lips they can often be quite large and may protrude beyond the labia majora. Most of the variation between vulvas lies in significant differences in size, shape, and color of the labia minora. This variation has also been demonstrated in a large 400-printed view of the vulva called the 'Great Wall of Vagina' which was created to fill the lack of information about the normal shape of the vulva. The cast prints taken from the many and varied groups of women show clearly that there is a great deal of variation. The clitoris is located in front of the vulva, where the labia minora meet, at the clitoral frenulum. The visible part of the clitoris is the clitoral sheath. Typically, the clitoral sheath or head is roughly the size and shape of a pea, although it can be significantly larger or smaller.

Eritrea (Ge'ez ኤርትራ ʾĒrtrā) is a country located in northeastern Africa. Eritrea is bordered by Sudan to the west, Ethiopia to the south, and Djibouti to the southeast. The Red Sea to the east of Eritrea separates the country from the Middle East. The eastern and northeastern parts of the country have a long seafront that faces the Red Sea, directly opposite Saudi Arabia and Yemen. The Dahlak Archipelago and many of the islands of the Hanish Archipelago form part of Eritrea. Its name comes from the Latin word for the Red Sea, Mare Erythraeum, which comes from the Greek word meaning "red" (ερυθρός, erythros). Eritrea was incorporated into a colony by the Kingdom of Italy on 1 January 1890. The modern nation state of Eritrea achieved independence from Ethiopia on 24 May 1993 after 30 years of war from 1961 to 1991. Eritrea is officially a parliamentary democracy consisting of six regions, but now functioned as a one-party state. Eritrea is a multilingual and cultural country with two main religions and nine ethnic groups, each of them speaking a different language. The country has no official language, but uses three working languages, namely Tigrinya, Arabic and English. A fourth language, namely Italian, is also sometimes spoken for commerce. Eritrea is located on the Horn of Africa in East Africa. It is bordered northeast and east by the Red Sea, Sudan to the west, Ethiopia to the south, and Djibouti to the southeast. Eritrea lies between latitudes 12° and 18° N, and longitudes 36° and 44° E. The country is nearly bisected two by the East African Rift branch.

Eritrea, at the southern tip of the Red Sea, is home to the fork. The Dahlak Islands and their fishing grounds lie off a sandy, arid coast. Eritrea's Dahlak Archipelago can be divided into three ecoregions. To the east of the plateau are the hot, arid coastal plains that extend to the southeast of the country. The cooler and more fertile highlands, reaching up to 3000 m, have different habitats. The habitats here vary from the sub-tropical rain forests of Filfil Solomona to the sheer cliffs and canyons of the southern highlands. The Afar Triangle or Danakil Depression of Eritrea is a possible location of a triple junction where three tectonic plates move away from each other. The country's highest point, Emba Soira, is located in central Eritrea, at 3,018 meters (9,902 feet) above sea level. The main cities of the country are the capital Asmara and the port city of Asseb in the southeast, as well as the cities of Massawa in the east, the city of Keren in the north and the central city of Mendefera. Eritrea is part of a 14-country constituency within the Global Environment Facility, which partners with international agencies, civil society organizations and the private sector to address global environmental issues while supporting national sustainable development initiatives. Local variations in rainfall patterns and/or reduced rainfall are known to occur, which can lead to soil erosion, flooding, drought, land degradation and desertification. In 2006, Eritrea also announced that it would be the first country in the world to turn an entire coast into an environmentally protected zone. The 1,347 km (837 mi) coastline, along with another 1,946 km (1,209 mi) of beach around more than 350 islands, will come under government protection.

Usability, use value or utility in the economic field is the value of satisfaction or benefits that a consumer receives from a good or service that he consumes. If the level of satisfaction is higher, then the efficiency of an item for the service will also be higher. Efficiency can be divided into two types, namely total usability and marginal usability. Total utility is the amount of utility obtained by consumers in consuming an item or service, while marginal efficiency is the additional utility obtained by consumers due to additional consumption of a good or service. In economic analysis, usability is often used to describe the order of preference for a group of goods, for example a consumer named Bambang feels more satisfied buying 3 books than buying one shirt, this means that the books provide greater usability than clothes. just now. The usability function can be represented by a set of indifference curves, each of which has a numerical indicator. Efficiency can be divided into several types, namely as follows: Time efficiency is when an item or service is provided at the most appropriate time or the time consumers most desire. Companies can maximize the time efficiency of an item or service by adjusting the performance of the production, logistics and delivery processes. For example, renting an umbrella when it rains. Place utility focuses on providing goods or services so that potential consumers can easily access them. For example, sand in a river will have a useful effect when it is sent to a city for development purposes. The usability of form refers to how well the product or service succeeds in satisfying consumers. For example, a company researches what features buyers want, so the company then adds these features to its products.

A supernova (plural Supernovae) is an extremely energetic explosion of a large, massive star at a certain point in its life cycle, caused by a gravitational core collapse which can emit more energy than a nova and can last for several months in brightness. This usually occurs when its fusion nuclei cannot withstand the core from its own gravity and eventually the core collapses and explodes. This supernova event marks the end of a star's history. Supernovas are temporary objects. A star that experiences a supernova will appear very bright and even its brilliance can reach a billion times the star's original light (which can surpass the entire galaxy), after a few weeks it finally dims, and disappears. For this reason, these objects are difficult to observe and study, astronomers have now made supernova searches dedicated to finding new supernovae and obtaining fast and extensive observations. A few weeks or months before a star goes supernova, the star will release energy equivalent to the solar energy that is released by the sun in its lifetime, this explosion collapses most of the star's material at speeds of 10,000 - 30,000 km/s (some up to 10% light years) and releasing a shockwave capable of annihilating the interstellar medium. This sweeps away a floating shell of gas and dust, known as a supernova remnant. Supernovas can briefly outperform entire galaxies and emit more energy than our Sun in its lifetime. Astronomers divide supernovae into 2 main types, Type I and II depending on the light curve and the nature of the spectrum, either stopping or activating the production of energy through nuclear fusion. A type I supernova can most likely form as a white dwarf that steals hot gas from its companion star.

If enough gas accumulates on the surface of the white dwarf, a runaway thermonuclear explosion will pulverize the star, leaving nothing behind. It is the brightest supernova, and can measure distances to other galaxies. A type II supernova is the final stage in the evolution of an old massive star that is at least 8 times as massive as the Sun when it collapses. Such a star reaches a point where it can no longer generate nuclear energy in its core. Without the external pressure that this energy creates, gravity wins out and causes the star's core to collapse. The difference between the two is that a type I supernova does not have a hydrogen line in its spectrum, while a type II supernova does have one. After the core of an old star stops producing energy, it undergoes a sudden gravitational collapse and leaves behind a supernova remnant. A medium-sized star (between two and the mass of the sun) becomes a very dense neutron star, and if enough mass remains so large (more than five times the mass of the sun) that gravity collapses the core into a black hole, releasing gravitational potential energy that heats and destroys the star's outer layers. The smaller star (which is similar in size to the Sun) will become a white dwarf. On average, a supernova occurs every 50 years in a galaxy the size of the Milky Way. Supernovas have a role in enriching the interstellar medium with elements of a larger mass. Then, the shock wave from the supernova explosion can form new stars. Based on the spectral lines of the supernova, it is divided into several types of supernova: Based on the energy source of the supernova, the following types of supernova are obtained. Supernovas occur when there is a change in the core, or center, of a massive star.

Bamboo, reed, or aur is a perennial evergreen flowering plant from the Bambusoideae subfamily which belongs to the Poaceae family. Bamboo is also known as preng or pring in Javanese, awi or tamiang or haur or torch in Sundanese, tabatiko in Ternate, and ute in Ambon. In this world bamboo is one of the plants with the fastest growth. Due to its unique rhizome-dependent system, bamboo can grow up to 60 cm (24 in) in a day or more, depending on soil conditions and the climatology where it is planted. Bambuseae (tropical woody bamboos) Olyreae (herbaceous bamboos) Arundinarieae (temperate woody bamboos) Pooideae Oryzoideae There are two general forms of bamboo, namely woody bamboos from the Arundinarieae and Bambuseae tribes, and grassy bamboos from the Olyreae tribes. Molecular analysis of the pastida indicates that there are three to five major lineages of bamboo. Bamboo is classified into more than 10 genera and 1450 species. Bamboo species are found in a variety of climatic locations, from the cool climates of the mountains to the hot tropics. They are found throughout East Asia from latitude 50o North on Sakhalin to northern Australia, and west of India to the Himalayas. They also occur in sub-Saharan Africa, and in the Americas from mid-Atlantic North America south to Argentina and Chile, reaching the southernmost point of Bambu at 47o South latitude. The European continent has no native bamboo species. More recently efforts have been made to cultivate bamboo commercially in the African Great Lakes of east Central Africa, especially in Rwanda. In addition, various companies in the United States also grow, harvest, and distribute bamboo species such as Phyllostachys edulis.

Bamboo is the fastest growing plant in the world, reportedly growing 100 cm (39 in) in 24 hours. However, this growth rate is largely determined by local soil conditions, climate, and species types. The most common growth rate is around 3–10 cm (1.2–3.9 in) per day. Bamboo grew on a large scale in the Cretaceous period, in what is now Asia. Some of the largest bamboo species can grow to over 30 m (98 ft) in height, and may reach a trunk diameter of 15–20 cm (5.9–7.9 in). However, certain species can only grow to a height of only a few inches. Bamboo belongs to the grass family, which may explain why it has such a high growth rate. This means that when bamboo is harvested, it will grow back quickly without disturbing the ecosystem. Unlike trees, bamboo culms rise from the surface to their full diameter and grow to their maximum height in one growing season (about 3 to 4 months). During those few months, every shoot that appears will grow vertically without growing branches until the age of maturity is reached. Then, branches grow from the nodes and leaves appear. In the following year, the pulp-containing stem walls will harden. In the third year, the stem hardens even more. Up to the fifth year, the fungus can grow on the outside of the culm and penetrate deep into and rot the culm. Up to the eighth year (depending on species), fungal growth will cause the bamboo culms to rot and collapse. This suggests that bamboo is best harvested when it is between three and seven years old. Bamboo will not grow taller or swell after its first year, and bamboo that has collapsed or been harvested will not be replaced by new bamboo shoots where it once grew.

Untranslated articles can be quickly deleted according to criteria A2. Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel (IPA: ˈgeɔʁk ˈvɪlhɛlm ˈfʁiːdʁɪç ˈheːgəl]) (27 August 1770 – 14 November 1831) was a German idealist philosopher born in Stuttgart, Württemberg, now in southwest Germany. His influence was far-reaching on writers of various positions, including his admirers (F. H. Bradley, Sartre, Hans Küng, Bruno Bauer, Max Stirner, Karl Marx), and those who opposed him (Kierkegaard, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Schelling). It can be said that he was the first to introduce into philosophy the idea that History and the concrete are necessary to break out of the circle of philosophia perennis, that is, eternal problems in philosophy. He also emphasizes the importance of the Other in the process of attaining self-awareness (see master-servant dialectic). Hegel was born in Stuttgart on August 27, 1770. During his childhood he read extensively in literature, newspapers, philosophical essays and writings on various other topics. His avid childhood was partly due to his extraordinarily progressive mother who actively nurtured the intellectual development of her children. The Hegels were an established middle-class family in Stuttgart. His father was a civil servant in government administration in Württemberg. Hegel was a sickly child and nearly died of smallpox before reaching the age of six. His relationship with his older sister, Christiane, was very close and remained close throughout his life. Philosophy of Hegel 1. Freedom What is meant by civil society according to Hegel is society after the French revolution. At that time Hegel was in a society that was undergoing fundamental changes in the industrial revolution which massively created a new middle class. Civil Society is also a society where people in it have the right to choose what life they like and fulfill their desires according to their abilities.

The state does not have the right to impose a certain type of life on members of civil society as it does in a feudal society. 2. The State and Individual Rights According to Hegel, the state is an absolute spirit whose power goes beyond the rights of the individual itself. According to Hegel, the state includes a process in the development of an absolute idea which is marked by the dialectical development of its thesis-antithesis, the antithesis then gives birth to a synthesis. In contrast to J.J Rousseau and John Locke, as well as the Marxists who see the state as a tool for power, Hegel actually argues that the state is not a tool but an end in itself. In Hegel's logic, people must become servants of the state for the good and welfare of society itself. 3. Integralistic State In the concept of an integralistic state, the state is an integrally structured unit of society. Society is an organic unit that is not separate and moves together into a single, essential goal. In the process of discovering this true purpose, the leader acts as the head who will guide the movement of other organic elements, so as to create harmony between the leader and the people. Hegel is known as a philosopher who uses dialectics as a method of philosophy. According to Hegel, dialectic is two things that are opposed and then reconciled, or commonly known as the thesis (assent), antithesis (denial) and synthesis (union of contradictions). The affirmation must be a sensory-empirical understanding concept. The meaning contained in it comes from everyday words, is spontaneous, not reflective so that it seems abstract, general, static and conceptual. This understanding is explained radically so that in the process of thinking it loses firmness and melts away. Denial is the concept of the first meaning (affirmation) being counter-interpreted, so that a second concept of understanding appears which is empty, formal, uncertain and unlimited. According to Hegel, in the second concept, actually stored the meaning of the first concept.

Deuterium, also known as Hydrogen-2, or heavy hydrogen (symbol written as D or 2H), is one of three isotopic forms of hydrogen, consisting of protium, deuterium, and tritium. Deuterium is a stable isotope with a natural abundance in Earth's oceans of approximately one in 6500 hydrogen atoms (~154 ppm). Thus deuterium constitutes 0.015% (0.030% by weight) of all naturally occurring hydrogen. The deuterium nucleus, called a deuteron, contains one proton and one neutron, while the most common hydrogen nucleus consists of only one proton and no neutrons. The isotope name comes from the Greek, deuteros meaning "two", to denote the 2 subatomic particles that make up the nucleus. As an isotope of hydrogen, the accepted chemical symbol for deuterium is 2H. However, the unofficial symbol, D, is often used. This significant difference in relative atomic weights compared to pure protium (1H) is probably the reason why the symbol D, which resembles that of an element, is used. The atomic weight of deuterium is 2.014 amu, while the average weight of hydrogen is 1.007947 amu, and that of protium is 1.007825 amu. For the other chemical elements, the isotope weight ratios are quite insignificant, which explains why no unique isotope symbol is used elsewhere. Naturally, deuterium is found in small quantities as the gas deuterium, written 2H2 or D2, but most of it occurs naturally in the universe bound to 1H atoms to form a gas called hydrogen deuteride (HD or 1H2H). The deuteron has spin +1, so it is a boson. The nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) frequency of deuterium differs significantly from that of ordinary light hydrogen. Infrared spectroscopy can also easily distinguish many compounds that are deuterium, because a large difference in infrared absorption frequency can be seen in the vibrations of a chemical bond containing deuterium, compared to one containing light hydrogen.

The two stable isotopes of hydrogen can also be distinguished using mass spectrometry. The physical properties of deuterium compounds can differ from those of their hydrogen analogues; for example, D2O is more viscous than H2O. Chemically, deuterium behaves the same as ordinary hydrogen, but there are differences in the bond energies and compound lengths of heavy hydrogen isotopes that are greater than the isotopic differences in any other element. The bond involving deuterium and tritium is slightly stronger than the corresponding bond between light hydrogen, and this difference is sufficient to make significant changes in biological reactions (see heavy water). Deuterium can displace the normal hydrogen in water molecules to form heavy water, which is 10.6% denser than ordinary water (ice made from it will sink in plain water). Heavy water is moderately toxic to eukaryotic organisms, whereas 25% replacement of water in the body with heavy water can cause problems with cell division and infertility, 50% replacement causes death caused by cytotoxic syndrome (bone marrow failure and gastrointestinal lining). Prokaryotic organisms are still able to survive in pure heavy water (albeit with slower growth). Heavy water consumption is not a threat to humans except in very large quantities (exceeding 10 litres). Small doses of heavy water (a few grams is the equivalent amount in the body) are routinely used as a non-hazardous metabolic tracer to humans and animals. The existence of deuterium on Earth, in the Solar System (as the planetary probes have confirmed), and in the spectra of stars, is an important fact in cosmology. Nuclear fusion reactions in stars destroy deuterium, and no known natural process of deuterium creation other than Big Bang nucleosynthesis, may have produced deuterium in the abundances observed today.

Rajgir (originally known as Girivraj) is a town and nagar panchayat of the Nalanda District in the Indian state of Bihar. The city of Rajgir (ancient: Rājagṛha; Pali: Rājagaha; Hindi: राजगृह) was the first capital of the Magadha kingdom, a state that would eventually develop into the Mauryan Empire. Its date of origin is unknown, although ceramics dating from around 1000 BC have been found within the city. This region is also important in Jainism and Buddhism as it was one of the favorite places for Venerable Mahavira and Gautama Buddha and the famous "Atanatiya" conference was held on Mount Vulture Peak (Gijjhakuta). Rajgir is connected to Patna via Bakhtiarpur by rail and road. Bakhtiarpur is located halfway between Patna and Mokameh. The name Rajgir comes from the word "Rājagṛiha" which means "house of the king" or "house of the kingdom", or the word Rajgir may come from its simple literal meaning, "royal mountain". Rajgir was the ancient capital of the Magadha kingdom until the 5th century BC when Udayin (460-440 BC), son of Ajatshatru, moved the capital to Pataliputra. During this time, the city was called Rajgrih, which translates as "home of the royal family". Shishunaga founded the Shishunaga Dynasty in 413 BC with Rajgir as the initial capital before moving to Pataliputra. Rajgir was also famous for his association with the kings of the Haryanka Dynasty, Bimbisara and Ajatashatru. Ajatashatru kept his father Bimbsara in prison here. Sources disagree that the royal family of the Buddha's contemporaries, Bimbisara and Ajatashatru, were responsible for its construction. Ajatashatru is also associated with moving the capital to Pataliputra (present-day Patna). The Epic Mahabharata calls it Girivraja and tells the story of its king, Jarasanda, and his battle with the Pandava brothers and their ally Krishna.

Copenhagen (/ˌkoʊpənˈheɪɡən/; Danish: København kʰøb̥m̩ˈhɑʊ̯ˀn] (listen)) is the capital and largest city of Denmark with an urban population (as of January 2015) of 1,263,698 and a metropolitan area of ​​2,013,009. The name comes from the word Købmandshavn, which means "merchant's harbor". Copenhagen is located on the east coast of the island (Sjælland) on the river Sont. The city is divided into several municipalities. The core section "Municipality of Copenhagen" for example contains the Frederiksberg enclave, a municipality in its own right. Founded as a fishing village in the 10th century, Copenhagen became the capital of Denmark-Norway in the early 15th century. In the early 17th century, under Christian IV of Germany, Copenhagen developed into an important European regional center, consolidating its position as capital of Denmark and Norway with resources from both kingdoms. Various magnificent architectures were erected and remain tourist attractions to this day, such as Børsen (Bursa), Rundetårn (Round Tower), Rosenborg Castle and Frederiksstaden. After experiencing the effects of plague and fire in the 18th century, the city underwent a period of rebuilding. This included the establishment of the prestigious Frederiksstaden district and the establishment of several cultural institutions such as the Royal Theater and the Royal Academy of Fine Arts. After facing disaster in the early 19th century when Nelson attacked the Dano-Norwegian fleet and destroyed the city, rebuilding in the Danish Golden Age brought a Neoclassical look to the city's architectural appearance. After World War II, the Finger Plan further developed the business center and residential area along the rail line out of the city center. In the 21st century, Copenhagen is growing, supported by investment into existing infrastructure and institutions. The city is the cultural, economic and political center of Denmark, as well as one of the financial centers in Northern Europe with the Copenhagen Stock Exchange.

Since the completion of the Øresund Bridge, the Copenhagen metropolitan area has been connected to the Swedish province of Scania, with its largest city Malmö. Notable landmarks in Copenhagen include Tivoli Gardens, Little Mermaid Statue, Amalienborg and Christiansborg Palace, Rosenborg Castle and Frederik Church. Copenhagen has more than 94,000 students enrolled at universities and other institutions, such as the University of Copenhagen, the Danish Technical University and the Copenhagen Business School. The University of Copenhagen, founded in 1479, is the oldest university in Denmark. Copenhagen is also the home of football clubs FC København and Brøndby, as well as ice hockey teams Rødovre Mighty Bulls, Herlev Eagles and Hvidovre Ligahockey. Copenhagen is one of the best cities for cyclists. The Copenhagen Metro serves the city center along with a network of S-trains connected to the surrounding boroughs. Copenhagen Airport is the largest airport among the Nordic countries. Although the oldest recorded history of Copenhagen dates back to the late 12th century, recent archaeological finds of ruins near Kongens Nytorv date back to around 1020, thanks to the development of the city's rail network. Dredging at Pilestræde also uncovered a well from the late 12th century. Remains of an ancient church, with graves from the 11th century, were also found near Strøget. These discoveries suggest that the city's origins date back to at least the 11th century. During World War II in Denmark, Copenhagen was occupied by German troops along with the rest of the country from 9 April 1940 to 4 May 1945. Adolf Hitler hoped that Denmark could become a "model protectorate" and the Nazi authorities came aiming to come to terms with the Danish government. The 1943 Danish parliamentary elections were also allowed, except for the Danish Communist Party being barred from participating.

Bolivia, or officially the Plurinational State of Bolivia (Spanish: Estado Plurinacional de Bolivia), is a country in South America bordered by Brazil to the north and east, Paraguay and Argentina to the south, and Chile and Peru to the west. Among the countries in South America, the Bolivian region is the highest and remotest. This country is one of the largest coca and tin producers in the world. The country of Bolivia was founded as "República Bolívar" in honor of its founder Simón Bolívar. The analogy used in the naming is: "Romulus derives from Rome, while Christopher Columbus derives from Colombia, and Bolívar derives from Bolivia. The important part of the name to perpetuate seems to have been the surname. The area now known as Bolivia was occupied for more than 2,500 years when the Aymara arrived. However, today the Aymara associate themselves with the ancient civilization of the Tiwanaku Empire whose capital is Tiwanaku, in Western Bolivia. The capital of Tiwanaku dates back to 1500 BC when it was still a small agricultural village. The Aymara community grew to urban proportions between 600 AD and 800 AD, became an important regional power in the southern Andes. According to early estimates, the city covered approximately 65 square kilometers (25 square miles) at its maximum level and had between 15,000 and 30,000 inhabitants.In 1996 Satellite imaging was used to map the extent of collus-like fossils (fields that t flooded) across the three main valleys of Tiwanaku, arriving at an estimated carrier population capacity of between 285,000 and 1,482,000 people. Around AD 400, Tiwanaku transformed from a dominant local power into a predatory nation. Tiwanaku extended its reach to the Yungas and brought its culture and way of life to many other cultures in Peru, Bolivia and Chile.

Tiwanaku is not a culture of violence in many ways. To expand its reach, the Tiwanaku used great political acumen, created colonies, pushed through trade agreements (which made other cultures somewhat dependent), and instituted a cult of the state. The empire continues to grow with no end in sight. William H. Isbell states "Tiahuanaco underwent a dramatic transformation between AD 600 and 700 that set a new monumental standard for civil architecture and greatly increased the resident population." The Tiwanaku continued to absorb culture rather than eradicate it. Archaeologists record the dramatic adoption of Tiwanaku ceramics into the cultures that were part of the Tiwanaku empire. The power of the Tiwanaku was further strengthened through trade carried out between the cities of his kingdom. The Tiwanaku elite earned their status through surplus food which they controlled, collected from remote areas, and then redistributed to the general population. Furthermore, elite control of this llama herd becomes a powerful control mechanism, as llamas are essential for transporting goods between the civic center and the outskirts. This herd also symbolizes the class distinction between the commoners and the elite. Through the control and manipulation of these surplus resources, elite power continued to grow until around AD 950. At this time, a dramatic change in climate occurred, causing a significant decrease in rainfall in the Titicaca Basin, which archaeologists believe was on the scale of a major drought. As rainfall decreased, many towns farther from Lake Titicaca began providing the elites with less food. As the food surplus dwindled, and thus the amount available to sustain their power, the control of the elites began to falter. The capital city became the last viable place for food production because of the resilience of elevated field farming methods.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark gray)– in the African Union  (light blue) Libya (Arabic: ‏ليبيا, translit. Lībyā‎), officially the State of Libya is a country in the Maghrib region of North Africa. Libya is bordered by the Mediterranean Sea to the north, Egypt to the east, Sudan to the southeast, Chad and Niger to the south, and Algeria and Tunisia to the west. With an area of ​​nearly 1.8 million square kilometers (700,000 sq mi), Libya is the fourth largest country in Africa by area, and the 17th largest in the world. Its largest city, Tripoli, is home to 1.7 million of Libya's 6.4 million people. The country's three traditional territorial divisions are Tripolitania, Fezzan and Cyrenaica. In 2009, Libya had the highest HDI in Africa and the highest GDP (PPP) per capita in Africa, followed by Seychelles, Equatorial Guinea and Gabon. Libya has the 10th largest oil reserves of any country in the world and the 17th highest oil production. As a result of the civil war that lasted from February to October 2011, the Libyan government, which at that time had been in power for more than 40 years, collapsed and Libya entered a period of government by an interim government called the National Transitional Council (NTC). The NTC will oversee the first phase of a transition to democracy, after which it will disband and be replaced by a representative assembly. The name "Libya" comes from the Egyptian "Lebu", a name for the Berber people who lived west of the Nile River, and was adopted by the Greek as "Libya". In ancient Greece, the term had a much broader meaning, encompassing all of North Africa west of Egypt, and sometimes applied to the entire continent of Africa.

Originally, Libya was a kingdom founded on December 24, 1951. King Idris I acted as government leader. Italy seized Libya from the Ottoman Empire (Turkey) and made it a colony. A country located in North Africa and bordering the Mediterranean Sea, gained independence after Italy surrendered to the Allies in World War II. Demonstrations took place in Libya in March 2011. These demonstrations mimicked actions that took place in Algeria, Tunisia and Egypt. The Libyan people are demanding that Libyan leader Muammar al-Qaddafi step down from the position he has led for 42 years. Demonstrations took place in various cities in Libya, such as Tripoli, Tajoura, Zawiyah, Zintan, Ajdabiyah, Ras Lanuf, Sirte, Al Bayda, Benghazi, Bin Jawed, Bani Walid, Ar Rajban and Misratah. This demonstration has claimed the lives of 165 people, including children. Most of the Libyan population fled to the 2 nearby countries, Tunisia and Egypt. There are also foreigners who have fled from Libya, namely from Indonesia, China, the Philippines, and others. A few days later, NATO, assisted by troops from the United States, France and others launched a barrage of attacks on Tripoli. Until the end of October 2011, there were two entities that claimed to be the de jure government authority in Libya. The Tripoli-based National Transitional Council, chaired by Mustafa Abdul Jalil, controls most of the country and uses the short-form name Libya for the country of Libya, but also occasionally refers to it in the long-form as the Libyan Republic. Until September 16, 2011, Libya under al-Qaddafi was officially known as the Libyan Arab Jamahiriyah by the United Nations. The former regime and its institutions, led by Muammar al-Qaddafi, referred to the Libyan state as the Great Socialist People's Arab Community of Libya and was based in Sirte.

in Europe  (gray) Iceland (Icelandic: Ísland), officially the Republic of Iceland, is a Nordic country located in northwestern Europe and in the northern Atlantic Ocean, consisting of the Island of Iceland and several smaller islands around it. Iceland is located 300 kilometers east of Greenland and 1,000 kilometers from Norway. The country has a population of 332,529 and an area of ​​103,000 sq km, making it the most sparsely populated country in Europe. The nation's capital and largest city is Reykjavík. Reykjavík and its surroundings are home to two-thirds of the population. The first people to live in Iceland were Irish monks who arrived in the early 9th century. In the mid-9th century, the Vikings migrated and settled in Iceland. The first Viking to live in Iceland was Flóki Vilgerðarson. It was he who gave Iceland the name it is today. Ingólfur Arnarson, a tribal chief from Norway, lived and settled in southwest Iceland and founded a city called Reykjavik. Around the 930s, Iceland's rulers began writing their country's constitution. They formed Althing, a type of parliament headquartered in the city of Þingvellir. Iceland can be said to be the country with the oldest democratic system that still survives today. In 985, Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for killing someone. He then sailed west and found Greenland. Erik's son, Leif Erikson, discovered America in 1000 and named it Vinland. The journey of Erik, Leif and their followers is told in a saga. In 1262 Iceland became part of Norway until 1814 Iceland became part of Denmark. At the end of the 19th century, many Icelanders wanted independence from Denmark.

In 1918, Iceland gained sovereignty, but the king of Denmark was still crowned king of Iceland. When Germany occupied Denmark on April 9, 1940, Althing decided that Iceland belonged to the Icelandic people. However, they still had not declared independence at that time. British troops and following later the United States took the initiative to occupy Iceland so that it would not be attacked by Germany. In 1944, Iceland finally declared its independence. After World War II, Iceland became a member of NATO, but not a member of the European Union. Between 1958 and 1976, there were three disagreements between Iceland and the UK over who had the right to take cod from the waters around Iceland. The war is called the Cod War. There were no casualties in the war. In 1980, Vigdís Finnbogadóttir was elected president. She is Iceland's first female president. Iceland is located at the junction of the North Atlantic and the Arctic Ocean. The main island is located south of the Arctic Circle, which passes through the small Icelandic island of Grímsey off the main island's north coast. The country lies between latitudes 63 and 68°N, and longitudes 25 and 13°W. Iceland is located closer to mainland Europe than mainland North America; thus, this island is generally included in Europe for historical, political, cultural, and practical reasons. Geologically, this island is part of both continental plates. The nearest land mass from Iceland is Greenland (290 km). The closest landmasses in Europe are the Faroe Islands (420 km); Jan Mayen Island (570 km); Shetland and Outer Hebrides, both about 740 km; and mainland Scotland and Orkney, both about 750 km. Mainland Norway is about 970 km away. Iceland is the 18th largest island in the world, and the second largest island in Europe after England.

Czechoslovakia or Czechoslovakia (Czech and Slovak: Československo or Česko-Slovensko), is a country that once existed in Central Europe. Czechoslovakia's existence began when it liberated itself from Austria-Hungary in October 1918 as a result of World War I. The periods leading up to and after World War II were critical times for Czechoslovakia. In October 1938, a year before the war began, Czechoslovakia lost the Sudetenland to the Germans and Zaolzie to the Poles in the Munich Agreement. A month later, the First Vienna Judgment forced Czechoslovakia to cede territory south of its Slovak side and Carpathian Ruthenia to Hungary. In the end, Czechoslovakia dissolved into the Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia under German sovereignty and independent Slovakia. After the war ended, Czechoslovakia was liberated and restored, but still lost its Ruthenia Carpathians, this time to the Ukrainian SSR of the Soviet Union. After the coup in 1948, Czechoslovakia turned into a communist country with a command economy. It joined the Comecon in 1949 and the Warsaw Pact in 1955. The Prague Revival opened Czechoslovak politics in 1968, but was undermined by the Warsaw Pact Invasion. Communism ended after its government was overthrown by the Velvet Revolution during the Fall of Communism. In 1993, Czechoslovakia again disbanded into two countries, namely Czechoslovakia and Slovakia now. After World War II, the political monopoly in the country was controlled by the Czechoslovak Communist Party (KSČ). Gustáv Husák was elected as first secretary of KSČ in 1969 (the post was changed to general secretary in 1971) as well as president of Czechoslovakia in 1975. There were parties of other organizations but were subordinated to KSČ. All political parties, as well as various mass organizations in the country, are united under the umbrella of the National Front. Human rights activists and religious activists were greatly pressured by this policy.

In cell biology, an organelle is a specialized subunit, usually within a cell, that has a specific function. The name organelle comes from the idea that these structures are part of the cell, just as organs are to the body. Finally, the name given is the organelle, with the ending -el describing its diminutive (small) property. Organelles are units that are separately enclosed within their own lipid bilayer (also called membrane-bound organelles) or are spatially distinct functional units without a surrounding lipid bilayer (nonmembrane-bound organelles). Although most organelles are functional units within the cell, some functional units that extend outside the cell are often called organelles, such as cilia, flagella and archaelum, and trichocysts. Organelles are identified microscopically, and can also be purified by cell fractionation. There are many types of organelles, especially in eukaryotic cells. They include structures that make up the internal endomembrane system (such as the nuclear envelope, endoplasmic reticulum, and Golgi bodies), as well as other structures such as mitochondria and plastids. Although prokaryotes lack eukaryotic organelles, some do contain protein-coated bacterial microcompartments, which are thought to act as primitive prokaryotic organelles; and there is also evidence regarding other membrane-bound structures. In addition, the prokaryotic flagella that protrude outside the cell, and their motors, as well as most of the extracellular pilus, are often referred to as organelles. In biology, an organ is defined as a limited functional unit within an organism. The analogy of body organs to microscopic cellular substructures is so obvious that even from early works, the authors of the respective textbooks seldom outlined the difference between the two. In the 1830s, Félix Dujardin disproved Ehrenberg's theory that microorganisms had the same organs as multicellular animals, only smaller in size. The first person known to use the term organ diminutive (i.e. small organ) for cellular structures was the German zoologist Karl August Möbius (1884), who used the term organula (plural of organulum, diminutive form of Latin organum).

In a footnote published as a correction in a later issue of the journal, he justified his opinion of calling the organs in unicellular organisms "organella" because they are simply different parts of a single cell, in contrast to the multicellular organs in multicellular organisms. Although most cell biologists consider the term organelle to be synonymous with the cell compartment, a space often bounded by one or two lipid bilayers, some cell biologists prefer to limit the term to include only the cell compartment containing deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA), derived from previously autonomous microscopic organisms, obtained through endosymbiosis. By that definition, there would only be two major groups of organelles (i.e. those containing their own DNA, and those derived from endosymbiotic bacteria): mitochondria (in nearly all eukaryotes), and plastids (e.g. in plants, algae, and some protists). Other organelles are also thought to have an endosymbiotic origin, but do not contain their own DNA (especially flagella – see evolution of flagella). The second, less strict, definition of organelles is that they are membrane-bound structures. However, even using this definition, some parts of the cell that have been shown to be separate functional units do not qualify as organelles. Therefore, the use of organelles also to refer to nonmembrane bound structures such as ribosomes, is also common and accepted. This has led to many texts distinguishing between membrane-bound and nonmembrane-bound organelles. Nonmembrane-bound organelles, also called large biomolecular complexes, are large groups of macromolecules that carry out specific and specialized functions, but have no membrane boundaries. Many of these are referred to as "protein organelles" because many structures are made of proteins. The cell structure includes: The mechanism of nonmembrane bound organelles in forming and maintaining their spatial integrity has been likened to liquid-liquid phase separation.

Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System and the closest to the Sun. This planet's period of revolution is the shortest of all the planets in the Solar System, namely 87.79 days. Like Venus, Mercury is an inferior planet whose orbit lies inside Earth's orbit, and when observed from Earth, its angular distance from the Sun never exceeds 28°. Due to its proximity to the Sun, this planet can only be seen near the western horizon after sunset or the eastern horizon before sunrise, or usually at dusk. Mercury would appear to be a bright star to observe at this time, but is often much more difficult to observe than Venus. When observed through a telescope, Mercury will display a series of phases similar to those of Venus and the Moon, as it moves in its inner orbit relative to Earth and repeats itself in one synodic cycle, which is about 116 days. Mercury has a unique rotation in the Solar System. The planet is tidally locked with the Sun in a 3:2 spin–resonant orbit, meaning that relative to the fixed stars, it rotates on its axis exactly three times for every two periods of revolution around the Sun.a] As observed from the Sun, in frame of reference in which it rotates with orbital motion, Mercury appears to rotate only once every two Mercury years. Mercury's axis has the smallest tilt of all the planets in the Solar System, which is only about ​1⁄30 degrees. It also has the largest orbital eccentricity of any planet in the Solar System; when at perihelion, Mercury is only about two thirds (or 66%) of its distance from the sun at aphelion.

Mercury's surface is full of craters and has a shape similar to that of the Moon; this indicates that geological processes on its surface have stopped billions of years ago. Having almost no atmosphere to retain heat, Mercury has a wide range of surface temperatures each day, from 100 K (−173 °C; −280 °F) at night to 700 K (427 °C; 800 °F) at night. during the day along the equator. The surface temperature in the polar regions is always below 180 K (−93 °C; −136 °F). Mercury has no known natural satellites. The two space probes that have visited Mercury are Mariner 10, which flew by the planet in 1974 and 1975, and MESSENGER, which launched in 2004 and orbited Mercury more than 4,000 times in four years before running out of fuel and crashing into space. surface of the planet on April 30, 2015. The BepiColombo space probe is expected to arrive at Mercury in 2025. With a diameter of 4879 km at the equator, Mercury is the smallest of the four terrestrial planets in the Solar System. Mercury's distance to the sun is 57 million km, and Mercury's distance from Earth is 92 million km. Mercury consists of 70% metals and 30% silicates and has a density of 5.43 g/cm3, only slightly below that of Earth. However, if the effects of gravitational pressure are not taken into account, Mercury is denser than Earth with an uncompressed density of Mercury 5.3 g/cm3 and Earth only 4.4 g/cm3. Mercury's density is used to estimate its internal structure. Earth's high density is created due to gravitational pressure, especially in the core.

The Republic of Benin, formerly known as Dahomey, is a country in western Africa. The country is bordered by Togo to the west, Nigeria to the east, and Burkina Faso and Niger to the north. During French colonial rule and after independence on August 1, 1960, the country was named Dahomey after its predecessor kingdom, the Kingdom of Dahomey. On November 30, 1975, the country was renamed Benin following the Marxist-Leninist military coup. The Bay of Benin borders this country and the name of the bay is taken from the name of the Kingdom of Benin which is located in present-day Nigeria. The African kingdom of Dahomey arose in Benin. Since the 17th century, the kingdom was ruled by the oba, far beyond the borders of present-day Benin, covering most of West Africa. This prosperous kingdom was an "exporter" of slaves and traded with the Portuguese and the Dutch. But chaos here eventually resulted in Dahomey being colonized by the French in 1892. In 1904, Dahomey became a part of French West Africa, no longer Dahomey. In 1958, Dahomey was granted autonomy, and full independence was achieved in 1960. A period of turbulence followed independence, and there were several coups and regime changes before Mathieu Kérékou took power. Kérékou embraced Marxism, and the country was renamed "Benin". In the late 1980s, Kérékou abandoned Marxism and made the decision to re-establish democracy. He was defeated in the 1991 elections, but won again in 1996. The overall shape of the country is bounded by the Niger River in the north and the coastal plains in the south, with the east being slightly rugged. The northern part of the country is mainly composed of semi-arid savannas and mountains. Its highest point is Mount Sagboroa at 658 m. The south of the country consists of a spreading marshy coastal plain, lakes and lagoons such as Lake Nohoué or the lagoon at Porto Novo.

Most of the population lives on the coast, where most of Benin's major cities are concentrated, particularly Porto Novo and Cotonou. The country is located in the intertropical zone, the climate is dry and humid, compared to the rains, which occur 10 times (April to July and September to November). The International Court of Justice at the Hague declared on 12 July 2005 the border between Benin and Niger included the islands on the banks of the Niger and Mékrou rivers: the 16 new islands were assigned to Benin, and Lété to Niger. The climate is tropical, hot and dry along with the seasonality of the geography across the country, the seasons are clear and alternating. Stretching 900 to 1300 mm of water, the areas that receive the most rain are in the southeastern corner, Cotonou to Porto Novo, between Atacora-Natitingou and Djougou, the Dassa and Ndali regions north of Parakou. Maximum rainfall is in the south (equatorial climate), in mid-March to July, and rainfall decreases in November/December. Monsoons, blow from April to November, in the southeast. The dry Harmattan blows in the opposite direction of the monsoons, November to May, producing an orange dust. The humidity level, always high, is between 65 and 95%. Average temperatures include 22 and 34°C, hot in April and May (right after the Harmattan blows for 6 months, after monsoons that bring rain). There are several lakes in Benin, including: Lake Ahémé, Lake Aziri, Lake Nokoué, Lake Porto Novo, Lake Sele, Lake Toho, and Togbadji Lagoon. Benin's politics take place within the framework of a presidential representative democratic republic, in which the President of Benin is the head of state and head of government, and a multiparty system takes various forms.

– in Europe  (green & dark gray)– in the European Union  (green)  –  legend] Sweden (officially: Kingdom of Sweden, Swedish: Konungariket Sverige (help·info)), is a Nordic country in Scandinavia, Northern Europe . The country is bordered by Norway to the west and Finland to the northeast, the Skagerrak Strait and Kattegat Strait to the southwest, and the Baltic Sea and Gulf of Bothnia to the east. Sweden is connected to Denmark by a bridge-tunnel through Öresund. At 450,295 square kilometers (173,860 sq mi), Sweden is the third largest country in the European Union, with a total population of around 9.8 million. Sweden has a low population density with 21 inhabitants per square kilometer, most of the population living in the southern half of the country. About 85% of the population lives in urban areas. Northern Sweden is mostly agricultural area, while the north is mostly forest. Sweden is part of the geographical area Fennoscandia. Germanic people have inhabited the country since prehistoric times, were then known as Geats/Götar and Swedes/Svear and lived on the coast of what is now the Norsemen. Sweden became an independent country during the Middle Ages. In the 17th century, Sweden expanded its territory to form the Swedish Empire, which remained one of the major powers in Europe until the early 18th century. Swedish control outside the Scandinavian Peninsula gradually disappeared in the 18th and 19th centuries, beginning with the Russian Empire's annexation of present-day Finland in 1809. The last war in which Sweden was directly involved was when Norway was forced militarily into the Swedish Union and Norway in 1814. Since then, Sweden has maintained a conciliatory position, maintaining its official policy of being neutral in its foreign policy. The union with Norway was peacefully separated in 1905, forming the boundaries of present-day Sweden.

Although formally neutral in both world wars, Sweden took part in humanitarian efforts such as accepting refugees from German-occupied Europe. After the end of the Cold War, Sweden joined the European Union on January 1, 1995, but rejected NATO membership. Currently, Sweden is a constitutional monarchy and a parliamentary democracy, with the monarch as head of state. The capital is Stockholm, it is also the largest city in the country. Legislative power is determined by the 349-member unicameral Riksdag. Executive power is vested in the government headed by the Prime Minister. Sweden is a unitary state, currently divided into 21 counties and 290 municipalities. Sweden implements a Nordic social security system that provides universal healthcare and higher education for its citizens. Sweden ranks eighth in terms of per capita income in the world and ranks high in various sectors, such as quality of life, health, education, protection of civil liberties, economic competitiveness, equality, prosperity and the Human Development Index. Sweden has been a member of the European Union since January 1, 1995, but rejected Eurozone membership after a referendum. The country is also a member of the United Nations, the Nordic Council, the Council of Europe, the World Trade Organization and the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). Sweden is a unitary state consisting of 21 counties (Swedish: län) and 290 communes (Swedish: kommuner). The area of ​​Sweden is located in the Northern Hemisphere and in the north, there are areas within the Arctic Circle but the climate is moderate. To the east, it is bounded by the Baltic Sea and the Gulf of Bothnia. Its western boundary with Norway is the Scandinavian Mountains. Population density tends to be higher in the south where the majority is agriculture and the further north, the denser the forest.

in Europe (gray) Albania, officially the Republic of Albania (Albanian: Republika e Shqipërisë), is a country located in Southeastern Europe. The country is bordered by Montenegro to the north, Kosovo to the northeast, North Macedonia to the east and Greece to the south, the Adriatic Sea lies to the west of Albania, and the Ionian Sea to the southwest. Albania in his language is called Shqipëria, which means Homeland of the Eagles. Albanians attribute this definition to the nickname of their people as a whole, and this nickname is also associated with the image of the double-headed eagle on the Albanian flag and emblem (the double-headed eagle was actually the symbol of the Byzantine Empire which once ruled the Balkans and Anatolia). , which in turn was borrowed from the pre-Roman civilizations of Anatolia. It can also be found on the emblems of other countries, such as Russia). The name "Albania" may also come from the Indo-European word albh (white). Scholars believe the Albanian population is descended from a non-Slavic, non-Turkish tribal group known as the Illyrians, who arrived in the Balkans around 2000 BC. Modern Albanians still distinguish between the Gheg (northern tribe) and Tosk (southern tribe). After falling under Roman authority in 165 BC, Albania was controlled almost continuously from successive foreign powers until the mid-20th century, with brief periods of self-rule. Following the breakup of the Roman Empire in 395, the Byzantine Empire began to control what is now Albania. In the 11th century, the Byzantine Emperor Alexius I Comnenus produced a certificate in which the first recorded area or land known as Albania and its inhabitants were recorded. The Ottoman Empire ruled Albania between 1385-1912. During this time, most of the population converted to Islam, and Albanians also emigrated to Italy, Greece, Egypt and Turkey.

Although its control was briefly interrupted by the upheaval of 1443-1478, led by Gjergj Kastrioti Skenderbeg, the Ottoman Empire eventually reasserted their control. In the early 20th century, the Ottoman Empire lost control here. The Prizren League (1878) introduced the idea of ​​an Albanian nation-state and created the modern Albanian alphabet. Following the end of the First Balkan War, Albanians issued the Vlore Proclamation on 28 November 1912, declaring 'independence'. Albania's borders were defined by the Great Powers in 1913. Albania's territorial integrity was affirmed at the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, after United States President Woodrow Wilson rejected plans by European powers to divide Albania among its neighbours. During World War II, Albania was annexed first by Italy (1939-43) and then by Germany (1943-44). After the war, Communist Party leader Enver Hoxha set out to protect Albania's territorial integrity for the next 40 years, but it cost a heavy political price from its population, which was subjected to purges, abatement, suppression of civil and political rights, a total ban on religious practices, and increasing isolation. . Albanians loyal to austere Stalinist philosophy eventually withdrew from the Warsaw Pact in 1968 and distanced themselves from its last ally, the People's Republic of China in 1978. Following Hoxha's death in 1985 and then the fall of communism in 1991, Albanian society is struggling to overcome its isolation and historical backwardness . During the initial transitional period, the Albanian government envisioned closer ties with the West in order to improve economic conditions and introduce basic democratic reforms, including a multiparty system. In 1992, after the broad electoral victory of the Democratic Party, Sali Berisha became the first democratically elected President of Albania. Berisha began a more cautious program of economic reform and 'democracy' but as it progressed there were rumors it failed in the mid-1990s, due to political gridlock.

Hydrogen (Latin: hydrogenium, from Greek: hydro: water, genes: to form), or sometimes called water, is a chemical element on the periodic table that has the symbol H and atomic number 1. At standard temperature and pressure, hydrogen is colorless , odorless, non-metallic, monovalent, and a highly flammable diatomic gas. With an atomic mass of 1.00794 amu,a] hydrogen is the lightest element in the world. Hydrogen is also the most abundant element, accounting for approximately 75% of the total elemental mass of the universe. b] Most stars are formed by hydrogen in the plasma state. Compound hydrogen is relatively rare and rarely occurs naturally on Earth, and is usually produced industrially from various hydrocarbon compounds such as methane. Hydrogen can also be produced from water by electrolysis, but this process is commercially more expensive than producing hydrogen from natural gas. The most common isotope of hydrogen found in nature is protium, whose atomic nucleus has only a single proton and no neutrons. Hydrogen ionic compounds can be positively charged (cations) or negatively charged (anions). Hydrogen can form compounds with most elements and is found in water and in organic compounds. Hydrogen is very important in acid-base reactions in that many of these reactions involve the exchange of protons between solute molecules. Because hydrogen is the only neutral atom for which the Schrödinger equation can be solved analytically, studies of the energetics and bonding of atomic hydrogen played a very important role in the development of quantum mechanics. The solubility and characteristics of hydrogen with various metals is a subject of great importance in metallurgy (because embrittlement of hydrogen can occur in most metals) and in research and development of safe ways to store hydrogen as a fuel.

Hydrogen is very soluble in various compounds consisting of nadir earth metals and transition metals and can be dissolved in crystalline metals as well as amorphous metals. Hydrogen solubility in metals is caused by local distortions or impurities in the metal's crystal lattice. Hydrogen gas (dihydrogen or molecular hydrogen) is highly flammable and will burn at concentrations as low as 4% H2 in air. The enthalpy of combustion of hydrogen is −286 kJ/mol. Hydrogen burns according to the chemical equation: 2 H2(g) + O2(g) → 2 H2O(l) + 572 kJ (286 kJ/mol)c] Hydrogen will self-explode at 500 °C. Hydrogen forms explosive mixtures with air in hydrogen concentrations of 4–74% and with chlorine in concentrations of 5–95%. Explosive reactions can be triggered by sparks, heat, or sunlight. Flames produced by burning pure hydrogen-oxygen emit ultraviolet waves and are almost invisible to the naked eye. Burning hydrogen leak detection may require a flame detector; such leaks can be very dangerous. Hydrogen flames under other conditions are blue, resembling the blue flames of natural gas. The Hindenburg explosion case is one of the famous examples of hydrogen combustion. Another characteristic of hydrogen fires is that the flames tend to dissipate quickly in air, so the damage from a hydrogen explosion is less than that of a hydrocarbon explosion. In the case of the Hindenburg crash, two-thirds of those on board survived and most of the deaths were caused by the burning of leaking diesel fuel. H2 is relatively unreactive. The thermodynamic basis of this low reactivity is the very strong H-H bond, with a bond dissociation energy of 435.7 kJ/mol. The kinetic basis of low reactivity is the nonpolar nature of H2 and its weak polarizability.

in ASEAN (dark gray)  – Legend] Vietnam, fully named the Socialist Republic of Vietnam is a country in Mainland Southeast Asia. Vietnam is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, and the South China Sea to the east. The South China Sea in Vietnam is called the East Sea. In Vietnam there are 84 million people living there. Vietnam is included in the "Next Eleven" economic group. Vietnam's GDP per capita grew by 8.17% in 2006, which is considered fast in East Asia and Southeast Asia. At the end of 2007, Vietnam's finance minister explained that Vietnam's GDP per capita increased to 8.44%, which was the highest in the last decade. The history of Vietnam goes back 4000 years. Vietnam from the 11th century BC to the 10th century AD was mostly under Chinese imperial rule. In 939 AD, Vietnam became politically independent, and started using Champa as the country's name. This period is considered to be the period of building Vietnamese identity. Vietnam's area is 332,698 km², almost equal to the area of ​​Germany. The part of Vietnam bordered by its international borders is 4639 km wide and has a coastline of about 3444 km. The topography consists of hills and heavily forested mountains, with lowlands constituting no more than 20% of it. Mountains make up 40% of Vietnam's total area, with small hills contributing 40% and tropical forests 42%. The northern part consists mostly of mountains and the Red River delta. Phan Xi Pang, located in Lao Cai province, is the highest mountain in Vietnam at 3,143 meters. The south is divided into a seaside lowland, the peaks of the Annamite Chain, with extensive forests. Comprising five flat basalt plateaus, the mountains contribute 16% of Vietnam's cultivated land and 22% of Vietnam's total forested land.

The Red River Delta (also known as Song Hong), is a flat, triangular region of 15 000 km², smaller but more developed and densely populated than the Mekong River Delta. Formerly the Red River Delta was an inlet in the Gulf of Tonkin region, filled by large deposits of river silt over the millennium period and extending 100 meters into the Gulf of Tonkin each year. The Mekong Delta covers about 40,000 square kilometers, is a lowland area not more than three meters above sea level from any point and criss-crossed by a network of canals and rivers. So much sediment is carried by the branches and outflows of the Mekong River that the delta extends some 60 to 80 meters seaward each year. Vietnam has a tropical monsoon climate, with an average humidity of 84% year-round. However, because of differences in latitude and topographical diversity, climate tends to vary widely from place to place. During the cold or dry season, generally from November to April, the monsoon winds usually blow from the Northeast along the coast of China and towards the Gulf of Tonkin, increasing the amount of humidity; As a result, winters for most of Vietnam are dry. The average annual temperature is generally higher in the lowlands than in the mountains and highlands. The Socialist Republic of Vietnam is a one-party state. A new constitution was passed in April 1992 replacing the 1975 version. The former main role of the Communist party was reinstated in all organs of government, politics and society. Only political organizations that cooperate with or are supported by the Communist Party are allowed to participate in elections. These include the Vietnamese Fatherland Front, the trade union and workers' parties.

Korea is a nation in East Asia, which is located on the Korean Peninsula. Korea was divided into two countries, namely the Democratic People's Republic of Korea in the north, and the Republic of Korea in the south, after World War 2 in 1945. The Republic of Korea then developed into a democratic country, while the Democratic People's Republic of Korea became a communist country. The Unification Flag of Korea is often used to represent Korea at international sporting events, but it is not the official flag of the two countries. Due to the end of the historical dynasties, the current term Korea is defined based on the combination of the 2 entities divided by the Korean Demilitarized Zone, namely North Korea and South Korea. The Korean peninsula is bounded on the north by China, and Russia on the northeast, and Japan on the southeast which is separated by the Korea Strait. The term "Korea" is taken from the name of the famous Korean dynasty, namely Goryeo (935-1392). Goryeo itself named the country from the abbreviation of the name of one of the Three Kingdoms of Korea, Goguryeo (37 BC-668 AD). In Chinese it was pronounced "Gao-li" and the word spread to Middle Eastern traders, and over time it became "Korean". The word "Korea" is generally used in the international world today to refer to the two Korean countries. In Korean in South Korea, "Korea" means "Han-Guk" (South Korea; short for "Dae Han Min Guk") while "Chosŏn" is used by North Koreans to refer to their country's name. The term "Korea" was first used by Percival Lowell (1855-1916), an American writer, adventurer and astronomer who visited Korea about 100 years ago. The name is a literal interpretation of the word Chosǒn (Joseon, 조선 / 朝鮮, 1392-1910), the name of the country he visited in the late 19th century.

Lowell considered the name suitable for a kingdom that was closed to the outside world. Korea at that time was unknown to the western world, but in earlier times, the Goryeo Dynasty was well known to the western world, and it was from that country that the word Korea came from. Korean history spans from the Early Paleolithic to the present. Pottery culture in Korea began around 8000 BC, and the Neolithic Age began before 6000 BC which was followed by the Bronze Age around 2500 BC. Then, the Kingdom of Gojoseon was established in 2333 BC. It wasn't until the 3rd century BC that Korea began to be divided into many kingdoms. In the first year AD, the Three Kingdoms of Korea such as Goguryeo, Silla and Baekje began to dominate the Korean Peninsula and Manchuria. The three kingdoms competed with each other economically and militarily. Goguryeo and Baekje are the two strongest kingdoms, especially Goguryeo, which has always been able to fend off attacks from Chinese dynasties. The Kingdom of Silla slowly grew stronger, and eventually subdued Goguryeo. For the first time the Korean Peninsula was unified by Silla in 676 to become Unified Silla. The surviving Goguryeo escapees established another kingdom on the northeastern side of the Korean peninsula, namely Balhae. Unified Silla finally collapsed in the late 9th century, which also ended the reign of the Three Kingdoms. A new kingdom, the Goryeo Dynasty, began to dominate the Korean Peninsula. The Balhae Kingdom collapsed in 926 due to the attack of the Khitans and most of the population and its leader, Dae Gwang-hyeon, fled to the Goryeo Dynasty. During the reign of the Goryeo Dynasty, new laws were enacted, public services were established, and the spread of Buddhism flourished. In 1392, Taejo of Joseon founded the Joseon Dynasty after overthrowing Goryeo.

Church is an ecclesiological term used by various Christian denominations to describe the body of true Christian fellowship or the original institution founded by Jesus. The term "Church" is also used in the scientific realm as a synonym for Christianity, even though in reality Christianity consists of many Churches or denominations, and many of them claim to be "the only true Church" over others. For many Protestant Christians, the Church contains two elements, the visible and the invisible. The visible Church is the institution where "the Word of God is purely preached and listened to, and the sacraments are administered according to the ordinance of Christ", while the invisible Church is all people "who are truly saved" (and become members of the visible Church) . Within this understanding of the invisible Church, "Church" (or the general Church) does not refer to a specific Christian denomination, but includes all saved individuals. According to the branch theory, which is held up among Anglicans, the Churches maintaining the apostolic succession are part of the true Church. This theory is opposed to the attitude of pinning the label "the only true Church" on a certain real Christian institution, namely the ecclesiological attitude adopted by the Catholic Church, the Eastern Orthodox Church, the Oriental Orthodox Churches, the Assyrian Church and the Ancient Church in the East. In the Indonesian Bible, the word "congregation" is used as a counterpart to the Greek word "ekklesia" (ἐκκλησία), which generally means "congregation" or "congregation". The word "ecclesia" appears in 2 verses of the Gospel of Matthew, 24 verses of the Acts of the Apostles, 58 verses of Paul's letters (including the earliest examples of its use to refer to a body of Christian fellowship), 2 verses of the Epistle to the Hebrews, 1 verses of the Letter of James, 3 verses of the Letter of John III, and 19 verses of the Book of Revelation.

The total number of occurrences of the word "ecclesia" in the New Testament is 114 times, although it is not always used technically to refer to the Church. Thus, ecclesia is used as a designation for local communities as well as a term that has universal meaning for all believers. The term "Christianity" (Greek: Χριστιανισμός, Kristianismos) is first recorded as being used around 100 AD by Ignatius, Bishop of Antioch. The Four Characteristics of the Church first surfaced in the Nicene Creed in 381 which emphasized that the Church is one, holy, catholic (am) and apostolic (apostolic). The Greek word "eklēsia", literally means "who is called out" or "who is called forward", and is usually used to characterize a group of people who are called together to do something, especially to characterize the meeting of citizens of a city, for example in the text of Acts Apostles 19:32-41. This word is a New Testament term that refers to the Church (both in the sense of the local assembly and in the sense of all the faithful). In the Septuagint, the word "eklesia" is used as the equivalent of the Hebrew word "qahal" (קהל). Most Romance and Celtic languages ​​use various derivatives of this word, either inherited or borrowed from its Latin form, ecclesia. One example is the word "igreja" in Portuguese, which is absorbed into the word "church" in Indonesian. The early church was formed in Judea, a Roman colony, in the first century of our Common Era, based on the teachings of Jesus of Nazareth, who first gathered disciples. These disciples were later called "Christians". According to the Scriptures, Jesus commissioned them to spread his teachings throughout the world. For most Christians, Pentecost (the event that occurred after Jesus ascended into heaven) is the anniversary of the Church, marked by the descent of the Holy Spirit upon the assembled disciples of Jesus (Acts 2).

Africa · AmericasSouth America · AsiaEurope · Oceania Microeconomics · Macroeconomics History of economic thinking Methodology  · Heterodox Approaches  · Culture  · Growth Evolution  · Development  · International History  · Economic Systems Finance and Financial Economics of Society and Health Welfare Economics ・Labor ・Managerial Information Business  · Information · Game Theory of Industrial Organization · Agricultural Law · Natural Resources Environment · Ecological Economic Geography · Cities · Rural · Area Maps of Mathematical Economics ·EconometricsExperimental · National Accounts Journals· Publication Category· Topics· Economist Anarchism· Capitalism Communism· Corporatism Fascism· Islamic Georgism · Globalization of the Market Economy Socialism · Protectionist Mercantilism · Socialism Syndicalism · The Third Way Economics is a social science that studies human behavior in managing limited resources and channeling them into various existing individuals or groups in a society. The term "economy" comes from the Greek, namely οἶκος (oikos) which means "family, household" and νόμος (nomos) which means "rules, rules, law". Broadly speaking, economics is defined as "household rule" or "household management". Meanwhile, what is meant by economists or economists are people who use economic concepts and data in their work. The word "economy" is an absorption word from the Ancient Greek οἰκονόμος which means "management of the household". This word is a combination of two words, namely οἶκος ("house") and νέμω ("management; distribution"). This word was first recorded as being used in a work made by a church in 1440 to describe a system of management or administration. The meaning of economics that is widely used today, namely the economy as a system used in a country or region, only developed in the 19th or 20th century.

Economic action is carried out by observing the rules known as economic principles. There are two basic principles in carrying out economic actions. First, economics is carried out with the aim of obtaining as much profit as possible by taking into account expenses as part of the profit calculation. Second, the benefits obtained as much as possible only require spending as little as possible. These two principles serve as general guidelines for economic action. The results of the application of economic principles can be observed through the level of efficiency which is measured through a comparison between the profits earned and the expenses required during economic activity. An economic action is said to be efficient if an outcome is achieved with the most appropriate sacrifice and is accompanied by cost savings. Economics is widely discussed in a special science known as economics, which includes sociology. history, anthropology, and geography. Some parts of economics which are applied sciences such as production, distribution, trade, and consumption are also discussed in other disciplines such as engineering, management, business administration, applied science, and finance. There are many sectors in the economy, which are then grouped into three main sectors namely the primary sector, the secondary sector, and the tertiary sector. Microeconomics is a branch of economics that studies economic activities and economic units within an individual scope. All economic activity is assessed from an individual point of view.
