In microeconomics, individuals act as consumers, owners of factors of production, and as producers. Economic analysis is fully carried out on individual roles from demand and supply to market structure. Analytical activities in microeconomics are generally divided into three, namely price theory, production theory, and distribution theory. Included in the primary sector are sectors that make direct use of natural resources, including agriculture, forestry, fisheries and mining.

Calapan City is a city in the province of Oriental Mindoro, Philippines. Kota is one of the five towns of Oriental Mindoro. As of 2010, the city had a population of 116,976 lives and 2,924 inhabitants. This economic quarter falls under agriculture and finance. Administratively, Calapan City has 62 barangays, namely: J.P. Claudius Ptolemaeus (Greek: Κλαύδιος Πτολεμαῖος; 90 – 168), was a geographer, astronomer, and astrologer who lived during the Hellenistic period in the Roman province of Aegyptus. Ptolemaeus was the author of several scientific treatises, three of which later played important roles in Islamic and European scholarship. The first is the astronomical treatise known as the Almagest (in Greek Η μεγάλη Σύνταξις, "Great Treatise"). The second is Geographia, which is a thorough discussion of Hellenistic geographical knowledge. The third is the astrological treatise known as the Tetrabiblos ("Four books") in which he attempts to adapt astrological horoscopes to the Aristotelian natural philosophy. He also preserved a list of ancient kings, called the "Canon of Ptolemy", which is important for the study of Middle Eastern history. Claudius is a Roman nomen; Ptolemy bore this name, thus proving that he was a Roman citizen. As was customary, the first Ptolemy to become a citizen (whether he or an ancestor) took the name from a Roman named Claudius, thus giving him citizenship. If this Roman was emperor, citizenship would have been granted sometime between AD 41 and 68 (when Claudius, then Nero, was emperor). The astronomer also had a praenomen (first name), which remains unknown. However, it is probably Tiberius, since the praenomen was very common among those families granted citizenship by this emperor. Ptolemaeus is a Greek name. Appears once in Greek mythology, in Homeric form. It was quite common among the Macedonian upper sol class at the time of Alexander the Great, and there were several among Alexander's armies, one of which was in 323 B.C. made himself King of Egypt: Ptolemy I Soter; all the kings after him, until Egypt became a province of Rome in 30 B.C.E., were also Ptolemaic.

Nusantara is a term derived from words in Kawi (a form of Old Javanese which is heavily influenced by Sanskrit), namely ꦤꦸꦱ (nusa) trans. har. "island" and ꦲꦤ꧀ꦠꦫ (between) trans. har. "outside". In Indonesia, the term "Nusantara" specifically refers to Indonesia (the Indonesian archipelago),:3:230 this word was recorded for the first time in the Negarakertagama book to describe the concept of statehood adopted by Majapahit; whose territory covers most of Southeast Asia, especially in the archipelago. Outside of Indonesia, the term Nusantara is used to refer to the Malay Archipelago (Malay Archipelago), which lies between the mainland of Indochina⁠—Indochina consisting of Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam, and Malaysia⁠—and mainland Australia. The concept of the Archipelago as a unified region did not originally come from Gajah Mada, but by King Kertanegara of the Singhasari Kingdom⁠—also called Singasari or Singosari⁠—in the Mula Malurung Inscription published by Kertanegara in 1255 on the orders of his father, Wisnuwardhana (reigning in 1248-1268), as the king of Singhasari. In addition, in 1275, the term Cakravala Mandala Dvipantara was used by Kertanegara to describe aspirations for the Southeast Asian Islands to unite under Singhasari's rule and marked the beginning of his efforts to realize these aspirations. Dvipantara is a Sanskrit word which means "islands in the middle" as a synonym for the word Nusantara because both dvipa and nusa both mean "island". Kertanegara created a vision of a unified maritime government and empire in Southeast Asia as a defense against the rise of the expansionist Yuan dynasty of China⁠—or China⁠—led by the Mongols. In the 1900s this term was revived by Ki Hajar Dewantara as an alternative name for an independent country other than the Dutch East Indies.

Even though the name "Indonesia" (trans. 'Indian Islands') was approved to be used as the official name of the Unitary State of the Republic of Indonesia, the word Nusantara was still enshrined as a synonym for the Indonesian archipelago. The use of this term in ancient times was used to describe the geographical-anthropological unity of the islands located between the continents of Asia and Australia (including Peninsular Malaysia). In a broader sense, the Archipelago in modern language includes Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Southern Thailand, the Philippines, Brunei Darussalam, Timor Leste (or Timor Timur, Leste comes from the Portuguese meaning "East"), Taiwan⁠, and Papua Indonesia ⁠—excluding Papua New Guinea. Pribumi-Nusantara (Native Indonesia), also known as pribumi (lit. 'first in Indonesia's homeland), are Indonesian people whose ancestral roots are in the Archipelago since prehistoric times from the 7th century AD to the 13th century AD, distinguished Indonesians of foreign descent (partially) known, such as Chinese Indonesians, Arab Indonesians, Indian Indonesians and Indo-Europeans (Eurasians) whose predecessors were in Indonesia from the colonial colonial era since the 16th century AD. The term pribumi was popularized after Indonesian independence as a respectful replacement for the Dutch colonial term Inlander. In the Javanese concept of statehood in the 13th to 15th centuries, the king was a "King-God": the king who ruled was also an incarnation of a god. Because of that his territory exudes the concept of the power of a god. The Majapahit Kingdom can be used as an example. The country was divided into three regional parts: In 1336 AD Gajah Mada stated in the Palapa Oath: Sira Gajah Mada pepatih amukubumi tan ayun amukita palapa, sira Gajah Mada: But huwus lost to Nusantara ingsun amukti palapa, but lost to the Gurun ring, Seram ring, Tanjungpura, Haru ring, Pahang ring, Dompo, Bali ring, Sundanese, Palembang, Tumasik, Samana Ingsun Amukti Palapa.

The Republic of Somaliland (Somali: Soomaaliland, Arabic: أرض الصومال or صوماليلاند, English: Somaliland) is a detached state constituting a former territory of the United Kingdom, located in the northwestern part of Somalia on the Horn of Africa. In May 1991, clans in the northern region proclaimed independence for Somaliland which now covers 5 of Somalia's 18 administrative regions. Somaliland is roughly located between Ethiopia, Djibouti and the Gulf of Aden, with an area of ​​137,600 km². The capital city of Somaliland is Hargeisa. Although not recognized by most countries, this entity still exists with the help of powerful ruling clans and an economic infrastructure left behind by military cooperation programs with Britain, Russia and the United States. The name Somaliland is derived from two words: "Somali" and "land". The area was named when the British took control of Egypt in 1884, after signing successive treaties with the ruling Sultans of Somalia from the Isaaq, Issa, Gadabursi, and Warsangali clans. The British established a protectorate in the area known as British Somaliland. In 1960, when the protectorate became independent from Britain, the territory became the State of Somaliland. Four days later, on 1 July 1960, Somaliland was united with Italian Somaliland. The name "Republic of Somaliland" was adopted after declaring independence following the Somali Civil War in 1991. At the Grand Conference on Burao held in 1991, many country names were proposed, including Puntland, referring to Somaliland's location in ancient Punt and what is now Puntland in neighboring Somalia, and Shankaroon, which means "better than five" in Somali, refers to the five regions of Greater Somalia. Somaliland was formerly the British Somaliland Protectorate. Shortly after British Somaliland became independent, it merged with Italian Somaliland to form Somalia in 1960.

Indium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol In and atomic number 49. It is a post-transition metal that makes up 0.21 ppm of the earth's crust. Indium is very soft and malleable, having a higher melting point than sodium and gallium, but lower than lithium and tin. Chemically, indium is similar to gallium and thallium, and most of its properties fall between gallium and thallium. Indium was discovered in 1863 by Ferdinand Reich and Hieronym Theodor Richter by spectroscopic method. They named it after the indigo line in its spectrum. Indium was isolated the following year. Indium is a minor component in zinc sulfide ores and is produced as a by-product of zinc refining. The metal is used primarily in the semiconductor industry, in low melting point alloys such as solder, in high pressure vacuum sealers, and in the production of transparent indium tin oxide (ITO) conductive coatings on glass. Indium has no biological role, although its compounds are mildly toxic when injected into the bloodstream. Most of the occupational exposure is through ingestion, which absorbs indium compounds less well, and inhalation, which absorbs quite well. Indium is a very ductile silvery-white post-transition metal with a bright luster. It is very soft (Mohs hardness 1.2) like sodium, and can be cut with a knife. It also leaves visible lines on the paper. It is a member of group 13 on the periodic table and its properties lie mostly between that of its vertical neighbours, gallium and thallium. Like lead, a high-pitched screeching sound is heard when indium is bent – ​​the crackling sound caused by twinkling of crystals. Like gallium, indium is able to wet glass. Like the two, indium has a low melting point, 156.60°C (313.88°F); higher than its lighter homologue, gallium, but lower than its heavier homologue, thallium, and lower than tin.

Its boiling point is 2072°C (3762°F), higher than that of thallium, but lower than that of gallium, in contrast to the general melting point trend, but decreasing trend with the other post-transition metal groups due to the weak metallic bond with few delocalized electrons. The density of indium is 7.31 g/cm3, greater than that of gallium, but lower than that of thallium. Below the critical temperature, 3.41 K, indium becomes a superconductor. At standard temperature and pressure, indium crystallizes in a face-centered tetragonal crystal system in the space group I4/mmm (lattice parameters: a = 325 pm, c = 495 pm): this is a slightly distorted en:face-centered cubic structure, where each indium atom has four neighbors at a distance of 324 pm and eight neighbors slightly further away (336 pm). Indium displays a ductile viscoplastic response, which is found to be size independent of tension and compression. However, it has a size effect in bending and indentation, associated with a length scale at the 50–100 μm level, relatively large when compared to other metals. Indium has 49 electrons, with the electron configuration Kr]4d105s25p1. In compounds, indium most often donates its three outer electrons to indium(III), In3+. In some cases, the 5s electron pair is not donated, resulting in indium(I), In+. The stabilization of the monovalent state is related to the inert pair effect, whereas a relativistic effect stabilizes the 5s orbital, which is observed in the heavier elements. Thallium (the heavier homologue of indium) exhibits a stronger effect, making oxidation to thallium(I) more probable than to thallium(III), whereas gallium (the lighter homologue of indium) usually exhibits only the +3 oxidation state. Thus, although thallium(III) is a moderately strong oxidizing agent, indium(III) is not, and indeed many indium(I) compounds are strong reducing agents.

Ketapang or katapang (Terminalia catappa) is the name of a type of shady seaside tree. Fast growing and forming a beautiful terraced canopy, ketapang is often used as a shade tree in parks and roadsides. In addition to the name ketapang with various dialect variations (for example Bat. : hatapang; Nias: katafa; Mink. : katapiĕng; Teupah: lahapang; Tim. : ketapas; Bug. : rooftop; etc.), this tree also has many names such as talisei, tarisei, salrisé (North Sulawesi); tiliso, tiliho, ngusu (North Maluku); sarisa, sirisa, sirisal, sarisalo (Mal. ); lisa (Rotes); kalis, kris (West Papua); etc. In English this plant is known by the names Bengal almond, Indian almond, Malabar almond, Singapore almond, Tropical almond, Sea almond, Beach almond, Talisay tree, Umbrella tree, and others. Large tree, up to 40 m high and with a trunk up to 1.5 m. Shady crown with branches that grow horizontally and terraced; Young trees often look like pagodas. Old and large trees are often buttressed (root boards), up to 3 m high. The leaves are scattered, most of them are crowded at the ends of the branches, short-stemmed or almost sitting. Inverted ovate leaf blade, 8–25(–38) x 5–14(–19) cm, with broad tip with a sharp tapering and narrow base, blade at base heart shape, base with glands on either side of midrib on the down side. Strands like skin, smooth on the top, fuzzy on the underside; redness if it will fall out. The flowers are small, collected in spikes near the ends of the branches, 8–25 cm long, green and yellow. Uncrowned flowers, with 5-cup petals, plate or bell shape, 4–8 mm, white or cream. Stamens in 2 whorls, arranged five-five.

Flat ovoid stone fruit, narrow-sided or winged, 2.5–7 x 4–5.5 cm, green-yellow-red, or reddish purple when ripe. Ketapang is a plant native to Southeast Asia and is commonly found in this region, except in Sumatra and Kalimantan which are rather rare in nature. This tree is commonly grown in northern Australia and Polynesia; likewise in India, Pakistan, Madagascar, East and West Africa, Central America, and South America. This tree is suitable for coastal and lowland climates up to an altitude of about 400 m asl. ; rainfall between 1,000–3,500 mm per year, and dry months for up to 6 months. Ketapang sheds its leaves up to twice a year, so it can withstand the dry months. The cork-coated fruit can float in river and sea water for months before growing in a suitable place. The fruit is also dispersed by bats. Its bark and leaves are used by people to tan leather, as a black dye, and also to make ink. Papagan produces a yellow-brown to olive color, and contains 11–23% tannins; while the leaves contain 12 kinds of tannins which can be hydrolyzed. Meanwhile, it is a popular belief among ornamental fish enthusiasts that placing dried ketapang leaves in the aquarium, especially betta fish (Betta spp.), can improve the health and extend the life of the fish. Ketapang leaves can lower the pH level of water, absorb toxins in water, lighten the color of betta fish and also treat wounds on betta fish after spawning. moderately hard and resilient, but not very durable. This wood is known in the trade as red-brown terminalia, and is used as a floor covering or veneer.

The Vajjis (Sanskrit: Vṛji) or Vrijji were a confederation and one of the main mahājanapadas of Ancient India. Both the Buddhist text, the Anguttara Nikaya and the Jaina religious text, the Bhagavati Sutra (I xv Uddesa I) include the Vajji in their lists of solasa (sixteen) mahājanapada. This mahājanapada name comes from one of its ruling clan, the Vṛjis. The region they ruled was the area in Mithila. The Vajji state is indicated as a republic. This clan is mentioned by Pāṇini, Chanakya, and Xuanzang. The Vajji region lies to the north of the Ganges and extends to the Madhesh region of Nepal. To the west, the Gandaki River may have been the boundary between the Vajji and mahājanapada Malla and may also have separated it from the mahājanapada of Kosala. To the east, its territory probably extended into the forests along the banks of the Koshi and Mahananda rivers. The capital of this mahājanapada is Vaishali. Other important towns and villages are Kundapura or Kundagrama (a suburb of Vaishali), Bhoganagara, and Hatthigama. The Vajji rulers were a confederation of eight clans (atthakula) of which the Vajjians, Licchavi, Jñatrika and Videha were the most important. Manudeva was a famous king of the Licchavi who wanted Amrapali after he saw Amrapali dancing at the Vaishali. The identities of the other four clans are uncertain. However, in one passage of the Sutrakritanga, the Ugra, Bhoga, Kaurava, and Aikshvaka are related to the Jñatri and Licchavi as subjects of the same ruler and members of the same assembly. Known as the Vajji Sangha "Vajji Confederation", the Vajjians consist of janapada, grama (village), and gostha (group). Dignitaries are selected from each khanda (district) as representatives for the Vajji gana parishad "council of the Vajjians".

Rain is a liquid form of precipitation, in contrast to non-liquid precipitation such as snow, hail and slit. Rain requires the presence of a thick layer of the atmosphere to meet temperatures near and above the surface of the Earth above the melting point of ice. On Earth, rain is the process of condensing water vapor in the atmosphere into water droplets that are heavy enough to fall and usually reach land. Two processes that may occur simultaneously can push the air to become more saturated before it rains, namely cooling the air or adding water vapor to the air. Virga is precipitation that falls on Earth but evaporates before reaching land; this is one way of saturating the air. Precipitation is formed by the collision of water droplets or ice crystals with clouds. Raindrops range in size from squares, like pancakes (large grains), to small balls (small grains). Moisture moving along three-dimensional zones of temperature and humidity differences called weather fronts is the main method of making rain. If at that time there is sufficient moisture and upward movement, rain will fall from convective clouds (clouds with strong upward movement) such as cumulonimbus (thunderstorms) which can collect into narrow rainbands. In mountainous areas, heavy rain may occur if the up-valley flow increases on the windward side to an elevation that forces moist air to condense and fall as rain along the mountainside. On the leeward side of mountains, desert climates can exist due to dry air caused by down-valley flows which warm and dry the air masses. The movement of the monsoon trough, or intertropical convergence zone, brings monsoons to savannah climates.

Rain is the main source of fresh water in most areas of the world, providing conditions suitable for a variety of ecosystems, as well as water for hydroelectric power generation and farm irrigation. Rainfall is calculated using a rain gauge. The amount of rainfall is calculated actively by weather radar and passively by weather satellites. The urban heat island effect drives an increase in rainfall in amount and intensity below the urban wind. Global warming can also cause changes in rain patterns around the world, including a rainy climate in eastern North America and a dry climate in the tropics. Rain is a major component in the water cycle and the main provider of fresh water on the planet. The global average annual rainfall is 990 millimeters (39 in). Clustering systems such as the Köppen climate clustering system use annual average rainfall to help distinguish climate regions. Antarctica is the driest continent on Earth. In other areas, rain has also fallen containing methane, iron, neon and sulfuric acid. Air contains water vapor and the amount of water in the mass of dry air, called the Mixing Ratio, is measured in grams of water per kilogram of dry air (g/kg). The amount of moisture in the air is also referred to as relative humidity; i.e. the percentage of total water vapor air can hold at a given air temperature. The amount of water vapor that the air can hold before it becomes moist (100% relative humidity) and forms clouds (a small, visible collection of water and ice particles suspended above the Earth's surface) depends on its temperature. Hotter air has more water vapor than cool air before it becomes humidified. Therefore, the only way to humidify the air is to cool it. The dew point is the temperature reached by cooling the air to humidify the air.

Lhasa (拉萨市) is a prefecture-level city, one of the main administrative divisions of the Tibet Autonomous Region, China. Lhasa covers 29,274 square kilometers (11,303 mi) of rugged and sparsely populated terrain. Its capital and largest city is Chengguan, with about 300,000 residents, most of which correspond to the administration of the Chengguan District, while its suburbs extend to Doilungdêqên District and Dagzê District. The consolidated prefecture-level cities contain an additional five counties, mostly rural. The city limits are roughly the same as the basin of the Lhasa River, a major tributary of the Yarlung Tsangpo River. Lhasa is located on the Lhasa terran, the last unit of Earth's crust to ossify onto the Eurasian plate before the Indian sub-continent collided with Asia about 50 million years ago and pushed up the Himalayas. High Terran, contains complex and tectonically active fault patterns. Temperatures are generally warm in summer and rise above freezing on sunny days in winter. Most of the rain falls in summer. The northern highlands and prairie areas are used for grazing yaks, sheep and goats, while the river valleys support agriculture with crops such as barley, wheat and vegetables. Wildlife is not abundant, but includes the rare snow leopard and black-necked heron. Mining has caused several environmental problems. The 2000 census gave a total population of 474,490, of whom 387,124 were ethnic Tibetans. The Han population at that time was mainly concentrated in urban areas. The prefecture-level city is served by two major highways and by the Qinghai-Tibet Railway, which terminates in the city of Lhasa. Two large dams on the Lhasa River generate hydroelectric power, as do many smaller dams and the Yangbajain Geothermal Field.

A bank (Indonesian pronunciation: bang]) is an intermediary financial institution that is generally established with the authority to accept deposits, lend money, and issue promissory notes. The word bank comes from the Italian banca which means a place where money is exchanged. Meanwhile, according to the banking law, a bank is a business entity that collects funds from the public in the form of savings and distributes them to the public in the form of credit and/or other forms in order to improve the standard of living of the common people. At first, the bank was a group of traders who would provide seed loans to farmers or traders who brought goods. The banking industry has undergone major changes in recent years. The industry has become more competitive due to regulatory deregulation. Currently, banks have flexibility in the services offered, the location in which they operate, and the rates paid as deposits by depositors. Banks can be interpreted as business entities that collect funds from the public in the form of savings and distribute them to the public in the form of credit or other forms in order to improve the standard of living of the people at large. Digitalization has also disrupted the banking sector by looking at the transition from distribution networks: branch offices (physical), telephone banking services (analog), internet services and mobile banking (digital). Etymologically, the word "bank" comes from the French banque or the Italian banca which means bench. Florentine bankers during the Renaissance carried out their transactions sitting behind a money exchange counter, as opposed to most people's jobs which did not allow them to sit down and work. According to Law Number 7 of 1992 concerning Banking as amended by Law Number 10 of 1998, a bank is a business entity that collects funds from the public in the form of savings and distributes them to the community in order to improve the standard of living of the common people.

The banking business includes three activities, namely collecting funds, channeling funds, and providing other banking services. Activities to collect and distribute funds are the main activities of the bank, while providing other bank services are only supporting activities. Fundraising activities, in the form of collecting funds from the public in the form of demand deposits, savings and time deposits. Usually while being given attractive remuneration such as flowers and gifts as a stimulus for the community. Activities channeling funds, in the form of lending to the community. Meanwhile, other banking services are provided to support the smooth running of these main activities. Some of the benefits of banking in life are: Apart from the main banking (bank) functions or their derivatives, what needs to be considered for the world of banking is the philosophical purpose of the existence of banks in Indonesia. This is very clearly reflected in Article four (4) of Law Number 10 of 1998 which explains, "Indonesian Banking aims to support the implementation of national development in the context of increasing equity, economic growth, and national stability towards increasing the welfare of the people at large." Taking a deeper look at the business activities of banks, Indonesian banks (banks) in conducting their business must be based on the principle of economic democracy which uses the principle of prudence. This is necessary because philosophically banks have macro and micro functions in the process of nation building. The bank was first established in the form of a firm in general in 1690, when the British Empire was willing to plan to rebuild its naval strength to compete with the French naval power but the British government at that time did not have the funding capability then based on the idea of ​​William Paterson who later by Charles Montagu was realized by establishing a financial intermediary institution which was finally able to fulfill the funding in just twelve days.

The Industrial Revolution occurred in the period between 1760-1850 where massive changes occurred in agriculture, manufacturing, mining, transportation and technology and had a profound impact on social, economic and cultural conditions in the world. This revolution led to massive developments that occurred in all aspects of human life. In short, the industrial revolution is a time when human work in various fields begins to be replaced by machines. The Industrial Revolution started in Great Britain and then spread throughout Western Europe, North America, Japan, and spread throughout the world. The Industrial Revolution marked a major turning point in world history, almost every aspect of daily life was affected by the Industrial Revolution, particularly in terms of the continuous and unprecedented increase in population growth and average income. During the two centuries following the Industrial Revolution, the average per capita income of countries in the world increased by more than six times. As Nobel Prize winner Robert Emerson Lucas stated: "For the first time in history, the standard of living of ordinary people has experienced sustained growth. This kind of economic behavior is unprecedented." England provided the legal and cultural foundation that enabled entrepreneurs to start the Industrial Revolution. The key factors that contributed to the occurrence of the Industrial Revolution included: (1) A period of peace and stability followed by the unification of England and Scotland, (2) there were no barriers to trade between England and Scotland, (3) the rule of law (respecting the sanctity of contracts), (4) a simple legal system that allows the formation of joint stock companies (corporations), and (5) the existence of a free market (capitalism). The Industrial Revolution began at the end of the 18th century, where there was a shift in the use of labor in England which previously used animal and human power, which was then replaced by the use of manufacturing-based machines.

The initial period began with the mechanization of the textile industry, the development of iron-making techniques and the increased use of coal. Trade expansion was also developed by building canals, improving roads and railroads. The transition from an agriculture-based economy to a manufacturing-based economy led to massive population movements from villages to cities, and ultimately led to a swell in the population of the major cities in England. The origins of the Industrial Revolution are still debated. T.S. Ashton wrote about 1760-1830. There is no point of separation from the Second Industrial Revolution around 1850, when technological and economic advances gained momentum with the development of steam-powered ships, railroads, and later in the century the development of the internal combustion engine and the development of electric power. The factor behind the Industrial Revolution was the scientific revolution in the 16th century with the emergence of scientists such as Francis Bacon, René Descartes, Galileo Galilei. Besides that, it is accompanied by the development of research and research with the establishment of research institutions such as The Royal Improving Knowledge, The Royal Society of England, and The French Academy of Science. There are also internal factors, such as domestic political resilience, the development of entrepreneurial activities, the British empire being vast and rich in natural resources. The term "Industrial Revolution" itself was introduced by Friedrich Engels and Louis-Auguste Blanqui in the mid-19th century. Some 20th century historians such as John Clapham and Nicholas Crafts have argued that the process of gradual economic and social change and long-term revolution is ironic. The gross domestic product (GDP) per capita of countries in the world increased after the Industrial Revolution and gave rise to the modern capitalist economic system. The Industrial Revolution marked the start of an era of growing per capita income and a growing capitalist economy.

Compost is the result of partial/incomplete decomposition of a mixture of organic materials which can be accelerated artificially by a population of various kinds of microbes in warm, humid, and aerobic or anaerobic environmental conditions (Modification from J.H. Crawford, 2003). Meanwhile, composting is a process in which organic matter undergoes biological decomposition, especially by microbes that utilize organic matter as an energy source. Making compost is regulating and controlling this natural process so that compost can be formed more quickly. This process includes making a balanced mixture of ingredients, providing sufficient water, setting aeration, and adding composting activators. Compost can be used as organic mulch for small pieces of land cover, peat can also be processed into compost, compost can contain or become humus after it decomposes. Garbage consists of two parts, namely organic and inorganic parts. The average percentage of waste organic matter reaches ±80%, so composting is an appropriate alternative for handling. Compost has the potential to be developed considering the increasing amount of organic waste that is disposed of in landfills and causes odor pollution and the release of methane gas into the air. DKI Jakarta produces 6000 tons of waste every day, of which about 65% is organic waste. And of that amount, 1400 tons are produced by all markets in Jakarta, where 95% is organic waste. Seeing the amount of organic waste generated by the community, there is potential to process organic waste into organic fertilizer for environmental sustainability and community welfare (Rohendi, 2005). Naturally organic materials will experience decomposition in nature with the help of microbes and other soil biota. However, the composting process that occurs naturally takes a long time and is slow. To speed up the composting process, many composting technologies have been developed.

Good composting with simple technology, medium, and high technology. In principle, the development of composting technology is based on the process of decomposing organic matter that occurs naturally. The decomposition process is optimized in such a way that composting can run more quickly and efficiently. Composting technology is currently very important, especially to overcome the problem of organic waste, such as to overcome the problem of waste in big cities, industrial organic waste, as well as agricultural and plantation waste. There are various technologies for composting waste, both aerobically and anaerobically, with or without a composting activator. Composting activators that have been widely circulated include: PROMI (Promoting Microbes), OrgaDec, SuperDec, ActiComp, BioPos, EM4, Green Phoskko Organic Decomposer and SUPERFARM (Effective Microorganism) or using worms to obtain compost (vermicompost). Each activator has its own advantages. Aerobic composting is the most widely used, because it is easy and cheap to do, and does not require too difficult process control. The decomposition of the material is carried out by microorganisms within the material itself with the help of air. Meanwhile, anaerobic composting utilizes microorganisms that do not require air to degrade organic matter. The end result of this composting is a much needed material for the benefit of agricultural lands in Indonesia, as an effort to improve the chemical, physical and biological properties of the soil, so that crop production becomes higher. Compost produced from composting waste can be used to strengthen the structure of critical land, re-fertilize agricultural land, re-fertilize gardening soil, as a cover material for landfill waste, post-mining beach reclamation, and as a planting medium, and reduce the use of chemical fertilizers. Composting raw materials are all materials that contain carbon and nitrogen, such as animal manure, forage waste, municipal waste, liquid sludge and agricultural industrial waste.

Cartography ( /kɑːrˈtɒɡrəfi/; derived from the Greek chartes χάρτης, "papyrus, sheet of paper, map", and graphein γράφειν, "to write") is the study and art of making and studying maps. Cartography combines science, aesthetics, and engineering, to be able to suggest that reality (or imagined reality) can be modeled in a way that communicates spatial information effectively. The basic goals of traditional cartography are to: Modern cartography is a theoretical and practical foundation of geographic information systems and geographic information science. There is still debate about what exactly the earliest maps were made of, both because the term "map" is not well defined and because some artefacts that may be maps may actually be something else. A fresco possibly depicting the ancient Anatolian city of Çatalhöyük (formerly known as Catal Huyuk or Çatal Hüyük) has been dated to the late 7th millennium BC. Among the prehistoric alpine rock carvings of Mount Bego (France) and Valcamonica (Italy), dating from the 4th millennium BC, geometric patterns consisting of dotted and dashed rectangles are widely interpreted in archaeological literature as depicting cultivating plots. Other known maps of the ancient world include the Minoan fresco "House of the Admiral" from c. 1600 BC, showing seaside communities in oblique perspective, and engraved map of the sacred Babylonian city of Nippur, from the Kassite period (14th–12th century BC). The oldest surviving world map comes from Babylon in the 9th century BC. One of them shows Babylon on the Euphrates, surrounded by Assyria, Urartu and several cities, all of them, in turn, surrounded by a "bitter river" (Oceanus). Others describe Babylon as north of the center of the world.

The ancient Greeks and Romans made maps from the time of Anaximander in the 6th century BC. In the 2nd century AD, Ptolemy wrote his treatise on cartography, Geographia. This book contains maps of the world of Ptolemy, or Western society now knows it as the Oikumene. In the early 8th century, Arab scholars translated the works of Greek geographers into Arabic. In ancient China, geographic literature dates back to the 5th century BC. The oldest extant map of China is from the State of Qin, made in the 4th century BC during the Age of Warring States period in the book Xin Yi Xiang Fa Yao published in 1092 by the Chinese scientist Su Song, in the form of a star map on the equidistant cylinder projection. Although this method of charting seems to have existed in China even before the publication of this scientist, the greatest significance of Su Song's star charts is that they represent the oldest existing star charts in printed form. Early forms of Indian cartography included the depiction of the polar star and the constellations around it. This chart may have been used for navigation. Mappae mundi ("world map") is a world map of medieval Europe. About 1,100 places are known to have survived: of these, 900 are found in manuscript illustrations and the rest are found in documents. There were three main functions of maps during the Renaissance: Referring to the medium used to transfer images onto paper, there were two types of printmaking techniques during the Renaissance, namely woodcut and copper plate intaglio. Letters in making maps are important to show information. Smooth lettering was difficult in woodcut, as they often turned into squares and squares, as opposed to the round style of writing that was popular in Italy at the time.

Animism (from the Latin anima or "spirit") is the belief in spirits and spirits which is the basis of religious belief that first appeared among early humans. Animistic beliefs believe that every object on this Earth (such as certain areas, caves, trees or large rocks), has a soul that must be respected so that the spirit does not disturb humans. Apart from the souls and spirits that inhabit the places mentioned above, animist beliefs also believe that the spirits of people who have died can enter the bodies of animals. The spirits of people who have died can also enter the bodies of pigs or tigers and are believed to take revenge on people who have become sworn enemies during their lifetime. In fact, it is believed to be hereditary. This belief is different from the belief in reincarnation as found in Hinduism and Buddhism, where in reincarnation, the soul does not move directly into the body of another living animal, but through a process of being reborn into the world in a new form of life. In Hinduism and Buddhism there is also the concept of the law of karma which is different from this animist belief. The term "animism" comes from the Latin word anima or animae. This word means breath or spirit. The development of the concept of animism is the existence of a soul or spirit in every living and inanimate object. This existence then made the animist consort glorify objects. The purpose of this breeding is so that these objects do not disturb humans, but provide good luck. In animism, every object is believed to be able to provide benefits and help. Abrahamism Akosmism Agnosticism Animism Anti-religion Atheism Dharmism Deism Dualism Esotericism Feminist theology Gnosticism Henotheism Humanism Immanenke Monism Monotheism Mysticism Naturalism Nondualism Pandeism Pantheism Polytheism Process Theology Shamanism · Taoist · Theism · Transcendent · New Age This article on the topic of religion or belief is a stub.

Iran (Persian: ایران), officially the Islamic Republic of Iran and also known as Persia, is a country located in Southwest Asia. Although this country has been known locally as "Iran" since ancient times, until 1935 Iran was still referred to as "Persia" in the Western world. In 1959, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi announced that both terms could be used. The name Iran is a word "Aryan" which means "Land of the Aryans". Iran is bordered by Azerbaijan (500 km) and Armenia (35 km) to the northwest, the Caspian Sea to the north, Turkmenistan (1,000 km) to the northeast, Pakistan (909 km) and Afghanistan (936 km) to the east, Turkey (500 km) ) and Iraq (1,458 km) to the west, and the waters of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman to the south. In 1979, an Iranian Revolution led by Ayatollah Khomeini established an Islamic Theocratic Republic so that the current full name of Iran is "Islamic Republic of Iran" (جمهوری اسلامی ایران). Iran is a multicultural country that has many ethnic groups and languages. Persian (61%), Azerbaijani (16%), Kurdish (10%) and Lorestan (6%). From historical writings, the first Iranian civilization was Proto-Iranian, followed by the Elamite civilization. In the second, and third millennia, the Aryans emigrated to Iran, establishing Iran's first empire, the Median Empire (728-550 B.C.). This empire has become a founding symbol of the nation, and also the empire of Iran, which was followed by the Achaemenid Empire (648–330 BC) founded by Cyrus the Great. Cyrus the Great is also notable for being the first government to enact legislation regarding human rights, inscribed on an artifact known as the Cylinder of Cyrus. He was also the first ruler to use the title Supreme, and was also the Shah of Iran.

In his time, slavery was prohibited in the areas he conquered (also known as the Persian Empire.) This idea later had a great impact on human civilizations after his time. The Persian Empire was then ruled by Cambyses for seven years (531-522 AD), and his death was followed by a power struggle where Darius the Great (522-486 AD) was finally declared king. The Persian capital at the time of Darius I was moved to Susa, and he began to build Persepolis. A canal between the Nile River, and the Red Sea was also built, and made it a forerunner to the development of the Suez Canal. The road system was also renewed, and a road was built connecting Susa, and Sardis. This road is known as Jalan Kerajaan. In addition, coins in the form of darics (gold coins), and also Shekels (silver coins) were introduced to the whole world. Old Persian was also introduced, and published in royal inscriptions. Under the rule of Cyrus the Great and Darius the Great, the Persian Empire became the largest and strongest empire in the world at that time. His main achievement was being the first great empire to practice tolerance, and respect other cultures and religions in its colonies. Parthia began with the unifying Arsacid Dynasty, and ruled the Iranian plateau, which also conquered eastern Greece in the early third century AD, as well as Mesopotamia between 150 BC, and 224 AD. Parthia was also a sworn enemy of Rome in the east, and limit the Roman danger in Anatolia. The Parthian army was divided into two groups of cavalry, the armored cavalry, and carrying heavy weapons, and the lightly armed cavalry, whose horses were agile in movement. Meanwhile, the Roman army relied too much on infantry, making it difficult for the Romans to defeat the Parthians.

in Europe  (grey) North Macedonia (Macedonian: Република Северна Македонија, Republika Severna Makedonija) or Republic of North Macedonia (Macedonian: Република Северна Македонија; Albanian: Republika e Maqedonisë së Veriut)), is a country located on the peninsula Balkans, Southern Europe. The country is bordered by Serbia and Kosovo to the north, Albania to the west, Greece to the south and Bulgaria to the east. The country has been called the "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" (English: Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia) by the United Nations since 1993 pending resolution of the naming dispute with Greece. Many international institutions and other countries have recognized this country with the same name, although the majority of countries recognize this country with a constitutional name. Only since February 12 2019, the Republic of Macedonia officially changed its name to the Republic of North Macedonia, ending the name dispute. The Republic of North Macedonia covers 35.8% of the territory and 40.9% of the population of Macedonia. The capital is Skopje, which had a population of 506,926 in 2004. The country has several smaller cities, such as Bitola, Kumanovo, Prilep, Tetovo, Ohrid, Veles, Štip, Kočani, Gostivar and Strumica. In North Macedonia, there are more than 50 natural lakes and reservoirs, and it also has sixteen mountains that are over 2,000 meters above sea level. The country is a member of the United Nations, NATO and the Council of Europe; as well as a member of La Francophonie, the World Trade Organization (WTO), and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Since December 2005, this country has been a candidate for membership in the European Union. The first state to rule over the Macedonian area was the kingdom of Paionia, which ruled over the Axius river valley and surrounding areas. In 336 BC, King Phillip II of Macedon conquered the southernmost part of Paeonia and founded the city of Heraclea Lisentis, now near Bitola.

Philip II's son, Alexander the Great, controlled the Macedonian area which was still under the hands of Paionia, and later became part of Alexander the Great's kingdom. The Macedonian area was later controlled by the Roman army and became part of the two Roman provinces. The larger area was in the Macedonian province of Salutaris, but the northern border area inhabited by the Dardani became part of the province of Moesia Superior. In 400 AD, the Paeonians lost their identity and Paeonia is now a geographical term. At the end of the 6th century, as Byzantine power began to weaken, a number of Slavic tribes began to enter and occupy Macedonian territory. The Slavic tribes that occupy Macedonian territory include the Draguvite, Sagudate, and Strymonoi tribes. Some of the native Macedonian tribes, due to the arrival of the Slavs, began to move to settle new areas in the mountains and in the fortified areas around Greece. However, some of the native Macedonian tribes also assimilated with the Slavs. These Slavs then grouped themselves together, where this group was named by the Byzantines as "Σκλαβινίαι" (Sklaviniai). Byzantium, which initially had less power, began to cooperate with the Slavs who lived in Macedonia. Later, Justinian II undertook a military expedition throughout Macedonia to pacify and enlist the Macedonian Slavs to cooperate with the Byzantines. After this expedition, many Slavs in Macedonia moved to Anatolia to become part of the army of the Byzantine Empire. Although many Slavic peoples were subject to Byzantine rule, many tribes were still free from Byzantine rule. These tribes live separately, and do not create a power that unites the tribes. Around 850 AD, the First Bulgarian Kingdom invaded Macedonian territory and it went very smoothly, because the Byzantine power in Macedonia was very weak and also influenced by the willingness of the Slavic tribes to join the Bulgarian First Kingdom.

arXiv (pronounced "ar-kay-f" (archive), because the "X" here stands for the Greek letter Chi, χ) is an electronic preprint repository (often called an electronic preprint) of scientific papers in the fields of mathematics, physics, astronomy, computer science , quantitative biology, statistics, and quantitative finance, which can be accessed online. In various fields of mathematics and physics, almost all of his scientific papers are self-archived on arXiv. arXiv.org was started on August 14, 1991 and managed to print the 500,000th article on October 3, 2008. In 2014, the publication rate increased to 8,000 papers per month. As of October 2016, paper submissions have increased to over 10,000 papers per month. TeX's compact file format makes arXiv possible, making it easy to send scientific papers over the internet and display to clients. Initially arXiv covered only preprint physics, but soon expanded to include astronomy, mathematics, computer science, quantitative biology, and statistics. The original domain name is xxx.lanl.gov. However, in 2001 the repository was renamed to arXiv.org. Its existence is one of the triggering factors that gave birth to a movement in scientific publishing known as open access. Mathematicians and scientists regularly upload their papers to arXiv.org for worldwide access and sometimes for review prior to publication in peer-reviewed journals. The annual budget for arXiv was approximately $826,000 from 2013 to 2017, funded jointly by Cornell University Libraries, the Simons Foundation (in the form of gifts and grants) and annual fee revenues from member institutions. This model emerged in 2010, when Cornell sought to expand project financial funding by requiring agencies to make annual voluntary contributions based on the number of downloads used by each institution.

Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius was a Roman philosopher. He was born in Rome around 480. Boethius had served as a high official under Emperor Theodoric. He was accused of being a traitor and then sent into exile. Finally, Boethius was executed in 525. Boethius' ideas had an important influence on philosophy at the end of the Classical era and also at the beginning of the Middle Ages. Moreover, Boethius' translations and comments on Aristotle's works also greatly influenced the entire subsequent history of philosophy. Boethius' most famous work is entitled "On the Consolation of Philosophy" which was written while he was in exile. The content of the work is a reflection on the nature of human happiness, as well as on the problem of crime. Apart from that, the work also discusses themes such as destiny, chance, human free will, and so on. Boethius wrote papers on Christian theology, supporting Catholicism and opposing Arianism and other heterodox forms of Christianity. Five recognized theological works: His theological works played an important role in Medieval philosophical thought, including the areas of logic, ontology, and metaphysics. "The Boethian Wheel" is a model for Boethius' belief that history is a wheel, which Boethius often uses in his Consolation. This style was very popular throughout the Middle Ages, and is still frequently seen today. When the wheel turns, those who have power and wealth will turn to dust; people can rise from poverty and hunger to become great people, while great people will fall with the turning of the wheel. In the Middle Ages many depicted in art relics depicting the rise and fall of man. Descriptions of the "Wheel of Boethius" can be found in Medieval writings from Romance of the Rose to Chaucer.

Supercomputers are computers that lead the world in processing capacity, especially computing speed, at the time of their introduction. Supercomputer performance is usually measured in floating point operations per second (FLOPS). Since 2017, there have been supercomputers that can do 1017 FLOPS (i.e. one hundred dwiyar FLOPS, or 100 petaFLOPS). As of November 2017, every supercomputer from the TOP500 uses a Linux-based operating system. As of June 2018, the combined speed of the supercomputers listed in the TOP500 is over 1 exaFLOPS. As of 2022, Fugaku in Japan is the fastest supercomputer in the world. Supercomputers are used for computation-intensive tasks such as weather forecasting, climate research (including global warming research, molecular capital, physical simulations (such as airplane aerodynamics, nuclear weapons detonation simulations, and nuclear fusion research), cryptographic analysis, etc. Military and science agencies one of the main users of supercomputers. Supercomputers are superior in speed to computers in ordinary homes by using an innovative cabinet-shaped design that allows them to multitask in parallel, as well as complex civil details. These computers are usually specialized for computation memory hierarchies are carefully designed to ensure the processor is still receiving data and instructions at all times; in fact, the difference in performance with a typical computer lies in the memory hierarchies and their components The I/O system is also designed to allow me support wide bandwidth. As with parallel systems in general, Amdahl's law applies, and supercomputers are designed to eliminate the drawbacks of serial arrays, and use the hardware of parallel systems to speed up from the drawbacks of tight bandwidth. The five fastest supercomputers out of the 500 fastest computers in the world according to the Top 500 (November 2020) are: This computer-related article is a stub.

148,940,000 km2 of land (29.2%) Earth is the third planet from the Sun, which is the densest and fifth largest of the eight planets in the Solar System. Earth is also the largest of the four terrestrial planets in the Solar System. Earth is sometimes called the world or the Blue Planet. Earth formed about 4.54 billion years ago, and life appeared on its surface at least 3.5 billion years ago. Earth's biosphere then gradually changed its atmosphere and other basic physical conditions, which allowed the proliferation of organisms and the formation of the ozone layer, which together with Earth's magnetic field blocks harmful solar radiation and allows microscopic living things to safely reproduce on land. The physical properties, geological history, and Earth's orbit make it possible for life to continue to exist. Earth's lithosphere is divided into a number of rigid segments, or tectonic plates, which move across the Earth's surface over millions of years. Over 70% of the Earth's surface is covered by water, and the remainder is made up of continents and islands which have many lakes and other water sources that contribute to the formation of the hydrosphere. Earth's poles are mostly covered in ice; solid ice in Antarctica and sea ice in the polar ice packs. The Earth's interior remains active, with an inner core composed of solid iron, a fluid outer core that creates a magnetic field, and a thick layer of relatively solid mantle. Earth interacts gravitationally with other objects in space, especially the Sun and Moon. When it orbits the Sun in one orbit, the Earth rotates on its axis 366.26 times, which creates 365.26 solar days or one sidereal year. note 7] The Earth's rotation on its axis is tilted 23.4° from the plane of the orbit, which causes seasonal differences on the Earth's surface with a period of one tropical year (365.24 solar days).

The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite, which began orbiting Earth about 4.53 billion years ago. The gravitational interaction between the Moon and Earth stimulates ocean tides, stabilizes the axial tilt, and gradually slows Earth's rotation. Earth is home to millions of living things, including humans. Earth's mineral resources and other biosphere products contribute to providing the resources to support the global human population. The regions of Earth inhabited by humans are grouped into 200 sovereign nations, which interact with each other through diplomacy, travel, trade, and military action. In modern English, the noun earth developed from the Middle English word erthe (recorded 1137), which is derived from the Old English eorthe (before 725), while the word itself is derived from the Proto-Germanic *erthō. Earth has cognates in all other Germanic languages, including Dutch aarde, German Erde, and Swedish, Danish, and Norwegian jord. Earth is a parable for the Germanic pagan goddess (or Jörð in Norse mythology, mother of the god Thor). In Indonesian, the word bumi comes from the Sanskrit bhumi, which means land, and is always written with a capital letter ("Earth"), to refer to planet Earth, while "earth" is lowercase to refer to the surface of the world, or land. Earth is classified as a terrestrial planet which generally consists of rocks, not a gas giant like Jupiter. Earth is the largest of the four terrestrial planets in terms of size and mass. Of the four planets, Earth is the planet with the highest density, highest surface gravity, strongest magnetic field, and fastest rotation, and is thought to be the only planet with active plate tectonics.

Liquids are incompressible fluids that conform to the shape of their container but maintain a (nearly) constant volume regardless of pressure. As such, it is one of the four basic states of matter (the others being solid, gas, and plasma), and is the only state with a definite volume but no fixed shape. Liquids consist of particles of matter with fine vibrations, such as atoms, held together by intermolecular forces. Water is, by far, the most common liquid on Earth. Like gases, liquids can flow and take the shape of their container. Most liquids are incompressible, although others are compressible. Unlike gases, liquids do not spread to fill every space of the container, and maintain a fairly constant density. A characteristic property of the liquid state is surface tension, which leads to the wetting phenomenon. The density of liquids is usually close to that of solids, and much higher than that of gases. Therefore, liquid and solid are both called condensed matter. On the other hand, since liquids and gases share the ability to flow, they are both called fluids. Although water is abundant on Earth, this state of matter is actually the least common in the known universe, because the existence of liquid requires a relatively narrow temperature/pressure range. Most known matter in the universe exists in the gaseous state (with detectable traces of dense matter) as interstellar clouds or in the plasma form within stars. Liquid is one of the four main states of matter, along with solid, gas and plasma. Fluid is fluid. Unlike solids, molecules in liquids have much greater freedom of movement. The forces that bind molecules together in solids are only temporary in liquids, allowing the liquid to flow while the solid remains rigid.

Liquids, like gases, display fluid properties. Liquids can flow, imagine the shape of a container, and if placed in a closed container, will distribute pressure evenly over every surface of the container. If the liquid is placed in the bag, it can be pressed into any shape. Unlike gases, liquids are nearly incompressible. It has a nearly constant volume over a wide pressure range; it does not expand to fill the empty space in a container but forms its own surface, and does not always mix easily with other liquids. This property makes the fluid suitable for applications such as hydraulics. The liquid particles are held together tightly but not rigidly. They are able to move freely, resulting in a limited degree of particle mobility. As the temperature increases, the molecular vibrations increase causing the distance between molecules to increase. When the liquid reaches its boiling point, the cohesive forces holding the molecules together are broken, and the liquid turns into a gas (unless superheating occurs). If the temperature drops, the distance between the molecules gets closer and closer. When a liquid reaches its freezing point, the molecules usually lock together into a specific order, which is called crystallization, and the bonds between them become more rigid, turning the liquid into its solid state (unless supercooling occurs). There are only two elements that are liquids at standard temperature and pressure: mercury and bromine. Four other elements have melting points just above room temperature: francium, cesium, gallium and rubidium. Metal alloys that are liquid at room temperature include NaK, sodium-potassium alloys, galinstan, and some amalgams (alloys involving mercury). Pure substances that are liquids under normal conditions include water, ethanol and many other organic solvents. Water is a vital fluid in chemistry and biology; it is believed to be a vital necessity for survival.

Canada, with the original name Dominion of Canada, is the northernmost country in the North American region. This kingdom (constitutional monarchy) is divided into 10 provinces and 3 territories, adhering to a decentralized system. Canada was founded in 1867, after the passing of the Confederation Act. Ottawa is the nation's capital. The offices of the Governor-General, the Prime Minister and the national parliament are located in the city. Canada was once a French colony; which was later captured by the British, until its independence day. Today, this country is a member of La Francophonie, as well as a British Commonwealth of Nations. Canada's area reaches 9,970,610 km². This country is classified as a developed country, whose economy depends on natural products. Canada is a constitutional monarchy, with a government that is a federal parliamentary democracy. King Charles III becomes head of state. Canada is one of the most ethnically and multiculturally diverse countries in the world. Immigrants in this country are relatively large, when compared to other countries. In addition, Canada's economy is the tenth largest in the world. Natural resources (which are abundant), and international trade networks are the main pillars of this country's economy. The long relationship with the United States has had a significant impact on the economy and culture of both countries. Canada is a developed country and has the fifteenth highest nominal per capita income and ranks tenth highest on the Human Development Index. It is among the highest in the human development index which consists of government transparency, civil liberties, quality of life, economic freedom, and education. Canada is a territory within the Commonwealth of Nations, a member of Francophonie, and part of several international and intergovernmental groupings and institutions including the United Nations, North Atlantic Treaty Organization, G7 (formerly G8), Group of Ten, G20, Free Trade Agreement North America and the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.

The name "Canada" is believed to come from the Huron-Iroquoia word Kanata, meaning "village", "settlement", or "collection of cottages". Canada has been inhabited by indigenous people (known in Canada as Canadians) for more than 40,000 years. A Scandinavian expedition visited it around 1000, staying briefly at what is known as L'Anse aux Meadows. British claims to North America began when John Cabot reached what he called "Newfoundland" in 1497. French claims began with the explorations of Jacques Cartier (from 1534), and Samuel de Champlain (from 1603). In 1604, the French settlers, who became known as Acadia, were the first Europeans to live permanently in Canada, followed by another French settlement in St. Lawrence, and the Canadian Atlantic area. British settlements existed along the Atlantic seaboard, and around Hudson Bay. With the expansion of the French and British colonies, and the war between the French and the British in Europe, the French and Indian Wars broke out four times from 1689 to 1763. In the Treaty of Paris of 1763, France ceded to Great Britain most of New France, including Acadia, and what made up Quebec, and Ontario today. Great Britain founded the colonies of Nova Scotia, Lower Canada, and Upper Canada. A new colony equal to the current statutory rights of the Provinces of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island was soon formed. Canadas working together form Canada. Cape Breton is joined to Nova Scotia. During, and after the American Revolution, many British Loyalists left the Thirteen Colonies to settle in Canada. Other settlers during this time from the boom came from Europe, especially the British Isles. In 1812, the War of 1812 began when the United States invaded Canada, in an attempt to further undermine the British Empire, fearing that it was under attack.

Irrigation or watering is an effort made by humans to irrigate agricultural land. In the modern world, there are currently many models of irrigation that can be done by humans. In ancient times, if the water supply was abundant because of a place close to a river or spring, irrigation was done by channeling the water to agricultural land. However, irrigation is also usually done by carrying water using a container and then pouring it on the plants one by one. For irrigation with this model in Indonesia it is usually called watering. As already stated, in the modern world there are many ways that can be done to do irrigation and this has been going on since Ancient Egypt. Since Ancient Egypt has been known to exploit the Nile River. In Indonesia, traditional irrigation has also been going on since our ancestors. This can also be seen in the way of farming during the kingdoms in Indonesia. By damming the river alternately to flow it into the rice fields. Another way is to look for mountain water sources and flow them with continuous bamboo. There are also carrying with a bucket made of areca leaves or drawing from the river thrown into the fields with buckets of areca leaves as well. The irrigation system was one of the Dutch efforts to implement Cultivation (Cultuurstelsel) in 1830. The Dutch East Indies Government in the Forced Cultivation endeavored that all land that was printed for rice fields and plantations must produce optimal harvests in exploiting the lands of their colonies. Irrigation systems that used to know primary, secondary, or tertiary channels. But the water source has not used the Multipurpose Reservoir system like TVA in the United States. Water in the old irrigation was channeled from river sources arranged in an integrated irrigation system, to fulfill rice field irrigation, where farmers were required to pay rent for the use of water for their rice fields.

The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) initiated by US President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1933 is one of the first Multi-Purpose Reservoirs built in the world. The economic recession (inflation) of 1930 hit the whole world, so TVA was a model for rebuilding the United States economy. TVA's issues are regarding: electric power production, navigation, flood control, malaria prevention, reforestation, and erosion control, so that in the future, the TVA Project will become one of the models in dealing with similar matters. Therefore, the Jatiluhur Reservoir Project is a nearly identical copy of the TVA in the US. Jatiluhur Reservoir is located in Jatiluhur District, Purwakarta Regency (± 9 km from the center of Purwakarta City). The dam was named by the government Waduk Ir. H. Juanda, with a panoramic view of the lake which covers 8,300 ha. This dam was built in 1957 by a contractor from France, with a potential available water of 12.9 billion m3/year and is the first multi-purpose dam in Indonesia. Surface Irrigation is the drainage of water above the surface with a water level of about 10 – 15 cm above the ground. Surface irrigation is an irrigation system that taps water directly into the river through a weir building or through a free intake building and then irrigation water is channeled by gravity through canals to agricultural land. Here known primary, secondary, and tertiary channels. Water regulation is done with a sluice gate. The process is gravity, high land will get water first. Primary Irrigation Channel This system water is distributed by means of piping. Here gravity also applies, where high land gets water first. However, the water that is distributed is only limited once or locally.

Tin (or tin) is a chemical element in the periodic table. is also in group 14 and has two possible oxidation numbers, the slightly more stable +2 and +4. Tin is the 49th most abundant element on earth, having 10 stable isotopes, the largest number in the periodic table. This element is a poor metal (post-transition metal) silvery, malleable, not easily oxidized in air so it is rust resistant, found in many alloys, and used to coat other metals to prevent rust. Tin is obtained mainly from the mineral cassiterite which is formed as an oxide. Tin ore mined in Indonesia generally comes from alluvial tin deposits and is often referred to as secondary tin deposits or called placer tin. This type of tin ore has been separated from its parent precipitate, namely primary tin, and is deposited back in another, lower place by water. Economically, the tin-producing mineral is cassiterite with the chemical formula SnO2, although a small amount of tin is produced from sulfides such as stanit, cylindrite, frankeite, kanfieldite and thealite. The main mineral contained in tin ore is cassiterite, while the accompanying minerals are pyrite. , quartz, zircon, ilmenite, galena, bismuth, arsenic, stibnite, chalcopyrite, xenotim and monazite. Broadly speaking, the processing of tin ore into tin metal consists of concentration/mineral dressing operations, and extraction, namely smelting or smelting and refining or refining. The tin ore concentration stage is an operation to increase tin levels using equipment such as a jig concentrator, palong and rocking table.

Processed tin ore has an initial grade of around 30 to 65 percent Sn. After going through the separation operation, the minimum tin content that must be achieved so that it can be used as feed for the first stage of smelting is 70 percent Sn. The smelting process is a reduction process of tin ore concentrate at high temperatures into tin metal. The principle of reduction is to release the oxygen bonds contained in the mineral cassiterite. The reducing agent used as a reducing agent is CO gas. The reaction that occurs during the smelting process is: SnO2 + CO = SnO + CO2 SnO + CO = Sn + CO2 In the smelting process, molten slag and tin are formed which do not dissolve in each other. Slag will bind the impurities contained in the concentrate. The most abundant impurity in tin concentrate is the Fe element. The smelting process consists of two stages. The first stage of smelting is tin concentrate smelting which produces crude tin and slag I (slag). The lead content in slag I is about 20 percent. This stage is also known as tin concentrate smelting because the feed that is melted is tin ore concentrate. Slag I is then melted again in the second stage of smelting. Smelting in this second stage produces Fe-Sn compounds called hardhead and slag II with a Sn content of less than one percent. Hardhead becomes the raw material for stage one smelting. Crude tin from the first smelting process is then taken to the next process, namely the refining process. The lead content in crude tin is Sn > 90 percent and the rest are impurities such as As, Pb, Ag, Fe, Cu, and Sb. Refining tin from impurities can be done by kettle refining, eutectic refining, and electrolytic refining.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Geology is a branch of earth science that studies the Earth and everything in it. The study in geology covers the history of the formation of the Earth along with the materials, structures and processes that accompany it. The scope of the object of study of geology ranges from something as small as an atom to something as large as a continent or ocean. Geological knowledge is used to meet various household needs, building construction, mining to engineering. People who study geology are called geologists. Geologists have been able to determine the age of the Earth which is estimated to be around 4.5 billion (4.5x109) years which can be mapped onto a geological time scale, and also found that the Earth's crust is breaking up into tectonic plates that move over the semi-molten mantle (asthenosphere) through a process called plate tectonics, besides that geologists help find and manage natural resources on earth, such as petroleum, coal, and also metals such as iron, copper, and uranium, as well as other minerals that have economic value, such as asbestos, perlite, mica, phosphate, zeolite, clay, pumice, quartz and silica, as well as other elements such as sulfur, chlorine and helium. Astrogeology is the application of geological science to the terrestrial planets or other natural satellites in the solar system. Other special terms such as selenology (study of the moon), areology (study of the planet Mars), and others.. The word "geology" was first used by Jean-André Deluc in 1778 and was introduced as a standard term by Horace-Bénédict de Saussure. The word "geology" is a word that comes from the Greek γη or geo which means "earth" and λογος or logos which means "word" or "reason". Historical geology discusses the history of the formation of the Earth along with the history of events that have occurred on the surface of the Earth.

Gypsum or gypsum is an example of a mineral with calcium levels dominating the mineral. The most commonly found gypsum is a type of calcium sulfate hydrate with the chemical formula CaSO4.2H2O. Gypsum is one of several volatile minerals. Other examples of these minerals are carbonates, borates, nitrates, and sulfates. These minerals are deposited in seas, lakes, caves and in salt seas due to the concentration of ions by evaporation. When the water is hot or water has a high salt content, the gypsum turns into basanite (CaSO4.H2O) or also becomes anhydrite (CaSO4). In a balanced state, gypsum above 108°F or 42°C in pure water will turn into anhydrite. The word Gypsum comes from the Greek verb μαγειρεύω, which means to cook. It is called cooking because in the Montmartre area, Paris, several centuries ago people burned gypsum for various purposes, and the material was then plastered with plaster from Paris. People in this area also use gypsum in foot creams, shampoos, and as other hair care products. Because gypsum is a mineral that does not dissolve in water for a long time, gypsum is rarely found in the form of granules or sand. But there is a unique incident at White Sands National Monument, in the state of New Mexico, USA, there is 710 km² of white gypsum sand which is enough as a raw material for the drywall industry for 1000 years. The largest gypsum crystal with a length of more than 10 meters was found in Naica, Chihuihua, Mexico.Gypsum is found in various regions of the world, namely Jamaica, Iran, Thailand, Spain (the largest gypsum producer in Europe), Germany, Italy, England, Ireland , Manitoba, Ontario, Canada, New York, Michigan, Indiana, Texas, Iowa, Kansas, Oklahoma, Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, Utah, Nevada, Paris, California, New South Wales, Borneo and West Java.

Gypsum generally has a group consisting of rock gypsum, alabaster gypsum, satin spar, and selenite. Gypsum can also be classified based on where it occurs, namely salt lake deposits, associated with sulfur, formed around volcanic fumaroles, efflorescence on limestone soils or caves, salt dome caps, iron oxide caps (gossan) on pyrite deposits in limestone areas. Gypsum is formed under conditions of varying purity and thickness. Gypsum is the first salt to precipitate due to the evaporation of seawater followed by anhydrite and halite when the salinity increases. As an evaporite mineral, gypsum deposits form layers between sedimentary rocks of limestone, red shale, sandstone, clay, and rock salt, and often also form lens deposits within sedimentary rock units. According to experts, gypsum deposits occurred in the Permian era. Gypsum deposits are usually found in lakes, seas, hot springs, and sulfur deposits that originate from volcanoes. Gypsum is a mineral with a monoclinic crystal system of 2/m, but its gypsum crystals belong to the orthorhombic crystal system. Gypsum is generally white, gray, brown, yellow and transparent. This depends on the impurity minerals associated with gypsum. Gypsum generally has soft and dense properties with the Mohs scale of 1.5 – 2. The specific gravity of gypsum is between 2.31 – 2.35, the solubility in water is 1.8 g/liter at 0°C which increases to 2.1 g/liter at 40°C, but decreases again as the temperature gets higher. Gypsum has a good fraction, between 66o to 114o and the cleavage is of the choncoidal type. Gypsum has a silky to waxy sheen, depending on the type. Gypsum scratch is white, has a degree of transparency from transparent to translucent, and has the property of repelling magnets or called diamagnetite.

Positivism Functionalism Antipositivism Conflict theory Structuralism Symbolic interaction Intermediate distance Mathematical Critical theory Socialization Quantitative structures and agents Computational Qualitative Ethnography religion culture economic demographics law science science internet industry social networking gender crime class class family health · city · educational environment · knowledge · deviance social psychology · medical mobility · politics · race & ethnicity rationalization · secularization · stratification Journal · Publishing · Outline List of sociologists · Demographic Index is a combination of two words derived from Greek, namely demos and graphein which means people and writing. So demography is any writing about the people or human population. The population analysis can refer to society as a whole or certain groups based on criteria such as education, citizenship, religion, or certain ethnicities. Demography is the scientific study of population, especially with regard to fertility, mortality and mobility. Demographics include population size, geographic distribution, population composition and demographic characteristics and how these factors change over time. Therefore, demography focuses on studying population problems quantitatively, such as the number, structure, composition, and size of the population so that techniques for calculating population or demographic data are needed to get good results and quality calculations. Practitioners or experts in the field of population are referred to as demographers. Demographers are interested in statistics on fertility (birth), mortality (death), and mobility (movement) because these three variables are components that influence population change. These three components are measured by the birth rate, death rate and migration rate which determine the population size, age composition and the rate of increase or decrease in the population. Demographic studies have existed since ancient civilizations, such as in ancient Greece, ancient Rome, civilizations in China, and India.

The term demography generally refers to the study of the population as a whole. Relics in ancient Greek times regarding demography are found in the writings of Herodotos, Thucydides, Hippocrates, Epicurus, Protagoras, Polus, Plato and Aristotle. While in Rome, one can find studies that resemble demography in writings such as Cicero, Seneca, Pliny the elder, Marcus Aurelius, Epictetus, Cato, and Columella. In the Middle Ages many Christian thinkers provided classical ideas about demography, such as William from Conches, Bartholomew from Lucca, William from Auvergne, and William from Pagula, as well as Muslim scientists such as Ibn Khaldun. The earliest study of demography in the modern age is John of Graunt's book Natural and Political Observations Made upon the Bills of Mortality, published in 1662. It contains an early form of a table of life. Some of the data contained in the book is data such as a third of children in London died before their sixteenth birthday. Later mathematicians, such as Edmond Halley, developed these life tables as the mathematical basis for life insurance. In 1755, Benjamin Franklin published his essay Observations Concerning the Improvement of Mankind, Peopling of Countries, etc., which illustrated the exponential growth in the British colonies. His work was further scrutinized by Thomas Robert Malthus, who wrote in the late 18th century. He contributed to the idea that if population growth is not controlled, it will tend to outstrip growth in food production, leading to ever-increasing hunger and poverty.
