The 1860s to 1910s were a transitional period in which demography emerged from the field of statistics as a separate study. This period also gave rise to a number of demographers such as Adolphe Quételet (1796–1874), William Farr (1807–1883), Louis-Adolphe Bertillon (1821–1883) and his son Jacques (1851–1922), Joseph Körösi (1844–1906) , Anders Nicolas Kaier (1838–1919), Richard Böckh (1824–1907), Mile Durkheim (1858-1917), Wilhelm Lexis (1837–1914), and Luigi Bodio (1840-1920) who contributed to the development of demographics and tools methods and techniques of demographic analysis.

Hydrology (from Greek: Yδρoλoγια, Yδωρ+Λoγos, Hydrologia, "science of water") is the branch of geography concerned with the movement, distribution and quality of water throughout the Earth, including the hydrologic cycle and water resources. People who specialize in hydrology are called hydrologists, working in the fields of earth sciences and environmental sciences, as well as civil and environmental engineering. Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences The study of hydrology includes hydrometeorology (water in the air and is in the form of gas), potamology (surface runoff), limnology (surface water that is relatively calm such as lakes; reservoirs) geohydrology (groundwater), and cryology (water solid state such as ice and snow) and water quality. Hydrological research also has further uses for environmental engineering, environmental policy, and planning. Hydrology also studies rain behavior, especially including the return period of rainfall because it is related to flood calculations and plans for every civil engineering building including weirs, dams and bridges. Groundwater is water below the earth's surface that is normally pumped for use as drinking water. Groundwater hydrology (hydrogeology) considers the measurement of groundwater flow and solute transport. Problems in describing saturated zones include characterizing aquifers in terms of flow direction, groundwater pressure, and based on groundwater depth estimation. Measurements here can be made using a piezometer. Aquifers are also described in terms of hydraulic conductivity, storage and transmissivity. There are a number of geophysical methods to characterize aquifers. In addition, there are also problems in characterizing the unsaturated zone (vadose zone). Infiltration is the process by which water enters the soil. Some of the water is absorbed, while the rest experiences percolation toward the groundwater table. The maximum rate of absorption of water by the soil, called the infiltration capacity, is affected by several factors.

Saturated soil layers slow down the absorption rate in proportion to the thickness of the layer, while the water above the soil provides the driving force (hydraulic head). Compaction reduces porosity and reduces the size of the soil pores which also results in slower infiltration. Dry soil accelerates infiltration due to capillary action. This property will be weaker as the wetter soil. High temperatures reduce the viscosity thereby accelerating infiltration. Soil moisture can be measured by means of a capacitance probe, time domain reflectometer or tensiometer. There are also other methods that can be used, namely solute sampling and geophysical methods. The study of water quality in hydrology is related to organic and inorganic compounds, including dissolved and sedimentary materials. In addition, water quality is also affected by the interaction of dissolved oxygen with inorganic materials and various chemical transformations that may occur. Water quality measurement can use in-situ methods, which are carried out by on-site analysis, often also automatically. It can also be done by laboratory-based analysis which can include bacteriological analysis of water. In studying hydrological processes, remote sensing can be used to gather information at remote locations. Remote sensing can also be used to measure several variables that affect the water balance on the Earth's surface, such as groundwater storage, soil moisture, precipitation, evapotranspiration and rain. Instruments used for remote sensing include ground, air and satellite based sensors. Precipitation is any product of condensation of water vapor in the atmosphere. Precipitation can be measured in various ways. To measure the nature of precipitation at short time intervals, a disdrometer can be used. Radar can be used to determine cloud characteristics, predict rainfall, and detect hail and snow.

Venezuela (Spanish pronunciation: Beneˈswela] ( listen)), officially the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela (Spanish: República Bolivariana de Venezuela) is a country in the northern tip of South America. The country is bordered by the Caribbean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean to the north, Guyana to the east, Brazil to the south and Colombia to the west. Off the coast of Venezuela are also the Caribbean countries of Aruba, the Netherlands Antilles and Trinidad and Tobago. According to the most popular and accepted version, in 1499 an expedition led by Alonso de Ojeda visited the coast of Venezuela. The stilt houses in the Lake Maracaibo area reminded Italian navigator Amerigo Vespucci of the city of Venice, Italy, so he named the region Veneziola, or "Little Venice". The Spanish version of Veneziola is Venezuela. Martín Fernández de Enciso, a member of the Vespucci and Ojeda crew, provides a different account. In his Summa de geografía, he states that the crew found an indigenous people who called themselves Veneciuela. Thus, the name "Venezuela" may have evolved from the original word. Previously, the official names were Estado de Venezuela (1830–1856), República de Venezuela (1856–1864), Estados Unidos de Venezuela (1864–1953), and again adopted the name República de Venezuela (1953–1999). Venezuela is located north of South America; Geologically, the land lies on the South American Plate. Having a total area of ​​916,445 km2 (353,841 sq mi) and a land area of ​​882,050 km2 (340,560 sq mi), makes Venezuela the 33rd largest country in the world. The area it controls lies between latitudes 0° and 13°N and longitudes 59° and 74°W Shaped like a triangle, the country has a coastline of 2,800 km (1,700 mi) in the north, which includes many islands in the Caribbean and northeast bordered by the North Atlantic Ocean.

Pansori is a genre of traditional Korean music featuring a singer (sorikkun) and drummer (gosu). Sorikkun tells and sings stories about love, virtue, loyalty, and various moral values ​​which are summarized in 5 pansori songs (pansori madang). Pansori was registered as a Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity on 7 November 2003 by UNESCO. Pansori was born among the lower classes of the people during the Joseon Dynasty's rule of the Korean peninsula in the late 17th century (1690's). Entertainment for the common people performed in the open in the center of the crowd called nori-pan or gut-pan. Those who perform at the nori-pan are groups of wandering entertainers who perform various performing arts (pan-gut/pan-noreum) such as acrobatics, percussion music, puppetry, tightrope walking and singing stories. Because it was popular among the crowd (pan), the art of singing (sori) performed by these nomads gradually became known as pansori. This music genre then separated itself from other performing arts and the singers began to perform everywhere. At the beginning of the 19th century, pansori singers were well known not only among the common people, but were also favored by royalty and kings. When Heungseon Daewongun held a celebration party for the construction of Gyeonghoe Pavilion at Gyeongbok Palace, he invited the first female pansori singer named Jin Chae-seon. When Emperor Sunjong was forbidden to invite pansori singers, he would call and ask them to sing over the phone. During the period of the Japanese Occupation of Korea, pansori was banned and nearly extinct. Preservation is continued through teaching between teachers and students. William Äson Grebst, a journalist from Sweden, wrote that during the colonial period, all publishing and publications were banned to suppress nationalism, but that could not compete with the ability of artists and pansori singers in Joseon who could memorize all the contents of books and retell them to the people.

In the early periods of its development, pansori singers sang an incomplete story section because it was too long, but, starting in the 21st century, short scenes have been put together to perform the whole story. A complete pansori like this one should take at least 4 hours or more to complete. During his performance, sori-kkun was accompanied by a gosu in the middle of the crowd of spectators. Important things that become components of pansori include: Until the 21st century, far fewer pansori stories have survived compared to the previous period, which reached 12 stories. The stories performed in pansori are taken from folk tales that are passed down by word of mouth, so pansori is credited with preserving Korean folk storytelling traditions from ancient times, which were often not written down in scripts or lost. The stories that were made popular because they raised themes that were the hopes of commoners in the past, such as love of different statuses, justice, prosperity, filial piety and loyalty. At present only 5 stories survive, including: According to Sin Jae-hyo, one of the figures who popularized pansori in the 19th century, there are 4 requirements to become a pansori singer, namely: All requirements to become a pansori singer are easy to obtain except deugeum, which is the hardest challenge to become pansori myeongchang (master). Deugeum which means "to reach or get a sound" is obtained by practicing it for a long time. The ultimate goal is to achieve the voice that every pansori singer craves, namely a husky and rough voice. Pansori singers (sori-kkun) in ancient times used to go to the mountains to practice pansori for 100 days, starting on Dano Day and returning on Chuseok Day. They live in temples and train sounds on mountains and waterfalls without stopping.

Acacia (English pronunciation: əˈkeɪʃə]) is a genus of shrubs and trees belonging to the subfamily Mimosoideae of the family Fabaceae, first identified in Africa by the Swedish botanist Carl Linnaeus in 1773. Many non-Australian species of acacia tend to be spiny, whereas the majority of Australian Acacias do not. Acacia is a legume, with its sap and leaves usually bearing large amounts of tannins. This common name comes from ακακία (akakia), the name given by the early Greek physician-botanist Pedanius Dioscorides (c. 40-90 AD) to the medicinal tree A. nilotica in his Materia Medica. The name is derived from the Greek word for the characteristic thorns of the Acacia plant, ακις (akis, "thorn"). The species name nilotica was given by Linnaeus from the most famous range of Acacia trees along the Nile. Acacia is also known as a thorn tree, in English it is called whistling thorns ("whistling thorn") or Wattles, or yellow-fever acacia ("yellow fever acacia") and umbrella acacias ("umbrella acacia"). As of 2005, there were an estimated 1,300 species of acacia worldwide, approximately 960 of them native to Australia, with the remainder distributed throughout the tropics to warm and temperate regions of both hemispheres, including Europe, Africa, southern Asia, and America . However, the genus was later divided into five, with the name Acacia only being used for Australian species, and most species outside Australia being divided into Vachellia and Senegalia. Acacia pennata in the Talakona forest, in Chittoor, Andhra Pradesh, India. Acacia pennata in the Ananthagiri Valley, Rangareddy in Andhra Pradesh, India. Acacia pennata tree trunk in Talakona forest, in Chittoor, Andhra Pradesh, India. Acacia pennata in the Talakona forest, in Chittoor, Andhra Pradesh, India.

Antimony is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Sb and atomic number 51. Its symbol is taken from the Latin Stibium. Antimony is a metalloid and has four allotropic forms. The stable form of antimony is a blue-white metal. Yellow and black antimony is an unstable metal. Antimony is used as a fire retardant in paints, ceramics, electronics and rubber. Antimony is a silvery-white, brittle crystalline solid element. Electrical conductivity (conductivity) and heat is weak. This substance sublimes (evaporates from the solid phase) at low temperatures. As a metalloid, antimony resembles a metal in its physical appearance but reacts chemically differently from a true metal. Antimony is used in the semiconductor industry in the production of diodes and infrared detectors. As an alloy, this pseudo metal increases the mechanical strength of the material. The most important use of antimony is as a lead booster for batteries. Other uses are anti-scratch mixtures, matches, medicines, and pipes. Antimony oxides and sulfides, sodium antimonate, and antimony trichloride are used in the manufacture of refractory compounds, ceramics, glass, and paints. Natural antimony sulfide (stibnite) is known to have been used as a medicine and cosmetic in Biblical times. Antimony and its compounds are toxic (poisonous). Clinically, the symptoms of antimony poisoning are similar to those of arsenic poisoning. In low doses, antimony causes headaches and depression. In high doses, antimony will result in death within days. At high temperatures, antimony can sometimes act as a catalyst, helping the breakdown of chemical compounds into their original chemical elements, especially in compounds that have a relatively high melting temperature or high ignition temperature, for example decomposing thinner from anti-scratch materials in metal paint or decomposing alcohol from brake fluids or lubricating fluids. .

Algiers (Arabic: ولاية الجزائر‎ El-Jazair; French: Alger; English: Algiers ) is the capital city of Algeria and the largest city of Algeria, located in North Africa. The city was also a major seaport, political center and cultural base, as well as the "home" of the famous Berber pirates from the 16th to the 19th centuries. According to the 1998 census, the city's population is 1,519,570 inhabitants, while the total population is 2,135,630. The city's nickname is "White Algiers" (Arabic: El-Bahdja (البهجة) or Alger la Blanche ("Algiers the White"), because of the radiant white buildings that reflect the sun's rays as seen from the sea. These buildings are in the western part of the Mediterranean Sea. The city gets its name from its location in the valley of the "Sahel" hills, a chain of hills parallel to the coast. Its geographical coordinates are: 36°47′N 3°4′E Barbarossa, a Turkish commander who conquers Algiers for the Ottoman Empire in 1529, liberating Penon from the Spaniards as well, at the request of the Emir of Algiers. Then he gathers the Moors—who had been driven out of Spain—and turns them into an army of pirates who rule the seas and terrify European merchants in the Mediterranean.In 1830, The French conquered Algiers and crushed the pirate army, turning Turkey into a military base for control of West and North Africa.For the previous 300 years, however, Algiers had flourished under Barbarossa's reign. Although Barbarossa's reign was well known in Europe, he was a fine leader. The prisoners were released in the city, where they were treated almost the same as Algiers. They were the main commodity of Turkish pirates, because of this they succeeded in constructing white buildings facing the Mediterranean Sea. The city grew from its obscure origins as a Phoenician colony in North Africa and spread across the slopes of the Sahel Hills and (reclaimed) offshore islands.

Oganesson is a synthetic chemical element with the symbol Og and atomic number 118. The element was first synthesized in 2002 by a joint team of Russian and United States scientists at the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (JINR) in Dubna, Russia. In December 2015, this element was designated as one of four new elements by the Joint Working Party of IUPAC and IUPAP. The element's name was formalized on November 28, 2016. The element is named after nuclear physicist Yuri Oganessian, in keeping with the tradition of naming new elements after scientists. Yuri Oganessian is credited with discovering the heaviest elements on the periodic table. Oganesson is one of two elements named after people who were still alive at the time of the element's naming, the other being seaborgium. Oganesson has the highest atomic number and atomic mass of all known elements. The oganesson atom is radioactive and unstable; hence since 2005, only five (possibly six) 294Og atoms have been detected. As a result, very few of the properties of organesson can be investigated experimentally. The predictions of the properties of these elements were made through theoretical calculations, which discovered some surprising properties. For example, even though oganesson is a member of group VIIIA – the first synthetic element of this group which is often called the noble gas – it is possible that this element is quite reactive, unlike the other noble gas elements. Initially, organeson was thought to be a gas under normal conditions but now the element is predicted to be a metal due to relativistic effects. On the periodic table of elements, oganesson is included in the p-block elements and is the last element in the 7th period. Danish physicist Niels Bohr was the first to seriously consider the possibility of an element with a high atomic number of 118.

In his 1922 notes, the element would come under radon in the periodic table as the seventh noble gas. After that, Aristid von Grosse wrote an article in 1965 predicting the properties that element 118 might have. Bohr's and van Grosse's predictions were highly speculative, because the method of elemental synthesis was not known in 1922, and there was no theory of "islands of stability" for the heavy elements until 1965. The element was synthesized in 2002 (80 years after Bohr's prediction), and at that time its chemical properties had not been investigated so it was not known whether it really behaved like a noble gas as predicted. In late 1998, Polish physicist Robert Smolańczuk wrote calculations on the fusion of atomic nuclei for the synthesis of superheavy atoms, including oganesons. According to his calculations, it was possible that oganesson could be prepared by fusing lead with krypton under tightly controlled conditions. He also predicts that the chance of this reaction occurring will be almost the same as the chance of a lead and chromium fusion reaction that previously succeeded in synthesizing element 106, seaborgium. This calculation contradicts previous predictions that the chances of a fusion reaction involving lead or bismuth would decrease exponentially as the atomic number of the products of the fusion reaction increased. In late 1998, researchers at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory used Smolańczuk's predictions and reported the discovery of the elements livermorium and oganesson in the journal Physical Review Letters, soon after these results were reported in the journal Science. They reported having carried out the following reaction However, the following year, they withdrew the report because these results could not be repeated, neither by researchers in other laboratories, nor when the experiment was repeated by the same laboratory.

An atoll (pronounced /'æt?l/) is a coral island that partially or completely surrounds a lagoon. The distribution of atolls around the world is instructive: most of the world's atolls are located in the Pacific Ocean (with concentrations in the Tuamotu Islands, the Caroline Islands, the Marshall Islands, the Coral Sea Islands, and the island groups of Kiribati, Tuvalu and Tokelau) and the Indian Ocean (Atolls in the Maldives, Laccadive Islands, Chagos Islands and Seychelles Outer Islands). The Atlantic Ocean lacks a large group of atolls more than the eight atolls east of Nicaragua that belong to the Colombian departments of San Andres and Providencia in the Caribbean Sea. Coral-building corals can only live in tropical and subtropical warm water oceans and seas, and previously atolls could only be found in tropical and subtropical regions. The northernmost atoll in the world is Kure Atoll at 28°24' N, along with the other atolls in the Northwest Hawaiian Islands. The world's southernmost atolls are Elizabeth Reef at 29°58' S, and Middleton Reef at 29°29' S, in the Tasman Sea, both part of the Coral Sea Islands Territory. The next southernmost atoll is Ducie Island in the Pitcairn Archipelago, at 24°40' S. Bermuda is sometimes claimed to be the "northernmost atoll" at latitude 32°24' N. At this latitude coral reefs cannot live without the warm waters of the Gulf. Streams. However, Bermuda is referred to as a pseudo-atoll because its original shape, while forming an atoll, has a very different shape. While no atoll is directly on the Equator, the closest atoll to the Equator is Aranuka in Kiribati, with its southern tip 12 km North of the Equator. The largest atolls by area (lagoon plus reef and dry land) are (information from ): In some ways, the land area of ​​an atoll is very small compared to the total area.

Mind is a set of cognitive abilities that enable awareness, perception, judgment and memory in humans and other organisms. Various traditions in philosophy, religion, psychology, and cognitive science have attempted to understand the mind and its properties. The main problems related to the mind are related to the brain and nervous system, which are commonly called mind-body problems. Various approaches have been proposed, such as dualism which holds that the mind is separate from the body and physicalism which emphasizes that the mind originates from and is reducible to physical phenomena such as neurological processes. Another problem is related to the existence of a mind like that of animals or artificial intelligence. Some important philosophers of mind are Plato, Descartes, Leibniz, Kant, Martin Heidegger, John Searle, and Daniel Dennett. Psychologists such as Sigmund Freud and William James have also developed influential theories of the human mind. In the late 20th and early 21st centuries, cognitive science developed and led to the emergence of various new approaches. Mind or mentality is usually contrasted with body, matter, or physicality. This problem of the nature of contrast and in particular the relationship between mind and brain is called the mind-body problem. Traditional viewpoints include dualism and idealism, which regard the mind as non-physical. Modern views often center on physicalism and functionalism, which argue that the mind is roughly identical to the brain or can be reduced to physical phenomena such as neural activity. Psychologists such as Freud and James, and computer scientists such as Turing developed influential theories about the nature of the mind. The possibilities of the nonbiological mind are explored in the field of artificial intelligence, which works closely in conjunction with cybernetics and information theory to understand how the processing of information by nonbiological machines is comparable or different to mental phenomena in the human mind.

Mind is also sometimes described as a stream of consciousness in which sensory impressions and mental phenomena are constantly changing. The majority of the human mind and mind are 'sub-critical' in nature. This is because an idea presented to such a mind will, on average, elicit less than one idea in response, but a small proportion are highly critical. The real mind must be peeled deep to get the core idea of ​​one's mind. Budi or mind comes from the Old English word gemynd meaning the ability to remember, not to think in general. Old English had other words for "mind," such as hyge "mind, spirit." The generalization of the meaning of mind or mind, that is to include all mental faculties, thought, will, feeling, and memory, gradually developed during the 14th and 15th centuries. Mind or mind is often understood as an ability that manifests itself in mental phenomena such as sensation, perception, thinking, reasoning, memory, belief, will, emotion and motivation. Mind or mentality is usually contrasted with the body, material or physical. Central to this contrast is the intuition that the mind exhibits various features which are not found and perhaps even do not correspond to the material universe as described by natural science. In the traditionally dominant substantialist view associated with René Descartes, mind is defined as an independent thinking substance. However, it is more common in contemporary philosophy to understand mind not as a substance, but as a trait or capacity possessed by humans and the higher animals. Despite this agreement, there are still many differences of opinion regarding the true nature of mind and various competing definitions have been proposed. Philosophical definitions of the mind are usually proceeding not only from the various kinds of phenomena of the mind, but by looking for a "mental sign": that part which is shared by all mental states and only by mental states.

Overweight or obesity is a medical condition in the form of excess body fat that has accumulated in such a way as to have a detrimental effect on health, which then reduces life expectancy and/or increases health problems. A person is considered overweight (obese) if the body mass index (BMI), which is a measurement obtained from the division of body weight in kilograms by the square of height in meters is more than 30 kg/m2. Obesity increases the chance of many diseases, especially heart disease, type 2 diabetes, obstructive sleep apnea, certain cancers, osteoarthritis and asthma. Obesity is most often caused by a combination of excess food energy intake, physical inactivity, and genetic predisposition, although a small percentage of cases are primarily caused by genes, endocrine disorders, drugs or psychiatric disease. There is little evidence to support the view that obese people eat less but gain weight because their metabolism is slow; on average, fat people expend more energy than thin people because it takes energy to maintain greater body mass. Diet control and physical activity are still the main management of obesity. The quality of intake can be improved by reducing the consumption of energy-dense foods, for example foods that are high in fat and sugar, and by increasing fiber intake. Anti-obesity drugs can be taken to reduce appetite or inhibit fat absorption, accompanied by proper dietary intake. If diet, exercise, and medication are not effective, gastric balloons can help reduce weight or surgery can be performed to reduce stomach volume and intestinal length. This can give you a feeling of fullness earlier and reduce the ability to absorb nutrients from food. Obesity is the leading cause of preventable death in the world, with an increasing prevalence in both adults and children, for which authorities consider obesity to be one of the most serious public health problems of the 21st century.

Obesity is generally a stigma in the modern world (especially in the Western World), although at one time in history obesity was widely considered a symbol of wealth and fertility, and is still so in some parts of the world today. In 2013, there were 2.1 billion people with obesity in the world and Indonesia was in the top 10 with 40 million overweight people or the equivalent of the entire population of West Java. Unlike in developed countries, most are men, in Indonesia, most are women who are fat. Obesity is a medical condition in the form of excess body fat that has accumulated in such a way as to cause adverse effects on health. Obesity was assessed based on body mass index (BMI), and then based on fat distribution through waist-to-hip ratio and total cardiovascular risk factors. BMI is closely related to body fat percentage and total body fat. In children, a healthy weight varies by age and sex. Obesity in children and adolescents is not defined by an absolute number, but is related to a history of groups with normal weight, obesity is defined when BMI is greater than the 95th percentile. The reference data on which these percentiles are based are from 1963 to 1994, and therefore have not been affected by recent weight gains. BMI is calculated by dividing a subject's weight by the square of their height, which is usually written in either metric units or in the American system: lb{\displaystyle lb} is the subject's weight in pounds and in{\displaystyle in} is the subject's height in inches . The most frequently used definition is that created by the World Health Organization (WHO) in 1997 and published in 2000, as shown in the table to the right.

Steel is an iron-based alloy metal. Pure iron has properties that are less strong and easily corroded, but has a high level of ductility. The ferrous metal in steel is combined with several other elements, including carbon to modify its characteristics. Some common metals used as alloys are Nickel, Manganese, Aluminum, and Bismuth. Other elements that are used less frequently include Titanium, Vanadium, Chromium, Tungsten, Molybdenum, Boron, and Niobium. The ratio of steel constituents will affect the properties and characteristics of the steel itself. Elemental Carbon (C) is usually added to steel to increase its strength. Carbon in steel causes the strength of steel to increase but carbon also causes the elasticity of steel to decrease. The elemental carbon content of steel ranges from 0.2% to 2.1% by weight. Too much percentage of carbon will cause the steel to become brittle or break easily. Iron can be formed into two crystal forms, namely Body Center Cubic (BCC) and Face Center Cubic (FCC), depending on the temperature at which it is forged. In the BCC arrangement, there is an iron atom in the center of the atomic cube, and the FCC arrangement has iron atoms on each side of the six-sided cube of atoms. The allotropic interaction that occurs between ferrous metals and alloying elements, such as carbon, is what gives steel and cast iron their own characteristics. Although steel had previously been produced by blacksmiths using kilns for thousands of years, its use grew when more efficient production methods were discovered in the 17th century. With the invention of the Bessemer process in the mid-19th century, steel became a mass-produced material which made it cheaper to produce. Today, steel is one of the most common materials in the world, with the production of more than 1.3 billion tons annually replacing wrought iron.

Steel is a major component of buildings, infrastructure, ships, cars, machines, tools and weapons. Modern steel is generally classified according to its quality by several standard bodies. Advanced refining processes, such as basic oxygen steelmaking (BOS), replace most of the older methods by lowering production costs and improving the quality of the final product. The steel industry is a vital element in industrialization. Without a good steel industry, industrialization will not work. The importance of the steel industry considering the use of steel in the construction of infrastructure, machine components, and transportation. The steel industry is able to absorb a lot of manpower, besides that the steel industry requires high technology supported by a skilled workforce. In its history, the Soviet Union made the steel industry a priority in the Soviet Industrialization in 1929 - 1941. According to statistics, China and India are the 2 largest steel producing countries. The English word Steel, namely steel, comes from the Proto-Germanic adverb, namely stahlija or stakhlijan (made of steel), which is related to stahlaz or stahlija (standing straight). As already reviewed, the carbon content in the steel alloy is between 0.002% and 2.14% by weight of the iron–carbon alloy. This amount can vary depending on the alloying elements present in the alloy such as manganese, chromium, nickel, iron, tungsten, carbon, and so on. Basically, steel is an iron-carbon alloy that does not undergo eutectic reactions. On the contrary, cast iron actually undergoes this reaction. If the carbon content in the steel is too little, then the pure iron in the alloy will become ductile, soft, and weak. The higher carbon content than normal steel will create an alloy which is often called pig iron. Although iron that is successfully alloyed with carbon is called carbon steel, alloy steel is steel that is alloyed with other elements in order to impart certain characteristics to the steel.

Thermodynamics is a branch of physics that deals with the conversion of heat energy into other forms of energy. The first law of thermodynamics and the second law of thermodynamics become a reference in discussing energy changes. Measurements in thermodynamics are not expressed in microscopic quantities but in macroscopic quantities. Thermodynamics deals with the relationship between energy, heat, work, entropy and the spontaneity of processes. Thermodynamics is closely related to statistical mechanics from which the thermodynamic relationships originate. The origin of the word thermodynamics is from two Greek words, namely thermos which means heat and dynamic which means change. The discovery of the concept of thermodynamics began with the efforts of scientists in the 19th century AD to create machines that had the ability to carry out energy changes. The purpose of converting this energy was originally to facilitate work by converting energy into work with the maximum amount of energy change. The earliest machines created by scientists were able to convert the energy of motion into potential energy. Its working principle is based on collision events. There was an effort from these scientists who later in the 20th century succeeded in developing theories regarding thermodynamics. The theory of thermodynamics applies to a hot state or a system in an equilibrium state at the start or end. After the 19th century AD, the development of the theory of thermodynamics turned to quantum physics and phase transitions. Phenomenologically, the development of the theory of thermodynamics is aimed at macroscopic systems. In physics, the formulation of thermodynamics becomes an axiom that includes the three laws of thermodynamics. The main concepts underlying the three laws of thermodynamics are energy and entropy. The application of the science of thermodynamics existed in the 3rd century BC in the city of Alexandria. At that time, an inventor named Hero used the science of thermodynamics to adjust the position of the gate at the Alexandrian Temple. Scientifically, the science of thermodynamics was first developed by a German scientist named Otto von Guericke in 1650.

The pioneering of the science of thermodynamics was accompanied by the invention of the world's first vacuum pump and vacuum chamber. The vacuum pump design created by Guericke was later studied by the Irish chemist and physicist Robert Boyle. After studying it, Boyle along with an English scientist named Robert Hooke developed a design during 1656. The result of this development was the invention of an air pump which was later called a compressor. This pump was then used by the two inventors to analyze the relationship between volume, pressure and temperature. The results of the analysis between volume, pressure and temperature produce Boyle's law. This law states that pressure and volume are inversely related. In 1679, Boyle's co-worker, Denis Papin, succeeded in making a boiler that could produce steam at high pressure. In the initial experiments, this boiler produced a strong explosion, so a redesign was held. In the new design, a steam opening valve is added. Papin also became the originator of ideas in making engines that use cylinders and pistons in the form of finished designs. This design did not have time to be made by Papin, so an engineer named Thomas Savery continued to build it. The results of this design resulted in a motorbike that was the first in the world. In the 17th century steam engines were also found in England. The existence of this steam engine expands the field of thermodynamics. After that, scientists appeared in the field of thermodynamics, especially in the 19th century. These scientists include William John Macquorn Rankine, Rudolf Clausius, and Lord Kelvin. The scientific development of thermodynamics developed in the 19th century AD is known as classical thermodynamics. The approach used is macroscopic. Observations regarding the general behavior of the particles of matter which serve as media for the transfer of energy are characteristic of classical thermodynamics.

Syria (Arabic: سُورِيَا or سُورِيَة, sūriyā), with the official name of the Syrian Arab Republic (Arabic: ٱلْجُمْهُورِيَّةُ ٱلْعَرَبِيَّةُ ٱلسُّورِيَّةُ, translit. Syria is bordered by the Mediterranean Sea to the west, Turkey to the north, Iraq to the east and southeast, Jordan to the south, and Israel, Palestine and Lebanon to the southwest. Cyprus lies to the west across the Mediterranean Sea. A country of fertile plains, high mountains, and desert, Syria is home to diverse ethnic and religious groups, including the majority of Syrian Arabs, Kurds, Turkmen, Assyrians, Armenians, Circassians, and Greeks. Religious groups include Sunnis, Christians, Alawites, Druze, Ismailis, Shiites, Salafis and Yazidis. The capital and largest city of Syria is Damascus. Arabs are the largest ethnic group, and Sunnis are the largest religious group. Syria is a unitary republic consisting of 14 governorates and is the only country that politically supports Baathism. The country is a member of an international organization other than the United Nations, the Non-Aligned Movement; as well as being suspended from the Arab League in November 2011, the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, and being suspended himself from the Union for the Mediterranean. The name "Syria" historically referred to the wider region widely identified with the Levant and known in Arabic as al-Sham. The modern state includes the sites of several ancient kingdoms and kingdoms, including the Eblan civilization in the 3rd millennium BC. Aleppo and the capital city of Damascus is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world. In the Islamic era, Damascus was the seat of the Umayyad Caliphate and the provincial capital of the Mamluk Sultanate in Egypt. The modern Syrian state was founded in the mid-20th century after centuries of Ottoman rule and after a brief period as a French mandate.

The newly created state represented the largest Arab state to emerge from the former Ottoman-controlled provinces of Syria. It gained de jure independence as a parliamentary Republic on 24 October 1945. The Syrian Republic became a founding member of the United Nations, an act that legally ended the previous French Mandate, although French troops did not leave the country until April 1946. The post-independence period was tumultuous , with numerous military coups and coup attempts rocking the country from 1949 to 1971. In 1958, Syria entered into a brief union with Egypt called the United Arab Republic which was ended by the 1961 Syrian coup. The republic was renamed the Syrian Arab Republic at the end of the year 1961 after the December 1 constitutional referendum of that year. After that things became increasingly unstable until the Ba'athist coup in 1963, when the Ba'ath Party retained power. Syria was under the Emergency Law from 1963 to 2011, which effectively suspended most constitutional protections for citizens. Bashar al-Assad has been president since 2000 succeeding his father Hafez al-Assad, who served from 1971 to 2000. Throughout his rule, Syria and its ruling Ba'ath Party have been condemned and criticized for numerous human rights violations, including frequent executions. against citizens and political prisoners, and massive censorship. Since March 2011, Syria has been embroiled in a multi-faceted civil war, with a number of countries in the region and outside engaging militarily or otherwise. As a result, a number of self-proclaimed political entities have emerged on Syrian territory, among them the Syrian Opposition, Rojava, Tahrir al-Sham and the Islamic State group. Syria ranked last on the Global Peace Index from 2016 to 2018, making it the most violent country in the world due to war.

– in Europe  (green & dark grey)– in the United Kingdom  (green) Scotland (English and Scottish: Scotland, /ˈskɒt.lənd/; Scottish Gaelic: Alba ˈal̪ˠapə] ( listen)) is a constituent country of a sovereign nation Great Britain. Covering the northern third of the Isle of Britain, Scotland is bordered by England to the south, the North Sea to the east, the Atlantic Ocean to the north and west, and the North Channel and Irish Sea to the southwest. As well as the mainland, Scotland is also made up of over 790 islands, including the Northern Isles and the Hebrides. Edinburgh, the nation's capital and second largest city, is one of the largest financial centers in Europe. Edinburgh was the center of the Scottish Enlightenment in the 18th century, which transformed Scotland into one of Europe's industrial, commercial and intellectual powers. Glasgow, Scotland's largest city, was once one of the world's leading industrial cities and is currently located at the center of the Greater Glasgow conurbation. Scottish waters comprise a large sector of the North Atlantic and North Sea, containing the largest oil reserves in the European Union. Because of this, Aberdeen, the third largest city in Scotland, is called the oil capital of Europe. The Kingdom of Scotland became an independent sovereign state in the Early Middle Ages and remained in existence until 1707. After James VI, King of Scotland inherited the English and Irish thrones in 1603, Scotland united politically with the Kingdom of England on 1 May 1707, forming the Kingdom of Britain Raya. This union was legalized through the Act of Union agreed by the Parliaments of the two countries in 1707, followed by popular opposition to Scotland and outbreaks of anti-unification riots in Edinburgh, Glasgow and elsewhere.

The Kingdom of Great Britain was also politically united with the Kingdom of Ireland on 1 January 1806 to form the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. Although part of a single sovereign nation, Scotland's legal system is separate from those used in England and Wales and Northern Ireland; Scotland has public law and private law jurisdiction that is different from the rest of the British constituencies. The separation of Scotland's legal, educational and religious institutions from the rest of the British constituency has contributed to the continuity of Scottish culture and national identity since the Union in 1707. Following the 1997 referendum, a devolutive legislature was created, the Scottish Parliament, in 1999. This parliament has broad powers to administer Scotland's internal affairs which do not fall under the jurisdiction of the United Kingdom. In May 2011, the Scottish National Party won a landslide victory in parliament and plans to hold an independence referendum on 18 September 2014. The results of this referendum show that the majority of Scottish people reject independence from the United Kingdom. Scotland is a member state of the British–Irish Council, the British–Irish Parliamentary Assembly, and also participates in the Common Travel Areas agreement. Scotland is also represented in the European Union and has six members of the European Parliament. The word "Scotland" comes from Scoti, Latin for Gaelic (Gaelic). The Late Latin word Scotia (land of the Gaels) was originally used to refer to Ireland. In the 11th century, Scotia began to be used to refer to the Gaelic-speaking population living north of the River Forth, along with Albania or Albany, both of which are derived from the Gaelic language Alba. The use of the words Scots and Scotland to refer to the whole of what is now Scotland dates back to the Late Middle Ages. The area of ​​modern day Scotland has undergone repeated glaciations, wiping out all traces of life that may have existed before the Mesolithic period.

Dance is a rhythmic body movement as an expression of the soul of the creator of the movement so as to produce elements of beauty and deep meaning. Dance emphasizes creative concepts and choreography. The word dance in English is related to the French danse, both of which are considered to be rooted in the Old German donson which means stretch or drag. Dance has the function of facilities and infrastructure in religious ceremonies. Bali is an example of a region in Indonesia that is still consistent in applying culture in everyday life. Not only Bali, but there are still many areas in Indonesia such as Papua, South Sulawesi and Kalimantan. Ceremonies that use dance such as birth, cutting teeth, first hair cutting, maturity, marriage and death. This religious dance has sacred, holy and magical powers. For example, the Barong dance and Sanghyang dance from Bali, the Birth Dance from Papua and the dance to bring rain from East Nusa Tenggara. Dance also acts as a performing art or is often referred to as a theatrical art. According to Susanne K. Langer, an American art philosopher, philosophically, dance as a performing art is an outward manifestation of the human inner process to be seen by oneself and by others. Indonesian group dance is a type of dance from the archipelago which is exhibited by a group of dancers. Basically, the single term only shows the number of dancers. While this type of dance can be played by one or more dancers. For example, the Merak Dance can be a solo dance, it can also be a pair or group dance. The nature of single dance leads to a psychological direction that will make a person a subject or object in an activity. The nature of single dance consists of: Dancing is an activity that requires a partner and other partners as an enlivener.

Sanskrit (non-standard spelling: Sanskrit, Sanskrit, Sanskrit, Devanagari script: संस्कृतम्, saṃskṛtam) is an ancient South Asian language which is the Indo-Aryan branch of the Indo-European language family. This language developed in South Asia after its ancestors experienced trans-cultural diffusion in the northwestern region of South Asia during the Bronze Age. Sanskrit is the sacred language of Hindus, Buddhists and Jains. This language was the basis of South Asia in ancient and medieval times, and became the language of religion, culture, and politics spread across a number of regions in Southeast and Central Asia. This language exerts a lot of influence on the languages ​​of South, Southeast, and East Asia, especially through the vocabulary it learns. Sanskrit still retains features of the ancient Indo-Aryan languages. Its archaic form is the Vedic language found in the Rigveda, a collection of 1,028 hymns composed by Indo-Aryan tribal peoples who migrated from what is now Afghanistan to Pakistan and then northern India. This Vedic language acculturated with ancient languages ​​that already existed in the Indian subcontinent, absorbing vocabulary related to the names of animals and plants; and in addition, the ancient Dravidian languages ​​influenced Sanskrit phonology and syntax. "Sanskrit" can also refer to the classical Sanskrit whose grammar was most fully standardized in the middle of the first millennium BC,b] which is contained in Pāṇini's Aṣṭādhyāyī ("Eight Chapters"). The great poet and playwright Kalidasa wrote in classical Sanskrit, and the foundations of classical arithmetic were first described in classical Sanskrit. c] The two great epics Mahabharata and Ramayana, were composed in the style of spoken narrative spoken in North India between 400 BC and 300 BC, and roughly contemporaries with classical Sanskrit. In the following centuries Sanskrit began to be bound by tradition, stopped being studied as a mother tongue, and finally stopped developing as a living language.

The Rig Vedic chants closely resemble the ancient Iranian and Greek poetry, the Gathas of the Avestan and Homer's Iliad. Because the Rigveda passed from mouth to mouth in a rote way, and was considered a single text without any variants, it preserved the morphology and syntax that led to the reconstruction of the language's ancestor, the Proto-Indo-European language. Sanskrit does not have a specific writing system: around the turn of the first millennium AD, it was written in scripts of the Brahmi family and currently uses the Devanagari script. official in the Eighth Schedule of the Indian Constitution. However, despite its rise, no society has recognized this language as the mother tongue in India. At the last census in India, about thousands of Indian citizens recognized Sanskrit as their mother tongue,d] and this figure is considered to indicate the hope of alignment with the prestige of the language. Sanskrit was taught in gurukula since ancient times; and is now taught in junior high schools. The oldest modern school of Sanskrit is the Sampurnanand Sanskrit Vishwavidyalaya, founded in 1791 during the reign of the British East India Company. Sanskrit is the liturgical language for Hindus and Buddhists, used to recite chants and mantras. In Sanskrit the verbal adjective sáṃskṛta- is a compound composed of sam (cultured, good, good, perfect) and krta- (composed). It means a language that is "well composed, pure, perfect, holy, and cultured". According to Biderman, the perfection implied by this etymology tends to have a tonal quality rather than a semantic one. Oral tradition was valued in Ancient India, and its rishis composed the alphabet, word structure and grammar into "a collection of sounds, a kind of musical mold of great value", as Biderman called it, as a language called Sanskrit.

Nurse (English: nurse, derived from Latin: nutrix which means to care for or care for) is a profession focused on individual, family and community care in achieving, maintaining and healing optimal health and functioning. The modern definition of nursing is defined as a science that focuses on promoting the quality of life defined by the person or family, through the entire experience of life from birth to care at death. Meanwhile, according to Law Number 38 of 2014, the definition of nursing is the activity of providing care to individuals, families, groups or communities, both in sickness and in health. The nurse develops a nursing care plan, working with doctors, therapists, patients, families and other teams to focus on treating disease and improving quality of life. Nurses work in most specialties where they work independently or as part of a team to assess, plan, implement and evaluate care. Florence Nightingale was a pioneer of modern nursing, writer and statistician. She was known as The Lady With The Lamp as immortalized in Longfellow's poem “Santa Filomena”, because she would inspect the wards at night, offering emotional solace to wounded troops. Nursing science is a field of knowledge formed based on contributions from nursing scientists through peer-reviewed scientific journals and evidence-based practice or commonly referred to as EBNP (Evidence Based Nursing Practice). It is a dynamic field of practice and research that is grounded in contemporary culture and concerns itself with both mainstream and marginalized subcultures in order to provide the most culturally sensitive and competent care. Nurse professional education refers to the professionalism of the nursing discipline in accordance with Law Number 38 of 2014 concerning Nursing, and over time most nurses are required to have a minimum bachelor-professional education or KKNI Level 7 (S1-Ners).

Robotics is a branch of technology that deals with the design, construction, operation, structural disposition, manufacture and application of robots. Robotics is related to the science of electronics, machines, mechanics, and computer software. The idea of ​​building self-driving machines dates back to the Classical Era, but research into their use did not develop significantly until the 20th century. Today, many robots perform jobs that are dangerous to humans such as defusing bombs, exploring shipwrecks, and mining. The word robotics comes from the word robot, which was introduced to the public by a Czech writer named Karel Čapek in his drama R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots), published in 1920. The game begins in a factory that makes artificial humans called robots, creatures that can be mistaken for humans–very similar to modern ideas of androids. Karel Čapek did not coin the word himself. He wrote a short letter referring to an etymology in the Oxford English Dictionary in which he credits his brother Josef Čapek as the actual originator. According to the Oxford English Dictionary, the word robotics was first used in print by Isaac Asimov, in his science fiction short story "Liar!" , published in May 1941 in Stunning Science-Fiction. Asimov did not realize that he had coined the term; because the science and technology of electrical devices is electronics, he considers robotics already refers to the science and technology of robots. In some of Asimov's other works, he states that the first use of the word robotics was in his short story Runaround, where he introduced his concept of the Three Laws of Robotics. However, the original publication "Liar!" predates "Runaround" by 10 months, so the former is generally cited as the origin of the word.

As more and more robots are designed for specific tasks, this classification method becomes more relevant. For example, many robots are designed for assembly work, which may not be easily adaptable for other applications. They are referred to as "assembly robots". For seam welding, some suppliers provide complete welding systems with robots i.e. welding equipment along with other material handling facilities such as turntables, etc. as a unit. Such integrated robotic systems are called "welding robots" although their discrete manipulator units can be adapted to a variety of tasks. Some robots are specifically designed for the manipulation of heavy loads, and are labeled as "heavy duty robots". Current and potential uses include: Robotics is a critical component in many modern manufacturing environments. As the use of robots by factories increases, the number of jobs related to robotics grows and is observed to continue to increase. The use of robots in industry has increased productivity and efficiency savings and is usually seen as a long-term investment for philanthropists. A paper by Michael Osborne and Carl Benedikt Frey found that 47% of US jobs are at risk of automation “for an unspecified number of years. This claim has been criticized on the grounds that social policies are causing unemployment to rise. In a 2016 article in The Guardian, Stephen Hawking stated that "Factory automation has destroyed jobs in traditional manufacturing, and the rise of artificial intelligence is likely to extend this job destruction far into the middle class, with only the most caring, creatives. or remaining supervisory roles". The discussion paper produced by EU-OSHA highlights how the deployment of robotics presents both opportunities and challenges for occupational safety and health (OSH). The greatest OSH benefits to stem from the wider use of robotics should replace people working in environments unhealthy or dangerous.

A megalopolis (Megapolis, Megalopolitan, Megapolitan, Megaregion , English: megalopolis; /ˌmɛɡəˈlɒpəlɪs/) or large city is a group of metropolitan areas that are considered as sustainable urban areas through public transportation systems, economy, resources, ecology, and so on. They are sufficiently integrated that coordinating policy is invaluable, although the constituent cities retain their individual identities. The megapolitan concept is very influential because it introduces new thinking on a larger scale about urban patterns and growth. The term megalopolis, sometimes also spelled megapolis, is described as having Greek origins — reported by ancient philosophers, related to the world of ideas by Jean Gottmann, professor of political science at the University of Paris, and member of the Institute for Advanced Studies at Princeton, who at the end of 1950s and early 1960s directed "A Study of Megalopolis" for The Twentieth Century Fund. In particular, the term has an earlier geographic definition dating back to 1832, when it meant "a metropolis," that is, "a very large and densely populated urban complex", of which Greek origin is recorded; mégas, meaning "big," and pólis, meaning "city." The Online Etymology Dictionary notes that the term was used "in classical times as an epithet of the great cities (Athens, Syracuse, Alexandria)", that is, for the major cities of the time, and that it is "the name of former cities in Arcadia". Jean Gottmann, in his extensive studies, applied the term megalopolis to his analysis of the urbanized northeastern coastal areas of the United States, particularly from Boston, Massachusetts to Washington, D.C. (now often referred to as the Northeast Corridor – Northeast Corridor). He chose the term megalopolis in consultation with classicists, noting its earlier use "with quite different meanings" (other than by the ancients), by Lewis Mumford in reference to a general trend in history and geography "toward large cities").

Mumford, in The Culture of Cities (1938), describes their formation as the first stage in urban over-development and social decline. In 1994, William S. Ellis and editors of National Geographic, writing about the city of Boston, pointed out that Gottmann's 1961 use of the term northeast for megalopolis was the first specific use of the term with a subtle meaning of merging several urban areas into a larger area. big. Yoav Hagler, writing in 2009 for the Regional Plan Association's (RPA) Americas Project 2050 and similarly in introducing the term historically, cites megalopolis as the precursor to RPA's preferred term for the United States example, "megaregion". Pedagogically, the term "supercity" has been offered as a synonym for both terms. According to an assistant professor at the University of Syracuse; Lydia Kallipoliti (and her students, quoting from Volker Welter's – Biopolis: Patrick Geddes and the City of Life), the term megalopolis was coined by Patrick Geddes in his 1915 book, Cities in Evolution, and that it was later used by Oswald Spengler in his 1990s. 1918, The Decline of the West. Megalopolis is often called Megapolis. Both come from μέγας (mégas) which in Greek means "big" and πόλις (pólis) which means "city", so that as a whole it means "big city". Literally, megalopolis in Greek is a very large city because the prefix megalo- denotes large size. Megalopolis is also an Ancient Greek city formed by the Arcadian League by uniting small communities. A megalopolis, also known as a megaregion or in Indonesian it is called a megapolitan, is a grouped network of cities. Jean Gottmann explained that a megalopolis must have a population of 25 million.

Kazakhstan (Kazak: Қазақстан/Qazaqstan in Latin script, Karakalpak: ұғуҚазақштаны бгу/wğuQazaqştanı bgu), officially the Republic of Kazakhstan is a transcontinental country that is mostly in Central Asia and to a lesser extent in Eastern Europe. Kazakhstan stretches from the Altai Mountains in the east, to the Caspian Sea in the west, making it the 9th largest country in the world and the 2nd largest of the former Soviet Union countries after Russia. Kazakhstan is often referred to as the "Virgin Land", because some areas of this country have not been touched at all. Most of Kazakhstan shares a direct border with Russia, especially to the north and west. To the east, it is directly adjacent to China (with the autonomous region of Xinjiang). To the south it is bordered by Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Kyrgyzstan and the Caspian Sea. There are many Russians living in Kazakhstan. The launch site for the Russian space rocket, Baikonur, is located in Kazakhstan. Kazakhstan proclaimed its independence on December 16, 1991. The Kazakhs are the largest ethnic group occupying the territory of Kazakhstan and are descended from Turkic and Mongol tribes. At the beginning of the XVIII century, Kazakhstan was ruled by Russia. In the nineteenth century, along with the region in Central Asia, Kazakhstan's religious tolerance was 70.2% of all Muslims, 26.6% Christians, 0.1% Buddhists, 0.2% mostly Jews, and 2.8% Atheists, while 0.5% chose not to answer, possibly Christians of mixed Russia or Europe. When the communist revolution won in Russia and the Soviet Union was established, since 1920, Kazakhstan was made one of the 15 countries that joined the Soviet Union. Along with the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Kazakhstan also became independent and became a republic in the form of a country. This country has a geographical advantage because it is located between Central Asia and Eastern Europe, so it is worth considering geopolitically.

Kazakhstan is bordered by Russia to the north, China to the east, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, and Turkmenistan to the south, and to the west by the Caspian Sea and Russia. Most of Kazakhstan is geographically located in the southwestern part of the Asian continent, and a small part of its territory is in the European continent. The area of ​​Kazakhstan is 2,717,300 square km which makes it the largest country in Central Asia, and the second largest after Russia among the former Soviet Union countries. The plains of Kazakhstan are dominated by deserts and steppes or grasslands, although the boundaries of Kazakhstan's territory to the east and south are mountains. Kazakhstan is one of only two landlocked countries in the world that is in between two continents (the other being Azerbaijan). With an area of ​​2,700,000 square kilometers (1,000,000 sq mi), equivalent in size to Western Europe, Kazakhstan is a the ninth largest and the largest landlocked country in the world. It shares a 6,846 kilometers (4,254 mi) border with Russia, 2,203 kilometers (1,369 mi) with Uzbekistan, 1,533 kilometers (953 mi) with China, 1,051 kilometers (653 mi) with Kyrgyzstan, and 379 kilometers (235 mi) with Turkmenistan The largest cities there are Nur Sultan, Almaty, Karagandy, Shymkent, Atyrau and Öskemen. The country lies between latitudes 40° and 56° N, and longitudes 46° and 88° E. In Kazakhstan is the Charyn gorge, this gorge is located in Almaty, southeastern Kazakhstan north of the Tian Shan mountains. This 80 km long gorge was formed by the erosion of the Charyn river. When independent, Kazakhstan did not have its own armed forces. This is because the soldiers who used to serve in Kazakhstan were Soviet soldiers who then returned to Russia.

The Republic of Honduras (Spanish: República de Honduras) is a developing country in Central America. The country is neighboring Guatemala to the west, El Salvador to the south, and Nicaragua to the east. Honduras and its neighbors are home to Mesoamerican peoples such as the Mayans. Spain came in the 16th century and brought with it its culture and Catholicism, resulting in a mixture of Spanish and indigenous culture. Honduras became independent from Spain in 1821 and until now has always experienced political instability which has caused Honduras to become one of the poorest countries in the Americas. Honduras is also ranked at the top of the world in rates of homicide and sexual violence. Poverty is caused by corruption, exploitation from other countries plus natural disasters. In addition, the operation carried out by the United States to prevent the entry of drugs into its territory has also increased crime in Honduras. This operation gave birth to criminal gangs in Central America such as MS-13 which are active in the illegal drug trade. These criminal gangs have their own territory and are often at war with each other. Their activities are very dangerous for the population so that large-scale migration occurs to other countries such as the United States. Honduras' main economy is in agriculture mainly fruit, sugarcane and coffee. Before the Spanish arrived, Honduras was already inhabited by various ethnic groups, especially the Mayans. Christopher Columbus reached Islas de la Bahía on the coast of Honduras in 1502. Columbus sent his brother Bartholomew Columbus to explore the islands. Bartholomew and his crew met a Mayan boat carrying a large cargo. The boat is intercepted, the cargo is stolen, and the captain is forced to act as an interpreter. This event marked the first contact between the Spanish and the Maya. In 1524, Gil Gonzalez Davila became the first Spaniard to set foot in Honduras, followed by Hernan Cortez who brought troops from Mexico which had already been occupied by Spain.

The small kingdoms of Honduras fell one by one to the Spanish. Spain established the Captain General of Guatemala which covered all of Central America and Honduras became one of its provinces. Spain ruled Honduras for three centuries. Its capital was first at Trujillo, then at Comayagua, and finally at Tegucigalpa. Honduras is rich in minerals, especially silver which was exploited by the Spanish by utilizing the indigenous people as miners. The only area of ​​Honduras that had not been controlled by Spain was the Miskito Kingdom which was protected by pirates from other European countries, especially the British who controlled Jamaica. Honduras became independent from Spain in 1821 and was part of the Mexican Empire until 1823. After its separation from Mexico, Honduras and its neighbors united in the Federal Republic of Central America. For various reasons, the republic broke up and each of its provinces became separate states including Honduras. After becoming its own country, Honduras received various investments from other countries, especially the United States. Honduras is a banana exporting country which is exploited by US fruit companies such as the United Fruit Company, thus earning the nickname Banana Republic. This export of bananas in no way increased Honduran economic growth but instead the United States was able to interfere in Honduran politics and enrich certain elites. This American political influence is called the Banana Wars and is often referred to as neocolonialism. The effects of this American exploitation are still being felt today and contributing to Honduran poverty. In 1969, there was the Football War between Honduras and El Salvador due to the problem of immigrants from El Salvador. Called a football war because it coincided with the 1970 World Cup qualification between Honduras and El Salvador which ended in chaos. This war ended after four days and resulted in hundreds of casualties and hundreds of thousands of Salvadorans expelled from Honduras.

Adaptation Genetic drift Gene flow Mutations Natural selection Speciation Evidence History of the evolution of life History Modern synthesis Social effects Theory and facts Objection / Controversy Cladistics Ecological genetics Evolutionary development Human evolution Molecular evolution Phylogenetics Population genetics Evolution (in biology) means changes in the heritable traits of a population of organisms from one generation to the next. These changes are caused by a combination of three main processes: variation, reproduction, and selection. The traits that form the basis of this evolution are carried by genes that are passed on to the offspring of a living thing and become varied within a population. When organisms reproduce, their offspring will have new characteristics. New properties can be obtained from changes in genes due to mutations or gene transfer between populations and between species. In sexually reproducing species, new gene combinations are also produced by genetic recombination, which can increase variation between organisms. Evolution occurs when these inherited differences become more common or rare within a population. Evolution is driven by two main mechanisms, namely natural selection and genetic drift. Natural selection is a process that causes inherited traits that are useful for the survival and reproduction of organisms to become more common in a population - and conversely, traits that are detrimental to them become less. This happens because individuals with favorable traits are more likely to reproduce, so that more individuals in the next generation inherit these beneficial traits. Over many generations, adaptation occurs through the combination of these small, continuous and random changes in traits with natural selection. Meanwhile, genetic drift (English: Genetic Drift) is an independent process that produces random changes in the frequency of a population trait. Genetic drift results from the probability of whether a trait will be inherited when an individual survives and reproduces.

Although the changes produced by drift and natural selection are small, these changes will accumulate and cause substantial changes in organisms. This process culminates in producing a new species. And in fact, the similarities between organisms suggest that all the species we know came from a common ancestor by this slowly diverging process. Documentation of the facts of evolution is carried out by a branch of biology called evolutionary biology. This branch also develops and tests theories explaining the causes of evolution. Studies of the fossil record and the biodiversity of living organisms convinced scientists in the mid-19th century that species changed over time. However, the mechanisms driving these changes remained unclear until Charles Darwin's 1859 publication, On the Origin of Species, which detailed the theory of evolution by natural selection. Darwin's work was quickly followed by the acceptance of the theory of evolution in the scientific community. In 1930, Darwin's theory of natural selection combined with Mendelian inheritance to form the modern evolutionary synthesis, which links the units of evolution (genes) to the mechanism of evolution (natural selection). The theory's explanatory and predictive power drives research that continually raises new questions, which have become a central principle of modern biology providing a more comprehensive explanation of the diversity of life on earth. Although the theory of evolution is always associated with Charles Darwin, in fact, evolutionary biology has its roots since the time of Aristotle. However, Darwin was the first scientist to come up with a theory of evolution that has proven itself well in the face of scientific scrutiny. Until now, Darwin's theory of evolution as a result of natural selection is considered by the majority of the scientific community to be the best theory in explaining evolution.

Family (Latin: familia, plural familiae) in scientific classification is a taxon that is between the order and the genus, is a taxonomy which consists of several genera that are phylogenetically separate from other families. The Indonesian taxon is tribe (used in many scientific literature), familia (non-standard form), or family. A family can be divided into several subfamilies, namely intermediate taxa above the genus. In the use of common names, a family can be named the same as the name of one of its members which is commonly known. What is or is not included in a family or when a family is recognized separately is proposed and defined by taxonomists. There are no standard rules for describing or explaining a family, or even another taxon. Taxonomists may take different positions regarding the description of a taxon and there may not be a widely accepted consensus within the scientific community for some time. As long as there is no consensus, new data and opinions will always be provided that allow for adjustments. Family names are codified in various international codes. The term was first introduced by the French botanist Pierre Magnol in his book Prodromus historiae generalis plantarum, in quo familiae plantarum per tabulas disponuntur in 1689. He named 76 groups of plants which he identified as families (familiae). The concept of rank/taxon was not yet established at that time and in the foreword to the book, Magnol mentions uniting these families into a wider genera, long before the term came into use as it is today. Carolus Linnaeus used the term family in his Philosophia botanica (1751) to refer to the main groups of plants. He uses the term only in the morphological part, namely the part that talks about the vegetative and generative organs of plants.

Society is a group of living things that are closely intertwined because of certain systems, certain traditions, conventions and certain laws that are the same, and lead to collective life. Systems in society are interconnected between one human being and another human being that form a unit. Society is divided into two main groups, namely the rulers or exploiters and those who are controlled or exploited. The personality of society is formed through the amalgamation of individuals and their cultural actions and reactions. Society is a group of people who are closely intertwined because of certain systems, certain traditions, conventions and certain laws that are the same, and lead to collective life. Society is a group of people who, because of the demands of needs and the influence of certain beliefs, thoughts, and ambitions, are united in collective life. The systems and laws contained in a society reflect individual behaviors because these individuals are bound by these laws and systems. According to anthropologist Elman Service, to make it easier to study the diversity of society, society can be divided into four categories based on increasing population size, political centralization, and social stratification, namely: herd, tribe, unity, and state. The smallest type of society or herd usually consists of only a few groups, many of which are collections of one or several large families. Society is a system that is interconnected between one human being and another human being that forms a unity. Humans as social beings need other humans to meet their needs. They cannot live alone in a society. The criteria for human interaction are described as follows: People do not incarnate because they exist at one point in time, but they exist in time, they are the incarnations of time. Society has always existed from the past to the future. His presence goes through a phase between what has happened and what will happen.

In today's society, there are influences, traces, and plagiarism of the past accompanied by seeds and potential for the future. The essence of society is in accordance with the scenario of the creation of humans as caliphs on earth, namely the upholding of divine justice that applies to nature and humans. Society is a human being who is always in touch (interacting) with other humans in a group. Community life is always changing (dynamic) is something that can not be avoided. Civil society or political society was formed with specific objectives: guaranteeing private property rights and carrying out social order by imposing sanctions on those who break the rules. According to Marion Levy, there are four criteria that must be met in order for a group to be called a community, namely: Meanwhile, according to Soerjono Soekanto, the elements that make up society are as follows: According to Soerjono Soekanto, the characteristics of society are: get along”, or in scientific terms, “interact” with each other. A human unit can have infrastructure so that its citizens can interact with each other. The modern state, for example, is a human unit with various kinds of infrastructure, which enables its citizens to interact intensively, and with high frequency. A modern country has a communication network in the form of a road network, railroad network, air transportation network, telecommunications network, radio and television system, various kinds of newspapers at the national level, a ceremonial system on national holidays and so on. Countries with smaller geographical areas have the potential to interact intensively than countries with very large geographical areas. In addition, if the country is an archipelago, like our country. The existence of infrastructure for interaction causes members of a human group to interact with each other. Conversely, if there is only a potential for interaction, it does not mean that members of a human unit will actually interact.

Guernsey is a British crown dependency with Bailiwick status off the coast of Normandy. Besides the island of Guernsey, Bailiwick Guernsey also includes the islands of Alderney, Sark, Herm, Jethou, Brecqhou, Burhou and other smaller islands. Bailiwick Guernsey together with Bailiwick Jersey form the Channel Islands. The Guernsey region was formed when the sea level rose. At that time, Guernsey was located at the tip of a protruding peninsula in the English Channel. In 6000 BC, Guernsey and its surrounding headlands separated from the European continent and became an archipelago. During the Neolithic period, farmers settled on the coast and created dolmens and menhirs. On the island of Guernsey there are three menhirs that are unique in terms of archeology. Christianity was first introduced to Guernsey by Saint Samson Dol. Guernsey was ruled by the Duchy of Brittany until 933 when the Duchy of Normandy annexed it. The Channel Islands (including Guernsey) are the last remnants of the medieval Duchy of Normandy. Elizabeth II's traditional title as head of state in Guernsey is Duke of Normandy. Bailiwick Guernsey was occupied by German troops during World War II. Many Guernsey residents were sent to camps in southwestern Germany. The area of ​​Bailiwick Guernsey is 78 km² with a coastline of 50 km. Lihou, a high tide island, is connected to Guernsey by an artificial bridge during low tide. Most of Guernsey's surface is flat. Financial services account for 55% of Guernsey's total revenue. The tourism, manufacturing and horticulture sectors are in decline. Guernsey has two seaports and two airports as well as a 5 km railroad. Guernsey's population is 65,031 (2004). The median age for men is 39.6 years and for women 41.5 years. The population growth rate is 0.31% with 9.16 births/1,000 population; 9.87 deaths/1,000 population.

Silver is a metallic element with atomic number 47. Its symbol is Ag, from the Latin argentum, from the root PIE which is reconstructed as *h₂erǵ-, "gray" or "shining". A soft, white, and lustrous transition metal, it has the highest electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, and reflectivity of all metals. The metal occurs naturally in its pure, free form (native silver), as an alloy with gold and other metals, and in minerals such as argentite and chlorargyrite. Most silver is produced as a by-product of copper, gold, tin and zinc mining. Silver has long been valued as a precious metal. More abundant than gold, the metal silver has served in many premodern monetary systems as a coinage species, sometimes even alongside gold. Purity is usually measured on a per-mile basis; a 94% pure alloy is described as "0.940 fine". In addition, silver has many applications beyond currency, such as in solar panels, water filters, jewelry and ornaments, high-value cutlery and furnishings (hence the term silverware), as well as investment in coins and bullions. Silver is used industrially in electrical sockets and conductors, in special mirrors, window coatings and in the catalysis of chemical reactions.
