Its compounds are used in photographic film and X-rays. Aqueous solutions of silver nitrate and other silver compounds are used as a disinfectant and microbicide (oligodynamic effect), added to bandages and wound dressings, catheters and other medical devices. Silver is produced during certain types of supernova explosions by nucleosynthesis from lighter elements via the r-process, a form of nuclear fusion that produces many elements heavier than iron, one of which is silver. Silver is highly elastic, malleable (slightly harder than gold), univalent coinage metal, polishable bright white metallic sheen.

Protected silver has a higher optical reflectivity than aluminum at wavelengths greater than ~450 nm. At wavelengths less than 450 nm, the reflectivity of silver becomes that of aluminum and drops drastically to zero at 310 nm. Silver's electrical conductivity is the highest of all metals, even higher than that of copper, but it is not widely used for electrical purposes due to its high cost. An exception to this is in radio frequency engineering, especially VHF and higher frequencies, where silver plating is applied to increase the electrical conductivity of certain parts and cables (at high frequencies current tends to flow on the surface of the conductor, not inside , therefore gold plating increases the overall conductivity). Silver also has the lowest contact resistance of all metals. During World War II in the US, 13,540 tons were used in electromagnets used for uranium enrichment, mainly because of wartime shortages of copper. Pure silver has the highest thermal conductivity of all metals, although the non-metallic carbon in the diamond form and the superfluid helium-4 are higher. Silver halides are photosensitive and have the amazing ability to record latent images which can then be developed chemically. Silver is stable in pure air and water, but tarnishes when exposed to air or water containing ozone or hydrogen sulfide, the latter forming a black layer of silver sulfide, which can be removed with dilute hydrochloric acid. The most common oxidation state of silver is +1 (eg, silver nitrate, AgNO); less common are +2 compounds (for example, silver(II) fluoride, AgF), even less common are +3 (for example, potassium tetrafluoroargentate(III), KAgF), and even +4 compounds (for example, potassium hexafluoroargentate( IV), K).

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Genetics (an loanword from Latin and Dutch: genetica; from Greek: γέννω, genno, meaning "to give birth") is a branch of biology that studies the inheritance of genes in organisms and sub-organisms. In short it can also be said that genetics is the science of genes and all its aspects. The term "genetics" was introduced by William Bateson in a personal letter to Adam Chadwick and he used it at the 3rd International Conference on Genetics in 1906. In relation to genetics, DNA has a very important role. DNA is the fundamental genetic material that controls the properties of living things, expressed in the form of polypeptides, although not entirely protein (can be expressed as RNA which has a catalytic reaction, such as SNRPs). Francis Crick explained the flow of information carried by DNA in a series of The Central Dogma, which reads that the flow of DNA information can be passed on to cells or other individuals by replication, can be expressed into an intermediate signal in the form of RNA, which can then be translated into polypeptides, units construct a phenotype of an existing organism. The field of genetic studies starts from the subcellular (molecular) region to populations. In more detail, genetics attempts to explain: Although people usually define genetics starting with the rediscovery of the manuscript of an article written by Gregor Mendel in 1900, in fact genetics as "the science of inheritance" or heredity has been known since prehistoric times, such as the domestication and development of various breeds of livestock and plant cultivars. People have also recognized the effects of crosses and inbreeding and made a number of procedures and regulations regarding these matters since before genetics was established as an independent science. The genealogy of diseases in the family, for example, had already been studied before that.

However, this practical knowledge does not provide an explanation of the causes of the symptoms. The popular theory of inheritance that was adopted at that time was the theory of mixed inheritance: a person inherits a flat mixture of traits brought by his parents, especially from males because they carry sperm. The results of Mendel's research showed that this theory was not valid because traits were carried in combinations carried by distinctive alleles, rather than a flat mixture. Another related opinion is Lamarck's theory: traits that parents acquire in life are passed on to their children. This theory also breaks with Mendel's explanation that traits carried by genes are not influenced by the experience of the individual who inherits that trait. Charles Darwin also provided an explanation with the pangenesis hypothesis and later modified by Francis Galton. In this opinion, the body's cells produce particles called gemmula which will be collected in the reproductive organs before fertilization occurs. So, every cell in the body has a contribution to the characteristics that will be brought by zuriat (heredity). In pre-Mendelian times, people did not know about genes and chromosomes (even though DNA had been extracted, but in the 19th century their function was not known). At that time, people still thought that traits were passed on through sperm (the female parent didn't contribute anything to the nature of her child). Laying the scientific basis through systematic experiments was only carried out in the latter half of the 19th century by Gregor Johann Mendel. He was a monk from Brno (Brünn in German), the Austro-Hungarian Empire (now part of the Czech Republic). Mendel is generally accepted as the 'founder of genetics' after his work "Versuche über Pflanzenhybriden" or Experiments on Plant Crosses (published in print in 1866) was rediscovered separately by Hugo de Vries, Carl Correns, and Erich von Tschermak in 1900. Mendel first discovered that the inheritance of traits in plants (he used seven traits in the pea plant, Pisum sativum) followed a number of simple mathematical ratios.

Kosovo (Albanian: Kosova or Kosovë, Serbian: Косово – latin: Kosovo, Turkish: Kosova) is a de facto independent limited territorial recognition state, located in southeastern Europe. Previously, Kosovo was a province in Serbia under UN administration, but on 17 February 2008 Kosovo declared independence unilaterally. This declaration was opposed by Serbia, but supported by Western countries. The capital of Kosovo is Pristina. Kosovo's independence has been officially recognized by various countries, including Albania, the United States, the United Kingdom, France and Turkey. Countries that rejected Kosovo's independence included the People's Republic of China, Russia, and Serbia. The Indonesian government itself was careful in recognizing Kosovo's independence even though there were pressures from some quarters for Indonesia to immediately recognize Kosovo's independence. Kosovo is home to ongoing territorial disputes between the Serbian government and its predominantly ethnic Albanian population. At the founding of Yugoslavia, Kosovo became a province of Serbia with the status of a Special Autonomous Region. But since the war Kosovo has been under UN supervision as a protectorate. Outside of Serbia, the entire region that makes up the country of Kosovo is simply known as Kosovo or, in Albanian, Kosovë (indefinite form) / Kosova (definite form). In contrast, Serbia defines two regions as forming the administrative region of Kosovo: Kosovo (Косово) which is centered on the Kosovo Field located in the east, and Metohija (Метохија) which is centered in the west (in Albanian, Metohija is known as Dukagjini). In Serbian, Kosovo (Косово) is the neuter possessive adjective from kos (кос) meaning black flycatcher. The name is an abbreviation of Kosovo Land (Kosovo Polje (Косово Поље)), a land in eastern Kosovo and the site of the Battle of Kosovo in 1389 between Serb troops and the Ottoman Empire.

The Ottoman government then named a province (vilayet) that included Kosovo and its environs from these lands. The official name of the country of Kosovo, according to the Constitution of Kosovo, is the Republic of Kosovo. Pursuant to the agreement between Belgrade and Pristina brokered by the European Union, Kosovo may join international forums under the name "Kosovo*" with the footnote "This designation is without prejudice to the position of status, and in accordance with UNSC 1244 and the ICJ Opinion on the declaration of independence." Kosovo". The "Asterisk Ordinance" was approved on 24 February 2012. Prior to the declaration of independence, Kosovo was known by several names: "Autonomous Province of Kosovo and Metohija" from 1946 to 1974 and reinstated in 1990, and "Socialist Autonomous Province of Kosovo" from 1974 until 1990. In Serbia, Kosovo is still known by the official name "Autonomous Province of Kosovo and Metohija" (Аутономна Покрајина Косово и Метохиja) as part of its claim to Kosovo. On February 17, 2008 Kosovo gained independence from Serbia. Kosovo has come a long way to achieving independence. The first attempt in 1990 failed because it was invaded by Serbia. The unequal battle between Serbia and the Kosovo or KLA guerrillas resulted in a tragedy of mass massacres and displacement. NATO led by the United States repelled Serbia with airstrikes for 78 days. Kosovo was then under UN and NATO protection. Kosovo's independence effort this time has the support of nearly a third of European Union countries and the United States. Meanwhile, the countries that rejected it were Serbia and Russia. Serbia was so angry at America recognizing Kosovo's independence that it even recalled its ambassador serving in America. According to the Kosovo Statistics Office Survey in 2005, the population of Kosovo is estimated to be between 1.9 and 2.2 million with the following ethnic composition: 92% Albanian, 4% Serb, 2% Bosnian and Gorani, 1% Turkic, 1% of Roma.

Manila (Maynila in Filipino) is the capital of the Philippines. The city is located on the eastern edge of Manila Bay on the Philippines' largest and northern island, Luzon. Despite some places of poverty, it is one of the world's cosmopolitan cities and its metropolitan area is the country's economic, cultural, educational and industrial center. Manila is often called the Pearl of the Orient. Manila is a metropolitan area with a population of over 100 million. The metropolis is called Metro Manila, but is often called simply Manila by foreigners and non-residents there, consisting of 17 cities and municipalities. This article discusses the city; see Metro Manila for articles on the metropolis. This city is the second most populous city in the Philippines after Quezon City, the former capital of the Philippines. Manila and the surrounding area were made into one unit as Metro Manila to facilitate the management of this super fast growth area. Today, the city and metropolis thrive as cultural and economic centers. But the city also has problems of over-population, congestion, pollution. Manila started as a Muslim settlement at the mouth of the Pasig River along the coast of Manila Bay. the origin of the name "manila" itself is from the word fii amanillah which literally means "under the protection of allah. In the mid-16th century, the area around Manila was ruled by three kings namely: King Sulayman and Raja Matanda in the community south of the Pasig River and Raja Lakandula in the north. They also entered into contact with the Sultanates of Brunei, Sulu, and Ternate in Cavite. In 1570, a Spanish expedition under Miguel López de Legazpi established the occupation of Manila. His subordinate, Martín de Goiti, left Cebu and on arrival in Manila, he was received by Muslim Tagalog people.Even so, Goiti attacked Manila with an army of 300 men.

Determinism is the philosophical belief that all events occur as a result of some imperative and therefore inevitable. In particular, the idea that the choices of certain rational agents in the past could have been carried out differently—or even the idea that the decisions of these agents in the future could have resulted in something other than what they desired—usually get challenge in this view. Thus the "problem" of free will—or the idea that free will is an "illusion"—often arises as a result of the central claim produced by determinism, namely that the past, present, and future are identified with a set of conditions. which is essentially unbroken and no single condition can be avoided. Some determinists completely reject the idea of ​​"probability" or "randomness", even stating that these ideas are simply creations of the mind and/or mere products of the imagination. In the end it is a result of ignorance in dealing with all factors. However, talking about free will is a concern in itself, and any discussion of determinism in principle does not require a discussion of free will. Apart from these issues, there are debates about the strenuous effort of language to actually capture what is meant precisely—assuming there is some intent—or what the true nature of reality is regardless of how convincing the nature of the concept of determinism is. "There is a lot of determinism, depending on what preconditions are considered to be the determinants of an event or action." Deterministic theories throughout the history of philosophy have developed out of the diversity and sometimes overlapping of motives and considerations. Some forms of determinism can be tested empirically with ideas from physics and the philosophy of physics.

Madeira is an archipelago off the southwest coast of Portugal and belongs to this country as well. Located in the Atlantic Ocean, about 360 miles west of Morocco, and 540 miles southwest of Lisbon. Madeira and Porto Santo are the two inhabited islands. The main island of the archipelago, Madeira, originally known as the Purple Island by the Romans, was rediscovered (accidentally) by Portuguese sailors and occupied by Portugal in 1418. Today it is an autonomous region. The islands are a popular resort all year round, known for their Madeira wine, artisanal embroidery, landscapes, and beautiful flowers. The archipelago includes the islands of Madeira, Porto Santo and Desertas, which are managed together with the separate islands of the Savage Archipelago. This region has political and administrative autonomy through the Administrative Political Status of the Autonomous Region of Madeira which is regulated in the Portuguese Constitution. The autonomous region is an integral part of the European Union as an outer region. Madeira generally has a very mild to moderate subtropical climate with the Mediterranean causing dry summers and rainy winters, and microclimates are also found at different altitudes. Madeira, originally an uninhabited island, was claimed by Portuguese sailors while serving as Prince Henry's servant in 1419 and settled there in 1420. The archipelago is considered the first territorial discovery of the period of exploration of the Age of Discovery. It is a popular resort location throughout the year, especially for Portuguese residents, but in 2021 tourists from the UK accounted for 148,000 visits, and then Germany with 113,000 visits. Madeira is the most populous island in the Portuguese region, the region is famous for its Madeira wine, flora and fauna and its pre-historic laurel forests which have been classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

The main port is located at Funchal and has long been a prominent Portuguese port for cruise ship docking, as well as an important stopover for Atlantic passenger shipping between Europe, the Caribbean and North Africa. In addition, the Madeira International Business Center or also known as the Madeira Free Trade Zone, was created officially in the 1980s as a regional economic policy tool, this policy consists of a series of incentives, mainly related to taxes, which are provided with the aim of attracting foreign direct investment. based on international services to Madeira. Plutarch in his book Parallel Lives (Sertorius, 75 AD) refers to the military commander Quintus Sertorius (d. 72 BC), relating that after he returned to Cádiz, he met sailors who spoke of the islands in the beautiful Atlantic: "Islands -the islands are said to be two in number separated by a very narrow strait and located 10,000 furlong .0 km] from Africa. They call them the Islands of the Blessed." There is also archaeological evidence to suggest that the islands may have been visited by Vikings between 900 and 1030. Accounts by Muhammad al-Idrisi state that the Mugharrarin discovered an island where they found "a great number of sheep, whose flesh was bitter and not edible" before heading to the even more indisputable and inhabited lands that are the Canary Islands. This island, possibly Madeira or Hierro, must have been inhabited or previously visited by people for livestock. During the reign of King Edward III of England, lovers Robert Machim and Anna d'Arfet are said to have fled England for France in 1346. They were swept up in a violent storm, and their ship ran aground on the coast of an island that may have been Madeira.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Geophysics is a part of earth science that studies the earth using the rules or principles of physics. It also includes meteorology, atmospheric electricity and ionospheric physics. Geophysics research is carried out to determine the conditions under the earth's surface involving measurements above the earth's surface of the physical parameters possessed by the rocks inside the earth. From this measurement it can be interpreted how the properties and conditions below the earth's surface both vertically and horizontally. In different scales, geophysical methods can be applied globally, namely to determine the structure of the earth, locally, namely for mineral exploration and mining including petroleum and on a small scale, namely for geotechnical applications (determination of building foundations and others). Geophysics (in English: geophysics) consists of two words namely Geo which means earth and Physics which means physics. In principle, geophysics solves problems related to the earth using the principles of physics. In geology, research is carried out directly on rocks, conducting historical analysis, examining rock structure and composition with interpretation of measurements using supporting equipment. In Indonesia, this knowledge is studied in almost all state universities. Usually, geophysics is included in the Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Sciences (MIPA), because it requires a strong foundation of physics, or some include it in the Geology section. Currently, both geophysics and geology are almost an integral part of Earth science. Geophysics studies the earth with the principles of physics including heat, electromagnetic, mechanics and waves. Some examples of studies from solid earth geophysics are, for example, seismology which studies earthquakes, the science of volcanoes (volcanoes) or volcanology, geodynamics which studies the dynamics of the movement of earth's plates, and seismic exploration used in the search for hydrocarbons.

The field of study of geophysics includes meteorology (air), solid earth geophysics and oceanography (sea). Usually specialization in geophysics is directed at aspects of oil and gas exploration, geothermal and mining as well as disaster mitigation. In general, geophysical methods are divided into two categories, namely passive and active methods. The passive method is carried out by measuring the natural field emitted by the earth. The active method is carried out by creating a disturbance field and then measuring the response made by the earth. The natural fields referred to here are, for example, earthquake wave radiation, the earth's gravitational field, the earth's magnetic field, the earth's electric and electromagnetic fields and the earth's radioactivity radiation. Artificial fields can be in the form of dynamite explosions, giving electric currents into the ground, sending radar signals and so on. Practically, the methods commonly used in geophysics look like the table below: The seismic method is a method based on the concept of wave propagation in the earth's medium. Seismic methods are divided into two, namely active seismic and passive seismic, active seismic methods namely refraction and reflection (conventional methods) which have become standard in exploration, for passive seismic methods use seismic waves generated by nature so that they can be used to see or predict earthquake disasters earth, but its development is still lacking so it is rarely used for exploration. The systemic method can carry out mapping and monitoring, in monitoring symptoms of increased seismic activity in volcanoes. The presence of magma in the bowels of the earth that rises to the surface affects seismic activity, and when the rocks are no longer able to withstand the pressure, volcanic earthquakes will occur. In the world of exploration and natural gas, seismic methods are used to obtain good depth and boundary resolution of seismic layers, especially using reflection seismic with additional well log data.

Palladium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Pd and atomic number 46. It is a rare, silvery-white, lustrous metal discovered in 1803 by William Hyde Wollaston. He named it after the asteroid Pallas, the nickname of the Greek goddess Athena, which he earned when he killed Pallas. Palladium, platinum, rhodium, ruthenium, iridium, and osmium form the group of elements referred to as the platinum group metals (platinum group metals, PGM). They share similar chemical properties, but palladium has the highest melting point and lowest density of the group. More than half of the supply of palladium and similar platinum goes into catalytic converters, which convert up to 90% of the noxious gases from motor vehicle exhaust (hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide and nitrogen dioxide) into less hazardous substances (nitrogen, carbon dioxide and water vapour). ). Palladium is also used in electronics, dentistry, medicine, hydrogen purification, chemical applications, groundwater recovery and jewelry. Palladium plays a key role in the technology used for fuel cells, which combine hydrogen and oxygen to produce electricity, heat and water. Deposits of palladium and other PGM ores are rare, and the most abundant deposits have been found in the norite belt of the Bushveld Igneous Complex which includes the Transvaal Basin in South Africa, the Stillwater Complex in Montana, United States, the Thunder Bay District in Ontario, Canada, and the Norilsk Complex in Russia. Palladium is in group 10 of the periodic table, but has a very aberrant configuration in its outer electron shell compared to other members of group 10 (see also niobium (41), ruthenium (44), and rhodium (45)), i.e. it has fewer electron shells filled than the previous elements (a unique phenomenon for palladium).

This makes the valence shell have eighteen electrons - ten more than the eight found in the valence shells of the noble gases from neon onwards. Palladium is a soft, silvery-white metal that resembles platinum. It is the least dense and has the lowest melting point of the platinum group of metals. Pd is soft and ductile when heated and greatly increases strength and hardness when cooled. Palladium dissolves slowly in concentrated nitric acid, in hot concentrated sulfuric acid, and in hydrochloric acid when ground. Common oxidation states of palladium are 0, +1, +2 and +4. There are relatively few known compounds with palladium in the +3 oxidation state, although they have been proposed as intermediates in many palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions. In 2002, palladium(VI) was first reported. Coated palladium with defects produced by bombardment of alpha particles at low temperatures exhibits superconductivity with Tc=3.2 K. Natural palladium consists of seven isotopes, six of which are stable. The most stable radioisotopes are 107Pd with a half-life of 6.5 million years (found in nature), 103Pd with a half-life of 17 days, and 100Pd with a half-life of 3.63 days. Eighteen other radioisotopes were identified with atomic masses ranging from 90.94948(64) u (91Pd) to 122.93426(64) u (123Pd). Most have a half-life of less than thirty minutes, except for 101Pd (half-life: 8.47 hours), 109Pd (half-life: 13.7 hours), and 112Pd (half-life: 21 hours). For isotopes with atomic mass unit values ​​less than the most abundant stable isotope, 106Pd, the principal decay mode is electron capture with the primary decay product being rhodium. The main decay mode for Pd isotopes with atomic masses greater than 106 is beta decay which gives the main product silver.

The Republic of Lebanon is a country in the Middle East, along the Mediterranean Sea, and is bordered by Syria to the north and east, and Palestine to the south. The Lebanese flag features a green cedar on a white background, flanked by two horizontal red stripes above and below. Because of its sectarian diversity, Lebanon adheres to a special political system, known as confessionalism, which is intended to divide up seats of power based on representation of different religious sects. Prior to the Lebanese Civil War (1975-1990), the country enjoyed relative calm and prosperity, driven by the tourism, agriculture, and banking sectors of its economy and the native religion of the Lebanese Arab population, the Canaanite religion. Lebanon is considered the banking capital of the Arab world and is generally referred to as the "Switzerland of the Middle East." Due to its financial strength, Lebanon also attracts large numbers of tourists, to the point where its capital, Beirut, is referred to by many as the "Paris of the Middle East." Immediately after the war, there were many attempts to revive its economy and rebuild its national infrastructure. By early 2006, considerable stability had been achieved in most of the country, Beirut's reconstruction was nearing completion, and an increasing number of foreign tourists were arriving to Lebanese resorts. However, the 2006 Lebanon War resulted in civilian and military casualties, extensive damage to civilian infrastructure, and massive displacement from 12 July 2006 until a ceasefire took effect on 14 August 2006. By September 2006, the Lebanese government had put in place an initial recovery plan aimed at building returned property destroyed by Israeli attacks in Beirut, Tyre, and other villages in southern Lebanon. The name Lebanese ("Lubnān" in standard Arabic; "Lebnan" or "Lebnèn" in the local dialect) is derived from the Semitic root "LBN", which is related to a number of closely related meanings in various languages, such as white and milk.

This is thought to be a reference to the snow-topped Mount Lebanon. This name appears on three of the 12 tablets of the Epic of Gilgamesh (2900 BC), Ebla library text (2400 BC), and the Bible. The word Lebanon is also mentioned 71 times in the Old Testament. A country in the Middle East, Lebanon is bordered on the west by the Mediterranean Sea (coast line: 225 kilometers) and on the east by the Syrian-African Depression. Lebanon is bordered by Syria for 375 km to the north and to the east; with Israel along 79 km to the south. The border with Israel has been approved by the UN (see Blue Line (Lebanon), although a small piece of land called Shebaa Farms which is located on the Golan Heights is claimed by Lebanon but occupied by Israel, which claims it is Syrian land. The UN has officially declared that this territory does not belong to Lebanon, but that Lebanese fighters occasionally launch attacks on Israelis who reside in it. would inevitably seek to fairly represent the demographic distribution of denominations in government.Therefore, high positions in government are reserved for members of certain religious groups.For example, the President of Lebanon, must be a Maronite Catholic Christian, Prime Minister seor a Sunni Muslim, the Deputy Prime Minister is an Orthodox Christian, and the Speaker of Parliament is a Shi'a Muslim. This division was the result of an unwritten agreement in 1943 between the President (Maronite) and the then Prime Minister (Sunni) and was only formalized by the constitution in 1990. This trend continued in the distribution of the 128 parliamentary seats which were split in half between Muslims and Christians.

Others Others Sunni (/ˈsuːni, ˈsʊni/, KBBI: Suni) are the largest branch of Islam, belonging to 85–90% of the Muslim population. Its name comes from the word Sunnah, i.e. imitating what the Islamic Prophet Muhammad taught. The difference between Sunni and Shia is related to the conflict about who is appropriate as Muhammad's successor which leads to differences between aqidah and fiqh. According to Sunni tradition, Muhammad had no successors and those involved in the Saqifah affair appointed Abu Bakr as caliph. This is different from the Shia view, which considers that Muhammad appointed Ali bin Abi Talib as his successor. People who adhere to this branch of Islam prefer to refer to themselves as "experts of sunnah", or more fully ahlus-sunnah wal-jamāʻah ("people who follow the Sunnah and are in the group of Jamaah"). Followers of ahlus-sunnah are known as Sunnis. Sunnis are often referred to as "Orthodox Islam", although many religious scholars and scholars oppose this. Al-Qur'an and hadith (mainly those contained in Kutubussittah) and ijma', become the basis of Sunni fiqh. Sharia was derived by considering these sources, along with qiyas, istislah, and istihsan, using the ijtihad method developed by the priests of the schools of thought. In terms of faith, Sunnis adhere to the pillars of faith. In addition, Asy'ariyah and Maturidiyah adherents adhere to an understanding of theology and textual thought which are also referred to as Atsariyyah. When the Prophet Muhammad died, there was a misunderstanding between the Muhajirin and Ansar groups as to who would become the leader of the Muslims. The Companions saw that this would lead to discord between the Muhajirin and Ansar Muslims. After each submitted a delegation to determine who the Khalifah (successor of the Prophet Muhammad saw). Finally it was agreed by the Muslims to appoint Sayyidina Abu Bakr ra as caliph. citation needed] During the Caliphate III, Sayyidina Uthman bin Affan ra, there was quite serious slander in the body of Islam at that time, which resulted in the martyrdom of Caliph Uthman ra.

His killers were a group of delegations set up by Abdullah bin Saba' from Egypt who wanted to rebel against the caliph and wanted to kill him. Abdullah bin Saba' managed to develop a misguided understanding to pit Muslims against each other in order to destroy Islam from within. Then many people at that time, especially the men of Abdullah bin Saba' managed to kill Sayyidina Uthman ra in a sadistic manner while he was reading the Qur'an. reference needed] When Sayyidina Ali became caliph, he experienced many difficulties. The people who were influenced by Abdullah bin Saba' continued to pit the companions against each other. Their efforts were successful. Friends have a misunderstanding about the legal case of killing Caliph Uthman ra. The first comes from ummul mu'minim, Sayyidatina Aisyah ra, who was with Sayyidina Thalhah ra and the second is with Sayyidina Zubair ra. They were successfully pitted against each other until the Jamal War or the Camel War occurred. And then by Sayyidina Muawiyah ra who was appointed by Sayyidina Uthman ra as governor in Sham, resulting in the Shiffin War. Seeing the large number of sacrifices from the Muslim community, the disputing parties held ishlah or reconciliation. The rebels are not happy with the peace between the Muslims. Then there was a rebellion by those who initially pretended/hypocritical and they are the group called Khawarij. reference needed] The Khawarij wanted to seize the caliphate. However, they were prevented by Sayyidina Ali and Sayyidina Muawiyah ra, so they planned to kill them both. Ibn Muljam from the Khawarij managed to kill the caliph, Sayyidina Ali ra when he was leading the dawn prayer in Kufa, but not against Sayyidina Muawiyah ra because he was closely guarded. Even Sayyidina Muawiyah ra succeeded in consolidating himself and the Muslims, thanks to his political skills and the rigidity of his leadership.

Mutations are changes that occur in genetic material both at the gene level and at the chromosomal level. Mutations at the gene level are called point mutations, while mutations at the chromosomal level are usually called aberrations. Mutations in genes can lead to the emergence of new alleles and form the basis for new variations within species. Mutations occur at a low frequency in nature, typically lower than 1:10,000 individuals. Mutations in nature can occur due to mutation-generating substances (mutagens, including carcinogens), solar radiation, radioactivity, ultraviolet rays, X-rays, and electrical energy jumps such as lightning. Individuals who show changes in character (phenotype) due to mutations are called mutants. In genetic studies, mutants are usually compared with individuals who do not experience any change in traits (wild-type individuals). Point mutations are changes to the N base of DNA or RNA. Point mutations are relatively common but their effects can be mitigated by gene recovery mechanisms. Point mutations can result in changes to the sequence of amino acids in proteins, and can result in reduction, change or loss of enzyme function. Current technology uses point mutations as markers (called SNPs) to study changes that occur in genes and are associated with phenotypic changes that occur. An example of a gene mutation is the reaction of nitric acid with adenine to form hypoxanthine. This substance will take the place of the original adenine and pair with cytosine, no longer with thymine. Chromosomal mutations, often also called major mutations or chromosomal aberrations, are changes in the number of chromosomes and the arrangement or sequence of genes in the chromosomes. Chromosomal mutations often occur due to errors in meiosis and few in mitosis. Euploidy is the change in the n number. In this case, "n" denotes the number of sets of chromosomes. For example, human body cells have 2 packages of chromosomes so they are called 2n, where one human n package has 23 chromosomes.

Euploidy is divided into two, namely autopolyploidy and allopolyploidy. In autopolyploidy, the n doubles itself due to errors in meiosis, while in allopolyploidy, that is, marriage or hybridization between species with different number of sets of chromosomes. Aneusomy is a change in the number of chromosomes. The cause is anaphase lag (the event of the spindle threads not attaching to the centromere) and non disjunction (failure to separate). Aneusomy in humans can cause: Occurs when a fragment of a chromosome is broken and lost during cell division. The chromosome from which the fragment originates will then be missing certain genes. However, in some cases, these broken fragments can bind to homologous chromosomes to produce duplications. The fragment can also be reattached to the original chromosome in the reverse direction and results in an inversion. Substances that cause mutations are called mutagens. Mutagens are divided into three, namely: In general, mutations are detrimental, the mutants are lethal and homozygous recessive. However, mutations are also beneficial, for example, through mutations, superior polyploid plants can be created. For example, seedless watermelons, seedless oranges, large strawberries, and so on. This mutation is also one of the keys to evolution in this world. The formation of polyploid plants is beneficial for humans, but detrimental for plants that have mutations, because these plants become unable to reproduce generatively. Although biologically most mutations cause disturbances in individual fitness, even death, mutations are actually one of the keys to the adaptability of a species (species) to a new or changing environment. This positive side is exploited by a number of fields of applied biology. The application of radiotherapy radiation (such as X-ray irradiation) and chemotherapy to inhibit the growth of tumor and cancer cells is basically to induce mutations in cancer cells as the target.

Aluminum is a chemical element. Aluminum's symbol is Al (Latin: Aluminium), and its atomic number is 13. Aluminum is the most abundant metal. Aluminum is not a heavy metal, but it is an element that accounts for about 8% of the earth's surface and is the third most abundant. Aluminum is present in food additives, antacids, buffered aspirin, astringents, nasal sprays, antiperspirants, drinking water, car exhaust, tobacco smoke, use of aluminum foil, cookware, cans, ceramics and fireworks. Aluminium is a good electricity conductor. Light and strong. It is a good conductor of heat too. It can be hammered into sheet, stretched into wire and extruded into bars of various cross-sections. corrosion resistance. Alumunium used in many things. Most of it is used in high-voltage cables. Also widely used in window frames and aircraft fuselage. Found in homes as pots, soft drink bottles, milk bottle caps etc. Aluminum is also used to cover car lights and compact disks. In the 19th century, before the discovery of electrolysis, aluminum could only be obtained from bauxite by the Wöhler chemical process. Compared to electrolysis, this process is not very economical, and the price of aluminum used to far exceed that of gold. Once considered a precious metal, Napoleon III of France (1808-1873) once served his first guest with aluminum dishes and his second guest with gold and silver plates. In 1886, Charles Martin Hall of the United States (1863-1914) and Paul L.T. French Héroult (1863-1914) invented the process of electrolysis that has hitherto made aluminum production economical. The first person to separate aluminum from its compounds was Orsted in 1825 by reducing aluminum chloride, but not yet in a pure state.

Pure aluminum was discovered by Wohler in the form of a gray powder in 1827 by modifying the Orsted process. Today the process used to obtain aluminum on a large scale is the Hall-Heroult process. This method was discovered by two people who were the same age (23 years) but in different places, namely Charles Martin Hall in America and Heroult in Paris in 1886. This process made these two people rich in a short time and died in the same year ( 1914). After this method was discovered, the price of aluminum, which was initially very expensive, dropped drastically. Aluminum refining is carried out in two stages: The aluminum production process starts with extracting aluminum-containing mining materials (bauxite, corundum, gibbsite, boehmite, diaspore, and so on). Next, the mined material is brought to the Bayer process. The Bayer process produces alumina (Al2O3) by washing aluminum-containing minerals with Al(OH)3 sodium hydroxide solution. Aluminum hydroxide is then heated to a temperature slightly above 1000 oC to form alumina and H2O which becomes water vapor. After Alumina is produced, it is conveyed to the Hall-Heroult process. The Hall-Heroult process begins by dissolving alumina in molten Na3AlF6, or cryolite as it is commonly called. The solution is then electrolyzed and will cause molten aluminum to stick to the anode, while the oxygen from the alumina will be oxidized along with the anode which is made of carbon, forming carbon dioxide. Liquid aluminum has a lighter density than alumina solution, so separation can be done easily. The electrolysis of aluminum in the Hall-Heroult process consumes a significant amount of energy. The world's average consumption of electrical energy in electrolyzing alumina is 15 kWh per kilogram of aluminum produced. Electrical energy accounts for around 20-40% of the cost of producing aluminum worldwide.

in Europe  (gray) The Principality of Liechtenstein (German: Fürssuretum Liechtenstein) (alternative name: Listenstaina) Vaduz is a principality area of ​​approximately 160 square kilometers that is doubly landlocked. Located on the east bank of the River Rhine between Austria and Switzerland. All foreign affairs of this German-speaking country are taken care of by Switzerland. Liechtenstein is a constitutional monarchy headed by the Prince of Liechtenstein. Economically, Liechtenstein has one of the highest gross domestic products per person in the world when adjusted for purchasing power parity. The country has a strong financial sector centered in Vaduz. Liechtenstein was once known as a billionaire tax haven, but it no longer exists due to being on the official blacklist of uncooperative tax haven countries. As an Alpine country, Liechtenstein has mountains that make it a winter sports destination. In addition, Liechtenstein relies on its income from the tourism sector, especially the sale of stamps. Liechtenstein is a member of the United Nations, the European Free Trade Association and the Council of Europe. Although not a member of the European Union, it participates in the Schengen Area and the European Economic Area. The country has a customs union and a monetary union with Switzerland. Who is this noble family?] originates from Liechtenstein Castle in Lower Austria, which it belonged to at least from 1140 to the 13th century, and from 1807 onwards. Henry I. von Liechtenstein (d. 1265) was ruler of Nicolsburg, Liechtenstein and Petronell. Over the centuries, this dynasty acquired bits and pieces of territory, especially in Moravia, Lower Austria, Silesia and Styria, although in each case the they were fiefdoms under other, more senior feudal lords, notably the various descendants of the Habsburg house, of which several princes of Liechtenstein served as their close advisors.

As such, and because none of their territories were directly subordinate to the throne of the Holy Roman Empire, the House of Liechtenstein was unable to fulfill the primary prerequisite for a seat on the Imperial Council of the Reichstag. A seat on the government of the Imperial Council would add power, and was assigned to the fiefs who were responsible directly (Reichfreiheit), ie without going through any other feudal lord, to the Holy Roman Emperor as the primary owner of the rights to the lands of the empire. The heads of these noble families were later able to arrange purchases with the Hohenems of the small county of the Schellenberg Chair in 1699, and the County of Vaduz in 1712. Schellenberg and Vaduz did not have any other feudal lords apart from their own sovereign regents, and as vassals to the Emperor. On January 23, 1719, after the purchase had taken place, Charles VI as Holy Roman Emperor decreed the union of Vaduz and Schellenberg and was elevated to the Principality, with the name "Liechtenstein" in honor of his true "servant," Anton Florian Liechtenstein. On that date, Liechtenstein became a member state of the Holy Roman Empire. The princes of Liechtenstein had not set foot in the new principality for decades, attesting to the purely political importance of the purchase. According to the Constitution of the Principality of Liechtenstein Household of 26 October 1993, all members other than the reigning prince are entitled Prince or Princess of Liechtenstein as well as Regent or Female Regent of Rietberg. Liechtenstein is located in the Upper Rhine valley in the European Alps and is bordered on the east by the Austrian state of Vorarlberg and on the south by the canton of Grisons (Switzerland) and on the west by the canton of St. Gallen (Switzerland). The River Rhine forms Liechtenstein's entire western border.

in Europe  (gray) Serbia or officially the Republic of Serbia (Serbian: Република Србија or Republika Srbija) is a republic in southeast, and central Europe. From 2003 to 2006, Serbia joined Montenegro in a commonwealth called the Union of Serbs and Montenegro with Belgrade as its capital. Serbia is bordered by Hungary to the north, Romania and Bulgaria to the east, North Macedonia and Albania to the south, and Montenegro, Croatia, and Bosnia-Herzegovina to the west. Serbian origins date back to the early-mid 9th century. The Serbian kingdom emerged in the 11th century, and in the 13th century it became the Serbian Empire. After 1918, Serbia was a founding member of Yugoslavia in several state forms (Kingdom of Yugoslavia, Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and Federal Republic of Yugoslavia). On May 21, 2006, the people of Montenegro held elections in the form of the Montenegro Independence Referendum and 55.5 percent of the electorate wanted Montenegro independence. Then on June 3, 2006, the Parliament of Montenegro proclaimed the independence of Montenegro, so that Montenegro became a separate country. The modern Serbian state was born in 1817 following the Second Serbian Uprising. Then, this country expanded southwards by taking control of Kosovo and Metohija, Raška, and Macedonia in 1912. Finally, Vojvodina (formerly an autonomous region within the Habsburg Voivodeship named Voivodship Serbia and Tamiš Banat) declared its separation from Austria-Hungary and joined returned with Serbia in 1918. as a former colony of Turkey during the Ottoman dynasty. The current state borders of Serbia were defined following the end of the Second World War when Serbia became a federal unit within the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. Serbia became an independent nation again in 2006 after Montenegro left the State Union of Serbs and Montenegrins that emerged after the dissolution of Yugoslavia in the 1990s.

Meditation or meditation is a practice that involves releasing the mind from all things that are interesting, burdensome, or worrying in our daily lives. The literal meaning of meditation is the activity of chewing or flipping through the mind, thinking, contemplating. The meaning of the definition, meditation is structured mental activity, carried out over a certain period of time, to analyze, draw conclusions, and take further steps to address, determine actions or resolve personal, life, and behavioral problems. In other words, meditation releases us from the agony of highly subjective good and bad thoughts which are proportionally directly related to our attachments to certain thoughts and judgments. We begin to understand that life is an endless series of subjective thoughts, judgments, and releases that intuitively let's start letting go. In a state of mind that is free from thinking activity, it turns out that humans do not die, nor faint, and remain conscious. The best teacher for meditation is experience. There are no teachers, seminars, or meditation books that can teach exactly how we should live a meditative life. Meditation or meditation is often misinterpreted, considered the same as daydreaming so that meditation is considered a waste of time and is of no use. Meditation is actually a conscious act because the person doing the meditation knows and understands what he is doing. The benefits of meditation that we do can be directly or indirectly felt physically. One of these benefits is the healing we get, if we suffer from certain illnesses. From a physiological point of view, meditation is the best anti-stress. When you experience stress , heart rate and blood pressure increase, breathing becomes quick and short, and the adrenal glands pump out stress hormones. As you meditate, your heart rate slows down, your blood pressure normalizes, your breathing calms down, and your level of stress hormones decreases. During meditation, over time you can listen to your heart beat, and even more so you can coordinate the rhythm of your heart rate with the rhythm of going in and out. breath.

Radon is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Rn and atomic number 86. Radon also belongs to the noble gas group and is radioactive. Radon is formed from the decay of radium. Radon is also the heaviest and most dangerous gas for health. Rn-222 has a half-life of 3.8 days and is used in radiotherapy. Radon can trigger lung cancer and is responsible for 20,000 deaths in the European Union each year. Radon is chemically non-reactive, but radioactive. Radon is a gas with a high density of 9.73 g/L (the heaviest gas at standard temperature and pressure is tungsten hexafluoride, WF6, with a density of 13 g/L). At room temperature and pressure, radon is colorless but when cooled until it freezes, radon turns yellow, while liquid radon is red-orange. The natural buildup of radon gas in the earth's atmosphere occurs very slowly so that water that touches free air continues to lose radon due to the "volatilization" process. Groundwater has a higher radon content than surface water. Radon is sometimes used by some hospitals for therapeutic purposes. The radon is obtained by pumping from a radium source and stored in small tubes called ''seeds'' or ''needles''. Radon is rarely used anymore, but considering that hospitals can now get seeds from a "supplier" that produces seeds with the desired decay rate. Cobalt and cesium are usually used, which are durable for several years, making it more practical from a logistical point of view. Due to its rapid decay, radon is also used in hydrologic investigations that study the interactions between groundwater, streams and rivers. An increase in radon in a creek or river is an important indication that an underground water source exists.

The name radon comes from radium. Radon was discovered in 1900 by Friedrich Ernst Dorn, who designated it as radium emission. In 1908 William Ramsay and Robert Whytlaw-Gray, who named it niton (from the Latin nitens meaning "shining"; symbol Nt), isolated it, determined its density and they found that Radon was the heaviest gas at that time (and still is today). . Since 1923 element 86 has been called Radon. On average, there is one molecule of radon in 1 x 1021 molecules of air. Radon can be found in some springs and hot springs. The city of Misasa, Japan, is famous for its radium-rich springs which produce radon. Radon is released from the soil naturally, especially in the land areas of Granite. It is also possible for radon to accumulate in basements and living quarters (however this also depends on how the house is maintained and how well ventilated it is) The European Union has determined that the safe limit for radon is 400 Bq/meter3 for old houses, and 200 Bq/m3 for new houses . The American ''Environmental Protection Agency'' recommends taking immediate action for all homes with a Radon concentration exceeding 148 Bq/m3 (measured as 4 pCi/L). Nearly one home every 15 in the U.S. has statistically high levels of radon (U.S. Surgeon General) and the EPA recommends that all homes be tested for radon. Since 1985 in America, millions of homes have been tested for radon content. Tests show that fluorine can react with radon and form radon fluoride compounds. Radon clathrate compounds have also been found. There are twenty isotopes of radon known. The most stable is Rn-222 which is a byproduct of the decay of radium-236, Rn-222 has a half-life of 3.823 days (330,307.2 seconds) and emits alpha particles.

General election (abbreviated as Election) is the process of choosing someone to fill a certain political position in Indonesia. These positions vary, ranging from presidential/executive positions, people's representatives/legislative institutions at various levels of government, to village heads. In a broader context, Elections can also mean the process of filling positions such as student council president or class president, although for this the word 'election' is more often used. Elections are one of the efforts to influence the people persuasively (not forcing) by carrying out rhetorical activities, public relations, mass communication, lobbying and other activities. Although agitation and propaganda in democratic countries are highly criticized, in general election campaigns, agitation and propaganda techniques are widely used by candidates or politicians, always political communicators. In elections, voters in elections are also called constituents, and it is to them that election participants offer their promises and programs during the campaign period. The campaign was carried out during a predetermined time, leading up to voting day. After voting is done, the counting process begins. Election winners are determined by the rules of the game or a winner-determination system that has previously been determined and approved by the participants, and socialized to the voters. According to Law No. 7 article 348-350 of 2017, voters are Indonesian citizens who are even 17 years old or older, whether married or not and have been married. In elections, voters are usually divided into three categories of voters. The categories of voters are permanent voters, additional voters and special voters. In 2019 these three categories are used as election standards. Permanent voters are voters who have been registered at the KPU and registered on the DPT (permanent voter list). Voters for this category have been checked and updated by the KPU with proof of having an invitation to vote or C6.

Additional voters are categories of voters who move to vote at another TPS from the TPS that has been determined. According to Law No.7 article 210 of 2017, additional voters must report no later than 30 days before voting. At the time of voting additional voters bring their vote transfer letter (A5), KTP and other identity documents (KK, passport or driver's license). Special voters are categories of voters who are not registered on the DPT (Permanent Voter List) and DPTb (Additional Voter List). Special voters can vote by bringing their KTP or other identity to the TPS. The Voting Organizing Group (KPPS) will give voting rights taking into account the availability of ballot papers at TPS. The party list (party-list) in a proportional system is divided into 4, namely: If the number of votes has the same then it is taken from the top number of votes. all the above rounding count methods. An example of a general election is as follows: For example, it is enough to be divided into 2, namely parts 1 and 2 only. Description: Note: For example, it is sufficient to divide into 2, namely parts 1 and 2 only. Note: Description: Note: Note: x is the number of DPR seats won by each party. An absolute majority means that each political party wins as much as two-thirds of the total number of seats in the DPR and can change the rules of the Constitution. An ordinary majority means that each political party wins between half and two-thirds of the total number of seats in the DPR but cannot change the provisions of the Constitution. The majority of the coalition is that each political party wins less than half of the total number of seats in the DPR but is in the first position so that it must form a coalition to achieve at least half of the total number of seats in the DPR. Note: x is the number of DPR seats won by forming a coalition.

The Republic of Yemen is a southernmost country on the Arabian Peninsula in Southwest Asia, part of the Middle East. Yemen is bordered by the Arabian Sea to the south, the Gulf of Aden and the Red Sea to the west, Oman to the east and Saudi Arabia to the north. Most of the people of Arab descent in Indonesia come from this country. Yemen's population is estimated at around 23 million. The area of ​​this country is around 530,000 km2 and its area includes more than 200 islands. Its largest island, Socotra, is located about 415 kilometers south of Yemen, off the coast of Somalia. Yemen is the only republic on the Arabian Peninsula. In ancient times, Yemen was home to the People of Sabae, a trading nation that included parts of today's Ethiopia and Eritrea. Then in 275 AD, the Himyar Kingdom was influenced by Judaism. Christianity arrived in the fourth century. Islam spread rapidly in the seventh century and the Yemeni forces played a crucial or very important role in the early Islamic conquests. Several dynasties emerged in the 9th to 16th centuries, such as the Rasulid dynasty. The country was divided between the Ottoman and British empires in the 1800s. The Zaidid school of Mutawakkiliyah Yemen was founded after World War I prior to the formation of the Yemen Arab Republic—also known as North Yemen with Islam as the official religion of the majority Sunni and Zaidi school of Shia Islam—in 1962. The People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, also known as the Yemeni People's Democratic Republic as the communist-leaning South Yemen, it remained a British protectorate as the Aden Protectorate until 1967 when it became an independent state and later, a Marxist-Leninist state. The two Yemeni countries united to form the Republic of Yemen (al-Jumhūrīyah al-Yamanīyah) as it is today in 1990.

President Ali Abdullah Saleh was the first president of the new republic until his resignation in 2012 following the Arab Spring. Yemen is a member of the Arab League, the United Nations, the Non-Aligned Movement and the Organization of Islamic Cooperation. It belongs to the group of least developed countries (group of least developed countries), referring to many "severe structural obstacles to sustainable development". In 2019, the United Nations reported that Yemen is the country most in need of humanitarian assistance, with around 24 million people, or 85% of its population. In 2020, the country ranks highest on the Index of Failing Countries, second worst on the Global Hunger Index, surpassed only by the Central African Republic, and has the lowest Human Development Index of all non-African countries. As of February 2004, Yemen was divided into twenty governorates (muhafazat) and one municipality called "Amanat Al-Asemah" (the latter containing the capital city, Sana'a). sub-districts, and then into 38,284 villages (as of 2001). Asia is the largest continent on Earth bordered by the Ural Mountains and the Caucasus and the Arctic, Pacific and Indian Oceans. This continent covers 8.7% of the total surface area of ​​the Earth and comprises 30% of its land area. With around 4.3 billion people, they make up 60% of the world's human population today. Asia has a high growth rate in the modern era. For example, during the 20th century, Asia's population nearly quadrupled. The continents of Asia and Europe are continents that are connected by land and both form a giant continent known as Eurasia. The boundaries between Asia and Europe are so blurred that countries like Turkey can sometimes be included in both Asia and Europe. Some of the landscapes that are often used to separate the two continents are the Dardanelles Strait, Marmara Sea, Bosphorus Strait, Black Sea, Caucasus Mountains, Caspian Sea, Ural River (or Emba River), and the Ural Mountains to Novaya Zemlya. Apart from being directly adjacent to the European continent, the Asian continent also has a direct border with the African continent which has land borders and meets around the Suez Canal. Given its size and diversity, the Asian concept – the name goes back to classical times – may actually have more to do with human geography than physical geography. Asia is extremely diverse and within each of its regions there are well-established ethnic groups, cultures, environments, economies, historical relationships, and systems of government. The word "Asia" entered Indonesian, via Dutch, from Ancient Greek Ασία (Asia; see also list of traditional Greek place names). The name is first attempted at Herodotus (in 440 BC), which refers to Asia Minor; or, for the purpose of portraying the Persian Wars, to the Persian Empire as the enemy of Greece and Egypt.

Even before Herodotus, Homer knew of the Trojan pass named Asios, son of Hyrtacus, ruler over several cities, and he describes the marshes as "ασιος" (ilias 2, 461). The Greek term derived from Assuwa, a confederation of states in Western Anatolia in the 14th century BC. Hittite assu - "Good" was probably part of the name. Also, the principal origin of the term is probably from the Akkadian (w)aṣû(m), which is a relative of the Hebrew word יצא, meaning "go out" or "go up", referring to the direction of the sun at dawn (sunrise). in the Middle East, and also seems to be related to the Phoenician word asa meaning east. This contrasts perhaps with the proposed European origin of the word, from Arabic and Persian erēbu "to enter" or "to set" (for the sun). However, the origins of the Mesopotamian or Middle Eastern expectations would not explain how the term "Asian" first came to be combined with Anatolia as the western abode of the vernacular Persian Arabic. As already mentioned, Asia can be considered as a part of the larger Eurasian continent. For divisions based on this term, see Northern Eurasia and Central Eurasia. Asia itself is often divided into several regions: There is no definite consensus on the use of this term, but it usually includes: East Asia is also called the Far East, because Europeans saw it as geographically very far from Europe. This term includes: This area includes the Malacca Peninsula, Indochina and the islands of the Indian and Pacific Oceans. The countries included in this area are: Malaysia is divided into two parts by the South China Sea, and the mainland, the first land on the Malacca Peninsula, and the second on the island of Borneo.

The Republic of Guatemala is a country in Central America, in the south of the North American continent, bordered by the Pacific Ocean and the Caribbean Sea. It is bordered by Mexico to the north, Belize to the northwest, and Honduras and El Salvador to the southeast. Guatemala is one of the largest coffee producing countries in the world. The Mayan civilization ruled Guatemala and the surrounding area until around 1,000 AD. After 1,000 AD, Guatemala was a Spanish colony for approximately three centuries, until 1821 when Guatemala won its independence. Since Guatemala's independence, the country has experienced various governments, including civilian and military ones. In 1996, a peace treaty was signed by the government that ended the internal conflict in the region, which resulted in more than 200,000 deaths and around one million refugees. Guatemala was once famous when a gigantic earthquake devastated the country on February 4, 1976. Injured 74,000 people and destroyed 22,000 people. Located the most northerly among the countries of Central America. Its land area is slightly smaller than the province of West Kalimantan, and is bordered by Mexico to the north, west and east, Belize, Honduras and El Salvador to the east. With the exception of the southern seaboard and the vast Petern lowlands in the north, Guatemala is mostly mountainous, with a hot tropical climate — more hospitable in the highlands, and drier in the easternmost department. All major cities are located in the southern half of the country; Its major cities are the capital Guatemala City, Quetzaltenango and Escuintla. The large lake Lago de Izabal is located near the Caribbean coast. Guatemala's unicameral parliament, the Guatemalan Congress (Congreso de la República) with 158 seats, is elected every 4 years, concurrent with presidential elections.

Thallium is a chemical element with the symbol Tl and atomic number 81. It is a gray, poor metal that is not found free in nature. When isolated, thallium resembles lead, but changes color when exposed to air. Chemists William Crookes and Claude-Auguste Lamy independently discovered thallium in 1861, in the residue of sulfuric acid production. Both use the flame spectroscopy method, in which thallium produces striking green spectral lines. Thallium, from the Greek θαλλός, thallós, meaning "green shoot" or "twig", was named by Crookes. He was isolated by Lamy and Crookes in 1862; Lamy through electrolysis, and Crookes through the precipitation and melting of the resultant powder. Crookes exhibited it as a powder precipitated by zinc at the international exhibition, which opened on May 1 that year. Thallium tends to form the +3 and +1 oxidation states. The +3 state resembles that of the other elements in group 13 (boron, aluminum, gallium, indium). However, the +1 state, which is much more prominent in thallium than in the elements above it, is reminiscent of the chemistry of the alkali metals, and thallium(I) ions are found geologically mostly in potassium-based ores, and (when ingested) are handled in much like potassium ions (K+) by ion pumps in living cells. Commercially, thallium is not produced from potassium ore, but as a by-product of refining heavy metal sulfide ores. About 65% of thallium production is used in the electronics industry, and the rest is used in the pharmaceutical industry and in the manufacture of glass. It is also used in infrared detectors. The radioisotope thallium-201 (as the soluble chloride TlCl) is used in small quantities as a scanning agent in nuclear medicine, during a type of nuclear cardiac stress test.

Soluble thallium salts (many of which are nearly tasteless) are highly toxic, and were historically used in rat poison and insecticides. Because of their nonselective toxicity, the use of these compounds has been restricted or banned in many countries. Thallium poisoning usually causes hair loss. Due to its historical popularity as a murder weapon, thallium has gained fame as the "poisoner's poison" and "heritage powder" (along with arsenic). A thallium atom has 81 electrons, arranged in the electron configuration Xe]4f145d106s26p1; In this configuration, the three outermost electrons in the sixth shell are valence electrons. As a result of the oblique pair effect, the 6s electron pair is relativistically stabilized and it is more difficult to involve it in a chemical bond than it is for heavier elements. Thus, very few electrons are available for metallic bonding, similar to neighboring elements such as mercury and lead. Thallium, like its relative, is a soft, highly electrically conducting metal with a low melting point of 304°C. A number of standard electrode potentials, depending on the reactions studied, are reported for thallium, reflecting a large decrease in the stability of the +3 oxidation state: Thallium is the first element in group 13 in which the reduction of the +3 oxidation number to +1 occurs spontaneously under standard conditions. Since the bond energies decrease down the group, with thallium, the energy released in forming two additional bonds and reaching the +3 state is not always sufficient to exceed the energy required to engage the 6s electrons. Thus, thallium(I) oxide and hydroxide are more basic and thallium(III) oxide and hydroxide more acidic, indicating that thallium conforms to the general rule that an element is more electropositive at lower oxidation states. Thallium feels quite malleable and can be cut with a knife at room temperature.

Boron is a chemical element with the symbol B and atomic number 5. In its crystal form, it is a brittle, dark, and shiny metalloid; in its amorphous form, it is a brownish powder. As the lightest element in the boron group, it has three valence electrons to form covalent bonds, giving rise to many compounds such as boric acid, the mineral sodium borate, and ultrahard crystals of boron carbide and boron nitride. Boron is synthesized entirely by cosmic ray spallation and supernovae, and not by stellar nucleosynthesis, so it is a low abundance element in the Solar System and in the Earth's crust. It covers about 0.001 percent of the total weight of the Earth's crust. It is concentrated on Earth by the water solubility of its more common natural compound, the mineral borates. This mineral is mined industrially as an evaporite, such as borax and kernite. The largest known deposits are in Turkey, the largest producer of the mineral boron. Elemental boron is a metalloid found in trace amounts in meteoroids but chemically uncombined boron is not found naturally on Earth. Industrially, very pure elements are produced with difficulty due to contamination by carbon or other elements that resist removal. There are several allotropes of boron: amorphous boron is a brownish powder; crystals of boron are silvery to black, very hard (about 9.5 on the Mohs scale), and a poor conductor of electricity at room temperature. The main use of boron is as a boron filament with applications similar to carbon fiber in some high-strength materials. Boron is used primarily in chemical compounds. About half of all production consumed globally is an additive in glass fibers for insulation and structural materials.

The next major use is in polymers and ceramics in high-strength, lightweight and heat-resistant structural materials. Borosilicate glass is preferred because of its greater strength and resistance to thermal shock than ordinary soda lime glass. As sodium perborate, it is used as a bleach. Small amounts of boron are used as dopants in semiconductors, and reagent intermediates in the synthesis of organic fine chemicals. Several organic boron-containing pharmaceuticals have been used or are being studied. Natural boron consists of two stable isotopes, one of which (boron-10) has a number of uses as a neutron capturing agent. Boron's intersection with biology is minuscule. Consensus on this as essential to mammalian life is lacking. Borates have low toxicity to mammals (similar to table salt) but are more toxic to arthropods and are sometimes used as insecticides. Boron-containing organic antibiotics are known. Although only trace amounts are required, it is an important plant nutrient. The word boron was coined from borax, the mineral from which it was isolated, by analogy with carbon, which is chemically similar to boron. Borax in its mineral form (later known as tincal) was first used as a glaze, starting in China around AD 300. Some raw borax traveled west, and is apparently mentioned by the alchemist Jabir bin Hayyan around AD 700. Marco Polo brought some glazes back to Italy in the 13th century. Around 1600 AD, Georgius Agricola, reported the use of borax as a flux in metallurgy. In 1777, boric acid was discovered in hot springs (soffioni) near Florence, Italy, which became known as sal sedativeum, with obvious medical benefits. The mineral is given the name sasolite, from Sasso Pisano in Italy.

(−2 ± 8) × 10−22 e (experimental limit) The neutron or neutron is a subatomic particle that has no charge (neutral) and has a mass of 940 MeV/c² (1.6749 × 10−27 kg, slightly heavier than the proton. Its spin is ½. The atomic nucleus of most atoms (all but the most common isotope Hydrogen, which consists of a proton) is composed of protons and neutrons. Outside the nucleus, neutrons are unstable and have a half-life of about 15 minutes (881.5±1.5 seconds), decays by emitting electrons and antineutrinos to become protons.The same method of decay (beta decay) occurs in some atomic nuclei.The particles in an atomic nucleus are usually neutrons and protons, which change into one another by the emission and absorption of pions.A neutron is classified as a baryon and is composed of two down quarks and one up quark.The antibody Neutron's equivalent is an antineutron.The main difference between a neutron and other subatomic particles is that they have no payload. This property of the neutron made his discovery more retarded, and highly penetrating, making it difficult to observe directly and making it extremely important as an agent in nuclear change. The research conducted by Rutherford, apart from being successful in obtaining several satisfactory results, also found an oddity, namely that the mass of the atomic nucleus of an element is always greater than the mass of the protons in the atomic nucleus. Rutherford suspected that there were other particles in the atomic nucleus that were uncharged because atoms were positively charged due to the presence of positively charged protons. The existence of other particles in the atomic nucleus that is not charged was proved by James Chadwick in 1932. Chadwick conducted research by shooting beryllium metal using alpha rays. The results showed that an uncharged particle is released when beryllium metal is bombarded with alpha rays and these particles are called neutrons.

In Buddhism, Nirvana (Sanskrit: निर्वाण nirvāṇa; Pali: nibbāna; Chinese: 涅槃; pinyin: nièpán) is the culmination of the Buddhist quest for freedom from samsara, the cycle of death and rebirth. Siddartha Gautama, the Buddha, described Buddhism as a raft which, having floated down a river, would allow its passengers to reach nirvana. In a deeper sense, Nibbana is the highest bliss, a state of extraordinary eternal bliss. [citation needed] The bliss of Nibbana cannot be experienced by indulging the senses, but by calming them. Nibbana is not a place. Nibbana is not an absence or extinction. Nibbana is not a heaven. There are no suitable words to describe this Nibbana. Nibbana can be realized by eliminating greed (lobha), hatred (dosa) and delusion (moha). citation needed] In the Udana VIII:3, Nibbana is explained by the Buddha as follows: Further in the Milinda Panha Book it is also explained about Nibbana through The conversation between the Bhikkhu Nagasena and King Milinda goes as follows: So it can be concluded that Nibbana is not a place or realm of existence, but a state free from all defilements which are the cause of the sufferings of birth, old age, disease, death, pain, lamentation and despair. despair, namely Greed (Lobha), Hatred (Sin), and Ignorance (Moha). Nibbana can be attained while still alive (Sa-upadisesa Nibbana) and when you die (An-upadisesa Nibbana). When Prince Siddhartha attained Perfect Enlightenment and became Samma Sambuddha, then at that time He experienced Sa-upadisesa Nibbana. When Buddha Gotama died at the age of 80 in Kusinara, he attained An-upadisesa Nibbana or Parinibbana. The way to attain Nibbana is to practice the Noble Eightfold Path for yourself, namely: Hinduism also uses nirvana as a synonym for their thoughts on Moksha, and nirvana is spoken of in several Hindu tantric writings as well as the Bhagawad Gita.

Rubidium is a chemical element with the symbol Rb and atomic number 37. Rubidium is a very soft whitish-gray metal in the alkali metals group. Rubidium metal is similar to potassium metal and cesium metal in physical appearance, softness and conductivity. Rubidium cannot be stored under atmospheric oxygen, as a highly exothermic reaction would occur, sometimes even causing the metal to catch fire. Rubidium is the first alkali metal in its group to have a higher density than water, so it sinks, unlike the metals above it in its group. Rubidium has a standard atomic weight of 85.4678. On Earth, naturally occurring rubidium consists of two isotopes: 72% of which is the stable 85Rb, and the remaining 28% is the slightly radioactive 87Rb, with a half-life of 48.8 billion years—more than three times the estimated age of the universe. German chemists Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff discovered rubidium in 1861 by a newly developed technique, namely flame spectroscopy. The element's name comes from the Latin word rubidus, meaning dark red, from the color of its emission spectrum. Rubidium compounds have a wide range of chemical and electronic applications. Rubidium metal is volatile and has a convenient spectral absorption range, making it a frequent target for laser atomic manipulation. Rubidium is not a known nutrient for any living organism. However, rubidium ions have the same properties and the same charge as potassium ions, and are actively taken up and treated by animal cells in the same way. Rubidium is a very soft, ductile, silvery-white metal. It is the second most electropositive stable alkali metal and melts at 393 °C (739 °F).

Like other alkali metals, rubidium metal reacts violently with water. As with potassium (which is slightly less reactive) and cesium (which is slightly more reactive), this reaction is usually strong enough to ignite the hydrogen gas it produces. Rubidium has also been reported to spontaneously ignite in air. It forms amalgams with mercury and alloys with gold, iron, cesium, sodium, and potassium, but not with lithium (although rubidium and lithium are in the same group). Rubidium has a very low ionization energy, only 406 kJ/mol. Rubidium and potassium show a very similar purple color in the flame test, and distinguishing the two elements requires more sophisticated analysis, such as spectroscopy. in others, it is used to induce living cells to take up DNA; it is also used as a biomarker, because in nature, it is only found in small amounts in living organisms and when present, replaces potassium. Another common rubidium compound is the corrosive rubidium hydroxide (RbOH), the starting material for most rubidium-based chemical processes; rubidium carbonate (Rb2CO3), used in some optical glasses, and rubidium copper sulfate, Rb2SO4·CuSO4·6H2O. Rubidium silver iodide (RbAg4I5) has the highest room temperature conductivity of any known ionic crystal, a property that is exploited in thin film batteries and other applications. Rubidium will form a number of oxides when exposed to air, including rubidium monoxide (Rb2O), Rb6O, and Rb9O2; rubidium in excess oxygen will produce superoxide RbO2. Rubidium will form salts with the halogens, giving rubidium fluoride, rubidium chloride, rubidium bromide, and rubidium iodide. Although rubidium is a monoisotope of the element, rubidium in the Earth's crust consists of two isotopes: the stable 85Rb (72.2%) and the radioactive 87Rb (27.8%).

Meiosis (from the Greek for "reduction") is a type of cell division that occurs in organisms that reproduce sexually to produce gamete cells such as sperm or egg cells. The main feature of meiosis is that it occurs in two stages of division. Ultimately, cells that undergo meiosis will produce four cells with each cell having only one copy of the parent chromosome (haploid). In addition, before the first division, the chromosomes of cells undergoing meiosis will share genetic material with each other in a process called crossing over which will result in a combination of genetic material in each of the cell's chromosomes. Later, when this haploid meiotic cell fuses with another haploid cell in a process called fertilization, the cell with two pairs of chromosomes (diploid) will form again as a zygote. This mechanism of meiosis allows organisms that reproduce sexually to maintain the number of chromosomes. In humans and animals, meiosis occurs in the gonads and produces gamete cells such as spermatocytes or egg cells. In plants, meiosis occurs in the antheridium and ovary and produces meiospores which will later differentiate into gamete cells as well. The first stage that occurs in the process of meiosis is DNA replication. This DNA replication will produce a new chromatid for each chromosome (now the term chromosome refers to the two sister chromatids). Next, the first meiotic division will produce haploid cells but still have sister chromatids so that another division is needed to release sister chromatids.
