This haploid cell is the end product of meiosis which has half the chromosomes of the parent. The first division is called meiosis I and the second division is called meiosis II. Before meiosis can begin, the cell must first undergo interphase.

The DNA of each chromosome is replicated to produce two sister chromatids that are identical and bonded together. This replication occurs in the S-phase. After DNA replication, the cell will enter the G2 phase. Furthermore, homologous chromosomes (chromosomes that encode the same properties, but one is of paternal origin, while the other is of maternal origin) will pair with each other to form a tetrad and share genetic material in a process called genetic recombination. This process is aided by a physical bridge formed between the two homologous chromosomes called chiasmata (from the Greek, chi (X)). In many organisms, this bonding will direct each pair of homologous chromosomes to separate from each other in the process of meiosis I, resulting in a haploid cell that has half the number of chromosomes but its sister chromatids are still attached. In meiosis II, the cohesion between these sister chromatids begins to break free and they begin to segregate from one another as in the process of mitosis. This process results in four types of cells that have haploid chromosomes and no longer have sister chromatids. In some organisms, these four cells will turn into gametes such as sperm, spores, or pollen. In female animals (including humans), three of these four cells will be eliminated to become polar bodies so that only one cell will develop into a gamete to form an egg (ovum). Because their chromosome number is halved during meiosis, these gametes can fuse (fertilize) to form a diploid zygote consisting of two copies of a chromosome, one from each parent. Thus, repeated cycles between meiosis and fertilization allow sexual reproduction to occur. Through this cycle, the next generation can maintain the same number of chromosomes as its parent.

Knowledge is information or information that is known or realized by someone. Knowledge includes, but is not limited to descriptions, hypotheses, concepts, theories, principles and procedures that are Bayesian Probability correct or useful. In another sense, knowledge is a variety of symptoms encountered and obtained by humans through the observation of reason. Knowledge arises when a person uses his mind to recognize certain objects or events that have never been seen or felt before. For example, when someone tastes a new dish that he is familiar with, he will gain knowledge about the shape, taste, and aroma of the dish. Knowledge is information that has been combined with understanding and the potential to act; which then sticks in someone's mind. In general, knowledge has the ability to predict something as a result of recognizing a pattern. Where information and data only have the ability to inform or even cause confusion, then knowledge has the ability to direct action. This is called the potential to act. Knowledge possessed by a person, of course, comes from various sources. Here are the sources of knowledge: In the view of the philosophers, reason is the source of knowledge. This view arises from the fact that knowledge is not formed by soul and matter. Therefore, knowledge must be sourced from a substance that is not material in terms of substance or actualization. The degree of this source of knowledge must be higher than that of the soul. This is based on the view that the soul in its actualization is still bound by matter. This substance is then referred to as reason. Especially in the subject matter of Knowledge Management, there are two main types of knowledge when viewed from their explicitity: Implicit knowledge is knowledge that is still embedded in the form of one's experience and contains factors that are not real such as personal beliefs, perspectives, and principles.

One's silent knowledge is usually difficult to transfer to others either in writing or orally. The ability to speak, design, or operate complex machines or tools requires knowledge that cannot always be seen explicitly, nor is it so easy to transfer it to others explicitly. A simple example of implicit knowledge is the ability to ride a bicycle. Common knowledge of how to ride a bicycle is that in order to balance, if the bicycle turns to the left, then point the steering wheel to the right. To turn right, first turn the steering wheel to the left a little, then when the bike is leaning to the right, turn the steering wheel to the right. But knowing that alone is not enough for a beginner to be able to steer a bicycle. A person who has implicit knowledge is usually unaware that he actually has it and also how that knowledge can benefit others. To get it, learning and skills are needed, but not necessarily in written forms. Implicit knowledge often contains customs and culture of which we are not even aware. Explicit knowledge is knowledge that has been documented or stored in a tangible form in the form of media or the like. It has been articulated in formal language and can be disseminated relatively easily. The most common forms of explicit knowledge are instructions for use, procedures, and how-to videos. Knowledge can also be mediated audio-visually. Art work and product design can also be seen as a form of explicit knowledge which is an externalization of human skills, motives and knowledge. How to make implicit knowledge explicit is a key function of a Knowledge Management strategy. Knowledge that emphasizes observation and sensory experience is known as empirical knowledge or a posteriori knowledge.

The Creation Narrative according to the Book of Genesis (English: Genesis creation narrative) is a record of the creation of the universe according to Judaism and Christianity. Consists of two parts, roughly equivalent to the first two chapters of the Book of Genesis. In the first part, Genesis 1:1-2:4, Elohim, which is the generic Hebrew word for "God", created the heavens and the earth in six days, beginning with the light that brightened the darkness on the first day, and ending with the creation of man on the sixth. . God then rested, blessed and sanctified the seventh day or Sabbath. In the second part, Genesis 2:4-2:25 God, referred to by His personal name, "Yahweh", created the first man (Adam) from the dust of the ground and breathed life into him. God then placed him in the Garden of Eden and created the first woman (Eve) from Adam's rib as his companion. There are those who view that the universe created in the record of Genesis 1:1–2:4 seems to bear a resemblance to the Tabernacle recorded in Exodus 35–40, and this was a prototype of the Temple in Jerusalem, as well as a center for Yahweh worship through the priests. Because of this, and because the creation story in other Middle Eastern regions also climaxes in the erection of a temple or shrine for a creator-god, Genesis 1 can be interpreted as the building of the universe as God's temple, where the Temple in Jerusalem is a reflection on earth. The use of numbers in ancient texts is often numerological rather than factual - that is, they were used because they had symbolic meaning for their authors. The number "seven", symbolizing divine perfection, permeates Genesis 1: Genesis 1:1-51:1   In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.1:2   The earth was formless and empty; darkness covered the great ocean, and the Spirit of God hovered over the surface of the waters. 1:3 God said: "Let there be light."

Then there was light. 1:4 God saw that the light was good, so He separated the light from the darkness. 1:5 And God named the light day, and the darkness night. The opening sentence of Genesis 1:1 is generally translated as given above. There are some scholars who think that this sentence could actually be translated in at least 3 ways: It has been argued recently that the second version is what the authors of class of "Priestly". The verb "bara" ("to create") is used only of God, (humans are not involved in the act of bara), and this is related to the assignment of roles, since in the first creation humans were "male and female" (i.e., the allocation of gender ). In other words, Allah's power is shown not only by the creation of matter, but also by determining destiny. One interpretation states that the phrase "heaven and earth" is a unity denoting "everything", that is, "the universe". It occurs in 3 levels, the world inhabited by life is in the center, the heavens above and the realm below the earth below, completely surrounded by an "ocean" of waters of chaos (= chaos). It is associated with the Bebel Tiamat myth. In that myth, the earth is described as a flat disk, surrounded by mountains and seas. Above it is the firmament, a solid transparent dome that rests on the mountains, enabling men to see the blue waters above, with "windows" that let in the rain, and contain the sun, moon and stars. The waters that are under the earth, leaning on pillars that are submerged under the earth as Sheol, the abode of the dead. The opening sentence of Genesis 1 is followed by: "(And) the earth was formless and void..." The phrase "formless and empty" is a translation of the Hebrew phrase "tohu wa-bohu", (Hebrew: תֹהוּ וָבֹהוּ‎), which is the state "chaotic" (=chaos), which is then ordered by the act of creation (bara).

Predation or predation is a biological interaction when a predator organism kills and eats another organism which is its prey. It is one of a number of common feeding behavior types that includes parasitism and micropredation (which usually does not kill the host) and parasitoidism (which it always does eventually). This is different from scavenging on dead prey, although many predators also scavenge. This overlaps with herbivores because both seed predators and destructive frugivores are predators. Predators may actively seek, chase, or wait for prey, which is often hidden. When prey is tracked, the predator judges whether to attack it or not. This can sometimes be accompanied by an ambush or chase after stalking prey. If the attack is successful, the predator kills the prey, removes any inedible parts, such as shells or thorns, and eats it. Predators are adapted to keen senses, such as sight, hearing, or smell, which are often highly specialized for hunting. Many predators, both vertebrates and invertebrates, have sharp claws or jaws for gripping, killing, and tearing their prey. Other adaptations include aggressive and stealthy mimicry that increase hunting prowess. Predation has such a strong selective effect on prey that prey develops antipredator adaptations, such as warning colours, distress calls and other signals, camouflage, well-defended species mimicry, spines and defensive chemicals. Predators and prey sometimes enter into evolutionary arms races, adaptation cycles, and opposing adaptations. Predation has been a major driver of evolution since at least the Cambrian period. At the most basic level, predators kill and eat other organisms. However, the concept of predation is very broad, defined differently in different contexts and includes various methods of feeding, as well as some relationships which do not result in the death of the prey not generally called predation.

Parasitoids, such as ikneumon wasps, lay their eggs in or on their host. Then, the eggs hatch into larvae that eat their host and eventually die. Zoologists generally refer to this as parasitism, although parasites are generally considered to not kill their hosts. A predator can be defined differently from a parasitoid in that a predator has many prey items to catch during its life and a parasitoid larva has only one or at least has a food supply for it on only one occasion. There are other things that are difficult and limited. Micro predators are small predator-like animals that feed entirely on other organisms. These animals include fleas and mosquitoes which feed on the blood of living animals, and aphids which feed on the sap of living plants. However, these animals are now often regarded as parasites because they usually do not kill their hosts. Animals that graze on phytoplankton or microbial mats are predators because they eat and kill the organisms they feed on, but herbivores that graze on grass are not, because the plants they eat usually survive such attacks. When an animal eats seeds (seed predation or granivore) or eggs (egg predation), it eats the entire living organism, which makes it a predator by definition. Scavengers, organisms that feed only on organisms found dead, are not predators, but many predators such as jackals and hyenas which scavenge when the opportunity arises. Among invertebrates, the social (yellow-skinned) wasp is a hunter and scavenger of other insects. While examples of predators among mammals and birds are well known, they can be found in a variety of taxa including arthropods. It is common among insects, including mantis, dragonflies, netwing insects and scorpion flies. In some species, such as the alder fly, only the larvae are prey, as the adults do not eat.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union   (light blue) Lesotho, officially the Kingdom of Lesotho, is a landlocked enclave in southern Africa completely surrounded by South Africa. It is over 30,000 km2 in size and has a population of slightly over two million. Its capital and largest city is Maseru. Formerly known as Basutoland, Lesotho declared its independence from the United Kingdom on 4 October 1966. The country is a member of the United Nations, the Commonwealth of Nations and the South African Development Community (SADC). The name Lesotho roughly means the land of people who speak the Sesotho language. About 40% of the population live below the international poverty line standard with an income of US$ 1.25 per day. At the beginning of the nineteenth century, wars caused suffering in the southern regions of Africa. Some residents fled to mountainous areas. In the 1820s they reunited to become a Basotho nation with its leader being appointed king Moshoeshoe I. Lesotho was colonized by the British from 1868, but became an independent kingdom since 1966. Lesotho covers an area of ​​30,355 km2. This country is the only independent country where all of its parts are located above 1,000 meters. The lowest point is 1,400 m, and more than 80% of Lesotho is located at altitudes exceeding 1,800 m. Lesotho is also the largest landlocked country in the world and is completely surrounded by South Africa. Due to its altitude, Lesotho remains colder year-round than other areas at the same latitude. Maseru and the surrounding lowlands often reach 30°C in summer. Winter can bring lowland temperatures down to -7°C and upland to -20°C at times.

Contextualism describes a set of views in philosophy that emphasize the context in which an action, utterance, or expression takes place, and hold that, in some important respects, be it an action, utterance, or utterance can only be understood relative to that context. The contextualist view holds that controversial philosophical concepts, such as "the meaning of P", "knowing that P", "having reasons for A", and perhaps even "being right" or "being right" only have meanings relative to the given context. Some philosophers argue that context dependence can lead to relativism; However, the contextual view is gaining popularity in philosophy. In ethics, the "contextual" view is often associated with situational ethics, or with moral relativism. In architectural theory, contextualism is a theory of design in which modern building types (not to be confused with modernism) adapt ordinary city forms to traditional cities. The contextual principle is one of Gottlob Frege's three fundamental principles for philosophical analysis, first discussed in his Introduction to the Foundations of Arithmetic (Grundlagen der Arithmetik, 1884). Frege argues that there are many philosophical errors, especially those related to psychology in the philosophy of logic and philosophy of mathematics, so that these mistakes can be avoided by adhering to the principle of context. The meaning of the view expressed by the principle of context is sometimes called contextualism, but it should not be confused with the contemporary use of the term contextualism according to its epistemology or ethics. This view need not be contrasted with the view that the meaning of a word or expression can (or must) be determined in advance, and regardless, the meaning of the proposition in which it occurs, is often referred to as composition. The principle of context is also prominent in the work of other analytic philosophers, such as Bertrand Russell and Ludwig Wittgenstein, who were heavily influenced by Frege's work.

In epistemology, contextualism is the treatment of the word 'know' as context-sensitive. Context sensitive expressions are contexts that "advance different propositions relative to the use of different contexts". For example, some relatively uncontroversial terms considered context sensitive are indexical, such as 'I', 'here', and 'now'. While the word 'I' has a linguistic meaning that is constant in all contexts of use, which refers to various contexts. Likewise, contextual epistemic argues that the word 'know' is context sensitive, expressing different relationships in different contexts. Contextualism was introduced, in part, to undermine the skeptical argument that has this basic structure: The contextualist's solution is not to reject any premise, or say that the argument does not follow, but to relate the truth value (3) to the context, and say that we can reject (3) in everyday conversational contexts like contexts - where we have different requirements to say we know. The main principle of contextual epistemology, no matter what kind of knowledge it adheres to, what is important is that knowledge links are sensitive to context. Then the truth value of the term "know" depends on the context in which it is used. We can realize that in a context where the standard for claiming correct knowledge is very high-e. e., in a skeptical context - if we say something like 'I know that I have hands' then this statement will be false. Nonetheless, if we utter the same proposition in an ordinary context - for example, in a cafe with friends -, where a lower standard is available, the statement will be true, even more so, the negation will be false. So, it is only when we participate in philosophical discourse of a skeptical kind, do we seem to lose our knowledge.

Light is energy in the form of visible electromagnetic waves with a wavelength of about 380–750 nm. In physics, light is electromagnetic radiation, with both visible and invisible wavelengths. Moreover, light is a packet of particles called photons. Both definitions are properties that light exhibits simultaneously so it is called "wave-particle dualism". Packages of light called the spectrum are then perceived visually by the sense of sight as colors. The field of study of light, known as optics, is an important research area in modern physics. The study of light began with the emergence of the era of classical optics which studied optical quantities such as: intensity, frequency or wavelength, polarization and phase of light. The properties of light and its interaction with the surroundings are carried out using a geometric paraxial approach such as reflection and refraction, and an approach to its physical optical properties, namely: interference, diffraction, dispersion, polarization. Each study of classical optics is called geometrical optics (en:geometrical optics) and physical optics (en:physical optics). At the peak of classical optics, light was defined as an electromagnetic wave and sparked a series of discoveries and thoughts, dating back to 1838 by Michael Faraday with the discovery of cathode rays, 1859 with the theory of black mass radiation by Gustav Kirchhoff, 1877 Ludwig Boltzmann said that the energy state of a physical system can be became discrete, quantum theory as a model of black mass radiation theory by Max Planck in 1899 with the hypothesis that radiated and absorbed energy could be divided into discrete quantities called elemental energies, E. In 1905, Albert Einstein made an experiment on the photoelectric effect, light which shines light on the atom excites electrons to shoot out of their orbits. In 1924 experiments by Louis de Broglie showed that electrons have particle-wave duality properties, so that the theory of particle-wave duality was born.

Albert Einstein later in 1926 made a postulate based on the photoelectric effect, that light is composed of quanta called photons that have the same duality. The work of Albert Einstein and Max Planck won the Nobel Prizes in 1921 and 1918 respectively and became the basis for the theory of quantum mechanics developed by many scientists, including Werner Heisenberg, Niels Bohr, Erwin Schrödinger, Max Born, John von Neumann, Paul Dirac, Wolfgang Pauli, David Hilbert, Roy J. Glauber and others. This era was later called the era of modern optics and light was defined as the dualism of electromagnetic transverse waves and streams of particles called photons. Further development occurred in 1953 with the discovery of the maser beam, and laser light in 1960. The era of modern optics did not necessarily end the era of classical optics, but introduced other properties of light, namely diffusion and scattering. The Ancient Greeks believed that everything was composed of the four elements of fire, air, earth and water. In the fifth century BC, Empedocles stated that the goddess Aphrodite created the human eye from these four elements. He also kindled a fire in the eyes so that rays came out of the eyes and allowed humans to see. Empedocles added that there is an interaction between light from the eye and light from sources such as the sun so that humans cannot see at night. Around 300 BC, Euclid wrote his Optica which discussed the properties of light. Euclid stated that light travels in straight lines and he studied the laws of reflection mathematically. He questioned the notion that vision is the result of light emanating from the eye. If a person closes his eyes at night and opens them, he will immediately see a distant star.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Psychology is a field of science and applied science that studies human behavior, mental functions and mental processes through scientific procedures. A person who practices psychology is referred to as a psychologist. Psychologists try to improve a person's quality of life through certain interventions on mental function, individual and group behavior, which are based on physiological, neurological and psychosocial processes. The word Psychology comes from the Ancient Greek: psyche (meaning breath, soul or mind) and logos (meaning words, discourse and knowledge), so that literally, psychology means the study of mind. The term "psychology" is a mistake that often arises because the word "psychology" itself means "science of the soul". The history of the development of psychology is generally divided into 3 periods, namely pre-systematic psychology, systematic psychology and scientific psychology. Pre-systematic psychology begins when humans begin to contemplate their existence. These reflections are irregular in nature and are generally associated with mythological and religious thought. Systematic psychology began to develop in 400 BC through Plato's thoughts. Psychology began to be given contemplations that are rationally ordered. Meanwhile, scientific psychology began to develop at the end of the 19th century AD. Psychology is a separate science that has various factual conclusions with clear definitions. As part of science, psychology has gone through a long journey. The concept of psychology can be traced back to the ancient Greeks. Psychology has roots in the field of philosophy which was initiated since the time of Aristotle as the science of the soul, namely the science of life force (levens beginsel). Aristotle saw psychology as a science that studies the phenomena of life. The soul is the element of life (Anima), therefore every living thing has a soul.

The history of psychology paralleled intellectual developments in Europe, but found its pragmatic form in the Americas. Although there has always been an idea about a science that studies humans along with the idea of ​​a science that studies nature, due to the complexity and dynamics of human understanding, psychology has only been created as a science since the late 1800s, when Wilhelm Wundt founded a psychology laboratory. first in the world. In 1879, Wilhelm Wundt founded the first Psychology laboratory at the University of Leipzig, Germany. Marked by the establishment of this laboratory, Wundt cemented psychology as an independent field of experimental study even though the scientific method to better understand humans was not very adequate. With the establishment of this laboratory, the conditions for making psychology a science are complete. Thus, the year Wundt's laboratory was founded is also recognized as the date of the founding of psychology as a science. Beginning in the 19th century, at which time 2 theories developed to explain behavior, namely: Psychology has three functions as a science, namely: The following: In the developmental psychology method, there are 2 methods, namely the general method and the special method. in this general method the approach used is a longitudinal, transversal, and cross-cultural approach. From this approach it can be seen that there is data obtained as a whole for development or only a few aspects and can also look at various factors from innate and environmental, especially culture. Whereas the special method is a method that will be investigated with a careful and definite process of tools or calculations. In this approach can be used with experimental and observational approaches.

Twins or twins are two or more individuals who share the same uterus and are usually, but not always, born on the same day. In humans, mothers with wombs carrying twins will thus experience multiple deliveries and usually a shorter gestation period (34 to 36 weeks) than singleton pregnancies. Because premature birth usually has health consequences for the baby, multiple births are often treated in a different way than regular births. Twins are common in animals because many animals produce mature (ready to be fertilized) eggs at the same time. Domestic animals such as cats, dogs, rats or sheep usually have more than one child. Judging from the origin of the zygote, there are two types of twin births: fraternal (dizygotic) and identical (monozygotic). Dizygotic twins are common in vertebrates, while monozygotic twins are rare. Humans have this ability. The nine-banded armadillo (Dacypus novemcinctus) when giving birth always has monozygotic quadruplets. Dizygotic twins (known as "non-identical twins") occur because the zygotes that form come from different eggs. There is more than one egg attached to the uterine wall that is fertilized by sperm cells at the same time. In humans, the process of ovulation sometimes releases more than one mature egg into the fallopian tube which, if fertilized, gives rise to more than one zygote. Dizygotic twins are genetically no different from siblings and develop in separate amnions and placentas. They can have different or the same sex, but with the consequence of having a different physical appearance such as face, posture, skin color, or hair. Studies also show that the talent for giving birth to DZ twins is passed on to their offspring (genetic), but only female offspring/ females who are able to show it (because only females/females can regulate the release of eggs).

The term wet twins is given to twins with different sexes. The term mixed twins is given to twins with different skin colors. Monozygotic twins occur when a single egg is fertilized and forms a zygote (monozygotic). During its development, the zygote divides into different embryos. The two embryos develop into fetuses that share the same uterus. Depending on the stage of separation of the zygote, identical twins may share the same amnion (known as monoamniotic) or different amnions. Furthermore, identical non-monoamniotic twins may or may not share the same placenta (known as monochorionic, monochorionic). All monoamniotic twins are definitely monochorionic. Sharing the same amnion (or the same amnion and placenta) can cause complications in pregnancy. For example, the umbilical cord of monoamniotic twins can become entangled, reducing or interfering with blood supply to the developing fetus. MZ twins are always of the same sex and are genetically the same (clones) except when there is a mutation in the development of one individual. The degree of resemblance to these twins is very high, with the difference sometimes occurring in the form of a mirror resemblance. Differences occur in details, such as fingerprints. As individuals grow older, the level of similarity usually decreases due to different personal experiences or lifestyles. Research from Fraga et al. (2005) revealed that there is an epigenetic influence in the process that distinguishes individuals who are MZ twins, due to different activated genes. Although there is the influence of habit or experience that influences these differences, scientists think random processes play more of a role in the differences that occur. Studies with mice have even shown differences in activity in histones (related to epigenetics) of the first four cells formed. Until now scientists have not agreed on the existence of a genetic influence for the occurrence of MZ twins.

Epigenetics (English: epigenetics), in biology, is the study of changes in phenotype or genetic expression caused by mechanisms other than changes in the basic DNA sequence. Epigenetics comes from the Greek, epi- which means "over" or "covers", and -genetics. There is no change in the basic DNA sequence, but rather non-genetic factors that cause the organism's gene expression to change. The best example of epigenetic change in eukaryotes is the process of cell differentiation. During morphogenesis, totipotent stem cells transform into various pluripotent cells of the embryo which then transform into fully differentiated cells. In other words, a zygote, a fertilized egg, turns into various types of cells, such as neurons (nerve cells), muscle cells, epithelium, blood vessels, and so on, which will then continue to divide. This is the case where the activation of some genes results in the muting of others. Another example is as shown in the figure, two cloned mice with the same gene and different DNA methylation status produce different genetic expressions. The history of epigenetics is related to the study of evolution and development, but then the term epigenetics has undergone changes along with the rapid increase in understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes. Until the 1950s, the term epigenetics was used differently, namely to group all developmental events starting from the zygote to the adult organism, in this case all the regulatory processes, starting from the genetic material which then forms the final product (Waddington, 1953). Organisms used in epigenetic research include Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Schizosaccharomyces pombe, Neurospora crassa, which are single-cell and low-level eukaryotic organisms with short life cycles, Arabidopsis thaliana in which there is suppression of gene transcription by complex RNAi, Tetrahymena and Paramecium which having a unique dimorphic cell nucleus, Caenorhabditis elegans and Drosophila melanogaster, invertebrates which are multicellular organisms, to vertebrate organisms (mammals).

Abortion or abortion (Latin: abortion) is the ending of a pregnancy by removing the fetus or embryo before it has the ability to survive outside the uterus, resulting in its death. note 1] Abortion that occurs spontaneously is also called "miscarriage". Intentional abortions are often called "induced abortions" or "provocated abortions". The word abortion is generally only used in the sense of abortion provocatus. A similar procedure performed after the fetus has the potential to survive outside the uterus is also known as a "late-stage abortion". It is said that abortion in developed countries, where it is permitted, is one of the safest medical procedures in medicine. Modern methods use drugs or surgery in carrying out abortions. The drug mifepristone in combination with prostaglandins is probably as safe and effective as surgery during the first and second trimesters of pregnancy. Birth control, such as pills or an intrauterine device, may be used immediately after the abortion. It is reported that provocatus abortion, if carried out safely and legally, does not increase the risk of physical or mental problems in the long term. In contrast, unsafe abortions result in 47,000 deaths and 5 million hospitalizations each year. The World Health Organization recommends making safe and legal abortion available to all women. About 56 million abortions occur annually worldwide, with nearly half of them being carried out unsafely. The number or rate of abortion changed little between 2003 and 2008, having previously declined for at least two decades due to increased access to birth control and family planning. In 2008, 40% of women worldwide had access to legal abortions without any particular restrictions as reasons.

Each country that permits abortion has different limits on how late a pregnancy abortion is allowed. Since ancient times, abortions have been performed using herbal medicines, sharp objects, coercion, or other traditional methods. There are differences in abortion laws and religious or cultural views around the world. In some jurisdictions, abortion is legal in certain cases such as rape, problems with the fetus, poverty, risk to the mother's health, or incest. In various regions of the world there are many debates related to moral, ethical and legal issues in the case of abortion. Those who oppose abortion generally insist that the embryo or fetus is a human person with the right to life and they equate abortion with murder. Meanwhile, those who support the legality of abortion are generally of the view that a woman has the right to make decisions about her own body. The act of abortion according to the Indonesian Criminal Code (KUHP) is categorized as a criminal act. The articles of the Criminal Code that regulate this are articles 299, 341, 342, 343, 346, 347, 348, and 349. According to the Criminal Code, abortion is: In medical science, these terms are used to distinguish abortion: Spontaneous abortion is abortion which take place without action, in this case are distinguished as follows: A. Definition Imminent abortion is spotting bleeding that indicates a threat to the continuity of a pregnancy. Under these conditions it is still possible for the pregnancy to continue or be maintained. (Syaifudin. Bari Abdul, 2000) Imminent abortion is vaginal bleeding in pregnancy less than 20 weeks, without signs of increasing cervical dilatation (Mansjoer, Arif M, 1999) Imminent abortion is vaginal discharge that appears in the first half of pregnancy (William Obstetrics, 1990) B. Etiology Abortion can occur for several reasons, namely: C. Clinical Features D. Pathophysiology At the beginning of an abortion, decidual basalis bleeding occurs, followed by necrosis of the surrounding tissue which causes the products of conception to detach and are considered foreign bodies in the uterus.

Thorium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Th and atomic number 90. Thorium metal is silvery and stains black when exposed to air, forming thorium dioxide; This metal is quite hard, malleable, and has a high melting point. Thorium is an electropositive actinide whose chemistry is dominated by the +4 oxidation state; this element is quite reactive and can ignite in air when finely divided. All known isotopes of thorium are unstable. The most stable isotope, 232Th, has a half-life of 14.05 billion years, or about the age of the universe; this isotope decays very slowly through the process of alpha decay and begins a decay chain called the "thorium series" ending at the stable 208Pb. On Earth, thorium, bismuth and uranium are the three radioactive elements that still exist naturally in large quantities as primordial elements. a] It is estimated that thorium is three times more abundant than uranium in the Earth's crust. Thorium metal is primarily refined from monazite sand as a by-product of the extraction of rare earth metals. Thorium was discovered in 1828 by the Norwegian amateur mineralogist Morten Thrane Esmark and identified by the Swedish chemist Jöns Jacob Berzelius, who named it after Thor, the Norse god of thunder. Its first use was developed in the late 19th century. Thorium's radioactivity was widely recognized during the early decades of the 20th century. By the second half of this century, thorium had been supplanted for use in a variety of situations due to concerns about its radioactivity. Thorium is still used as an alloying element in TIG welding electrodes, but is slowly being replaced by other materials. It is also used as an ingredient in advanced optical and scientific instruments, and as a light source in gas lighting devices, but its use has become increasingly rare.

Thorium has been proposed to be used as a substitute for uranium for nuclear reactor fuel and several thorium reactors have been built. Thorium is a bright silvery, paramagnetic, radioactive metal actinide. In the periodic table, thorium is to the right of actinium, to the left of protactinium, and below cerium. Pure thorium is very malleable, and like most metals, can be cold rolled, tempered, and shaped. At room temperature, thorium metal has a face-centered cubic crystal structure. It also has two other forms, one at high temperature (over 1360°C), which is body-centered cubic and another at high pressure (about 100 GPa), which is body-centered tetragonal. Thorium metal has a compression modulus (a measure of the resistance to compression of a material) of 54 GPa, about the same as tin (58.2 GPa). For comparison, the compression modulus of aluminum is 75.2 GPa; copper 137.8 GPa; and mild steel of 160-169 GPa. Thorium is as hard as mild steel, so when heated it can be rolled into sheets and drawn into wire. The density of thorium is nearly half that of uranium and plutonium. But it is harder than the two metals. Thorium becomes superconductive below 1.4 K. Thorium's melting point of 1,750°C is above that of actinium (1,227°C) and protactinium (1568°C). In the early elements of period 7, from francium to thorium, the melting points of the elements increase (as do elements in other periods). This is due to the number of delocalized electrons each atom contributes increasing from one electron in francium to four in thorium. This causes the attractive force between the electrons and the metal ion to become greater as the positive charge on the metal increases from one to four.

Mature · Censorship Circumcision · Adultery Pornography · Child grooming Child pornography · Child prostitution, Incest · Prostitution Pedophilia · Rape (Statutory rape) Sexting · Child sexual abuse Sexual slavery · Sexual harassment Zoophilia Pornography (from the Greek πορνογαφία pornographia — literally writing or pornography images of prostitutes) (sometimes also shortened to "porn," "pr0n," or "porno") are depictions of the human body or the act of human sexuality openly (explicitly) with the aim of arousing arousal (sexual arousal). Pornography is different from erotica. It can be said, pornography is an extreme/vulgar form of erotica. Erotica itself is the physical elaboration of erotic concepts. The pornography industry often uses the term erotica with euphemistic motives but results in confusion among the general public. Pornography can use a variety of media — written and spoken text, photographs, engravings, drawings, moving images (including animation), and sounds such as the sound of someone gasping for breath. Pornographic films incorporate moving pictures, spoken erotic text and/or other erotic sounds, while magazines often incorporate photographs and written text. Novels and short stories feature written text, sometimes with illustrations. A live show can also be called porn. In its original sense, pornography literally means "writing about prostitutes", from the classical Greek roots "πορνη" (porne) and "γραφειν" (graphein). Originally it was a euphemism and literally meant '(something that is) sold.' This word is derived from the Greek term for people who record "pornoai", or prostitutes who are famous or have certain skills from ancient Greece. In modern times, the term has been adopted by social scientists to describe the work of men such as Nicholas Restif and William Acton, who in the 18th and 19th centuries published treatises studying prostitution and made proposals to regulate it.

The term continued to be used with this meaning in the Oxford English Dictionary until 1905. Later the term came to be used for publications of any sexual nature, especially those considered to be in poor taste or immoral, when the manufacture, presentation or consumption of the material was intended solely to arouse sexual arousal. Today the term is used to refer sexually to any kind of written or graphic material. The term "pornography" often carries negative connotations and is of low artistic value, compared to the more respectful nature of erotica. Euphemistic terms such as adult films and adult videos are usually preferred by those who produce these materials. Nevertheless, the definition of pornography is very subjective in nature. Works that are generally recognized as art such as Michelangelo's sculpture "David" are considered pornographic by some. References are needed] Sometimes people also distinguish between mild pornography and heavy pornography. Mild pornography generally refers to material featuring nudity, suggestively sexual scenes, or imitating sex scenes, while heavy pornography contains images of arousal genitalia and sexual activity including penetration. Within the industry itself, further classification is carried out informally. These distinctions may seem insignificant to many people, but uncertain legal definitions and varying standards at different dealers mean producers shoot and edit in different ways. They also first consulted their films in different versions to the legal team concerned. In several jurisdictions in America the appearance of pictures or films of a person defecating is also included in the definition of pornography. Pornography has a long history. Artwork that is sexually suggestive and explicit is as old as artwork featuring any other imagery.

Ferromagnetism is a property of materials with high magnetic susceptibility and a positive value. This property arises in the strong interaction between atoms and permanent magnets. The magnetism generated will still be there even if the trigger magnet has been removed. The existence of this magnetic force is maintained by the constituent materials and is described by means of a hysteresis curve. The material has regular spontaneous magnetic moments. Ferromagnetism can persist as long as the temperature of the material does not exceed the Curie temperature. Dear Felicia Molecules Ferromagnetism can occur in materials with atoms having magnetic moments of the atoms in random directions with each other. The magnetic moments become regular and align in the presence of an external magnetic field. After the external magnetic field is removed, the magnetic moments on the atoms of the material will cancel each other to form a magnetic moment with a small amount. Ferromagnetism has two similar magnetic poles related to the spins of the unpaired electrons. These magnetic poles have a uniform direction with the surrounding magnetic poles in groups of very small sizes. This group is called a domain. The domains in ferromagnetism have random directions with each other. Permanent magnets are formed by abbreviation of existing domains. The degree of ferromagnetism is determined by the regularity of the electron spins. Strong magnetism results from spins with long regularity, whereas magnetism disappears when the spins are completely random. Ferromagnetism can reach a magnetization stage with a value of zero at the Curie temperature. This stage appears after the ferromagnetism has gone through its maximum magnetization. Ferromagnetism will disappear when the magnetization approaches zero. After that, ferromagnetism turns into paramagnetism. Ferromagnetism is utilized in the material for making hard disks which contain magnetic discs. The ferromagnetic materials used are iron, cobalt, and nickel. The combination of cobalt and nickel results in a strong magnetic arrangement and a large anisotropic magnetic value.

The Republic of The Gambia (English: Republic of The Gambia) is a country in West Africa. The Gambia's entire land border is surrounded by Senegal to the north, east and south and the Atlantic Ocean to the west. The area of ​​the smallest country in mainland Africa is unique because if the country of Senegal is considered a mouth, then Gambia is the tongue and teeth, while the shape of the Gambia itself is like a snake with a flat chin with the mouth of the Gambia River as the tongue and mouth. The Gambia River runs through the center of the Gambia and flows into the Atlantic Ocean in the west and along that line the Gambia's boundary is formed from its center to the Atlantic Ocean. The Gambia is one of the countries with the narrowest area like Chile, only it is shorter and smaller than Chile. The Gambia has the nickname The Smiling Coast (Smiling Beach). A country measuring 10,500 km² with a population of 1.7 million people is Banjul as its capital city, while its largest city is Serekunda. On 18 February 1965, The Gambia was granted independence by the United Kingdom and then joined the Commonwealth of Nations, until it withdrew in October 2013. The Gambia shares historical origins with many west African countries, with the slave trade being a major factor in the creation of a colony on the Gambia River, first by the Portuguese and then by the British. Since independence, The Gambia has experienced a period of stability, except for a brief military dictatorship in 1994. Agriculture in The Gambia follows a traditional cultivation system relying solely on peanuts as its main commodity. The Gambia is a rich agricultural country, whose economy is dominated by farming and animal husbandry, fishing and tourism. Unfortunately, almost a third of the population lives below the poverty line with an income of US$1.25 a day.

The name "Gambia" comes from the Mandinka term Kambra/Kambaa, which means river Gambia. After independence as a Commonwealth of Nations, the country adopted the name The Gambia. After the proclamation of the republic in 1970, the country's full name became Republic of the Gambia. Yahya Jammeh's administration changed the long name to Islamic Republic of The Gambia in December 2015. On 29 January 2017 the new President Adama Barrow said the country's name would return to the Republic of Gambia. The Gambia gained independence on 18 February 1965, as a constitutional monarchy within the Commonwealth, with Elizabeth II as Queen of the Gambia, represented by the Governor-General. Shortly thereafter, the national government held a referendum proposing that the country become a republic. This referendum failed to receive the two-thirds majority needed to change the constitution. On 24 April 1970, The Gambia became a republic within the Commonwealth, following a second referendum. Prime Minister Sir Dawda Kairaba Jawara becomes President, an executive post, combining head of state and head of government President Sir Dawda Jawara was re-elected five times. A coup attempt on 29 July 1981 followed a weakening economy and accusations of corruption against leading politicians. The coup attempt took place while President Jawara was visiting London and was carried out by the left wing of the National Revolutionary Council, consisting of Kukoi Samba Sanyang's Socialist and Revolutionary Workers' Party (SRLP) and elements of the Field Forces, paramilitary forces which make up most of the country's armed forces. President Jawara requested military assistance from Senegal, which deployed 400 troops to The Gambia on 31 July. By 6 August some 2,700 Senegalese troops had been deployed, defeating the rebel forces. Between 500 and 800 people died during the coup and the ensuing violence.

Introductory status, as a metalloid, of several elements in the p block of the periodic table. Percentage is the median frequency of appearance in the metalloid list. n 1] The ladder-shaped line is a typical example of the metal–non-metal dividing line found in some periodic tables. Metalloids are a type of chemical element that has more of the properties of, or is a mixture of, metals and non-metals. There is no standard definition of a metalloid and no complete agreement on which elements are metalloids. Despite this lack of specificity, the term is still used in the chemical literature. The six commonly recognized metalloids are boron, silicon, germanium, arsenic, antimony, and tellurium. Five elements are less frequently classified: carbon, aluminum, selenium, polonium and astatine. On the standard periodic table, the eleven elements are located in the diagonal region of the p-block that extends from boron on the top left to astatine on the bottom right. Several periodic tables include a dividing line between metals and nonmetals, and metalloids can be found close to this line. Typical metalloids have a metallic appearance, but are brittle and only reasonable conductors of electricity. Chemically, they behave mostly as nonmetals. They can form alloys with metals. Most of its other physical and chemical properties are intermediate. Metalloids are usually too brittle to have a structural use. They and their compounds are used in alloys, biological agents, catalysts, flame retardants, glass, storage optics and optoelectronics, pyrotechnics, semiconductors and electronics. The electrical properties of silicon and germanium allowed the establishment of the semiconductor industry in the 1950s and the development of solid electronics from the early 1960s. The term metalloid originally referred to a nonmetal. Its newer meaning, as a category of elements with intermediate or hybrid properties, became widespread in 1940–1960. Metalloids are sometimes called semimetals, a practice that is discouraged, because the term semimetal has a different meaning in physics than in chemistry.

In physics, this term refers to a particular type of electronic band structure of a substance. In this context, only arsenic and antimony are semimetals, and they are commonly known as metalloids. Metalloids are elements that have more intermediate properties, or which are mixtures, of metals and non-metals, and therefore are difficult to classify as metals or non-metals. This is a general definition referring to the attributes of metalloids that are consistently cited in the literature. 2] Difficulty of categorization is a key attribute. Most elements have a mixture of metallic and non-metallic properties, and can be classified according to which set of properties is predominant. n 3] Only the elements at or near the margins, lacking any appreciable advantage of either metallic or non-metallic properties, are classified as metalloids. Boron, silicon, germanium, arsenic, antimony, and tellurium are commonly known as metalloids. n 4] Depending on the author, selenium, polonium, or astatine are sometimes added to the list. Boron is sometimes excluded, on its own, or with silicon. Sometimes tellurium is not considered a metalloid. The inclusion of antimony, polonium, and astatine as metalloids has been questioned. The other elements are sometimes classified as metalloids. These elements include hydrogen, beryllium, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur, zinc, gallium, tin, iodine, lead, bismuth, and radon. The term metalloid has also been used for elements that exhibit a metallic luster and electrical conductivity, and which are amphoteric, such as aluminum, vanadium, chromium, arsenic, molybdenum, tin, antimony, tungsten, and lead. P-block metals, and non-metals (such as carbon or nitrogen) that can form alloys with metals or modify their properties are also sometimes considered metalloids. There is no widely accepted definition of a metalloid, nor is there a division of the periodic table into metals, metalloids, and nonmetals; Hawkes questioned the feasibility of establishing a specific definition, noting that anomalies could be found in some of the experimental constructs.

Astatine is a chemical element with the symbol At and atomic number 85. It is the rarest naturally occurring element in the Earth's crust, occurring only as the decay product of various heavier elements. All astatine isotopes are short-lived; the most stable is astatine-210, with a half-life of 8.1 hours. A sample of pure astatine is never made, because any macroscopic specimen of it is immediately vaporized by its own radioactive heat. The properties of most astatines are not known with certainty. Many of these properties are derived from the prediction of astatine's position on the periodic table as a heavier analogue of iodine, and a member of the halogens (the group of elements that contains fluorine, chlorine, bromine, and iodine). However, astatine also lies along the dividing line between metals and nonmetals, so some metal behavior has also been observed and predicted for it. Astatine tends to have a dark or shiny appearance and may be a semiconductor or may be a metal. Chemically, several anionic astatine species are known and most of their compounds are similar to iodine, but sometimes also exhibit metallic characteristics and show some similarities to silver. The first synthesis of the element was carried out in 1940 by Dale R. Corson, Kenneth R. MacKenzie, and Emilio G. Segrè at the University of California, Berkeley, who named it from the Ancient Greek ἄστατος (astatos) 'unstable'. Four isotopes of astatine were later found to occur naturally, although far less than one gram is present at any given time in the Earth's crust. Neither the most stable isotope astatine-210, nor the medically useful astatine-211, occur naturally; they can only be produced synthetically, usually by bombarding bismuth-209 with alpha particles. Astatine is a highly radioactive element; all of which have half-lives of 8.1 hours or less, decaying into the other isotopes of astatine, bismuth, polonium, or radon.

Most of the isotopes are highly unstable, with half-lives of one second or less. Of the first 101 elements in the periodic table, only francium is the less stable, and all isotopes of astatine which are more stable than francium, however, are synthetic and do not occur in nature. The properties of most astatines are not known with certainty. Research is limited by its short half-life, which prevents the creation of a quantifiable quantity. A visible piece of astatine will soon vaporize itself due to the heat generated by its intense radioactivity. It remains to be seen whether, with sufficient cooling, macroscopic amounts of astatine can be deposited as thin films. Astatine is usually classified as a nonmetal or metalloid; metal formation has also been predicted. Most of the physical properties of astatine have been estimated (by interpolation or extrapolation), using theoretically or empirically derived methods. For example, halogens get darker with increasing atomic weight – fluorine is almost colorless, chlorine is yellow green, bromine is red brown, and iodine is dark gray/purple. Astatine is sometimes described as possibly being a black solid (assuming following this trend), or having a metallic appearance (if it is a metalloid or metal). Astatine sublimes more easily than iodine, because it has a lower vapor pressure. However, half of a given amount of astatine will evaporate in about one hour if placed on a clean glass surface at room temperature. a] The absorption spectrum of astatine in the mid-ultraviolet region has lines at 224.401 and 216.225 nm, indicating a 6p to 7s transition . The structure of solid astatine is still unknown. As an iodine analogue, it may have an orthorhombic crystal structure consisting of diatomic astatine molecules, and be a semiconductor (with a band gap of 0.7 eV).

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Glaciology (from the French glace meaning ice and the Greek Λoγος (logos) meaning science) is the study of the physical and chemical properties of ice and snow (glaciers), the formation, movement and also evolution. The study of glaciology also includes aspects of other sciences such as geophysics, geology, physical geography, geomorphology, climatology, meteorology, hydrology, biology and ecology. Glaciers are one of the natural phenomena that are extensively reviewed by glaciologists. Structural glaciology is a branch of glaciology that specifically deals with the structure of glaciers. The scope of the discussion is an understanding of the process of distribution and movement of ice debris in the glacier. The formation of the glacial structure is related to the transport of ice debris as a result of internal deformation. The study of glaciology, especially the study of ice masses, is a complex study because it requires an understanding of various processes of dynamics, thermodynamics and long-term behavior of ice sheets. On the other hand, this study was difficult to carry out because the environmental conditions were very cold and dark for a very long time. Remote sensing has provided useful results in glaciological studies, especially in the study of ice masses. Since the 1950s, radar systems have been developed as a remote sensing method for measuring ice thickness. One of the radar systems that is widely used in remote sensing in glaciology is radio echo sounding. The working principle utilizes electromagnetic waves that can penetrate the ice layer. Radio echo sounding is used to obtain information about the electromagnetic properties of different interfaces. These interfaces include ice cubes, ice water, and ice on sea water. The resulting sound echoes back into the radar. The large use of energy characterizes radio echo sounding.

Its power consumption is between 10 Watts and 10 kiloWatts pulse-width that is supplied on a variable basis. The delivery speed is around 0.5 nanoseconds to a few microseconds. Radio echo sounding is used to investigate the characteristics of bedrock down to the thickest permafrost zone. The maximum thickness of the ice it reaches is 4,755 meters. Prior to the 1980s, glaciology was not considered important in international policy studies on climate change. The initial study that started to tie the knot was a project called the Vostok Ice Core which had been under way since the 1970s. The study was conducted at a Soviet Union station located at a remote point in the arctic part of East Antarctica. The Soviet Union and France then collaborated on this study in the mid-1980s. Then in 1987, the two countries published the results of their collaboration regarding the relationship between stable water isotopes and greenhouse gas concentrations. These greenhouse gases include methane and carbon dioxide. The identification process is carried out in air bubbles in the ice core. The isotope ratios in the ice make it clear that there is a clear relationship between the concentration of greenhouse gases and the temperature of the air above the ice sheet. At a depth of 2 kilometers in the ice core, the signal conditions of the glacial-interglacial cycle for about 110 thousand years were recorded. The results of deep-sea sediment records have provided information that temperature signals do not only respond to changes in the geometry of the Earth's orbit. The temperature signal is also getting stronger due to the presence of greenhouse gases. This is why the United Nations launched the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change in 1988. This scientific panel then produces regular reports that provide summaries of the current state of knowledge about the climate system. Changes to the exterior of the Greenland glaciers have been the initial motivation for the study of modern glaciology.

The Republic of Liberia is a country on the west coast of Africa bordered by Sierra Leone, Guinea and Ivory Coast. Liberia is the oldest republic in Africa which declared independence on July 26, 1847. Several decades ago Liberia was hit by two civil wars (1989–1996 and 1999–2003) which resulted in hundreds of thousands of residents fleeing while destroying the economy. Along with Ethiopia, Liberia is one of only two modern countries in Sub-Saharan Africa that did not experience European colonization. Beginning in 1820, the area was colonized by black people from the United States, most of whom were freed slaves. These immigrants founded a new nation with help from the American Colonization Society, a private organization that believed that former slaves would have greater freedom and equality in Africa. Black people in America were given the choice of staying in America and being restricted in their rights or moving to their continent of origin. In 1847, a country was founded called the Republic of Liberia, and established a government modeled on that of the United States with the capital city of Monrovia, a city named in honor of James Monroe, the fifth president of the United States and a prominent supporter of colonization. The colonists, known as Americo-Liberians, led the country's political and economic sectors. Liberia's constitution and flag are modeled after the United States. The country began to modernize in the 1940s following investment from the United States during World War II and economic liberalization under President William Tubman. Liberia is a founding member of the United Nations and the Organization of African Unity. Before the Americo-Liberians arrived, this area was already inhabited by various tribes, so there was tension between the newcomers and the native tribes. Despite having the same skin color, Americo-Liberians have a higher culture and level of education than indigenous peoples so that Americo-Liberians are able to dominate various sectors.

The military coup that overthrew the American-Liberian leadership in 1980 marked the beginning of political and economic instability and two successive civil wars that killed around 250,000 people and destroyed the country's economy. A peace agreement in 2003 led to democratic elections in 2005. Today, Liberia is recovering from their civil war and economic upheaval, but about 85% of the population lives below the international poverty line. Liberia is located in West Africa, bordered by the North Atlantic Ocean to the southwest. Liberia is located between latitudes 4° and 9°N, and longitudes 7° and 12°W. Much of the landscape is characterized by flat to rolling coastal plains dotted with mangroves and marshes, rising to rolling plateaus and low mountains in the northeast. Tropical rainforest covers the hills, while elephant grass and semi-deciduous forests are the dominant vegetation in the north. The climate is equatorial, in the south of the country, hot all year round with heavy rainfall from May to October with short breaks in mid-July to August. During the winter months November to March, dry, dust-laden harmattan winds blow inland, causing a lot of trouble for residents. The Liberia watershed tends to move in a southwesterly pattern toward the sea as fresh rains fall on the forested plateau of the inland mountains of Guinée Forestire, in Guinea. Cape Mount near the border with Sierra Leone receives the most rainfall in the country. Liberia's main northwestern boundary is traversed by the Mano River while the southeastern boundary is bounded by the Cavalla River. Liberia's three largest rivers are the St. Paul exiting near Monrovia, St. John in Buchanan, and the Cestos River, which all flow into the Atlantic.

Water is a compound that is essential for all life forms known hitherto on Earth, but not on other planets. Its chemical formula is H2O, each molecule of which contains one oxygen and two hydrogen atoms connected by covalent bonds. Water covers almost 71% of the Earth's surface. There are 1.4 trillion cubic kilometers (330 million mi³) of water available on Earth. Most of the water can be found in the sea (salt water) and in the ice caps (at the poles and on the tops of mountains). Apart from that, water can also be found in clouds, rain, rivers, surface fresh water, lakes, water vapor, and sea ice. The water in these objects moves according to a water cycle, namely: through evaporation, rain, and the flow of water over the ground surface (runoff, including springs, rivers, estuaries) towards the sea. Clean water is important for human life. In addition to Earth, large amounts of water are also thought to exist at the north and south poles of Mars, as well as on the moons Europa and Enceladus. Water can be solid (ice), liquid (water) and gas (water vapour). Water is the only substance that naturally occurs on the surface of the Earth in all three of its forms. Improper management of water resources can lead to water shortages, monopolization and privatization and even trigger conflicts. Indonesia has had laws governing water resources since 2004, namely Law number 7 of 2004 concerning Water Resources. However, because the law was considered to be contrary to the 1945 Constitution, the Constitutional Court annulled all the articles in the law. Thus, Law Number 11 of 1974 concerning Irrigation is again in effect to fill the legal vacuum until a new law is formed.

Water is a chemical substance with the chemical formula one water molecule composed of two hydrogen atoms covalently bonded to one oxygen atom. Water is colorless, tasteless and odorless under standard conditions, namely at a pressure of 100 kPa (1 bar) and a temperature of 273.15 K (0°C). This chemical is an important solvent, having the ability to dissolve many other chemicals, such as salts, sugars, acids, several types of gases and many types of organic molecules. The liquid state of water is an unusual condition under normal conditions, especially considering the relationship between other similar hydrides in the oxygen column of the periodic table, which suggests that water should be in a gaseous state, as is hydrogen sulfide. By looking at the periodic table, it can be seen that the elements surrounding oxygen are nitrogen, fluorine and phosphorus, sulfur and chlorine. All of these elements when bonded to hydrogen will produce gas at normal temperature and pressure. The reason why hydrogen bonds with oxygen to form a liquid state is because oxygen is more electronegative than these other elements (except fluorine). The oxygen atom's pull on the bonding electrons is much stronger than that of the hydrogen atom, leaving a sum of the positive charges on the two hydrogen atoms, and a sum of the negative charges on the oxygen atom. The presence of a charge on each of these atoms makes the water molecule have a number of dipole moments. The electric attraction between water molecules due to the presence of this dipole pulls the individual molecules closer together, making it difficult to separate them and which in turn raises the boiling point of water. This force of attraction is known as a hydrogen bond. Water is often referred to as the universal solvent because it dissolves many chemicals.

Democracy is a form of government in which important decisions, either directly or indirectly, are based on the majority agreement freely given by the adult community. Democracy is a form of government in which all citizens have the same right to make decisions that can change their lives. Democracy allows citizens to participate—either directly or through representatives—in the formulation, development and making of laws. Democracy includes social, economic, customary and cultural conditions that allow for the free and equal practice of political freedom. Democracy is also a set of ideas and principles about freedom and its practices and procedures. Democracy means respect for human dignity. , and minorities. The word comes from the Ancient Greek δημοκρατία (dēmokratía) "rule of the people", which was formed from δῆμος (dêmos) "the people" and κράτος (kratos) "power" or "rulership" in the 5th century BC to refer to the political system of states- Greek cities, one of which is Classical Athens; this word is an antonym of wikt:ἀριστοκρατία (aristocratie) "elite power". Theoretically, the two definitions contradict each other, but the reality is no longer clear. The classical Athenian political system, for example, granted democratic citizenship to free elite men and excluded slaves and women from political participation. In all democratic governments throughout modern history, democratic citizenship has remained with the elite until all the adult population in most modern democracies is truly free following the struggle for the suffrage movement from the 19th century onwards. The word democracy (democracy) itself has existed since the 16th century contemporaneously with the sultan of Banten Abdul Mahasin Muhammad Zainal Abidin, Democracy comes from Middle French and old Middle Latin.

The year AD starts from 570 AD. The concept of democracy was born from ancient Greece which was practiced in state life between the 4th century BC to the 6th century BC. The democracy practiced at that time was direct democracy, meaning that the people's right to make political decisions was carried out directly by all the people or citizens. A democratic government is different from a form of government in which the power is held by one person, such as a monarchy. Derived from the Greek philosophy today seems ambiguous because some contemporary governments mix elements of democracy, oligarchy, and monarchy. Karl Popper defined democracy as distinct from dictatorship or tyranny, thus focusing on the opportunity for a society to control its dishonest or untrustworthy leaders and remove them without needing a revolution. There are several types of democracy, but only two basic forms. Both explain how all people carry out their wishes. The first form of democracy is direct democracy, in which all citizens play a direct and active role in making government decisions. In most modern democracies, the entire people is still a sovereign power but political power is exercised indirectly through representatives; so-called indirect democracy. A brief history Throughout its independence, the Indonesian nation has tried to implement various types of democracy. Until 1959, democratic practices were carried out which tended to be a Liberal Democracy system, as was the case in individualistic Western countries. In 1959-1966 Guided Democracy was implemented, which in practice tended to be authoritarian. Starting in 1966 until the end of the New Order period in 1998 Pancasila Democracy was implemented. This model also does not encourage the growth of people's participation. After the rollout of reform in 1998, freedom of speech and expression, freedom of choice, political freedom and others are increasingly free.

Monism is the metaphysical and theological concept that there is only one substance in nature. Monism is opposed to dualism and pluralism. In dualism there are two substances or realities, while in pluralism there are many realities. The concept of monism is often associated with pantheism and the concept of an eternal God. The origins of the word and meaning of Monad are historically rooted in the Hellenic philosophical teachings of Pythagoras. Monad comes from the Greek word "μόνος" or "Mono" which means single and undivided. Monism is often seen as divided into three basic types: Monism is further defined by three types: Several other positions are difficult to reconcile with the above categories, including: Some of the following pre-Socratic philosophers describe reality as monistic: Post-Socratic philosophers: Following a tradition at length H. P. Owen (1971: 65) claims that Although, like Spinoza, some pantheists can also be monists, and monism is even essential to some versions of pantheism (such as Spinoza's pantheism), not all pantheists are monists. Some are supporters of polytheism and some are supporters of pluralism; they believe that there are many different things and different kinds and kinds of values. (Stanford Cyclopedia of Philosophy). Not all Monists are Pantheists. Exclusive Monists believe that the universe, the God of the Pantheists, does not exist. In addition, monists can also be Deists, Pantheists, Theists or Panentheists; belief in a monotheistic God who is omnipotent and all-embracing, and eternal and transcendent. There are polytheistic monists and panentheists in Hinduism (especially in Advaita and Vishistadvaita), Judaism (monistic panenteism is found mainly in Kabbalah and Hasidic philosophy), in Christianity (especially in Oriental Orthodox, Eastern Orthodox, and Anglican) and in Islam (for Sufis, especially Bektashis). Abrahamism Akosmism Agnosticism Animism Anti-religion Atheism Dharmism Deism Dualism Esotericism Feminist theology Gnosticism Henotheism Humanism Immanenke Monism Monotheism Mysticism Naturalism Nondualism Pandeism Pantheism Polytheism Process Theology Shamanism · Taoist · Theism · Transcendent · New Age

Asteroids, also called minor planets or planetoids, are bodies smaller than planets but larger than meteoroids, generally found in the inner Solar System (deeper than Neptune's orbit). Asteroids differ from comets in their visual appearance. Comets display commas ("tails") while asteroids do not. This term has historically applied to all astronomical objects that orbit the sun and that have not been observed to have the characteristics of an active comet. There are millions of asteroids, which many think are the remnants of planetesimal destruction, material within the solar nebula of the young sun that never grew to become planets. The majority of known asteroids orbit in the asteroid belt between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter or share an orbit with Jupiter (Jupiter's Trojan Asteroids). However, there are other orbital families with significant populations, including near-Earth asteroids. Individual asteroids are classified based on their characteristic emission spectra, with the majority falling into three main groups: C-type, M-type, and S-type. This group is named and commonly identified by its carbon, metal, and silicate composition. Only one asteroid, 4 Vesta, has a relatively reflective surface, normally visible to the naked eye and this only in very dark skies and positions permitting it. Small asteroids that pass close to Earth are rarely visible to the naked eye for a short time. As of April 2016, the Minor Planet Center has data for more than 1.3 million objects in and out of the Solar System, 750,000 of which have sufficient information for numbered naming. The first asteroid discovered was Ceres in 1801 by Giuseppe Piazzi and was initially considered a new planet. note 1] This discovery was followed by the discovery of other similar objects which, with the equipment of the time, appeared as points of light, such stars, denote planetary disks that are small or absent at all, although they are easily distinguishable from stars because of their visible motion.

This prompted the astronomer Sir William Herschel to propose the term "asteroid", from the Greek, ἀστεροειδής asteroeidēs meaning 'starlike, star-shaped', from Ancient Greek, ἀστήρ astēr meaning 'star, planet'. Asteroid discovery methods have evolved dramatically in the last two centuries. In the last few years of the 18th century, Baron Franz Xaver von Zach organized a group of 24 astronomers to search for a lost planet at a distance of about 2.8 au from the sun based on the Titius-Bode law because that law was also used by Sir William Herschel to discovered the planet Uranus in 1781. This task required a handwritten celestial chart containing all the stars of the zodiacal belt up to an agreed line of sight. The following night, the sky will be charted again as per the previous chart and hopefully any moving objects will be visible. The observed missing planet's motion of about 30 arcseconds per hour is easily visible to observers. The first object, Ceres, was not discovered by members of the group, but rather by chance in 1801 by Giuseppe Piazzi, director of the Palermo observatory in Sicily. He discovered a new star-like object in Taurus and followed its movement for several nights. Later that year, Carl Friedrich Gauss used these observations to calculate the orbit of the unknown object, which was known to lie between the planets Mars and Jupiter. Piazzi takes its name from Seres, the Roman goddess of agriculture. Three other asteroids, namely (2 Pallas, 3 Juno, and 4 Vesta) were discovered several years later. Vesta was discovered in 1807. After eight years of fruitless searching, most astronomers thought there was no new object and did not continue the search.

Sirius (/ˈsɪriəs/, or α Canis Majoris (Latin letters: Alpha Canis Majoris, abbreviated Alpha CMa, α CMa)) is the brightest star in the night sky. Sirius' name comes from the Greek word Σείριος (Seirios), which means "to sparkle". With an apparent magnitude of −1.46, Sirius is almost twice as bright as Canopus, the 2nd brightest star in the night sky. Sirius is a binary star system consisting of a main sequence star with spectral class A0 or A1, called Sirius A, and a dim white dwarf with spectral class DA2, called Sirius B. Sirius A and B orbit each other in 50 year. Sirius appears bright due to its luminosity and proximity to the Solar System. At a distance of 2.64 parsecs (8.6 tc), Sirius is one of Earth's closest neighbours. Sirius is gradually moving closer to the TatCoordinates: 06h 45m 08.9173s, −16° 42′ 58.017″a Solar, so its brightness will increase in the next 60,000 years. After that, Sirius would begin to recede, and Sirius would become dimmer, but would continue to be the brightest star in Earth's night sky for the next 210,000 years. Sirius A has a mass about 2 times that of the Sun (M☉) and has an absolute magnitude of +1.42. This star is 25 times brighter than the Sun but has a much lower luminosity when compared to other bright stars such as Canopus or Rigel. This star system has an age of between 200 and 300 million years. This system originally consisted of 2 bright bluish stars. Sirius can be seen almost everywhere on the Earth's surface except by people living at latitudes above 73.284° north.

The best time to see this star is around January 1, when it reaches the meridian at midnight. Under the right conditions, Sirius can be seen with the naked eye while the Sun is still above the horizon. When overhead, this star can be seen in very clear weather conditions, provided the observer is high up, and the position of the Sun is low enough. The star's name comes from the Greek Σείριος (Seirios, meaning "flaming" or "very hot"). As the brightest star in the constellation "Big Dog", it is often referred to as the "Dog Star".
