The Latin name for this star is Canicula ("little dog") and in Arabic: الشعرى, aš-šyi‘rā in Islamic astronomy, from which the alternative name Al Shira is derived. With the name aš-šyi‘rā, this star is referred to in the Al-Quran Surah An-Najm verse 49, which reads: and that He is the Lord (who owns) the syi'ra star. In Sanskrit, this star is known as Mrgavyadha ("deer hunter") or Lubdhaka ("hunter"). As Mrgavyadha, Sirius represents Shiva. In Chinese this star is known as the sky wolf star or (a star in the constellation) Wolf in the Sky. (Chinese and Japanese: 天狼; Korean: 천랑; Chinese Romanization: Tiānláng; Japanese Romanization: Tenrō; Korean Romanization: Cheonlang) in the House of Jǐng (井宿) (the Chinese constellation that is part of the modern constellation Gemini), while names in Japanese market language this star is 青星 (Aoboshi, "blue star"). Other names of earlier astronomers were: Apart from the constellation Canis Major, this star is also a member of the following constellations, asterisms or groups: Based on changes in its self-motion, in 1844 Friedrich Wilhelm Bessel concluded that Sirius might have a partner.

Voltmeter is a measuring instrument used to measure the potential difference or electric voltage from two points of electric potential. In electronic equipment, a voltmeter is used to monitor the value of the working voltage. The voltmeter is composed of several parts, namely the positive and negative terminals, measuring limits, function control setups, pointer and high and low scales. In electrical circuits, a voltmeter is a device for measuring electric voltage. The movement of the pointer on the voltmeter occurs because of the magnetic force that arises as a result of the interaction between the magnetic field and the electric current. The deviation generated by the movement of the needle is proportional to the strength of the flowing electric current. The electric current that is measured is the electric current through the coil placed between the magnetic fields. An increase in current means an increase in the deviation of the movement of the needle so that it will point to a larger voltage measurement value. The voltmeter is connected in parallel with the component to be measured in the electrical circuit. The constituent parts consist of three copper plates. The location of the copper is in a bakelite on an inner plate that is arranged in a glass or plastic tube. The size of the glass tube is generally about 15 cm in diameter and 10 cm. The outer plate serves as the anode and the plate in the middle functions as the cathode. The voltmeter is made by having a galvanometer and resistance connected in series as a multiplier. Series resistance increases the range of a voltmeter several times. A voltmeter is a measuring instrument that functions to measure the amount of electric voltage that exists in an electric circuit in a certain quantity and unit. Measuring limits in voltmeters are expressed in millivolts (mV), voltmeters (V), microvolts, or kilovolts (kV). The measuring limit is the maximum value of the voltage that can be measured by a voltmeter.

Measurement of electric voltage that exceeds the maximum value of the voltmeter measuring limit will result in damage to the voltmeter component. The measuring limit of the voltmeter can be enlarged several times by using a multiplier factor. Voltmeters that use the rotating coil principle have coils connected in series with a high resistance. In direct current voltmeters, the resistance multiplier is placed in series with the permanent magnet rotating coil which functions as the multiplier factor. The resistance multiplier converts the movement of the coil into a direct current voltmeter. In the resistance multiplier, the current is limited to the meter so as not to exceed the full scale current. Voltage measurements in direct current are only made at the potential difference between two points in a direct current circuit. Voltmeters are connected in parallel to a voltage source or circuit component. The polarity determination makes the terminals on the voltmeter marked positive and negative. Enlargement of the measuring limit is done by determining the value of the resistance multiplier through the factor of maximum range voltage (V), deflection current (Im), internal resistance (Rm), and multiplier resistance. (Rs), with the formula: V= Im (Rs+Rm). On a voltmeter with a measuring limit of up to 500 Volts, the multiplier resistance is installed on the inside of the voltmeter. At higher voltages, a resistance multiplier is attached to a pair of polar probes on the outside of the voltmeter. The purpose of external mounting is to prevent overheating inside the voltmeter. The addition of a number of multipliers along with a selector switch, makes the voltmeter usable at a number of voltage values. A digital voltmeter is a voltmeter that shows the results of measuring the electric voltage digitally. The working principle is to convert analog input voltage to digital. Digital voltmeters use an analog-to-digital converter. Digital representation is done using BCD-codes. The use of an analog-to-digital converter is only carried out if the voltage to be measured is of small value.

Kalimantan (toponym: Kalamantan, Calémantan, Kalémantan, Kelamatan, Kilamantan, Klamantan, Klémantan, K'lemantan, Quallamontan), or also called Borneo by the international world. Kalimantan is the third largest island in the world, located north of Java Island and west of Sulawesi Island. The island of Borneo is divided into the territories of Indonesia (73%), Malaysia (26%) and Brunei (1%). The island of Borneo is known as the "Island of a Thousand Rivers" because of the many rivers that flow on this island. Borneo—which comes from the name of the sultanate of Brunei—is the name used by British and Dutch colonials to refer to this island as a whole, while Kalimantan is the name used by residents of the eastern part of the island which is now part of Indonesia. The northern region of this island (Sabah, Brunei , Sarawak) for Malaysia and Brunei Darussalam. Meanwhile for the northern region of Indonesia, is the province of North Kalimantan. In a broad sense, "Kalimantan" includes the entire island which is also called Borneo, while in a narrow sense, Kalimantan only refers to the territory of Indonesia. The origin of the name Kalimantan is not very clear. The term kelamantan is used in Sarawak to refer to groups of people who consume sago in the northern region of the island. According to Crowfurd, the word Kalimantan is the name of a type of mango (Mangifera) so that the island of Kalimantan is an island of mangoes. But he added that the word was fairytale and unpopular. Until now, there are many local mangoes called klemantan in rural areas in Ketapang and its surroundings, West Kalimantan. According to C. Hose and Mac Dougall, "Kalimantan" comes from the names of six groups of local tribes namely Iban (Dayak Laut), Kayan, Kenyah, Klemantan (Dayak Darat), Murut, and Punan. In his essay, Natural Man, a Record from Borneo (1926), Hose explained that Klemantan was a new name used by the Malay people.

However, according to Slamet Muljana, the word Kalimantan is not an original Malay word but a pinzaman word like the word Malaya, Malay which comes from India (malaya which means mountain). Another opinion states that Kalimantan or Klemantan comes from Sanskrit, Kalamanthana is an island where the air is very hot or burning (kala]: season, time and manthana]: burning). Because the vowels a in kala and manthana are not pronounced according to custom, then Kalamanthana is pronounced Kalmantan which is then called the native of Klemantan or Quallamontan which is finally revealed to be Kalimantan. There are three major (main) kingdoms on this island, namely Borneo (Brunei/Barune), Succadana (Tanjungpura/Bakulapura), and Banjarmasinn (Nusa Kencana). Residents of the eastern region of the island call it K'lemantan Island, Italians know it Calemantan and Ukrainians: Калімантан. If judging from the Javanese language, the name Kalimantan can mean "River of Diamonds". Throughout its history, Kalimantan has also been known by other names. The Singasari Kingdom, for example, called it "Bakulapura" which is its colony in southwest Kalimantan. Bakula in Sanskrit means cape tree (Mimusops elengi) so that Bakulapura got the Malay name "Tanjungpura" which means land/island of cape trees, namely the royal name of Tanjungpura which is often used as the name of the island. Meanwhile the Majapahit Kingdom in the Kakawin Nagarakretagama written in 1365 called it "Tanjungnagara" which also included the Philippines such as Saludung (Manila) and the Sulu Archipelago. Hikayat Banjar, an ancient chronicle from South Kalimantan whose final chapter was written in 1663, but the Hikayat Banjar manuscript itself originates from a manuscript with an older Malay language text during the Hindu kingdom, in which it calls Borneo Island with the Malay name, namely the island "Hujung Soil". The term Hujung Tanah appears based on the geomorphological shape of the South Kalimantan region in ancient times in the form of a peninsula formed from a row of Meratus Mountains with land ending in the South Cape which juts into the Java Sea.

Idealism is a term used for the first time in philosophy by Leibniz in the early 18th century. He applied this term to Plato's thought, while contrasting it with Epicurus' materialism. The term Idealism is a philosophical school that views the mental and ideational as the key to the nature of reality. From the 17th century to the beginning of the 20th century this term was widely used in clarifying philosophy. Idealism provides the doctrine that the nature of the physical world can only be understood in its dependence on the soul (mind) and spirit (spirit). This term is taken from "idea", which is something that is present in the soul. In modern philosophy, this view was first seen in George Berkeley (1685-1753) who stated that the nature of physical objects are ideas. Leibniz used this term at the beginning of the 18th century, characterizing Plato's thought as opposed to Epicurus' materialism (Reese: 243). Idealism has its own epistemological argument. Therefore, the theist figures who teach that matter depends on the spirit are not called idealists because they do not use the epistemological arguments used by idealism. They use the argument that physical objects are ultimately God's creations; the idealists argue that physical objects cannot be understood apart from spirit. Idealism comes from the word idea which means the world in the soul (Plato), so this view emphasizes things that are ideas, and degrades things that are material and physical. Reality itself is explained by psychic symptoms, spirit, mind, self, absolute mind, not with regard to matter. There are quite a number of other characters; Berkeley, Jonathan Edwards, Howison, Edmund Husserl, Messer and others. In the world of literature, there is also a stream of idealism, for example a story, in which there is a message that the author wants to convey.

Swans are large water birds from the genus Cygnus in the Anatidae family. Short-necked ducks and geese also occur in the family Anatidae. Geese and short-necked geese belong to the Anserinae subfamily, but the swans have their own tribe, the Cygnini tribe. There are seven species in the genus Cygnus. Swans are monogamous animals, 'divorce' sometimes occurs when the nesting process fails. The swans are the largest members of the waterfowl family Anatidae, and are among the largest flying birds. The largest species, including the mute swan, trumpeter swan, and whooper swan, can reach length of over 60 inches and weigh over 50 pounds. Their wingspan can reach up to three meters in length. Compared to the closely related geese, they are much larger in size and have proportionally larger feet and necks. In adult geese, they have a marked patch of bare skin between the eyes and bill. Male and female swans are similar, showing no sexual dimorphism. However, the size of the male goose is generally larger and heavier. Species in the Northern Hemisphere have pure white plumage, but geese in the Southern Hemisphere are a mix of black and white. The Australian Black Swan (Cygnus atratus) is black throughout except for the flight feathers on its wings. Young black swans are light gray. In South America, the black-necked goose has a black neck, hence its name. Swan legs are generally dark gray, except for two species from South America which have pink feet. Beak color varies; subarctic species have a black bill with an admixture of yellow. The others are red and black.

Dehydrogenation is a chemical reaction that involves the removal of hydrogen from organic molecules. This is the opposite of hydrogenation. Dehydrogenation is an important reaction because it converts alkanes, which are relatively inert and of low value, to olefins, which are reactive and more valuable. Alkenes are precursors for aldehydes, alcohols, polymers and aromatics. The dehydrogenation process is used extensively to produce aromatics and styrene in the petrochemical industry. Such a process is highly endothermic requiring a minimum temperature of 500°C. Dehydrogenation also converts saturated fats into unsaturated fats. The enzymes that catalyze dehydrogenation are called dehydrogenases. Various dehydrogenation processes have been described, especially for organic compounds: One of the largest-scale dehydrogenation reactions is the production of styrene via the dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene. Typical dehydrogenation catalysts are iron(III) oxide based, using a few percent potassium oxide or potassium carbonate. Formaldehyde is produced industrially by the catalytic oxidation of methanol, which can also be considered as dehydrogenation using O2 as an acceptor. The most common catalysts are metallic silver or a mixture of iron oxide and molybdenum or vanadium. In the commonly used formox process, methanol and oxygen react at approx. 250–400 °C in the presence of iron oxide in combination with molybdenum and/or vanadium to produce formaldehyde according to the chemical equation: The importance of the catalytic dehydrogenation of paraffinic hydrocarbons to olefins has been growing with steady in the last few years. Light olefins, such as butene, are important raw materials for the synthesis of polymers, gasoline additives and various other petrochemical products. Cracking processes, especially liquid catalytic cracking and steam cracking, produce high-purity mono-olefins, such as 1-butene or butadiene. Nonetheless, further research is focused on developing alternatives such as oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) for two reasons: (1) unwanted reactions that occur at high temperatures leading to catalyst deactivation, which makes frequent catalyst regeneration unavoidable, and (2 ) consumes a large amount of heat and requires a high reaction temperature.

in ASEAN (dark gray)  –  Legend] Indonesia (Indonesian pronunciation: in.ˈdo.nɛ.sja]), known as the official name of the Republic of Indonesia or more fully the Unitary State of the Republic of Indonesia, is an archipelago in Southeast Asia crossed by the line equator and is between the continents of Asia and Oceania, so it is known as a transcontinental country, as well as between the Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean. Indonesia is the 14th largest country as well as the largest archipelagic country in the world with an area of ​​1,904,569 km², and the 6th largest island country in the world, with a total of 17,504 islands. The alternative name used for the Indonesian archipelago is called Nusantara. In addition, Indonesia is also the 4th most populous country in the world with a population reaching 270,203,917 people in 2020, as well as the largest Muslim country in the world, with more than 230 million adherents. Indonesia is a multiracial, multiethnic and multicultural country in the world, just like the United States of America. Indonesia borders a number of countries in Southeast Asia and Oceania. Indonesia borders on land with Malaysia on the islands of Borneo and Sebatik, with Papua New Guinea on New Guinea Island, and with Timor Leste on Timor. Countries that only share sea borders with Indonesia are Singapore, the Philippines, Australia, and the union territory of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands in India. Indonesia is a unitary state with a republican form of government based on a valid constitution, namely the 1945 Constitution of the Republic of Indonesia (1945 Constitution). Also based on the 1945 Constitution, the People's Representative Council (DPR), Regional Representative Council (DPD), and the President are nominated and then elected in general elections. The current capital city of Indonesia is Jakarta. On January 18, 2022, the Indonesian government designated the Archipelago Capital on the island of Kalimantan, which occupies the area of ​​North Penajam Paser Regency, to replace Jakarta as the new capital.

Until 2022, the process of moving the capital city is still ongoing. The history of Indonesia has been heavily influenced by immigrants and colonizers. The Indonesian Archipelago became an important trading area since the 7th century, namely since the founding of Srivijaya, a Hindu-Buddhist patterned kingdom based in Palembang. The Srivijaya Empire established religious and trade relations with the Chinese, Indians and also Arabs. Hinduism-Buddhism religion and culture grew, developed, and assimilated in the Indonesian archipelago in the early 4th to 13th centuries AD. After that, traders and scholars from the Arabian Peninsula brought Islamic religion and culture around the 8th to 16th centuries. At the end of the 15th century, Europeans came to the Indonesian archipelago and fought for a monopoly on the spice trade in Maluku during the Age of Exploration. After being under the Dutch colonial era, Indonesia, which was then called the Dutch East Indies, proclaimed independence at the end of World War II, on August 17, 1945 to be precise. Furthermore, Indonesia faced various challenges and serious problems, ranging from natural disasters, massive corruption practices , social conflicts, separatist movements, democratization processes, and periods of development, socio-economic-political changes and developments, as well as rapid modernization. Indonesia consists of various ethnic groups, languages ​​and religions. Based on the national family, Indonesia consists of indigenous peoples, namely Austronesians and Melanesians, where the Austronesians are the largest in number and mostly inhabit the western part of Indonesia. The Javanese and Sundanese make up the largest ethnic group with a percentage reaching 57% of the entire population of Indonesia. Indonesia's national motto, "Unity in Diversity" (Different but still one), means the socio-cultural diversity that forms a unified country. Besides having a dense population and a large area, Indonesia has nature that supports the 2nd largest level of biodiversity in the world.

Frankfurt am Main (German: ˈfʁaŋkfʊʁt ʔam ˈmaɪn] ( listen); Hessian: Frangford am Maa, also called Frankfurt or written Frankfurt (Main) to distinguish from Frankfurt (Oder)) is the largest city in the German state of Hesse and the largest city fifth in Germany, with a population in 2012 of 704,449 people. The city's urban area has an estimated population of 2.3 million people in 2010. The Frankfurt Metropolitan Area has a population of approximately 5.6 million people and is the second largest metropolitan area in Germany. Frankfurt is a financial and transportation center and the largest financial center in continental Europe. The city is home to the headquarters of the European Central Bank, the Federal Bank of Germany, the Frankfurt Stock Exchange and the Frankfurt Trade Fair, as well as several other major banks such as Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank and DZ Bank. Frankfurt Airport is one of the world's busiest international airports, Frankfurt Central Station is one of the largest station terminals in Europe, and Frankfurter Kreuz is also one of the busiest Autobahn junctions in Europe. Indonesia also has a consulate general in this city. In 2011, consulting firm Mercer ranked Frankfurt as the city with the seventh best Quality of Living in the world. According to The Economist magazine, the cost of living in Frankfurt is the most expensive in Germany, and the city's cost of living is the 10th most expensive in the world. Frankfurt has been the center of German politics for centuries. Even Frankfurt is often referred to as the non de facto capital of Germany. From 855-1792 Frankfurt was the election city for the German Emperors of the Holy Roman Empire. From 1848/49 the city was the capital of the revolution and the site of the first democratically elected German parliament.

The revolution ultimately failed, and in 1949 Frankfurt lost the parliamentary election for capital city of West Germany to Bonn by one vote, which was elected because of its proximity to the home of the first German Chancellor, Konrad Adenauer. Another reason why Frankfurt was not chosen was that they feared that the Germans would be reluctant to move the capital back to Berlin, if Germany were to reunite. But on the other hand, Germany's main international airport is located in Frankfurt and not near Bonn or Berlin. After the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1990, Berlin became the obvious choice for Germany's capital. "Römer" in German means "Roman" and is the name of a complex of 9 houses that make up the Frankfurt city hall (Rathaus). These houses were purchased by the town council in 1405 from a wealthy merchant family. The house in the middle became the town hall and then connected to the building next to it. Above it is the Kaisersaal ("Emperor's Hall"), where the new king is installed. Römer was partially destroyed during World War II and then rebuilt. The nearby square is called Römerberg. St Bartholomew's Cathedral (Dom Sankt Bartholomäus), named after Saint Bartholomew, is a Gothic building built during the 14th and 15th centuries. Starting in 1356, the leader of the Holy Roman Empire was elected from this church, and from 1562 to 1792, king of Rome Germany also ascended the throne from this cathedral. Currently, St. Bartholomew's Cathedral is the main church of the city of Frankfurt. Although it is called a "cathedral", it was never the residence of bishops. This church burned down in 1867 and was later rebuilt in its present form. The church was destroyed again in World War II and rebuilt in the 1950's.

The United Nations (UN) is an international organization founded on October 24, 1945 to encourage international cooperation. This body was a successor to the League of Nations, and was created after World War II to prevent similar conflicts from occurring. At the time of its founding, the UN had 51 member states; currently there are 193 members. In addition to member countries, several international organizations and inter-state organizations have a place as a permanent observer with an office at the UN Headquarters, and some only have observer status. Palestine and the Vatican are non-member states and are permanent observers (the Vatican has a permanent representative at the United Nations, while Palestine has a permanent office at the United Nations). The United Nations Headquarters is located in New York, New York, United States of America, and has extraterritoriality rights. Other main offices are located in the cities of Geneva, Nairobi and Vienna. The organization is funded by assessed, voluntary contributions from its member countries. The main purposes of the United Nations were: During World War II, United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt initiated talks for a successor body to the League of Nations with British Prime Minister Winston Churchill aboard the battleship Augusta in Newfoundland Bay. The UN Charter was drawn up at a conference in April-June 1945. This Charter entered into force on October 24, 1945, and then the UN began to run. The first UN General Assembly – attended by representatives from 51 countries – only took place on January 10, 1946 (at Church House, London). The UN mission to maintain world peace was initially quite difficult to achieve due to the Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union. The UN participated in military operations in the Korean War and UN Operations in the Congo, and approved the creation of the state of Israel in 1947.

Membership of the organization grew rapidly after the decolonization period of the 1960s, and by the 1970s the budget for economic and social development programs far exceeded that for peacekeeping. After the end of the Cold War, the United Nations carried out military and peacekeeping missions in various parts of the world with varying results. The United Nations won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2001, and several of its officials and agencies have also been awarded the prize. However, opinions differ regarding the effectiveness of the UN. Some commentators believe the organization has an important role to play in maintaining peace, and promoting human development, while others feel it is ineffective, corrupt, or biased. The League of Nations was considered to have failed to prevent the outbreak of World War II (1939–1945). In order to prevent the outbreak of the Third World War which was not wanted by all of humanity, in 1945 the United Nations was established to replace the failed League of Nations in order to maintain international peace, and enhance cooperation in solving international economic, social and humanitarian problems. The initial concrete plans for this new world organization began under the auspices of the US Department of State in 1939. Franklin D. Roosevelt is credited with being the first to coin the term "United Nations" as a term to describe the Allied nations. The term was first officially used on January 1, 1942, when 26 nation governments pledged to continue the war effort to sign the Atlantic Charter. The four Atlantic Charter agreements are As a follow-up to the Atlantic Charter, on April 25, 1945, the United Nations Conference on International Organization was held in San Francisco, attended by 50 state governments, and a number of non-governmental organizations involved in drafting the United Nations Charter. Nation (Declaration of the United Nations).

in Europe  (gray) Montenegro (Montenegro: Црна Гора / Crna Gora, pronounced /'t͡sr̩naː 'ɡɔra/, meaning "black mountain") is a country located in Southern Europe. Precisely located in the Balkans and is bordered by the Adriatic Sea to the south, Croatia to the west, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia to the north, and Albania to the south. As the national capital is Podgorica. According to its constitution, this country is a democratic, social and ecological state. For several centuries Montenegro was a de facto independent principality governed by a hereditary ruler and dynasty. The country received de jure international recognition of its independence, following the Eastern Crisis (1875-1878), at the Berlin Congress. On 28 August 1910, the ruler of Montenegro Prince Nikola Petrović Njegoš proclaimed himself King. An independent state from the Middle Ages until 1918, it later became part of the Yugoslav state and was incorporated into the territories of Serbia and Montenegro. Between 1945 and 1992, Montenegro was part of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. From 1992 to 2003, Montenegro merged with Serbia to form the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. In 2003 the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia was changed so that the relationship between Serbia and Montenegro was more separate and the name was changed to Serbia and Montenegro. Serbia and Montenegro existed from 2003 to 2006 when Montenegro decided to secede through a referendum. By a referendum held on May 21, 2006, Montenegro declared its independence on June 3, 2006. According to groups opposed to independence, Montenegro as part of the Union with Serbia would have a much greater chance of becoming a member of the European Union, than on its own. The European Union does not expect an independent Montenegro. Because of this, the Montenegrin Serbian Union was founded.

However, the Prime Minister of Montenegro Milo Djukanovic only agreed to the Union, if the people, through a referendum, are given the opportunity to voice their opinion regarding an independent Montenegro. Djukanovic is also considered to be the leader of Montenegro's independence. Surrounded by a group of around 20 family friends, Djukanovic managed to master almost all fields, be it economics, politics or the media. He played the most powerful role for the last 15 years. Djukanovic believes he can speed up the process of joining Montenegro in the European Union and NATO, if Montenegro can be free from Serbia. Serbia, and automatically also Montenegro, was sanctioned by Brussels, because they had not succeeded in arresting and extraditing General Ratko Mladic to the Yugoslav Tribunal in The Hague. Talks with Brussels have been postponed. While the President of Serbia and Montenegro, Vojislav Kostunica and Prime Minister of Serbia, Zoran Djinjic want the federation to be maintained, but are willing to give broad autonomy rights to Montengero. In March 2006, the Parliament of Montenegro unanimously supported a proposal to hold a historic referendum on independence from Serbia, on 21 May 2006. The European Union finally demanded that at least half of all voters must vote. In addition, Brussels will only recognize Montenegro's independence if it is supported by at least 55% of voters. According to the latest independent poll published in November 2006, 43 percent of Montenegrins want independence, 31 percent oppose it, and the remaining 24 percent are undecided. Montenegro's government says its quest for independence is motivated by a desire not to be dominated by Serbia, which has a population of more than eight million people. On May 22, 2006, Referendum Commission President Frantisek Lipka announced the results of the preliminary vote count of the referendum, in which 55.4 percent of the Montenegrin people who participated in the referendum wanted Montenegro to become independent or secede from Serbia.

Potassium, or also called potassium, is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol K and atomic number 19. From the Neo-Latin language potassium. It was first isolated from potash en], plant ash, from which its English name is derived. In the periodic table, potassium is one of the alkali metals. All the alkali metals have one valence electron in their outer electron shell, which is easily released to form a positively charged ion – a cation, which combines with an anion to form a salt. Potassium is found in nature only in ionic salts. Elemental potassium is a soft, silvery-white alkali metal that oxidizes rapidly in air and reacts violently with water, producing enough heat to ignite the hydrogen emitted in the reaction and burning with a purple flame. It is found dissolved in seawater (i.e. 0.04% potassium by weight), and is a part of many minerals. Potassium is chemically very similar to sodium, the previous element in group 1 of the periodic table. They have the same first ionization energy, which allows each atom to lose its only outer electron. That they were different elements combining with the same anions to make similar salts was suspected in 1702, and proved in 1807 using electrolysis. Naturally occurring potassium consists of three isotopes, of which 40K is radioactive. Trace 40K is found in all potassium, and it is the most common radioisotope in the human body. Potassium ions are necessary for the function of all living cells. Transfer of potassium ions across the nerve cell membrane is necessary for normal nerve transmission; Potassium deficiency and excess can respectively result in many abnormalities, including abnormal heart rhythms and various electrocardiographic (ECG) abnormalities.

Fresh fruit and vegetables are good sources of potassium. The body responds to the influx of dietary potassium, which increases the serum potassium level, by shifting potassium from the outside into the cells and increasing the excretion of potassium by the kidneys. Most industrial applications of potassium exploit the high solubility of potassium compounds in water, such as potassium soaps. Heavy crop production quickly depletes soil potassium, and this can be countered by potassium-containing fertilizers, which account for 95% of global potassium production. English name: potassium for the element potassium comes from the word "potash", which refers to an early method of extracting various potassium salts: burning wood ashes or tree leaves were put in a pot, water was added, heated, and the solution was evaporated. When Humphry Davy first isolated the pure element using electrolysis in 1807, he named it potassium (English: potassium) after the word potash. The symbol "K" comes from kali, which is rooted in the word alkali, which is of Arabic origin: القَلْيَه‎ al-qalyah "plant ashes." In 1797, the German chemist Martin Klaproth discovered "potash" in the minerals leucite en] and lepidolite en], and realized that "potash" was not a product of plant growth but actually contained a new element, which he proposed to name kali. In 1807, Humphry Davy produced the element by electrolysis: in 1809, Ludwig Wilhelm Gilbert proposed the name Potassium for Davy's "potassium". In 1814, the Swedish chemist Berzelius suggested the name potassium for potassium, with the chemical symbol "K". The English and French-speaking countries adopted the names Davy and Gay-Lussac/Thénard, Potassium; while the Germanic countries adopted the name Gilbert/Klaproth, Kalium. The "Gold Book" of the International Union of Physical and Applied Chemistry has designated its official chemical symbol as K. Potassium is the second lowest density metal after lithium.

Epistemology (from the Greek ἐπιστήμη epistēmē; meaning "knowledge", and λόγος, logos, meaning "science") is a branch of philosophy concerned with the nature or theory of knowledge. In the field of philosophy, epistemology includes discussions about the origin, sources, scope, value validity, and truth of knowledge. Epistemology studies the nature of knowledge, justification, and the rationality of beliefs. Epistemology has become widely discussed in various fields, epistemology is centered into four areas, namely 1) Philosophical analysis related to the nature of knowledge and how this is related to conceptions such as truth, belief, and justification, 2) Various problems of skepticism, 3) Sources and scope of knowledge and justification for belief, and 4) Criteria for knowledge and justification. Epistemology addresses questions such as, "What makes justifiable truths justifiable?", "What does it mean to say that someone knows something?", and the fundamental question, "How do we know that we know?". The term 'Epistemology' was introduced to the philosophical field by the Scottish philosopher James Frederick Ferrier in 1854. However, according to Brett Warren, King James VI of Scotland had previously taken this philosophical concept by heart and personified it, with the term Epistemon, in 1591. In a In a philosophical debate, King James VI of Scotland wrote the character Epistemon as the personification of a philosophical concept to respond to a debate by arguing whether the perceptions developed by the ancient religion of witchcraft should be punished in the presence of Christian society. King James' argument shows that through the character of Epistemon, who bases his argument on theological ideas regarding reasoning and beliefs that develop in society, meanwhile his opponent Philomathes takes a philosophical stance on legal aspects in society, but seeks to gain greater knowledge of Epistemon, the Greek term for scientist.

This philosophical approach signifies a Philomath who seeks greater knowledge through epistemology by using theology. This dialogue was used by King James to educate the public on various concepts, including historical concepts and the etymology of the subject in dispute. Etymologically, this word comes from the classical Greek epistēmē which means knowledge and logos which means explanation or knowledge. So epistemology is "the theory of knowledge" or the theory of knowledge. Using the term, epistemology is a branch of philosophy of science that examines and discusses the nature of science or knowledge about knowledge (scientific knowledge). The term terminologically, the word epistemology in English: "epistemology" which is the part of philosophy that deals with knowledge. Epistemology in Webster's New International Dictionary online, epistemology is defined as a study or theory regarding the nature and basis of knowledge, especially with reference to its limits and validity. Meanwhile, in terms of Indonesian terminology, the word epistemology in the online Big Indonesian Dictionary (KBBI) is defined as a branch of philosophy concerning the basis and limits of knowledge. So, it can be concluded that epistemology is a part or branch of philosophy that studies and discusses the occurrence of knowledge, sources of knowledge, origins of knowledge, limits, nature, methods and truth of knowledge. Literally, in the French expression "doctrine de la Science" or the doctrine of science, whose appearance the word term is followed in German: "Wissenschaftslehre" which means "teaching of science". In the Jena period (1794-1799), this term was used by thinkers named Johann Fichte and Bernard Bolzano for their various projects. Fichte uses the term "Wissenschaftslehre" as a free act in positioning oneself, setting, and primordial as a condition of all knowledge and experience. The use of the term in exclusively subjective practice is the first step of any scientific theory.

Positivism Functionalism Antipositivism Conflict theory Structuralism Symbolic interaction Intermediate distance Mathematical Critical theory Socialization Quantitative structures and agents Computational Qualitative Ethnography religion culture economic demographics law science science internet industry social networking gender crime class class family health · city · educational environment · knowledge · deviance social psychology · medical mobility · politics · race & ethnicity rationalization · secularization · stratification Journal · Publishing · Outline List of sociologists · Index Socialization is an effort to incorporate cultural values ​​into individuals so that the individual become part of society. The process of socialization is lifelong education through individual understanding and acceptance of their role in a group. Socialization can occur because there are primary agents, namely families with emotional and affective characteristics, and secondary agents, namely friends and associations that are flexible. The purpose of socialization is to teach the culture that applies in a group to individuals in terms of social roles and status. Peter L. Berger (1978) defines socialization as the process through which a child learns to become a participating member of society. This definition was presented by Berger in a study entitled Society in Man. According to Kamanto Sunarto, the definition presented by Berger shows the view that it is through socialization that (values) of society enter into human individuals. Based on its type, socialization is divided into two: primary socialization (in the family) and secondary socialization (in the community). According to Goffman, both processes take place in total institutions, namely the place of residence and place of work. In both institutions, there are a number of individuals in the same situation, separated from the wider community for a certain period of time, living together in a confined and formally regulated life.

Peter L. Berger and Luckmann define primary socialization as the first socialization that an individual undergoes as a child by learning to become a member of society (family). Primary socialization takes place when children are 1-5 years old or when children have not yet entered school. Children start to recognize family member and family environment. Gradually he began to be able to differentiate himself from others around his family. In this stage, the role of the people closest to the child becomes very important because a child has limited interaction patterns in it. The color of the child's personality will be largely determined by the color of the personality and the interactions that occur between the child and his closest family members. Secondary socialization is an advanced socialization process after primary socialization that introduces individuals into certain groups in society. The forms are resocialization and desocialization. In the process of resocialization, a person is given a new identity. Meanwhile, in the process of desocialization, a person experiences a long 'revocation' of self-identity. According to Erving Goffman, the process of resocialization and desocialization is related to the function of social institutions. These social institutions include prisons and mental hospitals. The following is what Goffman means by social institutions: "A place where a number of individuals in the same situation live and work, cut off from the wider community for a certain period of time, together leading a life that is confined and formally regulated." Each group of people has different standards and values. For example, the standard 'whether someone is good or not' in school and in the playgroup is certainly different. At school, for example, a person is called good if his test score is above seven or he has never been late for school. While in the playgroup, a person is said to be good if he is in solidarity with friends or helps each other.

Untranslated articles can be quickly deleted according to criteria A2. A maar or funnel volcano, is a volcano that has a broad but flattened volcanic crater formed by a phreatomagmatic eruption (an explosion that occurs when water comes into contact with hot lava or magma). A typical maar fills with water to form relatively shallow crater lakes which may also be called maars. the name originates from the local Moselle Franken dialect of Daun in Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany, where it is derived from the Latin mare (sea). Maars are shallow, flat-floored craters that scientists interpret could have formed above diatremes as a result of the violent magmatic expansion of gas or vapor; deep erosion of the maar may expose the diatreme. Maars range in size from 60 to 8,000 m (200 to 26,250 ft) deep and from 10 to 200 m (33 to 656 ft) deep; most maars usually fill with water to form natural lakes. Most maars have low rims consisting of a loose mixture of volcanic rock fragments and rock ripped from the diatreme walls. The dry maar results when maar lakes dry up, become aggraded or silted up. The last example is Eckfelder Maar. Near Steffeln is Eichholzmaar (also called Gussweiher) which has dried up over the last century and is being renaturalised into a maar. In some cases the underlying rock is so porous that lake maar cannot form. After a winter of snow and rainfall many dry maars fill partially and temporarily with water; others contain a small marsh or often an artificial pond that, however, only occupies part of the hollow.

The largest known maar is found on the Seward Peninsula in northwestern Alaska. These maars range in size from 4,000 to 8,000 m (13,000 to 26,000 ft) in diameter and up to 300 m (980 ft) in depth. These eruptions occurred over a period of about 100,000 years, with the youngest (Devil Mount Maar) occurring around 17,500 years ago. This large size is due to the explosive reaction that occurs when magma comes into contact with permafrost. Hydromagmatic eruptions are increasingly explosive when the ratio of water to magma is lower. Since permafrost thaws slowly, it provides a steady source of eruptive water while keeping the water for magma too low. This produced prolonged, explosive eruptions that created these massive maars. Examples of the Seward maar Peninsula include North Killeak Maar, South Killeak Maar, Devil's Mountain Maar Whitefish and Maar. Maars occur in western North America, Patagonia in South America, the Eifel region of Germany (where they were originally described), and other geologically young volcanic regions of Earth. Elsewhere in Europe, La Vestide du Pal in the Ardèche department of France provides spectacular examples of maars easily visible from the ground or from the air. Kilbourne Hole and Hunting Hole, in southern New Mexico near El Paso, Texas, maar. The Crocodile Lake at Los Banos in the Philippines was originally thought to be a maar and volcanic crater. The famous, carbon dioxide-saturated Lake Nyos in Africa is another example. An excellent example of a maar is the Zuni Salt Lake in New Mexico, a shallow salt lake that occupies a flat-bottomed crater about 6,500 ft (2,000 m) across and 400 ft (120 m) deep.

The general definition of a base is a chemical compound that absorbs hydronium ions when dissolved in water. Bases are the opposite (dual) of acids, which are intended for chemical elements/compounds that have a pH of more than 7. Kostic is the term used for a strong base. Bases can be divided into strong bases and weak bases. The strength of a base is highly dependent on the ability of the base to release OH ions in solution and the concentration of the base solution. When dissolved in water, sodium hydroxide, which is a strong base, ionizes into sodium ions and hydroxide ions: at the same time, hydrochloric acid in water forms chloride ions and hydronium ions: When these 2 mixtures are combined, H3O+ and OH ions − will combine to form water: If the amount of NaOH and HCl dissolved is exactly the same, then the acid and base will be neutralized exactly, so there will only be a solution of NaCl (or table salt). A strong base is a type of simple compound that can deprotonate a very weak acid in an acid-base reaction. The most common examples of strong bases are the hydroxides of the alkali metals and alkaline earth metals such as NaOH and Ca(OH)2. The following is a list of strong bases: The cations from the above strong bases are in the first and second groups of the periodic list (alkaline and alkaline earth). An acid with a pKa of more than 13 is considered very weak, and its conjugate base is a strong base. Some strong bases such as calcium hydroxide are very insoluble in water. That's not a problem – the calcium hydroxide is still 100% ionized into calcium ions and hydroxide ions. Calcium hydroxide is still counted as a strong base because calcium hydroxide is 100% ionized.

Metabolism (Greek: μεταβολισμος, metabolismos, change) are all the life-sustaining biochemical reactions that occur within an organism. Chemical reactions occur as a result of specific, regular interactions between molecules in the cell environment and their changes. Cells will stop working if metabolism does not take place in the body. Metabolism also plays a role in detoxification. The types of reactions that occur during metabolic processes are divided into catabolism and anabolism. Metabolic processes require the help of enzymes as activators. The three main goals of metabolism are converting food into energy to carry out processes at the cellular level, converting food into raw materials for building proteins, lipids, nucleic acids and several types of carbohydrates, and eliminating metabolic waste. These enzyme-catalyzed reactions enable organisms to grow, reproduce, maintain structures, and respond to their environment (the word metabolism can be defined as all the chemical reactions that occur in living organisms including digestion and the movement of substances within and between different cells) The group of reactions above that occur at the cellular level can be known as intermediary metabolism or intermediate metabolism). Chemical reactions in metabolic processes are divided into several metabolic pathways, where one compound can change through several processes into another compound. Each process is facilitated by a specific enzyme. In general, metabolism has a two-way pathway of organic chemical reactions: Both directions of the metabolic pathway are necessary for every organism to survive. The direction of the metabolic trajectory is determined by a compound known as a hormone, and is accelerated (catalyzed) by enzymes. In organic compounds, the determinant of the direction of a chemical reaction is called a promoter and the determinant of the acceleration of a chemical reaction is called a catalyst. In each direction of metabolism, chemical reactions involve a number of substrates that react with enzymes as catalysts in the reaction steps to produce intermediate compounds, which become substrates in the next reaction step.

The entire chemical reactants involved in a reaction step is called the metabolome. All of this is studied in a branch of biology called metabolomics. Enzymes are crucial to metabolic processes because they allow an organism to regulate desired reactions that require energy not to occur by themselves by partnering with them. This pairing will produce a spontaneous reaction that will produce energy. Enzymes that function as catalysts will allow a reaction to run faster while at the same time regulating the rate of a metabolic reaction, for example in response to environmental changes experienced by cells or signals from other cells. The basal metabolic rate of an organism is a measure of the amount of energy consumed by all the chemical reactions that occur. The metabolic system of an organism determines which compounds are nutrients for the body or are toxic. For example, some types of prokaryotes use hydrogen sulfide as a nutrient, although this gas is toxic to animals. However, the specific features of metabolism are common in almost all the different species. For example, the known carboxylic acid group is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle, occurring in all known organisms. These compounds are also found in very different species such as the unicellular bacterium Eschirichia coli and large multicellular organisms such as elephants. The similarities in these metabolic pathways may be due to their presence in early evolutionary history and their retention due to their consequent efficacy. Cancer cell metabolism is very different from normal cells and this difference can be used as a therapeutic intervention in cancer. The term metabolism is derived from the French "métabolism" or Ancient Greek μεταβολή – "Metabole" which is translated as "a change" which is derived from the word μεταβάλλ – "Metaballein" which is translated as "to change" Aristotle's book entitled The Parts of Animals explains in sufficient detail about his views on metabolism which is described by an open flow diagram model.

Pāli (पाळि) is a variety of Old Prakrit languages ​​that are part of the Indo-Aryan language family. This language is most famously used by the Theravadins to write the collection of writings that became known as the Pāli Canon (or Tipitaka in Pāli and Tripitaka in Sanskrit), because it contains three groups of writings, namely the collection of rules (Vinaya), teachings (Suttas) and special teaching (Abhidhamma). In Buddhism, the Tipitaka is then seen as a holy book. The meaning of the Tipitaka in Pali is three groups or three baskets. This book was written in Sri Lanka in the first century BC. The Pāli language is written using the Brahmi script, Devanagari and so on. In the Latin script, the spelling system was coined by T. W. Rhys Davids of the Pali Text Society. The word Pāli itself means "lines/lines" or "(canonical) text" and is now classified as a literary language. While it is uncertain whether Pali was ever used as a vernacular; Pali has long been the language in which Theravada Buddhists chant their religious texts. Experts stated that the Buddha, Siddhartha Gautama was a speaker of Magadhi or another Middle Indo-Aryan language which is the language of the people living near the city of Benares (Varanasi), northeastern Central India. It was there that the Buddha resided and spread his teachings. The Pāli language is considered by Buddhists to be similar to the ancient Magadhi language, or even a continuation of it. But Magadhi is an east Indian language, while Pāli is most similar to the language spoken on west Indian inscriptions. Today Pāli is mainly studied to be able to study Buddhist texts, and it is often chanted. The Foundation of the Pali Text Society, which exists in the United Kingdom, since its founding in 1881 is a foundation that has played a major role in promoting the study of Pali by Western scholars.

The foundation publishes transliterated Pali texts in the Latin alphabet and often accompanied by English translations. Pali is a literary language of the Prakrit language family and was first written down in Sri Lanka in the first century BCE. Pali, as a Middle Indo-Aryan language, differs from Sanskrit, not only in terms of the time of origin but also in terms of its dialect base in that a number of morphological and lexical features are not a direct continuation of the Sanskrit Ṛeg Veda; it is derived from a dialect or dialects which, although they have much in common, differ from the Ṛeg Veda. However, some scholars such as AC Woolner believe that Pali derives from Vedic Sanskrit, but not necessarily from Classical Sanskrit. Pāli vocabulary has its roots in Sanskrit, but with a slightly different meaning, adapted to Buddhist teachings. Some of the rest of the Pāli vocabulary is rooted in the area of ​​use of the language (For example, adding Sinhalese vocabulary to the Pāli vocabulary. Conversely, much of the Sinhalese vocabulary is derived from Pali). The Pāli vocabulary itself indicates that Pāli was used as a liturgical language or for teaching Buddhism. The similar vocabulary between Sanskrit and Pali shows a contradiction in meaning. For example, Buddhists do not believe in the existence of a soul or the essential nature of things, so the term "dhamma" is used to reflect this (in Sanskrit it means "dharma"). The philosophy contained in Sanskrit and Pāli is also contradictory and reflects the differences between Buddhist and Hindu thought in the Middle India period. Sanskrit vocabulary was seen as inherently part of the things or things they describe, whereas Pali vocabulary was seen as having only conventional resemblance. Pali and Sanskrit are very closely related, and common characteristics of Pali and Sanskrit are always easily recognized by those in India who are familiar with both.

The Islamic Salvation Front (Arabic: الجبهة الإسلامية للإنقاذ, al-Jabhah al-Islāmiyah lil-Inqādh; French: Front Islamique du Salut/FIS) is a political party in Algeria with an Islamic ideology. Until 1988, the only political party in Algeria was the government party, the FLN. After the rebellion and opposition to the government and the FLN, Algerian President at that time Chadli Bendjedid, who incidentally was the Secretary General of the FLN, carried out reforms by allowing the establishment of various new political parties. In 1989 FIS was established at the insistence of the majority Muslim community. They were disappointed because the only party formed under President Boumedienne, namely the FLN, which had a secular basis, failed to make progress. As an Islamic political party, it is natural for FIS to raise issues around Islam. FIS offers programs that attract the sympathy of the people of Algeria such as the people's economy, supports the realization of a more Islamic life, democratization, and a government that is closer to the Islamic State than the West. In a short time, FIS succeeded in attracting the sympathy of the Algerian people, who are predominantly Muslim. The results in the first round of elections on June 20, 1991, FIS won 54% of the vote and won 188 (81%) seats in parliament. Algerian Muslims welcomed this victory and hoped that FIS would win the second round of elections. As expected, in the second round of elections in December 1991, the FIS won big. FIS' victory in round I and II elections shows that the Algerian people want a change towards a better and Islamic life. Starting January 11, 1992 when President Chadli Benjedid resigned after his party failed in the election at the urging of some members of his cabinet, especially the military. They are not willing if an Islamic political party leads there because it endangers their position. Then the military rulers dissolved the Algerian parliament and annulled the election results.

Tenesin (old name: Ununseptium) is the provisional name of the artificial superheavy chemical element with symbol Ts and atomic number 117. Six atoms were detected by a joint Russia-US collaboration at Dubna, Moscow Oblast, Russia, in October 2009. Although currently located As the heaviest member of the halogen family, there is no experimental evidence that the chemical properties of ununseptium match those of the lighter members such as iodine or astatine and theoretical analysis suggests there may be some important differences. In January 2010, scientists at the Flerov Nuclear Reactions Laboratory announced internally, that they had successfully detected the decay of a new element with Z = 117 using the reaction: Only six atoms were synthesized from two neighboring isotopes, which are not weathered for known isotopes of the elements. light element. The results were published April 9, 2010 in the journal Physical Review Letters. The element with atomic number 117 was historically known as eka-astatine. The name ununseptium is the systematic element name, used as a placeholder until the discovery is recognized by the IUPAC, and the IUPAC decides on that name. Usually, the name suggested by the inventor is selected. According to current guidelines from the IUPAC, end names for all new elements must end in "-ium", meaning names for ununseptium may end in -ium, not -ine, even if ununseptium turns out to be a halogen. Scientists at Dubna are continuing their study of the 249Bk + 48Ca reaction in order to attempt a first chemical study of ununtrium. The team at GSI in Darmstadt, recently recognized as the discoverers of copernisium, have started experiments aimed towards synthesizing ununseptium. GSI has indicated that if they are unable to acquire any 249Bk from the United States, which is likely given the situation regarding efforts in Russia, they will study the reaction 244 Pu (51 V, x n) instead, or perhaps 243 Am (50 Ti, x n) .

Relativism comes from the Latin word, relativus, which means relative or relative. In line with the meaning of the word, in general relativism argues that differences in human beings, culture, ethics, morals, religion, are not differences in essence, but differences due to external factors. As an ethical understanding and view, relativism argues that good and evil, right and wrong depend on each person and the culture of society. Teachings such as this were held by Protagras, Pyrrho, and their followers, as well as by the Skeptics. Ethical relativism which argues that the judgment of right and wrong depends on each person is called subjective or analytical ethical relativism. The ethical relativism which argues that ethical judgments are not the same, because there are no similarities between society and culture is called cultural ethical relativism. According to subjective ethical relativism, emotions and feelings play an important role in ethical issues. Therefore, the influence of emotions and feelings in moral decisions must be taken into account. Good and evil, right and wrong cannot be separated from those who are involved and judge them. Ethical relativism argues that there are no absolute criteria for moral decisions. Westermarck embraced an ethical relativism that linked decision criteria to individual culture, which exhibited individual differences. Joseph Fletcher's situational ethics considers the morality of an action relative to the goodness of that action's purpose. The strength of subjective ethical relativism is its awareness that humans are unique and different from one another. Because of this, living people respond to life's twists and turns and make ethical judgments about life differently. That way humans can live according to the demands of the situation. He can respond to his life in line with existing data and facts. He can determine what is good and bad, right and wrong, according to his own judgment and thinking.

Melilla (US /məˈliːjə/ mə-LEE-yə, UK /mɛˈ-/ MEH--; Spanish: meˈliʎa]; Arabic: مليلية‎ maˈliːlja]) is a Spanish autonomous city located on the east coast of Morocco, North Africa . Formed under the province of Malaga before being granted Autonomous Status, Melilla was a free port before Spain joined the European Union; The main industry is fishing. Other sources of income include cross-border trade (both legal and illicit) and aid from Spain and Europe. In 1994, the population numbered 63,670 people who embrace Christianity, Islam, Judaism and Hindu minorities. Since its independence from France and Spain, Morocco claims Melilla, Ceuta, the Canary Islands and several islets belonging to Spain near the African mainland (Plaza de soberania) as its territory. The claim is based on a similar comparison of Spanish claims to the Gibraltar region. However, the Spanish government rejected the comparison (citizens of the claimed territory also objected) on the grounds that Ceuta and Melilla were part of the unified Spanish state, while Gibraltar, a British overseas territory, could never become part of the United Kingdom. Many refugees from Africa are trying to enter the Melilla region, part of the European Union. The Melilla border fence, consisting of two 3 m high fences equipped with lookout towers, protects the border. But some refugees often make it through illegally and thus avoid being deported by Spanish police. Melilla was first ruled by the Phoenician Kingdom before becoming part of Punic under the name Rusadir. Later it became part of the Roman province of Mauretania Tingitana. The Vandal Empire, Byzantine Visigothic and Islamic Umayyads also ruled Melilla later. Melilla was on the border of the Kingdoms of Tlemcen and Fes when the duke of Medina Sidonia conquered it in 1497, a few years after the Spanish conquered the last of the Moorish kingdoms of Al-Andalus.

A molecule is an electrically ordinary group of two or more atoms held together by chemical bonds. Molecules are distinguished from ions by the absence of an electric charge. However, in quantum physics, organic chemistry, and biochemistry, the term molecule is often used somewhat loosely, also being used for polyatomic ions. In the kinetic theory of gases, the term molecule is often used for any gas particle regardless of its composition. According to this definition, noble gas atoms are considered as molecules as monatomic molecules. A molecule can be homonuclear, that is, it contains atoms of one chemical element, for example oxygen (O2); or it can also be heteronuclear, a chemical compound composed of more than one element, for example water (H2O). Atoms and complexes connected by non-covalent bonds, such as hydrogen bonds or ionic bonds, are generally considered to be single molecules. Molecules as components of plural matter are found in organic matter (and biochemistry of course). They make up most of the oceans and atmosphere. However, the majority of the solid matter known to us on Earth, including most of the minerals that make up Earth's crust, mantle, and core, contains many chemical bonds, but is not composed of identifiable molecules. In addition, there are no distinct molecules that can be defined as ionic crystals (salts) and covalent crystals (network solids), although these are often composed of unit cells that repeat so that they form a plane (as in graphene) or three dimensions ( such as diamond, quartz, or sodium chloride). The repeated unit cell structure theme also applies to most denser phases with metallic bonds, meaning that solid metals are also not made of molecules. In glass (a solid in a disorganized vitreous state), atoms can also be held together by chemical bonds without any definitive molecules present, nor the regular repeating units as in crystals.

Molecular science is called molecular chemistry or molecular physics, depending on whether the focus is on chemistry or physics. Molecular chemistry deals with the laws that govern the interactions between molecules that result in the formation and breaking of chemical bonds, while molecular physics deals with the laws that govern their structure and properties. In practice, however, this distinction is not unequivocal. In the molecular sciences, a molecule consists of a stable system (bond state ] made up of two or more atoms. Polyatomic ions can sometimes be thought of as electrically charged molecules. The term unstable molecule is used for highly reactive molecules, i.e. term pairing short (resonant) electrons and atomic nuclei, such as radicals, molecular ions, Rydberg molecules, transition states, van der Waals complexes, or systems of colliding atoms such as Bose–Einstein condensates. According to the Merriam-Webster and Online Etymology Dictionary, the term " molecule" is derived from the Latin "moles" or small unit of mass. The definition of molecule has evolved with increasing knowledge of molecular structure. The previous definition was less precise, defining a molecule as "the smallest particle of a pure chemical substance that still retains its chemical composition and properties". This definition is often contradicted by many substances in ordinary experience, such as rock, salt, and metals, consisting of a large crystalline network of chemically bonded atoms or ions, but not made of discrete molecules. Molecules are held together by covalent bonds or ionic bonds. Some types of non-metallic elements only exist as molecules in the environment. For example, hydrogen only exists as molecular hydrogen. A compound molecule is made of two or more elements. A covalent bond is a chemical bond that involves sharing of electron pairs between atoms. This pair of electrons is called a shared pair or bond pair, and the stable balance of attractive and repulsive forces between atoms, when they share electrons, is called a covalent bond.

Sigmund Freud (6 May 1856 – 23 September 1939) was an Austrian of Jewish descent and the founder of the school of psychoanalysis in the field of psychology. According to Freud, the life of the soul has three levels of consciousness, namely conscious, preconscious and unconscious. The most famous concept of Freud's theory is that there is a subconscious that controls most behavior. In addition, he also gave a statement that human behavior is based on sexual desire (eros) which is initially felt by humans since childhood from their mother. The sexual experience of the mother is like breastfeeding. Then it develops or is sublimated, giving rise to various other behaviors that are adapted to the rules of society's norms or father's norms. After his colleague, Alferd Adler, revealed that there is a death instinct in humans, even though Freud initially rejected Adler's statement by completely denying it. In the end, Freud aligns or does not leave only the sexual instinct that exists in humans, but juxtaposes it with the death instinct (Thanatos). Even so, he never mentioned that actually the origin of this theory was originally put forward by Adler. Freud became interested in and studied hypnosis in France, then used it to help people with mental illness. Freud later abandoned hypnosis after he succeeded in using new methods to treat sufferers of psychological distress, namely free association and dream analysis. The basis for creating this method comes from the concept of the subconscious. Free association is a method used to uncover problems that are suppressed by one's self but continue to push out without realizing it, causing problems, whereas dream analysis was used by Freud from his understanding that dreams are messages from the abstract subconscious to the conscious.

These messages contain wishes, fears, and various kinds of other emotional activities that are completely unconscious. and anger that is not realized because it is suppressed by someone. When these subconscious problems have been successfully uncovered, the next solution will be easier to solve. These things were done to develop what is now known as "medicine by talking". These things become the core elements of psychoanalysis. Freud was especially interested in the condition that was then called hysteria and is now called conversion syndrome. Freud's theories and his way of treating patients caused controversy in nineteenth century Vienna and are still hotly debated today. Freud's ideas are usually discussed and analyzed as works of literature, philosophy, and general culture, as well as as an ongoing debate as these scientific and medical treatises. Freud is a prominent figure related to his opinions in the field of psychology. Many of the terms are used by the public, for example: ego, super ego, and the Oedipus complex. Sigmund Freud was born in Freiberg on May 6, 1856. His family was of Jewish descent. His father was named Jacob Freud while his mother was named Amalia Natashon. His mother married his father when his mother was 19 years old. His father had two wives. He is the first child of his father and mother of the second wife. Freud's father worked as a merchant. His mother married when the child from his first wife was of an adult age. Freud had two half-brothers by his father's first wife. Freud's half-brother was almost the same age as his mother. As a child, Freud played with his nephew who was the son of his eldest half-brother.

–  in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Slovakia (Slovak: Slovensko, ˈslɔʋenskɔ]), officially known as the Slovak Republic (Slovak: Slovenská Republika, ˈslɔʋenskaː ˈrepublika]), is a sovereign state in Central Europe fraction of Czechoslovakia. This landlocked country is bordered by Poland to the north, the Czech Republic to the northwest, Ukraine to the east, Hungary to the south, and Austria to the southwest. Slovakia is a mountainous country with an area of ​​49,000 square kilometers and a population of more than 5.6 million people. The country's capital is Bratislava, and its second largest city is Kosice. Previously this country was part of the Great Moravian and Austro-Hungarian empires. Since January 1, 2009 Slovakia started to use the Euro. The Slavs arrived in the region in the 5th and 6th centuries AD and later founded the Samoan Empire in the 7th century, they also founded the Principality of Nitra in the 9th century which was later conquered by the Principality of Moravia which eventually formed Great Moravia. After Great Moravia was dissolved in the 10th century, it was annexed by the Principality of Hungary which later became the Kingdom of Hungary in 1000. In 1241 and 1242, large parts of Slovakia were destroyed by the Mongol Empire. The area was later rebuilt by King Béla IV of Hungary who also had Germans living there. Subsequently, this region became part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire until its collapse after World War I. Then, the Slovak region became part of Czechoslovakia. The fascist state of the Slovak Republic founded in 1939 was ruled by a totalitarian clergy-fascist regime that became a puppet of Nazi Germany. Czechoslovakia was re-established after World War II, which after a 1948 coup was ruled by a Soviet-backed communist regime.

Efforts to clean up the influence of communism peaked during the Prague Spring which was then crushed in August 1968 by the Warsaw Pact Invasion of Czechoslovakia so that the communist regime in that country was in power until the Velvet Revolution succeeded in overthrowing it without bloodshed in 1989. Slovakia separated peacefully from Czechoslovakia on January 1, 1993 through the Dissolution of Czechoslovakia better known as the "Velvet Divorce". Slovakia lies between latitudes 47° and 50° north latitude, and longitudes 16° and 23° east. Slovakia's landscape is noted primarily for its mountainous nature, with the Carpathian Mountains spanning much of the northern part of the country. Among these mountain ranges are the high peaks of the Fatra-Tatra Area (including the Tatra Mountains, Big Fatra and Small Fatra), Slovak Ore Mountains, Slovak Central Mountains or Beskids. The largest lowlands are the fertile Danubian Lowlands in the southwest, followed by the East Slovak Lowlands in the southeast. Forests cover 41% of Slovakia's land surface. Slovakia is divided into 8 regions (kraj), each named after its main city: Each kraj is subdivided into districts (okres). Slovakia currently has 79 districts. The population of this country is more than 5.4 million people. The average population density is 110 inhabitants per km2. According to the 2021 census, the majority of the population of Slovakia are Slovaks (83.82%). Meanwhile, Hungary is the largest ethnic minority (7.75%). Other ethnic groups are Roma (1.23%), Czech (0.53%), Rusyn (0.44%) and others or unspecified (6.1%). In 2018 the average age of Slovakian residents was 41 years. The largest wave of Slovak emigration occurred in the 19th and early 20th centuries. In the 1990 US census, 1.8 million people identified themselves as of Slovak descent.

Untranslated articles can be quickly deleted according to criteria A2. The Republic of Angola is a country located in southern Africa. Angola is bordered by Namibia, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Zambia and the Atlantic Ocean. Cabinda, an exclave-shaped province of Angola, borders the Republic of the Congo. Angola's area is almost twice the size of the island of Borneo; is ranked 22nd in the world (after Niger and before Mali). This country is one of the main coffee producers in the world and is one of the richest countries in Africa thanks to its natural resources, especially iron ore, diamonds and copper. The early settlers of this area were the Khoisan hunter-gatherer tribe. They were massively replaced by the Bantu during the Bantu migration. In present-day Angola, Portugal made a stop in 1483 on the Congo River, where the Congo, Ndongo and Lunda States were located. The country of the Congo stretched from modern Gabon in the north to the Kwanza River in the south. In 1575 Portugal established a Portuguese colony in Luanda based on the slave trade. The Portuguese gradually took control of the coastline throughout the 16th century through a series of treaties and wars. They formed the Angolan colony. The Dutch occupied Luanda between 1641-48, giving impetus to anti-Portuguese states. In 1648 Portugal retook Luanda and began a process of military conquest in the Congo and Ndongo states that ended with a Portuguese victory in 1671. Full Portuguese administrative control of internal affairs did not occur until the early 20th century. In 1951 the colony was reformed as an overseas province, also called Portuguese West Africa. As Portugal resisted the decolonization process 3 independence movements emerged: After 14 years of guerrilla war for independence, and the overthrow of Portugal's fascist government by a military coup, Angolan nationalist parties began negotiations for independence in January 1975.

Independence would be declared in November 1975. Almost immediately, civil war broke out between the MPLA, UNITA and the FNLA, exacerbated by foreign interference. South African troops allied with UNITA and invaded Angola in August 1975 to ensure that there was no encroachment (by the newly independent Angolan state) on Namibia, then still under South African occupation (Hodges, 2001, 11). The Soviet Union began assisting the MPLA and providing much of the economic support, while Cuban troops arrived to support the MPLA in October 1975, putting them in control of the capital, Luanda, and keeping South African forces at bay. The MPLA declared itself to be the de facto government of the country when formal independence was declared in November, with Agostinho Neto as first president. In 1976, the FNLA was defeated by combined MPLA and Cuban forces, leaving UNITA (backed by the United States and South Africa) and the Marxist MPLA fighting for power. Conflict broke out, fueled by Cold War geopolitics and by the ability of the two parties to access Angola's natural resources. The MPLA creates a tax on offshore oil resources, while UNITA has access to alluvial diamonds which are easily smuggled across the country's porous borders (LeBillon, 1999). In 1991, the factions agreed to the Bicesse Accords that turned Angola into a multiparty state, but after then (and current) president Jose Eduardo dos Santos of the MPLA won UN-supervised elections, UNITA declared fraud and war broke out again. The 1994 peace agreement (Lusaka protocol) between the government and UNITA provided for the integration of former UNITA rebels into the government. A national unity government was formed in 1997, but war broke out again in late 1998, leaving millions of people homeless.

Rajgir (originally known as Girivraj) is a town and nagar panchayat of the Nalanda District in the Indian state of Bihar. The city of Rajgir (ancient: Rājagṛha; Pali: Rājagaha; Hindi: राजगृह) was the first capital of the Magadha kingdom, a state that would eventually develop into the Mauryan Empire. Its date of origin is unknown, although ceramics dating from around 1000 BC have been found within the city. This region is also important in Jainism and Buddhism as it was one of the favorite places for Venerable Mahavira and Gautama Buddha and the famous "Atanatiya" conference was held on Mount Vulture Peak (Gijjhakuta). Rajgir is connected to Patna via Bakhtiarpur by rail and road. Bakhtiarpur is located halfway between Patna and Mokameh. The name Rajgir comes from the word "Rājagṛiha" which means "house of the king" or "house of the kingdom", or the word Rajgir may come from its simple literal meaning, "royal mountain". Rajgir was the ancient capital of the Magadha kingdom until the 5th century BC when Udayin (460-440 BC), son of Ajatshatru, moved the capital to Pataliputra. During this time, the city was called Rajgrih, which translates as "home of the royal family". Shishunaga founded the Shishunaga Dynasty in 413 BC with Rajgir as the initial capital before moving to Pataliputra. Rajgir was also famous for his association with the kings of the Haryanka Dynasty, Bimbisara and Ajatashatru. Ajatashatru kept his father Bimbsara in prison here. Sources disagree that the royal family of the Buddha's contemporaries, Bimbisara and Ajatashatru, were responsible for its construction. Ajatashatru is also associated with moving the capital to Pataliputra (present-day Patna). The Epic Mahabharata calls it Girivraja and tells the story of its king, Jarasanda, and his battle with the Pandava brothers and their ally Krishna.

Psychoanalysis is a branch of science developed by Sigmund Freud and his followers, as the study of human psychological functions and behavior. Sigmund Freud himself was born in Moravia on May 6, 1856 and died in London on September 23, 1939. At first the term psychoanalysis was used only in relation to Freud, so that Freud's "psychoanalysis" and "psychoanalysis" were synonymous.
