When some of Freud's followers later deviated from his teachings and went their separate ways, they too abandoned the term psychoanalysis and chose a new name to denote their teachings. Notable examples are Carl Gustav Jung and Alfred Adler, who coined the names "analytical psychology" (English: analitycal psychology) and "individual psychology" (English: individual psychology) for their respective teachings. Psychoanalysis has three applications: Within the broad spectrum of psychoanalysis there are at least 20 theoretical orientations that underlie theories about the understanding of human mental activity and human development. The various approaches to the treatment of so-called "psychoanalytic" are as varied as the various theories. Freudian psychoanalysis, both theory and therapy based on Freud's ideas has become the basis for modern therapies and is one of the largest currents in psychology. In addition, the term psychoanalysis also refers to research methods of child development. Psychoanalysis is a type of therapy that aims to release pent up or repressed emotions and memories. In other words, the goal of psychoanalysis is to bring to the surface what is in the subconscious. This goal is achieved by conversing with an individual about life's big questions, important matters, and diving into the complexities of life into the subconscious that seems simple on the surface. Freud was born in Austria and spent most of his childhood and adulthood in Vienna.

He entered medical school and trained to become a neurologist until obtaining his medical degree in 1881. Immediately after graduating, he opened private practice and began treating patients with psychological disorders. Freud had an interesting experience from a colleague and a patient; his partner is Dr. Josef Breuer and his patient, known as "Anna O.,", suffered from physical symptoms for no apparent physical cause. Dr Breuer found that her symptoms subsided when he helped her recover memories of traumatic experiences that she had kept hidden from her conscious mind. This incident sparked Freud's interest in the unconscious mind and led to the development of several ideas in the field of psychoanalysis. Sigmund Freud assumed that the initial driving energy of human behavior comes from within humans which lies deep in the subconscious. That is why so many physical ailments are caused by a person's psychological distress. That psychological pressure was pressed into one's subconscious. According to Freud, the life of the soul has three levels of consciousness, namely conscious, preconscious and unconscious. This topography or awareness map is used to describe the element of awareness in every mental event such as thinking and fantasizing. Until the early 1920s, theories about psychological conflict only involved these three elements of consciousness. Only in 1923 did Freud recognize three other structural models, namely the id, ego, and superego. This new structure does not replace the old structure, but completes and perfects the mental picture, especially in its function or purpose. The six supporting elements of the personality structure are as follows: Conscious (Conscious) The original level of consciousness that we observe at a particular moment. According to Freud, only a small part of mental life (thoughts, perceptions, feelings, and memories) enters consciousness.

The Republic of Kiribati (English: Republic of Kiribati), pronounced /kiribas/, is an island nation located in the Pacific Ocean. The country's 33 atolls are spread over 3,500,000 km² near the equator. Its name is a transliteration of "Gilberts", the English name for the largest group of islands, the Gilbert Islands in Kiribati. Kiribati became independent from the United Kingdom in 1979. The capital is South Tarawa, which is today the most densely populated area, consisting of a number of smaller islands, connected by a series of causeways which cover about half the area of ​​Tarawa atoll. Kiribati is a member of the South Pacific Community (SPC), Commonwealth of Nations, IMF, and World Bank, and became a full member of the United Nations in 1999. The name Kiribati was adopted at independence. This is the local pronunciation of the word Gilberts . The name is derived from the main islands that make up this country. The Gilbert Islands were formerly named after the British explorer Thomas Gilbert. He saw many of the islands in 1788 while charting the outer route from Port Jackson to Guangzhou. The Kiribati Islands were named Îles Gilbert (Gilbert Islands), in circa 1820, by Russian admiral Adam von Krusenstern and French captain Louis Duperrey. Both of their maps, published in 1820, were written in French. In English, the islands were often referred to as Kingsmills in the 19th century, although the name Gilbert Islands is increasingly used, including in the Western Pacific Order in Council in 1877. The name Gilbert was included in the names of all the colonies of the Gilbert and Ellice Islands from 1916, and was retained after the Ellice Islands became a separate nation, Tuvalu, in 1976. The Gilberts spelling of Kiribati can be found in Gilbertese books by missionaries and others (see e.g.

Hawaii Missionary Council, 1895). It has also been suggested that the local name for the Gilbert Islands is Tungaru (eg by Arthur Grimble in 1989). However, the name Kiribati was chosen as the name of the new independent nation by local consensus, on the grounds that it is more modern, requiring clarification] and in recognition of the inclusion of islands such as the Phoenix Islands and the Line Islands, which had not previously been considered part of an island chain. Mite (or Gilberts). The pronunciation is different: Kiribas is the official pronunciation because ti in Gilbert is s. Kiribati is inhabited by a Micronesian ethnic group who spoke a common type of Oceanic language for 2,000 years before coming into contact with Europeans. The islands were named the Gilbert Islands in 1820 by an Estonian admiral, Adam von Krusenstern, and a French captain, Louis Duperrey; named after Thomas Gilbert, who crossed the islands in 1788. In 1892, the Gilbert Islands became a protectorate of Great Britain along with the neighboring Ellice Islands. Both became colonies in 1916 and finally autonomous regions in 1971. In 1943, the Battle of Tarawa took place in the capital city of Kiribati on the island of Tarawa. In 1978, the Ellice Islands became an independent nation called Tuvalu, and Kiribati became independent on July 12, 1979. After Kiribati's independence, the United States withdrew all claims to Phoenix Island and all of the islands in the Line Islands (except three islands) which later became the Kiribati region. Kiribati is made up of 32 atolls and one island (Banaba), with at least three in each hemisphere. The islands are: The other three islands in the Line archipelago belong to the United States. Banaba is an elevated coral island that was once rich in phosphates, but all of them were mined before independence.

In biology, plants are multicellular eukaryotic organisms that belong to the kingdom Plantae. It consists of several clades, namely, flowering plants, gymnosperms or open seed plants, Lycopodiopsida, ferns, mosses, and some green algae. Green plants have tough cell walls containing cellulose. Green plants are included in the category of autotrophs (able to produce their own food). Almost all plant members are autotrophic, that is, they produce their own energy by converting sunlight energy through a process called photosynthesis in cell organelles called chloroplasts. Due to the dominant green color in members of this kingdom, another name used is Viridiplantae ("green plants"). Another name is Metaphyta. But there are also plants that are parasitic and some no longer have the ability to photosynthesize with little or no chlorophyll. Plants can also be characterized by the way they reproduce, growth ability, and alternation of generations. It is recorded that about 350,000 species of organisms are included in it, not including green algae. Of that amount, 258,650 species are flowering plants and 18,000 species of moss plants. Green plants produce almost all of the oxygen molecules on earth and are the most important part of the earth's ecological system. Plants that have been domesticated can produce seeds, fruits and vegetables which are useful as basic ingredients for human food. In addition, plants are also used as ornamental plants and many have medicinal properties and are used in medical science. The science of studying plants is called botany, which is a branch of biology. Past plant classifications included all algae ("algae") and fungi (fungi, including slime molds, even bacteria), as members. This kind of plant limitation is known as a plant in a broad sense, which is now considered obsolete.

The criticisms that emerged made the fungi separated from the plants. Although growing stationary, fungi are saprotrophic, obtaining energy from the remains of organic matter. In addition, the cell wall of fungi is not composed of cellulose, the material that makes up plant cell walls, but is composed of chitin, which in fact is mostly produced by animals. When the name Plantae or plant is used for a particular group of organisms or taxon, it generally refers to one of four concepts. From least to most inclusive, the four groupings are: Another way of looking at the relationships between the different groups that have been called "plants" is through cladograms, which show their evolutionary relationships. The evolutionary history of plants has not been fully established, but one accepted relationship between the three groups described above is shown below. Those that have been called "plants" are in bold. Glaucophyta Rhodophyta (red algae) Chlorophyta (green algae part) Streptophyta algae (green algae part) Charales (stonewort, often included in green algae) Land plants or Embryophyta The way the groups of green algae are put together and named varies between authors. Most algae are no longer included in the Kingdom Plantae. Algae consist of several different groups of organisms that produce energy by photosynthesis, each of which arose independently from non-photosynthetic ancestors. The most conspicuous algae are sea weeds, multicellular algae that may look more or less like terrestrial plants, but are classified alongside green, red, and brown algae. Each of these algae groups also includes various types of microscopic organisms and unicellular organisms. Most of the algae then also began to be separated from plant membership because they did not have tissue differentiation and did not form chlorophyll as an energy-capturing pigment.

Biology or life science is the study of life, and living organisms, including their structure, function, growth, evolution, distribution, and taxonomy. Modern biology discusses knowledge that is very broad, eclectic, and consists of various branches and sub-disciplines. In general, all branches of biology are united by the basic concepts that govern all biological research, namely the concepts of cells, genes, and evolution. Cells are recognized as the basic unit of life, genes are recognized as the basic unit of inheritance, and evolution is assumed to be the mechanism that drives the creation of new species. In addition, the survival of living things is believed to occur due to consumption behavior, changes in energy and regulation that maintains stability and vitality in the body. Subdisciplines of biology are defined based on the scale of the organisms studied, the types of organisms studied, and the methods used to study them, including: A person skilled in biology is called a biologist, biologist, or biologist. The term biology comes from the Greek word βίος, bios, which means means "life," and the ending -λογία, -logia, means "knowledge." The Latin form of the word (biology) was first used by Linnaeus (Carl von Linné) in his work entitled Bibliotheca botanica in 1736. The word was used again in 1766 by Michael Christoph Hanov in his writing entitled Philosophiae naturalis sive physicae: tomus III , continens geologyan, biologian, generalist phytologian. The German translation, Biologie, first appeared in a translation by Linnaeus in 1771. In 1797, Theodor Georg August Roose used the term in the introduction to his book Grundzüge der Lehre van der Lebenskraft. Karl Friedrich Burdach in 1800 used this term in a narrower sense, namely human research from a morphological, physiological and psychological point of view (Propädeutik zum Studien der gesammten Heilkunst).

The term biology in its modern sense only appeared in the book Biologie, oder Philosophie der lebenden Natur (1802–22) written by Gottfried Reinhold Treviranus. In the book it is written: Although modern biology is a relatively new development, the science concerned has been studied from the past. Natural philosophy can be found in the civilizations of Mesopotamia, Egypt, India and China. However, the origins of, and approaches to, modern biology date back to Ancient Greece. Although medical research can be traced back to the time of Hippocrates (ca. 460 BC–ca. 370 BC), Aristotle (384 BC–322 BC) was the figure most credited with developing biology. One of his most important works is Historia Animalium, and several other works that show the point of view of a natural researcher, as well as his empirical works that try to study biological causation and biodiversity. Aristotle's successor at the Lyceum, Theophrastus, wrote books on botany that were influential into the Middle Ages. Medieval Islamic scientists who studied biology included al-Jahiz (781–869), Ad-Dinawari (828–896), who wrote on botany, and ar-Razi (865–925), who wrote on anatomy, and physiology. Medicine is studied based on the Greek philosopher tradition, while the natural sciences are heavily influenced by Aristotle's thought, especially regarding the hierarchy of life. Biology began to develop rapidly after Antony van Leeuwenhoek improved his microscope. Thanks to him, spermatozoa, bacteria, infusoria, and various other microscopic life were discovered. The investigations carried out by Jan Swammerdam sparked interest in the field of entomology, and helped develop techniques for surgery, and microscopic staining. Advances in microscopy also greatly influenced thinking about biology. In the early 19th century, a number of biologists began to recognize the importance of the cell concept. Then, in 1838, Schleiden, and Schwann began advocating the (now widely accepted) idea that (1) the basic unit of organisms is the cell, and (2) each cell has the characteristics of life, although they opposed the idea that (3) all cells come from the division of other cells.

Others Others Sunni (/ˈsuːni, ˈsʊni/, KBBI: Suni) are the largest branch of Islam, belonging to 85–90% of the Muslim population. Its name comes from the word Sunnah, i.e. imitating what the Islamic Prophet Muhammad taught. The difference between Sunni and Shia is related to the conflict about who is appropriate as Muhammad's successor which leads to differences between aqidah and fiqh. According to Sunni tradition, Muhammad had no successors and those involved in the Saqifah affair appointed Abu Bakr as caliph. This is different from the Shia view, which considers that Muhammad appointed Ali bin Abi Talib as his successor. People who adhere to this branch of Islam prefer to refer to themselves as "experts of sunnah", or more fully ahlus-sunnah wal-jamāʻah ("people who follow the Sunnah and are in the group of Jamaah"). Followers of ahlus-sunnah are known as Sunnis. Sunnis are often referred to as "Orthodox Islam", although many religious scholars and scholars oppose this. Al-Qur'an and hadith (mainly those contained in Kutubussittah) and ijma', become the basis of Sunni fiqh. Sharia was derived by considering these sources, along with qiyas, istislah, and istihsan, using the ijtihad method developed by the priests of the schools of thought. In terms of faith, Sunnis adhere to the pillars of faith. In addition, Asy'ariyah and Maturidiyah adherents adhere to an understanding of theology and textual thought which are also referred to as Atsariyyah. When the Prophet Muhammad died, there was a misunderstanding between the Muhajirin and Ansar groups as to who would become the leader of the Muslims. The Companions saw that this would lead to discord between the Muhajirin and Ansar Muslims. After each submitted a delegation to determine who the Khalifah (successor of the Prophet Muhammad saw). Finally it was agreed by the Muslims to appoint Sayyidina Abu Bakr ra as caliph. citation needed] During the Caliphate III, Sayyidina Uthman bin Affan ra, there was quite serious slander in the body of Islam at that time, which resulted in the martyrdom of Caliph Uthman ra.

His killers were a group of delegations set up by Abdullah bin Saba' from Egypt who wanted to rebel against the caliph and wanted to kill him. Abdullah bin Saba' managed to develop a misguided understanding to pit Muslims against each other in order to destroy Islam from within. Then many people at that time, especially the men of Abdullah bin Saba' managed to kill Sayyidina Uthman ra in a sadistic manner while he was reading the Qur'an. reference needed] When Sayyidina Ali became caliph, he experienced many difficulties. The people who were influenced by Abdullah bin Saba' continued to pit the companions against each other. Their efforts were successful. Friends have a misunderstanding about the legal case of killing Caliph Uthman ra. The first comes from ummul mu'minim, Sayyidatina Aisyah ra, who was with Sayyidina Thalhah ra and the second is with Sayyidina Zubair ra. They were successfully pitted against each other until the Jamal War or the Camel War occurred. And then by Sayyidina Muawiyah ra who was appointed by Sayyidina Uthman ra as governor in Sham, resulting in the Shiffin War. Seeing the large number of sacrifices from the Muslim community, the disputing parties held ishlah or reconciliation. The rebels are not happy with the peace between the Muslims. Then there was a rebellion by those who initially pretended/hypocritical and they are the group called Khawarij. reference needed] The Khawarij wanted to seize the caliphate. However, they were prevented by Sayyidina Ali and Sayyidina Muawiyah ra, so they planned to kill them both. Ibn Muljam from the Khawarij managed to kill the caliph, Sayyidina Ali ra when he was leading the dawn prayer in Kufa, but not against Sayyidina Muawiyah ra because he was closely guarded. Even Sayyidina Muawiyah ra succeeded in consolidating himself and the Muslims, thanks to his political skills and the rigidity of his leadership.

Calcium or lime is a chemical element with the symbol Ca and atomic number 20. It has an atomic mass of 40.078 amu. Calcium is one of the alkaline earth metals, and is the fifth most abundant element on earth. Calcium is also the fifth most abundant ion in seawater in terms of molarity and mass, after sodium, chloride, magnesium and sulfate. Calcium is the fifth most abundant metal element in the human body. As an electrolyte, calcium ions play an important role in the physiological and biochemical processes of organisms and cells. As for the signal transduction pathway, calcium acts as a second messenger. Calcium also plays a role in the release of neurotransmitters from neurons. This element has a role in the contraction of all types of muscle cells and as a cofactor in many enzymes, as well as a role in fertilization. Calcium ions outside the cell function to maintain potential differences across the cell membrane, protein synthesis, and bone formation. On the table of the periodic table, calcium belongs to group 2A (or IIA), namely the alkaline earth metals, along with several other elements, namely beryllium (Be), magnesium (Mg), calcium (Ca), strontium (Sr), barium (Ba), and radium (Ra). The physical properties of calcium are harder than sodium, but softer than aluminum. Calcium is also less chemically reactive than the other alkali and alkaline earth metals. A calcium atom has twenty electrons arranged in the electron configuration Ar]4s2{\displaystyle Ar]4s^{2}}. Calcium is harder than lead but can be cut with a knife with difficulty. While calcium is a worse conductor of electricity than either copper or aluminum by volume, calcium is a better conductor by mass than either of them due to its very low density. The melting point of calcium is 850°C (1,560°F) while the boiling point is 1,440°C (2,620°F).

Meanwhile, calcium has a density of 1.54 g/cm3. Calcium is an alkaline earth metal with the symbol Ca and atomic number 20, located in the fourth period of the periodic table in Group 2. Calcium is the fifth most abundant element and third most abundant metal by weight in the earth's crust. However, calcium easily reacts with oxygen and water so that calcium is not found in metal form in nature, but in the form of limestone (CaCO3), lime (CaO) and calcium fluoride. Calcium can form salts with halides, such as CaCl2 or CaF2. Calcium chloride has various functions, one of which is as a drying agent. CaCl2+2H2OH2(l)⟶2CaCl2⋅2H2O{\displaystyle {\ce {CaCl2 + 2H2OH2(l) -> 2 CaCl2.2H2O}}} Calcium carbonate is important in the formation of cave stalactites and stalagmites. This reaction allows calcium carbonate to dissolve into solution as calcium bicarbonate. The reverse reaction can then turn the solution into solid calcium carbonate, forming limestone spikes in the caves as the calcium bicarbonate solution drips vertically over several millennia. The chemical reaction takes place as follows. CaCO3(s)+CO2(l)+H2O(l)⟶Ca(HCO3)2{\displaystyle {\ce {CaCO3(s) + CO2(l) + H2O (l) -> Ca(HCO3)2}} } In addition, calcium metal is quite reactive and combines with water at room temperature to produce hydrogen gas and calcium hydroxide. The product will then form hydrogen bubbles on the surface of the calcium metal. Ca(s)+2H2O(g)⟶Ca(OH)2(aq)+H2(g){\displaystyle {\ce {Ca(s) + 2H2O (g) -> Ca(OH)2(aq) + H2(g)}}} Calcium can react and dissolve in acids to form dissociated Ca and Cl ions together with Hydrogen gas, as in the following reaction. Ca(s)+2HCl(aq)⟶Ca2(aq)+2Cl−(aq)+H2(g){\displaystyle {\ce {Ca(s) + 2HCl (aq) -> Ca^2 (aq) + 2Cl- (aq) + H2 (g)}}} Although calcium is the fifth most abundant element in the earth's crust, it is never found free in nature because it easily forms compounds by reacting with oxygen and water.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth science Health science Mathematicsb] (from Ancient Greek μάθημα (máthēma), meaning "knowledge, thinking, study, learning"), is a scientific field, which includes the study of topics such as numbers (arithmetic and number theory), formulas and related structures (algebra), the shapes and spaces in which they exist (geometry), and their magnitudes and changes (calculus and analysis). There is no general agreement on its exact scope or epistemological status. Mathematics has always thrived, for example in China in 300 BC, in India in 100 AD, and in Arabia in 800 AD, until the Renaissance, when new mathematical discoveries interacted with new scientific discoveries leading to a rapid increase in the rate of discovery. mathematics. Continuing today, mathematics is used around the world as an important tool in a variety of fields, including natural sciences, engineering, medicine/medical sciences, and social sciences such as economics, and psychology. Applied mathematics, the branch of mathematics concerned with the application of mathematical knowledge to other fields, inspires and makes use of new mathematical discoveries, and sometimes leads to the development of entirely new disciplines, such as statistics and game theory. Mathematics is widely used in science for modeling phenomena. This allows the extraction of quantitative estimates from the experimental laws. For example, the motions of planets can be predicted with high accuracy using Newton's laws of gravity combined with mathematical calculations. The independence of the mathematical truth of any experiment implies that the accuracy of such an estimate depends only on the adequacy of the model to describe reality. So, when there are some imprecise estimates, it means that the model has to be corrected or changed, it doesn't mean that the math is wrong. For example, Mercury's apse or perihelium precession cannot be explained by Newton's laws of gravity, but it is accurately described by Einstein's general relativity.

This experimental validation of Einstein's theory shows that Newton's law of gravity is only an approximation (which is still very accurate in everyday life). Mathematics is important in many fields, including natural sciences, engineering, medicine, finance, computer science, and social sciences. Several areas of mathematics, such as statistics and game theory, were developed in direct correlation with their applications, and are often grouped under the name applied mathematics. Other areas of mathematics were developed independently of any application (and are therefore called pure mathematics), but practical applications are often found later. A good example is the prime factorization problem, which was referenced to Euclid, but which had no practical application prior to its use in the RSA cryptosystem (for computer network security). The word "mathematics" comes from the Ancient Greek: μάθημα (máthēma), which means "that which is studied," "what one wants to know," thus also means "study" and "science". The word for "mathematics" had a narrower and more technical meaning "the study of mathematics" even in Classical times. The adjective is mathēmatikós (μαθηματικός), meaning "related to learning" or "studying hard," which in turn means "mathematical". Specifically, mathēmatikḗ tékhnē (μαθηματικὴ τέχνη; Latin: ars mathematica) means "the art of mathematics". Similarly, one of the two main schools of thought within Pythagoreanism was known as the mathēmatikoi (μαθηματικοί)—which at the time meant "student" rather than "mathematician" in the modern sense. In Latin, and in English until about 1700, the term mathematics more often meant "astrology" (or sometimes "astronomy") than "mathematics"; the meaning gradually changed to what it is understood today from the 1500's to the 1800's. This resulted in several erroneous translations. For example, Saint Augustine's warning call that Christians should be wary of mathematici, meaning astrologers, is sometimes mistranslated as a mathematician's curse.

Fanömba adu is a traditional belief of the people of Nias Island which is part of the administrative area of ​​North Sumatra. Fanömba adu actually only refers to a ritual, namely the worship of a statue but later its use has developed into a term for the beliefs of the Nias tribe in general. Some authors refer to this belief as pelebegu which also refers to the traditional beliefs of other tribes in Indonesia such as the Batak and Acehnese. In carrying out the ritual, adherents of fanömba adu perform Molehe Adu, which is an activity of worshiping ancestral spirits. As a means of ritual, used wooden statues (fighting). These statues are believed to be occupied by the spirits of the ancestors. Examples of statues related to ancestors include Adu Zatua or a wooden statue of the ancestor of the male family, or Adu Nuwu which is a statue of the ancestor of the female family. Regarding these statues, adherents of fanömba adu also make them to symbolize various figures such as knights, skilled hunters, or people with strength. In the fanömba adu belief, there are several gods known by its adherents. The first god is Lowalangi. This god is positioned as the most important of the other gods. need clarification] Lowalangi is considered the ruler of the upper world or the creator. Lowalangi has the authority to impose punishment on those who do evil. The term Lowalangi is now used as a reference to God for followers of Christianity in Nias, first introduced by the missionary Denninger in 1865. Lowalangi is believed to have a family whose members are also gods for fanömba adu adherents. The god Lature Danö is considered the elder brother of Lowalangi and the king of the gods of the underworld. Lature Danö acts as a god who spreads various calamities such as disease, death, and earthquakes. Furthermore, there is Silewe Nazarata who acts as a protective deity for religious leaders as well as the wife of Lowalangi. Needs clarification] Another opinion also mentions another role for Silewe Nasarata, namely a liaison between the gods in the upper world and the underworld, also between the gods and the mankind.

Like humans, gods are also believed to be created. The one who is believed to be the creator of these gods is known as Ida Samihara Luo. This so-called Ida Samihara Luo has no reality, but from it two twins are born. Furthermore, these two twins married and the marriage produced gods and humans. Before the gods Lowalangi and Lature Danö existed, belief also said that there were other gods who existed after the universe was still in the form of chaos and darkness. It is Tuha Sihai who is considered the first god to exist. Tuha Sihai lives in the upper realms the size of a house and is supported by the wind. From the breath of Tuha Sihai, Aloloa Nangi was created, and from his head, the Toro'a tree emerged. The Toro'a tree produces three plant shoots and it is from the top bud that the gods Lowalangi and Lature Danö are born. Apart from these two, two evil spirits named Nadaoya and Afökha were born. Meanwhile, from the middle bud, a good spirit and an evil spirit are born, while no gods or spirits are born from the lowest bud. Apart from gods, spirits also have an important position in fanömba adu beliefs. Its adherents recognize various spirits as incarnations of people who have died. There are many spirits who are known and differentiated based on what they experienced in life. For example, there is Matiana/Maciana, the spirit of a woman who died giving birth to a child. This spirit is thought to exist to disturb women who are about to give birth. Later it was known that Solofo was the spirit of someone who was skilled in hunting. There is also Bekhu, the spirit of an ordinary dead person. If the spirit has come to its world, then what it does then is to continue its life as in the world during its lifetime.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union  (light blue) The Republic of Mali (French: République du Mali) is a landlocked country in West Africa, formerly a French colony. West Africa's second largest country is bordered by Algeria to the north, Niger to the east, Burkina Faso and Ivory Coast to the south, Guinea to the southwest, and Mauritania to the west. Its northern border extends into the middle of the Sahara desert. The majority of the population lives in the south, where the Niger and Senegal Rivers are located. The country, formerly known as French Sudan, takes its name from the Mali Empire. The Mali Empire became the center of the gold trade which made its leader Mansa Musa one of the richest men in history. Mansa Musa is a devout Muslim so he goes on pilgrimage to Mecca. On his way he brought many slaves, gold, and silk bodyguards. He distributed his gold to the poor people he passed. Unknowingly, this donation caused the price of gold in the Middle East to drop dramatically. The most famous city in Mali is Timbuktu which is famous as one of the trading centers in Africa in the 14th to 16th centuries during the Mali Empire. Goods traded included salt, gold, ivory, and slaves. In addition, this city is also known as one of the centers for the spread and education of Islam in Africa with the establishment of the University of Timbuktu. Timbuktu in its heyday was part of the Mali Empire. Another famous city is Djenné where there is the Great Mosque of Djenné which is made of mud. This mosque is included in the national coat of arms of Mali and is a UNESCO world heritage site.

On December 20, 2012, to help Mali recapture northern parts of the country that are now controlled by Islamic rebel groups, the UN Security Council approved sending military troops to Africa. Tuareg rebels and Islamist militant groups linked to Al-Qaeda have used a coup in March to gain control of the vast north. Historically Mali was divided into eight regions (régions) and one district. Each region has its own governor. Because the size of one region is very large, it is further divided into 49 cercles and 288 arrondissements. The elected mayor and city councilors govern the arrondissement. The list of regions and districts in Mali is as follows: The varied everyday culture of Mali reflects the ethnic and geographical diversity of the country. Most Malian people wear flowing colored robes called boubous which is characteristic of West Africa. Malian people often participate in traditional festivals, dances and ceremonies. Lutetium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Lu and atomic number 71. Lutetium is a white and silver mixed metal that is resistant to corrosion and is a rare earth product. Lutetium is the hardest and densest metal in the lanthanide group, which is located in the last column of the group on the periodic table. Lutetium was first discovered in 1907 by Baron Carl Auer von Welsbach, Georges Urbain, and Charles James while each of them was conducting research in different locations. They examined a mineral thought to consist purely of ytterbium, but in the end it was discovered that this mineral was also a combination of lutetium and several other chemical elements. Because Georges Urbain took the swift step to publicize his discovery, the naming of the chemical element lutetium was chosen and officially recognized globally. Lutetium has the atomic number 71 and the electron configuration Xe] 4f145d16s2. Lutetium is resistant to corrosion and is a mixture of white and silver in color. The atomic mass of lutetium is large compared to its size, so it has high boiling and melting points. Actually, the electrons of the element lutetium do not completely fill the d orbitals, but are still classified as lanthanides because they have physical and chemical characteristics that are very similar to the 14 other chemical elements of the lanthanide group. Lutetium has 59 isotopes, but only two are stable, namely Lu-175 and Lu-176. 97.41% of the total lutetium found on earth is Lu-175, while only 2.59% is Lu-176. Although less abundant and radioactive, elemental Lu-176 can last for 4x1010 years. In real life, lutetium can be obtained from minerals containing a mixture of lutetium and other lanthanide group chemical elements.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Romania (also spelled Romania; Romanian: România) is a country located in Central and Southeastern Europe, in the northern part of the Balkan Peninsula and bordering the Black Sea. Almost the entire Danube delta is located on the territory of Romania. The country is bordered by Hungary and Serbia to the west, Ukraine and the Republic of Moldova to the northeast, and Bulgaria to the south. History records that the Dacians, the Roman Empire, the Bulgarian Empire, the Hungarian Kingdom and the Ottoman Empire once controlled this region. As a country, Romania was formed in 1859 from the unification of the territories of Moldavia and Wallachia, and gained international recognition in 1878. In 1918, Transylvania, Bukovina and Bessarabia joined Romania. At the end of World War II, the Soviet Union occupied part of its territory (roughly covering the entire territory of modern Moldova) and Romania became a member of the Warsaw Pact. With the fall of the Iron Curtain in 1989, Romania began political and economic reforms. In the face of post-revolutionary economic problems, the country implemented low taxes in 2005 and joined the European Union on January 1, 2007. Although Romania's income level is one of the lowest in the European Union, reforms have boosted its economic growth. Romania is now a country that has an upper middle income. Romania is a country with the 9th largest area and 7th largest population in the European Union. Its capital and largest city is Bucharest (Romanian: Bucureşti), which is also the 6th largest city in the European Union. Sibiu, a city in Transylvania, was elected as the European Capital of Culture in 2007. Romania also joined NATO on March 29, 2004, and is also a member of the Latin Union, Francophonie, OSCE, and CPLP.

The country is a semi-presidential unitary state. The oldest modern human remains in Europe have been found in "Peştera cu Oase", Romania. These remains are estimated to be around 42,000 years old, and are probably the remains of the first Homo sapiens to enter the European continent, but the first written evidence of humans living in the Romanian region comes from Herodotus, who in his Historia volume IV in 440 BC wrote about the existence Getae tribes. The Dacians, who were considered part of the Getae, were a branch of the Thracian peoples who inhabited the region of Dacia (located in modern Romania, Moldova and northern Bulgaria). The Kingdom of Dacia reached its heyday during the reign of King Burebista around 82 BC. After the Dacians attacked the Roman province of Moesia in 87, Emperor Trajan launched the Dacian Wars which ended in a Roman victory in 106. As a result of this victory, Dacia became the Roman province of Dacia. The large amount of iron ore, gold and silver found in the province caused the Romans to colonize the Dacia region. The process of colonization brought with it Vulgar Latin and started a period of romanization, which would give rise to the proto-Romanian languages. In the 3rd century nomadic tribes such as the Goths carried out many invasions, forcing the Romans around 271 to withdraw from Dacia, making it the first province to be abandoned by the Romans. After the Romans left Dacia, the region was successively invaded by Goths, then by the Huns in the 4th century, and was followed by other nomadic tribes such as the Gepids, Avars, Bulgars, Pechenegs, and Cumans. The Romanian nation was further divided into three distinct principalities: Wallachia (Romanian: Ţara Românească), Moldavia (Romanian: Moldova) and Transylvania. Transylvania became part of the Kingdom of Hungary in the 11th century, and gained independence as the Principality of Transylvania from the 16th century to 1711.

Untranslated articles can be quickly deleted according to criteria A2. Pollination or pollination (from English: pollination cf. pollen, "pollen"), is the process of dropping pollen grains on the pistil surface. Pollination can occur in open seed plants and flowering plants. In open-seeded plants, the pollen must reach the pollinating drop, whereas in flowering plants, the pollen must reach the stigma. Successful pollination will soon be followed by the growth of powder reeds that enter the pistil to the ovule. It is in this ovule that the next process occurs, namely fertilization. Abiotic pollination refers to the situation where pollination occurs without the involvement of other organisms. Only 10% of flowering plants pollinate without the help of animals. The most common form of abiotic pollination is anemophilic, i.e. wind pollination. This form of pollination predominates in grasses, such as conifers, and deciduous trees. Hydrophile is the water pollination of aquatic plants which release their pollen directly into the surrounding water, either at the surface of the water or submerged in the water. In hydrophilic pollination, pollen grains have a density heavier than water, so the stamens sink and stick to the stigma. Approximately 98% of abiotic pollination is anemophilous, while the remaining 2% is hydrophilic, i.e. pollination with the help of water. Biotic pollination is a pollination process that requires organisms that carry or transfer pollen from the anther to the receptive part of the pistil. About 80% of plants pollinate biotically. The type of gymnosperm at biotic pollination generally occurs at a particular time when pollination occurs, although some gymnosperms and organisms adapt to the pollination process. Well-known examples are members of the order Cycadales and related species of beetles.

Most anemophilous conifers depend on wind pollination. The different characteristics of various flowers (and their combinations) attract one type or another which is known as a pollination syndrome. In the wild, there are about 200,000 species of animals that pollinate most of them are insects. Entomophily, pollination by insects, often occurs in plants that have colored flower petals and a strong scent to attract insects such as bees, wasps and ants (Hymenoptera), beetles (Coleoptera), moths and butterflies (Lepidoptera), and flies (Diptera). ). In zoophilia, pollination is carried out by vertebrate animals such as bats and birds, in particular, hummingbirds, pijantung, sriganti honeybirds, and fruit bats. Plants that use bats or moths as pollinators usually have white petals and a strong scent. Whereas plants that use birds as pollinators tend to develop red petals and rarely develop a scent (some birds rely on their sense of smell to find food). Anthropophilia, pollination by humans, is commonly used in hybridization techniques or for plants that require human assistance such as dragon fruit, vanilla, and plants grown in greenhouses. In agriculture, pollination management is a branch of agriculture that aims to protect and enhance the pollinating organisms present and often involves the culture and addition of the pollination process in monoculture situations, such as commercial orchards. The largest managed pollination activity in the world is in California almond orchards, where nearly half (about one million hives) of US honeybees are trucked to almond orchards each spring. New York City apple plants need about 30,000 hives, blue berry plants use about 50,000 hives each year. Bees are also brought into the commercial cultivation of cucumbers, squash, melons, strawberries, and other crops.

Saudi Arabia Algeria Libya Israel Jordan Lebanon Morocco Fatimid Italy, or al-Fāthimiyyūn (Arabic: الفاطميون, translit. al-Fāthimiyyūn‎) was a Shia ruler who ruled over various regions of the Maghreb, Egypt, and Syria from 5 January 910 to 1171. This country was ruled by the Ismailis, a branch of the Shiites. The leaders were also Shia priests, so they had religious interests in Isma'iliyyun. Sometimes this dynasty is also called Bani Ubaidillah, according to the name of the founder of the dynasty. The Fatimids had their origins in what is now Tunisia ("Ifriqiya") but after the conquest of Egypt around 971, the capital was moved to Cairo. During the Fatimid period, Egypt became the center of power which included North Africa, Sicily, the African Red Sea coast, Palestine, Syria, Yemen, and the Hijaz. During the Fatimid period, Egypt developed into a vast trading center in the Mediterranean and Indian Ocean, which determined the economic course of Egypt during the Late Middle Ages that Europe was then experiencing. The Fatimids were founded in 909 by ˤAbdullāh al-Mahdī Billa, who legitimized his claim through descent from the Prophet Muhammad from the line of Fāthimah az-Zahra and her husband ˤAlī ibn-Abī-Tālib, {the first Shīˤa Imam. Therefore this country was named al-Fātimiyyūn "Fatimiyah". Abdullāh al-Mahdi's control quickly extended throughout the Maghreb, the territories that are today Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia and Libya, which he ruled from Mahdia, the capital city built in Tunisia. The Fatimids entered Egypt in 972, conquered the Ikhshidid dynasty and established a new capital at al-Qāhirat "The Bower" (modern Cairo)- a reference to the emergence of the planet Mars. They continued to conquer the surrounding territories until they ruled from Tunisia to Syria and instead crossed into Sicily and southern Italy. Unlike local governments, Fatimid progress in state administration was based more on skill than on heredity.

Slavery or servitude is an act or condition that makes a person a slave, which is a property object owned by another person. Slavery usually occurred with enslaved people being made to do some form of work and their location also being determined by the person who owned them. Historically, when people were enslaved, it was often because that person was in debt, broke the law, or suffered a military defeat: The duration of their slavery could be a lifetime, or a period of time before they were granted freedom. An individual is usually enslaved against his will or under duress, although there is also voluntary slavery done to pay debts or to obtain money for a specific purpose. Throughout human history, slavery has been an aspect of civilization, and was once legal in most of the world's societies, but is now outlawed in all countries of the world. In traditional slavery (chattel slavery), people who are legally enslaved are considered the private property (chattel) of the slave owner. In economics, the term de facto slavery refers to the forced labor conditions experienced by the majority of slaves. In 2019, around 40 million people, of whom 26 percent were children, were enslaved worldwide despite being illegal. In the modern world, more than 50 percent of people are enslaved to perform forced labor, usually in factories in a country's private sector. In industrialized countries, human trafficking is a modern form of slavery; in non-industrialized countries, debt bondage is a common form of enslavement, such as captive domestic service, forced marriage, and child soldiers. The word slave (English: slave) in English was adopted from the Old French sclave.

In Medieval Latin it was sclavus and in Greek σκλάβος. Use of the word arose during the Early Medieval Period, when Slavic peoples from Central and Eastern Europe (Saqaliba) were often enslaved by Moors from the Iberian Peninsula and North Africa. There is debate among historians about whether terms such as "forced laborers" or "enslaved persons" were better used than "slaves" for victims of slavery. According to those who proposed changing the terminology, the term slave perpetuated the crime of slavery by reducing its victims to nouns and non-humans. Other historians prefer slaves because the term is more familiar and shorter, or because it accurately reflects the inhumane practice of slavery, and vice versa, one might say, implicitly indicating a degree of autonomy possessed that slavery simply did not exist. As an institutionalized social practice, traditional slavery denies human agency or autonomy and legally degrades their human status and status into goods (chattel) owned by their owners; therefore slaves are supposed to give birth to slaves; children of slaves were also born as slaves, under the legal doctrine of 2100 BC, the Law of Ur-Nammu ("4. If a slave marries a slave, and the slave is set free, he does not leave the house. 5. If a slave is married a freedman, she must leave her firstborn child to its owner....") or legal doctrine in 1662 CE partus sequitur venttrem ("That which is born follows the womb"). Like livestock, they can be bought and sold at will. By law, slaves could be used sexually in any way their owners wanted; women have no right to refuse.

Anthropology is the science of humans. Anthropology comes from the Greek word άνθρωπος (read: anthropos) which means "man" or "person", and logos which means "discourse" (in the sense of "reasoning", "reasoning") or etymologically anthropology means the science that studies humans. In conducting studies on humans, anthropology puts forward two important concepts, namely: Holistic and Comparative. Because of that, anthropological studies pay great attention to historical aspects and a thorough explanation to describe humans through knowledge of social sciences, life sciences (nature), and also the humanities. Anthropology aims to better understand and appreciate humans as biological entities, homo sapiens and social beings within an interdisciplinary and comprehensive framework. Therefore, anthropology uses the theory of biological evolution in providing meaning and historical facts in explaining the journey of mankind on earth since its inception. Anthropology also uses cross-cultural studies in emphasizing and explaining differences between human groups in the perspective of material culture, social behavior, language, and way of life. With its holistic orientation, anthropology is divided into four interrelated branches, namely: Biological Anthropology, Socio-Cultural Anthropology, Archeology, and Linguistics. The four branches have their own concentration studies in academic specialties and scientific research, with unique topics and different research methods. Anthropology was born or originated from Europeans' interest in the physical characteristics, customs, and culture of other ethnicities that were different from the people known in Europe. At that time, anthropological studies focused more on the population which was a single society, single in the sense of a community unit that lived in the same geographical area, had similar physical characteristics and used language, and had the same way of life. However, in its development, anthropology no longer only studies single human groups that inhabit the same geographical area.

Anthropological studies on migration issues, for example, later gave birth to multi-site ethnographic studies. This happens because in its development, the movement of people both within a certain regional area to in global scope is an increasingly common phenomenon. Anthropology is a broad discipline in which the humanities, social, and natural sciences combine to explain what is human and what it means to be human. Anthropology builds on knowledge from the natural sciences, including discoveries about the origin and evolution of Homo sapiens, human physical characteristics, human behavior, variations among various human groups, how the evolutionary past of Homo sapiens has influenced social organization and culture. As well as from the social sciences, anthropology studies the organization of social and cultural human relations, systems of descent and kinship relations, spirituality and religion, institutions, social conflicts, and so on. Early anthropology came from classical Greece and Persia which studied and tried to understand the diversity of cultures that can be observed. By this time, anthropology (late 20th century) had become central to the development of several new interdisciplinary fields such as cognitive science, globalization studies, genetics, and various ethnic studies. Broadly speaking, anthropology consists of: Biological Anthropology or also called Physical Anthropology is a branch of anthropology that studies humans and non-human primates (non-human primates) in terms of biology, evolution, and demography. Biological/Physical Anthropology focuses on the biological and social factors that influenced (or determined) the evolution of humans and other primates, which produced, maintained, or altered their present genetic and physiological variations. Biological Anthropology is further divided into several branches of science, including: Social anthropology is the study of the relationship between people and groups. Meanwhile Cultural Anthropology is a comparative study of how people understand the world around them in different ways.

Afghanistan (Pashtun and Dari: افغانستان, Afghanistan), officially the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan is a country located in South and Central Asia. The country is directly bordered by Pakistan to the east and south, Iran to the west, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan to the north, Tajikistan and China to the northeast. Its area covers 652,000 km² (252,000 sq mi), making it the 41st largest country in the world. Afghanistan has a population of about 31.4 million as of 2020, with a population that includes the Pashtun, Tajik, Hazara and Uzbek ethnic groups. Kabul is the capital and largest city of Afghanistan. Humans have settled in Afghanistan since the Middle Old Stone Age (Paleolithic). Location's proximity to the silk routes linked the country with Europe and other parts of Asia. Throughout the centuries, Afghanistan has been home to many peoples and has been the goal of numerous military campaigns, notably those of Alexander the Great, Mauryans, Muslim Arabs, Mongol Empires, British, Russian Empires, Soviet Union, and the United States. Afghanistan is also the place where the Kushan, White Hun, Samanid, Safarid, Ghaznavid, Gurid, Khilji, Mughal, Hotaki, Durrani and others dynasties have risen to form great empires. The political history of the modern state of Afghanistan begins with the rule of the Hotaki and Durrani Empires in the 18th Century. In the late 19th Century, Afghanistan became a buffer state between the Russian Empire and the British Empire. After the Third Afghan War in 1919, King Amannullah tried to modernize Afghanistan, but failed to do so. Afghanistan became a peaceful country during the forty year reign of Zahir Shah. In the 1970s, a series of coups or forced coups followed by a series of civil wars devastated large parts of Afghanistan. These events began when the country was made a socialist state under the influence of the Soviet Union during the Soviet-Afghan War.

After the Soviet troops left Afghanistan, the country became an Islamic state with the Peshawar Agreement, but most of its territory has been controlled by the Taliban fighters who ruled the country for almost five years by strictly enforcing Islamic Sharia. Since the September 11, 2001 attacks on America, when the Taliban were forced out of Afghanistan by a coalition led. NATO's largest terrorist organization for hiding the whereabouts of the great fighter Osama bin Laden (Founder of Al Qaeda). Afghan politics was replaced with a pro-Western government elected through a democratic process. In 2021, after 20 years of war, US President Joe Biden has decided to withdraw all US troops from Afghanistan. This decision gave room for the Taliban to immediately attack and seize Afghanistan's territories from the control of the central government. After taking control of other provinces, the Taliban managed to enter Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, on August 15, 2021. Afghanistan then became an Islamic country that established Islam as the official religion and law. The name Afghanistan comes from the word Afghanistan. The Pashtuns or the largest ethnic group in Afghanistan appear to have started using the term Afghan as a name for themselves from the Islamic period onward. According to W.K. Frazier Tyler, M.C. Gillet, and several other scholars, "The word Afghanistan first appears in history in al-Hudud Alam in 982 AD." There are many views, regarding the origin of the name Afghanistan. Most of them are purely speculative and presumptive as can be seen below: Excavations of a prehistoric site by Louis Dupree and several others have shown that humans lived in what is now Afghanistan at least ± 50,000 years ago, and that agricultural peoples in that area including the oldest in the world.

The judge is an official who exercises judicial power and presides over the trial as stipulated in the law. The judge means the person who adjudicates the case (in court and court). In carrying out their duties and functions, judges are obliged to maintain the independence of the judiciary. The term "judge" itself comes from the Arabic word حكم (hakima) which means "rules, regulations, power, government". He decides the punishment for the accused party. Judges must be respected in the courtroom and violation of this can result in punishment. Judges usually wear black clothes. Its powers vary in different countries. Judges have the main task, which is to resolve legal disputes in a final and open manner, indirectly the judge confirms the existence of the rule of law. Judges as state officials have significant authority in government. They oversee the trial procedures followed, with the aim of ensuring consistency, impartiality, as well as abuse of power. In addition, judges can give orders to the military, police or court officials so that the investigation process runs smoothly. Orders can be search, arrest, imprisonment, disturbance, confiscation, deportation, and other non-criminal acts. As for the court of appeal and the highest court which has higher power than a judge, they can examine the power of a judge. Usually before conducting a trial, the National Police (officers and Coroners (political)), the public prosecutor or the public prosecutor conduct pre-trial investigations to gather facts. The court has three main court officials who are trained and legally recognized: judges, public prosecutors and defense lawyers. Judges have many roles between legal systems. In System (common law) cases, as has happened in the United States and England, the judge acts as an impartial arbiter, especially to ensure procedures run properly. While the prosecution and defense present their cases before a jury, which is usually selected from ordinary citizens.

The jury is the main fact finder, while the judge will finalize the sentence. However, in smaller court cases the judge may issue a summary decision without having to proceed to a jury trial. In a melit (civil law) system, as is the case on the European continent, there is no jury and judge as the main factfinder, whose job is to preside over the trial, judge, and pass sentences. Thus, judges are expected to be able to apply the law directly, as in the French expression Le juge est la bouche de la loi ("The judge is the mouth of the law"). It is explained further, that in some systems an investigation can be carried out by a judge who functions as an examining judge. According to Galih Maulana, Lc "When making a qada decision a judge must avoid 10 circumstances," The ten conditions that a qadi must avoid when handling the case are: Judges can work alone in smaller cases, but in criminal, family and other cases another important case, they work in panels. In some civil law systems, this panel may include lay judges. A lay judge, unlike a professional judge, is usually not legally trained. There are voluntary judges and professional judges. A voluntary judge, such as a British judge, is not required to have legal training and is not paid. Meanwhile, professional judges must be legally educated. In the United States, professional judges usually require a Juris Doctor degree, in addition to professional experience. In the US judges who are often appointed are judges who have experience and are usually appointed by the head of state. However, in some US jurisdictions, judges are elected in political elections. In the rule of law, impartiality is considered so important, that in most jurisdictions, judges can be removed by the executive.

Savanna is a meadow filled with shrubs or shrubs and is interspersed with several types of trees that grow spread out, such as palms and acacias. This biotic system usually forms between the tropics and subtropics. Several continents that have savannas include Africa, South America, and Australia. The lack of precipitation served as the impetus for the emergence of savannas. So that the savanna is also known as a tropical meadow. The climate is not too dry to be desert, but not wet enough to be forest. The air temperature in the savanna area remains the same throughout the year, which is warm. But the savanna has two very different seasons, namely the dry season and the wet season. In the dry season, there is only 4 inches of rainfall. Even between December and February there is no rain at all. But in the dry season, the weather is noticeably cooler. Meanwhile, in the summer, the savanna gets a lot of rain. In Africa, the rainy season starts in May and it gets 15 to 25 inches of rain around the clock. There are several different types of savanna around the world. The best known savannas are located in East Africa where acacia trees grow. The Serengeti Plain in Tanzania is one of them. There live animals such as Lions, Zebras, Elephants, Giraffes, and Buffaloes. The savannas of the tropics have rainfall ranging from 40 – 60 inches per year, but the type of season determines the temperature and humidity. The largest savanna in the world is in Africa and the widest savanna is also in Australia. The savanna biome is grasslands located in tropical and sub-tropical climates. Apart from that, the savanna biome is also in the form of a forest with various shrubs, single trees or canopy trees.

Enlil (nlin), 𒂗𒇸 (EN = Lord + LÍL = Wind, "Lord (of) Storm") was the Sumerian god of wind, breath, majesty and vastness (referring to space: heights and spans) in Mesopotamian religion. Enlil is the name of the supreme god written in Sumerian religious clay tablets, and later in Akkadian (Assyrian and Babylonian), Hittite, Canaanite and later other Mesopotamian clay tablets. The name of this god was later pronounced and translated as "Ellil" in later Akkadian, Hittite, and Canaanite literature. In later Akkadian times, Enlil is referred to as the son of the gods Ansar and Kishar. In the myth of Enlil and Ninlil it is said that when Enlil was young, he was banished from Ekur, the home of the gods in Nippur, and then he fell into Kur, the underworld, where he seduced a goddess named Ninlil. Ninlil was captivated, and followed him to the underworld, whereupon she married him and bore him a son, Enlil, the moon god Sin (Sumerian Nanna/Suen). After becoming the father of three gods of the underworld (Sin's successor), Enlil is allowed to return to Ekur. Enlil is credited with inventing the hoe (an important farming tool, hoe, ax or Sumerian digging tool) and helping plants grow. Enlil, along with the gods Anu/An, Enki and Ninhursag were important gods in Sumer. Together with his wife Ninlil or Sud, Enlil fathered Nanna/Suen (Sin) in Akkadian religion and Ninurta (also called Ningirsu). Enlil is the father of Nisaba the god of grain and grain, as well as Pabilsag who is equated with Ninurta, or Enbilulu. According to Ereshkigal Enlil was the father of Namtar. In one myth, Enlil advised his son, the god Ninurta, on how to kill the demon Asag. This advice was conveyed to Ninurta by means of the weapon Sharur, a magical talking mace, which Ninurta sent to the realm of the gods to contact Enlil directly.

Bermuda is an overseas territory of the United Kingdom in the northern Atlantic Ocean. It is located about 933 km from the coast of North Carolina, United States of America. The region consisting of 138 islands is divided into 10 parish and 2 municipalities. Bermuda takes its name from the Spanish sailor Juan de Bermúdez, who discovered the islands in 1505, while sailing to Spain from a supply voyage to Hispaniola on the ship La Garça. (His last name comes from the Visigothic name "Bermund" or "Veremund".) The name's earliest appearance in English literature is in Shakespeare's The Tempest, a play inspired by the shipwreck of the Sea Venture, though not set on an island: Thou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dewFrom the still-vex'd Bermoothes John Donne's poem "The Storm" uses the same idea: Compared to these storms, death is only a quality, Hell is mild, and 'Bermuda is serene. Bermuda was discovered in the early 1500's by Spanish explorer Juan de Bermúdez. Bermuda had no indigenous population when it was discovered, or during early British settlement a century later. It is mentioned in Legatio Babylonica, published in 1511 by the historian Pedro Mártir de Anglería, and included in the Spanish charts that year. Both Spanish and Portuguese ships used the islands as a replenishment point for fresh meat and water. The shipwrecked Portuguese sailor is now held responsible for the 1543 inscription on Portuguese Rock, formerly called Spanish Rock. The legend arose of spirits and demons, now ascribed to the croaking calls (most likely the Bermuda petrel, or cahow) and the nocturnal noises of wild boars. With frequent storm conditions and treacherous coral reefs, the archipelago is known as "Devil's Island".

Neither Spain nor Portugal are trying to work it out. For the next century, the island was visited frequently but not settled. The English began to focus on the New World, initially settling in Virginia, beginning the English colonization of North America, establishing a colony at Jamestown, Virginia in 1607. Two years later, a fleet of seven ships left England with several hundred settlers, food and supplies for the liberated the Jamestown colony. However, the fleet was broken up by a storm and the flagship, Sea Venture, pushed the ship onto the Bermuda reef to prevent it from sinking, resulting in the safety of all aboard and crew. The settlers were unwilling to move, having heard about the real conditions in Jamestown from sailors, and made various attempts to rebel and settle in Bermuda. They argued that they had the right to live and establish their own government. The new settlement became a prison labor camp, and built two ships, Deliverance, and Patience. Bermuda is now claimed for the British Crown. Template:Citation needed? In 1612, the English began the settlement of the archipelago, officially named Virgineola, with the arrival of the ship Plow. New London (renamed St. George's Town) was established that year and established as the colony's first capital. It is the oldest continuously inhabited English city in the New World. In 1615 the colony, which had been renamed Somers Islands in memory of Sir George Somers, passed to the Somers Islands Company. While Bermudians settled the Carolina Colony and contributed to establishing other British American colonies, several other locations were named after the islands. During this period the first slaves were held captive and traded to the islands. It is a mix of African Natives trafficked to America through the African slave trade and enslaved Native Americans from the Thirteen Colonies.

Consequentialism is an understanding of normative ethics which emphasizes that the rightness of an action must be judged by the consequences of that action. In consequentialism, actions that are considered right are actions that produce beneficial results in the form of good for society. Moral in consequentialism is based on the selection of the results of actions that provide the greatest benefit. Consequentialism is one of the principles applied in utilitarianism. In addition, consequentialism is also applied in hedonism. The term consequentialism was first used in 1957 by Elizabeth Anscombe. In consequentialism, an action is performed not only with respect to the consequences of that action. The consequences of an action must first be chosen based on the level of goodness. An action can generally produce several equally valuable consequences, so it is necessary to select the most valuable consequence to work on. The views of consequentialism and deontological ethics began to be used for intellectual property rights because of the difficulty in justifying ownership rights to objects as part of them. Protection does not get a guarantee if it is only based on a legal and constitutional basis. Therefore, another basis of protection is needed which is independent and applies as a rule. This thinking developed in United States jurisprudence. The principle of consequentialism is part of the deontological ethics of utilitarianism. This is due to his view which determines that the ethical quality of an action is determined by the consequences of his actions and not because of the action itself. Good deeds are only valued as good when they produce the greatest benefit. Meanwhile, good deeds that do not produce any benefit are not considered good. Consequentialism is also related to teleological studies on utilitarianism which judges actions based on goals. The teleological system also judges actions by their consequences. One of the thinkers of this utilitarianism is Jeremy Betham.

Desiderius Erasmus Roterodamus (28 October 1466 – 12 July 1536), known as Erasmus or Erasmus of Rotterdam, note 1] was a Dutch theologian, teacher, social critic, Catholic priest, and Renaissance humanist. Erasmus was a classical scholar and wrote in a pure Latin style. In humanist circles, he is called the "Prince of the Humanists", and has been called "the crowning glory of Christian humanists". Using humanist techniques to work on texts, he compiled important new editions of the Greek and Latin New Testaments, giving rise to issues that would later influence the Protestant Reformation and Counter-Reformation (Catholicism). He also wrote On Free Will, Praise of Ignorance, A Christian Knight's Handbook, On Modesty in Children, Copia: The Fundamentals of Abundant Style, Julius Exclusus, and many other works. Erasmus opposed the European religious reforms that were developing in his time, but he was critical of abuses within the Catholic Church and called for reforms. He kept his distance from Martin Luther and Philip Melanchthon and continued to recognize the authority of the pope, emphasizing a middle way with a deep respect for grace, piety, and faith according to tradition, rejecting Luther's emphasis on faith alone. Erasmus remained a member of the Roman Catholic Church throughout his life, remaining committed to reforms from within the Church and the abuses committed by its clerics. He also adhered to the Catholic doctrine of free will, which some reformers rejected because of their predestination doctrine. His middle ground approach ("Via Media") disappointed, and even angered, academic circles on both sides. Erasmus died suddenly in Basel in 1536 while preparing to return to Brabant, and was buried in the Basel Minster, the city's former cathedral.

A bronze statue of him was erected in his hometown in 1622, replacing an earlier work made of stone. Desiderius Erasmus is reported to have been born in Rotterdam on October 28, in the late 1460s. He was named after Saint Erasmus of Formia, a figure favored by Gerard, Erasmus' father. A legend from the 17th century states that Erasmus was originally called Geert Geerts (also Gerhard Gerhards or Gerrit Gerritsz), but this is unfounded. He was born in Rotterdam, however, it is thought that there were insufficient records to conclusively warrant a referral]. A well-known woodcut indicates: Goudæ conceptus, Roterodami natus (Latin for: conceived in Gouda, born in Rotterdam). According to an article by the historian Renier Snooy (1478–1537), Erasmus was born in Gouda. There is controversy as to the exact year he was born, but most agree that he was born in 1466. Evidence confirming 1466 as the year Erasmus was born can be found in his own words: fifteen of the twenty-three statements he makes regarding his age indicate the year 1466. He was baptized with the name "Erasmus", after a saint with that name, St. Erasmus of Formia. Although closely associated with Rotterdam, he lived there for only four years, never to return. Information about Erasmus' family and early life comes mainly from the vague references in his writings. His parents are said to be legally unmarried. Gerard's father was a fellow priest in Gouda. Little is known about his mother, although the name that is known is Margaretha Rogerius (the Latin form of the Dutch surname 'Rutgers'), the daughter of a doctor from Zevenbergen.

The hydrosphere is the layer of water that is on the surface of the earth. The formation of the hydrosphere comes from various sources of water on earth. The word hydrosphere comes from the English word hydrosphere; hydro means water and sphere means circle or scope. So, the hydrosphere is the layer of water that covers the earth. The hydrosphere on the surface of the earth includes lakes, rivers, seas, oceans, snow or glaciers, groundwater and water vapor contained in the air layer. The hydrologic cycle is a process of circulation or recycling of water sequentially and continuously. Sunlight has an effect on the hydrologic cycle. Water on the entire surface of the earth will evaporate when exposed to sunlight. At a certain height, when the temperature drops, water vapor will condense and turn into water droplets and fall as rain. The hydrologic cycle is divided into three, namely short cycle, medium cycle and long cycle. In the short cycle, seawater that is exposed to the sun's heat evaporates into gas so that it condenses before it reaches the land and forms clouds, resulting in rain on the sea surface. On the medium cycle, water vapor originating from the ocean is blown by the wind towards the mainland. On land water vapor forms clouds which eventually fall as rain over land. The rainwater will flow through rivers, ditches and so on until it returns to the sea... In a long cycle, water vapor originating from the ocean is blown by the wind onto the land. There is cooling that reaches the freezing point at a certain height, making clouds containing ice crystals form. These clouds drop hail or snow on the mountains. On the surface of the earth, ice flows in the form of glaciers, enters rivers and then returns to the oceans.

The hydrosphere on earth will then be grouped into two, namely inland waters and sea waters. The Process of the Hydrological Cycle To form a hydrological cycle there are several processes that occur within it, including evaporation, transpiration, sublimation, interception, condensation, advection, precipitation, run off, and infiltration. Waters on land are classified as fresh waters, namely all waters that cross land. Ground water includes groundwater and surface water. Groundwater is water that is found in the ground. Groundwater comes from snow, rain or other forms of precipitation that seep into the ground and are stored in an impermeable layer. Phreatic water is groundwater that lies on an impermeable layer not far from the ground surface. Phreatic water is strongly influenced by the absorption of water around it. In the dry season the amount of phreatic water decreases. Conversely, during the rainy season, the amount of phreatic water will increase. Phreatic water can be taken from wells or springs. Artesian water is groundwater that lies deep in the ground, between two impermeable layers. The layer between the two impermeable layers is called the aquifer layer. This layer holds a lot of water. If the waterproofing layer cracks, water will naturally escape onto the surface. The water that gushes to the surface is called an artesian spring. Artesian water can be obtained by drilling. The well drilled is called an artesian well... Surface water is a container of water that is found on the surface of the earth. Forms of surface water include rivers, lakes, swamps. River is rainwater or spring water that flows naturally through a valley or between two banks with clear boundaries, towards a lower place (ocean, lake or other river).

Jainism (Sanskrit: जैनधर्म - Jainadharma, Tamil: சமணம் - Samaṇam) is a dharma religion. Jaina means the religion of conquest. It is intended to subdue the natures of lust in the order of human life. The Jaina religion was founded by Nataputta Vardhamana, who lived in 559–527 BC who was called Mahawira, which means great hero. Jaina religion was born before Buddhism. Buddhism has a wider following outside India, but Jaina religion is limited to India only. Both religions are a reaction to the conditions within Hinduism regarding the development of its teachings in the past. Today there are more than 8 million followers of this religion. They are mainly found in India. Socially, Jainism adherents usually belong to the upper middle class. The Jaina religion has inherited temple buildings which are very famous for their architectural beauty in India and are always visited by tourists. The closest Jaina term to "scripture" is religion, the "arrival" of a set of doctrines through transmission by authoritative gurus and clear lineages, that is, "enlightened" people who have discovered the truth of ahimsa. Religion is summed up in an oft-quoted statement: “The Decent Man follows the meaning, then the disciples compose the suttas (sacred texts), and then the sacred texts proceed for the good of the doctrines.” This is what makes the meaning of a text separate from its words. What's more, the sutta means "indication" - something that only hints at or points to a meaning that can only be fully explained by a qualified teacher. Through this, it can be seen that this three-layered process also occurs in the story of Mahavira. After his enlightenment, it is reported that he preached at the tree spirit temple before the king and queen of Champa, as well as a large crowd of ascetics, gods, lay people, and animals.

Mahavira's disciples who listened to the sermon then conveyed his message orally, so that it became a sutta. However, this is only an "indication" of Mahavira's words. He narrates eternal and immutable truths which, like the universe itself, have no beginning and have been conveyed by “enlightened humans” in previous eras. The Sutta does not record Mahavira's own words, but is simply a commentary on his message. This perhaps explains the strong belief of Jains that their scriptures are incomplete and that important truths have been lost – a theme we encounter in other traditions as well. It is said that each of the 24 tithankaras taught the doctrine of ahimsa to his circle of disciples, and that at each age the disciples recorded the teachings of the guru in the fourteen scriptures. However, tragically after the death of each tithankara, the disciples responsible for imparting the teachings died in a famine, resulting in the loss of important teachings. Therefore, whenever a tithankara dies, the Jains always get only an incomplete canon of scriptures. The few remaining holy books only enshrine doctrines that are less important and are intended for women and children, because only men are capable of understanding higher teachings. The Jains try to correct the weaknesses of their method of transmitting scriptures through a series of sidings (vacana). The first council was held in the mid-3rd century BC at Pataliputra, and the second and third councils were held in the 4th and 5th centuries AD. A more accurate translation of vacana is "discourse" or "recitation". There is no intellectual debate in these sessions; participants listened to the monks recite the holy books they had memorized. According to Karen Armstrong, Jainism is often seen as atheistic.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health Sciences Biogeography is a branch of biology that studies the diversity of life in space and time. This scientific branch aims to reveal about the life of an organism and what influences it. Biogeography includes the analysis and explanation of distribution patterns combined with an understanding of changes in the distribution of living things from the past to the present. The main study in biogeography discusses the historical development of groups of organisms. The observed developments relate to the origin, spread, and the relationship between the present distribution in explaining past history. The focus of the discussion of biogeography lies in the interaction of organisms with the physical environment and interactions between organisms. Biogeography also studies the relationships that influence the species and taxa found today. Biogeography is divided into regions and sub-regions with reference to the degree of human intervention.
