Markers for biogeographical regions and sub-regions are sign systems that use letter symbols and a decimal system. This marker serves to describe an ecosystem with a concise and globally understood formula. Science doesn't just ask What species? and Where?, but he also asks Why? and sometimes Why not?. In biogeography, historical approaches and ecological factors are used to study the distribution of flora and fauna in the world. The historical approach views biogeography from the aspects of the development and evolution of organisms, which are influenced by climate, migration, past developments on the earth's surface, and its relationship with the present environment. The ecological point of view views biogeography from the point of view of the relationship between the organism itself and the environment and its influences. The pattern of distribution of species at this level can be explained by a combination of hereditary factors such as speciﬁcation, extinction, continental drift, glaciation (which is also related to sea level, river channels and related matters), as well as river capture and availability of natural resources.

The branch of biogeography that studies the distribution and distribution of plants is called Phytogeography. Meanwhile, Zoogeography studies the distribution of animals. The term biogeography was introduced by biologists, namely Robert H. MacArthur and E.O. Wilson in the 1960s, which is a field of science that contains biological evolution, namely discussions about biology, ecology, genetics, geography, and paleontology, which are used to determine the distribution of species. Biogeography was developed and popularized by early naturalists such as Carl von Linne, Alexander von Humbolt, Edward Forbes, Joseph Hooker, Louis Agassiz, Alfred R. Wallace, and Charles Darwin, who originally classified different aspects of plants. Molecular biologists define biogeography as the study of gene lineage, while ecologists consider biogeography to be the study of ecosystems and geographic distribution. Biogeography is also known as learning related to the biosphere, which contains the physical nature around it, both soil, animals and plants. Biogeographic regions are shaped by the presence of climate. The types of organisms that live in an area are determined by one of the climatic elements, namely humidity. Moisture levels are determined by sunlight and soil temperature in an environment. Plant development and biodiversity are determined by rainfall. Heavy rainfall supports the growth of large trees. On the other hand, little rainfall favors the development of short trees, shrubs, grasses, and desert plants. Rainfall and soil temperature in an area are directly proportional to the number of plants that can develop in an area. Climatic conditions greatly affect the state of plants, while the state of vegetation affects the existence of certain types of animals. The state of the fauna in each area (biome) largely depends on the possibilities that area can provide for providing food.

Diarrhea or diarrhea (English: diarrhea) is a disease when stools or feces turn soft or liquid which usually occurs at least three times in 24 hours. In developing countries, diarrhea is the most common cause of death for children under five, and also kills more than 2.6 million people each year. This condition can be a symptom of injury, disease, allergies (fructose, lactose), excess vitamin C, and consuming certain fruits. Usually accompanied by abdominal pain and sometimes nausea and vomiting. There are other conditions that involve but not all of the symptoms of diarrhea, and the official medical definition of diarrhea is stools in excess of 200 grams per day. Eating foods that are sour, spicy, or coconut milk in excess can also cause diarrhea because it shocks the intestines. This occurs when insufficient fluid is absorbed by the large intestine. As part of the digestion process, or due to fluid intake, food is mixed with large amounts of water. Therefore digested food consists of liquids before it reaches the large intestine. The large intestine absorbs water, leaving other materials as semi-solid waste. If the large intestine is damaged/inflamed, absorption does not occur and the result is watery feces. Diarrhea is mostly caused by some viral infection but is also often the result of bacterial toxins. In clean living conditions and with adequate food and water available, healthy patients usually recover from common viral infections within a few days and as long as a week. However, for sick or malnourished individuals, diarrhea can cause severe dehydration and can be life-threatening without treatment. Diarrhea can be a symptom of a more serious disease, such as dysentery, cholera or botulism, and it can also be indicative of a chronic syndrome such as Crohn's disease.

Although people with appendicitis generally do not experience diarrhea, diarrhea is a common symptom of appendicitis. Diarrhea can also be caused by excessive alcohol consumption, especially in someone who is not eating enough. so if you want to consume alcohol better eat first. Unstable weather conditions, poor sanitation in refugee camps and dirty houses exposed to stagnant water, as well as the difficulty of getting clean water makes it easy for diarrheal outbreaks to occur after a flood. Diarrhea that looks mild can actually be life-threatening, because when the body lacks fluids, all organs will experience interference. Diarrhea will be more dangerous if it occurs in children. Symptoms that are usually found are continuous bowel movements accompanied by prolonged heartburn, dehydration, nausea and vomiting. But other symptoms that can arise include back pain, and frequent stomach sounds. Treatment of diarrhea involves the patient consuming sufficient amounts of water to replace what is lost, preferably mixed with electrolytes to provide the required salt and some nutrients. ORS and zinc tablets are the treatment of choice and have been estimated to have saved 50 million children in the last 25 years. For many people, further treatment and legal medication are not needed. If powdered ORS is not available, ORS can be made with the following ingredients: Mix all the ingredients until dissolved and then drink it to people with diarrhea. Take ORS under the following conditions: The following diarrhea usually requires medical supervision: Infective diarrhea that is unusual for diarrhea can last a long time. This diarrhea is caused by several organisms that cause it can survive for years without clear symptoms of long-term disease.

in Europe  (gray) Turkey (or Türkiye), officially known as the Republic of Turkey (Turkish: Türkiye Cumhuriyeti) is a unitary state with a presidential system in the Eurasia region. Its territory stretches from the Anatolian Peninsula in Northwest Asia to the Balkans in Southeastern Europe. Turkey is bordered by the Black Sea to the north; Bulgaria to the northwest; Greece and the Aegean Sea to the west; Georgia in the northeast; Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Iran to the east; Iraq and Syria in the southeast; and the Mediterranean Sea to the south. The Marmara Sea which is part of Turkey is used to mark the boundaries of the European continent and the Asian continent, so that Turkey is known as a transcontinental country. The Turks started migrating to the area that was called Turkish in the 11th century. This migration process accelerated even more after the victory of the Seljuk Sultanate against the Byzantine Empire at the battle of Manzikert. Several Beylik (Turkish Emirates) and the Seljuk Sultanate of Rûm ruled Anatolia until the invasion of the Mongol Empire. Beginning in the 13th century, the Ottoman beylik unified Anatolia and formed an empire encompassing much of Southeastern Europe, Western Asia, and North Africa. After the Ottoman Empire collapsed following defeat in World War I and internal problems (the Young Turk Movement rebellion and the Arab Rebellion) parts of its territory were occupied by the Allies who won World War I. Mustafa Kemal Atatrk then organized resistance movements against the Allies. In 1923, this resistance movement succeeded in establishing the Modern Republic of Turkey with Mustafa Kemal Atatürk serving as its first president. Turkey's capital is in Ankara but the country's largest city is Istanbul or Constantinople which was formerly the capital of the Byzantine Empire and the Ottoman Empire. Due to its strategic location at the junction of two continents, Turkish culture is a unique blend of Eastern and Western cultures which are often introduced as a bridge between the two civilizations.

With the existence of a strong area from the Adriatic to China in the land route between Russia and India, Turkey has acquired rapidly increasing strategic importance. Turkey is a democratic constitutional republic, united with a presidential republic system since the era of President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan. Turkey has been gradually joining the western countries of the European Union but its membership is still suspended, while at the same time forging ties with the East. This country is one of the founding members of the United Nations, the Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC), OECD, and OSCE, as well as a member state of the Council of Europe since 1949, and NATO since 1952. Since 2005, Turkey is the first Islamic country to negotiate joins the European Union, having been a member of the coalition since 1963. Turkey is also a member of the G20 industrial countries which bring together the 20 largest economies in the world. The name Turki or Türkiye in Turkish consists of two components, namely: the ethnonym Türk and the abstract ending –iye which means "owner", "land" (derived from the ending in Arabic –iyya which is similar to the ending –ia in Greek and Latin ). The earliest record of the term "Türk" or "Türük" as an autonym is found in Orkhon writings by the Göktürk (Scientist Turks) of Central Asia (c. 8th century AD). Tu–kin was used as evidence as early as 177 BC as the name given by the Chinese to residents in the southern region of the Altai Mountains in Central Asia. The Indonesian name "Turkish" comes from the Middle Latin, namely Turchia (c. 1369). This name is closely related to Tourkia in Greek, which was originally used by the Byzantines to refer to Hungary in the Middle Ages (because the Hungarians and Turks had the same ancestry) but later they began to use this name to name the areas Seljuk conquered in Anatolia, hundreds of thousands of years ago. years after the Battle of Manzikert in 1071.

in Europe (gray) Switzerland, officially the Swiss Confederation (German: Schweiz, French: Suisse, Italian: Svizzera, Romansh: Svizra, Latin: Confoederatio Helvetica), is a federal state of 26 cantons in Europe Central is bordered by Germany to the north, France to the west, Italy to the south, Liechtenstein and Austria to the east. Switzerland is a country that is mostly made up of the Alps. Switzerland is known as a neutral country but still has strong international cooperation. Switzerland is divided into 26 cantons. Six of these are sometimes considered "half cantons" because they stem from the separation of the three cantons, resulting in only one representative on the Council of State. The capital of this country is Bern. Other important cities are Zurich, the largest city in Switzerland (which was named the city with the best quality of life in the world in 2006 and 2007), and Geneva, which is home to various international agencies such as the United Nations, WHO, ILO, and UNHCR. Switzerland is bordered by Germany, France, Italy, Austria and the small principality of Liechtenstein. Swiss people speak many languages, and there are four official languages: German, French, Italian and the less popular Romansh. Switzerland has a rich history as a neutral country regardless of war or peace (and has not been involved in war against a foreign government since 1815). Therefore, Switzerland has become the host for various international organizations such as the United Nations which, although their headquarters are in New York City, have many offices in Switzerland. Switzerland's Latin name, Confoederatio Helvetica, which means Confederation of Helvetica, was chosen to avoid choosing one of Switzerland's four official languages ​​(German, French, Italian and Romansh).

The country's TLD, .ch, is also named after this. Of its 26 cantons, 17 are Swiss-German, 4 Swiss-Romande/French, 1 Italian, 3 bilingual (German-French), and 1 trilingual (Italian-German-Romansh). Commonly used names for Switzerland in French (Confédération suisse), Italian (Confederazione Svizzera), and Romansh (Confederaziun svizra) are translated as "Swiss Confederation"). Schweizerische Eidgenossenschaft is the German term found in official documents. Its Latin name is "Confœderatio Helvetica" (Confederation of Helvetia). The country TLD is "ch" for internet. The car's license plate relates to the Helvetii, an ancient Celtic tribe that once occupied the Alps. Switzerland marks August 1, 1291 as its independence day; following the history of this country, which was originally a united country, then became an alliance since 1848. August 1 was made a public holiday so that banks, post offices, and general administration offices were closed. The system of government is excellent, truly reflecting and absorbing the diversity of its population. As a federal state, its democracy is "direct", but represented by the Federal Assembly. This parliament elects seven people to be the "government". The seven of them have ministerial status, head departments, and one of them becomes president for one year in rotation. The first known tribes in this area were members of the Hallstatt and La Tène cultures. The La Tene culture grew, and thrived during the late Iron Age from around 450 BC, possibly with some influence from Greek, and Etruscan civilizations. One of the most important tribal groups in the Swiss region are the Helvetii. In 15 BC, Tiberius I, who would be nominated as 2nd Roman Emperor, and his brother Drusus, conquered the Alps, incorporating them into the Roman Empire. The area inhabited by the Helvetii people – who later derived the name Confoederatio Helvetica – first became part of the Roman Voivodeship of Gallia Belgica, and then to Germania Superior, while the eastern part of modern Switzerland was incorporated into the Voivodeship of Raetia.

Suriname or Suriname, officially the Republic of Suriname (Dutch: Republiek Suriname), formerly Dutch Guiana or Dutch Guiana is a country in South America and a former colony of the Netherlands. The country is bordered by French Guiana to the east and Guyana to the west. In the south it is bordered by Brazil and in the north by the Atlantic Ocean. There are around 75,000 Javanese living in Suriname and Javanese as one of the official languages ​​in Suriname, they were brought there from the Dutch East Indies between 1890-1939. Suriname is a member of the Organization of the Islamic Conference. Suriname became widely known since the 15th century, when European imperialist nations competed for control of Guyana, a vast plain situated between the Atlantic Ocean, the Amazon River, the Rio Negro, the Cassiquiare River and the Orinoco River. Originally this plain was named by the cartography experts as Guyana Karibania (Guyana which means a wide plain which is flowed by many rivers and Karibania from the word Caribs which is the name of the native people who first inhabited the plains). In a fictional story "El Dorado", Guyana is described as a region rich in gold deposits. Historians estimate that this fictitious story was one of the factors that encouraged Europeans to compete for control of Guyana. In 1449 Spanish sailors, Alonzo de Ojeda and Juan de la Cosa sailed along the northeastern coast of South America, which they called the Wild Coast at that time, and landed in the territory of Guyana. Vincent Juan Pinzon then ruled Guyana in the name of the King of Spain. During the 16th and 17th centuries, Guyana was ruled alternately by Spain, the Netherlands, England, France and Portugal. In 1530 the Dutch established the first trading center on the plains.

In 1593 the Spanish king took over and controlled Guyana until 1595, when English nobles arrived and started to control the coastal areas. Meanwhile, the Dutch began to gradually develop their trade in the hinterlands. Guyana fell completely to the British from 1630 to 1639. In the same year the Dutch managed to regain control of most of Guyana while the French controlled the areas beside the Suriname river. As a result of this competition, the territory of Guyana is currently divided into five parts, namely Guyana Espanola (part of present-day Venezuela); Inglesa (present-day Guyana); Holandesa (Suriname); Francesa (Cayenne) and Portuguesa (part of Brazil). Suriname is located in the central part of the divided Guyana region, stretching between 2 degrees to 6 degrees north latitude, and between 54 degrees to 58 degrees west longitude with an area of ​​approximately 163,265 square kilometers. The eastern boundary of Suriname is the Marowijne River which separates Suriname from Cayenne; in the south, there are a series of mountain ranges, the Carai and Toemoe hoemak mountains, which separate Suriname from the territory of Brazil. To the west it is bordered by Guyana which is marked by the Corantijne River, while to the north it is bounded by the coastline of the Atlantic Ocean. In 1651 Suriname was invaded by the British and from then on, became a British territory until the signing of the Breda peace treaty in 1667. Based on that agreement, Suriname became a Dutch territory. However, the British re-entered Suriname in 1781 to 1783 and Suriname was then made a British protectorate from 1799 to 1802. Through the Treaty of Amiens, 27 March 1802, Suriname, Barbice, Demerara and Essquibo came under Dutch control, but a year later the British reconquered these territories and since 1804 Suriname became a British colony as the British Interregnum.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark gray)– in the African Union  (light blue) Mauritania (Arabic: موريتانيا Mūrītānyā; Berber: Muritanya or Agawej; Wolof: Gànnaar; Soninke: Murutaane; Pulaar: Mauritania), with the official name Islamic Republic of Mauritania (République islamique de Mauritanie), is a country in North Africa. The country is bordered by Mali to the east and south, Senegal to the southwest, the Atlantic Ocean to the west, Western Sahara to the north and northwest, and Algeria to the northeast. Mauritania is the eleventh largest country in Africa; 90 percent of its territory lies in the Sahara. Most of its 4.4 million people live in the temperate climates of the south, with about a third concentrated in the capital and largest city, Nouakchott, which lies on the Atlantic coast. The country's name comes from Mauretania, a region that housed Berber kingdoms from the 3rd century BC to the 7th century on the northwestern tip of Africa in what is now Morocco and Algeria. The Berbers began to occupy the territory of Mauritania from the 3rd century AD. Arabs conquered the area in the 8th century, bringing with them Islam, Arabic culture and the Arabic language. In the early 20th century, Mauritania was colonized by France as part of French West Africa. Mauritania achieved its independence in 1960. Since its independence, Mauritania has experienced repeated coups and has experienced periods of military dictatorship. The most recent incident occurred on 6 August 2008. The government was overthrown in a military coup led by General Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz. On April 16, 2009, Aziz resigned from the military to run for president in the July 19 presidential election and won. He also won the next presidential election in 2014.

Mohamed Ould Ghazouani replaced Abdel Aziz after he won the 2019 general election. This event is considered the first peaceful transition of power in Mauritania since independence. Culturally and politically, the country is part of the Arab world: Mauritania is a member of the Arab League and Arabic is the country's only official language. French is widely spoken and functions as an intermediary, reflecting its colonial heritage. The official religion is Islam and almost the entire population is Sunni Muslim. Despite its Arab identity, Mauritania is a multiethnic country: 30 percent of the population are Midwives, or "white moors" as they are known, while Haratin, or "black moors" as they are known, comprise 40 percent. The two groups reflect an Arab-Berber mix of ethnicity, language and culture. The remaining 30 percent of the population is made up of various sub-Saharan ethnic groups. Despite having abundant natural resources, including iron ore and petroleum, Mauritania is one of the poorest countries; The main basis of its economy is agriculture, animal husbandry and fishing. About 20% of Mauritanians live on less than US$1.25 per day. Slavery in Mauritania is a major human rights problem, with around 4% (155,600 people) of the country's population in slavery. This number is the highest of all countries. Other human rights issues in Mauritania include female genital mutilation, and child labour. Mauritania was the last country in the world to abolish slavery, in 1981, and criminalize it in 2007. The peoples who inhabited ancient Mauritania were the Berbers, Niger-Congo, and Bafour. The Bafour people were one of the first Saharan peoples to abandon the nomadic lifestyle and adopt an agricultural lifestyle. Due to the gradual drying of the Sahara desert which made it difficult for plants to grow, they eventually migrated south.

Polyvinyl chloride (IUPAC: Poly(chloroethanediol)), commonly abbreviated as PVC, is the third most widely used thermoplastic polymer in the world, after polyethylene and polypropylene. Worldwide, more than 50% of PVC produced is used in construction. As a building material, PVC is relatively inexpensive, durable and easy to assemble. PVC can be made more elastic and flexible by adding plasticizers, generally phthalates. Flexible PVC is commonly used as clothing, piping, roofing, and electrical cable insulation. PVC is produced by polymerizing vinyl chloride monomer (CH2=CHCl). Because 57% of its mass is chlorine, PVC is a polymer that uses the lowest petroleum raw material among other polymers. The production process used in general is suspension polymerization. In this process, vinyl chloride monomer and water are introduced to the polymerization reactor and polymerization initiator, along with chemical additives to initiate the reaction. The ingredients in the reaction vessel are continuously mixed to maintain suspension and ensure uniformity of the particle size of the PVC resin. The reaction is exothermic, and requires a cooling mechanism to maintain the reactor at the required temperature. As the volume contracts during the reaction (PVC is denser than vinyl chloride monomer), water is continuously added to the mixture to maintain suspension. When the reaction is complete, the resultant liquid PVC must be separated from the excess vinyl chloride monomer to be reused for the next reaction. Then the finished PVC liquid will be centrifuged to separate the excess water. The liquid is then dried with hot air and the resulting PVC granules are produced. In normal operation, the excess of vinyl chloride monomer in PVC is only less than 1 PPM. Other production processes, such as micro-suspension and emulsion polymerization, produce PVC with smaller granules, with slightly different properties and therefore different applications.

The product of the polymerization process is pure PVC. Before PVC becomes the final product, it usually requires conversion by adding heat stabilizer, UV stabilizer, lubricant, plasticizer, process aid, thermal regulator, filler, flame retardant, biocide, developer, and selected pigment. PVC was discovered by accident by Henri Victor Regnault in 1835 and Eugen Baumann in 1872. In the early 20th century, Russian chemists Ivan Ostromislensky and Fritz Klatte of the German chemical company Griesheim-Elektron tried to establish the use of PVC as a commercial product. However, the difficulty of stiffening the material hindered their efforts. In 1926, Waldo Semon and the B. F. Goodrich company developed a method of making PVC 'completely plastic' by adding various additives. As a result, PVC becomes more flexible and easier to process which then achieves widespread use. 1 The attractive properties of PVC make it suitable for a wide variety of uses. PVC is biologically and chemically resistant, making it the plastic of choice as a material for household drainpipes and other piping where corrosion is a barrier to metal piping. With the addition of various anti-pressure and stabilizer materials, PVC is becoming a popular material for window and door frames. With the addition of a plasticizer, PVC becomes elastic enough to be used as a cable insulator. PVC has been used extensively in clothing, making leather-like materials. PVC is cheaper than rubber, leather, or latex and so it is widely used. PVC is also waterproof, so it is used as a material for making jackets, coats and bags. PVC used as electrical cable insulation must use a plasticizer to make it more elastic. However, if exposed to fire, cables covered with PVC will produce HCl fumes and become a material that is hazardous to health.

India, officially known as the Republic of India (Hindi: भारत गणराज्य, Bhārat Gaṇarājya) is a federal, parliamentary system in the form of a constitutional republic in South Asia with a coastline of 7,000 km, and part of the Indian Subcontinent. The country shares borders with Afghanistan, Pakistan, China, Nepal, Bangladesh, Bhutan and Myanmar. Maldives, Sri Lanka and Indonesia are island nations that are next to each other. With the second largest population after China, which is more than one billion people, and is the seventh largest country based on the size of the geographical area. India's population has grown rapidly since the mid-1980s. India is part of an important and historic trade route. India's economy is the third largest in the world by gross domestic product, measured in terms of purchasing power parity, and one of the fastest growing economies in the world. India is a country with the largest liberal democratic system in the world and has a government. India has also emerged as an important regional power, has the largest military force, and has weapons of mass destruction. India is home to ancient civilizations such as the Indus River Valley Civilization, and is the birthplace of four of the world's major religions: Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, and Sikhism. The country was part of the United Kingdom before gaining independence in 1947. India was one of the first places to be settled by humans after migration from Africa. Humans arrived in India via the coasts along the Arabian Peninsula and the Persian Gulf. It is likely that the first group of people arrived in India around 50,000 BC. In the 3000s BC, the Harappans built Bronze Age cities on the Indus River (modern Pakistan). They did trade with West Asia. In the 2000s BC, the Harappa civilization collapsed.

It is not known exactly what caused this collapse. Not long after that, Indo-Europeans came from West Asia and Central Asia to India. They were also called Vedic or Aryan peoples, and brought with them their horses, chariots, and language. Their religion mixed with local religions to produce Hinduism. The caste system also began to emerge at this time. Around 800 BC, the Vedic peoples moved from the Indus Valley to conquer all of North India, including the Ganges valley. In 539 BC, the Persians, under Cyrus the Great, invaded northern India (modern Pakistan) and made it part of the Persian Empire. In 323 BC, Alexander the Great, while conquering the Persian Empire, also launched an invasion of India. After that came the powerful states in India. The first was the Mauryan Empire which was founded in 321 BC and collapsed in 184 BC. This was followed by a period of minor kingdoms until in 320 AD the Gupta Empire lasted until 550 AD. Other major kingdoms also appeared in southern India. Starting around 400 AD, waves of attacks from Central Asia and West Asia began to invade India. Initially, the Huns attacked, then, after the fall of the Guptas, the Muslims managed to capture northern India and establish the Delhi Sultanate. Around the 1200s and 1300s AD, the Mongols also made repeated attacks on India. All these conflicts took place mainly in northern India. Meanwhile in southern India, the local Indian kingdoms were relatively undisturbed. In northern India, Mongol power had disappeared before finally in 1526 AD the Mongol state was established called the Mughal Empire. In the 1700s AD, the Mughals weakened and split into small kingdoms. This triggered Great Britain to move and conquer India.

1.8808 Julian years 2.7% Nitrogen1.6% Argon0.2% Oxygen0.07% Carbon monoxide0.03% Water vapor0.01% Nitrogen monoxide2.5 ppm Neon300 ppb Krypton130 ppb Formaldehyde80 ppb Xenon30 ppb Ozone Mars is the fourth closest planet to the Sun . Its name is taken from the Roman god of war, Mars. This planet is often called the "red planet" because it looks reddish from a distance. This is due to the presence of iron(III) oxide on the surface of Mars. Mars is a rocky planet with a thin atmosphere. On the surface of Mars there are craters, volcanoes, valleys, deserts and ice caps. The rotational period and seasonal cycles of Mars are similar to Earth's. On Mars stand Olympus Mons, the highest mountain in the Solar System, and Valles Marineris, the largest valley in the Solar System. In addition, in the northern hemisphere there is the Borealis basin which covers 40% of the surface of Mars. Mars environment is more friendly for life than the state of the planet Venus. However, the situation is not quite ideal for humans. The air temperature is quite low and the air pressure is low, coupled with the composition of the air which is mostly carbon dioxide, causing humans to have to use breathing apparatus if they want to live there. Missions to this red planet, until the end of the 20th century, have not found traces of life there, even if it is very simple. This planet has 2 satellites, namely Fobos and Deimos. This planet orbits for 687 days around the Sun. This planet also rotates. The rotation period is 25.62 hours. On the planet Mars, there is a unique appearance in the Cydonia Mensae area. This appearance is a hill which when viewed from above appears as a human face. Many people have taken it as evidence of a long-lost civilization on Mars, although in recent times, it has been proven that the feature is just an ordinary feature.

Mars has a radius of about half that of Earth. This planet is less dense than Earth, and has only about 15% by volume and 11% by mass of Earth. Its surface area is less than the sum of the dry areas on Earth. Mars is larger than Mercury, but Mercury is denser. As a result the two planets have a nearly similar gravitational pull on the surface—and that of Mars is stronger by about less than 1%. The size, mass, and surface gravity of Mars is "between" Earth's and the Moon's (the Moon's diameter is only half that of Mars, while Earth's is twice that; Earth is nine times as massive as Mars, and the Moon is one-ninth). The reddish-orange appearance of the Martian surface is due to the presence of iron(III) oxide, which is better known as hematite. Based on orbital observations and examination of the Martian meteorite assemblage, the surface of Mars is composed of basalt. Some evidence suggests that parts of the Martian surface are richer in silica than ordinary basalt, and may be similar to Earth's andesitic rocks. Most of the surface of Mars is covered with iron(III) oxide dust, which gives it a red appearance. Currently Mars does not have a global magnetic field, but observations show that some of the planet's crust is magnetized, and a global magnetic field did exist in the past. One theory, announced in 1999 and re-examined in October 2005 (with the assistance of the Mars Global Surveyor) suggests that four billion years ago, Mars' dynamo stopped functioning and caused its magnetic field to disappear. There is also a theory that a very large asteroid once hit Mars and disabled its magnetic field. The core of Mars, whose radius is estimated at 1,480 km, is composed of iron and 14–17% sulfur. This iron sulfide core is liquid.

– in Europe  (green & dark gray)– in the European Union    (green)  –  legend] Finland (officially: Republic of Finland, Finnish: Suomen Tasavalta; B. Sweden: Republiken Finland), is a Nordic country located in Northern Europe, as well as a member of the European Union. Finland has land borders with Sweden to the west, Norway to the north, and Russia to the east while its maritime boundaries are the Baltic Sea to the southwest, the Gulf of Finland to the south, and the Gulf of Bothnia to the west. Finland is part of the geographic area of ​​Fennoscandia, which also includes Scandinavia and parts of Russia. Finland is the 1st happiest country in the world. As of 2013, Finland's population has reached 5.5 million, and the majority live in the south. In terms of area, this country has the eighth largest area in Europe and the country that has the lowest population density in the European Union. Finland is a parliamentary republic with a central government in the capital Helsinki, with local governments in 317 municipalities, and the autonomous region of the Åland Islands. More than 1.4 million people live in the Greater Helsinki region, which produces a third of the country's gross domestic product. Other major cities include Tampere, Turku, Oulu, Jyväskylä, Lahti and Kuopio. From the late 12th century to 1809, Finland was part of Sweden, whose influence is still felt today with Swedish being widely spoken and one of the official languages. Later, it was included in the Russian Empire as the Grand Duchy of Finland until the Russian Revolution of 1917 resulted in the Finnish Declaration of Independence. This was followed by the Finnish Civil War in which the pro-Bolshevik Finnish Socialist Workers' Republic was defeated by the pro-conservative Whites with assistance from the German Empire.

After a while of trying to form an empire, the country became a republic. During World War II, the Finnish armed forces fought three conflicts including the Winter War (1939–1940) and Continuation War (1941–1944) against the Soviet Union, and the Lapland War against Nazi Germany. Finland joined the United Nations in 1955 and established itself as a neutral country. Finland also joined the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in 1969, the European Union in 1995, and the Eurozone in 1999. Finland is a relatively new industrial country, this country still depended on the agricultural sector until the 1950s. The economy began to develop when it developed the nordic model of the welfare state, which resulted in prosperity and is currently one of the countries with the highest per capita incomes in the world. Finland topped the list in areas such as education, economic competitiveness, civil liberties, quality of life and human development. The country has a long history of progressivism. In 1906, Finland became the second country in the world to give all citizens full voting rights. About 73.9% of Finns are members of the Finnish Evangelical Lutheran Church (2014), but the Lutheran Church estimates that only 2% of its members go to church weekly. A document legalizing same-sex marriage was approved by parliament on 12 December 2014, which was signed by the president on 20 February 2015. In 2010, Newsweek voted Finland the best country in the world. Finland also ranks first in the May 2015 World Human Index. The origin of the name Finland (Suomi in Finnish) is unclear but is most likely derived from the proto-Baltic language zeme meaning "land". According to an earlier theory the name is derived from suomaa or suoniemi.

Curling is the sport of launching stones over the surface of ice to reach the target area. This sport has officially become an Olympic sport since 1998. Curling is still related to bowling, boules and shuffleboard. Two teams, each consisting of 4 players, take turns launching granite stones towards a target area called the house. The target area (house) is on opposite sides of the track, and is marked with red and blue circles. The playing field is called a sheet, in the form of a rectangular track that has a smooth, ice-covered surface. The granite stone that is played is granite that has been polished, so that it can be launched on the surface of ice by being pushed. Stones are given different colors to distinguish their own stones from the opponent's stones. One team gets 8 stones for one round (end). The aim of the game is to collect as many numbers as possible. Points are earned by the team that has the closest stone to the center of the house at the end of each round (when all the stones have been launched). In an effort to dominate the house with one's own stone, the opponent's stone may be hit so that it is pushed out of the house. When the stone has been released by a teammate, two players carrying a brush (broom) are tasked with directing the stone towards the target by rubbing the brush in front of the path the stone will pass. The surface of the ice when brushed will make the stone slide further or slightly change the direction of the stone. This game requires a mature strategy, played in turns at a relaxed tempo, so it's like chess and baseball. The game of curling is thought to have been invented in the late Middle Ages in Scotland. The first written record of playing stones on ice is a document belonging to Paisley Abbey in Renfrewshire from February 1541.

Two paintings by Pieter Bruegel Senior ("Hunters in the Snow" and "Winter Landscape with a Bird Trap", both from 1565) depict Dutch sharecroppers playing curling. During this time, Scotland and the Low Countries already had strong trade and cultural links, as is also evident in the history of golf. The game of curling existed in Scotland in the early 16th century, based on the discovery of evidence of a curling stone inscribed with the year 1511 (found along with another stone written with the year 1551) in an old drained pool in Dunblane, Scotland. The Kilsyth Curling Club claims to be the world's first curling club. The club, which was officially founded in 1716, still exists today. The town of Kilsyth also boasts a pool at Colzium that was built specifically for curling. A low dam was built to create a shallow pool measuring 100 × 250 meters, although these are rarely used for curling nowadays due to the warm winters. The word curling first appears in print from Perth Scotland in 1620. It is found in the preface and lines of a poem by Henry Adamson. The game of curling is still now called the "rumbling game" (and still is, in Scotland and Scotland-settled areas such as southern New Zealand) also known as the "rumbling game" (the roaring game) because of the roaring sound of stones sliding over the surface slippery ice. The verbal noun curling comes from the Scottish verb curl (and English; Indonesian: to curl, to roll) which describes the circular motion of a stone. At first, people played curling using large stones taken from the riverbed.

Lipids are a group of naturally occurring molecules that include fats, waxes, sterols, fat-soluble vitamins (such as vitamins A, D, E, and K), monoglycerides, diglycerides, triglycerides, phospholipids, and others. The main biological functions of lipids are to store energy, play a role in signaling, and act as a building component of cell membranes. Lipids are used in the cosmetic and food industries as well as in nanotechnology. Lipids can be broadly defined as hydrophobic or amphiphilic small molecules; The amphiphilic nature of some lipids allows them to form structures such as vesicles, multilamellar/unilamellar liposomes, or membranes in aquatic environments. Biological lipids are derived, wholly or in part, from two distinct types of biochemical subunits or "building-blocks", namely ketoacyl and isoprene groups. Using this approach, lipids can be divided into eight categories: fatty acids, glycerolipids, glycerophospholipids, sphingolipids, saccharolipids, and polyketides (derived from the condensation of ketoacyl subunits); and sterol lipids and prenol lipids (derived from condensation of isoprene subunits). Although the term lipid is sometimes used as a synonym for fat, it is a subgroup of lipids called triglycerides. Lipids also include molecules such as fatty acids and their derivatives (including tri-, di-, monoglycerides, and phospholipids), as well as other sterol-containing metabolites such as cholesterol. Although humans and other mammals use various biosynthetic pathways to break down and synthesize lipids, some essential lipids cannot be made in this way and must be obtained from the diet. Fatty acids (or fatty acid residues when they are part of a lipid) are groups of molecules synthesized by chain elongation of an acetyl-CoA primary with a malonyl-CoA or methylmalonyl-CoA group in a process called fatty acid synthesis. They are formed from a hydrocarbon chain terminated by a carboxylic acid group; This arrangement gives the fatty acid molecule a polar, hydrophilic end and a nonpolar, water-insoluble hydrophobic end.

The fatty acid structure is one of the most fundamental groupings of biological lipids, and is widely used as a building block for most of the more complex lipids. The carbon chains, usually between four and 24 carbons in length, can be either saturated or unsaturated, and can be bonded to functional groups containing oxygen, halogens, nitrogen, and sulfur. If a fatty acid contains double bonds, it is possible that it has cis or trans geometric isomers, which significantly affect the configuration of the molecule. The cis- double bond causes the fatty acid chain to bend and results in the multiplication of the double bonds in the carbon chain. The three double bonds in linolenic acid (C-18), the most abundant acyl fatty chain in the thylakoid membrane, makes this membrane very "fluid" even at low ambient temperatures. This also makes linolenic acid display sharp peaks in the chloroplast spectrum when viewed with high-resolution C-13 NMR. This in turn plays an important role in the structure and function of the cell membrane. Most naturally occurring fatty acids have a cis configuration, although trans forms exist in some natural or partially hydrogenated fats and oils. Examples of biologically important fatty acids are the eicosanoid group, which are mainly derived from arachidonic acid and eicosapentaenoic acid, which include prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and thromboxane. Docosahexanoic acid is also important in biological systems, especially those related to vision. The other major classes in the fatty acid category are fatty esters and fatty amides. Fatty esters include important biochemical intermediates such as wax esters, coenzyme A thioester fatty acid derivatives, ACP thioester fatty acid derivatives, and carnitine fatty acid. Fat amides include N-acylethanolamine compounds, such as the nerve-conducting cannabinoid anandamide.

Keris is a stabbing weapon of the dagger class originating from Java which has a variety of cultural functions known in the western and central parts of the archipelago. The shape is distinctive and easy to distinguish from other sharp weapons because it is asymmetrical at the base which is widened, often the blade is winding, and many of them have damascene, that is, you can see the bright metal coating fibers on the blades. In the past, keris served as a weapon in duels or wars, as well as a complementary object for offerings. In present-day use, kerises are more of an accessory object (ageman) in clothing, have a number of cultural symbols, or become a collection item that is valued from an aesthetic point of view. The keris has been registered and recognized by UNESCO as a World Cultural Heritage Intangible Human originating from Indonesia since 2005. The origins of the keris have not been fully explained because there are no written sources that are descriptive about it from before the 15th century, even though the mention of the term "keris" has been listed on inscriptions from the 9th century AD. However, it is thought that the origin of the mention of the word "keris" is a Javanese abbreviation of "Mlungker-mlungker kang bisa ngiris", in Javanese means "(the words sinengker, karana, and aris). Sinengker or sengkeran has the meaning of confinement, karaname has the meaning of running, and aris means without suloyo." Scientific studies on the development of keris shapes are mostly based on analysis of figures in temple reliefs or statues. Meanwhile, knowledge about the function of the keris can be traced from several inscriptions and reports from foreign explorers to the archipelago. One relief panel of Borobudur Temple (9th century) showing a person holding a keris-like object but has no degree of inclination and the upstream/deder is still attached to the blade. From the same century, the Karangtengah inscription in Temanggung, Central Java, dated 824 AD mentions the term "keris" in a list of tools.

The Poh inscription (904 AD) mentions "keris" as part of the offerings that need to be offered. However, it is not known whether the "keris" refers to the object as it is known today. Most scientific studies on the development of keris forms are based on analysis of figures in temple reliefs or statues. Meanwhile, knowledge about the function of the keris can be traced from several inscriptions and reports from foreign explorers to the archipelago. Sharp weapons with shapes that are thought to be the source of inspiration for keris making can be found in heritage relics from the Dongson Culture and southern China. It is possible that the influence of Ancient Chinese culture in the use of stabbing weapons, as the forerunner of the keris, entered through the Dongson (Vietnamese) culture, which was a "bridge" for the entry of Chinese cultural influence into the archipelago. A number of modern kerises for offering purposes have human-shaped hilts (not stylized as modern kerises), the same as a Dongson dagger, and are integrated with the blade. From the 15th century, one of the reliefs at Sukuh Temple, a place of worship from the late Majapahit period, clearly shows a master making a keris. The relief on the left depicts Bhima as the personification of a master forging iron, Ganesh in the center, and Arjuna pumping an air blower for a kiln. The wall behind the master displays various forged metal objects, including a dagger. ... . These people of Majapahit] always wore a pu-la-t'ou (dagger? or dagger? ) tucked into their belts. ...], which was made of steel, with intricate patterns and fine lines on the leaves; the hilt is made of gold, horn or ivory which is carved in the form of a human or a giant's face with a very fine and diligent workmanship. — Ma Huan, "Ying-yai Sheng-lan Fai" Notes of Ma Huan from 1416, a member of Cheng Ho's expedition, in "Ying-yai Sheng-lan" mentions that the Majapahit people always wore (pu-la-t'ou ) tucked into the belt. Regarding the word Pu-la-t'ou, even though it is only based on the sound resemblance, many argue that what is meant is "dagger", and because a keris is a stabbing weapon like a dagger it is considered pu-la-t 'ou describes the dagger.

Rammstein (pronounced ˈʀamʃtaɪ̯n]) is a German musical group Neue Deutsche Härte, formed in Berlin, Rammstein is well known for its NDH-scene music, much like Oomph! and Die Krupps. Their flow of music is often called Tanz-Metal (lit. "Dance Metal"). Formed in 1994, they have sold 22 million records worldwide. The name Rammstein is taken indirectly from a small town in West Germany, namely Ramstein, a city where there is a United States military base, and in that city there was also an accident at the Western Bloc aerospace exhibition in 1988. One of their songs is entitled "Rammstein", actually more intended to commemorate the tragic event rather than being a song about the band itself. Although the songs they perform are not in English, the band is quite popular outside Germany, and has a strong fan base in Western Europe, Russia, North America, Central, and Australia. And with the release of the album "Reise, Reise" in 2004, they became the most phenomenal German band in the international music scene. Their songs also always rank in the top ten in Germany. All members of the band are from East Germany, particularly East Berlin and Schwerin. They are: Riedel, Schneider and Kruspe were the first three people to form this Rammstein band, which was originally joined by a West German band called Orgasm Death Gimmicks with a musical style that was very identical to, or imitated, the American style of music. Kruspe once said, "I realized it's really important to make music and make it fit with your language, which I didn't do in the past. I came back to Germany] and said, 'It's time to make music that's really authentic. '

I was starting a project called Rammstein to really try to make German music." He also invited Till Lindemann, a drummer from the East German band, First Arsch, to join the Rammstein project, as a vocalist. at that time, and they won the contest and as it turned out, caught the attention of Paul Landers, who would later join the project Rammstein "Flake" Lorenz was the last member to join the band; he had previously played with Landers in the band Feeling B, an East German band that was well known to the Soviet Union at that time.At first, he was reluctant to join this new band project, but after several invitations, he finally agreed to join Rammstein.Their first album, Herzeleid, was released a year after the formation of their band.Rammstein was founded by guitarist Richard Z. Kruspe.In 1989, he me fled to West Berlin and started a band, Orgasm Death Gimmicks. At that time, he was heavily influenced by American music, especially Kiss. After the Berlin Wall fell, he moved back to Schwerin where Till Lindemann worked as a basket weaver and played drums for the band First Arsch (often called "Apex Ass"). At the time, Richard was living with Oliver Riedel, of the band Inchtabokatables, and Christoph "Doom" Schneider (of Die Firma). Richard realized that the music he had previously created was not quite what he wanted it to be. He created something by combining the sound of a machine and the sound of a distorted guitar. Eventually the three men started working together on a new project. Richard found it difficult to write lyrics and music simultaneously.

In physics, acceleration or acceleration is the change in velocity in a given unit of time. The acceleration of an object is caused by a force acting on the object, as explained in Newton's second law. The SI unit for acceleration is meters per second squared (m s−2). Acceleration is a vector quantity, so it has both magnitude and direction. As a vector, the total force is equal to the product of the object's mass (a scalar quantity) and its acceleration. Generally, acceleration is seen as the movement of an object getting faster or slower. In other words, an object that is turning (for example a car that is turning a corner) also has acceleration too. Average acceleration is the ratio of the object's change in velocity (Δv){\displaystyle (\Delta \mathbf {v} )} to the time it takes for it to reach a change in velocity (Δt){\displaystyle (\Delta t)}. the speed changed. Mathematically, the average acceleration is formulated: Instantaneous acceleration, is the limit of the average acceleration per very small time interval. In calculus, instantaneous acceleration is the vector derivative of velocity with respect to time: (Here and everywhere, if motion is in a straight line, the vector quantity can be substituted by a scalar in the equation.) It can be seen that the integral of the acceleration function a(t) is the velocity function v(t) ) ; where the area under the acceleration vs. time curve (a vs. t) equals velocity. Since acceleration is defined as the derivative of velocity v with respect to time t and velocity is defined as the derivative of position x with respect to time, acceleration is the second derivative of x with respect to t: a=dvdt =d2xdt2{\displaystyle \mathbf {a} ={\frac {d\mathbf {v} }{dt}}={\frac {d^{2}\mathbf {x} }{dt^{2}}} } In classical mechanics, the acceleration of an object with a fixed mass is directly proportional to the resultant force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass. F=ma→a=F/m{\displaystyle \mathbf {F} =m\mathbf {a} \quad \to \quad \mathbf {a} =\mathbf {F} /m} where F is the acting force on the object, m is the mass of the object, and a is the acceleration of the object's center of mass.

Cadmium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Cd and atomic number 48. This soft, bluish-white metal is chemically similar to the other two stable metals in group 12, zinc and mercury. Like zinc, Cd prefers the +2 oxidation state in most compounds and, like mercury, it exhibits a low melting point compared to most transition metals. Cadmium and its congeners have not always been considered transition metals, as they do not have partially or completely filled d or f electron shells, either in their elemental form or in their common oxidation state. The average concentration of cadmium in the Earth's crust is between 0.1 and 0.5 parts per million (ppm). Cd was discovered in 1817 simultaneously by Stromeyer and Karl Samuel Leberecht Hermann, both in Germany, as an impurity in zinc carbonate. Cadmium occurs as a minor component in most zinc ores and is therefore a by-product of zinc production. Cadmium has long been used as a corrosion-resistant coating on steel, while cadmium compounds are used as red, orange and yellow pigments, to color glass and to stabilize plastics. The use of cadmium has generally declined because of its toxicity. (This is specifically listed in the European Restrictions on Hazardous Substances) and replacement of nickel-cadmium batteries with nickel-metal hydride and lithium ion batteries. One of its few new uses is cadmium telluride solar panels. Although cadmium is not known to have a biological function in higher organisms, cadmium-dependent carbonic anhydrase has been found in marine diatoms. Cadmium is a bivalent metal that is soft, malleable, elastic, and bluish-white in color.

It is similar in many ways to zinc except for the formation of complexes. Unlike most other metals, cadmium is resistant to corrosion, which is why it is used as a protective coating when deposited on other metals. In bulk metal form, cadmium is insoluble in water and non-flammable; however, in its powdered form, it can burn and release toxic fumes. Although cadmium usually has a +2 oxidation state, it is also present with a +1 oxidation state. Cadmium and its congeners are not always considered transition metals, as they do not have partially or completely filled d or f electron shells, either in their elemental form or in their common oxidation state. Cadmium burns in air to form cadmium oxide (CdO) which is amorphous and brown in color; the crystals that form from this compound are a deep red color that changes color when heated, much like zinc oxide. Hydrochloric, sulfuric and nitric acids dissolve cadmium to form cadmium chloride (CdCl2), cadmium sulfate (CdSO4), or cadmium nitrate (Cd(NO3)2). The +1 oxidation state can be obtained by dissolving cadmium in a mixture of cadmium chloride and aluminum chloride, forming the Cd2+2 cation, much like the Hg2+2 cation in mercury(I) chloride. Most of the structures of cadmium complexes with nucleobases, amino acids and vitamins have been determined. Naturally occurring cadmium consists of 8 isotopes. Two of them are radioactive, and three of them are thought to be decaying but this has not been confirmed experimentally. The two naturally occurring radioactive isotopes are 113Cd (beta decay, with a half-life of 7.7 × 1015 years) and 116Cd (two double beta decay neutrinos, with a half-life of 2.9 × 1019 years). The other three are 106Cd, 108Cd (both electron capture doubles), and 114Cd (double beta decay); only a lower limit on their half-lives has been set.

Thermochemistry is a branch of chemistry that studies the energy that accompanies physical changes or chemical reactions. The main goal of thermochemistry is the establishment of criteria for determining the likelihood or spontaneity of the required transformation. In this way, thermochemistry is used to predict the energy changes that occur in chemical reactions, phase changes, and solution formation. Most properties in thermochemistry develop from the application of the I law of thermodynamics, the law of the 'conservation' of energy, to functions of internal energy, enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy. Energy is the ability to do work. Every object has energy. Energy possessed by objects can be divided into kinetic energy and potential energy. Kinetic energy is the energy possessed by moving objects. Examples of energy in the wind, waterfalls, and rotating fans. Potential energy is the energy that an object has due to its state or position. Examples are gravitational potential energy and springs. Heat is energy that is transferred from one object to another due to a temperature difference. The unit for heat is the same as the unit for energy, namely the Joule. Sometimes the units used are calories or kilocalories. The heat of reaction is the heat that accompanies a chemical reaction. The system is everything that is the center of attention. The system is the part whose energy changes are being observed. For example, in observing the process of dissolving table salt in water, table salt and water are a system. The environment is part outside the system. For example, in the process of dissolving table salt, apart from table salt and water, it is the environment, for example the air around it. The system is divided into three, namely: Thermochemical reactions can be divided into exothermic reactions and endothermic reactions. The difference between the two reactions can be seen in the following table.

Enthalpy is the chemical energy contained in a system. The enthalpy of a system cannot be measured, what can be measured is the enthalpy change (ΔH) that accompanies the change in the system. Enthalpy is also defined as the amount of heat in a substance. Enthalpy change is the heat change that occurs in a chemical reaction. ΔH = HP - HR Note: ΔH = enthalpy change HP = enthalpy of products HR = enthalpy of reactants The thermochemical equation is a chemical equation that is completed with the price of the enthalpy change. Example of a thermochemical equation: The standard enthalpy of formation is the heat absorbed or released in the formation of one mole of a substance from its elements measured at a temperature of 250C and a pressure of 1 atm. Example: C(S) + O2(g) → CO2(g) ∆Hfo = -393.5 kJ. The standard enthalpy of decomposition is the heat absorbed or released in the breakdown of one mole of a substance into its elements. Example: H2O(l) → H2(g) + 1/2 O2(g) ∆Hdo = +285.8 kJ. The standard enthalpy of combustion is the heat released when 1 mol of substance is burned (reaction with oxygen) measured at 250C and 1 atm pressure. Example: CH4(g) + 2 O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2 H2O(g) ∆Hco = -802 kJ. The enthalpy of neutralization is the heat released in the formation of 1 mole of water and an acid-base reaction at 250C and 1 atmosphere pressure. The enthalpy of dissolution is the heat released or absorbed in the dissolution of one mole of a substance. NaCl(s) → Na+(aq) + Cl-(aq) ΔHs0 = 4 kJ Thermochemical activation is part of the stain development process in thin layer chromatography. Stains will glow where exposed to ultraviolet light when heated to high temperatures. Solution reactions can be detected by separating the silica gel with aminopropyl bonds.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Ethnobiology is the interdisciplinary scientific study of how other living things are treated or used in various human cultures. This field studies the dynamic relationship between humans, biota and the environment, from the distant past to the present. "Human-biota-environment" interactions around the world are documented and studied over time, across cultures, and across disciplines in search of reliable answers to two 'important' questions: "How do humans use nature?" and "How do humans use nature?" human society views nature?” Ethnobiology is a small, coherent, and more specific field that has developed from studies in ethnobotany and ethnozoology. But its scientific spectrum spans a wide range of approaches, from the careful study of culture and linguistics to the rigorous study of biology. At the linguistic end of the spectrum, studies focus on semantics: vocabulary, linguistic concepts, meaning and symbols, and art and religion. The middle spectrum, where anthropology and biology converge, is the study of how people actually think about the use and management of plants: ethnomedical, food production and consumption, and ethnoecology. Further into biology, but still taking an anthropological approach, is the field of archeology; archeozoology and archeobotany, which reconstruct past life from biotic data. The study of Ethnobiology received its first official definition from the American ethnobotanist Edward F. Castetter in 1944, where he described Ethnobiology as "...the use of plant and animal life by primitive peoples..." its aim was to establish integration between the two scientifically based ethnoscience studies of biology, ethnobotany and ethnozoology. Both studies have begun anonymously on the ancient civilizations of Asia and the Mediterranean Basin, they are accounts of the observations of "different" cultures, from urban cultures, by explorers, traders, and government officials.

Some of the early ones were in Egypt, China, and India, especially in plant and animal medicines and foods. When European societies began to colonize in the early 15th to 19th centuries, they brought with them biological scientists who were increasingly interested in the local biological wisdom of the people in the colonized areas. The local biological wisdom, collected and sampled during these early centuries significantly informed the early development of modern biology, including: visited by western scientists. As a practice, she supports other activities when documenting local people's language, folklore, and natural resource use. The 'first stage' in the development of ethnobiology as a practice still has an essential use objective, often focusing on identifying 'native' plants, animals and technologies of some potential use and value in increasingly dominant western economic systems. Following the course of Phase I, beginning the 'second stage' in the development of 'ethnobiology', researchers began seeking to better document and better understand how alien societies "conceptualized and categorized" the natural world around them. This 'second' phase was marked by the publication of several scholarly works: At the turn of the 21st century, ethnobiological practice, research, and findings had a significant impact and influence in a number of fields of biological inquiry including ecology, conservation biology, development studies, and political ecology. Ethnobiology has emerged from its place as an auxiliary practice under the shadow of other core pursuits, emerging as a whole field of inquiry and research in its own right: it is taught in many tertiary institutions and educational programs around the world; with its own method manual, its own readers, and its own textbooks.

Phonons are vibrational waves in crystals like light waves. Atomic vibrations in crystals are not so numerous at low temperatures, atomic vibration waves must be viewed as phonons, so that the results of measurements of changes in heat capacity with temperature at low temperatures can be explained. Microscopically, heat conduction in solids can only be explained by collisions between phonons and other phonons. A phonon in physics is a quantum vibrational mode of a rigid crystal lattice, such as a crystal lattice in a solid. Crystals can be formed from solution, vapor, melt or a combination of the three. Crystal formation is strongly influenced by the rate of nucleation and growth. If the growth is slow, the crystals formed will be quite large, accompanied by regular arrangement of atoms or molecules repeated so that the potential energy is minimum. Solid state physics is closely related to crystals and the electrons in them. Solid state physics experienced rapid development after the discovery of X-rays and success in modeling the arrangement of atoms in crystals. Atoms or molecules can form a crystal lattice through attractive forces (coulomb forces). The lattice is arranged periodically to form crystals. The atoms that make up a solid vibrate against their equilibrium position so that the crystal lattice also vibrates. Phenomena that arise from the quantization of solid-state physics systems but have different energies with longer wavelengths than electromagnetic waves are called phonons. The quantum energy of a moving vibration in an elastic wave field is analogous to that of a photon in an electromagnetic wave. Pakistan (/pækstæn/ ( listen) or /pɑːkiˈstɑːn/ ( listen); Urdu: پاکِستان) (Urdu pronunciation: paːkɪˈst̪aːn] ( listen)), officially the Islamic Republic of Pakistan (Urdu: اسلامی جمہوریۂ پاکِستان) is a country in South Asia. It has a 1,046-kilometre (650 mi) coastline with the Arabian Sea and Gulf of Oman to the south, bordered by Afghanistan and Iran to the west, India to the east and China to the northeast. Tajikistan is located very close to Pakistan, but is bounded by a narrow landmass called the Wakhan Corridor. Pakistan is strategically located between the important regions of South Asia, Central Asia and the Middle East. The name Pakistan means pure land in both Urdu and Persian. This name was coined as Pakistan by Choudhary Rahmat Ali, a Pakistani movement figure who published a pamphlet entitled Now or Never. This name is also a portmanteau of the main ethnic names found in Pakistan, namely: Punjab, Afgan, KashmIr, Sindh, and Baluchistan. In the past, the territory of present-day Pakistan was the site of ancient cultures such as the Neolithic culture, Mehrgarh and the Indus River Valley Civilization. And is part of the history of the Vedas, Persians, Indo-Greek, Islamic civilization, Turkic-Mongol dynasties and Sikh culture through various invasions. As a result, this place has the legacy of various dynasties such as the Persian dynasty, the Umayyad caliph, the Mauryan empire, the Mongol empire, the Mughal empire, the Sikh empire, and (lastly) British imperialism. Pakistan gained its independence from British imperialism in 1947 after the independence movement led by Mohammad Ali Jinnah who wanted an independent state from the western and eastern parts of the British Empire which were dominated by Islam. After adopting a new constitution in 1956, Pakistan officially became an Islamic Republic.

In 1971, a civil war occurred in the state of East Pakistan which eventually made the state split into a new country called Bangladesh. Pakistan's geography and climate is extremely diverse, and it is home to a wide variety of wildlife. Pakistan has an area of ​​796,095 km2 (307,374 sq mi), about the same area as France and England combined. Pakistan is the 36th largest country in the world. Pakistan has a 1,046 km (650 mi) coastline along the Arabian Sea and the Gulf of Oman and a land border of 6,774 km (4,209 mi) in total: 2,430 km (1,510 mi) with Afghanistan, 523 km (325 mi) with China, 2,912 km (1,809 mi) with India and 909 km (565 mi) with Iran. And has a sea border with Oman. Mount K2, the second highest mountain in the world after Mount Everest, is the highest mountain in the country. The mountain which has a height of 8611 meters is located in the Karakoram mountain range which is located in the north of Pakistan which borders China. Pakistan occupies an important geopolitical location at the crossroads of South Asia, the Middle East and Central Asia. Pakistan is a federal state with a parliamentary system consisting of 4 provinces and 4 federal regions. With a population of more than 170 million people, Pakistan is one of the most populous countries in the world and has the largest Muslim population in the world after Indonesia. Pakistan is also a multi-ethnic and geographically diverse country. In the post-independence period, Pakistan's government experienced instability and conflict with its closest neighbour, India. This country has various challenges and problems, such as poverty, illiteracy, corruption and terrorist attacks. The United States Census Bureau estimated Pakistan's population at 199,085,847 (199,100,000) in 2015, which is equivalent to 2.57% of the world's population.

Gas is one of the four basic states of matter (the others are solid, liquid and plasma). Pure gases can be composed of atoms (for example noble gases such as neon), molecular elements composed of one type of atom (eg oxygen), or compound molecules composed of many different types of atoms (eg carbon dioxide). The gas mixture will contain a variety of pure gases such as air. What distinguishes gases from liquids and solids is the separation of the very large gas particles. This separation usually makes the colorless gas invisible to human observation. The interaction of gas particles in the presence of electric and gravitational fields can be neglected as shown by the constant velocity vector in the figure. One type of gas that is commonly known is steam. Gaseous matter is found between the liquid and plasma states, note 1] the latter provides an upper temperature limit for gases. The lower limit of the temperature scale lies degenerative quantum gases note 2] which are receiving increasing attention. note 3] High density atomic gases that are supercooled at very low temperatures are classified according to their statistical behavior as either Bose gases or Fermi gases. For a complete list of the forms of this exotic matter see list of states of matter. The only chemical elements that make up the diatomic homonuclear molecule at STP are hydrogen (H2), nitrogen (N2), oxygen (O2), and two halogens: fluorine (F2) and chlorine (Cl2). When grouped together with the monatomic noble gases – helium (He), neon (Ne), argon (Ar), krypton (Kr), xenon (Xe), and radon (Rn) – these gases are referred to as "elemental gases." " or "elemental gases". Alternatively, they are sometimes known as "molecular gases" to distinguish them from molecules which are also chemical compounds. The term gas was first used in the early 17th century by the Flemish chemist J.B. van Helmont.note 4] Van Helmont's term appears to simplify the phonetic transcription of the ancient Greek term χάος Khaos – the Dutch g is pronounced like kh in "end" – in this case Van Helmont is simply following an established alchemical usage first attested in the work of Paracelsus .

According to Paracelsus' terminology, chaos meant something like "ultra-scarce water". Another story is that van Helmont's words are truncated from gahst (or geist), which means ghost or spirit. This is because certain gases depict a supernatural origin, such as from their ability to cause death, extinguish fires, and occur in "mines, well bottoms, churchyards and other deserted places". Because most gases are difficult to observe directly, they are described by four physical properties or macroscopic characteristics: pressure, volume, number of particles (chemists classify them by moles) and temperature. These four characteristics have been repeatedly observed by scientists such as Robert Boyle, Jacques Charles, John Dalton, Joseph Gay-Lussac and Amedeo Avogadro for various gases in various situations. Their detailed studies eventually yielded a mathematical relationship between these properties which is expressed by means of the ideal gas law (see simplified models section below). Gas particles are separated far from each other and, as a result, have weaker intermolecular bonds than liquids or solids. These intermolecular forces result from electrostatic interactions between gas particles. The similarly charged gas regions with different gas particles repel each other, while the differently charged regions attract one another; gas containing permanently charged ions is known as plasma. Gaseous compounds with polar covalent bonds contain a permanent charge imbalance and thus experience relatively strong intermolecular forces, even though the net charge of the compound remains neutral. Meanwhile, randomly induced charges are present in non-polar covalently bonded molecules and the electrostatic interactions caused by them are referred to as Van der Waals forces. The interaction of these intermolecular forces varies within the substance which determines many of the physical properties unique to each gas.note 5]note 6] A comparison of the boiling points for compounds formed by ionic and covalent bonds leads us to this conclusion.

Albigensis (Per. )Hussite (Boh. )Lollard (Ing. )Waldensis (Per./Ita./Jer.) Anabaptist Anglicanism (English)Calvinism (Switzerland)Lutheranism (Jer. )Reformed Socinianism (Pol. )Zwinglianism (Swiss. ) Amish (Ame. )Baptist (Ing. )Congregational Mennonite (Bel./Swi./Ame./Kan. )Methodism (Ing. )Pietism Presbyterianism (Scot./Ame. )Puritanism (Ing. )Evangelical Universalism Pentecostal Revivalism Movement Protestant Adventist Restoration (in Indonesia known as Protestantism) is a denomination in Islam that worships God which refers to the Protestant reform movement by Martin Luther in 1517 with 95 of his postulates. Protestant etymology itself comes from Latin, namely: "Pro Testanum", (English: "Pro Testament"). "Pro" means: to take sides, vote for or against. While "Testanum" means: Covenant. These are 2 words that refer to the Old Testament and the New Testament in the Bible. This word is defined as a Christian Reformed/Christian/follower of Christ/Jesus movement that begins a return based on the faith and practice of Christianity based on the beginnings of the Bible, originating from the encouragement of the Protestant Reformation in doctrinal, political and ecclesiological terms, against what are perceived as abuses of the Church Roman Catholics at the time. This is one of the three main affirmations of "Nicene Christianity", that is, alongside the Roman Catholic Church and the Orthodox Church. The term "Protestant" also refers to the "Protestant Reformation letter" submitted by dignitaries who supported Martin Luther's statement, against the Diet Speyer decision in 1529 which upheld the Diet of Worms decision (edict) which condemned Martin Luther's teachings as heretical (heretic). And the Pro-Testan Reformation movement carried out by Martin Luther is not the first time it has occurred in the Catholic Church, because previously there had been similar movements like what happened in :- France led by Peter Waldo (and now his followers are members of the Church Waldensis) in the mid-12th century;- Bohemia (now including Czech) under Jan Hus (1369-1415), followers of John Hus in Bohemia later joined the Calvinist Church. and- Countries with large numbers of immigrants from Italy, such as Uruguay.

In 2005, around 5.9%–14,276,459 people out of 241,973,879 people in Indonesia followed the teachings of Protestantism and the 2010 census was around 6.96% - 16,528,513 people. Because most missionaries to Indonesia came from the Netherlands and Germany, most Protestant Christian churches in Indonesia are heavily colored by Calvinist and Lutheran colors. Number of Protestant Christians Based on Population Census by province (June 2022): Although the doctrines of Protestant denominations are far from uniform, there are several beliefs that are spread in Protestantism, namely the doctrines of sola gratia, sola fide, and sola scriptura. Protestant churches generally reject Catholic and Orthodox doctrines regarding apostolic inheritance and sacramental ministry of the clergy. The exception is found in many countries, such as in southern Europe, which were under non-Catholic influence long before the Reformation. Protestant pastors and church leaders have slightly different roles and authority within their communities than Catholic, Anglican and Orthodox pastors and bishops. Followers of the Protestant movement refer to the grouping of churches according to their basic doctrines as "denominations". They are the names of the different parts of a single "Church". Protestants reject the doctrine of the Roman Catholic Church as the only true church. Some Christian denominations are more strict than others and there are conflicting grounds of orthodoxy between them. Individual denominations also emerge according to theological differences which are sometimes very subtle. There are also many denominations which are simply regional or ethnic expressions of the same belief, which recognize the five solas as the main basic principles of the Christian faith. Non-denominational groups are also included in the Protestant group. Due to all these factors, an exact count is not possible, but it is estimated that there are about 33,000 Protestant denominations.

Olive (Olea europaea) is a small annual and evergreen tree whose young fruit can be eaten raw or preserved as a refreshment. The old fruit is squeezed and the oil is extracted into olive oil which can be used for various purposes. Olives are members of the Oleaceae tribe. Olive plants have the following characteristics: Olives begin to bear fruit when they are five years old and can reach thousands of years old, so that what was once a shrub has become a large tree. Olive trees that are thousands of years old have been found in Palestine which have lived up to 2000 years. Olives are harvested when they are still green until they are purple. Canned black olives may contain chemicals (usually ferrous sulfate) that artificially turn them black. Olea europaea seeds are usually called pit or rock in English in America, while in England they all mean "stone". Its distribution includes areas with hot climates to temperate climates. Most of the species can be found in Asia, Africa and the Mediterranean region. The Pisciottana variety, which consists of 40,000 trees found only in the area around Pisciotta, Campania, in the south of Italy, is taller than the average olive elsewhere, and has a larger trunk in diameter. This plant is still related to jasmine (Jasminum sambac). Six natural subspecies of Olea europaea are known which are spread over a wide area: Subspecies maroccana is hexaploid while cerasiformis is tetraploid. The wild plant form is often considered a separate species with the scientific name Olea oleaster. The olive sprig with leaves is often used as a symbol of peace and has long been a part of Western culture. In this society the olive branch is a symbol of peace and has been planted hundreds of years ago for its delicious fruit.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Lithuania, officially the Republic of Lithuania (Lithuanian: Lietuvos Respublika, Lietuva) is a country in Northern Europe.
