Lithuania is one of the three Baltic States that are close to the Baltic Sea. The country is bordered by Latvia to the north, Belarus to the southeast, Poland to the south, and Russia's Kaliningrad Oblast to the southwest and shares the Baltic Sea with Sweden. Since 2004 Lithuania is one of the European Union countries entering the Schengen area, which has no border controls. Since 2015 the country belongs to the euro area. Lithuania is a developed economy with high incomes, having achieved a high standard of living, Lithuania's level of civil liberties, media freedom, internet freedom and democracy are highly valued. Lithuania is a member of the European Union (since 2004), European Council, NATO and OECD. The first inhabitants moved to the territory of present-day Lithuania after the last ice age 11-13 thousand years ago. The Paleolithic inhabitants belong to the Madlen Svidras and Baltic cultural groups. The inhabitants of the Mesolithic belong to the Nemunas and Kunda cultures. The first residents were nomads, not making permanent settlements. VIII thousand pr. m. e. climate warms, forests expand. Residents began to wander less, engage in local hunting, fishing, gathering. Agriculture reached the territory of present-day Lithuania in the third thousand. pr. m. e. In the Neolithic region, the Pomeranian culture, which belongs to the group of rope pottery cultures considered to be the Baltic, spread. In the first centuries of our era, the union of the Baltic tribes, including the Samogitians and Lithuanians, was already distinguished. The Baltic tribes did not maintain close cultural or political contact with the Roman Empire, but traded with Rome (see Amber Way). Around 97 m.e.m.

In his "Germans", Tacitus describes Aistian (Aesti), who lived on the southeast coast of the Baltic Sea and usually associated with western white people. Western whites were distinguished into tribes earlier than others, and knowledge of them reached the earliest chroniclers of other nations. Claudius Ptolemy II c. already knew the Galindians and Jotvingians, and early medieval chronicles mention the Prussians, Curons and Semigallians. The name Lithuania is first mentioned in the Quedlinburg Annals when it describes the death of Bishop Bruno Brverfurt on the Prussian-Lithuanian border on 14 February or 9 March 1009. X - XI a. Russian chronicles mention Lithuania as one of the lands that paid tribute to Russia in Kiev, chronicles mention the military march of Yaroslav the Wise to Lithuania. From the 12th century. In the middle of the 19th century, the Lithuanians began raiding Russian lands. 1183 ravaged Polotsk and Pskov lands, even to the mighty Novgorod Republic in the 12th century. At the end of the 19th century, Lithuanian troops were repeatedly threatened. As the wealth brought by the plundering marches and prisoners became more differentiated property, the princes in charge of the army split and began to consolidate power in their hands. The unification of the duchies created by the different white tribes of Lithuania into a single confederation or federal Lithuanian state probably began in the 10th century, but according to the prevailing historiographical concepts, the process of state formation ended only in the 13th century. In the second quarter, when the Grand Duchy of Lithuania was founded on the hypothetical basis of Lithuanian lands or Duchy of Lithuania. 13c. Mindaugas became the first ruler of the Lithuanian state in the 1930s, and he was baptized in 1253.  was crowned king in July.

Gambir (Uncaria) is a genus of plants belonging to the Rubiaceae tribe. In Indonesia gambier is generally used for chewing. Its more important use is as a leather tanner and dye. Gambir also contains catechins (catechin), a natural ingredient that is an antioxidant. India imports 68% gambier from Indonesia, and uses it as a mixture of betel nut. Gambir is also produced from the plant U. acida. Uncaria gambir in the form of a semi-climbing/or climbing herbaceous plant with elongated and horizontal branches; the stem is quadrangular—especially when young—and armed with hook-like curved spines. Single leaves, opposite, slightly leathery, oval to broadly elliptical, (6-)9-12(-15) cm x (3.5-)5-7(-8) cm, rounded or heart-shaped at base, apex tapering , hairless surface (slick), with short petioles. The flowers are compound in a head with a diameter of (3.5-)4–5 cm; pink or green crown; short petals, funnel-shaped corolla (like coffee flowers), five stamens. The fruit is a capsule with two chambers, 14–18 mm long, has many seeds, wings, and stems up to 20 mm. Gambir has long been cultivated in the Malay Peninsula, Singapore and Indonesia (Sumatra, Java, Bali, Kalimantan and Maluku). Its origin is thought to be from Sumatra and Kalimantan, where wild species are found growing in nature. Rumphius reported that this plant was planted by people in Maluku in the mid-18th century, but other sources believe that its trade in the Malay region has been going on since the 17th century. Wild gambier is often found in secondary forests. It doesn't grow in dry areas, but it can't stand flooding either. Grows well up to a height of 200 m, gambier can live up to an elevation of 1,000 m above sea level. Gambir is also planted in the lowlands.

The climate suitable for gambier cultivation is climate type B2 according to Schmidt and Ferguson's classification. Gambir produces well on red yellow to brownish red podzolic soil types. The appropriate altitude is between 100–500 m above sea level with rainfall of around 3,000 – 3,353 mm per year (Anonymous, 2000 in Noor Roufiq et al, tt.). In the past gambier was produced from West Sumatra, Riau, Bangka, Belitung and West Kalimantan (Heyne, 1987), but now it is mainly produced by West Sumatra, Riau, South Sumatra, Jambi and Bengkulu with around 90% of Indonesia's gambier production coming from Sumatra Province. West and Riau (Roswita, 1998). The main export destination countries for Indonesian gambier are India and Singapore. Gambir is an extract of hot water from the leaves and twigs of the Gambir plant which is precipitated and then molded and dried, which functions as an astringent. Almost 95% of production is made into this product, which is called betel bite or plan masala. The shape of the mold is usually cylindrical, resembling brown sugar. The color is blackish brown or yellowish. Gambir (known in interstate trade as gambier) is usually shipped in packs of 50 kg. Another form is powder or "biscuits". Other names are catechu, gutta gambir, catechu pallidum (pale catechu). The main use is as a component of betel nut, which has been known to the people of the archipelago, from Sumatra to Papua since at least 2,500 years ago. It is known, gambier stimulates the release of bile so that it helps smooth the digestive process in the stomach and intestines. Another function is as a mixture of drugs, such as as a medicine for burns, medicine for headaches, medicine for diarrhea, medicine for dysentery, mouth rinses, medicine for thrush, and medicine for skin diseases (rubbed on). Gambir is also used as a tanner for leather and textile dyes.

Socrates (Greek: Σωκράτης, Sǒkratēs) (c. 470 BC–399 BC) was a Greek philosopher. He is one of the thinkers of anthropocentrism who lived during the Classical Greek period. Socrates' philosophical thought aims to know humans by understanding the universe through theory. The main concern in Socrates' philosophical thought is the nature of human life. He changed the concern of philosophy from natural philosophy to human philosophy. The approach he uses is rationalism. He examines all fields of thought as long as his studies can use reason. Socrates begins every philosophical thought with curiosity. He then made this curiosity the beginning of wisdom. In his time, he became one of the Greek figures who no longer believed in myths. Socrates lived during the development of sophistic thought. His ability to use the dialogue method earned him the sympathy of the youth. Meanwhile, Socrates was despised by followers of the belief in God and God because he was considered corrupting the morals of the youth and rejecting the existence of a god or God that was recognized by his country. Socrates was one of the figures who introduced the term "philosophy" in educational institutions. Socrates used a philosophical method known as the midwifery method which became the de facto beginning of the development of the inductive method. Socrates' thoughts influenced his students namely Plato and then to Aristotle who was a student of Plato. The influence of Socrates' thoughts spread from his country, namely Athens, to the Western world. His main thoughts are about moral philosophy or ethics. Socrates was born to a father named Sophroniskos, while his mother was named Phairnarete in 470 BC. His father worked as a sculptor, while his mother was a midwife. Socrates married Xantipe. Socrates' family was a wealthy family so that Socrates received adequate education.

Socrates served as an Athenian soldier, but was only interested in philosophy and had no interest in politics. This then makes him live in poverty. Socrates' critical thinking made him arrested, imprisoned and sentenced to death. The imposition of the death penalty was the result of the accusations of the Sophists. Socrates was then executed in 399 BC by drinking poison. The charge laid against him was that he had perverted the minds of the Athenian youths. He died at the age of 70 years. Socrates provides philosophy teaching through the provision of knowledge of something that has been understood by someone. The teaching of Socratic philosophy is referred to as the midwifery method. He likens the process of philosophizing to that of a midwife helping a woman to give birth to her child. In philosophizing, he engages in dialogue. His main concern in philosophy is with what belongs to the human person. Socrates shifted the focus of philosophy from natural philosophy to human philosophy. He uses a critical method in philosophizing, especially regarding ethics. Socrates believes that a lot of knowledge and opinions from humans are pseudo, but humans use them in solving life's problems. He considers that human knowledge about life's problems is unclear and only conjectures. Socrates then examines two knowledges that are a matter of life, namely about happiness and virtue. Socrates begins the study of philosophy with a dialogue that requires agreement on the formulation of the topics being discussed. Submission of descriptions or real examples is carried out in each formulation. After the formulation was set, Socrates held a process of rebuttal which included comparison activities or asking questions. The answers given are in the form of statements that are contradictory or different from the formulations and real examples. This conflict is then resolved by an induction process that outlines the statement and provides a definition for each term in the statement.

Monarchy (or Kingdom) comes from the Greek monos (μονος) meaning one, and archein (αρχειν) meaning king. Monarchy is a type of government led by a monarch. Monarchy or royal system of government is the oldest system in the world. At the beginning of the 19th century, there were more than 900 royal thrones in the world, but this decreased to 240 in the 20th century. Whereas in the eighth decade of the 20th century, only 40 thrones remained. Of these, only four countries have an absolute monarchy and the rest have a constitutional monarchy system. The difference between the monarch and the president as the head of state is that the monarch is the head of state for the rest of his life, while the president usually holds this position for a certain period of time. However, in federated countries such as Malaysia, the monarch or Yang diPertuan Agung is only in power for 5 years and will be replaced by monarchs from other countries in the alliance. Nowadays, the concept of absolute monarchy almost no longer exists and most of them are constitutional monarchies, namely monarchs whose powers are limited by the constitution. Democratic monarchy is different from the concept of a real monarchy. At habit monarch would inherit the throne. But in a democratic monarchy system, the throne of the monarch will rotate among several sultans. Malaysia, for example, practices both systems, namely a constitutional monarchy and a democratic monarchy. For most countries, the monarch is a symbol of the country's continuity and sovereignty. In addition, monarchs are usually religious leaders as well as commander-in-chief of a country's armed forces. For example in Malaysia, Yang Tuantuan Agung is the head of the Islamic religion, whereas in the United Kingdom and the countries under his auspices, King Charles III is the Supreme Governor of the Church of England.

The Republic of Uzbekistan (sometimes spelled Uzbekstan or Ozbekistan) (Uzbek: O'zbekiston Respublication or O'zbekiston Jumhuriyati: Kiril: Ўзбекистон Республикаси; Russian: Республика Узбекистан), is a sovereign state located in and formerly Central Asia from the Soviet Union. This landlocked country is bordered by Kazakhstan to the west and north, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan to the east and Afghanistan and Turkmenistan to the south. The official languages ​​in Uzbekistan are Uzbek a Turkic language and Russian, a remnant of Soviet rule. About 1 million Tajiks, an ethnic group that is still allied with the Persians, inhabit this country and make up 4.8% of the total population. The word Ozbek is formed from oz ("true/real") and bek ("leader/nobleman") so "Ozbek" means "nobleman" or "true leader". The territory of Uzbekistan has been inhabited since the second millennium BC. There are finds of ancient human tools and monuments in the areas of Ferghana, Tashkent, Bukhara, Khorezm (Khwarezm, Khorasmia) and Samarkand. Alexander the Great conquered Sogdia and Bactria in 327 BC, marrying Roxana, daughter of a local Bactrian chief. However, this conquest apparently did not help Alexander much because the people fought back fiercely, so that Alexander's army was finally hit in this area. For centuries the Uzbekistan region was ruled by Iranian Empires, such as the Parthian and Sassanian Empires. In the 14th century AD, Timur, also known as Timur Lenk, defeated the Mongols and built an empire. In his war, Timur Lenk expanded his territory to the Middle East. He defeated the Ottoman Sultan Bayezid I. Bayezid was captured and died in captivity. Timur Lenk tried to build his empire's capital in Samarkand. Today Timur Lenk is considered one of the greatest heroes in Uzbekistan who played an important role in its national identity and history.

After the fall of the Timur Lenk Empire, Uzbek nomads took control of this area. In the 19th century, the Russian Empire began to expand and spread to Central Asia. The period of the "Great Game" is generally considered to have lasted from about 1813 until the 1907 Anglo-Russian Convention. After the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917 a second, less intensive phase took place. At the start of the 19th century, about 3,200 km (3,200 km) separated British India from the areas on the outskirts of the Russian Empire. Much of this intermediate area is unmapped. Uzbekistan has an area of ​​447,400 square kilometers (172,700 sq mi). Making it the 56th largest country in the world by area. Uzbekistan is also the 42nd largest country by population. Among the former Soviet Union states, Uzbekistan is the 5th largest country by area and the 3rd largest by population. Uzbekistan lies between latitudes 37° and 46° N, and longitudes 56° and 74° E. The country stretches for 1,425 kilometers (885 mi) from west to east and 930 kilometers (580 mi) from north to south. Bordered by Kazakhstan and the Aral Sea to the north and northwest, Turkmenistan to the southwest, Tajikistan to the southeast, and Kyrgyzstan to the northeast, Uzbekistan is one of the largest Central Asian countries and the only Central Asian country that borders all of Central Asia. Uzbekistan also has a short border (less than 150 km or 93 miles) with southern Afghanistan. Uzbekistan is a dry landlocked country, and is one of only two truly landlocked countries in the world (that is, a country completely surrounded by countries that are also landlocked), the other being Liechtenstein.

Fishery comes from the root word fish which is affixed to pe and an which means all activities related to fish. Fisheries are human activities related to the management and utilization of aquatic biological resources. Aquatic biological resources are not strictly limited and generally include fish, amphibians and various invertebrates that inhabit waters and adjacent areas, as well as their environment. In Indonesia, according to RI Law no. 31/2004, as amended by RI Law No. 45/2009, activities included in fisheries start from pre-production, production, processing to marketing, which are carried out in a fishery business system. Thus, fisheries can be considered an agribusiness venture. Generally, fisheries are intended for the benefit of providing food for humans. In addition, other purposes of fishing include sports, recreation (fishing), and perhaps also for the purpose of making jewelry or extracting fish oil. Fishing business is all businesses of individuals or legal entities to catch or cultivate (hatching, breeding, enlargement) fish, including activities to store, cool, dry, or preserve fish with the aim of creating economic added value for business actors (commercial/business). One of the world's oldest trade histories is the trade of dried cod from the Lofoten area to southern Europe, Italy, Spain and Portugal. This fish trade began in the Viking period or earlier, spanning over 1000 years, but is still an important type of trade today. In India, the Pandyas, the oldest Dravidian Tamil kingdom, is known for its pearl fishery dating back a century BC. Tuticorin Harbor is known for its deep sea pearl fisheries. The Paravas, a Tamil nation centered in Tuticorin, developed into a prosperous society due to their pearl trade, seafaring knowledge and fishing.

ντ (Tau neutrino): Mid 1970s A neutrino is an elementary particle that has neither mass nor electric charge. Neutrinos have a spin of 1/2 and are therefore fermions. It has a very small mass, although recent experiments (see Super-Kamiokande) show that it is not exactly zero. Neutrinos interact only through weak and gravitational interactions, neither through strong interactions nor electromagnetic interactions. A neutrino is a subatomic particle that is very similar to an electron, but has no electrical charge and a very small mass, which might even be zero. Neutrinos are one of the most abundant particles in the universe. Because they have very little interaction with matter, however, they are incredibly difficult to detect. To detect neutrinos, very large and very sensitive detectors are required. Typically, a low-energy neutrino will travel through many light-years of normal matter before interacting with anything. Consequently, all terrestrial neutrino experiments rely on measuring the tiny fraction of neutrinos that interact in reasonably sized detectors. For example, at the Sudbury Neutrino Observatory, a 1000 ton heavy water solar-neutrino detector picks up about 1012 neutrinos every second. About 30 neutrinos per day are detected. Neutrinos are created as a result of certain types of radioactive decay or as a result of nuclear reactions such as those that occur in the Sun, in nuclear reactors, or when cosmic rays strike a group of atoms. There are three types (or "flavors)" of neutrinos: electron neutrinos, muon neutrinos, and tauon neutrinos (or tau neutrinos); and each type also has a corresponding antiparticle, called an antineutrino. Electron neutrinos (or antineutrinos) are produced when a proton changes to a neutron (or a neutron to a proton), which are two forms of beta decay.

Interactions involving neutrinos are mediated through the weak interaction process. Because in the weak interaction process the nuclear cross section is very small, neutrinos can pass through matter almost unhindered. For typical neutrinos generated inside the Sun (with an energy of a few MeV) it would take about a light year (~1016m) of lead to block half of the amount. Neutrinos were first postulated in December, 1930 by Wolfgang Pauli to describe the energy spectrum of beta decay, the decay of a neutron into a proton and an electron. Pauli theorized that an undetected particle was responsible for the difference between the energy and angular momentum of the particles at the beginning and end of the decay. Due to its "ghost" nature, the first experimental detection of neutrinos had to wait 25 years since it was first discussed. In 1956, Clyde Cowan, Frederick Reines, F. B. Harrison, H. W. Kruse, and A. D. McGuire published the article "Detection of the Free Neutrino: a Confirmation" in the journal Science (see neutrino experiment), a result which was awarded the 1995 Nobel Prize. is a sub-atomic particle claimed by scientists at the CERN nuclear research center, based on recent research in Geneva, that neutrinos move faster than the speed of light, so that with this finding it breaks the laws of physics that have been established for more than 100 years, Einstein with his theory of relativity once said that if one day a new particle is discovered that can exceed the speed of light, then the theory of relativity will automatically be invalidated. The neutrino experiment was carried out at a distance of 730 km between the source in Geneva and the detector located in an underground laboratory in Italy. Dario Autiro CNRS Researcher, Particle Physicist said: "At that distance we found that Neutrinos are 60 nanoseconds faster or one 60 billionth of a second faster than the time light takes to travel the same distance.

Cable News Network (CNN, "Cable News Network") is an American cable news channel founded in 1980 by American media tycoon Ted Turner. When it was launched, CNN was the first television channel to broadcast 24-hour news coverage, and the first news television channel in the United States. Despite having many branches, CNN broadcasts mostly from its headquarters at the CNN Center in Atlanta, 30 Hudson Yards in New York City, and studios in Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles. CNN is owned by its parent company, Warner Bros. Discovery. CNN is sometimes called CNN/U.S. to differentiate between the United States channel and its international channel, CNN International. As of August 2010, CNN can be seen in more than 100 million homes in the US. Its broadcast coverage includes more than 890,000 hotel rooms in the United States, and this US channel also broadcasts in Canada. Globally, CNN programs broadcast through CNN International which can be watched in 212 countries and territories. In late 2010, the domestic version of CNN/U.S. is available in high definition in Japan under the name CNN HD. CNN was launched at 5:00 p.m. Eastern Time on Sunday, June 1, 1980. Following Ted Turner's introduction, husband and wife team David Walker and Lois Hart hosted the first news program. Burt Reinhardt, who later became CNN's executive vice president, hired most of CNN's first 200 employees, including its first news anchor, Bernard Shaw. Since its debut on US television, CNN has expanded its reach to a number of cable and satellite television companies, several websites, and specialty channels with limited reach (such as the CNN Airport Network). CNN has 36 bureaus (10 domestically in the US, 26 worldwide), more than 900 local affiliate stations, and several non-English language regional networks around the world.

A transgender person is a person who has a gender identity or expression different from the sex assigned at birth. Transgender people are also sometimes referred to as transsexuals if they seek medical assistance to transition from one sex to another. Transgender is also a general word. As well as covering people whose gender identity is the opposite of their designated sex (trans men and trans women), the term transgender can also include people who are not specifically masculine or feminine (genderqueer people such as bigender, pangender, genderfluid, or Agender). Other definitions of transgender also include people who belong to the third gender or are transgender in the third gender. In rarer cases, the term transgender is used to include cross-dressers, regardless of gender identity. Being transgender is not tied to sexual orientation. Transgender people can have heterosexual, homosexual, bisexual, asexual, and other orientations. The term transgender is different from the term intersex, which is the condition of a person born with physical sex characteristics that are "...not compatible with the general notion of being male or female". The degree to which an individual feels genuine, pure, and comfortable with their outer appearance and accepts their true identity is referred to as transgender congruence. Many of the transgender people experience what is called gender dysphoria and some receive medical assistance such as hormone replacement therapy, sex reassignment surgery or psychotherapy. Not all transgender people want medical treatment and some do not do so due to economic or health constraints. The majority of transgender people face discrimination in employment and job search, meeting housing needs, and health services. Transgender people are also not protected by law from discrimination in many places. Psychiatrist John F. Oliven from Columbia University coined the term transgender in his 1965 scientific reference book entitled Sexual Hygiene and Pathology.

He writes that the previously used term transsexualism is wrong and notes that "...transgenderism is the term meant because sexuality is not a primary factor in primary transvestism." The term transgender was later used and defined in various ways by transgender, transsexual, and transvestite people including Virginia Prince, who she used in the December 1969 issue of Transvestia, a cross dresser magazine she founded. In the mid-1970s, both trans-gender (with a hyphen -]) and trans people were used as general terms. note 1] cross-gender living without sex reassignment surgery. The concept of a transgender society developed in 1984 with the use of the word transgender as a general word (hypernym). In 1985, Richard Elkins founded the Trans-Gender Archive at the University of Ulster. The International Conference on Transgender Law and Employment Policy in 1992 defined the word transgender as an umbrella term that includes "...transsexuals, transgenderists, cross dressers..." as well as people who are in transition. The term trans man refers to someone who is transgender female-to-male (English: female-to-male, FtM or F2M) while the term trans woman refers to someone who is transgender male-to-female (English: male -to-female, MtF or M2F). Health practice guidelines, professional journalism style guidelines, and LGBT advocacy groups recommend the use of names and pronouns that identify an individual, including when referring to that person in their past life. The word transgender itself is used as an adjective. Examples of correct usage are Max is a transgender person, Max is a transgender person, or Max is a transgender man not Max is transgender or Max is a transgender person.

Chromium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Cr and atomic number 24. It is the first element in group 6. It is a steel-gray, shiny, hard and brittle metal that requires high polishing, resists tarnishing, and has a high melting point. The element's name is derived from the Greek χρῶμα, chroma, meaning color, because many chromium compounds are very colorful. Ferrochromium alloys are produced commercially from chromite by cilicothermal or aluminothermal reactions and chromium metal by roasting and leaching followed by reduction using carbon and then aluminum. Chromium metal is of high value because of its high resistance to corrosion and hardness. A major development was the discovery that steel could be made highly corrosion and tarnishing resistant by the addition of metallic chromium to form stainless steel. Stainless steel and chrome plating (electroplating with chromium) together account for 85% of commercial use. Trivalent chromium ion (Cr(III)) in trace amounts is an essential nutrient in humans for insulin, sugar and lipid metabolism, although this issue is still being debated. While chromium metal and Cr(III) ions are considered non-toxic, hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)) is toxic and carcinogenic. Obsolete chromium production sites often require environmental cleaning. Chromium is amazing for its magnetic properties: it is the only solid element that exhibits a degree of antiferromagnetism at room temperature (and below). Above 38°C, it becomes paramagnetic. Chromium metal left in the open air is passivated by oxidation, forming a thin protective surface layer. This layer is a spinel structure only a few molecules thick. It is very dense, and prevents the diffusion of oxygen into the underlying metal.

This is different from the oxides that form on the surface of iron and carbon steel, in which elemental oxygen is constantly migrating, reaching the metal underneath where it causes ongoing rusting. Passivation can be enhanced by brief contact with an oxidizing acid such as nitric acid. Passivated chromium is stable to acids. Passivation can be removed by strong reducing agents which destroy the protective oxide layer on the metal. Chromium metal that has been given this treatment is easily soluble in weak acids. Chromium, unlike similar metals such as iron and nickel, is not affected by hydrogen embrittlement. However it is affected by nitrogen embrittlement, reacting with nitrogen from water and forming brittle nitrides at high temperatures which are part of metal works. Chromium is the 22nd most abundant element in the Earth's crust with an average concentration of 100 ppm. Chromium compounds are found in the environment from erosion of chromium-containing rocks, and can be disseminated by volcanic eruptions. Typical background chromium concentrations in environmental media are: atmosphere <10 ngˑm−3; soil <500 mgˑkg−1; vegetation <0.5 mgˑkg−1; fresh water <10 ugˑL−1; seawater <1 ugˑL−1; sediment <80 mgˑkg−1. Chromium is mined as chromite ore (FeCr). About two-fifths of the world's chromite ores and concentrates are produced in South Africa, while Kazakhstan, India, Russia and Turkey are also substantial producers. Untapped chromite deposits are abundant, but geographically concentrated in Kazakhstan and southern Africa. Native chromium deposits exist, although they are rare. Udachnaya Pipeline in Russia produces natural metal samples. The mine is a kimberlite pipe, rich in diamonds, and the reducing environment helps to produce both elemental chromium and diamond. The relationship between Cr(III) and Cr(VI) is highly dependent on the pH and oxidative properties of the sites.

Beirut (Arabic: بيروت;, Bayrūt; French: Beyrouth) is the capital city of the Lebanese state and also the largest city in the country. The city is inhabited by 1.2 million people, but if the surrounding metropolitan area is calculated it becomes 2.1 million. Before the Lebanese Civil War broke out, the city earned the nickname "Paris of the East" because of its cosmopolitan atmosphere. The airport located in this city is Rafik Hariri International Airport, which was previously named Beirut International Airport. The new name was used to honor Rafik Hariri, the slain former Lebanese Prime Minister. Beirut is located between Al-Asyrafiyah and Al-Musaytibah Hills, Beirut is located in a sheltered valley, where the Romans built underground aqueducts to supply the city's growing population. Beirut, the capital and principal port of Lebanon dates back to 3000 BC, when it was an important seaport for the Phoenicians. It was the Romans who first drew attention to Beirut in 14 BC. Beirut gained a reputation for its law schools (the third since the 6th century), but was destroyed by a series of fast-moving earthquakes, culminating in a tidal wave in 551. The Muslims entered Beirut in 635, generally finding only ruins and then building it slowly -land, allowing the development of a trading port that became the main transit port in Syria for the Venetian spice merchants. The Industrial Revolution and the Egyptian occupation of Syria in 1832 revived its importance in commerce which was waning during the Ottoman rule. Christian refugees fled here from the civil war in the mountains of Syria, while Protestant missionaries from the US, UK and Germany added to the city's population. At the end of World War I, which marked the fall of the Ottoman Empire, France created the state of Greater Lebanon, which became the Republic of Lebanon in 1926.

Lead or lead (also known as lead or lead)a] is a chemical element with the symbol Pb and atomic number 82. This element is a heavy metal with a higher density than many materials found in everyday life. Lead is malleable, malleable, and has a low melting point. When freshly cut, lead has a silvery bluish glow, but when exposed to air it turns an opaque gray color to the surface. Lead is the stable element with the highest atomic number and three of its isotopes are the end products of the chain decay of heavier elements. Lead is a metal of group IVA (14) which is relatively inert or does not react easily. This metal is amphoteric; Elemental lead and its oxide compounds easily react with acids and bases. In compounds, lead usually has an oxidation number of +2, and is rarely oxidized to the +4 which is common in the above group IVA elements. However, the oxidation number +4 occurs frequently in organolead compounds. Lead can be mined from certain mineral ores; this was practiced since prehistoric times in Asia Minor. Galena, the principal ore of lead, often contains silver, so it was extensively mined and used in Ancient Rome. However, production has declined since the fall of Rome, and it was not until the Industrial Revolution that lead production again reached Roman levels. In 2014, world lead production exceeded 10 million tonnes per year, and more than half of it was recycled. Useful properties of lead include high density, low melting point, malleability, and corrosion resistance. In addition, this metal is relatively cheap and has many sources, so it is often used by humans, including for buildings, water pipes, batteries, bullets, ballast, solder, paint, fuel additives, and radiation shields.

However, since the 19th century, the toxic properties of lead were discovered and its use was reduced. Lead can enter the human body through food, drink, and polluted air or dust. This element damages the nervous system and interferes with the function of enzymes in the body. Lead is especially dangerous for children because it can interfere with brain growth. The lead atom has 82 electrons, with the configuration Xe]4f145d106s26p2. The sum of lead's first and second ionization energies (energy to remove its two outer electrons) is similar to that of tin (Sn), lead's top neighbor in group IVA. This is unreasonable because an element's ionization energy is usually lower than that of its upper neighbors in the same group, because its outer electrons are farther from the atomic nucleus and are separated by a greater number of lower-level orbitals. This abnormality is caused by a phenomenon called lanthanide contraction, namely the reduction in atomic radii from lanthanum (atomic number 57) to lutetium (71), and the relatively small atomic radii of the following elements. This is a result of the ineffectiveness of the 4f electrons in shielding the outer electrons from the pull of the atomic nucleus. Even when the first through fourth ionization energies are added up, the total ionization energy of lead exceeds that of tin, reversing the pattern that is common for the top-down neighbors of the periodic table. Among the causes of this anomaly are relativistic quantum chemical effects. One of them is the oblique pair effect, which causes the two 6s electrons of lead to tend not to be involved in the bond, so that the distance between the atoms in the lead crystal becomes very far. The elements above lead in group IVA (carbon, silicon, germanium, and tin) have an allotrope with a cubic structure like diamond, that is, with covalent bonds in a tetrahedral arrangement. In these elements, the energy levels of the outermost s and p orbitals are so similar that they can hybridize to form sp3 orbitals.

A nation is a group of people who have a common identity, and share a common language, ideology, culture, history and goals. They are generally considered to have the same ancestral origin. Also mentioned as "a fully mobilized or institutionalized ethnic group". Some nations are considered equal to ethnic groups (see Ethnic nationalism and nation-state) and some are considered equal to a social and political constitutional affiliation (see Civic nationalism and Multiculturalism). A nation is also defined as a political-cultural community that is aware of autonomy, unity and common interests. In international law, nation is the term for a sovereign state. American Political Researcher Ben Anderson characterizes the nation as an "imagined Community", and Australian Academic Paul James (academician) sees it as an "Abstract Community". The nation is an Envisioned Community in the sense that the material conditions exist to broaden images and relations together and are objectively impersonal, even if each individual in that country experiences themselves as a subjective part of a part of oneness with others. For the most part, the members of a nation remain strangers to one another and may never meet. Hence the phrase, "a nation of strangers" is used by writers such as the American journalist Vance Packard. So the nation is the reality of intersubjectivity and exists solely in the minds of the people's shadows. Even if someone finally believes that the nation does not exist, the nation will still not be threatened, because the nation is not a reality of subjectivism that exists in one person's mind. Only if the multitude of people who believe that the nation does not exist and end its validity will the nation become non-existent. The definition of a nation according to experts. A nation is a group of people who are in an inner bond that are united because they have a similar history, as well as the same ideals.

A nation is a group of people who share the same character because of a similar fate and experience of cultural history that grows together with the development of the nation. The nation is a political community imagined in a territory that is clearly defined and sovereign. The nation is formed because of the similarities in race, language, customs and religion that are the difference between one nation and another. The word nation first appeared from Old French, namely nacion – which means birth (naissance), "place of birth" -, which was originally obtained from Latin, namely natio (nātĭō) which has a literal meaning, namely birth. Black's legal dictionary explains the meaning of nation namely: nation, n. (14c) 1. A large group of people who have the same origin, language and tradition which then constitutes a political entity. constituting a political entity. When a nation coincidentally coexists with a state, that is why it is also referred to as a nation-state or nation and state. ... 2. An association of people living within a defined and organized territory under an independent government; a country that has political sovereignty. The word "nation" is sometimes used as a synonym for: So the phrase "nations of the world" might refer to the highest levels of government (the same as the name for the United Nations), large geographic territories, or large ethnic groups . Depending on when the meaning of the word "nation" is used, the meaning of "National State" itself can also be used to distinguish larger areas of the country from city-states in the country, or also to distinguish countries that have a Multinational State from those that have one ethnic group. In her book entitled Kingdoms and Communities in Western Europe 900-1300, Susan Reynolds stated that many medieval European kingdoms were modern nations.

Juche (Korean: 주체/主體; Korean pronunciation: tɕutɕʰe]; usually untranslated or sometimes "self-sufficient") is North Korea's official ideology, described by the North Korean government as the "genuine, brilliant, and revolutionary contribution of Kim Il- sung to national and international thinking". Juche postulated that "man masters his destiny", and the North Korean people are "masters of revolution and development" and that when the people become strong and self-sufficient, the nation will gain a more real socialism. Kim Il-sung (1912–1994) created this ideology, which was originally a variant of Marxism–Leninism that was later given North Korean characteristics that included Marxist–Leninist materialism and placed great emphasis on the individual, nation-state, and sovereignty. The North Korean government uses the Juche ideology as its way of life and has continued to use it as its political identity since the 1950s onwards. The basic principle of Juche is to move the nation towards independence (jaju), through building a "national economy" (jarip) and emphasizing self-reliance (jawi) in the context of building socialism. The Juche practice is rooted in the idea of ​​sustainability over self-sufficient agriculture. This ideology has been described as ethnic Korean ultranationalism that developed after the loss of the original elements of Marxism–Leninism. The tower-shaped monument named after this ideology is located on the east bank of the Taedong River in Pyongyang, North Korea. This monument was built to celebrate Kim Il-sung's 70th birthday. During the Cold War, the North Korean government promoted this ideology globally. In 1964, President Sukarno paid a visit to North Korea and imitated this ideology to apply its positive side in Indonesia. References needed] The President of Romania, Nicolae Ceauşescu, was also impressed by the concept of Juche after visiting North Korea in a series of visits to Asia in 1971 and soon implemented this ideology in his country starting in 1974.

Uruguay (Spanish: República Oriental del Uruguay, Republic of Oriental Uruguay) is a small country in Latin America. The country is bordered by Brazil to the north, the Uruguay River to the west, the Río de la Plata (River Plate) estuary to the southwest, with Argentina on the opposite bank of both, and the South Atlantic Ocean to the southeast. Uruguay is home to around 3.5 million people, of whom 1.8 million live in the capital city of Montevideo and its metropolitan area. 88% of the population is of European descent. The country is the second smallest in South America and one of the most economically and politically stable. Uruguay borders on the north is Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil , on the west is the Uruguay River , on the southwest is the Rio de la Plata estuary with Argentina, and on the south is the Atlantic Ocean . Uruguay, with an area of ​​about 176,000 square kilometers (68,000 sq mi), is South America's second-smallest nation in area after Suriname. Colonia del Sacramento, one of the oldest European settlements in Uruguay, was founded by the Portuguese in 1680. Montevideo was founded by the Spaniards in the early 18th century as a military fort. Uruguay achieved independence in 1811 after a three way struggle between claims from Spain, Argentina and Brazil. It is a constitutional democracy, the president fulfills the roles of both head of state and head of government. Uruguay is one of South America's most economical countries, with a high per capita GDP and the 52nd highest quality of life index in the world in 2010, and the highest in quality of life/human development in Latin America. According to Transparency International, Uruguay is rated as the second lowest corrupt country after Chile in Latin America, although Uruguay fares better than Chile on domestic opinion polls on corruption perceptions.

The People's Republic of China (simplified Chinese: 中华人民共和国; traditional Chinese: 中華人民共和國; pinyin: Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó; literally: 'People's Republic of China', abbreviated PRC) or commonly known as China or China is a country located in East Asia whose capital city is Beijing. This country has the largest population in the world (about 1.4 billion people, the majority of whom are Han people) and a land area of ​​9.59 million square kilometers, making it the 3rd largest country in the world. The country was founded in 1949 after the end of the Chinese Civil War, and since then has been governed by a 1-party system by a single party, namely the Communist Party of the People's Republic of China/China (CCP). Although often seen as a communist state, much of the republic's economy has been privatized since the 1980s. However, the government still controls the economy politically, especially with state-owned companies and the banking sector. Politically, it remains a one-party government. Mainland China is a term used to refer to areas under the rule of the People's Republic of China/China, excluding Hong Kong, Macau, and while the Republic of China/Taiwan refers to other entities that once ruled Mainland China from 1912 until its expulsion in the Civil War. China to Formosa Island and surrounding islands in 1949. However, the Republic of China/Taiwan managed to survive and retain the rest of its territory to this day. Currently the Republic of China/Taiwan only governs the island of Formosa and the surrounding islands. The People's Republic of China/China claims territory belonging to the Republic of China/Taiwan but does not govern it, while the Republic of China/Taiwan claims sovereignty over all of mainland China which is currently controlled by the People's Republic of China/China. China's government from ancient times until today's split has had the world's largest and most complex economy for over two thousand years and dozens of dynasties of the Chinese Empire, along with several highs and lows.

Since the introduction of economic reforms in 1978 by President Deng Xiaoping, the People's Republic of China/China has become the country with the fastest growing economy in the world. As of 2013, this country is the second largest economy in the world based on total nominal GDP and PPP, as well as being the largest exporter and importer in the world. The People's Republic of China/China is a nuclear-weapon country and has the world's largest active army, with the world's second largest military spending. The People's Republic of China/China became a member of the United Nations in 1971, where it replaced and expelled the Republic of China/Taiwan as a permanent member of the UN Security Council. The People's Republic of China/China is also a member of various other organizations such as WTO, APEC, BRICS, Shanghai Cooperation Organization, BCIM and G-20. The People's Republic of China/China is a great power in Asia, and a potential super-state according to some observers. After World War II, the Chinese Civil War between the Chinese Communist Party and the Kuomintang Nationalist Party ended in 1949 with the communists taking control of Mainland China and then establishing the People's Republic of China/China. Meanwhile, the Kuomintang withdrew to the island of Formosa and continued to rule the Republic of China and some of the surrounding islands that were successfully defended. On October 1, 1949, Mao Zedong proclaimed the People's Republic of China and established a communist state, but did not try to completely annihilate the Republic of China. Proponents of Maoism say that under Mao, the unity and sovereignty of the People's Republic of China were ensured for the first time in decades, and there were developments in infrastructure, industry, health, and education, which they believed had helped raise people's living standards. They also believe that campaigns such as the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution are important in accelerating the development of the People's Republic of China and purifying their culture.

Pluto (minor planet name: 134340 Pluto) is a dwarf planet in the Kuiper belt and the first trans-Neptunian object to be discovered. Pluto is the largest and second-largest dwarf planet in the Solar System and the ninth-largest and tenth-largest object that orbits the Sun directly. Pluto is a trans-Neptunian object with the largest volume and slightly less mass than Eris, the dwarf planet in the scattered disk. Like other objects in the Kuiper belt, Pluto is composed of rock and ice and is relatively small—about one sixth the mass of the Moon and one third the volume of the Moon. Pluto has an eccentric, tilted orbit at a distance of 30 to 49 astronomical units (4.4–7.3 billion km) from the Sun. This means that there are times when Pluto is closer to the Sun than Neptune; stable orbital resonance with Neptune keeps the two planets from colliding. In 2014, Pluto was 32.6 AU from the Sun. Sunlight takes 5.5 hours to reach Pluto at its average distance (39.4 s). Pluto was discovered in 1930 and originally stated to be the ninth planet from the Sun. After 1992, its planetary status was called into question after astronomers discovered the Kuiper belt, the circle of objects beyond Neptune that includes Pluto and other objects. In 2005, Eris, which is 27% more massive than Pluto, was discovered. The International Astronomical Union (IAU) issued its first official definition of "planet" in 2006. Pluto did not fit this definition and was moved to the newly created class of "dwarf planets", more precisely plutoids. Some astronomers believe that Pluto is still considered a planet. Pluto is known so far to have five satellites: Charon (largest; half the diameter of Pluto), Styx, Nix, Kerberos, and Hydra. Pluto and Charon are sometimes considered binary systems because their orbital barycenters lie between these two objects.

The IAU has yet to formalize the definition of a binary dwarf planet, and Charon is officially declared a satellite of Pluto. On July 14, 2015, New Horizons became the first probe to fly past Pluto. NASA plans to make detailed measurements and take photographs of Pluto and its satellites using the New Horizons probe. In the 1840s, Urbain Le Verrier used Newtonian mechanics to estimate the position of the then-undiscovered planet Neptune after analyzing perturbations in the orbit of Uranus. Observations of Neptune in the late 19th century led astronomers to speculate that Uranus's orbit was influenced by a planet other than Neptune. In 1906, Percival Lowell—a Boston resident who founded the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona, in 1894—started a long-term project to search for a ninth planet, which he dubbed "Planet X". In 1909, Lowell and William H. Pickering gave some approximate celestial coordinates for the planet. Lowell and his observatory conducted this search without success until his death in 1916. Unbeknownst to Lowell, his surveys captured two fuzzy photographs of Pluto on March 19 and April 7, 1915, but its status was unknown at the time. There were fourteen other prediscovery observations at that time; the oldest finding was made by Yerkes Observatory on August 20, 1909. Following a ten-year legal dispute with Constance Lowell, Percival's wife, who attempted to seize a multi-million dollar portion of Lowell's observatory inheritance, the search for Planet X was halted until 1929. Observatory director, Vesto Melvin Slipher , immediately handed over the task of finding Planet X to Clyde Tombaugh, a 23-year-old Kansas resident who was brought to Lowell Observatory because Slipher was fascinated by his astronomical sample images. Tombaugh's task is to systematically map the night sky through several pairs of photos, then study each pair of photos and determine which objects are moving.

Borate is the name for a large amount of boron which contains oxyanions. The term "borate" can also refer to the tetrahedral boron anion, or a looser description of chemical compounds containing a borate anion. The larger borates consist of flat trigonal BO3 or tetrahedral BO4 structural units, joined together via a shared oxygen atom and may be cyclic or linear in structure. Boron most often occurs in nature as borates, such as borate and borosilicate minerals. The simple borate anion, the orthoborate ion, BO33− is known in the solid state, for example in Ca3(BO3)2. In this case, the borates adopt a near flat trigonal structure. This compound is a structural analogue of the carbonate anion CO32−, with which it is isoelectronic. The simple bond theory points to a flat trigonal structure. In terms of valence bond theory, the bonds are formed by using sp2 hybrid orbitals on boron. Some compounds called orthoborates do not always contain a flat trigonal ion, for example gadolinium orthoborate, GdBO3 contains the polyborate ion (B3O9)9−, while the high temperature form contains a flat BO33−. All borates can be considered as derivatives of boric acid, B(OH)3. Boric acid is a weak acidic proton donor due to its reaction with water, forming tetrahydroxyborate, releasing a proton: In the presence of cis-diols such as mannitol, glucose, sorbitol, and glycerol the pK drops to about 4. Under acidic conditions, boric acid undergoes a condensation reaction to form forms polymeric oxyanions: The tetraborate anion (tetramer) includes two tetrahedral and two trigonally symmetrical boron atoms assembled in a cyclic structure. The two tetrahedral boron atoms are linked together by a common oxygen atom and each also carries a negative charge carried by the additional OH- lateral groups that accompany it. This anion is a complex molecule that also exhibits three rings: two distorted hexagonal rings and one distorted octagonal ring.

Each ring is made of an alternate succession of boron and oxygen atoms. The tetraborate anion exists in the mineral borax, as the octahydrate, Na2B4O5(OH)4 8H2O. The chemical formula for borax is also often written in a denser but equivalent notation as Na2B4O7·10H2O, simply by changing the stoichiometry of 4 OH− to 2 O2− and 2 H2O. Sodium borate can be obtained at high purification and can be used to prepare standard solutions in titrimetric analysis. A number of metal borates are known. The metal is produced by treating boric acid or boron oxide with metal oxides. Further examples include linear chains of 2, 3, or 4 trigonal BO3 structural units, each sharing one oxygen atom with adjacent units: Metaborates, such as LiBO2 contain chains of trigonal BO3 structural units, each sharing two oxygen atoms with adjacent units. , while NaBO2 and KBO2 contain cyclic B3O62− ions. Borosilicate glass, also known as pyrex, can be seen as a silicate in which some SiO44− units are replaced by BO45− centers, together with cations to compensate for differences in the Si(IV) and B(III) valence states. Because these substitutions cause imperfections, the material is slow to crystallize and forms a glass with a low coefficient of thermal expansion and resistant to cracking when heated, such as soda glass. Common borate salts include sodium metaborate, NaBO2, and borax. Borax dissolves in water, so mineral deposits are found only in places with very low rainfall. Extensive deposits were discovered in Death Valley and transported by the famous team of twenty mules (1883-1889). Later (1925), deposits were discovered in Boron, California on the edge of the Mojave Desert. The Atacama Desert in Chile also contains concentrations of mineable borates. Lithium metaborate or lithium tetraborate, or a mixture of the two, can be used in the sample preparation of smelting borates of various samples for analysis by XRF, AAS, ICP-OES, ICP-AES and ICP-MS. Borate smelting and energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectrometry with polarized excitation have been used in the analysis of contaminated soils.

Herman Willem Daendels (21 October 1762 – 2 May 1818), was a Dutch politician and general who became the 36th Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies. He reigned between 1808 – 1811. At that time the Netherlands was being controlled by France. AdulthoodIn 1780 and 1787 he participated in the collection of the Dutch rebels and then fled to France. There he witnessed the French Revolution up close and then joined forces with the republican Batavia. Finally, he reached the rank of General and in 1795, he entered the Netherlands and joined the Batavian Republican army with the rank of Lieutenant-General. As head of the Unitarians, he took care of drafting the first Dutch Constitution. He even intervened militarily twice. But the British and Russian invasion in the province of Noord-Holland is bad for him. He is considered to be less responsive and attacked by various parties. Finally, he was disappointed and resigned from the army in 1800. He decided to move to Heerde, Gelderland. In 1806, he was summoned by the King of the Netherlands, King Louis (Koning Lodewijk) to serve again in the Dutch army. He was tasked with defending the provinces of Friesland and Groningen against Prussian attacks. Then after success, on January 28 1807 on the advice of Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte, he was sent to the Dutch East Indies as Governor-General. Daendels arrived in Batavia on 5 January 1808 replacing Governor-General Albertus Wiese. Daendels carried out the task given by King Louis of Hollandia to reform the corrupt government left by the VOC. He was also given the highest military rank as marshal Hollandia—which was given a year earlier—on January 28, 1807 to defend Java from British attacks. This rank took effect when he arrived in Java.

Daendels' appointment as Marshal Hollandia displeased Napoleon. He considered that the Dutch were not a nation that could fight and did not deserve to have officers of such high rank. In the end he reprimanded his younger brother, Louis Bonaparte, who at that time became King of Hollandia. Daendels' government in Java was heavily militaristic. This can be seen from the way he dresses. Unlike the previous governor general during the VOC era, who wore royal elite clothing, the uniform he wore was a marshal's uniform. In addition, the government he founded had a centralized structure similar to the command structure of Napoleon's troops. He also divided Java into nine administrative regions, each consisting of districts under the control of a regent. Ong Hok Ham commented on Daendels' militaristic style of government: "Glorious the militarization of the colonial government by giving all officials, both European and Javanese, a military rank. Perhaps he hoped that this would lead to greater discipline!" Since then, a tradition has begun among Dutch colonial administrative officials, who were known post-1816 as Pangreh Praja (Binnenlands Bestuur) and that post-Java War prijajis wore military-style uniforms as a sign of civil servant status. A practice that is still carried out today. In addition to carrying out government reforms with a militaristic style of government, Daendels was also the originator of the construction of Jalan Raya Pos which stretches from west to east of Java Island. The construction of this road was carried out by observing the condition of the island of Java at that time, which was being blockaded by the British under the command of Rear Admiral Sir Edward Pellew. This blockade which was carried out along the northern coast of Java resulted in not a single ship sailing on the north coast of Java being free from the supervision of the British fleet.

The People's Republic of Bangladesh (Bengali: গণপ্রজাতন্ত্রী বাংলাদেশ, Gôṇôprôjātôntrī Bānlādēś) is a country in South Asia bordered by India to the west, north and east, Myanmar to the south and the Gulf of Bengal to the southeast. Bangladesh, together with West Bengal in India, forms the ethno-linguistic region of Bengal. Bangladesh (বাংলাদেশ) literally means "Country of Bangla". The capital and largest city of Bangladesh is Dhaka. The borders of Bangladesh were defined through the partition of India in 1947. This country is the eastern wing of Pakistan (East Pakistan) which is separated from the western wing by 1,600 kilometers. Political, linguistic and economic differences led to divisions between the two wings, which led to the war of independence in 1971 and the creation of the state of Bangladesh. The years after independence were marked by famine, natural disasters, poverty, political turmoil, corruption and military coups. Bangladesh has the eighth largest population in the world and is one of the most populous countries in the world with high poverty rates, but Bangladesh's per capita income has doubled since 1975 and the poverty rate has fallen by 20% since the early 1990s. This country is included as one part of the "Next Eleven". The capital Dhaka and other urban areas are the main drivers behind this growth. Geographically, the country is in the fertile Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta. Bangladesh experiences annual monsoon and cyclone flooding. Remnants of civilization in Greater Bengal can be traced back to four thousand years ago, when the area was settled by Dravidian, Tibeto-Burmese and Austro-Asiatic peoples. The origin of the words "Bangla" or "Bengal" is unknown, but it is thought to have come from the Bang, a Dravidian-speaking tribe who lived in the region around 1000 BC. The Gangaridai kingdom was formed around the 7th century BC, which was later unified with Bihar under the Magadha, Nanda, Mauryan, and Sunga Empires.

Bengal was later part of the Gupta and Harsha Empires from the 3rd to 6th centuries. After his downfall, Shashanka founded an empire, and he is considered to be the first independent monarch in the history of Bangladesh. After experiencing a period of anarchism, the Buddhist Pala dynasty ruled the region for four hundred years before being replaced by the Hindu Sena dynasty. Islam entered Bengal in the 12th century through Arab traders. Sufi missionaries and Muslim conquests helped spread Islam in this region. Bakhtiyar Khilji, a general of the Turkic Nation, defeated Lakshman Sen of the Sena dynasty and conquered most of Bengal in 1204. This area was ruled by the Sultan dynasties and Bhuiyan landlords for the next several hundred years. In the 16th century, the Mughal Empire ruled Bengal and Dhaka became an important provincial center of the Mughal government. European traders arrived in the 15th century, and their influence grew until the British East India Company took control of Bengal after the Battle of Plassey in 1757. The bloody rebellion of 1857 – known as the Sepoy Mutiny – resulted in the transfer of power to the royal crown with a viceroy as administrator. During the colonial period, famine hit the Indian subcontinent many times, such as the famine in Bengal in 1943 which killed 3 million people. Between 1905 and 1911, an attempt was made to separate the province of Bengal into two zones, with Dhaka as the capital of the eastern zone. When India was divided in 1947, Bengal was divided along religious lines. The western part of Bengal belonged to India, and the eastern part joined Pakistan as a province called East Bengal (later to become East Pakistan). In 1950, land reform was carried out in East Bengal with the abolition of the feudal zamindar system.

Philosophy (from the Greek word φιλοσοφία,philosophy, meaning "love of wisdom" ) is the study of general and fundamental questions, such as questions of existence, reason, values, reason, and language. This term is probably first used by Pythagoras (c. 570–495SM). The methods used in philosophy include asking questions, critical discussion, dialectics, and systematic presentations. Classical philosophical questions include: Is it possible to know everything and prove it? What's the most real? Philosophers also ask more practical and concrete questions such as: Is there a best way to live? Is it better to be fair or unfair (if one can get away with it)? Do humans have free will? Historically, philosophy encompasses the core of all knowledge. From the time of Ancient Greek philosophers such as Aristotle until the 19th century, natural philosophy encompassed astronomy, medicine, and physics. For example, Newton's Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy in 1687 is later classified as a physics book. In the 19th century, the development of modern university research ushered in professionalized and specialized academic philosophy and other disciplines. In the modern era, several investigations that were traditionally part of philosophy have become separate academic disciplines, some of which are psychology, sociology, linguistics, and economics. Other investigations closely related to art, science, politics and several other fields remained part of philosophy. For example, is beauty objective or subjective? Are there many scientific methods or is there only one? Is political utopia a hopeful dream or a vain delusion? The main sub-fields of academic philosophy include metaphysics (dealing with the nature of reality and being), epistemology (concerning "the origins and fields of knowledge and] ... their limits and validity" ), ethics, aesthetics, political philosophy, logic, philosophy of science , and the history of western philosophy.

Since the 20th century, professional philosophers have contributed to society primarily as professors, researchers, and writers. However, many of those who study philosophy in undergraduate or postgraduate programs contribute to the fields of law, journalism, politics, religion, science, business and various arts and entertainment activities. The word philosophy or philosophy in Indonesian is an absorption word from Arabic: فلسفة‎, which is also taken from Greek; Φιλοσοφία philosophia. In this language, this word is a compound word, and comes from the words (philia = friendship, love, etc.) and (sophia = wisdom, س** ایرانی citation needed], so its literal meaning is a "lover of wisdom". which is taken from the Dutch language is also known in Indonesia. This last form is more similar to the original. In Indonesian a person who studies philosophy is called a "philosopher". knowledge. In this sense, philosophy is closely related to religion, mathematics, natural science, education, and politics. "Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy", Newton's work in 1687 was classified in the 2000s as a physics book; he used the term "philosophy nature" because the term was used to cover disciplines later associated with science such as astronomy, medicine, and physics. In classical times, Philosophy t is traditionally divided into three main branches: This division is not obsolete but has changed. Natural philosophy has divided into various natural sciences, especially astronomy, physics, chemistry, biology, and cosmology. Moral philosophy has given birth to the social sciences, but still includes value theory (including aesthetics, ethics, political philosophy, etc.). Metaphysical philosophy has given birth to formal sciences such as logic, mathematics and philosophy of science, but still includes epistemology, cosmology and others.

Uranus (derived from the Latin name Ūranus for the name of the Greek god Οὐρανός) is the seventh planet from the Sun. Uranus is the planet with the third largest radius and fourth largest mass in the Solar System. Uranus is also the only planet named after a character in Greek mythology, the Latinized version of the name of the Greek sky god Ouranos. Uranus is similar in composition to Neptune, and both have different chemical compositions from the larger gas giants Jupiter and Saturn. Because of this, astronomers often place Uranus and Neptune in the category of "ice giants" to distinguish them from the gas giants. Uranus's atmosphere is similar to Jupiter's and Saturn's in that it is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium, but contains more "ice" elements such as water, ammonia and methane, along with traces of hydrocarbons. Uranus's atmosphere is the atmosphere of the coldest planet in the Solar System, with a minimum temperature of 49 K (−224 °C; −371 °F). Uranus's atmosphere has a layered and complex cloud structure, and it is estimated that the lowest cloud layer consists of water and the highest cloud layer consists of methane. The interior of Uranus is mostly composed of ice and rock. Like the other giant planets, Uranus has a ring system, a magnetosphere, and numerous moons. The Uranus system has a unique configuration among the planets because its axial tilt is tilted sideways, nearly into the plane of its revolution about the Sun. Therefore, its north and south poles are located where other planets are equator. In 1986, images taken by the Voyager 2 spacecraft showed Uranus as a planet that appears to be virtually invisible in visible light, ie without the cloud bands or storms typical of giant planets.

However, observers on Earth saw signs of changing seasons and increased weather activity when Uranus reached its equinox in 2007. Winds on Uranus's surface can reach 250 meters per second (900 km/h; 560 mph). Uranus had been observed on many occasions prior to its discovery as a planet, but it was mistaken for a star. The earliest recorded sighting was in 1690 when John Flamsteed observed the planet at least six times, cataloging it as 34 Tauri. French astronomer Pierre Lemonnier observed Uranus at least twenty times between 1750 and 1769, including on four consecutive nights. Sir William Herschel observed the planet on 13 March 1781 while in the garden of his house at 19 New King Street in the city of Bath, Somerset (now the Herschel Museum of Astronomy), but initially reported it (on 26 April 1781) as a "comet". Herschel "made a series of observations of the parallax of fixed stars", using a telescope of his own design. He noted in his journal "In the near quartiles of ζ Tauri … it could be a Nebula star or a comet". On March 17, he noted, "I looked for that Comet or Nebula Star and found that it is a Comet, because it changed its position". When he presented his findings to the Royal Society, he continued to assert that he had found a comet while implicitly comparing it to a planet: Herschel informed Astronomer Royal, Nevil Maskelyne, of his discovery and received this astonished reply from him on April 23: "I don't know what to call it." what.Maybe it's a regular planet moving in a nearly circular orbit around the Sun because Comets move on highly eccentric ellipses.

Siemens AG (German pronunciation: ˈziːməns] or -mɛns]) is a multinational conglomerate headquartered in Munich, Germany, and Europe's largest industrial manufacturing company, with offices worldwide. The main divisions of the company are Industry, Energy, Health Care (Siemens Healthineers), and Infrastructure & Cities. The company is a leading manufacturer of medical diagnostic equipment, and its healthcare division, which accounts for approximately 12% of its total sales, is the second most profitable business unit, after its industrial automation division. The company is a component of the Euro Stoxx 50 stock market index. Siemens and its subsidiaries employ around 385,000 people worldwide and generated revenues of around €87 billion in 2019. Siemens & Halske was founded by Werner von Siemens and Johann Georg Halske on October 1, 1847. Based on the telegraph, their invention used a needle to designate a sequence of letters instead of using Morse code. The company, which was later named Telegraphen-Buanstalt von Siemens & Halske, opened its first workshop on October 12, 1847. In 1848, Siemens & Halske built the first long-distance telegraph line in Europe, which was 500 km from Berlin to Frankfurt am Main. In 1850, Werner von Siemens' younger brother, Carl Wilhelm Siemens, later Sir William Siemens, began representing Siemens & Halske in London. The agency in London became a branch office in 1858. In the 1850s, Siemens & Halske was involved in building long-distance telegraph networks in Russia. In 1855, Siemens & Halske opened a branch office in St Petersburg, Russia, led by Werner von Siemens' other younger brother, Carl Heinrich von Siemens.

In 1867, Siemens completed construction of over 11,000 km of the Indo-European telegraph line from London to Calcutta. In 1867, Werner von Siemens invented a dynamo without permanent magnets. Similar systems were developed by Ányos Jedlik and Charles Wheatstone, but Siemens was the first company to manufacture such a device. In 1881, a Siemens AC alternator powered by a waterwheel, was used to power the world's first electric street lights, in Godalming, United Kingdom. This company continues to grow and expand into electric trains and lights. In 1887, the company opened its first office in Japan. In 1890, Werner von Siemens retired and the operations of this company were handed over to his brother Carl and his sons Arnold and Wilhelm. Siemens & Halske (S & H) was founded in 1897, and then merged some of its businesses with Schuckert & Co., Nuremberg in 1903 to form Siemens-Schuckert. In 1907, Siemens (Siemens & Halske and Siemens-Schuckert) employed 34,324 people, making it the seventh most-employed company in the German Empire. (see List of German companies by employee in 1907) In 1919, S & H along with two other companies formed a lamp manufacturer called Osram. During the 1920s and 1930s, S&H began manufacturing radios, television sets, and electron microscopes. In 1932, Reiniger, Gebbert & Schall (Erlangen), Phönix AG (Rudolstadt), and Siemens-Reiniger-Veifa mbH (Berlin) merged to form Siemens-Reiniger-Werke AG (SRW). In 1966, Siemens-Reiniger-Werke, Siemens & Halske, and Siemens-Schuckert officially merged to form Siemens AG. In the 1920s, Siemens built the Ardnacrusha hydroelectric plant on the Shannon River, in what was then the Irish Free State, and was the first in the world of this design.

Epidemiology is a branch of biology that studies and analyzes the distribution, patterns, and determinants of health and disease conditions in certain populations. Epidemiology is a cornerstone of public health, which shapes decision-making in public policy and evidence-based practice by identifying risk factors for disease and identifying disease prevention goals. Epidemiologists assist with study design, collection and statistical analysis of data, making interpretations, and disseminating findings (including occasional peer reviews and systematic reviews). Epidemiology has helped develop methodologies used in clinical research, public health research, and, to a lesser extent, basic research in biology. The main areas of epidemiological study include disease causation, disease transmission, outbreak investigation, disease surveillance, environmental epidemiology, forensic epidemiology, occupational epidemiology, screening, biological monitoring, and comparison of treatment effects as in clinical trials. Epidemiologists rely on other disciplines such as biology to better understand disease processes, statistics to utilize data efficiently and draw appropriate conclusions, social sciences to better understand proximate and proximate causes, and engineering for exposure assessment. Epidemiology, literally "the study of what is in people", comes from the Greek epi, meaning 'amongst', and demos, meaning 'people, district', and logos, meaning 'study, word , discourse', thus showing that epidemiology only applies to human populations. However, the term is widely used in the study of animal populations (veterinary epidemiology), despite the availability of the term "epizoology", and has also been applied to the study of plant populations (plant disease epidemiology). The distinction between "epidemic" and "endemic" was first expressed by Hippocrates, to distinguish between diseases that "visit" a population (epidemic) and diseases that "live in" a population (endemic).
