Horton that Society is a collection of people who have independence together for a long period of time and also inhabit a certain area or area.

Where in that region has a culture that does not but has different customs in that area, that area. There are several types of families, namely: We can observe that children experience a process of growth and development that will be influenced by their environment and association, including the type of family. In a review of developmental psychology, the view of the parent-child relationship is generally related to the attachment theory first put forward by John Bowlby. He then identified the impact of parenting behavior as an important factor in the parent-child relationship that had been formed since childhood. The nuclear family, also known as the nuclear family, consists of father, mother and children. The nuclear family is part of the social institutions that exist in society. For primitive peoples whose livelihoods are hunting and farming, the family is already a sufficient structure to handle production and consumption. The family is the basic social institution from which all other institutions develop because an increasingly complex culture makes these institutions important. Family roles describe a set of interpersonal behaviors, traits, activities related to individuals in certain positions and situations. Personal roles in the family are based on the expectations and behavior patterns of the family, group and society. The various roles contained in the family are as follows: Basically, there are eight main tasks of the family as follows: references are needed] The functions carried out by the family are: There are two kinds of family forms seen from how decisions are made, namely based on location and based on patterns of authority. There are three types of subsystems in the family, namely husband-wife subsystem, parent-child subsystem, and sibling subsystem (siblings). The husband-wife subsystem consists of a man and a woman who live together with the explicit aim of building a family.

Tobacco is a group of plants from the genus Nicotiana whose leaves are commonly used as a raw material in smoking activities. Indonesian tobacco is an absorption of the word "tabaco" from Spanish which is considered as the origin of the word. The largest production of tobacco comes from the species Nicotiana tabacum, although Nicotiana rustica is also used in some places. Bernardino de Sahagún was the first to distinguish between the two species in the Florentine Codex written between 1540 and 1585. Tobacco is an annual agricultural product that is not a food commodity, but a plantation commodity. This product is consumed not for food but as a spare time filler or "entertainment", namely as a raw material for cigarettes and cigars. Tobacco can also be chewed. The rich content of secondary metabolites also makes it useful as a pesticide and medicinal raw material. Tobacco has long been used as an entheogen in America. The arrival of Europeans to North America popularized the tobacco trade, especially as a sedative. This popularity led to the economic growth of the southern United States. After the United States Civil War, changes in demand and labor led to the development of the tobacco industry. This new product quickly burgeoned with the tobacco companies until a scientific controversy occurred in the mid-20th century. The word tobacco comes from the Spanish word "tabaco". However, the origin of the word "tabaco" is still a matter of debate among etnomologists. This word is thought to be an absorption word in the Guarani language, which refers to the tube used to suck the tobacco powder used by the Haitian Indians and is made from tapir bone. This opinion is in accordance with the statement of Gonzalo Fernández de Oviedo y Valdés who said that "tabaco" is a kind of Y-shaped pipe for inhaling tobacco smoke, while the tobacco leaves used are referred to as cohiba.

Another opinion by Bartolomé de las Casas also states that at the time Christopher Columbus sent Luís Vaz de Torres on his way to meet the Emperor of China. He landed wrong and met with Indians rolling tobacco leaves. They call the leaves "cohiba" or "cojiba" and roll the leaves to make "tabaco" which is a cigarette that is inserted in the nose to inhale the smoke. The tobacco plant is an annual plant, although Nicotiana var fruticosa is an annual plant. The height of the tobacco varies depending on the species and where it is grown with the tallest varieties reaching 12 feet. This plant takes 40 to 60 days to germinate before grafting when it is 15 cm high. Tobacco is able to grow in a wide range of climates with a growing time of 60 to 90 days with frost-free conditions from grafting to harvest with temperatures of 20°C to 30°C . The dry season is the time to harvest and ripen the leaves so that the leaves are in good quality. Because when it rains excessively, the leaves that are harvested will have a thin and light leaf shape. Tobacco stalks vary in size depending on the variety. Most varieties have a rough, uneven surface, while other species have a smooth surface. Tobacco stalks are characterized by being erect, round, sticky, hairy, sticky and large in size. The stalks are composed of a wood-like substance and contain a sticky pith. Tobacco has various leaf shapes, such as oval, lanceolate and pointed. N.Tabacum has attached, oval or lanceolate leaf shapes, while N.rustica has a stem shape and is usually oval or heart-shaped. The color of the leaves varies depending on soil conditions and will change as they mature or go through the ignition process.

Natural philosophy has divided into various natural sciences, especially astronomy, physics, chemistry, biology, and cosmology. Moral philosophy has given birth to the social sciences, but still includes value theory (including aesthetics, ethics, political philosophy, etc.). Metaphysical philosophy has given birth to formal sciences such as logic, mathematics and philosophy of science, but still includes epistemology, cosmology and others.

Nasreddin or Nasreddin (Turkish: Nasreddin Hoca, Ottoman Turkish:نصر الدين خوجه, Persian:خوجه نصرالدین, Pashtun:ملا نصرالدین}}, Arabic: نصرالدین جحا‎, ALA-LC: Naṣraddīn Juḥā, Urdu:ملا نصرالدین, Ulama-LC: Naṣraddīn Juḥā, Urdu:ملا نصرالدین 'ja, Nasreddīn Hodja, Bosnian: Nasrudin Hodža) was a satirical Sufi of the Seljuk dynasty, believed to have lived and died in the 13th century in Akshehir, near Konya, the capital of the Seljuk Sultanate of Rûm, now in Turkey. He was widely regarded as a philosopher and sage, known for his humorous stories and anecdotes. He appears in thousands of stories, sometimes witty and clever, sometimes wise, but often stupid or the butt of jokes. Every Nasruddin story usually contains witty and educational humor. The Nasreddin Hodja Festival is celebrated internationally between July 5-10 every year in the city where he lives. Various societies claim Nasreddin as their ethnicity. Some sources give his birthplace as Hortu Village in Sivrihisar, Eskişehir Province, present-day Turkey, in the 13th century. He later lived in Akşehir, and then in Konya during the Seljuk dynasty. He died in 1275/6 or 1285/6 AD. Nasruddin's tomb is believed to be in Akşehir and the "Nasreddin Hodja International Festival" is held annually in Akşehir on 5–10 July. According to Prof. Mikail Bayram who made an extensive research on Nasreddin Hoca, his full name is Nasir ud-din Mahmud al-Khoyi, his title Ahi Evran (as being the leader of the ahi organization). IUa was born in Hoy City in Azerbaijan, was educated in Horasan and became a student of the famous mufassir of the Quran, Fakhr al-Din al-Razi, in Herat. He was sent to Anatolia by the Caliph in Baghdad to organize defense and resistance against the Mongol invasion. He served as a kadı (Islamic judge) in Kayseri.

This explains why he is asked judicial problems in the jokes not only the religious ones. During the chaos of the Mongol invasion, he became a political opponent of Jalaluddin Rumi, another great figure of the time who also lived in Konya. He was recognized in Masnavi by juha anecdotes for this reason. He was superintendent in the courtroom of Kaykaus II in Konya. Having lived in numerous cities in vast area and being steadfastly against the Mongol invasion as well as having his witty character, he was embraced by various nations and cultures from Turkey to Arabia, and from Russia to China, most of which suffered from those invasions. After several generations passed, several new stories were added to the collection of stories of Nasruddin, some stories were modified, he and his stories spread to various regions. The themes in the stories become part of the folklore of several countries and express the national imagination of various cultures. Although most depict Nasruddin as being in a small village location, several other stories use the concept of Nasruddin's lifetime not being limited in time. They complete their folklore with concise but sharp wisdom that overcomes all trials and tribulations. The oldest Nasruddin manuscript dates from 1571. Today, Nasruddin's stories have been translated into various languages. Several regions developed figures resembling Nasruddin. In some areas, Nasruddin is part of the culture and is often mentioned in everyday life. Because there are thousands of different Nasruddin stories, there are always stories that are in accordance with everyday events in society. Nasruddin often appears as a character acting strangely in various folk traditions of Albanian, Arabic, Armenian, Azerbaijani, Bengali, Bosnian, Bulgarian, Chinese, Greek, Gujarati, Hindi, Italian, Ladino, Kurdish, Pashtun, Persian, Romanian, Serbian , Russian, Turkish, and Urdu.

Emotions are intense feelings directed at someone or something. Emotions are also reactions to a person or event. Emotions can be shown when feeling happy about something, angry at someone, or afraid of something. The word "emotion" comes from the French word, émotion, from émouvoir, 'joy' from the Latin emovere, from e- (variant ex-) 'outside' and movere 'to move'. Most experts believe that emotions are more fleeting than moods. For example, if someone is being rude, people will feel angry. These intense feelings of anger may come and go fairly quickly but when one is in a bad mood, one can feel bad for several hours. There are fundamental aspects to emotion to consider, including: All emotions originate in the limbic system of the brain which is about the size of a walnut and located in the brainstem People tend to feel happy when their limbic system is relatively inactive. People's limbic systems are not the same. The limbic system is more active in depressed people, especially when they receive negative information. Everyone responds differently to stimuli that trigger the same emotions. In some cases, personality is the cause of these emotional differences. At other times, the differences arise as a result of job requirements. The success of meeting an employee's emotional demands of a job depends not only on the emotions that must be displayed and their intensity but also on how often and how long they try to display them. Emotions are important to rational thinking because they provide important information about understanding the world around us. In an organization, the key to making good decisions is to apply thoughts and feelings in a decision.

In “The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals,” Charles Darwin stated that emotions developed over time to help humans solve problems. Emotions are very useful because they 'motivate' people to engage in actions essential to survival – actions such as gathering food, finding shelter, choosing mates, defending against predators and predicting behavior. Emotions greatly influence human behavior. another human. One way of classifying emotions is based on whether they are positive or negative. Positive emotions - such as joy and gratitude - express an evaluation or feeling of benefit, whereas negative emotions - such as anger or guilt - express the opposite. Emotions cannot be neutral, because to be neutral is to be nonemotional. Personality predisposes people to experience certain moods and emotions, for example some people feel guilty and experience anger more easily than others, whereas others may feel calm and relaxed in any situation. In essence, some people have a tendency to experience any emotion more intensely or to have a high affect intensity (individual differences in the strength with which individuals experience their emotion). People tend to be in their worst moods early in the week and in their best moods at the end of the week. Weather being an extraordinary event has little influence on mood. One expert concluded, “Contrary to prevailing cultural views, these data suggest that people do not report a better mood on a sunny day or vice versa. low causes workers to experience a longer level of tension as time goes on increasing.

Dubai (/duːˈbaɪ/ DOO-by; Arabic: دبي, translit. Dubayy‎ dʊˈbajj]) is the most populous city in the United Arab Emirates and is the capital of the Emirate of Dubai. The city is located along the southeastern coast of the Arabian Peninsula and south of the Persian gulf, the Municipality of Dubai is called Dubai City to distinguish it from the Emirate of Dubai. Dubai is one of the most popular tourism destinations in the world. The city has the second most five-star hotels in the world and also the tallest building in the world, Burj Khalifa. Written documents state the existence of this city for 150 years before the formation of the UAE. Dubai shares legal, political, military and economic powers with the other emirates within the federal sphere, although each emirate has jurisdiction over some powers such as civil law enforcement and monitoring and updating of local facilities. Dubai has the largest population and is the second largest emirate by area, after Abu Dhabi. Dubai and Abu Dhabi are the only two emirates with veto power over critical matters of national interest within the country's Federal National Council. Dubai has been ruled by the Al Maktoum dynasty since 1833. Its current leader, Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, also serves as Prime Minister and Vice President of the UAE. The emirate's income comes from trade, real estate and financial services. Revenue from oil and natural gas accounts for less than 6% (2006) of Dubai's US$37 billion (2005) economy. Real estate and construction contributed 22.6% to the economy in 2005, before the large-scale construction season that has lasted until now. Dubai has attracted worldwide attention through its innovative real estate projects and sporting events. This increasing concern, along with its importance as a world business hub, has also raised human rights concerns regarding the involvement of large numbers of foreign workers.

In the 1820s, Dubai was referred to as Al Wasl by British historians. However, few records mentioning the cultural history of the UAE or its emirates arise because of the region's tradition of recording and passing on folklore and myths. The linguistic origin of the word Dubai is also debated, some believe it is derived from Persian, while others consider Arabic to be the linguistic root of this word. According to Fedel Handhal, a researcher on UAE history and culture, the word Dubai may come from the word Daba (a derivative of Yadub), which means to spread; this word could be a reference to the flow of Dubai Creek inland. Very little is known about the pre-Islamic culture of the southeastern Arabian peninsula, except for the many ancient cities in the region which were centers of trade between the Eastern and Western worlds. The remnants of an ancient mangrove swamp, dated at 7,000 years, were discovered during the construction of sewer lines near Dubai Internet City. This area was covered with sand about 5,000 years ago after the coastline retreated inland, becoming part of the city's present coastline. Before Islam, people in this region worshiped Bajir (or Bajar). The Byzantine and Sassanid empires were dominant at this time, with the Sassanids controlling most of the territory. After the spread of Islam there, the Umayyad Caliph, from the eastern Islamic world, expanded into southeastern Arabia and defeated the Sassanids. Excavations undertaken by the Dubai Museum in the Al-Jumayra (Jumeirah) area confirmed the presence of several artifacts from the Umayyad period. The first recorded mention of Dubai is in 1095, in the "Book of Geography" by the Andalusian-Arab geographer Abu Abdullah al-Bakri. The Venetian pearl merchant Gaspero Balbi visited the area in 1580 and mentioned Dubai (Dibei) for its pearling industry.

in Europe (gray) Armenia (Armenian: հայաստան, translit. Hayastan, Natural Sciences: Halance)), officially named Armenia (Armenian: հայաստանի հանրապետություն, translit. Hayastani Hanrapetut'yun, Natural Science is a landlocked country located in the South Caucasus region, Eurasia. Located in West Asia, on the Armenian Highlands, the country is bordered by Turkey to the west, Georgia to the north, the Lachin Corridor which is still under peacekeeping control and Azerbaijan to the east, and Iran and the Azerbaijani exclave of Nakhichevan to the south. In Armenian, the country was called Hayq, and later Hayastan, meaning land of the Haik people, the addition of the term making the name Haik part of the prefix '-stan' which in Persian means land. According to legend, Haik is descended from Prophet Noah who is the ancestor of all the Armenian people (according to ancient Armenian tradition). Haik settled at the foot of Mount Ararat, and left Armenia to help build the Tower of Babel, when he returned, he was defeated by Bel a Babylonian king (some researchers think he was defeated by Nimrod on 11 August 2492 BC near lake Van, south of ancient Armenia (Today this area belongs to Turkey.) Hayq was the name given to Armenia by the other countries that surrounded it. This name was taken from the strongest tribe that lived in the ancient Armenian lands, and called themselves ''Armens''. Traditionally this name is derived from Armenak or Aram (descendant of Haik).According to research conducted from the Jewish and Christian sides the name 'Armenia' is taken from Har-Minni which means Mount Minni (or Mannai).Explanations taken from pre-Christian times assume that Nairi , meaning land flowed by rivers, is the ancient name given to the country's mountainous region and this name was used by the Assyrians around 1200 BC; but the Behistun Inscription found in Iran and dated to 521 BC is recorded as writing Armenian.

Armenia has been inhabited by humans since prehistoric times, and has been suggested to be the site of the Biblical Garden of Eden. Armenia was a culturally rich empire until the late 1st century, and its territory stretched from the Black Sea to the Caspian Sea and the Mediterranean Sea during the reign of Tigranes the Great. However, Armenia's strategic location between the two continents has become a magnet for many invaders, including the Assyrians, Persians, Greeks, Romans, Byzantines, Mongols, Arabs, and Turks. In 301 AD, Armenia became the first country in the world to recognize Christianity as the official state religion, twelve years before the Roman Empire granted official tolerance for Christianity under Galerius, and 30-40 years before Constantine was baptized. Although there were other religious communities before Christianity, when this country was colonized these communities were converted by missionaries of Christianity. After being repeatedly colonized and transformed by different dynasties including Parthian (Iranian), Roman, Byzantine, Arab, Mongol, and Persian – Armenia became weak. In the 1500s the Ottoman Turks and the Savavid Persians divided Armenia. Modern Armenia was ruled by the Erivan Khanate, a Safavid puppet state centered on Erivan, the ancient name for Yerevan, the capital of modern Armenia. In 1813 and 1828, modern Armenia (consisting of Erivan and Karabakh which was still a territory of the Persian sultanate) was made a part of the Russian Empire temporarily. The Bolshevik Revolution in Petrograd allowed Armenia to become an independent republic for a short time, then become part of the Soviet Union again. The territory of Armenia controlled by the Soviet Union was later merged with those of Georgia and Azerbaijan to form the Transcaucasian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic in 1922 and 1936 respectively.

Fossils (Latin: fossa meaning "dig out of the ground") are objects preserved in amber, hair, petrified wood, oil, coal, and remnants of DNA. In order for an organism to become a fossil, the remains of this organism must soon be buried in sediment. Paleontologists classify fossils into several types. Animals or plants that are thought to be extinct but in fact still exist are called living fossils. The most common fossils are skeletal remains such as shells, teeth and bones. Soft tissue fossils are very rare. The science that studies fossils is paleontology, which is also a branch of science embraced by archeology. Fossilization is the process of hoarding the remains of animals or plants that accumulate in sediments or deposits that are either completely preserved, partially or only in traces. There are several conditions for fossilization to occur, including: The term "living fossil" is a term used for a living species that resembles a species known only from fossils. Some of the living fossils include coelacanth fish and ginkgo trees. A living fossil can also refer to a living species that has no other close species or a small group of close species that does not have any other close species. An example of this last criterion is nautilus. Most fossils are found in open-surface sedimentary rocks. Rocks that contain many fossils are called fossiliferous. The types of fossils contained in rocks depend on the type of environment in which the sediments were scientifically deposited. Marine sediments, from coastlines and shallow seas, usually contain the most fossils. Fossils are formed from the process of destroying remains of organisms that once lived. This often occurs when plants or animals are buried in oxygen-free environmental conditions.

In biology, tissue is the level of organization of life among cells and organs. Tissue is a collection of similar cells and their extracellular matrix that together carry out certain functions. At the next level, a number of different tissues can work together to form organs. The branch of biology that studies tissue is histology, while the branch of biology that studies changes in tissue shape and function in relation to disease is histopathology. The classic tool used to study tissue is the paraffin block, to which the tissue is attached, cut, stained, then examined under a microscope. Technological developments such as the use of electron microscopy and immunofluorescence have made it possible to observe more and more detailed tissues. Tissues are owned by organisms that already have a division of tasks for each group of cells. Thallus organisms, such as algae ("algae") and fungi ("mushrooms"), do not have differentiated tissues, although they can form characteristic organ-like structures, such as fruiting bodies and sporophores. Moss plants can be said to have a clear network, even though it does not yet have a clear vascular network. In animals, tissues are grouped into four basic types, namely epithelial tissue, connective tissue, muscle tissue, and nervous tissue. Although all animals are generally considered to contain all four of these tissue types, their manifestations may differ depending on the type of organism. Differences during the developmental period of an organism raises differences in the origin of its cells and tissues. The epithelium in all animals is derived from the ectoderm and endoderm layers, and a small part of the mesoderm, which forms the endothelium, a special type of epithelium that forms blood vessels. In contrast, true epithelial tissue is present in only a single layer of cells held together by a junction, called a tight junction, to create a selectively permeable barrier. This tissue covers all surfaces of organisms that come in contact with the external environment such as the skin, respiratory tract, and digestive tract.

Its function is as a protector, a means of secretion and absorption, and is separated from other tissues underneath by the basal lamina. Epithelial tissue is formed by cells that line the surfaces of organs, such as the surface of the skin, the respiratory tract, the surface of soft organs, the reproductive tract, and the inner lining of the digestive tract. The cells that make up the lining of the epithelium are connected by tight junctions that are semipermeable; hence, this tissue acts as a barrier between the external environment and the organs it encloses. In addition to this protective function, epithelial tissue can also be specialized for functions in secretion, excretion, and absorption. Epithelial tissue helps protect organs from microorganisms, injury, and fluid loss. Epithelial tissue consists of three kinds, namely exothelium which covers the outside of the body, endothelium which lines the internal organs of the body, and mesothelium which lines the body cavities. There are various functions of epithelial tissue: There are many types of epithelium and their names vary quite a bit. Generally, classification schemes combine descriptions of cell shape with words indicating the number of layers: simple (one cell layer) or stratified (multiple cell layers). However, other cellular characteristics such as cilia can also be described in a classification system. Common types of epithelium include simple squamous epithelium, stratified squamous epithelium, simple cuboidal epithelium, transitional epithelium, pseudo columnar epithelium (also known as ciliated columnar epithelium, columnar epithelium, and glandular epithelium. Connective tissue is fibrous tissue composed of cells -cells separated by non-living material, called extracellular matrix. This matrix can be liquid or rigid. For example, blood is liquid because its matrix is ​​plasma and bone is rigid because it is such a matrix. Connective tissue functions to give organs shape and hold them together or "bind" them Blood, bone, tendons, ligaments, adipose, and areolar tissue are examples of connective tissue.

Hydrolysis is the decomposition of substances in a chemical reaction caused by water. The chemical reaction in hydrolysis breaks down water molecules (H2O) into hydrogen cations (H+) and hydroxide anions (OH−). Hydrolysis depends on the chemistry, solubility, degree of acidity and oxidation-reduction of each compound. Chemically and physiologically, hydrolysis is a double decomposition reaction with water as the reactant, so when a compound is represented by AB (for example) where A and B are groups and HOH is water, the reaction is reversible as follows AB↽−−⇀HOH{\displaystyle {\ce {AB <=> HOH}}} . In addition to water as a reactant and product of hydrolysis, neutral molecules can involve organic compounds or ionic molecules such as the hydrolysis of salts, acids and bases. Hydrolysis can be applied to complex lipids such as phospholipids and glycolipids. On the other hand, hydrolysis cannot be applied to simple lipids such as fats, oils and waxes. The word "hydrolysis" comes from the Greek hydro "water" + lysis "separation". When in aqueous solution it decomposes into hydrogen cations (H+) and hydroxide anions (OH−) which will then react with other compound ions which causes leftover or excess hydrogen cations (H+) and hydroxide anions (OH−) so that the solution is acidic or basic. If water ions do not react with compounds in certain solutions, the solution remains neutral (still the pH of water). This process is usually used to break down certain polymers, especially those prepared by step-growth polymerization. Simply put, hydrolysis is the breaking down of chemical bonds with the help of water, for example sucrose saccharification. Saccharification is carbohydrates that are broken down into simpler sugars by hydrolysis. Hydrolysis is different from hydration. On hydration, the molecule does not split into two new compounds. Usually hydrolysis occurs during the digestion of carbohydrates.

It can be said that hydration occurs when water molecules surround the ion in a certain state. Usually hydrolysis is a chemical process that is the addition of one molecule of water to a chemical substance. Sometimes these additions cause the chemicals and water molecules to separate into two parts. In such a reaction, a fraction of the target molecule (or parent molecule) gains a hydrogen ion. In general, there are 3 types of hydrolysis namely acid hydrolysis, salt hydrolysis and base hydrolysis. Water can act as either an acid or a base, according to the Bronsted-Lowry acid-base theory. In this case, the water molecule will release a proton. Acid hydrolysis in chemistry, is defined as a process in which prostatic acid is used to catalyze chemical bonds through nucleophilic substitution reactions, with the addition of water. Hydrolysis usually occurs when a salt of a weak acid or weak acid (or both) is dissolved in water. Water will spontaneously ionize into hydronium cations (H3O+ or commonly known as H+) and hydroxide anions (OH- single bonds). For example salt using sodium acetate then dissociates into constituent cations (Na+) and anions (CH3COO-). Sodium ions tend to remain ionic (Na+) and slightly react with hydroxide ions (OH-) while acetate ions combine with hydronium ions to produce acetic acid (CH3COOH). The net result is a relative excess of hydroxide ions and the nature of the solution to become alkaline. In addition, it is known that strong acids can also undergo hydrolysis, when sulfuric acid is dissolved in water, and the solvent is accompanied by hydrolysis to produce hydronium ions and bisulfate ions. Most of the acid hydrolysis is carried out using concentrated sulfuric acid, as for other mineral acids such as phosphoric or nitric acids. so acid-base hydrolysis is very important in life. Basically, pure water has a weak electrolyte, weak due to the lack of dissociation of hydrogen and hydroxide, but there is a balance with these two ions.

Semiotics or the science of signs (also called the study of semiotics and in the Saussurean tradition semiology) is the study of the meaning of decisions. This includes the study of signs and sign processes (semiosis), indications, designation, likeness, analogy, metaphor, symbolism, meaning, and communication. Semiotics is closely related to the field of linguistics, which, in part, studies the more specific structure and meaning of language. However, different from linguistics, semiotics also studies non-linguistic sign systems. Semiotics is divided into three branches, namely: Semiotics is often seen as having an important anthropological dimension; for example, Umberto Eco proposed that every cultural phenomenon can be studied as communication. However, some semioticians focus on the logical dimension of knowledge. They also examine areas for the life sciences – such as how organisms make predictions about, and adapt, semiotics to their niches in the world (see semiosis). In general, semiotic theories take signs or sign systems as their object of study: the communication of information in living organisms is included in biosemiotics (including zoosemiotics). Syntax is a branch of semiotics that deals with the formal properties of signs and symbols. More precisely, Syntax deals with "the rules that govern how words are combined to form phrases and sentences". Charles Morris added that semantics is concerned with the relation of signs to their designata and the objects that enable or indicate; and, pragmatics deals with the biotic aspect of semiosis, that is, with all the psychological, biological, and sociological phenomena that occur in the functioning of signs. The term semiotics comes from the Greek σημειωτικός sēmeiōtikos, "jelly marks" (from σημεῖον sēmeion, "sign, stamp") and was first used in English by Henry Stubbes in a very precise sense to denote the branch of medical science which deals with interpretation. from signs. John Locke uses the term sem(e)iotike in Book 4, Chapter 21 of An Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1690).

Semiotics is often defined as the study of signs. Everything in the world can be read as a sign. Regarding signs, they have existed since prehistoric times. There are two figures that need to be known when discussing signs in a semiotic perspective, namely Ferdinand de Saussure and Charles Sanders Pierce. Both laid the basic ideas that became the basis for the development of semiotics. For Saussure, semiotics (semiology) is the general science of signs, a science that examines the life of signs in a society. Pierce himself argues that semiotics is another form of logic, namely the formal doctrine of signs. Thus, semiotics for Saussure is part of the discipline of social psychology, while semiotics for Pierce is a branch of philosophy. In subsequent developments, semiotics was influenced by structuralism and poststructuralism through figures such as Claude Lévi-Strauss, Louis Althusser, Jacques Lacan, Michel Foucault, Jacques Derrida, Julia Kristeva, Gilles Deleuze, Félix Guattari, Umberto Eco, and Zlavoj Zizek. Semiotics is a rapidly growing object of study. While studying a form of semiotics, a new form of semiotics has emerged. This makes defining it precisely difficult. Here are three general definitions that were successfully defined by Eugene Gorny to explain it. The first definition that is often used is the science of signs or sign systems. This definition then raises the question "who can determine the difference between a sign and not a sign?" Before semiotics came into being, Augustine of Hippo was aware of the difficulty of distinguishing "things" from signs. Someone is able to know something and talk about "something" with the help of signs. Humans replace "something" with a sign adapted to "something". This is the idea of ​​the father of modern semiotics, Charles Sanders Pierce, who tries to return all "things" to "something in itself", as well as the step of carrying out sign studies in efforts to understand the human mind and its world.

Culture is a way of life that develops and is owned by a person or group of people and is passed down from generation to generation but not hereditary. Meanwhile, culture comes from Sanskrit, namely buddhayah, which is the plural form of buddhi (mind or reason), defined as matters relating to the mind and human reason. Another form of the word culture is culture which comes from the Latin cultura. Culture is a way of life that develops and is shared by a group of people, and is passed down from generation to generation. Culture is made up of many complex elements, including religious and political systems, customs, languages, tools, clothing, buildings, and works of art. Language, like culture, is an inseparable part of human beings so that many people tend to think that it is genetically inherited. One can communicate with people of different cultures and adjust for the differences between them, thus proving that culture can be learned. Culture is a whole way of life. Culture is complex, abstract, and broad. Many aspects of culture also determine communicative behavior. These socio-cultural elements are scattered and include many human social activities. Some of the reasons why people experience difficulties when communicating with people from other cultures are seen in the definition of culture: Culture is a complex set of values ​​polarized by an image that bears a view of its own privileges. This "coercive image" takes different forms in various cultures such as "crude individualism" in America, "individual harmony with nature" in Japan, and "collective obedience" in China. -its members with guidelines regarding proper behavior and defines a world of meaning and logical value that its most humble members can borrow to gain a sense of dignity and affinity with their lives.

Thus, it is culture that provides a coherent framework for organizing one's activities and enabling it to predict the behavior of others. Culture is very closely related to society. Anthropologists Melville J. Herskovits and Bronisław Malinowski argue that everything contained in society is determined by the culture that belongs to the community itself. The term for that opinion is cultural-determinism. Herskovits views culture as something that is passed down from one generation to another, which is then referred to as superorganic. Meanwhile, according to Andreas Eppink, culture contains the entire notion of social values, social norms, knowledge, as well as all social, religious, and other structures, in addition to all intellectual and artistic statements that characterize a society. According to Edward Burnett Tylor, culture is that complex whole which includes knowledge, belief, art, morals, law, customs, and any other capabilities acquired by a person as a member of society. Selo Soemardjan and Soelaiman Soemardi stated that culture is a means of creation, taste and creation of society. Meanwhile, M. Selamet Riyadi, culture is a form of love from our ancestors which is passed on to all their descendants, and according to Koentjaraningrat, culture is the entire system of ideas and actions created by humans in the context of social life that humans possess by learning. From these various definitions, it can be concluded that culture is something that will affect the level of knowledge and includes a system of ideas or ideas contained in the human mind so that in everyday life, culture is abstract. Meanwhile, cultural embodiments are objects created by humans as cultured beings, in the form of behavior, and objects that are real, for example behavior patterns, language, tools of life, social organization, religion, art, and so on. others, all of which are intended to help humans in carrying out social life.

Hangeul (한글; pronounced ˈhɑːŋɡʊl] (listen)), or Joseon-geul/Josŏn-gŭl (in North Korea) is the alphabet used to write Korean. Hangeul was created by King Sejong the Great (1397-1450) in 1443 during the Joseon Dynasty. Even though Hangeul looks like ideographic writing (writing in the form of 'symbols' like Chinese characters), Hangeul is actually a phonetic alphabet or alphabet, as each letter represents a different vowel and consonant. The Hangeul alphabet consists of 24 letters (jamo) — 14 consonants (consonants) and 10 vowels (vowels). Actually Hangeul still has 3 consonants and 1 vowel, but it's omitted. Apart from writing Korean, Hangeul is also used for the Cia-Cia language, in Southeast Sulawesi, Indonesia. Every October 9 in South Korea is celebrated as Hangeul Day. Hangeul was created by King Sejong the Great. Subsequently, in 1446, Hangeul was presented in a published form along with detailed explanatory guidelines. Sejong named the alphabet Hunminjeongeum ("The right sound to teach the people"). This alphabet is now called Hangeul which means "Han Alphabet" or "Great Alphabet". Despite being recommended by the king, not many Joseon scholars were willing to write with Hangeul. Scholars consider Hangeul to be the alphabet for women (eon-mun) because it is so easy to learn. Scholars and aristocrats who are mostly male still use hanja. Women writers known for their works in Hangeul include Shin Saimdang (1504-51), Heo Nanseolheon (1563-89) and Myeongseong(1851-95). Of the 6,000 languages ​​spoken in the world today, only 100 languages ​​have their own script, one of which is Korean, which uses the Hangeul writing system. Hangeul is the only script created by an individual based on well-planned theories and intentions.

Compared to the scripts of other nations, Hangeul is not based on a written language or imitates other scripts, but is uniquely Korean. What's more, Hangeul is a scientific writing system, based on deep linguistic knowledge and philosophical principles that make it practical, easy to learn, and beautiful in appearance. For most of its history, Koreans wrote with Chinese characters (Hanja). Because the languages ​​spoken by the two peoples come from different families, Korean cannot be accurately expressed in Chinese characters. In Chinese, sentences are marked with particles, while in Korean, endings are used to add or modify meaning. Despite the discomfort, the Korean nobility (yangban) supported the steadfast use of hanja. King Sejong was a leader as well as a scientist, and a cultural pioneer. Through years of painstaking effort, he researched the basic units of the Korean language using his own linguistic skills and finally succeeded in translating them into a script, Hunminjeongeum. An inscription in Sejong Sillok, the volume of Joseon Wangjo Sillok (Annals of Joseon) dated December 30, 25th year of Sejong's reign, reads: Based on "Explanations and Examples of Hunmin Jeongeum" (1446): the basic consonant symbols are formed systematically based on the organs of the human mouth when pronouncing some types of sound, while other consonants are formed by adding strokes to the 5 basic shapes. ㄱ · ㄴ · ㄷ · ㄹ · ㅁ · ㅂ · ㅅ · ㅇ · ㅈ ㅈ · ㅊ · ㅌ · ㅌ · ㅍ ㅎ ㅏ ㅏ · ㅓ · ㅓ · ㅗ · ㅛ · ㅜ · ㅠ · ㅡ · ㅣ ㅣ · ㄳ · ㄵ · ㄶ · ㄸ · ㄺ · ㄻ · ㄼ · ㄽ · ㄾ · ㄿ · ㅀ · ㅃ · ㅄ · ㅆ · ㅉ ㅐ · ㅒ · ㅔ · ㅖ · ㅘ · ㅙ · ㅚ· ㅢ ㅢ

Intuition is the term for the ability to understand something without going through reasoning and intellect. The word intuition comes from the Latin verb "intueri" which is translated as "to consider" or from the English, "intuit" which is "to ponder". This intuitive understanding comes instantly from another world and beyond human self-consciousness. For example, someone suddenly compelled to read a book. Apparently, in the book found the information he was looking for years. Or for example, feeling that he has to go somewhere, it turns out that there he found a big discovery that changed his life. But not all intuition comes from psychic powers. Some intuition can be used as a basis for thinking to get objective truth. One study showed that people who were in the top ranks of business or executives scored better in sixth sense test experiments than the average person. The research seems to confirm that successful people apply more psychic powers in their daily lives, which can support their success. One form of psychic ability that often appears is the ability of intuition. Not infrequently, intuition determines the decisions they make. However, many people think intuition is often considered irrational and unjustified as the main method of decision making. In fact, intuition can be true because it is the result of filtered knowledge and experience to be used as a reference for decision making. For example, some scientists claim that mathematical truth can only be obtained through intuition. Thus, now many people believe that good and sharp intuition is a requirement for someone to be successful in life. It is therefore not surprising that many books on successful tips always include sharpening intuition strategies.

Intuition is the ability to acquire knowledge without relying on conscious reasoning. Other fields use the word "intuition" in very different ways, but are not limited to direct access to unconscious knowledge; subconscious cognition; inner sensing; inner insight into subconscious pattern recognition; and the ability to understand something instinctively without the need for conscious reasoning. According to Sigmund Freud, knowledge can only be achieved through the intellectual manipulation of observations that are carried out seriously and reject ways of acquiring knowledge, such as using intuition. Thus, knowledge cannot be achieved only through intuition, but must be based on rational thinking and a scientific attitude. In the Ego Theory expressed by Carl Jung, it is defined that intuition is an 'irrational function' and perceptions obtained through the unconscious. Such as using sensory perception only as a starting point for discovering ideas, images, possibilities, and ways out of difficult situations through processes that are largely unconscious. Jung classifies several types of human psychology which are written in his book. Jung further explained that someone who predominantly uses his intuition, the "intuitive type", will act not on the basis of rational thinking but only on mere perception. Extroverted intuitive types, oriented to new possibilities that are promising even if they have not been proven true, they tend to pursue new possibilities before old efforts bear fruit, so they often make changes constantly. The introverted intuitive type is oriented towards images from the subconscious, always exploring the psychic world of archetypes, trying to understand the meaning of events, but often not interested in playing a role in these events and does not see any connection between the psychic world and himself. Jung thought that the intuitive, extroverted type was most likely to be a businessman, a speculator, or a cultural revolutionary.

Linguistik generatif · FonologiMorfologi · Sintaksis · LeksikologiSemantika · Pragmatika Linguistik komparatif · EtimologiLinguistik historis · FonetikaSosiolinguistik Linguistik kognitifLinguistik komputasiLinguistik forensikAkuisisi bahasaPenilaian bahasaPengembangan bahasaPendidikan bahasaLinguistic prescriptionAntropologi linguistikNeurolinguistikPsikolinguistikStilistika Kimia Astronomi Ilmu Bumi Ilmu kesehatan Linguistik (IPA: /liŋuistik/) atau ilmu bahasa adalah ilmu yang mempelajari tentang bahasa . Depending on the point of view and approach of a researcher, linguistics is often classified into cognitive science, psychology and anthropology. There are three broad aspects of research, which include language form, language meaning, and language in context. The earliest known activity in language descriptions has been attributed to Pāṇini around 500 BC with his analysis of Sanskrit in Ashtadhyayi. Language can be understood as an interaction of sound and meaning. The discipline that studies the sounds of language is called phonetics, which is concerned with the actual and non-sounding properties of speech sounds and how they are produced and perceived. The study of language meaning, on the other hand, is concerned with how language uses logic and real-world references to convey, process, and assign meaning and to manage and resolve ambiguity. This in turn includes the study of semantics (meanings inferred from words and concepts) and pragmatics (meanings inferred from context). There is a system of rules (known as grammar) that govern communication between members of a given speech community. Grammar is influenced by sound and meaning, including morphology (the formation and composition of words), syntax (the formation and composition of phrases and sentences from these words), and phonology (sound system). Through corpus linguistics, large chunks of text can be analyzed for the possible occurrence of particular linguistic forms and stylistic patterns in written or spoken discourse. Linguistics develops in harmony with the complexity of the object or material being studied.

In addition, the science that studies language is also open to influences and closeness to other sciences. This is what makes linguistics rich in branches of science, each of which concentrates on the type of approach to study and the object studied. The branches of linguistics include the following: Linguistics has several aspects including phonological aspects, morphological aspects, syntactic aspects, semantic aspects, and pragmatic aspects. The basic tenet of humanistic linguistics is that language is an invention created by humans. A semiotic tradition of linguistic research considers language as a sign system that arises from the interaction of meaning and form. The organization of language structure is considered computational. Linguistics is basically seen as related to the social sciences and culture because different languages ​​are formed in social interactions by speech communities. Frameworks representing the humanistic view of language include structural linguistics, among others. Structural analysis means dissecting every layer: phonetic, morphological, syntax, and discourse, down to the smallest units. These are aggregated into an inventory (e.g. phonemes, morphemes, lexical classes, types of phrases) to study their relatedness in structural hierarchies and layers. Functional analysis adds to the structural analysis of the assignment of semantic roles and other functional roles that each unit may have. For example, a noun phrase can function as the grammatical subject or object of a sentence, or as a semantic agent or patient. Functional linguistics, or functional grammar, is a branch of structural linguistics. In a humanistic context, the terms structuralism and functionalism are related to their meanings in other human sciences. The difference between formal and functional structuralism lies in their answer to the question why language has the properties it has. Functional explanation entails the notion that language is a tool for communication, or that communication is the primary function of language.

Plato (Greek: Πλάτων) (born c. 427 BC - died c. 347 BC) was a Greek philosopher and mathematician, specifically from Athens. Viewed from the perspective of the history of philosophy, Plato is classified as an Ancient Greek philosopher. He is the author of philosophical dialogues and the founder of the Platonic Academy in Athens, the first high school in the western world. Plato is believed to be a philosopher who played a major role in the development of Ancient Greek philosophy and western philosophy in general. Plato's teacher, Socrates, and Plato's student, Aristotle, also made a great contribution. Apart from being a philosopher, Plato is also known as one of the founders of western religions and spirituality. Plato's thought was developed into Neoplatonism by thinkers such as Plotinus and Porphyry. Neoplantonism had a major influence on the development of Christianity, especially influencing the thinking of Church Fathers such as Augustine. The philosopher Alfred North Whitehead even credited Plato with saying, "The safest general characterization of the European philosophical tradition is that it consists of a series of footnotes to Plato". Plato's thinking was heavily influenced by Socrates. His most famous work is The Republic (in Greek Πολιτεία or Politeia, "country") in which he outlines his views on the "ideal" state. . citation needed] One of Plato's famous parables is the parable of the man in the cave. Cicero said Plato scribend est mortuus (Plato died while writing). In the works written in his youth, Plato always displays the personality and writings of Socrates as the main topics of his essays. Almost all of Plato's works are written in a dialogue tone. In Epistle VII, Plato argues that pen and ink freeze true thought written in silent letters.

Therefore, according to him, if a thought needs to be written down, then the most suitable is writing in the form of a dialogue. Plato's most important contribution is his view of ideas. Plato's view of ideas was influenced by Socrates' view of definition. The idea meant by Plato is not the idea meant by modern people. Modern people think that ideas are ideas or responses that exist in thought alone. Reference needed] According to Plato, ideas are not created by human thought. Idea is a world that transcends humans, so ideas do not depend on human thinking, but the human mind depends on the world of ideas. Ideas are the principal and prime images of reality, immaterial, eternal and unchanging. Ideas already exist and stand alone outside of our thinking. These ideas are related to one another. For example, the idea of ​​two paintings cannot be separated from the second idea, the second idea itself cannot be separated from the even idea. However, in the end there is a peak between the highest relation of ideas. This peak is called a "beautiful" idea. This idea goes beyond all existing ideas. The sensory world is the real world which includes concrete physical objects, which can be felt by our five senses. This sensory world is nothing but a reflection or shadow of the ideal world. There are always changes in this sensory world. Everything that exists in this physical world is mortal, perishable, and mortal. The world of ideas is a world that is only open to our reason. In this world there is no change, all ideas are eternal and unchangeable. There is only one “good”, “beautiful” idea. In the world of ideas everything is so perfect.

A concept or a nggitan is an abstract, universal mental entity that refers to a category or class of an entity, event or relationship. The term concept comes from the Latin: conceptum, meaning: something that is understood. Aristotle in "The classical theory of concepts" states that concepts are: the main constituents in the formation of scientific knowledge and philosophy of human thought. The concept is an abstraction of an idea, idea, imagination or mental picture, expressed in a word or symbol. The concept is also expressed as a fractional unit of knowledge that is built from many examples of character classifications. Many examples of understanding the concept found by several experts. The concept is defined as a meaning that fulfills the requirements of a number of objects that have the same characteristics. The concept is also interpreted as an abstraction of the characteristics of something that facilitates communication between humans and allows humans to think or generate ideas. Other meanings of a concept are: a general or abstract intellectual representation of a situation, object or event, a thought, an idea or a mental image. A concept is an element of a proposition just as words are elements of a sentence. Concepts are abstract in that they removes the differences from everything in the extension, treating them as if they were identical. Concepts are universal in that they apply equally to each extension. Concepts are carriers of meaning. A single concept can be expressed in any language. Concepts can be expressed as 'Hund' in German, 'chien' in French, 'perro' in Spanish. Unfortunately, there are still many people who do not know the meaning of the concept so that it is still being questioned. The concept is something that has components, elements, characteristics that can be named. That is the definition of the concept. The concept has five elements, namely: 1.

Ethics is the concept of assessing the nature of the truth or goodness of social action based on traditions owned by individuals and groups. The formation of ethics through a process of philosophy so that ethics is part of philosophy. The main element that makes up ethics is morals. Ethics only regulates the way humans act and does not pay attention to the physical condition of humans. The scope of ethics includes the analysis and application of the concepts of right, wrong, good, bad and responsibility. The general grouping of ethics consists of descriptive ethics, normative ethics, deontological ethics, and teleological ethics. The benefit of ethics is the existence of individual self-control. which can facilitate the fulfillment of the interests of social groups. The word 'ethics' comes from the ancient Greek word ethos. In general, it means habit or good will that is permanent. Meanwhile, in the singular form, this word also has several meanings related to places or thoughts. Its meaning as a place is an ordinary place to live, a meadow, or a stable. While its meaning as a thought is habit, custom, morals, character, attitude or way of thinking. In philosophy, the meaning of ethics used is as a way of thinking. This term was used in philosophy for the first time by Aristotle (384–322 BC) to describe moral philosophy. In this sense, ethics is defined as the science of customs and habits. Ethics is a scientific discipline that aims to study morals. Apart from ethics, there are several other scientific disciplines that study morals, including anthropology, sociology, and psychology. The difference lies in the approach used in understanding morals. The approach used in ethics is a descriptive study of morality. Ethics becomes human social action as the main problem. The purpose of ethics is both descriptive and prescriptive.

Descriptive means that ethics presents observations about individual characteristics. Meanwhile, prescriptive means that ethics aims to evaluate human actions and provide recommendations or approval of human actions. The concept of ethics began to emerge among students of Pythagoras (570–496 BC) in the Greek region of the Mezzogiorno. Pythagoras' students formed a tradition that lasted two hundred years. This tradition takes the form of a statement that mathematical principles are the basis of all reality. These students believe in reincarnation where the human body acts as a tomb for the soul. The soul can only be freed from sensual attraction by doing cleansing. This form of soul cleansing is spiritual work and asceticism. This form of asceticism is primarily through philosophical and mathematical thought. Aristotle then explained the notion of ethics as a science that studies human actions. Its scope only includes procedures or habits that result in actions that are considered good or bad according to human nature. The term "ethics" has similarities and differences with several other terms, namely "ethics" and "etiquette". The similarities between the three are in terms of form and elements. Ethics is the study of ethics. While etiquette is customs, manners, and behavior in positive human relations. The similarities between ethics and etiquette are that they both discuss human behavior and regulate it. Hence, the terms ethics and etiquette are not used for animals. The difference between the two is in the condition of human behavior. Etiquette only talks about how the action is done. While ethics determines the appropriateness of a way of doing things. Etiquette also only applies to association with other people, while ethics applies to oneself and others. The nature of etiquette is relative while ethics is absolute to apply.

Quietism is a view or teaching in philosophy-theology that emphasizes the intimate relationship between humans and God through prayer. Quietism arose in France and Italy in the 17th century. In France this view or teaching was introduced by Bishop Fenelon. Meanwhile, Quietism in Italy was introduced by M. de Molinos. These two figures believe that true Christianity lies in the presence of God when one prays and meditates. The teachings of Quietism were condemned as heretical by Pope Innocent XI in 1687 through the encyclical Coelestis Pastor. The "Quietis" heresy was seen as involving false 'contemplation' through 'meditation'. Quietism first appeared in the 17th century, through a view of the works of a Roman diocesan priest, namely M. de Molinos in 1996 and the bishop of Fenelon in 1715 in France. As for after its appearance, this quietism teaching continued to develop rapidly. The teachings of Quietism were condemned as heretical by Pope Innocent XI in 1687 through the encyclical Coelestis Pastor. The figures from the teachings of Quietism are Miguel de Molinos who was condemned (considered to teach heretical teachings) by the church in 1678 and Pietro Petrucci who was condemned in 1688. In addition, there is also a French mysterious figure named Jeanne Guyon (1648-1717) , more commonly known as Madame Guyon. That said, Madame Guyon's involvement in Quietism was based on personal and family problems. Madame Guyon has conflicts with her husband and mother-in-law. The teachings of Quietism state that perfection can be achieved by means of silence, both of the mind and of the will. this state is achieved by spiritual prayers, so that the soul will rest in peace before God and God will work according to His will.

Guizhou (simplified Chinese: 贵州; traditional Chinese: 貴州; pinyin: Gùizhōu; Wade–Giles: Kuei-chou; also spelled Kweichow) is a province of the People's Republic of China located in the southwestern part of the country. The provincial capital is Guiyang. Guizhou was known to the Chinese for thousands of years but it was not until the Ming dynasty that it was under Chinese domination while it was still a province. This prompted large-scale migration from Sichuan, Hunan and the surrounding provinces to Guizhou. Numerous rebellions by the indigenous Miao population occurred throughout the Qing dynasty. That said, during the Qing dynasty every 30 years there would be a small rebellion and every 60 years there would be a major rebellion. All the rebellions that the empire could quell. Guizhou is adjacent to Sichuan Province and Chongqing Municipality to the north, Yunnan Province to the west, Guangxi Province to the south and Hunan Province to the east. The whole of Guizhou is a mountainous province but there are more hills in the west while the east and south are relatively flat. The western part of the province forms part of the Yunnan-Guizhou Plateau. Other cities include: Anshun, Kaili, Zunyi, and Qingzhen. Guizhou has a subtropical humid climate. There are slight seasonal changes. The average annual temperature is around 10-20°C, with January temperatures ranging from 1-10°C and July temperatures ranging from 17-28°C. Guizhou is a relatively poor and undeveloped province. It has a modest economy compared to coastal provinces. Its nominal GDP in 2004 was 159.2 billion yuan (US$19.75 billion). Its per capita 3568 RMB (470 USD) is the smallest in the entire People's Republic of China. Its natural industries include timber and forestry. Other important industries in the province include energy (power generation) and mining, particularly coal, limestone, arsenic, gypsum and oil shale.

Lakes, lakes, lakes, or lakes (English: lake) are water areas that are formed naturally, in the form of a very wide basin of water. A lake is a large depression on the surface of the earth that is flooded by fresh or salty water, the entire basin is surrounded by land. The average lake has a shallow depth and the water comes from various sources such as springs, groundwater, river water, and rainwater. Most lakes are fresh water and many are also located in the Northern Hemisphere at higher elevations. A periglacial lake is a lake in which a sheet of ice, or glaciers, forms in one of which the ice covers the outflow of water. The term lake is also used to describe phenomena such as Lake Eyre, where it is dry most of the time and only fills up during the rainy season. Many lakes are man-made and purposely built for the provision of hydro-electric power, recreation (swimming, windsurfing, etc.), water supply, etc. Finland is known as the "Land of a Thousand Lakes" and Minnesota is known as the "Land of Ten Thousand Lakes". The Great Lakes in North America also have ice age origins. About 60% of the world's lakes are located in Canada; This is due to the chaotic drainage system that dominates this country. On the moon there is a basalt dark area, similar to the lunar mare but smaller, called the lacus (from the Latin for "lake"). They are thought by astronomers to be lakes. Lake is a form of ecosystem that occupies a relatively small area on the surface of the earth. The area occupied by a lake is smaller than that of the sea and land. The lake has a positive impact on the people who live around the lake area.

Florida (/ˈflɒrɪdə/ (help info)) is an American state located in the southeastern United States, bordering Alabama and Georgia. The capital is Tallahassee, with the largest city being Jacksonville. This state has a population of 15,982,378 people. Florida is the 27th state to join the US. Most of Florida is a peninsula bounded by the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean. Florida is the fourth most populous state in the United States. The population center is located in Polk County, in the city of Lake Wales. In 2008, the population of Florida was estimated at 18,328,340 people. Using the latest estimates, the state is in 30th place in terms of population growth. In 2005, this state occupied the 5th position in terms of population growth, with an increase of 2.2%. There were 186,102 retired soldiers living in Florida in 2008. According to the 2000 census, the largest populations were German (11.8%), Irish (10.3%), British (9.2%), American (8%), Italian (6.3%), French (2.8%), Poland (2.7%) and Scotland (1.8%). Before the American Civil War, when slavery was legalized and also during the reconstruction period, African Americans made up half of the state's population. After that, their population numbers continued to decline over the next century as many of them moved northward during the Great Migration, and also many of the white people who moved here. Recently, the black population has been increasing again. Most of these black people live in the northern Florida areas (such as Jacksonville, Gainesville, Tallahasssee, and Pensacola), the Tampa Bay area, the Orlando area, and Sanford. Also, there is an increasing number of black people in the south Florida area, where they are immigrants from Cuba, Haiti, and Jamaica.

Multiplication (denoted by the cross symbol ×, by the centerline dot operator ⋅, by alignment, or, on a computer, by an asterisk *) is one of the four basic mathematical operations of arithmetic, the others being addition, subtraction and division. The result of the multiplication operation is called a darab. Multiplication of integers can be thought of as repeated addition; that is, the product of two numbers is the same as adding up as many copies of one of them as possible, the multiplication, as the quantity of the other, the "multiplier". These two numbers can be referred to as factors. For example, 4 times 3, written as 3×4{\displaystyle 3\times 4} and pronounced as "3 times 4", can be calculated by adding 3 copies of 4 together: So 3 (multiplier) and 4 (multiplier) is the factor, and 12 is the product. One of the main properties of multiplication is the commutative property, which states that adding 3 copies of 4 gives the same result as adding 4 copies of 3: Thus the designation of the multiplier and the multiplier does not affect the product. The multiplication of integers (including negative numbers), rational numbers (fractions) and real numbers is defined by a systematic generalization of these basic definitions. Multiplication is also visualized as counting objects arranged in a rectangle (for integers), or finding the area of ​​a rectangle whose sides have a certain length. The area of ​​a rectangle is independent of which side is measured first—a consequence of the commutative property. The product of two measurements is a new type of measurement. For example, multiplying the length of the two sides of a rectangle gives its area. The darab is the subject of dimensional analysis. The inverse operation of multiplication is division. For example, since 4 times 3 equals 12, 12 divided by 3 equals 4.

Indeed, multiplication by 3, followed by division by 3, yields a natural number. The division of any number other than 0 is by itself equal to 1. Multiplication is also defined for other types of numbers, such as complex numbers, and abstract constructs such as matrices. For some of these abstract constructs, the order in which the operands are multiplied is important. A list of the various types of products used in mathematics is given by Darab (mathematics). In arithmetic, multiplication is often written using the "×{\displaystyle \times }" sign between the terms (that is, in infix notation). For example, Code sign in Unicode at U+00D7 × multiplication sign (HTML: × ×). There is another mathematical notation for multiplication: In computer programming, the asterisk (as in 5*2) is still the most common notation. This is due to the fact that most computers have historically been limited to small character sets (such as ASCII and EBCDIC) that do not have a multiplication sign (such as ⋅ or ×), while an asterisk appears on every keyboard. This usage comes from the FORTRAN programming language. The result of the multiplication is called darab. The product of integers is the multiple of each factor. For example, 15 is the product of 3 and 5, and is a multiple of 3 and a multiple of 5. A common method for multiplying numbers using pencil and paper requires memorizing or consulting the multiplication table of small number products (usually two numbers from 0 to 9), but one method is the Ancient Egyptian multiplication algorithm|farmer's multiplication]. Multiplying numbers to more than a few decimal places by hand is tedious and error prone. Common logarithms were invented to simplify these calculations, because adding logarithms is equivalent to multiplying. Slide slides allow numbers to be multiplied quickly to about three places of accuracy. Beginning in the early 20th century, mechanical calculators, such as the Marchant, automatically multiplied to 10 numbers.

The Republic of Botswana (Setswana: Lefatshe la Botswana, English: Republic of Botswana) is a landlocked country in southern Africa. Previously this country was a protectorate of the United Kingdom called Bechuanaland. Economic ties with South Africa are very close. The main products are animal husbandry and mining. In the late 19th century, animosity began to flare between the Tswana people from Botswana and the Ndebele people who had moved to the area from the Kalahari Desert. Tensions also increased because of the Boer settlers from the Transvaal. Following pleas from the Batswana leaders Khama III, Bathoen and Sebele for assistance, on 31 March 1885 the British Government placed "Bechuanaland" under its protection. The northern area remained under direct administration as the Bechuanaland Protectorate and is now Botswana, while the southern area became part of the Cape Colony and is now the province of South Africa; the majority of Setswana speakers now live in South Africa. When the Union of South Africa was created in 1910 from the main British colony in the area, the Protectorate of Bechuanaland, Basutoland (now Lesotho), and Swaziland ("High Commission Territory") were excluded, but provision was made for their eventual merger. however, a vague measure was taken to check on the population, and although successive South African governments appeared to have called for the territory to be handed over, the British held off, and it never happened. The election of a National Party government in 1948, which promulgated apartheid, and South Africa's withdrawal from the Commonwealth in 1961, ended hopes of the territories' annexation to South Africa. An expansion of the British central government and the development of tribal governments resulted in the establishment in 1920 of 2 advisory councils representing Africans and Europeans. The proclamation in 1934 regulated tribal rule and power. A European-African advisory council was created in 1951, and the 1961 constitution established a consultative legislative council.

In June 1964, Britain agreed to a proposal for democratic self-government in Botswana. The seat of government was moved from Mafikeng in South Africa, to the newly founded Gaborone in 1965. The 1965 constitution gave rise to the first elections and independence on September 30, 1966. Seretse Khama, leader of the independence movement and legitimate claimant to the position of chairman of Ngwato, was appointed as the first president, re-elected 2 times, and died in 1980 in office. The post of president went to the Vice President, Ketumile Masire, who was elected in his own right in 1984 and re-elected in 1989 and 1994. Masire resigned from the post in 1998. Then the then Vice President, Festus Mogae, who was elected in his own right in 1999 and re-elected in 2004. Botswana is bordered by the countries of Zimbabwe, South Africa and Namibia. It is also possible to get to Botswana directly from Zambia by crossing the Zambesi River on a ferry. Botswana has no sea shores, nor lakes. It is called a landlocked country, and this means that all of Botswana's trade must be carried out by land, or by plane. The 2 most important geographical features in Botswana are the Okavango delta and the Kalahari desert. Botswana's politics take place within the framework of a presidential representative democratic republic, whereas the President of Botswana is the head of state and head of government, and a multiparty system. Executive power is exercised by the government. Legislative power is exercised by the government and Parliament of Botswana. Since independence the party that has dominated is the Botswana Democratic Party. The judicial system is independent of the executive and legislature. Botswana is divided into 9 districts: The districts are divided into 28 sub-districts. Big cities Small towns and villages During its independence, Botswana did not have an army. After the attack the Botswanan Rhodesian Army formed the Botswana Defense Force (BDF) for self-defense in 1977.

– in Europe  (green & dark gray)– in the European Union    (green) Portugal or Portugal, with the official name referred to as the Portuguese Republic (Portuguese: República Portuguesa) is a unitary state with a semi-presidential system with a constitutional republic in Southern Europe. This country is bordered by Spain in the north and east, while in the west it is bordered by the Atlantic Ocean. In addition, Portugal also has areas in Madeira, the Azores and the Selvagens Islands. Portugal claims a small area called "Olivença" which was controlled by Spain since the Congress of Vienna. The old or Latin name of this country is Lusitania. The word Portuguese (from the original word português) is often used to refer to residents or people who come from Portugal and also the language spoken by this nation. Portuguese speaking countries are often referred to as Lusophone countries. Portugal is also a developed country and a member of the European Union, joining in 1986. During the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, Portugal was a pioneer in offshore exploration, establishing the first colonial empire of global scope, with possessions in Africa, Asia, and South America, became world economic, political, and military powers. In 1580, after a "crisis of succession", it was united with Spain in the summons of the Iberian Union which would last until 1640. After the Wars of the Restoration it returned to independence under the new dynasty of Braganza, with the separation of the two crowns, and the principality. The 1755 earthquake in Lisbon, the Spanish and French invasions, the loss of its greatest overseas territorial possession, Brazil, followed by civil wars, resulted in cuts to political and economic stability, reducing Portugal's status as a global power in the nineteenth century. After the fall of the monarchy in 1910 a republic was proclaimed by starting the current system of government.

The unstable First Republic was followed by a dictatorship under the name New State. In the second half of the twentieth century, following the Portuguese colonial wars, and the Carnation Revolution coup of 1974, the dictatorship was overthrown, establishing a parliamentary democracy, with all the territories to gain independence, most notably Angola, and Mozambique in Africa, the last overseas territory, Macau, handed over to China in 1999. Portugal is a developed country, economically prosperous, socially, and politically stable, and with a very high Human Development Index. Is among the 20 countries with the best quality of life while having the lowest GDP per capita among Western European countries. He was a member of the United Nations and the European Union (at the time of his accession in 1986, EEC), and a founding member of NATO, the OECD, the eurozone (European Union) and the CPLP. Participated in various UN peacekeeping missions. Portugal is also a member of the Schengen area. Portugal is a coastal country in southwest Europe, located on the western tip of the Iberian Peninsula, bordering Spain (on its northern and eastern borders: 1,214 kilometers (754 mi) total). Portuguese territory also includes a series of islands in the Atlantic Ocean (Açores and Madeira), which are strategic islands along the North Atlantic. The southern extreme is not too far from the Strait of Gibraltar, leading to the Mediterranean Sea. In total, the country occupies an area of ​​92,090 square kilometers (35,560 square miles) of which 91,470 square kilometers (35,320 square miles) is land and 620 square kilometers (240 square miles) of water. Despite this definition, the Portugal-Spain border remains an unresolved territorial dispute between the two countries. Portugal did not recognize the border between the Caia River delta and the Ribeira de Cuncos, since the beginning of the Spanish occupation of Olivenza in 1801.

Tripoli (Arabic: طرابالس‎, Tharābulus) is the capital and largest city of Libya. Tripoli is located in the northwestern part of the country, at the very end of the Mediterranean Sea. Its population is 1,150,000 people (2003). The word "Tripoli" comes from the Greek word meaning 'three cities', which is the result of the amalgamation of the three ancient regions of Libya namely Oea, Leptis Magna and Sabratha. Tripoli is located on the western tip of Libya close to the Tunisian border, on the African continent. More than a thousand kilometers (621 Miles) separate Tripoli from Libya's second largest city, Benghazi. Coastal oases alternate with sandy areas and lagoons along the coast of Tripolitania for more than 300 km (190 mi). Tripoli has a hot semiarid (Köppen: BSh) climate with dry summers and relatively wet winters. Summers are hot with temperatures often exceeding 38 °C (100 °F); July's average temperature is between 22 and 33 °C (72 and 91 °F). In December, temperatures have dropped as low as 0°C (32°F), but averages remain between 9 and 18°C ​​(48 and 64°F). The average annual rainfall is less than 400 millimeters (16 inches). Snowfall has occurred in recent years. Rainfall can be very erratic. For example a flood in 1945 kept Tripoli underwater for several days, but two years later an unprecedented drought caused the death of thousands of head of cattle. The lack of rainfall is due to the absence of permanent rivers or streams in the city as is the case throughout the country. The Red Castle Museum (Assaraya al-Hamra) is a vast palace complex with many courtyards, located on the outskirts of Medina.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health science Criminology comes from the word crimen which means crime and logos which means science, so that criminology is the study of crime and criminal acts. Definition according to experts: There were three main schools of thought in criminological theory in the early generations, covering the period from the mid-18th century to the mid-twentieth century: These schools of thought were replaced by several contemporary criminological paradigms such as sub-culture, control, strain, labeling, critical criminology, cultural criminology, postmodern criminology, feminist criminology and so on.
