According to Muhammad Mustafa, the scope of discussion in criminology can be divided into: The basics of criminological theory, namely: It is an initial thought that was developed on the basis of irrational thinking, where a criminal behavior committed by an individual is the influence of an evil spirit (demon = Devil). Right or wrong behavior is determined by the definition of the chief or person who is considered a god. This thinking is still conventional where the most serious violation for Demonologists is to use black magic or known as black magic. The punishments used are also still traditional in nature which are aimed at expelling evil spirits within the individual, such as burning individuals who have black magic. In the explanation of classical thought, evil behavior by humans is a reflection of the concept of "free will". In an explanation of classical thinking with the concept of free will, it assumes that individuals have choices and thoughts to determine the actions they will take. The punishment applied to this thinking is general according to the crime committed. Figures in this classic thinking include Cesare Beccaria and Jeremy Bentham.

Tea (English: tea) is a drink containing caffeine, an infusion made by brewing the leaves, leaf buds, or dried stalks of the Camellia sinensis plant with hot water. Teas that come from the tea plant are divided into four groups: black tea, oolong tea, green tea, and white tea. The term "tea" is also used for drinks made from fruit, spices or other medicinal plants that are brewed, for example rosehip, chamomile, chrysanthemum and jiaogulan teas. Teas that do not contain tea leaves are called herbal teas. Tea is a natural source of caffeine, theophylline and antioxidants with nearly zero percent fat, carbohydrate or protein content. The slightly bitter taste of tea is a distinct pleasure from tea. Flower tea mixed with jasmine flower buds called jasmine tea or jasmine scented tea is the most popular type of tea in Indonesia. Tea consumption in Indonesia is 0.8 kilograms per capita per year, still far below other countries in the world, even though Indonesia is the fifth largest tea producing country in the world. China is the birthplace of tea. That's where the Chinese tea tree (Camellia sinensis) was found and originated, precisely in Yunnan province, southwestern China. Yunnan's tropical and subtropical climate, which is warm and humid, is a very suitable place for tea plants. Yunnan has many ancient forests, there are even wild tea plants that are 2,700 years old. The rest of the planted tea plants that reach the age of 800 years are also found in this place. A legend, one of the oldest forms of documentation, tells that it was Shennong who became the forerunner of agriculture and medicinal herbs, as well as the inventor of tea.

It is said in his book that he personally tried many herbal concoctions and used tea as an antidote if he was poisoned by the concoctions he tried. His life ended because he drank a poisonous concoction and did not have time to drink poison eradicating tea causing his internal organs to become inflamed. Chinese tea was originally used for medicinal ingredients (8th century BC). While the Chinese were chewing tea (770 BC–476 BC) they enjoyed the pleasant taste of the tea leaves. Tea is also often combined with various types of food and soup concoctions. During the Han Dynasty (221 BC – 8 AD), tea began to be processed using relatively simple processing (rounded, dried and stored) and made into a drink by brewing it and combining it with other ingredients (eg ginger) and this habit stuck firmly. with Chinese culture. Furthermore, tea is used as a tradition in entertaining guests. After the Ming Dynasty, many varieties of tea were discovered and added to. Later this popular tea was developed in the Canton (Guangdong) and Fukien (Fujian) regions. The habit of drinking tea spreads, even firmly attached to every level of society. In 800 AD, Lu Yu wrote a book called Ch'a Ching which defined tea. Lu Yu is an orphan who was raised by a Buddhist priest in one of the best monasteries in China. As a young man, he often struggled with the discipline of the clergy which later gave him good discernment, and his performance improved year after year. Despite this, he feels his life is empty and meaningless. After halfway through his life, he retired for 5 years to isolate himself.

A microscope (from Ancient Greek: μικρός, mikrós, "small" and σκοπεῖν, skopeîn, "to see") is a laboratory instrument used to observe very small objects and objects that are not visible to the human eye directly. The size of the image or image produced by a microscope can reach millions of times the size of the original object. The magnification produced by a microscope depends on the type of microscope used. The types of microscopes can be grouped by various categories. One way is through the methods used by the instrument to interact with the sample and generate images. For example by sending a beam of light or electrons through a sample in an optical path, and detecting the emission of photons from that sample to form an image or image, or by scanning the surface of the sample a short distance with a probe. The two types of microscopes that are often used are the optical microscope (often referred to as a light microscope) and the electron microscope. The science that studies small objects using a microscope is called microscopy. The benefit of using a microscope is being able to measure objects that cannot be measured with high accuracy by conventional measuring instruments, such as bacteria, viruses, blood cells and cells of living organisms. The microscope has a measuring scale that can coincide with the image of an object so that the size of the object can be known with certainty. Lens-like objects have been recorded as far back as 4,000 years ago, where Greek records of the optical properties of a ball filled with water (5th century BC) were continued for centuries. However, the earliest known use of a simple microscope (magnifying glass) dates back to the widespread use of lenses in spectacles in the 13th century. The earliest known example of a compound microscope (English: compound microscope), which combines an objective lens near the specimen with an eyepiece to view the real image, appeared in Europe around 1620.

Despite the many claims regarding this invention, until now the inventor of the compound microscope is still unknown. Some of the claims include the invention by Zacharias Janssen (a claim made by his son) and/or Zacharias' father, Hans Martens, in 1590, where these claims originated in Holland, in a center for the manufacture of spectacles. Another claim was made by a neighboring county that was a competitor to the spectacle maker, Hans Lippershey (the first person to patent a telescope in 1608). In addition, there are also claims that the compound microscope was invented by the expatriate Cornelis Drebbel who owned another version of this microscope in London in 1619. Galileo Galilei (also sometimes cited as the inventor of the compound microscope) allegedly invented the compound microscope after 1610 when he managed to focus his telescope on small objects, and after seeing a compound microscope built by Drebbel and shown at an exhibition in Rome in 1624, Galileo created an improved version of the microscope. Giovanni Faber gave the name "microscope" to Galileo's compound microscope which was submitted to the Accademia dei Lincei in 1625. Prior to that, Galileo called his instrument "occhiolino" or "little eye". The first detailed description of the microscopic anatomy of organic tissue based on the use of a microscope did not appear until 1644, in Giambattista Odierna's L'occhio della mosca, or The Fly's Eye. In general, the microscope was a novelty until the 1660s and 1670s when naturalists in Italy, Holland and England began using it to study biology. The Italian scientist Marcello Malpighi, who is called the father of histology by some historians of biology, began his analysis of the biological structure of the lung. The publication of Robert Hooke's Micrographia in 1665 had considerable impact, mainly because of its impressive illustrations.

Cuba, officially the Republic of Cuba (Spanish: República de Cuba) is a sovereign state consisting of the island of Cuba, Isla de la Juventud, as well as several smaller islands. Cuba is located in the northern Caribbean at the confluence of the Caribbean Sea, the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean. Cuba is a place south of Florida and the Bahamas, west of Haiti and east of Mexico. Havana is the largest city and capital; other major cities include Santiago de Cuba and Camagüey. Cuba is the largest island in the Caribbean, and the second-most populous after Hispaniola, with over 11 million inhabitants. Before Spanish colonization in the late 15th century, Cuba was inhabited by Amerindian tribes. It remained a Spanish colony until the Spanish–American War of 1898, which resulted in the Platt Amendment as a de facto United States protected area in 1902. As a fragile republic, Cuba attempted to strengthen its democratic system, but mounting political radicalization and social discord culminated in the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista in 1952. Further unrest and instability led to Batista's overthrow in January 1959 by the 26th of July Movement, which then established a government under Fidel Castro. Since 1965, the country has been governed by the Cuban Communist Party. A pawn during the Cold War between the Soviet Union and the United States, nuclear war nearly broke out during the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis. Culturally, Cuba is considered Latin America. It is a country of multiethnic people, cultures and customs of diverse origins, including the Taíno aboriginal and Ciboney peoples, a long period of Spanish colonialism, the introduction of African slaves, and close ties to the Soviet Union in the Cold War. Cuba is a Marxist–Leninist one-party state, in which the role of the Communist Party is enshrined in the Constitution.

Independent observers accuse the Cuban government of human rights abuses, including arbitrary imprisonment and torture. Cuba is a developed country with a planned economy dominated by exports of sugar, tobacco, coffee and skilled labour. Ranks highly on several national performance metrics, including health care and education. Cuba was first visited by Europeans when Christopher Columbus first landed on October 28, 1492, at the eastern tip of Cuba, in Cazigazgo, Baracoa area. Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar led the Spanish invasion, subdued the native population, became governor of Cuba for Spain in 1511 and built a villa in Baracoa, which became the island's first capital. In 1518 it became the seat of the Diocese of the first bishop of Cuba. At that time Cuba was inhabited by at least two different indigenous peoples: the Taíno and the Siboney. Both of these peoples had a prehistoric Neolithic culture, and perhaps also a Bronze Age culture. Some scholars feel it necessary to distinguish the Taíno from the new Taíno from Cuba, Lucaya from the Bahamas, Jamaica, and to some extent from Haiti and Quisqueya (roughly the present-day Dominican Republic), because the new Taíno had much more cultural input. the diversity and heterogeneity of peoples and ethnicities far greater than the true high Taíno of Boriquen (Puerto Rico). Most of the population of Cuba from pre-Columbian times, including the Siboney people, can at first be classified in the general group of the new Taíno. The Taínos were skilled farmers and the Siboneys were a hunter-gatherer society with little agriculture to support it. The Taínos and Siboney peoples share similar customs and beliefs, namely sacred rituals are practiced using a tobacco called cohoba, or "smoking".

Protists are eukaryotic microorganisms that are not animals, plants, or fungi. They were once grouped into a single kingdom called the protista, but now it is no longer maintained. It is still used for ecological and morphological studies for all single-celled eukaryotic organisms that live independently or, if forming colonies, together but do not show differentiation into distinct tissues. From a taxonomic point of view, this grouping was abandoned because it is paraphyletic. The organisms in the Protista have nothing in common, except for an easy grouping—either single-celled or multi-celled with no tissues. Protists live in almost any environment that contains water. Most protist members come from protozoa and algae. Many protists, such as algae, are photosynthetic and vital primary producers in ecosystems, particularly in the ocean as part of the plankton. Other protists, such as Kinetoplastid and Apicomplexa, are dangerous diseases for humans, such as malaria and trypanosomiasis. Protists were first proposed by Ernst Haeckel. Traditionally, protists are classified into several groups based on their similarity to a higher kingdom, which include Protozoa which resemble single-celled animals, Protophyta which resemble plants (the majority of single-celled algae), as well as slime molds and water molds which resemble mushrooms. In the past, bacteria and sponges were also considered as protists in the three kingdom system (Animalia, Plantae including fungi, and Protista). But then bacteria separated from protists after it was discovered that they were prokaryotes. Meanwhile, sponges are separated from protists because they have larval stages. In 1878, 10 taxa namely, Monera, Lobosa (Amoebina), Gregarinae, Flagellata, Catallacta (eg, Synura), Ciliata, Acinetae (Suctoria, a group of ciliates), Labyrinthuleae (a peculiargroup with bloodoid cells that form ectoplasmic tissues) , Bacillariae (diatoms), Fungi, Myxomycetes, Thalomorpha (Rhizopoda), Heliozoa ("sunanimalcules"), and Radiolaria belong to the kingdom of protista.

Protozoa are almost all single-celled, mobile protists that feed by phagocytosis, although there are some exceptions. They are usually 0.01-0.5 mm in size and are generally too small to be seen without the aid of a microscope. Protozoa cell shape varies greatly, some are fixed and some are changing. In general, protozoa can move actively because they have locomotion in the form of pseudopodia, whip feathers (flagellum), vibrating feathers (cilia), but some do not have locomotion. Protozoa mostly reproduce asexually by binary fission. Some other Protozoa perform sexual reproduction by the union of generative cells (gamete cells) or by the union of the vegetative cell nucleus. Sexual reproduction by fusion of the vegetative nuclei is called conjugation. Some protozoa are holozoic, holophytic and saprozoic. Holozoic means eating organisms that are smaller than their body size. Holophytic means able to produce their own food through the process of photosynthesis. The saprozoik means eating dead organisms that have decayed. The way of life of protozoa is solitary, some are colonies. If environmental conditions are unfavorable, protozoa can protect themselves by forming cysts. If the environment returns to normal, the protozoa will become active again. In obtaining protozoa there are parasites, saprophytes, and free living. Most protozoa develop in life stages in the form of trophozoites and cysts. The system is a form of protozoa life that experiences environmental conditions that are less conducive to protozoa life, such as the availability of food, high temperatures and lack of water (dry). In the form of a system, protozoa can survive and develop outside their living media. Protoza can be found everywhere, such as aqueous environments and soil, generally able to survive dry periods as cysts (cyst?)

Oman (/oʊˈmɑːn/ ( listen) oh-MAHN; Arabic: عمان‎ ʻUmān), officially the Sultanate of Oman (Arabic: سلطنة عُمان‎ Salṭanat ʻUmān, Arabic pronunciation: sal.tˤa.na ʕu.maːn]), is a an Arab country in Southwest Asia on the southeastern coast of the Arabian Peninsula. Oman is bordered by the United Arab Emirates (UAE) to the northwest, Saudi Arabia to the west, and Yemen to the southwest. The coast is formed by the Arabian Sea to the southeast and the Gulf of Oman to the northeast. The Madha and Musandam enclaves are surrounded by the UAE on its land borders, with the Strait of Hormuz and the Gulf of Oman forming Musandam's coastal boundaries. For a period, Oman was a moderate regional power, having had an empire across the Strait of Hormuz to Iran, and into what is now Pakistan, and as far south as Zanzibar on Africa's southeastern coast. Times changed, its power weakened, the sultanate came under strong British influence, although Oman was never officially part of the British Empire, nor was it a British protectorate. Oman has been ruled by the Al Said dynasty since 1744, and has long enjoyed military and political ties with the United Kingdom and the United States, although Oman maintains an independent foreign policy. Oman is an absolute monarchy, in which the Sultan of Oman exercises plenary powers, although parliament has some legislative and oversight powers. In November 2010, the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) stated that Oman, among 135 countries worldwide, was the country that had improved the most in the last 40 years. According to international indices, Oman is one of the most developed and stable countries in the Arab World. Oman is located east to southeast of the Arabian Peninsula, sharing land borders with the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia and the Republic of Yemen.

To the northeast and southeast, the country faces the Gulf of Oman and the Arabian Sea. Most of Oman is made up of dry desert with humid coastal areas and hot, dry interior land. Central Oman is almost entirely a nearly flat desert, while to the north and south there are rocky mountains that border it with the coast. Oman has a hot desert climate and very little rainfall – which makes the interior of Oman almost uninhabited – so pockets of the population are more widely scattered around the coast. Annual rainfall in Muscat averages 100 mm (3.9 in), mostly in January. Dhofar is subject to the southwest monsoon, and up to 640 mm (25.2 in) of rain has been recorded in the rainy season from late June to October. While the mountainous areas receive more rainfall, some parts of the coast, especially near the island of Masirah, sometimes receive no rain at all during the year. It is generally very hot, with temperatures reaching around 50 °C (122.0 °F) (peak) in summer, from May to September. Oman has natural resources in the form of petroleum, copper, asbestos, limited marble, limestone, chromium, gypsum and natural gas. As of 28 October 2011, Oman is divided into eleven governorates (muhafazah): Under governorates, Oman is divided into provinces (wilayat). Muscat Fortress (built by the Portuguese in the 16th century) facing Muscat Harbour, Mutrah and Al Alam Palace Unusual long beach, with a steep cliff in the middle, Muscat City street gate entering Muscat Heavy rains can last for days in Oman Ruwi – Muscat trade center including market – Ruwi Highway Bullfighting in Oman Afghanistan · Albania · Algeria · Saudi Arabia · Azerbaijan · Bahrain · Bangladesh · Benin · Brunei · Burkina Faso · Chad · Gabon · Gambia · Guinea · Guinea Bissau · Guyana · Indonesia Iraq Senegal Sierra Leone Somalia Somalia Sudan Syria Syria Suriname Tajikistan Togo Tunisia Turkey Turkmenistan Uganda United Arab Emirates Uzbekistan Yemen Yemen This Middle East-related article is a stub.

An Empire (also known as an Overlordship or Empire) is a grand political entity covering a large geographical area, comprising many nations, tribes, and peoples, which are united and ruled by a monarchy (emperor), or by some form of oligarchic government. From a geopolitical point of view, the term empire has different interpretations, ranging from an extreme territorial state on the strongest side, to a state that is only a union of several city-states on its weakest side. The term Maharajaan was known for the first time in history and the Indonesian language was derived from the influence of ancient India, namely Sanskrit; Maharaja, i.e. "King above Kings"; hence the term Maharajaan refers to a great Kingdom which is in charge of many other kingdoms. Great empires such as Sriwijaya and Majapahit are known in Indonesian history. Another term comes from European influence, namely Imperium which comes from the Latin meaning "strength" or "authority". Another term Empire derived from the name of Caesar, the ruler of the Roman Empire. Etymologically, the use of the term "empire" denotes a powerful centralized nation-state, but in looser usage it also refers to large-scale transnational corporations. The political structure of an empire was constructed in two ways: (i) as a territorial empire by direct conquest by force (direct physical action to fulfill the emperor's ambitions), and (ii) as a coercive hegemonic empire, by indirect conquest through the control of power (the perception that the emperor can impose his will). The first concept provides for greater powers and direct political control, but limits further development by absorbing military power within a given garrison. The second concept provides for less power and indirect control, but allows military power to expand further. Territorial empires (examples: the Mongol Empire, and the Persian Empire) tended to be territorial in nature.

The term empire also refers to maritime empires or thalassocracies, (examples: the Delian League and the British Empire) with a looser structure and more dispersed territories. The Akkadian empire, led by Sargon the Great (24th century BC), was one of the earliest major empires. In the 15th century BC, the New Kingdom of Ancient Egypt under Thutmosis III was the earliest empire in Africa that united Nubia and the city-states of the Levant. The earliest empire comparable to the Roman Empire was the Assyrian Empire (2000–612 BC). One of the most successful empires was the vast and multi-cultural Persian Empire, the Achaemenid Empire (550–330 BC), which absorbed Mesopotamia, Egypt, parts of Greece, Thrasia, and most of the Middle East, central Asia, and northwestern India (now Pakistan). The Mauryan Empire was the most geographically extensive and powerful empire in ancient India, ruled by the Mauryan dynasty from 321 to 185 BC. The Roman Empire was the most extensive western empire until the modern period. Formerly the Macedonian kingdom under Alexander the Great became a vast empire stretching from Greece to northwestern India. After Alexander the Great's death, his empire split into four empires, all of which are commonly called the Hellenistic Empires. In the east, the Persian Empire refers to the empire built by the Iranian nation which spans various periods from the pre-Islamic period to the post-Islamic period. In East Asia various celestial empires rose and fell periodically in China, interspersed with periods of civil war, and foreign conquests. In India Chandragupta expanded the Mauryan Empire into northwestern India (now Pakistan and Afghanistan). Likewise the development of Buddhism under the influence of Ashoka the Great. In China the Han dynasty became one of Asia's longest-lived empires, following on from the short-lived Qin dynasty, but which first unified China.

Mercury (old name: mercury) or mercury or hydrargyrum (Latin: Hydrargyrum, water/liquid silver) is a chemical element in the periodic table with the symbol Hg and atomic number 80. This transition metal group element is silvery in color and is one of the five elements (along with cesium, francium, gallium, and bromine) which are liquid at room temperature, and evaporate easily. Hg will solidify at a pressure of 7,640 Atm. The abundance of Hg on earth ranks 67th among other elements in the earth's crust. In nature, mercury (Hg) is found in the form of elemental mercury (Hg0), monovalent mercury (Hg1+), and bivalent (Hg2+). they are the most brittle of metals. Mercury is widely used as an ingredient in dental amalgams, thermometers, barometers, and other scientific equipment, although its use as a filler for thermometers has been replaced (by alcohol, digital, or thermistor thermometers) for reasons of health and safety due to its toxic properties. it is obtained primarily by the reduction process from the mineral cinnabar. [citation needed] Its high density causes objects such as billiard balls to float when placed in liquid mercury with only 20 percent of their volume submerged. The oldest archaeological evidence of the use of mercury has been found in an Ancient Egyptian burial dated to 1500 BC. Records and findings from various ancient civilizations also mention the use of mercury. In China and Tibet, mercury is considered efficacious for prolonging life, treating fractures and maintaining health, although in reality it is reversed because mercury vapor is very toxic. The first emperor of unified China, Qín Shǐ Huáng Dì, reportedly died from drinking mercury mixed with jade powder which was considered a longevity elixir. Aristotle mentions that Daedalus made a wooden statue of the goddess Venus to appear to move by pouring mercury inside.

The Ancient Greeks, Ancient Egyptians, and Ancient Romans used cinnabar (mercury sulfide) as a spread or cosmetic mixture. The alchemists believed that mercury was a prima materia (starting element) from which all metals were born. Mercury is believed to be able to form other metals by adjusting the quality and quantity of sulfur mixed with mercury. The purest alloys form gold, and it was the main goal of many alchemists to make gold from mercury. Around 500 BC mercury was used as an amalgam (metal mixture). In Lamanai, which was once the main city of the Mayan culture, a remains of a mercury pool was found under a field. In November 2014 large quantities of mercury were found in a chamber located 20 meters deep beneath a pyramid named "Temple of the Feathered Serpent", the third largest structure left in Teotihuacan, Mexico, together with "a jade statue, jaguar remains, and a box containing carved shells and rubber balls". Mercury mines at Almadén (Spain), Monte Amiata (Italy), and Idrija (now in Slovenia) dominated mercury production from their opening 2500 years ago, until new deposits were discovered in the late 19th century. Naturally, Hg pollution comes from volcanic activity or seepage of groundwater that passes through Hg deposits. Reference is needed] When it enters the waters, mercury easily binds with chlorine in seawater and forms HgCl bonds. Reference is needed] In the form In this case, Hg easily enters the plankton and can move to other marine biota. References needed] Inorganic mercury (HgCl) will turn into organic mercury (methylmercury) by the role of microorganisms that occur in bottom sediments. References needed] Mercury can also be compounded with carbon to form organo-mercury compounds. citation needed] The most common organo-mercury compound is methyl mercury produced by microorganisms in water and soil. citation needed] Microorganisms are then ingested by fish so that the concentration of mercury in fish increases. citation needed] Methyl Hg has a high solubility in the bodies of aquatic animals so that Hg accumulates through bioaccumulation and biomagnification processes in tissues n the body of aquatic animals, due to the uptake of Hg by aquatic organisms which is faster than the excretion process.

–  in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) France (French: France, fʁɑ̃s]), officially known as the French Republic (French: République française, ʁepyblik fʁɑ̃sɛz]), is a country that its metropolitan territory is located in Western Europe and also includes various overseas islands and territories located on other continents. The country is bordered by Belgium, Luxembourg, Germany, Switzerland, Italy, Monaco, Andorra and Spain. Due to its overseas departments, France also shares land borders with Brazil and Suriname (bordering French Guiana), and Sint Maarten (bordering Saint-Martin). France is also connected to the United Kingdom by the Channel Tunnel, which runs under the English Channel. This metropolitan country extends from the Mediterranean Sea to the English Channel and the North Sea, and from the Rhine to the Atlantic Ocean. French citizens often refer to Metropolitan France as "L'Hexagone" ("Hexagon") because of the geometric shape of its territory. France is a Constitutional Republic country. Its main ideology is embodied in the Declaration on the Rights of Man and the Citizen and the hard-line Secular. France has been one of the world's greatest powers since the mid-17th century. In the 18th and 19th centuries, France created one of the largest colonial empires of its time, stretching across West Africa and Southeast Asia, influencing the culture and politics of the region. France is a developed country, with the sixth (nominal GDP) or eighth (PPP) largest economy in the world. It is the most visited country in the world, receiving 82 million foreign tourists per year (including business travelers, but excluding those staying less than 24 hours in France). France is a founding member of the European Union, and has the largest area of ​​any member. France is also a founding nation of the United Nations, and a member of the Francophonie, G8, NATO and the Latin Union.

It is one of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, as well as a major nuclear power with 360 active warheads and 59 nuclear power plants. The name "France" comes from the Latin Francia, meaning "land of the Franks" or "Frankland". There are various theories about the origin of the name Frank. One is from the Proto-Germanic word frankon which means javelin or lance because of the Frankish throwing ax known as francisca. Another etymology is that in an Old Germanic language, Frank meant "free" referring to slaves. It was still used in French as franc, also being used as a translation of "Frank" and the name of the local currency, until the use of the euro in the 2000s. In German, France is still called Frankreich, which means "Kingdom of the Franks". To differentiate it from Charlemagne's Frankish Empire, Modern France is called Frankreich, while the Frankish Empire is called Frankenreich. The word "Frank" was used from the fall of Rome through the Middle Ages, from Hugh Capet's accession as "King of the Franks" ("Rex Francorium") to normally referring to the Kingdom of Francia, which later became France. The Capetian kings descended from the Robertine, who had two Frankish kings, and previously held the title "Dux Francorum". The Frankish lands covered most of modern Northern France but as royal power was weakened by the regional princes this designation was later assigned to the royal demesne as shorthand. Until finally this name was taken for the whole Kingdom as the central power was set for the whole kingdom. The borders of modern France are the same as those of ancient Gaul, which was inhabited by Celtic Gauls. Gaul was ruled for Rome by Julius Caesar in the 1st century BC, and Gaul adopted Roman (Latin, from which French developed) and Roman culture.

In chemistry, a nonmetal is a chemical element that generally does not have predominantly metallic properties; they range from colorless gases (such as hydrogen) to shiny solids with high melting points (such as boron). Electrons in non-metals behave differently than electrons in metals. With a few exceptions, nonmetals stay in place, so they are usually poor conductors of heat and electricity and are brittle when solid. Electrons in metals generally move freely and this is why metals are good conductors and most are easily flattened into sheets and pulled into wires. Nonmetal atoms have moderate to high electronegativity; they tend to withdraw electrons in chemical reactions and form acidic compounds. Two nonmetals, hydrogen and helium, make up about 99% of the ordinary matter in the observable universe by mass. The five non-metallic elements, hydrogen, carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and silicon, largely make up the Earth's crust, atmosphere, oceans, and biosphere. Most nonmetals have biological, technological, or domestic roles or uses. Living organisms are composed almost entirely of hydrogen, oxygen, carbon, and nitrogen. Nearly all nonmetals have specific uses in medicine and pharmaceuticals; lighting and lasers; as well as household items. Although the term nonmetal dates back at least to 1566, there is no single, widely agreed upon definition of nonmetal. Some elements have a marked mixture of metallic and non-metallic properties; which of these limit cases count as a nonmetal may vary depending on the classification criteria. Fourteen elements are effectively always identified as nonmetals, and up to about nine more elements are occasionally added, as shown in the accompanying periodic table extract. A nonmetal is a chemical element that has, among other properties, a relatively low density and moderate to high electronegativity.

In general, they lack more metal attributes, such as luster, deformability, good thermal and electrical conductivity, and low electronegativity. Since there is no precise definition of a nonmetal, some variation may be found among sources as to which elements are classified as nonmetals. The decisions involved depend on which property or properties are considered most indicative of non-metallic or metallic character. Although Steudel, as of 2020, recognizes twenty-three elements as nonmetals, such a list is open to challenge. The fourteen elements that are effectively always recognized as non-metals are hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur; the halogens which are corrosive to fluorine, chlorine, bromine, and iodine; and the noble gases helium, neon, argon, krypton, xenon, and radon; see e.g. Larrañaga et al. Although the same authors recognize carbon, phosphorus and selenium as nonmetals, Vernon has previously reported that these three elements are sometimes counted as metalloids. The elements commonly known as metalloids are boron; silicon and germanium; arsenic and antimony; and tellurium is sometimes counted as an intermediate class between a metal and a non-metal when the criteria used to distinguish between a metal and a non-metal are inconclusive. Other times they are counted as nonmetals based on their nonmetallic chemical properties. Of the 118 known elements, the 23 that can be considered non-metals are several times outnumbered by metals. Astatine, the fifth halogen, is often overlooked because of its rarity and intense radioactivity; theory and experimental evidence suggest that it is a metal. The superheavy elements copernium (Z = 112), flerovium (114), and oganesson (118) can turn into non-metals; their actual status has not been confirmed. Outwardly, about half of the nonmetallic elements are colored or colorless gases; most of the rest are shiny solids.

Mammals or mammals (from the Latin mamma, 'breast') are a class of vertebrate animals characterized by the presence of mammary glands (which in female animals produce milk as a food source for their young), neocortex, hair, and three bones in the middle ear. These characteristics set them apart from reptiles and birds, whose genetic divergence occurred in the Carboniferous period, more than 300 million years ago. About 6,400 surviving mammal species have been described. The largest order in mammals is Rodentia (rodents), Chiroptera (bats), and Eulipotyphla (porcupines, moles, shrews, and so on). The next three largest orders are the Primates (including humans, apes, monkeys, etc.), Artiodactyla (animals with even nails, including Cetacea), and Carnivora (cats, dogs, seals, and others). In cladistics, which reflect evolutionary history, mammals are the only surviving members of the Synapsids. Synapsida and Sauropsida (reptiles and birds) are included in the larger clade Amniota. The early ancestors of Synapsid mammals were Sphenacodontia under Pelycosauria, the group which also includes the nonmammalian Dimetrodon. At the end of the Carboniferous period about 300 million years ago, mammals branched off from the Sauropsida line that led to today's reptiles and birds. The lineage following the stem group sphenacodontia split into several diverse nonmammalian Synapsid groups—sometimes incorrectly referred to as mammal-like reptiles—before giving rise to the Therapsids in the Early Permian period. Mammals descended from Cynodontia, an advanced group of Therapsids, during the Late Triassic. The modern mammalian order emerged in the Paleogene and Neogene periods of the Cenozoic era after the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs. Since 66 million years ago, mammals have been the dominant land animal group today. The basic body type of mammals is quadrupedal and most mammals use all four of their extremities for ground locomotion.

However, some mammals have limbs adapted for life in the sea, in the air, in trees, underground, or for walking on two legs. Mammals range in size from the 30–40 mm (1.2–1.6 in) Craseonycteridae bat to the 30 m (98 ft) blue whale—perhaps the largest animal that has ever lived. The maximum lifespan of mammals varies from two years in shrews to 211 years in bowhead whales. All modern mammals give birth to live young, except for five species of monotremes, which are egg-laying mammals. Placentalia are a group of mammals with many species. They have a placenta to feed the fetus during gestation. The majority of mammals are intelligent creatures, and some mammals have large brains, are self-aware and capable of using tools. Mammals can communicate and vocalize in a number of ways, including generating ultrasonics, scent marking, giving alarm signals, singing, and using echolocation. Mammals can organize themselves into fission-fusion groups, harems, and hierarchies, but they can also be solitary and territorial. Most mammals are polygynous, but some mammals can be monogamous or polyandry. The domestication of various types of mammals by humans played a major role in the Neolithic Revolution, which saw humans change from hunting and gathering to farming for the main food source. This led to a major restructuring of human society from nomadic to sedentary and forming more cooperation among larger and then larger groups, eventually developing civilizations. Domestic mammals provide energy for transportation and agriculture, are a source of food (meat and dairy products), and are used for their hair and skin. Mammals are also hunted and contested in sports, and are used as model organisms in science.

Extremophiles (from the Latin extremus meaning "extreme" and the Greek philiā (φιλία) meaning "love") are microbes that prefer extreme habitat environments for their survival. These microbes simply cannot thrive in an environment in which most other living things can live comfortably. For example, hyperthermophiles have enzymes that are very stable and can only react at high temperatures. Such enzymes are ideal for industrial reaction processes. Enzymes that are not damaged when reacted and are durable at high temperatures are indispensable for the food or beverage industry. In the 1980s and 1990s, biologists discovered that microbial life has great flexibility to survive in extreme environments — acidic or very hot niches, for example — that would be completely inhospitable to complex organisms. Some scientists have even concluded that life may have started on Earth in hydrothermal vents deep beneath the surface of the ocean. According to astrophysicist Steinn Sigurdsson, "There are bacterial spores found that are 40 million years old on Earth — and we know they are highly resistant to radiation." Some of the bacteria were found living in the cold and dark conditions in a lake buried half a mile under ice in Antarctica, and in the Maria Trench, the deepest place in Earth's oceans. Some microorganisms have been found thriving in rock up to 1,900 feet (580 m) beneath the ocean floor to a depth of 2,600 m off the northwest coast of the United States. According to one researcher, "You can find microbes everywhere—they are very adaptable to conditions, and survive wherever they are."

The key to the adaptation of extremophiles is their amino acid composition, which influences their protein folding ability under certain conditions. Studying the extreme environments on Earth can help researchers understand the limits of habitability on other worlds. Tom Gheysens of the University of Ghent in Belgium and colleagues have presented research findings showing that spores of a species of Bacillus bacteria survive and are viable after being heated to 420°C (788°F). Extremophiles have a variety of species and habitats that vary from very low temperatures to very high or very acidic environments. The types include: Organisms with optimal growth at a pH level of 3.0 or below. Organisms that grow optimally at a pH level of 9.0 or greater. Organisms that live in microscopic spaces in rock, such as the pores between aggregate grains. These organisms may also be called endoliths, a term that also includes organisms that fill fissures, aquifers, and faults filled with groundwater beneath the deep surface. Organisms that grow optimally at a dissolved salt concentration of 50 g/L (= 5% m/v) or more. Organisms that grow optimally at temperatures above 80°C (176°F). Organisms that live under rocks in a cold desert. Able to tolerate high levels of dissolved heavy metals in solution, such as copper, cadmium, arsenic, and zinc. Examples include Ferroplasma sp., Cupriavidus metallidurans and GFAJ-1. An organism with optimal growth in a nutrient-limited environment. Organisms with optimal growth in environments with high sugar concentrations. Organisms with optimal growth in hydrostatic pressures above 10 MPa (= 99 atm = 1,450 psi). Also known as barophil. Organisms that qualify as extremophiles in more than one category.

Iron is a chemical element with the symbol Fe (from Latin: ferrum) and atomic number 26. Iron is a metal in the first transition series. Iron is the most common element on Earth by mass, making up most of Earth's outer and inner core. Iron is the fourth most abundant element in the earth's crust. Its abundance in rocky planets such as Earth is due to the abundance of production due to fusion reactions in high-mass stars, where production of nickel-56 (which decays into the most common isotope of iron) is the last exothermic nuclear fusion reaction. As a result, radioactive nickel was the last element to be produced before the violent supernova collapse. The collapse scattered iron radionuclide precursors into space. Like the other group 8 elements, iron exists in a wide range of oxidation states, −2 to +6, although +2 and +3 are the most common. Elemental iron occurs in meteorites and other low-oxygen environments, but is reactive with oxygen and water. The surface of fresh iron appears shiny silvery-gray, but it oxidizes in normal air to produce hydrated iron oxide, known as rust. Unlike other metals which form a passivation oxide layer, iron oxide takes up more space than the metal itself and then flakes off, exposing the fresh surface to corrosion. Ferrous metal has been used since ancient times, although copper alloys, which have a lower melting point, were used earlier in human history. Pure iron is relatively soft, but cannot be obtained through smelting. This material hardens and is strengthened significantly by impurities, particularly carbon, from the smelting process. A certain proportion of carbon (between 0.002% and 2.1%) produces steel, which is harder than pure iron, perhaps up to 1000 times.

Crude ferrous metal is produced in blast furnaces, where the ore is reduced with coal into pig iron, which has a high carbon content. Further processing with oxygen reduces the carbon content so that it reaches the correct proportions for steelmaking. Low carbon iron steels and alloys along with other metals (alloy steels) are by far the most commonly used metals in industry, due to the wide range of properties acquired and the abundance of iron-containing rocks. Iron chemical compounds have many benefits. Iron oxide mixed with aluminum powder can be ignited to make the thermite reaction, which is used in welding and ore refining. Iron forms binary compounds with the halogens and chalogens. Its organometallic compounds include ferrocene, the first sandwich compound to be discovered. Iron plays an important role in biology, forming complexes with molecular oxygen in hemoglobin and myoglobin; these two compounds are oxygen-transporting proteins in vertebrates. Iron is also a metal in the active site of most redox enzymes that play a role in cellular respiration and oxidation and reduction in plants and animals. The mechanical properties of iron and its alloys can be evaluated using a variety of tests, including the Brinell test, Rockwell test and Vickers hardness test. The data on iron is so consistent that it is often used for equipment calibration or comparison tests. However, the mechanical properties of iron are greatly affected by the purity of the sample: single crystalline pure iron for research purposes is in fact softer than aluminum, and the purest industrially produced iron (99.99%) has a hardness of 20–30 Brinell. An increase in the carbon content of iron will cause a significant increase in hardness and tensile strength. The maximum hardness of 65 Rc is achieved with a carbon content of 0.6%, although this procedure is for low tensile metals. Because of its significance for planetary cores, the physical properties of iron at high pressures and temperatures have also been studied extensively.

Intervention is a form of action that often occurs in certain relationships. Often interventions are steps intended to make things better. But, interventions can also be intended for negative purposes. Intervention is also a term related to political, economic, social and cultural affairs. In politics, intervention is a measure used to interfere in state affairs. Intervention is a familiar term in international relations. In addition, intervention is a term that is also used in various fields. This includes the economy, military, law, health, and psychology. Intervention is a term that is often referred to as interference or interference. According to KBBI, intervention is interference in a dispute between two parties. This action can happen to people, groups, countries, and so on. Intervention comes from the Latin intervenire, which means "to be present between or to interrupt". According to the Cambridge Dictonary, intervention is the act of deliberately getting involved in a difficult situation, to improve it or prevent it from getting worse. According to Merriam Webster, intervention is the act of entering into the outcome or direction especially of a condition or process to prevent harm or improve function. An intervention includes one thing among others, such as a person trying to help. Often interventions are meant to make things better. But, intervention can also be considered a detrimental action. The interference of other parties or intervention in a problem that is not their problem aims to help the party's problems to be resolved. But interventions can also aim to benefit from other people's problems. State intervention can have a positive (good) or negative (bad) impact according to its purpose, as follows: Intervention is a form of propaganda or other activities carried out by a country with the aim of encouraging a revolution or civil war in another country.

Nitrogen is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol N and atomic number 7. This element, also known as nitrogen, was first discovered and isolated by the Scottish physician Daniel Rutherford in 1772. Although Carl Wilhelm Scheele and Henry Cavendish separately had doing the same thing around the same time, Rutherford was generally fit to receive the award because his work was published first. The name nitrogen was suggested by Jean-Antoine-Claude Chaptal in 1790, when he discovered that nitrogen is present in nitric and nitric acids; the name is derived from the Greek: νἰτρον "nitre" and -γεννᾶν "to form". Antoine Lavoisier instead suggested the name azote, from the Greek άζωτικός "non-living", because the element is an asphyxiant gas; Lavoisier's proposed name is instead used in many languages, such as French, Russian, and Turkish, and appears in two English names for several nitrogen compounds such as hydrazine, azide and azo. Nitrogen is the lightest member of group 15 of the periodic table, and is often called a pnictogen. The name comes from the Greek πνίγειν "to choke", referring directly to the asphyxiating properties of nitrogen. Nitrogen is a common element in the universe, estimated to be 7th in total abundance in the Milky Way galaxy and the Solar System. At standard temperature and pressure, two atoms of the element bond to form dinitrogen, a colorless and odorless diatomic gas with the chemical formula N2. Dinitrogen makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere, making it the most abundant element on its own. Nitrogen is present in all organisms, especially in amino acids (and of course proteins), in nucleic acids (DNA and RNA) and in the energy transfer molecule adenosine triphosphate (ATP).

The human body contains about 3% nitrogen (by mass), and is the 4th most abundant element in the body after oxygen, carbon and hydrogen. The nitrogen cycle describes the movement of elements from the air, into the biosphere and organic compounds, and then back into the atmosphere. Many compounds of industrial importance, such as ammonia, nitric acid, organic nitrates (propellants and explosives), and cyanides, contain nitrogen. The very strong triple bond in elementary nitrogen (N≡N), the second strongest bond in diatomic molecules after carbon monoxide (CO), dominates nitrogen chemistry. This causes difficulties for both organisms and industry in converting N2 into useful compounds, but at the same time, burning, detonating, or decomposing nitrogen compounds to form nitrogen gas releases large amounts of energy which are often beneficial. Synthetic ammonia and nitrates are the main industrial fertilizers, and nitrate fertilizers are the main pollutants in the eutrophication of water systems. Apart from its use as a fertilizer and energy storage, nitrogen is a constituent of many organic compounds such as Kevlar which is used in high tenacity fabrics and cyanoacrylate which is used in superglue. Nitrogen is a constituent of all major pharmacological drug classes, including antibiotics. Many drugs or prodrugs mimic natural nitrogen-containing signaling molecules: for example, the organic nitrates nitroglycerin and nitroprusside control blood pressure by metabolizing them to nitrous monoxide. Many important nitrogen-containing drugs, such as caffeine and natural morphine or synthetic amphetamine, act as receptor neurotransmitters in animals. Nitrogen compounds have a long history, ammonium chloride was known by Herodotus. They were famous in the Middle Ages. Alchemists knew nitric acid as aqua fortis (strong water), as well as other nitrogenous compounds such as ammonium salts and nitrate salts.

Integral is a concept of continuous addition in mathematics. The integral and its inverse, differentiation, are the main operations in calculus. The integral was developed following the development of problems in differentiation, that is, mathematicians have to think about how to solve problems that are the opposite of the solutions of differentiation. The symbol for the integral is ∫{\textstyle \int }. When given a function f of the real variable x with intervals a, b] of a straight line, the definite integral is defined as the area bounded by the curve f, the x-axis, the y-axis, and the vertical lines x = a and x = b with the area above the x-axis is positive and the area below the x-axis is negative. The word integral can also be used to refer to the antiderivative, a function F whose derivative is a function f. In this case, it is called an indefinite integral and the notation is written as follows. The principles and techniques of integration were developed separately by Isaac Newton and Gottfried Leibniz in the late 17th century. By the fundamental theorem of calculus that they each developed, the integral is related to the differential: if f is a continuous function defined on a closed interval a, b], if the antiderivative F of f is known, the definite integral of f on that interval can be defined as: Integrals and differentials play an important role in calculus with various applications in science and engineering. The integral over x of the real value function f of the real variable x at intervals a, b] can be written as The integral sign ∫ represents integration. The symbol dx, called the differential of the variable x, indicates that the integrating variable is x. The function of f(x) to integrate can be called the integrant. The dx symbol is separated from the integrand by a space (as shown).

A function is said to be integrated if the integral of the function over its domain is finite. In essence a and b are called integral limits. An integral for which a limit is determined is called a definite integral. The integral is said to exceed the interval a, b]. When the integral is moved from the finite value a to the upper limit of infinity, the integral expresses the limit of the integral from a to the value b because b is infinite. If the integral value gets closer to the finite value, then the integral is said to be able to merge to that value. Otherwise, the integral is said to deviate. When the limit is omitted, the integral is called an indefinite integral, which represents a class of functions (antiderivatives) whose derivatives are integrands. The fundamental theorem of calculus links the evaluation of definite integrals to indefinite integrals. Sometimes, integration limits are omitted for certain integrals when the same limits appear repeatedly in certain contexts. Usually, the author will explain this convention at the beginning of the relevant text. There are several extensions to the integral notation to include integration over infinite domains, and/or over multiple dimensions (see the next section of this article). Historically, the symbol dx was taken to represent an infinitesimal "small part" of the independent variable x, which would be multiplied by the integrand and summed in an infinite sense. While this notion was still heuristically useful, later mathematicians considered infinitesimal numbers untenable from the point of view of the real number system. In introductory calculus, the expression dx is therefore not assigned an independent meaning; instead, it is seen as part of the symbol of integration and serves as its delimiter on the right side of the expression being integrated. In more sophisticated contexts, dx can have its own significance, the meaning of which depends on the specific area of ​​mathematics being discussed.

Chemistry, Astronomy, Earth Science, Health Science, Archaeoastronomy is an interdisciplinary science of astronomy and various social sciences that investigates the relationship of the culture of society in the past to objects or phenomena that existed and occurred in the sky. The definition of archeoastronomy is often misinterpreted due to the name "archeo" which is the prefix of this term—instead of only studying historical heritage related to astronomy, archeoastronomy is also involved in studying values, traditions, and practices in the culture of society regarding various objects and phenomena that is in the sky. The object of this study generates other terms such as ethnoastronomy—the interdisciplinary science of ethnography and astronomy—and astronomical anthropology with studies that often intersect or even be considered the same as archeoastronomy. Anthony F. Aveni, one of the pioneers in the development of archeoastronomy, stated that archeoastronomy has become a confluence of three fields of scientific study that are related to the study of ancient astronomy, namely: Archeoastronomy is a relatively new branch of science. Even so, studies with related topics have long been carried out by researchers. The birth of the science of archeoastronomy was initially based on the interest of archaeologists in the 1960s to study the relationship of the monuments of ancient civilizations such as the Pyramids of Giza, Stonehenge and Newgrange to the constellations of stars, planets and the movement of the Sun. Over time, the themes and problems studied in archeoastronomy began to expand. Archeoastronomy no longer only examines the relation of ancient monuments to the sky, but begins to pay attention to concepts related to culture, calendars, ancient navigation systems, to political events. —Syanislaw Iwaniszewski, (Alignments and Orientations Again). According to the methods and sources of discussion, the study of archeoastronomy can be divided into two types of approaches, namely green archeoastronomy and brown archeoastronomy. The words green and brown refer to the colors of the front covers of the books entitled Archaeoastronomy in the Old World (green) and Archaeoastronomy in the New World (brown)—first published in 1982a]—which contain articles on the results of archeoastronomy research in various European regions and America.

This understanding implies that the green archeoastronomy approach is closely related to research and studies conducted at archaeological sites found in the Old World (Europe, Asia, and Africa). In research and studies in this area, archeoastronomy researchers often deal with statistical data. Meanwhile, the brown archeoastronomy approach deals more with research involving social data and is used to investigate the culture of the indigenous peoples of the Americas (New World). To obtain accurate conclusions, these two types of approaches should be combined with each other. Research conducted on ancient monuments in the Old World (Asia, Africa and Europe) to find their association with celestial bodies such as planets, star constellations, the Sun, comets and the Moon, generally uses statistical data. This statistical data is the result of calculating the relative position of these celestial bodies to the intended monument or archeoastronomical site. This approach is called the green archaeoastronomy approach. The green archeoastronomy approach involves rigorous data selection and field methodologies. The use of this approach, for example, in research conducted in the 1970s at Stonehenge. This study aims to find the relationship between the orientation or landscape of the site with the position and angle of inclination of the Sun and Moon. However, the lack of social data such as historical records, reliefs, or rituals found or studied to support this conclusion, has resulted in the association of Stonehenge with the movements of the Moon and Sun from the results of this research still being debated. This then becomes a separate criticism of the green archeoastronomy approach which is considered to ignore socio-cultural aspects. The brown archeoastronomy approach emerged in the 1970s in North America, when studies and research were carried out on the relationship between the cultures of the indigenous peoples of North America and Mesoamerica (Central America) in the pre-Columbian period with astronomy.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Systematics is the study of the diversity of life on Earth, both past and present, and the relationships between living things throughout history. The relationship is visualized in the form of an evolutionary tree (cladogram, phylogenetic tree). This branch of science is closely related and sometimes even considered synonymous with taxonomy. Systematics biology is a branch of biology that studies the classification system and nomenclature of organisms. The word systematics comes from the Latin word "systema", which means the systematic order of organisms. Biological systematics studies what characterizes a species and how these species relate to each other over time. Therefore, systematics is used as the basis of the evolution of life. To study the relationships between these organisms, specifically, researchers in biological systematics need to do: Systematics is sometimes confused with taxonomy. However, systematics is broader than taxonomy. The relationships studied in biological systematics are visualized through the branches of the evolutionary tree. There are two evolutionary trees: a phylogeny that describes the actual relationships between organisms in evolution and a cladogram that explains the hypotheses. Phylogeny has two components: branching order (describes the relationships between living things) and branch length (indicates how much a trait changes). As many species are studied in biology, over time, the classification and organization of these species has become a complex sub-discipline of biology. This researcher is called a biosystematicist and his field is called biosystematics. In studying biological systematics, researchers use branches to explain the relationships between different organisms. This branch is used for various applications in modern systematics. Biological systematics uses three ways to create branches that classify species. Numerical systematics or biometry uses statistics to identify and classify animals.

Biochemical systematics classifies and identifies animals based on the analysis of the chemicals present in a cell. Finally, there is experimental systematics that identifies and classifies animals based on their evolutionary units such as mutations, genetic differences, hybridization, and other things. With specific branches like this, researchers can apply knowledge in systematics in several fields: Although the application of systematics uses various complex methods, actually all hierarchies of biological classification are essentially hypothetical, which means that humans subjectively determine what the name of the organism is and classify it. the organism. In 1970, Michener et al explained the difference between biological systematics and taxonomy and their relationship with each other as explained as follows: Systematic biology (hereinafter referred to as systematics) is the field of biology which (a) gives scientific names to organisms, (b) describes them, (c ) maintain collections, (d) provide classifications for organisms, keys to their identification, and data on their distribution, (e) investigate their evolutionary history, and (f) study their adaptations to the environment. Systematics is a field with a long history which in recent years has experienced an important renaissance, especially with regard to theoretical content. Part of the theoretical material is related to the field of evolution (topics e and f above), the rest is related to classification problems. Taxonomy is part of systematics related to topics (a) to (d) above. Europeans usually use systematics and biosystematics to study biodiversity as a whole, while for this, Americans usually use the terms taxonomy. However, taxonomy is more often used specifically for the identification, description, and naming of organisms. Taxonomic characters are the characters of living things that are used as evidence to make a relationship (phylogeny) between taxa.

Chinese or Tionghwa (origin from Hokkien; traditional Chinese: 中華; simplified Chinese: 中华; pinyin: Zhōnghuá; Pe̍h-ōe-jī: Tiong-hôa) or Huaren (traditional Chinese: 華人; simplified Chinese: 华人) is a term in Indonesia for people of Chinese ethnicity or nation. Although the use of the term "Chinese" is rarely used outside Indonesia, this term can also refer to Chinese people living outside the People's Republic of China, such as in Indonesia (Chinese-Indonesian), Malaysia (Chinese-Malaysian), Singaporean, Hong Kong. Kong, Taiwan, the United States, and so on. Thus, in Indonesian, the terms Chinese people and Chinese people have different meanings; the first refers to ethnicity or national origin, the second refers to the nationality of the People's Republic of China. Chinese people who go abroad are generally referred to as overseas Chinese (Hoakiao). In China itself, a similar concept is known as Huaxia (traditional Chinese: 華夏; simplified Chinese: 华夏) which refers to the concept of the Chinese nation and civilization, which originates from the consciousness of the Han nation (the majority ethnic group in Mainland China, which originates from the Han Dynasty). over their ancestry, collectively referred to as Huaxia. While the term Zhonghua itself was used officially in the name of the country, both before World War II (Republic of China - Zhonghua minguo) and after the Chinese Civil War (People's Republic of China - Zhonghua remin gongheguo). Zhonghua minzu (traditional Chinese: 中華民族; simplified Chinese: 中华民族), sometimes translated as "Chinese nation" or Chinese race in the modern sense refers to all people in China regardless of ethnic group. Zhonghua is translated into Chinese, while Minzu is translated as the people or ethnic group. The so-called Chinese do not necessarily refer to the Han people, who make up the majority in China, but also to the other 55 ethnic minorities in China.

The term Zhonghua minzu is a key political term whose history is closely related to the history of the modern Chinese state, both the history of China's national awakening and the history of the struggle of the Chinese people. Since the late 1980s, the most fundamental change in citizenship and minority policy in the People's Republic of China has been the change of name from "people of China" (Chinese: 中国人民 or zhongguo renmin) to "nation of Chinese" (Chinese: 中华民族 zhonghua minzu), which signifies a paradigm shift from a communist country with various ethnic groups, to a national state with a single identity. While the rulers of the Qing Dynasty adopted the imperial model of the Han Dynasty, and considered their country to be "China" ("中國", lit. Central State or Middle State), Chinese nationalist figures such as Dr. Sun Yat-sen described the Manchu government as "foreign invaders" who had to be driven out, and planned to build a modern Chinese state, which was coveted like any other modern state at the time. After the fall of the Qing dynasty, controversies arose around the status of areas dominated by ethnic minorities, such as Tibet and Mongolia. Although the last Qing Emperor to abdicate had bestowed all Qing territory to the newly born republic, the position of the Mongols and Tibetans at that time was only loyal to the Qing monarch, so they did not feel loyal to the republican government that had replaced the Qing monarchy. The positions of these two regions have so far been rejected by both the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China. During the early Republican (1912–27) and Nationalist (1928–49) periods, the term Zhonghua minzu was first used by Liang Qichao, who at first referred only to the Han nation. Later the term was expanded to cover four other majority peoples: the Man (Manchu), the Menggu (Mongol), the Hui (a Muslim ethnic group in northwestern China), and the Zang (Tibetan) nation, which was a subdivision carried out by the Chinese dynasty. Qing, under the concept of Five Nations Under One State (Chinese: 五族共和).

Identity according to Stella Ting Toomey is a self-reflection or self-reflection that comes from family, gender, culture, ethnicity and socialization processes. Identity basically refers to the reflection of ourselves and other people's perceptions of us. Meanwhile, Gardiner W. Harry and Kosmitzki Corinne see identity as defining oneself as an individual who differs in behavior, beliefs and attitudes. Identity originates from the theory of social identity put forward by Henri Tajfel and John Turner in 1979. The theory was originally developed to understand the psychological basis of discrimination between groups. Tajfel and Turner attempted to identify the minimal conditions that would bring members of one group to discriminate against members of another group. Sexual identity refers to the identification of a person with different categories of sexuality. It can be heterosexual, gay, lesbian and bisexual. The sexual identity that we have will affect what we consume. What television programs will we watch or what magazines will we read. Sexual identity can also affect one's job. Gender identity is a view of masculinity and femininity and what it means to be a man or a woman. The meaning of being a woman or a man is strongly influenced by cultural views. For example, activities that are considered more masculine or more feminine. Gender expressions not only communicate who we are, but also construct the sense we desire. Gender identity is also indicated by the style of communication. The female communication style is often described as supportive, egalitarian, personal and disclosive, while the male communication style is described as competitive and assertive. Personal identity is a unique characteristic that distinguishes it from others. Everyone has their own personal identity so that it will not be the same as someone else's identity.

Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra (29 September 1547 – 22 April 1616) was a Spanish novelist, poet and playwright. He is best known for his novel Don Quixote de la Mancha (Don Quixote), which is considered by many to be the first modern novel, one of the greatest works in Western literature, and the greatest in Spanish. This novel is one of the "Greatest Books in the Western World" in the Encyclopedia Britannica. Russian author Fyodor Dostoyevsky called it "the highest and most sublime word of human thought". Israeli Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion learned Spanish so he could read it in the original, and considers it a prerequisite for being an effective statesman. Cervantes was born in Alcála de Henares, Spain, on an unrecorded day, but since he was named Miguel it is thought he was born on the feast day of St. Patrick. Mikael (29 September) in 1547. He was the fourth child and second of seven children of Rodrigo de Cervantes and Leonor de Cortinas. His father was a poor surgeon and pharmacist and came from an old family in Northern Spain. Cervantes was baptized on November 9, 1558. Although Cervantes' reputation rested almost entirely on his appearance as a lanky country lord, ''El ingenioso hidalgo'', his literary production was enormous. William Shakespeare, Cervantes' great contemporary, had clearly read Don Quixote, but it is almost certain that Cervantes never heard of Shakespeare. As a child, Cervantes saw the famous actor-manager and playwright Lope de Rueda and mentioned his name in the introductions to his plays. This seems to fuel his love of theater in later life. Cervantes' life was unsettled, full of suffering and adventure.

His father was a surgeon who claimed to be royalty, while his mother appears to have been of Jewish descent who later converted to Christianity. Not much is known about his childhood, but it appears that during his childhood Cervantes moved from town to town, while his father looked for work. After studying in Madrid (1568-1569), under his teacher, Juan López de Hoyos, a humanist, Cervantes went to Rome to serve Giulio Acquavita. Arriving in Italy, he immediately began his acquaintance with Italian literature. This knowledge of his soon appeared in his own productions. In 1570, he joined the army, and fought bravely on a ship in the great battle of Lepanto in 1571, and was shot in his left hand so much that he could never use it again. However his health recovered sufficiently for him to take part in the naval battle against the Muslims of Navarino on October 7, 1572. He was involved in the capture of the city of Tunis on October 10, 1573 and in the unsuccessful expedition to liberate La Goletta in the fall of 1574. After several while still living in Italy, and several times having escort duties to Palermo and Naples, he finally determined to return to his homeland in 1575. His ship was captured by the Turks and he and his brother, Rodrigo, were captured and taken to Algiers as slaves. There he lived for five years, experiencing great suffering, which is partly mirrored in the episode "The Prisoner" in Don Quixote, and in scenes from his play, El trato de Argel. After four unsuccessful attempts to escape, he was ransomed by Trinitarians, and returned to his family in Madrid in 1580. In 1584, he married Catalina de Salazar y Palacios, who was 22 his junior.

Beauty or beauty is a characteristic of a person, animal, place, object, or idea that provides a perceptual experience of pleasure, meaning, or satisfaction. In the Big Indonesian Dictionary, beauty is defined as a state of being pleasing to the eye, beautiful, good or beautiful. Beauty is studied as part of aesthetics, sociology, social psychology, and culture. The experience of "beauty" often involves the interpretation of some entity in balance and harmony with nature, which can lead to feelings of attraction and emotional well-being. Because it is a subjective experience, it is often said that beauty is in the eye of the beholder or "beauty is in the eye of the beholder." The classical Greek noun for "beauty" is κάλλος, kallos, and the adjective for "beautiful" is καλός, kalos. The Koine Greek word for beautiful is ὡραῖος, hōraios, an etymological adjective derived from ὥρα, hora, meaning “hour.” In Koine Greek, such beauty is associated with “to be at the hour (time) that it should be. " A fruit that was ripe (in time) was considered beautiful, whereas a young woman trying to appear older or an old woman trying to appear younger would not be considered beautiful. In the Attic Greek language, hōraios had many meanings, including "young" and "mature age." Beautiful women are apparently called "beautiful" or "beautiful", while good-looking men are called "handsome" or "handsome" in society. The characteristics and characteristics of someone who is considered "beautiful", whether individually u or by societal consensus, is often based on some combination of Inner Beauty, which includes psychological factors such as personality, intelligence, grace, modesty, charisma, integrity, and conformity, and Outer Beauty is outside), namely physical attractiveness which includes physical factors, such as health, youth, facial symmetry, and facial skin structure.

Moral (Latin: Morality; Arabic: أخلاق, akhlāq) is (the teachings about) good and bad that are generally accepted regarding actions, attitudes, obligations, and so on. Moral is a standard of behavior that allows everyone to live cooperatively in a group. Moral can refer to community sanctions related to correct and acceptable behavior. Etymologically Moral comes from the Latin mos (plural: mores) which means habit, custom. The word mos” (mores) in Latin means the same as ethos in Greek. In Indonesian, the word moral is translated as "rules of decency" or a term used to determine the limits of the nature of other roles, desires, opinions or limits of actions that can be properly said to be right, wrong, good or bad. the word 'moral' is often equated with the word 'ethics', because both words have the same meaning of habit, custom. Moral itself can be interpreted as: values ​​and norms that become a guideline for a person or group in regulating their behavior. In addition, there are words related to morals which are affixed words derived from the word 'moral', namely 'morality'. 'Morality' is the moral character or overall principles and values ​​relating to good and bad. So, the morality of an action means the moral aspect of an action or whether the action is good or bad. The term human refers to humans or other people in actions that have a positive value. Humans who do not have morals are called amoral, meaning they are immoral and do not have positive values ​​in the eyes of other humans. So that morals are absolute things that must be possessed by humans. Explicitly morals are matters relating to the process of individual socialization. Without morals, humans cannot carry out the socialization process.

Today's morality has an implicit value because many people have that moral or immoral attitude from a narrow point of view. Moral is a basic trait that is taught in schools and humans must have morals if they want to be respected by others. Moral is absolute value in social life as a whole. Assessment of morals is measured from the culture of the local community. Moral is a person's actions, behavior or speech in interacting with humans. If what a person does is in accordance with the values ​​prevailing in that society and is acceptable and pleasing to the community, then that person is considered to have good morals, and vice versa. Morals are products of culture and religion. Each culture has different moral standards according to the prevailing value system and has been built for a long time. Consistency of self-character is a major part of morals. The assessment of consistency in morals includes the continual conformity and continuity between words and actions. Individuals who have morals must have consistent words and deeds. The nature of consistency in morals can be tested through various problems that connect words and deeds. One of the observations regarding this consistency can be observed in politicians when they take office as well as in making decisions and using power. Some notions of morality according to experts, namely Al-Ghazali, Helden and Richards, Baron, et al, Chaplin, Hurlock, Immanuel Kant Al-Ghazali According to Al-Ghazali, moral is a temperament (character, character) that remains strong in the human soul and is a source of the emergence of certain actions from him easily and lightly, without the need to think about and plan beforehand. Helden and Richards Moral is a sensitivity in thoughts, feelings, and actions compared to other actions that are not only in the form of sensitivity to principles and rules.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union  (light blue) Burundi (French: Burundi), Republic of Burundi (French: République du Burundi, Template:Lang-run) is a landlocked country in the Lake region Big in the middle of the African continent. The country is bordered by Rwanda to the north, Tanzania to the south and east, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo to the west. Although the country has no maritime borders, much of its western border is contiguous with Lake Tanganyika. The country's name comes from the Bantu language, Kirundi. This country is very poor. Compared to Indonesia, its per capita income is 400 times less than Indonesia. Without sea borders, facing population pressures and having few natural resources, Burundi is one of the poorest and most conflict-ridden countries in Africa and in the world. Its small size overshadows the enormous problems it faces in seeking to settle claims of supremacy from the ruling Tutsi minority with demands for political participation from the majority Hutu. Burundi is an independent kingdom since the 16th century. The origins of the Burundi kingdom itself are shrouded in myth. According to some legends, Ntare Rushatsi, founder of the first dynasty, came from Rwanda in the 17th century; other, more reliable sources suggest that Ntara came from Buha, in the southeast, and founded his kingdom in the Nkoma region. Until the fall of the monarchy in 1966, it was one of the last links to Burundi's historical past. In 1903, Burundi became a German colony and ceded to Belgium during World War II.
