It later became part of the Belgian League of Nations mandate, Ruanda-Urundi in 1923, and then a UN Trust Territory under Belgian authority after World War II.

From independence in 1962 until elections in 1993, Burundi was ruled by a series of military dictators, all from the Tutsi minority. The period was filled with ethnic riots including major incidents in 1964, 1972 and the late 1980s. In 1993, Burundi held its first democratic elections, which were won by the Hutu-dominated Front for Democracy in Burundi (FRODEBU). FRODEBU leader Melchior Ndadaye became the first Hutu president of Burundi, but months later he was assassinated by a group of Tutsi soldiers. This killing then resulted in a civil war. The civil war between Hutu and Tustsi continued until 1996, when former president Pierre Buyoya took power in a coup. Between 1993 and 1999, inter-ethnic wars between the Tutsis and Hutus claimed as many as 250,000 lives. In August 2000, a peace agreement was signed by almost all political groups in Burundi outlining plans for peace. Then in 2003, a ceasefire was agreed between the Buyoya government and the largest Hutu rebel group, CNDD-FDD. Although there has been a peace agreement, until now the conflict is still continuing. In the elections held in July 2005, the former Hutu rebels, CNDD-FDD won the elections. Burundi is divided into 17 provinces, 117 communes and 2,638 choline (hills). The provincial government is structured around these boundaries. In 2000, the province that includes Bujumbura was separated into two provinces, Bujumbura Rural and Bujumbura Mairie. Here is a list of provinces in Burundi: Being one of the smallest countries in Africa, Burundi is landlocked and has an equatorial climate. Burundi is part of the Albertine Fault, the western extension of the East African Fault. The country is situated on a rolling plateau in the middle of Africa. Burundi is bordered by Rwanda to the north, Tanzania to the east and southeast, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo to the west.

The Republic of Peru (Spanish: Perú; Quechua and Aymara: Piruw) is a country in western South America, bordered by Ecuador and Colombia to the north, Brazil to the east, Bolivia to the east, southeast, and south, Chile to the south, and the Pacific Ocean to the west. Peru is a country rich in anthropological culture and is known as the birthplace of the Inca Empire, whose capital is Machu Picchu. Before the Spanish arrived, Peru was home to various pre-Inca cultures and later, the Inca Empire. Francisco Pizarro landed on the Peruvian coast in 1532, and by the late 1530s, Peru became the Virreinato and a major source of gold and silver for the Spanish Empire. Peru declared its independence from Spain on July 28, 1821 thanks to an alliance between the Argentine army of José de San Martín, and the Neogranadine army of Simon Bolivar. Its first elected president, however, did not come to power until 1827. From 1836 to 1839 Peru, and Bolivia became one in the Peru-Bolivia Confederation, dissolved after armed conflicts with Chile and Argentina. Between these years, political insecurity did not end, with the army as an important political force. Again, between 1879 and 1883, Peru and Bolivia made an alliance, and fought against Chile in the Pacific War. After the war ended (with the loss of Tarapaca province), political stability was achieved, during the early 1900's; until Augusto Leguia and his dictatorship came along. Peru is located in western South America, bordering the South Pacific Ocean, between Chile and Ecuador. It also shares borders with Colombia, Brazil and Bolivia. The plains of the west coast are separated by the forested lowlands of the Amazon Basin in the south by the high, rugged Andes in the center. On the border of Bolivia is Lake Titicaca, the highest navigable lake in the world at 3821 m. The combination of tropical latitude, mountains, topographic variations, and two ocean currents (Humboldt and El Niño) gives Peru a great variety of climates.

Coastal areas have moderate temperatures, low rainfall, and high humidity, except for the warmer and wetter northern parts. In the mountainous region, rain is common in summer, and the temperature and humidity decrease as the altitude reaches the freezing peaks of the Andes. The Peruvian Amazon is characterized by heavy rains and high temperatures, except for its southernmost part, which has cold winters and seasonal rainfall. Due to its varied geography and climate, Peru has high biodiversity with 21,462 species of plants and animals reported in 2003, of which 5,855 are endemic, and is a megadiverse country. Peru has more than 1,800 species of birds (120 of which are endemic), more than 500 species of mammals, more than 300 species of reptiles, and more than 1,000 species of freshwater fish. Hundreds of mammals including endangered species such as cougars, jaguars and spectacled bears. Peruvian birds produce large quantities of guano, an economically important export. The Pacific harbors large quantities of sea bass, flounder, anchovies, tuna, crustaceans and shellfish, and is home to many sharks, sperm whales and whales. President Alejandro Toledo is the current leader of the Peruvian state, and the Chairman of Perú Posible. He was elected with 53% of the vote in the second round of elections in 2001, defeating former socialist president Alan García Pérez. Perú Posible won 45 seats out of 120 seats in parliament. For the second and third positions, respectively, were occupied by Partido Aprista Peruano (PAP, 28 seats) led by Alan García Pérez, and Unidad Nacional (UN, 17 seats) led by Lourdes Flores Nano. Peru's territory is divided into 25 regions (plural:regiones; singular: región). These regions are divided into provinces, which are made up of districts.

The Wehrmacht was the name of the Nazi-German armed forces from 1935 to 1945. During World War II, the Wehrmacht consisted of the Heer (Army), Kriegsmarine (Navy) and Luftwaffe (Air Force). The term "Wehrmacht" comes from a compound German word: wehren, "to defend" and macht, "force" and literally means "To defend force". after the rise of the NSDAP, the term Wehrmacht began to be used in a general sense to refer to the armed forces of any nation, which functioned as "fatherland defense". For example, the term Britische Wehrmacht means to refer to the British armed forces. Article 47 of the 1919 Constitution of the Weimar Republic stated "the Reichspräsident shall have supreme authority over all the armed forces of the Reich". To give a characteristic, the term Reichswehr is used to refer to the German armed forces. In 1935, or when the Nazis rose, the Reichswehr was changed to the Wehrmacht. Thus, the term Wehrmacht was used unofficially to refer to the German armed forces during the 3rd Reich and World War II. By law, the Commander-in-Chief of the Wehrmacht was Adolf Hitler in his capacity as President of Germany, a position which Hitler assumed after the death of President Paul von Hindenburg in August 1934. By founding the Wehrmacht in 1935, Hitler appointed himself Supreme Commander of the Wehrmacht's Armed Forces, retaining his position as President or Chancellor until his suicide on April 30, 1945. The title Commander in Chief was given to the Minister of the Reichswehr, namely Werner von Blomberg who was simultaneously renamed the Reich Minister of War. After the Blomberg-Fritsch Affair, Blomberg resigned and Hitler abolished the Wehrmacht's Ministry of War system. Instead of the ministry, the Wehrmacht High Command, namely Oberkommando der Wehrmacht (OKW), under Field Marshal Wilhelm Keitel, was placed in place of the Ministry of War.

under the OKW, there were three branches within the OKW: Oberkommando des Heeres (OKH), Oberkommando der Marine (OKM), and Oberkommando der Luftwaffe (OKL). The OKW was intended to function as joint command and coordinate all military activities, with Hitler as its superior. Although many senior officers such as von Manstein, OKW had advocated for a real tri-service Joint Command, or the appointment of a single Joint Chief of Staff, Hitler refused. Even after his crushing defeat at Stalingrad, Hitler had refused, declaring that Göring, as Reichsmarschall and Hitler's deputy, would not be ruled by anyone else or see himself as equal to other service Wehrmacht military commanders. However, a more likely reason was that Hitler feared it would damage his image of the "Midas touch" on military strategy. By establishing the OKW, Hitler solidified his control over the Wehrmacht. Showing restraint early in the war, Hitler also became increasingly involved in the military operations conducted by Germany. In addition, there is a clear cohesiveness between the three High Commands and the OKW, as senior generals are not aware of the needs, capabilities and limitations of the other branches. With Hitler serving as Commander-in-Chief, branch commands were often forced to fight over influence with Hitler. However, influence with Hitler came not only from rank and merit, but also those whom Hitler viewed as loyal, leading to inter-service competition, not cohesion between his military advisers. According to estimates, 6,000,000 soldiers were injured during the war, while more than 11,000,000 soldiers became prisoners of war. Overall, some 5,318,000 soldiers from Germany and other nations fighting for the German armed forces, including personnel from the Waffen-SS, Volkssturm, and foreign collaborators are thought to have died in combat, or died from wounds, and also died in custody by allies or lost in World War II.

Axioms, postulates or assumptions are statements that serve as premises or starting points for further reasons and arguments. An axiom is also interpreted as a statement that contains basic terms and defined terms and does not stand alone and is not tested for truth. However, axioms in mathematics do not mean self-evident propositions. Rather, a starting point of a logical system. For example, 1+1=2{\displaystyle 1+1=2} Another name for an axiom is a postulate. An axiom is the basis of a formal logic system which together with the rules of inference define logic. In the end, an axiom is a statement whose truth is certain. The term axiom is most commonly used as a term in mathematics, the target or object of mathematical study in the form of facts, concepts, operations and principles that require certain methods to find the truth or validity of the concepts contained therein. The object of this study uses symbols that are empty of meaning, meaning that every symbol used in mathematics is an abstract symbol. This feature allows mathematics to enter the field of study or other branches of knowledge. In essence, mathematical thinking is based on agreements called axioms. Therefore mathematics is an axiomatic system. One of the phenomena about existing axioms is that for 2000 years axioms about numbers and geometry have been considered a definite truth because theorems are a logical consequence of axioms, so theorems are considered undeniable truths. The word axiom comes from the Greek word ἀξίωμα (Axioma), a verbal noun from the verb ἀξιόειν (Axioein), meaning "to deem worthy", but also "to require", which in turn comes from ἄξιος (áxios), meaning " balanced", and therefore "has (same) value (as)", "deserves", "deserves".

Among the ancient Greek philosophers, an axiom was a claim that could be seen as a self-evident truth without the need for proof. The term axiom is also understood in mathematics. The word axiom in mathematics is also called postulate. The basic meaning of the word postulate is "to demand"; for example, Euclid demanded that one agree that some things could be done (for example, any two points could be joined by a straight line). Ancient geometry retained some differences between axioms and postulates. While commenting on Euclid's books, Proclus states that "Geminus argued that this Postulate should not be classed as a postulate but as an axiom, for it does not, like the first three Postulates, assert the possibility of several constructions but expresses an important property." Boethius translates 'postulates' as petitio and calls the axiom notiones communes but in later manuscripts this usage is not always strictly preserved. The logic-deductive method by which conclusions (new knowledge) follow from premises (old knowledge) through the application of sound arguments (syllogisms, rules of inference) was developed by the ancient Greeks, and has become a core tenet of modern mathematics. Tautologies are excluded, nothing can be concluded if nothing is assumed. The axioms and postulates are thus the basic assumptions that underlie certain bodies of deductive knowledge. They were accepted without demonstration. All other statements (theorems, in the case of mathematics) must be proved with the help of these basic assumptions. However, interpretations of mathematical knowledge have changed from ancient to modern times, and consequently the terms axioms and postulates mean slightly different things to today's mathematicians, than they do to Aristotle and Euclid. The ancient Greeks considered geometry only one of several sciences, and considered geometric theorems to be equivalent to scientific facts.

Definition is a limitation or meaning, it can also be interpreted as a word, phrase, or sentence that expresses the meaning, description, or main characteristics of a person, thing, process, or activity. In the Big Indonesian Dictionary, definition is a formulation of the scope and characteristics of a concept which is the subject of discussion or study. Definitions are also interpreted as descriptions of meanings that function to limit objects, concepts, and situations based on the time and place of a study. Definitions are attempts by scientists to limit facts and concepts. The lexical definition means to limit. In both formal and informal logic, definitions are needed to explain how key terms are used. In the field of computers, definition (definition) is a notification (property) object and at the same time allocate memory to the object. A meaning/meaning of a word cannot be directly referred to as a definition, because a definition has special characteristics. The meaning/meaning of a word can be interpreted as a definition if there is an element of a word or term that is defined, or commonly called a definiendum. Furthermore, within that meaning there must be an element of word, phrase, or sentence that functions to describe the meaning, commonly called definiens, and of course there must also be a choice of words. The word choice is where the definiens starts with a noun, preceded by the word is-is. For example the sentence Love is a feeling of loyalty, pride and concern and the sentence Student is a student in college. Second, definiens begins with a noun, for example a verb or preceded by a word, namely. For example, Faithful, namely feeling compelled to acknowledge, understand, accept, appreciate, respect, obey, and preserve. Then, the definiens are also required to give an understanding of form or form beginning with the word is, such as the sentence Loving is a commendable act to end conflict. The last thing is that definiens is a synonym that is preceded by the word is.

For example Men are men. Nominal definition in the form of a brief understanding. The definitions of this type are divided into three types. First, synonyms or equivalents, like the word human which is synonymous with the word person, so if written the result is Human]] is a person. Furthermore, it is related to translations from other languages, for example Performance is performance. The origin of a word in the nominal definition is also important, for example: Psychology comes from the word "psyche" which means soul, and "logos" means science, psychology is the science of the soul. Nominal definition explains a word with other commonly understood words. Nominal definition is mainly used at the beginning of a conversation or discussion. There are six types of nominal definitions, namely synonymous definitions, symbolic definitions, etymological definitions, semantic definitions, stipulative definitions, and denotative definitions. The stipulative definition is the definition used when determining the use of the term. Stipulative definitions must be judged not as right or wrong but as useful or useless. These definitions determine the meaning to be used for the term in other senses creating a technical vocabulary. It can also be referred to as a clarifying definition that defines which is clearer for terms that are not clear. For example, courts may establish a more precise definition of “death” to resolve certain legal disputes. A formal definition is also called a terminological definition, which is a definition based on formal logic consisting of three elements. The structure of this definition is "class", "genus", "differentiation" (differentiation). These three elements must appear in the definition. The formal structure begins with clarification, followed by determining the word to be used as a definition, followed by mentioning the genus, and ends by mentioning different words or descriptions. The differentiator must be complete and comprehensive so that it really shows a very distinctive understanding and distinguishes the meaning from other classes.

Religion is a system that regulates belief and worship of God (or the like) as well as rules related to customs, and a worldview that connects humans with the order of life, the implementation of religion can be influenced by local customs. During historical times, adat became a tool for conveying religious teachings. While religion is difficult to define, a standard model of religion, used in lectures on religious studies, was proposed by Clifford Geertz, who simply calls it a "cultural system". A critique of the Geertz model by Talal Asad categorizes religion as "an anthropological category." Many religions have mythologies, symbols, and sacred histories that purport to explain the meaning, purpose of life and the origins of life or the universe. From their beliefs about the cosmos and human nature, people derive morality, ethics, customary laws, or preferred lifestyles. According to some estimates, there are about 4,200 religions in the world. Many religions may have organized behavior, clergy, definitions of what constitutes obedience or membership, holy places, and holy books. Religious practices may also include rituals, sermons, commemoration or worship of gods, gods or goddesses, sacrifices, festivals, parties, trances, initiations, burial practices, weddings, meditation, prayer, music, art, dance, or any other aspect of human culture. . Religions may also contain mythology. The word religion is sometimes used interchangeably with faith, belief system, or sometimes set of duties. However, according to sociologist Émile Durkheim, religion differs from personal belief in that it is "something socially real". Émile Durkheim also said that religion is an integrated system consisting of beliefs and practices related to sacred things. A 2012 global opinion poll reported that 59% of the world's population self-identify as religious, and 36% have no religion, including 13% who are atheist, with a 9% drop in religious belief from 2005.

On average, women are more religious than men. Some people follow several religions or several religious principles at the same time, regardless of whether or not their religious principles follow traditional ways that allow for an element of syncretism to occur. According to the Big Indonesian Dictionary, religion is a regulator (system) that regulates the system of faith (belief) and belief as well as devotion to the Almighty Creator and the rules relating to human relations and humans and their environment. The word "religion" comes from the Sanskrit word, āgama (आगम) which means "Way of Life". Another word to express this concept is religion which comes from the Latin religio and is rooted in the verb re-ligare which means "to tie again". That is, by being religious, a person binds himself to God. According to the philologist Max Müller, the root of the English word "religion", which is Latin religio, was originally used to mean simply "fear of God or the gods, careful contemplation of divine things, piety" (later later Cicero degrade to mean "persistence"). Max Müller characterizes many other cultures around the world, including Egyptian, Persian, and Indian, as sharing a common power structure at this point in history. What are the so-called ancient religions today, they will only be referred to as "laws". Many languages ​​have words that can be translated as "religion", but they may use them in very different ways, and some have no word to describe religion at all. For example, the Sanskrit word dharma, sometimes translated as "religion", also means law. Throughout classical South Asia, the study of law consisted of concepts such as penance through piety and practical rituals and traditions. Japan originally had a similar union between "imperial law" and universal or "Buddhist law", but this later became an independent source of power.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health science Physiology or physiology (pronounced fa-al) is one of the branches of biology that studies the functioning of living systems. The term physiology comes from the Greek words physis and logos which mean nature and story. The scientific method used in physiology aims to study the physical and chemical functions of biomolecules, cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, and organisms as a whole. The study of physiology began when the anatomist William Harvey described the existence of blood circulation in the 17th century AD. Physiology then became a scientific discipline through a textbook titled Institutiones Medicae (1708) written and taught by Herman Boerhaave in Leiden. Physiology does not care about the types of living things studied. The term "physiology" is borrowed from the Dutch language, physiologie, which is formed from two Ancient Greek words: φύσις, physis, meaning "origin" or "substance" and λογία, logia, meaning "study". The term "faal" is taken from Arabic, meaning "sign", "function", "work". Physiology is one of the fields of science that is the object of the Nobel Prize (Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine). Other sciences have developed from physiology considering that this science is quite old. Some important derivatives are biochemistry, biophysics, biomechanics, cell genetics, pharmacology, and ecophysiology. The development of molecular biology influences the direction of the study of physiology. The science of human physiology dates from around 420BC to the time of Hippocrates, who is also known as the father of medicine. Aristotle's critical thinking and attention to the relationship between structure and function marked the beginning of the science of physiology in Ancient Greece. Jean Fernel, a French researcher, introduced the term "physiology" in 1525. But experimental physiology only started in the 17th century, when the anatomist William Harvey explained the existence of blood circulation.

Herman Boerhaave is often called the father of physiology because of his textbook Institutiones Medicae (1708) and his brilliant teaching at Leiden. In the 19th century, the science of physiology began to develop rapidly, especially in 1838 with the discovery of the cell theory by Matthias Schleiden and Theodor Schwann. Radically this theory states that organisms are composed of units called cells. Claude Bernard (1813–1878) later discovered the concept of milieu interieur (internal environment), which was later referred to as "homeostasis" by the American researcher, Walter Cannon. In the 20th century, biologists also developed an interest in how organisms other than humans function, which gave rise to comparative physiology and ecophysiology. In recent years, evolutionary physiology has become a subdiscipline of physiology. Physiology in the field of medicine plays a very large role. As a result of the in-depth study, there are several subfields. Electrophysiology deals with how nerves and muscles work; neurophysiology studies the physiology of the brain; Cell physiology refers to the function of individual cells. Many fields are related to physiology, including Ecophysiology which studies the influence of the environment on physiological changes in the bodies of animals and plants. Genetics is not the only factor that influences the physiology of animals and plants. Environmental stress also often causes damage to eukaryotic organisms. Organisms that do not live in aquatic habitats must store water in a cellular environment. In such organisms, dehydration can be a major problem. Dehydration in humans can occur when there is an increase in physical activity. In the field of exercise physiology, various studies have been conducted on the effect of dehydration on homeostasis. Animal physiology stems from the methods and equipment used in studying human physiology which then extends to animal species other than humans. Plant physiology makes extensive use of techniques from both of these fields.

Kalimantan (toponym: Kalamantan, Calémantan, Kalémantan, Kelamatan, Kilamantan, Klamantan, Klémantan, K'lemantan, Quallamontan), or also called Borneo by the international world. Kalimantan is the third largest island in the world, located north of Java Island and west of Sulawesi Island. The island of Borneo is divided into the territories of Indonesia (73%), Malaysia (26%) and Brunei (1%). The island of Borneo is known as the "Island of a Thousand Rivers" because of the many rivers that flow on this island. Borneo—which comes from the name of the sultanate of Brunei—is the name used by British and Dutch colonials to refer to this island as a whole, while Kalimantan is the name used by residents of the eastern part of the island which is now part of Indonesia. The northern region of this island (Sabah, Brunei , Sarawak) for Malaysia and Brunei Darussalam. Meanwhile for the northern region of Indonesia, is the province of North Kalimantan. In a broad sense, "Kalimantan" includes the entire island which is also called Borneo, while in a narrow sense, Kalimantan only refers to the territory of Indonesia. The origin of the name Kalimantan is not very clear. The term kelamantan is used in Sarawak to refer to groups of people who consume sago in the northern region of the island. According to Crowfurd, the word Kalimantan is the name of a type of mango (Mangifera) so that the island of Kalimantan is an island of mangoes. But he added that the word was fairytale and unpopular. Until now, there are many local mangoes called klemantan in rural areas in Ketapang and its surroundings, West Kalimantan. According to C. Hose and Mac Dougall, "Kalimantan" comes from the names of six groups of local tribes namely Iban (Dayak Laut), Kayan, Kenyah, Klemantan (Dayak Darat), Murut, and Punan. In his essay, Natural Man, a Record from Borneo (1926), Hose explained that Klemantan was a new name used by the Malay people.

However, according to Slamet Muljana, the word Kalimantan is not an original Malay word but a pinzaman word like the word Malaya, Malay which comes from India (malaya which means mountain). Another opinion states that Kalimantan or Klemantan comes from Sanskrit, Kalamanthana is an island where the air is very hot or burning (kala]: season, time and manthana]: burning). Because the vowels a in kala and manthana are not pronounced according to custom, then Kalamanthana is pronounced Kalmantan which is then called the native of Klemantan or Quallamontan which is finally revealed to be Kalimantan. There are three major (main) kingdoms on this island, namely Borneo (Brunei/Barune), Succadana (Tanjungpura/Bakulapura), and Banjarmasinn (Nusa Kencana). Residents of the eastern region of the island call it K'lemantan Island, Italians know it Calemantan and Ukrainians: Калімантан. If judging from the Javanese language, the name Kalimantan can mean "River of Diamonds". Throughout its history, Kalimantan has also been known by other names. The Singasari Kingdom, for example, called it "Bakulapura" which is its colony in southwest Kalimantan. Bakula in Sanskrit means cape tree (Mimusops elengi) so that Bakulapura got the Malay name "Tanjungpura" which means land/island of cape trees, namely the royal name of Tanjungpura which is often used as the name of the island. Meanwhile the Majapahit Kingdom in the Kakawin Nagarakretagama written in 1365 called it "Tanjungnagara" which also included the Philippines such as Saludung (Manila) and the Sulu Archipelago. Hikayat Banjar, an ancient chronicle from South Kalimantan whose final chapter was written in 1663, but the Hikayat Banjar manuscript itself originates from a manuscript with an older Malay language text during the Hindu kingdom, in which it calls Borneo Island with the Malay name, namely the island "Hujung Soil". The term Hujung Tanah appears based on the geomorphological shape of the South Kalimantan region in ancient times in the form of a peninsula formed from a row of Meratus Mountains with land ending in the South Cape which juts into the Java Sea.

In chemistry, hydronium is the common name for the aqueous cation H3O+, a type of oxonium ion produced by the protonation of water. This ion is a positive ion present when an Arrhenius acid dissolves in water, because an Arrhenius acid molecule in solution releases a proton (a positive hydrogen ion, H+) to the surrounding water molecules (H2O). The amount of hydronium ions relative to the hydroxide ions determines the pH value of a solution. Molecules in pure water auto-dissociate (ie: react with each other) into hydronium and hydroxide ions in the following equilibrium: In pure water, there are equal amounts of hydroxide and hydronium ions, so the solution is neutral. At 25°C, water has a pH of 7 (this value varies as the temperature changes). A pH value less than 7 indicates an acidic solution, and a pH value greater than 7 indicates an alkaline solution. According to the IUPAC nomenclature of organic chemistry, the hydronium ion is best referred to as oxonium. Hydroxonium can also be used to clearly identify it. The draft IUPAC proposal also recommends the use of oxonium and oxidonium in the context of organic and inorganic chemistry, respectively. An oxonium ion is any ion with a trivalent oxygen cation. For example, a protonated hydroxyl group is an oxonium ion, but not a hydronium ion. Because O+ and N have the same number of electrons, H3O+ is isoelectronic with ammonia. As shown in the figure above, H3O+ has a trigonal pyramidal molecular geometry with an oxygen atom at the apex. The H–O–H bond angle is approximately 113°, and the center of mass is very close to the oxygen atom. Since the base of the pyramid consists of three identical hydrogen atoms, the configuration of the molecular symmetry of H3O+ is as if it belongs to the C3v point group.

Because of this symmetry and the fact that it has a dipole moment, the rotational selection rules are ΔJ = ±1 and ΔK = 0. The transition dipole is located along the c-axis and, because the negative charge is localized near the oxygen atom, the dipole moment is apex, perpendicular straight to the ground plane. Hydronium is a cation formed from water in the presence of hydrogen ions. These hydrons do not exist in a free state: they are highly reactive and are dissolved by water. An acidic solute is generally the source of these hydrons; However, hydronium is present even in pure water. This special case where water reacts with water to produce hydronium (and hydroxide) ions is commonly known as self-ionization of water. The hydronium ions produced are few and short-lived. pH is a measure of the relative activity of hydronium and hydroxide ions in aqueous solutions. In acidic solutions, hydronium is more active, excess protons readily available for reaction with basic species. The hydronium ion is highly acidic: at 25°C, its pK is −1.7. It is the most acidic species that can exist in water (assuming sufficient water for dissolution): a strong acid will ionize and protonate water molecules to form hydronium. The acidity of hydronium is an implicit standard used to judge the strength of acids in water: a strong acid must be a better proton donor than hydronium, otherwise most of the acid will be in the non-ionized state (ie: a weak acid). Unlike hydronium in neutral solution which results from the autodissociation of water, hydronium ions in acidic solution are durable and concentrated, proportional to the strength of the dissolved acid. pH was originally conceived to be a measure of the hydrogen ion concentration in an aqueous solution.

Communism (Latin: communis) is an ideology related to philosophy, politics, social and economics whose main goal is to create a society with socio-economic rules based on shared ownership of the means of production and the absence of social classes, money and the state. The term communism is often confused with International Communism. Communism or Marxism is the basic ideology commonly used by communist parties around the world. Meanwhile, international communism is an ideological blend originating from Lenin's thoughts, so it can also be called "Marxism–Leninism". In communism, social change must start from taking over the means of production through the role of the communist party. In summary, the logic is that social change begins with the workers, or better known as the proletariat (see: The Holy Family), but the organization of workers can only succeed through party struggle. The party needs the role of the Politburo as a think-tank. It can be summarized that social change can only be successful if it is initiated by the Politburo. Communism as anti-capitalism uses the communist party system as a means of taking over power and strongly opposes the ownership of accumulated capital in individuals. In principle, everything is represented as belonging to the people and therefore, all means of production must be controlled by the state for the people's prosperity evenly. Communism introduces the use of a representative democratic system carried out by communist party elites. Therefore it greatly limits direct democracy to people who are not members of the communist party. Therefore, in communism, individual rights are not recognized as found in liberalism. International communism as an ideological theory began to be applied after the outbreak of the Bolshevik Revolution in Russia on November 7, 1917. Since then communism has been applied as an ideology and spread to other countries. In 2005, countries that still adhered to communism were China, Vietnam, North Korea, Cuba and Laos.

Seoul (Korean: 서울, meaning: "Capital City"; Korean pronunciation: sʌ.ul]), officially known as Seoul Special City, is the capital city of South Korea for over 600 years and until 1945, the capital of all Korea. This city is the hometown of K-Pop idols such as BTS, EXO, BLACKPINK, BIGBANG, SNSD, Super Junior, etc. Since the founding of the Republic of Korea, known as South Korea in 1948, Seoul has been the nation's capital, except for a few moments during the Korean War. Seoul is located in the northwest of the country, in the southern part of the Korean DMZ, on the Han River. The city is the political, cultural, social and economic center of South Korea and East Asia. Seoul is also a center for business, finance, multinational companies and global organizations. Until now, the city is considered the economic center of East Asia, a symbol of the Korean economic miracle. With 10 million registered residents living in an area of ​​605.21 km², Seoul is one of the most densely populated cities in the world. Its density has made it one of the world's digital-wired cities. The city also has registered vehicles of more than 1 million vehicles causing traffic jams until past midnight. Parts of the greater Seoul and commuter areas, including the pier city of Incheon and the residential area of ​​Seongnam, are among the most densely populated areas in the world. Seoul is considered a global city and rated an Alpha – City by the Globalization and World City Research Network (GaWC), Seoul was the 4th largest metropolitan economy in the world in 2014 after Tokyo, New York, and Los Angeles. In 2015, Seoul was rated Asia's most liveable city with the second highest quality of life globally by Arcadis, with Seoul's GDP per capita (PPP) of around $40,000.

With major technology hubs based in Gangnam and Digital Media City, the Seoul Capital Area is home to 15 Fortune Global 500 companies. Seoul has hosted the 1986 Asian Games, 1988 Summer Olympics, and the 2010 G20 Seoul Summit. Seoul was named World Design Capital 2010. This city is also the birthplace of K-pop and the Korean wave. In the past, the city was known as Wiryeseong (Hangul: 위례성; Hanja: 慰禮城, during the Baekje era), Hanyang (한양; 漢陽, during the Goryeo era), Hanseong (한성; 漢城, during the Joseon era), and Keijō (京城) or Gyeongseong (경성; 京城) in the Japanese colonial period. During the Japanese annexation of Korea, Hanseong (漢城) was renamed Keijō (京城) by Imperial authorities to prevent confusion with hanja "漢" (a transliteration of the old Korean Han (한) meaning "great"), which also refers to people Han or Han dynasty in Chinese and in Japanese is the term for "China". After World War II and the liberation of Korea, the city has continued to use the name Seoul, which is derived from the Korean word meaning "capital", which is believed to be derived from the ancient word Seorabeol (Hangul: 서라벌; Hanja: 徐羅伐), which originally referred to in Gyeongju, the capital of Silla. City formation began in the Baekje era, Wirye-seong, in 17 BC. The initial location of the city formation is thought to be around the border area of ​​present-day Seoul. In the 11th century Goryeo, which replaced Unified Silla, built a summer palace in Seoul, which was referred to as the "Capital of the South". It was from this period that Seoul became a larger settlement. When Joseon replaced Goryeo, the capital was moved to Seoul (also known as Hanyang or Hanseong).

Positivism Functionalism Antipositivism Conflict theory Structuralism Symbolic interaction Intermediate distance Mathematical Critical theory Socialization Quantitative structures and agents Computational Qualitative Ethnography religion culture economic demographics law science science internet industry social networking gender crime class class family health cities environmental education knowledge deviance social psychology medical mobility politics race & ethnicity rationalization secularization stratification Journal Publishing Outline List of sociologists Chemistry Index Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Ethnography (Greek ἔθνος ethnos= folk and γραφία graphia = writing) is a field of scientific research that is often used in the social sciences, especially in anthropology and some branches of sociology. Ethnography is also known as a part of historical science which studies societies, ethnic groups and other ethnic formations, ethnogenesis, composition, displacement of residence, characteristics of social welfare, as well as their material and spiritual culture. Ethnography is often applied to collect empirical data about human society and culture. Data collection is usually done through participant observation, interviews, questionnaires and others. This science aims to explain the state of the society being studied (eg to describe a person, an ethnos) through writing. In biology, this type of study is called a "field study" or a "case report", both of which are used as common synonyms for "ethnography". Activities in ethnography are analyzing and observing certain social groups or cultural supporters. This activity is carried out directly with the subject under study. Observations can be aimed at certain people and locations as objects. Ethnography is also in the form of research based on fieldwork, using inductive methods of observation and in-depth interviews to investigate social life practices, as well as capture the meaning behind the behavior of social interaction.

Ethnographic activities are focused on cultural behavior by social groups and see how the daily life is carried out by these groups as the subject under study. The task of an ethnographer is almost the same as that of an investigator, but the difference is that an ethnographer records, writes, and perpetuates the daily life of that group of people within a certain period of time. Habits, ways of thinking, and behavior of the subject were observed, recorded and analyzed in depth by an ethnographer. Ethnography has been known since anthropology began to develop, namely at the end of the 15th century when European, Asian, American and Australian explorers began to visit. Initially the explorers had a mission to conquer the new territory, but encountered obstacles such as resistance from the natives. In its development, other explorers who served as travelers, sailors, priests, missionaries of Christianity, Bible translators, and government officials wrote stories of their journeys to their destination countries which were compiled in the form of diaries or travel journals in the form of descriptions of customs, social structure, language and physical characteristics of various ethnic groups in Africa, Asia, Oceania (namely the islands in Lawan Teduh) and Indian tribes, native Americans. Ethnographers by the Europeans at that time had the function of knowing the spread of human culture, building colonies (colonies) and looking for the weaknesses of indigenous tribes and then conquering them. At the end of World War II, ethnography served to apply other sciences, especially for the implementation of development programs. From a scientific point of view, ethnography can be defined as a part of the study of anthropology which holistically describes the culture of a society, ethnicity, and nation based on the results of field research in the more recent or recent period. Whereas. Ethnography as a branch of social science is dynamically developing following the findings of research in the social field, especially anthropology and socio-culture.

Aging (in English: aging) is the result of accumulation of changes in organisms or objects due to time. Aging has a broad meaning, one of which is aging is the life cycle from when humans are born, through childhood, adolescence, adulthood, to the point where humans feel old. However, in the process of aging, all living things are not the same in terms of time. Some people age faster, and some people age more slowly. This is because the aging process is a fairly broad phenomenon, involving physical, psychological, and social processes. Biologically, aging is the result of all the accumulation of molecular and cellular damage over time. This causes reduced physical and mental capacity, and increases the risk of disease and death. Old age also causes hearing loss, cataracts, osteoarthritis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes, depression and dementia. The worst impact of aging in old age is geriatric syndrome. Aging also results in a loss of the ability of the network to repair itself, and it is no longer able to maintain its normal function. This causes a decline in organ structure and function. Physical signs of aging can be felt by reduced muscle mass, increased fat, wrinkles on the skin, and reduced memory ability. Signs of aging are psychologically marked by decreased passion for life, difficulty sleeping, often feeling anxious, and irritable. The wear and tear theory is a theory regarding aging which states that aging occurs due to excessive damage to cells making it difficult for the body to repair. The process of cell damage continues to occur from time to time. This theory was first coined by August Weismann a biologist from Germany in 1882.

The theory of neuroendocrinology is one theory of aging, which states that the aging process occurs because the hormones produced are no longer able to balance excessive bodily functions, causing hormone deficiency. However, this theory has been criticized because for some living things such as vertebrates to lack hormones and complex neuroendocrine systems, they still age. The next theory of aging is about human genetic control, which is completely set in a person's DNA. As technology develops, the aging factor due to genetics can be overcome, by preventing damage and repairing DNA with technology. If the human body receives too many free radicals, it can cause oxidative stress. This can damage the cells in the body, and cause various diseases, as well as causing aging. Free radicals are considered to be the main cause of the aging process, besides being modified by genetic, and environmental factors. Free radicals have high reactivity to cause age-related cell and tissue damage. Oxidative modification of biological molecules consisting of lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids influences cell aging and death. UV rays are electromagnetic wave radiation caused by the sun. Exposure to UV radiation is one of the causes of oxidative stress on the skin that can cause aging. Frequent skin exposure to UV rays can lead to the formation of wrinkles, lesions, and cancer. On sun exposure, skin molecules absorb UVR which results in the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS). The first hormone that influences the aging process is estrogen, which functions to produce collagen and elastin. When the hormone estrogen is reduced, human skin will experience wrinkles, the shape of an oval face is uneven. The impact on the body if there is a lack of the hormone estrogen is that you experience fatigue more quickly.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Latvia, officially the Republic of Latvia (Latvian: Latvijas Republika), is a country in the Baltic region, Northern Europe. Latvia is bordered by Estonia (343 km) to the north, Lithuania (588 km) to the south, Russia (276 km) to the east, Belarus (141 km) to the southeast, and shares a maritime border with Sweden to the west. . With a population of 2,070,371 people and an area of ​​64,589 sq km, Latvia is one of the few and sparsely populated countries in the European Union. The seat of government is in Riga. The official language is Latvian and the unit of currency is Lats (Ls). This country has a temperate climate. It joined the European Union on 1 May 2004 and to NATO on 29 March 2004. The nation of Latvia is a part of the Baltic peoples, culturally related to the nation of Lithuania. Together with the Livonian-Finnish people, the Latvian people are indigenous Latvians. Latvian is part of the Indo-European language family and, together with Lithuanian, forms the two surviving branches of the Baltic languages. The languages ​​of the indigenous minorities are Latgalian and the almost extinct Livonian-Finnish languages. In terms of geography, area and population, Latvia is in the middle of the three Baltic states: Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. Latvia and Estonia share a long history together: historical Livonia, Polish-Lithuanian times, Germany (Teutonic Order), Sweden, Russia, NAZI Germany, and Soviet rule, Christianization in the 13th century, and the Protestant Reformation in the 16th century. Both countries are home to a large number of ethnic Russians (26.9% in Latvia and 25.5% in Estonia) most of whom are not citizens. Latvia has historically been predominantly Protestant, except for the region of Latgalia in the southeast which has historically been Catholic.

Latvia is a unitary state in the form of a republic with a parliamentary style of government. Latvia is divided into 118 regions, namely 109 municipalities and 9 cities. There are five planning areas: Kurzeme, Latgalia, Riga, Vidzeme and Zemgale. The Republic of Latvia was founded on November 18, 1918. Latvia was occupied and controlled by the Soviet Union from 1940-1941 and 1945-1991, and by Nazi Germany from 1941-1945. The peaceful "Singing Revolution" of 1987-1991 and the "Baltic Road" demonstrations of August 23, 1989 widened the chances of independence for the Baltic countries. Latvia declared the restoration of de facto independence on 21 August 1991. Latvia is a member of the United Nations, the European Union, the European Assembly, NATO, the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe, the International Monetary Fund, and the World Trade Organization, and part of the Schengen Zone . Latvia is a member of the League of Nations (1921-1946) and the Baltic Free Trade Zone (1994-2004). Latvia is also a member of the Council of Baltic Sea States and the Nordic Investment Bank, and together with Estonia and Lithuania is involved in the tripartite cooperation of the Baltic countries and the Nordic-Baltic cooperation. After an economic stagnation in the early 1990s, Latvia posted relatively high GDP growth in Europe in the period 1998-2006. During the 2007–2012 financial crisis, Latvia was the European Union member that suffered the most, with a 26.54% decline in GDP. Commentators noted signs of stabilization of the Latvian economy in 2010, and economic conditions continued to improve, as Latvia once again became one of the fastest growing economies in the European Union in 2011. The United Nations lists Latvia as a country on the Human Development Index. the "very high". The name Latvija derives from the ancient Latgalian name, one of the four Indo-European Baltic peoples (along with the Couronians, Selonians and Semigallians), who form the modern ethnic core of the Latvian people along with the Finnish Livonians.

Momolianism, Bobolianism, Kadazandusun belief is one of the indigenous religions of the archipelago, namely the belief flow of the Dayak Kadazandusun tribe in Sabah, Kalimantan, Malaysia. The Kadazandusun people are bumiputera and include 27 sub-tribes: Dusun Liwan, Dusun Lotud, Rungus, Tagahas, Tangara and others, most of whom have now converted to Christianity, but the ancestral religion still survives and its adherents officially comprise 0.09% of the Malaysian population. The name Momolianism comes from the word Bobohizan (Tangara Kadazan accent) alias Bobolian (Liwan Village accent). Bobolian is a title for the group of priestesses who lead the offering ceremony. The first Bobolian is believed to be taught by the incarnation of the spirit of Dewi Huminodun, namely Unduk Ngadau. Unduk Ngadau teaches serapah spells that are practiced until now. The goddess is also said to be the one who first taught Bobolian incantations. These Bobolians are made up of women, because based on folklore, the Goddess called someone for four years to be taught in the middle of the night, but only a brave woman who was not afraid to meet the spirit. The Bobolians are feared to be unable to control strong spirits. In the ceremony held, there are times when a gong is struck to accompany the ceremony held to call certain Spirits, such as the skull spirit during the Apprentice festival. After that, Bobolian will say mantras and play kombuongo or instruments in order to unite two different worlds. After being possessed by the spirit Bobolian conversed with someone who was the spirit he summoned. Sometimes the spirit wants tumbal (chicken, 10 boiled eggs, turmeric rice, and tapai/lihing). Momolianism is a religion of animism. Adherents worship and believe in the spirit realm (Susukuon) with five types of ethereal beings: Gods and Goddesses (the highest ethereal beings); Rusod (spirit of all living things except humans); Koduduwo (human spirit, meaning "the second you"); Tombiruo (spirits of people who have died in the afterlife of Akinabalu, Mount Kinabalu); and Rogon (evil spirits).

The god Kinoingan (another accent: Kinorohingan/Kinoringan) is worshiped as God ("Minamangun") and is the god of creation, besides there is a rice spirit known as Bambaazon (spirit of food source). His wife is Dewi Suminundu. Before people touch the animal they hunt, they will cut it a little and give it as a tribute to the spirit that gave it. Their daughter is the Goddess Huminodun (meaning "sacrificed one") who sacrificed herself to the spirits of the earth in return for a bountiful crop for mankind. Once upon a time, the Kadazandusun people experienced a famine because there was no source of food. Sang Kinoingan felt sorry for the suffering of the Kadazandusun people and then sacrificed Huminodun and his body was buried in the earth and rice plants grew and from there the Kadazandusun people got their food source. It is believed that the incarnation of the spirit of Huminodun came back to life after seven days as Unduk Ngadau (meaning "the girl crowned with sunshine") from within Keakanan, after seven days she was sacrificed. Tadau Kaamatan/Kaamatan Festival is celebrated throughout the month of May although this festival is only on May 30 and 31) and is a special celebration ceremony to honor Bambaazon, the spirit of rice. This festival is usually held after the rice harvest. The highlight of the Kaamatan festival is the election of the Queen of Beauty or Unduk Ngadau which is held to commemorate the spirit of Dewi Huminodun and her sacrifice. The word Unduk Ngadau is used to symbolize beauty and nobility of character. Among the mantras (rinait or inaait) are as follows: According to legend, "Nunuk Ragang" is the first residence of the Kadazandusun tribe (Ranau district, West Coast, Sabah). Where their ancestors have lived in the forest collectively by living in longhouses that gather several families (such as the few Kadazandusun tribes that still live together between 150-200 people) and have not yet known rice.

Toulouse (Tolosa in Occitan) is a city in southwest France on the banks of the Garonne River, halfway between the Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea. With a population of 1.05 million in 2004, the Toulouse metropolitan area is the second largest in southern France and one of the fastest growing in Europe. Toulouse is the base of the aviation industry in Europe and is home to Airbus' headquarters. Toulouse is the former capital of the province of Languedoc (the provincial system was abolished during the French Revolution). It is now the capital of the region (region) Occitanie (formerly the region Midi-Pyrénées when the French region was 22 and now is 18; at that time the region was the largest in France although it was only half the size of the old province of Languedoc). In addition, Toulouse is also the prefecture (capital) of the Haute-Garonne département. It is also where the Académie des Jeux Floraux, parallel to the French Academy for the Occitan-speaking region in southern France, is located, making Tolouse the unofficial capital of Occitan culture. The traditional Occitan cross was adopted as the symbol of the city of Toulouse and the Midi-Pyrénées region. Toulouse is a sister city with: Atlanta (USA), Chongqing (China), Tel Aviv (Israel), Kiev (Ukraine), Bologna (Italy) and Elche (Spain). The downtown (French: commune) population is 390,350 (1999 census), with 964,797 residents in the metropolitan area (French: aire urbaine) (1999 census). Toulouse is the fourth largest city in France, after Paris, Marseille and Lyon. In 1999 Toulouse was the fifth largest metropolitan area in France, after Paris, Lyon, Marseille and Lille. The city hosts the Cité de l'espace, dedicated to space exploration, and the Aeroscopia, dedicated to aviation.

Astronomy (Greek: ἀστρονομία, translit. astronomía, from ástron 'star' and nómos 'law'), also called astrology or astronomy, is the natural science concerned with the study of celestial bodies and natural phenomena that occur outside the Earth, including phenomena in Earth's upper atmosphere that comes from outer space such as meteors and auroras. This science basically studies various aspects of celestial objects such as their origin, physical/chemical properties, meteorology, and motion as well as how knowledge of these objects explains the formation and development of the universe. Astronomy as a science is one of the oldest, as it is known from astronomical artifacts dating back to the prehistoric era; for example the monuments from Egypt and Nubia, or Stonehenge which is from Britain. People from early civilizations such as Babylon, Ancient Greece, China, India and the Maya were also found to have made methodological observations of the night sky. Despite having a long history, astronomy was only able to develop into a modern branch of science through the invention of the telescope. Quite a number of branches of science have been included as part of astronomy, and when one pays attention, the nature of these branches is very diverse: from astrometry, space-based navigation, observational astronomy, to calendar compilation and astrology. However, today professional astronomy is considered synonymous with astrophysics. In the 20th century, professional astronomy was divided into two branches, namely observational astronomy; Astronomical studies that involve collecting data from observations of celestial bodies, which will then be analyzed using the basic principles of physics and theoretical astronomy; The study of astronomy that focuses on efforts to develop computer/analytical models to explain the properties of celestial bodies and other natural phenomena. The two branches are complementary; Theoretical astronomy tries to explain the results of observational astronomy, and observational astronomy tries to prove the conclusions made by theoretical astronomy.

Astronomy is to be distinguished from astrology, which is the belief that human destiny and affairs are related to the position of heavenly bodies such as the stars or their constellations. It is true that these two fields have the same origin, but at present they are very different. In general, both "astronomy" and "astrophysics" may be used to refer to the same science. When referring to the KBBI definition, "astronomy" is the science of "the sun, moon, stars and other planets" while "astrophysics" is a branch of astronomy that studies "the behavior, physical properties, and dynamics of celestial bodies and phenomena." In certain cases, for example at the opening of the book The Physical Universe by Frank Shu, "astronomy" may be used for the qualitative side of this science, while "astrophysics" for the other side which is more physics oriented. However, most modern astronomical studies deal with topics related to physics, so that it can be considered that modern astronomy is astrophysics. Many research bodies, in deciding which term to use, depend solely on whether or not they were historically affiliated with physics departments. Many professional astronomers themselves have degrees in physics. To further illustrate, one of the leading scientific journals in this branch of science is called Astronomy and Astrophysics. At first, astronomy only involved observations and predictions of the movements of celestial bodies visible to the naked eye. At sites such as Stonehenge, early civilizations also compiled artifacts thought to have had astronomical uses. These ancient observatories were mostly for ceremonial purposes, but they could also be used to determine the seasons, weather and climate —something you need to know if you want to grow crops—or understand the length of the year. Before the invention of tools such as the telescope, research had to be done from the top of buildings or high ground, all with the naked eye.

Neodymium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Nd and atomic number 60. This lanthanide element is used, among others, as a glass coloring agent. This metal element is silvery in color, hard, rather ductile, and corrodes easily in air and damp areas. When oxidized, neodymium reacts rapidly to give pink, purple or blue, and yellow compounds in oxidation states of +2, +3 and +4. Neodymium was discovered in 1885 by the Austrian chemist Carl Auer von Welsbach. The element can be found in significant quantities in the mineral monazite and bastnäsite ores. Neodymium is not found naturally in metallic form or is not alloyed with other lanthanides and is usually reworked for common metal uses. Although neodymium is classed as a rare earth element, it is still widely distributed in the Earth's crust and is not as rare as cobalt, nickel, or copper. Most of the world's commercial neodymium is mined in China. At first, neodymium compounds were first widely used as a glass colorant in 1927. The color of neodymium compounds is due to the presence of Nd3+ ions which are generally reddish purple in color and can change depending on the type of lighting. This is due to the interaction of the sharp light absorption bands from neodymium with the surrounding light which is dominated by the emission bands of mercury, trivalent europium or terbium which look sharp. Some neodymium doped glass is used in the use of lasers which emit infrared with wavelengths between 1047 and 1062 nanometers. This glass has been used in high energy applications, such as in ICF (inertial confinement fusion) experiments. Neodymium is also used with various crystalline substrates, such as yttrium aluminum garnet in Nd:YAG lasers.

Holism is a thought which states that the system of the universe, both physical, chemical, biological, social, economic, mental-psychic, and linguistic, and all its accessories must be seen as a whole and not as a unit of separate parts. . Natural systems cannot be understood if we study them in isolation: they must be studied as a whole as a whole. The word 'holism' was first introduced in 1926 by Jan Smuts, a statesman from South Africa, in his book Holism and Evolution. The origin of the word 'holism' is taken from the Greek, holos, which means all or the whole. Smuts defines holism as a natural tendency to form a whole so that it is greater than the sum of its evolutionary parts. Examples of holism can be found throughout human history and in the most diverse socio-cultural contexts confirmed by many ethnological studies. A missionary from France, Maurice Leenhardt, coined the term cosmomorphism to indicate the existence of a perfect reciprocal relationship between a person and his environment. This is found in Melanesian people in New Caledonia. For the people of the area, an isolated individual has no clear status until he finds his position in the environment. By knowing an individual, it cannot be used as a benchmark that we already know a community. The opposite of holism is reductionism, which is an understanding that states that a complex system can be explained by studying the things that form the basis of the system (reduction). For example, a biological process can be explained through a chemical process. Then the chemical process can be explained through physical processes. As a result, physical processes can explain the chemical processes that form the basis of biological processes.

Nicholas A. Christakis, a social scientist and physicist, states that "in the last few centuries, Cartesian projections in science have managed to separate a problem into smaller parts with the aim of gaining an understanding. And it worked within the limits - certain limitations. However, putting the small parts back together to understand it as a unified whole is more difficult to do". Holism can be viewed from a variety of scientific disciplines, there are several definitions of holism viewed from various disciplines, some of these meanings include the following disciplines: In the second half of the 20th century, holism refers to system thinking and its derivatives, such as the science of chaos and complexity. Systems in biology, psychology, sociology are often so complex that their behavior appears 'new', and cannot be deduced from the properties of the constituent elements alone. Holism has been used as a slogan. This contributes to the resistance encountered by scientific interpretations of holism which believe that there are ontological reasons that prevent reductive models in principle from providing efficient algorithms for predicting the behavior of systems within certain classes. Scientific holism believes that the behavior of a system cannot be perfectly predicted, no matter how much data is available. Natural systems can produce unpredictable behavior, and it is presumed that the behavior of the system is not computationally reducible, so one cannot predict the state of the system without a full simulation of all the events that occur in the system. A key characteristic of the high-order behavior of a particular class of systems can be mediated by rare 'surprises' in the behavior of its elements due to the principle of interconnectivity, so that it cannot be predicted except by brute-force methods. Stephen Wolfram provides examples of the behavior of cellular automata, which are generally very simple but sometimes very difficult to predict.

Aristotle (Greek: 'Aριστοτέλης Aristotleēs), (384 BC – 322 BC) was a Greek philosopher who became the teacher of Alexander the Great. He became a student of Plato while in Athens. Aristotle studied from Plato for 20 years. During his life, he wrote about philosophy and other sciences, namely physics, politics, ethics, biology and psychology. Aristotle divided philosophy into four issues, namely logic, physics, metaphysics and practical knowledge. Analysis of philosophy is done using a syllogism. Aristotle's thoughts regarding logic which utilize the deductive method are used as the basis for formal logic. Aristotle also believed that the existence of science was intended to support human life. Aristotle was born in a small town called Stagira in 384 BC. The city is part of the Kalkidiki peninsula. Aristotle's upbringing was carried out by his family in Atarneus, Anatolia. This condition was caused by his father dying at a young age during a trial in Pella, Central Macedonia. His father's occupation was as a physicist. At first, Aristotle was a student of Plato. But he later rejected some of Plato's thoughts and started his own philosophical thought. Aristotle founded an educational and research center called the Lyceum. Through this place, he conveyed his thoughts which then influenced the thinking of other philosophers, theologians or scientists. Aristotle lived in an environment that supported cultural and intellectual creativity. During his lifetime, the city-states of Greece were divided by the defeat of Athens by Sparta in the Peloponnesian War in 404 BC. The long-running conflict between the Greek city-states ended when Philip II of Macedon conquered these countries and founded the Macedonian Empire. Aristotle lived under the reign of Philip II of Macedon's son, Alexander the Great. During this time, he became a student of Plato who wrote many dialogues.

Aristotle developed his own philosophical system at this time. Aristotle believed that abstractions form categories that can be applied to objects of thought. Aristotle considered that human thought transcends the three types of abstractions that make up philosophy, namely physics, mathematics and metaphysics. Man transcends physics when he begins to think while making observations. During thinking, the human mind escapes from observations that use the senses to feel everything that can be felt by its existence. General knowledge is then known from particular and real things. Physics knowledge is then formed through abstract knowledge and human reason. Furthermore, the abstraction of mathematics enables humans to understand invisible matter. Reason detaches itself from everything that can be understood. All the material characteristics of this abstraction then produce science. Meanwhile, the abstraction of metaphysics appears after humans do abstraction of physics. In the third abstraction, humans have been able to think about the reality of all matter along with its origins and purposes for its formation. Aristotle considers this abstraction to be the first philosophy. Aristotle used the term "first philosophy" instead of metaphysics because according to him all philosophy was derived from this abstraction. The first philosophy in Aristotle's view can be interpreted into two senses. The first is as science which is the first principle. While the second is a science that discusses existence as an existence along with the characteristics of objects. Aristotle argued that the method of discovering new knowledge and truth is divided into two. First, the inductive method and the second is the deductive method. The inductive method aims to conclude specific things into a general conclusion. Meanwhile, the deductive method only concludes the truth of two things that are certain and undoubted. The nature of the deductive method is to conclude from something that is general to be specific.

Nutrients, nutrients, or nutrients are substances needed by organisms to live, grow, and develop. Nutrients are elements or chemical compounds used in the metabolism of an organism. Nutrients are usually categorized into those that provide energy and those that are used as components for body or cell structures. A nutrient is called essential for organisms if the substance cannot be synthesized by organisms and must be met from food sources. In everyday usage, the term nutrient is often equated with nutrition. Among several nutrients, which are classified as organic nutrients are carbohydrates, fats, proteins, amino acids, but inorganic chemical compounds such as water (H₂O) and oxygen (O₂) can also be considered nutrients. The nutrients needed in small amounts are called micronutrients, while the nutrients needed in large amounts are called macronutrients. The effects of nutrients depend on the dose. Three types of macromolecules can be processed into energy through metabolism, namely carbohydrates, fats and proteins. Fat contains 9 kcal/g (~37.7 kJ/g) energy, protein and carbohydrates 4 kcal/g (~16.7 kJ/g), while ethanol (grain alcohol) contains 7 kcal/g (~ 29.3 kJ/g). The substances that support metabolism are: Plants absorb nutrients from the soil or from the air, or from water (especially aquatic plants). Of course with the exception of carnivorous plants which ingest nutrients from animals trapped in external plant traps. Chemical elements consumed in large quantities by plants in the form of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen are obtained in the form of water and carbon dioxide, while energy is obtained from sunlight. Nitrogen, phosphorus, and sulfur (sulphur) are also needed in relatively large quantities. All of these are called the "big six" macronutrient elements in all life which are usually sourced from inorganic compounds (eg carbon dioxide, water, nitrate, phosphate, sulfate) or organic compounds (eg carbohydrates, lipids, proteins).

Vaccination is the administration of vaccines to help the immune system develop protection from a disease. Vaccination is a form of immunization. Vaccines themselves contain microorganisms or viruses that are weak, live or dead, or contain proteins or toxins from organisms. In stimulating the body's adaptive immunity, vaccines help prevent the body from becoming sick from infectious diseases. When a large percentage of the population has been vaccinated to a certain percentage, herd immunity is achieved. Herd immunity protects those who may have a compromised immune system and cannot be vaccinated. The effectiveness of vaccination has been extensively studied and verified. Vaccination is the most effective method of preventing infectious diseases; Widespread immunity as a result of vaccination played a major role in the worldwide eradication of variola and the elimination of diseases such as poliomyelitis and tetanus in many countries of the world. However, some diseases, such as measles in the United States, have seen an increase in cases due to relatively low vaccination rates in the 2010s, which is partly due to vaccine hesitancy. The first disease prevented by inoculation was most likely variola. The first recorded application of variolation occurred in the 16th century in China. Variola was also the first disease for which a vaccine was produced. Although at least six people had used the same principle years before, the variola vaccine was invented in 1796 by an English physician, Edward Jenner. He was the first to publish evidence that the variola vaccine was effective and to recommend its production. Louis Pasteur then continued the concept of vaccines through his works in microbiology. Variola is a contagious and deadly disease, causing the death of 20-60% of infected adults and more than 80% of infected children. When variola was finally eradicated in 1979, it had killed an estimated 300–500 million people in the 20th century.

Vaccination is an artificial way to activate the immune system to protect the body from infectious diseases. Activation occurs through exposure of the immune system to immunogens, ie substances capable of stimulating the immune system. The process of strengthening the immune system is known as immunization, which can occur actively or passively, naturally or artificially. Vaccination is a form of artificial active immunization that can be done in various ways to introduce immunogen into the body. Most vaccines are given before a person catches a disease to help increase protection in the future. However, some vaccines are given after a person has contracted a disease. Vaccines given after exposure to variola are reported to provide protection from the disease or can reduce the severity of the disease. Louis Pasteur gave the first rabies vaccination to a child after he was bitten by a rabid dog. Since its discovery, the rabies vaccine has been shown to be effective in preventing rabies in humans when given several times within 14 days after a dog bite along with rabies immunoglobulin administration and wound care. Other examples include administering experimental vaccines for AIDS, cancer, and Alzheimer's disease. Vaccination aims to trigger an immune response more quickly and with less harm than natural infection. Most vaccines are given by injection because the vaccine content is not absorbed properly by the intestine. Live attenuated vaccines, such as the polio vaccine, rotavirus, some types of typhus, and some cholera vaccines are given orally to produce immunity in the digestive system. Although vaccinations have a lasting effect, it usually takes several weeks for an immune response to develop. This is different from passive immunization (giving antibodies, such as during breastfeeding), which has an immediate effect. Vaccination failure is a condition when an organism catches a disease even though it has been vaccinated against the cause of the disease.

One-chamber system (unicameral) is a government system that has only one chamber in the parliament or legislature. Many countries that use a single chamber system are often small, homogeneous unitary states and consider an upper house or second chamber unnecessary. Support for the one-chamber system is based on the notion that if the upper house is democratic, it merely reflects the lower house which is also democratic, and therefore is only a duplication (Double). Theories supporting this view argue that the functions of the second chamber, for example reviewing or revising laws, can be carried out by parliamentary committees, while efforts to safeguard the constitution can then be carried out through a written Constitution. Many countries that now have parliaments with a one-chamber system have previously adopted a two-chamber system, and recently abolished their upper house. One reason is because the elected upper house only overlaps with the lower house and hinders the approval of bills. An example is the Landsting case in Denmark (abolished in 1953). Another reason is that the appointed assembly has proven to be ineffective. An example is the case of the Legislative Council in New Zealand (abolished in 1951). Proponents of the one-chamber system note the need for control over government spending and for eliminating the duplicating work of the two chambers. Critics of the one-chamber system point out that the double checks and offsets provided by the two-chamber system can increase the level of consensus on legislative matters. Another drawback of the one-room system is that urban areas with a large population will have more influence than rural areas with a smaller population. The only way to get the less populated areas represented in a unitary government is to implement a two-chamber system (as in the early United States, for example).

The Svalbard Archipelago (formerly Spitsbergen or Spitzbergen) is the northernmost territory of Norway located in the Arctic Ocean, north of the European continent. Svalbard is an archipelago with Longyearbyen as its capital. The most densely populated islands are Spitsbergen, Bjornoya and Hopen. The Vikings and/or Russians may have discovered Svalbard in the 12th century. According to traditional Norse lore, there is a land called Svalbard - literally "cold edge". The legally recognized discoverer of the Svalbard Archipelago was Dutchman Willem Barents who explored the islands in 1596. Svalbard served as an international whaling base in the 17th and 18th centuries and the headquarters of several Arctic exploration expeditions. The largest island in the archipelago is Spitsbergen (Jagged peak); this name, although incorrect, is often used to refer to the entire archipelago. According to the Treaty of Svalbard on 9 February 1920, the international community recognized Norway's sovereignty over Svalbard and designated it as a neutral zone (demilitarized). Norway took over administrative Svalbard in 1925. However, according to the contents of the unique agreement, residents of other countries have the right to exploit mineral deposits and other natural resources "on a footing of absolute equality"). As a result, a permanent Russian settlement with autonomous status emerged in Barentsburg. In 2000, another Russian settlement in Pyramiden was abandoned. At one time, the Russian (or Soviet) population of Svalbard once outnumbered the Norwegian population. Svalbard's seat of government is in the town of Longyearbyen under the leadership of a governor with Sysselmann status who is appointed by the central government. Svalbard consists of only one district, namely Longyearbyen. Svalbard, which consists of a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, is the northernmost territory of Norway.

Its area is 62,050 km². The three largest islands are Spitsbergen (39,000 km²), Nordaustlandet (14,600 km²) and Edgeøya (5,000 km²). 60% of Svalbard is covered by glaciers and snow; according to the meaning of the word 'Svalbard' which means 'cold coast'. The North Atlantic Current warms the Arctic climate so that ships can sail most of the year. Svalbard is north of the Arctic Circle. In Longyearbyen, the midnight sun appears from April 20 to August 23, and perpetually dark skies appear from October 26 to February 15. Svalbard is a habitat for geese and a variety of other bird species. Mammal species living on Svalbard include: the mouse Microtus epiroticus, the Arctic fox, the Svalbard reindeer and the polar bear. Due to the large number of polar bears in Svalbard, local residents take precautions when outside settlements with rifles. Surprisingly, the local government prohibits anyone from disturbing or harming the animal. Settlements There are no main roads connecting the individual settlements; means of transportation only in the form of boats, planes, helicopters, and snowmobiles.
