Svalbard's economy is based on the coal mining, fishing and snare industries. As the 21st century approaches, the sectors of tourism, research, advanced education, and high-tech companies such as satellite-relay stations are growing rapidly. Norway claims an exclusive fishing zone of 200 nautical miles; Russia does not recognize it. The Svalbard Submarine Cable System, which entered service in January 2004, has a 1,440 km dual fiber optic network from Svalbard to Harstad via Andoy for linkages with satellite stations in Svalbard owned by NASA and NOAA. A Norwegian state-owned company engaged in coal mining employs 60% of the ethnic Norwegian population in Svalbard.

Theology (Greek θεος, theos, "], God", and λογια, logia, "words," "speech," or "discourse"), sometimes called theology, is reasoned discourse about religion, spirituality, and God. . Thus, theology is a science that studies everything related to religious beliefs or the knowledge of God. Theology includes everything related to God. The term theology refers to the tendency to use a theological point of view in discussing and discussing all human problems. Theologians seek to use analysis and rational arguments to discuss, interpret and teach in any one area of ​​religious topics. Theology enables a person to better understand his own religious tradition or other religious traditions, helps make comparisons between various traditions, preserves, renews a particular tradition, helps spread a tradition, applies the sources of a tradition in a current situation or need, or to various other reasons. The word 'theology' comes from the Greek Koine, but gradually acquired a new meaning when the word was adopted in both Greek and Latin forms by Christian writers. Therefore, the use of this word, especially in the West, has a Christian background. However, at present the term can be used for discourse based on reason in the environment or on various religions. Within Christianity itself, the discipline of 'theology' gave birth to its many sub-divisions. In the Christian church, early theology only discussed the teachings about God, then the meaning became broader, namely discussing the entirety of Christian teachings and practices. In an effort to formulate what is the science of theology, there are several elements that need to be considered, namely that there will be no Christian theology without the belief that God acts or speaks specifically in Jesus Christ which fulfills the covenant with the people of Israel.

Grand Est is a region in France. This area is a combination of administrative regions namely Alsace, Champagne-Ardenne and Lorraine. The region's capital is Strasbourg. The provisional name for this region is Alsace-Champagne-Ardenne-Lorraine, which was formed by combining the names of the three regions—Alsace, Champagne-Ardenne, and Lorraine—in alphabetical order with a hyphen. The formula for having a regional name was established by the territorial reform law and applies to all but one regional name for the new area. The ACAL Regional Council, which will be elected in December 2015, must choose a name for the territory and submit to the Conseil d'État—the highest authority in French legal administration—from 1 July 2016 for approval. It allowed the Conseil d'État until 1 October 2016 to issue a decree formally recognizing the new name for the territory. In Alsace and Lorraine, the new regional name is often called ALCA, for Alsace-Lorraine-Champagne-Ardennes, on the internet. In a poll conducted in November 2014 by France 3 in Champagne-Ardenne, Grand Est (29.16%) and Austrasie (22.65%) were the top two choices out of 25 candidates and 4,701 votes. Grand Est also received the highest rating in the following month's poll organized by L'Est Republicain, with 42% of 3,324 votes. Among the other proposed names are: ACAL covers 57,433 square kilometers (22,175 sq mi) and is the sixth largest area in France as of January 1, 2016. ACAL is bordered by four countries—Belgium, Luxembourg, Germany, and Switzerland—on its north and east sides . It is the only French territory that borders more than two countries. To the west and south, it is bordered by the regions Nord-Pas-de-Calais-Picardie (temporary name), Île-de-France, and Burgundy-Franche-Comté (temporary name). The ACAL consists of ten sections: Ardennes, Aube, Bas-Rhin, Marne, Haute-Marne, Haut-Rhin, Meurthe-et-Moselle, Meuse, Moselle, Vosges.

The main mountains in the region are the Vosges Mountains to the east and the Ardennes Mountains to the north. The area is bounded by the River Rhine which forms the border with Germany. While the main rivers that flow in this area: Meuse, Moselle, Marne, and Saône. Lakes in the region include: lac de Gérardmer, lac de Longemer, lac de Retournemer, lac des Corbeaux, Lac de Bouzey, lac de Madine, étang du Stock and lac de Pierre-Percée. The ACAL is the result of a territorial law reform enacted in 2014 by the French Parliament to reduce the number of areas in Metropolitan France—the French part of the European continent—from 22 to 13. The ACAL is an amalgamation of three regions: Alsace, Champagne-Ardenne, and Lorraine. This amalgamation of territories was strongly opposed in Alsace. This territorial reform freed new regions to elect regional council seats, with Strasbourg being chosen as the center, a move to calm the political situation in the region. This region has a population of 5,552,388 people (January 1, 2013). Regional councils have limited administrative authority, focusing more on economic development and financing education and cultural activities. The Regional Council has no legislative authority. Meanwhile the center of the Regional Council will be based in Strasbourg. Regional Council members who, elected in December 2015, are controlled by Republicans. The first President of the ACAL Regional Council was elected Philippe Richert, who was previously President of the Alsace Regional Council. The region has five Railroad networks: The region has four airports: The region has eighteen highways: The region has twelve cities whose Grand Est ring is rich with architectural monuments from the Roman Empire to the early 21st century. Gothic architecture is very striking, with many cathedrals, basilicas and famous churches, such as Reims Cathedral, Strasbourg Cathedral, Metz Cathedral, Troyes Cathedral, Châlons Cathedral, Toul Cathedral, L'Épine Basilica, Saint-Nicolas-de-Port Basilica, Basillica of Avioth (fr), St Urbain Troyes Basilica, Thann Church, Niederhaslach Church, Notre-Dame-en-Vaux, St. George, Sélestat Church and St Peter and St Paul's Church, Wissembourg.

Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun and is the second largest planet in the Solar System after Jupiter. Saturn is also a gas giant with an average radius of about 9 times that of Earth. Saturn's average density is only 1/8 of Earth's average density, but with a larger volume than Earth's, Saturn's mass is 95 times that of Earth's. Saturn is named after the Greek god of welfare and agriculture; the astronomical symbol (♄) represents the scythe used by the god. Saturn's interior most likely consists of a core containing iron, nickel, and rock (compounds of silicon and oxygen). Saturn's core is surrounded by an inner layer of metallic hydrogen, an intermediate layer of liquid hydrogen and liquid helium, and an outer layer of gas. Saturn has a pale yellow hue because of the ammonia crystals that fill its upper atmosphere. The electric current contained in the metallic hydrogen layer is thought to be the generator of Saturn's magnetic field, which is known to be weaker than Earth's magnetic field, but has a magnetic moment 580 times greater than Earth's due to Saturn's larger size. The strength of Saturn's magnetic field is only about 1/20 that of Jupiter's. Although the appearance of the outer atmosphere is ordinary, there is a long-lived appearance that fills this layer of the atmosphere. Wind speeds on Saturn can reach 1,800 km/h (1,100 mph; 500 m/s), which is higher than the winds on Jupiter, but not as high as those on Neptune. Saturn is famous for its unique ring system, which is mostly composed of ice particles with some rock debris and dust. At least 82 natural satellites orbiting Saturn are known, 53 of which have received official names; this number does not include the hundreds of minor moons in the ring system.

Titan, Saturn's largest moon and the second largest moon in the Solar System, has a larger diameter than Mercury, but has less mass than Mercury. Titan is also the only natural satellite in the Solar System that has a thick atmosphere. Saturn is called a gas giant because hydrogen and helium are the main constituents of this planet. Despite not having a solid surface, Saturn is thought to have a solid core. Saturn's shape resembles that of a flat spheroid, a ball that is flattened along its axis from pole to pole so that it bulges around the equator. This shape appears due to Saturn's rotation, which causes the equatorial radius of 60,268 km to be almost 10% larger than the radius of 54,364 km from pole to pole. The other giant planets, Jupiter, Uranus and Neptune also have this shape, but are less obtuse than Saturn. The combination of the rotational speed and the bulge around Saturn's equatorial plane causes a surface gravity of 8.96 m/s2 at the equator that is 74% higher than surface gravity at the poles and lower than Earth's surface gravity. However, Saturn's escape velocity is nearly 36 km/s, much higher than Earth's escape velocity. Saturn is the only planet in the Solar System whose density is lower than that of water (about 30% less). Despite having a planetary core which is much denser than water, this planet only has a relative density of 0.69 g/cm3 due to its gaseous atmosphere. Jupiter's mass is 318 times that of Earth, while Saturn's mass is 95 times that of Earth. These two planets make up 92% of the total mass of all the planets in the Solar System. Although most of its constituent material is hydrogen and helium, Saturn's mass is not in the gas phase because hydrogen would be a non-ideal solution when its density is above 0.01 g/cm3; something like this could be achieved at a radius that comprises 99.9% of Saturn's mass.

The Open Directory Project (ODP), known as Dmoz (from its original domain name, directory.mozilla.org) is a multilingual open content directory of the World Wide Web, this directory is owned by AOL (now part from Verizon's Oath Inc.), but compiled and maintained by a team of volunteer editors from a virtual community. The ODP Directory seeks no profit in listing submitted websites. ODP uses an ontology hierarchical schema to organize the list of websites in its directory. The list of websites in the ODP directory that have similar topics are grouped into a category, which can include smaller categories. DMOZ closed on March 17, 2017 because AOL no longer wanted to support the project. The site became one landing page that day, with links to the DMOZ static archive, and to the DMOZ discussion forum, where plans to rebrand and relaunch the directory are being discussed. As of September 2017, uneditable mirrors remain available on dmoztools.net, and it is stated that while the DMOZ URL will not return, there will be a successor version of the directory, on Curlie.org. Even though a website now lives on the domain, the top-level directory category page is currently just a static HTML file whose category links link users to the dmoztools.net static archive. ODP was founded in the United States under the name Gnuhoo by Rich Skrenta and Bob Truel in 1998 while they were both working as engineers for Sun Microsystems. Chris Tolles, who worked at Sun Microsystems as head of marketing for network security products, also joined in 1998 as a co-founder of Gnuhoo along with co-founders Bryn Dole and Jeremy Wenokur, Rich Skrenta to have developed TASS, which is an advanced version of its predecessor Tin, and the thread of the popular Usenet newsreader for Unix systems.

Incidentally, the original category structure of the Gnuhoo directory was loosely based on the structure of the Usenet newsgroups that then began to exist. The Gnuhoo directory went live on June 5, 1998. After a Slashdot article advising Gnuhoo to always use tools closely related to Freeware, as other GNU projects had previously existed, Richard Stallman and the Free Software Foundation objected. with the use of the GNU system on Gnuhoo. So Gnuhoo changed the name to NewHoo. But Yahoo! also objected to the name change, because it used the word Hoo, thus forcing them to change their name back to ZURL, because the name ZURL was the most likely choice among other names. However, before it could switch to ZURL, Netscape Communications Corporation acquired it in October 1998 and changed its name to the Open Directory Project. Netscape releases ODP data under the Open Directory Project license. Not long after, Netscape was acquired by AOL, and ODP became one of the assets that AOL took part in acquiring. Then AOL merged with Time Warner. By the time Netscape began taking on the work of maintaining the project, the Open Directory Project had about 100,000 URLs indexed with contributions from some 4,500 editors. On October 5, 1999, the number of URLs indexed by ODP reached one million. According to unofficial estimates, then in April 2000 URLs in the Open Directory Project reached 1,600,000, that number exceeded the number of people in the Yahoo! Directory. ODP achieved the milestone of indexing two million URLs on August 14, 2000, three million registrations on November 18, 2001 and four million on December 3, 2003. Since January 2006, the Open Directory Project publishes online reports to inform the public about the progress of the project.

Karate (Japanese: 空 手 ) is a martial art that originated in Japan. This martial art is slightly influenced by the Chinese martial art, Kempo. Karate was brought into Japan via Okinawa and began to develop in the Ryukyu Islands. This martial art was first called "Tote" which means like "Chinese Boxing". became 'karate' (empty hand) to make it more easily accepted by Japanese society. Karate consists of two kanji. The first is 'Kara'　空 and means 'empty'. And the second, 'te'　手, means 'hand'. The two kanji together mean "empty hand"　空手 (pinyin: kongshou). According to the Zen-Nippon Karatedo Renmei / Japan Karatedo Federation (JKF) and the World Karate Federation (WKF), which are considered the main styles of karate, namely: The four streams are recognized as the main Karate style because it participated in the formation of JKF and WKF. However, the world's leading karate styles are not just the four styles above. Several major schools such as Kyokushin, Shorin-ryu, and Uechi-ryu are widespread in various countries a in the world and is known as the famous Karate stream, although it is not included in the "Big 4 WKF". In Japan, the organization that accommodates Karate sports throughout Japan is JKF. The organization that accommodates Karate all over the world is WKF (formerly known as WUKO - World Union of Karatedo Organizations). There is also the ITKF (International Traditional Karate Federation) which accommodates traditional karate. The function of JKF and WKF is mainly to reinforce Karate which is "without direct contact", in contrast to the Kyokushin or Daidojuku schools which are "direct contact".

Karate basic training is divided into three, namely: Currently, karate can also be divided into traditional streams and sports streams. The traditional stream emphasizes the aspects of martial arts and combat techniques, while the sport stream emphasizes techniques for matches. The level/position in karate is differentiated by the ability to memorize or perform the maximum movement in the stance. That is, the levels are distinguished by belts. To get this level/position, we are required to take a belt exam session. Which takes place every 4 months. This level is divided into: Karate techniques are divided into three main parts: Kihon (basic techniques), Kata (movements) and Kumite (fighting). Advanced students are also taught to use weapons such as sticks (bo) and ruyung (nunchaku). Kihon (基本:きほん, Kihon?) literally means foundation or foundation. Karate practitioners must master Kihon well before learning Kata and Kumite. Kihon's training starts with studying punches and kicks (white belt) and slams (brown belt). At the dan or black belt stage, students are considered to have mastered all kihon well. Kata (型:かた) literally means shape or pattern. Kata in karate is not just an ordinary physical or aerobic exercise. But it also contains a lesson about fighting principles. Word Movements also contain many philosophies of life. Each Kata has a different rhythm of movement and breathing. In Kata there is something called Bunkai. Bunkai is an application that can be used from the basic movement of Kata. Each flow has a different movement and a different name for each word. For example, Kata Tekki in the Shotokan school is known as Naihanchi in the Shito Ryu school. As a result, the Bunkai (word application) of each school is also different. Kumite (組手:くみて) literally means "hand meeting".

Kakawin Nagarakretagama (Nāgarakṛtâgama) (Javanese Script: ꦏꦏꦮꦶꦤ꧀ꦤꦴꦒꦫꦏꦽꦠꦴꦒꦩ), (Balinese Aksara: ᬓᬓᬧᬶᬦ᭄ᬓᬵᬕᬭᬓᬺᬢᬵᬕᬫ) or also called the name Kakawin Desanawarnana (deçawarṇana) (Javanese Aksara: ꦏꦏꦮꦶꦤ꧀ꦢꦺꦯꦮꦂꦟ꧀ꦤꦤ), (Balinese Aksara: ᬓᬓᬧᬶᬦ᭄ᬤᬾᬰᬯᬃᬡ᭄ᬦᬦ) by Empu Prapañca can be said to be ancient Javanese kakawin the most famous. Kakawin is also the most researched. Kakawin, which was written in 1365, was first discovered back in 1894 by J.L.A. Brandes, a Dutch scientist who accompanied the KNIL expedition in Lombok. He saved the contents of the King of Lombok's library in Cakranagara before the king's palace was burned by KNIL soldiers. The title of this kakawin, Nagarakretagama means "Country with Holy (Religious) Traditions". The name "Nagarakretagama" itself is not mentioned in the kakawin. In pupuh 94/2, Prapanca calls his creation Deçawarnana or descriptions of villages. However, the name given by the author is even forgotten by the public. Until now, Kakawin is commonly referred to as Nagarakretagama. The name Nagarakretagama is listed in the colophon of the manuscript worked on by Dr. J.L.A. Brandes: "Iti Nagarakretagama Samapta". Apparently, the name Nagarakretagama was added to the copyist Arthapamasah in the month of Kartika in the year 1662 (October 20, 1740 AD). Nagarakretagama was copied with Balinese script in Kancana. This manuscript was completed in Aswina, Saka year 1287 (September – October 1365 AD), the author uses the pseudonym Prapanca, based on the results of historical analysis that has been done, it is known that the author of this manuscript is Dang Acarya Nadendra, a former official in Buddhist affairs at the Majapahit palace. He was the son of a palace official in Majapahit with the rank of Dharmadyaksa Kasogatan (Buddhist state official). The author of this script completed the manuscript of the Negarakretagama kakawin in his old age in a hermitage on a mountainside in a village called Kamalasana.

Until now it is generally known that the poet "Mpu Prapanca" is the writer of Nagarakretagama. :290-308 This Kakawin describes the situation in the Majapahit palace during the reign of King Hayam Wuruk, the great king of Java and the Archipelago. He reigned from 1350 to 1389 AD, during the peak of the Majapahit empire, one of the largest empires that had ever existed in the archipelago. The most important part of this text, of course, describes the areas of the "territory" of the Majapahit kingdom that must pay tribute. Nagarakretagama is written in Old Javanese kakawin (poetry) form. Each kakawin consists of four lines, called pada. Each line consists of eight to 24 syllables, called matra. The kakawin manuscript consists of 98 stanzas, divided into two parts, each of which consists of 49 stanzas. Each stanza consists of one to ten on. From the point of view of the contents, the distribution of the pupuhs has been carried out very neatly. :1 The first part is 49 pupuhs, from cantos 1 to 49, with details::1 The second part is 49 pupuhs, from cantos 50 to 98, with details::1-2 This Kakawin is pujanastra in nature, meaning literary works that flatter and glorify King of Majapahit Hayam Wuruk, as well as the authority of the Majapahit kingdom. However, this work was not compiled at the behest of Hayam Wuruk himself with the aim of self-image politics or power legitimacy. But purely the will of the poet Mpu Prapanca who wanted to give devotion to the crown, and hoped that the King would remember the poet who had served at the Majapahit palace. This means that this manuscript was compiled after Prapanca retired and resigned from the palace. :319-20 The name Prapanca itself is a pen name, a pseudonym to hide the true identity of this literary writer. :287, 317 Because it is literary, only good things are written, things that don't contribute much to the authority of Majapahit, even though the poet might know them, are simply passed over.

In Buddhism, a Bodhisattva; Bodhisattva (Sanskrit) or Bodhisatta (Pali) or Photishat (Thai: โพธิสัตว์) is a Buddha-to-be who is perfecting the 10 paramis / virtues before becoming a Buddha. In Sanskrit, the term Bodhisattva consists of two words, namely bodhi which means enlightenment or illumination, and sattwa which means creature. Bodhisattva also refers to the Buddha in his previous life. In Mahayana teachings, Bodhisattvas take a vow not to enter nirvana until all beings have attained Buddhahood. This means that he postponed entering nirvana and chose to descend to earth to sacrifice himself to help other beings achieve enlightenment. That's why Bodhisattvas are known to have compassion and selflessness and self-sacrifice. This is not the same as in the traditional Theravada tradition, beings who attain enlightenment are Arhats, not Buddhas. The Bodhisattva meaning in the Pali Canon (collection of scriptures on Theravada teachings) and Theravada tradition does not say that a Bodhisattva makes a promise not to become enlightened until everyone else is enlightened. This is an innovation from Mahayana. So a Bodhisatta and a Bodhisattva are different things. Bodhisattvas are much admired in famous art, including one of the tallest statues of the Bodhisattva at Puning Monastery in China, built in 1755. The Pali word Bodhisattva is used by the Buddha in the Pali Canon to refer to himself in previous and present lives towards enlightenment and in the period when he was still moving towards liberation. Siddhartha Gautama's life as a Bodhisattva is recorded in the Jataka Book. When Siddhartha Gautama talks about himself first, he uses the term "when I was a Bodhisattva". One Bodhisattva who is frequently mentioned in the Pali Canon is Maitreya Buddha, for whom Theravada Teaching does not mention any other Bodhisattva.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health Sciences Geodesy in the layman's view is a branch of geoscience that studies the mapping of the earth. Geodesy is one of the oldest branches of science related to the earth. Geodesy comes from the Greek, Geo (γη) = earth and daisia ​​/ daiein (δαιω) = dividing, the word geodaisia ​​or geodeien means dividing the earth. Actually the term "Geometry" is enough to mention the science of measuring the earth, where geometry comes from the Greek, γεωμετρία = geo = earth and metria = measurement. Literally means measurement of the earth. However, the term geometry (more precisely spatial or spatial science) which is the basis for studying geodesy is commonly referred to as a branch of mathematics. According to Helmert and Torge (1880), Geodesy is the science of measuring and mapping the earth's surface which also includes the surface of the seabed. According to the IAG (International Association Of Geodesy, 1979), Geodesy is a scientific discipline that studies the measurement and representation of the Earth and other celestial bodies, including their respective gravitational fields, in three-dimensional space that changes with time. In the report of the United States National Research Council, the definition of Geodesy can be read as follows: a branch of applied mathematics that determines by observations and measurements the exact position of points and the figures and areas of large portions of the earth's surface,the shape and size of the earth, and the variations of terrestrial gravity. In a different language, geodesy is a branch of applied mathematics, which is carried out by making measurements and observations to determine: This definition has two aspects, namely: Now geodetic techniques are no longer only related to surveys and mapping. The development of digital computer technology has expanded the scope of geodetic engineering knowledge and expertise.

Empiricism is a school of philosophy which states that all knowledge comes from the experience of the human senses. Etymologically, the term empiricism comes from the Greek emperia, which means experience. In empiricism, truth can only be obtained through experience. The empiricist mindset relies on empirical evidence. Empiricism is a type of ontology. In empiricism, humans can gain knowledge from experience by observing and sensing. Empiricism is one of the three schools of philosophy of science in the Western world. Philosophical thinking on empiricism has a nature that is contrary to rationalism. Empiricism thought was pioneered by Thomas Hobbes as a reaction against rationalism. The development of empiricism thought took place rapidly in England and the surrounding area during the renaissance during the 17th to 18th centuries. Empiricism was first developed in England by John Locke (1632–1704), but has more influenced thinkers in the United States, especially in the fields of environmental preservation and environmental psychology. Supporting figures come from adherents of Western philosophy, including Francis Bacon, Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, and David Hume. The empiricism of its leaders has contributed to the development of the scientific field. These figures include John Locke (social science and scientific method), George Berkeley (physics, mathematics and theology), and David Hume (historical science and science). Empiricism is also the basis for the development of philosophy in positivism. In addition, empiricism is also one of the main streams in educational philosophy which is the basis for the development of various models of education in the world. The understanding of empiricism has been put forward by Aristotle with the opinion that perception is the basis of science. Empiricism first appeared in England as a thought that contradicted the rationalist thought put forward by René Descartes.

The initial idea of ​​empiricism was put forward by Thomas Hobbes (1588–1679) with the opinion that the beginning of all knowledge comes from sensory experience. The laws of mechanism are considered as the basis of the processes that take place in the world, including humans. Then, another idea about empiricism was put forward by John Locke (1632–1704) who argued that the source of knowledge received by reason comes from experience. The empiricism of thought was further developed by George Berkeley who argued that material substances do not exist at all, only observable characteristics exist. When the world entered the Industrial Revolution, humans began to rely on science and technology to determine policies to address various social problems in society. Mysticism and beliefs about the occult and magic have begun to be abandoned by society. Social problems began to be solved by compiling and testing various scientific theories. The benchmarks used are empiricism and the scientific method. The main teachings of empiricism can be divided based on their views on sources of knowledge, methods of thinking and models of reasoning used. The source of knowledge in the view of empiricism is only from experience. The method of thinking he uses is through empirical evidence and experiments. While the reasoning model he uses is inductive reasoning. The main teachings of empiricism are contrary to rationalism, because rationalism considers knowledge recognition by the senses to be unclear. Meanwhile, empiricism believes that the senses are the perfect and clearest means of recognizing knowledge. In another sense, empiricism prioritizes the use of a posteriori elements, while rationalism prioritizes the use of a priori elements. Another difference between empiricism and rationalism lies in the type of mindset used. Empiricism uses an inductive mindset, while rationalism uses a deductive mindset. The epistemological view of empiricism is based on the principle that everything that exists in the mind exists in the form of sensory data.

Medicine is the science and practice of diagnosing, treating and preventing disease. Medicine includes the various health care practices developed to maintain and restore health by preventing and treating disease. Contemporary medicine uses biomedical science, biomedical research, genetics, and medical technology to diagnose, treat, and prevent injuries and disease, usually through drugs or surgery, but also through a variety of therapies, including psychotherapy, external splints and traction, among others. medical devices, biopharmaceuticals, and radiotherapy. Medicine has been around for thousands of years, much of this time being practiced as an art (an area of ​​skill and knowledge) and often linked to religious beliefs and local cultural philosophies. For example, a shaman would use medicinal plants and pray for healing or ancient philosophers and doctors would bleed according to the theory of humoralism. In recent centuries, since the advent of modern science, most medical practices have been a combination of art and science (both basic and applied sciences, under the medical umbrella). Meanwhile, the technique of performing sutures is an art that is learned through practice and knowledge of what happens at the cellular and molecular level in the sutured tissue emerges through science. The pre-scientific forms of medicine are now known as traditional medicine and folk medicine. They remain so commonly used with or in lieu of scientific medicine that they are called alternative medicine. Meanwhile, treatment outside the limits of safety and efficacy according to medical science is called quackery. The practice of medicine is carried out by medical professionals, usually doctors, and other medical professional groups which include nurses or pharmacists. Historically, only doctors have been considered to be literally practicing medicine, as opposed to related health care professions.

The medical profession is a social structure, and the work of a group of people who are formally educated, and are given the authority to apply medical knowledge. In many countries, and jurisdictions, there are legal limits on who can practice medicine or a health-related field. Medical science is generally considered to have various specialist branches, ranging from pediatrics (child health), gynecology (women's disease), neurology (neurology), to cover other fields such as sports medicine, and public health. Systems of medicine and health care practices have developed in various human societies since at least the beginning of human recorded history. These systems have developed in different ways, in different cultures, and in different areas. What is meant by modern medical science in general is the medical tradition that has developed in the Western world since the beginning of modern times. Despite this, various traditional medical and health procedures are still practiced throughout the world, largely considered separate and distinct from Western medicine, which is also called biomedicine or the Hippocratic tradition. The most developed system of medical science apart from the Western system is the Ayurvedic tradition from India and traditional Chinese medicine. Various unconventional health care traditions were also developed in the Western world that are different from medical science in general. In many places, Western systems of medicine are often practiced alongside traditional local or other systems of medicine, although these are also considered to be in competition or even conflict. Veterinary medicine or what is commonly called veterinary medicine is a health practice that is specific to animal species and is a medical science other than for humans. The practice of medicine combines science and art. Science, as well as technology, is the evidence base for many clinical problems in society.

in Europe (gray) The Republic of Belarus or often called Belarus is a country in Eastern Europe with the capital city of Minsk. The country is administratively divided into 6 provinces (voblasts) and a special city. It is bordered by Russia to the east and northeast, Ukraine to the south, Poland to the west, and Lithuania and Latvia to the northwest. Belarus covers an area of ​​207,600 square kilometers (80,200 square miles), with a population of 9.4 million, and is the thirteenth largest and twentieth most populous country in Europe. The country is administratively divided into seven regions, and is one of the most urbanized in the world, with more than 40% of its total land area being forest. Belarus is a developing country with a very high ranking on the Human Development Index. Belarus has been a member of the United Nations since its founding; and a member of the CIS, CSTO, EAEU, and the Non-Aligned Movement, it has shown no aspirations to join the European Union but maintains bilateral relations with the European Union, and has also participated in two EU projects: the Eastern Partnership and the Baku Initiative. From 5000 to 2000 BC, the Bandkeramic culture predominated. In addition, remnants from the Dnieper-Donets culture have been found in Belarus and parts of Ukraine. Cimmerians and other herders roamed the area by 1,000 BC, and by 500 AD, Slavs had taken up residence, bordered by the Scythians who explored the outskirts. Asian invaders, among whom were Huns and Avars, swept across c. 400–600 AD, but couldn't get rid of the Slavic presence. The area that is now Belarus was first settled by Baltic tribes in the 3rd century AD. Around the 5th century, the area was taken over by Slavic tribes.

The takeover was partly due to a lack of Balt military coordination but the gradual assimilation of the Balts into Slavic culture was peaceful. In the 9th century, the territory of modern Belarus became part of Kievan Rus', a vast East Slavic state ruled by the Rurik dynasty. After the death of the ruler of Kievan Rus', Yaroslav I the Wise, the state split into several independent principalities. Many of the early Rus' principalities were nearly destroyed or severely affected by the great Mongol invasion in the 13th century, but the lands of modern Belarus were spared the brunt of the invasions and eventually joined the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. During this time, the Grand Duchy of Lithuania engaged in several military campaigns, including fighting on the Polish side against the Teutonic Order at the Battle of Grunwald in 1410; mutual victory allowed the Grand Duchy to control the northwestern borders of Eastern Europe. The Muscovites, led by Ivan III of Moscow, began a military campaign in 1486 in an attempt to annex the former lands of Kievan Rus', specifically the territories of modern Belarus, Russia and Ukraine. On 2 February 1386, the Grand Duchy of Lithuania and the Kingdom of Poland were joined in a personal union by the marriage of their rulers. This union set in motion the developments that would eventually lead to the creation of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, formed in 1569 by the Union of Lublin. In the years following the union, the process of gradual Polonization of both Lithuania and Ruthenia gained steady momentum. In culture and social life, Polish and Catholicism became dominant, and in 1696, Polish replaced Ruthenian as the official language — with Ruthenian banned from administrative use. However, the Ruthenian peasants continued to speak their own language and remained loyal to the Belarusian Greek Catholic Church. The Statutes were initially issued in Ruthenian only and later also in Polish.

The Republic of Iraq (local name: جمهورية العراق note 1] – local short name: العراق note 2], Turkish: Iraqi, Kurdish: عيَراق) is a country in the Middle East or Southwest Asia, encompassing most of Mesopotamia as well as the northwestern tip of the Mountain Range. Zagros and the eastern part of the Syrian Desert. The country is bordered by Kuwait and Saudi Arabia to the south, Jordan to the west, Syria to the northwest, Turkey to the north and Iran to the east. Iraq has a very narrow section of coastline at Umm Qashr on the Persian Gulf. Iraq has a rich history. Iraq is now a developing country in the midst of a civil war. There are several opinions about the origin of the name Iraq; – one of them is from the city of Uruk (or Erech) from the time of the Sumer Kingdom. Others argue that Iraq is derived from the Aramaic word, meaning "land along the banks of the rivers." Others argue that Iraq is a reference to the roots of the palm tree, as there are so many of them in that country. Under the Persian Sassanid dynasty, there was a region called "Erak Arabi" which refers to the southwestern part of the Persian Empire, which is now part of southern Iraq. Al-Iraq is the name used by the Arabs themselves for this area since the 6th century. Historically Iraq was known as Mesopotamia, which literally means "between the two rivers" in Greek. This land became the birthplace of the world's first known civilization, the Sumerian culture, followed by the Akkadian, Babylonian and Assyrian cultures whose influence spread to neighboring areas from about 5000 BC. These civilizations produced the oldest writings and some of the world's first science, mathematics, law and philosophy, thus making this region the center of what is commonly known as the "Cradle of Civilization".

The ancient Mesopotamian civilization dominated the other civilizations of its time. In the 6th century BC, it was part of the Persian Empire under Cyrus the Great for nearly 4 centuries, before being conquered by Alexander the Great and remaining under the rule of the Kingdom of Macedonia for nearly two centuries. An Iranian tribe from Central Asia called the Parthians later conquered this area, followed by the Persian Sassanid dynasty for 9 centuries, until the 7th century. In the early 7th century, Islam spread to what is now Iraq. The Prophet Muhammad's cousin and son-in-law, Ali bin Abi Talib, moved the capital to Kufah "fi al-Iraq" where he became the 4th Rashidun Khulafaur. The Umayyads who ruled from Damascus in the 7th century controlled the Province of Iraq. Baghdad, the capital of the Abbasid Caliphate, was the main city for the Arab and Islamic world for 5 centuries. In 1258, Baghdad was destroyed by the Mongols. The Ottoman Empire took Baghdad from the Persians in 1535. The Ottomans lost Baghdad to the Safavid Persian dynasty in 1509, and recaptured it in 1632. Ottoman rule over Iraq lasted until World War I when the Ottoman Empire coexisted with the German Empire and the Central Powers. Iraq lies between latitudes 29° and 38° N, and longitudes 39° and 49° E. Its area is 437,072 km (168,754 sq mi), making it the 58th largest country in the world. It is comparable in size to the US state of California, and somewhat larger than Paraguay. Iraq is mostly desert, but around the Euphrates and Tigris rivers there are fertile alluvial plains. The north of the country is mostly made up of mountains; The country's highest point is at Chekha Dar at 3,611 m (11,847 ft).

Electronics is the science that studies weak current electrical devices that are operated by controlling the flow of electrons or electrically charged particles in a device such as a computer, electronic equipment, thermocouple, semiconductor, and so on. The study of devices like this is a branch of physics, while the design and manufacture of electronic circuits is part of electrical engineering, computer engineering, and electronics and instrumentation science/engineering. Tools that use the basic work of electronics are referred to as electronic equipment (electronic devices). Examples of these electronic equipment (devices): Cathode Ray Tubes, radios, TVs, cassette recorders, video cassette recorders (VCRs), VCD recorders, DVD recorders, video cameras, digital cameras, desktop personal computers, laptop computers, PDAs (pocket computers) , robots, smart cards, etc. The history of electronics begins in the 18th century, involving three main components, namely vacuum tubes, transistors and integrated circuits. In 1883, Thomas Alva Edison discovered that electrons could move from one conductor to another through a vacuum. This discovery of conduction or displacement is known as the Edison effect. In 1904, John Fleming applied the Edison effect to invent a two-element electron tube known as a diode, and Lee De Forest followed in 1906 with a three-element tube, called a triode. The vacuum tube is a device made to manipulate the possibility of electrical energy so that it can be amplified and sent. The first application of the electron tube was in the field of radio communications. Guglielmo Marconi pioneered the development of the wireless telegraph in 1896 and long-distance radio communication in 1901. In 1918, Edwin Armstrong invented the "super-heterodyne" receiver which could select radio signals or stations and could receive signals over long distances.

Armstrong also invented wide-band FM frequency modulation in 1935; previously only used AM or amplitude modulation in the range 1920 to 1935. Bell Laboratories brought television to the public in 1927, and it is still an electromechanical form. When electronic systems became the guarantee of quality, Bell Labs engineers introduced the cathode-ray picture tube and color television. But Vladimir Zworykin, an engineer at the Radio Corporation of America (RCA), is considered the "father of television" for his inventions, the picture tube and camera tube iconoscope. By the mid-1950s, television had superseded radio for home and entertainment use. After the war, electron tubes were used to develop the first computers, but these tubes were impractical due to the size of the electronic components. In 1947, the transistor was invented by a team of engineers from Bell Laboratories. The transistor functions like a vacuum tube, but is smaller, lighter, consumes less power, and is more robust, and less expensive to manufacture due to its combination of metal connectors and semiconductor materials. The concept of the integrated circuit was proposed in 1952 by Geoffrey W. A. ​​Dummer, a British electronics expert with his Royal Radar Establishment. In 1961, integrated circuits went into full production by a number of companies, and equipment designs changed rapidly and in several different directions to adapt the technology. Electronic components in the form of a tool in the form of an object that is a supporting part of an electronic circuit that can work according to its use. Starting from directly attached to the circuit board in the form of PCB, CCB, Protoboard or Veroboard by means of soldering or not directly attached to the circuit board (with other connecting devices, such as cables). This electronic component consists of one or more electronic materials, which consist of one or several material elements and if put together, for the desired circuit design it can function according to the function of each component, some are for regulating current and voltage, leveling currents, insulating current, amplify the current signal and many other functions.

Positivism Functionalism Antipositivism Conflict theory Structuralism Symbolic interaction Intermediate distance Mathematical Critical theory Socialization Quantitative structures and agents Computational Qualitative Ethnography religion culture economic demographics law science science internet industry social networking gender crime class class family health city education environment knowledge deviance social psychology medical mobility politics race & ethnicity rationalization secularization stratification Journal Publishing Outline List of sociologists Index Sociology is the science that discusses various aspects of society and their influence on human life. sociology was first used by Auguste Comte and then expanded into a scientific discipline by Herbert Spencer. The development of sociology as a science is divided into four stages, namely the medieval period, the renaissance period, the period of sociology as the science of society using scientific methods from other disciplines (18th century AD), and the period of sociology as a science with an independent scientific method ( 19th century AD). Sociology has a clear object of study and can be investigated through scientific methods and can be structured into a coherent and interconnected system. The main object of study in sociology is the structure of society, social elements, socialization and social change. The branches of sociology are a combination of the science of social phenomena that occur in society with other sciences. Sociology was founded by the ancient Greeks. Initially, sociology was united with social philosophy. Separated because then community discussion revolves around matters that attract public attention. Such as war and social conflict. In the book Sociology: Society Diving in Society (2007), in the 19th century, a French philosopher named Auguste Comte expressed his concern about the state of French society after the booming French Revolution.

The impact of the revolution caused positive changes with the emergence of an atmosphere of democracy, but also brought negative changes. Negative changes in the form of class conflict that causes anarchism in society. Conflicts are triggered by a lack of understanding to cope with change or laws such as social stability arrangements. Under such conditions, Auguste Comte suggested that the study of society should be developed into an independent science. C tis where sociology was born as the youngest branch of the social sciences. The term sociology was popularized by Auguste Comte in his Cours de Philosophe Positive (1830). In the book it is explained that the object of sociology is human or society at large. Sociology then became a science that developed in Europe, especially in Germany and France. In the process of its development, sociology can be separated from other social sciences such as economics and history. Sociology, which is a thought against society, is slow to become a science that stands alone. Many efforts, both scientific and non-scientific, have shaped sociology as an independent science. The main motivating factor for the emergence of sociology is the increasing attention to the welfare of society and the changes that occur in it. At first, humans united all fields of knowledge as part of natural philosophy. Then natural philosophy developed into various branches of science, one of which is social philosophy. Social philosophy discusses the ethics that need to exist and be applied in society. Its characters are Plato (429-347 BC) and Aristotle (384-322 BC). Plato discussed the elements of sociology in the state, while Aristotle discussed social ethics. In its development, sociology became a knowledge that was different from social philosophy. Sociology prioritizes knowledge about social reality in society, compared to knowledge about how society applies ethics.

The Sthavira nikāya (Sanskrit: "Sect of the Elders"; Traditional Chinese: 上座部; pinyin: Shàngzuò Bù) is one of the early Buddhist schools. They broke away from the majority of the Mahāsāṃghikas at the time of the Second Buddhist Council. The Sthavira nikāya (Sanskrit "Sect of the Elders"; Traditional Chinese: 上座部; pinyin: Shàngzuò Bù) is one of the early Buddhist schools. The Sthavira nikāya broke away from the majority of the Mahāsāṃghikas at the time of the Second Buddhist Council resulting in the first schism in the Sangha. The Śāriputraparipṛcchā Mahāsāṃghika, a text written to give reasons for the school's deviation from the disciplinary code of the senior monks, asserts that the council met in Pāṭaliputra on the question of the vinaya, and it explains that the split occurred because the majority (Mahāsaṃgha) refused to accept additions to the Vinaya rules by minority (Sthavira). The Mahāsāṃghika, therefore, saw the Sthavira as a breakaway group trying to change the original Vinaya. Scholars generally agree that the matter of dispute is indeed a matter of the vinaya, and have noted that this Mahāsāṃghika account is supported by the vinaya texts themselves, since the vinayas associated with the Sthavira contain more rules than those in the Mahāsāṃghika Vinaya. Therefore, modern scholarship generally agrees that the Mahāsāṃghika Vinaya is the oldest. According to Skilton, future scholars might determine that a study of the Mahāsāṃghika school would contribute to a better understanding of the early Dhamma-Vinaya than the Theravada school. The Tibetan historian Buton Rinchen Drub (1290-1364) writes that Mahāsāṃghika used Prakrit, Sarvāstivādin used Sanskrit, Sthavira used Paiśācī, and Saṃmitīya used Apabhraṃśa. The Sthavira later divided into other schools such as: The Vibhajyavāda branch gave rise to a number of schools such as: The Theravada School in Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia has identified itself exclusively with the Sthavira, for the Pali word thera is equivalent to the Sanskrit sthavira.

Thales of Miletus was a philosopher who started the history of Western philosophy in the 6th century BC. Before Thales, Greek thought was dominated by mythological ways of thinking in explaining everything. The thought of Thales is considered the first philosophic activity and is called the father of philosophy. Because it tries to explain the world and the phenomena in it without relying on myths but on human ratios. He is also known as one of the Seven Wise Men (in Greek hoi hepta sophoi), whom Aristotle called 'the first philosopher'. Apart from being a philosopher, Thales is also known as an expert in geometry, astronomy, and politics. Together with Anaximander and Anaximenes, Thales belongs to the Miletus School. Thales did not leave written evidence regarding his philosophical thought. Thales's thoughts are mainly obtained through Aristotle's writings about him. Aristotle said that Thales was the first person to think about the origin of the universe. For this reason, Thales is also considered a pioneer of natural philosophy (natural philosophy). Thales (624-546 BC) was born in the city of Miletus which was the land of the Greeks in Asia Minor. Miletos' affluent situation allowed the people there to pass the time discussing and thinking about things. It was the beginning of philosophical activity so it is not surprising that the first Greek philosophers were born in this place. Thales was a merchant who often sailed to Egypt. In Egypt, Thales studied geometry and brought it to Greece. He is said to be able to measure the pyramid from its shadow alone. In addition, he can also measure the distance of ships in the sea from the coast. Then Thales became famous after successfully predicting the occurrence of a solar eclipse on May 28, 585 BC. Thales was able to make this prediction because he studied astronomical records stored in Babylon since 747 BC.

In politics, Thales was military and technical adviser to King Crosus in Lydia. In addition, he was also a political adviser to the twelve cities of Iona. Thales stated that water is the basic principle (in Greek arche) of all things. Water is the base, principal, and foundation of everything in the universe. Thanks to its own creative power and power, without any external causes, water is able to appear in all forms, is steady and imperishable. According to Thales, water is the source of life. Thales' argument for this view is how all living things' food ingredients contain water and how all living things also need water to live. In addition, water is a substance that can change state (solid, liquid, and gas) without decreasing. In addition, he also put forward the view that the earth is located above the water. Earth is seen as a material that once came out of the sea and then floated on it. Thales believed that everything in the universe has a soul. The soul is not only found in living things but also in dead things. This theory of animate matter is called hylezoism. Thales' argument was based on a magnet which was said to have a body and soul because it was able to move iron. In geometry, Thales is known for contributing what is called the theorem of Thales, although not necessarily entirely his original ideas. Thales' theorem contains the following: Based on the record of Herodotus, Thales once gave advice to the Ionian people who were being threatened by attacks from the Persian Empire in the mid-6th century BC. Thales advised the Ionians to form a common administrative and administrative center in the city of Teos which had a central position in all of Ionia.

In the branch of mathematics in topology, homeomorphism or topological isomorphism or dual or dimalar functions are continuous functions between topological spaces that have inverse functions that are also continuous. Homeomorphism is an isomorphism in a topological space category. Two topological spaces with a homeomorphism between them are called homeomorphic. The word homeomorphism comes from the Greek words ὅμοιος (homoios) = similar or the same and μορφή (morphē) = shape, shape, introduced to mathematics by Henri Poincaré in 1895. Roughly speaking, a topological space is a geometric object, with homeomorphism it is continuous bending and stretching to a new shape. Thus, the square and the circle are homeomorphic to each other, but not to the spherical shell and torus. However, this description can be misleading. Some malar deformations are not a homeomorphism, for example the curvature of a line into a point. Some homeomorphisms are not constant deformations, for example the homeomorphism between trefoil vertices and circles. One of the most repeated math jokes is that a topologist cannot tell the difference between a coffee cup and a donut, because a fairly soft donut can be shaped into a coffee cup by creating a depression which is then enlarged while keeping the donut hole the size of the cup handle. A function f:X→Y{\displaystyle f:X\to Y} between two topological spaces (X,TX){\displaystyle (X,{\mathcal {T}}_{X})} and (Y,TY ){\displaystyle (Y,{\mathcal {T}}_{Y})} is called a homeomorphism if it has the following properties: A function with these three properties is also called dicontinuous. If there exists a function with these properties, we say (X,TX){\displaystyle (X,{\mathcal {T}}_{X})} and (Y,TY){\displaystyle (Y,{\mathcal {T}}_{Y})} is homeomorphic. A swahomeomorphism or autohomeomorphism is a homeomorphism from a topological space to itself. Homeomorphism establishes an equivalence relationship within a class or family of topological spaces. This equivalence class is called a homeomorphism class.

The third condition, namely that f−1{\textstyle f^{-1}} be continuous, is very important. Suppose a function f:0,2π)→S1{\textstyle f:,2\pi )\to S^{1}} (inner circle R2{\textstyle \mathbb {R} ^{2}}) defined as f (ϕ)=(cos⁡ϕ,sin⁡ϕ){\textstyle f(\phi )=(\cos \phi ,\sin \phi )}. This function is bijective and continuous, but not a homeomorphism (S1{\textstyle S^{1}} is compact but 0.2π){\textstyle ,2\pi )} is not compact). The function f−1{\textstyle f^{-1}} is discontinuous at point(1,0){\textstyle (1,0)}, because even though f−1{\textstyle f^{-1}} maps ( 1,0){\textstyle (1,0)} to 0{\textstyle 0}, all neighbors of this point also contain points which this inverse function maps close to 2π{\textstyle 2\pi }, but the point -the point is outside the neighbors of 2π{\textstyle 2\pi }. Homeomorphism is an isomorphism in a topological space category. Thus, the composition of two homeomorphisms is also a homeomorphism, and the set of all the swahomeomorphisms X→X{\textstyle X\to X} forms a group, called the homeomorphism group of X, which is often denoted Homeo(X){\textstyle {\ text{Homeo}}(X)}. This group can be given a topology, such as a compact-open topology, which with certain assumptions can make it a topological group. For some purposes, homeomorphism groups may be too large, but with isotopic relations, we can reduce these groups to mapping class groups. As is usual in category theory, if given two mutually homeomorphic spaces, the homeomorphic space between them, Homeo(X,Y){\textstyle {\text{Homeo}}(X,Y)}is a tosor for the homeomorphic group Homeo(X ){\textstyle {\text{Homeo}}(X)} and Homeo(Y){\textstyle {\text{Homeo}}(Y)}and, by specifying a homeomorphism between X{\displaystyle X} and Y{ \displaystyle Y}the three sets can be identified. The intuitive criteria for stretching, bending, cutting and regluing require a certain amount of practice to apply correctly it may not be clear from the description above that defoliation. Therefore, it is important to realize that it is the formal definition given above that counts.

Dharma or Sanatana Dharma is absolute truth that is eternal and eternal. "truth" is different from "correct" because "true" is relative, adjusting to the point of view or perspective used, while "truth" is absolute and cannot be refuted from any point of view. Dharma (/ˈdɑːrmə/; Sanskrit: , romanized: dharma, pronounced dʱɐrmɐ] (listen); Pali: dhamma) is a key concept with multiple meanings in Indian religions, such as Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism and others. Although there is no direct single word translation for dharma in European languages, dharma is generally translated as "righteousness", "merit" or "religious and moral obligations" that govern individual behavior. Dharma is often equated with a particular religion/belief, but the term religion/belief is actually different from Dharma. In Hinduism, dharma is one of the four components of the Puruṣārtha, the goal of life, and denotes conduct deemed appropriate to the order that makes life and the universe possible. These include duties, rights, laws, conduct, virtues and "right way of life". In Buddhism, dharma means "cosmic law and order", as expressed by Buddhist teachings. In Buddhist philosophy, dhamma/dharma is also a term for "phenomenon". Dharma in Jainism refers to the teachings of the Tirthankara (Jina) and a collection of doctrines related to the purification and moral transformation of humans. In Sikhism, dharma means the right path and true religious practice and one's moral duty towards God. The concept of dharma has been used throughout the history of Vedic religion, and its meaning and conceptual scope have evolved over the millennia. The ancient Tamil moral text Tirukkuṟaḷ, although a collection of aphoristic teachings on dharma (aram), artha (porul), and kama (inpam),: 453 : 82  is wholly and exclusively based on aṟam, the Tamil term for dharma.

: 55  Like the other components of the Puruṣārtha, the concept of dharma is pan-Indian. The antonym of dharma is adharma. Dharma values ​​can be implemented properly by anyone, while religious values/beliefs can only be implemented properly by their respective adherents. Manu says: DHARMA EVA HATO HANTI, Dharmo RAKSHATI RAKSHITAH Meaning: A religion is destroyed/kills people but ultimately religion protects its followers. Dharma is eternal because it is able to make all those who have faith in it eternal by giving them ultimate knowledge. To get this better, let's think a little deeper and compare different nations, who were superpowers at some point in history. Greeks, Romans, Syrians, Persians, Macedonians, Babylonians, Phoenicians, Egyptians were powerful empires that once held power in human history; however none of them exist today. The two kingdoms had all the wealth, power and great armies. But they don't have the spiritual awareness to sustain themselves for long. And that lack of capacity was the reason for their extermination. But India or Bali do have such a capacity and so their religions suffer every attack and exist even today. Undoubtedly, Dharma plays an important role in keeping our culture alive. According to the definition given in the scriptures: DHAARNAAT DHARMAH Arinya: Dharma is something to be endured all the time. Thus, it is a powerful way that saves us from disaster and causes evolution. For example, the Vedas are not only a means of attaining comfort in the metaphysical world but also point the way towards overall development and well-being. Dharma: Dharma is the spirit of humanity. Dharma is the heart to feel humanity. Dharma is the examiner and investigator of the spiritual religion.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union   (green) 22.0% Irreligious 7.9% Austrian Muslims, officially the Republic of Austria (German: Republik Österreich; Austrian-Bavarian: Republic Östareich, see (help·info)), is a country that does not have a sea in Central Europe which consists of 9 (nine) states (Bundesländer), one of which is Vienna, Austria's seat of government as well as its largest city. Austria covers an area of ​​83,879 square kilometers and has a population of nearly 9,000,000 people. Austria is bordered by Germany and Czechia to the north, Slovakia and Hungary to the east, Slovenia and Italy to the south, and Switzerland and Liechtenstein to the west. Although German is the official language, many Austrian-Bavarian people communicate in everyday conversation. In about 976, Austria initially grew as a margrave (border zone) in the southeast of the Holy Roman Empire and developed into a duchy and principality. In the 16th century, Austria began to act as the heart of the Habsburg Monarchy and a younger branch of the House of Habsburg – one of the most influential dynasties in history. As a principal duchy, Austria was the principal part and seat of government of the Holy Roman Empire. After the dissolution of the Holy Roman Empire, Austria formed its own empire in the 19th century, which became the great power and leading force of the German Confederation. After its dissolution, the Austrian Empire went its own way, independent of the affairs of the other German lands. After the Austro-Prussian War and compromise with the Kingdom of Hungary, the Austria-Hungary bimonarchy (dual empire) was established. Austria entered World War I under Emperor Franz Joseph after the assassination of Archduke Ferdinand, heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne. Austria is also the birthplace of Adolf Hitler, who became Reich Chancellor of Germany. Before the invasion of Poland in 1939, Germany had annexed Austria through the Anschluss and seized the Sudetenland based on the terms stipulated in the Munich Agreement.

After the defeat of Nazi Germany and an extended period of Allied occupation, Austria re-established itself as a sovereign, democratic, and self-governing state, known as the Second Austrian Republic. Austria is a representative democracy using a parliamentary system with a directly-elected Federal President as head of state and the Chancellor as head of the federal government. Some of the major cities in Austria are Graz, Linz, Salzburg and Innsbruck. Austria always ranks in the top 20 countries with the highest GDP per capita in the world. The country achieves a high standard of living and in 2018 was ranked 20th in the world based on the Human Development Index. Vienna always ranks at the top of international quality of life indicators. What is now the Austrian Republic had been formed in 1918, after World War I, which resulted in the defeat of Austria-Hungary, from the former German-speaking monarchy, which was originally called German Austria. The Treaty of Saint-Germain established the boundaries and name of the Republic of Austria. This was followed by the loss of the region of South Tyrol (now part of Italy with the nomenclature Bolzano-Bozen Voivodeship). The Austrian First Republic was characterized by internal tensions that gave rise to civil war and an authoritarian dictatorship. As a result of the Anschluss, or annexation, the country was under Nazi German rule from 1938. After the collapse of Nazi Germany in World War II, Austria regained independence. The Second Republic proclaimed its perpetual neutrality in foreign policy affairs at the end of the Allied Occupation in 1955. Austria has been a member of the United Nations since 1955 and joined the European Union in 1995. Austria plays host role to OSCE and OPEC and is a member founder of the OECD and Interpol.

Eubacteria (Woese & Fox, 1977) Bacteria (scientific name: Bacteria) are a group of single-celled microorganisms classified at the domain level. Together with the Archaea domain, bacteria are classified as prokaryotes. Bacterial cells have a specific shape, such as a ball, rod or spiral, which is usually a few micrometers in size. Bacteria were one of the first forms of life to appear and currently inhabit the majority of habitats on Earth. Bacteria can live in soil, water, acidic hot springs, radioactive waste, to the Earth's crust. Bacteria also establish symbiotic relationships with plants and animals. Most of the bacteria are unknown, and only about 27 percent of the bacterial phyla have species that can be grown in the laboratory. The study of bacteria is called bacteriology, a branch of microbiology. Almost all animals depend on bacteria for their survival because only bacteria and some archaea have the genes and enzymes necessary to synthesize vitamin B12. This vitamin is obtained by animals through the food chain or produced by microorganisms that live in their digestive system. There are about 40 million bacterial cells in one gram of soil and one million bacterial cells in one milliliter of fresh water. Altogether, there are about 4–6 x 1030 bacteria and archaea on Earth, which form a biomass surpassed only by plants. Bacteria play an important role in the nutrient cycle, for example in the process of fixing nitrogen from the atmosphere and decomposing corpses. In communities of organisms around hydrothermal vents and cold vents, extremophile bacteria provide the nutrients needed to sustain life by converting dissolved compounds, such as hydrogen sulfide and methane, into energy. In humans and most animals, bacteria are most abundant in the digestive tract.

The skin is also inhabited by bacteria in large numbers. The majority of bacteria in the body are harmless because the body is protected by the immune system. In addition, many beneficial bacteria, especially as intestinal flora. However, several species of bacteria are pathogenic and cause infectious diseases, including cholera, syphilis, gonorrhea, anthrax, leprosy, and the plague. The most commonly found deadly bacterial disease is respiratory tract infection. Tuberculosis kills around two million people a year, mostly in Sub-Saharan Africa. Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections and are also used in agriculture, which has made antibiotic resistance a growing problem. In the industrial sector, bacteria play an important role in the treatment of waste and the decomposition of oil spills, the production of cheese and yoghurt through fermentation, the refining of gold, palladium, copper and other metals in the mining sector, as well as in biotechnology such as the manufacture of antibiotics and other chemicals. Bacteria are microscopic organisms that are difficult to detect, especially before the invention of the microscope. This organism was first observed in 1676 by Antony van Leeuwenhoek, a Dutch trader and scientist. He used a single-lens microscope he designed himself. Leeuwenhoek then published his observations in a series of letters to the Royal Society of London, which were published in English in 1684. Bacteria were objects within the limits of what Leeuwenhoek's simple lens could see and no one else could see them for over a century. Leeuwenhoek also observed protozoa, all of which he referred to as "small animals". Christian Gottfried Ehrenberg, German scientist, introduced the word bacterium in 1838. This word comes from a romanization of the Greek βακτηριον (bacterion), a diminutive form of βακτηρία (bacteria) meaning "rod" or "stick" because the first bacteria discovered were rod-shaped. .

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Geomorphology is a science that studies natural forms and the processes that shape them. Geomorphologists try to understand why a landscape looks the way it does, to understand the history and dynamics of the landscape, and predict future changes using a combination of field observations, experiments and modelling. Geomorphology is studied in geography, geology, geodesy, archeology and earth engineering. Geomorphology had become a scientific discipline before the 17th century AD. In the 19th century, geomorphology began to be applied to developing countries. In the 20th century AD, geomorphology experienced rapid development in the Western world (Europe and America). Basically the scope of study of geomorphology is the shape of the Earth's surface. In scientific discussions, the shape of the Earth's surface includes the discovery and identification of land forms and their forming factors. Geomorphology also discusses the history and origins of land forms. In addition, geomorphology also discusses the discovery and recognition of landscape-forming aspects of constructional and destructive landscapes. Geomorphology determines the object of study is the shape of the land. Therefore, the study aspects of geomorphology can be divided into 4, namely morphology, morphogenesis, morphochronology, and morphoarrangement. Morphology deals with issues of shape and origin of the Earth's surface. The discussion is divided into two into morphography and morphometry. Morphography provides a descriptive explanation with descriptions, while morphometrics provides a quantitative explanation through measurement. Morphogenesis discusses the morphological processes that cause changes in land forms. The discussion is carried out on the process of change in the short term as well as in the long term. Morphogenesis discusses changes in the shape of the land caused by exogenous and endogenous forces. Morphochronology discusses the evolution of the addition of the number of landforms due to the processes that work on these landforms.

Morphochronology also discusses the sequence and age of the formation of landforms. The morphoarrangement discusses the relationship between the landform and its constituent elements. The relationship between geomorphology and the environment is studied in the morphoarrangement. The formation elements discussed include rock and water content in the land, land structure, land vegetation and land use. Destructional landscapes are also known as exogenic landscapes. The formation of destructive landscapes is driven by exogenous forces. Exogenous forces are forces that result from the influence of forces from solar energy and gravity. Types of exogenous forces include weathering, erosion, mass wasting and sedimentation. Constructional landscapes are also known as endogenic landforms. The formation of destructive landscapes is controlled by ecdogenous forces. Endogenous forces include all types of forces originating from the Earth. In general, endogenous forces include tectonic activity, magmatic activity and volcanic activity. Tectonic activity is caused by plate shifts and the formation of mountains. Magmatic activity includes all magma intrusions that reach the Earth's surface or are near the Earth's surface. While volcanic activity includes the formation of volcanoes and volcanic eruptions. The main forming processes responsible for the formation of topography are wind, waves, weather, soil movement, water flow, glaciers, tectonics, and volcanism. [citation needed] Fluvial processes are natural formation processes related to the movement of sediments, erosion and deposits in rivers. citation needed] The aeolian process is a process related to wind as its forming source. Wind can erode, carry and collect material. reference needed] Soil and rock move downward under the force of gravity. reference needed] The movement of ice and glaciers can cause abrasion and move rocks. reference need] Tectonic processes occur due to tectonic activity. reference needed] Igneous processes greatly affect geomorphology, both from volcanic origin and from tectonics. References are needed] The interaction between living things and natural forms can affect the process of forming geomorphology. References are needed] Below are some forms of karst surface morphology in meters to kilometers in size: reference needed] The island of Java has a quite specific karst area, namely the Sewu Mountains karst, where the formation of hills like upside down cups and cones is so perfect with its valleys.

Tungsten, also known as tungsten, is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol W and atomic number 74. The term tungsten comes from the Swedish tung sten, meaning heavy stone. Its name in Swedish is volfram, but to differentiate it from scheelit, it is given the alternative name tungsten in Swedish. Natural tungsten is found on earth almost always as a chemical compound. It is a rare metal that is hard at standard conditions when not combined. It was identified as a new element in 1781, and first isolated in 1783. Important tungsten ores include wolframite and scheelite. Its free elemental resistance is remarkable, especially the fact that it has the highest melting point of all the elements discovered. It melts at 3,422°C (6,192°F). Its high density is up to 19.3 times that of water, comparable to uranium and gold, and higher (about 1.7 times) than lead. Polycrystalline tungsten is a brittle and hard material, making it difficult to work with. However, pure single-crystalline tungsten is more ductile, and can be cut using a hard steel saw. Many tungsten alloys have a variety of applications, including incandescent lamp filaments, X-ray tubes (both as filaments and targets), electrodes in WIG welding, superalloys, vacuum tubes, and radiation shielding. The hardness and high density of tungsten provide it with military applications in penetrating projectiles. Tungsten compounds are also often used as industrial catalysts. Tungsten is the only metal of the third transition series known to occur in biomolecules, which is used by several species of bacteria and archaea. It is the heaviest element known to be essential for living organisms. Tungsten interferes with molybdenum and copper metabolism and is mildly toxic to animal life.

In its raw form, tungsten is a hard gray metal that is often brittle and difficult to work with. When made very pure, tungsten retains its hardness (which exceeds that of most steels), and becomes malleable enough to be easily machined. It is processed by forging, drawing, or extrusion. Tungsten objects are also commonly formed by sintering. Of all the metals in its pure form, tungsten has the highest melting point (3,422°C (6,192°F)), lowest vapor pressure (at temperatures above 1,650°C (3,000°F)) and highest tensile strength. Although carbon remains solid at higher temperatures than tungsten, it sublimes at atmospheric pressure rather than melting, and so has no melting point. Tungsten has the lowest coefficient of thermal expansion of any pure metal. The low thermal expansion and high melting point and tensile strength of tungsten stem from the strong covalent bonds formed between the tungsten atoms by the 5d electrons. Alloying small amounts of tungsten with steel greatly increases its toughness. Tungsten exists in two main crystalline forms: α and β. The first form has a body-centered cubic structure and is a more stable form. The β-phase structure is called cubic A15; it is metastable, but may coexist with the α phase under ambient conditions due to synthesis or non-equilibrium stabilization by impurities. In contrast to the α phase which crystallizes in isometric grains, the β form exhibits a columnar stature. The α phase has one third the electrical resistivity and a much lower TC superconducting transition temperature than the β phase: ca. 0.015 K vs 1-4 K; mixing the two phases allows obtaining intermediate TC values. The TC value can also be increased by alloying tungsten with other metals (eg 7.9 K for W-Tc). Such tungsten alloys are sometimes used in low temperature superconducting circuits.

Herakleitos of Ephesus (Greek: Ἡράκλειτος ὁ Ἐφέσιος, Hērákleitos ho Ephésios) was a pre-Socratic Ancient Greek philosopher who did not belong to any school, although he can be classified by his origin as an Ionian thinker or philosopher who emerged in the region of Asia Minor (including Thales, Anaximanders, Anaximenes, and Xenophanes). In his writings, he actually criticized and denounced famous philosophers and figures, such as Homer, Archylochus, Hesiodos, Pythagoras, Xenophanes, and Hecataeus. Even though he turned away from the common philosophical teachings of his time, that does not mean that he was completely uninfluenced by those philosophers. Herakleitos is known to have written one book, but it has been lost. Until now, only 130 fragments have been stored, consisting of short proverbs, the meaning of which is often unclear. His philosophical thoughts are not easy to understand, so he is nicknamed "the dark one" (in English, the obscure). Herakleitos is known to have come from Ephesus in Asia Minor. He lived around the 5th century BC (about 540-480 BC). The account of Diogenes Laertius also states that Herakleitos was born around 540 BC into an aristocratic family in Ephesus, but later abandoned political life and devoted the rights of power he bequeathed to his brother. Herakleitos was a contemporary of Pythagoras and Xenophanes, but he was younger than both of them. However, Herakleitos was older than Parmenides because he was criticized by the philosopher. Apart from coming from a respectable family in Ephesus, there is no other credible information about the life history of Herakleitos considering that almost all sources regarding his life are anecdotes that are not authentic, imagined or made up by the author of the anecdotes based on Herakleitos' thoughts. No source mentions that he ever left his hometown, which was at that time part of the Persian empire.

If you look at the works he left behind, it appears that Herakleitos' character was arrogant and haughty. Apart from criticizing the above philosophers, he also looked down on the ignorant people and insisted that most humans were bad. In addition, he also cursed the citizens of Ephesus. The most famous thought of Herakleitos is that of changes in the universe. According to Herakleitos, nothing in the universe is permanent or permanent. Nothing really exists, everything is in the process of becoming. He is famous for saying panta rhei kai uden mei which means, "everything flows and nothing stays constant." Herakleitos envisioned this unceasing change in two ways: Everything that is constantly changing in the universe can operate in an orderly manner because of the logos. The view of logos here should not be equated with the concept of logos in the Stoic school. Logos is the ratio that becomes the law that controls everything and moves everything, including humans.
