Logos is also understood as something material, but at the same time transcends ordinary matter. This is because at that time, there were no philosophers who were able to separate the spiritual from the material. According to Herakleitos, every thing is composed of opposites. Nevertheless, in the resistance there is still unity. In short, it can be said that 'the one is many and the many is one.' Anaximenes also held this view, but the difference with Herakleitos was that Anaximenes said the conflict was injustice, while Herakleitos stated that the conflict was the principle of justice. We will not be able to know what 'day' is without us knowing what 'night' is. We will not know what 'life' is without the reality of 'death'.

Actinides are a group of chemical elements consisting of 15 elements, from actinium (Ac) to lawrencium (Lr) on the periodic table, with atomic numbers 89 to 103. This series is named after the elements actinium. All actinides except lawrencium are f-block elements. The actinide group elements are radioactive, with only actinium, thorium, and uranium found naturally in the Earth's crust. The actinide group of elements, which can also be called actinoida or actinone, consists of fifteen elements. The atomic spectra of these heavy elements are very complex, and it is difficult to characterize the levels in the quantum numbers and their configurations. The -ide suffix is ​​used to refer to anions (eg halide ions and oxides), the -on suffix is ​​chosen to refer to non-metals (such as the noble gas groups). This group of elements is metallic, so it is now recommended to use the –oid ending. The actinoide group of elements is in the last row under the body of the periodic table which was first proposed by Glenn Seaborg (1944). The 5f electron filling of actinoides is similar to that of lanthanoids, their chemical properties are not uniform and each element has unique properties. All actinoide metals are radioactive, highly toxic, and have half-lives that decrease dramatically with increasing atomic number. The main feature of the actinoide elements is that they are all electropositive metals. This actinoide metal has a fairly high density (15-20 g cm−1), high melting point (~1000 °C) and very high boiling point (~3000 °C). In addition, the actinoide metals are not as reactive as the lanthanide metals. Actinides have 15 elements, i.e. The actinoide elements are capable of forming oxidation states. Thus, actinoides lose 6dx 7s2 electrons, but some metals (Ac, Th, Pa, and U) are capable of removing 5f electrons thereby achieving the noble gas electronic configuration Rn].

The +3 state is the common one for all actinoids except for Th and Pa. The state prefers this state for Ac, Am, and all elements that follow Am. The most easily oxidized +3 ion is U3+, which is oxidized by air or more slowly by water. This +4 state is the main state for Th, and for Pa, U, Np, Pu, and Bk, the +4 cations are known in solution, but for Am and Cm in solution there are only fluoroanion complexes. All of them form +4 compound solids. Element 104 has been found only in the +4 state. The +5 state is the state favored by Pa, where Pa is similar to Ta. For U-Am only a few solid compounds are known. For these elements, the dioxo ion, MO2+ (aq) is important. Condition +6. The only simple compound is the hexafluoride, MF6, of U, Np and Pu. The main chemical is the dioxo ion MO22+ of U, Np, Pu, and Am. Condition +2 and +7. This state is very rare, and the +2 state is limited to Am (5f Eu analog) where +2 ions are present in the CaF2 lattice, and to Cf, Es, Fm, Md, and No, which have +2 ions in solution. Chemically this is the same as Ba2+. Md2+ ions are less oxidized than Eu2+. The +7 state is known only in oxo anions Np and Pu when alkaline solutions are oxidized by O3 or PuO2 and Li2O3 are heated in oxygen. All actinoid metals are radioactive and the half-life of actinoid elements decreases dramatically as the atomic number increases. The presence of uranium and thorium isotopes on earth is due to their long enough half-lives that allow them to remain since the beginning.

Time or period according to the Big Indonesian Dictionary (1997) is a whole series of moments when processes, actions, or conditions exist or take place. In this case, the time scale is the interval between two states/events, or it can be the duration of an event. The main types of time meters or clocks are: Time scales are measured by units: Different societies have relatively different views of the time they live. For example: Western society sees time as a straight line (linear). The straight-line concept of time is followed by the formation of the concept of sequence of events. In other words, human history is seen as a process of travel in a timeline from the past, present, and future. In contrast to Western society, Hindu society sees time as a cycle that continues without end. The way of looking at time is not just a way of looking at the ticking of a watch on the wall that keeps on rotating without stopping and waiting for orders from everyone, but time is more seen as an opportunity, money, and work that continues to carve out an endless life. Freedom of time occurs where people are able to provide all their creations, creations, and initiatives for all. To measure very fast time scales (in the world of electronics and semiconductors), most people use units: In the world of physics, the dimensions of time and space (length, area, and volume) are the fundamental units of measurement, as is the mass of an object. objects (time, length and mass). This combination of time, space and mass can be used to tell and explain the mysteries of the universe quantitatively (based on measurement results). For example power (energy) is expressed in units of measurement kg * (meters squared) / (seconds squared) or what we often know as units of watts * seconds or joules.

Untranslated articles can be quickly deleted according to criteria A2. Tennis or volleyball is a sport that is usually played between two players or between two pairs of two players each. Each player uses a racket to hit a rubber ball. The object of the game is to play the ball in such a way that the opposing player cannot return the ball. Tennis is an Olympic sport and is played at all levels of society at all ages. This sport can be played by anyone, including people who use wheelchairs. The modern game of tennis originated in Birmingham, England in the late 19th century as "lawn tennis". The rules of tennis have changed little since the 1890s. Two minor changes were that from 1908 to 1961 the player serving (the first shot) had to keep one foot on the ground until the service changed and the tie-break system was adopted in the 1970s. The last addition applied to professional tennis is electronic review technology. Tennis is played by millions of people as a recreational sport and is also a popular spectator sport worldwide. The four leading tennis championships are the Australian Open which is played on hard courts, the French Open which is played on clay courts, Wimbledon which is played on grass courts, and the US Open. also played on a hard court. The first origins of tennis are still a matter of debate. Some opinions believe that the ancient Egyptians, Greeks and Romans played a game that became the forerunner of tennis. Images or statements about the tennis-like game have never been found, but several Arabic words dating from ancient Egypt have been cited as evidence. These theories state that the word tennis comes from the name of an Egyptian city, Tinnis, which is located on the banks of the Nile and the word racket developed from the Arabic word for palm, namely rahat.

Most historians believe the origins of tennis are in an ancient game played in northern France in the 12th century. The game is played by hitting the ball with the palm of the hand. Louis X of France was a fan of the game jeu de paume, (“play of the palm”), which later developed into tennis, and he is credited with constructing indoor tennis courts according to the modern style. Louis disliked playing outdoor tennis and ordered indoor indoor courts to be built in Paris "around the end of the 13th century". Unfortunately, in June 1316 at Vincennes, Val-de-Marne, and after one particularly grueling game, Louis drank a large quantity of chilled wine and later died of pneumonia or pleurisy, although poisoning is also suspected. Because of his death, Louis X became the first tennis player whose name is recorded in history. Racquets came into use in the 16th century and the game began to be called "tennis", from the Old French term tenez, which could mean "hold!", "receive!", or "take!", an interjection used by The player serving is aimed at his opponent. The game was popular in England and France, although the game was only played indoors and the ball could occasionally go over the wall. It was only in the 19th century that tennis was revived by British aristocrats by building country club facilities or tennis courts in their big houses. Because at that time tennis was popularly played on lawns, it was known as 'Lawn Tennis' or grass court tennis. At this time, balls of vulcanized rubber began to appear, which at that time was thought to reduce damage to the grass on the field without reducing the elasticity of the ball itself.

Paris (French pronunciation: /pæˈriː/] or /pəˈriː/ paʁi] (help·info)) is the capital city of France. It is located on the river Seine, in northern France, in the heart of the Île-de-France region (also known as the "Paris Region"; French: Région parisienne). The city of Paris at its administrative limits (unchanged since 1860) has a population of 2,167,994 (January 2006). The Paris unité urbaine (or urban area) extends beyond the administrative city limits and has an estimated population of 9.93 million (2005). Paris' aire urbaine (or metropolitan area) has a population of nearly 12 million people, and is one of the most densely populated metropolitan areas in Europe. An important settlement for more than two millennia, Paris today is one of the world's leading business and cultural centers, and its mix of politics, education, entertainment, media, fashion, science and the arts all contribute to its status as one of the world's largest global cities. The Paris Region (Île-de-France) is the largest urban economy in Europe, and the fifth largest on the list of cities by world GDP. With €500.8 billion (US$628.9 billion), the city generated a quarter of France's 2006 gross domestic product (GDP). The Paris region has 36 of the Fortune Global 500 companies in several business districts, most notably La Défense, Europe's largest business district. Paris also has many international organizations such as UNESCO, OECD, ICC and Paris Club. Paris is the world's most popular tourist destination, with 30 million foreign visitors a year. There are a number of famous landmarks among its attractions, along with famous institutions and the world's most popular parks. Paris is pronounced paʀi] (help·info) in French. Paris' Latin name was Lutetia (/lutetja/), or Lutetia Parisiorum, (French: Lutèce (lytɛs])), which was later truncated to just Paris.

The name is derived from the Gallic Parisii tribe, whose name may be of Celtic Gallic origin, meaning "large kettle", but it is unrelated. Other authors ascribe the name Parisii to the Gallic Celtic word parisio meaning "workman" or "craftsman." Since the early 20th century, Paris has been known as Paname (panam) in French slang (Moi j'suis d'Paname, meaning "I am from Paname"), a slang that has become popular among teenagers in recent years. Parisians are known as Parisians pəˈɹɪzjənz] or pəˈɹiː.ʒn̩z] in English and Parisien (paʀizjɛ̃] (help info)) in French. The word Parigot (meaning "Parisian", pronounced paʀigo] (help info)) is sometimes used in French slang. Often considered pejorative, Parigot has good connotations, as in the famous song by Maurice Chevalier: "C'est un gars d'Ménilmontant, un vrai p'tit Parigot, ..." ("He's a man from Ménilmontant, a little Parisian, ..."). Locally, residents of the Paris suburbs are known as banlieusard bɑ̃ljøzaʀ] (help·info)), meaning banlieue ("suburb") residents. Residents of the Île-de-France region (Paris Region) are known officially as Francilien (fʀɑ̃siljɛ̃] (help info)). Parisians refer to people from outside Île-de-France as Provinciaux (from the different provinces). The use of this title, such as referring to all of France as la province, is sometimes considered pejorative. The earliest archaeological signs of a permanent settlement in Paris date back to 4200 BC. The Parisii, a Celtic sub-tribe of the Senones, known as the merchants[citation needed], inhabited the area near the river Seine since 250 BC[citation needed]. The Romans conquered the Paris basin around 52 BC, with a permanent settlement by the end of the same century on the Left Bank Sainte Geneviève Hill and the Île de la Cité. This Gallic-Roman city was originally called Lutetia, but was Galician to become Lutèce. It expanded greatly over the following centuries, becoming a prosperous city with a forum, palaces, baths, temples, theatres, and an amphitheatre.

Zirconium is a gray-white metal that is rarely found in nature. It has the chemical symbol Zr, atomic number 40, relative atomic mass 91.224. Zirconium metal is used in nuclear reactor cores because it is corrosion resistant and does not absorb neutrons. Zircaloy is an aliase of zirconium which is important for nuclear adsorption, such as coating fuel components. Zirconium is abundant in minerals such as zircon and baddelyite. Baddeleyit itself is a zirconium oxide that is resistant to extremely high temperatures, so it is used for furnace linings. Zirconium is an element in nature that is resistant to high temperatures. Zirconium does not exist in free form in nature but in the form of zirconium silicate in zircon (ZrSiO4) and zirconium oxide in badelleyite (ZrO2). Zirconium is found in volcanic rocks, basalt and granite rocks. The mineral baddeleyit or ZrO2 is a natural form of zirconium dioxide. The crystals have a density between 5.4 – 6.02 and a hardness of 6.5 on the mesh scale containing 80% – 90% zirconium dioxide. Zirconium is found in many zircon minerals varying from 61% - 67%. Theoretically zirconium in normal silicates is 67.2%. In small amounts, zirconium is found in many minerals such as the minerals titanate, tantolo niobat, rare earths, silicates, and so on. In rather large quantities, zirconium is found in baddeleyite minerals and zircon minerals or a mixture of zircon dioxide and zircon silicate (ZrSiO4). Zirconium has two allotropic forms namely α with a hexagonal structure, stable at temperatures of 863°C and below and β form with a latticed cubic structure that is stable at temperatures of 863°C and above. Zirconium metal is resistant to corrosion, does not react with water, acids (nitrates, sulfates as solvents) even with heating.

At high temperatures, zirconium can react with oxygen, nitrogen, halogens, sulfur, hydrogen or carbon. Zirconium as a result of processing from zircon sand in its utilization can be combined with other metal elements, which are called zircaloy. Commonly added metals include chromium (Cr), iron (Fe), nickel (Ni), tin (Sn), and copper (Cu). Zirconium is widely used in the High-tech industry due to its favorable mechanical, thermal, electrical, chemical and optical properties. This element is widely used in the production of ceramics and in nuclear reactors as a coating for nuclear fuel. Zirconium is also used to manufacture pumps, valves and heat exchangers. Due to its fire resistance properties, zirconium is often used as the main composition of armament equipment, fuse boxes, and is present in vacuum-opening pyrophoric bullets, as well as laser excitation in photography. The application of pure zirconium alloys, such as alloying them with niobium to produce a superconductor, alloying them with titanium is used in aircraft, and combining them with copper improves the properties of the zirconium. Due to its resistance to corrosion, zircon metal is used as an additive in pumps, faucets, pipes, heat exchangers and chemical tanks, especially sulfuric acid and hydrochloric acid. The use of zirconum metal is also used by factories producing urea, hydrogen peroxide, methyl methacryrate and acetic acid. Zirconium is a material that has a very strategic role in various industries because of its advantages compared to other materials. Nuclear reactors require corrosion-resistant materials, low neutron absorption, suitable mechanical properties, can be used as structural support materials, as well as surfaces for good heat transfer. Beryllium (Be) is a mineral that can withstand high temperatures, but this mineral is rare, besides being expensive, its mechanical properties are also not good and its fabrication is difficult.

iNews (short for Indonesia News, previously named SUN TV and Sindo TV) is a private television network in Indonesia. Owned by the conglomerate PT Media Nusantara Citra Tbk, its programs focus on news and sports content broadcast 24 hours a day. iNews initially broadcast under the name SUN TV, which was founded in June 2007. Its initial broadcast began on 2 February 2008 and was later launched on 5 March 2008, by which time it could only be viewed via subscription television Indovision, OkeVision, and Top TV (now all known as MNCVision). The name SUN TV is interpreted as Matahari TV, which is the hope that the show can give enthusiasm to the viewers. During its development, SUN TV planned to broadcast on a terrestrial basis (especially in Greater Jakarta) in June 2008, but this could not be realized due to the government's lack of permission. Even so, SUN TV then continued to try to expand its broadcasts by acquiring a number of other local television stations in various regions (for example Deli TV in Medan which was experiencing financial difficulties, and PRO TV in Semarang) with a percentage of 50-99% or forming partnerships, so that by the end of 2008 , SUN TV can already broadcast in 16 cities networked. In the end, on November 17 2009, SUN TV was only able to broadcast in Greater Jakarta by cooperating with a local television station based in Tangerang called TV3. In these networks (including TV3), the majority of their broadcast hours are relayed to SUN TV broadcasts (which broadcast their programs for viewers on Indovision, OkeVision and Top TV), while the rest broadcast local programs (which are adjusted to the tastes of the broadcasting city but still adhere to national standards). as well as infomercials during free time. With the vision of becoming one-stop television, entertainment-based SUN TV programs, coupled with a number of information and educational programs.

However, in 2011, TV3 separated from SUN TV and was later taken over by CTV Banten, so that SUN TV could not be enjoyed in Greater Jakarta on a terrestrial basis for several years. Even so, SUN TV still survives as the first local television network that broadcasts 24 hours non-stop in other areas. On September 26, 2011, SUN TV changed its name to Sindo TV which is part of the Sindo Media synergy with Sindo Radio and Sindonews.com. It is hoped that with this change, Sindo Media can become the wing of the MNC Group in the field of news-based media. Continuing what was pioneered by SUN TV, Sindo TV was originally a network television that broadcast its programs with a number of local television stations in various regions, such as PRO TV (Semarang), Urban TV (Batam), L-TV (Bandar Lampung), Minang TV ( fields), and others. Broadcasts on various local television stations (18 hours per day) are divided between local programs and Sindo TV programs. It can be said, Sindo TV is a pioneer of implementing a network system in Indonesia. Sindo TV programs tend to prioritize information/news, coupled with entertainment such as animated children's series and various programs that have been broadcast on RCTI, MNCTV and Global TV. In its development, Sindo TV then showed its intention to become a national television network, which can be seen by the changes in the logos of its network members to resemble its parent (dominated by blue and red). In 2013-2014, Sindo TV's identity was further strengthened by changing some of its network names to Sindo TV + regional names, or establishing new local television stations in several other regions with similar names. It is estimated that in 2014, Sindo TV will have 44 network members spread across various regions.

Leaves are one of the plant organs that grow from twigs, are usually green in color (contain chlorophyll) and primarily function as a catcher of energy from sunlight for photosynthesis. Leaves are important organs for plants to sustain their life because plants are obligate autotrophic organisms, they must supply their own energy needs through the conversion of sunlight energy into chemical energy. A perfect leaf is composed of three parts: the midrib, petiolus and leaf blade. The leaf sheath places the leaves on the stem. The petiole connects the sheath or stem to the leaf blade. The leaf blade is the most important part of most leaves because this is where the main function of the leaf as a photosynthetic organ is most dominant. The shape of the leaf blade is very diverse, but usually in the form of strands, can be thin or thick. The two-dimensional image of the leaf is used as a differentiator for leaf shapes. The basic shape of the leaf is rounded, with variations in the finger lobes or being elliptical and elongated. The extreme shape can be long tapered. Assorted leaf ornaments. The surface of the leaves can be covered with small hairs. Between the base of the leaf or petiole is often decorated with supporting leaves. On the leaves of grasses, the borders of the strands and the midrib are often decorated with ligulas. Leaves can also be modified into thorns (for example in cacti) and result in the leaves losing their function as photosynthetic organs. Leaves of succulent plants or xerophytes can also experience a change in function to become water storage organs. The green color of the leaves comes from the chlorophyll content of the leaves. Chlorophyll is a pigment compound that plays a role in selecting the wavelength of light whose energy is taken in photosynthesis. Actually leaves also have other pigments, such as carotene (orange), xanthophyll (yellow), and anthocyanin (red, blue, or purple, depending on the degree of acidity).

Old leaves lose chlorophyll so they turn yellow or red (this can be seen clearly in fallen leaves). The epidermis of leaves is the outermost layer of living cells. This tissue is divided into the upper epidermis and lower epidermis, which functions to protect the underlying tissue. Pole tissue or palisade tissue, this network contains many chloroplasts which function in the process of making food. One of the characteristics of this network is that the cells are cylindrical in shape, and are tightly packed and compact. Also called spongy tissue because it is more hollow when compared to palisade tissue, serves as a place to store food reserves. Consists of xylem or wood vessels and phloem or filter vessels, in dicotyledonous plants both are separated by cambium. In roots, xylem functions to transport water and minerals to the leaves. In the stem, xylem functions as a sponsor of plant enforcement. Phloem functions to distribute the results of photosynthesis from the leaves to all parts of the plant. Stoma (plural: Stomata) functions as a respiratory organ. Stoma takes CO2 from the air to be used as material for photosynthesis, releasing O2 as a result of photosynthesis. Stoma is like our nose where the stoma takes CO2 from the air and emits O2, while the nose takes in O2 and emits CO2. Stoma is located in the lower epidermis. Apart from stomata, higher plants also breathe through lenticels which are located on the stems. Stomata are opening structures that have guard cells beside them. In general, stomata are found under the leaf surface, but some are above or below. In lotus plants, stomata are only located at the top. Water plants do not have stomata at all, while grass plants have stomata above and below. The guard cells in the stomata of dicotyledonous plants are pea-like and are in pairs.

Argentina (Spanish pronunciation: aɾxenˈtina] ( listen)), officially the Republic of ArgentinaA] (Spanish: República Argentina), is a country in the southern and southeastern half of the South American subcontinent and is the largest Spanish-speaking country in the world. Its official name for legislative purposes is 'State of Argentina' (Nacion Argentina). Argentina covers an area of ​​2,780,400 square kilometers,B] which makes it the 2nd largest country in the South American continent after Brazil, the 4th largest country in the Americas, and the 8th largest country in the world. Its continental shelf, recognized by the United Nations in 2016, is 6,581,500 km², making it one of the largest in the world, stretching from the Americas to the South Pole in Antarctica, via the South Atlantic. If the island system of the Malvinas, South Georgia, South Sandwich and many other smaller islands (administered by the United Kingdom, but whose sovereignty is disputed) is counted, plus the portion of Antarctica called Argentine Antarctica south of the 60th parallel, which claims sovereignty by Argentina, the area has increased to 3,761,274 km². Argentina is one of 20 countries with a permanent presence in Antarctica, including among those with the largest number of permanent bases, six in all. Argentina is located in the southern part of the South American continent. Its position is between the Andes Mountains to the west and the Atlantic Ocean to the south. This location has earned Argentina the reputation as the 'southernmost country in the south' (Spanish: "Sur del sur"). Argentina controls most of the Southern Cone, is bordered by Chile to the west, and also borders to Bolivia and Paraguay to the north, Brazil to the northeast, Uruguay and the South Atlantic Ocean to the east, and the Drake Passage to the south. Argentina claims sovereignty over parts of Antarctica, the Malvinas Islands, and South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands.

Its territory incorporates great climatic diversity, which is due to latitude ranges exceeding 30° —including several geographic zones—, altitude differences ranging from 107 m below sea level (Laguna del Carbón) to nearly 7,000 meters above sea level and length coastline which reaches 4,725 km. Vast moist plains border vast deserts and high mountains, while the tropical and subtropical climate of the north contrasts with extreme cold and snowfall in the Andes and south. Argentina adopted a decentralized republican, democratic, representative and federated form of government, which since 1994 has been subdivided into 23 provinces and one autonomous city, which serves as the capital federala] and the largest city in the country, Buenos Aires which also serves as one of the most densely populated metropolises in the world. The federal capital and each province have their own constitution, flag and security forces, but are subject to a federal system. The 23 provinces retain all powers not delegated to the national State, have three autonomous powers and guarantee the autonomy of their municipalities. The earliest recorded presence of settlers in the area that is now Argentina dates back to 13,000 years BC, in the Paleo-American period. In ancient times, the Pre-Columbian period, it was inhabited by many indigenous peoples, some of whom still inhabit the country; among them Guaykuru, Guarani, Mapuche, Tehuelche, and Diaguita, the last of which was part of the Inca Empire. The Inca empire expanded to the northwest of the country in Pre-Columbian times. The country has its roots in the Spanish colonization of the region in the 16th century, which began with the voyages of exploration by Juan Díaz de Solís in 1512, the founding of settlements in 1528, and the division of territories in 1534.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union  (light blue) The Republic of Mozambique (Portuguese: República de Moçambique) is a country in southern Africa bordering South Africa, Eswatini, Tanzania, Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Mozambique is a member of the Community of Portuguese-Speaking Countries and the Commonwealth of Nations. The capital and largest city is Maputo which is located at the southern end. During the first and fifth centuries AD, Bantu-speaking tribes migrated from the far north and west to occupy the region. Then the Swahili tribes, and then the Arabs, established maritime trade along the coast until the arrival of Europeans. Vasco da Gama explored this area in 1498 and eventually this area became a colony of Portugal starting in 1505. After four centuries of Portuguese colonization, Mozambique gained its independence in 1975, and declared itself the People's Republic of Mozambique, in which the Communist regime ruled the country. until the late 1990s. After two years of independence, a protracted civil war broke out from 1977 to 1992. In 1994, Mozambique held its first elections with multiparty participation and achieved political stability thereafter. Mozambique is one of the poorest and most underdeveloped countries in the world. Mozambique has a large and wide natural wealth. The country's economy is largely dependent on agriculture, but industry, especially food and beverage, chemical manufacturing, aluminum and petroleum production is growing, as is the tourism sector. This country establishes special cooperation with South Africa in trade relations, as well as being a place for foreign investment from South Africa. Portugal, Brazil, Spain and Belgium are also important partners in economic cooperation. Since 2001, Mozambique's average GDP (Gross Domestic Product) growth has been high.

However, this country's ranking is still low in terms of GDP per Capita, Human Development Index, Social Inequality, and Life Expectancy. Even though there are more Christians than Muslims, Mozambique is a member of the OIC. Mozambique Island is a small atoll at the mouth of the Mossuril Bay on the coast of Nacala, northern Mozambique, first explored by Europeans in the late 15th century. After the Portuguese invaded Mozambique in around 1500, Portuguese trading posts and forts replaced the Arab military, becoming a port of call. regular on the new European sea route to the east. Vasco da Gama's journey around the Cape of Good Hope in 1498 marked the Portuguese foray into trade, politics and society in the region. The Portuguese gained control of the island of Mozambique and the port city of Sofala in the early 16th century, and in the 1530s, small groups of Portuguese traders and prospectors searching for gold penetrated the interior, where they established garrisons and trading posts at Sena and Tete on the Zambezi River and trying to gain exclusive control over the gold trade. In the central part of Mozambique, the Portuguese attempted to legitimize and consolidate their trading and settlement position through the creation of prazos (land grants) associated with their settlement and administration. While prazos were originally developed to be held by the Portuguese, through intermarriage they became African Portuguese or African Indian centers defended by a large army of African slaves known as Chikunda. Historically in Mozambique there was slavery. Humans were bought and sold by African tribal chiefs, first to Arab Muslim traders and shipped to Middle Eastern Asian cities and plantations, and then to other Portuguese and European traders as well. Many of Mozambique's slaves were supplied by tribal chiefs who raided the warring tribes and sold their captives to the prazeiros.

–  in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Spain (Spanish: España esˈpaɲa] ( listen)), officially known as the Kingdom of Spain (Spanish: Reino de España) is a country in Europe southwestern with Portugal, is on the Iberian Peninsula. Spain's land borders with Europe are the Pyrenees with France and Andorra. Its territory consists of the cities of Ceuta and Melilla in North Africa, the Canary Islands in the Atlantic Ocean, and various islands in the Mediterranean Sea. Spanish territory also includes the Balearic Islands in the Mediterranean, the Canary Islands in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Africa, and two autonomous cities in North Africa, Ceuta and Melilla, which border Morocco, plus Alboran, Chafarinas Islands, Alhucemas, Vélez de la Gomera and other smaller islands. including Perejil. In addition, the city of Llívia is a Spanish exclave situated within French territory. With an area of ​​505,992 square kilometers (195,365 square miles), Spain is the second largest country in Western Europe and the European Union and the fifth largest country in Europe. Modern humans first arrived on the Iberian Peninsula around 35,000 years ago. It came under Roman rule around 200 BC, after which the region was named Hispania. In the Middle Ages it was conquered by Germanic tribes and later by the Muslim Moors to the south. Spain emerged as a unified nation in the 15th century, following the marriage of the Catholic Monarchs and the completion of the centuries-long conquest, or Reconquista, of the peninsula from the Moors in 1492. Spain became an influential global empire in the early modern period, being one of the first nations to colonize the World. New and left a legacy of more than 500 million Spanish speakers today, making it the second most spoken first language in the world.

Spain is a democracy organized in a parliamentary form of government under a constitutional monarchy. It is a developed country with the thirteenth largest economy in the world by nominal GDP. Spain also has a high standard of living with the tenth highest quality of life index ranking in the world in 2005. It is a member of the United Nations, NATO, OECD, and WTO. The origin of the Roman name Hispania, from which the modern name España is derived, is uncertain and may not be known due to insufficient evidence. Hispania may have originated from the poetic use of the term Hesperia, reflecting the Greek perception of Italy as the "land of the West" or "land of the setting sun" (Hesperia, Ἑσπερία in Greek) and Spain, which was still further west, such as Hesperia ultima. It may also be a derivation from the Punic I-Shpania (אי שפניא), meaning "island of rabbits", "land of rabbits" or "edge", a reference to Spain's location in the late Mediterranean; Roman coin struck in the region of Hadrian's reign showing a female figure with a hare at his feet. There are also claims that Hispania is derived from the Basque word Ezpanna meaning "edge" or "border", another reference to the fact that the Iberian peninsula is southwest of the European continent. Renaissance scholar Antonio de Nebrija suggests that the word Hispania evolved from the Iberian word Hispalis, meaning "city of the west". Jesús Luis Cunchillos argues that the root of the term span is a Phoenician word spies, meaning "to forge metal". Hence i-spn-ya means "the land where the metal is forged". Spain is one of the former colonies of the Roman Empire in 218 BC – 400 AD in their mission to expand their territory. With the colonial period that long, of course, they "romanized" a lot of things, such as culture and buildings.

Liquids are incompressible fluids that conform to the shape of their container but maintain a (nearly) constant volume regardless of pressure. As such, it is one of the four basic states of matter (the others being solid, gas, and plasma), and is the only state with a definite volume but no fixed shape. Liquids consist of particles of matter with fine vibrations, such as atoms, held together by intermolecular forces. Water is, by far, the most common liquid on Earth. Like gases, liquids can flow and take the shape of their container. Most liquids are incompressible, although others are compressible. Unlike gases, liquids do not spread to fill every space of the container, and maintain a fairly constant density. A characteristic property of the liquid state is surface tension, which leads to the wetting phenomenon. The density of liquids is usually close to that of solids, and much higher than that of gases. Therefore, liquid and solid are both called condensed matter. On the other hand, since liquids and gases share the ability to flow, they are both called fluids. Although water is abundant on Earth, this state of matter is actually the least common in the known universe, because the existence of liquid requires a relatively narrow temperature/pressure range. Most known matter in the universe exists in the gaseous state (with detectable traces of dense matter) as interstellar clouds or in the plasma form within stars. Liquid is one of the four main states of matter, along with solid, gas and plasma. Fluid is fluid. Unlike solids, molecules in liquids have much greater freedom of movement. The forces that bind molecules together in solids are only temporary in liquids, allowing the liquid to flow while the solid remains rigid.

Liquids, like gases, display fluid properties. Liquids can flow, imagine the shape of a container, and if placed in a closed container, will distribute pressure evenly over every surface of the container. If the liquid is placed in the bag, it can be pressed into any shape. Unlike gases, liquids are nearly incompressible. It has a nearly constant volume over a wide pressure range; it does not expand to fill the empty space in a container but forms its own surface, and does not always mix easily with other liquids. This property makes the fluid suitable for applications such as hydraulics. The liquid particles are held together tightly but not rigidly. They are able to move freely, resulting in a limited degree of particle mobility. As the temperature increases, the molecular vibrations increase causing the distance between molecules to increase. When the liquid reaches its boiling point, the cohesive forces holding the molecules together are broken, and the liquid turns into a gas (unless superheating occurs). If the temperature drops, the distance between the molecules gets closer and closer. When a liquid reaches its freezing point, the molecules usually lock together into a specific order, which is called crystallization, and the bonds between them become more rigid, turning the liquid into its solid state (unless supercooling occurs). There are only two elements that are liquids at standard temperature and pressure: mercury and bromine. Four other elements have melting points just above room temperature: francium, cesium, gallium and rubidium. Metal alloys that are liquid at room temperature include NaK, sodium-potassium alloys, galinstan, and some amalgams (alloys involving mercury). Pure substances that are liquids under normal conditions include water, ethanol and many other organic solvents. Water is a vital fluid in chemistry and biology; it is believed to be a vital necessity for survival.

Histology or microscopic anatomy is a branch of biology that studies the structure of cells and tissues in detail using a microscope. Histological activities are carried out on thinly sliced ​​tissue preparations. Histology is very useful in studying the physiological functions of cells in the body, both humans, animals and plants, and in the form of histopathology it is useful in diagnosing diseases involving changes in physiological functions and organ deformation. For example, in medicine, the presence of a tumor requires the results of a tissue sample. In agriculture, examination of the condition of the transport network can support the diagnosis of tobacco leaf blight. Histology greatly requires the use of microscopy as well as the technique of providing tissue samples. The method of making histological preparations is called microtechnics. Making preparations from a tissue begins with surgery, biopsy, or autopsy. The extracted tissue is then processed with a fixative which will prevent the preparation from being damaged (shifted in position, rotted, or damaged). The most commonly used fixative for animal (including human) tissues is formalin (10% formaldehyde dissolved in water). Bouin's solution can also be used as an alternative fixative although the results will not be as good as formalin because it will leave yellow marks and artifacts. Artifacts are objects that are not present in the original tissue, but appear in the final preparation. This artifact was formed due to imperfect preparations. The fixed tissue sample is immersed in a graded ethanol (alcohol) liquid for the process of removing water from the tissue (dehydration). Then the sample was transferred into toluene to remove alcohol (dealcoholization). The final step is to place the tissue sample in hot paraffin which infiltrates the tissue. During this process which lasts for 12-16 hours, the tissue that was initially soft will become hard so that it is easier to cut using a microtome.

Flowers or flowers (an absorption word from Javanese: ꦏꦼꦩ꧀ꦧꦁ, translit. kêmbang; Latin: flos) are a means of sexual reproduction in flowering plants (divisio Magnoliophyta or Angiospermae, "closed seed plants"). In flowers there are reproductive organs, namely stamens and pistils. Flowers can appear singly or together in a series. Flowers that appear together are known as compound interest or inflorescence. In some species, compound interest can be considered ordinary as a (single) flower, for example in Anthurium and sunflower. The floral units that make up compound interest are called florets. Botanically, the flower is the part of the plant that produces seeds. Pollination and fertilization take place in flowers. After fertilization, the flower will develop further to form the fruit. In flowering plants, the fruit is a structure that carries and protects the seeds. The biological function of flowers is the sexual organ, as a vessel for the union of male (microspores) and female (macrospores) gametes to produce seeds. That flowers are analogous to sexual organs in animals was only scientifically realized in the 17th century in Europe. Some flowers have bright colors that function as pollinator animal decoys. Some other flowers produce heat or a distinctive aroma, also aimed at luring animals to help pollinate. Flowers can also be considered as organs to survive in unfavorable conditions for growth. A number of plants will immediately form flowers if they experience a lack of water or low temperatures. The best known example is the Bougainvillea paper flower. Flowers reduce metabolism and if the plant dies, seeds are expected to have formed as a survival effort. Humans have long been fascinated by flowers, especially the colorful ones that have cultural significance. Flowers are one of the determinants of the value of a plant as an ornamental plant.

Flowers are modified leaves and stems around them. This modification is caused by the production of a number of enzymes stimulated by a number of certain phytohormones. Flower formation is tightly controlled genetically and in many species is induced by certain environmental changes, such as low temperature, long exposure to light, and availability of water (see section Flowers: Flower formation). Flowers are almost always symmetrical in shape, which can often be used as an identifier for a taxon. There are two flower shapes based on their shape symmetry: actinomorphic ("star-shaped", radial symmetry) and zygomorphic (mirror symmetry). The actinomorphic form is more common. A flower is called a perfect flower if it has male organs (stamens) and female organs (pistils) together in one organ. Such flowers are called pansy or hermaphrodite flowers. A flower is said to be a complete flower if it has all the main parts of the flower. The four main parts of a flower (from outside to inside) are as follows: The female reproductive organ is the fruit leaf or carpellum at the base of which there is an ovary (ovary) with one or a number of ovule (ovulum, plural ovules) which carry female gametes) inside embryo sac. At the tip of the pistil there is a stigma or stigma to receive pollen or pollen. The pistil or stylus serves as a pathway for the pollen to the ovary. Although the floral structure described above is said to be a "common" plant structure, plant species exhibit highly variable modifications. This modification is used by botanists to make connections between plants with one another. For example, the two subclasses of flowering plants are distinguished by the number of floral organs: dicot plants generally have 4 or 5 organs (or in multiples of 4 or 5) whereas monocot plants have three organs or multiples thereof.

The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) is the UK's public broadcaster. Headquartered at Broadcasting House in Westminster, London, the BBC is the oldest national broadcaster in the world (formed in 1927), and the broadcaster with the largest number of employees in the world. The BBC employs more than 22,000 staff in total, more than 16,000 of whom are in public sector broadcasting. There are a total of 35,402 staff when part-time, flexible and permanent contract staff are included. The BBC was established under a Royal Charter and operates under an agreement with the UK Government's Secretary of State for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport. Its activities are funded primarily by the annual television license fee charged to all households, companies and organizations in the UK who use any type of equipment to receive or record broadcasts from television directly and through the iPlayer service. License fees are set by the UK Government, agreed by Parliament, and are used to fund the BBC's radio, television and online services covering the countries and territories of the UK. Since 1 April 2014, the fee has also funded the BBC World Service (launched in 1932 as BBC Empire Service), which broadcasts in 28 languages ​​and provides comprehensive television, radio and online services in Arabic and Farsi. The BBC's television services in Britain include BBC One, BBC Two, BBC Three, BBC Four, the news channel BBC News, and two children's channels, CBBC Channel and CBeebies. The BBC also maintains a station devoted to politics, BBC Parliament, which provides news on the Parliaments of Britain, Scotland, the European Parliament and the United States Senate. BBC operations are run by BBC Worldwide including its international television channels such as BBC World News, BBC Prime, BBC America, BBC Canada and BBC Japan.

From its beginnings, through World War II (where its broadcasts helped unify the country), through the 21st century, the BBC has played an important role in British life and culture. BBC television was founded in 1932 in London, England. The following are a number of television stations managed by the BBC, both BBC Television in the UK and BBC Television Abroad. The channel was the first BBC TV, launched in 1936, BBC One can be received digitally in the UK. This channel is the second BBC TV, founded in 1964, BBC Two can be received digitally in the UK. This channel is the BBC's third TV channel, founded in 2003, BBC Three can be received analogously in the UK. It is the fourth BBC TV channel and also the youngest, founded in 2004, BBC Four can be received analogously in the UK. The BBC's 24/7 news channel in England. BBC TV channel providing information about the UK parliament. BBC TV channels that HDTV can catch. BBC TV channel for children over 6 years. BBC TV channel for children under 6 years. BBC International news channel 24 hours / 7 days. As well as being the first BBC foreign TV channel. BBC TV channel caught in USA. Arabic language BBC TV Channels 24 hours / 7 days. BBC TV channel captured in Canada. BBC TV Channels for entertainment 24 hours / 7 days. BBC TV channel for culinary tours 24 hours / 7 days. The BBC TV channel for children is captured also in Canada. Replaces CBBC Channel and CBeebies. BBC TV channel showing documentaries & real life in the world.

Cybernetics is an interdisciplinary study of the structure of regulatory systems. Cybernetics is closely related to information theory, control theory, and systems theory, at least in its first order form. (Second-order cybernetics has crucial methodological and fundamental epistemological implications for the field as a whole.) Both in its original form and in its evolution in the second half of the 20th century, Cybernetics is equally applicable to physical and (language-based) social systems. Template:Cybernetics Science is most applicable when the system to be analyzed is involved in a closed loop signal; that is, when the action of the system causes some change in its environment and that change feeds into the system through information (feedback) that causes the system to adapt to these new conditions: the change in the system affects its behavior. This "cause-and-effect" relationship is necessary and sufficient for a cybernetics perspective. Systems dynamics, a related field, began with the application of electrical engineering control theory to other types of simulation models (particularly business systems) by Jay Forrester at MIT in the 1950s. Contemporary cybernetics began as an interdisciplinary study linking the fields of control systems, circuit theory, mechanical engineering, modeling logic, evolutionary biology, neuroscience, anthropology, and psychology in the 1940s, often associated with the Macy's Conference. Other fields of study that have influenced or been influenced by cybernetics include game theory, systems theory (a mathematical counterpart to cybernetics), perceptual control theory, sociology, psychology (especially neuropsychology, behavioral psychology, cognitive psychology), philosophy, architecture and organizational theory. The term cybernetics comes from the ancient Greek κυβερνήτης (kybernētēs, helmsman, governor, pilot, or rudder - the same root as government). Cybernetics is a very broad field of study, but the important goal of cybernetics is to understand and determine the functions and processes of systems that have a purpose and participate in a causal chain loop that moves from action to sensing and then compares it with the desired goal. and back to action.

Aesthetics is a branch of philosophy that deals with beauty. Aesthetics is the science that discusses beauty can be formed and can feel it. Further discussion of aesthetics is a philosophy that studies sensory values ​​which are sometimes considered as judgments of sentiment and taste. Aesthetics is a branch that is very close to the philosophy of art. Aesthetics comes from the Greek αἰσθητικός (aisthetikos, meaning "beauty, sensitivity, awareness, related to sensory perception"), which is a derivative of αἰσθάνομαι (aisthanomai, meaning "I see, feel, feel"). First used by the philosopher Alexander Gottlieb Baumgarten in 1735 for the notion of the science of things that can be felt through feelings. Even though initially something beautiful is judged from a technical aspect in forming a work, changes in the mindset of society will also influence the assessment of beauty. For example, at the time of romanticism in France, beauty meant the ability to present a majesty. In the era of realism, beauty meant the ability to present something as it is. At the time of de Stijl's rise in the Netherlands, beauty meant the ability to combine color and space and the ability to abstract objects. Further developments made him realize that beauty does not always have a certain formula. It develops according to the public's acceptance of the ideas raised by the creator of the work. That's why there are always two things known in the assessment of beauty, namely the beauty, a work that is recognized by many parties to meet the standards of beauty, and the ugly, a work that does not meet the standards of beauty at all and is considered by many people to be bad, but when viewed from many things turn out to show beauty. Beauty should have been judged when works of art were first created, but the definition of beauty was first documented by the philosopher Plato who determined beauty from proportion, harmony, and unity.

Carbohydrates ('hydrates of carbon'), carbohydrates, or saccharides (from the Greek σάκχαρον, sákcharon, meaning "sugar") are biomolecules composed of carbon (C), hydrogen (H), and oxygen (O) atoms, usually with a hydrogen–oxygen atom ratio of 2:1 (as in a water molecule) and the empirical formula Cm(H2O)n (with m may be the same or different from n). However, not all carbohydrates fit this stoichiometric definition (eg uronic acid and deoxy sugars such as fucose) and some contain nitrogen, phosphorus or sulphur. In addition, not all chemicals that fit this definition are automatically classified as carbohydrates (eg formaldehyde). Biochemically, carbohydrates contain a carbonyl functional group (as an aldehyde or ketone) and many hydroxyl groups (–OH), or compounds which yield these compounds when hydrolyzed. The simplest form of carbohydrate molecule consists of one simple sugar molecule called a monosaccharide, such as glucose, galactose, and fructose. Two monosaccharides joined together are called disaccharides, for example sucrose is made from glucose and fructose. There are also oligosaccharides which are a series of several monosaccharides. Many carbohydrates are polymers (long repeating chains), which are composed of many chains of sugar molecules, called polysaccharides, such as starch, chitin, and cellulose. Carbohydrates are the most abundant organic compounds on Earth. Carbohydrates have various functions in living bodies, primarily as fuel (eg glucose), food reserves (eg starch in plants and glycogen in animals), and building materials (eg cellulose in plants, and chitin in animals and fungi). In the process of photosynthesis, chlorophyll plants and some other organisms convert carbon dioxide into carbohydrates. Nutritionists divide carbohydrates into two, namely simple carbohydrates (eg sugar and candy) and complex carbohydrates (eg whole grains and foods that contain fiber such as fruit).

In the scientific literature, the term "carbohydrate" has many synonyms, such as "sugar" (in its broadest sense), "saccharides", "oses", "glucoses", "carbon hydrates" or "polyhydroxy compounds with aldehydes or ketones". Some of these terms, in particular "carbohydrate" and "sugar", are also used with other meanings. In food science and in many informal contexts, the term "carbohydrate" often refers to foods that are rich in complex carbohydrates, which are starches (such as cereals, bread, and pasta) or simple carbohydrates, such as sugar (found in candies, jams, and desserts). . Often in nutritional information lists, such as the USDA National Nutrient Database, the term "carbohydrate" is used for anything other than water, protein, fat, ash, and ethanol. Sometimes it includes chemical compounds such as acetic acid or lactic acid, which are not normally considered carbohydrates. On the nutrition label, carbohydrates also include dietary fiber which is a carbohydrate but does not contribute much food energy (kilocalories), although it is often included in calculations of total food energy as if this fiber were sugar. In a narrow sense, "sugar" is applied to sweet, soluble carbohydrates, many of which are used in food. Previously, the name "carbohydrate" was used in chemistry for any compound with the formula Cm(HO)n. According to this definition, some chemists consider formaldehyde (CH2O) to be the simplest carbohydrate, while others claim the name glycolaldehyde as the simplest carbohydrate. Today, the term carbohydrate is generally understood in a biochemical sense, excluding compounds having only one or two carbons and including many biological carbohydrates that deviate from this formula. While the above formula seems to cover the most common carbohydrates, the abundant and ubiquitous carbohydrates often deviate from the formula.

Shantideva (also known as Śantideva, Zh: 寂天) was a Buddhist scholar who originated in India in the 8th century. He is a scholar of Nalanda University and a follower of the Prasangika Madhyamaka philosophy. The Chinese Madhyamika sect Chan Ssu Lun identifies two distinct individuals under the name "Shantideva", the first being Shantideva who was the founder of the Avaivartika Sangha in the 6th century and the other being Shantideva who studied at Nalanda University in the 8th century, Shantideva it is the latter that appears in various Tibetan biographical sources. An excerpt of this discovery can be found at Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh, a website developed by the Asiatic Society of Bangladesh, or you can also refer to the Bodhicaryavatara Historical Project Archived 2014-08-17 at the Wayback Machine., An academic research project that originated at Mahabodhi Sunyata Seminary in Tarragona, Spain. Shantideva was born in northern Bodhgaya. His father's name was Gyelwey Gocha (Winning Armor), his mother's name was Vajrayogini. Shantideva was born with various amazing signs, with the nickname Shiwe Gocha (Peace Vest). As a child she respected her parents very much, and her playmates also respected her very much because of her noble attitude and character. His father passed away to demonstrate that all beings are impermanent, and later Shantideva's realization of impermanence and death grew. When his father died, he had no other choice but to accept the reins of king. He could not refuse, therefore he accepted to ascend the throne of the king. One night before the ceremony, Manjusri appeared in his dream and said: “You will sit on my throne. You are my student. “How can a student and a teacher sit on the same throne? Instantly he woke up from a dream and realized that he would be more useful if he became a monk than ascending the throne to become a king.

That same night he went to Nalanda Monastery. When he arrived in Nalanda he met the famous scholar of Nalanda; Gyalwa Lha, and it was also as the abbot of Nalanda, he received the ordination with the name of Shantideva. Under the direct guidance of the abbot, Shantideva became very good at learning, debating, and many other things. Although he was an extraordinary scholar, he did not show his intelligence to others. A group of students from a school in Nalanda were not happy to see Shantideva and wanted to expel him from the monastery. They loudly said that Nalanda was a monastery full of famous scholars, and he belittled Shantideva by saying that Shantideva was not a scholar at all, all he knew was eating, sleeping, urinating, and defecating. Therefore they challenged Shantideva to give Dharma lessons, if he did not want to, then he should immediately leave the monastery. The first request was rejected, then the second request he accepted. They made a plan to insult him in front of other classmates. They built a very high throne, so that Shantideva could not climb and sit on the throne. The monk of the school also gathered a number of other monks of the school. As Shantideva walked towards the throne, touched it gently and the big and tall throne suddenly became low and Shantideva could climb on it. At that moment they all felt strange, how could this happen? Then Shantideva sat on the throne and asked them, "What lesson should he give, something that has already been taught or something that has never been taught?" They begged him to teach a dharma lesson that had never been taught before.

Faith is the energy that accumulates due to the opening of feelings; there is a desire, there is an unwillingness, the memory feels stronger, the energy of belief increases and turns into energy of belief, and there is an urge to choose a certain feeling or a certain way. Memories feel stronger (good or bad memories, don't always have to be felt). Then the energy goes to the words that are inside, spoken words, silence, motion, style, assertiveness, or doing something. Examples of Using the Energy of Faith. 1. A baby who can't walk yet feels sure he can walk and then tries to do it, because he wants to walk. When he didn't succeed, he cried sadly, his belief changed to believing or doubting, but he became convinced again when he wanted to be able to walk. Then his parents taught him little by little until he could walk. 2. A cellphone user has never seen a cellphone creator, but still believes that cellphones have benefits for life. Even though here and there there are still problems or misuse of cellphones and so on, he is still confident. Previously, he was someone who didn't know cell phones, came to know cellphones, learned them little by little, until he was sure of using cellphones in his daily life. 3. An alcoholic is sure that he must choose hatred, then he says he hates other people, but so that he is seen as a victim, because he wants money or alcohol. 4. A brawler believes he still chooses revenge, because he doesn't want anything and because he wants to fight. 5. Someone who feels sorry for seeing other people's circumstances helps him confidently without hesitation. 6. A public figure believes that the public must have various kinds, different points of view, various opinions, and so on, so he doesn't really care about those differences.

in ASEAN (dark gray)-Legend] Republic of Myanmar Unity (Myanmar: ပြည်ထောင်စု သမ္မတ မြန်မာနိုင်ငံတော်, MLCTS: Pranyhtau: Ngcu. Sammata. Mranmanuingngamtau) "Burman" in the Western world) is a sovereign state in Southeast Asia. Myanmar is bordered by India and Bangladesh to the west, Thailand and Laos to the east and China to the north and northeast. The country of 676,578 km² has been ruled by a military government since the 1988 coup. It is a developing country and has a population of over 51 million (2014 census). The nation's capital was previously located in Yangon before being transferred by the military junta government to Naypyidaw on November 7, 2005. Myanmar has joined as a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) since 1997. Early civilization in Myanmar included a Tibeto-Burmese speaking population in Northern Burma and the Mon Kingdom in Southern Burma. In the 9th century, the Bamar people entered the upper valley of the Irrawaddy River, following which the Pagan Kingdom was founded in the 1050s. Since then, the Burmese language, including Theravada culture and Buddhism has slowly become dominant in the country. The Pagan Kingdom fell due to the Mongol invasion. In the 16th century, after being unified by the Taungoo Dynasty, the country briefly became the largest empire in Southeast Asian history. In the 19th century, the Konbaung dynasty ruled the area that includes modern Myanmar and briefly controlled Manipur and Assam. The British ruled Myanmar after the 3 Anglo-Burmese Wars in the 19th century and the country later became a British colony. Myanmar gained independence in 1948, initially as a democracy, but after a 1962 coup it was ruled by the military.

After independence, this country experienced a lot of ethnic violence. During this period, the United Nations and many other organizations reported continuing and systematic violations of human rights. In 2011, the military junta was dissolved after the 2010 general elections were held, and civilian rule began. This, along with the release of Aung San Suu Kyi and other political prisoners, has improved the country's human rights record and foreign relations, allowing it to escape economic sanctions. However, this country has not been free from criticism due to the government's treatment of ethnic minorities. In the 2015 general election, Aung San Suu Kyi's party won a majority in parliament. However, the Myanmar military remains a major force in politics. Myanmar is a country rich in jade, gemstones, petroleum, natural gas and other minerals. Income inequality in Myanmar is one of the widest in the world, as most of the economy is controlled by a few people backed by the military. As of 2016 update], Myanmar occupies 145th position out of 188 countries in the world according to the (Human Development Index). The prehistoric times of Myanmar or Burma were no different from other Southeast Asian countries. Typical Southeast Asian tools that appeared for the first time during the middle Pleistocene, the tool is a stone plate sharpened on one side which is often called an axe, evidence has been found in the highlands of Burma which is associated with the stone age period. Judging from the findings in the Burmese region, since prehistoric times it has been inhabited by humans. If you look at other areas such as Java, which produced tools like that, it was Homo Wajakensis, so that in Burma the same species lived as in Java, so prehistoric life in Burma was no different from in the rest of Southeast Asia.

Arizona (/ˌærɪˈzoʊnə/ ( listen); Navajo: Hoozdo Hahoodzo) is a state in the southwestern region of the United States. Its capital and largest city is Phoenix. Arizona shares the Four Corners territory with Utah, Colorado, and New Mexico; the other neighboring states are Nevada and California to the west and the Mexican states of Sonora and Baja California to the south and southwest. Arizona was the 48th and last contiguous state to be admitted to the Union, achieving statehood on February 14, 1912, Valentine's Day. Historically part of the Alta California region of New Spain, it became part of independent Mexico in 1821. After being defeated in the Mexican-American War, Mexico ceded most of this territory to the United States in 1848. The southernmost part of the state was acquired in 1853 through Gadsden Purchase. Southern Arizona is known for its desert climate, with very hot summers and cool winters. Northern Arizona has forests of pine, Douglas fir, and fir trees; Colorado Plateau; mountains (such as the San Francisco Mountains); and large, deep canyons, with much more moderate summer temperatures and significant winter snowfall. There are ski resorts in the Flagstaff, Alpine, and Tucson areas. Apart from the internationally known Grand Canyon National Park, which is one of the seven natural wonders of the world, there are several national forests, national parks and national monuments. About a quarter of the state is made up of Indian reservations that serve as the home of 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation, the largest in the state and the United States, with more than 300,000 residents.

The Anschluss or Anschluß (German: ˈʔanʃlʊs] ( listen), literally "continuation") was the annexation of Austria by Nazi Germany that took place on March 12, 1938. The Anschluss was part of the efforts of German leader Adolf Hitler (who himself was of Austrian origin) to establish a Reich unifying the German-speaking areas. After successfully taking over Austria, Nazi Germany acquired the Sudetenland (inhabited by German-speaking people) from Czechoslovakia in September 1938. Prior to the Anschluss, Nazi groups in Germany and Austria wanted the unification of the two countries because according to them the people of Germany and Austria were one nation who speak the same language, namely German. On the other hand, Austrian Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg tried to defend his country's independence despite constant pressure from the Nazis. Schuschnigg planned a referendum for 13 March 1938 in the hope that the Austrian people would demonstrate their desire to remain independent. However, an ultimatum from Nazi Germany forced Schuschnigg to step down. The March 13 referendum was cancelled. The German armed forces called the Wehrmacht then entered Austrian territory on March 12, 1938 to annex the country. The Wehrmacht met no resistance at all. German troops and Hitler instead get a warm welcome. On March 13, 1938, Germany passed the law formalizing the Anschluss. About one month later, on April 10, 1938, the Nazi regime held a plebiscite so that the Austrian people could "pass" the law. The results of the plebiscite showed that 99.75% of voters in Austria supported unification. The victorious Allies of World War I were supposed to be responsible for enforcing the terms of the Treaty of Versailles and the Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye which prohibited Austria's unification with Germany. However, the Allied countries didn't take any action at all.

As a result of the Anschluss, Austrian society underwent a process of nazification, while the Austrian state itself dissolved until the defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II in 1945. A provisional government was formed in Austria on April 27, 1945, and Austrian territory was then divided into four Allied zones of occupation, each administered by the United States, the Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, and France. Austrian sovereignty was only restored in 1955 after the signing of the Austrian State Treaty. Regarding Austria's role in World War II, the United States, Soviet Union and Britain signed the Moscow Declaration on 30 October 1943 which stated that Austria was "the first country to fall victim to Hitler's aggression". The Austrian provisional government in 1946 also spread the myth of Austria as the "first victim of the Nazis" by publishing the Red-White-Red Book (Rot-Weiß-Rot-Buch). This myth continued to be adhered to in Austria until the international scandal took place in 1986 which ensnared Austrian President Kurt Waldheim due to his involvement as an aide-de-camp (personal assistant) in the Wehrmacht. Now the myth of the "first victim of the Nazis" has been dispelled, and the Austrian government itself has also acknowledged Austria's involvement in Nazi crimes. The word "Anschluss" in German literally means "connection", "connection" or "contact". There are sources that call the Anschluss "unification". However, various modern sources also describe the Anschluss as an "annexation". In German, the events of the Anschluss are usually written in quotation marks („Anschluss“) by historians. According to Austrian historian Florian Wenninger, this was intended to distance itself from a term used by Nazi propaganda to cover up the fact that Austria's takeover was violent. However, not all historians follow this practice; Austrian historian Kurt Bauer omitted the quotation marks for the sake of legibility. According to him, the historical relation of the Anschluss can be seen from the context, and he also feels that the practice of using quotation marks spreads because it is considered to be a habit and does not offend.

Aurora or polar light is a natural phenomenon that produces a flaming and dancing glow in the night sky in the ionosphere layer of a planet as a result of the interaction between the planet's magnetic field and charged particles emitted by the sun (solar wind). . This phenomenon can only be enjoyed in countries far from the equator, one of the countries where natural phenomena are good to see is New Zealand. On earth, auroras occur in the area around its magnetic North and South Poles. The aurora that is in the sky at the south pole is called the Aurora Australis, while the Aurora that is in the sky at the north pole of the earth is called the Aurora Borealis. Auroras that occur in the north are known as Aurora Borealis (IPA /ɔˈɹɔɹə bɔɹiˈælɪs/), named after the Roman goddess of dawn, Aurora, and the Greek name for the north wind, Boreas. This is because in Europe, the aurora often looks reddish on the northern horizon as if the sun will rise from that direction. The aurora borealis always occurs between September and October and March and April. The aurora phenomenon in the south, known as Aurora Australis, has similar characteristics. But sometimes auroras appear on mountain peaks in tropical climates. Several important things related to the formation of the aurora, namely: This aurora phenomenon is related to the magnetic field envelope or the earth's magnetosphere and the activity of the appearance of light from the sun. The stronger and longer the aurora's light, the stronger the disturbance from the sun, known as a solar storm, can be expected. A solar storm is a cycle of violent explosive activity from the peak of sunspot activity, usually every 11 years it will enter a period of solar storm activity.

Meanwhile, disturbances that occur in the earth's magnetic field are called magnetic storms. The sudden change in the magnetic field causes charged particles in the atmosphere to increase or change direction (for example, in the ionosphere). Auroras can also appear when further phenomena occur in the magnetosphere known as magnetic sub-storms. This event gives rise to the oval aurora at the poles of the earth which are symmetrical to each other. Although this phenomenon has been suspected by experts for a long time, new observational evidence (Blue & Pink) was obtained in 2001 through NASA satellite observations. The role of a large magnetic field in the occurrence of aurora causes aurora to occur most often in the area around the magnetic north pole and south pole, and very rarely occurs in the equator. The famous aurora are Aurora Borealis (at the north pole) and Aurora Australis (at the south pole). The aurora borealis is most commonly seen in Fairbanks, Alaska, and in some locations in Eastern Canada, Iceland and Northern Scandinavia. Aurora australis is the least frequently seen because this aurora usually looks bright in areas that are sparsely populated. Aurora australis is usually seen in Australia on the 11-year cycle of sunspot activity. The solar maximum occurred in 2000. Aurora Australis has been seen in Tasmania. Apart from location, weather and pollution, light also affects the quality of the aurora. In Alaska, the best time to see the aurora is in the months of March and September to late October. At that time the sky was dark and the weather was very bright. In summer, the night sky is not so dark. In winter, on the other hand, the air gets too cold, thus disturbing the comfort of those who want to observe it. Aurora appears in many different forms.

The Korean wave (Korean: 한류; English: Korean wave) is a term that refers to the global spread of Korean pop culture in various countries around the world starting from the 1990s. In general, the Korean Wave sparked many people in other countries to learn the Korean language and Korean culture. The craze for Korean pop culture started in China and Southeast Asia from the late 1990s. The term Hánliú (韓流, Korean: 한류; Hallyu) was adopted by the Chinese media after a Korean pop music album, H.O.T, was released in China. Korean television drama series began to be screened in China and spread to other countries such as Hong Kong, Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines, the United States, Latin America and the Middle East. At this time, the Korean Wave was followed by a lot of attention for South Korean products, such as Korean cuisine, electronics, music and films. This phenomenon also promotes the Korean language and Korean culture to various countries. The Korean wave encompasses a global awareness of various aspects of South Korean culture including film and television (especially drama), pop music, comics, language, and Korean cuisine. Some commentators also consider traditional Korean culture as a whole to be part of the Korean Wave. The Korean Wave refers to the global popularity of South Korea's cultural economy exporting pop culture, entertainment, music, television series and films. Hallyu is a Chinese term that literally translates to the "Korean wave". It is a collective term used to refer to the phenomenal growth of Korean culture and popular culture which includes everything from music, movies, television series to online games and Korean cuisine just to name a few. During former president Barack Obama's state visit to South Korea in March 2012, he referred to the Korean Wave, which the government has made the country's top priority.

South Korea is the only country in the world, if not the only one, that has a specific goal of becoming the world's leading exporter of popular culture. This is a way for Korea to develop its "soft power". Soft power is a popular term coined in 1990 by Harvard political scientist Joseph Nye. It refers to the intangible power that a country has through its image, not through violence. Hard power refers to military might or economic power. An example of soft power at play is how the US persuaded the world to buy Levi's jeans, Apple iPhones, Marlboro cigarettes, Coca-Cola soft drinks, and Hollywood movies, all by leveraging its desired image. Cool unique picture. The Korean wave first spread to China and Japan, then to Southeast Asia and several countries around the world where it continues to have a strong impact. In 2000, a 50-year ban on the exchange of popular culture between Korea and Japan was partially lifted, which led to a surge in Korean popular culture among Japanese people. South Korean broadcasting authorities have sent delegations to promote their TV programs and cultural content in several countries. The Korean wave has been a blessing for Korea, business, culture and the country's image. Since early 1999, the Korean Wave has become one of Asia's biggest cultural phenomena. The Hallyu effect is tremendous, contributing 0.2% of Korea's GDP in 2004, which was around USD 1.87 billion. Most recently in 2019, the Korean Wave was estimated to have an economic boost of USD 12.3 billion. Over the last two decades, South Korea has become very rich and very futuristic. In 1965, Korea's GDP per capita was lower than that of Ghana.

Statistics is a science that studies how to plan, collect, analyze, then interpret, and finally present data. In short, statistics is the science concerned with data. The term statistics is different from statistics. Statistics generally works by using numerical data which is the result of counting or measurement results using categorical data that are classified according to certain criteria. Statistics is a science related to data. Statistics is the data itself, the information, or the result of applying statistical algorithms to that data. From a collection of data, statistics can be used to conclude or describe data; This is what is called descriptive statistics. Information is then recorded as well as collected both in the form of numerical information and categorical information which is referred to as an observation. Most of the basic concepts of statistics provide assumptions about probability theory. Some statistical terms include the following: population, sample, sample unit, probability. Statistics has also been widely applied in various scientific disciplines, both natural sciences (eg astronomy and biology as well as social sciences (including sociology and psychology), as well as in business (regarding products, etc.), economics, and industry. Statistics also used in government to achieve various purposes; the population census is one of the most well-known procedures. There are also other applications of statistics that are now popular, namely polling procedures (for example carried out before a general election), as well as quick counts (quick calculation of the results elections) or Quick count. In the field of computing, statistics can also be applied in pattern recognition and artificial intelligence ("AI"). The development of statistics occurred simultaneously with the development of human history. Statistical data has been used by nations in Mesopotamia, Egypt, and China in BC.
