They use statistics to obtain information about the amount of taxes each resident has to pay and the amount of agricultural produce. At the time of Ancient Greece, Aristotle had used statistics in his book entitled Politea. Aristotle uses statistics to explain data about the state of 158 countries. In the Middle Ages, statistics developed within the church and was used to record the number of births, deaths and marriages. In the 17th century AD, statistics was applied in England as political arithmetic. The term statistics was then put forward by a German mathematician named Gottfried Achenwall (1719-1772). In the 18th century, the term statistics was popularized by John Sinclair (1791-1799) in his book entitled Statistical Account of Scotland. In the 19th century and early 20th century statistics began to make extensive use of fields in mathematics, especially probability. The branch of statistics currently widely used to support the scientific method, statistical inference, was developed in the second half of the 19th and early 20th centuries by Karl Pearson (introducing the linear regression method and the standard deviation term in 1894), Ronald Fisher ( founding fathers of inferential statistics and publishing Design of Experiments in 1935), and William Sealey Gosset (researching small sample problems). Today's use of statistics can be said to have touched all fields of science, from astronomy to linguistics. The fields of economics, biology and its applied branches, as well as psychology are heavily influenced by statistics in their methodology. As a result, combined sciences such as econometrics, biometrics (or biostatistics) and psychometrics were born. Although there are those who consider statistics as a branch of mathematics, others consider statistics as a field that has a lot to do with mathematics, looking at its history and applications. In Indonesia, most statistical studies are included in the faculties of mathematics and natural sciences, both in separate departments and in association with mathematics.

Gabon (French pronunciation: ɡabɔ̃]), officially the Republic of Gabon (French: République gabonaise), is a country on the west coast of West Africa. Located on the equator, Gabon is bordered by the countries of Equatorial Guinea to the northwest, Cameroon to the north, the Republic of the Congo to the east and south, and the Gulf of Guinea. The country has an area of ​​nearly 270,000 square kilometers (100,000 sq mi) and an estimated population of 2.1 million people. There are also three distinct regions, namely: the coastal plains, the mountains (the Crystal Mountains and the Chaillu mountains in the center), and the savannah region which is located in the western part of the country. The coastal plains area is part of the World Fund for Nature's Atlantic Equatorial coastal forest ecological area. The capital and largest city is Libreville, and the country's official language is French. The indigenous people of Gabon are the Pygmies, many of whom were absorbed into the Bantu when they migrated. In the 15th century, the first Europeans arrived. The name Gabon comes from "Gabão", which means "mantle" in Portuguese, related to the shape of the mouth of the river Komo near Libreville. French explorer Pierre Savorgnan de Brazza led the first mission to Gabon and Congo in 1875. He founded the city of Franceville, and later became colonial governor. Several Bantu groups lived in what is now Gabon when the French occupied it in 1885. In 1910, Gabon became 1 of the 4 territories of French Equatorial Africa, a federation that lasted until 1959. The territory became independent on August 17, 1960. The first president was Léon M'ba was elected in 1961, with Omar Bongo Ondimba as Vice President.

French interests were decisive in the leadership of Gabon after independence; French logging interests lavish funds for the election campaign of M'ba, the 'evolué' of the coastal areas. After Gabriel Leon M'ba's ascension to power, the press was suppressed, political demonstrations were banned, freedom of expression was curtailed, other political parties were gradually removed from power and the constitution was amended with French guidance to give power to the presidency, a post which Leon M'ba himself occupied. However, when Gabriel Léon M'ba dissolved the National Assembly in January 1964 to establish a one-party rule, a military coup emerged to remove him from power and restore parliamentary democracy. The era of M'ba's dictatorship known as "French Matters" became prominently manifested when French paratroopers flew in within 24 hours to restore him to power. After several days of fighting, the coup ended and the opposition was jailed despite widespread protests and rioting. The French government is undaunted by international criticism; and paragliding remains at Camp de Gaulle, outside the Gabon capital. When M'Ba died in 1967, Bongo succeeded him as president, and continued to be head of state until his death in 2009, winning each election with a simple majority. Gabon is located on the Atlantic coast in Central Africa. Located on the equator, Gabon has an equatorial climate with an extensive rainforest system covering 85% of the area. There are 3 distinct areas: the coastal plains (range 20–300 km from the coastline), the mountains (the Crystal Mountains to the northeast of Libreville, the Chaillu Plateau in the center culminating in Mont Iboundji which reaches an elevation of 1575 m), and the savannas to the east . The coastal plains form a large part of the World Wildlife Fund's Atlantic Equatorial rainforest ecological area and contain Central African mangroves, particularly in the Muni river estuary near the border of Equatorial Guinea.

The state of Kedah or also known as Kedah Darul Aman is one of the states in Malaysia. Around the year 788 BC, a systematic government of a large settlement of the Kedah Malay tribe was established around the northern bank of the Merbok River. In that era, this state also consisted of the vast Bujang Valley region, covering the branches of Sungai Merbok and Sungai Muda about 1000 square miles. The capital city of this settlement was built at the mouth of Sungai Merbok, which is now known as Sungai Batu. Some of the rock formations found in the Bujang Valley are relics of an Anismist kingdom that ruled ancient Kedah as early as 110 AD. The discovery of rock formations, the remains of a wharf, an iron smelting site, and a clay brick monument dating back to 110 AD show that Maritime trade routes with the Tamil kingdom in southern India had been established since then. The discovery of rock formations in the Bujang Valley also makes ancient Kedah the oldest civilization in Southeast Asia. According to Hikayat Merong Mahawangsa or History of Kedah, Kedah was founded by a Hindu king named Merong Mahawangsa. According to further texts, the Sultanate of Kedah began in 1136 when King Phra Ong Mahawangsa converted to Islam and adopted the name Sultan Mudzafar Shah. However, an Acehnese record mentions the date 1474 as the year the ruler of Kedah converted to Islam. This latter date is in accordance with the record in Sejarah Melayu where a king of Kedah visited Malacca during the reign of his last sultan to seek the honor of the royal group that marked the sovereignty of a Muslim ruler. Kedah politics has become a political system that is highly respected and admired throughout the country. Among the greatest figures from Kedah is Tunku Abdul Rahman Putra Al-Haj, the first Prime Minister of Malaysia and Tun Dr. Mahathir Mohamed.

Kedah is divided into 12 administrative districts. These 12 districts are further divided into administrative municipal councils (City/Municipal and District Councils). The main cities in Kedah are Alor Setar (the capital), Jitra, Sungai Petani, Kuah and Kuala Nerang. Kedah is famous for its nickname "Malaysia's Rice Barn" because this area is the area with the largest rice fields in Malaysia. Kedah is also the province that founded the Malay Sultanate. This state has a Universiti Utara Malaysia (UUM) campus located in Bandar Baru Sintok. It was officially established on February 16, 1984. The university was established with the specific mission of providing a leadership role for management education in this country. The academic board at UUM includes the College of Business (COB), the College of Law, Government and International Studies (COLGIS) and the College of Arts and Sciences (CAS). Several other state and private universities such as Universiti Teknologi MARA (UiTM) in Merbok, Malaysian Spanish Institute of Universiti Kuala Lumpur (UniKL MSI) and Polytechnic Institute of Sultanah Bahiyah (PSB) in Kulim, the Asian Institute of Medicine, Science and Technology ( AIMST University) in Bedong, Kolej Universiti Insaniah (KUIN) alias UNISHAMS (Kuala Ketil, Baling Kedah) in Mergong and Sultan Abdul Halim Mu'adzam Shah Polytechnic Institute (POLIMAS) in Jitra. There are 2 teacher training institutes in Kedah, namely the Sultan Abdul Halim Campus Teacher Education Institute (IPGKSAH) in Sungai Petani and the Darul Aman Campus Teacher Education Institute (IPGKDA) in Bandar Darulaman which were established by the government to provide teaching courses for teacher trainees. Kedah has a relatively heterogeneous population consisting of three main ethnic groups; Malays, Chinese and Indians as well as some Siamese ethnic groups in Malaysia, similar to most other Malaysian states.

Solubility or solubility is the ability of a particular chemical substance, the solute (solute), to dissolve in a solvent (solvent). Solubility is expressed in the maximum amount of solute that dissolves in a solvent at equilibrium. The resulting solution is called a saturated solution. Certain substances are soluble in any ratio to a solvent. An example is ethanol in water. This trait is more precisely in English called miscible. The solvent is generally a liquid which can be a pure substance or a mixture. The dissolved substance can be a gas, another liquid, or a solid. Solubility varies from always soluble as ethanol in water, to poorly soluble, as silver chloride in water. The term "insoluble" is often applied to compounds that are poorly soluble, although in fact there are very few cases where there is really no substance dissolved. Under some conditions, the equilibrium solubility may be exceeded to give a so-called supersaturated solution which is metastable. Under certain conditions, the solubility equilibrium can be exceeded to produce what is called a supersaturated solution, which is metastable. Crystal metastability can also lead to visible differences in the amount of dissolved chemical depending on the shape or size of the crystalline particles. A supersaturated solution generally crystallizes when 'seeds' of crystals appear and equilibration rapidly occurs. Phenylsalicylate is one of the substances observed when it melts completely and then cools below its fusion point. The solubility ranges widely, from very soluble (indefinitely) (completely dissolved) like ethanol in water, to very insoluble, like silver chloride in water. The term insoluble is sometimes used for compounds that are very insoluble. A number of other descriptive terms are used to classify the degree of solubility for a given application.

The threshold for describing something as insoluble, or a term similar to it, may depend on the application. For example, one source states that a substance is described as "insoluble" when its solubility is less than 0.1 g per 100 mL of solvent. A large number of reactions used in qualitative inorganic analysis involve the formation of precipitates. The precipitate is a substance that separates itself as a solid phase out of solution. The precipitate may be crystalline (crystalline) or colloidal, and can be removed from solution by filtration or centrifugation. A precipitate forms if the solution becomes oversaturated with the substance in question. The solubility (S) of a precipitate, by definition, is equal to the molar concentration of the saturated solution. Solubility depends on various conditions, such as temperature, pressure, the concentration of other ingredients in the solution, and on the composition of the solvent. The change in solubility with pressure is of no practical importance in qualitative inorganic analyses, since all the work was carried out in an open vessel at atmospheric pressure; slight change of atmospheric pressure has no significant effect on solubility. Of particular importance is the change in solubility with temperature. In general it can be said that the solubility of precipitates increases with increasing temperature, although in some exceptional cases (such as potassium sulfate), the opposite occurs. The rate of increase in solubility with temperature varies, in some cases it is very small, in other cases it is very large. In some cases the change in solubility with changing temperature can be the basis for separation. For example, separation of lead ions from silver and mercury(I) can be achieved by precipitating the three ions first as chlorides, followed by adding hot water to the mixture. This hot water will dissolve lead(II) chloride, but silver and mercury(I) chloride are practically insoluble in it.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health sciences Parasitology is the study of parasites, their hosts and the relationships between them. As a branch of biology, the scope of parasitology is not determined by the organisms or the environment it relates to, but by their way of life, which means that this field is synthesized with other fields, and uses techniques such as cell biology, bioinformatics, biochemistry, molecular biology, immunology, genetics, evolution. and ecology. This study of diverse organisms means that the field is often broken down into simpler, more focused units that employ common techniques, even if the field is not studying the same organism or disease. Most research in parasitology falls between 2 or more of these definitions. Generally, the study of prokaryotes is included in the field of bacteriology rather than parasitology. One of the largest fields of parasitology, medical parasitology is the study of a number of parasites that infect humans, which includes organisms such as: Medical parasitology can involve drug development, epidemiological studies and zoonotic studies. Study of parasites that cause economic losses in agricultural or aquaculture operations, or that infect companion animals. Examples of species studied are: Is a study of the protein structure of parasites. Determination of the structure of parasite proteins can help understand how these proteins function differently from homologous proteins in humans. In addition, protein structure can inform the drug discovery process. Parasites can provide information about the ecology of host populations. For example, in fisheries biology, parasite communities can be used to distinguish different populations of fish species that together inhabit that area. In addition, parasites have a number of special traits and life history strategies that allow them to colonize hosts. Understanding these aspects of parasite ecology can shed light on the host's parasite avoidance strategies.

Protagoras is a philosopher who belongs to the class of sophists. He is one of the first sophists and also the most famous. Apart from being a philosopher, he is also known as an orator and an accomplished debater. In addition, he was famous as a teacher who taught many youths of his time. Protagoras came from Abdera which is located on the north coast of the Aegean Sea. He lived between 490 BC - 420 BC. He made frequent trips to other countries, including several visits to Athens. In Athens, Protagoras was asked by Pericles to take part in drafting a constitution for the Athenian colony of Thurioi in 444 BC. According to the testimony of Diogenes Laertios, at the end of his life Protagoras was accused in Athens of blasphemy against religion. Protagoras' books were publicly burned. Then Protagoras is said to have fled to Sicily, but the boat in which he was traveling sank. Protagoras authored many books, but only a few fragments have survived. However, the contents of his philosophy can still be known because Protagoras's thoughts were widely discussed by subsequent philosophers. Plato is the main source, especially the two dialogues entitled Theaitetos and Protagoras. The most famous book of Protagoras is called "The Truth" (Aletheia). In a book entitled "Truth", Protagoras states that the human being referred to here is human as an individual. Thus, recognition of something depends on individuals who feel something with their five senses. For example for people who feel sick, the wind can feel cold. Meanwhile, for a healthy person, the wind feels hot. Here the two people are right, because the recognition of wind is based on the physical and psychological conditions of these people. A view like this can be said to be relativism because truth is based on each person who feels it.

In another work entitled "Contradictory Positions" (Antilogiai), Protagoras argues that this view is related to the notion of the relativity of human knowledge. If truth is determined by everyone, then it can be concluded that one opinion is no more correct than the opposite. The consequence of this is the art of speech. An orator must succeed in convincing his listeners of the truth he adheres to. Thus, it requires the ability to make convincing arguments for the listeners. According to Protagoras, the state was created by humans. The purpose of forming a country is so that humans can be released from the insecurities and difficulties of living in a wild nature. For this reason, humans establish relationships with other humans and form a state. However, then humans realize that living with other humans is not easy. With a myth, Protagoras stated that humans were given two things by the gods to be able to live with each other. These two things are awareness of justice (dike) and respect for others (aidos). With these two things, humans can live with each other. Humans do this by making laws or constitutions. Thus, certain laws are not truer than other laws. There are laws that are suitable for certain societies but not suitable for others. In his work entitled "About the Gods" (Peritheon), Protagoras stated that Protagoras' view is a skepticism, meaning that it is impossible to reach a truth. This fits perfectly with his relativistic view of cognition. During his lifetime, Protagoras influenced the minds of many young men through his thoughts on rhetoric and knowledge. He also influenced Democritus in his theory of knowledge and political philosophy. Apart from that, he also had a great influence on statesmen, poets, historians, and orators.

Mineralogy is an earth science that focuses on the chemical, crystal structure, and physical (including optical) properties of minerals. This study also covers the initial process of formation and also changes in minerals. In geology, mineralogy is included in basic geology. Mineralogy is a part of geology that specifically studies minerals. Mineralogy is also part of the earth sciences. The scientific scope in mineralogy includes physical, chemical, optical and mechanical properties of minerals. Mineralogy can be divided into two scientific branches, namely physical mineralogy and optical mineralogy. Physical mineralogy specifically deals with the arrangement of crystals in minerals. In the science of physical mineralogy. The main study is mineral crystallography. The study of mineral crystallography is based on an understanding of elemental chemistry, stoichiometry, geometry and vectors. The primacy of mineral crystallography in physical mineralogy is caused by the condition of each mineral which is crystalline. Because of this, minerals have crystalline properties that can be described and projected. This depiction and projection is done in the form of a graphic presentation. This presentation enforces the laws of the crystallization mechanism. Soil mineralogy discusses solid minerals in the form of crystals with boundaries in the form of flat planes. Certain minerals have certain flat plane features. The main discussion in soil mineralogy is rock. Meanwhile, soil organic matter is not discussed in soil mineralogy. The formation of metamorphic rocks is the result of crystallization within the Earth's crust. These metamorphic rocks range between 3–20 kilometers below the Earth's surface. Most of the formation of metamorphic rocks do not go through a liquid phase and immediately become solid. The new physical environment with a certain pressure and temperature produces a new structure and mineralogy in metamorphic rocks. The process of forming metamorphic rocks that change their mineral content is called metamorphism.

The main factor is the change in physical and chemical conditions in the Earth's crust. This process of metamorphism does not involve weathering and diagenesis. The minerals contained in metamorphic rocks can originate from the original rock or result from metamorphism. Minerals due to metamorphism can be divided into three types. First, the common minerals in igneous and metamorphic rocks include biotite, hornblende, pyroxene, olivine and iron ore. Second, common minerals in sedimentary and metamorphic rocks include quartz, muscovite, clay minerals, calcite and dolomite. Third, minerals that only exist in metamorphic rocks include garnet, andalusite, cyanite, sillimanite, staautolite, cordierite, epidote and chlorite. Clay minerals at the beginning of the development of mineralogy are defined as minerals with fine textured grains. The grain diameter is smaller than 2 μm. Observations of its structure can no longer be done using an ordinary microscope. In its development, clay minerals are no longer interpreted based on the diameter of the grains, but on the shape of the layers which are like a pile of paper. The definition of clay minerals then turns into minerals that have a layered structure with an aluminosilika structure as a constituent of the framework. Grain mineralogy analysis is an analysis that aims to determine the mineral composition or mineral content in a grain-shaped mineral. The grain mineraological analysis process uses samples in the form of sand grains, sediment deposits, soil and rocks that have previously undergone preparation. The preparation process is carried out by panning method until it becomes concentrate. A binocular microscope is used as a tool for making observations. Another method that can be used is the X-ray fluorescence method. This method is widely used in mineralogy and other scientific fields. The advantage is that it only requires a small amount of grain mineral preparation so that the analysis process becomes faster.

Tellurium is a chemical element with the symbol Te and atomic number 52. The element is a brittle, slightly toxic, rare, silver-white metalloid. Tellurium is chemically related to selenium and sulfur, all three of which are chalcogens. It is sometimes found in its native form as elemental crystals. Tellurium is much more common in the Universe as a whole than it is on Earth. Its extreme rarity in the Earth's crust, comparable to that of platinum, is partly due to the formation of volatile hydrides which caused tellurium to be lost to space as a gas during Earth's formation, when conditions were very hot, and partly due to tellurium's low affinity for oxygen, which causes it to bind violently. preferential to the other chalcophiles in the solid minerals that permeate the Earth's core. Tellurium-carrying compounds were first discovered in 1782 in a gold mine at Kleinschlatten, Transylvania (now Zlatna, Romania) by the Austrian mineralogist Franz-Joseph Müller von Reichenstein, although it was Martin Heinrich Klaproth who named the new element in 1798 after the Latin word for " earth", Tellus. The mineral gold telluride is the best-known naturally occurring gold compound. However, they are not a commercially significant source of tellurium, which is usually extracted as a by-product of copper and tin production. Commercially, the main use of tellurium is in copper (copper tellurium) and steel alloys, where it can improve machinability. Applications in CdTe solar panels and cadmium telluride semiconductors also consume a large part of tellurium production. Tellurium is considered a critical element for technology. Tellurium has no biological function, although fungi can use it in place of sulfur and selenium in amino acids such as eggocysteine ​​and egg-methionine. In humans, tellurium is partially metabolized to dimethyl tellurium, (CH3)2Te, a gas with a garlic-like odor that is exhaled in the breath of victims of tellurium exposure or poisoning.

Tellurium has two allotropes, namely crystalline and amorphous. When crystalline, tellurium is silvery white with a metallic luster. It is a brittle and easily crushed metalloid. Amorphous tellurium is a black-brown powder prepared by precipitation from a solution of telluric or telluric acid (Te(OH)6). Tellurium is a semiconductor that exhibits greater electrical conductivity in certain directions depending on the alignment of the atoms, its conductivity increasing slightly when exposed to light (photoconductivity). When molten, tellurium is corrosive to copper, iron, and stainless steel. Of the chalcogen, tellurium has the highest melting and boiling points, namely 72.266 K (129.619 °F) and 1.261 K (1.810 °F), respectively. Tellurium adopts a polymeric structure consisting of zig-zag chains of Te atoms. This gray material resists oxidation by air and is non-volatile. Naturally occurring tellurium has eight isotopes. Six of these isotopes, 120Te, 122Te, 123Te, 124Te, 125Te, and 126Te, are stable. The other two, 128Te and 130Te, were found to be slightly radioactive, with very long half-lives, 2.2×1024 years for 128Te. It is the longest known half-life of all radionuclides and is about 160 trillion (1012) times the known age of the universe. Stable isotopes make up only 33.2% of all naturally occurring tellurium. Furthermore, 31 radioisotopes manufactured by tellurium are known, with atomic masses ranging from 104 to 142 and with half-lives of 19 days or less. Also, 17 nuclear isomers are known, with half-lives of up to 154 days. With the exception of the beryllium-8 and beta-delayed alpha emission branches in some lighter nuclides, tellurium (104Te to 109Te) is the lightest element with isotopes known to undergo alpha decay.

Science, science (Arabic: العِلْـمُ) or also called science (English: science) is a systematic effort with scientific methods in developing and organizing knowledge as evidenced by explanations and predictions that are tested as human understanding of the universe and its world. These aspects are limited in order to produce definite formulations. Science provides certainty by limiting the scope of its views, and the certainty of science is obtained from its limitations. Science is not just knowledge (knowledge), but summarizes a set of knowledge based on agreed theories and can be systematically tested with a set of methods that are recognized in a particular field of science. Viewed from a philosophical point of view, science is formed because humans try to think further about the knowledge they have. Science is a product of epistemology, in other words science is formed from 3 branches of philosophy namely ontology, epistemology and axiology, if these three branches are fulfilled it means that it is valid and recognized as a science. Natural science can only be certain after its field is limited to material matters, or psychology can only predict human behavior if its field of view is limited to general aspects of concrete human behavior. With regard to this example, natural sciences answer the question of how far the sun is from the earth, or psychology answers whether a young woman is fit to be a nurse. The word science in Arabic "ilm" which means to understand, understand, or know. In terms of absorption of the word, science can mean understanding a knowledge, and social science can mean knowing social problems, and so on. In contrast to knowledge, science is specific knowledge about what causes something and why. There are scientific requirements that something can be called a science. The nature of science as a requirement for science is heavily influenced by the paradigms of the natural sciences that existed earlier.

The terms "model", "hypothesis", "theory" and "law" have different meanings in scholarship from the common understanding. Scientists use the term model to describe something, specifically one that can be used to make conjectures that can be tested by conducting experiments or observations. A hypothesis is a conjecture that has not been supported or proven experimentally, and laws of physics or natural laws are scientific generalizations based on empirical observations. Mathematics is very important to science, especially in the role it plays in expressing scientific models. Observing and collecting measurement results, as well as making hypotheses and conjectures, inevitably requires mathematical models and exploitation. The branches of mathematics that are often used in science include calculus and statistics, although in fact all branches of mathematics have applications, even "pure" fields such as number theory and topology. Some thinkers view mathematicians as scientists, assuming that mathematical proofs are equivalent to experiments. Others do not consider mathematics as a science, because it does not require experimental tests on theories and hypotheses. However, despite these two assumptions, the fact that mathematics is important as a very useful tool for describing/explaining the universe has become a major issue for the philosophy of mathematics. See Eugene Wigner, The Unreasonable Effectiveness of Mathematics. Richard Feynman said, "Mathematics is not real, but it feels real. Where does it belong?", while Bertrand Russell was fond of defining mathematics as "a subject about which we never know what we are talking about, nor do we know the truth of it". In philosophy, science is a type of accident in the category of relations. In science, there is a knowing subject and a known object. The relationship between these two things is called science. This view is supported by Fakhruddin Ar-Razi. A different opinion is given by peripatetic philosophers.

The Commonwealth of Dominica is an island nation of the Caribbean. This Commonwealth member state located in the eastern Caribbean Sea is flanked by two other small island nations, namely Guadeloupe and Martinique. In 1493, the country was contested by Great Britain and France. But from 1815 the British controlled it and in 1978 it gained its independence. Dominica is one of the smallest countries in the world (172nd) and is only the size of Ambon Island in the Moluccas. The indigenous people of Dominica, the Arawak people, were driven out and exterminated by the Caribbean in the 14th century. The Arawak people are guided to Dominica, and other islands in the Caribbean, by the South Equatorial current from the waters of the Orinoco River. The descendants of those early Taino people were driven out by a Caribbean tribe called Kalinago. Caribbean people arrived on this island in special boats that are still built in their own area of ​​this island. Christopher Columbus arrived on the island on Sunday 3 November 1493. He and his crew left the island soon after being defeated by the Caribbean. In 1627 the English also tried and failed to conquer Dominica. In 1635 France claimed ownership of the island and sent missionaries, but could not take the island from the Caribbean. They left the island with Saint Vincent Island, in the 1660s. For the next hundreds of years Dominica remained isolated, and Caribbean people settled there after being expelled from the surrounding islands when European powers entered the area. Initially France ceded possession of Dominica to Great Britain in 1763. Great Britain then set up a government and made the island a colony in 1805. Emancipation of African slaves occurred throughout the British Empire in 1834, and from 1838, Dominica became the first British Caribbean colony to have a black-controlled legislature.

In 1896, the United Kingdom took back control of the government of Dominica and made it a crown colony. Half a century later, between 1958-1962, Dominica became a province of the short-lived West Indies Federation. In 1978 Dominica finally became an independent country. Dominica is an island nation located in the Caribbean Sea, or the northernmost of the Windward Islands (though sometimes considered the southernmost of the Leeward Islands). The country is about 289.5 square miles (750 km2) wide and about 29 miles (47 km) long and 16 miles (26 km) wide. Also known as the “Natural Island of the Caribbean” due to its lush landscape and diverse flora and fauna, Dominica is mostly covered by rainforest and is home to the second largest hot springs in the world. Within are two ecoregion boundaries: the moist forests of the Windward Islands and the scrub of the Windward Islands. The most mountainous of the Lesser Antilles, its volcanic peaks are cones of lava craters, the largest being (north-to-south) Morne aux Diables, Morne Diablotins (highest on the island at 1,447 m), Morne Trois Pitons and Morne Anglais. Morne Trois Pitons National Park is a tropical forest mixed with volcanic features; was recognized as a World Heritage Site on April 4, 1995, a distinction the same as the other four Caribbean islands. The Calibishie area in the northeast of the country has sandy beaches. Several plants and animals that were thought to be extinct on the surrounding islands can still be found in the Dominican jungle. The island has several protected areas, including the Cabrits National Park, as well as 365 rivers. For several years the government has been trying to push the island as an ecotourism destination, although the 2017 hurricane has changed these plans.

Platinum is a chemical element in the periodic table having the symbol Pt and atomic number 78. This gray-white transition metal is dense, malleable, ductile, highly unreactive, and valuable. Its name comes from the Spanish word platinum, which literally translates to "little silver". Platinum is a member of the platinum group elements and is an element in group 10 of the periodic table. It has six naturally occurring isotopes. This metal is one of the rarest elements in the earth's crust with an average abundance of about 5 µg/kg. It occurs in several nickel and copper ores along with several natural deposits, mostly in South Africa, which accounts for 80% of world production. Due to its scarcity in the earth's crust, only a few hundred tons are produced annually, and for its important uses, it is highly valuable and a major precious metal commodity. Platinum is the least reactive metal. Its amazing resistance to corrosion, even at high temperatures, has earned it the title of noble metal. Consequently, platinum is often found as a naturally occurring element. Because it occurs naturally in the alluvial sands of rivers, it was first used by the indigenous people of pre-Columbian South America to make artifacts. European writings refer to the 16th century, but the report of Antonio de Ulloa who published a new metal in Colombia in 1748 became the object of research by scientists. Platinum is used in catalytic converters, laboratory equipment, electrical contacts and electrodes, platinum resistance thermometers, dental equipment, and jewelry. Because it is a heavy metal, platinum has health problems when exposed to its salts, but because of its resistance to corrosion, platinum is not as toxic as some other metals. Compounds containing platinum, such as cisplatin, oxaliplatin and carboplatin, are used in chemotherapy to fight certain types of cancer.

Pure platinum is a silvery-white metal that is lustrous, ductile, and malleable. Platinum is more ductile than gold, silver or copper, making it the most ductile of most pure metals, but less malleable than gold. This metal has excellent resistance to corrosion, is stable at high temperatures and has stable electrical properties. Platinum reacts slowly with oxygen at very high temperatures. This metal reacts violently with fluorine at 500°C (932°F) to form tetrafluoride. The metal is also attacked by chlorine, bromine, iodine and sulfur. Platinum is insoluble in hydrochloric and nitric acids, but dissolves in hot aqua regia to form chloroplatinic acid, H. Its physical properties and chemical stability make it useful for industrial applications. Its resistance to wear and stains makes it suitable for use in jewelry. The most common oxidation states of platinum are +2 and +4. The +1 and +3 oxidation states are less common, and are sometimes stabilized by metallic bonds in bimetallic (or polymetallic) species. As expected, tetracoordinated platinum(II) compounds tend to adopt a 16-electron planar quadrilateral geometry. Although elemental platinum is usually unreactive, it dissolves in hot aqua regia to form chloroplatinic acid (H): As a weak acid, platinum has a great affinity for sulfur, as for dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO); a number of DMSO complexes have been reported and the choice of reaction solvent must be made with great care. Platinum has six naturally occurring isotopes: 190Pt, 192Pt, 194Pt, 195Pt, 196Pt, and 198Pt. The most abundant isotope is 195Pt, composing 33.83% of all platinum. It is the only stable isotope without zero spin; with a spin of ½, the 195Pt satellite peak is frequently observed in 1H and 31P NMR spectroscopy (ie, Pt-phosphine and Pt-alkyl complexes). 190Pt is the least, only 0.01%.

Catalyst is a substance that accelerates the rate of chemical reactions at a certain temperature, but does not change or decrease in amount. The catalytic reaction rate occurs over a large surface area in solid fluids so that it is applied to porous solid materials. In a chemical reaction, the catalyst does not act as a chemical reactant or product. Commonly used catalysts are metal ions by impregnation method to produce zero valence and acid sites during the reduction process. The role of the catalyst is to increase the catalytic performance of solid materials. A catalyst is a substance that speeds up the reaction rate of a chemical reaction. The acceleration of the rate of reaction occurs at a certain temperature by lowering the activation energy of a reaction, without affecting the results of the reaction (product). It should be noted that the catalyst participates in the reaction. This can be proven by conducting experiments. At the end of the reaction, it will be found that the effectiveness of a catalyst is reduced. This is the proof that the catalyst reacts in a reaction. A catalyst plays a role in the reaction but not as a reactant or product. Catalysts allow reactions to occur more quickly or allow reactions to occur at lower temperatures due to the changes they induce in the reactants. The catalyst provides an alternative pathway with a lower activation energy. Catalyst reduced energy needed for reaction. Catalysts can be divided into two main groups: homogeneous catalysts and heterogeneous catalysts. Heterogeneous catalysts are catalysts that exist in a different phase from the reactants in the reaction they catalyze, whereas homogeneous catalysts are in the same phase. One simple example of heterogeneous catalysis is that of the catalyst providing a surface on which the reactants (or substrates) are temporarily adsorbed. The bonds in the substrates become weak enough to form new products.

the bond between the product and the catalyst is weaker, so it is finally released. Homogeneous catalysts generally react with one or more reactants to form a chemical intermediate which then reacts to form the end product of the reaction, in a process which recovers the catalyst. The following is a general scheme of a catalytic reaction, where C represents the catalyst: Even though the catalyst (C) is consumed by reaction 1, it is subsequently regenerated by reaction 2, so that for the overall reaction to be, the catalyst is neither consumed nor created. Enzymes are biocatalysts. The use of the term "catalyst" in the broader cultural context is analogous to this context. Some well-known catalysts that have been developed include the Ziegler-Natta catalyst which is used for the mass production of polyethylene and polypropylene. The best known catalytic reaction is the Haber process for the synthesis of ammonia, which uses ordinary iron as a catalyst. The catalytic converter—which can destroy the most stubborn exhaust by-products—is made of platinum and rhodium. The lipase enzyme becomes a catalyst for triglycerides which causes hydrolysis of fats or oils. Hydrolysis of fat or oil occurs due to the presence of bacteria in the air which contain lipase enzymes. At room temperature and moist air, the hydrolysis of fats or oils results in a rancid odor and an unpleasant taste when left in moist air at room temperature. The esterification reaction requires an acid or base catalyst to accelerate the reaction between glycerol and fatty acids to produce monoglycerides, diglycerides and water. The catalyst is fed at a heating temperature between 210°C and 230°C. The ratio between glycerol and fatty acids in the reaction will determine the monoglyceride composition. While the composition of diglycerides is determined by an interesterification reaction involving glycerol, fat or oil and an alkaline catalyst such as calcium hydroxide.

–  in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Greece (Greek: Ελλάδα, Ellaada eˈlaða] ( listen)), officially named the Republic of Greece,a] known in ancient times as Hellas,b] is a country where the culture of the Western World was born in southeastern Europe, located at the southern tip of the Balkan Peninsula, in the eastern part of the Mediterranean Sea (Mediterranean). The word "Greek" in Indonesian comes from Arabic: namely اليُونَان (al-yūnān), absorbed from Persian, namely Yunân. The name is based on Ionia, a region on the west coast of Anatolia that was once part of Greece, now part of Turkey. In Ancient Greek, this land was called Ἑλλάς (Hellas), while according to modern standard pronunciation it is Elláda. In Indonesian, the Greek term is also known, especially the mention of Greek, which was absorbed from Latin: Graecus, namely to name the area now located to the north of Greece, which was once inhabited by the Graekos tribe. The area around Attica was inhabited since the Upper Paleolithic period (30,000–10,000 BC), but archaeological evidence can only show that the small caves around the "Athenian Acropilis" and the "Klepsythra" spring were used in the Neolithic period (3000–2800 BC). It was in this area of ​​Greece that European culture first appeared, starting with the "Cycladic" civilization on the islands of the Aegean Sea around 3000 BC, the "Minoan" civilization on the island of Crete (2700–1500 BC) and the "Mycenaean Greek" civilization on the mainland (1900–1100 BC). The period between 1200 and 800 BC known as the "Greek Dark Ages" is thought to have followed the Dorian invasion, which ended the Mycenaean age. Two of the most famous works of Greek literature, Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, were written during this period. At the end of the Greek Dark Ages, various states and city-states emerged throughout the Greek peninsula to the Black Sea coast, Greater Greece (Southern Italy) and Anatolia (Asia Minor/Asia Minor), achieving high levels of prosperity with rapid cultural development, such as evidences of architectural heritage, drama, science and philosophy, which are preserved in a democratic environment.

However, because it is not a unit, conflicts often occur between the small countries in Greece. The worst was the Peloponnesian War, because it marked the end of the Athenian Empire as an important ruler in Greece. In 500 BC, the Persian Empire (Achaemenid Empire) controlled this region. Alexander the Great's empire stretched from Greece in the west to Pakistan in the east and Egypt in the south, before his sudden death in 323 BC. After his death, the kingdom split into a number of smaller countries, which eventually became the 4 leading states:1. Ptolemaic kingdom in Egypt (south) 2. Seleucid Empire in Persia (east)3. Kingdom of Pergamon in Asia Minor (north)4. Kingdom of Macedonia in Greece (west). The Eastern Roman Empire lasted more than 1000 years, from the 4th century AD to 1453. During its existence, the Byzantines were an important economic, cultural and military force in Europe. The Ottoman Empire began to colonize Greece in the late 14th century. By the time Istanbul (Constatinople) fell in 1453, much of the Byzantine Empire, including its second largest city (which is now the second largest city in modern Greece), Thessaloniki, had been captured by the Ottomans. By the 1500s most of Greece was under Ottoman rule, including Cyprus (captured 1571) and Crete (captured 1670). The parts not controlled by the Ottomans were the Ionian islands, which remained independent under the protection of the Republic of Venice until annexation by the First French Republic in 1797 and Great Britain in 1809, and were restored to unity with Greece in 1864. After years of negotiations, the Republic The First Hellenic was finally recognized under the London Protocol in 1830. Greece became the 10th member of the European Community (later to become the European Union) on 1 January 1981, and entered a period of rapid economic growth.

Pythagoras of Samosa] (born c. 570 BC - died c. 495 BC) was an ancient Ionian Greek philosopher and founder of the Pythagorean school. His political and religious teachings were known in the Magna Graecia area at his time and influenced the thinking of Plato and Aristotle, so that he indirectly influenced the development of Western philosophy. Details about his life are shrouded in legend, but he seems to have been the son of Mnesarkos, a jewel engraver or wealthy merchant on the island of Samos, off the coast of Anatolia. Modern scholars are still debating who was Pythagoras' teacher and which thinkers had influenced him. However, they agree that around 530 BC, Pythagoras moved to Croton on the Italian coast and founded a society with a special membership. Those who wish to join must be initiated first, and the community follows a lifestyle of togetherness and seclusion. This community also has rules regarding food. It is said that his followers were supposed to be vegetarians, but modern scholars doubt whether Pythagoras really ever required his followers to abstain from meat. The most obvious teaching propounded by Pythagoras was metempsychosis, namely the belief that every soul is immortal, and that after death it passes into a new body. He may also have been the originator of the doctrine of musica universalis, according to which the planets move according to mathematical equations, thus producing an inaudible musical symphony. Scholars still debate whether some of the numerology and musical teachings associated with the name Pythagoras were actually developed by him or were creations of his followers after his death, especially Philolaus of Croton. After Kroton defeated its neighbor Sibaris around 510 BC, the followers of Pythagoras came into conflict with the supporters of democracy, as a result the meeting hall of the Pythagoreans was burned down.

Pythagoras may have died during these events or escaped to Metapontum and met his death there. In ancient times, the name Pythagoras was associated with numerous mathematical and scientific discoveries, such as the Pythagorean theorem, five regular geometric shapes, the theory of proportionality, the spherical Earth theory, and the idea that the eastern and western stars are the same planet, Venus. He is also said to have been the first to call himself a philosopher ("lover of wisdom") and to divide the world into five climatic zones. However, classical historians still debate whether Pythagoras actually made these discoveries, and many of the accomplishments attributed to his name may have preceded or been instigated by his contemporaries or successors. In addition, it is still debated whether he really has contributed to the field of mathematics or natural philosophy. Pythagorean thought influenced Plato, and Plato's dialogues (especially Timaios) show the influence of Pythagoreanism. The Pythagorean notion of mathematical perfection also had an impact on ancient Greek art. Pythagoreanism made a comeback in the first century BC among medieval Platonists, which coincided with the emergence of neopythagoreanism. Pythagoras continues to be regarded as a major philosopher in the Middle Ages, and his philosophy was very influential on scientists such as Nicolaus Copernicus, Johannes Kepler, and Isaac Newton. Pythagorean symbolism is also used by modern Western esotericists, and its teachings as detailed in the Metamorphoses by Roman poet Ovidius have influenced the modern vegetarian movement. None of the original writings of Pythagoras have survived into modern times. In addition, there is almost no information about his life that can be confirmed. The first sources on Pythagoras' life are brief, ambiguous, and often satirical. The first source dealing with Pythagoras's teachings is a satirical poem probably written after his death by Xenophanes of Colophon, one of his contemporaries.

Infrastructure or infrastructure is all structures as well as basic facilities, both physical and social such as buildings, electricity supply, irrigation, roads, bridges and so on that are needed for the operational activities of communities and companies. Referrals are needed] Physical and social infrastructure can be defined as needs the physical basis for organizing the structural system needed for public sector and private sector economic guarantees as services and facilities needed for the economy to function properly This term generally refers to technical or physical infrastructure that supports structural networks such as facilities which can include roads, trains, etc. fire, clean water, airports, canals, reservoirs, embankments, waste management, electricity, telecommunications, ports functionally, infrastructure besides facilitating but can also support the smooth running of community economic activities, distribution of production flows of goods and services as For example, roads can expedite the transportation of raw materials to factories and then for distribution to markets to reach the community. In several senses, the term infrastructure includes social infrastructure in the form of basic needs, including schools and hospitals. If in the military, this term can also refer to the permanent buildings and installations needed to support the operation and transfer. In use in other applications, infrastructure can refer to information technology, formal and informal communication channels and software development tools, socio-political networks or trust in certain groups of people. In the conceptual notion that the organizing structure is the provision of infrastructure and support for systems or for organizational services such as in a city, country, company, or group of people with a common interest. Infrastructure can also refer to a concept developed by Karl Marx that articulates with superstructure Infrastructure is the same as infrastructure, namely everything that is the main support for the implementation of a process.

A nation is a group of people who have a common identity, and share a common language, ideology, culture, history and goals. They are generally considered to have the same ancestral origin. Also mentioned as "a fully mobilized or institutionalized ethnic group". Some nations are considered equal to ethnic groups (see Ethnic nationalism and nation-state) and some are considered equal to a social and political constitutional affiliation (see Civic nationalism and Multiculturalism). A nation is also defined as a political-cultural community that is aware of autonomy, unity and common interests. In international law, nation is the term for a sovereign state. American Political Researcher Ben Anderson characterizes the nation as an "imagined Community", and Australian Academic Paul James (academician) sees it as an "Abstract Community". The nation is an Envisioned Community in the sense that the material conditions exist to broaden images and relations together and are objectively impersonal, even if each individual in that country experiences themselves as a subjective part of a part of oneness with others. For the most part, the members of a nation remain strangers to one another and may never meet. Hence the phrase, "a nation of strangers" is used by writers such as the American journalist Vance Packard. So the nation is the reality of intersubjectivity and exists solely in the minds of the people's shadows. Even if someone finally believes that the nation does not exist, the nation will still not be threatened, because the nation is not a reality of subjectivism that exists in one person's mind. Only if the multitude of people who believe that the nation does not exist and end its validity will the nation become non-existent. The definition of a nation according to experts. A nation is a group of people who are in an inner bond that are united because they have a similar history, as well as the same ideals.

A nation is a group of people who share the same character because of a similar fate and experience of cultural history that grows together with the development of the nation. The nation is a political community imagined in a territory that is clearly defined and sovereign. The nation is formed because of the similarities in race, language, customs and religion that are the difference between one nation and another. The word nation first appeared from Old French, namely nacion – which means birth (naissance), "place of birth" -, which was originally obtained from Latin, namely natio (nātĭō) which has a literal meaning, namely birth. Black's legal dictionary explains the meaning of nation namely: nation, n. (14c) 1. A large group of people who have the same origin, language and tradition which then constitutes a political entity. constituting a political entity. When a nation coincidentally coexists with a state, that is why it is also referred to as a nation-state or nation and state. ... 2. An association of people living within a defined and organized territory under an independent government; a country that has political sovereignty. The word "nation" is sometimes used as a synonym for: So the phrase "nations of the world" might refer to the highest levels of government (the same as the name for the United Nations), large geographic territories, or large ethnic groups . Depending on when the meaning of the word "nation" is used, the meaning of "National State" itself can also be used to distinguish larger areas of the country from city-states in the country, or also to distinguish countries that have a Multinational State from those that have one ethnic group. In her book entitled Kingdoms and Communities in Western Europe 900-1300, Susan Reynolds stated that many medieval European kingdoms were modern nations.

Saṃsara or sangsara in Buddhism is a state of endlessly repeated rebirth. Apart from Buddhism, the word samsara is also found in Hinduism, Jainism, as well as some other related religions, and refers to the concept of reincarnation or rebirth according to Indian philosophical traditions. Saṃsāra or Sansar (Devanagari: संसार) is a Sanskrit word meaning "wandering" or "world", with connotations of cyclic change and rotation. It is also the concept of rebirth and the "cycle of all life, matter, existence", a fundamental belief of most Indian religions. In short, it is a cycle of death and rebirth. Saṃsāra is sometimes referred to by terms or phrases such as transmigration, cycles of karma, reincarnation, and "the cycle of aimless drift, wandering or worldly existence". The concept of Saṃsāra has its roots in post-Vedic literature; this theory is not discussed in the Vedas themselves. It appears in a developed form, but without any mechanistic details, early in the Upanishads. Full exposition of the Saṃsāra doctrine is found in Sramanic religions such as Buddhism and Jainism, as well as various schools of Hindu philosophy after about the middle of the first millennium BC. The doctrine of the Saṃsāra is related to the karmic theory of Indian religions, and liberation from Saṃsāra has been at the heart of the spiritual pursuits of the Indian traditions, as well as their internal disagreements. Liberation from Saṃsāra is called Moksha, Nirvana, Mukti or Kaivalya. Etymology and terminology EditSaṃsāra (Dewanagari: संसार) means "to wander", as well as "the world" where the term has the connotation of "cyclic change". Saṃsāra is a fundamental concept in all Indian religions, related to the theory of karma, and refers to the belief that all living things undergo cyclical birth and rebirth. The term is related to phrases such as "the successive cycles of existence", "transition", "karmic cycle", "wheel of life", and "the cycle of all life, matter, existence".

Silicon is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Si and atomic number 14. The compound it forms is paramagnetic. This chemical element, which is also known as sand, was discovered by Jöns Jakob Berzelius. Silicon is a tetravalent metalloid element, which is less reactive than carbon (the non-metal right above it on the periodic table, but more reactive than germanium, the metalloid immediately below it on the periodic table. Controversy about the properties of silicon dates back to its discovery: Silicon was first prepared in its pure form in 1824 under the name silisium (from the Latin: silicis), with the suffix -ium meaning metal. However, in 1831, the name was changed to silicon due to its closer physical properties to carbon. and boron. Silicon is the eighth most abundant element in the universe in terms of mass, but it is very rarely found in its pure form in nature. Silicon is most widely distributed in dust, sand, planetoids, and planets in various forms such as silicon dioxide or silicates. More than 90 % of the Earth's crust is composed of silicate minerals, making silicon the second most mel impah in the earth's crust (about 28% by mass) after oxygen. Silicone is often used to make optical fibers and in plastic surgery it is used to fill patient parts in silicone form. Silicon in mineral form is also known as a grit substance. Most silicon is used commercially unseparated, sometimes with little processing from its compounds in nature. An example is the direct use of rock, silica sand and clay in building construction. Silica is also found in ceramics. Many modern silicon compounds such as silicon carbide are used in the manufacture of high-strength ceramics.

Silicon is also used as a monomer in the manufacture of silicone synthetic polymers. The element silicon also plays a major role in the modern economy. Although much of the silicon is used in steel refining, aluminum casting, and some other industrial chemical processes, some silicon is also used as a semiconductor material in electronics. Because of their heavy use in integrated circuits, the basis of computers, the survival of modern technology depends on silicon. Silicon is also an essential element in biology, although it is only needed by animals in very small amounts. Several types of living things that need it, among others, types of sponges and microorganism types of diatoms. Silicon is used to make their body structure. Silicon is solid at room temperature, with melting and boiling points of 1,400 and 2,800 degrees Celsius, respectively. Interestingly, silicon has a greater density when in liquid form than in its solid form. But like most other substances, silicon doesn't mix in its solid phase, but only expands, just as ice has a lower density than water. Due to its high thermal conductivity (149 W m−1 K−1), silicon conducts heat so it is never used to insulate hot objects. In its crystalline form, pure silicon is metallic gray. Like germanium, silicon is somewhat tough but very brittle and easily peels off. Like carbon and germanium, silicon crystallizes in the diamond-cube crystal structure, with a lattice distance of 0.5430710 nm (5.430710 Å). The outer electron orbital of silicon has 4 valence electrons. The 1s, 2s, 2p, and 3s atomic shells are completely filled, while the 3p atomic shells are filled with only 2 of their maximum number of 6. Silicon is a semiconductor. Silicon is a metalloid, readily giving or sharing its outer 4 atoms, allowing many chemical bonds.

In chemistry, an oxidizing agent, better known in Indonesian as an oxidizing agent, has two meanings. In the first sense, an oxidizing agent is a chemical species that removes electrons from other species. It is one of the components in an oxidation-reduction (redox) reaction. In another sense, an oxidizing agent is a chemical species that transfers electronegative atoms, usually oxygen, to a substrate. Combustion, explosions in general, and organic redox reactions involve atomic displacement reactions. Electron acceptors (receivers) participate in electron transfer reactions. In this context, an oxidizing agent is referred to as an electron acceptor and a reducing agent (in Indonesian it is better known as a reducing agent) is referred to as an electron donor. The classic oxidizing agent is the ferrocenium ion Fe(C' Too many ('";, which accepts an electron to form Fe(C' Too many ('";). There is a tabulation ranking the electron acceptor properties of various reagents (redox potential), see Standard potential). electrode (data page). Of particular interest to chemists are the details of the electron transfer event, which can be described as inner or outer sphere. In common usage, the oxidizer transfers oxygen atoms to the substrate. In this context, the oxidizer can be referred to as an oxygenating reagent or oxygen-atom transfer (OAT) agents. Examples include MnO' Too many ('"; (permanganate), CrO' Too many ('"; (chromate), OsO (osmium tetroxide), and in particular ClO' Too many ('"; (perchlorate). Note that these species are all oxides. In some cases, these oxides also act as electron acceptors, as illustrated by the conversion of MnO' Too many ('"; becomes MnO' Too many ('"; manganate. The definition of an oxidizing hazardous substance is a substance that can cause, or contribute to, the combustion of other substances. Based on this definition, some materials that are classified as oxidizing agents by practitioners and academics of analytical chemistry are not classified as oxidizing agents within the scope of hazardous materials.

Methane is the simplest gaseous hydrocarbon with the chemical formula CH4. Pure methane is odorless, but when used for commercial purposes, a slight odor of sulfur is usually added to detect any possible leaks. As the main component of natural gas, methane is the main fuel source. Combustion of one molecule of methane with oxygen releases one molecule of CO2 (carbon dioxide) and two molecules of H2O (water): Methane is a greenhouse gas. The concentration of methane in the atmosphere in 1998, expressed as mole fractions, was 1,745 nmol/mol (parts per billion), up from 700 nmol/mol in 1750. By 2008, the concentration of methane gas in the atmosphere had increased again to 1,800 nmol/ mole. Methane is a tetrahedral molecule with four equivalent C-H bonds. Its electronic structure can be explained by 4 bonding molecular orbitals resulting from complementary C and H valence orbitals. The low energy molecular orbitals result from the 2s orbitals on the carbon atom pairing with the 1s orbitals of 4 hydrogen atoms. At room temperature and standard pressure, methane is a colorless and odorless gas. The smell of methane (which is deliberately created for safety reasons) is produced by the addition of an odorant such as methanthiol or ethanthiol. Methane has a boiling point of −161 °C (−257.8 °F) at 1 atmosphere. As a gas, methane is only flammable when its concentration reaches 5-15% in air. Liquid methane will not burn unless subjected to high pressure (4-5 atmospheres). The main reactions in methane are combustion, reformation of the vapor to syngas, and halogenation. In general, the methane reaction is difficult to control. Partial oxidation to methanol, for example, is a rather difficult reaction to carry out because the chemical reaction that occurs still forms carbon dioxide and water even though the amount of oxygen available is insufficient.

The enzyme methane monooxygenase can be used to produce methanol from methane, but due to its limited amount it cannot be used in industrial-scale reactions. Like other hydrocarbons, methane is a very weak acid. Its pKa value in DMSO is estimated to be 56. Methane cannot be deprotonated in solution, but its basic conjugate with methyllithium is known. Protonation of methane can be prepared by reacting it with superacids to produce CH5+, sometimes called methanium ions. In the methane combustion reaction, there are several steps that are skipped. The initial product obtained is formaldehyde (HCHO or H2CO). Formaldehyde oxidation produces formyl radical (HCO), which in turn produces carbon monoxide (CO): H2 is oxidized to H2O and releases heat. This reaction takes place very quickly, usually even less than a millisecond. Eventually, CO will oxidize and form CO2 while releasing heat. This reaction proceeds more slowly than the other steps, usually taking several milliseconds. The final reaction result of the above equation is: Methane reacts with the halogens, the chemical reaction is: where X is the halogen atom: fluorine (F), chlorine (Cl), bromine (Br), or iodine (I). The mechanism for this process is called free radical halogenation. The reaction starts with the Cl radical attaching to methane to give CH3, the two combine to form methyl chloride (CH3Cl). Another reaction will produce dichloromethane (CH2Cl2), chloroform (CHCl3), and carbon tetrachloride (CCl4). The energy required for this reaction can be via ultraviolet radiation or heating. Methane is used in chemical industrial processes and can be transported as a frozen liquid (liquefied natural gas, or LNG). When in frozen liquid form, methane will be heavier than air because the cooled methane gas will have a greater density, .

Transistors are semiconductor devices used as amplifiers, as circuit breakers and current connectors (switching), voltage stabilization, and signal modulation. A transistor can function as a kind of electric valve, where based on its input current (BJT) or input voltage (FET), it allows a very accurate flow of electricity from the power supply circuit. In general, a transistor has 3 terminals, namely Base (B), Emitter (E) and Collector (C). The voltage at one terminal, for example the emitter, can be used to regulate currents and voltages that are greater than the base input (input) current, namely the output voltage and output current (output) of the collector. Transistor is a very important component in the world of modern electronics. In analog circuits, transistors are used in amplifiers (amplifiers). Analog circuits include loudspeakers, stabilizers, and radio signal amplifiers. In digital circuits, transistors are used as high-speed switches. Some transistors can also be arranged in such a way that they function as logic gates, memory and other circuit functions. Basically, transistors and vacuum tubes have a similar function; both regulate the amount of electric current flowing. To understand how semiconductors work, consider a glass filled with pure water. If a pair of conductors is inserted into it, and a DC voltage is applied just below the electrolytic voltage (before the water turns into hydrogen and oxygen), no current will flow because water has no charge carriers. So that, pure water considered as isolator. If a small amount of table salt is placed in it, conductive current will start to flow, because a number of free carriers (mobile carriers, ions) are formed. Increasing the salt concentration will increase conduction, but not by much. Kitchen salt itself is a non-conductor (insulator), because the charge carrier is not free.

Pure silicon itself is an insulator, but if small impurities are added, such as arsenic, by a process called doping, in amounts small enough so that they do not mess up the layout of the silicon crystals, the arsenic gives up free electrons and the result allows the conduction of electric currents. This is because arsenic has 5 atoms in its outer orbit, whereas silicon has only 4. Conduction occurs because free charge carriers have been added (by the excess electrons from Arsenic). In this case, an n-type silicon (n for negative, since the charge carriers are electrons which are negatively charged) has been formed. Additionally, silicon can be mixed with boron to make p-type semiconductors. Since Boron has only 3 electrons in its outermost orbit, new charge carriers, called "holes" (positive charge carriers), will form in the layout of the silicon crystal. In a vacuum tube, charge carriers (electrons) are emitted by thermionic emissions from a cathode heated by a filament wire. Therefore, vacuum tubes cannot create positive charge carriers (holes). It can be seen that charge carriers with the same charge will repel each other, so that without any other force, these charge carriers will be evenly distributed in the semiconductor material. But in a bipolar transistor (or diode junction) where a p-type semiconductor and an n-type semiconductor are fabricated on a single silicon chip, these charge carriers tend to migrate toward the P-N junction (the boundary between the p-type semiconductor and the diode junction). n-type), because they are attracted by opposite charges from across it. An increase in the amount of contaminants (doping level) will increase the conductivity of the semiconductor material, provided that the layout of the silicon crystals is maintained. In a bipolar transistor, the emitter terminal has a greater amount of doping than the base terminal.

In meteorology, a tropical cyclone (or hurricane, cyclone, tropical storm, typhoon, or hurricane depending on the area and strength) is a type of low pressure system that forms commonly in the tropics. While these winds can be very destructive or highly destructive, tropical cyclones are an important part of the atmospheric circulation system, which transfers heat from the equator to higher latitudes. The most fertile tropical cyclone growth area in the world is the northwest region of the Pacific Ocean, followed by the southeastern region of the Indian Ocean or the western waters of Australia. As explained by the Australian Bureau of Meteorology, the growth of cyclones in the region reaches an average of 10 times per year. Tropical cyclones apart from destroying the areas they pass through, also cause flooding. Australia has developed early warnings to reduce the risk of tropical cyclones since the 1960s. By structure, a tropical cyclone is a giant area of ​​varying cloud, wind, and thunderstorm activity. The primary energy source for a tropical cyclone is the release of condensation/condensation heat from water vapor that condenses at high altitudes. Therefore, a tropical cyclone can be interpreted as a giant churning coal machine. The elements of a tropical cyclone include pre-existing weather disturbance, warm tropical oceans, moisture (moisture), and relatively mild winds. If the right conditions persist long enough, they can link together to produce fierce winds, incredible waves, torrential rains, and floods alongside this phenomenon. The use of this condensation as a driving force is the primary difference that distinguishes tropical cyclones from other meteorological phenomena. Mid-latitude cyclones, for example, derive their energy largely from preexisting temperature fluctuations in the atmosphere.

In order to continue to fuel its coal engine, tropical cyclones must stay above warm water, which provides the required atmospheric humidity. This moisture evaporation is driven by the high winds and reduced atmospheric pressure present in the storm, resulting in a protracted cycle. As a result, when a tropical cyclone passes over land, its strength decreases rapidly. Tropical cyclones are classified into three main groups: tropical depressions, tropical storms, and a third group whose name depends on the area. A tropical depression is a system of falling clouds and thunderstorms with maximum surface circulation and sustained winds of less than 17 meters per second (33 knots, 38 m/h, or 62 km/h). It has no eyes, and is not characteristic of the spiraling shape of the stronger storms. It is already a low pressure system, however, hence the name "depression". A tropical storm is a descending system of powerful thunderstorms with maximum surface circulation and sustained winds of between 17 and 33 meters per second (34–63 knots, 39–73 m/h, or 62–117 km/h). At this time, a distinctive cyclone shape begins to form, although its eyes usually do not appear. The terminology used to describe tropical cyclones with maximum sustained winds exceeding 33 meters per second (63 knots, 73 m/h, or 117 km/h) varies depending on the region of origin, for example as follows: Elsewhere in the world, hurricanes have been known as Bagyo in the Philippines, Chubasco in Mexico, and Taino in Haiti. The center of a tropical cyclone called the eye is a circle between 10 and 100 kilometers in diameter, most commonly reported as being around 40 meters. The wind speed in this area is lower even when the sky is clear. The eye is surrounded by a wall of dense clouds 16 kilometers high with violent winds and rain.

The turbine is a rotating machine that takes energy from a fluid flow. Simple turbines have one moving part, the "rotor-blade assembly". The moving fluid makes the propeller spin and generates energy to drive the rotor. Examples of early turbines are windmills and water wheels. A turbine that works in reverse is called a compressor or turbo pump. Gas, steam and water turbines usually have a "casing" around the blades which focuses and controls the fluid. The "casing" and vanes may have variable geometries that allow efficient operation for various fluid flow conditions. The energy is obtained in the form of a rotating "shaft". Wind turbines can convert kinetic energy in the wind into mechanical energy. The part of the turbine that is capable of converting this form of energy is called the turbine blade. Energy changes carried out by wind turbines always experience losses. The reason is that not all of the potential kinetic energy of the wind can be converted into other forms of energy by the turbine. The energy that can be converted is greater when the energy losses due to the shape of the turbine are smaller. The kinetic energy generated by the turbine is then forwarded to the gearbox which is connected to an electric generator. Then the generator will convert the mechanical energy from the wind turbine into electrical energy. The mechanical energy generated by a wind turbine can be estimated by measuring the wind speed. The most common type of measuring instrument is the anemometer. Gas turbine is a turbine with a driving medium in the form of a gaseous fluid. This fluid comes from a fan that introduces the working fluid into the heating system. The fluid is heated in the combustion engine. Types of internal combustion engines can vary from internal combustion engines to external combustion engines. Combustion of this fluid produces hot gas which is then flowed to the turbine.

Hamburg (Lower Saxony: Hamborg), officially the Free City and Hansa Hamburg (German: Freie und Hansestadt Hamburg, Lower Saxony: Friee un Hansestadt Hamborg) is the second most populous city in Germany after Berlin, and one of the busiest cities in the world. world. Hamburg was founded in 825. With an area of ​​755 km2 and crossed by the river Elbe, this city is classified as a cosmopolitan city thanks to the reputation of its sons such as the famous classical composers Felix Mendelssohn and Johannes Brahms and director and theater player Gustaf Grudgens of the Deutsche Schauspielhaus. The city of Hamburg has a strong publishing industry which began to develop in the 17th century. The physical character of this city is marked by the canal system that divides it. Hamburg also has beautiful lakes, parks and museums including the Kunsthalle (1868), Museum of Arts and Crafts (1877), Museum of Ethnology and Prehistory (1878). Its official name reflects Hamburg's history as a member of the Hanseatic League in medieval times and an independent imperial city from the Holy Roman Empire. Prior to the German Unification in 1871, Hamburg was a fully sovereign city-state, and prior to 1919 it formed a civil republic governed constitutionally by the hereditary great burgher class or Hanseaten. Struck by disasters such as the Great Hamburg Fire, the North Sea floods of 1962 and military conflicts including bombing raids during World War II, the city has managed to recover and become more prosperous after each disaster. The history of the city of Hamburg is both tragic and romantic. Located between the Elbe and Alster rivers, Hammaburg castle was built in 825 and became the home of the Archbishop of Ansgar, which made it a base for expanding Christian influence over the pre-Christian population of Northern Europe. The city was burnt to the ground by the Vikings in 845, but was later rebuilt only to be burned again 8 times in 300 years.

In the 13th century AD, Hamburg became part of the Hanseatic League, which included the Baltic trading cities of Lübeck, Breslau and Danzig. This league strengthened the economy of the cities of the unified North Germany. Trade flourished, and Hamburg became a major port of trade between Russia and Flanders with its position as ruler and guardian of the river Elbe. Although the Hanseatic League broke up in the late Middle Ages, Hamburg continued to grow. Its growth has outpaced Lübeck. The Hamburg stock exchange was founded in 1558. Between 1616-1625, Hamburg built its own defenses and also built public facilities such as an orphanage built in 1604 and a hospital built in 1605. In 1625, the city strengthened its defenses so that it could continue its trading activities went through hard times in the Thirty Years' War (1618-1648) which left other cities in a slump. It's just that when it was attacked by the French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte in 1830, Hamburg was subdued and then dissolved in the French Empire. However, after Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte fell, Hamburg was able to reclaim its former glory as a free Hanseatic port city. Trade also expanded to Africa, America and Asia. Since rebuilding the damage suffered by its port during World War II, Hamburg has reclaimed its position as Germany's main port and has become one of the most important ports in Northern Europe. In the early 1960s, members of the world famous band from Great Britain, The Beatles often performed regularly in the city of Hamburg and became so famous that it can be said that this city was the starting point of the band's success.
