There are 5 main churches in the city of Hamburg which were rebuilt after the big fire. The development of the city of Hamburg is marked by the many areas in the suburbs of Hamburg that have sprung up along the shores of Lake Aussenalster, and the many consulates general that occupy the beautiful Patrisian style houses in this city .

Alkenes or olefins in organic chemistry are unsaturated hydrocarbons with a double bond between carbon atoms. The terms alkene and olefin are often used interchangeably (see Nomenclature section below). The simplest acyclic alkenes, which form one double bond and are not attached to any functional group, are known as mono-enes, forming a homologous series of hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n. Alkenes have two less hydrogen atoms than related alkanes (with the same number of carbon atoms). The simplest alkene is ethene or ethylene (C2H4) is the largest organic compound produced on an industrial scale. Aromatic compounds are often described as cyclic alkenes, but their structure and properties are different and so they are not considered alkenes. Like a single covalent bond, a double bond can be described in terms of overlapping atomic orbitals, except that, unlike a single bond (which consists of single sigma bonds), a carbon–carbon double bond is composed of one sigma bond and one pi bond. These double bonds are stronger than single covalent bonds (611 kJ/mol for C=C vs 347 kJ/mol for C–C) and also shorter, with an average bond length of 1.33 Ångström (133 pm). Each carbon in the double bond uses three sp2 hybrid orbitals to form sigma bonds to three atoms (one other carbon and two hydrogen atoms). The non-hybridized 2p atomic orbitals, which are perpendicular to the plane created by the axes of the three sp² hybrid orbitals, combine to form pi bonds. These bonds lie off the principal C–C axis, with half of the bonds on one side of the molecule and half on the other. Rotation around a carbon–carbon double bond is limited because it requires a large amount of energy to break the alignment of the p orbitals on the two carbon atoms.

As a consequence, substituted alkenes exist as one of two isomers, which are called cis or trans isomers. More complex alkenes may be named with the E–Z notation for molecules with three or four distinct substituents (side groups). For example, in the butene isomer, two methyl groups (Z)-but-2-ene (aka cis-2-butene) appear on the same side of the double bond, and on (E)-but-2-ene (aka trans- 2-butene) methyl group appears on the opposite side. These two isomers of butene differ slightly in their chemical and physical properties. A 90° turn of the C=C bond (which can be determined by the position of the functional group attached to the carbon) requires less energy than the strength of the pi bond, so the bond can hold. This contradicts the common statement in textbooks that p orbitals would not be able to maintain such bonds. In fact, the deviation of the p orbitals is less than expected due to pyramidalization (see: pyramidal alkenes). trans-Cyclooctene is a stable straight alkene with an orbital deviation of only 19° with a dihedral angle of 137° (normal 120°) and a pyramidalization degree of 18°. The trans cycloheptene isomer is only stable at low temperatures. As predicted by the VSEPR electron pair repulsion model, the molecular geometry of the alkene includes the bond angle around each carbon in the double bond being around 120°. The angle varies because the steric chain is affected by unbonding interactions between the functional groups attached to the carbon of the double bond. For example, the C-C-C bond angle in propylene is 123.9°. For bridged alkenes, the Bredt rule states that a double bond cannot form at the base of a bridged ring system unless the ring is large enough (8 or more atoms). The physical properties of alkenes do not differ much from alkanes. They are colorless, nonpolar, flammable, and nearly odorless.

Number is a mathematical concept used in enumeration and measurement. Symbols or symbols used to represent a number are called numbers or number symbols. In mathematics, the concept of number has over the years been extended to include zero, negative numbers, rational numbers, irrational numbers, and complex numbers. Certain procedures that take numbers as input and produce other numbers as output are called numerical operations. The uner operation takes one input number and produces one output number. The more commonly encountered operation is the binary operation, which takes two numbers as input and produces one number as output. Examples of binary operations are addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, exponents, and square roots. The field of mathematics that studies numerical operations is known as arithmetic. In everyday usage, number is often interpreted as either a number or a number, but the three terms are by definition distinct entities. A number is a sign or symbol used to represent a number. For example, the number five can be represented using the Hindu-Arabic numerals "5" (base 10 numeral system), "101" (binary numeral system), or using the Roman numeral 'V'. The symbols "5", "1", "0", and "V" used to represent the number five are called numbers. Number usually refers to one or more digits representing an integer in a sequence of consecutive integers. For example the word 'number 3' refers to a position in the sequence of numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, ..., etc. The word "number" is closely related to the notion of sequence. The early history of the emergence of numbers (mathematics) comes from nations that live along rivers such as the Egyptians in the Nile river, the Babylonians who inhabited the banks of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, the Indian Hindus along the Indus and Ganges rivers, and the Chinese along the the Huang Ho and Yang Tze rivers.

Mathematics is needed by these nations for calculating various daily needs involving numbers such as trade calculations, calendars, seasonal change calculations, land area measurements and others. In the development of human civilization, mathematics is increasingly needed in trade, finance, and tax collection. The number system used by ancient nations varied until it finally developed into the number currently used, namely the Hindu-Arabic number system. There are various types of numbers. The best known numbers are the integers 0, 1, -1, 2, -2, ... and the natural numbers 1, 2, 3, ..., both of which are often used to calculate in arithmetic. Integer itself is divided into three types, namely positive integers, negative integers, and zero. Whole numbers are the set of non-negative integers, namely {0, 1, 2, 3 ...}. In other words, the set of natural numbers is added by 0. So, whole numbers must have a positive sign. The set of all integers in algebra textbooks is usually represented by the symbol Z and the set of all natural numbers is usually represented by the symbol N. Any form of p/q ratio between two integers p and a non-zero integer q is called a rational number or a fraction. The set of all rational numbers is marked with Q. The elements of the three sets N, Z and Q above can still be 'sorted' (enumerated) without any being left or scattered. Sets of infinite size that can be sorted are called countable sets. The set of all natural numbers (real numbers), that is, all rational numbers combined with all irrational (or irrational) numbers, is represented by the symbol R. This set, apart from being infinite in size, is also an uncountable set because it can be proven mathematically, every attempt to sort it always fails, because it leaves natural numbers.

An ecosystem is an ecological system formed by an inseparable reciprocal relationship between living things and their environment. An ecosystem can also be said to be a complete and comprehensive unitary arrangement between all elements of the environment that influence each other. An ecosystem is an amalgamation of each biosystem unit that involves reciprocal interactions between organisms and the physical environment so that the flow of energy leads to a certain biotic structure and a material cycle occurs between organisms and inorganics. The sun is the source of all existing energy. In an ecosystem, organisms in a community develop together with the physical environment as a system. Organisms will adapt to the physical environment, otherwise organisms also affect the physical environment for the purposes of life. This definition is based on the Gaia Hypothesis, namely: "organisms, especially microorganisms, together with the physical environment produce a control system that maintains conditions on earth suitable for life". This has led to the fact that the chemistry of the atmosphere and Earth is very controlled and very different from that of the other planets in the solar system. The presence, abundance and distribution of a species in an ecosystem is determined by the level of availability of resources and conditions of chemical and physical factors that must be within the range that can be tolerated by the species, this is what is called the law of tolerance. For example: Pandas have a wide tolerance for temperature, but has a narrow tolerance for its food, namely bamboo. Thus, pandas can live in ecosystems under any conditions as long as the ecosystem has bamboo as a food source. Unlike other living things, humans can widen their range of tolerance because of their ability to think, develop technology and manipulate nature. Ecosystems are formed from environmental elements that have two roles, namely autotrophic and heterotrophic.

Autotrophic is the role of environmental elements as food providers independently with the help of solar energy. While heterotrophic is the role of environmental elements as beneficiaries of the existence of food. The food produced can be either organic or inorganic. The environmental elements that form ecosystems are abiotic, biotic, producers, consumers, and decomposers. Abiotic or non-living components are physical and chemical components which are the medium or substrate in which life takes place, or the environment in which life takes place. Most of the abiotic components vary in space and time. Abiotic components can be organic materials, inorganic compounds, and factors that influence the distribution of organisms, namely: Biotic is a term that is usually used to refer to living things (organisms). The biotic component is a component that makes up an ecosystem other than the abiotic (non-living) component. Based on their roles and functions, living things are divided into two types, namely: The heterotrophic component consists of organisms that utilize organic materials provided by other organisms as food. Heterotrophic components are also called macroconsumers (fagotrophs) because the food eaten is smaller. Heterotrophs include humans, animals, fungi and microbes. Decomposers or decomposers are organisms that decompose organic matter derived from dead organisms. Decomposers are also called macroconsumers (sapotrophs) because the food they eat is larger. Decomposing organisms absorb some of the results of this breakdown and release simple materials that can be reused by producers. Classified as decomposers are bacteria and fungi. There are also decomposers called detritivores, which are decomposer animals that eat the remains of organic matter, for example, wood lice. There are three types of decomposition, namely: Dependence on the ecosystem can occur between biotic components or between biotic and abiotic components.

Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) is a standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in internet browsers. This can be aided by technologies such as Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) and other scripting languages ​​such as JavaScript, VBScript and PHP. Internet browsers receive HTML documents from web servers or from local storage and render documents into multimedia web pages. HTML describes the semantic structure of a web page and the prefixes that are included for the appearance of the document. HTML elements are described by tags, written using square brackets. Tags like and directly introduce content into the page. Other tags such as

surround and provide information about the document text and may include other tags as sub-elements. Browsers do not display HTML tags, but use them to interpret page content. HTML can embed programs written in scripting languages ​​such as JavaScript, which influence the behavior and content of web pages. The inclusion of CSS defines the appearance and layout of the content. The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), the former maintainer of HTML and the current maintainer of CSS standards, has been pushing the use of CSS over explicit presentation HTML since 1997. In 1980 a physicist, Tim Berners-Lee, and also a contractor at CERN (European Organization for Nuclear Research) proposed and developed ENQUIRE, a system for CERN scientists to share documents. Nine years later, Berners-Lee proposed an internet-based markup system. Berners-Lee specified HTML and wrote the network and software in the late 1990s. That same year, Berners-Lee and Robert Cailliau, CERN's data systems engineer collaborated on a request for funding, which was not formally accepted by CERN. In his personal notes since 1990 he lists "some of the many areas using hypertext" and first places an encyclopedia.

The first publicly shared description of HTML was in a document called "HTML Mark", first mentioned on the Internet by Tim Berners-Lee in late 1991. This tag describes the 18 elements of the original, simplified version of HTML. Except for hyperlink tags, which are heavily influenced by SGMLguid, CERN's in-house Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML)-based document format. These eleven elements are still present in HTML 4. HTML is the markup language that browsers use to interpret and write text, images and other material into web pages both visually and audibly. The basic characteristics for each item of HTML markup are defined in the browser, and these characteristics can be changed or enhanced by using additional web page designer CSS. Many text elements are found in the ISO technical report in 1988 TR 9537 Techniques for using SGML, which in turn include language features of early text formats such as those used by the RUNOFF commander developed in the early 1960s for operating systems: these format commands are derived from commands used by typists to manually format CTSS documents. However, the SGML concept of generic markup is based on elements rather than just print effects, with separate structure and markup as well; HTML has increasingly moved in this direction with CSS. HTML documents are similar to ordinary written documents, only in this document an article can contain instructions marked with code or better known as certain tags. For example, if you want to make your text appear bold like: SHOW BLOCK, then write it in the following way: SHOW BLOCK. The mark is used to activate the bold print instructions, followed by the text you want to bold, and ends with the sign to deactivate the bold print. HTML places more emphasis on describing the structure and formatting components in web pages rather than determining their appearance. .

Antinomianism is a word that comes from the Greek anti and nomos. Anti means against. Nomos means law. Antinomianism means anti against the law. This teaching teaches that Christians have been freed from the Torah law and do not need to do the Torah law anymore because Christians have received God's grace. Additionally, in Theology, Antinomianism is defined as someone who believes that only faith, not the moral law is necessary for salvation. In a theological sense, a person also tends to despise, and consider himself above all laws and social rules that are due to faith, grace or some special knowledge that makes salvation possible. Antinomianism, as a most radical ideology, arose in the 2nd and 3rd centuries in a sect of Adamites from North Africa. At that time, many currents within the Gnostics were antinomian. As for the Gnostic schools given by Demiurgos and Martin Luther, taught that the Torah law makes everyone aware of all the sins they have committed. However, this teaching from Luther was opposed by John from Agrrikola who said that the Torah law did not have any meaning or benefit. John of Agrrikola also said that a conversion occurs not because of the Torah law, but occurs through the preaching of the Gospel of Salvation. This statement caused a great debate between Luther and John. In 1537 to 1540, Luther continued to debate with John, emphasizing that the role of the law in the life of Christians was very important. This is what causes, so that in 1539 Luther succeeded in producing an article against this Antinomianism. The contents of Martin Luther's writings were made with the aim of opposing the words of John, to fight against sin and provide rules of life for those who believe in Christ.

Electrons are subatomic particles that have a negative charge and are commonly written as e-. The electron has no known basic components or substructures, so it is believed to be an elementary particle. Electrons have a mass of about 1/1836 the mass of a proton. The intrinsic angular momentum (spin) of the electron is half its integer value in units of ħ, which means that it is a fermion. The antiparticle of the electron is called the positron, which is identical to the electron, but has a positive charge. When an electron collides with a positron, the two may either scatter or completely annihilate, producing a pair (or more) of gamma-ray photons. Electrons, which belong to the first generation of the lepton particle family, participate in gravitational interactions, electromagnetic interactions and weak interactions. Like all matter, the electron has both particle-like and wave-like properties (wave-particle duality), so it can collide with other particles and diffract like light. Because electrons are fermions, two different electrons cannot occupy the same quantum state according to the Pauli exclusion principle. The concept of an indivisible electric charge was theorized to explain the chemical properties of atoms by the natural philosopher Richard Laming as early as 1838; The name electron was introduced for this charge in 1894 by the Irish physicist George Johnstone Stoney. The electron was identified as a particle in 1897 by J. J. Thomson. In many physical phenomena, such as electricity, magnetism and thermal conductivity, electrons play a very important role. An electron moving relative to the observer will generate a magnetic field and the trajectory of the electron will also be warped by the external magnetic field. When an electron is accelerated, it can absorb or emit energy in the form of photons. Electrons together with the atomic nucleus consisting of protons and neutrons, make up the atom.

However, electrons take up only 0.06% of the total atomic mass. The Coulomb force of attraction between electrons and protons causes electrons to be bound in atoms. The exchange or sharing of electrons between two or more atoms is the main cause of chemical bonds. According to his theory, most electrons in the universe were created in the Big Bang, but they can also be created through the beta decay of radioactive isotopes or in high-energy collisions, such as when cosmic rays enter the atmosphere. Electrons can be destroyed by annihilation with positrons, or they can be absorbed during stellar nucleosynthesis. Modern laboratory equipment can be used to load or monitor individual electrons. Electrons have many uses in modern technology, for example in electron microscopy, radiation therapy and particle accelerators. The Ancient Greeks noticed that amber attracted small objects when rubbed with animal hair. Apart from lightning, this phenomenon is one of humanity's earliest records of electricity. In his 1600 work De Magnete, English physicist William Gilbert coined the new term electricus to refer to the attracting property of small objects after being rubbed. The English word for electric is derived from the Latin ēlectrum, which comes from the Greek ήλεκτρον (ēlektron) for amber. In 1737, C. F. du Fay and Hawksbee independently discovered what they believed to be two types of frictional electricity; one is produced by rubbing glass, the other is produced by rubbing resin. From this, Du Fay theorized that electricity consists of two electrical fluids, namely "vitreous" and "resinous", which are separated by friction and neutralize each other when combined. A decade later, Benjamin Franklin proposed that electricity did not originate from various electrical fluids, but from the same electrical fluid under different pressures.

Cinnamon bark is a kind of spice obtained from the inner bark of several species of trees of the genus Cinnamomum which is used for sweet and savory dishes. Although cinnamon is sometimes referred to as "true cinnamon", most cinnamon bark in international trade is from another closely related species, which is also called "kasia" to distinguish it from "true cinnamon bark". In 2018, Indonesia and China together produced 70 percent of the world's cinnamon, with Indonesia 40 percent and China 30 percent. Cinnamon is the name for a dozen species of trees and the commercial spice products some of these trees produce. All belong to the genus Cinnamomum in the Lauraceae family. Only a few of these species are grown for sale as spices. Cinnamon has been known since ancient times, first being imported to Egypt 2000 BC. Some claim that this product originates from China, because they mistakenly identify Chinese cinnamon (Cinnamomum cassia). Cinnamon was a highly valued commodity among ancient peoples, and was said to be an appropriate item to make as a gift to royalty. There are carvings that mention that Chinese cinnamon and cinnamon were made offerings to the gods, one of which was Apollo in Miletus. The origin of cinnamon was kept as a trade secret in the Mediterranean region for centuries by those who traded in spices to maintain their monopoly practice. In ancient Egypt, sweet mayu skin was one of the materials used for embalming mummies. From the Ptolemy era onwards, recipes for kyphi, ancient Egyptian incense, used cinnamon bark. According to Herodotus, cinnamon grows in the Arabian region, along with other incense ingredients such as myrrh and labdanum resin, guarded by "winged serpents".

Besides Herodotus, Aristotle and other writers also mention Arabic as the origin of cinnamon. They say that the "cinnamon bird" collects cinnamon sticks from the tree to build a nest. :111 Pliny the Elder mentions that cinnamon was transported across the Arabian peninsula in rafts that had no rudder, sails, or oars. They move using the winter trade winds. He also mentions cassia cinnamon as a flavoring for wine, and the story that cinnamon is collected from the nests of cinnamon birds is a fiction concocted by merchants to attract higher prices. But the story lasted until the time of the Byzantine empire until 1310. According to Pliny the Elder, a pound of cassia and cinnamon (pound roman = 327 gr) was valued at 1500 denarii, or the equivalent of fifty months' salary of laborers at that time. Diocletian's book, Edict on Maximum Prices in 301 AD mentions the price of 125 denarii per pound, or the equivalent of five days of farm laborers' wages at that time. Cinnamon was so expensive that it was rarely used as incense for funerals, but one day Emperor Nero burned a year's supply of the city of Rome's cinnamon for the funeral of his wife, Poppaea Sabina, in 65 AD. Throughout the Middle Ages, the origin of cinnamon remained a mystery to the western world. According to Herodotus, Europeans at the time found out that cinnamon came across the Red Sea to trading ports in Egypt, but where they came from is still unclear. When Jean de Joinville accompanied his king, Louis IX of France to Egypt on the Seventh Crusade in 1248, he reported, and believed what he had been told, that cinnamon was hauled from the Upper Nile at "the end of the world" (Ethiopia).

Mysticism is an understanding that gives teachings that are all mystical (for example the teachings are in the form of secrets or the teachings are all secret, hidden, dark or shrouded in darkness) so that they are only known, known or understood by certain people, especially its adherents. The word mystical comes from the Greek mystikos which means secret (geheim), all secret (geheimzinnig), hidden (verborgen), dark (donker) or shrouded in darkness (in het duister gehuld). According to the book by De Kleine W.P. Encylopaedie (1950, Mr. G.B.J. Hiltermann and Prof. Dr.P. Van De Woestijne page 971 under the word mystiek) the word mystic comes from the Greek myein which means to close the eyes (de ogen sluiten) and musterion which means a secret (geheimnis). Some opinions about mysticism or mysticism: In addition to obtaining definitions, the opinions about mysticism above based on their teaching material also provide a distinction between religious mysticism (related to God and divinity) and non-religious mysticism (not related to god or divinity). Besides being completely mystical, his teachings are also completely subjective and not objective. There are no universal and authentic basic guidelines. Sourced from the personality of the main character so that mystical understanding is not the same as one another even though it is about the same thing. So that the discussion and experience of his teachings cannot be controlled or controlled in the proper sense. Usually the characters are highly glorified, glorified and even idolized (mythed, cultized) by their adherents because they are considered to have personal privileges called charisma. This presumption of privilege can be caused by: Whereas how the character receives teachings or understanding of the understanding he teaches is usually through inner adventure, self-isolation, asceticism, meditating, meditation, silence etc. in the form of ecstasy, visions, inspiration etc. So his teachings were obtained through the character's own personal experience and his acceptance was impossible to prove to others himself.

Thus the acceptance of his teachings was almost solely based on belief, not thought. So that's why some of us call it understanding, teaching of belief or flow of belief (geloofsleer). Bearing in mind that it is impossible to control its teaching in the proper sense, it is easy for mystical understanding to give rise to new branches into new schools according to the interpretation of each of its characters. Or vice versa, it is easy to combine or mix the teachings of pre-existing understandings. Because it is all mystical, mysticism or groups of adherents of mysticism are not too difficult to use by people who have specific goals and who need to be kept secret because they violate or conflict with public opinion or applicable law as a hiding place. The material is completely abstract, meaning it is not concrete, for example about God (divine mysticism), about spirituality or psychology, the nature behind the natural world, etc. (non-religious mysticism). Thus his talk is all speculative, that is all guessing, searching, making possible etc. (not computative). know, still trying to make it possible). Therefore, among adherents of mysticism, there is no known disciplinary discussion regarding their teachings as is the case in discussions or munaqasyah. Among them there are still those who try to rationalize the mystical teachings they adhere to, and there are also those who are completely free from the demands of the progress of this era. Nevertheless, mystical understanding can instill ethical and moral standards in civilizational arrangements. Although mystical understanding is usually conveyed using parables, there is actually value in it that can be contemplated and is still relevant to apply in everyday life. source: MH Amien Jaiz, Mystical Problems of Sufism & Mysticism (PT Alma'arif, Bandung, Print 1980) Abrahamism Akosmism Agnosticism Animism Antireligion Atheism Dharmism Deism Dualism Esotericism Feminist theology Gnosticism Henotheism Humanism Immanenke Monism Monotheism Mysticism Naturalism Nondualism Pandeism Pantheism Polytheism Process Theology Syamanism Taoist Theism Transcendent New Age This article on the topic of religion or belief is a stub.

Molybdenum is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Mo and atomic number 42. Its name is taken from the Neo-Latin molybdaenum, from the Ancient Greek Μόλυβδος molybdos, meaning lead, because its ore was confused with lead ore. The mineral molybdenum has been known throughout history, but the element was discovered (in the sense of distinguishing it as a new entity from salts of other metallic minerals) in 1778 by Carl Wilhelm Scheele. The metal was first isolated in 1781 by Peter Jacob Hjelm. Molybdenum does not occur naturally as a free metal on Earth; it is only found in various oxidation states in minerals. The free element, a silvery metal with gray stains, has the 6th melting point of all the elements. It readily forms stable and hard carbides in alloying metals, and for this reason, a large part of the element's world production (about 80%) is used in steel alloys, including high-strength alloys and superalloys. Most molybdenum compounds have low solubility in water, but when molybdenum minerals are exposed to oxygen and water, the resulting MoO molybdate ion is moderately soluble. On an industrial scale, molybdenum compounds (about 14% of world production) are used in high pressure and high temperature applications as pigments and catalysts. Molybdenum fixing enzymes are by far the most common bacterial catalysts for breaking chemical bonds in atmospheric nitrogen molecules in the nitrogen fixation process. At least 50 molybdenum enzymes are now known in bacteria and animals, although only bacterial and cyanobacterial enzymes are involved in nitrogen fixation. These nitrogenases contain molybdenum in a form different from the other molybdenum enzymes, which all contain fully oxidized molybdenum in a molybdenum cofactor. These molybdenum cofactor enzymes are essential for organisms, and molybdenum is an essential element for life in all higher eukaryotic organisms, though not in all bacteria.

In its pure form, molybdenum is a silvery-gray metal with a Mohs hardness of 5.5. Mo has a melting point of 2,623°C (4,753°F; 2,896K); Of the natural elements, only tantalum, osmium, rhenium, tungsten and carbon have higher melting points. The weak oxidation of molybdenum begins at 300°C (572°F; 573K). It has one of the lowest coefficients of thermal expansion of the metals used commercially. The tensile strength of molybdenum wire increases about 3 times, from about 10 to 30 GPa, as the diameter decreases from ~50-100 nm to 10 nm. There are 35 known isotopes of molybdenum, with atomic masses ranging from 83 to 117, as well as four metastable nuclear isomers. Seven isotopes occur naturally, with atomic masses of 92, 94, 95, 96, 97, 98, and 100. Of these naturally occurring isotopes, only molybdenum-100 is unstable. Molybdenum-98 is the most abundant isotope, making up 24.14% of all molybdenum. Molybdenum-100 has a half-life of about 1019 years and undergoes a double beta decay to become ruthenium-100. Molybdenum isotopes with mass numbers 111 to 117 all have half-lives of about 150 ns. All the unstable isotopes of molybdenum decay into niobium, technetium, and ruthenium. As also noted below, the most common isotopic molybdenum applications involve molybdenum-99, which is a product of fission. It is the parent radioisotope to the short-lived, gamma-emitting daughter radioisotope technetium-99m, a nuclear isomer used in a variety of imaging applications in medicine. In 2008, Delft University of Technology applied for a patent for the production of molybdenum-99 based on molybdenum-98. Molybdenum is a transition metal with an electronegativity of 2.16 on the Pauling scale and a standard atomic weight of 95.95 g/mol.

Bonn is a city on the banks of the River Rhine in the State of North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany. The city was the provisional capital of West Germany from 1949 to 1990 and the official seat of government for the unified Germany from 1990 to 1999. Bonn is located in the southern part of the Rhine-Ruhr, Germany's largest metropolitan area; exactly 20 kilometers south of Cologne. Bonn is home to two of Germany's main DAX-listed companies. As of December 2011, it had an area of ​​141.22 km² and an estimated population of 327,913; 19th largest city in Germany. Although Berlin replaced Bonn as the capital of unified Germany in 1990, it is still the political and administrative center. Approximately half of the functions of the federal government, many federal government departments, and several government agencies under federal ministries are still centralized in Bonn. In honor of these circumstances, the former capital was given the status of a Federal City (Bundesstadt). Bonn has developed into a center for international cooperation, particularly in the environmental and sustainable development spheres. In addition to a number of international organizations and institutions, such as the United Nations Center for Environmental Law on Nature Reserves (IUCN ELC), the city also hosts 18 United Nations agencies. Together, Bonn asserts itself as a center for national and international meetings, conventions and conferences, most of which relate directly to the work of the United Nations. A conference center capable of accommodating thousands of participants is currently under construction near the UN Campus. The city is home to the University of Bonn, one of the best higher education institutions in Germany. From 1597 to 1794, Bonn was the Electorate of Cologne and the residence of the Archbishops and Prince-electors of Cologne, and was the birthplace of the famous composer Ludwig van Beethoven in 1770.

The Book of Genesis (abbreviated Genesis; acronym Kej. ; Hebrew: סֵפֶר בְּרֵאשִׁית, translit. Sefer Beresyit‎) is the first book and part of the group of books of the Torah (or Pentateuch) in the Old Testament Christian Bible and Tanakh (or Hebrew Bible). This book tells about the creation of the world, the early history of mankind, the ancestors of Israel and the origin of the Jewish people. In the Jewish and Christian traditions, it is said that the Book of Genesis was written by Moses, as well as the Book of Exodus, Leviticus, and most of the contents of Deuteronomy. Modern scholarship, however, especially since the 19th century, considers the books to have been written in the 6th–5th century B.C.E., hundreds of years after the time Moses was supposed to have lived. Based on scientific interpretations of archaeological, genetic, and linguistic evidence, most scientists believe that the Book of Genesis is not historical fact but simply Judeo-Christian mythology. Within Judaism, the theological importance of the Book of Genesis is centered on the covenant linking God to His chosen people and His chosen people to the Promised Land. Christianity has interpreted the Book of Genesis as an early description of certain important faiths of Christianity, especially the need for salvation (the hope or assurance for all Christians) and Christ's atoning act on the Cross as the fulfillment of the covenant as the Son of God. The name "Genesis" is a free translation of the name of the book in the Greek Septuagint version, "Genesis" (Γένεσις, translit. Génesis, lit. "origin, beginning, beginning, birth, creation"). The name is a translation of the Hebrew word in Hebrew: בְּרֵאשִׁית‎ (beresyit), which literally means "in the beginning". The name is taken from the first word in the book, namely the first word in Genesis 1:1 as follows. בְּרֵאשִׁית, בָּרָא אֱלֹהִים, אֵת הַשָּׁמַיִם, וְאֵת הָאָרֶץ. (Hebrew text) Beresyit, bara elohim, et hassyamayim, we'et ha'arets.

In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. (TB) The book of Genesis in general tells stories before the time of Moses, starting from the story of creation to the story of the ancestors of the Israelites who moved from Canaan to Egypt. This book can be divided into two major parts according to the type of content contained in this book. The division and explanation of each is as follows. Divisions based on Bible facts This first section covers Genesis 1–11. This section presents the author's concept of divinity and the relationship between humans and their Creator. This section contains several toledot lists ("history, genealogy"), some in the form of narratives and some in the form of genealogies (descendants). Toledot that appear in this section include the history of creation (1:1), the history of heaven and earth (2:4), the genealogy of Adam (5:1), the history of Noah (6:9), the genealogy of Shem, Ham, and Japheth (10:1), the genealogy of Shem (11:10), and the history of Terah (11:27). The second section called history covers Genesis 12–50. This section describes the prehistoric times of the Israelites, namely God's chosen nation, by telling their forefathers. Like the first part, this section also contains several toledot lists, which consist of the genealogy of Ishmael (25:12), the history of Isaac (25:19), the history and genealogy of Esau (36:1, 36:9), and the history of Jacob ( 37:2). At God's command, Noah's descendant, Abraham, traveled from his birthplace (described as Ur of the Chaldeans) to the God-given land of Canaan, where he lived as a foreigner, as did his son Isaac and grandson Jacob. Jacob's name was changed to "Israel", and through the intercession of his son Joseph, the children of Israel descended into Egypt, 70 people with all their households and God promised them a great future.

Democracy is a form of government in which important decisions, either directly or indirectly, are based on the majority agreement freely given by the adult community. Democracy is a form of government in which all citizens have the same right to make decisions that can change their lives. Democracy allows citizens to participate—either directly or through representatives—in the formulation, development and making of laws. Democracy includes social, economic, customary and cultural conditions that allow for the free and equal practice of political freedom. Democracy is also a set of ideas and principles about freedom and its practices and procedures. Democracy means respect for human dignity. , and minorities. The word comes from the Ancient Greek δημοκρατία (dēmokratía) "rule of the people", which was formed from δῆμος (dêmos) "the people" and κράτος (kratos) "power" or "rulership" in the 5th century BC to refer to the political system of states- Greek cities, one of which is Classical Athens; this word is an antonym of wikt:ἀριστοκρατία (aristocratie) "elite power". Theoretically, the two definitions contradict each other, but the reality is no longer clear. The classical Athenian political system, for example, granted democratic citizenship to free elite men and excluded slaves and women from political participation. In all democratic governments throughout modern history, democratic citizenship has remained with the elite until all the adult population in most modern democracies is truly free following the struggle for the suffrage movement from the 19th century onwards. The word democracy (democracy) itself has existed since the 16th century contemporaneously with the sultan of Banten Abdul Mahasin Muhammad Zainal Abidin, Democracy comes from Middle French and old Middle Latin.

The year AD starts from 570 AD. The concept of democracy was born from ancient Greece which was practiced in state life between the 4th century BC to the 6th century BC. The democracy practiced at that time was direct democracy, meaning that the people's right to make political decisions was carried out directly by all the people or citizens. A democratic government is different from a form of government in which the power is held by one person, such as a monarchy. Derived from the Greek philosophy today seems ambiguous because some contemporary governments mix elements of democracy, oligarchy, and monarchy. Karl Popper defined democracy as distinct from dictatorship or tyranny, thus focusing on the opportunity for a society to control its dishonest or untrustworthy leaders and remove them without needing a revolution. There are several types of democracy, but only two basic forms. Both explain how all people carry out their wishes. The first form of democracy is direct democracy, in which all citizens play a direct and active role in making government decisions. In most modern democracies, the entire people is still a sovereign power but political power is exercised indirectly through representatives; so-called indirect democracy. A brief history Throughout its independence, the Indonesian nation has tried to implement various types of democracy. Until 1959, democratic practices were carried out which tended to be a Liberal Democracy system, as was the case in individualistic Western countries. In 1959-1966 Guided Democracy was implemented, which in practice tended to be authoritarian. Starting in 1966 until the end of the New Order period in 1998 Pancasila Democracy was implemented. This model also does not encourage the growth of people's participation. After the rollout of reform in 1998, freedom of speech and expression, freedom of choice, political freedom and others are increasingly free.

Proteins are large groups of biomolecules made up of one or more long chains of amino acids. Proteins have many functions in living things, including accelerating metabolic reactions, replicating DNA, responding to stimuli, giving shape to cells and bodies, and moving molecules from one location to another. The main difference between one protein and another is the sequence of its amino acids, which is determined by the nucleotide sequence of its genes, and usually causes the folding of the protein into a special three-dimensional structure suited to its function. A number of amino acids form a straight chain called a polypeptide. A protein consists of at least one long polypeptide. Short polypeptides (with less than 20–30 amino acids) are not usually considered proteins, but are called peptide or oligopeptide molecules. Each amino acid in a protein is bound to a nearby amino acid by a peptide bond. The sequence of amino acids in a protein is determined by the sequence of genes encoded in the genetic code. In general, the genetic code produces a standard 20 amino acids, although some organisms have additional amino acids. Shortly after or even during synthesis, residues in proteins are often chemically modified through posttranslational modification processes that change the physical and chemical properties, folding, stability, activity, and function of the protein. Some proteins have nonpeptide (non-amino acid) groups, which can be called cofactors and prosthetic groups. Some proteins can also work together to carry out specific functions, and such groups often form stable protein complexes. Once formed, proteins exist only for a certain period of time and then are degraded and recycled within the cell through the process of protein turnover. The lifespan of a protein is measured by its half-life and covers a long range.

Proteins can be several minutes to several years old with an average lifespan of 1–2 days in mammalian cells. Abnormal or misfolded proteins degrade more rapidly, either because they are targeted for destruction or because they are unstable. Along with other giant biomolecules such as polysaccharides and nucleic acids, proteins are an essential part of organisms and are involved in almost all processes in cells. Some proteins are enzymes that function as catalysts in biochemical reactions and are vital for metabolism. Some proteins have a building or strengthening function, for example actin and myosin proteins in muscles and proteins in the cytoskeleton. Other proteins have important roles in cell signaling, immune response, cell adhesion, and cell cycle. Animals need protein in their diet to obtain essential amino acids that cannot be synthesized in the body. The digestive system breaks down protein from food to be used in metabolism. Proteins can be purified from other cellular components using various techniques such as ultracentrifugation, precipitation, electrophoresis and chromatography. Genetic engineering allows a number of methods to facilitate this purification. Methods commonly used to study protein structure and function are immunohistochemistry, site-directed mutagenesis, X-ray crystallography, nuclear magnetic resonance, and mass spectrometry. Proteins were recognized as a group of biomolecules in the eighteenth century by Antoine Fourcroy and others, characterized by their ability to coagulate or flocculation under treatment with heat or acids. Examples recorded at that time were albumin from egg white, albumin in blood serum, fibrin, and wheat gluten. Proteins were first described by the Dutch chemist Gerardus Johannes Mulder and named by the Swedish chemist Jöns Jacob Berzelius in 1838. Mulder performed elemental analysis of common proteins and found that almost all proteins have the same empirical formula, namely C400H620N100O120P1S1.

in Europe  (gray) Norway (officially: Kingdom of Norway, Norwegian: Kongeriket Norge (Noreg)), is a Nordic country on the Scandinavian Peninsula, in the extreme west bordering Sweden, Finland, Russia, the United Kingdom in the west southwest, and 1,000 kilometers from Iceland to the west. Its shores on the North Atlantic Ocean and Barents Sea are the locations of famous fjords. Svalbard and Jan Mayen came under Norwegian sovereignty under the Treaty of Svalbard. Norway has an island called Bouvet which is located in the southern Atlantic Ocean. The total area of ​​Norway is 385.207 km². Norway is usually called Kongeriket Norge (Kingdom of Norway) in Bokmål scripts, whereas Kongeriket Noreg in Nynorsk scripts. The Old Norwegians usually called Norway Noregr, and the Medieval peoples Nor(th)vegia. Several medieval texts mention the mythical king Norr, son of Snær (personified snow), a descendant of Fornjót, the legendary ruler of Finland. However, it is generally assumed that the name is of Old Norse origin, meaning "norðvegr" (north of the road). Norway also has the terms austrvegr "land to the east" (Russia), vestrvegr "land to the west" (English and Ireland) and suðrvegr "land to the south" (Mediterranean). The Viking Age is characterized by expansion and emigration by Viking seafarers. Tradition has it that Harald Fairhair (Harald Hårfagre) joined them in 872 AD after the Battle of the Hafrsfjord in Stavanger, thus becoming the first king of a united Norway. The Harald area is primarily the coast of South Norway. Harald Fairhair ruled with a firm hand, and according to history, many Norwegians left the country to live in Iceland, the Faroe Islands, Greenland, and parts of Great Britain and Ireland. Present-day Irish cities such as Dublin, Limerick and Waterford were founded by Norwegian and Danish settlers.

Norway is bordered by the North Sea to the southwest and the Skagerrak Islands to the south, the Norwegian Sea to the west and the Barents Sea to the northeast. To the east, Norway is bordered by Sweden, Finland and Russia. The highest point in Norway is Galdhøpiggen at 2,469 meters above sea level. The climate in Norway is temperate, especially in the coastal areas due to the influence of the Gulf Stream. Norway's landscape is generally rugged and mountainous, mostly covered by glaciers, and has more than 83,000 km of coastline bordered by fjords. The northern part of the country is also known as the Land of the Midnight Sun because it is located at the northernmost tip of the Earth, where in summer, the sun never sets and in winter, it never appears at all. Norway's landscape is generally rugged and mountainous, mostly covered by glaciers and has more than 83,000 km of coastline bordered by fiords. The northern part of the country is also known as the Land of the Midnight Sun because it is located at the northernmost tip of the earth, where in summer, the sun never sets and in winter, it never appears at all. Norway is directly bordered by the North Sea to the west. southwest and the Skagerrak Islands to the south, the Norwegian Sea to the west, and the Barents Sea to the northeast. To the east, Norway is bordered by Sweden, Finland and Russia. The highest point in Norway is Galdhøpiggen at 2,469 meters above sea level. Rondeslottet in Rondane National Park, eastern Norway. Feigefossen, Sogn og Fjordane. The large islands off the northern coastline of Norway.

pH (Potencial of Hydrogen) is the degree of acidity used to express the level of acidity or alkalinity possessed by a solution. It is defined as the cologarithm of the activity of dissolved hydrogen ions (H+). The hydrogen ion activity coefficient cannot be measured experimentally, so its value is based on theoretical calculations. The pH scale is not an absolute scale. It is relative to a set of standard solutions whose pH is determined by international agreement. The concept of pH was first introduced by the Danish chemist Søren Peder Lauritz Sørensen in 1909. It is not known exactly what the abbreviated "p" means in "pH". Some references suggest that the p comes from the abbreviation for power (rank), others refer to the German word Potenz (which also means rank), and still others refer to the word potential. Jens Norby published a scholarly paper in 2000 arguing that p is a constant meaning "negative logarithm". Pure water is neutral, with its pH at 25°C defined as 7.0. Solutions with a pH less than 7 are said to be acidic, and solutions with a pH greater than 7 are said to be basic or alkaline. pH measurement is very important in fields related to life or the chemical processing industry such as chemistry, biology, medicine, agriculture, food science, engineering (engineering), and oceanography. Of course, other fields of science and technology also use it though at a lower frequency. pH is defined as the minus logarithm of the activity of hydrogen ions in an aqueous solution. pH is a dimensionless quantity. where aH is the hydrogen ion activity. The reason for using this definition is that aH can be measured experimentally using ion-selective electrodes that respond to hydrogen ion activity.

pH is generally measured using a glass electrode which measures the potential difference E between a sensitive electrode with hydrogen ion activity and a reference electrode. The potential difference across this glass electrode ideally follows the Nernst equation: where E is the measured potential, E0 is the standard electrode potential, R is the gas constant, T is the temperature in kelvins, F is the Faraday constant, and n is the number of electrons transferred. The electrode potential E is directly proportional to the logarithm of the hydrogen ion activity. This definition is inherently impractical because the hydrogen ion activity is the product of the concentration times the activity coefficient. The activity coefficient of a single hydrogen ion cannot be calculated experimentally. To overcome this, the electrode is calibrated with a solution whose activity is known. The operational definition of pH is formally defined by International Standard ISO 31-8 as follows: For a solution X, first measure the electromotive force EX of the galvanic cell and then measure the electromotive force ES of the galvanic cell which differs only on replacement of solution X of unknown pH with a solution of S whose pH (standard) is known as pH(S). The pH of solution X is therefore the difference between the pH of solution X and the pH of a standard solution depends only on the difference between the two measured potentials. Thus, pH is obtained from potential measurements with electrodes calibrated to one or more pH standards. A pH meter is adjusted so that the meter reading for a standard solution is equal to the pH(S) value. The pH(S) values ​​for various S standard solutions are given by IUPAC recommendations. The standard solution used is often a standard buffer solution. In practice, it is preferable to use two or more standard buffer solutions to allow small deviations from the ideal Nerst's law at the actual electrode.

The Cooperative Republic of Guyana, formerly British Guiana, is a country on the north coast of South America. Guyana is the only country in the region that has English as its official language. Guyana is bordered by Suriname to the east, Brazil to the south, Venezuela to the west and the Atlantic Ocean to the north. The exploitation of the bauxite and aluminum industries has reduced the country's dependence on purely traditional agriculture. The area controlled by Guyana lies between latitudes 1° and 9°N, and longitudes 56° and 62°W; it is one of the most sparsely populated countries in the world. The country can be divided into five natural areas: the narrow, fertile marshy plains along the Atlantic coast (lower coastal plains) where most of the population lives; the belt of white sands further inland (areas of hilly sands and clays), which contains most of Guyana's mineral deposits; dense rainforest (Forested Highland Region) in the south of the country; drier savanna areas in the southwest; and the smallest interior lowlands (interior savannah) consisting mostly of mountains that gradually rise to the Brazilian border. Some of the highest mountains in Guyana are Mount Ayanganna (2,042 m or 6,699 ft), Monte Caburaí (1,465 m or 4,806 ft) and Mount Roraima (2,772 m or 9,094 ft - highest mountain in Guyana) at the Brazil-Guyana-Venezuela border tripoint, part of from the Pakaraima range. Mount Roraima and table mountain in Guyana (tepuis) ​​are said to have been the inspiration for Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's 1912 novel The Lost World (Arthur Conan Doyle). There are also many escarpment volcanoes and waterfalls, including Kaieteur Falls which is believed to be the world's largest single-drop waterfall by volume.

Samadhi (Sanskrit: समाधि) is a high-level ritual of concentration, transcending the awareness of the physical realm found in Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, and yoga schools. Samadhi is also the highest phase in the eight phases of Yoga mastery. When entering the samadhi phase, analytical and logical faculties become dysfunctional or stagnant. According to the Bhargava Dictionary, Samadhi is the strongest phase of yoga in which a person gains the power to suspend the connection between body and soul for as long as He likes. Samadhi is also understood as a part of religious ritual, as opposed to meditation or meditation, both of which are concentration training practices used outside of religious rituals. In terms of awareness, it is described that samadhi emphasizes non-duality, in which the subject's consciousness becomes one with the object experienced or that exists outside of it, and at this very moment the mind becomes still, focused on one thing or concentrated while one remains aware. Whereas in Buddhism, it can also refer to a submissive state in which the mind becomes very still and completely disengaged with the object of attention, thereby gaining insight and a stream of changes regarding experience. The word samadhi is first used in Sanskrit literature in the Maitri Upanishad. The word samadhi itself generally means "concentration" or "not distracted", while in terms of raising awareness by doing meditation. Then, we traced the etymology of the word originating from the Pali language which is a combination of the prefix sam (meaning "unity" or "integration"), a ("toward"), and finally dha ("achievement of goals or intellect"). Another opinion says samadhi is a verb from samadahati which means "put everything, concentrate, combine" everything that is in the mind or mind.

Another opinion says that the meaning of the word samadhi is a state of balance (sama) and human intellectual detachment (dhi). In addition, this term can also be interpreted as uniformity (sam) and determination (dhi) which means to determine oneself to be fully uniform in one's true self-awareness. So from this etymology it can be concluded that samadhi is an attempt to obtain the whole, the goal, or the truth (samapatti). In Hinduism, Samadhi is part of the religious ritual procedures described in the Yoga Sutras in the first chapter entitled Samadhi-pada. Likewise, Vyasa, an influential figure in Hinduism and also the author of the Mahabharata, explained that samadhi is the same as yoga from a practical point of view. In addition, Hindu teachings also do not only emphasize the concept of samadhi as a state of peace without content, but rather a person changes his consciousness to focus on feeling happy and serene following the flow of life. In Hindu teachings, samadhi is divided into five levels: laya samadhi, savikalpa samadhi, nirvikalpa samadhi, sahaja samadhi, and mahasamadhi. At the first level of laya samadhi one recognizes for the first time the form of peace and happiness through singing, dancing, or other daily activities. In this phase a person begins to grow and recognize the potential talent within him to continue samadhi to the next level. In the second level, savikalpa samadhi, the meditator will experience the sensations of space and time travel differently. During these periods of samadhi, the meditator tries to understand the consummation of samadhi. All kinds of feelings and thoughts flooded into his mind, but he consciously put them out. The third is Nirvikalpa Samadhi, in which the yogi will experience the pinnacle of great bliss. He felt as if the world and everything in it was following him.

The hypothesis or basic assumption is a temporary answer to a problem that is still presumptive because it still has to be proven true. The alleged answer is a temporary truth, which will be verified by data collected through research. The scientific hypothesis tries to express a temporary answer to the problem to be studied. The hypothesis becomes tested if all the symptoms that arise do not contradict the hypothesis. In an effort to prove the hypothesis, the researcher may deliberately cause or create a symptom. This intention is called a trial or experiment. A hypothesis that has been tested for truth is called a theory. Example: The hypothesis comes from the Greek: hypo = under; thesis = establishment, upheld opinion, certainty. That is, the hypothesis is a scientific term used in the context of scientific activities that follow the rules of ordinary thinking, consciously, thoroughly and purposefully. In everyday use this hypothesis is often also called a hypothesis, there is no difference in meaning in it. When thinking on a daily basis, people often refer to a hypothesis as an assumption, estimate, conjecture, and so on. Hypothesis also means a statement or proposition which says that among a number of facts there is a certain relationship. This proposition will shape the process of forming a hypothesis in research, one of which is social research. The process of forming a hypothesis is a reasoning process, which goes through certain stages. This also happens in making scientific hypotheses, which are done consciously, thoroughly, and purposefully. Thus, it can be said that a hypothesis is a type of proposition that can be directly tested. Hypothesis is an important element in scientific research, especially quantitative research. There are three main reasons that support this view, including: Although hypotheses are important as directions and work guidelines in research, not all research absolutely must have hypotheses.

The use of hypotheses in a study is based on the problem or research objectives. In the problems or research objectives, it appears whether the research uses hypotheses or not. An example is exploratory research whose goal is to explore and collect as much data or information as possible without using hypotheses. This is the same as descriptive research, some argue that it does not use hypotheses because it only makes descriptions or measures carefully about the phenomenon under study, but there are also those who think descriptive research can use hypotheses. Meanwhile, in explanatory research that aims to explain the relationship between variables, it is imperative to use a hypothesis. The important function of the hypothesis in research, namely: One hypothesis can be tested if the hypothesis is formulated correctly. Failure to formulate a hypothesis will obscure the research results. Even though the hypothesis has met the requirements proportionally, if the hypothesis is still abstract it not only confuses the research procedure, but also is difficult to test in real terms. To be able to formulate a good and correct hypothesis, at least it must have several main characteristics, namely: The stages of forming a hypothesis are generally as follows: This hypothesis is a type of proposition that is formulated as a tentative answer to a problem and then tested empirically. As a type of proposition, hypotheses generally state the relationship between two or more variables in which the relationship statements have been formulated in a theoretical framework. This hypothesis is derived from, or derived from, theories and literature reviews related to the problem to be studied. The statement of the relationship between variables, as formulated in the hypothesis, is only a temporary assumption of a problem based on the relationship that has been described in the theoretical framework used to explain the research problem. Because, the right theory will produce the right hypothesis to be used as a temporary answer to the problem being researched or studied in research.

Empiricism is a school of philosophy which states that all knowledge comes from the experience of the human senses. Etymologically, the term empiricism comes from the Greek emperia, which means experience. In empiricism, truth can only be obtained through experience. The empiricist mindset relies on empirical evidence. Empiricism is a type of ontology. In empiricism, humans can gain knowledge from experience by observing and sensing. Empiricism is one of the three schools of philosophy of science in the Western world. Philosophical thinking on empiricism has a nature that is contrary to rationalism. Empiricism thought was pioneered by Thomas Hobbes as a reaction against rationalism. The development of empiricism thought took place rapidly in England and the surrounding area during the renaissance during the 17th to 18th centuries. Empiricism was first developed in England by John Locke (1632–1704), but has more influenced thinkers in the United States, especially in the fields of environmental preservation and environmental psychology. Supporting figures come from adherents of Western philosophy, including Francis Bacon, Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, and David Hume. The empiricism of its leaders has contributed to the development of the scientific field. These figures include John Locke (social science and scientific method), George Berkeley (physics, mathematics and theology), and David Hume (historical science and science). Empiricism is also the basis for the development of philosophy in positivism. In addition, empiricism is also one of the main streams in educational philosophy which is the basis for the development of various models of education in the world. The understanding of empiricism has been put forward by Aristotle with the opinion that perception is the basis of science. Empiricism first appeared in England as a thought that contradicted the rationalist thought put forward by René Descartes.

The initial idea of ​​empiricism was put forward by Thomas Hobbes (1588–1679) with the opinion that the beginning of all knowledge comes from sensory experience. The laws of mechanism are considered as the basis of the processes that take place in the world, including humans. Then, another idea about empiricism was put forward by John Locke (1632–1704) who argued that the source of knowledge received by reason comes from experience. The empiricism of thought was further developed by George Berkeley who argued that material substances do not exist at all, only observable characteristics exist. When the world entered the Industrial Revolution, humans began to rely on science and technology to determine policies to address various social problems in society. Mysticism and beliefs about the occult and magic have begun to be abandoned by society. Social problems began to be solved by compiling and testing various scientific theories. The benchmarks used are empiricism and the scientific method. The main teachings of empiricism can be divided based on their views on sources of knowledge, methods of thinking and models of reasoning used. The source of knowledge in the view of empiricism is only from experience. The method of thinking he uses is through empirical evidence and experiments. While the reasoning model he uses is inductive reasoning. The main teachings of empiricism are contrary to rationalism, because rationalism considers knowledge recognition by the senses to be unclear. Meanwhile, empiricism believes that the senses are the perfect and clearest means of recognizing knowledge. In another sense, empiricism prioritizes the use of a posteriori elements, while rationalism prioritizes the use of a priori elements. Another difference between empiricism and rationalism lies in the type of mindset used. Empiricism uses an inductive mindset, while rationalism uses a deductive mindset. The epistemological view of empiricism is based on the principle that everything that exists in the mind exists in the form of sensory data.

Animals, animals, fauna, wildlife or animals are multicellular eukaryotic organisms that make up the biological kingdom Animalia. With few exceptions, animals consume organic matter, breathe oxygen, are able to move, reproduce sexually, and grow from a hollow ball of cells, the blastula, during the embryonic phase of development. More than 1.5 million living animal species have been described—about 1 million of which are insects—but it is estimated that there are more than 7 million animal species in total. Animals range from 8.5 micrometers to 33.6 meters in length and have complex interactions with one another and with their environment, as well as forming intricate food webs. The study of animals is called zoology. Most of the living animal species are classified in the Bilateria, a clade whose members have a bilaterally symmetrical body shape. The Bilateria includes protostomes and deuterostomes. Within the protostomes there are many groups of invertebrates, such as nematodes, arthropods, and molluscs, while the deuterostomes include echinoderms and chordates (including vertebrates). Life forms that are interpreted as ancient animals are classified within the Ediacaran biota that lived in the late Precambrian eon. Modern animal phyla formed clearly in the fossil record as marine species during the Cambrian explosion about 542 million years ago. 6,331 gene groups have been identified that belong to all living animals; these genes probably arose from a single ancestor that lived 650 million years ago. Aristotle divided animals into those that have blood and those that don't. Carolus Linnaeus created the first hierarchical biological classification for animals in 1758 in his book, Systema Naturae, which Jean-Baptiste Lamarck expanded into 14 phyla in 1809. In the late 1800s, Ernst Haeckel divided the animal kingdom into the multicellular Metazoa (now a synonym for from Animalia) and Protozoa, single-celled organisms that are no longer considered animals.

In modern times, animal classification relies on sophisticated techniques, such as molecular phylogenetics, which are effective in demonstrating evolutionary relationships among animal taxa. Humans use many other animal species for food, such as meat, milk, and eggs; for materials, such as leather and wool; as pets; and as working animals to be utilized for energy and used as a means of transportation. Dogs are used in hunting, while many land and water animals are hunted as sport. Animals have appeared in art since the earliest times and are a part of mythology and religion. The word "animal" is a loan from Arabic, حيوان (animal) which means animal. The word "animal" is a loan from Sanskrit which means "creature". While "animal" is an original Malay word. citation needed] In English, "animal" is called animal, from the Latin word "animalis", which means "has breath". In everyday non-formal usage, the word usually refers to non-human animals. Occasionally, close human relatives such as mammals and other vertebrates are designated in informal use. The biological definition of the word refers to all members of the kingdom Animalia, including creatures as diverse as sponges, jellyfish, insects and humans. Animals have several characteristics that set them apart from other living things. Animals are eukaryotic (have a nuclear membrane) and multicellular, unlike bacteria which are prokaryotic and unlike protists which are eukaryotic but unicellular. Unlike plants and algae which produce their own nutrients, animals are heterotrophs, meaning they eat organic matter and digest it internally. With very few exceptions, animals breathe oxygen and respire aerobically. All animals are motile (able to spontaneously move their bodies) during at least part of their life cycle, but some, such as sponges, coral, clams, and barnacles, become sessile later.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Education is the learning of the knowledge, skills and habits of a group of people passed down from one generation to the next through teaching, training or research. Education often takes place under the guidance of others, but is also possible on a self-taught basis. The etymology of the word education itself comes from the Latin word ducare, meaning "to guide, direct, or lead" and the prefix e, meaning "to go out". So, education means the activity of "leading out". Any experience that has a formative effect on the way people think, feel, or act can be considered educational. Education is generally divided into stages such as preschool, elementary school, junior high school, high school, and then college, university or apprenticeship. A right to education has been recognized by several governments. At the global level, Article 13 of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights recognizes the right of everyone to education. Although education is compulsory in most places up to a certain age, attending school is often not practiced, and a minority of parents opt for home-schooling, e-learning or similar education for their children. Education usually begins when a baby is born and lasts a lifetime. Education could have started before the baby was born as many people do by playing music and reading to babies in the womb with the hope that he can teach their babies before birth. For some people, the experiences of everyday life mean more than formal education. As Mark Twain said, "I never let school interfere with my education." Family members have a very deep teaching role, often deeper than they realize, even though the teaching of family members takes place informally.

According to Horton and Hunt, educational institutions are related to the following real (manifest) functions: Other functions of educational institutions are as follows. According to David Popenoe, there are four kinds of educational functions, namely as follows: It has been argued that a high level of education is very important for countries to be able to achieve high levels of economic growth. Empirical analysis tends to support the theoretical prediction that poor countries should grow faster than rich countries because they can adopt technologies that are already tried and tested by rich countries. However, technology transfer requires knowledgeable managers and engineers who are able to operate new machines or production practices borrowed from leaders in order to close the gap through imitation. Therefore, a country's ability to learn from leaders is a function of "human capital" effects. Recent studies of the determinants of aggregate economic growth have emphasized the importance of fundamental economic institutions and the role of cognitive skills. At the individual level, there is a large body of literature, largely related to the work of Jacob Mincer, on how profit relates to education and other human capital. This work has motivated a large number of studies, but it is also controversial. The main controversy revolves around how to interpret the impact of schools. Some students who have demonstrated a high potential for learning, by testing with a high intelligence quotient, may not reach their full academic potential, due to financial difficulties. reason-actually some students at the low end get better treatment than those in the middle with grants , etc. needs RS] Economists Samuel Bowles and Herbert Gintis argued in 1976 that there is a fundamental conflict in American education between the egalitarian goals of democratic participation and the inequalities implied by the continuing profitability of capitalist production on the other.

Ssireum is a traditional form of wrestling from Korea. Ssireum is the oldest sport in Korea which has been practiced since prehistoric times. In the past, Korean people protected themselves from enemy threats by developing martial arts. Ssireum started with gripping movements with hands and gradually new movements began to be created. During the Three Kingdoms period, ssireum was played for competition and military purposes. The ssireum paintings depicted on the Goguryeo Burial Site (37 BC-660 AD) are called Gakjeochong (角抵塚). The earliest written evidence mentioning information about ssireum is the Chinese text of the Book of Hou Han which records the lives of Korean people in the past. The sport of ssireum spread rapidly during the Joseon Dynasty (1394-1910). At that time, ssireum competitions were held with great fanfare on holidays and major festivals in the summer and autumn. The winners usually get prizes such as cows or agricultural products. Based on historical records and texts, in the past ssireum was called by many terms such as Gakjeo, Gakhui, Gakryeok, Gakgi, Chihui, Sangbak and Jaenggyo which describe the various developments of ssireum techniques. The word "gak" (角) comes from a Chinese character which means a fight between two animals such as a cow to show physical strength. The ancient Chinese also called Korean grappling techniques Goguryeo-gi (高句麗技). The term "ssireum" began to be widely used since the 1920s. The ssireum competition is contested in a circle with a diameter of about 7 meters which is bounded by a mound of sand. First, two wrestlers grip the waist belt (satba) of their opponent in a kneeling position, this position is called (baro japki). After the signal was given, 2 contestants started to get up and tried to knock each other down. The winner will be determined if he succeeds in dropping the opponent to the ground if the knee or body part that is higher above the knee is hit.

Zimbabwe (/zɪmˈbɑːbweɪ, -wi/), officially the Republic of Zimbabwe, is a landlocked country located in Southeast Africa, between the Zambezi and Limpopo Rivers. The country is bordered by South Africa to the south, Botswana to the southwest, Zambia to the south north, and Mozambique to the east. Its capital and largest city is Harare. Zimbabwe has a population of around 15 million people, who speak 16 official languages, with English, Shona and Ndebele being the most common. The country was once called by Samora Machel the "Jewel of Africa" ​​because of its great prosperity during Robert Mugabe's early years. Beginning in the 9th century, during the late Iron Age, the Bantu people (who would later become the Shona ethnicity) founded the city-state of Greater Zimbabwe. This city-state became one of Africa's major trading centers in the 11th century, controlling the gold, ivory, and copper trade with the Swahili coast, which was linked to the Arab and Indian states. By the mid-15th century, the city-state had been abandoned. From there, the Kingdom of Zimbabwe was founded, followed by the kingdoms of Rozvi and Mutapa. The British South African alliance, Cecil Rhodes, demarcated the territory of Rhodesia in 1890 when they conquered Mashonaland and then in 1893 Matabeleland after fierce resistance by the Matabele people in what became known as the First Matabele War. Alliance rule ended in 1923 with the establishment of Southern Rhodesia as a self-governing British colony. In 1965, the white separatist minority government unilaterally declared independence as Rhodesia. The country endured international isolation and a 15-year guerrilla war with black nationalist forces; this culminated in a peace agreement establishing universal suffrage and de jure sovereignty as Zimbabwe in April 1980. himself in December 2003.

Mugabe became Prime Minister of Zimbabwe in 1980, when his party ZANU–PF won general elections following the end of white minority rule. Later he was President of Zimbabwe from 1987 until his resignation in 2017. Under Mugabe's authoritarian regime, the state security apparatus dominated the country and was responsible for widespread human rights violations. From 2000 to 2009 the economy experienced decline and hyperinflation before recovering once the use of currencies other than the Zimbabwean dollar was permitted, though growth has since faltered. On 15 November 2017, after more than a year of protests against his government as well as Zimbabwe's rapidly declining economy, Mugabe was placed under house arrest by the country's national army in a coup, and Mugabe resigned six days later. Emmerson Mnangagwa has since served as president of Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe is a member of the United Nations, the Southern African Development Community, the African Union and the Common Market for East and Southern Africa. There are two theories about the origin of the word "Zimbabwe": Various sources suggest that the word comes from "mabwe dzimba--dza", translated from the Karanga Shona dialect as "large house of stones" (dzimba = plural of imba, "house"; mabwe = plural of BWE, "stones"). Archaeologist Peter Garlake claims that "Zimbabwe" is a contracted form of dzimba-hwe which means "respected house" in the Zezuru dialect of Shona, and is usually applied to the chief's house. Archaeological records mention human settlement in Zimbabwe dating back at least 500,000 years. The earliest known inhabitants were probably the San people, who left behind arrows and cave paintings. The first Bantu speaking farmers arrived during the Bantu migration some 2,000 years ago. Peoples who spoke the proto-Shona language first appeared in the central Limpopo River basin in the 9th century before moving to the highlands of Zimbabwe.

Sumatra (non-standard form: Sumatra) is the sixth largest island in the world located in Indonesia, with an area of ​​473,481 km². The population of the island is approximately 57,940,351 (2018 census). This island is also known by other names, namely Percha Island, Andalas, or Suwarnadwipa (Sanskrit, meaning "golden island").
