Then on the Padang Roco Inscription in 1286, swarnnabhūmi (Sanskrit, meaning "golden land") and bhūmi mālayu ("Malay Land") were carved to refer to this island. Furthermore, in the Negarakertagama manuscript from the 14th century it also mentions "Bumi Malayu" (Malay) for this island. The origin of the name Sumatra originates from the existence of the Samudra Kingdom (located on the east coast of Aceh). Beginning with the visit of Ibn Battuta, a Moroccan adventurer to the country in 1345, he pronounced the word Samudra to become Shumathra, and then became Sumatra, then this name was listed on Portuguese 16th century maps, to be referred to this island, so later known widely until now. The original name of Sumatra, as recorded in historical sources and folklore, is "Golden Island". We find the term Pulau Ameh (Minangkabau language, meaning island of gold) in the story of Cindua Mato from Minangkabau. In Lampung folklore, the name Tanoh Mas is written to refer to the island of Sumatra. A traveler from China named I-tsing (634-713) who lived in Sriwijaya (now Palembang) for many years in the 7th century, called Sumatra by the name chin-chou which means "land of gold". In various inscriptions, Sumatra is referred to in Sanskrit by the terms: Suwarnadwipa ("golden island") or Suwarnabhumi ("golden land"). These names have been used in Indian texts before Christ. One of the oldest Buddhist texts, the Jataka Book, tells of Indian sailors crossing the Bay of Bengal to Suwarnabhumi. In the Ramayana story, it is told that the search for Dewi Sinta, Rama's wife who was kidnapped by Rahwana, reaches Suwarnadwipa.

Arab travelers call Sumatra by the name "Serendib" (precisely: "Suwarandib"), a transliteration of the name Suwarnadwipa. Abu Raihan Al-Biruni, a Persian geographer who visited Sriwijaya in 1030, said that the country of Srivijaya was located on the island of Suwarandib. But there are also people who identify Serendib with Sri Lanka, who are never called Suwarnadwipa. Among the ancient Greeks, Sumatra was known as Taprobana. The name Taprobana Insula was used by Klaudios Ptolemaios, a Greek geographer of the second century AD, in 165 to be precise, when he described the Southeast Asian region in his Geographical Hyphegesis. Ptolemaios wrote that on the island of Taprobana there is the country of Barousai. It is very likely that the country in question is Barus on the west coast of Sumatra, which has been known since ancient times as a producer of camphor. The 70s Greek text, Periplous tes Erythras Thalasses, reveals that Taprobana was also called chryse nesos, which means 'island of gold'. Since ancient times traders from areas around the Mediterranean Sea have visited the archipelago, especially Sumatra. Besides looking for gold, they were looking for frankincense (Styrax sumatrana) and camphor (Dryobalanops aromatica), which at that time only existed in Sumatra. On the other hand, traders from the Archipelago also sold their commodities to West Asia and East Africa, as stated in the manuscript of Plini's Historia Naturalis in the first century AD. In the Jewish book, Melakim (Kings), chapter 9, it is explained that Prophet Sulaiman a.s. the king of Israel received 420 talents of gold from Hiram, king of Tire who was under him. The gold was obtained from the land of Ophir. The book of the Qur'an, Surat Al-Anbiya '81, explains that the ships of Prophet Sulaiman sailed to "the land that We blessed him" (al-ardha l-lati barak-Na fiha). Many historians argue that Ophir's country was located in Sumatra (Mount Ophir in West Pasaman, West Sumatra, which is now called Mount Talamau?).

Masculinity (also known as masculinity) is a set of attributes, behaviors and roles associated with boys and men. Masculinity is socially defined and biologically created. Masculine traits are different from gender. both men and women can be masculine. The characteristics attached to the masculine term are courage, independence and firmness. these characteristics vary and are influenced by social and cultural factors. Masculine characteristics are usually found in boys and men. In men, comparisons are often made regarding men who are very masculine, masculine or not masculine. The concept of masculinity is quite varied. Depends on history and culture. In the 19th century, a person who liked to dress up both men and women was seen as feminine but by modern standards was called feminine. Ronald F. Levant in his book Masculinity Reconstructed explains that there are distinctive traits in someone who is considered masculine, including avoiding femininity, limiting emotions, ambitious, independent, strong and aggressive. These traits reinforce gender roles that are grouped according to male or female sex because most men are masculine. On the other hand, most women are feminine. The study of masculinity received increased attention in the late 1980s and early 1990s. In the United States, masculinity courses increased from 30 to more than 300 courses. This has sparked various studies on masculinity and in the end this field has developed more broadly. The birth of theories of social discrimination, social construction and gender differences is a development of this field of study. However, it should be noted that masculinity and femininity are not concepts with a single category dimension. There are different forms of masculinity and femininity. This means that the concept varies between societies, social classes, and levels of civilization. In other words, masculinity and femininity are social constructions that can be given different meanings by each society.

By realizing masculinity as a multi-dimensional concept, space is opened for us to deconstruct and reconstruct this concept. Boys and girls can show masculine traits and behavior. People who mix masculine and feminine characteristics in themselves are considered androgynous. In the past, gender classification was generally only masculine and feminine. However, with the emergence of androgyny studies, feminist experts argue that the definition of gender has obscured gender classification. In some cultures, displaying characteristics that do not match the sex one has is a social problem. In sociology, this labeling is known as gender assumption. Behavior outside the standards set by tradition in certain cultures can be considered as an indication of homosexuality for men and lesbian for women. Because it is necessary socialization and genetic efforts in the development of masculinity. Psychologists and psychoanalysts such as Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung believed that "feminine" and "masculine" aspects of identity are actually present in all men. The history of the development of these gender roles is often a problem dealt with by geneticists, evolutionary psychologists, human ecologists, anthropologists and sociologists. In every human culture, gender roles are heavily featured in literature, clothing and singing. Such as in the literary Epic of Homer, the stories of Hengist and Horsa and the normative commentaries of Confucius. Other treatises of masculinity can be found in the Bhagavad Gita and bushidō from Hagakure. One way to address men's issues in a patriarchal society is to dissect or deconstruct and reconstruct the concept of masculinity, and relate this new social construction to more comprehensive social change, namely the process of institutionalizing egalitarian social relations. Masculinity is a stereotype about men that can be contrasted with femininity as a stereotype of women.

Sharks or sharks are a group (superorder Selachimorpha) of fish with a complete cartilaginous frame and a slender body. They breathe using five gills (sometimes six or seven, depending on the species) on the sides of, or starting slightly behind, their head. Sharks have bodies covered with dermal denticles to protect their skin from damage, from parasites, and to enhance water dynamics. They have several rows of replaceable teeth. Sharks include species that are the size of a palm. The pygmy shark, Euprotomicrus bispinatus, a species from the deep sea which is only 22 cm long, to the whale shark, Rhincodon typus, the largest fish which can grow to around 12 meters and which, like whales, feeds solely on plankton through a filter in its mouth. The bull shark, Carcharhinus leucas, is the best known of several species that swim in both salt and fresh water (it is found in Lake Nicaragua, in Central America) and in deltas. The shark skeleton is very different from that of bony fish such as cod, in that it is made of young bone (cartilage), which is very light and flexible, although the young bones in older sharks can sometimes partially calcify, resulting in making it harder and more bone-like. Shark jaws are diverse and are thought to have evolved from the first gill cavities. These jaws are not attached to the cranium and have additional mineral deposits that give them greater strength. Sharks are generally slow to reach sexual maturity and produce very few offspring compared to other fish harvested. This has caused concern among biologists because of the increased effort put into catching sharks over the years, and many species are now considered to be endangered.

The environment is a combination of physical conditions which include the condition of natural resources such as land, water, solar energy, minerals, as well as flora and fauna that grow on land and in the oceans, with institutions which include human creations such as decisions about how to use the physical environment. The environment can also be interpreted as everything that is around humans and influences the development of human life. Environment consists of biotic and abiotic components. Abiotic components are everything that is inanimate, such as land, air, water, climate, humidity, light, sound. While the biotic components are all living things such as plants, animals, humans and micro-organisms (viruses and bacteria). The science that studies the environment is ecology. Environmental science is a branch of biology. Environment, in Indonesia is often also called "environment". For example, in Law no. 23 of 1997 concerning Environmental Management, the definition of the Environment is the unity of space with all objects, power, circumstances, and living things, including humans, and their behavior, which affect the continuity of life and welfare of humans and other living things. The definition of the environment can be said as everything that exists around humans or living things that have reciprocal and complex relationships and influence each other between one component and another. In an environment there are two important components of its formation so as to create an ecosystem namely biotic components and abiotic components. The biotic component of the environment includes all living things in it, namely animals, humans, plants, fungi and other living things. while the abiotic components are inanimate objects that are useful for the survival of living things in an environment that includes soil, water, fire, rock, air, and so on.

23 of 2007, the more in-depth understanding of the environment is the unity of space with all objects or units of living things, including humans and all their behavior for the sake of sustaining life and welfare of humans and other living things around them. Damage to the environment occurs due to two factors, either natural factors or due to the ignorant hands of humans. The importance of a well-maintained environment is sometimes forgotten by humans, and this can result in ecosystems and life that are not optimal in that environment. The following are some of the in-depth factors that cause environmental damage: The number of natural disasters and erratic weather is the cause of environmental damage. These natural disasters can be in the form of floods, landslides, tsunamis, tornadoes, hurricanes, volcanic eruptions, or earthquakes. Besides being dangerous for the safety of humans and other creatures, this disaster will damage the environment. Humans as intelligent beings and have high abilities compared to other creatures will continue to develop from a simple lifestyle to a modern life. With the development of life, of course, their needs will also greatly develop, including the need for excessive exploitation of natural resources. Environmental damage due to the human factor can be in the form of illegal logging which causes floods or landslides, and dumping garbage anywhere, especially rivers and seas, will create pollution. Institutionally in Indonesia, the agency that regulates environmental issues is the Ministry of Environment and Forestry of the Republic of Indonesia (formerly: State Minister of Population and Environment) and in the regions or provinces it is Bapedal. While in the United States is the EPA (Environmental Protection Agency). In addition, on August 31 2013, the then president of the Republic of Indonesia, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono through Presidential Decree No. 62/2013 established the REDD+ Management Agency (Reducing Emissions and Deforestation and Forest Degradation).

Palembang (Jawi: ڤاليمبڠ) is the capital city of South Sumatra province which is also the center of government and economy of South Sumatra Province, Indonesia. This city with an area of ​​400.61 km² is inhabited by more than 1.6 million residents in 2021. Palembang is also the second most populous city and the second largest in Sumatra after Medan City, the fifth most populous city in Indonesia after Jakarta Raya, Surabaya, Bandung, Medan , and the nineteenth largest city in Southeast Asia. The city of Palembang and several of its neighboring regencies (Banyuasin Regency, Ogan Ilir Regency and Ogan Komering Ilir Regency) were developed by the central government as a metropolitan area in Indonesia with an area called the Great Statue or Great Palembang. The history of Palembang, which was once the capital of the largest Buddhist maritime empire in Southeast Asia at that time, the Sriwijaya Empire, which dominated the archipelago and the Malay Peninsula in the 9th century, also made this city known as the "Bumi Sriwijaya". Based on the Kedukan Bukit inscription found on Siguntang Hill to the west of Palembang City which states the formation of a wanua which is interpreted as a city on June 16, 683 AD, making Palembang the oldest city in Indonesia. In the Western world, the city of Palembang is also nicknamed the Venice of the East ("Venice of the East"). The origin of the name Palembang has several versions. One version is that when the Sriwijaya rulers founded a Wanua (city) which is now known as Palembang City; The topography of Palembang city is surrounded by water and even submerged by water. The water comes from tributaries and swamps, even according to statistical data for 1990, Palembang still has 50% of the land that is inundated by water (swamps). It is possible that because of this topographical condition, the ancestors of the Palembang people named this city as Palembang, which means Pa or Pe as a place or situation, and Lembang or Lembeng means low ground, root valleys that swell because they have been submerged in water for a long time (according to the Malay dictionary), while according to the Palembang Malay language, a lembang or lembeng is a pool of water.

So Palembang is a place that is inundated by water. One other version also associates Palembang with the Javanese word "limbang", which means cleaning ore or metal from the ground or other external objects. Separation is carried out with the help of a tool in the form of a small basket to sift metal-containing soil or seeds in the river. "Pa" is a preposition used by the Javanese to refer to a place where a business or situation takes place. This version is closely related to the role of Palembang in the past as a place to wash gold and tin ore. Another version connects Palembang with the word "lemba", which means land washed away by water. This city was considered as one of the centers of the Sriwijaya Datuan, the Attack of Rajendra Chola from the Chola Kingdom in 1025, causing this city to only become a simple port which was meaningless for foreign traders. Furthermore, based on Chinese chronicles the name Pa-lin-fong contained in the Chu-fan-chi book written in 1178 by Chou-Ju-Kua was referred to Palembang. Based on the story of the Song of Pamacangah and the Babad Arya Tabanan, it is mentioned that a character from Kediri named Arya Damar as the regent of Palembang participated in the conquest of Bali together with Gajah Mada Mahapatih Majapahit in 1343. In the early 15th century, the city of Palembang was occupied by the pirate Chen Zuyi who came from China. Chen Zuyi's pirate fleet was then crushed by Admiral Cheng Ho in 1407. Then around 1513, Tomé Pires, a Portuguese pharmacist said Palembang, had been led by a governor appointed from Java who was then referred to the sultanate of Demak and participated in attacking Malacca which at that time it had been occupied by the Portuguese. Palembang emerged as a sultanate in 1659 with Sri Susuhunan Abdurrahman as its first king.

Multiculturalism or cultural pluralism (derived from the words "multi" and "cultural"; which means "multiple cultures") is an ideology that recognizes and glorifies difference. The differences in question are individual differences with other individuals or differences in adopted values, such as differences in systems, culture, religion, habits, and politics. Multiculturalism is related to culture and the possibility of its concept being limited by value content or having certain interests. Multiculturalism contrasts with monoculturalism and assimilation which have been the norm in the nation-state paradigm since the early 19th century. Monoculturalism requires normative cultural unity (the term 'monocultural' can also be used to describe pre-existing homogeneity). Meanwhile, assimilation is the desire to unite between two or more different cultures by reducing differences. thus creating a new culture.Multiculturalism began to be made official policy in English-speaking countries, starting in Africa in 1999. This policy was later adopted by most members of the European Union, as official policy, and as social consensus among the elite.citation needed] In recent years, however, a number of European countries, notably the UK and France, have begun to shift their policies towards multiculturalism, a change in policy that has also become the subject of debate in the UK and Germany, among other countries. kind of meaning and to The trend towards the development of concepts and practices of multiculturalism expressed by experts has made a character named Parekh (1997:183-185) distinguish five kinds of multiculturalism (Azra, 2007, summarizing Parekh's description): Indonesian society is a society with a very complex level of diversity. Societies with various diversity are known as multicultural societies. If we know society as a group of people who have lived and worked together long enough so that they are able to organize themselves and think of themselves as a social unit with certain boundaries (Linton), then the concept of society when combined with multiculturalism has a very broad meaning. and a deep understanding is needed to be able to understand what a multicultural society really is.

Multiculturalism can be interpreted as diversity or differences between one culture and another. So that a multicultural society can be interpreted as a group of people who live and live permanently in a place that has its own culture and characteristics that are able to distinguish one society from another. Each society will produce its own culture which will become the hallmark of that society. This is where the term multiculturalism comes from. There are many definitions of multiculturalism, including multiculturalism which is basically a worldview which can then be translated into various cultural policies which emphasize acceptance of the reality of diversity, plurality and multiculturalism in people's lives. Multiculturalism can also be understood as a world view which is then embodied in the "politics of recognition" (Azyumardi Azra, 2007). Lawrence Blum revealed that multiculturalism includes an understanding, appreciation, and assessment of one's culture, as well as respect and curiosity about other people's ethnic cultures. The various understandings of multiculturalism can be concluded that the essence of multiculturalism is about acceptance and appreciation of a culture, both one's own culture. and other people's culture. Everyone is emphasized to respect each other and respect every culture that exists in society. Whatever form a culture has, it must be accepted by everyone without discriminating between one culture and another. Basically, multiculturalism that is formed in Indonesia is the result of socio-cultural and geographical conditions that are so diverse and broad. According to geographical conditions, Indonesia has many islands where each island is inhabited by a group of people who form a society. From this society a culture is formed about the community itself. Of course this has an impact on the existence of very many and varied cultures.

Qur'an surah al-Baqarah (2) verse 228 stipulates reference. Relative competency is based on the limits of authority to adjudicate based on regional jurisdiction. Elephants are large mammals from the Elephantidae family and the order Proboscidea. Traditionally, two species are recognized, namely the African elephant (Loxodonta africana) and the Asian elephant (Elephas maximus), although some evidence suggests that the African bush elephant and African forest elephant are separate species (L. africana and L. cyclotis). Elephants are distributed throughout sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, and Southeast Asia. Elephantidae is the only extant family of the order Proboscidea; other families now extinct include mammoths and mastodons. The male African elephant is the largest land animal with a height of up to 4 m and a mass that can also reach 7,000 kg. Elephants have special features, and the most striking is the trunk or proboscis which is used for many things, especially for breathing, sucking water, and picking up objects. The incisors grow into canines which can be used as weapons and tools for moving objects or digging. Their large ears help regulate their body temperature. African elephants have larger ears and a concave back, while Asian elephants have smaller ears and a convex back. Elephants are herbivorous animals that can be found in various habitats, such as savannas, forests, deserts and swamps. They tend to be near water. Elephants are considered a keystone species because of their impact on the environment. Other animals tend to keep their distance from elephants, and predators such as lions, tigers. hyenas, and wild dogs usually only attack young elephants. Female elephants tend to live in family groups, consisting of one female and her young or several related females and their young. The group is led by an individual elephant called a matriarch, who is usually the oldest female.

Elephants have a fission-fusion group structure, which is when family groups meet to socialize. Male elephants leave their family groups when they reach puberty and live alone or with other males. Adult males typically interact with family groups while looking for a mate and enter a stage of increased testosterone and aggression called musth, which helps them achieve dominance and reproductive success. The calf is the center of attention of the family group and is dependent on its mother for about three years. Elephants can live for 70 years in the wild. They communicate by touch, sight, smell, and sound; elephants also use infrasound and seismic communication over long distances. The intelligence of elephants has been compared to that of primates and cetaceans. They appear to be self-aware and show empathy for other elephants who are near or have died. The African elephant is classified as a vulnerable species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), while the Asian elephant is classified as a threatened species. One of the biggest threats to elephants is the ivory trade which fuels poaching. Another threat is habitat destruction and conflicts with local residents. On the other hand, elephants are used as working animals in Asia. Once they were used for war; today, elephants are often exhibited in zoos and circuses. Elephants are easily recognizable and have been depicted in art, folklore, religion, literature and popular culture. In Indonesian, Javanese, Sundanese, Minangkabau and Acehnese, this animal is called "elephant". The word itself comes from the Sanskrit word, "gaja", which is the root of the masculine noun. In the case of the nominativus (as a stand-alone subject), the singular "gaja" should be declined to become "gajas", but this word is then subject to the law of the s sound at the end of the word and changes to h, thus becoming "elephant".

Nestorianism is a doctrine (teaching) that teaches that Jesus existed as two persons, namely as the human Jesus and as the Son of God, or Logos, not as one single person. This doctrine is attributed to Nestorius (c. 386–c. 451), Patriarch of Constantinople. This view of Christ was condemned at the Council of Ephesus in 431, and conflict over this view resulted in the Nestorian Schism, which separated the Assyrian Church of the East from the Byzantine Church. The Assyrian Church of the East refused to withdraw support for Nestorius and refused to label him a heretic, so this Church was henceforth called the "Nestorian Church" by the Western Church, to distinguish it from other ancient Eastern Churches. Nevertheless, the Assyrian Eastern Church actually does not consider its Church doctrine to be Nestorian, but teaches the view of Babai Agung, that Christ has two qnomes (essences) that do not mix and are eternally united in one parsopa (personality). According to some interpretations, the origin of this belief is largely historical and linguistic: for example, the Greek has two words for 'person', which are not properly translated into Syriac, and the meanings of these terms are not even established at the time. life of Nestorius. Nestorianism emerged in the Church in the 5th century as a result of attempts to rationally explain and understand the incarnation of the Divine Logos, the Second Person of the Most Holy Trinity, as the man Jesus Christ. Nestorianism taught that the human essence and the divine essence of Christ were separate and therefore there were two persons, namely the human person Jesus Christ, and the divine Logos person, who dwelt in the man Jesus Christ. Consequently, the Nestorians rejected the existence of terms such as "God suffered" or "God was crucified", because the suffering humanity of Jesus Christ was separate from his divinity.

Likewise, they rejected the term Theotokos (Giving Begotten of God/Mother of God) as a title for Mary, instead they proposed the title Christotokos (Giving Birth of Christ/Mother of Christ), because in their view Mary only gave birth to the human person Jesus, not his divine person. Nestorius (c. 386–c. 451) was a pupil of Theodorus of Mopsuestia in Antioch, Syria (now in Turkey) and later became Patriarch of Constantinople. He taught that the human and divine aspects of Christ were distinct, not one, attributes. He preached against using the title Mother of God (Theotokos) for the Virgin Mary and calling her only the Mother of Christ (Kristotokos). He also argued that God could not suffer on the cross, because God is omnipotent. Therefore, the human part of Christ died on the cross, but not the divine part. His opponents accused him of dividing Christ into two persons: they argued that God the Word did not suffer suffering and died on the cross, while Jesus the man did, or claimed God the Word was omniscient, while Jesus the man had limited knowledge, means that there are two separate persons having separate experiences. In response, Nestorius said that he believed Christ was truly one person (Greek: prosopon). Opposed by Cyril of Alexandria, Nestorius was finally condemned at the Council of Ephesus in 431. The council taught that Christ is one person, and that the Virgin Mary is the Mother of God. The condemnation of the council resulted in the Nestorian Schism and the separation of the Assyrian Church of the East from the Byzantine Church. Archived 2008-07-04 at the Wayback Machine. However, not even the Council of Ephesus itself could determine the subject matter, so the Byzantine Church was soon once again divided over the question of whether Christ had one or two natures, resulting in the Chalcedonian Schism.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union  (light blue) The Republic of Chad (Arabic: تشاد , Tašād; French: TCad) is a landlocked country in Central Africa. Chad is bordered by Libya to the north, the Central African Republic to the south, Niger to the west, Sudan to the east and Nigeria and Cameroon to the southwest. Due to its distance and mostly desert climate, the country is referred to as the 'dead heart of Africa.' In the north, it includes the Tibesti Mountains, the largest mountain range in the Sahara desert. Chad is part of the former French Equatorial African Fellowship. As the largest former French colony, Chad is a poor country. More than 75% of the population lives below the poverty line. In the 2000s, the situation had relatively improved because the per capita income had exceeded US$1,000. The area now known as Cad was once inhabited by a group of politically unrelated tribes. Human skulls and cave paintings from ancient times have been found there. Gradually weak local kingdoms developed; then everything was overtaken by the even bigger and more powerful Kanem-Bornu Empire. Then, the arrival of foreigners came to give a lot of influence in Chad. In the early Middle Ages, Chad became a crossroads for Muslim traders and native tribes. In 1900, after the Battle of Kousséri, Cad became part of the French colonial system. In WWII, Chad was the first French colony to join the Free France and the Allies, under its governor Félix Éboué. In 1960, Cad became an independent country, with François Tombalbaye as its first president. Chad's post-independence history was marked by instability and violence from tensions between the mainly Arab Muslim north and the largely Christian and animist south.

In 1965, Muslim discontent with President Tombalbaye - a Christian from the south - led to a guerrilla war. This, coupled with a severe drought, undermined his rule and in 1975, President Tombalbaye was killed in a coup led by Noël Milarew Odingar, who was soon replaced by another southerner, general Félix Malloum. Malloum also failed to end the war, although he concurrently served as prime minister in 1978 from rebel leader Hissène Habré, head of the Northern Armed Forces (FAN), and in 1979 replaced by Libyan-backed northerner Goukouni Oueddei, as the country entered a period of civil war anarchy. Cad. At this level France and Libya intervened repeatedly to support one side over the other. Habre in 1982 conquered the capital ousted President Oueddei, and gained complete control of the country. His 8-year reign led to many political upheavals, leading various human rights organizations to accuse him of having ordered the death penalty for political opponents and members of tribes considered enemies of his regime. Libya attacked Chad in 1980, to keep Oueddei in office and continue the expansionist policy of uniting Libya and Chad politically. Previously, the Libyans had occupied a narrow strip of land in the area known as the Aouzou Strip in 1972-73. France and the US responded by assisting Habré to try to fuel Muammar al-Qaddafi's Libyan regional ambitions. The civil war is widespread. In December 1980 the Libyans occupied all of northern Chad, but Habré defeated the Libyan forces and expelled them in November 1981. In 1983, Gaddafi's forces conquered all of the country north of Koro Toro. The US used clandestine bases in Chad to train captured Libyan soldiers it was trying to organize into anti-Qaddafi forces.

Pancasila is the ideological pillar of the Indonesian state. The name is composed of two words from Sanskrit: पञ्च "pañca" means five and शीला "śīla" means principle or principle. Pancasila is the formulation and guidelines for the life of the nation and state for all Indonesian people. The five main ideologies that make up Pancasila are the five principles of Pancasila. The main ideology is stated in the fourth paragraph in the Preamble to the 1945 Constitution: Even though there were changes to the content and order of the five Pancasila precepts which took place in several stages during the formulation of Pancasila in 1945, June 1 is jointly commemorated as the birthday of Pancasila. On March 1, 1945, the Preparatory Committee for Indonesian Independence was formed, chaired by Dr. Kanjeng Raden Tumenggung (K.R.T.) Radjiman Wedyodiningrat. In his opening speech, Dr. Radjiman asked the members of the session what is the basis for the State of Indonesia that we are going to form. In an effort to formulate Pancasila as the official basis of the state, there were private proposals put forward by the Investigative Body for the Preparatory Work for Indonesian Independence. Mohammad Yamin formulated the Five Fundamentals during a speech on May 29, 1945. The formulations included: nationality, humanity, faith in God, democracy, and people's welfare. He said that the five precepts formulated were rooted in history, civilization, religion, and constitutional life that had long developed in Indonesia. However, Mohammad Hatta, in his memoirs, doubted Yamin's speech. Pancasila by Soekarno which was put forward on June 1, 1945 in his spontaneous speech which became known as the Birth of Pancasila. Sukarno put forward the basic ideas of his country, which he named "Pancasila". These ideas include: Indonesian nationality or nationalism, humanity or internationalism, consensus or democracy, social welfare, as well as cultural divinity. References are needed] The name "Pancasila" was uttered by Soekarno in his speech on June 1, he said: Now there are many principles: nationality, internationalism, consensus, welfare, and divinity, the five numbers.

Its name is not Panca Dharma, but I named it at the suggestion of a friend of ours who is a linguist – his name is Pancasila. Sila means principle or basis, and it is on these five principles that we establish the state of Indonesia, eternal and everlasting. Before the first session ended, a small committee was formed to reformulate Pancasila as the foundation of the State based on a speech uttered by Soekarno on June 1, 1945, and to make the document the text for proclaiming an independent Indonesia. From this small committee, nine people were chosen, known as the Committee of Nine, to carry out this task. Their plan was approved on June 22, 1945, which was later named the Jakarta Charter. After the formulation of Pancasila was officially accepted as the foundation of the state, several of the stipulation documents were: On June 1, 2016, President Joko Widodo signed Presidential Decree (Keppres) Number 24 of 2016 concerning the Birthday of Pancasila and at the same time designated it as a national holiday that took effect from 2017 .On September 30, 1965, an event called the September 30th Movement (G30S) occurred. This incident itself is still being debated in academic circles about who was the activist and what was the motive behind it. However, the military authorities and the largest religious group at the time spread the news that the incident was an attempt by the PKI to change Pancasila elements into communist ideology, to dissolve the Indonesian Communist Party, and justify the 1965–1966 Massacre in Indonesia. On that day, six generals and one captain and several others were killed by elements the government described as a coup attempt. The turmoil caused by the G30S itself was eventually suppressed by the Indonesian military authorities. The New Order government then designated 30 September as the Commemoration Day of the 30 September G30S Movement and 1 October as the Sanctity Day of Pancasila.

Mayotte (French: Mayotte, pronounced majɔt]; Shimaore: Maore, maore]; Kibushi: Mahori), officially the Region of Mayotte (French: Region de Mayotte), is a French Region consisting of the main island, Grande-Terre ( or Mahoré), one islet, Petite-Terre (or Pamanzi), and several smaller islands around the two islands. Mayotte is located at the northern end of the Mozambique Channel in the Indian Ocean, between northern Madagascar and northern Mozambique. The territory is geographically part of the Comoros Islands, but has been politically separated since the 1970s. The territory is also known as Mahoré, the original name of the main island, particularly by supporters of its creation within the Comoros Union. The main island, Grande-Terre (or Mahoré), is geographically the oldest of the Comoros Islands, 39 kilometers (24 mi) long and 22 kilometers (13½ mi) wide, and its highest point is Mount Benara (French: Mont Bénara; Shimaore: Mlima Bénara) at 660 meters (2,165 feet) above sea level. Because there are volcanoes, the soil is fertile in some areas. Coral reefs that surround most of the islands ensure boat protection and marine life. Dzaoudzi was the capital city of Mayotte until 1977. Dzaoudzi is located on Petite-Terre (or Pamanzi) which has an area of ​​10 square kilometers (3.9 square miles) and is the largest of several islets near Mahoré. Mayotte is a member of the Indian Ocean Commission, with a separate membership from the Comoros Islands. In 1500, the sultanate of Maore or Mawuti (based on جزيرة الموت in Arabic (meaning island of the dead) and changed to Mayotte in French) was founded on the island. In 1503, Mayotte was discovered by Portuguese explorers, but was not made a colony. In 1832, the island was ruled by Andriantsoly, former king of Iboina in Madagascar; in 1833 it was conquered by the neighboring sultanate of Mwali (Mohéli in French); on 19 November 1935 it was reconquered by the sultanate of Ndzuwani (Anjouan in French; the government was established in the form of a Qadi (from Arabic قاض meaning judge), a kind of 'Inhabitant Magistrate' in British designation), but in 1836 independence was achieved under the last local Sultan.

Mayotte along with the other Comoros Islands was purchased by France in 1843. When the Comoros Islands entered the 1974 and 1976 referendums for independence from France, Mayotte was the only constituency that rejected independence and voted to remain with France (63 each). .8% and 99.4%). Even so, the Comoros still claim Mayotte as part of their country. A 1976 draft United Nations Security Council resolution endorsed by 11 of the Council's 15 members recognized Comoros sovereignty over Mayotte, but France vetoed the resolution (until 2011, it was the only instance where France granted a single veto of a UN resolution). The General Assembly of the United Nations has passed various resolutions on this issue, which was based on the title: "The Mayotte Island Question in the Comoros" in 1995. Since 1995, Mayotte has not been discussed by the General Assembly. After 10 years as an overseas collectivity of France, Mayotte officially became an overseas department of France in March 2011 following the results of the March 29, 2009 referendum. In the resulting referendum, 95.5 percent of the electorate voted to change the island's status from an "overseas collectivity" to French 101st department. Unofficial traditional Islamic laws that applied to some aspects of everyday Mayotte society would be phased out and replaced by French laws that promised freedom of religion, outlawed polygamy, and equalized the rights of men and women. In addition to the French taxation system that will be implemented in Mayotte as a condition for becoming a department, Mayotte's social welfare will be gradually increased over 20 years to bring it on a par with the departments of Metropolitan France. Mayotte's politics prevail in the French overseas association of parliamentary representative democracy, in which the President of the General Council is the head of government, and in a multi-party system.

The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing (in Indonesian: National Association for Stock Car Racing) or commonly abbreviated by the acronym NASCAR is a family company that organizes various kinds of racing events. The company was founded by Bill France, Sr. in 1948. Today NASCAR is the largest promoter of auto racing in the United States. NASCAR's three biggest racing series are the Cup Series, the Xfinity Series, and the Truck Series. NASCAR approves more than 1,500 races on 100 tracks in 38 states in the United States. In addition NASCAR also operates its own series in Europe, Canada and Mexico. NASCAR also held several exhibition races in Suzuka, Japan, Motegi, Japan, and Calder Park Raceway, Australia. NASCAR's headquarters are in Daytona Beach, Florida including branch offices in three cities within the state of North Carolina: Charlotte, Concord, and Conover Regional offices are in New York City and Los Angeles. For offices outside America are located in Mexico City and Toronto. NASCAR is one of the most watched sports by television ratings in the United States. Outside America, NASCAR is broadcast in more than 150 countries around the world. In 2004, NASCAR's director of safety declared NASCAR to be 17th of the 20 regular weekly spectator sporting events each season. Fortune magazine stated that the flow of corporate sponsorship money flowing in NASCAR exceeded that of other racing events such as Formula One or MotoGP, although since the September 11, 2001 attacks which had a direct impact on the economy in the United States, several companies began to reduce their sponsorship activities in sporting events. Beginning in the 1920s and 1930s, Daytona Beach is widely known as one of the places to set speed records.

France and Belgium competed here and recorded eight speed records between 1927 and 1935. After being used as the location of the historic race between Ransom Olds and Alexander Winton in 1903. This beach was then used as the center of speed contests with 15 records successfully recorded at the same location. it became known as the Daytona Beach Highway Circuit between 1905 and 1935. It was also during this time that the Bonneville Salt Flats became the location for setting land speed records. In 1936 Daytona Beach became synonymous with fast cars. Racers raced the 6.6 km track, with the 2.4-3.2 km beach straight and another straight that is now known as the country road. These two straight tracks meet each other with a part of the sand that covers the bend where the two meet. Stock car racing in the United States has its roots in the prohibition of liquor in the early 1920s. The entrepreneurs and liquor manufacturers at that time were looking for ways to distribute their products, so in the end they took a creative but illegal step, namely smuggling the product into vehicles (in this case cars) that had been modified so that they were fast but stable so that they could pass through hillsides while at the same time avoiding police investigation/chase. Changes to the rules regarding the prohibition of the distribution of liquor in 1933 stopped this illegal distribution effort which at the same time made entrepreneurs and drivers who had already modified cars look for other ways so that what they had done to their cars would not end up in vain. In the end, in the early 1940s, car modifications continued and this time they made a sort of small racing event with cash prizes. This race successfully attracted the attention of spectators and became a new trend in the South of the United States with close association with the Wilkes County region in North Carolina.

in ASEAN (dark gray) – Legend] Malaysia (Japanese: мелисия) is a federal country consisting of thirteen states (states) and three federal territories in Southeast Asia with an area of ​​330,803 square km. Its capital is Kuala Lumpur, while Putrajaya is the center of the federal government. The total population of this country reached 32,730,000 people in 2020. The country is separated into two regions — Peninsular Malaysia and East Malaysia — by the Natuna Islands, an Indonesian territory in the Natuna Sea located to the south of the South China Sea. Malaysia borders Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, Brunei, and the Philippines. The country is located near the equator and has a tropical climate. The head of state of Malaysia is a King or a Sultan who is elected in turn every 5 years from among the kings of the states that are ruled. The King of Malaysia usually wears the title Sri Paduka Baginda Yang di-Pertuan Agong and his government is headed by a Prime Minister. The Malaysian government model is similar to the Westminster parliamentary system. Malaysia as a federal state did not exist until 1963. Before that, a group of colonies were established by Great Britain at the end of the 18th century, and the western part of modern Malaysia consists of several separate kingdoms. The group of colonial territories was known as British Malaya until its dissolution in 1946, when the group was reorganized as the Union of Malaya. Along with the growing resistance, the group was again reorganized as the Federation of Malaya in 1948 and then gained independence on August 31, 1957. On September 16, 1963, in accordance with UN General Assembly Resolution 1514, in the process of decolonization, Singapore, Sarawak, Borneo The North or what is now better known as Sabah changed into a state of the newly formed federation called Malaysia including the Federation of Malaya.

Singapore was then expelled from Malaysia on August 9, 1965 and became an independent country called the Republic of Singapore. During the early years of the formation of the new federation, there was also opposition from the Philippines and military conflict with Indonesia. The nations of Southeast Asia experienced an economic boom and underwent rapid development at the end of the 20th century. Rapid growth in the 1980s and 1990s, averaging 8% from 1991 to 1997, has turned Malaysia into a newly industrialized country. International trade plays an important role in its economy because Malaysia is one of the three countries that control the Malacca Strait. At one time, Malaysia was the world's largest producer of tin, rubber and palm oil. The manufacturing industry has a major influence on the economy of this country. Malaysia is also considered as one of the 18 most biodiverse countries in the world. Malays make up the largest part of the Malaysian population. There are also sizable ethnic ("race") Chinese Malaysians and Malaysian Indians. Malay and Islam are the official state languages ​​and religions respectively. Malaysia is a pioneer member of ASEAN and participates in various international organizations, such as the United Nations. As a former British colony, Malaysia is also a member of the Commonwealth of Nations. Malaysia is also a member of D-8 (Developing-8), which is an agreement for development cooperation among its eight member countries: Bangladesh, Indonesia, Iran, Malaysia, Egypt, Nigeria, Pakistan and Turkey. The name "Malaysia" was adopted in 1963 when the Federation of Malaya added Singapore, Sabah, and Sarawak to form the federation named Malaysia. However, the name itself was once confused when it was used to refer to areas in Southeast Asia. A map published in 1914 in Chicago displays the name Malaysia in certain areas of the archipelago.

see text Rubiaceae, The ranggitan-ranggitanan or Kopi-kopian tribe is a family of flowering plants. According to the APG II Classification System, this tribe belongs to the Gentianales order. This tribe consists of trees, shrubs, lianas, or herbs that grow on the ground. This includes a number of important plant alkaloids such as caffeine (in coffee it is produced from several types of Coffea) and quinine (from the bark of Cinchona stems). Other important members are gambier (Uncaria; aromatic plants), soka (Ixora; ornamental plants), (Gempol;) and noni (Morinda; medicinal plants). The APG II system incorporates several minor families (such as Dialypetalanthaceae, Henriqueziaceae, Naucleaceae, and Theligonaceae) into Rubiaceae, making it the fourth largest family of flowering plants with members of about 650 genera and more than 13,000 species. The Rubiaceae has a cosmopolitan distribution, however, the greatest species diversity is concentrated in (sub)tropical regions. Rubiaceae are morphologically easy to recognize as groups that are close to each other with a combination of characters: all leaves grow opposite and are simple in shape, petals are radially symmetrical and become one (simpetal) forming a tube (tubular), and inferior ovary. The Rubiaceae grows in many forms, the most common being shrubs, which can be trees, lianas, or herbs. The Rubiaceae has a cosmopolitan distribution and is found in almost all regions of the world, except in extreme environments, such as polar regions and deserts. The distribution pattern of this tribe is very similar to the global distribution of plants. However, the greatest diversity is clearly concentrated in the humid tropics and subtropics. The exception is the Rubieae tribe, spread cosmopolitan, but concentrated in areas with moderate temperatures. The highest number of species is found in Colombia, Venezuela and New Guinea. When adjusted for area, Venezuela is the most diverse, followed by Colombia and Cuba.

Hinduism (in Indonesia it is called Hinduism) is the dominant belief in South Asia, especially in India and Nepal, which contains various traditions. This belief encompasses various traditions, among them Shaiva, Vaishnava, and Sakta, as well as a broad view of the laws and rules of "everyday morality" based on karma, dharma, and societal norms. Hinduism tends to be like a collection of various philosophical or intellectual views, rather than a standardized and uniform set of beliefs like the Abrahamic religions. Hinduism is claimed by some to be the "oldest religion" in the world which still exists today,a] and Hindus call their own religion Sanātana-dharma (Dewanagari: सनातन धर्म),b] meaning "eternal dharma" or "eternal path" that transcends human origins. This religion provides "eternal" obligations to be followed by all its followers—regardless of strata, caste, or sect—such as honesty, chastity, and self-control. Scholars from the West see Hinduism as a fusion or synthesis of various traditions and cultures in India, with diverse origins and no founding figures. Its roots include Brahmanism (ancient Vedic religion), the religions of the ancient Indus Valley civilization, and popular local traditions. The synthesis appeared around 500–200 BC, and coexisted with Buddhism until the 8th century. From North India, the "Hindu Synthesis" spread south, to parts of Southeast Asia. This is supported by Sanskritization. Since the 19th century, under the domination of Western colonialism and Indology (when the term "Hinduism" came into widespread use), Hinduism was reaffirmed as a place for a coherent and independent collection of various traditions. Popular understanding of Hinduism was stimulated by the "Hindu modernism" movement, which emphasized mysticism and the unity of Hindu traditions. Hindutva ideology and Hindu politics emerged in the 20th century as the political power and national identity of India.

Hindu religious practices include daily rites (eg prayer prayers and recitation of prayers), holy celebrations on certain days, and pilgrimages. The ascetics who are called sadu (holy people) choose to take more extreme actions than Hindus in general, namely breaking away from worldly activities and carrying out asceticism for the rest of their lives in order to achieve moksa. Hindu literature is classified into two groups: Sruti (what is "heard") and Smerti (what is "remembered"). The literature contains theology, philosophy, mythology, yadnya (sacrifice), ritual processions, and even the principles of Hindu architecture. The main scriptures include the Vedas, Upanishads (both belonging to the Sruti), Mahabharata, Ramayana, Bhagawadgita, Puranas, Manusmerti and Religion (all belonging to the Smerti). With around 1 billion adherents, Hinduism is the third largest religion in the world, after Christianity and Islam. In Arabic texts, al-Hind is the term used to refer to ethnic groups in an area now called India, while 'Hindu' or 'Hindoo' was used from the late 18th century onwards by the British to refer to the inhabitants of 'Hindustan' , that is, the nation southwest of India. Eventually, 'Hindu' became the equivalent term for 'Indians' who were not Muslim, Sikh, Jaina or Christian, thus encompassing a wide variety of adherents and practitioners of different traditional beliefs. The ending '-ism' was added to the word Hindu around the 1830s to refer to the culture and religion of the Brahmin caste which was different from other religions, and later the term was accepted by the Indians themselves in terms of building national identity to oppose colonialism, although the term '-ism' Hindu' was mentioned in Sanskrit and Bengali chronicles as an antonym for 'Yawana' or Muslim, around the beginning of the 16th century. —Gavin Flood, An Introduction to Hinduism.

The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite and is the fifth largest satellite in the Solar System. The Moon is also the largest natural satellite in the Solar System by size of the planet it orbits, e] with a diameter of 27%, a density of 60% and a mass of ​1⁄81 (1.23%) of Earth. Among other natural satellites, the Moon is the second densest after Io, a satellite of Jupiter. The Moon is in synchronous rotation with Earth, always showing the same side of Earth, with the near side marked by dark volcanic mare that occur between the bright crustal plateaus and prominent impact craters. The moon is the brightest celestial body after the sun. Although the Moon appears very white and bright, its surface is actually dark, with a brightness slightly higher than molten asphalt. Since ancient times, its prominent position in the sky and its regular phases have influenced many cultures, including language, calendar, art and mythology. The gravitational influence of the Moon causes the tides in the oceans and the lengthening of the Earth's day. The Moon's current orbital distance from Earth is about thirty times Earth's diameter, which causes the Moon to appear in the sky almost as large as the Sun, allowing the Moon to cover the Sun and result in a total solar eclipse. The Moon's linear distance from Earth is currently increasing at a rate of 3.82±0.07 cm per year, although this rate is not constant. The Moon is thought to have formed about 4.5 billion years ago, shortly after the formation of Earth. Although there are a number of hypotheses about the origin of the Moon, the most accepted hypothesis today is that it formed from the debris that was lost after a celestial body the size of Mars collided with Earth.

The moon is the only celestial body besides Earth that has been landed by humans. The Soviet Union's Luna program was the first probe to reach the Moon by unmanned spacecraft in 1959; The United States NASA's Apollo program is the only manned space mission to have reached the Moon to date, beginning with the Apollo 8 manned lunar orbiting mission in 1968, and was followed by six manned landing missions between 1969 and 1972, the first was Apollo 11. This mission returned to Earth with 380 kg of Moon rock, which was used to develop a geological understanding of the origin, formation of internal structures, and the geological history of the Moon. After the Apollo 17 mission in 1972, the Moon was visited only by unmanned spacecraft. These missions are generally orbital missions; since 2004, Japan, China, India, the United States, and the European Space Agency have launched Moon orbiters, which have contributed to the discovery of water ice in the Moon's polar craters. Post-Apollo, two countries have also sent rover missions to the Moon, namely the last Soviet Lunokhod mission in 1973, and the ongoing Chang'e 3 PRC mission, which launched the Yutu rover on December 14, 2013. Future manned missions to the Moon are planned by various countries, whether funded by the government or private. Under the Outer Space Treaty, the Moon remains free for exploration by all nations for peaceful purposes. In English, the name for Earth's natural satellite is moon. The noun moon comes from moone (c. 1380), which also develops from mone (1135), from Old English mōna (before 725).

Gibraltar (/dʒɪˈbrɒltər/) is a British overseas territory located on the southern tip of the Iberian Peninsula at the entrance to the Mediterranean Sea. Gibraltar has an area of ​​68 square kilometers (26 sq mi) and is bordered by Andalusia, Spain to the north. The Rock of Gibraltar is the area's most interesting landmark. At its foot is a densely populated residential area inhabited by nearly 30,000 Gibraltarians and other nationalities. Anglo-Dutch troops invade Gibraltar in 1704 during the War of the Spanish Succession. The city, along with its castle, harbor and defenses, ceded to Britain "indefinitely" under the Treaty of Utrecht in 1713. Gibraltar was a major base for the Royal Navy; currently its economy is heavily dependent on tourism, financial services, and shipping. Sovereignty of Gibraltar is a key issue in Anglo-Spanish relations as Spain asserts its claim to the territory. Gibraltarians rejected the proposed Spanish sovereignty in the 1967 and 2002 referendums. Under the 2006 Gibraltar constitution, Gibraltar administered the territory independently, although matters such as defense and foreign relations were still the responsibility of the British government. The name Gibraltar is a Spanish word derived from the Arabic name Jabal-ı Tārıq (جبل طارق), meaning "Tariq mountains." The name refers to the geological formation of the Rock of Gibraltar which was named after the Umayyad Berber general, Tariq ibn-Ziyad, who led the first invasion of Iberia ahead of the main Moorish army in 711 under the Umayyad Caliph Al-Walid I. Previously, the mountains were named Mons Calpe, one of the Pillars of Hercules. Evidence of Neanderthal settlement of Gibraltar between 128,000 and 24,000 BC has been found in Gorham's Cave, making Gibraltar the last settlement of Neanderthals. In written history, the first inhabitants of Gibraltar were the Phoenicians, around 950 BC.

Later, Gibraltar became known as the Pillars of Hercules after the Greek legend of Heracles' creation of the Strait of Gibraltar. The Carthaginians and Romans also established semi-permanent settlements. After the fall of the Roman Empire, Gibraltar came under the control of the Vandals. This area later became part of the Visigothic Kingdom of Hispania until the Muslim conquest of Iberia in AD 711. In 1160, the Almohad Sultan Abd al-Mu'min ordered that a permanent settlement, including a castle, be built in Gibraltar. The settlement was named Medinat al-Fath (City of Victory). When the construction of the city was complete, the Sultan crossed the Channel to monitor construction and stayed in Gibraltar for two months. The Tower of Homage at Moorish Castle still stands today. From 1274 onward, the city was contested by the Nasrids of Granada, the Marinids of Morocco, and the Catholic kings of Castile. In 1462, Gibraltar was conquered by Juan Alonso de Guzmán, 1st Duke of Medina Sidonia. Following the conquest, King Henry IV of Castile assumed the title King of Gibraltar, and made the area part of the comarca Campo Llano de Gibraltar. Six years later, Gibraltar was returned to the Duke of Medina Sidonia, who sold it in 1474 to a group of Jewish conversos from Cordova and Seville in exchange for managing the city's defenses for two years. After that, 4,350 Jews were expelled by the Duke as part of the Inquisition. In 1501, Gibraltar ceded to the Kingdom of Spain, and Isabella I of Castile issued a Royal Decree giving Gibraltar the coat of arms which is still used today. In 1704, during the War of the Spanish Succession, a combined Anglo-Dutch force captured the city of Gibraltar and prompted a permanent exodus of its inhabitants to the surrounding areas of the Campo de Gibraltar. Under the 1713 Treaty of Utrecht, Gibraltar ceded indefinitely to the United Kingdom.

Albigensis (Per. )Hussite (Boh. )Lollard (Ing. )Waldensis (Per./Ita./Jer.) Anabaptist Anglicanism (English)Calvinism (Switzerland)Lutheranism (Jer. )Reformed Socinianism (Pol. )Zwinglianism (Swiss. ) Amish (Ame. )Baptist (Ing. )Congregational Mennonite (Bel./Swi./Ame./Kan. )Methodism (Ing. )Pietism Presbyterianism (Scot./Ame. )Puritanism (Ing. )Evangelical Universalism Pentecostal Revivalism Movement Protestant Adventist Restoration (in Indonesia known as Protestantism) is a denomination in Islam that worships God which refers to the Protestant reform movement by Martin Luther in 1517 with 95 of his postulates. Protestant etymology itself comes from Latin, namely: "Pro Testanum", (English: "Pro Testament"). "Pro" means: to take sides, vote for or against. While "Testanum" means: Covenant. These are 2 words that refer to the Old Testament and the New Testament in the Bible. This word is defined as a Christian Reformed/Christian/follower of Christ/Jesus movement that begins a return based on the faith and practice of Christianity based on the beginnings of the Bible, originating from the encouragement of the Protestant Reformation in doctrinal, political and ecclesiological terms, against what are perceived as abuses of the Church Roman Catholics at the time. This is one of the three main affirmations of "Nicene Christianity", that is, alongside the Roman Catholic Church and the Orthodox Church. The term "Protestant" also refers to the "Protestant Reformation letter" submitted by dignitaries who supported Martin Luther's statement, against the Diet Speyer decision in 1529 which upheld the Diet of Worms decision (edict) which condemned Martin Luther's teachings as heretical (heretic). And the Pro-Testan Reformation movement carried out by Martin Luther is not the first time it has occurred in the Catholic Church, because previously there had been similar movements like what happened in :- France led by Peter Waldo (and now his followers are members of the Church Waldensis) in the mid-12th century;- Bohemia (now including Czech) under Jan Hus (1369-1415), followers of John Hus in Bohemia later joined the Calvinist Church. and- Countries with large numbers of immigrants from Italy, such as Uruguay.

In 2005, around 5.9%–14,276,459 people out of 241,973,879 people in Indonesia followed the teachings of Protestantism and the 2010 census was around 6.96% - 16,528,513 people. Because most missionaries to Indonesia came from the Netherlands and Germany, most Protestant Christian churches in Indonesia are heavily colored by Calvinist and Lutheran colors. Number of Protestant Christians Based on Population Census by province (June 2022): Although the doctrines of Protestant denominations are far from uniform, there are several beliefs that are spread in Protestantism, namely the doctrines of sola gratia, sola fide, and sola scriptura. Protestant churches generally reject Catholic and Orthodox doctrines regarding apostolic inheritance and sacramental ministry of the clergy. The exception is found in many countries, such as in southern Europe, which were under non-Catholic influence long before the Reformation. Protestant pastors and church leaders have slightly different roles and authority within their communities than Catholic, Anglican and Orthodox pastors and bishops. Followers of the Protestant movement refer to the grouping of churches according to their basic doctrines as "denominations". They are the names of the different parts of a single "Church". Protestants reject the doctrine of the Roman Catholic Church as the only true church. Some Christian denominations are more strict than others and there are conflicting grounds of orthodoxy between them. Individual denominations also emerge according to theological differences which are sometimes very subtle. There are also many denominations which are simply regional or ethnic expressions of the same belief, which recognize the five solas as the main basic principles of the Christian faith. Non-denominational groups are also included in the Protestant group. Due to all these factors, an exact count is not possible, but it is estimated that there are about 33,000 Protestant denominations.

Sabah (Jawi:سابه) is one of the 13 states in Malaysia. Sabah is the second largest state in Malaysia after Sarawak. Sabah is also bordered by Indonesia's North Kalimantan Province, to the south. The state capital is Kota Kinabalu. Sabah is often referred to as the "Country Beneath the Winds" (trans. land below the wind), a phrase used by sailors in the past to describe the lands south of the typhoon belt. The origin of the name Sabah is still unclear, and many theories have emerged. One theory is that during the time when Sabah was part of the Sultanate of Brunei, saba bananas (also known as banana decline) were found in the coastal areas of the region, which grew widely and were popular in Brunei. The Bajau people call it banana jaba. The name Saba also refers to a variety of bananas in Tagalog and Visaya. In addition, in the Visayan language the word also means "noisy". Maybe because of the dialect, the word Saba is spoken by local people in Sabah. When Brunei was one of Majapahit's vassal states, the Old Javanese manuscript Kakawin Nagarakretagama by Empu Prapañca called the region that is now Sabah as Seludang. Meanwhile, although China has been associated with Borneo Island since the time of the Han Dynasty, they do not have a specific name for the region. It was only during the Song dynasty that they called Borneo by the name Po Ni (also called Bo Ni), which was the same name that referred to the Sultanate of Brunei at that time. Due to the location of Sabah in relation to Brunei, it seems that Sabah is a word in Brunei Malay meaning upstream or "to the north". Due to the location of Sabah in relation to Brunei, "Sabah" is a word in Brunei Malay meaning upstream or "to the north".

Another theory states that the name comes from the Malay word sabak which means the place where palm sugar is extracted. Sabah is also an Arabic word which means sunrise. The multitude of theories makes it difficult to determine the true origin of the name Sabah. The earliest historical evidence showing human life in this area is the discovery of stone tools and food remains from excavations along the Darvel Bay area in the Madai-Baturong cave near the Tingkayu River which is estimated to date from 20,000-30,000 years ago. The first humans in the area are thought to resemble Aboriginal Australians, but the reasons for their disappearance are unknown. In 2003, archaeologists discovered the Mansuli Valley in the Lahad Datu district which shows the history of Sabah going back 235,000 years. The first migration of the Mongoloids to the south occurred around 5,000 years ago, as evidenced by the discovery of an archaeological site at Skull Hill, Semporna which is famous for being the largest pottery production site in Southeast Asia during the Neolithic era. Some anthropologists, such as S.G. Tan and Thomas R. Williams, believe that the Mongoloid race (now the Kadazan-Dusun, Murut, Sungai People, etc.) originates from South China and North Vietnam and is a close relative of a number of indigenous tribes in the Philippines and Formosa (Taiwan). , as well as Sarawak and other parts of Borneo. In the 7th century AD, a Srivijaya colony called Wijayapura is thought to have been in northwestern Borneo. Based on the Chinese language book Taiping Huanyu Ji, the first kingdom in the region was Po Ni which is thought to have existed in the early 9th century. It is believed that Po Ni is at the mouth of the Brunei River and is the forerunner of the Sultanate of Brunei. In the 14th century, it became a vassal state of Majapahit, but in 1370 its allegiance switched to the Ming dynasty of China.

Sport is a form of physical activity that is usually competitive with the aim of improving one's physical abilities and skills while providing entertainment for players or spectators. Sport is a physical activity that is intentional and planned starting from the direction, purpose, time and location. In social life, sport is a phenomenon as well as a form of human expression. Sports can be done individually or in groups. Another definition, sport is a competitive activity that involves physical and mental abilities, in which there must be rules in the game. So that in a sports competition there will be winners and losers. Sports that involve physical ability as a major controller in influencing the outcome of the game include football, basketball, badminton, and others. While sports that do not involve too much physical abilities, include card games and chess. The involvement of sports in human life occurred about 3000 years ago. At that time, sports were used to support training for soldiers in preparation for war. Some sports such as javelin throwing and discus throwing are adaptations of sports in ancient times. Over time, sports have developed and formed various types of sports. The Pharaoh Monument, located in Egypt, shows the development of the sport in running as represented by Zoser participating in a running race during the festival. The first sporting Olympics were held in 776 BC (BC) by the ancient Greeks. At that time, the Olympics could only be followed by Greek men, especially those who were free from slavery. In 1896, the first modern Olympics were held in Athens, Greece under the leadership of Pierre de Coubertin. The following is an incomplete list of sports that are still contested in the modern era. Sport is very beneficial for the health of the body.

Lutetium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Lu and atomic number 71. Lutetium is a white and silver mixed metal that is resistant to corrosion and is a rare earth product. Lutetium is the hardest and densest metal in the lanthanide group, which is located in the last column of the group on the periodic table. Lutetium was first discovered in 1907 by Baron Carl Auer von Welsbach, Georges Urbain, and Charles James while each of them was conducting research in different locations. They examined a mineral thought to consist purely of ytterbium, but in the end it was discovered that this mineral was also a combination of lutetium and several other chemical elements. Because Georges Urbain took the swift step to publicize his discovery, the naming of the chemical element lutetium was chosen and officially recognized globally. Lutetium has the atomic number 71 and the electron configuration Xe] 4f145d16s2. Lutetium is resistant to corrosion and is a mixture of white and silver in color. The atomic mass of lutetium is large compared to its size, so it has high boiling and melting points. Actually, the electrons of the element lutetium do not completely fill the d orbitals, but are still classified as lanthanides because they have physical and chemical characteristics that are very similar to the 14 other chemical elements of the lanthanide group. Lutetium has 59 isotopes, but only two are stable, namely Lu-175 and Lu-176. 97.41% of the total lutetium found on earth is Lu-175, while only 2.59% is Lu-176. Although less abundant and radioactive, elemental Lu-176 can last for 4x1010 years. In real life, lutetium can be obtained from minerals containing a mixture of lutetium and other lanthanide group chemical elements.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth science Mechanics (Latin mechanicus, from Greek mechanikos, "one who is skilled in the field of machinery") is a special kind of science that studies the function and operation of machines, tools or machine-like objects. Mechanics is a very important part of physics, especially for scientists and engineers. Mechanics also means the science that studies the force of motion of an object and the effects of the force it produces. Broadly speaking, the branch of mechanics is divided into two, namely statics and dynamics. While the dynamics can also be divided into two into kinematics and kinetics. Early thought about mechanics dates back to the time of Aristotle (384–322 BC). The earliest field of mechanics was celestial mechanics. Aristotle in his time considered the Earth as a stationary object with the stars that revolve around it experiencing movement or rotation. Aristotle's thought was further developed by an astronomer named Tycho Brahe in the 16th century AD and further developed by his student named Johannes Kepler in the early 17th century AD. The laws of mechanics were only scientifically formulated in the early 17th century AD by Isaac Newton from empirical evidence found by Brahe and Kepler. The basic concepts put forward by Newton were force and mass, which were later developed again into the theory of gravity. The science of mechanics then continued to be developed in the second half of the 17th century AD to the first half of the 19th century AD. Its developers include Johann Bernoulli, Jean le Rond d'Alembert, Joseph-Louis de Lagrange and William Rowan Hamilton. At this time, mechanics was known as classical mechanics, theoretical mechanics or analytic mechanics. From this classical mechanics, the science of mechanics which is more complicated and related to modern physics, namely wave mechanics, statistical mechanics, and quantum mechanics develops.

The development of mechanics then continued through the thoughts of Albert Einstein in the first half of the 20th century AD, Einstein's thoughts then developed relativistic mechanics using the special theory of relativity. Mechanics is included in the scientific field of physics, so the units used are related to physical mechanical quantities. In mechanics, the units used are length, mass, and time. The unit systems used in mechanics are the MKS unit system and the CGS unit system. The following are classified as classical mechanics: Fluid mechanics is a branch of mechanics that studies the motion of fluids. This movement is observed in both liquid and gaseous forms. Fluid mechanics also studies fluids that are not in a state of motion or rest. Much of what is discussed in fluid mechanics deals with continuum mechanics. Broadly speaking, fluid mechanics is divided into fluid statics, which studies fluids at rest, and fluid dynamics, which studies fluids in motion. Especially in fluid dynamics, mathematical approaches and complicated empirical evidence are used to solve problems. Soil mechanics is a field of science that combines several branches of mechanics with the aim of studying soil and its components to carry out construction activities. In practical applications, soil mechanics is used in civil engineering to predict soil performance characteristics. In its application, soil mechanics uses statics techniques, dynamics techniques, fluid mechanics, and other technologies to analyze soil structure. Major studies in soil mechanics include the study of soil composition, strength, consolidation, and the use of hydraulic principles. The benefit of soil mechanics is to reduce and overcome engineering geology problems caused by the presence and properties of sedimentary rocks and other depositional reactions. Meanwhile, engineers utilize the theory of soil mechanics for building construction engineering purposes, planning equipment and supporting materials and managing the type of work required.

Enzymes are biomolecules in the form of proteins that function as catalysts (compounds that speed up the reaction process without being finished reacting) in an organic chemical reaction. Enzymes function as biocatalysts of a chemical reaction. The energy required by enzymes in chemical reactions is very small so that it functions to lower the activation energy. The initial molecule called the substrate will be accelerated to change into another molecule called the product. All biological processes of the cell require enzymes in order to proceed quickly enough in a certain direction of metabolic pathway. Enzymes work by reacting with substrate molecules to produce intermediate compounds through an organic chemical reaction that requires a lower activation energy, so that the acceleration of chemical reactions occurs because chemical reactions with higher activation energies take longer. For example: Although the catalyst compound may change in the initial reaction, in the final reaction the catalyst molecule will return to its original shape. Most enzymes work uniquely, which means that each type of enzyme can only work on one type of chemical compound or reaction. This is due to differences in the chemical structure of each enzyme which is fixed. For example, the α-amylase enzyme can only be used in the process of breaking down starch into glucose. Enzyme work is influenced by several factors, especially the substrate, temperature, acidity, cofactors and inhibitors. Each enzyme requires a different optimum temperature and pH (acidity level) because enzymes are proteins, which can change shape if the temperature and acidity change. Outside the appropriate temperature or pH, enzymes cannot work optimally or their structure will be damaged. This will cause the enzyme to lose its function completely. Enzyme work is also influenced by other molecules. Inhibitors are molecules that decrease enzyme activity, while activators are those that increase enzyme activity.

Many drugs and poisons are enzyme inhibitors. At least in the late 17th and early 18th centuries, several processes involving enzymes were known, namely the digestion of meat by gastric secretions and the breakdown of starch into sugars by plant extracts and saliva. However, the mechanisms by which these processes occur have not been identified. French chemist Anselme Payen was the first scientist to discover an enzyme, namely diastase, in 1833. Decades later, Louis Pasteur, who was researching the fermentation of sugar into alcohol using yeast, wrote that this fermentation reaction was caused by a "vital force" contained in yeast cells, referred to as "ferment", according to which it only functions in the body of living organisms. He wrote that "alcoholic fermentation is an action related to the life and order of the yeast cells, and not to their death or decay." In 1878, the German physiologist Wilhelm Kühne (1837–1900) first used the term "enzyme", which comes from the Greek ενζυμον meaning "in leavening agent" or "in yeast", to describe this process. The word "enzyme" (enzyme) was later used to refer to inanimate substances such as pepsin, and the word ferment was used to refer to chemical activities produced by living organisms. In 1897, Eduard Buchner began his series of scientific papers on yeast extract. In experiments at the University of Berlin, he found that the fermentation of sugar by yeast extract continued even if there were no surviving yeast cells in the mixture. He named the enzyme that triggers this fermentation of sucrose "zymase" (zimase). In 1907, he received the Nobel Prize in chemistry for "discovering cellless fermentation".
