The nomenclature of enzymes up to now has followed Buchner's example, namely with the ending -ase and according to the reaction catalyzed by the enzyme.

Pretoria is the capital city of South Africa and also the seat of government of this country. It is located 50 km north of Johannesburg and is in the Transvaal region. In general, Pretoria is considered the capital of South Africa but it is actually the seat of government for the executive only. Cabinet offices of ministries and embassies of foreign countries that have representatives in South Africa are also based here. Its population is about 1.3 million people. Decades ago, the city was criticized for being the seat of an apartheid government. Today, the city of Pretoria is a multinational and cultural hub with several theaters and museums and is also a city of science and technology. There are four universities including the Council of Scientific and Industrial Inquiry (CSIR) and the Onderstepoort Veterinary Research Institute, two world-renowned universities. ZAR's first president, Marthinus Wessel Pretorius had named the city Pretoria in honor of his father, Commander General Andries Pretorius, officer of the Voortrekkers after his victory in the Battle of the Rivers of Blood against the Zulu empire. Because Commander General Pretorius is a symbol of oppression for black people, when they came to power in 1995, they gave Pretoria a new name, namely Tshwane. The capital - now known as Pretoria - was founded in 1855 and designated as the capital of the Zuid-Afrikaansche Republiek (ZAR) or the Republic of South Africa, a Boer republic in the Transvaal region. The Volksraad Parliament agreed to the establishment of a central city which was named Pretoria. The decision was made on 16 December 1855 and is considered Pretoria Day. Pretoria was elevated to seat of government on 1 May 1860. Prior to this decision there were several difficulties over the choice of name. Pretoriusdorp, Pretorium, Pretoriusstad and Pretoria-Philadelphia are among those proposed.

Post-structuralism is a thought that arises as a result of dissatisfaction or disagreement with previous thoughts, namely structuralism. Post-structuralism was born as a deconstruction of structuralism. Poststructuralism figures include Michel Foucault, Jacques Derrida, Gilles Deleuze, Jean-François Lyotard, Roland Barthes, Jacques Lacan, Louis Althusser, Jean Baudrillard, Slavoj Žižek, Ernesto Laclau, Julia Kristeva, Chantal Mouffe, Judith Butler and Hélène Cixous. Jacques Derrida is a highly influential poststructuralist figure. He named his method deconstruction (he himself called it "Praxis"). If structuralists see order and stability in the language system, then Jacques Derrida, the main character of the poststructuralism approach, sees language as disorderly and unstable. Derrida degrades the role of language which according to him is just "writing" which does not force its users, he also sees that social institutions are nothing but writing, because they are unable to force people. Different contexts give words with different meanings. As a result, the language system does not have coercive power over people, which according to the views of structuralist theorists does. Therefore, according to Derrida, it is impossible for scientists to discover the general laws that underlie language. He criticized society in general for being enslaved by logocentrism (the search for a universal system of thinking that expresses what is right, right, beautiful and so on). Poststructuralism contains both criticism and absorption. Absorbing various aspects of structural linguistics while making it a critique that is considered capable of transcending structuralism. In short, poststructuralism rejects the idea of ​​a stable structure that underlies meaning through binary (black-and-white, good-bad) pairs. Meaning is something that is unstable, which always slips in the process, not only limited to certain single words, sentences or texts, but the result of relationships between texts. Like its predecessor, it is antihumanist in its attempt to marginalize the unified and coherent human subject as the origin of stable meaning.

Sigmund Freud, the father of psychoanalysis, has thoughts that often inspire other researchers. One of them is the post-structuralist philosopher, Jacques Lacan. The concepts of the subconscious, ego, fear of castration by the father, and Freud's process of identification underlie Lacan's thinking. In an effort to revisit the theory of subjectivity derived from the work of Sigmund Freud, Lacan rereads Freud to clarify and enliven a set of concepts, especially that of the unconscious. The theory about the ego in humans which gives rise to the human unconscious extends to various social and human fields. In America and other English-speaking countries it thrived under the influence of Heinze Hartman. In the period after the great war, the humanism movement became important, and an understanding emerged of the importance of human consciousness, a belief that the ego, good or bad, is at the center of human psychic life. With a structuralist emphasis on language as a system of differences without positive meaning, Lacan highlights the importance of language in Freud's work. However, before the structuralist approach became popular, in 1936 Lacan had developed a mirror image theory which spoke of the ability of babies aged 6-18 months (no voice) to be able to recognize their own reflection in a mirror. The act of self-knowledge does not become self-evident by itself, this is because the baby will see the image either as himself or not (only a reflected image). At that age, the baby does not yet have the concept of self-awareness, then at a later age -after he begins to speak, it is called a marker of self-awareness. Thus, the formation of the ego takes place, that is the center of consciousness. In 1953, Lacan in the Roman Discourse said, "Man speaks,... but it is the symbol that makes him human." Foucault is both a body sociologist and a post-structuralist theorist.

Untranslated articles can be quickly deleted according to criteria A2. A bridge is a structure made to cross a chasm or an obstacle such as a river, railroad or highway. Bridges are built for crossing pedestrians, vehicles or trains over obstacles. Bridges are also part of the land transportation infrastructure which is very vital in traffic flows. Bridges are often a critical component of a road section, because it determines the maximum load of vehicles passing through the road. The first bridge was made with a wooden footbridge to cross the river. There are also people who use two ropes or rattan, which are tied to the rocks by the river. Henceforth, stone was still used, but only as a frame. The first arched bridges were built during the time of the Roman Empire, and there are still many bridges and aqueducts of the Romans that we know today. The Romans also had the knowledge to know the difference in the strength of different stones. The brick and mortar bridges were built during the time of the Roman emperors, because after that time, knowledge technology was lost. In the Middle Ages, the pillars of stone bridges were usually larger, causing difficulties for ships traveling on the river. In the 18th century, many reforms began in the construction of wooden bridges by Hans Ulrich, Johannes Grubenmann and others. With the advent of the Industrial Revolution in the 19th century, truss systems used iron to advance the technology of building larger bridges, but steel did not have sufficient tensile strength to support the large loads. If they have high tension strength, larger bridges will be built, mostly using Gustave Eiffel's ideas, which were first demonstrated on the Eiffel Tower in Paris, France.

Which is suitable for making long bridges because it has the strength to support high loads, but concrete also has cheaper maintenance costs. So, often "reinforced concrete" (reinforced concrete) is used - the weak tensile strength of the concrete is filled by copper cables embedded in the concrete. The types of bridges can be categorized based on their use or support structure. A bridge is usually designed equally for trains, for road users or for pedestrians. There are also bridges built for large pipes and waterways that can be used to carry goods. Sometimes there are limitations in the use of bridges; for example, there are bridges that are dedicated to roads and cannot be used by pedestrians or cyclists. There are also bridges built for pedestrians (crossing bridges), and can be used for cyclists. Half the bridge is made higher than necessary, so that the reflection of the bridge will complete a circle. This kind of bridge, which is often found in oriental gardens, is called "Bridge of the Moon", because the bridge and its reflection resemble a full moon. Usually in the bridge palaces an artificial river is made as a symbol of the journey to an important place or event. There is a set of five bridges that cross a winding river in one of the important places in the Forbidden City in Beijing, China. The bridge in the middle can only be passed by the Emperor, Queen and their concubines. The planning and construction materials of the bridge depend on the location and also the type of load it will bear. Here are some of the main types of bridges: The earliest bridges were made by humans using fallen trees that crossed the river.

Theravāda Negara Naskah Kanon PaliKitab KomentarKitab Subkomentar Sejarah Buddhisme pra-sektarianSekte-sekte awal • SthaviraAsoka • Dewan KetigaVibhajjavadaMahinda • SanghamittaDipavamsa • MahavamsaBuddhaghosa Ajaran Saṃsāra • NibbāṇaJalan TengahJalan Utama Berunsur DelapanEmpat Kebenaran MuliaTahap PencerahanPedoman • Tiga Mustika  Theravāda (Pāli: थेरवाद theravāda; Sanskerta: स्थविरवाद sthaviravāda) ; literally, "Teachings of the Elders" or "Prior Teachings", is the oldest surviving classification of Buddhism. Found in India. Theravāda is conservative, and overall the closest teaching to Buddhism in its beginnings, and for centuries it was the dominant belief in Sri Lanka (about 70% of the population) and most of the continents of Southeast Asia (Cambodia), (Laos ), (Myanmar), (Thailand), (Indonesia). The Theravāda School is also practiced by some minorities from Southwestern China by the Shan and Tai ethnicities), Vietnam (by the Khmer Krom), Bangladesh (by the ethnic groups of Barua, Chakma, and Magh), Malaysia and Indonesia, and has recently gained more popularity in Singapore and the West. Today, the Theravāda school of Buddhism has over 100 million adherents worldwide, and in the last decade or so Theravāda school has taken root in the West and in India. Theravadins (Theravadins) claim that the name Theravada is descended from the Sthaviravada ancestors. After unsuccessfully trying to modify the Vinaya, the small group of “elders”, the sthavira, split from the majority of the Mahāsāṃghikas during the Second Buddhist council, resulting in the emergence of the Sthaviravada. According to his accounts, Theravada stems essentially from the Vibhajjavāda (or "analytical doctrine") grouping which was a division of the Sthaviravada. The Theravadin accounts of the origins of Theravāda say that this school received the teachings agreed upon during the Third Buddhist Council under the patronage of King Asoka of India, around 250 BC.

These teachings are known as the Vibhajjavada. The Vibhajjavada adherents (Vibhajjavādins) were in turn divided into four groups: Mahīśāsaka, Kāśyapīya, Dharmaguptaka, and Tāmraparṇīya. Theravada descends from the Tāmraparṇīya sect, which means “the Sri Lankan lineage.” In the 7th century AD, Chinese pilgrims named Xuanzang and Yijing referred to the Buddhist schools in Sri Lanka as Shàngzuòbù, after the Sanskrit “Sthavira Nikāya” and the Pali “Thera Nikāya”. This school has used the name Theravada in written form since at least the 4th century, when the term appears in the Dīpavaṁsa. According to Buddhist scholar A.K. Warder, Theravāda According to the Pali chronicles of the Sinhalese tribal tradition, Buddhism was first brought to Sri Lanka by Arahant Mahinda, who is believed to have been the son of the Mauryan king Asoka, in the third century BC, as part of the dhammaduta (missionary) activities of the Asoka era. In Sri Lanka, Arahat Mahinda founded the Mahāvihāra Monastery in Anuradhapura. During most of the early history of Buddhism in Sri Lanka, three branches of Theravada existed in Sri Lanka, consisting of monks from the Mahāvihāra, Abhayagiri Vihāra, and Jetavana Vihāra. The Mahāvihāra was the first tradition to be founded, while the Abhayagiri Vihāra and Jetavana Vihāra were founded by monks who had broken away from the Mahāvihāra tradition. According to A.K. Warder, the Indian Mahīśāsaka sect also established its own school in Sri Lanka alongside the Theravāda and was later absorbed into it. The northern region of Sri Lanka also appears to have been handed over to sects from India at some point. When the Chinese monk Faxian visited the island in the early 5th century AD, he recorded 5000 monks in Abhayagiri, 3000 monks in Mahāvihāra, and 2000 monks in Cetyapabbatavihāra. Over the centuries, the Abhayagiri Theravadins maintained close ties with Indian Buddhists and adopted many new teachings from India, including many elements from the Mahāyāna teachings, while the Jetavana Theravādins adopted the Mahāyāna to a lesser extent.

Mysticism is an understanding that gives teachings that are all mystical (for example the teachings are in the form of secrets or the teachings are all secret, hidden, dark or shrouded in darkness) so that they are only known, known or understood by certain people, especially its adherents. The word mystical comes from the Greek mystikos which means secret (geheim), all secret (geheimzinnig), hidden (verborgen), dark (donker) or shrouded in darkness (in het duister gehuld). According to the book by De Kleine W.P. Encylopaedie (1950, Mr. G.B.J. Hiltermann and Prof. Dr.P. Van De Woestijne page 971 under the word mystiek) the word mystic comes from the Greek myein which means to close the eyes (de ogen sluiten) and musterion which means a secret (geheimnis). Some opinions about mysticism or mysticism: In addition to obtaining definitions, the opinions about mysticism above based on their teaching material also provide a distinction between religious mysticism (related to God and divinity) and non-religious mysticism (not related to god or divinity). Besides being completely mystical, his teachings are also completely subjective and not objective. There are no universal and authentic basic guidelines. Sourced from the personality of the main character so that mystical understanding is not the same as one another even though it is about the same thing. So that the discussion and experience of his teachings cannot be controlled or controlled in the proper sense. Usually the characters are highly glorified, glorified and even idolized (mythed, cultized) by their adherents because they are considered to have personal privileges called charisma. This presumption of privilege can be caused by: Whereas how the character receives teachings or understanding of the understanding he teaches is usually through inner adventure, self-isolation, asceticism, meditating, meditation, silence etc. in the form of ecstasy, visions, inspiration etc. So his teachings were obtained through the character's own personal experience and his acceptance was impossible to prove to others himself.

Thus the acceptance of his teachings was almost solely based on belief, not thought. So that's why some of us call it understanding, teaching of belief or flow of belief (geloofsleer). Bearing in mind that it is impossible to control its teaching in the proper sense, it is easy for mystical understanding to give rise to new branches into new schools according to the interpretation of each of its characters. Or vice versa, it is easy to combine or mix the teachings of pre-existing understandings. Because it is all mystical, mysticism or groups of adherents of mysticism are not too difficult to use by people who have specific goals and who need to be kept secret because they violate or conflict with public opinion or applicable law as a hiding place. The material is completely abstract, meaning it is not concrete, for example about God (divine mysticism), about spirituality or psychology, the nature behind the natural world, etc. (non-religious mysticism). Thus his talk is all speculative, that is all guessing, searching, making possible etc. (not computative). know, still trying to make it possible). Therefore, among adherents of mysticism, there is no known disciplinary discussion regarding their teachings as is the case in discussions or munaqasyah. Among them there are still those who try to rationalize the mystical teachings they adhere to, and there are also those who are completely free from the demands of the progress of this era. Nevertheless, mystical understanding can instill ethical and moral standards in civilizational arrangements. Although mystical understanding is usually conveyed using parables, there is actually value in it that can be contemplated and is still relevant to apply in everyday life. source: MH Amien Jaiz, Mystical Problems of Sufism & Mysticism (PT Alma'arif, Bandung, Print 1980) Abrahamism Akosmism Agnosticism Animism Antireligion Atheism Dharmism Deism Dualism Esotericism Feminist theology Gnosticism Henotheism Humanism Immanenke Monism Monotheism Mysticism Naturalism Nondualism Pandeism Pantheism Polytheism Process Theology Syamanism Taoist Theism Transcendent New Age This article on the topic of religion or belief is a stub.

Glucose, a monosaccharide sugar, is one of the most important carbohydrates used as a source of energy for animals and plants. Glucose is one of the main products of photosynthesis and the start of respiration. Its natural form (D-glucose) is also called dextrose, especially in the food industry. Glucose (C6H12O6, molecular weight 180.18) is a hexose—a monosaccharide containing six carbon atoms. Glucose is an aldehyde (contains -CHO group). Its five carbons and one oxygen form a ring called a "pyranose ring", the most stable form for six-carbon aldoses. In this ring, each carbon is bonded to a hydroxyl and hydrogen side group except the fifth atom, which is bonded to the sixth carbon on the outside of the ring, forming a CH2OH group. This ring structure is in equilibrium with the more reactive form, which accounts for 0.0026% at pH 7. Glucose is a ubiquitous energy source in biology. We can surmise the reason why glucose, and not other monosaccharides such as fructose, is so widely used. Glucose can be formed from formaldehyde under abiotic conditions, making it readily available to primitive biochemical systems. Of more importance to higher organisms is the tendency for glucose, compared with other hexose sugars, to react nonspecifically with the amino groups of proteins. This reaction (glycosylation) reduces or even impairs the function of various enzymes. The low rate of glycosylation is due to glucose being mostly in less reactive cyclic isomers. However, acute complications such as diabetes, blindness, kidney failure, and peripheral nerve damage (''peripheral neuropathy''), may be caused by protein glycosylation. In respiration, through a series of enzyme-catalyzed reactions, glucose is oxidized to finally form carbon dioxide and water, producing energy, mainly in the form of ATP. Before use, glucose is broken down from polysaccharides.

Glucose and fructose are chemically bonded to sucrose. Starch, cellulose, and glycogen are common glucose polymers (polysaccharides). Dextrose is formed when the D-glucose solution rotates polarized light to the right. In the same case D-fructose is called "levulose" because levulose solution rotates polarized light to the left. Sugar occurs in two enantiomers (mirror isomers), D-glucose and L-glucose, but in organisms, only the D-isomer is found. A D or L shaped carbohydrate corresponds to an isomeric conformation on the 5 carbon. If it is to the right of the Fischer projection, the ring shape is the D enantiomer, if to the left, it is the L enantiomer. Very easy to remember, referring to D for "dextro", which is the Latin root for "right" (right), while the L stands for "levo" which is the root for "left". The ring structure itself can be formed in two different ways, which produce glucose-α (alpha) jeungt β (beta).Structurally, glucose-α jeung -β differs in that the hydroxyl group attached to the first carbon of the ring.The α form has the hydroxyl group "underneath" the hydrogen (as this molecule is usually drawn, as shown in the figure above), whereas the β form of the hydroxyl group is "above" the hydrogen. The two forms alternate over time in aqueous solution, until they reach a stable ratio α:β of 36:64, in a process called accelerated murotation at. Carbohydrates are the main source of energy for the human body, providing 4 calories (17 kilojoules) of food energy per gram. The breakdown of carbohydrates (eg starch) produces mono- and disaccharides, mainly glucose. Through glycolysis, glucose is immediately involved in the production of ATP, the cell's energy carrier. On the other hand, glucose is very important in the production of proteins and also in lipid metabolism. Since there is no lipid metabolism in the central nervous system, this tissue is highly dependent on glucose.

In Buddhism, Nirvana (Sanskrit: निर्वाण nirvāṇa; Pali: nibbāna; Chinese: 涅槃; pinyin: nièpán) is the culmination of the Buddhist quest for freedom from samsara, the cycle of death and rebirth. Siddartha Gautama, the Buddha, described Buddhism as a raft which, having floated down a river, would allow its passengers to reach nirvana. In a deeper sense, Nibbana is the highest bliss, a state of extraordinary eternal bliss. [citation needed] The bliss of Nibbana cannot be experienced by indulging the senses, but by calming them. Nibbana is not a place. Nibbana is not an absence or extinction. Nibbana is not a heaven. There are no suitable words to describe this Nibbana. Nibbana can be realized by eliminating greed (lobha), hatred (dosa) and delusion (moha). citation needed] In the Udana VIII:3, Nibbana is explained by the Buddha as follows: Further in the Milinda Panha Book it is also explained about Nibbana through The conversation between the Bhikkhu Nagasena and King Milinda goes as follows: So it can be concluded that Nibbana is not a place or realm of existence, but a state free from all defilements which are the cause of the sufferings of birth, old age, disease, death, pain, lamentation and despair. despair, namely Greed (Lobha), Hatred (Sin), and Ignorance (Moha). Nibbana can be attained while still alive (Sa-upadisesa Nibbana) and when you die (An-upadisesa Nibbana). When Prince Siddhartha attained Perfect Enlightenment and became Samma Sambuddha, then at that time He experienced Sa-upadisesa Nibbana. When Buddha Gotama died at the age of 80 in Kusinara, he attained An-upadisesa Nibbana or Parinibbana. The way to attain Nibbana is to practice the Noble Eightfold Path for yourself, namely: Hinduism also uses nirvana as a synonym for their thoughts on Moksha, and nirvana is spoken of in several Hindu tantric writings as well as the Bhagawad Gita.

Gravity, or gravitas (from the Latin gravitas, meaning "weight"), is a natural phenomenon in which all things that have mass or energy in the universe—including planets, stars, galaxies, and even light—attract one another. On Earth, gravity causes physical objects to have weight, the Moon's gravity causes sea tides, and the sun's gravity causes planets and various other objects to be in their respective orbits in the solar system. The gravitational force of the matter in space that exists in the universe caused this matter to begin to gather, forming stars and causing these stars to gather to form galaxies so that it can be said that the large-scale structures in the universe were created by gravity. Gravity has an infinite range of values. However, the effect gets weaker the further away an object is. Modern physics most accurately describes gravity using the general theory of relativity proposed by Albert Einstein in 1915, which describes gravity not as a force, but as the consequence of mass moving "straight" in a curvature of space-time caused by the unequal distribution of mass. . The most extreme example of this curvature of space-time is a black hole, in which nothing, not even light, can escape once it passes through the black hole's event horizon. However, for most cases, gravity can be explained by Newton's simpler law of universal gravitation. Newton described gravity as a force that causes two physical objects to attract each other, with a force proportional to the resulting mass and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the two objects. Several theories that have not been proven yet state that the gravitational force arises because of the graviton particles in each atom.

Mauritius is an island nation in the southwest of the Indian Ocean, about 900 km east of Madagascar. Apart from the Island of Mauritius, the country also includes the Cargados Carajos Islands, Rodrigues and the Agalega Islands. Mauritius is included in the Mascarene Archipelago, along with France's Reunion Island 200 km southwest of Mauritius. The island of Mauritius was discovered by the Portuguese in 1505, and first colonized by the Dutch in 1638. The Dutch named the island "Mauritius" in memory of Prince Maurice of Nassau. The French controlled the island throughout the 18th century and then named it Ile de France. Mauritius was annexed by the United Kingdom in 1810 and reverted to its former name. Independence was achieved in 1968 with a republican government that was included in the group of Commonwealth of Nations in 1992. Mauritius is a relatively stable democracy with regular elections and a good human rights record. The large influx of foreign investment into Mauritius has made it one of the countries with the highest per capita income in Africa. Together with Reunion and Rodrigues, Mauritius forms part of the Mascarene Islands. The islands were formed by an underwater volcanic explosion as the African Plate moved toward the Reunion hotspot. Mauritius and Rodrigues formed 8-10 million years ago. The two mountains are no longer active and the hotspot now resides beneath Reunion. The island of Mauritius itself is formed around a central plateau, with the highest peak Piton de la Riviere Noire (828m). Around the plateau, the original krater can still be distinguished from the other mountains. Tropical weather in Mauritius is influenced by winds from the southeast; winter from May-November and summer from November-May. Cyclones usually occur during November-April. The capital and largest city is Port Louis in the northwest.

Other important cities are Curepipe, Vacoas, Phoenix, Quatre Bornes, Rose-Hill and Beau-Bassin. The head of state of Mauritius is a President with a five-year term who is elected by the National Assembly, Mauritius' unicameral parliament. Of the total 66 members of parliament, 62 are elected by popular vote and another 4 are elected to represent ethnic minorities, depending on the election results. Parliament is led by the Prime Minister and several ministers. The island of Mauritius is divided into 9 districts: The following three islands are dependencies of Mauritius: During independence in 1968, Mauritius has developed from an agrarian-based economy with low incomes to a medium-income economy with varied growth sectors such as industry, finance and tourism. In most periods, annual growth reaches 5%-6%. Therefore, the estimated age of the population increases, the under-five mortality rate decreases and the infrastructure improves. Sugar cane is grown on 90% of agricultural land and it accounts for 25% of export earnings. But in 1999, a record drought ravaged the sugar cane fields. The development strategy is centered on the entry of foreign investment. Mauritius has attracted at least 9,000 offshore businesses, mostly in India and South Africa. Investment in the banking sector has reached more than US$ 1 billion. The unemployment rate reached a level of 7.6% in 2004. The two official languages ​​of Mauritius, English and French, are used in administrative matters. Although France has not ruled the country for more than 200 years, French is still widely spoken. The Creole language, which originates from French with influences from English, Portuguese and Hindi, is also often spoken by the people of Mauritius. Written Creole languages ​​have developed since the late 1960s and bear little resemblance to French. Several South Asian languages ​​such as Hindi, Urdu and Telugu are also spoken.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) The Netherlands (Dutch: Nederland ˈneːdərˌlɑnt]  ( listen), trans. lit. "lowlands") is a country mainly located on the European Continent. The Netherlands is part of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, a constitutional monarchy that includes all parts of the European Netherlands as well as the Caribbean Netherlands. The Netherlands consists of twelve provinces in Western Europe and three island territories in the Caribbean. The European Netherlands is bordered by the North Sea to the north and west, Belgium to the south and Germany to the east, and shares maritime borders with Belgium, Germany and the United Kingdom. The Netherlands adheres to a parliamentary democracy system of government structured as a unitary state. The capital and largest city is Amsterdam, while the seat of government and monarchy is in The Hague. The Netherlands as a whole is often referred to as Holland although that term only includes the provinces of North Holland and South Holland. The Netherlands is geographically a low-lying country, with approximately 30% of its area, 31% of its population below sea level, and 50% of its land less than one meter above sea level. This unique fact is immortalized in its names: Nederland (Dutch), which means "low lands"; the name is also used with some variations in other European languages. Much of the land below sea level is the result of human intervention, due to centuries of widespread, poorly controlled peat extraction, lowering the surface by several meters. Even in flooded areas the peat extraction is continued through dredging. Since the end of the 11th century began; later large polder areas are now being preserved by elaborate drainage systems involving several dikes, canals and pumping stations.

Most of the Netherlands is formed by the estuaries of three important European rivers, which together with their tributaries form the Rhein-Maas-Schelde delta. Most of the country is very flat, with the exception of the foothills in the far southeast, and a few rows of hills in the centre. The Netherlands is one of the first few countries to have an elected parliament, and it is a founding member of the European Union, G-10, NATO, OECD, WTO, and participant in the trilateral Benelux economic union. The Netherlands is one of the countries that once controlled Indonesia, and only recognized Indonesian sovereignty on December 27, 1949, but now recognizes Indonesia as independent on August 17, 1945. In 2011, the Netherlands was ranked the tenth highest per capita income in the world. The country is host to the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, and five world courts: the Permanent Court of Arbitration, the International Court of Justice, the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, the International Criminal Court, and the Special Tribunal for Lebanon. The first four are based in The Hague; it is also home to the European Union's criminal intelligence agency, Europol; and the European judicial cooperation agency, Eurojust. This fact has led to the nickname "the legal capital of the world" for the City of The Hague. The Netherlands operates on the principle of a market-based mixed economy, ranking 17th out of 177 countries according to the Index of Economic Freedom. In May 2011, the Netherlands achieved the status of the "happiest" country according to the results released by the OECD. The Netherlands is one of the most densely populated countries in the world. The Netherlands is also famous for its dykes (dijk), windmills, wooden drums, tulips, and its open, liberal society. From 800 BC onwards, the Iron Age Celtic Hallstatt culture became influential, supplanting the Hilversum culture. Iron ore brings prosperity and is available throughout the land, including marsh iron.

Titanium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Ti and atomic number 22. This element is a light, strong, lustrous, corrosion-resistant transition metal (including resistance to seawater, aqua regia, and chlorine) with a white-metallic- silvery. Titanium was discovered in Cornwall, United Kingdom in 1791 by William Gregor and named by Martin Heinrich Klaproth from the Greek mythological Titan. This element is present among the deposits of various minerals, including rutile and ilmenite, which are abundant in the earth's crust and lithosphere, as well as in almost all living things, rocks, water and soil. The metal is extracted from its mineral ores via the Kroll process or the Hunter process. Its most common compound, titanium dioxide, is a common photocatalyst and is used in the manufacture of white pigments. Other compounds are titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4), a smoke screen component and catalyst; and titanium trichloride (TiCl3), used as a catalyst in the production of polypropylene. Titanium can be used as an alloy with iron, aluminum, vanadium, and molybdenum, to produce strong yet light alloys for aviation (jet engines, missiles, and space probes), military, industrial processes (chemical and petrochemical, desalination plants, pulp, and paper), automotive, agro-industry, medical devices, orthopedic implants, dentist tools and instruments, dental implants, sports equipment, jewelry, mobile phones, and many other applications. The two most useful properties of titanium are its corrosion resistance and the highest strength-to-density ratio of any metal. In its pure state, titanium is as strong as some steels, but lighter. There are two allotropic forms and five naturally occurring isotopes of the element, 46Ti to 50Ti, with 48Ti being the most abundant (73.8%) naturally occurring.

Despite having the same number of valence electrons and being in the same periodic table group as zirconium, the two have many differences in chemical and physical properties. The oxidation number +4 dominates elemental titanium, but compounds in the oxidation number +3 are also common. In general, titanium has an octahedral coordination geometry in its complexes, but the tetrahedral TiCl4 is an exception. Because of their high oxidation number, titanium(IV) compounds have high covalent bonding properties. Unlike other transition metals, the aquo Ti(IV) complex is unknown. The most important oxide is TiO2, which exists in 3 polymorphs; anatase, brookite, and rutile. All three are white diamagnetic solids, although some samples are dark (see rutile). Titanate usually refers to titanium(IV) compounds, such as barium titanate (BaTiO3). With a perovskite structure, this material has piezoelectric properties and is used as a transducer in the interconversion of sound and electricity. Many minerals are titanates, such as ilmenite (FeTiO3). Star sapphires and rubies have asteristic properties from the presence of titanium dioxide in them. Several kinds of reduced oxides of titanium are known. Ti3O5 is a purple semiconductor produced by the reduction of TiO2 with hydrogen at high temperatures, and is used in industry when a surface needs to be vapor-coated with titanium dioxide: it evaporates as pure TiO, while TiO2 evaporates as a mixed oxide and deposit coating. with varying refractive indices. Also known compounds are Ti2O3, with the carborundum structure, and TiO. The alkoxide of titanium(IV), prepared by treating TiCl4 with an alcohol, is a colorless compound that turns into dioxide when reacted with water. In industry it is useful to obtain solid TiO2 via the sol-gel process. Titanium isopropoxide is used in the synthesis of chiral organic compounds through the sharpless process.

Inquisition (with a capital I) is the term widely used to refer to the trials of heretics by the Roman Catholic Church. The term can also mean an ecclesiastical tribunal or institution within the Roman Catholic Church that is in charge of fighting or eliminating heresy, some of the historical expurgation movements against heretics (instigated by the Roman Catholic Church), or the trial of someone accused of heresy. The term "inquisition" comes from the Latin word Middle Ages, inquisitio. This word is used to refer to all kinds of judicial processes based on Roman law which were slowly revived in the Late Middle Ages. The term "Inquisition" is now used as a designation for a number of institutions to control heresy (as well as other violations of canon law) within the judicial system of the Roman Catholic Church. Although the plural is used as a designation for Catholic ecclesiastical courts, the term "Inquisition" actually refers to a judicial process, not an organization. The judges '...were called "inquisitors" because they applied a judicial technique called inquisitio, meaning "interview" or "investigation".' This judicial technique has been widely used by secular leaders. King Henry II applied it extensively in England in the 12th century. In trials using this technique, a formal interviewer would request information on a particular subject from anyone who felt they had something to say." Being an ecclesiastical court, the Inquisition had no authority to try Moros and Jews. In general, the Inquisition dealt only with heretical behavior of adherents or people who have just embraced Catholic Christianity. Almost all the punishments handed down by the Inquisition were acts of penance, for example wearing clothes embroidered with the sign of the cross, making pilgrimages, and so on. If the accused is proven to adhere to heretical teachings without feeling guilty, the assembly the inquisitor is legally obliged to hand over the person concerned to the district court for punishment.

The district court then determines the criminal sanction according to the law in force in the local country. The law includes prohibitions against religious crimes (heresy and so on) with the threat of being burned alive as a form of punishment, although the usual punishments are exile or life imprisonment, which are usually commuted by a reduced sentence after lived several years. Therefore the inquisitors generally knew what kind of fate would befall the accused who were being detained. The Directorium Inquisitorum (inquisitor's main guidebook) edition of 1578 describes the purpose of sentencing as follows: ... quoniam punitio non refertur primo et per se in correctionem et bonum eius qui punitur, sed in bonum publicum ut alii terreantur, et a malis committendis avocentur(. .. because punishment is not carried out primarily and per se for the betterment and benefit of the convict, but for the public good, so that other people become horrified and deterred from doing evil) Before 1100, the Catholic Church usually suppressed parties who were labeled heretics through a system of proscriptions ecclesiastical or imprisonment, but without torture, and rarely resulting in the death penalty. Such punishments are opposed by some clergy and theologians, although some countries impose the death penalty on convicted heretics. Pope Sirisius, Ambrose of Milan, and Martin of Tours protested against Priscilla's execution, primarily because it was seen as interference by civil courts in the enforcement of ecclesiastical discipline. Despite being labeled as a heretic, Priscilla was executed as a sorcerer. Ambrose refused to give Itasius of Osonuba a confession of any kind, "not wanting to have anything to do with the bishops who brought heretics to death". In the 12th century, to counter the spread of Catharism, judgments of heretical masters were often held.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health sciences Immunology is a branch of biology of biomedical sciences that includes the study of the immune system in all organisms. Immunology chart, measures, and contextualizes the physiological function of the immune system in states of health and disease; immune system damage in immunological disorders (such as autoimmune diseases, hypersensitivity, immune deficiency, and transplant rejection); and physical, chemical, and physiological characteristics of components of the immune system in vitro, in situ, and in vivo. Immunology has applications in various medical disciplines, especially in the fields of organ transplantation, oncology, rheumatology, virology, bacteriology, parasitology, psychiatry and dermatology. Before establishing immunity, from etymological immunos, which is Latin for "excluded", early physicians characterized the organs that would later prove to be essential components of the immune system. The important lymphoid organs of the immune system are the thymus, bone marrow, and major lymphatic tissues such as the spleen, tonsils, lymph vessels, lymph nodes, thyroid glands, and liver. When the health condition deteriorates to an emergency status, parts of the immune system organs, including the thymus, spleen, bone marrow, lymph nodes, and other lymphatic tissues, may be surgically removed for examination while the patient is still alive. Many components of the immune system are normally cellular and not associated with any specific organ, but are instead embedded in or circulating in various tissues located throughout the body. Due to the complexity of handling this science (the treatment of one patient and another is not the same), the profession has become less attractive to Indonesian medical personnel. In addition, there are very few medical faculties in the world that have master vaccinology programs. Dirga Sakti Rambe became the youngest vaccinologist in the world who graduated in 2012.

Falconry (/falkənrɪ/) or hawking (from English, meaning "hunting using a falcon") is a type of sport that utilizes the falcon (type of falcon or kestrel) or hawk (eagle) in a hunting activity. People who practice falconry are called falconers. This sport requires patience and perseverance in training birds. Birds need to be tamed or "humanized" and taught to do things like fly back to their master's arms or hunt in the game fields. In 2010, one of the oldest sports in the world was inscribed on the UNESCO Representative List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity by many countries, including the Republic of Korea, United Arab Emirates, Belgium, Czech Republic, France, Mongolia, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Spain and Syria. Falconry is one of the oldest sports in the world having been first practiced in the Middle East as far back as the 8th century BC. Furthermore, this tradition developed in Europe, especially among the nobility in the Middle Ages. At that time, each social class was given a certain type of bird of prey to be released as a symbol of position. Kings fly gyrfalcons and slaves fly goshawks. In Asia, falconry thrives in the Middle East, Central Asia, Mongolia, Korea, China and Japan. Falconry in Korea began during the Three Kingdoms period (57 BC-668) and was later introduced to China and Japan. In Japan, this activity is called Takagari. Beginning in the 17th century the sport of falconry declined in popularity after the invention of the gun and more land was cleared for agricultural activities. At this time, falconry was little practiced by humans, limited to hawking groups and associations. In South Korea, only two traditional falconry (maesanyang) are left. Birds used in falconry activities are various types of birds of prey, including Peregrine Falcons, goshawks, and sparrow hawks.

These birds are caught in the wild or kept as children. Although any type of bird of prey can be trained to fly freely and return to its master, only a few species have been traditionally used in falconry. The short-winged eagle and the falcon are often prized for their hunting abilities, while the broad-winged falcon is used mostly simply for its perfect flying style. The third group of birds are eagles and other broad-winged birds of prey. North American and Eurasian goshawks, Eurasian sparrowhawks, sharp-shinned hawks, Asian shikras, North American cooper eagles and short-winged eagles are the species most frequently used. These birds have adaptations for living in the forest and their method of hunting begins with reconnaissance behind a tree and then gliding to pounce on their prey. The largest eagle, the goshawk, is capable of catching large prey such as geese, pheasants, bustards, rabbits and hares. Cooper's Eagle is best at catching quail and cottontail rabbits, but larger females may occasionally catch quail. The kestrel can catch its prey by grabbing it with its claws and kill by gripping it tightly and haphazardly and tearing its prey's vital parts. Most of the action takes place on the ground and in certain species, such as the rabbit hawk, it will chase its prey down the hole. The most widely trained falcons include the peregrine, shaheen, gyrfalcon, saker, lanner, prairie falcon, merlin, red-necked falcon, and various types of kestrels. Kestrels are used more often in training for novice falconers than in hunting activities. Falcon is a great hunter in the open field where it will hunt from a height by sliding and folding some of its wings.

The United States Agency for International Development (English: United States Agency for International Development, USAID) is the independent agency of the United States government responsible for economic, development, and humanitarian assistance to the rest of the world in support of policy goals United States abroad. USAID's mission in Indonesia is headed by a Mission Director and a Deputy Mission Director. USAID is in Indonesia with the aim of assisting in accelerating Indonesia's democratic transition through; In supporting the process of regional decentralization in Indonesia, USAID's programs include supporting the improvement of local services and budgeting planning in the sectors of handling and processing natural resources and health. To reduce the threat of conflicts and crises in Indonesia related to ethnic and religious violence, USAID provides humanitarian assistance to refugees and victims of natural disasters. USAID's activities also prioritize health sectors such as child survival, family planning and HIV/AIDS. In implementing this, USAID works closely with the Government of Indonesia, other Donor Agencies, and other Indonesian and International Organizations. In the early 1970s, USAID assisted in the search for a potential location for a new international airport. At that time, the choice of location was Jonggol, Malacca, Babakan, Halim, Curug, South Tangerang and North Tangerang. USAID finally suggested Jonggol as the most appropriate location as the location for the new International Airport. In 1974-1975, a consortium of Canadian consultants consisting of Aviation Planning Services Ltd., Searlee Wilbee Rowland (SWR) together with PT Konavi as a representative partner from Indonesia finally decided to build a new international airport in Cengkareng, Tangerang, not in Jonggol as a result of a USAID study, the reason is that the Jonggol area has not been connected to other modes of transportation.

Violence or (English: Violence English pronunciation: /vaɪ(ə)ləns/] derived from (Latin: violentus which comes from the word vī or vīs means power or power) is a basic principle in Roman public and private law which is an expression either physically or verbally that reflects acts of aggression and attacks on a person's freedom or dignity that can be carried out by an individual or a group of people generally related to their authority, namely when translated freely it can mean that all authority without regard to the legitimacy of use or action that arbitrariness can also be included in this formulation of violence.The Roots of Violence: Wealth without work, Pleasure without conscience, Knowledge without character, Trade without morality, Knowledge without humanity, Worship without sacrifice, Politics without principles.The Roots of Violence: Wealth without work, Pleasure without cons science, Knowledge without character, Commerce without morality, Science without humanity, Worship without sacrifice, Politics without principles. Violence can also include violations (torture, rape, beatings, etc.) that cause or are intended to cause suffering or harm to others, and - to a certain extent - to animals and property. The term "violence" also connotes an aggressive tendency to engage in destructive behavior. Violence basically falls into two forms —indiscriminate violence, which includes small-scale or unplanned violence, and coordinated violence, which is perpetrated by both entitled and non-entitled groups —as occurs in war (i.e., inter-governmental violence) -society) and terrorism. Since the Industrial Revolution, the severity of modern warfare has increased to a level that is universally dangerous. From a practical standpoint, war on a large scale is considered a direct threat to property and people, culture, society, and other living things on earth.

Belize is a small country on the east coast of Central America, bordered by Mexico to the northwest and Guatemala to the west and south. Honduras is located 75 km to the southeast. In Spanish, Belize is often called Belice. Formerly called British Honduras until 1973, Belize was a former British colony for more than a century. The name "Belize" is taken from the Belize River. The origin of the name Belize is unclear, but one theory is that the name is derived from the Spanish pronunciation of Wallace, which was the last name of the pirate who made the first settlements in Belize in 1638. Another possibility is that the name is from the Mayan word belix, which means "muddy water". ", applied to the Belize River. The Mayan civilization spread in Belize between 1500 BC and 300 AD and flourished until about 900 AD. European settlers began with English Jews, pirate sailors and shipwrecked ships as early as 1638. The early "Belizean settlement on the Gulf of Honduras" developed from a few dwellings in Belize Town and St. George's Caye into the de-facto colony of Great Britain during the late 18th century. In the early 19th century the settlement was British Honduras, and in 1871 it became the Crown Colony. Hurricane Hattie did significant damage to Belize in 1961. The government decided that a coastal capital sprawling below sea level was too risky. Over the years, the British colonial government built a new capital city, Belmopan, in the country's geographic center, and in the 1970s gradually began moving government offices there. British Honduras became a self-governing colony in January 1964 and renamed Belize in June 1973; It was the last British colony on the American continent.

George Price led the country to full independence on September 21, 1981 after being delayed by territorial disputes with neighboring Guatemala, which did not formally recognize the country until 1991. Throughout Belize's history, Guatemala has claimed ownership of all or part of the territory. This claim is sometimes shown in maps showing Belize as the easternmost province of Guatemala. Until 2006, the border dispute with Guatemala remained unresolved and quite contentious; from time to time the matter has required mediation by the United Kingdom, the heads of government CARICOM, the Organization of American States and on one occasion, the United States. Since independence, a British garrison has been stationed in Belize under the administration of the Government of Belize. Notably, Guatemala and Belize are participating in confidence-building measures proposed by the OAS, including the Guatemala-Belize Language Exchange Project. Today Belize is the scene of riots directed at the country's ruling party over tax increases in the national budget. Although Belize City has problems with crime and drugs, its coastal area is quite safe and charming. Fresh scenery in Belize including the 2nd largest barrier reef after Australia. This makes for world class scuba diving. Hot spots include waterfalls such as Antelope Falls in Mayflower Park, and the beach at Hopkins, a village that has hotels for tourists. Belize is located between the Hondo and Sarstoon Rivers, with the Belize River running through the center of the country. The north of Belize consists mainly of low and swampy coastal plains where forests are dense. Flora is very diverse considering the narrow geographical area. The south has the low Mayan mountain range, of which Victoria Peak is the highest point in Belize at 3,675 feet (1,120 m) high.

Soil (Greek: pedon; Latin: solum) is that part of the earth's crust composed of minerals and organic matter. Soil has a very vital role for all life on earth because it supports plant life by providing nutrients and water as well as supporting roots. The hollow structure of the soil is also a good place for roots to breathe and grow. Soil is also the living habitat of various microorganisms. For most land animals, the land provides a place to live and move around. The science that studies various aspects of soil is known as soil science. In terms of climatology, soil plays an important role as water storage and suppresses erosion, although the soil itself can also erode. Soil composition varies from one location to another. Water and air are part of the land. Soil comes from the weathering of rocks with the help of organisms, forming a unique body that covers the rocks. The process of soil formation is known as ''pedogenesis''. This unique process forms soil as a natural body consisting of layers or is referred to as a soil horizon. Each horizon tells about the origin and physical, chemical and biological processes that have been passed through the soil body. Hans Jenny (1899-1992), a soil expert from Switzerland working in the United States, stated that soil is formed from parent material that has undergone modification/weathering due to the dynamics of climatic factors, organisms (including humans), and the relief of the earth's surface (topography). as time goes by. Based on the dynamics of these five factors, various types of soil are formed and soil classification can be carried out. Soil is formed from rocks and rocks take millions of years to turn into soil. Rocks become soil because of weathering, namely the process of breaking down rocks into soil.

Rocks can experience weathering due to various factors, including weather and the activities of living things. Weather factors that cause rock weathering, such as temperature and rainfall. Weathering caused by weather factors is called physical weathering. The living things that cause weathering, for example trees and mosses are called biological weathering. Soil is formed from several factors: rocks, climate, living organisms, topography and time. There are various differences in these factors, the processes of weathering and soil formation are different. This causes differences in soil types from one region to another. Decomposers or decomposers are organisms that eat dead organisms and waste products from other organisms. Decomposers help cycle nutrients back into the ecosystem. Decomposers make soil rich by adding organic compounds with it. Substances such as carbon, water and nitrogen are returned to the ecosystem through the action of decomposers. Examples of decomposers include insects, earthworms, bacteria, fungi, maggots, lactobacteria, cockroaches, yeast, slugs, mosses, and actinomycetes/actinobacteria. Decomposers or decomposers are living things that obtain energy by decomposing the remains of living things that have died. The soil component is the composition of the process of soil formation. Soil is not a pile of solid material in a dead and static system, but is a dynamic and living system that changes from time to time. Every soil is composed of mineral/inorganic matter, organic matter, groundwater, and air. Mineral material comes from the weathering of rocks, while organic matter comes from the decomposition of dead organisms. However, the ratio of each of the components making up the soil varies for each soil and changes at any time. For a good ratio of soil components what plants need ideally is 45% mineral matter, 5% organic matter, 25% water and 25% air.

Paleonthropology is a science that studies the origin and development of humans with ancient human fossils as the object of research and is one of the branches of Biology and Anthropology. Paleoanthropology comes from the Greek: παλαιός (palaeos) "old, ancient", anthrōpos (ἄνθρωπος), "man", understanding of humanity, and -logia (-λογία), "science"), which is a combination of the disciplines of paleontology and physical anthropology, is a science that studies humans in the past which are found in hominid fossils such as petrified bones and footprints. Since the time of Carl Linnaeus, great apes have been considered the closest relative to humans, based on morphological similarities. In the 19th century, it was thought that the closest relatives to humans were chimpanzees and gorillas, and based on their similarities, it was suggested that humans share a common ancestor with African apes and their fossils must be found in Africa. This branch of science is thought to have emerged at the end of the 19th century when important discoveries were made that led to the study of human evolution. This is the discovery of Neanderthal humans in Germany, Thomas Huxley's work entitled Evidence as to Man's Place in Nature, and Charles Darwin's work entitled The Descent of Man is an important beginning of paleoanthropological research. The modern branch of paleoanthropology began in the 19th century with the discovery of the "Neanderthal man" (found in 1856, but similar bones have been found elsewhere since 1830), and with evidence suggesting that it was a caveman. The idea that humans are similar to great apes had been around for some time, but the idea of ​​the biological evolution of species in general was not recognized until after Charles Darwin published On the Origin of Species in 1859.

Chromium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Cr and atomic number 24. It is the first element in group 6. It is a steel-gray, shiny, hard and brittle metal that requires high polishing, resists tarnishing, and has a high melting point. The element's name is derived from the Greek χρῶμα, chroma, meaning color, because many chromium compounds are very colorful. Ferrochromium alloys are produced commercially from chromite by cilicothermal or aluminothermal reactions and chromium metal by roasting and leaching followed by reduction using carbon and then aluminum. Chromium metal is of high value because of its high resistance to corrosion and hardness. A major development was the discovery that steel could be made highly corrosion and tarnishing resistant by the addition of metallic chromium to form stainless steel. Stainless steel and chrome plating (electroplating with chromium) together account for 85% of commercial use. Trivalent chromium ion (Cr(III)) in trace amounts is an essential nutrient in humans for insulin, sugar and lipid metabolism, although this issue is still being debated. While chromium metal and Cr(III) ions are considered non-toxic, hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)) is toxic and carcinogenic. Obsolete chromium production sites often require environmental cleaning. Chromium is amazing for its magnetic properties: it is the only solid element that exhibits a degree of antiferromagnetism at room temperature (and below). Above 38°C, it becomes paramagnetic. Chromium metal left in the open air is passivated by oxidation, forming a thin protective surface layer. This layer is a spinel structure only a few molecules thick. It is very dense, and prevents the diffusion of oxygen into the underlying metal.

This is different from the oxides that form on the surface of iron and carbon steel, in which elemental oxygen is constantly migrating, reaching the metal underneath where it causes ongoing rusting. Passivation can be enhanced by brief contact with an oxidizing acid such as nitric acid. Passivated chromium is stable to acids. Passivation can be removed by strong reducing agents which destroy the protective oxide layer on the metal. Chromium metal that has been given this treatment is easily soluble in weak acids. Chromium, unlike similar metals such as iron and nickel, is not affected by hydrogen embrittlement. However it is affected by nitrogen embrittlement, reacting with nitrogen from water and forming brittle nitrides at high temperatures which are part of metal works. Chromium is the 22nd most abundant element in the Earth's crust with an average concentration of 100 ppm. Chromium compounds are found in the environment from erosion of chromium-containing rocks, and can be disseminated by volcanic eruptions. Typical background chromium concentrations in environmental media are: atmosphere <10 ngˑm−3; soil <500 mgˑkg−1; vegetation <0.5 mgˑkg−1; fresh water <10 ugˑL−1; seawater <1 ugˑL−1; sediment <80 mgˑkg−1. Chromium is mined as chromite ore (FeCr). About two-fifths of the world's chromite ores and concentrates are produced in South Africa, while Kazakhstan, India, Russia and Turkey are also substantial producers. Untapped chromite deposits are abundant, but geographically concentrated in Kazakhstan and southern Africa. Native chromium deposits exist, although they are rare. Udachnaya Pipeline in Russia produces natural metal samples. The mine is a kimberlite pipe, rich in diamonds, and the reducing environment helps to produce both elemental chromium and diamond. The relationship between Cr(III) and Cr(VI) is highly dependent on the pH and oxidative properties of the sites.

– on the European continent  (light green & dark gray)– in the United Kingdom  (light green) England (English: England) is a constituent country which is part of the United Kingdom. The country is bordered by Scotland to the north and Wales to the west, the Irish Sea to the northwest, the Celtic Sea to the southwest, the North Sea to the east and the English Channel, which separates it from continental Europe, to the south. Most of England comprises the central and southern parts of the Island of Great Britain in the North Atlantic. England also includes more than 100 small islands such as the Isles of Scilly and the Isle of Wight. The area now known as England was first inhabited by modern humans during the Paleolithic period, but the name "England" derives from the word "Angles", who were one of the Germanic tribes that settled there in the 5th and 6th centuries. England became a unified nation in AD 927, and since the Age of Discovery which began in the 15th century, it has exerted significant cultural and legal influence on many parts of the world. The English language, the Anglican Church, and English law—which form the basis of the common law systems of other countries around the world—originated and developed in England, and the country's parliamentary system has also been widely adopted by other countries. The Industrial Revolution that started in the 18th century made England the first industrialized country in the world. The British Royal Society also played an important role in laying the foundations of modern experimental science for science and technology. England's topography consists mostly of hills and lowlands, especially in central and southern England. Uplands are found in the north (for example, the mountainous Lake District, Pennines, and the Yorkshire Dales) and in the southwest (for example, Dartmoor and the Cotswolds).

The former capital of England was Winchester, replaced by London in 1066. Today London is the largest metropolitan area in the United Kingdom and the largest urban zone in the European Union by area.note 3] The population of England is around 53 million, or about 84 % of the total population of the United Kingdom, most of which are concentrated in London, South East England, and the conurbation areas of the Midlands, North West, North East and Yorkshire, each of these areas developed as major industrial regions during the 19th century. While the prairie area is outside the area of ​​big cities. The Kingdom of England (after 1284 also including Wales) was a sovereign nation until 1 May 1707. Then the Act of Union which declared that the Kingdoms of England and Scotland were politically united to form the Kingdom of Great Britain was passed in 1707. In 1801, The United Kingdom united with the Kingdom of Ireland with the passage of the Act of Union 1800 and was later renamed the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. In 1922, the Irish Free State existed as a separate dominion, but six counties of Northern Ireland chose to remain part of the United Kingdom, which was renamed the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, in the context in which the country of Great Britain is known. until now. The name "England" comes from the Old English word Englaland, which means "land of the Angles". The Angles were one of the Germanic tribes that settled in Great Britain during the Early Middle Ages. The Angles originate from the Angeln peninsula in the Gulf of Kiel, in the Baltic Sea region. According to the Oxford English Dictionary, the first known use of "England" to refer to the southern part of the Island of Great Britain occurs in 897, and the modern spelling of the word was first used in 1538.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark gray)– in the African Union  (light blue) The Republic of the Sudan (Arabic: جمهورية السودان‎Jumhūrīyah as-Sūdān, English: Republic of the Sudan) is a country located in the northeast of the African continent. Prior to the general management of the Indonesian student federation, the referendum that separated Sudan into two parts, Sudan was the third largest country in Africa and the sixteenth largest in the world. The country is bordered by Egypt to the north, the Red Sea to the northeast, Eritrea to the east, Ethiopia to the southeast, Central Africa to the southwest, Chad to the west, Libya to the northwest, and South Sudan to the south. The Nile River which is the longest river in the world. As a member of the United Nations, Sudan is also a member of the Arab Union, the Arab League, the OIC, the Non-Aligned Movement and is also an observer at the WTO. The capital city of this country is Khartoum which is the center of politics, culture and commerce. While Omdurman is the largest city with a population of 42 million. Sunni Islam is the official and most professed religion while Arabic is the country's de jure official language and de facto English. Sudan is located in North Africa, with 853 km (530 mi) of coastline facing the Red Sea. It has land borders with Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia, South Sudan, Central African Republic, Chad and Libya. With an area of ​​1,886,068 km (728,215 sq mi), it is the third largest country on the African continent (after Algeria and the Democratic Republic of the Congo) and the sixteenth largest in the world. Sudan is located between latitudes 8° and 23° latitude. The area is plains and in some places there are mountains. In the west of Sudan is the Deriba Caldera (3042 m or 9980 ft), which is located on Mount Marrah, is the highest point in Sudan.

The Blue Nile and White Nile Rivers meet at Khartoum to form the Nile, which flows north through Egypt into the Mediterranean Sea. The Blue Nile runs through Sudan for 800 km (497 mi) in length and joins the Dinder and Rahad Rivers between Sennar and Khartoum. The White Nile has no significant tributaries as it flows through the Sudan. There are several dams on the Blue Nile and White Nile. Among them are the Sennar and Roseires Dams on the Blue Nile, and Jebel Aulia on the White Nile. There is also Lake Nubia on the Sudan-Egypt border. Mineral resources are available in abundance in Sudan such as asbestos, chromium, cobalt, copper, gold, granite, gypsum, iron, kaolin, tin, manganese, mica, natural gas, nickel, petroleum, silver, uranium and zinc. . Sudan is divided into 25 states which are further divided into 87 districts. In August 2005, Kurdufan West was disbanded and its territory was made part of Kurdufan South and Kurdufan North. In addition, there are 10 other states which since July 9, 2011 have become the state of South Sudan. Education in Sudan is free and compulsory for all children aged 6 to 13 years. Education starts from elementary education for eight years, then secondary education for three years. The education level was changed to 6 + 3 + 3 format in 1990. The language of instruction used at all levels is Arabic. School locations are concentrated in a number of urban areas, where a number of schools located in the South and West have been damaged or even destroyed by the conflict in the country. In 2001, the World Bank estimated that net enrollment of primary students was 46% and 21 per cent of secondary school enrollment consisted of eligible students.

Europe is geologically and geographically a peninsula or subcontinent (jazirah). Separation as a continent is more due to cultural differences. It is bounded to the north by the Arctic Ocean, to the west by the Atlantic Ocean, and to the south by the Mediterranean Sea. The eastern boundary is still unclear because the separation of the continent itself was initiated by cultural factors. The boundaries that are often used as the boundaries of the continents of Europe and Asia are the Ural Mountains and the Caspian Sea. This continent is the second smallest continent after Australia with an area of ​​10,355,000 km², while when calculated from its population, this continent is in third place with the most population (below Asia and Africa) with 742.5 million people in 2013 or equal to one eighth world population. The European continent is astronomically located at 35° N - 71° N and 11° West - 66° E. Europe has a long cultural and economic history, starting with the Palaeolithic. The recent discovery at Monte Poggiolo, Italy, of thousands of handcrafted rocks that are carbon dated as far back as 800,000 years ago, provides important evidence. The beginnings of Western democratic and individualistic culture are often attributed to Ancient Greece, although other influences, such as Christianity, also contributed to the spread of concepts such as egalitarianism and universality of law. The Roman Empire divided the continent along the Rhine and Danube for several centuries. Following the decline of the Roman Empire, Europe experienced the rise of what is known as the Age of Migration. The period is known as the Dark Ages right up to the Renaissance. During this time, isolated monastic communities in Ireland, and elsewhere guarded, and carefully amassed the written knowledge that had previously been accumulated. The Renaissance and New Monarchies marked the beginning of a period of discovery, exploration and increase in scientific knowledge.

In the 15th century Portugal opened the beginning of the discovery, which was followed by Spain. Later France, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom joined in building large colonial empires with vast territories in Africa, America and Asia. After a period of discovery, democratic concepts began to gain influence in Europe. Struggles for independence arose, especially in France during the period known as the French Revolution. This caused great upheaval in Europe as these revolutionary ideas spread across the continent. The rise of democracy caused increasing tensions in Europe in addition to the tensions that were already there because of competition in the New World. Of these, the most famous conflict was when Napoleon Bonaparte seized power, and created the French Empire which fell shortly thereafter. After these events, Europe has slowly stabilized, but the remnants of the old period concept have begun to crumble. The Industrial Revolution began in Great Britain at the end of the 18th century, which led to a shift away from agriculture, increasing public prosperity and population growth. Many countries in Europe found their present form post-World War II. Since the end of World War II until the Cold War, Europe was divided into two main political and economic blocs: the communist countries in Eastern Europe, and the capitalist countries in Western Europe. Around 1989, the East Bloc broke apart with the fall of the Berlin Wall. Geographically Europe is part of a larger landmass known as Eurasia. The continent begins with the Ural Mountains in Russia, which defines Europe's eastern boundary with Asia. The southeastern boundary with Asia is not clearly defined. Most common are the Ural River or the Emba River. The boundary continues with the Caspian Sea, and then the Caucasus Mountains, or the Kuma-Manych Depression, and all the way to the Black Sea; The Bosporus, Sea of ​​Marmara and Dardanelles end the boundaries of Asia.

The Republic of Haiti (French: République d'Haïti, Haitian Creole: Repiblik Ayiti) is a country in the Caribbean that includes the western half of the island of Hispaniola and several other smaller islands in the Caribbean Sea. Haiti is the second independent country in the Americas after the United States. The country is also one of the most important sugar producers in the world. Haiti is also one of the poorest countries in the world. Especially after being hit by a great earthquake in 2009 which caused the country's economy to fall apart. Haiti has been inhabited by humans starting around 8,800 years ago by ancestral Indian tribes, who later adapted and developed their own culture and became the Caribbean Indians. 16, since then stories about the Haitian Carribean Indian Tribe, culture and natural wealth began to be heard throughout Europe, then the King and Queen of the Kingdom of Spain sent thousands of troops there to ensure that Haiti really existed, and conquered it. After the Spanish conquest. France tried to seize it with the Conquest of Haiti by France, and after being conquered by France, Haiti was increasingly destroyed because of increased slavery and Haitian slaves trying to liberate Haiti with the Haitian Revolution 1791 - 1804. current dollars and a 90% discount on all goods owned by Haiti which makes it difficult for Haiti to pay its debts. Experts criticized this action, because of the actions taken by France, now Haiti is a poor and underdeveloped country. Haiti is divided into 10 departments, 41 arrondissement, 331 communes. The following departments are in Haiti: This article on the geography or place of Haiti is a stub.

Moggallana (Pali: Moggallāna; Sanskrit: Maudgalyayana; Hanyu: 目連 Mulian; Japanese: 目犍連 Mokuren), also known as Mahamoggallāna or Mahamaudgalyayana, was one of Siddhartha Gautama Buddha's closest disciples. Among such famous Arhats as Subhuti, Sariputta and Mahakasyapa, he is considered the second foremost disciple of the Buddha, along with Sariputta. Moggallana was a disciple of the Buddha who possessed the most powerful abilities compared to the other disciples. His abilities include the ability to read minds to tell lies from the truth, get out of his physical body and visit various planes of existence, talk to the spirits and gods. It can also do things like walk through walls, walk on water, fly through the air, and move faster than the speed of light. Various Suttas in the Tipitaka indicate that Moggalla spoke to the souls of the dead to explain to them the terrible state they were in and to give them an understanding of their own misery, so that they could either be liberated or accept it. Moggallana could also use his mind-reading ability to give good and suitable opinions to his disciples, so that they achieved immediate results. Moggallana who was close friends with Sariputta since childhood began their many years of spiritual quest. As their search together yielded no results, they finally decided to go in search of the correct teachings separately and promised each other to tell each other whoever found the teachings first would quickly tell the others. On this occasion, Moggallan was not fortunate enough to meet the ascetic Assaji. It was Sariputta who first found the ascetic Assaji and succeeded in attaining the stream entry (Sotapatti) stage. As soon as Sariputta discovered the teaching, he immediately reported it to Moggallana.

After Moggallana heard the verse repeated by Sariputta, he too immediately attained stream entry. As for the famous verse of the ascetic Assaji, it is as follows: "Of all things that arise due to a condition, the condition has been announced by the Tathagata, as well as its ending. This is what the Great Ascetic (Buddha Gotama) teaches." This illustrates that Sariputta attained stream-entry from an Arahant, whereas Moggallana attained stream-entry only through an ordinary lay follower, namely his own friend. Maudgalyayana's demise came when he was traveling in Magadha. Some argue that religious worshipers stoned him to death, others say that his death was caused by thieves. It is well known that Moggallana's death was brutal. When asked why Moggallana had not protected himself with his supernatural powers, and why a great Arahant had suffered such a brutal death, the Buddha said that Moggallana had had heavy karmic actions in his previous life (he had killed his own parents and it is one of the gravest misdeeds), he sincerely accepts the fruit of his deed and hastens such a death, so that it occurs as quickly as possible. Further, the Buddha stated that even supernormal powers will be of little or no use to oneself in avoiding their karma, especially when it is so heavy. The Ullambana Sutta is the Sutra of the Mahayana sect to which Moggallana is mentioned. This sutra deals with the topic of being kind to parents, and is a discourse Buddha Shakyamuni gave to Moggallana. In Japan, Ullambana was the basis for the Obon sect, which shares Confucian and Neo-Confucian understandings of ancestor worship. It is because of this that Ullambana is often the subject of criticism, and is often called inauthentic because the teachings of Confucianism are often not in accordance with the teachings of the Buddha.

Woman is a term for the human gender that is different from men. In Sanskrit the word woman is taken from the word per + empu + an. Per, means creature, and empu, which means noble, master, skilled. Thus women can be interpreted as beings who have nobility or ability. Women have organs of the female reproductive system, namely the ovaries, uterus and vagina, and are capable of producing gamete cells called eggs. Women also have the ability to menstruate, get pregnant, give birth, and breastfeed. The term "woman" is generally used for people of all ages. The general term for female adults is called a woman. Meanwhile, the term for a child who is female is called "daughter", "girl", or "girl". In Indonesia, a more polite greeting or address for respected or older women is "mother", or other greetings according to the local language of each region. The opposite sex of women is men.
