According to popular theory, the word "female" comes from the word "empu" in Old Javanese, which was later absorbed into Malay, meaning "lord, noble, respect". The word master was affixed with the addition of "per-" and "-an" which then formed the word "female". Some sources also state that the word empu in women is related to the word ampu which means "support, support". The word "woman" comes from the Sanskrit word vanita, which literally means "to be desired". Certain religious doctrines have specific provisions relating to gender roles, social and personal interactions between the sexes, appropriate clothing for women, and various other issues affecting women and their position in society. In many countries, these religious teachings influence the criminal or family law of those jurisdictions (see Islamic law, for examples).

An ion is an atom or molecule that has a non-zero total electric charge (the total number of electrons is not the same as the total number of protons). Cations are positively charged ions, while anions are negatively charged ions. Therefore, a cation molecule has a hydrogen proton without an electron, whereas an anion has an extra electron. Because of their opposite electrical charges, cations and anions are attracted to each other and easily form ionic compounds. Ions containing only one atom are called monatomic ions or atomic ions, while those containing two or more atoms form molecular ions or polyatomic ions. In the case of physical ionization in a medium, such as a gas, "ion pairs" are created by collisions of ions, where each pair formed contains a free electron and a positive ion. Ions are also created through chemical interactions, for example dissolving a salt in a liquid, or alternatively, passing a direct current through a conducting solution dissolves the anode via ionization. The word ion comes from the Greek: ἰόν, ion, "is going", the verb being forms from the Greek: ἰέναι, ienai, "goes". The term was introduced by the English physicist and chemist Michael Faraday in 1834 to describe an unknown species that travels from one electrode to another via an aqueous medium. Faraday did not know the nature of these species, but he did know that when a metal dissolves into and enters the solution at one electrode, a new metal arises from the solution at the other electrode; the substance has moved through the solution in a current. It carries matter from one place to another. Faraday also introduced the words anion for a negatively charged ion, and a cation for a positively charged ion.

In Faraday nomenclature, cations are so named because they are attracted to the cathode in a galvanic device and anions are so named because they are attracted to the anode. Svante Arrhenius proposed his explanation, in his 1884 dissertation, that in fact solid crystalline salts dissociate into pairs of charged particles when dissolved. This dissertation earned Arrhenius the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1903. Arrhenius' explanation was that in forming a solution, the salt dissociates into Faraday ions. Arrhenius proposed that ions were formed even in the absence of an electric current. Ions in their gaseous state are highly reactive and will quickly interact with ions with opposite charges to produce neutral molecules or ionic salts. Ions are also produced in the liquid or solid state when salts interact with a solvent (eg, water) to produce "solvated ions", which are more stable. The ions move away from each other to interact with the liquid for reasons that involve changes in energy and entropy. These stabilized species are more common in low temperature environments. A common example is the ions found in seawater, which come from dissolved salts. All ions have a charge, which means that, like other charged objects, they: Electrons, due to their small mass and large space-occupying properties, are considered matter waves. It determines the entire size of atoms and molecules that have electrons. Anions (negatively charged ions) are larger than the parent molecule or atom, because the excess electrons repel each other thereby increasing the physical size of the ion, and its size is determined by its electron cloud. Thus, in general, cations are smaller than their parent atoms or molecules because the size of their electron cloud is also smaller. The hydrogen cation has no electrons at all, so it only has a single proton - much smaller than the hydrogen atom.

Train à Grande Vitesse ("high-speed train") or commonly abbreviated as TGV is a high-speed train originating from France. The train was developed by Alstom and SNCF, and is operated by SNCF, the French National Rail Company. This train connects major cities in France, especially Paris, and also neighboring countries, such as Belgium, Germany, and Switzerland. TGV or TGV-based trains also operate in the Netherlands, South Korea, Spain, the United Kingdom and the United States. In France, TGVs have operated on special high-speed lines (LGV, Ligne à Grande Vitesse) since 1981. Most TGVs function as passenger trains, but there is also a variety of TGVs used for mail delivery between Paris and Lyon. The TGV network has penetrated into neighboring countries either directly (Italy, Spain, Belgium, Luxembourg and Germany) or through the TGV derivative network connecting France with Switzerland (Lyria), to Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands (Thalys), as well as to the United Kingdom (Eurostar). Cities such as Tours and Le Mans have become part of the "TGV commuter belt" around Paris; TGV also serves Charles de Gaulle Airport and Lyon–Saint-Exupéry Airport. The TGV users usually stop at Disneyland Paris or in tourist cities such as Avignon and Aix-en-Provence. Brest, Chambéry, Nice, Toulouse and Biarritz can be reached by TGV which uses a mix of LGV fleets and modern lines. In 2007, SNCF made a profit of €1.1 billion (about US$1.75 billion, £875 million), largely driven by higher margins on the TGV network. The TGV idea was first proposed in the 1960s. The first prototype, known as the TGV 001, used a gas turbine and produced its own electricity from oil, but after the 1973 energy crisis and the high increase in oil prices, this idea was deemed impractical.

The first electric prototype was completed in 1974, with the final version delivered in 1980 and the first service opened to the public between Paris and Lyon on 27 September 1981. Since then, other lines to Tours/Le Mans, Calais, Brussels and Marseille have been opened. The line to Strasbourg is under construction. There are also other lines out of France that are currently under construction to London, Cologne and Amsterdam. Further expansion into Spain and Italy is still being planned. The TGV was not the first high-speed train, as the Japanese Shinkansen connecting Tokyo and Osaka had been open since October 1, 1964, almost 17 years earlier than the TGV. TGV is the record holder for conventional electric trains, where on April 3 2007 the TGV train on the LGV Est line recorded a speed of 574.8 km/hour in a project test for the V150 variant of the TGV type. This TGV train has a semi-permanent shape with two powered trains at each end, using Jacobs bogies in each train set, making it easier for the train to run smoothly. And at the end of the series, the train has its own bogie. TGV trains can be extended with a series of two other TGVs together, by means of a hidden coupler located at the muzzle (nose) of the TGV train. This design is intended to be advantageous during travel, so that the train can run smoothly on the rails and not deviate from the track. Ordinary trains, on the other hand, can be assembled using couplers and jack-knife, as happened in the train disaster at Eschede. The downside to this train design is that it is difficult to divide train sets. While the TGV electric trains can be removed from the main train by standard uncoupling procedures, special depot equipment is required to split the trains, by lifting the trains all at once.

In Christian theology, remorse or remorse is a feeling of sadness or distress in one's heart because of the sins one has committed, accompanied by a desire not to do them again. The English word contrition or contriteness comes from the Latin word contritus 'crushed to pieces', which means to be crushed with guilt. In english says contrition Archived 2017-03-27 at the Wayback Machine. or permanently disabled link remorse] often synonymous with repentance Archived 2017-03-27 at the Wayback Machine. which generally translates to repentance in Indonesian. As a central concept in much of Christianity, contrition is seen as the first step, through Christ, toward reconciliation with God. This concept includes one's remorse for all one's sins, a desire for God rather than sin, and faith in Christ's atonement on the cross and its sufficiency for salvation (cf. regeneration and ordo salutis). Regret can be found in various parts of the Bible, for example Ezekiel 33:11, Psalm 6:7 etc., Psalm 51:1-12, Luke 13:5, Luke 18:9-13, and the parable of the prodigal son (Luke 15:11 -32). The Council of Trent defines contrition as "grief of the soul, and an abhorrence for sins committed, with a firm intention not to sin in the future". This hatred of sin can arise for various motives, for various reasons. Inner contrition is accompanied by a beneficent anguish and pain, which the Church Fathers called animi cruciatus (sorrow of the spirit) and compunctio cordis (remorse of the heart). The word regret implies the breaking or breaking of something that has hardened. St. Thomas Aquinas in his Commentary on Sententiarum thus explains its specific usage: "Since it is required for remission of sins, that one completely abandons sinful pleasures which implies a kind of continuity and stability in one's mind, this act for which forgiveness is obtained is figuratively termed 'repentance'".

This sadness or sorrow of the soul is not just a speculative sadness for the wrong done, remorse of conscience, or a determination to make changes, but is a real pain and trembling of the soul accompanied by a sense of hatred and horror for the sin committed. The feeling of hatred for the sin causes a person to be determined not to sin again. The early Christian writers, when talking about the nature of regret, sometimes emphasized the feeling of sadness, sometimes disgust for the wrong done. St. Augustine included both when he wrote: "Compunctus corde non solet dici nisi stimulus peccatorum in dolore pœnitendi". Almost all medieval theologians were of the view that the main regret was based on abhorrence or hatred of sin. Such hatred presupposes that one has a knowledge of the horrors of sin, and this knowledge produces sorrow and pain in the soul. "A sin is committed by the consent of the will], so it is covered by the argument of the rational will; then regret is basically sadness. But it should be noted that sadness has a double meaning--the argument of the will and the feeling that arises; the first mentioned is the essence of regret, the last mentioned is the impact". The official teaching or doctrine of the Church, presented in the Council of Trent, states that repentance is always necessary for a person to obtain forgiveness for his sins. Repentance is the first condition and must to obtain forgiveness. It is possible for a person to receive forgiveness when sacramental confession is not possible, but it is impossible for a person to receive forgiveness for his sins without repentance. According to the Catholic Encyclopedia, Catholic writers always emphasize that the need or necessity arises: (a) from the nature of repentance itself and (b) from God's positive command. In terms of the nature of the repentance, they emphasize that the words of Christ in Luke 13:5 are absolute: "... if you do not repent, you will all perish...", and from the Church Fathers they quote the following sentence from St. . Ciprianus, De Lapsis no.32: "Practice complete repentance, give evidence of the sorrow that comes from a sorrowful and lamenting soul ... those who put away remorse for sin, close the door to reconciliation."

Parthenogenesis (from Greek παρθένος parthenos, "virgin", + γένεσις genesis, "manufacturing") is the growth and development of an embryo or seed without fertilization by a male. Parthenogenesis occurs naturally in several species, including lower plants, invertebrates (examples of water fleas, aphids, and some bees), and vertebrates (examples of some reptiles, fish, and, very rarely, birds, and sharks). Parthenogenesis is a form of reproduction asexual namely the ability of an ovum to develop into a new individual without being fertilized by sperm. An example of parthenogenesis is in bees. Ovum that comes from a female bee if it is not fertilized by sperm will become a new individual, namely a male individual. Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction in which the female produces eggs that develop without going through the process of fertilization. We can see parthenogenesis in aphids, bees, water fleas, and several other invertebrates, as well as in some plants. It turns out that Komodo dragons and sharks are also capable of parthenogenetic reproduction, along with several genera of fish, amphibians and reptiles - which have shown different forms of asexual reproduction, including true parthenogenesis, gynogenesis and hybridogenesis (an imperfect form of parthenogenesis). Alternating between parthenogenesis and sexual reproduction is called heterogamy. Forms of reproduction related to parthenogenesis but requiring sperm are called gynogenesis and hybridogenesis. The form of asexual reproduction associated with parthenogenesis is gynogenesis. Offspring are produced by the same mechanism as in parthenogenesis, but with the provision that the egg must be stimulated in the presence of sperm so that it can develop. However, sperm cells do not contribute any genetic material to the offspring. In reproduction hybridogenesis reproduction is not strictly asexual but rather hemiclonal. Chromosome pairs from the mother are paired with their (similar) copies which can be described as half clones.

Nepal or the official name of the Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal is a landlocked country in South Asia. It is mainly located in the Himalayas, but also includes part of the Indo-Gangetic Plain, bordered by Tibet, China to the north and India to the south, while separated to the east and west by Bangladesh. Nepal has a diverse geography, including fertile plains, forested hills and eight of the ten highest mountains in the world including Mount Everest are in Nepal. Nepal is a multi-ethnic, multi-lingual, multi-religious and multi-cultural country with Nepali as its official language. Kathmandu is the country's capital and the country's largest city. The word "Nepal" is believed by scholars to have come from the word "Nepa:" which refers to the Newar Kingdom. In Sanskrit (Atharvaveda Parisista) and Gupta period inscriptions, the country is referred to as Nepala. Newars in Nepal, inhabitants of the Kathmandu Valley and its accoutrements, were referred to as "Nepa:" before the rise of the Shah dynasty. Local legend says that a Hindu sage named "Ne" stood alone in the Kathmandu valley in prehistoric times and that the word "Nepal" arose as a place of refuge ("nutmeg" in Sanskrit) by the sage "Ne". The folk etymology of this Nepali name means, "country nurtured by Ne". He is said to have performed religious ceremonies at Teku, at the confluence of the Bagmati and Bishnumati rivers and to have chosen a pious cowherd to be the first of the many kings of the Gopala dynasty. He is a ruler said to have ruled Nepal for over 500 years. He chose Bhuktaman to be the first king in the line of the Gopala (cowherd) dynasty. The Gopala dynasty is said to have ruled for 621 years. Yakshya Gupta was the last king of this dynasty.

However, according to the Skanda Purana, Rishis called "Ne" or "Nemuni" used to live in the Himalayas. In the Pashupati Purana, He is touted as a saint and protector. He is said to have practiced meditation at the Bagmati and Kesavati rivers and to have taught there. Neolithic tools found in the Kathmandu Valley show that humans have lived in the Himalayan region for around 11,000 years. Nepal is first mentioned in the Atharvaveda Pariśiṣṭa as a place that exported blankets. This place is also mentioned in the Atharvashirsha Upanishad. In Samudragupta's Allahabad Pillars, Nepal is referred to as a border country. The Skanda Purana also has a separate chapter, known as the "Nepal Mahatmya", which details the beauty and power of Nepal. Nepal is also mentioned in Hindu texts, for example Narayana Puja. Legends and ancient texts that mention the area now known as Nepal date back to the 30th century BC. The Gopal Bansa were probably one of the earliest inhabitants of the Kathmandu valley. Nepal's earliest rulers were the Kirata (Kirata Kingdom), a people often mentioned in Hindu texts. They ruled Nepal for centuries. Various sources state the existence of at least 32 Kirata kings. Around 600 BC, there were various small kingdoms and clan confederations in southern Nepal. From one of these, the city of Shakya, was born a prince who renounced his status to embrace the ascetic life, founded Buddhism, and became known as Gautama Buddha (traditionally, he is known to have lived 623-543 BC). In 250 BC, the southern regions came under the influence of the Maurya Kingdom from North India. Later, this area became a tributary kingdom of the Gupta Kingdom in the 4th century BC. The kingdom of Nepal is described in detail in the writings of a Chinese Buddhist monk, Xuanzang, which are known to date from around 645.

– in the Continental Europe  (camel & white)– in the United Kingdom    (camel) Wales (Welsh: Cymru) is a constituent country of the sovereign nation of Great Britain. Despite using the name 'Prince of Wales', this practice of governance is questionable as the Prince of Wales has no role whatsoever in governing the country. The Roman Empire once conquered this area, giving Wales its name: Cambria, which is probably the Latin form of Cymru. It is even said that Magnus Maximus, one of the last emperors, married Elen or Helen, daughter of a Welsh chief from Segontium, now called Caernarfon. Wales was never conquered by the Anglo-Saxon peoples when Great Britain was invaded in the 7th century AD thanks to the fierce resistance of the local population. A Saxon King; Offa of Mercia, is said to have built a gigantic wall along the borders of his kingdom to mark a large area called Powys that had been taken from the Welsh. Parts of “Offa's Dyke” (Offa's Dyke) can still be seen today. When the Normans led by (William the Conqueror) defeated king Harold at Hastings, England and conquered them in 1066, Wales had not yet been conquered. Wales was only defeated in 1282 when, King Edward I of England defeated Prince Llywelyn the Last, the last independent prince of Wales. To control the Welsh people the English built many castles such as at Caernarfon, Conway and Harlech. After the defeat of the Last Count of Llywelyn, the English gradually expanded their power until, in 1536, the "Act of Union" Wales was united with England and divided into 13 counties which roughly translate to counties, namely Anglesey, Brecon, Caernarfon, Cardigan, Carmarthen, Denbigh, Flint, Glamorgan, Merioneth, Monmouth, Montgomery, Pembroke and Radnor.

At that time English Law was enforced in Wales and Welsh was forbidden to use in official situations. Welsh people for the most part were also denied official office. Wales was considered part of England and then Great Britain until 1955, when Cardiff was declared the capital. Then in 1999 "The National Assembly for Wales" (Parliament of Wales) was established. Wales occupies approximately one-tenth of the total area of ​​the United Kingdom, with an area of ​​approximately 20,779 square kilometers (8,020 sq mi). Wales' topography is mostly mountainous, only the South Wales area is less mountainous than North and Central Wales. The main residential and industrial areas are located in South Wales, which includes the coastal cities of Cardiff, Swansea and Newport, as well as the South Wales Valleys area to the north of these cities. The highest mountains in Wales are in Snowdonia, including Mount Snowdon (Welsh: Yr Wyddfa), which at around 1,085 meters (3,560 ft) is the highest peak in Wales. There are 14 (or 15) mountains in Wales that reach 3,000 feet (914 m) high. These mountains are collectively known as the Welsh 3000s. Wales has more than 1,200 km (750 miles) of coastline. There are several islands located close to mainland Wales; the largest is Anglesey (Ynys Môn) in the northwest. Local government in Wales consists of 22 unitary authorities. These authorities include the cities of Cardiff, Swansea and Newport which have separate powers over their jurisdictions. General elections are held every four years using a majority voting system. The last elections were held in May 2008. The Welsh Local Government Association represents the interests of local authorities in Wales.

Taxonomy (from the Greek τάξις taxis meaning "grouping" and νόμος nomos meaning "rules") is the science of grouping things according to certain things. Originally, taxonomy referred only to the categorization of living things. However, in a broader and more general sense, taxonomy can also refer to the categorization of objects or concepts, as well as the principles that underlie this categorization. Many taxonomies have a hierarchical structure, but this is not a requirement. The taxonomy uses a unit known as a taxon (plural: taxa). Higher taxa are more general, while lower taxa are more specific. Taxonomy is different from menonomy, which deals with the categorization of parts of the whole. In biology, taxonomy is also a separate branch of science that studies the classification or systematics of living things. The system used is a two-name nomenclature, known as the binomial nomenclature proposed by Carl von Linne (Latin: Carolus Linnaeus), a Swedish naturalist. He introduced seven hierarchies (levels) to classify living things. The seven hierarchies (which are called taxons) successively from the highest level (general) to the lowest (specific) are: In binomial nomenclature, the name of a species is sufficient only to mention the surname (always starting with a capital letter) and the type designator (always starting with in lowercase) in italics (printed upright if the main text is italicized) or written in underlined. This rule should not be confusing because surnames cannot be the same for other higher taxa levels. Further development of knowledge forced the creation of a new taxon among the six existing ones (using the prefixes 'super-' and 'sub-'). In the branch of soil science (pedology), soil taxonomy is made based on a number of variables that characterize the state of a soil type.

Jersey (Jerriais: Jèrri) is a British crown dependency with bailiwick status off the coast of Normandy, France. Besides Jersey Island, this bailiwick also consists of the uninhabited islands of Minquiers and Ecrehous. Jersey, together with Bailiwick Guernsey, forms the Channel Islands. The United Kingdom is responsible for the defense of these islands. But Jersey is not part of British territory or the European Union, but a separate possession. Jersey was annexed by William Longsword, ruler of the Duchy of Normandy, in 933. His descendant, William the Conqueror, conquered England in 1066 resulting in the Duchy of Normandy and the kingdom of England being ruled in a form of monarchy. King John lost all of his lands in mainland Normandy in 1204 to the King of France, but retained control of the Channel Islands which have since been self-governing. Jersey was occupied by Nazi Germany from 1 May 1940 to 9 May 1945 during World War II. The Island of Jersey is 118.2 km² in area and is located in the English Channel, about 22.5 km from the Cotentin Peninsula in Normandy, France. It is the largest and southernmost island in the Channel Islands. Jersey's economy relies on financial services, tourism, the internet and agriculture. Value added tax (VAT) is not enforced on the island, so luxury items are often cheaper than in the UK. On May 13, 2005, the Jersey parliament approved the introduction of a goods and services tax effective from 2008. The main agricultural products are potatoes and milk. About 50% of Jersey's population is not indigenous. 30% of the population is concentrated in Saint Helier, the only town in Jersey. Of the 88,000 inhabitants, 40% are of Jersey/Norman descent and another 40% are of British descent. The largest minority groups are the British, Portuguese (especially Madeira), Irish and Poles.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union   (light blue) The Republic of Niger (French: République du Niger, Hausa language: Jamhuriyar Nijar) is a landlocked country in western Africa. Niger is bordered by Nigeria and Benin to the south; Mali to the west; Algeria and Libya in the north; and Chad to the east. The country's name is taken from the Niger River. Its capital is Niamey. Niger is a developing country, and is a country ranked 188th in the United Nations Human Development Index. Most of Niger's non-desert areas are threatened with periodic droughts and desertification. The center of economic activity is concentrated around the fertile lands of the south of the country, the export of raw materials, especially uranium ore. Niger faces serious challenges to development due to its landlocked position, poor education and poverty of its people, lack of infrastructure, poor health care and various environmental problems. Since independence, Nigeria has lived under five constitutions and three periods of military rule. After the military coup in 2010, Niger has become a democratic, multi-party state. The majority live in rural areas, and have little access to further education. Residents of Niger are called Nigerien to distinguish it from Nigerian which applies to residents of Nigeria. Stone tools, some dating from 280,000 BC, were found at Adrar Bous, Bilma and Djado in the northern Agadez Region. Some of these finds are associated with the Aterian and Mousterian tool culture of the Middle Paleolithic period, which flourished in North Africa around 90,000 BC–20,000 BC. In 4000–2800 BC the Sahara began to dry up, causing people to migrate to the South and East. At least in the 5th century BC the area that was later called Niger was once a trans-Saharan trading area.

Presided over by the Tuareg tribe from the North, camels are used as a means of transportation through the desert region. This mobility, which would continue throughout the centuries, was accompanied by further migration to the South and admixture between sub-Saharan and North African populations, and the spread of Islam. He was helped by the events of the Arab invasion of North Africa in the 7th century, which resulted in the movement of population to the South. Empires and kingdoms existed in the Sahel during this era. Niger is a landlocked country in West Africa situated along the border between the Sahara and Sub-Saharan regions. It is bordered by Nigeria and Benin to the south, Burkina Faso and Mali to the west, Algeria and Libya to the north and Chad to the east. Niger lies between latitudes 11° and 24° latitude, and longitudes 0° and 16° east. The territory of Niger has an area of ​​1,267,000 square kilometers (489,191 sq mi) with an inland area of ​​water (116 sq mi). It is less than twice the size of France, and the twenty-second largest country in the world. Niger borders seven countries and has a total perimeter of 5,697 km (3,540 miles). The longest borders are with Nigeria to the south (1,497 km or 930 miles), Chad to the east with a border length of 1175 km (730 miles), Algeria to the north-northwest with a long border (956 km or 594 miles), and Mali with a long border 821 km (510 miles). Niger also has small borders on the southwest with Burkina Faso at 628 km (390 mi) and Benin at 266 km (165 mi) and in the north-northeast with Libya at 354 km (220 mi).

Nickel is a metallic chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Ni and atomic number 28. Nickel is a silvery-white metal with a slight golden tinge. Nickel is a transition metal, and has hard and ductile properties. Nickel also belongs to the iron-cobalt group of metals, which can yield very valuable alloys. Pure nickel is powdered to maximize reactive surface area, has significant chemical activity, but large pieces react slowly with air under normal conditions because an oxidized layer forms on the surface and prevents further corrosion (passivation). However, pure nickel is only found in small quantities in the Earth's crust, usually in ultrabasic rocks, and in iron or siderite meteorites that were not exposed to oxygen while outside the Earth's atmosphere. Nickel in meteorites was found along with iron, which came from supernovae. An iron–nickel mixture is thought to make up the Earth's outer core and inner core. The use of nickel (as a nickel-iron alloy) dates back to 3500 BC. Nickel was first classified as a chemical element in 1751 by Axel Fredrik Cronstedt, who initially mistook the ore for the mineral copper, in the cobalt mines of Los, Hälsingland, Sweden. The element's name comes from the mischievous fairy from German miners' mythology, Nickel (similar to Old Nick), who personified the fact that copper–nickel ores could not be refined into copper. An economically important source of nickel is the limonite iron ore, which contains 1–2% nickel. Other important nickel ore minerals include pentlandite and a naturally occurring nickel-rich mixture of silicates known as garnierite. The main production sites are located in the Sudbury region in Canada (which is thought to have come from a meteorite), New Caledonia and Norilsk in Russia.

Nickel is slowly oxidized by air at normal temperatures and is considered corrosion resistant. Historically, nickel was used for plating iron and brass, coating chemical equipment, and making certain alloys that retain a high silver polish, such as German silver. About 9% is used for corrosion resistant nickel coating. Nickel-plated objects sometimes trigger a nickel allergy. Nickel is widely used in coins, although rising prices have led to its replacement by cheaper metals in recent years. Nickel is one of four elements (the others being iron, cobalt and gadolinium) that are ferromagnetic at normal temperatures. Nickel-containing Alnico permanent magnets are intermediate in strength between ferrous permanent magnets and rare earth magnets. The combination of nickel, chromium and iron produces stainless steel which is widely applied to kitchen utensils (spoon and cooking utensils), home and building ornaments, as well as industrial components. Nickel is important in modern times, especially for alloying; about 68% is used for stainless steel. 10% is used for nickel–copper alloys, 7% for alloy steel, 3% for casting, 9% for plating and 4% in other uses, which include the fast growing battery sector. As a compound, nickel has uses in the manufacture of specialty chemicals, such as catalysts for hydrogenation (Raney nickel is used for this), cathodes for batteries, pigments, and metal surface treatment. Nickel is an important nutrient for some microorganisms and plants that have enzymes with nickel as their active site. Nickel is a silvery-white metal with a slight golden tinge of high polish. It is one of four elements that can become magnetized at or near room temperature, along with iron, cobalt, and gadolinium, when held in close proximity to a magnet.

Utah is a state in the western United States, in the Rocky Mountains region. Its capital is Salt Lake City. The state had a population of 2,351,467 in 2003 according to United States Census Bureau estimates. This state is rugged and dry, and has spectacular natural landscapes. It is a popular tourist destination in summer and winter. Salt Lake City, the ski resorts of the Wasatch Range, and national parks to the south are the most popular places. The name Utah comes from the Southern Ute language and means "high above". Paiute, Navajo, and Goshute also inhabit parts of the state. Utah is the center of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS or Mormon Church), to which an estimated 60% of the population is a member, the LDS Church has a strong cultural influence, being one of only two states where gambling is illegal. Residents are called Utahn. Salt Lake City hosted the 2002 Winter Olympics, which gave the state's tourism industry (especially its ski resorts) a major boost. Religious affiliation of Utah residents according to WorldAtlas Religion The majority of religious adults in Utah are Christian (73%) of which 7% are evangelical Protestant, 6% are mainline Protestant, 5% are Catholic and 55% practice Mormonism, 4% adhere to another religion other than Christian while 22% have no religious affiliation. A large number of Utah people are members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS), popularly referred to as Mormons. About 55% of the country's population is said to be a member of a religion, the highest percentage in the country. Mormons make up between 34%-41% of Salt Lake City's population. The LDS Church has a high influence on the people of Utah and prefers conservatism to contemporaryism, a view clearly witnessed in the state's high birth rate which is 25% higher than the US average.

Food is a substance eaten by living things to get nutrients which are then processed into energy. Carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins and minerals are nutrients in food that are needed by the body. Liquids to be consumed are often referred to as drinks, but the word 'food' can also be used in its place. Food consumed by humans is called food, while food consumed by animals is called feed. The quality of a food can be judged from the food energy and shelf life it has. Inappropriate or insufficient food consumption will lead to malnutrition, and can have an impact on various health problems. In addition, some types of food can trigger food allergies when consumed by sensitive individuals. Foodstuffs are processed into a variety of different dishes and are characteristic of a culture or population in a particular geographical location. Food is a subject that is studied in various sciences, such as food science, nutrition or nutrition, and gastronomy. Most of the food comes from plants. Some foods are obtained directly from plants. Cereal grains are a staple food that provides more food energy worldwide than any other type of crop. Corn (maize), wheat and rice - in all their varieties - account for 87% of all grain production worldwide. Most of the grain produced worldwide is used as animal feed. Some foods that are not of animal or plant origin include various edible mushrooms, especially mushrooms. Fungi and bacteria are used in the preparation of fermented and pickled foods such as leavened bread, liqueurs, cheeses, pickles, kombucha and yogurt. Another example is blue-green algae such as Spirulina. Inorganic substances such as salt, baking soda and cream of tartar are used to preserve or modify chemicals.

Arte (Association Relative à la Télévision Européenne) is a French-German TV network. Declares itself as a European cultural channel and aims to promote quality programming especially regarding culture and arts. Its offices are located in Issy-les-Moulineaux near Paris, France, Strasbourg, France (headquarters) and Baden-Baden in Germany. As it is an international joint venture (an EEIG), the program caters to audiences from both countries. This resulted in double-title, double-dubbing and translation, using both languages ​​and two separate audio tracks (only one is available to air in France, but the other is selectable on digital satellite and cable television). Arte began broadcasting in 1992, under the socialist government, filling frequencies left by La Cinq, the first French language commercial television network (formed in 1986). Arte has survived the 1993 shift to a right-wing government and a number of changes. Programs created by Arte France were previously known as La Sept (La Société d'édition des programs de télévision, but this is also a play on words, making the name mean the seventh network and La Sept existed when the fifth network was still called La Cinq; makes satellite television programming at that time) and by ARTE Deutschland GmbH, a subsidiary of the two main German public TV networks ARD and ZDF. In France, in digital broadcasts, programming is permanently available (on digital cable, digital satellite and digital terrestrial television), but in analog broadcasts, it airs only in the afternoon, while France 5 operates the all-day frequency. Arte is more popular in France (about 5% market share) than Germany (about 1%), but in Germany the channel is experiencing a lot of competition. Arte is also available in Belgium and the Netherlands via cable. Arte is also an online radio website, called Arte Radio.

Labrador is the northern region of the Canadian provinces of Newfoundland and Labrador. separated from the island of Newfoundland by the Belle Isle Strait. It is the largest and northernmost geographic area in Atlantic Canada. Labrador occupies the eastern part of the Labrador Peninsula. This area is bordered on the west and south by the Canadian province of Quebec. Labrador also shares a small land border with the Canadian territory of Nunavut on Killiniq Island. Although Labrador is twice as large as the island of Newfoundland, it only has 8% of the province's population. The indigenous people of Labrador include the Northern Inuit of Nunatsiavut, Southern Inuit-Métis of Nunatukavut (NunatuKavut), and Innu. Many of Labrador's non-Aboriginal people did not permanently settle in Labrador until the natural resource developments of the 1940s and 1950s. Prior to the 1950s, very few non-aboriginal people lived in Labrador all year round. The few European immigrants who worked seasonally for foreign traders and brought their families were known as Settlers. Labrador has an irregular, large semi-triangular shape (see map at left) covering the easternmost part of Canada, a large geographical area with thin soils and abundant mineral resources. Its western border with Quebec is separated by drainage from the Labrador Peninsula. The land towards the Atlantic Ocean is part of Labrador, while the land towards Hudson Bay is part of Quebec. Labrador's northern climate is classified as arctic, while Southern Labrador's climate is classified as subarctic. Labrador can be divided into four geographical regions: the North Coast, Central Labrador, Western Labrador, and the South Coast. Each of those regions is described below. Average family income (CD10, CD11 refer to Census Divisions) Labrador is home to a number of fauna and flora species.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union  (light blue) The Republic of Madagascar (Malagasy: Repoblikan'i Madagascar, French: Republique de Madagascar) is an island nation in the Indian Ocean, off the east coast of Africa. The island of Madagascar is the fourth largest island in the world and the second largest archipelago in the world after Indonesia. In addition to the main island, several small islands in the vicinity also claim this republic, namely Juan de Nova Island, Europa Island, Glorioso Islands, Tromelin Island, and Bassas da India even though these islands belong to France. Although geographically adjacent to Africa, Madagascar's geological, biological and demographic history differs from that of the continent's mainland. If you visit this country, the atmosphere feels more like in Southeast Asia than Africa seen from the landscape, language, culture, and social conditions of the people. The name "Malagasy" is used to refer to the language and the nation. Geologically, Madagascar is on a separate plate from the main continent of Africa. First separated from the Indian subcontinent, the island is moving closer and closer to the continent. This island is an old continent, just like Australia, so the soil is deficient in minerals due to the absence of volcanic activity. Most of the soil is red, indicating a weathered state of the soil. As a result of hundreds of millions of years of isolation, the flora and fauna of Madagascar are very distinctive and many endemic species are found there. This situation is similar to what happened on the island of Sulawesi. The first humans to inhabit Madagascar came from the Archipelago, especially from South Kalimantan (Banjar tribe), and are thought to have been due to the trade relations of the Archipelago people to the east coast of Africa in the early centuries of the Christian era. Based on statistical and linguistic lexico evidence, the Malagasy language is still one of the closest to the Maanyan languages, and belongs to the Austronesian language family.

The Malagasy language is derived from the Southeastern Barito language, and the Ma'anyan language is its closest relative, with many Malay and Javanese loanwords. It is known that the Ma'anyan people were brought as laborers and slaves by the Malays and Javanese in their trading fleet, which reached Madagascar around AD 50-500. Indigenous ethnic groups such as Merina and Betsileo are speakers of Austronesian languages ​​with phenotypes that are often similar to those of the Indonesian and Filipino populations. Along with increased trade, people from the east coast of Africa migrated to this island. The present inhabitants of Madagascar are a mixture of both groups to varying degrees. Despite their different origins, all residents speak the same language, even though they have different dialects. Reference needed] In the Malagasy language, the island of Madagascar is called Madagascar and the people are called Malagasy. The island's title "Madagascar" is not of local origin but was popularized in the Middle Ages by Europeans. With an area of ​​592,800 square kilometers (228,900 sq mi), Madagascar is the 46th largest country in the world and the fourth largest island in the world. The country lies between the latitudes 12°S and 26°S, and 43°E and 51°E. The neighboring island countries are the French territory of Réunion and the country of Mauritius to the east, and the Comoros and the French territory of Mayotte to the northwest. The closest land country is Mozambique, located to the west. The breakup of the prehistoric continent of Gondwana separated Madagascar-Antarctica-India from the African-South American continent about 135 million years ago. Madagascar then broke away from India about 88 million years ago, so the island's plants and animals evolved in isolation. The east coast of the island is a narrow, steep slope containing much of the island's remaining tropical lowland forest.

A phenomenon (Greek: φαινόμενον, translit. phainómenon, lit. 'things that appear to be seen'; plural phenomena) is a fact or event that can be observed. The term came into use in modern philosophy with Immanuel Kant, who compared phenomena to noumena, which cannot be observed directly. Phenomena from the Greek; phainomenon, "what is seen", in Indonesian can mean: • symptoms, for example natural phenomena • things that are felt with the five senses • mystical or occult things • facts, reality, events Adjective derived word, phenomenal, means: "amazing". In popular usage, phenomenon often refers to an extraordinary event. The term is most often used to refer to events that initially contradict explanations or confuse observers. According to the Appearance Discourse Dictionary: In ordinary language, 'phenomena' refers to any incident that is worthy of note and investigation, usually an unexpected or unusual event, a person, or a fact that has special significance or vice versa. In modern philosophical usage, the term phenomenon means 'what is experienced based on reality'. In his inaugural dissertation entitled On Forms and Principles of a Reasonable and Understandable World, Immanuel Kant (1770) theorized that the human mind is limited to a logical world. Thus, the human mind can only interpret and understand events according to its physical appearance. He wrote that humans can infer as much as the senses can perceive, but not experience or feel the object itself. This may make sense in terms of a communication channel (epistemology) derived from an ensemble of reality-inputs (ontology), but not in the sense of exercising sober imagination (a-la Albert Einstein, for partial success). Thus, the term phenomenon refers to every event that deserves to be examined and investigated, especially processes and events that are very unusual or have special significance.

Sin (from Sanskrit: doṣa) is a term primarily used in a religious context to describe actions that violate the norms or rules set by God or Divine Revelation. In Buddhism, dosa (Pali: dosa; Sanskrit: dveṣa) means hatred, anger, destruction, dislike, displeasure, dissatisfaction, non-acceptance, which are classified as aversion. Sin is one of the causes of misconduct (akusalakamma) from the three initial evil beginnings or the three roots of evil (Pali: ti akusalamūla; Sanskrit: tri akushalamūla) consisting of lobha, dosa and moha. "So has the Sri Blessed One said, monks, these three are the beginnings of evil. What are these three? The beginning of the evil of greed (lobha), the beginning of the evil of hate (dosa), and the beginning of the evil of delusion (moha). These, monks, are the three evil beginnings. Thus it has been explained by Sri Bhagava. In connection with this He said: Greed, hatred and delusion, arising from within him, do harm to one who has an evil mind, just as the bamboo shoot destroys the very growth of the tree.” (Mūla Sutta) Sin is thirsting or craving for the absence or non-existence of something by wanting not to have it or not experiencing it over and over, over and over again, from what already exists. In other words, there is a strong rejection of something that is not liked. When a person is sinful, controlled by hatred, with a mind dominated by hatred, then he causes suffering to himself and others by doing evil. It is natural that everyone still has a dislike for something. But the feeling of disliking the desire for something to be absent or non-existent (annihilated) constantly and wanting more and more, becomes unnatural, and this is sin.

50g/L ethanol~4 g/L acetonitrile Urea is an organic compound composed of the elements carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen with the formula CON2H4 or (NH2)2CO. Urea is also known as carbamide which is mainly used in Europe. Other names that are also often used are carbamide resin, isourea, carbonyl diamide, and carbonyldiamine. This compound was the first synthetic organic compound that was successfully prepared from inorganic compounds, which ultimately undermined the concept of vitalism. Urea was first discovered by Hilaire Roulle in 1773. This compound was the first organic compound that was successfully synthesized from inorganic compounds. Urea is formed through an oxidation process that occurs in the liver. Erythrocytes or red blood cells that have been damaged (120 days) are broken down into 'haemo' and 'globin'. Furthermore, the 'haemo' will be converted into bile dyes, namely bilirubin and urobilin which contain urea and ammonia which will be excreted with urine and feces. About 90% of industrial urea is used as chemical fertilizer. Urea in the form of prills is used in agriculture as a chemical fertilizer that supplies nitrogen. In soil, urea will hydrolyze and release ammonium ions. The N content in urea is 46%, but half is used by plants. Because it is important in agricultural development, urea fertilizer is often subsidized by the government of a country, including Indonesia. In the Indonesian market, urea fertilizer is marketed in two forms: subsidized (in pink, used for development assistance) and unsubsidized (in white, to be marketed commercially). Urea fertilizer is produced as a by-product of natural gas processing or coal combustion. The carbon dioxide produced from these industrial activities is then mixed with ammonia through the Bosch-Meiser process. At low temperatures, liquid ammonia is mixed with dry ice (carbon dioxide) to produce ammonium carbamate.

The Hellenistic period or Hellenistic era is the period following the conquests of Alexander the Great. This term was put forward by the historian J. G. Droysen. During this time, the influence of Greek culture and power reached its peak in Europe and Asia. This period is sometimes called the transition period, or even decline, between the brilliant Classical Age and the rise of the Roman Empire. This period began after Alexander's death in 323 BC and ended when the Roman Republic conquered mainland Greece in 146 BC; or when Alexander's last successor state fell, the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt in 31/30 BC, in the Battle of Actium. The Hellenistic period is characterized by a new wave of colonies founded by Greek cities and kingdoms in Asia and Africa. The word Hellenistic comes from the German term hellenistisch, from Ancient Greek Ἑλληνιστής ( Hellēnistḗs, Greek speaking person), and Ἑλλάς (Hellás, "Greek"). Hellenistic is a modern word and a 19th century concept; however the idea of ​​the Hellenistic period was absent in Ancient Greece. Although there are several words associated with the term, such as Hellenist (Ancient Greek: Ἑλληνιστής, Hellēnistēs) has been attested since ancient times, in the mid-19th century, in his Geschichte des Hellenismus (history of Hellenism), J.G Droysen coined the term Hellenistic for refers to and defines the period when Greek culture spread in the non-Greek world after Alexander's conquests. Following Droysen, the term Hellenistic and other terms, such as Hellenism, have been widely used in various contexts; a well-known usage is in Culture and Anarchy by Matthew Arnold, where the term Hellenism is used in contrast to Hebraism. The main problem with the term Hellenistic lies in its suitability, as the spread of Greek culture was not the general phenomenon the term implies.

Some areas of the world that were conquered were more influenced by Greek influence than others. The term Hellenistic also explained simply that the Greeks formed the majority in the area where they lived, but in many cases the Greek settlers were actually a minority among the native population. The Greek population did not always mix with the natives; Greeks tend to move around and bring their own culture with them, but interaction doesn't always happen. Although there were early fragments, no complete historical form survived for hundreds of years after Alexander's death. The works of the Hellenistic historian Hieronymus of Cardia (who worked under Alexander, Antigonus I and other successors), Duris of Samos and Philarchus used as surviving sources have been lost. The most credible surviving source for the Hellenistic period is Polybius of Megalopolis, a statesman of the Achaean League until 168 BC when he was forced to go to Rome as a hostage. His historical records number 40 books, covering the years 220 to 167 BC. His other sources include Justin's epitoma from Pompeius Trogus's Historiae Philipicae and a summary of Arrian's activities after Alexander, by Photios I of Constantinople. Fewer additional sources include Curtius Rufus, Pausanias, Pliny, and the Byzantine encyclopedia Suda. In the field of philosophy, Diogenes Laërtius' Lives and Opinions of Famous Philosophers is his main source; works such as Cicero's De Natura Deorum also provide some further detail about the philosophical schools of the Hellenistic period. Ancient Greece was generally a collection of very independent city-states. After the Peloponnesian War, Greece had fallen under the hegemony of Sparta, in which Sparta was superior but not entirely strong. Spartan hegemony was replaced by Thivat hegemony after the Battle of Leuktra, but after the Battle of Mantinea, all of Greece was weakened so that no single state could claim victory.

Arsenic, arsenic, or arsenicum is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol As and atomic number 33. It is a notoriously toxic metalloid material and has three allotropic forms; yellow, black, and gray. Arsenic and arsenic compounds are used as pesticides, herbicides, insecticides and in various alloys. Arsenic has chemical characteristics similar to Phosphorus, and can often be used as a substitute in various biochemical reactions and is also toxic. When heated, arsenic rapidly oxidizes to arsenic oxide, which smells like garlic. Arsenic and some arsenic compounds can also directly sublimate, changing from a solid to a gas without first becoming a liquid. Arsenic is found in two solid forms which are yellow and metallic in color, with specific gravity of 1.97 and 5.73. The word arsenic is borrowed from the Persian زرنيخ Zarnik which means "yellow orpiment". Zarnik is borrowed in Greek as arsenicone. Arsenic has been known and used in Persia and in many other places since ancient times. It was often used to kill, and the symptoms of arsenic poisoning were difficult to explain, until the invention of the Marsh test, a sensitive chemical test for the presence of arsenic. Because it is often used by rulers to get rid of their opponents and because of its extraordinary killing power and difficulty to detect, arsenic is called the Poison of kings, and King of all poisons. In the Bronze Age, arsenic was often used in bronze, which made the alloy harder. Warangan, which is often used as a coating material for keris surfaces, contains the main ingredient arsenic. Arsen evokes the prestige of the keris by emphasizing the contrast on the prestige. In addition, arsenic also increases the lethality of the stabbing weapon. Albertus Magnus is credited with being the first to discover how to isolate this element in 1250.

In 1649 Johan Schroeder published 2 methods of preparing arsenic. The alchemical symbol for arsenic is shown on the right. During Queen Victoria's time in Great Britain, arsenic was mixed with vinegar and lime and eaten by women to improve the appearance of their faces, making their skin lighter to show that they were not working in the fields. Arsenic was also rubbed on women's faces and arms to whiten their skin. However this is highly discouraged now. Some places on earth contain arsenic high enough to seep into groundwater. WHO sets the highest safe threshold for arsenic in groundwater at 50 ppb (parts per billion). Most of the areas with the highest arsenic content are alluvial areas which are river silt deposits and soils rich in organic matter. It is estimated that around 57 million people drink groundwater contaminated with excess arsenic, making it potentially toxic. Arsenic in groundwater is naturally occurring, and is released from sediments into groundwater due to the absence of oxygen in the subsurface layer. This groundwater began to be used after a number of western NGOs researched large well water programs in the late 20th century, but failed to find the presence of arsenic in the groundwater. It is considered to be the worst mass poisoning in history and possibly the worst environmental disaster in history. In Bangladesh there is an epidemic of mass poisoning caused by arsenic. Many other countries in Asia, such as Vietnam, Cambodia, Indonesia and Tibet, are thought to have similar geological environments conducive to producing groundwater containing high levels of arsenic. Plants grown on soil containing arsenic can be absorbed by plants and leave residues in agricultural produce.

This article is not to be confused with Canal Sur Televisora ​​del Sur (Spanish for "Southern Television Station"), abbreviated as Telesur, is a pan-Latin American television network based in Caracas, Venezuela. The station began broadcasting on a limited schedule on July 24, 2005, while full broadcasts began on October 31, 2005. Telesur, proposed by Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez, was intended as a rival to popular private networks in South America such as CNN en Español and Univisión. This network is also intended to encourage the creation of Latin American integration. The network is supported by US$10 million in funding provided by the countries that jointly own the network: Venezuela (51% share), Argentina (20%), Cuba (19%), and Uruguay (10%), with Maybe other countries will join in too. These countries, including Brazil (which is developing its own international Portuguese-language station, TV Brasil), will cooperate on content and technology. TeleSUR's advisory board is composed of many international and regional intellectuals, including Nobel Peace Prize winner Adolfo Pérez Esquivel, poet Ernesto Cardenal, writers Eduardo Galeano, Tariq Ali and Saul Landau, editor-in-chief of Le Monde diplomatique and historian Ignacio Ramonet, pioneer of free software Richard Stallman, and actor Danny Glover. The current President of TeleSUR is Andrés Izarra, who was for a short time the Minister of Communications in the Venezuelan government. Izarra is also a veteran journalist and has worked for both CNN and RCTV, a private Venezuelan network. The station promised to be an alternative to big media conglomerates like CNN, and adopted the slogan "News from the South." The broadcast can be watched in at least 15 countries through at least 53 cable services, as well as five free stations.

Space is a concept that has been of concern to many philosophers and scientists throughout human history. This term is used differently in various fields of study, such as philosophy, mathematics, astronomy, psychology, etc., making it difficult to provide a clear and non-controversial universal definition regardless of the appropriate context. There is also disagreement about whether space itself is measurable or part of a measurement system. Science itself considers that space is a fundamental unit, namely a unit that cannot be defined by other units. The definition of space is usually more spatial in nature, while in reality the space is closely integrated with a group of people with all their activities within a certain period of time, in the study of environmental architecture and behavior, the term setting tends to be used more. The term setting places more emphasis on elements of human activity that are not clearly visible in terms of space. In Geography Studies: An Approach and Spatial Analysis (1981), Nursid Sumaatmadja describes the definition of space. Space is a place on the surface of the earth, either as a whole or only in part, that is used by living things to live. Space can also be interpreted as a container for all human, animal and plant activities on the surface of the earth. Space is not only limited to air in contact with the earth's surface. But also the lowest layer of the atmosphere that affects the earth's surface. Space also includes waters that are on the surface of the earth, namely seas, rivers, lakes, or those that are below the surface of the earth (groundwater) to a certain depth. Quoted from Education Standards, the concept of space is a concept that focuses on the location and spatial distribution, as well as how people organize and manage the space they live in. This physics-related article is a stub.

Psylocybe is a group of mushrooms that contain hallucinogenic substances. Psilocybe (known as Magic Mushroom; resemblance to a drug) includes macro-mushrooms belonging to the Strophariaceae tribe, the Agaricales nation. Agaricales is part of the kingdom fungi with a fruiting body and 3 main parts, namely the fruit cap/pileus, blades/lamellae or pores/pores, and stalk/stipe. Psilocybe grows cosmopolitan and functions as a satotroph. This fungus can grow in animal waste, moss, twigs, leaves, or rotting wood. It is estimated that there are around 116 species of this mushroom in the world and 1 species in Indonesia, namely Psilycobe subaeruginacens var. subaeruginacens. This type of mushroom is most abundant in Mexico (there are 44 species, about 39% of the total world species). The word Psilocybe comes from the Greek words ψιλός + κύβη, 'Psilo/bald+cybe/head' and literally means "bare-headed/bald", referring to the fungus' removable pellicle (loose skin over the cap). It is pronounced with the main stress on the third syllable, /ˌsaɪloʊˈsaɪbi/ SY-loh-SY-bee. The last E is not silent. Psilocybe has the characteristics of a small fruit body, fruit hood measuring 0.5-4 cm, convex, bell-shaped, protruding center, yellow-brown or brown in color. Has adnexed blades, adnate, the color changes to dark brown as the basidiopore gets older, the edges turn white because of the cystidia. Stems are thin, easily broken, glabrous, brown, and turn bluish when injured. Psilocybe and several other hallucination-causing mushroom genera have main compounds that cause hallucinations, namely psilocybin and psilocin compounds. This substance, which has the chemical name 4-hydroxylated-N-dimethyltryptamine (psychedelics), is used by several pharmaceutical companies in Switzerland in the formulation of pills. This hallucinatory mushroom is also used in the world of medicine. For example, in a study of a total of 26 correspondents, there were 22 people who had less headaches due to the use of psilocybin.

The use of psilocybin in cancer patients is also known to improve psychological conditions and reduce patient anxiety. The use of this mushroom compound as a treatment is still controversial, illegal in several countries, and not yet 'famous' in Indonesia. Especially in Indonesia, the development and research of this mushroom has begun to be carried out, moreover the cultivation process has begun to be carried out a lot so it is hoped that the cultivation and development of medicinal plants can be beneficial for pharmaceutical companies in Indonesia itself. Geographically, species of this genus can be found worldwide in almost all biomes. The greatest species diversity is in the neotropics (Brazil and Chile) region of Mesoamerica. There are also other sources that say the most common type of hallucinatory mushroom is found in the Mexican region, even though the neotropical region has many types too. Psilocybe is found in a variety of habitats and substrates. Some species are found in temperate climates, for example Psilocybe cyanescens (in certain park areas and rarely near human settlements). Only a small number of Psilocybe species were found in faeces, for example P. cubensis and P. sibcubensis which grow directly in faeces. Other species can be found in mossy, grassy, ​​humus soils or forests. Magic mushrooms are eaten fresh, mixed with tea/other drinks, or they can be used dry (such as smoking) and mixed with tobacco. Other names are shrooms, mushies, blue meanies, golden tops, liberty caps. There is no safe level of drug use. The use of any drug always carries risks. It is important to be careful when taking any type of medication. The use of this mushroom has a different effect on each person based on the user's size and state of health, the amount, strength of the mushroom (variation), and so on. The effects of this fungus usually begin within 30 minutes after consumption or 5 to 10 minutes when taken by mouth (such as tea, soup, juice), and can last up to 4-6 hours.

Marianne is a symbol of the French Republic. He is a figure of freedom and the Republic and first appeared during the French Revolution. Marianne's initial appearance is of a woman wearing a Phrygian cap. The origin of the name Marianne is unknown, but Marie-Anne was a common first name in the 18th century. The anti-revolutionaries of the time called him La Gueuse (The Announcer). It is believed that revolutionaries from the South of France wore the Phrygian cap as a symbol of freedom, having been worn by free slaves in Greece and Rome. Mediterranean sailors and criminals working in the galleys also wore similar head coverings. Under the Third Republic, statues of Marianne began to be made, mostly in town halls. He is shown in various forms of behavior, depending on whether the aim is to emphasize his revolutionary nature or his "wisdom". Over time, the Phrygian headdress was deemed too ostentatious, and was replaced by a diadem or crown. In recent times, many famous French women have been used as models for the Marianne. Some of them are Sophie Marceau and Laetitia Casta. It also appears on everyday items such as stamps and coins. Marianne (pronounced maʁjan]) has been the national personification of the French Republic since the French Revolution, as a personification of freedom, equality, brotherhood and reason, as well as a depiction of the Goddess of Freedom. Marianne is featured in many places in France and holds honorable places in town halls and law courts. He is depicted in The Triumph of the Republic, a bronze statue facing the Place de la Nation in Paris, and is represented with another Parisian bust on the Place de la République. His profile features prominently on the country's official government logo, is engraved on French euro coins, and appears on French postage stamps. Previously the image was also displayed in francs.

The Marianne is one of the most prominent symbols of the French Republic, and is officially used in most government documents. Marianne is an important republican symbol; another French monarchical equivalent was often Jeanne d'Arc. As a national icon, Marianne represents the resistance to monarchy and the champion of freedom and democracy against all forms of oppression. Other French national symbols include the tri-colour flag, the national motto Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité, the national anthem "La Marseillaise", the coat of arms and the official Grand Coat of Arms of France. Marianne also wears a folded cockade of the French coat of arms and a red hat which symbolizes Freedom. Since classical times, it has been common to symbolize abstract ideas and entities by gods, goddesses, and allegorical personifications. During the French Revolution of 1789, many allegorical personifications of 'Freedom' and 'Reason' appeared. The two figures eventually merge into one: a female figure, shown sitting or standing, and accompanied by various attributes, including a French cockade and a red Phrygian hat. This woman usually symbolizes Freedom, Reason, Nation, Homeland and the virtues of the Civil Republic. (Compare New York's Statue of Liberty, created as Freedom that Lights the World by French artist Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi, with copies in Paris and Saint-Étienne.) In September 1792, the National Convention decreed that the country's new seal would represent a standing woman. holding a spear with a Phrygian hat held high on it. The historian Maurice Agulhon, who in several notable works undertook detailed investigations to discover Marianne's origins, points out that it was French tradition and mentality that led to the use of a woman to represent the Republic. The feminine allegory was also a way of symbolizing a break with the old monarchy led by a king, and promoting a modern republican ideology.

Tax (from the Latin taxo; "rate") is a mandatory contribution to the state that is owed by individuals or entities that are coercive under the law, by not getting compensation directly and used for the needs of the state for the greatest prosperity of the people. According to Charles E. McLure, taxes are financial obligations or levies imposed on taxpayers (individuals or entities) by the state or institutions whose functions are equivalent to the state which are used to finance various kinds of public expenditures. Taxes are levied based on legal norms to cover the costs of collective production of goods and services to achieve the general welfare. Refusal to pay, avoidance, or resistance to taxes is generally a violation of the law. Taxes consist of direct taxes or indirect taxes and can be paid in money or in labor of equivalent value. Some countries do not impose taxes at all, for example the United Arab Emirates. The government agency that manages state taxation in Indonesia is the Directorate General of Taxes (DGT), which is a directorate general under the auspices of the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Indonesia. There are different legal and economic definitions of tax from tax. Economists believe that not all financial transfers to the public sector can be categorized as taxes. An example is some transfers to the public sector which are still affected by prices. This is for example, tuition fees at state universities and costs for providing services to the government. Governments also obtain financial resources by “creating” money (e.g. by printing money), through grants (e.g., contributions to state universities and museums), by imposing sanctions (such as fines for traffic violations), by taking on debt, and by seizing riches. From the point of view of economists, taxes are non-penalty transfers of resources from the private sector to the public sector which are levied on a predetermined basis and without declaring the benefits to be provided.

In the modern taxation system, the government collects taxes in money, but both in-kind and in-kind payments of taxes are characteristic of traditional or pre-capitalist taxes and function equally. The system of taxation and government spending on tax revenue is a topic that is often debated by whom?] in a political and economic context. Tax collection is carried out by public institutions such as the Directorate General of Taxes in Indonesia, the Canada Revenue Agency in Canada, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) in the United States, or Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC) in England. When taxes are not paid, the government can impose legal sanctions such as fines, confiscation of assets, and even detention of those who are proven to have done so. There are various definitions or definitions of "tax" put forward by experts, including: Taxes from an economic perspective are understood as the transfer of resources from the private sector to the public sector. This understanding illustrates that the tax causes two situations to change. First, the reduced ability of individuals to control resources for the benefit of controlling goods and services. Second, increasing the state's financial capacity in the provision of public goods and services which are the needs of the community. While the understanding of tax from a legal perspective according to Soemitro is an agreement that arises because of a law that causes the obligation of citizens to deposit a certain amount of income to the state, the state has the power to force and the tax money must be used for government administration. From this legal approach, it shows that the tax collected must be based on the law so as to guarantee legal certainty, both for the tax collector as a tax collector and for the taxpayer as a tax payer. Tax according to Article 1 point 1 of Law no. 6 of 1983, as amended several times, most recently by Law Number 16 of 2009 concerning general provisions and procedures for taxation, is "compulsory contributions to the state owed by individuals or entities that are coercive based on the law, without receiving reciprocal directly and used for the needs of the state for the greatest prosperity of the people'' The existence of tax collection was first known to have occurred in Ancient Egypt around 3000 – 2800 BC where the known tax system was in the form of a variable tax system, namely based on the height of the Nile river water.

A coup d'État (French pronunciation: \ˌkü-(ˌ)dā-ˈtä\], or French pronunciation for short: \ˈkōp\], meaning undermining legitimacy or a blow to the state) is an act of reversal of power against someone authorized in an illegal and often brutal, unconstitutional way in the form of "takeover of power", "overthrow of power" of a state government by attacking (strategic, tactical, political) the legitimacy of the government then intending to accept the handover of power from the overthrown government. A coup will be successful if it can first consolidate in building legitimacy as the approval of the people and has received support or participation from non-military and military (army) parties. According to a collection of coup data from Jonathan Powell and Clayton Thyne, there were 457 coup attempts that occurred from 1950 to 2010. Where 227 coup attempts were successful while 230 others failed. They found that coup attempts occurred frequently on the African and American continents (36.5% and 31%, respectively). This passage is a quote from Self-coup. edit] A self-coup, also called autocoup (from Spanish: autogolpe), is a form of coup in which the head of state, who has come to power through legal means, tries to stay in power through illegitimate means. He may dissolve or incapacitate the national legislature and illegally assume extraordinary powers not conferred under normal circumstances. Other steps taken may include annulling the country's constitution, suspending civil courts, and having the head of government assume dictatorial powers. Between 1946 and 2020, an estimated 148 self-coup attempts have taken place: 110 in autocracies and 38 in democracies. A soft coup, sometimes referred to as a silent coup, is an illegal overthrow of a government, but unlike a classical coup, it is accomplished without the use of force or violence.

Palace coups or palace revolutions are coups in which one faction within the ruling group replaces another faction within the ruling group. Along with popular protests, palace coups posed a grave threat to dictators. The 12th century BC Harem Conspiracy is one of the earliest. Palace coups were common in Imperial China. They also occurred among the Habsburg dynasty in Austria, the Al-Thani dynasty in Qatar, and in Haiti in the 19th to early 20th centuries. The majority of Russian tsars between 1725 and 1801 were either overthrown or seized power in palace coups. The term Putsch (pʊtʃ], from Swiss-German 'knock'), denotes the politico-military action of the failed minority reactionary coup. The term was originally coined for Züriputsch on September 6, 1839 in Switzerland. It was also used for attempted coups in Weimar Germany, such as the 1920 Kapp Putsch, Küstrin Putsch, and Adolf Hitler's 1923 Beer Hall Putsch. During the Night of the Long Knives in 1934, the alleged putsch was the basis of a disinformation tactic by Hitler and other members of the Nazi party. After starting the purge, the idea of ​​an imminent coup allowed them to falsely claim that the killings were justified (as a means of suppressing the uprising). Germans still use the term Röhm-Putsch to describe the event, a term given to it by the Nazi regime, despite the unproven implication that the assassination was necessary to prevent a reactionary coup. Thus, German writers often use quotation marks or write about sogenannter Röhm-Putsch ('so-called Röhm Putsch') for emphasis. Putsch Algiers 1961 and Putsch August 1991 also used the term. Main article: Pronunciation Pronunciamiento ("pronunciation") is a term of Spanish origin for a type of coup .

Macau (/məˈkaʊ/ ( listen); 澳門, Cantonese: ōu.mǔːn]; Portuguese: mɐˈkaw]), or officially the Macau Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China (Chinese: 中華人民共和國澳門特別行政區, Portuguese: Região Administrativa Especial de Macau da República Popular da China (RAEM) English: Macau Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China ("Macau SAR")) is a city and special administrative region in the People's Republic of China located in the western part of the Delta. The Pearl River which empties into the South China Sea. With a population of around 680,000 and an area of ​​329 km2 (127 sq mi), it is one of the most densely populated regions in the world. Macau is one of the 4 administrative regions of China, Macau is also called "makhao". Previously, Macau was a colony of the Portuguese whose territory was originally leased to Portugal as a trading post by the Ming dynasty in 1557. Portugal paid an annual lease to manage the Macau area which was then under Chinese sovereignty. However, in 1887, Portugal obtained permanent colony rights over Macau as provided for in the Sino-Portugal Treaty of Peking. The colony remained under Portuguese rule until 1999, when sovereignty of Macau was transferred by the Portuguese to China. Furthermore, Macau became a special administrative region that maintains a separate government and economic system from mainland China, under the principle of "one country, two systems" for the next 50 years starting from 1999 based on the "Join declaration of Macau" agreement. The historic center of the city, which depicts a unique blend of Portuguese and Cantonese architecture, was inscribed on the World Heritage List by UNESCO in 2005. Macau is divided into 4 divisions namely: The four divisions have a number of district-level areas which include articles on geography or this China place is a stub.

Distance is a numerical measure that indicates how far the position of an object is from another object. In the field of physics or in everyday terms, distance can refer to the length (physically) between two positions, or an estimation based on certain criteria (for example the distance between Jakarta and Bandung). The distance from point A to point B is generally expressed as |AB|{\displaystyle |AB|}. In most cases, the phrase "distance from A to B" is interchangeable with "distance from B to A". In mathematics, the distance or metric function is a generalization of the concept of physical distance; namely as a way to give an understanding of how "far" or "close" the positions of two objects are. In psychology and the social sciences, distance is a non-numeric measure. Physical distance can refer to several different things: An uncommon definition of distance can be useful for modeling certain physical situations, but is also used in pure mathematics: The measure of distance in cosmology is more complicated because it is affected by the expansion factors of the universe, and by the effects described by the theory of relativity (such as a contraction in the length of a moving object). The definition of "distance" is also used as an analogy for measuring two non-physical objects in some way. In computer science, there is a notation of "editing distance" between two strings. For example, the words "eat" and "tomb" which differ by only one letter, are closer together than the words "eat" and "night" which have a difference of two letters. This concept is used in code theory and in spell checkers. Mathematically distance can be defined in several ways: In mathematics, a metric space is a set in which the distance between the members of the set is defined. In this way, many types of "distance" can be computed, such as graph traversals, distribution comparisons and curves, and unusual definitions of "space" (for example folds and reflections).

Distance notation in graph theory is used to describe social networks, for example the Erdős number or Bacon number—a number that indicates the distance of a person's collaborative relationship between the mathematician Paul Erdős and the actor Kevin Bacon. In psychology, human geography, and the social sciences, distance is often understood not as an objective measure, but as a subjective experience.
