Both distance and displacement measure the movement of an object. Distance is a scalar quantity while displacement is a vector quantity with magnitude and direction. The distance between the two points cannot be negative. On the other hand, directional character does not measure movement; it measures the position of a point from a reference point, and is expressed in vector form. The distance traveled by a vehicle (e.g. as recorded by an odometer), person, animal, or object along a curved path from point A to point B must be distinguished from the straight-line distance from A to B, because in general straight-line distances do not equal the distance traveled, except for traveling in a straight line. The directional distance can be determined along a straight line and along a curved path. Directional distance along a straight line is a vector that provides distance and direction information between the start and end points. The directional distance of point C{\displaystyle C} from point A{\displaystyle A} on the line AB¯{\displaystyle {\overline {AB}}} and in the direction B{\displaystyle B} in Euclidean vector space is the distance from A{ \displaystyle A} to C{\displaystyle C} if C{\displaystyle C} falls on ray AB→{\displaystyle {\vec {AB}}}, but is negative if C{\displaystyle C} falls on ray BA→ {\displaystyle {\vec {BA}}}. The directional distance along a curved path is not a vector and is represented by curved line segments defined by endpoints A and B, with some specific information indicating the sense (or direction) of ideal or real movement from one endpoint of the path to another.

Power is the amount of work done per unit time. The unit used to express power is Joules per second or Watts. This name is in honor of James Watt, the inventor of the steam engine in the 18th century AD. Power is a scalar quantity. In physics, power is the speed with which work is done. Power is equal to the amount of energy required per unit time. The power integral over time defines the work done. Because the integral depends on the path of force and torque, the work calculation is path dependent. As a basic physics concept, force requires a change in a body and a specific time when the change occurs. This is different from the concept of work, which only measures changes in the state of things. For example, the work done by a person is the same when lifting weights up regardless of running or walking, but it takes more power to run because work is done in less time. The output power of an electric motor is the result of multiplying the torque produced by the motor and the angular speed of the output shaft. Power in a moving vehicle is the product of the traction force of the wheels and the speed of the vehicle. The speed at which a light bulb converts electrical energy into light and heat is measured in watts—the higher the value, the more electrical energy required per unit time. The dimension of power is energy divided by time. The SI unit of power is the watt (W), which is one joule per second. Other units of power are erg per second (erg/s), horsepower (hp), metric horsepower (Pferdestärke (PS) or cheval vapeur (CV)), and foot-pounds per minute. One horsepower equals 33,000 foot-pounds per minute, or the power required to lift a 550 pound load 1 foot in 1 second, equals 746 watts.

Another unit of power is the dBm, a relative logarithmic measurement with reference to 1 milliwatt; food calories per hour (called kilocalories per hour); Btu per hour (Btu/h); and tons of refrigeration (12,000 Btu/hour). Electrical power can be generated from changing the working power during the electromagnetic induction process taking place in the magnetic coil. The induced voltage on a conducting rod that is in a magnetic field will produce an induced current with a certain value. These induced voltages and currents produce a power in Joules which is equal to the power released into the conductor. This power in Joule units is generated as a result of mechanical work originating from the process of moving the conducting rods. Meanwhile, in the conducting rod there is a force that moves in the opposite direction, so that the mechanical power turns into electrical power. The distribution of electric power through cables always results in power losses. Reduction of power losses is done by reducing the value of the electrical resistance in the cable. Resistance values ​​can be reduced by using electrical materials with low specific resistance, such as copper or aluminum. The type resistance of an electrical material is a constant that cannot be changed, so that the reduction in the value of the electrical resistance can only reach a certain minimum value. Impairment can be done again by engineering electrical materials. The first way to engineer materials so that their electrical resistance is very small is to mix electrical materials so that a resistance that is smaller than the electrical materials found in nature is found. The second way is to use a cable with a larger cross-sectional area. The electrical resistance will be smaller if the cross-sectional area is larger. The second method cannot be applied effectively in electrical engineering work because large cross sections are stiff and difficult to bend.

The Fahrenheit scale is one of the temperature scales besides Celsius and Kelvin. The name Fahrenheit is taken from a German scientist named Gabriel Fahrenheit (1686-1736). This scale was proposed in 1724. In this scale, the freezing point of water is 32 degrees Fahrenheit (written as 32 °F) and the boiling point of water is 212 degrees Fahrenheit. Negative 40 degrees Fahrenheit is the same as negative 40 degrees Celsius. The Fahrenheit scale is widely used in the United States.) There is some debate as to how Fahrenheit thought of his temperature scale. Some claim that Fahrenheit determines the zero point (0°F) and 100°F on his temperature scale by recording the lowest outside temperature he can measure, and his own body temperature. He used the lowest outside temperature as the zero point which he measured in the winter of 1708 before 1709 in his hometown, Gdánsk (Danzig) (-17.8°C). Fahrenheit wanted to avoid negative temperatures as the Ole Rømer scale often indicates negative temperatures in everyday use. Fahrenheit determined that his own body temperature was 100°F (a normal body temperature is close to 98.6°F, meaning that either Fahrenheit had a fever when experimenting or the thermometer was inaccurate). He divided his normal scale into 12 divisions, and then the 12 divisions were each subdivided into 8 sub-divisions. This division results in a 96 degree scale. Fahrenheit said that on his scale, the freezing point of water is at 32°F, and the boiling point of water is at 212°F, a difference of 180 degrees. There are also those who say that Fahrenheit determines the zero point (0°F) on his scale as the temperature at which the mixture is evenly distributed. between ice and melted salt and 96 degrees being the temperature of his blood (he originally used horse blood to indicate the scale).

His scale consisted of 12 divisions, but then he divided each division into 8 equal sub-divisions. And make 96 degrees. He later found that water (without anything mixed in) would freeze at 32 degrees and boil at 212 degrees. The third is the most familiar story, as depicted on the popular physics television series The Mechanical Universe. The series states that Fahrenheit adopted Rømer's scale in which water freezes at 7.5 degrees and multiplied each value by 4 to eliminate fractions and increase the granularity of the scale (giving 30 and 240 degrees). Then he again scaled it between the freezing point of water and normal human body temperature (where he took 96 degrees); the freezing point of water is determined to be 32 degrees so there are 64 intervals it would halve. So he could mark the degree line on his tool by halving the interval twice. Not all measurements are accurate. Using the original scale, the actual freezing and boiling points of water would differ by 32°F and 212°F. Some time after his death, it was decided to re-sign the scale with 32°F and 212°F being the correct freezing and boiling points of pure water. This change makes it easy to convert from Celsius to Fahrenheit and vice versa using a simple formula. This change also explains why body temperature was once determined to be 96 or 100°F by Fahrenheit and is now defined as 98.6°F by many, although a value of 98°F would be more accurate. Fourth, is the little-known story about the origin of the Fahrenheit scale. The fourth story tells that the Fahrenheit scale was determined by Fahrenheit himself who was a member of a fraternal organization (there is no definite evidence).

The Republic of Tajikistan is a former Soviet Union country in Central Asia, bordered by Afghanistan to the south, the People's Republic of China to the east, Kyrgyzstan to the north and Uzbekistan to the west. Its geographical condition is a plateau that is not bordered by the sea. Most of Tajikistan's population belongs to the Persian-speaking Tajik ethnicity and shares a history, language and culture with Afghanistan and Iran. After becoming part of the Samanid Empire, Tajikistan became a constituent republic of the Soviet Union/USSR in the 20th century under the name Tajikistan Soviet Socialist Republic. The Soviet Union split in 1991 and Tajikistan became independent. After independence, Tajikistan suffered from a civil war that lasted from 1992 to 1997. Since the end of the war, newly established political stability and foreign aid have allowed the country's economy to develop. Commodity trading such as cotton, aluminum and uranium has contributed greatly to the country's continued improvement. However, fighting broke out again in late July 2012 with mixed results. Tajikistan is the smallest country in Central Asia and is landlocked. The country lies between latitudes 36° and 41° and longitudes 67° and 75° E. The area is covered by the Pamir mountains, and more than fifty percent of the country's landmass is located at elevations of over 3,000 meters (9,800 feet) in above sea level. The only lowland is located in the north (part of the Fergana Valley), and in the southern part are the valleys of the Kofarnihon and Vakhsh rivers, which form the Amu Darya river. Dushanbe, the nation's capital is situated on the southern slope above the Kofarnihon valley. The Amu Darya and Panj rivers form the border with Afghanistan, and the glaciers in the mountains of Tajikistan are the main water source for the Aral Sea.

Dams or Empangan or English borrowing terms dams are constructions built to hold back the rate of water into reservoirs, lakes, or recreational areas. Often dams are also used to drain water to a hydroelectric power plant. Most dams also have a section called a sluice for the gradual or continuous removal of unwanted water. The Indonesian Ministry of Public Works defines a dam as "a structure in the form of soil, stone, concrete or stone masonry that is built not only to hold and store water, but also to accommodate mine waste or mud." Dams (dam) and weir (weir) are actually different structures. Weir (weir) is a low-head dam structure (lowhead dam), which serves to raise the water level, usually found in rivers. River water whose level is raised will overflow through the crest/crest of the weir (overflow). It can be used as a velocity meter for water flow in canals/rivers and also as a drive for traditional milling in European countries. In countries with relatively large and fast-flowing rivers, a series of weirs can be operated to form a water transportation system. In Indonesia, weirs can be used for irrigation if, for example, the water level of a river is lower than the surface of the land to be irrigated. Dams can be classified according to structure, purpose or elevation. Based on the structure and materials used, dams can be classified as timber dams, "embankment dams" or "masonry dams", with various subtypes. Purposes include providing water for irrigation or urban water supply, improving navigation, generating hydroelectric power, creating recreational areas or habitats for fish and other animals, preventing flooding and restraining discharges from industrial sites such as mines or factories.

Peugeot (US /puːˈʒoʊ/; UK /ˈpɜːʒoʊ/; French pronunciation: pøʒo]) is a French car brand, and a subsidiary of Stellantis. The family business that started today's Peugeot, was founded in 1810, as a manufacturer of coffee grinders and bicycles. On November 20, 1858, Émile Peugeot proposed the use of the lion trademark which is still used today. In 1889, Armand Peugeot assembled Peugeot's first car, namely a steam car, with Leon Serpollet, which was then followed by a Panhard-Daimler engined car. As a result of family conflicts, Armand Peugeot founded the Société des Automobiles Peugeot in 1896. The Peugeot family originates from Sochaux, France. In fact, Peugeot has a large factory there, as well as a museum. In February 2014, Peugeot's shareholders agreed to a recapitalization plan, under which Dongfeng Motors and the French government would each buy a 14% stake in Peugeot. Peugeot has received many international awards for its cars, including four European Car of the Year awards. In 2013 and 2014, Peugeot also managed to rank second in terms of the lowest average CO2 emissions among other brands in Europe, with an average emission value of 114.9g CO2/km. Peugeot is also famous for the reliability of its cars, even Peugeot cars from the 1950s and 1960s are still running smoothly in Africa and Cuba. Peugeot also has a glorious history in the world of racing. Peugeot Sport has won the World Rally Championship five times, the Intercontinental Le Mans Cup twice, the World Endurance Championship twice, and the Intercontinental Rally Challenge Championship three times. In 2015, Peugeot returned to racing in the Dakar Rally after its four wins in the 1980s.

Nucleosynthesis is the process of creating new atomic nuclei from pre-existing nucleons (protons and neutrons). It is thought that the primordial nucleons themselves formed from the quark-gluon plasma from the Big Bang when it cooled below two trillion Kelvin. Minutes later, starting with just protons and neutrons, nuclei from aton down to lithium and beryllium (both mass number 7) formed, but only in relatively small numbers. Then the fusion process essentially stops as the temperature and density decrease, as the universe continues to expand. This first primordial nucleosynthesis process can also be referred to as nucleogenesis. Subsequent nucleosynthesis of the heavier elements required the explosion of heavy stars and supernovae. This happened theoretically because hydrogen and helium from the Big Bang (perhaps influenced by the concentration of dark matter), condensed into prime stars 500 million years after the Big Bang. The elements formed in stellar nucleosynthesis range in atomic numbers from 6 (carbon) to at least 98 (californium), which have been detected from the spectra of some supernovae. The synthesis of these heavier elements occurs as a result of either nuclear fission (including multiple slow and fast neutron capture) or nuclear fission, sometimes followed by beta decay. In contrast, many stellar processes actually tend toward the breakdown of deuterium and the isotopes of beryllium, lithium, and boron that were present in stars, after their primordial formation at the time of the Big Bang. The quantities of these lighter elements present in the present-day universe were then thought to have formed primarily through billions of years of cosmic rays (mainly high-energy protons) that mediated the breakup of the heavier elements present in interstellar dust and gas. The first notion of nucleosynthesis was that the chemical elements were created at the beginning of the universe, but no physics storyline succeeded in explaining this.

Hydrogen and helium are clearly much more abundant than the other elements (they make up less than 2% of the mass of the solar system, and it is suspected that other star systems are too). At the same time, it is clear that carbon is the next most abundant element, and there is also a general trend towards abundance of the light elements, especially those consisting of all the atomic number helium-4 nuclei. Arthur Stanley Eddington was the first to suggest in the 1920s that stars obtain energy by fusing hydrogen to form helium, but this idea was not generally accepted because of the flawed nuclear mechanism. Immediately a few years later, just before World War II, Hans Bethe was the first to provide the necessary nuclear mechanism, in which hydrogen fused to form helium. However, these two early works on star power were unable to explain the origin of elements heavier than helium. Fred Hoyle's original work on the nucleosynthesis of heavier elements in stars appeared after World War II. This work involved the creation of all the heavy elements in stars during the process of nuclear evolution of their composition, starting from hydrogen. Hoyle proposed that hydrogen was created continuously in the universe from vacuum and energy, without the need for a starting universe. Hoyle's work explains how the abundance of elements increases as galaxies age. In turn, Hoyle's picture was expanded in the 1960s by the creative contributions of William A. Fowler, Alastair G. W. Cameron, and Donald D. Clayton, and later by others. The creative 1957 review paper by Margaret Burbidge, Geoffrey Burbidge, Fowler, and Hoyle (see list of References) is a famous overview of the state of this branch of science in 1957.

Dielectric is a kind of electrical insulating material that can be given polarization by placing the dielectric material in an electric field. When this material is in an electric field, the electric charge contained in it will not flow, so that an electric current does not arise like a conductor material, but only shifts slightly from its equilibrium position resulting in the creation of a dielectric polarity. Because of the dielectric polarity, positive charges move towards the negative pole of the electric field, while negative charges move in the opposite direction (ie towards the positive pole of the electric field). This creates an internal electric field (inside the dielectric material) which causes the total amount of electric field surrounding the dielectric material to decrease. If the dielectric is composed of weakly bonded molecules, these molecules can not only become polarized, but can also rearrange so that their axes of symmetry follow the direction of the electric field. Although the term "insulator" also implies low electrical conductivity, the term "dielectric" is usually used for insulating materials that have a high degree of polarity, the magnitude of which is represented by the dielectric constant. A common example of a dielectric is the insulator between the conducting plates found in a capacitor. The polarization of a dielectric material by exposing an electric field to it changes the electric charge on the capacitor poles. Research on the properties of dielectric materials is closely related to their ability to store and release electrical and magnetic energy. Dielectric properties are very important for explaining various phenomena in electronics, optics, and solid-state physics. The term "dielectric" was first used by William Whewell (from the Greek "he" meaning "pass" and "electric") in response to a request by Michael Faraday. The Xe electrical susceptibility to a dielectric material is a measure of how easily this material is polarized in an electric field, which ultimately determines the electrical permittivity thereby affecting other properties of the dielectric material, for example the capacitance value when used in a capacitor.

this value of electric susceptibility is defined by a constant ratio between the electric field E and the polarity of the dielectric material P such that: where ε0{\displaystyle \,\varepsilon _{0}} is the permittivity of free space. The susceptibility of a material is related to its relative permittivity εr{\displaystyle \,\varepsilon _{r}} namely: So that in a vacuum, the displacement of the electric field D is related to the polar density P through: In general, a material cannot be directly polarized ) suddenly in an electric field. The general form of this formula as a function of polarization time is: This means that polarization occurs as a form of deflection (convolution) to the electric field in the past (previous time) with a current electric susceptibility value of χe(Δt){\displaystyle \chi _{e} (\Delta t)}. This upper limit of the integral can be extended to infinity because χe(Δt)=0{\displaystyle \chi _{e}(\Delta t)=0} for Δt<0{\displaystyle \Delta t<0}. A sudden polarizing response can occur because of the Dirac delta function with susceptibility χe(Δt)=χeδ(Δt){\displaystyle \chi _{e}(\Delta t)=\chi _{e}\delta (\Delta t)}. However, calculations become easier in linear systems if you use the Fourier transform formula and write this equation as a function of frequency. Due to the convolution theorem, the integral is changed to a simple product. It should be noted that this simple frequency depends on the susceptibility value, or permittivity value. The shape of this frequency-based susceptibility graph gives dispersion properties to dielectric materials. Furthermore, that polarity depends only on the electric field in the past (ie χe(Δt)=0{\displaystyle \chi _{e}(\Delta t)=0} for Δt<0{\displaystyle \Delta t<0 }), as a consequence of the law of causation, polarization has a Kramers–Kronig relationship to the vulnerability χe(0){\displaystyle \chi _{e}(0)}. In the classical theoretical approach to dielectric modelling, a material is made up of atoms. Each atom consists of a cloud of negatively charged (electrons) bound together and includes a positively charged point in the center.

Limonite, sometimes also called low-grade nickel ore, is an iron ore consisting of a hydrated iron(III) oxide-hydroxide mixture in various compositions. Its chemical formula is commonly written as FeO(OH)·nH2O, although this is not entirely accurate as the ratio of its oxide to hydroxide can vary considerably. Limonite is one of the two main ores of iron (the other being hematite), and limonite has been mined for iron production since at least 2500 BC. The name Limonit comes from the Greek word for 'meadow' (λειμών), which refers to the bog iron ore found in meadows and marshes. In its brown color it is sometimes called brown hematite or brown iron ore, while in its bright yellow form it is sometimes called lemon rock or yellow iron ore. Limonite is relatively dense, with a specific gravity ranging from 2.7 to 4.3. Variations in color range from bright lemon yellow to opaque grayish brown. The limonite streaks on unglazed porcelain plates are always brownish in color, a characteristic that distinguishes them from hematite, which gives rise to red streaks, or from magnetite, which gives black streaks. Hardness levels vary, but are generally in the 4-5.5 range. Although originally classified as a single mineral, limonite is now classified as a mixture of related hydrated iron oxide minerals, including goethite, akaganeite, lepidochrosite, and jarosite. The minerals in limonite may form crystals, but limonite itself does not, although specimens show a fibrous or microcrystalline structure, and limonite often occurs as concretions or solid, earthy lumps; sometimes mammary, clustered (bitrioidal), kidney (reniform), or stalactites. Because it is amorphous and occurs in hydrated areas, limonite often occurs as clay or loamy rock.

However, there is also a pseudomorphic form of limonite that resembles other minerals, such as pyrite. This means that chemical weathering changes the pyrite crystals to limonite by hydrating the molecules, but the external shape of the pyrite crystals remains unchanged. Pseudomorphic limonite can also form from other iron oxides, namely hematite and magnetite; or from carbonate siderites and from iron-rich silicates such as almandine garnets. Limonite is usually formed from the hydration of hematite and magnetite, from the oxidation and hydration of iron-rich sulfide minerals, and from the chemical weathering of other iron-rich minerals, such as olivine, pyroxene, amphibole, and biotite. Limonite is often the largest iron component in lateritic soils. It is also frequently deposited in runoff pathways from mining operations. One of limonite's early uses was as a pigment. Yellow limonite gives the ochre yellow color that Cyprus is famous for; while the darker limonite produces earth tones. Roasting converts the limonite to some of it into hematite, which gives red ocher, burnt source and sienna colors. Swamp iron ore and limonite claystone can be mined as a source of iron, although commercial mining of these has ceased in the United States. Gosan from siliceous iron oxides is usually formed as a result of intensive oxidation of sulfide ore deposits. Gosan is used by mine prospectors as a guide to find ore. In addition, if the oxidation of the sulfide deposit contains gold, this is usually an indication of the presence of gold concentrations in the iron oxide and quartz from gosan. Gold bearing limonite gosan is productively mined in the Shasta County district of California. Similar deposits have been mined near Rio Tinto in Spain and Mount Morgan in Australia.

– in Europe   (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Estonia (Estonian: Eesti), officially the Republic of Estonia (Estonian: Eesti Vabariik), is a sovereign state in the Baltic region of Northern Europe. Estonia is bordered by the Gulf of Finland to the north, by the Baltic Sea to the west, by Latvia and the Gulf of Riga to the south (343 km), and Lake Peipus (Peipsi) and Russia to the east (338.6 km). Across the west of the Baltic Sea lies Sweden, while to the north lies Finland. Since 21 December 2007, Estonia has also ratified the 1985 Schengen Agreement, namely an agreement made by a number of European countries to eliminate border controls between them. The area of ​​Estonia is 45,227 km (17,462 sq mi), and is influenced by a temperate climate. Estonians are a Fin Baltic people, and the official language is Estonian, which is related to Finnish although only a few percent closely resembles it. Estonia is a republic with a parliamentary democracy style and is divided into 15 counties (equivalent to districts). The largest city and seat of government of Estonia is Tallinn. With a population of 1.34 million people, Estonia is one of the least populated countries in the European Union, Eurozone and NATO. Today, Estonia has the highest per capita gross domestic product of any of the former Soviet republics. Estonia is listed as a High-Income Economy by the World Bank, as an Advanced Economy by the International Monetary Fund and a high-income member of the OECD. The United Nations declares Estonia a developed country with a "Very High" Human Development Index. The country also ranks highly in terms of press freedom, economy, democracy and politics, and education. In theory, the modern name Estonia comes from the Aesti described by the Ancient Roman historian Tacitus in his work Germania (c. 98 AD).

On the other hand, ancient sagas from Scandinavia refer to a land called Eistland, which is cognate with the Danish, German, Dutch, Swedish and Norwegian terms Estland for this country. The Latin name and other ancient versions are Estia and Hestia. Esthonia was once an alternative British spelling before independence. Human settlement in Estonia probably began 11,000 to 13,000 years ago, when the ice from the last ice age melted. The oldest known settlement in Estonia is the Pulli settlement, which once existed on the banks of the Pärnu River, near the small town of Sindi, in southwestern Estonia. According to carbon dating this area has been inhabited since approximately 11,000 years ago at the beginning of the 9th millennium BC. Evidence of bands of hunters and fishermen have been found, dating from 6500 BC near the small town of Kunda in northern Estonia. Bone and stone artifacts similar to those found at Kunda have also been found elsewhere in Estonia, as well as in Latvia, northern Lithuania, and southern Finland. The Kunda culture dates back to the Middle Stone Age, or Mesolithic period. The end of the Bronze Age and the beginning of the Iron Age were marked by major cultural changes. The most significant was the shift towards agriculture, which was at the core of the economy and culture at that time. Between the 1st and 5th centuries BC, residential agriculture was widely pioneered, the population increased, and settlements expanded. Cultural influences from the Roman Empire began to reach Estonia. The first people who are said to have inhabited the area that is now Estonia were the Aesti, according to the ancient Roman historian Tacitus in his book Germania (circa 98 AD). Tacitus wrote down their terms for amber in the Latin form glesum (from the Latin glīsas).

The chemical compound formaldehyde (also called methanal, or formalin), is an aldehyde with the chemical formula H2CO. Formaldehyde was originally synthesized by the Russian chemist Aleksandr Butlerov in 1859, but was identified by Hoffman in 1867. In general, formaldehyde is formed by the catalytic oxidation reaction of methanol. Therefore, formaldehyde can be produced from burning carbon-containing materials and is contained in smoke from forest fires, car exhausts, and tobacco smoke. In the Earth's atmosphere, formaldehyde is produced from the action of sunlight and oxygen on methane and other hydrocarbons present in the atmosphere. Formaldehyde in very small levels is also produced as a metabolite of most organisms, including humans. Although in free air formaldehyde exists in gaseous form, but it is soluble in water (usually sold in a 37% solution level using the trademark 'formalin' or 'formol'). In water, formaldehyde polymerizes and very little is present in the monomer form H2CO. Generally, these solutions contain a few percent methanol to limit their polymerization. Formalin is a solution of formaldehyde in water, with levels between 10% -40%. Although formaldehyde displays the chemical properties of most aldehydes, it is more reactive than other aldehydes. Formaldehyde is an electrophile, can be used in electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions and aromatic compounds and can undergo electrophilic and alkene addition reactions. In the presence of an alkaline catalyst, formaldehyde can undergo the Cannizzaro reaction, producing formic acid and methanol. Formaldehyde can form cyclic trimers, 1,3,5-trioxane or polyoxymethylene linear polymers. The formation of this substance makes the properties of formaldehyde gas different from those of an ideal gas, especially at high pressure or cold air. Formaldehyde can be oxidized by atmospheric oxygen to form formic acid, therefore the formaldehyde solution must be covered and isolated so that air does not enter it.

Industrially, formaldehyde is prepared from the catalytic oxidation of methanol. The catalyst most often used is metallic silver or a mixture of iron oxides and molybdenum and vanadium. In the more commonly used iron oxide system (Formox process), the reaction of methanol and oxygen occurs at 250 °C and gives formaldehyde, according to the chemical equation. The catalyst using silver is usually run at a higher temperature, about 650 °C. in this situation, there will be two chemical reactions simultaneously that produce formaldehyde: one as above, while the other is a dehydrogenation reaction. When this formaldehyde is oxidized again, it produces formic acid, which is often present in formaldehyde solutions in ppm levels. On a smaller scale, formalin can also be produced from ethanol conversion, which is commercially unprofitable. Formaldehyde can be used to eradicate most bacteria, so it is often used as a disinfectant and also as a preservative. As a disinfectant, Formaldehyde is also known as formalin and is used as a cleaner; floors, ships, warehouses and clothes. Formaldehyde is also used as a preservative in vaccinations. In the medical field, formaldehyde solutions are used to dry the skin, for example removing warts. Solutions of formaldehyde are often used in embalming to kill bacteria and temporarily preserve carcasses. In industry, formaldehyde is mostly used in the production of polymers and various chemicals. When combined with phenol, urea, or melamine, formaldehyde produces a hard thermosetting resin. This resin is used for permanent glues, for example those used for plywood/plywood or carpets. Also in the form of its foam as insulation. More than 50% of formaldehyde production is spent on formaldehyde resin production. To synthesize chemicals, formaldehyde is used for the production of polyfunctional alcohols such as pentaerythritol, which is used to make explosives paints.

Gilgamesh is a king figure in the history of the Sumerian city-state of Uruk who is also a hero in Ancient Mesopotamian mythology and a major character in the Epic of Gilgamesh, an epic written in Akkadian in the late second millennium BC. He probably reigned from about 2800–2500 BC and was deified after his death. He became the main character in Sumerian legend during the Third Dynasty of Ur (c. 2112 – 2004 BC). The legend of Gilgamesh is told in five Sumerian poems that have survived to this day. Of these five poems, the oldest are probably Gilgamesh, Enkidu, and the Underworld. This poem tells the story of Gilgamesh who helps the goddess Inanna to drive away the creatures that guard the goddess' huluppu tree. In honor of Gilgamesh, the goddess gave him two objects called a mikku and a pikku, but Gilgamesh later lost them. After the death of Enkidu (who is described as Gilgamesh's servant in Sumerian poetry), his spirit tells Gilgamesh about conditions in the Underworld. Meanwhile, the poem Gilgamesh and Agga tells of Gilgamesh rebelling against King Agga. Other Sumerian poems tell of Gilgamesh defeating the giant Huwawa and the Bull of Heaven, while most of the fifth poem is lost, although it seems to be about Gilgamesh's death and burial. In Babylonian times, these poems began to form a connected narrative. The Epic of Gilgamesh was recorded by a scribe named Sîn-lēqi-unninni, probably in the Middle Babylonian Period (c. 1600 – 1155 BC) and is based on more ancient sources. In this epic, Gilgamesh is depicted as a powerful two-thirds god. He travels with Enkidu (who is described as Gilgamesh's friend in this epic) and defeats Humbaba (Huwawa's name in East Semitic).

They also killed the Bull of Heaven sent by the goddess Ishtar (the name Inanna in East Semitic) to attack them because Gilgamesh refused the goddess's request to be his consort. After Enkidu dies of disease as punishment from the gods for killing the bull, Gilgamesh becomes fearful of death and goes to Utnapishtim (the sole survivor of the Flood) for eternal life. Gilgamesh fails the test given to him by Utnapishtim and he returns to Uruk. Most historians agree that the Epic of Gilgamesh influences the Iliad and Odyssey, two epics written in Ancient Greek in the eighth century BCE. The story of Gilgamesh's birth is described in an anecdote from De Natura Animalium by the Greek writer Claudius Aelianus in the second century C.E. Aelianus relates that Gilgamesh's grandfather kept his daughter from becoming pregnant, because he received a prophecy from a seer that his grandson would beget her. The girl became pregnant and the guards threw her child from a tower, but an eagle saved her and brought her to an orchard. He was then raised by a gardener. The Gilgamesh Epic itself was rediscovered in the Ashurbanipal Library in 1849. After the contents of the epic were completed in the early 1870s, it sparked debate over its partial similarities to the Hebrew Bible. Gilgamesh remained a relatively unknown figure until the mid-20th century, but it was after that that he began to be depicted in modern culture. Most historians agree that Gilgamesh was a real historical king of the Sumerian city-state of Uruk. Sumer itself was a civilization located between the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers in southern Mesopotamia (now in southern Iraq).

Polytheism is a form of belief that acknowledges the existence of more than one God or the worship of gods (many gods). Literally comes from the Greek poly + theoi, which means many gods. The opposite of this understanding is monotheism, or the belief that only recognizes one God. Polytheism comes from the Greek πολύ poly ("many") and θεός theos ("God") and the term was first used by the Jewish writer Philo of Alexandria to refute the Greeks. At the time of the spread of Christianity throughout Europe and the Mediterranean, non-Jewish nations or religions were considered heathen (a common term used by Jews to non-Jews) or (local) idol worshipers or, in decidedly pejorative idolatry (worship of gods " false"). The modern usage of the term was first revived in French through Jean Bodin in 1580, followed by Samuel Purchas' English use in 1614. The gods of polytheism are often depicted as complex figures of greater or lesser status, with skill individuals, needs, wants, and history; in many ways similar to (anthropomorphic) humans in their personalities, but with the respective additions of powers, abilities, knowledge or perceptions. Shirk cannot be cleanly separated from the animistic beliefs prevalent in most popular religions. The gods of polytheism are in most cases the highest order of the continuum of supernatural beings or spirits, which may include ancestors, demons, wights and others. In some cases these spirits are divided into celestial or chthonic classes, and belief in the existence of all these beings does not imply that all are worshiped. In Hinduism, the concept of the Trimurti is considered a form of polytheism. The concept of polytheism is based on materialism which is naturalism.

A crystal or crystal is a solid, i.e. atoms, molecules or ions whose constituents are packed regularly and in a repeating pattern that expands in three dimensions. In general, liquids form crystals when they undergo a solidification process. Under ideal conditions, the result could be a single crystal, in which all the atoms in the solid are "attached" to the same lattice or crystal structure. While, in general, most crystals form simultaneously resulting in a polycrystalline solid. Which crystal structure will form from a liquid depends on the chemical structure of the liquid itself, the conditions under which solidification occurred, and the ambient pressure. The process of forming a crystalline structure is known as crystallization. Although the cooling process often produces crystalline materials, under certain circumstances the liquid may freeze in a non-crystalline form. In many cases, this is due to cooling too fast for the atoms to reach their lattice locations. A non-crystalline material is usually called an amorphous or glassy material. Sometimes such materials are also referred to as amorphous solids, although there is a distinct difference between solids and glasses. The process of forming glass does not release specific heat of melting (English: latent heat of fusion). For this reason, many scientists consider glass materials to be liquids, not solids. This topic is controversial, please see glass for further discussion. Crystal structures occur in all classes of materials, with all types of chemical bonds. Almost all metallic bonds exist in the polycrystalline state; amorphous metals or single crystals have to be produced synthetically, with great difficulty. Ionic-bonded crystals can form when salts solidify, either from melting liquids or condensing solutions. Covalent bond crystals are also very common. Examples are diamond, silica, and graphite. Polymer materials will generally form crystalline sections, but the length of the molecules usually prevents complete crystallization.

Weak Van der Waals forces can also play a role in crystal structure. It is this type of bond that holds the hexagonal patterned layers of graphite together. Most crystalline materials have various types of crystallographic defects. The type and structure of the defects can have a major effect on the properties of the material. Although the term "crystal" has a defined meaning in materials science and solids physics, in everyday life, the term "crystal" refers to solid objects that exhibit a certain geometric shape, and are often pleasing to the eye. Various forms of these crystals can be found in nature. The forms of crystals depend on the type of molecular bonds between atoms (to determine their structure) and the circumstances in which the crystals were created. Snowflakes, diamonds, and table salt are all examples of crystals. Some crystalline materials may exhibit special electrical properties, such as the ferroelectric effect or the piezoelectric effect. The behavior of light in a crystal is described in crystal optics. Within the periodic dielectric structure, a series of unique optical properties can be found that are described in photonic crystals. Single crystals are also referred to as monocrystalline, which is a crystalline solid that has a crystal lattice that is regularly arranged continuously and the crystal lattice that forms the frame is not damaged or the structure remains intact. According to Milligan (1979), a single crystal is a solid in which the atoms in its molecules are arranged in a repeatability where some crystalline solids are composed of millions of single crystals called grains. In the process of forming the crystal structure, in the science of crystallography it is explained in two ways, namely hcp (hexagonal close-packed) in which crystals are formed in the order of atoms ABABAB and so on and the order in which other crystals are formed is ccp (cubic close-packed) in which the order of the atoms forming them is is ABCABC and so on. The identification of a single crystal cannot be separated from the Bravais lattice because knowing the crystal system or Bravais lattice can identify the type of single crystal.

Polymers are long, repeating chains of atoms formed by bonding identical molecules called monomers. Although they are usually organic (having carbon chains), there are also many inorganic polymers. Well-known examples of polymers are plastic and DNA. A polymer is defined as a substance consisting of molecules that are joined by a chain of one or more monomer units. Humans have used polymers in the form of oils, bitumen, resins, and chewing gum for centuries. But the modern polymer industry just started to develop during the industrial revolution. In the late 1830s, Charles Goodyear succeeded in producing a useful form of natural rubber through a process known as "vulcanization". 40 years later, celluloid (a hard plastic form of nitrocellulose) was commercialized. It was the introduction of vinyl, neoprene, polystyrene, and nylon in the 1930s that started an 'explosion' in polymer research that is still ongoing today. The word polymer is derived from the Greek words poly and mer. Poly means "many", while mer means "part". Polymer has a synonym that is macromolecule. This synonym relates to synthetic polymers which are produced from simple molecules called monomers. The first use of the word polymer was made in 1833 by the Swedish chemist Berzelius. Chemists in the 19th century AD worked with macromolecules without having a clear understanding of their structure. Although the term polymer more popularly refers to plastics, polymers actually comprise many classes of natural and synthetic materials with varying properties and uses. Natural polymeric materials such as shellac and amber have been used for centuries. Paper is produced from cellulose, a naturally occurring polysaccharide found in plants. Biopolymers such as proteins and nucleic acids play an important role in biological processes.

Polymers are made by bonding small molecules called monomers into polymers by polymerization. This process forms covalent bonds between monomers to form strong bonds. With certain catalysts or processes, polymers can have linear, branched, short chain structures, or a combination of several of these structures. Based on its source, polymers can be divided into 3 groups, namely: Thermoplastic is a type of plastic that softens when it is heated and hardens when it is cooled. The process of softening and hardening thermoplastics can take place repeatedly. The name thermoplastic is obtained from the reformation of plastic properties by heating. Thermoplastics contain hydrocarbon resins and glass beads. The most common application of thermoplastics is for road marking. Road markings made of thermoplastic have high reflection, strong durability and very long service life. Thermosets are polymers that cannot melt or melt when heated. The main property of thermosets is the existence of cross-links, causing a large increase in molecular weight. Thermosets are indeformable and do not dissolve when heated. Types of thermosetting include phenol formaldehyde, urea-formaldehyde, unsaturated polyester, epoxy, and melamine-formaldehyde. Phenol-formaldehyde is used in the manufacture of electrical and electronic equipment, auto parts, plywood adhesives, and kitchen utensil handles. Urea-formaldehyde is used as a coating material. Unsaturated polyester is used in building materials, automobile parts, ship hulls, ship accessories, anti-corrosion ducts, pipes, tanks and business equipment. Epoxy is found in protective coatings, adhesives, electrical and electronic equipment, industrial flooring materials, road paving materials, and composite materials. Meanwhile, melamine-formaldehyde is widely used in decorative frames, tablecloths and cutlery. Elastomers are impression materials made of polysulfide, polyether, condensation silicone and addition silicone.

in ASEAN (dark gray)  –  Legend] Thailand, officially the Kingdom of Thailand (Thai: ราชอาณาจักรไทย, Thai pronunciation: raːt̚˥˩.t͡ɕʰa˦˥.ʔaː˧.naː˧.t͡ɕak̚˨˩.tʰaj˧]) which is read Rātcha-āṇāchạk Thai, Rāja-ādnyācạkra Thai; or (Prathēt Thai, Pradēsa Thai), Muang Thai, or Mueang Thai (pronounced: "meng-thai", the same as the English version, means "Thai Country"), is a country in Southeast Asia bordered by Laos and Cambodia to the east. , Malaysia and the Gulf of Siam to the south, and Myanmar and the Andaman Sea to the west. The Kingdom of Thailand was known as Siam until May 11, 1949. The word "Thai" (ไทย) means "freedom" in Thai, but can also refer to Thai people, which is why the name Siam is still used among Thai citizens, especially the Chinese minority. and America. Thai people migrated from Yunnan China to mainland Southeast Asia for centuries. The earliest known reference to their presence in the region relates to the exile of the Siamese in a 12th-century inscription at the Khmer Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia which calls them "fake" or "old war". The area was ruled by various Indian state governments such as the Mon, Khmer Empire, and Malay states, rival states such as Thailand's Ngoenyang, Sukhothai, Chiang Mai empire, Lan Na and Ayutthaya were also opposed. Europeans arrived in the 16th century, starting with the Portuguese diplomatic mission to Ayutthaya in 1511. The following centuries saw various European colonial powers occupy areas of IndoChina, where Thailand lost most of its territory to France and England but still the only one. Southeast Asian countries that survived the occupation. Since the reign of King Rama IV in the mid-19th century, Thailand has campaigned to modernize the country according to Western standards.

This led to a transition from absolute monarchy to constitutional monarchy in 1932. But the next 60 years saw alternating military and democratic governments, with the most recent coup in May 2014. Thailand was a founding member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and remains a key ally United States of America. Despite relatively sporadic leadership changes, it is considered a regional power in Southeast Asia and a middle power in global affairs. With a high level of human development, the second largest economy in Southeast Asia, and the 20th largest by GDP, Thailand is classified as a newly industrialized economy; manufacturing, agriculture, and tourism are the main sectors of the economy. There is evidence that humans occupied Thailand 40,000 years ago with stone artifacts dating from the Tham Lod Rock Dam in Mae Hong Son. Similar to the rest of Southeast Asia, Thailand is heavily influenced by Indian culture and religion, originating from the Funan Kingdom around the first century AD with the Khmer Empire. Thailand in its early days was subject to the powerful Khmer Empire's Hindu roots, so its influence in Thailand remains to this day. India's influence on Thai culture extends little to direct contact with Indian settlers, but is primarily attributable to the dvaravati, Srivijaya, and Cambodian kingdoms. EA. Voretzsch believes that Buddhism flowed into Siam from India for a long time from the time of the Indian Emperor Ashoka of the Mauryan Empire to the first millennium. Later Thailand was influenced by the Pallava dynasty in southern India and the Gupta Empire in northern India. According to George Cœdès, "the Thai people first entered the history of Far India in the 11th century with so-called Syrian slaves or prisoners of war" in the Champa inscriptions, and "in the 12th century, the valley of Wat Angkor" was "a kind of hero” Described as Sham.

Gold (English: gold) is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Au (Latin: 'aurum') and atomic number 79. A soft, shiny, yellow, heavy, "malleable" transition metal (trivalent and univalent) , and "ductile". Gold does not react with other chemicals but is attacked by chlorine, fluorine and aqua regia. This metal is abundant in gold nuggets or dust in rocks and in alluvial deposits and is one of the coinage metals. The ISO code is XAU. Gold melts in liquid form at about 1000°C. Gold is a metal that is soft and malleable, its hardness ranges from 2.5 – 3 (Mohs scale), and its specific gravity depends on the type and content of other metals that are alloyed with it. Gold-bearing minerals are usually associated with associated minerals (gangue minerals). These associated minerals are generally quartz, carbonate, tourmaline, flourpar, and a small amount of non-metallic minerals. Gold-bearing minerals are also associated with oxidized sulfide deposits. Gold carrier minerals consist of nativ gold, electrum, telluride gold, a number of gold alloys and compounds with the elements sulfur, antimony, and selenium. Electrum is actually another type of nativ gold, only the silver content in it is >20%. Gold formed by magmatism or concentrating on the surface. Some precipitates are formed due to contact metasomatism and hydrothermal solutions, while mechanical concentration produces placer deposits. The genesis of gold is categorized into two namely: Gold is used as a financial standard in many countries and is also used as jewelry, and electronics. The use of gold in the monetary and financial sector is based on the absolute monetary value of gold itself against various currencies around the world, although officially on world commodity exchanges, gold prices are listed in US dollars.

The form of use of gold in the monetary field is usually in the form of bullions or gold bars in various weight units from grams to kilograms. Gold was also traded in the form of gold coins, such as the Krugerrand which was produced by the South African Mint Company in various weight units. Common units of weight for krugerrands are 1/10 oz (ounce), 1/4 oz, 1/2 oz and 1 oz. The price of the Krugerrand coin is based on the movement of gold prices on world commodity markets which move continuously throughout the trading period. Special Krugerrand coins (or so-called proof collector's edition) are also produced in limited quantities according to a certain theme. Due to limited production, often the price of the proof edition of the Krugerrand coin exceeds the price of the gold content of the coin depending on the rarity and condition of this particular coin. The edition that is quite popular and sought after by investors is the one that contains a picture of Nelson Mandela. There are several countries that mass-produce gold coins to offer as an alternative to gold investment, including: Precious Metals is a Business Unit of PT Aneka Tambang which is the only certified gold and silver refining business in Indonesia. Precious metals have recognition from the LBMA (London Bullion Market Association) and have been included in the Good Delivery List of Acceptable Refiners of Gold Bars since January 1, 1999. In recent days, gold has experienced a decline in price in line with the easing of the debt crisis that wrapped around a number of European countries such as Greece and Italy. The price of gold bars on Friday, September 25, 2022, is IDR 850,000 per gram. As a reference is the international price which is around USD 1,245 per Troy Ounce. (1 USD = IDR 13,323 and 1 troy ounce = 31.10 grams).

Untranslated articles can be quickly deleted according to criteria A2. A ship (English: Ship) is a vehicle for transporting passengers and goods at sea (rivers etc.) like a smaller boat or boat. Ships are usually large enough to carry small boats such as lifeboats. Meanwhile, in English terms, it is separated between larger ships and smaller boats. Traditionally ships can carry boats but boats cannot carry ships. The actual size at which a Boat is called a Ship is always fixed by local laws and regulations or custom. For centuries, ships have been used by humans to cross rivers or seas, which was preceded by the invention of boats. Usually, in the past, human beings used canoes, rafts or boats. When the greater the need for power, the bigger the boat or the raft that was called the ship, was made. The materials used for shipbuilding in the past used wood, bamboo or papyrus stems as used by the ancient Egyptians and then used metal materials such as iron/steel because of the human need for strong ships. For propulsion, humans initially used oars and then wind with the help of sails, steam engines after the industrial revolution appeared and diesel and nuclear engines. Several studies gave rise to motorized ships that run floating on water such as Hovercraft and Ekranoplane. As well as ships used on the ocean floor, namely submarines. For centuries, ships were used to transport passengers and goods until finally, in the early 20th century, airplanes were invented that were capable of transporting goods and passengers in a short time, so ships faced stiff competition. However, ships still have the advantage of being able to transport goods with a larger tonnage so that they are more dominated by commercial ships and tankers, while many passenger ships have been diverted into cruise ships such as the Queen Elizabeth and Awani Dream.

The word "ship" in Indonesian and Malay comes from the Dravidian language family "kappal". The word started appearing in Tamil literature as கப்பல் after the 17th century. In literature from the Archipelago before the 17th century, the word ship always refers to foreign-made vessels (in this case, India). "Ship" was formerly used to refer to any coastal watercraft from the Coromandel (East coast of India), from Telugu or Ear, which had a square-rigged vessel. :66, 379 Prior to that century, boat referred to large watercraft (see K'un-lun po), until it was actually replaced by the word "ship" to refer to large watercraft. :193 The history of ships goes hand in hand with human adventures. The first known boats were known in the Neolithic period, about 10,000 years ago. These early ships had a limited function: they could move on water, but that was it. Mainly used for hunting and fishing. The oldest canoes that archaeologists have found were often made from coniferous tree trunks, using simple stone tools. About 5,000 years ago, people living near Kongens Lyngby in Denmark invented separate hulls, which allowed boats to be gradually increased in size. The boats soon developed into keel boats similar to today's woodcraft ships. To determine direction, in the past ships sailed not far from continents or land. However, in accordance with developments, the ship's crew finally used the stars as a navigational aid with aids in the form of a compass and astrolabe as well as a map. The discovery of the hourglass by the Arabs also helped navigation coupled with the invention of the clock by John Harrison in the 17th century. Invention of the telegraph by Samuel F.B. Morse and radio by G. Marconi, moreover the use of radar and sonar which was discovered in the 20th century made the role of the navigator somewhat shifted.

Television (TV) is a telecommunication medium created from the electrode beam created by John Mc. Graham of Saththam The use of the word "Television" itself can also refer to "television box", "television program", or "television transmission". The invention of television was paralleled with the invention of the wheel, because this discovery was able to change world civilization. In Indonesia, 'television' is informally often referred to as TV (pronounced: tivi, teve or tipi.) Television boxes were first sold commercially since the 1920s, and since then television has become a common item in homes, business offices, as well as institutions, particularly as a source of demand for entertainment and news as well as being an advertising medium. Since the 1970s, the emergence of video cassettes, laser discs, DVDs and now Blu-ray discs, has also made television boxes a means of viewing broadcast material as well as recordings. In recent years, broadcast television has become accessible via the Internet, for example via iPlayer and Hulu. Although there are other forms of television such as closed circuit television, the type of television most often used is broadcast television, which is based on a radio broadcasting system developed around the 1920s, using high-power radio frequency transmitters to transmit television waves to television wave receivers. TV broadcasting is usually broadcast via VHF and UHF radio waves in a defined frequency band between 54-890 megahertz. Now TV waves have also emitted stereo sound or ambient sound in many countries. Until 2000, TV broadcasts were broadcast on analog waveforms, but more recently, public and private broadcasting companies have turned to digital broadcasting technology. A television box contains various electronic circuits inside, including broadcast receiving and receiving circuits.

A visual display device that does not have a signal receiving device is usually referred to as a monitor instead of a television. A television system can be used in various technological uses such as analog (PAL, NTSC, SECAM), digital (DVB, ATSC, ISDB etc.) or high definition (HDTV). Television systems are now also used for incident observation, control of industrial processes, and weapons aiming, especially for places that are normally too dangerous to observe directly. Amateur television (ham TV or ATV) is used for experimental and public entertainment activities run by amateur radio operators. Amateur TV stations have been used in urban areas before the emergence of commercial TV stations. Television has played an important role in socialization in the 20th and 21st centuries. In 2010, iPlayer was used in social media aspects in the form of internet television services, including Facebook and Twitter. In the early days of its development, television used a combination of optical, mechanical and electronic technologies to record, display and broadcast visual images. However, by the late 1920s, television systems using only optical and electronic technology had been developed, whereas all modern television systems implemented this technology. Although mechanical systems were eventually phased out of use, the knowledge gained from the development of electromechanical systems was of great importance in the development of fully electronic television systems. The first images to be successfully transmitted electrically were via simple mechanical facsimile machines, (such as the pantelegraph) developed in the late 19th century. The concept of sending moving pictures using electrical power was first described in 1878 as the "teleponoscope" (a combined concept of a telephone and moving pictures), not long after the invention of the telephone. At the time, science fiction writers had envisioned that one day light would also be able to be transmitted via a wired medium, just like sound.

Pragmatism is a school of philosophy that teaches that the truth of everything is based on the benefits it provides. This thing is judged by its usefulness for human action for life. The statement can be in the form of speech, proposition or theory. Pragmatism emerges as a tradition of thought originating in the West and developing especially in America. Its presence as a thought that seeks to answer the problems of human life. Pragmatism is classified as one of the 19th century philosophical schools in the history of Western philosophy. The pioneer of pragmatism thought was a philosopher from the United States named Chales Sanders Peirce (1839–1914). Influential figures in pragmatist thinking include William James (1842–1910) and John Dewey (1859–1952). The idea of ​​pragmatism was first put forward by Charles Sanders Peirce in the early 1870s at a meeting of a philosophical group called the Metaphysical Club. The meeting was held in Cambridge, Massachusetts informally. The discussion results from the meeting were written by Peirce into two articles entitled The Fixation of Belief (1877) and How to Make Our Ideas Clear (1878). Both of these articles were published in a magazine called Popular Science Monthly. The term "pragmatism" comes from the Greek, namely from the word pragma. This word has many meanings, including facts, objects, material, something that is made, activities, actions, results or work. From this collection of meanings, pragmatism is defined as a thought that prioritizes the function of ideas in action. On the other hand, the term "pragmatism" was obtained by Charles Sanders Peirce from the philosophical thoughts of Immanuel Kant. In Kant's thought there are two similar words with different meanings, namelypracticch and pragmatisch. These two words come from the Greek, namelypracticos and pragmatikos.

The term practicch is defined as an action carried out for his own sake. This type of action is not found in actual experience, but exists only in reason and intellect. Meanwhile, the term pragmatisch is defined as a movement produced by the human will to provide a definitive goal as an important stage for explaining thoughts correctly. Pragmatism becomes the logic of observation as its rationale. This view states that the reality of the world seen by humans is facts that are real, separate from one another and individual. The world is shown as is, so differences can be taken for granted. The manifestation of reality is always personal and not a public fact because it only arises from the human mind. The function of service and usability becomes a means of justifying an idea. Pragmatism does not discuss the philosophical study of truth, especially with regard to metaphysics. Pragmatism is a philosophical school that assesses the truth of a theory or belief based on its level of success or benefit in practical application. The main problem for pragmatism is about the usefulness of knowledge, not the nature of knowledge. This view is based on the idea that knowledge is a means of action. Pragmatism solves theoretical and practical problems in human life by relying on the use of reason. John Dewey is one of the most influential figures in pragmatist thought. The pragmatic thinking developed by Dewey is also known as experimentalism. This naming comes from his thinking which states that human growth is the goal of education. He calls it growth because he thinks that everything in this world is always changing. John Dewey's pragmatic thinking became one of the thoughts that influenced the start of mass education. William James (1842–1910) was one of the figures who studied the human way of overcoming life's problems in the form of industrialization and economic growth.

The system comes from the Latin (systēma) and Greek (sustēma) is a unit consisting of components or elements that are linked together to facilitate the flow of information, material or energy to achieve a goal. The term is often used to describe a set of interacting entities, around which a mathematical model can often be built. The system is also a unit of interconnected parts that are in an area and have driving items, general examples such as the state. The state is a collection of several other unitary elements such as provinces that are interconnected so as to form a state in which the people who live in that country act as the driving force. The word "system" is widely used in everyday conversation, in discussion forums and scientific documents. This word is used for many things, and in many fields as well, so that the meaning becomes varied. In the most general sense, a system is a collection of objects that have relationships among themselves. In principle, every system always consists of four elements: There are several elements that make up a system, namely: objectives, inputs, processes, outputs, limits, control and feedback mechanisms and the environment. The following is an explanation of the elements that make up a system: 1. Goals Each system has a goal, either just one or maybe many. This goal is the motivator that directs the system. With out any purpose, the system becomes undirected and uncontrolled. Of course, the goals of one system with another system are different. 2. Input System input is everything that enters the system and then becomes processed material. Input can be tangible (physically visible) or invisible things.

An example of a tangible input is raw materials, while an example of an intangible one is information (eg a customer service request). 3. Process The process is the part that changes or transforms the input into a useful and more valuable output, for example in the form of information and products, but can also be in the form of things that are not useful, for example, waste or waste. In the chemical plant, the process can be a raw material. At the hospital, the surgery can be activity of the patient. 4. Output Output is the result of processing. In an information system, output can be in the form of information, suggestions, printed reports, and so on. 5. Boundary The so-called system boundary is the separator between the system and the area outside the system (environment). System limits determine the configuration, scope, or capabilities of the system. For example, a soccer team has game rules and limited player abilities. The growth of a grocery store is influenced by customer purchases, competitor movements and limited funding from banks. Of course the boundary of a system can be reduced or modified so that it will change the behavior of the system. For example, by selling shares to the public, a company can reduce its limited funds. 6. Control and Feedback Mechanisms The control mechanism is realized by using feedback, which captures the output. This feedback is used to control both input and process. The goal is to arrange for the system to run according to its purpose. 7. Environment Environment is everything that is outside the system. The environment can affect the operation of the system in the sense that it can harm or benefit the system itself. An unfavorable environment of course must be restrained and controlled so as not to disrupt the continuity of the system's operation, while a profitable environment must still be maintained, because it will spur the survival of the system.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health science History (Greek: ἱστορία, historia (meaning "to investigate, knowledge obtained through research"); Arabic: تاريخ, tārīkh; German: geschichte) is the study of the past, especially how it relates to humans . In Indonesian, history, chronicle, saga, history, dates, chronicles, tambo, or history can be interpreted as incidents and events that really happened in the past or genealogical origins (descendants), especially for reigning kings. This is an umbrella term that relates to past events and the discovery, collection, organization and presentation of information about these events. The term includes cosmic, geological, and living history, but is often taken in general terms to mean human history. Scholars who write about history are called historians or historians. Events that occurred before written records are called Prehistory. History can also refer to an academic field that uses narrative to examine and analyze the sequence of past events and objectively determine the patterns of cause and effect that shaped them. Historians sometimes debate the nature of history and its usefulness by discussing the study of historical science as an end in itself and as a way of providing "views" on contemporary problems. Stories common to a particular culture, but unsupported by outsiders (such as the stories surrounding King Arthur) are usually classified as cultural heritage or legend, because they do not support the "interested inquiry" required of the historical discipline. Herodotus, 5th century BC Greek historian in Western society is considered the "Father of History" and, along with his contemporary Thucydides, helped form the basis for the modern study of human history. Their work continues to be read today and the gap between the military-focused cultures of Herodotus and Thucydides remains a point of contention or approach in modern historical writing.

In Eastern tradition, a state chronicle of Chun Qiu is known to have been compiled starting as early as 722 BC although 2nd century BC texts survive. Ancient influences have aided the interpretation of the seed variants of historical nature that have developed over the centuries and are constantly changing today. The modern study of history is expanding, and includes the study of specific areas and the study of certain topical or thematic elements in historical inquiry. History is often taught as part of primary education, secondary education, and the academic study of history is a major subject of research at universities. The word history literally comes from the Arabic word (شجرة, šajaratun) which means tree. In Arabic itself, history is called dates (تاريخ). The word date in Indonesian means more or less the time or calendar. The word history is closer to the Greek language, namely historia, which means knowledge or clever people. Then in English it becomes history, which means the human past. Another word that is close to this reference is Geschichte which means it has happened. In terms of European languages, the origin of the term history is used in Indonesian language literature, there are several variations, however, many admit that the term history originates in Greek historia. In English it is known as history, in French historie, in Italian storia, in German geschichte, which means what happened, and in Dutch it is known as gescheiedenis. This term entered English in 1390 with the meaning of "relationship of events, stories". In Middle English, it meant "story" in general. Restrictions on the meaning of "records of past events" appeared in the late 15th century. It was still in the Greek sense at the time that Francis Bacon used the term in the late 16th century, when he wrote on "Natural History".

Commonwealth is a term originating from the fifteenth century (from English commonwealth) which literally means for the common good/prosperity. The Commonwealth originally meant a country governed for the common good and not just for the prosperity of a few people of a certain class. Today this term has a more general meaning which more or less means a political community. The type of community in question can vary, can mean: The word "Commonwealth" with a capital 'P' usually refers to the 52 members of the Commonwealth of Nations - formerly known as the "British Commonwealth" - a confederation of independent nations which were formerly part of the British Empire (with one exception, the nation of Mozambique, which was formerly owned by the Portuguese). The head of the Commonwealth of Nations is the king/queen of Britain, currently King Charles III. King Charles III also led directly in several countries, known as the Commonwealth of Nations, including the United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, and several other countries. The Commonwealth of Independent States is an alliance or confederation of 12 of the 15 former Soviet member countries (Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania not included). The creation of the commonwealth marked the end of the Soviet Union and was a way of "civilized secession" between the Soviet republics. The Commonwealth has established an economic, defense and foreign policy partnership between its members. The following states use or have used the term: In addition, the term commonwealth is also used to describe the United States' relationship with the following two territories: The six Australian states formed the Commonwealth of Australia in 1901. The Australian Parliamentary system is derived from the British system, Canada, and the United States which formed a unique new system.

The People's Republic of China (simplified Chinese: 中华人民共和国; traditional Chinese: 中華人民共和國; pinyin: Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó; literally: 'People's Republic of China', abbreviated PRC) or commonly known as China or China is a country located in East Asia whose capital city is Beijing. This country has the largest population in the world (about 1.4 billion people, the majority of whom are Han people) and a land area of ​​9.59 million square kilometers, making it the 3rd largest country in the world. The country was founded in 1949 after the end of the Chinese Civil War, and since then has been governed by a 1-party system by a single party, namely the Communist Party of the People's Republic of China/China (CCP). Although often seen as a communist state, much of the republic's economy has been privatized since the 1980s. However, the government still controls the economy politically, especially with state-owned companies and the banking sector. Politically, it remains a one-party government. Mainland China is a term used to refer to areas under the rule of the People's Republic of China/China, excluding Hong Kong, Macau, and while the Republic of China/Taiwan refers to other entities that once ruled Mainland China from 1912 until its expulsion in the Civil War. China to Formosa Island and surrounding islands in 1949. However, the Republic of China/Taiwan managed to survive and retain the rest of its territory to this day. Currently the Republic of China/Taiwan only governs the island of Formosa and the surrounding islands. The People's Republic of China/China claims territory belonging to the Republic of China/Taiwan but does not govern it, while the Republic of China/Taiwan claims sovereignty over all of mainland China which is currently controlled by the People's Republic of China/China. China's government from ancient times until today's split has had the world's largest and most complex economy for over two thousand years and dozens of dynasties of the Chinese Empire, along with several highs and lows.

Since the introduction of economic reforms in 1978 by President Deng Xiaoping, the People's Republic of China/China has become the country with the fastest growing economy in the world. As of 2013, this country is the second largest economy in the world based on total nominal GDP and PPP, as well as being the largest exporter and importer in the world. The People's Republic of China/China is a nuclear-weapon country and has the world's largest active army, with the world's second largest military spending. The People's Republic of China/China became a member of the United Nations in 1971, where it replaced and expelled the Republic of China/Taiwan as a permanent member of the UN Security Council. The People's Republic of China/China is also a member of various other organizations such as WTO, APEC, BRICS, Shanghai Cooperation Organization, BCIM and G-20. The People's Republic of China/China is a great power in Asia, and a potential super-state according to some observers. After World War II, the Chinese Civil War between the Chinese Communist Party and the Kuomintang Nationalist Party ended in 1949 with the communists taking control of Mainland China and then establishing the People's Republic of China/China. Meanwhile, the Kuomintang withdrew to the island of Formosa and continued to rule the Republic of China and some of the surrounding islands that were successfully defended. On October 1, 1949, Mao Zedong proclaimed the People's Republic of China and established a communist state, but did not try to completely annihilate the Republic of China. Proponents of Maoism say that under Mao, the unity and sovereignty of the People's Republic of China were ensured for the first time in decades, and there were developments in infrastructure, industry, health, and education, which they believed had helped raise people's living standards. They also believe that campaigns such as the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution are important in accelerating the development of the People's Republic of China and purifying their culture.

Francium is a chemical element with the symbol Fr and atomic number 87. The element was formerly known as eka-cesium. This element is highly radioactive; its most stable isotope, francium-223 (originally called actinium-K), has a half-life of only 22 minutes. It is the second lowest electronegative element after cesium and the second rarest element in nature after astatine. The isotopes of francium decay very quickly to astatine, radium, and radon. As an alkali metal, this element has one valence electron. Francium in chunk form has never been seen. If one looks at the general characteristics of the other elements in the same column on the periodic table, it is assumed that francium is a very reactive metal. Obtaining a sample was nearly impossible, because the extreme heat of decay (the half-life of the longest isotope is just 22 minutes) would quickly vaporize any visible amount of element. Francium was discovered by Marguerite Perey in France (hence the element's name) in 1939. It was the last element first discovered in nature, not synthesized. a] Outside the laboratory, francium is extremely rare, with trace amounts found in ores uranium and thorium, where the isotope francium-223 continues to form and decay. The element occurs in the Earth's crust at a rate of 20-30 g at any time; the other isotopes (except francium-221) are synthetic. The largest number produced in the laboratory is 300,000 atoms. Francium is one of the most unstable naturally occurring elements: the isotope francium-223 has the longest half-life, only 22 minutes.
