In comparison with elemental astatine, the most stable naturally occurring isotope, astatine-219, has a half-life of 56 seconds, although synthetic astatine-210 has a much longer half-life (8.1 hours).

All francium isotopes decay into astatine, radium, or radon. Francium-223 also has a shorter half-life than the isotopes of all synthetic elements up to element 105, dubnium. Francium is an alkali metal whose chemical properties largely resemble that of cesium. A heavy element with one valence electron, it has the highest equivalent weight of all the elements. Liquid francium—if prepared—should have a surface tension of 0.05092 N/m at its boiling point. The melting point of francium is calculated to be around 27°C (80°F, 300 K). The melting point is uncertain due to the rarity of this element and its radioactivity. Thus, the estimated boiling point value of 677°C (1250°F, 950 K) is also uncertain. Linus Pauling estimated the electronegativity of francium to be 0.7 on the Pauling scale, the same as that of cesium; the value for cesium has been refined to 0.79, but there are no experimental data to allow for an improvement in the value for francium. Francium has a slightly higher ionization energy than cesium, 392.811(4) kJ/mol (cesium 375.7041(2) kJ/mol). Francium also has a higher electron affinity than cesium and the Fr− ion should be more polarized than the Cs− ion. There are 34 known isotopes of francium ranging from atomic masses 199 to 232. Francium has seven metastable nuclear isomers. Francium-223 and francium-221 are the only isotopes that occur in nature. Francium-223 is the most stable isotope with a half-life of 21.8 minutes, and until recently it was thought that it would not be possible to find a francium isotope with a longer half-life. Francium-223 is the fifth product in the actinium decay series as the daughter isotope of actinium-227. Francium-223 then decays to radium-223 by beta decay (decay energy 1149 keV), and minor (0.006%) by alpha decay to astatine-219 (decay energy 5.4 MeV).

Islam (Arabic: الإسلام‎, listen) is a religion (Din) of Abrahamic monotheism centered primarily around the Koran, a religious text considered by Muslims to be holy book and the direct word of God (Muslims refer to it as Allah ) as revealed to Muhammad, the main and final prophet of Islam. By 2020, it is estimated that 1.9 billion people around the world will follow Islam, making it the second largest religion after Christianity. Muslims believe that Islam is the complete and universal version of the primordial faith that was handed down many times through previous prophets such as Adam, Abraham, Musa, and Isa (Jesus), among others; This earlier revelation was associated with Judaism and Christianity, which are considered in Islam as spiritual predecessor religions. They also consider the Quran, when preserved in Classical Arabic, as God's unchanging and final revelation to mankind. Like other Abrahamic religions, Islam also teaches about the "Final Judgment" where the righteous will be rewarded in heaven (Jannah) and the unrighteous will be punished in hell (Jahannam). Religious concepts and practices include the Pillars of Islam —considered as obligatory worship — and following Islamic law (shari'a), which touch on almost every aspect of life, from banking and finance and welfare to the role of women and the environment. The cities of Mecca, Medina and Jerusalem are home to the three holiest sites in Islam, in descending order: the Grand Mosque, the Prophet's Mosque and Al-Aqsa Mosque, respectively. "Islam" in Arabic is the quadri-literal infinitive noun form (maṣdar rubā‘ī). The triliteral active perfect verb form (fi‘l māḍi ṡulaṡī mabnī ma‘lūm) is salima (سلم, "congratulations"). The semantic meaning of this quadriliteral form is submission and obedience (khadha'a wa istaslama), surrender, submit, surrender (sallama), follow (atba'a), fulfill, deliver (addā), or enter into peace, safety , or purity (dakhala fi al-salm au al-silm au al-salām).

All terms that have the same root as "Islām" are closely related to the meaning of safety, peace, and purity. In terms, Islam means surrender; submission and obedience to God's commands as well as surrendering and accepting with satisfaction to His provisions and laws. The concept of "surrender" in Islam to God is not a term for fatalism, but rather as the opposite of reluctance in following religious teachings and preferring to choose an easy path in life. A Muslim follows God's commands without opposing or questioning them, but with an effort to understand his wisdom. The term "Islam" can also be interpreted as a religion given by God to the Prophet Muhammad as a way of salvation in this world and the hereafter whose teachings are based on monotheism and are applied in all aspects of human life. Islam is actually also used to refer to the monotheistic beliefs shared by the heavenly religions (currently Judaism and Christianity); see QS al-Maidah verse 44, QS Ali Imran verse 67 and 52. However, Islam is more popularly used for the religion brought by Muhammad as found in a verse of the Qur'an that was revealed at the end of his prophethood: Islam is a religion Allah revealed for all mankind. In it there are guidelines and rules for happiness in this world and the hereafter. There are three things that are the main links in the religion of Islam itself, namely Faith, Islam, and Ihsan. In a hadith, it is mentioned: "From Umar bin al-Khattab RA, said: "One day we gathered with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, suddenly there came a man whose clothes were very white, his hair was very black. There were no signs that he had traveled far, and none of us knew him. The man then sat in front of the Prophet ﷺ while putting his knees on the Prophet ﷺ's knees.

Pollution or pollution is the entry or inclusion of living things, substances, energy and/or other components into water or air. Pollution can also mean changes in the order (composition) of water or air due to human activities and natural processes, so that the quality of the water/air becomes less or cannot function according to its designation. Pollution of the environment can occur anywhere at a very fast rate, and the burden of pollution is getting heavier due to industrial waste from various chemicals including heavy metals. Environmental pollution occurs when the cycle of matter in the environment changes so that the balance in terms of structure and function is disrupted. Imbalance in the structure and function of the material cycle occurs due to natural processes or also due to human actions. Development in the era of globalization is supported by the emergence of very sophisticated technology that can have a very large impact on environmental changes caused by environmental pollution by garbage and waste from development and technology. Residual waste or industrial waste can be in the form of gas or dust, liquids and solids. The remaining liquid waste released by industrial processes is often called industrial waste water. Industrial wastewater varies in amount and intensity of pollution, according to the unit of operation or process that is the source. This liquid waste can cause environmental pollution, namely if this waste or material cannot be destroyed by living organisms and accumulates in environmental components, it will cause health problems. Wastes that cause environmental pollution include oil, detergents, acids and alkalis, metal-containing liquid waste. The process of industrialization in a country only focuses on increasing the amount of production and the economic side without seeing the negative impact of the process.

The industrialization process will utilize as many resources as possible and then be processed as optimally as possible so that the waste materials released by an industry generally become very concentrated and harmful to the surrounding environment. Environmental pollution that occurs unknowingly will cause an imbalance in the environment or existing ecosystems. Because pollution will damage the state that was originally good to be bad. when there is pollution there will be a lot of disturbance, not only humans but animals and also plants. Environmental pollution can occur anywhere, one of which is the river. The condition of the river which is polluted due to waste and garbage can cause a lot of garbage to accumulate on the banks of the river and the water is cloudy and smells fishy. Waste and garbage have great potential in environmental pollution because it causes a decrease in the quality of the environment and damages its natural ecosystem. The negative impact of decreasing environmental quality, whether due to pollution or damage to natural resources, is the emergence of threats or negative impacts on health, decreased aesthetic value, economic losses and disruption of natural systems. The negative impact on public health will be felt in the long term. With the contamination of the environment by waste and garbage, the aesthetic value of the environment will decrease, the polluted environment will look dirty and cannot be used for daily purposes. Pollution of the environment will also disrupt the natural systems of the environment, the components contained in the environment will be damaged. Environmental pollution greatly affects flora and fauna. When pollutants enter the environment, they will kill several types of living flora and fauna. Environmental pollution will lead to a reduction in soil fertility. This decline is due to the excessive use of insecticides.

Enzymes are biomolecules in the form of proteins that function as catalysts (compounds that speed up the reaction process without being finished reacting) in an organic chemical reaction. Enzymes function as biocatalysts of a chemical reaction. The energy required by enzymes in chemical reactions is very small so that it functions to lower the activation energy. The initial molecule called the substrate will be accelerated to change into another molecule called the product. All biological processes of the cell require enzymes in order to proceed quickly enough in a certain direction of metabolic pathway. Enzymes work by reacting with substrate molecules to produce intermediate compounds through an organic chemical reaction that requires a lower activation energy, so that the acceleration of chemical reactions occurs because chemical reactions with higher activation energies take longer. For example: Although the catalyst compound may change in the initial reaction, in the final reaction the catalyst molecule will return to its original shape. Most enzymes work uniquely, which means that each type of enzyme can only work on one type of chemical compound or reaction. This is due to differences in the chemical structure of each enzyme which is fixed. For example, the α-amylase enzyme can only be used in the process of breaking down starch into glucose. Enzyme work is influenced by several factors, especially the substrate, temperature, acidity, cofactors and inhibitors. Each enzyme requires a different optimum temperature and pH (acidity level) because enzymes are proteins, which can change shape if the temperature and acidity change. Outside the appropriate temperature or pH, enzymes cannot work optimally or their structure will be damaged. This will cause the enzyme to lose its function completely. Enzyme work is also influenced by other molecules. Inhibitors are molecules that decrease enzyme activity, while activators are those that increase enzyme activity.

Many drugs and poisons are enzyme inhibitors. At least in the late 17th and early 18th centuries, several processes involving enzymes were known, namely the digestion of meat by gastric secretions and the breakdown of starch into sugars by plant extracts and saliva. However, the mechanisms by which these processes occur have not been identified. French chemist Anselme Payen was the first scientist to discover an enzyme, namely diastase, in 1833. Decades later, Louis Pasteur, who was researching the fermentation of sugar into alcohol using yeast, wrote that this fermentation reaction was caused by a "vital force" contained in yeast cells, referred to as "ferment", according to which it only functions in the body of living organisms. He wrote that "alcoholic fermentation is an action related to the life and order of the yeast cells, and not to their death or decay." In 1878, the German physiologist Wilhelm Kühne (1837–1900) first used the term "enzyme", which comes from the Greek ενζυμον meaning "in leavening agent" or "in yeast", to describe this process. The word "enzyme" (enzyme) was later used to refer to inanimate substances such as pepsin, and the word ferment was used to refer to chemical activities produced by living organisms. In 1897, Eduard Buchner began his series of scientific papers on yeast extract. In experiments at the University of Berlin, he found that the fermentation of sugar by yeast extract continued even if there were no surviving yeast cells in the mixture. He named the enzyme that triggers this fermentation of sucrose "zymase" (zimase). In 1907, he received the Nobel Prize in chemistry for "discovering cellless fermentation". The nomenclature of enzymes up to now has followed Buchner's example, namely with the ending -ase and according to the reaction catalyzed by the enzyme.

The tundra is a biome where tree growth is hampered by low ambient temperatures. Therefore, this area is called a treeless area. Tundra is found in the northern region of the earth (the arctic circle), is also found near Antarctica, and is found on high mountain peaks. Plant growth in tundra areas lasts only 60 days. The only types of plants found in the tundra are those that can survive cold weather, such as sphagnum, lichens, annuals, shrubs, and reeds. A polar climate with long, dark winters and persistently long, sunny summers and low rainfall characterizes this biome. The word "tundra" comes from the Russian тундра (tûndra) with the Sami word tūndâr meaning "highland" or "treeless mountain area". The tundra biome can be divided into two types, namely arctic tundra and alpine tundra. The Arctic tundra is located around the North Pole and is the youngest biome in the world. The Arctic tundra region extends southward into the conifer forests of the taiga. Alpine tundra sits at relatively high altitudes over cold mountains around the world. One of the alpine tundra areas is at the top of the Jayawijaya mountains (Papua). In the alpine tundra, it is very difficult for trees to grow because the soil does not have enough nutrients. The tundra biome is a biome that is found in the northern polar ring area and a small part in the south. At the North Pole, this biome is found around the arctic, including Greenland. While at the south pole, this biome is found in Antarctica and the small islands around it. The tundra in the arctic is vast, accounting for 20% of Earth's land surface.

The tundra biome has an arctic climate because it is located in the Arctic environmental area. The main feature of the tundra is that it is a treeless plain. The plants that grow in the tundra biome are mostly mosses and lichens. Other plants in the tundra biome have a very small amount, namely grasses and flowering plants with small sizes. The tundra biome is an area that has very long winters so it gets very little solar radiation energy. Winter can last as long as 9 months, so it's always dark inside the tundra biome. Plant growth occurs in summer which lasts only 3 months. In the tundra biome, there are two typical fauna, namely muskox and wildebeest. The height of the plant growth in the tundra only reaches the height of the average bush. The plants that are abundant in this area are included in the type of moss, especially spongnum and lichen. The color of the flowers from plants that grow in tundra areas are usually very striking. Plant growth period is also very short. In certain areas of the tundra certain types of plants grow. The marshy areas are mostly covered with sedge grass, cotton grass and peat mounds. Salik and Betua shrubs grow in wet basins such as Greenland. Areas that are a bit dry grow moss, puzzles, Ericeceae plants, and some plants with rather broad leaves. Meanwhile, lichens and algae grow on rock slopes. The fauna in this region generally have thick fur and layers of fat to keep their bodies warm. Some of the animals that live in the tundra region are sedentary and some come only in the summer.

In biology, a living thing or organism (from Greek: ὀργανισμός, organismos) is any individual entity capable of carrying out the functions of life. All organisms have cells. Organisms are classified on the basis of taxonomy and are grouped into groups such as animals, plants and fungi which are multicellular; or unicellular microorganisms such as protists, bacteria, and archaea. All types of organisms are capable of reproduction, growth and development, self-maintenance, and some forms of response to stimuli. Humans, squid, fungi, and vascular plants are all examples of multicellular organisms that differentiate to form specialized tissues and organs during development. Organisms can be classified into prokaryotes or eukaryotes. Prokaryotes include two separate domains, namely bacteria and archaea. Eukaryotes are characterized by the presence of a cell nucleus that is covered with a membrane and has organelles, which are also covered with a membrane (examples of organelles are mitochondria in animals and plants, and plastids in plants and algae, generally all organelles are considered to originate from endosymbiotic bacteria). Fungi, animals, and plants are examples of kingdoms within eukaryotes. Estimates of the number of species on Earth today range from two million to one trillion and more than 1.7 million of them have been documented. More than 99% of all the species with over five billion species that have ever lived are now thought to be extinct. In 2016, 355 genes from the last universal ancestor (LUCA) of all organisms were identified. The term "organism" (from the Greek ὀργανισμός, organismos, from ὄργανον, organon, i.e. "instrument, tool, sense organ, or organ") first appeared in English in 1703. It is directly related to the term "organization". . There is a long tradition of defining organisms as self-organizing beings, at least in Immanuel Kant's 1790 Critique of Judgment.

An organism can be defined as a functioning (more or less stable) collection of molecules that exhibit the properties of life. The dictionary definition could be broader, using phrases such as "any living structure, such as a plant, animal, fungus, or bacterium, capable of growth and reproduction." Many definitions exclude viruses and possibly man-made inorganic life forms because viruses depend on the host cell's biochemical machinery to reproduce. A superorganism is an organism consisting of many individuals working together as a single functional or social unit. Controversy exists about the best way to define organisms and about whether or not such a definition is necessary. Several studies were written in response to suggestions that the category "organism" may be inadequate in biology. page required] Viruses are not usually considered organisms because they are incapable of independent reproduction, growth, or metabolism. Although some organisms are also unable to survive on their own and must live as intracellular parasites, they are capable of metabolizing and reproducing independently. Although viruses possess some of the enzymes and molecules characteristic of living organisms, they do not have their own metabolism; viruses are unable to synthesize and organize the organic compounds that compose them. Naturally, these cannot be called autonomous reproduction: they can only be passively replicated by the host cell. In this respect, they are similar to inanimate objects. Although viruses do not maintain their metabolism independently and are therefore not classified as organisms, they do have their own genes and evolve by a mechanism similar to that of organisms. Thus, the argument that viruses should be classified as living organisms is based on their ability to evolve and replicate through self-assembly.

Astronomy Chemistry Earth Science Astrophysics is a field of science that studies the physical properties of astronomical objects and phenomena in the universe. Astrophysics deals with objects in outer space as well as Earth. Sometimes, the name may change with astronomy because the scope of study is similar to modern times. Astronomy is an ancient science, long separated from the study of terrestrial physics. In Aristotle's worldview, the objects in the sky looked like unchanging spheres and their only motion was uniform motion in a circle. Meanwhile, the terrestrial world is a realm undergoing growth and decay, and its motion is in a straight line that ends when the object reaches its destination. It has been suggested that outer space is made of a different type of matter than that found in the terrestrial world; believed by Aristotle to be the Aether, or as Fire by Plato. During the 17th century, natural philosophers such as Galileo, Descartes, and Newton began to argue that the celestial and terrestrial regions were made of similar types of matter and were subject to the same laws of nature. Their challenge was that at that time no tools had been found to prove this statement. During the nineteenth century, astronomical research focused on the routine measurements and calculations of the positions and motions of astronomical objects. A new branch of astronomy, later to be called astrophysics, only emerged when William Hyde Wollaston and Joseph von Fraunhofer independently discovered that many dark lines (areas where there is little or no light) are observed in the spectrum when sunlight is described. In 1860, physicist Gustav Kirchhoff and chemist, Robert Bunsen, observed that the dark lines in the spectrum of the Sun correspond to the light lines in the spectra of known gases, corresponding to unique chemical elements.

Kirchhoff concluded that the dark lines in the Sun's spectrum were caused by the absorption of chemical elements in the Sun's atmosphere. In this way it was proved that the chemical elements found in the Sun and stars are also found on Earth. In 1868, Norman Lockyer studied the light and dark lines in the Sun's spectrum. He worked with the chemist Edward Frankland to investigate the spectra of the elements at various temperatures and pressures but was unable to connect the yellow lines in the Sun's spectrum to those of the elements that were then known. He later stated the line represented a new element, called helium, from the Greek Helios, the sun god. In 1885, Edward C. Pickering ran the stellar spectrum classification program at the Harvard College Observatory, where a team of computer girls, notably Williamina Fleming, Antonia Maury, and Annie Jump Cannon, classified the spectra recorded on photographic plates. In 1890, a catalog of more than 10,000 stars was compiled, grouped into thirteen spectral types. In 1924, Cannon expanded the catalog to nine volumes with more than 250,000 stars, developing the Harvard Classification Scheme used worldwide in 1922. In 1895, George Ellery Hale and James E. Keeler, along with ten fellow editors from Europe and United States, founded The Astrophysical Journal. The journal is intended to fill gaps in journals in astronomy and physics, providing a venue for the publication of articles on the applications of the spectroscope in astronomy; laboratory research closely related to astronomical physics; experiments on solar radiation and absorption; the theory of the Sun, Moon, planets, comets, meteors and nebulae; and instrumentation for telescopes and laboratories. Around 1920, when the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram was still used as the basis for classifying stars and their evolution, Arthur Eddington anticipated the discovery and mechanism of the process of nuclear fusion in stars in his paper The Internal Constitution of the Stars.

Sikhs (/siːk, sɪk/; Punjabi: ਸਿੱਖ sikkh sɪkkʰ]) are followers of Sikhism which is a panentheistic religion that originated in the 15th century in the Punjab region of the northwestern Indian subcontinent. The term "Sikh" comes from the Sanskrit words शिष्य (śiṣya; follower, disciple) or शिक्ष (śikṣa; instruction). According to Article I of the Sikh Rehat Maryada, a Sikh is "any human being who believes in One Eternal God; ten Gurus, from Guru Nanak to Guru Gobind Singh; Guru Granth Sahib; teachings of ten Gurus and Khalsa". The term "Sikh" actually refers only to followers of Sikhism and not to any ethnic group. However, Sikhism rarely seeks outsiders, so most Sikhs have strong ethno-religious ties. Because of this, many countries (such as the United Kingdom) recognize the Sikhs as an ethnic group in their censuses. Sikh men have the middle or last name "Singh" (lion), while women have the name "Kaur" (princess). Sikhs who have gone through the khanḍe-kī-pahul (Sikh initiation rites) can also be identified by the five K's: Kesh, uncut hair covered with a turban; kara, iron or steel bracelet; kirpan, a sword tucked into a gatra strap or coarse kamal belt; kachera, cotton underwear; and kanga, a small wooden comb. The homeland of the Sikhs is the Punjab region of the Indian subcontinent, although in modern times they have spread to various countries, including the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada, Germany, Malaysia and Indonesia. . "Architectural Heritage of a Sikh State: Faridkot" by Subhash Parihar, Delhi: Aryan Books International, 2009, ISBN 978-81-7305-386-3 This article on the topic of religion or belief is a stub. This culture-related article is a stub.

Glass comes from materials that are liquid but have a high density, and an amorphous structure. The atoms in it do not form an orderly network, like crystals, or what is commonly called glass. Glass is mostly made from silica (SiO2), a mixture of sandstone and flux which produces a low viscosity and melting point, which is then mixed again with a stabilizer to make it strong. Window glass, lamps and bottles, are classified as sodalime glass which is made of silica (SiO2), soda flux, (Na2O) and stabilizer lime or lime clay (CaO) with magnesia MgO which is slightly mixed with alumina (Al2O2). The type of heat-resistant glass is borosilicate glass. This glass is made of silica, boron oxide (B2O3), alumina and soda which have a high melting point and do not break easily when heated, because the coefficient of expansion is very small. Glass like this is usually called pyrex. Fused silica glass or self-melting quartz, and 99.9% silica have a melting point of 1,580°C, low coefficient of expansion, transparent to ultraviolet and infrared radiation. The green color on the glass serves to indicate the presence of ferrous ions. This color can be removed by adding sodium nitrate or manganese dioxide at the manufacturing stage. To make blue glass we can use cobalt oxide, purple with manganese oxide, also red gold or selen, yellow with uranium oxide or plot, brown with ferrous ions, black with iridium oxide or a mixture of other oxide elements (cobalt, iron, nickel and manganese). . Milk glass is made from either or a mixture of calcium fluoride, arsenic trioxide, aluminum oxide, zinc oxide, and calcium phosphate. Safety glass is glass that is resistant to impact.

This glass is made of two layers of glass bonded together using a thin layer of cellulose acetate or other plastic material. This glass serves to protect the face area when someone is welding. Especially in electric welding activities. The glass is dark overall, because it has to absorb all infrared, ultraviolet, most other light that can cause glare. In protecting the dark glass from welding sparks, there is a clear protective glass that is installed on the outside of the glass. For electric welding, this tool becomes part of a welding mask or welding helmet. Is an optical instrument that is worn on the area in front of the eye, which functions as a lens and helps correct eye refractive errors. This disorder occurs due to a lack of eye refraction, with shorter eyeballs, or too strong eye refraction, with longer eyeballs. Glasses can be divided into several types, namely glasses with convex lenses (positive) for people with nearsightedness (hyperopia), glasses with concave lenses (negative) for people with nearsightedness (myopia). Glasses users who are over 10 years old, need bifocal glasses. Bifocal glasses are double-lens glasses, with the top lens for far vision and the bottom lens for near vision. Glass is widely used because of its transparent and light-permeable composition. The nature of polycrystalline, on the contrary, does not have the ability to conduct light. Crystals, in separate forms may be transparent, but the boundary grains of the crystal are able to reflect or emit light and produce diffuse reflections. Glass does not contain the internal parts associated with the limiting grains of polycrystalline and is not as capable of transmitting light as polycrystalline.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Italy ( Italy (help·info)), officially the Italian Republic (Italian: Repubblica Italiana), is a unitary parliamentary republic in Europenote 1] Located in the heart of the Mediterranean Sea. Italy is bordered by France, Switzerland, Austria, Slovenia, San Marino and the Vatican. Italy covers an area of ​​301,338 km² (116,347 mi²), and is influenced by a temperate and Mediterranean climate. Judging from its shape, the map of Italy is shaped like a boot or in Italy it is often called lo Stivale. With a population of 61 million people, Italy is the third most populous European Union member state after Germany and France. Since the Classical Era, Italy has been inhabited by various nations and civilizations. Like the Phoenicians, Carthaginians, and ancient Greeks who settled in southern Italy, the Etruscans and Celts inhabited central and northern Italy, and Ancient Italic and Italic tribes scattered throughout the Italian Peninsula and Insular Italy (Sardinia and Sicily). . The Italic tribes or known as the Latins formed the Roman Empire which eventually became a republic which managed to conquer and assimilate other nearby civilizations. Rome eventually emerged as the dominant power in the Mediterranean basin, successfully conquering most of the ancient world and becoming the leading cultural, political and religious center of Western civilization. The legacy of the Roman Empire is widespread and can be seen in the global channels of distribution of civil law, republican government, Christianity and Latin writing. During the Middle Ages, Italy experienced sociopolitical collapse amid costly barbarian invasions, but in the 11th century many Italian city-states and maritime republics rose to prosperity through shipping, commerce, and banking, laying the foundations for modern capitalism.

Independent statelets,note 2] which acted as Europe's principal trade center with Asia and the Near East, enjoyed a greater degree of democracy and wealth than the feudal monarchies that were consolidating across Europe at the time. Most of Central Italy remained under the control of the theocratic Papal States, while Southern Italy was feudal until the 19th century, as a result of a succession of Byzantine, Arab, Norman, Spanish and Bourbon conquests in the region. The Renaissance started in Italy and spread across Europe, bringing with it new interests in humanism, science, exploration and art. During this time Italian culture flourished, and produced famous scholars, artists and polymaths such as Leonardo da Vinci, Galileo, Michelangelo and Machiavelli. Also famous Italian explorers such as Marco Polo, Christopher Columbus, Amerigo Vespucci and Giovanni da Verrazzano discovered new routes to the Far East and the New World, which aided the European Age of Exploration. However, Italy's commercial and political power diminished with the opening of the Atlantic trade route and the route to the Indian Ocean via the Cape of Good Hope across the Mediterranean. Again, the Italian city-states engaged in bloody wars, culminating in the Italian Wars of the 15th and 16th centuries, which eventually exhausted them, with no one emerging as the dominant force. The weakened rulers soon fell victim to the conquests of European powers such as France, Spain and Austria. In the mid-19th century, a movement arose to support Italian nationalism and independence from foreign control. This movement led to a revolutionary political upheaval called the Risorgimento to unite the countries in Italy. After many failed attempts, the Italian War of Independence and the Thousand Expedition finally unified the countries of Italy in 1861, and are now a major power after centuries of foreign domination.

Actinium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Ac and atomic number 89. It is a radioactive chemical element that was discovered in 1899. It was the first non-primordial radioactive element to be isolated: polonium, radium and radon were observed before actinium, but were isolated only recently in 1902. Actinium gave its name to the actinide series, a group of 15 elements similar to actinium and lawrencium on the periodic table. It is also sometimes considered the first 7th period transition metal, although lawrencium is less common in that position. A soft, silvery-white, radioactive metal, actinium reacts rapidly with oxygen and moisture in air to form a white layer of actinium oxide that prevents further oxidation. Like most of the lanthanides and actinides, actinium has an oxidation state of +3 in almost all of its chemical compounds. Actinium is found only in trace amounts in uranium and thorium ores as the isotope 227Ac, ​​which decays with a half-life of 21.772 years, with predominantly emission of beta and occasionally alpha particles, and 228Ac, which is beta active with a half-life of 6.15 hours. One ton of natural uranium in its ore contains about 0.2 milligrams of actinium-227, and one tonne of natural thorium contains about 5 nanograms of actinium-228. The similar physical and chemical properties of actinium and lanthanum make it impractical to separate actinium from its ores. Instead, the element is prepared, in milligram amounts, by irradiating 226Ra neutrons in a nuclear reactor. Due to its rarity, high price and radioactivity, actinium has no significant industrial uses. Current applications include neutron sources and agents for radiotherapy targeting cancer cells in the body. André-Louis Debierne, a French chemist, announced the discovery of a new element in 1899.

He separated it from the pitchblende residue left by Marie and Pierre Curie after they extracted the radium. Around 1899, Debierne described the substance as similar to titanium and (in 1900) as similar to thorium. Friedrich Oskar Giesel independently discovered actinium in 1902 as a substance similar to lanthanum and called it "emanium" in 1904. After comparing the half-lives of the substances determined by Debierne, Harriet Brooks in 1904, and Otto Hahn and Otto Sackur in 1905 , Debierne's choice of name for the new element was retained out of consideration of seniority, despite the conflicting chemical properties he claimed for this element at different times. Articles published in the 1970s and later pointed out that Debierne's results published in 1904 contradicted those reported in 1899 and 1900. Furthermore, the chemistry of actinium known today precludes its presence as anything other than a minor constituent of Debierne's results in 1899 and 1900. In fact, the chemistry he reported makes it probable he had, by accident, identified protactinium, which would not be discovered for another fourteen years, only to have it disappear due to hydrolysis and adsorption on his laboratory equipment. This has led some authors to suggest that Giesel himself should be credited with the discovery. A cooler vision of scientific discovery was proposed by Adloff. He suggested that criticism of early publications had to be reconciled with the nascent state of radiochemistry: highlighting the caution with Debierne's claims in early newspapers, he noted that no one could argue that Debierne's substance did not contain actinium. Debierne, who is now credited by most historians as its discoverer, lost interest in the element and left the topic.

Positivism Functionalism Antipositivism Conflict theory Structuralism Symbolic interaction Intermediate distance Mathematical Critical theory Socialization Quantitative structures and agents Computational Qualitative Ethnography religion culture economic demographics law science science internet industry social networking gender crime class class family health city education environment knowledge deviance social psychology medical mobility politics race & ethnicity rationalization secularization stratification Journal Publishing Outline List of sociologists Index of Modernity is the jargon used in the humanities and social sciences to refer to a period of history (the modern era) and a particular mix of socio-cultural norms, behaviors and practices that emerged in post-medieval Europe and have developed worldwide since then. While it includes a variety of interrelated historical processes and cultural phenomena (from fashion to modern warfare), modernity can also refer to the subjective or existential experience of existing situations and their impact on human culture, institutions, and politics (Berman 2010, 15– 36). As a historical event, modernity refers to periods of criticism or rejection of tradition; prioritizing individualism, freedom and legal equality; belief in social, scientific, and technological progress, and human perfection; rationalization and professionalization, the shift from feudalism (or agrarianism) to capitalism and a market economy; industrialization, urbanization, and secularization; the formation of the nation-state and its subordinate institutions (eg representative democracy, public education, modern bureaucracy); and various forms of reconnaissance (Foucault 1995, 170–77). A number of writers have argued that the number of modernities may be more than one because the definition of the term and the history itself are not fixed. Charles Baudelaire is credited with coining the term "modernity" (modernité) in his 1864 essay, "The Painter of Modern Life".

The meter (symbol: m; English: metre, French: mètre) is the basic unit of length in the International System of Units (SI). After being redefined in 2019, the definition of the meter unit, as stated in the ninth edition of the SI Brochure, is as follows. The meter, symbolized by m, is the SI unit of length. This unit is defined by obtaining a fixed numerical value of the speed of light in a vacuum c of 299,792,458 when expressed in units of m⋅s−1, with the definition of second being determined with respect to the cesium frequency ∆νCs. The meter was originally defined in 1793 as one ten millionth of the distance from the equator to the North Pole along the great circle, so that the circumference of the Earth is approximately 40,000 km. In 1799, the meter was redefined in terms of a prototype meter bar (the actual bar used was changed in 1889). In 1960, the meter was redefined in terms of the specific number of wavelengths of a specific krypton-86 emission line. The current definition was adopted in 1983 and modified slightly in 2002 to make it clear that the meter is a proper measure of length. The etymological root of the word meter can be traced to the Greek verb μετρέω (metreo) (measure, count or compare) and the noun μέτρον (metron) (measure), which were used for physical measurement, for poetic meter and by extension for moderation or avoidance. extremism (as in "measured in your response"). This range of usage is also found in Latin (metior, mensura), French (mètre, mesure), English, and other languages. The Greek word comes from the Proto-Indo-European root *meh₁- 'to measure'. The motto ΜΕΤΡΩ ΧΡΩ (metro chro) on the badge of the International Bureau of Measures and Scales (BIPM), which is a saying of the Greek statesman and philosopher Pittakus of Methylene and can be translated as "Take measure!

", calling for both measurement and moderation. The use of the word meter (for the French unit mètre) in English dates back to at least 1797. The meter was originally defined by the French Academy of Sciences (Académie des sciences) as 110 000 000 distances along the surface of the Earth from the North Pole to the equator via the Paris meridian in 1791, and on 7 April 1795 France adopted the meter as the official distance for length.Uncertainty in the measurement of this distance led the International Bureau of Measures and Scales (BIPM - Bureau International des Poids et Mesures) to define 1 meter as the distance between two lines on a platinum-iridium bar kept at Sèvres, France in 1889. In 1960, when the laser was introduced, the 11th General Conference on Measures and Scales (CGPM - Conférence Générale des Poids et Mesures) changed the definition of the meter as 1.650 .763.73 times the wavelength of the orange-red light spectrum of krypton-86 atoms in s a vacuum. In 1983, the BIPM defined the meter as the distance traveled by light through a vacuum in 1299 792 458 seconds (the speed of light is set at 299,792,458 meters per second). Since the speed of light in a vacuum is the same everywhere, this definition is more universal than the distance measured around the Earth or a certain length of metal rod. Therefore, if the metal bar is lost or destroyed, standard meter lengths can still be repeated in any laboratory. In addition, meters can theoretically be measured more precisely than other sizes. SI prefixes can be used to denote decimal multiples and submultiples of meters, as shown in the table below. Long distances are usually expressed in km, astronomical units (149.6 Gm), light years (10 Pm), or parsecs (31 Pm), not in Mm, Gm, Tm, Pm, Em, Zm or Ym; "30 cm", "30 m" and "300 m" are more common than "3 dm", "3 checkers" and "3 hm".

Sulfide (systematic name is sulfanediide, and sulfide(2−)) is an inorganic anion of sulfur (or sulfur) with the chemical formula S. It does not give color to sulfide salts. Because it is classified as a strong base, dilute solutions of its salts such as sodium sulfide (Na) are corrosive and can attack the skin. Sulfide is the simplest sulfur anion. The systematic names are sulfanediides and sulfide(2−), valid IUPAC names, defined according to substitutive and additive nomenclature. However, the name sulfide is also used in compositional IUPAC nomenclature regardless of the nature of the bonds involved. Examples of such names are selenium disulfide and titanium sulfide, which contain no sulfide ions at all. Sulfide is also used non-systematically, to describe compounds which release hydrogen sulfide on acidification, or compounds containing sulfur in some form, such as dimethyl sulfide. "Hydrogen sulfide" itself is an example of a non-systematic name for this property. However, it is also a trivial name, and the IUPAC preferred name for sulfane. Sulfides are not present in sufficient concentrations, even in highly alkaline water, undetectable at pH < ~15 (8 M NaOH). The sulfide anion can assimilate protons by recombination: Due to proton capture (H+), sulfides have a basic character. In aqueous solution, it has a pKb value of less than 0. Its conjugate acid is bisulfide (SH−). In aqueous solutions, most of the sulfide ions are neutralized. After being treated with standard acid, the sulfides turn into hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and metal salts. Sulfide oxidation produces sulfur or sulfates. Metal sulfides react with non-metals including iodine, bromine and chlorine to form sulfur and metal salts. Sulfur can also be made from sulfides and appropriate oxidizing agents: Sulfides are strong bases, so solutions of sulfides in water are alkaline, because they undergo hydrolysis.

Sulfide solution emits a distinctive rotten egg odor as a result of hydrolysis. Solutions of transition metal cations in water react with sulfide sources (H2S, NaHS, Na2S) to form solid sulfide precipitates. Certain inorganic sulfides usually have very low water solubility, and many are associated with minerals of a similar composition (see below). One well-known example is the bright yellow species CdS or "cadmium yellow". The black tarnish that forms on pure silver is Ag2S. Such species are sometimes referred to as salts. Actually, the bonds in transition metal sulfides are covalent, which causes their semiconducting properties, which in turn is related to the brightness of their color. Some sulfides have practical applications such as pigments, solar cells, and as catalysts. Aspergillus niger plays a role in dissolving heavy metal sulfides. Many important metal ores are sulphides. Notable examples include: argentite (silver sulfide), cinnabar (mercury), galena (lead sulfide), molybdenite (molybdenum sulfide), pentlandite (nickel sulfide), realgar (arsenic sulfide), and stibnite (antimony), sphalerite (zinc sulfide). ), and pyrite (iron disulfide), as well as chalcopyrite (iron-copper sulfide). Dissolved free sulphides (H2S, HS− and S2−) are very aggressive species in the corrosion of many metals such as steel, stainless steel and copper. Sulfides present in aqueous solutions are responsible for stress corrosion cracking (SCC) in steel, also known as sulphide stress cracking. Corrosion is a major concern in many industrial installations of sulfide processing: sulfide ore plants, deep oil wells, bulk oil pipelines, Kraft paper mills. Microbially-induced corrosion (MIC) or biogenic sulfide corrosion is also caused by sulfate-reducing bacteria, producing sulfides, which are dispersed in air and oxidized in sulfuric acid by sulfur-oxidizing bacteria.

Pyongyang (/ˈpjɒŋˈjæŋ/; (Hangul: 평양; Hanja: 平壤), Korean pronunciation: pʰjʌŋjaŋ], literally: "Land of the Flats" or "Land of Peace", approx.: P'yŏngyang; other variants) has been dubbed the "Capital of the Revolution" " is the capital of North Korea, which is the largest city. Pyongyang is located 110 kilometers (68 mi) from the Taedong River upstream of the West Korean Sea and, according to preliminary results from the 2008 population census, had a population of 3,255,388. The city was divided from South Pyongan province in 1946. It was administered as a directly governed city (chikhalsi, 직할시) at the same level as the provincial government, as opposed to a special city (teukbyeolsi, 특별시) like Seoul in South Korea. Pyongyang is one of the oldest cities in Korea. It was the capital of two ancient Korean kingdoms, Gojoseon and Goguryeo, and served as the secondary capital of Goryeo. After North Korea's founding in 1948, Pyongyang became the de facto capital. The city was again destroyed during the Korean War, but was quickly rebuilt after the war with the help of the Soviet Union. "Pyongyang" literally means "Plain Land" in Korean. One of Pyongyang's several historical names is Ryugyong (류경; 柳京), or "the willow capital", as the willow trees have always been abundant throughout the city's history; this became the inspiration for a number of poems. Even today, the city has many willow trees, with many buildings and places that have "Ryugyŏng" in their name. The most famous of these is the Ryugyong Hotel, completed in 2011. Other historic names of the town are Kisong, Hwangsong, Rakrang, Sŏgyong, Sodo, Hogyong, Changan, and Heijo (during the Japanese Occupation of Korea). 20, Pyongyang became known among missionaries as "East Jerusalem", due to its historical status as a bastion of Christianity, named Protestantism.

After Kim Il-sung's death in 1994, some members of Kim Jong-il's faction proposed changing Pyongyang's name to "Kim Il-sung City" (김일성시), but others suggested that North Korea should start calling Seoul "Kim City". Il-sung" and instead gave Pyongyang the nickname "Kim Jong-il City", and in the end the proposal was not implemented. In 1955, archaeologists unearthed evidence of prehistoric occupation of a large ancient village in the Pyongyang area, called Kŭmtan-ni, in reference to Chŭlmun and the Mumun Pottery Age. North Korea associates Pyongyang with "Asadal" (아사달), or Wanggomsŏng (왕검성; 王儉城), the first millennium BC capital of the kingdom of Gojoseon according to Korean history books, especially the Samguk Yusa. Many South Korean historians who?] reject this claim because other Korean history books such as the Guanzi, Sanhaijing, Shiji, and Sanguozhi place Asadal on the Liao River in western Manchuria. The relationship between the two may have been asserted by North Korea for propaganda use. Nevertheless, Pyongyang became the main city under Gojoseon. According to legend, Pyongyang was built in 2333 BC. He was the main city of the Go-Joseon Dynasty. Goguryeo moved its capital here in 427. The Tang and Silla kingdoms aligned and defeated Goguryeo in 668. In 676, Pyongyang was overrun by Silla. After the Korean War, the city was quickly rebuilt with help from the Soviet Union, and many buildings were constructed in the Stalinist architectural style. Pyongyang's modern city plans were first shown for public viewing in a theatre. Kim Jung-hee, one of the founding members of the Korean Alliance of Architects, who had studied architecture in pre-war Japan, was appointed by Kim Il Sung to design the master plan for the city. The Moscow Architectural Institute, drafted the "Comprehensive Reconstruction and Construction Plan for the City of Pyongyang" in 1951, and it was formally adopted in 1953.

Oxides are chemical compounds that contain at least one oxygen atom as well as at least one other element. Most of the earth's crust consists of oxides. Oxides are formed when elements are oxidized by oxygen in the air. Combustion of hydrocarbons produces the two main oxides of carbon, carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide. Even materials considered to be pure elements often contain an oxide shell. For example aluminum foil has a thin Al2O3 shell which protects the foil from corrosion. Oxides of period 3 elements: Na2OMgOAl2O3SiO2P4O10SO3Cl2O7P4O6SO2Cl2O The oxides in the first row are known as the highest oxides of each element. These oxides are when the period 3 elements are in their highest oxidation state. In these oxides, all the outer electrons are involved in bond formation, from sodium with only one outer electron to chlorine with 7 outer electrons. Structure The trend in structure is for metal oxides to contain giant ionic structures on the left-hand side of the period, giant covalent oxides (silicon dioxide) in the middle and molecular oxides on the right-hand side of the period. The giant structures (metal oxides and silicon dioxide) have high melting and boiling points because it takes a lot of energy to break strong bonds (ionic or covalent) that act in three dimensions. The oxides of phosphorus, sulfur and chlorine consist of individual molecules, some of which are small and simple, and others that are polymers. The attractive forces between these molecules are in the form of dispersion/spreading van der Waals forces and dipole-dipole interactions. These vary in size depending on the size, shape and polarity of the individual molecules, but will always be weaker than is required to break ionic or covalent bonds in giant structures. These oxides tend to be gases, liquids or solids with low melting points.

None of these oxides have free or mobile electrons. This means that none of these oxides can conduct electricity in the solid state. These oxides can undergo electrolysis if melted. These oxides can conduct electric current due to the movement of the ions towards the electrodes and the discharge of the ions when they reach the electrodes. The oxides of sodium, magnesium and aluminum consist of giant structures containing metal ions and oxide ions. Magnesium oxide has a structure like NaCl. The other two have a more complex structure which is beyond the scope of the syllabus at this level. There are strong attractive forces between the ions in each oxide and these attractions require a large amount of energy to break. That is why these oxides have high melting and boiling points. None of the period 3 metal oxides can conduct electricity in the solid state, but electrolysis is possible when melted. The liquid can conduct electric current due to the movement and changes in the charge of the ions present. An important example is the electrolysis of aluminum oxide in the manufacture of aluminum. Whether we can electrolyze liquid sodium oxide depends on whether the liquid/melt sublimes or decomposes under normal circumstances or not. If it sublimes, then there will be no liquid for electrolysis. Magnesium and aluminum oxides have very high melting points making them difficult to electrolyze in a simple laboratory. The electronegativities / electronegativities of the elements increase across the period from left to right, and in silicon, the electronegativity difference between silicon and oxygen is not large enough to form ionic bonds. Silicon dioxide has a giant covalent structure. There are three different forms of silicon dioxide.

Iran (Persian: ایران), officially the Islamic Republic of Iran and also known as Persia, is a country located in Southwest Asia. Although this country has been known locally as "Iran" since ancient times, until 1935 Iran was still referred to as "Persia" in the Western world. In 1959, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi announced that both terms could be used. The name Iran is a word "Aryan" which means "Land of the Aryans". Iran is bordered by Azerbaijan (500 km) and Armenia (35 km) to the northwest, the Caspian Sea to the north, Turkmenistan (1,000 km) to the northeast, Pakistan (909 km) and Afghanistan (936 km) to the east, Turkey (500 km) ) and Iraq (1,458 km) to the west, and the waters of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman to the south. In 1979, an Iranian Revolution led by Ayatollah Khomeini established an Islamic Theocratic Republic so that the current full name of Iran is "Islamic Republic of Iran" (جمهوری اسلامی ایران). Iran is a multicultural country that has many ethnic groups and languages. Persian (61%), Azerbaijani (16%), Kurdish (10%) and Lorestan (6%). From historical writings, the first Iranian civilization was Proto-Iranian, followed by the Elamite civilization. In the second, and third millennia, the Aryans emigrated to Iran, establishing Iran's first empire, the Median Empire (728-550 B.C.). This empire has become a founding symbol of the nation, and also the empire of Iran, which was followed by the Achaemenid Empire (648–330 BC) founded by Cyrus the Great. Cyrus the Great is also notable for being the first government to enact legislation regarding human rights, inscribed on an artifact known as the Cylinder of Cyrus. He was also the first ruler to use the title Supreme, and was also the Shah of Iran.

In his time, slavery was prohibited in the areas he conquered (also known as the Persian Empire.) This idea later had a great impact on human civilizations after his time. The Persian Empire was then ruled by Cambyses for seven years (531-522 AD), and his death was followed by a power struggle where Darius the Great (522-486 AD) was finally declared king. The Persian capital at the time of Darius I was moved to Susa, and he began to build Persepolis. A canal between the Nile River, and the Red Sea was also built, and made it a forerunner to the development of the Suez Canal. The road system was also renewed, and a road was built connecting Susa, and Sardis. This road is known as Jalan Kerajaan. In addition, coins in the form of darics (gold coins), and also Shekels (silver coins) were introduced to the whole world. Old Persian was also introduced, and published in royal inscriptions. Under the rule of Cyrus the Great and Darius the Great, the Persian Empire became the largest and strongest empire in the world at that time. His main achievement was being the first great empire to practice tolerance, and respect other cultures and religions in its colonies. Parthia began with the unifying Arsacid Dynasty, and ruled the Iranian plateau, which also conquered eastern Greece in the early third century AD, as well as Mesopotamia between 150 BC, and 224 AD. Parthia was also a sworn enemy of Rome in the east, and limit the Roman danger in Anatolia. The Parthian army was divided into two groups of cavalry, the armored cavalry, and carrying heavy weapons, and the lightly armed cavalry, whose horses were agile in movement. Meanwhile, the Roman army relied too much on infantry, making it difficult for the Romans to defeat the Parthians.

In ASEAN (old gray)-Legend] Laos (Laos Language: ລາວ, Lāo Láːw]), Officially the Democratic Republic of the people of Laos (Laos: ສາ ທາ ລະ ລັດ ປະ ຊາ ທິ ປະ ໄຕ ຊາ ຊົນ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ ລາວ mainland in Southeast Asia, bordered by Myanmar and the People's Republic of China to the northwest, Vietnam to the east, Cambodia to the south, and Thailand to the west. From the 14th to the 18th century, the country was called Lan Xang or "The Land of a Thousand Elephants". Laos is a landlocked republic country located in the northern part of the Indochina Peninsula. Laos comes from the word Lan Xang which means elephant kingdom. This country is the only country in Southeast Asia that does not have a beach. Laos was once colonized by France and gained independence on October 22, 1953 in the form of a kingdom. Since December 2, 1975 the kingdom of Laos changed to the Republic of Laos. Laos is a communist country with a head of government in the form of a president named Thongloun Sisoulith and assisted by a prime minister named Phankam Viphavanh. When viewed from the point of view of Political Geography, the location of the territory of the country of Laos which does not have sea areas or beaches is known as a land-lock area. This condition is considered unfavorable in terms of defense and security, especially from attacks or invasions by other nations. Laos has fertile river valleys that produce many agricultural and plantation crops, especially rice, coffee and tobacco. It has mineral mining resources, such as tin, copper, gold and silver. Its territory is dominated by hills and mountains which are covered in dense forest, thus producing wood as one of its commodities. Socio-cultural potential consists of various ethnic groups with various cultures, most of the people still adhere to tradition, have a national language, namely Lao.

However, in daily life, apart from their national language, the people also speak Thai, English and French. They have many historical buildings, especially temples. Laos is one of the five communist countries in the world. Its area is around 236,800 km2 with a population of around 6.6 million people. Joined ASEAN since 1997, but this landlocked country only opened itself wide with other countries in 2004. The first step taken by Laos in opening up was to attract foreign capital. Laos has repeatedly revised its foreign investment law, as well as allowing foreign companies to transfer profits out of Laos. Foreign investors are also permitted to establish companies with pure capital or joint ventures. The Lao government does not even collect taxes on foreign companies for the first five years of business in Laos. To boost the economy, Laos establishes several economic zones, increases international trade and enhances regional cooperation. The main livelihood of the Lao population is in the agricultural sector. The main agricultural products are rice, corn, tobacco, cotton, coffee and citrus fruits. Agricultural areas are generally located in lowland areas, especially on the banks of the Mekong river. The Mekong River is the lifeblood of the Laotian economy which Laos uses to produce hydroelectric power. The hydroelectric power produced is then sold by Laos to neighboring countries such as Vietnam and Thailand. In 2012, the Lao government established the Laos Trade Center portal which provides information regarding the country's imports and exports. Along with the opening up of the economy, Laos's economy grew by 7.1% from 2001-2010 and is expected to increase by 7.6% from 2011-2015. It is not an impossible number if you look at the growth of Laos' Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in 2012 which reached 8.1%.

Vajrayana or sometimes written Wajrayana, is a Buddhist teaching which in Indonesia is more commonly known as Tantra or Tantrayana. But many other terms are also used, such as: mantrayana, secret mantra teaching, esoteric Buddhism. Vajrayana is a teaching that developed from Mahayana Buddhism, and differs in practice, not philosophy. In Vajrayana teachings, meditation practice is often preceded by a short mantra recitation and visualization. The term "Vajrayana" comes from the word vajra which in Sanskrit means 'thunder' or 'diamond'. Vajra symbolizes diamond as the hardest element on Earth, so the term Vajrayana can mean "Indestructible and changeless Vehicle". The philosophy of Buddhism can be divided into two: Hinayana/Pratimokshayana (one of which is Theravada) and Mahayana. Hinayana emphasizes attainment as an Arahant, whereas Mahayana emphasizes attainment as a Bodhisattva. Tantrayana which is part of Mahayana is also often known by the name of the Bodhisattva path. Hinayana can be divided into Vaibhashika and Sautrantika. Whereas Mahayana is divided into Cittamatra and Madhyamika. This Madhyamaka consists of Rangtong (which includes Sautrantika and Prasangika) and Shentong (Yogacara-Madhyamaka). These four Buddhist philosophies (Vaibhasika, Sautrantika, Cittamatra, and Madhyamika) have existed since the time of Gautama Buddha, arising from the different beliefs, different levels of understanding, different attainments, and realizations of the Buddha's disciples. Vaibhasika and Sautrantika teachings are widely found in Thailand, Burma, Sri Lanka and Cambodia. This Cittamatra teaching can be found in China, Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Tibet and its surroundings. The Shentongpa Main Teachings are part of the Madyamika teachings, which believe that self-nature is not simply empty, because self-nature is Buddha-nature, which has all the qualities Buddha.

"śūnyatā sarvadriṣṭīṇām proktā niḥsaraṇam jinaiḥyeṣām tu śūnyatādṛṣṭtis tan asādhyan babhāṣire" "The Conquerors say that (realization of) Sunyata eliminates all views. Everything that holds onto Sunyata views is said to be incurable." - Nagarjuna, Mūlamadhyamakakārikā 13.8 Holding onto the Sunyata view is wrong view that does not yet understand voidness. Among all wrong views, Nagarjuna stated that this one view is beyond treatment. Because this teaching of Sunyata is so profound, it should not be seen as simply 'empty'. Initially, the Madhyamika teachings were widely found in the Himalayas, such as in Tibet, Nepal, Bhutan, Sikkim, but now they exist in various Asian countries and in Western countries. The Vajrayana teachings in general in various countries are better known as the teachings of Tibetan Buddhism, which is part of the Mahayana and was taught directly by Sakyamuni Buddha which is very suitable for practice by householders, people who live alone (not married), or people who decide to marry. lived as a monk in the Vajrayana monastery. In several countries (especially in Asia), there are many assumptions that Vajrayana is a mystical teaching, full of occult. This is actually not true. In Vajrayana, there are many methods of practice. Indeed, there are many Vajrayana practitioners who have extraordinary abilities, but this is not something mystical. This is actually a by-product of the practice, and it should be ignored. As the Buddha said, what can save us at the time of death is the Dharma, not the powers we have. Often this acquired ability becomes a hindrance in achieving our ultimate goal, which is attaining enlightenment. The by-product of this ability (siddhi) will often increase our arrogance (me-ness), which we actually have to get rid of, and is not something to be proud of.

Busan (Korean pronunciation: pu.san]), formerly known as Pusan ​​and now officially known as Busan Metropolitan City, is the second most populous city in South Korea after Seoul, with a population of 3.5 million. The city is the economic, cultural and educational center of the southeastern region of Korea, and its port is the busiest port in Korea and the 9th busiest in the world, located about 120 miles (190 km) from the Japanese islands such as Kyushu and Honshu. The "Southeast Economic Zone" area (including Ulsan and South Gyeongsang) is currently the largest industrial area in South Korea. Busan is divided into 15 main administrative districts and one county, which together have a population of about 3.6 million. The entire metropolitan area, including the nearby cities of Gimhae and Yangsan, has a population of about 4.6 million. The city's most densely built-up area is located in a number of narrow valleys between the Nakdong River and Suyeong River, and most of the districts are separated by mountains. Nakdong is the longest river in Korea and Busan's Haeundae Beach is also the largest beach in Korea. Busan is the center of international meeting conventions, hosting APEC in 2005. Busan is also the center for sports tournaments in Korea, having hosted the 2002 Asian Games and the FIFA World Cup. Busan is home to the world's largest department store, Shinsegae Centum City. The name "Busan" is a refined Korean spelling version of the city's Korean name since the late 15th century. The name officially replaced the previous McCune-Reischauer romanization, Pusan, in 2000. b] The name 釜山 (now written 부산 using the Hangul syllabus) is the Sino-Korean version of "Crater Mountain", which is believed to be the former name of Mount Hwangryeong (황령산 , 荒嶺山, Hwangryeong-san) to the west of downtown.

The ancient area of ​​Mount Geochil (거칠산국, 居柒山國, Geochilsan-guk, "Land of Rough Mountains") is also thought to refer to the same mountain, which houses the city's harbor in Suyeong. (Geochilsan-gun district in the Silla Kingdom was later renamed Dongnae in 757). In 1957, Busan adopted a system of administrative divisions with the creation of six gu (districts): namely Busanjin-gu, Dong-gu, Dongnae-gu, Jung-gu, Seo-gu, and Yeongdo-gu. Currently, Busan is divided into fifteen gu and one gun (county). Attractions around Busan apart from the beach include: Religion in Busan (2005) According to the 2005 census, 39.2% of Busan's population embraced Buddhism and 17.8% embraced Christianity (10.4% Protestant and 7.4% Catholic) ). 43% of the population is basically irreligious or follows another indigenous religion. The city had planned to bid to host the 2020 Summer Olympics, but withdrew after the 2018 Winter Olympics hosting spot went to Pyeongchang, which is also in South Korea. The host for the 2020 Summer Olympics has finally been awarded to Tokyo. Currently, Busan is considering bids to host the 2032 Summer Olympics. Team sports and facilities Since 1982, the city has been home to the Lotte Giants, who play in the Korean Professional Baseball league. In Korea, Busan is known as the capital of baseball and has a reputation for passionate baseball fans. In its early years, Lotte Giants used the Gudeok Baseball Stadium as their home. In the mid-1980s, they moved to the Sajik Baseball Stadium, which was built as part of a sports complex for the 1986 Asian Games. The city is home to the K-League soccer team, Busan IPark. The team was formerly known as the Daewoo Royals and was a successful team during the 1990's.

Argon is a chemical element with the symbol Ar and atomic number 18. It is in group 18 of the periodic table and is a noble gas.n 1] Argon is the third most common gas in the Earth's atmosphere, with an abundance of 0.934% (9,340 ppmv), making it a gas with an abundance twice that of water vapor (average 4,000 ppmv, but varies) and 23 times that of another atmospheric gas, carbon dioxide (400 ppmv), and more than 500 times that of the next noble gas, neon (18 ppmv). Nearly all of this argon is radiogenic argon-40 derived from the decay of potassium-40 in the Earth's crust. In the universe, argon-36 is by far the most common isotope of argon, being the argon isotope produced by stellar nucleosynthesis in supernovae. In addition, argon is the most abundant noble gas in the Earth's crust, comprising 0.00015% of the crust. The name argon is derived from the Greek αργον, the singular form of αργος meaning "lazy" or "inactive", in reference to the fact that this element almost never undergoes chemical reactions. The complete octet (eight electrons) in its outer electron shell makes argon stable and resistant to bonding with other elements. Its triple point temperature of 83.8058 K is the fixed point defined in the 1990 International Temperature Scale. Argon is produced industrially by the distillation of the liquid air fraction. Argon is widely used as an inert shielding gas in welding and other high-temperature industrial processes where normally unreactive materials become reactive; for example, an argon atmosphere is used in graphite electric furnaces to prevent the graphite from burning. Argon gas has also been used in incandescent and fluorescent lamps, and other types of discharge tubes. Argon makes a distinctive blue-green gas laser.

Argon is also used as a light source for tube lamps. Argon has approximately the same solubility in water as oxygen, and is 2.5 times more soluble in water than nitrogen. Argon is colorless, odorless and non-flammable and non-toxic in solid, liquid or gaseous state. Argon is chemically inert under most conditions and does not form stable compounds at room temperature. Although argon is a noble gas, it has been found to have the ability to form several compounds. For example, the formation of argon fluorohydride (HArF), an argon compound with fluorine and hydrogen that is stable below 17 K, was reported by researchers from the University of Helsinki in 2000. Although neutral argon compounds in the ground state are currently limited to HArF, argon can be forms clathrate with water when its atoms are trapped in a lattice of water molecules. Ions containing argon and complexes in the excited state, such as ArH+ and ArF, are known to exist. Theoretical calculations have predicted several stable argon compounds, but their synthesis pathways are unknown. Argon ('αργόν, singular from 'αργός, Greek meaning "inactive", referring to its chemical inactivity) was suspected of being present in air by Henry Cavendish in 1785 but was not isolated until 1894 by Lord Rayleigh and Sir William Ramsay in University College London in an experiment removed all the oxygen, carbon dioxide, water and nitrogen from a sample of clean air. They have measured that the nitrogen produced from chemical compounds is one and a half percent lighter than nitrogen from the atmosphere. The differences seemed insignificant at first glance, but important enough to hold their attention for several months. They concluded that there were other gases in the air mixed with nitrogen.

Life is a characteristic that distinguishes physical objects that have biological processes (i.e. living organisms) from physical objects that do not, either because those functions have ceased (because they have died) or because they never had these functions and are classified as inanimate. The science related to the study of life is biology. Life exists in various forms of organisms on Earth, such as plants, animals, fungi, protists, archaea and bacteria. Living organisms undergo metabolism, maintain homeostasis, have the ability to grow, respond to stimuli, reproduce, and—through natural selection—adapt to their environment in successive generations. More complex living organisms can communicate in a variety of ways. The general characteristics of these organisms are carbon- and water-based cells, with complex organization and heritable genetic information. Abiogenesis is the natural process by which life arises from non-living matter, such as simple organic compounds. The current scientific hypothesis states that the transition from non-living to living entities is not a single event, but a gradual process of increasing complexity. Life on Earth first appeared 4.28 billion years ago, after the oceans formed 4.41 billion years ago, and shortly after Earth formed 4.54 billion years ago. The earliest known forms of life are bacterial microfossils. Researchers generally think that life today originated in the RNA world, even though RNA-based life may not have been the first life that ever existed. The Miller–Urey experiment in 1952 and similar studies demonstrated that most amino acids (the building blocks of proteins used by all living organisms) could be synthesized from inorganic compounds under conditions intended to mimic the early Earth period.

Complex organic molecules are found in the Solar System and in interstellar space, and these molecules may have provided starting material for the development of life on Earth. Since its inception, organisms on Earth have experienced environmental changes on geological time scales. They have also adapted to survive in most ecosystems and conditions. Some microorganisms called extremophiles grow in extreme environments (physically or geochemically) that are detrimental to most other organisms on Earth. The cell is considered the structural and functional unit of life. There are two types of cells, namely prokaryotes and eukaryotes, which consist of a cytoplasm enclosed in a membrane and contain many biomolecules such as proteins and nucleic acids. Cells reproduce by cell division, which is the process when the parent cell divides into two or more daughter cells. In the past, there have been many attempts to define what is meant by "life" through outdated concepts such as odic style, hylemorphism, spontaneous generation, and vitalism, which have now been disproved by biological discoveries. Aristotle is considered to be the first person to classify organisms. Carolus Linnaeus later introduced the binomial nomenclature system for classifying species. Later, new groups and categories of life were discovered, such as cells and microorganisms, which revised the structure of the relationships among living organisms. Although currently life is only known on Earth, scientists speculate the existence of extraterrestrial life. Meanwhile, artificial life is a computer simulation or man-made reconstruction of all aspects of life, which is often used to examine systems related to natural life. Death is the cessation of all biological functions that sustain an organism permanently so that it is the end of its life. Extinction is a term that describes the end of the life of a group or taxon, which usually refers to a species.

Nutrients or nutrients are organic substances needed by organisms for the normal function of body systems, growth, and maintenance of health. Research in the field of nutrition studies the relationship between food and drink on health and disease, especially in determining the optimal diet. In the past, research on nutrition was limited to preventing malnutrition and determining basic nutritional requirements (standards) in living things. This figure for basic nutritional needs is known internationally as the Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA). Along with scientific developments in the medical and molecular biology fields, medical evidence shows that RDA is not sufficient to maintain optimal body function and prevent or help treat chronic diseases. Medical evidence shows that the root of many chronic diseases is oxidative stress caused by an excess of free radicals in the body. The use of nutrients at an optimal level, known as Optimal Daily Allowance (ODA), is proven to be able to prevent and treat oxidative stress thereby helping to prevent chronic diseases. This optimal level can be achieved if the amount and composition of nutrients used are appropriate. In disease management, the use of nutrition as a complementary medicine can help the effectiveness of treatment and at the same time overcome the side effects of treatment. Therefore, nutrition / nutrition is closely related to optimal health and increased quality of life. The results of measuring can be done with the method of anthropometry. While the science of nutrition is the study of the relationship of food and drink to the health of the human body so that it does not experience nutritional disorders, where nutritional disorders themselves are diseases caused by a lack of certain vitamin substances that cause our bodies to experience nutritional disorders. The first nutritional disorder to be discovered was scorbut in 1497 or more popularly known as sprue.

At that time Vasco da Gama on his voyage to Indonesia had lost more than half of his crew who died from this disease. Referrals are needed] It was only at the beginning of the 20th century that medical experts were able to confirm that this disease was caused by a lack of vitamin C. At this time most of the population Indonesia is experiencing a nutritional surplus rather than a nutritional deficiency. In 2007 the mortality rate due to non-infectious diseases reached 59.5 percent or clearly exceeded the mortality rate due to infectious diseases. In 2015, the Ministry of Health launched the "G4 G1 L5" program or a maximum of 4 tablespoons of sugar (50 grams), 1 teaspoon of salt (5 grams) and 5 tablespoons of oil (67 grams). Nutrition Science (Nutrience Science) is the study of everything about food in relation to optimal health / body. Unfortunately, today's food can be said to have very little nutrition. approximately 1 month in the distribution process causes the nutritional content in the fruit to also decrease. The slogan 4 Healthy 5 Perfect was coined by Prof. Poorwo Soedarmo, known as the father of Indonesian nutrition in 1950. This slogan refers to the "Basic Four" slogan from America. The "Basic Four" were created in the 1940s to discourage the American diet which tended to be high in fat, high in sugar, and lacking in fiber. The composition of 4 healthy 5 perfect is as follows: 1. Staple Foods 2. Side dishes 3. Vegetables 4. Fruits 5. Milk At the world food conference held by FAO in 1992 in Rome and Geneva, among other things, it was determined that all developing countries which originally used a slogan similar to "Basic Four" changed to "Nutrition Guide for Balanced Diet".

A polytheist (Arabic: المشرك ) according to Islamic law is the perpetrator of the act of associating God with anything, which is the opposite of the teaching of monotheism, which has the meaning of worshiping God. The word shirk itself comes from the word syarikah or fellowship, that is to associate or make competition with other laws or teachings other than God's teachings/laws. Shirk is moral behavior that goes beyond the rules and is contrary to the principle of monotheism, namely by serving, submitting, consciously and voluntarily obeying a teaching / command other than the teachings of God. In Islam, polytheism is a sin that cannot be forgiven except by repentance and abandoning polytheism as far as possible.
