Personal idolatry is carried out by consciously and voluntarily following teachings other than God's teachings (allowing the teaching of polytheism in the heart, carrying it out in action and trying to uphold or protect the teaching of polytheism). Social/communal polytheism (congregation or nation) is explained in Surah Ar-Ruum 31-32: So group/sectarian fanaticism by dividing from God's teachings is a great polytheism because it involves people socially, among other things by creating streams or groups which is against the source of Islamic law (Quran and Hadith) with the purpose of their own group's interests and creating their own rules (based on the group's interests). This situation causes disintegration between people, even if there is peace, it is a pseudo-peace, so God's will for people cannot be fulfilled because of chaos. The purpose of sending the Messengers] is to reintegrate people from a divided state, back into an Ummah united in one Basis/Principle (Rubbubiyyah), one authority (Mulkiyah) and one obedience (Uluhiyah). As for the principles or principles that have been in the universe and the Books of God that have been revealed as the source of all the sources of Islamic law.

Actinium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Ac and atomic number 89. It is a radioactive chemical element that was discovered in 1899. It was the first non-primordial radioactive element to be isolated: polonium, radium and radon were observed before actinium, but were isolated only recently in 1902. Actinium gave its name to the actinide series, a group of 15 elements similar to actinium and lawrencium on the periodic table. It is also sometimes considered the first 7th period transition metal, although lawrencium is less common in that position. A soft, silvery-white, radioactive metal, actinium reacts rapidly with oxygen and moisture in air to form a white layer of actinium oxide that prevents further oxidation. Like most of the lanthanides and actinides, actinium has an oxidation state of +3 in almost all of its chemical compounds. Actinium is found only in trace amounts in uranium and thorium ores as the isotope 227Ac, ​​which decays with a half-life of 21.772 years, with predominantly emission of beta and occasionally alpha particles, and 228Ac, which is beta active with a half-life of 6.15 hours. One ton of natural uranium in its ore contains about 0.2 milligrams of actinium-227, and one tonne of natural thorium contains about 5 nanograms of actinium-228. The similar physical and chemical properties of actinium and lanthanum make it impractical to separate actinium from its ores. Instead, the element is prepared, in milligram amounts, by irradiating 226Ra neutrons in a nuclear reactor. Due to its rarity, high price and radioactivity, actinium has no significant industrial uses. Current applications include neutron sources and agents for radiotherapy targeting cancer cells in the body. André-Louis Debierne, a French chemist, announced the discovery of a new element in 1899.

He separated it from the pitchblende residue left by Marie and Pierre Curie after they extracted the radium. Around 1899, Debierne described the substance as similar to titanium and (in 1900) as similar to thorium. Friedrich Oskar Giesel independently discovered actinium in 1902 as a substance similar to lanthanum and called it "emanium" in 1904. After comparing the half-lives of the substances determined by Debierne, Harriet Brooks in 1904, and Otto Hahn and Otto Sackur in 1905 , Debierne's choice of name for the new element was retained out of consideration of seniority, despite the conflicting chemical properties he claimed for this element at different times. Articles published in the 1970s and later pointed out that Debierne's results published in 1904 contradicted those reported in 1899 and 1900. Furthermore, the chemistry of actinium known today precludes its presence as anything other than a minor constituent of Debierne's results in 1899 and 1900. In fact, the chemistry he reported makes it probable he had, by accident, identified protactinium, which would not be discovered for another fourteen years, only to have it disappear due to hydrolysis and adsorption on his laboratory equipment. This has led some authors to suggest that Giesel himself should be credited with the discovery. A cooler vision of scientific discovery was proposed by Adloff. He suggested that criticism of early publications had to be reconciled with the nascent state of radiochemistry: highlighting the caution with Debierne's claims in early newspapers, he noted that no one could argue that Debierne's substance did not contain actinium. Debierne, who is now credited by most historians as its discoverer, lost interest in the element and left the topic.

Venice (Venetian: Venice; Italian: Venezia) is the capital of the Veneto region and the Province of Venice in Italy. The city has an area of ​​412 km² and a population of 271,663 (2003 Census). The Republic of Venice existed in the city from the 9th to the 18th centuries. This canal city is famous for its water transportation facilities, including gondolas. The city was founded by residents of the greater Veneto region as a refuge from barbarian invasions, when the Western Roman Empire fell. During the Middle Ages, Venice slowly developed into an important commercial city. Around 1000 AD the Republic of Venice began to establish an empire in the eastern Mediterranean that lasted until 1797, when it was annexed by Napoleonic France. It then changed hands several times, becoming part of Austria twice, before becoming part of Italy during the unification of Italy. Venice greatly influenced the Venetian, Istrian and Dalmatian coasts for a thousand years. Venice began to deplete and lose population after the conquest of Napoleon Bonaparte, but with the unification of Italy the city regained importance. In addition, Venice is also one of the most visited places by tourists from all over the world. The sestieri are the main traditional division of Venice. The city is divided into six districts, namely: Cannaregio, San Polo, Dorsoduro (including Giudecca), Santa Croce, San Marco and Castello (including San Pietro di Castello and Sant'Elena). – in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Poland (Polish: Polska) (officially: Republic of Poland, (Polish: Rzeczpospolita Polskaa] ʐɛt​͡ʂpɔˈspɔlita ˈpɔlska] ( listen) is a republic in Central Europe which is directly bordered by Germany to the west of the Oder-Neisse Border, Czech and Slovakia to the south, Russia (Kaliningrad), Lithuania to the northeast and Belarus and Ukraine to the east. Poland is a member state of the European Union. Mother the city of Poland and the largest city is Warsaw. Poland is a developed and powerful country in the region. The country has the eighth largest economy and one of the most dynamic in the European Union with a very high Human Development Index. In addition, the Polish Stock Exchange in Warsaw is one of the largest and most important in Central Europe.Poland maintains a high-income economy along with a very high standard of living, quality of life, safety education, and economic freedom. Poland has 15 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, 14 of which are cultural. Poland is a member state of the European Union, the Schengen Area, the United Nations, NATO, the OECD, the Three Seas Initiative and the Visegrad Group. Polish history begins with the arrival of Slavic peoples, who established permanent settlements of West Slavic peoples in Poland in the Early Middle Ages. The Piast dynasty, the dynasty that first ruled Poland, emerged in the 10th century AD. Duke Mieszko I (d. 992) is honored as the de facto founder of the Polish state, and is honored as a figure who contributed to spreading Western-style Christianity in Poland after his baptism in 966. The Duchy of Poland founded by Duke Mieszko officially became a kingdom in 1025 thanks to the efforts of his son, King Bolesław the Brave.

Of the Polish kings of the Piast dynasty, King Casimir the Great was perhaps the most powerful. The last Polish king of the Piast dynasty reigned at a time when Poland was experiencing economic prosperity and experiencing an increase in the area of ​​sovereignty. King Kazimierz the Great died in 1370 without leaving a male heir. During the reign of the Polish kings of the Jagiellon dynasty, from the 14th to the 16th century, Poland cultivated close relations with the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, underwent a Renaissance, and continued efforts to expand its sovereign territory culminating in the creation of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth in in 1569. At first the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth was able to maintain the level of prosperity achieved by Poland during the Jagiellon dynasty by implementing a highly developed system of aristocratic democracy. However, since the mid-17th century, this gigantic country entered a period of decline due to war and the collapse of the political system. At the end of the 18th century, attempts at domestic reform were attempted, especially by passing the Constitution of May 3, 1791, but the surrounding foreign powers did not allow the reform process to run smoothly. The independence of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth of Nations ended in 1795, after the Russian Empire, Kingdom of Prussia, and the Austrian Habsburg Monarchy overthrew and divided the country. From 1795 to 1918, no Polish state was truly independent, despite the staunch Polish resistance movements. After the failure of the last armed uprising against the Russian Empire, the January Uprising of 1863, the Polish people kept their national identity intact through initiatives in the field of education and programs of "organic work" aimed at modernizing the Polish economy and society. Opportunities for independence arose only after World War I, when the three countries that controlled three parts of Poland were weakened by war and revolution.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Biochemistry or biological chemistry, is the study of chemical processes that exist in the body and those associated with living organisms. As a subdiscipline of biology and chemistry, biochemistry can be divided into three areas: structural biology, enzymes, and metabolism. Over the last decades of the 20th century, biochemistry has succeeded in explaining life processes through these three subdisciplines. Almost all fields of life sciences are being discovered and developed through methodological and biochemical research. Biochemistry focuses on understanding the basic chemistry that enables biological molecules to give rise to the processes that occur within living cells and between cells, which in turn is closely related to understanding tissues and organs, and the structure and function of organisms. Biochemistry is closely related to molecular biology which studies the molecular mechanisms of biological phenomena. Much of biochemistry deals with the structure, function, and interactions of biological macromolecules, such as proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and lipids. These molecules make up the structure of cells and perform many functions related to life. The chemical properties of cells also depend on the reactions of small molecules and ions. They can be inorganic (eg water and metal ions) or organic (eg amino acids used to synthesize proteins) compounds. The mechanism used by cells to utilize energy from their environment through chemical reactions is known as metabolism. Biochemical findings are applied primarily in medicine, nutrition, and agriculture. In medicine, biochemists investigate the causes and cures of disease. The science of nutrition studies how to maintain health and fitness and the effects of malnutrition. In agriculture, biochemists investigate soil and fertilizers. Improving crop cultivation, crop storage, as well as pest control are also the goals of biochemistry applications.

According to its most comprehensive definition, biochemistry can be seen as the study of the components and composition of living things and how they come together and work together to form life forms. In this sense, the history of biochemistry can go back to ancient Greece. However, biochemistry as a specific scientific discipline started around the 19th century, or earlier, depending on which aspect of biochemistry is focused on. Some suggest that biochemistry may have started with the discovery of the first enzyme molecule, namely diastase (now called amylase), in 1833 by Anselme Payen, while others consider Eduard Buchner's demonstration of the first complex biochemical process, namely the alcoholic fermentation of a free-form extract. cell in 1897 as a sign of the birth of biochemistry. Some might also point to the influential work published in 1842 by Justus von Liebig, Animal chemistry, or, Organic chemistry in its applications to physiology and pathology, which presented the chemical theory of metabolism, as the beginning of biochemistry, or even as early as the 19th century studies. 18 on fermentation and respiration by Antoine Lavoisier. Many other pioneers have been called the founders of modern biochemistry for helping to unravel the complexities of biochemistry. Emil Fischer, who studied protein chemistry, and F. Gowland Hopkins, who studied enzymes and biochemical dynamics, represent two examples of early biochemists. The term "biochemistry" itself comes from a combination of biology and chemistry. In 1877, Felix Hoppe-Seyler used the term (biochemie in German) as a synonym for physiological chemistry in the preface to the first edition of the Zeitschrift für Physiologische Chemie (Journal of Physiological Chemistry) when he suggested establishing an institute dedicated to this field of study. German chemist Carl Neuberg is often quoted as having coined the word in 1903, while several others credit it to Franz Hofmeister.

Oxygen (Latin: Oxygenium), or acid, sometimes known as a combustible substance, is a chemical element having the symbol O and atomic number 8. In the periodic table, oxygen is a group VIA non-metallic element (chalcogen) and can easily react with almost all other elements (mainly being oxides). At standard temperature and pressure, two oxygen atoms bond to form O (dioxygen), a colorless, tasteless, and odorless gas. Oxygen is the third most abundant element in the universe by mass (after hydrogen and helium) and the most abundant element in the Earth's crust. By volume, 20.9% of Earth's atmosphere is oxygen. All groups of organic molecules in living things, such as proteins, carbohydrates and fats, contain the element oxygen. The same goes for inorganic compounds found in animal shells, teeth and bones. Most of the oxygen in living things is in the form of water (H2O), an important compound in living things. Oxygen in the form O is produced from water by cyanobacteria, algae, and plants during photosynthesis, and is used in cellular respiration by nearly all living things. Oxygen is toxic to anaerobic organisms, which were the predominant form of life in the early days of life's evolution. O then began accumulating in the atmosphere around 2.5 billion years ago. There is also another allotrope of oxygen, namely ozone (O). The ozone layer in the atmosphere helps protect the biosphere from ultraviolet radiation, but at the Earth's surface it is a pollutant that is a by-product of smog. Oxygen was independently discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele in Uppsala in 1773 and Joseph Priestley in Wiltshire in 1774. Priestley's findings are more notable because his publication was the first to be printed.

However, Priestley called oxygen "dephlogisticated water" and did not know it was a chemical element. The term oxygen was coined by Antoine Lavoisier in 1777, whose experiments with oxygen disproved the famous phlogiston theories of combustion and corrosion. He also succeeded in explaining the role of oxygen in combustion. Oxygen is industrially produced by the gradual distillation of liquid air, by using zeolites to separate carbon dioxide and nitrogen from air, or the electrolysis of water, etc. Oxygen is used in the production of steel, plastics, and textiles. It is also used as a rocket propellant, for oxygen therapy, and as a life support in airplanes, submarines, spaceflight, and diving. One of the first known experiments on the relationship between combustion and air was performed by Philo of Byzantium, a 2nd century BC Greek writer on mechanics. In his work, Pneumatica, Philo observed that turning the crucible over a burning candle and placing water under the neck of the vessel caused the water to rise up the neck. Philo wrongly assumed that part of the air in the vessel was converted into classical elemental fire and thus escaped through the pores in the glass. Initially, many scientists thought that air was one of the four elements and not a mixture of various gases, as scientists know today. Therefore, initially scientists did not know the existence of oxygen as a component of air. Leonardo da Vinci who lived 1452–1519 observed that some air is used in the processes of combustion and respiration, and without it neither fire nor living things would die. At the end of the 17th century, Robert Boyle proved that air is necessary for the combustion process. The English chemist John Mayow complemented Boyle's work by showing that only a portion of the air component, which he called spiritus nitroaereus or nitroaereus, was required for combustion.

Dikarya (inc. Deuteromycota) Subphylum Incertae sedis Fungi is a kingdom of a large group of heterotrophic eukaryotic living things that digest their food outside their bodies and then absorb nutrient molecules into their cells. Scientists often use the term fungus as a synonym for Fungi. The common people refer to most members of the fungi as mushrooms, molds, yeasts, or yeasts, although it is often the external appearance that is visible, not the species itself. The difficulty in recognizing fungi is more or less due to the alternation of offspring that have completely different appearances (remember metamorphosis in insects or frogs). Fungi reproduce both sexually and asexually. Sexual propagation is by means of: two hyphae from different fungi fuse and form a zygote, then the zygote grows into a fruiting body, while asexual propagation is by forming spores, budding or fragmentation of hyphae. Fungi have a spore box called a sporangium. Inside the sporangium are spores. An example of a fungus that forms spores is Rhizopus. An example of a fungus that forms buds is Saccharomyces. Fungal hyphae can collapse and individual fragments can grow into fruiting bodies. The study of fungi is called mycology (from the Greek roots μυκες, "mucus", and λογοσ, "knowledge", "symbol"). The English word fungus is directly adopted from the Latin fungus (mushroom), used in the writings of Horatius and Pliny. The word is derived from the Greek word sphongos (σφόγγος "sponge"), which refers to the macroscopic structure and morphology of fungi and molds; this root is also used in other languages, such as the German Schwamm ("sponge") and Schimmel ("mold"). The use of the word mycology, which comes from the Greek mykes (μύκης "fungus") and logos (λόγος "science"), to denote the scientific study of fungi is thought to date back to 1836 with the publication of British naturalist Miles Joseph Berkeley The English Flora of Sir James Edward Smith, Vol.

5. The group of all the fungi present in a given area is known as a mycobiota (plural noun, no singular), for example, "mycobiota from Ireland". Prior to the introduction of molecular methods for phylogenetic analysis, fungi were first included in the plant kingdom/Plantae because fungi have several similarities with plants, namely they cannot move places, as well as their morphological structure and where they live are also similar. Like plants, most fungi also grow in the soil and, in fungi, form fruiting bodies, which sometimes resemble lichen-like plants. Fungi are now considered a separate kingdom, distinct from both plants and animals, which appear to have split up about a billion years ago (around the start of the Neoproterozoic Era). Some morphological, biochemical and genetic characteristics are shared with other organisms, while others are unique to fungi, clearly separating the fungi from the other kingdoms: Characteristics that are shared: Unique features: Most fungi do not have efficient systems for transport of water and nutrients over long distances, like xylem and phloem in many plants. To overcome this limitation, some fungi, such as Armillaria, form rhizomorphs, which resemble and perform functions similar to plant roots. As eukaryotes, fungi possess biosynthetic pathways for producing terpenes that use mevalonic acid and pyrophosphate as chemical building blocks. Plants and some other organisms have additional terpene biosynthetic pathways in their chloroplasts, structures that fungi and animals do not. Fungi produce several secondary metabolites that are structurally similar or identical to those made by plants. Many plant and fungal enzymes that make secondary metabolites differ from each other in sequence and other characteristics, which indicates the separate origin and convergent evolution of these enzymes in fungi and plants.

ABKHAZIA (ABKHAZ Language: ԥы ҳәыҭқыҭқррра/Apsny Ahwyntkarra, Georgian language: აფხაზეთი/apkhazeti, Russian language: репик блия/responsive abkhaziya) is a limited confession state Georgian. Abkhazia is located on the east coast of the Black Sea, bordering the Russian Federation to the north. With Georgia, the border is in the Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti area to the east. The status of Abkhazia is a central issue of the Georgian-Abkhazian conflict and Georgian-Russian relations. It is recognized as a state by Russia, Venezuela, Nicaragua, Nauru and Syria. While Georgia has no control over Abkhazia, the Georgian government and most United Nations member states consider Abkhazia de jure part of Georgia, with Georgia retaining a formal government. The region had autonomous status within the Georgian SSR at the time the Soviet Union began to disintegrate in the late 1980s. Ethnic tensions simmered between the region's titular Abkhaz ethnicity and the Georgians the largest single ethnic group at the time and culminated in the 1992-1993 War in Abkhazia, which resulted in Georgia's loss of control over most of Abkhazia and the ethnic cleansing of Georgians from Abkhazia. Despite a 1994 ceasefire agreement and years of negotiations, the dispute remains unresolved. The long-term presence of a United Nations Observe Mission and a Russian-led Commonwealth of Independent States peacekeeping force failed to prevent outbreaks of violence on several occasions. In August 2008, Abkhazian and Russian forces fought war against Georgian forces, which led to Russia's official recognition of Abkhazia, the cancellation of a 1994 armistice agreement and the termination of the UN mission. On August 28, 2008, the Georgian Parliament declared Abkhazia a Russian-occupied territory, a position mirrored by most UN member states.

Abkhazians call their homeland Аԥсны (Apsny, Aṗsny), which means country of the soul, but literally means "country of mortals". It may have first appeared in the seventh century in an Armenian text, possibly referring to the ancient Apsilians. The term Apkhazeti first appears in Georgian history, from the Mingrean "Apkha" meaning back or shoulder. It was used to denote the proper region of Abasgia and all of western Georgia within the Kingdom of Georgia. In early Muslim sources, the term Abkhazia is generally used to mean Georgian. Russians call it Абхазия (Abkhaziya) adapted from the colloquial Georgian pronunciation აფხაზეთი (Apkhazeti). Abkhazian names in most languages ​​including Indonesian are of Russian origin. The country was officially designated the "Republic of Abkhazia" or "Apsny". A common spelling in English before the 20th century was Abhasia. Between the 9th and 6th centuries BC, the territory of modern Abkhazia was part of the ancient Georgian kingdom of Colchis. Around the 6th century BC, the Greeks established trading colonies along the Black Sea coast in what is now Abkhazia, particularly in Pitiunt and Dioscurias. Classical writers described the various peoples who lived in the region and the many languages ​​they spoke. Arrian, Pliny, and Strabo have given accounts of the Abasgoi and Moschoi peoples somewhere in modern Abkhazia on the east coast of the Black Sea. This territory was then absorbed in 63 BC into the Kingdom of Lazika. The Roman Empire conquered Lazica in the 1st century AD; however, the Romans had little control over the interior of Abkhazia. According to Arrian, the Abasgoi and Apsilae were nominally Roman subjects, and there was a small Roman outpost at Dioscurias. After the 4th century Lazika regained its independence, but remained within the sphere of influence of the Byzantine Empire.

International Business Machines Corporation (abbreviated as IBM; NYSE: IBM) is an American corporation that manufactures and sells computer hardware and software. IBM was founded on June 16, 1911, has been operating since 1888 and is headquartered in Armonk, New York, United States. With more than 330,000 employees worldwide and US$96 billion in revenues (figures from 2004), IBM is the world's largest information technology company, and one of the last survivors of the 19th century. The company has engineers and consultants in more than 170 countries and development laboratories located around the world, in every branch of computer science and information technology; some of them are pioneers in fields ranging from mainframe computers to nanotechnology. Successful IBM machines and products were the Mainframe 370 system (in the 1960's), IBM PC, AS/400 and RS/6000 (1980's), PowerPC CPU (1990's, in partnership with Motorola, - now Freescale) In recent years, consulting and services revenue has been greater than production. Samuel J. Palmisano was appointed CEO on January 29, 2002 after leading IBM Global Services, and helped him become a businessman with a US$100 billion "backlog" in 2004. In 2002 the company strengthened its business capabilities with the acquisition of leading consulting services firm PricewaterhouseCoopers. The company continues to focus its efforts on business consulting, services and software, while also emphasizing high-priced chip and hardware technology. In 2004 IBM employed approximately 191,000 professional technicians, including 300-400 "Recognized Technicians" and 50-60 "IBM fellow", the most senior technicians. IBM Research has eight research laboratories located in the northern hemisphere of the world, with half located outside the United States.

IBM employees have won five Nobel Prizes. In America, they have also earned four Turing Awards, five National Medals of Technology, and five National Medals of Science, as well as many more outside America. On May 1, 2005, IBM's PC division was formally taken over by Lenovo, based in the People's Republic of China. The current CEO of IBM is Samuel J. Palmisano who replaced Louis V. Gerstner since January 29, 2002. Louis V. Gerstner became CEO of IBM for 10 years replacing John Ackers who was fired for nearly bankrupting IBM in 1992. Previously Louis V. Gerstner worked for Nabisco. In the 1880s, several technologies that would become IBM's business were discovered. Julius E. Pitrap invented computer scales in 1885, Alexander Dey invented the dial recorder (1888), Herman Hollerith invented the Electric Tabulating Machine in 1889 and in the same year Williard Bundy invented a tool to measure employee work time. On June 16, 1911, these technologies and the companies that owned them were merged by Charles Ranlett Flint to form the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company (C-T-R). The New York-based company has 1,300 employees and offices and manufacturing areas in Endicott and Binghamton, New York; Dayton, Ohio; Detroit, Michigan; Washington, D.C.; and Toronto, Ontario. C-T-R manufactures and sells a wide range of machines ranging from commercial weighing scales to working timers. In 1914, Flint recruited Thomas J. Watson, Sr., of the National Cash Register Company, to help him lead the company. Watson coined the slogan, "THINK", which soon became a mantra for C-T-R employees. Within 11 months of joining, Watson became president of C-T-R. The company focuses on providing large-scale accounting solutions for businesses.

Boxing is a sport and martial art in which two participants of a similar weight compete against each other using their fists in a series of one- or three-minute intervals known as rounds. In both the Olympics and professional sports, both boxers dodge their opponent's punches while trying to land their own on their opponent. Points are awarded for clean, steady punches to the front of the waist up to the face to the legal brain of the opponent, with blows to the head and chest receiving more points. The boxer with the higher score after the planned number of rounds is declared the winner. Victory can also be achieved if the opponent is knocked down and unable to get back up to the referee's tenth count (a Knockout or KO) or if the opponent is declared unable to continue the fight (a Technical Knockout or TKO). For match record purposes, TKO counts as a KO. The word "boxing" is a translation of the English word "boxing" or "Pugilism". The word Pugilism comes from the Latin word, pugilatus or a loan from the Greek word Pugno, Pignis, Pugnare, which signifies everything that is box-shaped or "box" in English. The Human Fist, when clenched, is shaped like a box. The Greek word pugno means hands clenched into fists, ready to pugnos, to fight, to box. In mythology, father and Boxing are Poliux, twin brother of Castor, legendary son of Jupiter and Leda. The first recorded boxing match in history was, among others, against Abel. Mahabharata Book also noted boxing matches, which preceded the recording of the stories in the fight between the Greeks, Romans, and Egyptians. The first famous Greek boxer named Theagenes of Thaos who won the Olympic Games 450 AD.

Potato, sweet potato, Dutch yam, or yam bengal is a plant from the Solanaceae tribe that has edible stem tubers and is called "potato". Potato tubers have now become one of the important staple foods in Europe even though they were originally imported from South America. Spanish and Portuguese explorers first brought this plant to Europe and cultivated it. The potato plant originates from South America and has been cultivated by residents there for thousands of years. This plant is an annual herbaceous (non-woody plant) and likes a cool climate. In the tropics it is suitable for planting in the highlands. Perfect and compound interest. The size is quite large, with a diameter of about 3 cm. The color ranges from purple to white. Historically, potatoes came from the highlands of Chile, Peru, and Mexico. This type was introduced by the Spanish from Peru to Europe since 1565. Since then, potatoes have spread to other countries -including Indonesia-. According to early records in Indonesia, this plant began to exist since 1794, starting with planting around Cimahi. Since then, potatoes can also be found in Priangan and Mount Tengger. In 1812, potatoes were known and sold in Kedu. Meanwhile, in Sumatra this plant was known a year earlier, 1811. Potatoes grow in the mountains with altitudes between 1000 masl to 2000 masl, on humus soil. Soil of former volcanic eruptions with a crumb structure is preferred. Potatoes are recognized by people as a staple food abroad. This is because potatoes contain carbohydrates. In Indonesia alone, potatoes are still considered a luxury vegetable. Nevertheless, potatoes are a delicious food and very nutritious. It is also known to contain a number of vitamins from A, B-complex, to C, to folic acid.

Ugamo Malim (Indonesian: Malim Trust) is a belief system originating from the Batak people. Followers of this belief are known as Parmalim. Parmalim are mostly spread in North Sumatra, especially in the area around Lake Toba, such as Samosir, North Tapanuli, Toba, Humbang Hasundutan, and Simalungun. Parmalim also spread in areas with other Batak populations, such as in Central Tapanuli, South Tapanuli, Dairi, and Pakpak Bharat. Parmalim believes in one God as the creator of the universe, referred to as Mulajadi Nabolon (Indonesian: The Great Beginning of Being). Ugamo Malim is a continuation of the ancient religious system that was first adopted by the Batak people long before the arrival of Protestantism, Islam and Catholicism. This ancient religious system is inherent in the way of life of its people without the label "religion" like other organized religions in the world. The emergence of the revitalization process of Ugamo Malim during the leadership of Sisingamangaraja XII was inseparable from the turbulent social, economic and political context at that time. Seeing the magnitude of the rocky influence of other religions and cultures, Sisingamangaraja XII took steps to save the Batak religious system by instituting it and giving it the name Ugamo Malim. Reference needed] The Batak people interpret religiosity by treating nature as the foundation of life and Mulajadi Nabolon's gift that must be maintained, both as source of life for his existence as well as a source of livelihood for his survival. The spirituality of caring for the created world is combined with gratitude and surrender to Mulajadi Nabaolon and is maintained with rituals that are aligned with the chronology of life and livelihood. Among these rituals is the offering ceremony (Batak language: pelean) to Mulajdi Nabolon. The activity of preparing ritual equipment is carried out very carefully according to the procedures and provisions referred to as "patik".

The activity of organizing ritual preparations and pelean is called "mang-ugamo-hon" (Indonesian: meng-agama-kan). "Ugamo" means order or proper arrangement. People who always carry out ritual ceremonies are referred to as "parugamo" or "parugama". The term "parugamo" became popular again in the Batak Lands when other religions grew in the Batak lands and became an identity that existed with the original Batak religiosity belief system. In the Batak language, people who follow and live up to the teachings of Ugamo Malim are called "parugamo malim", abbreviated as Parmalim. In the Batak language, a group of people who carry out one activity with one goal is called "punguan". The association of Ugamo Malim adherents is also known as "punguan parmalim". The association in question could be: During the Sisingamangaraja dynasty, there was Bale Pasogit Pamujian in Bakkara. This place was the center of worship and spirituality for the Batak people at that time. However, during the Toba War which destroyed Bakkara, the Bale Pasogit Pamujian was also burned. Due to the influx of foreign influences and the emergence of shocks to the social order as a result of Dutch colonialism and the activities of spreading Christianity, Sisingamangaraja XII instructed his students to establish a "bale pasogit" later as a place for "nabolon worship" (Indonesian: worship of the Supreme). which gathered loyal people with faith in Mulajadi Nabolon. citation needed] After the death of Sisingamangaraja XII on June 17, 1907, the mandate was again reminded by a figure calling himself Nasiakbagi. He also pointed to the position and appearance of the bale pasogit which would later be established by King Mulia. Regarding the mandate to establish bale pasogit, King Mulia reported and conveyed his intentions to the Dutch government through the Demang Office in Balige around 1913. The Dutch government conducted investigations into the activities of spreading Ugamo Malim's teachings for several years.

Baptism (derived from Greek: βαπτίζω, translit. baptizo) is known as the sacrament of Christian initiation that symbolizes the cleansing of sin. Baptism also symbolizes death with Jesus. By going into the water, the baptized person is symbolized as having died. When he came out of the water again, it was described as his resurrection. The Apostle Paul in the Letter to the Romans describes it as follows: "Or do you not know that all of us who were baptized into Christ were baptized into his death? Thus we were buried with him by baptism into death, so that, just like Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, even so we shall live in newness of life." (Romans 6:3-4). The word Baptism (derived from Greek: βαπτίζω, translit. baptizo) its origin is the word βάπτω - bapto, which means to immerse. Then it becomes baptizo which implies that something is soaked or dipped in water or a specific solution (liquid).. The essence of the term baptizō itself is not in the method (sprinkling or immersion), but in the process or in the effect produced from the baptism. In the religious sense itself, it means cleansing oneself from sin or, more simply, purification in the Christian life. On the other hand, it can be expressed as meaning that the person is a follower of Christ. In some religions such as Christianity, Mandaeanism, Sikhism, and some ancient sects of Judaism, baptism is a purification ritual using water. This Christian ritual was started by John the Baptist, who according to the Bible baptized Jesus in the Jordan River. Baptism is done with water. However, there are various ways of baptism, depending on the church denomination. The Biblical reference is indeed immersed in a lot of Water, which symbolizes death by being buried (entering the water) and being resurrected after coming out of the water.

The Apostolic Church baptises by sprinkling. There is no problem whether it should be sprinkling or immersion. The most common way baptism is performed is by sprinkling water on the head by a priest (romo) or priest, and saying the oneness of the Trinity, "In the name of the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit, Amen." The Roman Catholic Church and many denominations within the Protestant Church practice infant baptism because they believe that Jesus invited children to come to him (cf. Gospel of Mark 10:13-16, etc.). However, there are also churches that only baptize adults who have claimed to believe, for example Adventist churches, Pentecostals and Baptist churches. Usually, these churches practice immersion baptism. In this case, the priest and the candidate for baptism enter a pool and the person being baptized is immersed in the water. Apart from that, there are several churches that have to go through a process of confession of faith (sidi), for example the Apostles' Creed. Confession of faith is done before being baptized. Churches that do this include the Catholic Church, the Puritan Church, the Presbyterian Church, the Reformed or Calvinist Church, the Lutheran Church, and several other Protestant churches. The formula for washing (baptizontes) must be based on the Bible. The formulation of Baptism in the Bible itself must be "in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit.". which represents the Oneness of the Triune God But other than a formula, for example "In the name of the Father, Son and Holy Spirit, who is Jesus Christ", then Baptism performed is still invalid. Because it is not in accordance with Matthew 28:19-20. And not in accordance with the formulation of the Triune God. It is as if Jesus Christ contains 3 persons, namely the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. So there is a need for re-baptism. But on the other hand, for the case of baptizing in "in the name of Jesus" alone, especially Peter's Baptism in Acts 2:38-39; 10:44-48; and Paul in Acts 19:1-8 actually does not represent the presence of the Triune God.

Gout or gout (also known as podagra when it occurs in the big toe) is a medical condition usually characterized by recurrent acute attacks of inflammatory arthritis—with symptoms of red, tender, sore and hot swelling of the joints. The metatarsal-phalangeal joint at the base of the thumb is the most frequently affected site (approximately 50% of cases). However, this symptom may also present as tophi, kidney stones, or urate nephropathy. This condition is caused by an increase in uric acid levels in the blood. Uric acid crystallizes, and these crystals deposit in joints, tendons, and surrounding tissues. The clinical diagnosis is confirmed by looking for the characteristic crystals in the joint fluid. Treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), steroids, or colchicine can reduce inflammation. When the acute attack subsides, uric acid levels are usually reduced by lifestyle changes, and for those with recurrent attacks, allopurinol or probenecid provides long-term prevention. The frequency of gout has increased in recent decades, affecting around 1-2% of the Western population at some point in their lives. This increase is thought to be due to an increase in risk factors in the population, such as metabolic syndrome, longer life expectancy and changes in diet. Historically, gout has been known as the "disease of kings" or "disease of the rich". Gout can take many forms, although the most common is the recurring attacks of acute inflammatory arthritis (red, tender joints that are painful and hot and swollen). The metatarsal-phalangeal joint at the base of the big toe is affected most often, accounting for half of cases. Other joints, such as the heels, knees, wrists and fingers, can also be affected.

Joint pain usually starts after 2–4 hours and at night. Pain that appears at night usually occurs due to a decrease in body temperature at that time. Other symptoms that occur with joint pain, although rare, include fatigue and high fever. Low levels of uric acid for a long time (hyperuricemia) can cause other symptomatology, including the deposition of uric acid crystals that do not cause pain called tophi. Extensive tophi can lead to chronic arthritis due to bone erosion. Increased levels of uric acid can also cause crystal deposition in the kidneys, causing stone formation and subsequent urate nephropathy. Hyperuricemia is a cause of gout. This condition can occur for a variety of reasons, including diet, genetic predisposition, or decreased excretion of uric acid salts. Reduced excretion of uric acid in the kidneys is the cause of hyperuricemia which accounts for 90% of the main cases, whereas excess production only occurs in less than 10% of cases. Approximately 10% of hyperuricemia sufferers experience gout at some point in their life. However, the risk varies depending on the degree of hyperuricemia. If the level is between 415 to 530 µmol/l (7 to 8.9 µg/dL), the risk is 0.5% per year, whereas if the level is greater than 535 µmol/l (9 µg/dL), the risk is 4. 5% per annum. Food accounts for 12% of gout, and includes a strong association with consumption of alcohol, fructose-sweetened beverages, nuts and seafood. Other triggers include physical injuries and surgery. Recent studies have found dietary factors that have so far been thought to have a connection, it turns out to be evident, among others, with intake of purines, fatty vegetables (for example, beans, peas, legumes, and spinach) and total protein.

Montanism was a Christian sectarian movement premiering in the mid-2nd century AD, named after its founder Montanus. This movement developed mainly in and around Phrygia; here formerly his followers were called Cataphragians. But the movement spread quickly to other parts of the Roman Empire, and at a time before Christianity was tolerated or made legal. Although the mainline Christian Church triumphed over Montanism over several generations, branding it a heresy, the sect persisted in isolated places until the 8th century. Some people draw parallels between Montanism and Pentecostalism (which some call Neo-Montanism). The most famous Montanist is definitely Tertullian, who was the most prominent Latin church writer before he converted to Montanism. The Montanist known as Montanis Montanus visited rural settlements in Asia Minor after his conversion, and taught and testified to what he said was the Word of God. However, his teachings were deemed heretical by the orthodox Church for a number of reasons. He claimed not only to have received a series of direct revelations from the Holy Ghost, but personally to be the incarnation of the paraclete mentioned in the Gospel of John 14:16. Montanus was accompanied by two women, Prisca, sometimes called Priscilla, and Maximilla, who also claimed to be the embodiments of the Holy Spirit that moved and inspired them. Wherever they went, the "Three" as they were called, spoke with ecstatic visions and urged their followers to fast and pray, so that they too would be able to have this personal revelation. Montanus' preaching spread from his birthplace Phrygia (and here he states that the village of Pepuza was the site for the New Jerusalem) into the then Christian world, to Africa and Gaul.

It is generally agreed that this movement was inspired by Montanus' reading of the Gospel of John—"I will send you an advocate parakletos, the spirit of truth" (Heine 1987, 1989; Groh 1985). The response to this continuing revelation divided Christian communities, and more orthodox clergy generally struggled to suppress it. Bishop Apolinarius found the church in Ancyra split in two, and he opposed "false prophecy" (quoted by Eusebius 5.16.5). But there was serious doubt in Rome, and Pope Eleuterus even wrote letters in support of Montanism, although he later recanted (Tertullian, "Adversus Praxean" c.1, Trevett 58-59). Prisca confessed that Christ appeared to her in the form of a woman. When he was excommunicated, he cried out, "I was driven like a wolf from the sheep. I am not a wolf: I am word and spirit and power." The most famous defender of the Montanists was clearly Tertullian, a former defender of the orthodox faith, who believed the new prophecy to be genuine and began to abandon what he called the “church of many bishops” (On Modesty). Although the orthodox Christian church triumphed over Montanism within a few generations, inscriptions in the Tembris valley in northern Phrygia, which are dated between 249 and 279, openly declare their allegiance to Montanism.A letter from Jerome to Marsela, written in 385, refutes the claim that the Montanists had disturbed him (letter 41) A group of "Tertullianists" continued to have a presence in Carthage. The anonymous author of the Praedestinatus records that a preacher came to Rome in 388 when he was producing a large following and obtained permission to use a church for his congregation on the grounds that the martyrs to whom it belonged offered is Montanist.

Zinc, zinkum (Latin: zincum), zinc (Dutch: zinc), or tin is a chemical element with the symbol Zn and atomic number 30. Zinc is a slightly brittle metal at room temperature and has a silvery-gray appearance when heated. oxidation is removed. It is the first element in group 12 (IIB) of the periodic table. In some respects, zinc is chemically similar to magnesium: the two elements exhibit only one normal oxidation state (+2), and the Zn2+ and Mg2+ ions are similar in size. notes 1] Zinc is the 24th most abundant element in the Earth's crust and has five stable isotopes. The most common zinc ore is sphalerite (zinc alloy), a zinc sulfide mineral. The largest applicable Lodes are in Australia, Asia and the United States. Zinc is refined through flotation of ore, roasting, and final extraction using electricity (electric extraction). Brass, an alloy of copper and zinc in various proportions, was used from the third millennium BC in the Aegean region and in areas that today include Iraq, the United Arab Emirates, Kalmykia, Turkmenistan and Georgia. In the second millennium BC, it was used in areas that today include West India, Uzbekistan, Iran, Syria, Iraq and Israel. Zinc metal was not produced on a large scale until the 12th century in India, although it was known to the ancient Romans and Greeks. The mines of Rajasthan have provided definitive evidence of zinc production since the 6th century BC. To date, the oldest evidence of pure zinc comes from Zawar, in Rajasthan, in the early 9th century AD when a refining process was used to make pure zinc. Alchemists burned zinc in air to form what they called "philosopher's wool" or "white snow".

The element may have been named by the alchemist Paracelsus from the German word zinke (branch, tooth). The German chemist Andreas Sigismund Marggraf is credited with discovering the pure metallic zinc in 1746. The work of Luigi Galvani and Alessandro Volta discovered the electrochemical properties of zinc in 1800. Corrosion-resistant zinc plating of iron (hot-dip galvanization) is a major application for zinc. Other applications are in electric batteries, small nonstructural castings, and alloys such as brass. Various zinc compounds are commonly used, such as zinc carbonate and zinc gluconate (as dietary supplements), zinc chloride (in deodorants), zinc pyrithione (anti-dandruff shampoos), zinc sulfide (in luminescent paints), and dimethylzinc or diethylzinc in the organic laboratory. Zinc is an essential mineral, which is required for prenatal and postnatal development. Zinc deficiency affects around two billion people in developing countries and is associated with many diseases. In children, deficiency causes growth retardation, delayed sexual maturation, susceptibility to infection, and diarrhea. Enzymes with a zinc atom in the reactive center are widespread in biochemistry, such as alcohol dehydrogenase in humans. Excessive zinc consumption can cause ataxia, lethargy, and copper deficiency. Zinc is a bluish-white, lustrous diamagnetic metal, although the most common commercial grades of this metal have a dull finish. It is somewhat less dense than iron and has a hexagonal crystal structure, with a distorted hexagonal solid-state arrangement, in which each atom has six nearest neighbors (at a distance of 265.9 pm) in its own plane and another six at a greater distance (290.6 pm). The metal is hard and brittle at most temperatures but softens between 100 and 150°C. Above 210°C, the metal becomes brittle again and can be crushed by beating.

Electrochemistry is a branch of physical chemistry that studies the electrical aspects of chemical reactions. Elements used in electrochemical reactions are characterized by the number of electrons they have. In general, electrochemistry is divided into two groups, namely galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Electrochemical reactions can take place spontaneously, that is, when two electrodes immersed in a liquid electrolyte are connected by an electric circuit. Electrochemistry is used for metal refining and plating as well as electrosynthesis. The electrochemical method is based on redox reactions that combine oxidation and reduction processes. This reaction is carried out at the same or different electrodes. Electrochemical systems are formed through electrochemical reactions elicited by electrochemical cells. Electrochemical cells are divided into two types, namely galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Galvanic cells generate electricity due to spontaneous reactions, while electrolytic cells generate electricity due to non-spontaneous reactions. Redox is a term that describes changes in the oxidation number (oxidation state) of atoms in a chemical reaction. The term redox comes from two concepts, namely reduction and oxidation. An oxidizing agent is a substance that oxidizes another substance in a redox reaction. Meanwhile, a reducing agent is a substance that reduces another substance in a redox reaction. Corrosion is metal damage that occurs due to electrochemical reactions or direct chemical reactions. The most common corrosion events found are rust on iron, tarnish on silver, and green platinum that forms on copper and brass. The corrosion medium can be dry or wet. An example of corrosion that takes place in a dry medium is the rusting of iron metal by oxygen gas or by sulfur dioxide gas. Meanwhile, an example of corrosion that takes place in a wet medium is iron immersed in hydrochloric acid.

Corrosion damage causes losses in the industrial and economic fields. Electrosynthesis is one of the synthesis techniques applied to inorganic materials. The basic principle of electrosynthesis is electrochemistry. The equipment used in the electrosynthesis process is two or three electrode rods connected to an electric current. Setting the speed of the reaction is done by adjusting the potential difference and the level of electric current density within the desired limits. Synthesis using the electrosynthesis method is easy to control and has a very low level of pollution. A gas transducer is a transducer whose function is to determine the presence or measure the quantity of a particular gas. One of the working principles that can be applied to gas transducers is the electrochemical gas sensor. The target gas will react to the electrochemical gas sensor and generate an electrical signal. The magnitude of the value of the electrical signal sent is proportional to the concentration of the gas. The electrochemical gas sensor consists of two electrodes, each of which functions as a sensing and measuring gas quantity. These two electrodes are separated by a thin layer of electrolyte. Before the gas comes into contact with the sensor, it passes through a thin capillary opening and undergoes diffusion along the hydrophobic barrier until it reaches the surface of the electrode. The hydrophobic barrier prevents leakage of the liquid electrolyte and generates a sufficient electrical signal at the sensing electrode. The electrochemical gas sensor also has a reference electrode whose job is to maintain a continuous electrochemical reaction that occurs on the surface of the electrode. This reference electrode creates a stable and constant potential difference at the sensing electrode. The target gas undergoes an electrochemical reaction resulting in the flow of current between the sensing and counter electrodes. The passage of electric charge in the electride is carried out by the electrolyte. Paracetamol can be made using electrochemical reduction using nitrobenzene as raw material.

The Sahel (from Arabic ساحل sahil for 'coastal' or 'border') is the border zone in Africa between the Sahara to the north and the more fertile area to the south, known as Sudan (not to be confused with the country of the same name). The first time this term was used as a phytogeographical term, referring to the soil band between 75 - 450 isohyet (rain band). Here researchers have referred to a wide range of isohyets in determining the location of the Sahel. The term also refers to countries in West Africa. The Sahel is primarily savanna and extends from the Atlantic Ocean to the Horn of Africa, changing semiarid grasslands to thorny savannahs. Throughout African history this area has been home to several advanced kingdoms that benefited from trade across the desert. Together these countries are known as the Kingdoms of the Sahel. Countries that own the Sahel now include Senegal, Mauritania, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, Nigeria, Chad, Sudan, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Djibouti and Somalia. A map of this area can be viewed here. The Sahel receives 150–500 mm (6–20 in) of rainfall each year, mainly during the monsoon season. Rainfall is characterized by changes from year to year and from decade to decade. The two biggest factors determining soil productivity in the Sahel are water and micronutrients, mostly nitrogen and phosphate. There is a strong relationship between rainfall in the Sahel and intense tropical cyclone activity in the Atlantic. Traditionally, most of the Sahel population has become semi-nomadic, farming and raising livestock in a transhuman system, which is probably the most sustainable way of using the Sahel.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health Science Zoology or animal science is a branch of biology that studies animals. Scientific zoological studies have started since the 16th century AD. The object of his study includes structure, function, behavior, and the evolutionary process of animals. The main topics in zoology are comparative anatomy, ethology, animal psychology, molecular biology, ethology, behavioral ecology, evolutionary biology, taxonomy, and paleontology. People who study zoology are called zoologists. The Ancient Egyptians were known to have extensive knowledge about animals and raising cattle, sheep, geese and ducks. Then in ancient Greek civilization, appearing in the 6th and 5th centuries BC respectively Anaximander, Xenophanes, and Empedocles. They predict the origins of animal life in the world. In early Europe, they collected and described strange animals from far away lands or deep seas, as recorded in the Physiologus and in the works of Albertus Magnus. His work is largely based on the writings of Aristotle (384-322 BC). Magnus' De animalibus libri XXVI is not only a published volume on Natural History, but it remains one of the most extensive published observational zoological studies before modern times. Found roots in Arabia and China. Arab scholar, Al-Jahizz (781-868) wrote the Book of Animals. The two major Chinese writers in this field were Su Song (1020-1101) and Shen Kuo (1031-1095) during the Song dynasty, but there were many others. In Roman times, the main writer on natural history was Pliny the Elder (23-79). Zoology really started in the 16th century with the revival of a new spirit of observation and exploration. The spirit of inquiry first appeared in Italian university schools of anatomy in the 16th century and spread fifty years later to the University of Oxford. The first established European academy was the Akademik naturae Curiosorum (1651) which limited itself to descriptions and illustrations of plant and animal structures; eleven years later, the Royal Society of London was founded by means of a royal charter.

A little later the Paris Academy of Sciences was founded by Louis XIV. Collectors and systematisers matured in the second half of the 18th century as Linnaeus, other anatomists such as John Hunter also began work to examine the anatomy of the entire animal kingdom and to classify its members with the aid of careful study. Leeuwenhoek, a Dutch tailor and naturalist, introduced another revolution with his construction of the first microscope. It was not until the 19th century that microscopes were improved and completed for what some consider zoology to be its most important service. Refinement of the microscope led to an increased understanding of cell structure and the establishment of Cell Theory: Contributions of individuals such as William Harvey (circulatory system), Carolus Linnaeus (systems of nomenclature), Georges Buffon (natural history), Georges Cuvier (comparative anatomy), and Claude Bernard (homeostasis) ) very advanced field. Charles Darwin's On the Origin of Species, published on November 24, 1859, is a work of scientific literature, considered the foundation of evolutionary biology. Linnaeus' Tables of the Animal Kingdom from the first edition of Systema naturae (1735). Morphography is the tabulation, systematic exploration and characterization of data concerning animals, present or extinct. It is similar to ethnography. Groups of people who have contributed to the field include museums' recent makers and their modern descendants, curators and annotators of animal collections, early explorers and modern travelers naturalists and collectors of fossil authors and paleontologists. Although the study of animal life is ancient, its scientific incarnations are relatively modern. This reflects the transition from natural history to biology in the early nineteenth century. Since Hunter and Cuvier, the study of comparative anatomy has been linked to morphography shapes modern areas of zoological inquiry: anatomy, physiology, histology, embryology, and animal behavior. the first modern zoology appeared in German and English universities.

The Republic of Namibia (Afrikaans: Republiek van Namibië, German: Republic of Namibia (help·info)) is a country in southwestern Africa on the Atlantic coast. The country is bordered by Angola and Zambia to the north, Botswana to the east and South Africa to the south. Namibia became independent from South Africa in 1990 making it one of the youngest countries in the world. Its capital is Windhoek. In the late 19th century during European colonization, the German Empire established rule over most of the territory as a protectorate in 1884. It began developing infrastructure and agriculture, and maintained this German colony until 1915, when South African troops defeated it militarily. After the end of World War I, in 1920 the League of Nations assigned the country to England, under the administration of South Africa. It enforced its laws, including racial classifications and rules. From 1948, the National Party was elected to power, South Africa imposed apartheid on what was then known as South West Africa. In 1878 the Cape of Good Hope Colony annexed the harbors of Walvis Bay and the Penguin Islands; it became an integral part of the new South African Union in its creation in 1910. In the 20th century, uprisings and demands for political representation by indigenous African political activists who wanted independence resulted in the United Nations assuming direct responsibility for the territory in 1966, but South Africa maintain by de facto rule. In 1973 the United Nations recognized the South West African People's Organization (SWAPO) as the official representative of the people of Namibia; the party is dominated by the Ovambo tribe, who make up the vast majority in the region. After continuous guerrilla warfare, South Africa installed a provisional government in Namibia in 1985. Namibia gained full independence from South Africa in 1990.

But Walvis Bay and the Penguin Islands remained under South African control until 1994. Namibia is divided into 13 regions: Caprivi, Erongo, Hardap, Karas, Kavango, Khomas, Kunene, Ohangwena, Omaheke, Omusati, Oshana, Oshikoto and Otjozondjupa. The large and dry Namib Desert makes Namibia one of the least densely populated countries in the world. Namibia has high political, economic and social stability. Prior to its independence in 1990, the area was known as German Southwest Africa (Deutsch-Südwestafrika), then as Southwest Africa, reflecting the colonial occupation by Germany and South Africa (technically the name of the British crown reflects South Africa's ruling status within the British Empire). ). From around the 14th century, Bantu immigrants arrived during the Bantu expansion from Central Africa. From the late 18th century onwards, the Oorlam people from the Cape Colony crossed the Orange River and moved into present-day southern Namibia. their encounters with the nomadic tribes of Nama are mostly peaceful. The missionaries accompanying the Oorlams were well received by them, the right to use the watering holes and grazing was granted in terms of an annual payment. However, on their journey further north, the Oorlam encountered clans of the Herero tribe in Windhoek, Gobabis, and Okahandja, who resisted their encroachments. War between Nama and Herero broke out in 1880, with hostilities receding only after the German Empire deployed troops to the contested areas and secured the status quo between Nama, Oorlam, and Herero. The first Europeans to descend and explore the area were Portuguese navigators Diogo Cao in 1485 and Bartolomeu Dias in 1486, but the Portuguese did not try to claim the area.

Karl Heinrich Santury Marx (German: maɐ̯ks]; 5 May 1818 – 14 March 1883) was a German philosopher, economist, historian, political theorist, sociologist, journalist and revolutionary socialist. Born in Trier into a middle-class family, Marx studied law and Hegelian philosophy. Due to his political publications, Marx became stateless and lived in exile in London, where he continued to develop his ideas in collaboration with the German thinker Friedrich Engels and published his writings, conducting research in the reading room of the British Museum. His best-known works are the 1848 pamphlet, The Communist Manifesto, and the three-volume Das Kapital. His political thought and philosophy had an influence on later intellectual, economic and political history and his name is used as an adjective, pronunciation and school of social theory. Marx's theories on society, economics and politics—which are collectively understood as Marxism—stipulate that humanity develops through class struggle. In capitalism, manifest itself is in conflict between the governing class (known as the bourgeoisie) who control the means of production and the working class (known as the proletariat) who can be made use of by selling their labor power in return for wages. Advancing the critical convention known as historical materialism, Marx predicted that, like previous socio-economic systems, capitalism would produce internal tensions that would lead to self-destruction and be replaced by a new system: socialism. For Marx, class antagonism under capitalism, which is part and parcel of its unstable and crisis-prone nature, would then lead the working class to develop a classless society, leading to their conquest of political power and thus consolidating a classless, communist society governed by producer associations. free. Marx actively pushed for its implementation, arguing that the working class must take revolutionary action to overthrow capitalism and bring about socio-economic emancipation.

Marx is considered one of the most influential figures in human history, and his work has been both praised and criticized. His work in economics formed the basis for much of today's understanding of labor and its relationship to capital, and later economic thought. Several intellectuals, trade unionists, artists and political parties around the world were influenced by the work of Marx, with some modifying or adapting his ideas. Marx is usually cited as one of the principal architects of modern social science. Marx was born on 5 May 1818 to Heinrich Marx (1777–1838) and Henriette Pressburg (1788–1863). He was born in Brückengasse 664, Trier, a town then part of the Lower Rhine Province, Kingdom of Prussia. Marx is Jewish. His maternal grandfather was a Dutch rabbi, while his paternal line includes Trier rabbis from 1723, a role taken by his grandfather Meier Halevi Marx. His father, known as Herschel as a child, was the first in his family to receive a secondary education and he became a lawyer and lived a relatively affluent and middle-class life, with his family owning a number of Moselle vineyards. Prior to the birth of his son, and after the lifting of Jewish emancipation in the Rhineland, Herschel converted from Judaism to join the state religion of the Evangelical Church of Prussia, changing his first name from Herschel of Yiddish origin to Heinrich of German origin. Marx was a briefly abolished third cousin of the German Romance poet Heinrich Heine, who was also born into a German Jewish family in the Rhineland, who became an avid correspondent in his later life. Like most irreligious people, Heinrich was a figurehead of the Age of Enlightenment, interested in the ideas of the philosophers Immanuel Kant and Voltaire.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Belgium, officially the Kingdom of Belgium, is a country in western Europe. To the north, Belgium is bordered by the Netherlands, to the east by Germany, to the south by France and Luxembourg, and to the west by the North Sea, across from the United Kingdom. The country has an area of ​​30,689 square kilometers (11,849 sq mi) and a population of over 11.5 million, making it the 22nd most populous country in the world and the 6th most populous in Europe with a density of 376 per square kilometer (970/sq mi). The country's capital and largest city is Brussels; Other major cities include Antwerp, Gent, Brugge, Namur and Leuven. The country is a federal constitutional kingdom with a parliamentary system. The country is divided into three states: the Region of Flanders in the north, the Region of Wallonia in the south, and the Brussels-Capital Region. Within Belgium there are two main linguistic communities: the Dutch-speaking Flemish Community, which makes up about 60 percent of the Belgian population, and the French-speaking Community, which makes up about 40 percent of the population. The German-speaking community is small, numbering only about one percent, and is located in East Canton. The Brussels Capital Territory is officially bilingual in French and Dutch, although French is the dominant language. Belgium's linguistic diversity and related political conflicts are reflected in its complex system of government, which consists of six different governments. Belgium is one of the six founding countries of the European Union and its capital, Brussels, is the official host of the European Commission, European Union Council and European Council, as well as one of the two seats of the European Parliament (the other is located in Strasbourg).

Belgium is also a founding member of the Eurozone, NATO, OECD and WTO, as well as part of the trilateral union Benelux and the Schengen Area. Brussels hosts the headquarters of many major international organizations such as NATO. The Belgae were the inhabitants of the northernmost part of Gaul, which was much larger than modern Belgium. Caesar used the Latin word "Belgium", to refer to their country north of Gaul, which is now northern France. After Caesar's conquest, Gallia Belgica became the Latin name of the large Roman province that included most of Northern Gaul, including Treveri. Areas closer to the border of the lower Rhine, including the eastern part of modern Belgium, eventually became part of the border province of Germania Inferior, which interacted with Germanic tribes outside the empire. At a time when central government collapsed in the Western Roman Empire, the Roman provinces of Belgica and Germania were populated by a mixed German-speaking Roman and Frankish population who dominated the military and political class. During the 5th century, the area came under the rule of the Merovingian kings of the Franks, who were probably the first to be established in northern France. During the 8th century, the Frankish kingdom was ruled by the Carolingian dynasty, whose power center was around what is now eastern Belgium. Most of modern Belgium was in the Middle Kingdom, then known as Lotharingia, but the coastal areas of Flanders, west of the Scheldt, became part of West Francia, France's predecessor. In 870 in the Treaty of Meerssen, the lands of modern Belgium all but became part of the western empire for a period, but in 880 in the Treaty of Ribemont, Lotharingia returned to the control of the Holy Roman Emperor. The area of ​​Flanders extended to the Schelde to become the empire. In the 15th century, the French Dukes of Burgundy took control of Flanders, and from there they began to unify most of what is now the Benelux, which is called Dutch Burgundy.

Albigensis (Per. )Hussite (Boh. )Lollard (Ing. )Waldensis (Per./Ita./Jer.) Anabaptist Anglicanism (English)Calvinism (Switzerland)Lutheranism (Jer. )Reformed Socinianism (Pol. )Zwinglianism (Swiss. ) Amish (Ame. )Baptist (Ing. )Congregational Mennonite (Bel./Swi./Ame./Kan. )Methodism (Ing. )Pietism Presbyterianism (Scot./Ame. )Puritanism (Ing. )Evangelical Universalism Pentecostal Revivalism Movement Protestant Adventist Restoration (in Indonesia known as Protestantism) is a denomination in Islam that worships God which refers to the Protestant reform movement by Martin Luther in 1517 with 95 of his postulates. Protestant etymology itself comes from Latin, namely: "Pro Testanum", (English: "Pro Testament"). "Pro" means: to take sides, vote for or against. While "Testanum" means: Covenant. These are 2 words that refer to the Old Testament and the New Testament in the Bible. This word is defined as a Christian Reformed/Christian/follower of Christ/Jesus movement that begins a return based on the faith and practice of Christianity based on the beginnings of the Bible, originating from the encouragement of the Protestant Reformation in doctrinal, political and ecclesiological terms, against what are perceived as abuses of the Church Roman Catholics at the time. This is one of the three main affirmations of "Nicene Christianity", that is, alongside the Roman Catholic Church and the Orthodox Church. The term "Protestant" also refers to the "Protestant Reformation letter" submitted by dignitaries who supported Martin Luther's statement, against the Diet Speyer decision in 1529 which upheld the Diet of Worms decision (edict) which condemned Martin Luther's teachings as heretical (heretic). And the Pro-Testan Reformation movement carried out by Martin Luther is not the first time it has occurred in the Catholic Church, because previously there had been similar movements like what happened in :- France led by Peter Waldo (and now his followers are members of the Church Waldensis) in the mid-12th century;- Bohemia (now including Czech) under Jan Hus (1369-1415), followers of John Hus in Bohemia later joined the Calvinist Church. and- Countries with large numbers of immigrants from Italy, such as Uruguay.

In 2005, around 5.9%–14,276,459 people out of 241,973,879 people in Indonesia followed the teachings of Protestantism and the 2010 census was around 6.96% - 16,528,513 people. Because most missionaries to Indonesia came from the Netherlands and Germany, most Protestant Christian churches in Indonesia are heavily colored by Calvinist and Lutheran colors. Number of Protestant Christians Based on Population Census by province (June 2022): Although the doctrines of Protestant denominations are far from uniform, there are several beliefs that are spread in Protestantism, namely the doctrines of sola gratia, sola fide, and sola scriptura. Protestant churches generally reject Catholic and Orthodox doctrines regarding apostolic inheritance and sacramental ministry of the clergy. The exception is found in many countries, such as in southern Europe, which were under non-Catholic influence long before the Reformation. Protestant pastors and church leaders have slightly different roles and authority within their communities than Catholic, Anglican and Orthodox pastors and bishops. Followers of the Protestant movement refer to the grouping of churches according to their basic doctrines as "denominations". They are the names of the different parts of a single "Church". Protestants reject the doctrine of the Roman Catholic Church as the only true church. Some Christian denominations are more strict than others and there are conflicting grounds of orthodoxy between them. Individual denominations also emerge according to theological differences which are sometimes very subtle. There are also many denominations which are simply regional or ethnic expressions of the same belief, which recognize the five solas as the main basic principles of the Christian faith. Non-denominational groups are also included in the Protestant group. Due to all these factors, an exact count is not possible, but it is estimated that there are about 33,000 Protestant denominations.
