Cryolite (Na3AlF6, sodium hexafluoroaluminate) is a rare mineral that was first discovered in large deposits at Ivigtût on the west coast of Greenland, but these deposits were depleted in 1987. This mineral was previously used in the process for making pure aluminum. The difficulty in separating aluminum from oxygen in oxide ores (such as aluminum oxide) can be solved by mixing the compound with cryolite. Pure cryolite melts at 1012°C (1285 K) and mixing lowers the melting point of aluminum oxide, allowing aluminum to be extracted more easily in the electrolysis process. It still takes a large amount of energy to heat the required material and carry out the electrolysis process, but it is more energy efficient than melting the aluminum oxide itself. Natural cryolite is now too rare to be used in the process, so synthetic sodium aluminum fluoride is now used; These compounds are produced from the mineral fluorite. Cryolite deposits have been reported at Pikes Peak, Colorado; Mont Saint-Hilaire, Québec; and in Miass, Russia. It has also been found in small amounts in Brazil, the Czech Republic, Namibia, Norway, Ukraine and several states in the United States. Cryolite was first described in 1798 by Peder Christian Abildgaard of Denmark (1740-1801); Its name comes from the Greek words κρυος (cryos) meaning "ice" and λιθος (lithos) meaning "stone". The Pennsylvania Salt Manufacturing Company used large quantities of cryolite to make sodium hydroxide at Natrona, Pennsylvania, during the 19th and 20th centuries. This mineral is now a rare mineral, so cryolite is probably the only mineral on Earth that has been mined to extinction from commercial circulation. This mineral-related article is a stub.

Corrosion (Dutch: corrosie, English: corrosion) is the damage or destruction of materials due to chemical reactions in their environment. In general, corrosion can be divided into wet corrosion and dry corrosion. Corrosion is caused by physical chemical, metallurgical, electrochemical and thermodynamic factors. Corrosion can be classified into eight, namely general corrosion, galvanic corrosion, crevice corrosion, well corrosion, grain boundary corrosion, selective corrosion, erosion corrosion, and stress corrosion. In everyday language, corrosion is called rust. The most common example of corrosion is the rusting of iron. In the event of corrosion, metal undergoes oxidation, while oxygen (air) undergoes reduction. Metal rust is generally in the form of oxides or carbonates. The chemical formula for iron rust is Fe2O3.nH2O, a brown-red solid. Corrosion is an electrochemical process. In iron corrosion, a certain part of the iron acts as the anode, where the iron undergoes oxidation. Fe(s) <--> Fe2+(aq) + 2e The electrons liberated at the anode flow to another part of the iron which acts as the cathode, where the oxygen is reduced. O2(g) + 4H+(aq) + 4e <--> 2H2O(l) or O2(g) + 2H2O(l) + 4e <--> 4OH-(aq) Iron(II) ions formed at the next anode oxidizes to form iron(III) ions which then form a hydrated oxide compound, namely iron rust. Regarding which part of the iron acts as the anode and which part acts as the cathode, it depends on various factors, such as impurities, or differences in the density of the metal. Corrosion can also be interpreted as an attack that damages metal because metal reacts chemically or electrochemically with the environment. There is another definition that says that corrosion is the opposite of the process of extracting metal from its mineral ore. For example, iron metal mineral ores in nature exist in the form of iron oxide or iron(II) sulfide compounds, after being extracted and processed, iron will be produced which is used to manufacture steel or alloy steel.

During use, the steel will react with the environment which causes corrosion (turns back into iron oxide compounds). The Voltaic series and the Nernst Equation will help to determine the possibility of corrosion. The speed of corrosion is very dependent on many factors, such as the presence or absence of an oxide layer, because the oxide layer can block the potential difference to other electrodes which will be very different if it is still clean of oxide. Corrosion on iron causes many losses, because goods or buildings that use iron are not durable. Corrosion on iron can be prevented by turning iron into stainless steel, but this process is expensive, so it is not suitable for most uses of iron. water and air. Paints containing lead and zinc will better protect the iron against corrosion. The painting must be perfect because if there are parts that are not covered by paint, then the iron under the paint will corrode. Building fences and bridges are usually protected from corrosion by painting. The plastic prevents contact of the iron with water and air. Household appliances are usually wrapped in plastic to prevent corrosion. Chrome provides a protective layer, so that chromated iron will become shiny. Chromium plating is done by electrolysis process. Chrome can provide protection even if the chrome layer is damaged. This method is generally done on motorized vehicles, such as car bumpers. Tin is a metal that is stainless. Iron cans are generally coated with tin. The coating process is carried out by electrolysis or electroplating. The tin coating will protect the iron as long as it is intact. If there are scratches, tin actually accelerates the corrosion process because the potential of the iron electrode is more positive than tin.

Symmetry or summation is a characteristic of a geometric plane. There are three main types of symmetry operations namely reflection, rotation and translation. Even if two objects with high similarity appeared together, they should be different. For example, if you rotate an equilateral triangle about its center by 120 degrees, the triangle will appear the same as before the rotation. In Euclidean Geometry, this rotation results in an unrecognized change. In fact, each corner of an equilateral triangle modeled as a molecule exhibits a different symmetrical behavior. The object with the most symmetry is empty space because each part can be rotated, reflected or translated without changing. The most common type of symmetry is left-right or mirror image symmetry which is symbolized by T:. this symbol is used to reflect along the vertical axis. An equilateral triangle exhibits three axes of reflection symmetry, and a rotational symmetry. Rotating the triangle about the center of the triangle by 120 or 240 degrees shows no change. An object that only exhibits rotational symmetry behavior but does not have reflection symmetry is the swastika. Examples of wikipedia symmetry (similarity obtained by shifting one line down and two spaces to the right), and translational symmetry of two forms: (similarity obtained by shifting three positions to the right, or one line down and two positions to the right; until similarity is obtained for three lines down). In both cases it is neither mirror-image nor rotational symmetry. Felix Klein, the German geometer, gave a very influential statement in the Erlangen program in 1872, symmetry as a combination and organization of principles in geometry. This gave rise to the group's new concern in geometry and the slogan transformation of geometry (an aspect of the new Mathematics, but highly controversial in modern mathematical practices).

A fractal, as conceptualized by Mandelbrot, which has symmetry includes having a scale. For example, an equilateral triangle can shrink by one-third its original size by three. These smaller triangles can be rotated at the center line of the larger triangle and translated until they coincide. Smaller triangles can repeat the process, resulting in smaller triangles on sides. Structures into triangles can be created by repeating the scale of the symmetry operation several times. An example from mathematics that expresses symmetry is a2c + 3ab + b2c. If a and b are changed, the expression shows no change in the commutative property for addition and multiplication. In mathematics, a study of the symmetry of objects by collecting all operations that result in the object not changing. These operations form a group. For geometric objects, this is known as a symmetry group; for algebraic objects, the term automorphism group is used. In fact, at the end of the 20th century, group was synonymous with group transformation (con: group action). Only during the early 20th century were definitions of groups without reference to group action. A dyadic relationship R is symmetric if and if, while true for Wed, is true for Rba. The words age with are symmetry, for if Paul is the same age as Mary, then Mary is the same age as Paul. If we have a set of objects with multiple structures, then it is possible for a symmetry to convert one object to another. So it is necessary to generalize from the concept of a symmetric group to a groupoid. Physicists use generalizations such as supersymmetry and quantum groups. The generalization of symmetries in physics down to invariants under various transformations has become one of the tools of theoretical physics. See Noether's theorem (which, as an oversimplification, states that for every law of symmetry, there is a conservation law) for an explanation.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Toxicology is a field of science that studies the harmful effects that chemicals or substances can have on humans, animals and the environment. From the definition above, it is clear that in toxicology there are elements that interact with each other in a certain way to cause a response to a biological system that can cause damage to the biological system. One element of toxicology is chemical or physical agents capable of causing a response in biological systems. Furthermore, the mode of exposure is another element that also determines the emergence of these unwanted effects. Toxic substances can be classified based on the target organs, their uses, effects, physical properties, chemical types and level of toxicity. For example, toxic substances are discussed in relation to the target organs and are known as liver poisons, kidney poisons are known as pesticides, solvents, food additives and so on and when linked to the source they are known as animal and plant toxins when associated with their effects are recognized as carcinogens, mutagens and so on. Toxic agents may also be classified by: The classification of toxic substances on the basis of their biochemical mechanism of action (sulfhydryl inhibitors, metHb generators) is usually more self-explanatory than classification by general terms such as irritant and corrosive, but more general classifications such as pollutant Airborne agents, workplace-related agents, and acute and chronic toxins can provide a useful centerpiece for a specific problem. From the description above it has been proven that there is no single classification system that can be applied to all the various toxic agents. The combination of classification systems may be necessary for one particular purpose. However, a classification system based on the chemical and biological properties of the toxicant and the method of exposure is used to control the effects of the toxicant.

The cabinet is a body made up of senior/high-level government officials, usually representing the executive branch. The cabinet may also be referred to as the Council of Ministers, Executive Council or Executive Committee, this designation depends on the system of government and is chaired by the president or prime minister as head of the cabinet In some countries, especially those using the Westminster system, the cabinet collectively determines the policy and tactical direction of the government particularly regarding legislation approved by parliament. In countries with presidential systems, such as the United States, the cabinet does not function as a collective legislative influence; rather it is a formal advisory board to the head of government. In this way, the president obtains opinions and advice to use in determining future decisions. The second role of cabinet officers is to oversee government agencies or departments (in the United States known as the federal executive department). In many countries, including those using the Westminster system, cabinet ministers are appointed from a portion of the legislature and remain in the legislature while also working in the cabinet. In other countries, especially countries with presidential systems, opposition is possible: members of the cabinet may not concurrently serve as legislators, and legislators appointed to become members of the cabinet must resign from the legislature if they wish to be appointed ministers. In many governments, members of the cabinet are given the title of minister, and each holds a different government-assigned portfolio (eg "Minister of Health," and others). In some countries, for example in the United States, the Philippines and the United Kingdom, the title secretary is also used for some members of the cabinet (eg "Secretary for Education," etc.). The Attorney General also sits in the cabinet. The day-to-day role of most cabinet members is as head of one segment of the national bureaucracy, as head of the civil service to which all other employees in that department report.

Cabinet sizes vary, although some contain ten to twenty ministers. Many studies have found an inverse correlation between a country's level of development and cabinet size: on average, the more developed a country is, the smaller its cabinet size. Historically, the Cabinet began as a smaller subgroup of the Privy Council of the British Monarchy. This term comes from the name of a Cabinet (room) which is used to study a problem. The phrase cabinet counsel, meaning advice personally given to the king/queen of England, appeared in the late 16th century, and, given its non-standard spelling today, it is often difficult to tell whether council or counsel is being used. The Oxford English Dictionary cites Francis Bacon in his Essays (1605) with the first use of Cabinet council, in which it describes a foreign custom, which it disapproves of: "For what disfavour, Italian doctrine, and French practice, in the days of the kings- king, had introduced cabinet counsel; the way to recover was worse than the disease itself. Charles I started the formal "Cabinet Council" from his reign in 1625, as the Council of Privy Councilors, or "private council", proved to be insufficiently private, and the first recorded use of "cabinet" itself for an agency dates back to 1644, and is again hostile and associated with the term denoting foreign practice. This process was repeated recently, because leaders felt they had to have a Kitchen Cabinet.Under the Westminster system, members of the cabinet were responsible for all government policies know. All ministers, both senior and junior in the cabinet, must support government policies, regardless of personal interests. Although, theoretically, all cabinet decisions are taken by the cabinet collectively, in practice many decisions are delegated to various sub-committees within the cabinet (in Indonesia: deputy ministries), which report to the council of ministers on their findings and recommendations.

Drs. R. Soekmono (14 July 1922 – 9 July 1997) was an archaeologist from Indonesia and had led the restoration project of Borobudur Temple in 1971-1983. Together with Satyawati Suleiman, Soekmono was one of the first Indonesian archaeologists to successfully complete his bachelor's degree in 1953 from the Faculty of Letters, University of Indonesia. Pak Soek, usually called by colleagues, subordinates, and students. Together with Satyawati Suleiman, Soejono, Boechari, Uka Tjandrasasmita, Basoeki and Dutch archaeologists in 1954 made an expedition to Sumatra. From his expedition, he was of the opinion that during the Srivijaya period the eastern coast of Sumatra was located inland. In Jambi there is a bay, while the city of Palembang is located at the end of a peninsula. This opinion continued to be maintained until the end of his life. Soekmono was the first Indonesian to graduate as a doctorate in archeology. After graduating in 1953, that same year he was appointed Head of the Antiquities Service of the Republic of Indonesia, a position previously held by Dutchmen. He continued to hold this position until 1973. In 1970 he was entrusted by the government to lead the Borobudur Temple Restoration Project, a major project funded by the Indonesian government and UNESCO. In the midst of his busy life leading a large project, in 1974 he completed his dissertation entitled "Temples, Functions and Definitions" at the University of Indonesia. It is in this field of study that his expertise and experience can be tested, especially his knowledge of temples in Indonesia. His experience in the Borobudur Temple Restoration Project makes him an expert on the temple buildings he is handling. In the international world his knowledge of the conservation of monumental buildings is widely used. He held several positions related to conservation issues. His busy life as an "archaeological practitioner" does not make him forget about the academic world.

Poultry (English: poultry) is a type of livestock group of birds used for their meat and eggs or feathers. Generally part of the order Galliformes (such as chickens and turkeys), and Anseriformes (such as ducks). The word poultry is also commonly used for meat birds as above. More broadly, this word can also be used for the meat of other types of birds such as pigeons. Birds have the physical characteristics of wings, legs, beak and feathers. In everyday life, poultry are birds that are taken advantage of by humans, whether it's meat, eggs, feathers, or used as pets for entertainment purposes only. The fleshiest parts of the bird are the flight muscles of the chest, and the gait muscles of the first and second segments of the legs. The term poultry is actually only valid in the world of animal husbandry, if in the science of biology and the system of naming species there is absolutely no special order that becomes the translation of poultry. Therefore, it can be concluded that in scientific terms, this bird is actually a bird, but what distinguishes the mention of most birds and poultry is only in the benefits. Poultry is a bird that is taken advantage of by humans. According to the habitat, birds are divided into two: These birds usually really like to live in water, marked by the presence of membranes on both legs. This membrane is used to help its movement while in the water. So it is easier to use in swimming. Other features can also be seen from the fast drying of the fur, usually there is some kind of oil content that helps dry the fur when exposed to water. This non-air fowl is actually land fowl, but if it is called land fowl it will be very biased with the meaning of fowl. namely birds used by humans. For example, dove.

Chemists are scientists who study chemistry. Chemists study the composition of matter and its properties. Chemists carefully describe the properties they study in terms of quantity, detailing down to the level of molecules and their components (atoms). Chemists carefully measure the proportions of matter, reaction rates, and other chemical properties. The term 'chemist' is also used to refer to Pharmacists in the Commonwealth of Nations. Chemists use this knowledge to study the composition and properties of unconventional materials, as well as to manufacture and synthesize large quantities of natural materials and to develop new artificial materials and processes. Chemists may have specialized in a number of chemical subdisciplines. Materials scientists and metallurgists share a great deal of education and skills with chemists. The chemist's work is often associated with chemical engineering work, which is generally concerned with the design, construction and cost-effectiveness evaluation of large-scale chemical plants, and is closely linked with industrial chemists on the development of new processes and methods for the manufacture of chemicals and related products for commercial scale. . The roots of chemistry can be traced to the phenomenon of combustion. Fire in the past was a mystical power that could transform one material into another and thus became the main attraction of mankind. It was fire that sparked the discovery of iron and glass. After gold was discovered and became a precious metal, many people were interested in finding methods that could convert other materials into gold. This led to a protoscience called alchemy. The term chemist is derived from the Latin: chimista, short for alchimista (alchemist). Alchemists uncovered many of the chemical processes that led to the development of modern chemistry. Chemistry as it is known today, was created by Antoine Lavoisier with his law of conservation of mass in 1783.

The discovery of the chemical elements has a long history culminating in the creation of the periodic table by Dmitri Mendeleev. The Nobel Prize in Chemistry created in 1901 provides outstanding response to chemical discoveries since the early 20th century. Jobs for chemists usually require at least a bachelor's degree, but many positions, especially in research, require a doctorate. Most undergraduate programs emphasize mathematics and physics in addition to chemistry, because chemistry is also known as a "science center", so that chemists are required to have a thorough knowledge of science. At Masters level and above, students tend to experience specialization in a certain area. Fields of specialization include biochemistry, nuclear chemistry, organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry, polymer chemistry, analytical chemistry, theoretical chemistry, quantum chemistry, environmental chemistry, and thermochemistry. Postdoctoral experience may be required for certain positions. Workers who work involving chemistry, but with a complexity below that of a chemistry degree, are usually referred to as chemical technicians. Such technicians generally perform simpler tasks such as repeated analyzes for quality control or in a clinical laboratory. These chemical technicians in Indonesia are referred to as Associate Experts (D3). The top three companies that employ chemists are academic institutions, industry, especially the chemical and pharmaceutical industries, and government laboratories. Chemistry is usually divided into several main sub-disciplines. There are also several cross-disciplinary and more specialized fields. There is considerable overlap between the various branches of chemistry, as well as with other disciplines such as biology, medicine, physics, radiology, and some engineering disciplines. All of the above major fields of chemistry employ chemists. Other fields in which a chemistry degree can play a role include astrochemistry (and cosmos chemistry), atmospheric chemistry, chemical engineering, chemo-informatics, electrochemistry, environmental science, forensic science, geochemistry, green chemistry, history of chemistry, materials science, medical science, molecular biology , molecular genetics, nanotechnology, nuclear chemistry, oenology, organometallic chemistry, petrochemistry, pharmacology, photochemistry, phytochemistry, polymer chemistry, supramolecular chemistry and surface chemistry.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) The Republic of Cyprus is an island country (De facto controls 2/3 of the islands) in the eastern Mediterranean Sea, ±113 km south of Turkey and 120 km in the east west of Syria. The capital of this country is the city of Lefkosia (Nicosia). Other important cities were Lemesos (Limassol), Larnaca, Paphos, Ammochostos (Famagusta), and Kyrenia. Since 1974 after the Turkish Invasion of Cyprus, the northern part of the island (1/3 Island) has been controlled by the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, a country that is only recognized by the Turkish state. The earliest reliable reference is Mycenaean Greek from the 15th century BC ku-pi-ri-jo, meaning "Cyprus" (Greek: Κύπριος), written in Linear B. The classical Greek form of the name is Κύπρος (Kpros). The etymology of the name is unknown. Some estimates include: Through foreign trade, the island gave up its name to the Classical Latin word for copper via the aes Cyprium phase, "Cyprus metal", later shortened to Cuprum. The standard demonym associated with Cyprus or the people or culture is Cypriot. The terms Cypriote and Cyprian are also used, although less frequently. Cyprus, while still a British colony, would be given to Greece. But the Turkish minority refused. Eventually a compromise was agreed and in 1959 the independent state of Cyprus was established. But both sides were not satisfied and finally in 1974 a group that wanted unity with Greece staged a coup d'etat which Turkey reciprocated by occupying Cyprus. Since then Turkey occupied the northern region. On May 1, 2004, which coincided with the commemoration of Labor Day, Cyprus became a member of the European Union. However, only the southern regions are allowed to join, unless the northern regions also want to unite.

Eventually the inhabitants of the north put pressure on their government to unite with the south. On 24 April 2004 the northern regions (led by Raouf Denktash) said "yes" to unity. The south (led by Tassos Papadopoulos) said "no" to unity. So in the end only the southern part became a member of the European Union. Cyprus is an island country located in the Mediterranean Sea, south of the European Continent (Southern Europe). This country, which is astronomically located between 34°-36° N and 32°- 35° E, is located to the north of Egypt and to the northwest of Palestine, Lebanon and Israel. Cyprus is also to the west of Syria and to the southeast of Greece and to the south of Turkey. The capital of Cyprus is the city of Nicosia. Geographically the island of Cyprus is located only 75 kilometers from the Asian Turkish mainland, which is the part of Turkey that belongs to the Asian continent. Even this island visually on the map looks very close to the shores of Syria and Lebanon compared to the Greek peninsula. Cyprus is a presidential republic. Heads of state and government are elected through a general election process for a five-year term. Executive power is exercised by the government with legislative power in the hands of the House of Representatives. While the judiciary is independent from the executive and legislature. The 1960 constitution provided for a presidential system of government with independent executive, legislative and judicial branches as well as a complex system of checks and balances including power-sharing ratios designed to protect the interests of the Turkish Cypriots. The executive is headed by a Greek Cypriot president and a Turkish Cypriot vice president who are elected by their respective communities for five-year terms and each has veto power over certain types of laws and executive decisions. Legislative power rests with the DPR, which is also elected based on a separate list of voters.

A calendar is a system that divides time into date, month and year. better source needed] A calendar is generally a checkered chart with numbers, month names and holiday names. Calendar can also mean events or week of events that will be held. The calendars used in general are the solar calendar, the lunar calendar, the solar calendar, and the calendar of approval. The lunar calendar or lunar calendar is a calendar adapted to the movements of the Moon (moon phases). An example is Hijri. A solar calendar or solar calendar is a calendar based on the seasons and the movement of the Sun. Examples are the Persian Calendar, Gregorian Calendar, Julian Calendar and Roman Calendar. The solarcandra calendar or lunisolar calendar is a calendar adapted to the movements of the moon and sun, such as the Balinese calendar, the Jewish calendar and the Chinese calendar. Meanwhile, the calendar of approval is a calendar that is not adapted to the Moon and the Sun, for example, the Julian day and week used by astrologers. There are also calendars that appear to be timed to the movement of Venus, such as some of the Ancient Egyptian Calendars. This calendar also seems to have been used frequently in civilizations near the equator. The calendar that uses the seasons and the Earth's revolution around the sun is called the Solar Calendar. The Solar calendar was used by the Romans and their calculation system was used in the Julian calendar. There are 7 days used by the Solar Calendar, namely Sunday/Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and Saturday. Since the reign of a Roman emperor named Julius Caesar, on the advice of an astronomer named Sosigenes of Alexandria, Julius Caesar changed the number of days in each existing month to include leap year calculations. Julius Caesar's calendar is also known as the Julian calendar. The Gregorian calendar is the Gregorian calendar established by Pope Gregory XIII in 1582.

It is a correction to the Julian Calendar which was in effect since 47 BC. The only difference is the leap year regulations. The lunar calendar is a calendar based on the revolution of the Moon around the Earth. One revolution of the lunar calendar is equal to 12 revolutions of the Moon. The Moon's revolution lasts 29 days 12 hours 44 minutes 9 seconds. So that 1 lunar year equals 354 days 10 hours 49 minutes 48 seconds or 354.45125 days (10 days 17 hours 4 minutes 37 seconds or 10.711539351 days shorter than the solar calendar). A fiscal year is a one-year period used by governments or companies for financial reporting and budgeting. A fiscal year can start from January 1 to December 31. However, not all use a calendar-compliant fiscal year. This calendar is the calendar of the Egyptians, and is currently still used in secret by Indonesian supernaturalists/psychics. This calendar has many functions, namely to find out when someone died, was born, recovered, etc. For example, in the book written by the great teacher Abu Hayillah Al-Marzuki it is stated that if a Pisces person or someone who is sick starts on Saturday in the month of Kahik, then it is a sign that they will die. And indeed the astronomy in this book is also based on this calendar and the Roman or Roman calendar. The beginning of the year begins on the nearest September 12th. And the year is -283 AD. For example 2008. Then 2008-283=1725. So the year 2008 AD is the year 1725 Qibti, which starts in 1725 starting from 12 September 2008. The number of months is 13, namely Tutin, Babah, Hatur, Kahik, Tubah, Amsyir, Burmahat, Burmadah, Basnas, Buknah, Abib, Misri, Ayam NASA' . From Tutin to Misri each number of days is 30 days.

Emperor is one of the titles of the monarch in Indonesian. The territory ruled by the emperor was called an empire or empire. In Indonesian, another title that is equivalent to the emperor is maharaja. In its use, the emperor is more general, while the maharaja is more used for Hindu rulers. In the level of monarchy, the emperor and maharaja have a higher position than the king. The female equivalent of the title emperor is empress and this title can be used to refer to a female emperor or the wife of a male emperor. This word comes from the Greek Καῖσαρ (emperor) which in Latin is caesar. Caesar himself was originally the cognomen of Julius Caesar, Roman Dictator. His sister's grandson and adopted son, Gaius Octavius ​​or Augustus, took the name Caesar when he became the first Roman Emperor. This step was followed by his successors. Gradually, caesar was adopted in many languages ​​as a title for an emperor. In Germany, this title is called kaiser; whereas in Russia it is called a czar or tsar. Both the king and the emperor, both are monarchs. But the position of the emperor (and maharaja) is seen as higher than the king. An emperor usually had power that surpassed the other rulers around him, and also controlled several subordinate countries and kingdoms. One example is the Ottoman Turks who controlled several regions, including various kingdoms and duchies in Europe and Asia. In its progress, the title of emperor (and maharaja) was then carried by smaller regional rulers in order to increase their rank and status. Empires that were already divided generally also retained the title "emperor" for their ruler, even though his realm was no longer wider than the surrounding kingdoms and duchies. An example is what happened to the Eastern Roman Empire before its fall.

And also not all empires use the title of emperor like the Umayyad Dynasty and the Abbasid Dynasty which more often use the title Khalifah or Amirul Mukminin. In Indonesia, the monarchies that are considered on the same level as the empire are Sriwijaya and Majapahit. In everyday usage, the title emperor is synonymous with monarchs in East Asia, particularly those of China before the republic. Even though the position of the emperor is above the king, in general, there are still many Indonesian people who equate the position of these two titles. This makes the use of these two titles interchangeable, both in translation activities and in daily pronunciation. This is very possible because of Indonesia's republican background, so it does not pay much attention to the levels of the monarchy. The Japanese leader tennō (天皇) is now the only monarch in the world whose title in Indonesian is equivalent to emperor (English: emperor). Even so, in fact throughout history, tennō power only covers the islands of Kyushu, Honshu, Hokkaido, and Okinawa. This is different from the emperor in general whose territory covers a wide area, making his position seen above the king. During the Meiji Restoration (1868), the Satsuma-Chōshū Alliance made the English title emperor (Kaisar or Maharaja in Indonesian, Kaiser in German, and l'Empereur in French) the equivalent of the title tennō, instead of king (king in French). Indonesia). This was to express the high position of the Japanese leader over kings in general and to express his equality with the great world powers at that time, such as the Russian Emperor, the French Emperor (1857-1871), the Austrian Emperor, the German Emperor (from 1871), and the Empresses. Empress of India (from 1877) – and also Emperor of China, Mexico, and Brazil. In its course, the area that is now modern Indonesia was partially or completely controlled by foreign empires.

Steppes of the Pontus Caucasus East Asia Eastern Europe Northern Europe Steppes of Pontus North/East Steppes Europe South Asia Steppe Europe Caucasus India Indo-Aryans Iran East Asia Europe East Asia Europe Indo-Aryans Iran India Iran Other Europe *Dyḗus (literal meaning: "god" the midday sky"), also known as *Dyḗus ph₂tḗr (literally: "father god of the midday sky"), is a reconstruction of the name of the god of the midday sky in prehistoric Indo-European beliefs. *Dyēus has been traced as the divine embodiment of the clear midday sky and the throne of the gods is named *deywṓs, with both clear skies and cloudy skies and rain, *Dyēus is often paired with *Dʰéǵʰōm, the name of the ancient Indo-European goddess Mother Earth. Although his existence is not directly attested in writing or archaeologically, *Dyēus is considered by linguists to be the name of the closest reconstructed deity of all the Indo-European languages, which shares many similarities and similarities to the beliefs of the Indo-Aryans, Ancient Latin, Ancient Greek, Phrygian , Messapia, Thrace, Illyria, Ancient Albania, and Ancient Anatolia. The name *Dyēus comes from the root *dyeu-, referring to "diurnal sky" or "clear day", derived from *di or dei- ("to shine" or "bright"). Related words in Indo-European languages ​​revolve around the concepts of "day", "sky", as well as "gods and goddesses" which have the initial affix *dyeu- as etymology indicating that Dyēus was the wide and clear sky on that day which was understood as the embodiment of divine, for example in Sanskrit: dyumán- means "heavenly", "shining", "radiant". A derivative of Vṛddhi occurs in *deywós ("sky"), the common word for "god" in Proto-Indo-European. In a medieval Proto-Indo-European language, possibly related to the Khvalynsk culture (3900–3500 BC), *Dyēus also means "heaven", a departure from the meaning of "god" in general (or "sun god" in particular) in the Anatolian tradition Ancient.

Derivatives of the prefix *diwyós ("god") are also recorded in Latin, Greek and Sanskrit. The root *deynos (meaning "day"), interpreted as a word formation *deywós, has cognates in Old Sanskrit: divé-dive (meaning "day after day"); Latin: Dies, the goddess of the day who had a counterpart in Ancient Greek religion, namely Hemera; in Hittite: siwat ("day"); Pala: Tīyat- ("sun" or "day"), Ancient Greek: endios ("midday"), Ancient Armenian: տիւ, tiw ("clear day"); Old Irish: noenden ("nine day period"); Welsh: heddyw ("today"), or in Slavic Paganism: Poludnitsa (meaning "Woman of Day"). Although the Greek goddess Pandeia or Pandia (Greek: Πανδία, Πανδεία, meaning "all that is bright") may be another name for the moon goddess, Selene, her name retains the root *di-/*dei-, meaning "to shine" or "bright". The most constant epithet associated with *Dyēus is "father" or "father" (*ph2tḗr). The term "Father Dyēus" is inherited in the Old Vedic beliefs: Dyáuṣ Pitṛ́; Ancient Greek: Zeus Patēr, Illyrian: Dei-pátrous, Ancient Roman: Jupiter (*Djous patēr), even in the Old Scythian form "father" or "papa" equivalent to "Zeus", or an expression in Pala : Tiyaz, papaz. The epithet *Ph2tḗr Ǵenh1-tōr ("Creator Father") is also attested in the ritual traditions of the Vedas, Ancient Iran, Ancient Greece, and Ancient Rome. *Dyēus is the sky or day which is understood as the embodiment of the divine, and also the abode of the gods, namely heaven. As the gateway to the gods and father of the divine twins and goddess of the Dawn (*H2éwsōs), *Dyēus is the most recognized deity in the various pantheon of Proto-Indo-European beliefs. However, it doesn't seem like the ruler or holder of the highest power like Zeus and Jupiter. *Dyēus is associated with clear and wide skies, but also with cloudy weather in the Vedas and Ancient Greece, i.e. *Dyēus' rain.

Venus is the second closest planet to the Sun after Mercury. This planet orbits the Sun for 224.7 Earth days. Venus has no natural satellites and is named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty. After the Moon, it is the brightest natural object in the night sky, with an apparent magnitude of −4.6 which is bright enough to cast shadows. Venus is an inferior planet with an elongation angle of 47.8°. The maximum brightness of this planet can be seen immediately before sunrise or after sunset, so it is called the Morning Star or Evening Star. Venus is a terrestrial planet and is sometimes called Earth's "sister planet" because of its similar size, gravity, and composition (Venus is the closest planet to Earth and the planet closest in size to Earth). However, in other respects this planet is very different from Earth. This planet has the densest atmosphere of the four terrestrial planets consisting of 96% carbon dioxide. Venus's surface atmospheric pressure is 92 times greater than Earth's. With an average surface temperature of 735 K (462°C; 863°F), Venus is the hottest planet in the Solar System. The planet does not have a carbon cycle that traps carbon in rocks and surface features, nor does it have organic life that can sequester carbon in the form of biomass. Venus is shrouded in an opaque layer of highly reflective clouds of sulfuric acid, so its surface cannot be seen from space. Venus may have had oceans, but those oceans are evaporating due to increasing temperatures caused by the continuous greenhouse effect. Much of the water may have been photodissociated, and the solar wind may have allowed free hydrogen to escape into space as a result of the lack of an internal magnetic field on Venus.

The surface of Venus itself is deserted, dry, and punctuated by rock that is periodically renewed by volcanic activity. Venus is one of the four terrestrial planets in the Solar System, which means that it is a rocky planet like Earth. Its size and mass are similar to Earth, so this planet is often referred to as Earth's "sister" or "twin". The diameter of Venus is recorded at 12,092 km (only 650 km smaller than Earth) and its mass is approximately 81.5% of Earth's mass. However, conditions on the surface of Venus are very different from those on Earth, and this is due to Venus' thick atmosphere which is composed of 96.5% carbon dioxide and 3.5% nitrogen. There has been much speculation about the surface of Venus before it was discovered by space probes in the 20th century. The planet was mapped in detail by Project Magellan in 1990-91. On the surface there is evidence of volcanic activity, and sulfur in the atmosphere indicates that a volcanic eruption has occurred. About 80% of Venus' surface is made up of volcanic land, with 70% being land with wrinkled ridges and 10% being land that is smooth and indented. The remaining twenty percent make up the two upland "continents"; one of the continents is located in the northern hemisphere of Venus, while the other is south of the equator. The northern continent was called Ishtar Terra, named after Ishtar, the Babylonian goddess of love, and about the size of Australia. The highest mountain on Venus (namely Maxwell Montes) is located on Ishtar Terra. It is approximately 11 km above the average surface elevation of Venus. Meanwhile, the southern continent is nicknamed Aphrodite Terra, after the goddess of love in Greek mythology, and this continent is larger with a size more or less comparable to South America.

The Republic of Puntland is a limited state in the northeastern part of Somalia that is not recognized by anyone. The name "Puntland" is taken from the Land of Punt, now covering the territory of Somalia, which comes from sources in ancient Egypt. The ruler of Puntland regards his territory as an autonomous region under the auspices of Somalia. In 1969 when the Somali government was overthrown in a coup d'état, wars and riots arose. After the communists took power in Ethiopia, the Soviet Union changed its support from Somalia to Ethiopia. Without Soviet support, Somalia turned to the United States which allowed self-proclaimed president Siad Barre to remain in power until the end of the Cold War in 1991. Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the US no longer supported the Somali government, and Barre eventually stepped down. Somalia then did not have a strong government, coupled with a prolonged war that ravaged the southern part of Somalia. This series of events led to the formation of Somaliland in 1991; This Somali splinter republic was independent for only a few days in 1960. The constant anarchy that engulfed Somalia prompted the United Nations to send its peacekeepers there. In March 1995, the US withdrew its troops after several US soldiers were shot and slaughtered. Somalia, which is still in turmoil, lost its territorial control again in 1998 when Puntland was declared an autonomous region by Abdullahi Yusuf (deputy president of the Somali Salvation Democratic Front). Puntland's main mission is to become a nation in the form of a confederation of clans. Since 1998, the Sool and Sanaag areas have been disputed by Puntland and Somaliland. Unlike Somaliland, Puntland does not want international recognition as a sovereign state, but wants to become a federal division under the auspices of a unified Somalia in the form of a federal republic. Political turmoil began to emerge in Puntland in 2001 when President Ahmed wanted to extend his term in office.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health sciences Pedology is the study of various aspects of soil geology. It reviews various matters concerning soil formation (pedogenesis), soil morphology (physical and chemical properties and characteristics), and soil classification. The term is borrowed from the English pedology, which is formed from two Greek words: pedon ("soil") and logos ("symbol", "knowledge"). Pedology is one of the two main branches of soil science, besides edaphology (the science of soil fertility). Soil classification has various versions. There are technical difficulties in classifying soils because many factors influence soil formation. In addition, soil is a dynamic object, so it is always undergoing a process of change. Soil is formed from worn/weathered rock due to exposure to dynamics in the lower layers of the atmosphere, such as climate dynamics, topography/geography, and the activity of biological organisms. The intensity and time intervals of these factors also result in variations in the appearance of the soil. In classifying soil, experts first do it based on physical and chemical characteristics, as well as by looking at the layers that make up the soil profile. Furthermore, after the technology has developed far, the experts also look at aspects of the bedrock that forms the soil and the weathering process of the rocks which then gives certain characteristics to the soil that is formed. Based on these criteria, there are many types of soil in the world. To make it easier, experts often classify locally. For Indonesia, for example, the Dudal-Soepraptohardjo (1957-1961) classification system is known, which is still referred to today in Indonesia for agricultural purposes, especially in a modified version by the Center for Soil and Agro-climate Research (Puslittanak) in 1978 and 1982. In 1975 it was released USDA (US Department of Agriculture) classification system. This system was created because the old classification systems overlapped in naming due to different criteria.

In use, the USDA system provides clear criteria compared to other classification systems, so that the USDA system is usually included in soil classification to accompany naming based on the FAO or PPT (Center for Soil Research) systems. The weakness of this system, especially for developing countries, is that the criteria are based on detailed laboratory analysis, making it difficult for practitioners to define directly in the field. However, the USDA system is helpful because it uses a consistent naming system. For communication among world soil experts, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) has also developed a soil classification system since 1974. In 1998 it was agreed to use the WRB classification system from the World Reference Base for Soil Resources, a project formed by FAO, to replace the system this. The latest version of the WRB system was released in 2007. Soil taxonomy based on the Dudal-Soepraptohardjo system is based on the appearance of the soil profile and a number of physical and chemical characteristics. The basis of this system is that of Rudi Dudal, a soil expert from Belgium, who was modified for the Indonesian situation by M. Soepraptohardjo. This system is preferred by agricultural field workers because it is easy to implement in the field. The original version was released in 1957. Modifications were made by the Center for Soil Research in 1978 and 1982. This system (and its modifications) applies specifically to Indonesia, by adopting several international systems, especially in naming and assigning criteria. The following is the classification of Indonesian land according to the Dudal-Soepraptohardjo (D-S) system, given with its equivalent according to four other classification systems. Source: Equivalent Soil Names under Various Soil Classification Systems (simplified)permanent disabled link], except for the WRB system. The USDA or Soil Taxonomy system was developed in 1975 by a team of Soil Survey Staff working under the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA).

Jerusalem (/dʒəˈruːsələm/; Hebrew: יְרוּשָׁלַיִם Yerusyaláyim, pronounced jeruˈʃalajim] (see); Arabic: أُورُشَلِيمَ, translit. Ūrsyalīm), also known as al-quds (Arabic: القُدس, pronounced i] is one of the oldest cities in the world, located on a plateau in the Judean Mountains between the Mediterranean and the Dead Sea. The city is considered sacred in the three main Abrahamic religions—Judaism, Christianity and Islam. Throughout its long history, Jerusalem has been destroyed at least twice, besieged 23 times, attacked 52 times, and taken and recaptured 44 times. The oldest part of the city became a settlement in the 4th millennium BC. In 1538 a wall was built around Jerusalem during the reign of Suleiman Al-Qanuni. Today these walls surround the Old City, which is traditionally divided into four quarters—known since the early 19th century as the Armenian, Christian, Jewish, and Muslim Quarters. The Old Town became a World Heritage Site in 1981, and is included on the List of World Heritage Sites in Danger. Modern Jerusalem has expanded far beyond the boundaries of the Old City. According to biblical tradition, King David captured this city from the Jebus tribe and later founded it as the capital of the United Kingdom of Israel; his son, King Solomon, ordered the construction of the First Temple. These key events, from the beginning of the 1st millennium BC, have played a central role symbolically for the Jewish people. The nickname holy city (עיר הקודש, transliterated 'ir haqodesh) may have been attributed to Jerusalem in the post-exilic period. The sacredness of Jerusalem in Christianity, preserved in the Septuagint which the Christians adopted as their own authority, is confirmed by the New Testament account of Jesus' crucifixion there. In the view of Sunni Islam, Jerusalem is the third holiest city after Mecca and Medina. In Islamic tradition, in 610 AD Jerusalem became the first Qibla, i.e. the direction one should turn to in prayer, and Muhammad made his Night Journey there 10 years later, ascending to heaven where he spoke to Allah, according to the Quran.

As a result, even though it is only an area of ​​0.9 square kilometers, the Old City has many sites with very influential religious significance, among them the Temple Mount or Al-Aqsa Mosque, including Jami' Al-Aqsa, the Dome of the Rock or Dome of the Rock, and Western Wall; Church of the Holy Sepulcher, and Garden Cemetery. Currently, the status of Jerusalem remains one of the main issues in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. During the 1948 Arab-Israeli War, West Jerusalem was among the areas captured and later annexed by Israel; while East Jerusalem, including the Old City, was captured and later annexed by Jordan. Israel captured East Jerusalem from Jordan in the 1967 Six-Day War and thereafter annexed it to Jerusalem, along with additional territories surrounding it. viii] One of Israel's Basic Laws, namely the 1980 Jerusalem Law, designates Jerusalem as the undivided capital of that country. All areas of Israeli government are in Jerusalem, including the Knesset (Israel's parliament), the residence of the Prime Minister and President, as well as the Supreme Court. Although the international community rejects the annexation as illegal and treats East Jerusalem as occupied Palestinian territory, Israel has a stronger claim to sovereignty over West Jerusalem. The international community does not recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital, and no foreign embassies have been established in the city. There are also several non-governmental Israeli institutions of national interest in Jerusalem, such as the Hebrew University and the Israel Museum with the Shrine of the Book on its grounds. In 2011 Jerusalem had a population of 801,000, of whom 497,000 were Judaizers (62%), 281,000 (35%) Muslims, 14,000 (approximately 2%) Christians, and 9,000 (1%) were not grouped by religion.

Pastor (also pronounced Pastor) is a term for religious leaders within the Catholic Church. In Indonesia, this term is usually used for priests within the Roman Catholic Church, while in English-speaking countries, it is usually used within the Protestant Church. The word pastor itself comes from the Latin word pastor which means shepherd. The use of the word "pastor" comes from the Bible. In the Hebrew Bible and Old Testament, the Hebrew word רעה (ra'ah) is used for "shepherd". This word is used 173 times to describe the act of feeding the sheep as in the Book of Genesis 29:7 and also in relation to humans as in Jeremiah 3:15, "I will appoint for you shepherds according to My heart; they will shepherd you with knowledge and understanding." In the New Testament, the Greek word ποιμην (poimēn) is used and is usually translated as shepherd. This word is used 18 times in the New Testament. For example, Letter to Ephesians 4:11, "And it is he who gives both apostles and prophets, both evangelists and shepherds and teachers" (LAI). Jesus also referred to himself as the "Good Shepherd" in John 10:11. New Testament writers seem to use the words pastor or pastor as synonyms for the church offices of elder (presbuteros) or overseer or bishop (episkopos). For example, in Acts 20:17, the Apostle Paul urged the elders of the church in Ephesus to deliver a final message to them. In the process, in Acts 20:28, he told them that the Holy Spirit had made them overseers, and that their job was to shepherd their church. Peter uses the same language in 1 Peter 5:1-2, and tells the elders among his readers that they too must "feed" the flock entrusted to them, and act as "owners of the church."

Paul also lists the requirements of those serving this office. In 1 Timothy 3:1-7, Paul lists the requirements of those who serve as bishops. In Titus 1:5-9, a very similar list is given, this time for elders, who are also referred to in 1:7 as overseers of the church. According to many scholars, the practice of separating the offices of pastor and bishop occurred at least in the 2nd century AD. At this time, a bishop or overseer (as opposed to a group of overseers or presbyters, which the churches of the first century had) began overseeing groups of Christians throughout the city, even though they met in different places. In the 3rd and 4th centuries, the bishops of some of the most important cities began to have power over the entire ecclesiastical area with parish and diocesan groupings, or eparchy, of many of today's Christian groups. According to the rules of the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Church, especially the Orthodox Church, after being ordained, priests do not marry for the rest of their lives. The intention is to follow the traditions of the Church from the past, to focus more on serving God and the people, and when you are ordained as a priest, you are already committed to God (in other words, you have become God's bride). In Protestant churches, a Pastor is allowed to marry. Around AD 400, Augustine, the famous bishop of North Africa, described the duties of a pastor: Bullies must be rebuked, those who lack zeal must be encouraged, the weak must be supported, opposers refuted, the untrustworthy must be watched out for, the untrusted the gifted are taught, the lazy are encouraged, the contentious are controlled, the proud are suppressed, the demanding is appeased, the poor are helped, the oppressed are set free, the good are praised, the bad are endured, and all are to be loved.

Ornithology (from Greek: ορνισ, ornis, "bird"; and λόγος, logos, "science") is the branch of zoology that studies birds. Several aspects of ornithology differ from those closely related to the discipline, which relate to the heightened ability of vision and the aesthetic approach of birds. Most decisions among those being field level learning are done by amateur volunteers working within the parameters of scientific methodology. Ornithology has a long history and the study of birds has helped develop several key concepts in evolution, behavior and ecology such as species definition, speciation processes, instincts, learning, ecology, unions, island biogeography, phylogeography and conservation. Ornithology's Contribution to While early ornithology was principally concerned with the description and distribution of species, today's ornithologists seek answers to very specific questions, often using birds as models to test hypotheses or theory-based predictions. Most modern biological theories apply across taxonomic groups and the number of professional scientists who identify themselves as "ornithologists" has therefore declined. A variety of tools and techniques are used in ornithology, both in the laboratory and out in the field, and innovations continue to be made. The history of ornithology largely reflects trends in the history of biology. Trends include moving from mere description to identification of patterns and then towards elucidating the processes that generate patterns. Humans must have observed birds from the earliest times and rock age drawings are one of the oldest indications of interest in birds. The bird was probably important as a food source, and the bones of as many as 80 species have been found in excavations of early Stone Age settlements. Cultures around the world have a rich vocabulary related to birds. Traditional bird names are often based on detailed knowledge of behavior, with many names being onomatopoeic, still widely used. Traditional knowledge may also involve the use of birds in folk medicine and knowledge of these practices is passed on through oral tradition Hunting for wild birds and their domestication will require a good knowledge of their habits.

Farming fowl and falconry is practiced from the earliest times in different parts of the world. Artificial incubation of poultry was practiced in China around 246 BC and around at least 400 BC in Egypt. The Egyptians also made use of birds in their hieroglyphic script, many of which, although stylized, are still identified as species. Early records written provide valuable information on the past distribution of the species. For example Xenophon records the abundance of Ostrich in Assyria (Anabasis, i 5.), This subspecies from Asia minor became extinct and all extant Ostrich races are currently restricted to Africa. Other older writings such as the Vedas (1500–800 BC) show careful observation of the life history of birds and include early references to the parasitic habits of broodstock by Asia Koel]] Aristotle in 350 BC in his Historia Animalium recording the habits of migratory birds, molting, egg-laying and life. range. However he introduced and propagated several myths, such as the idea that swallows hibernated in winter although he noted that cranes migrated from the Scythian steppes to the swamps in the upper Nile. The idea of ​​hibernating swallows became so well established, in fact, that as late as 1878, Elliott Coues was able to list as many as 182 contemporary publications dealing with swift hibernation and published evidence to slightly contradict the theory. Template:Cite the journal</ref> Similar misconceptions exist regarding the captive barnacle goose. Their nests have never been seen and it is believed that they grew by the transformation of the barnacle goose, an idea which became prevalent from around the 11th century and was recorded by Bishop Giraldus Cambrensis (Gerald of Wales) in his 'Topographia Hiberniae (1187)'. The origins of the falconry have been traced to Mesopotamia and the earliest records date from the reign of Sargon II (722-705 BC). Falconry had entered Europe only after AD 400, brought from the East after invasions by the Huns and Allans.

Wind is the movement of air from areas of high pressure to areas of low pressure. The formation of wind direction occurs due to differences in air pressure in two different places. Air flows from places with high air pressure to places with low air pressure. The occurrence of wind is influenced by the earth's rotation along with the process of heating an area by the sun. Winds are named based on where they come from, such as land breezes, valley breezes, and mountain breezes. The power of the wind is utilized in various activities in human life. Residents who live on the coast take advantage of the wind when going to sea by sailing ship. The wind is also useful for flying toy kites. Dutch citizens use wind to become a source of energy for wind power plants. The process of the occurrence of wind can not be separated from the relationship between air pressure and temperature. When heated, air expands. The expanding air becomes lighter and the air pressure decreases as the air density decreases. The cold air then flows into the low pressure area. The flow of hot air up and cold air down is called convection. Wind speed is expressed in knots. While the cardinal directions are divided into eight directions namely north, south, west, east, southeast, northwest, northeast and southwest. Factors for the occurrence of wind, namely: Sea breeze (English: sea breeze) is a wind that blows from the sea towards the land which generally occurs during the day approximately from 09.00 to 16.00 in coastal areas. This wind is usually used by fishermen to return home from fishing in the sea. This sea breeze occurs during the day. Because water has a greater heat capacity than land, sunlight heats the sea more slowly than land.

When the temperature of the land surface increases during the day, the air above the land surface also increases due to conduction. The air pressure over land is lower because it is warmer, while the air pressure over the ocean tends to be higher because it is colder. As a result, there is a pressure gradient from higher oceans to lower land, causing sea breezes, where the strength is proportional to the temperature difference between land and sea. However, if there are offshore winds that are stronger than 8 km/hour, then sea breezes do not occur. Land breeze (English: land breeze) is a wind that blows from the land towards the sea which generally occurs at night from 20.00 to 06.00 in coastal areas. This type of wind is beneficial for fishermen to go fishing with a simple wind-powered boat. At night the land cools faster than the ocean, because the heat capacity of land is lower than that of water. As a result, the temperature difference that causes the sea breeze gradually disappears and vice versa, the opposite pressure difference appears because the air pressure over the hotter ocean becomes lower than the land, so land breezes occur, especially when the coastal winds are not strong enough to fight them. Mountain winds are winds that blow from mountain peaks to mountain valleys and occur at night. Valley breeze is a wind that blows from the valley towards the top of the mountain and occurs during the day. Fohn wind (local wind, waterfall wind, falling wind) (English: foehn wind) is a wind that occurs after orographic rain. The wind blows in an area with different temperature and humidity.

Language 1] is the ability possessed by humans to communicate with other humans using signs, for example words and gestures. The scientific study of language is called linguistics. Estimates of the number of languages ​​in the world vary between 6,000–7,000 languages. However, precise approximations depend on an arbitrary change that may occur between languages ​​and dialects. Natural languages ​​are speech or sign languages, but any language can be encoded into a second medium using audio, visual, or tactile stimuli, for example, graphic writing, braille, or whistles. This is because human language is independent of modality. As a general concept, "language" can refer to the cognitive ability to be able to learn and use complex systems of communication, or to describe the set of rules that make up those systems or the set of utterances that can result from those rules. All languages ​​rely on semiotic processes to link signs with specific meanings. Spoken languages ​​and sign languages ​​have a phonological system that governs how symbols are used to form sequences known as words or morphemes, and a syntactic system that governs how words and morphemes are combined to form phrases and utterances. Human language is unique in that it has productive, recursive, and shifting properties, and because human language as a whole depends on social conventions and education. Its complex structure affords a wider range of expression possibilities and uses than any known animal communication system. Since the time of hominins, language is thought to have begun to gradually change the system of communication between primates. Primates then begin to acquire the ability to form a theory of mind and intentionality. This development is sometimes thought to coincide with an increase in brain volume, and many linguists argue that the structures of language evolved to serve specific social and communicative functions.

Language is processed at many different locations in the human brain, especially in Broca's area and Wernicke's area. Humans acquire language through social interaction in infancy, and children can speak fluently by about three years of age. The use of language is deeply rooted in human culture. Therefore, apart from being used to communicate, language also has many social and cultural functions, for example to signify group identity, social stratification, and for social grooming and entertainment. Languages ​​changed and varied over time, and their evolutionary history can be reconstructed by comparing modern languages ​​to determine which traits an ancestral language must have had for later change to occur. A group of languages ​​descended from a common ancestor is known as a language family. The languages ​​spoken in the world today belong to the Indo-European family. This includes languages ​​such as English, Spanish, Portuguese, Russian and Hindi; Sino-Tibetan languages, which include Mandarin, Cantonese, and many others; The Afro-Asiatic language family which includes Arabic, Amhar, Somali, and Hebrew; and the Bantu languages, which include Swahili, Zulu, Shona, and hundreds of other languages ​​spoken in Africa. The consensus is that between 50–90% of languages ​​spoken since the start of the 21st century are likely to become extinct by 2100. The English word "language" is derived from Indo-European *dn̥ǵʰwéh₂s "tongue, speech, language" via Latin lingua, "language ; tongue", and Old French langage "language". The word is sometimes used to refer to codes, ciphers and other forms of artificially formed communication systems such as those used in computer programming. The meaning of language in this case is a system of signals for encoding and translating information. This article is specifically concerned with the properties of natural human language as studied in the discipline of linguistics.

Feudalism is a structure of delegation of sociopolitical power (social politics) that is run among the nobility/monarchy to control the various territories they claim through cooperation with local leaders as partners. In the original sense, this structure was embedded by historians in the political system in Europe in the Middle Ages, which placed knights and other noble classes (vassals) as rulers of certain areas or rights (called fiefs or, in Latin, feodum) appointed by monarchy (usually a king or lord). The term feudalism itself has been used since the 17th century and was never used by the actors themselves. Since the 1960s, historians have broadened the use of this term to include aspects of the social life of land workers on land controlled by landlords, giving rise to the term "feudal society". Because the use of the term feudalism has increasingly had a negative connotation, its critics now consider this term not helpful in clarifying the situation and are advised not to use it without clear qualifications. In everyday language use in Indonesia, this word is often used to refer to behaviors similar to those of tyrannical rulers, such as 'old-fashioned', 'always wanting to be respected', or 'holding on to old values ​​that have been many abandoned'. The ninth century in western Europe was a period of turmoil. Charlemagne had for some time created the integration of society that was the result of the invading Germanic peoples, and had united the warring tribes under a centralized government. But Charles magne's empire, as we have learned, did not last long. This empire broke up into several separate kingdoms. Charlemagne's successors in France, Germany, and Italy enjoyed little authority. They rule, but do not rule. During this dark age it was absolutely impossible for a king to rule strictly.

Ethane is a chemical compound with the chemical formula C2H6. This compound is an alkane with two carbons, and is an aliphatic hydrocarbon. At standard temperature and pressure, ethane is a colorless and odorless gas. In the industry ethane is produced by means of isolation from natural gas, and as a by-product of oil refining. Its main use is as a feedstock for the production of ethylene. Related compounds can be formed by replacing hydrogen atoms with other functional groups; The ethane moiety is called an ethyl group. For example, an ethyl group bonded to a hydroxyl group gives ethanol, the alcohol in beverages. Ethane was first synthesized in 1834 by Michael Faraday, via the electrolysis of a solution of potassium acetate. He thought the hydrocarbon product of this reaction was methane and did not investigate further. During the period 1847-1849, in an attempt to prove the radical theory of organic chemistry, Hermann Kolbe and Edward Frankland produced ethane by the reduction of propionitrile (ethyl cyanide) and ethyl iodide with potassium metal, and, as did Faraday, by electrolysis of aqueous solutions of acetate. However, they assumed that the product of this reaction was a methyl radical, whereas what was produced was a dimer of methyl, namely ethane. This error was corrected by Carl Schorlemmer in 1864, who showed that the product of all these reactions was actually ethane. The name ethane comes from the IUPAC nomenclature for organic chemistry. "Eth-" comes from the German for drinkable alcohol (ethanol), and "-ana" refers to the presence of single bonds between carbon atoms. At standard temperature and pressure, ethane is a colorless, odorless gas. It has a boiling point of −885°C (−1.561°F; −612 K) and a melting point of −1.828°C (−3.258°F; −1.555K).

Solid ethane exists in several modifications. On cooling under normal pressure, the first modifications to appear are plastic crystals, which form a cubic crystal system. In this form, the positions of the hydrogen atoms are not fixed; Molecules can rotate freely around the long axis. Cooling this ethane below approximately 899 K (626 °C; 1,159 °F) converts it to ethane II, which is monoclinic and metastable. Ethane is only very slightly soluble in water. Ethane can be viewed as two methyl groups joined together, namely a dimer of a methyl group. Ethane can be easily synthesized in the laboratory by Kolbe electrolysis. In this technique, electrolysis of aqueous acetate salt solutions is carried out. At the anode, acetate is oxidized to give carbon dioxide and a methyl radical, and the highly reactive methyl radical combines to give ethane: Another method that is conceptually similar is the oxidation of acetic anhydride with peroxide. The chemistry of ethane primarily involves free radical reactions. Ethane can react with halogens, especially chlorine and bromine, via free radical halogenation. This reaction proceeds via ethyl radical propagation: Since halogenated ethane can undergo further free radical halogenation, this process produces a mixture of several halogenated products. In the chemical industry, more selective chemical reactions are used to produce certain haloalkanes with two carbon atoms. The complete combustion process of ethane releases 1559.7 kJ/mol, or 51.9 kJ/g of heat, and produces carbon dioxide and water according to the chemical equation. Combustion can also occur without excess oxygen, forming a mixture of amorphous carbon and carbon monoxide. Combustion occurs via a complex series of free radical reactions. Computer simulations of the chemical kinetics of ethane combustion have included hundreds of possible reactions.

An acid is a molecule or ion that can donate a proton (H+ hydrogen ion), or, alternatively, can form a covalent bond with an electron pair (Lewis acid). The first category of acids is the proton donor or Brønsted acid. In the special case of an aqueous solution, the proton donor forms the hydronium ion H3O+ and is known as an Arrhenius acid. Brønsted and Lowry generalized the Arrhenius theory to include non-aqueous solvents. Both Brønsted and Arrhenius acids usually have hydrogen atoms attached to a chemical structure that remain energetically active after losing H+. Arrhenius acid in aqueous solution has characteristic properties that provide a practical description of acids. Acids form aqueous solutions with a sour taste, can turn blue litmus red, and react with bases and various metals (such as calcium) to form salts. The word acid (English from acid) comes from the Latin acidus/acēre which means sour. Acidic aqueous solutions have a pH of less than 7 and these solutions are also called 'acidic' in everyday context (as in the phrase 'dissolved in acid'), while the strict definition of an acid refers only to the substance in which it is dissolved. Lower pH means more acidity, as well as a higher concentration of positive hydrogen ions in solution. Common acidic aqueous solutions include hydrochloric acid (a solution of hydrogen chloride which is found in stomach acid and can activate digestive enzymes), acetic acid (vinegar is a dilute aqueous solution of this liquid), sulfuric acid (used in car batteries), and citric acid. (found in citrus fruits). Based on this example, acids (in general view) can be solutions or pure chemicals, and can be derived from acids (in strict view) in the form of solid, liquid, or gas.

Strong acids and some concentrated weak acids are corrosive, but there are exceptions such as carborane and boric acid. The second category of acids are Lewis acids, which form covalent bonds with electron pairs. One of them is boron trifluoride (BF3) where the boron atom has an empty orbital that can form covalent bonds by sharing lone pairs of electrons on atoms in basic compounds, for example the nitrogen atom in ammonia (NH3). Lewis considers this theory as a generalization of the Brønsted definition so that an acid is a chemical species that accepts an electron pair either directly or by releasing a proton (H+) into solution, which then accepts the electron pair. However, hydrogen chloride, acetic acid, and most other Brønsted-Lowry acids cannot form covalent bonds with electron pairs and are therefore not Lewis acids. In contrast, many Lewis acids are neither Arrhenius nor Brønsted-Lowry acids. In modern terminology, acid implicitly refers to a Brønsted acid and not a Lewis acid, since chemists almost always refer to a Lewis acid explicitly as a Lewis acid. The term "tamarind" is a translation of terms used for the same thing in European languages ​​such as acid (English), zuur (Dutch), or Säure (German) which are literally related to sour taste. In chemistry, the term acid has a more specific meaning. There are three definitions of acids that are generally accepted in chemistry, namely the Arrhenius, Brønsted-Lowry, and Lewis definitions. Although not the most broad theory, the Brønsted-Lowry definition is the one most commonly used. In this definition, the acidity of a compound is determined by the stability of the hydronium ion and its dissolved conjugate base when the compound has donated a proton to the solution in which the acid is present.
