Wudu (Arabic: الوضوو al-wuḍū', Persian: آبدست ābdast, Turkish: abdest, Urdu: وضو wazū') is one of the ways of purifying body parts with water. A Muslim is required to purify himself every time he prays. Wudu can also use dust called tayammum. The history of ablution is found in the Al-Qur'an in Surah Al-Ma'idah verse 6 which is the same as the order of obligatory prayer, which is six months before the Prophet Muhammad migrated to Medina. The requirements for performing ablution are five and six obligatory laws. In addition, there are eight things that invalidate ablution. Before performing salat, every Muslim must perform ablution. The trick is to clean certain parts of the body using water. Wudu is a mandatory condition before performing obligatory and sunnah prayers. The conditions for performing ablution are being Muslim, being of sound mind, using holy water, and not having any obstacles. The meaning of common sense is being able to distinguish between good things and bad things. Meanwhile, holy water is water that has never been used for other purposes, such as rainwater, seawater, river water, melting snow, and water from tanks or large ponds. Obstacle in ablution is najis or hadas. This barrier is divided into two, namely birth barrier and biological barrier. Birth barriers such as dirt stuck between the nails, while biological barriers such as menstruation and postpartum for women. Additional conditions are given to people with diseases that make them always have to stop. For those suffering from diseases that always have hadas, ablution is performed every time entering prayer. This bad disease is, for example, whiteness and not being able to hold back urination. Wudu begins with the intention of reading the Basmalah followed by washing both palms. Then gargle to wash the nose and the face, the palms of the hands up to the elbows, wipe the head and ears and finish by washing the soles of the feet up to the heels.

The ablution is carried out sequentially and the right side is prioritized once each, but if it feels incomplete it can be repeated up to a limit of 3 times. Wudu can be canceled due to several reasons. The most common cause is discharge from the anus or genitals. The next cause is sleeping with the body position on the stomach or legs raised. Wudu can also be canceled if the person performing the ablution loses his mind due to drunkenness, illness, epilepsy or madness. The cancellation of ablution is also caused by direct skin-to-skin contact with a person who is not a mahram. The presence or absence of lust does not affect the cancellation of wudu. The last condition that can invalidate wudu is touching the anus of oneself or another person, whether alive or dead. According to ijmaa, urine and excrement that come out of the genitals and anus invalidate wudu. Anything other than those two when it comes out of the genitals and anus also invalidates ablution. Only the Maliki School holds that the discharge of anything other than urine and excrement from the genitals and anus does not invalidate ablution. The Hanafi School, the Hambali School and the Maliki School are of the opinion that the discharge of semen invalidates ablution. Meanwhile, the Shafi'i school of thought is of the opinion that the release of semen does not invalidate ablution, but requires wandi to be obligatory. Meanwhile, the Hanafi School believes that urine, excrement and semen invalidate ablution. The priests of the madhhab agree that wudu is not invalidated when someone touches his own private parts, not with his hands. However, they differed on the cancellation of ablution due to touching the genitals with their hands. The Hanafi school of thought is of the opinion that it invalidates wudu by using any part of the hand. The Shafi'i school is of the opinion that wudu is invalidated if it touches the genitals without obstruction using the inside of the hand.

Thoughts are ideas and mental processes. Thinking allows one to represent the world as a model and treat it effectively according to goals, plans and desires. Words that refer to the same concepts and processes include cognition, understanding, consciousness, ideas and imagination. Thinking involves the brain's manipulation of information, as when we form concepts, engage in problem solving, reasoning, and making decisions. Thinking is a high-level cognitive function and the analysis of thought processes forms part of cognitive psychology. The term mind according to the Big Indonesian Dictionary comes from the word "thought" which means reason, or memory. Meanwhile, the mind is the result of thinking (thinking). The use of "thought" or "thinking" can be associated with a wide variety of psychological activities. Understanding in general, thinking is the process of using reason to consider something. It includes a variety of different mental processes, such as considering an idea or proposition or judging it to be true. In this sense, memory and imagination are forms of thought but perception is not. In a more limited sense, only the most paradigmatic cases are considered as thoughts. It involves conscious processes that are conceptual or linguistic and quite abstract, such as judging, inferring, problem solving, and reasoning. Sometimes the terms "thinking" and "thought" are understood in a very broad sense as referring to any form of mental process, conscious or unconscious. Mind is a word that comes from the Old English "þoht, or geþoht, from the root þencan" to imagine in the mind, consider". The basic mechanism of human brain cells reflects the process of pattern matching or pattern recognition. new experiences are judged on the basis of what is remembered.To make these judgments, the mind retains current experiences and ranks relevant past experiences.

This is done by maintaining that present and past experiences are separate experiences. The mind can mix, match, combine, exchange, and order concepts, perceptions, and experiences. This process is called reasoning. Logic is the science of reasoning. Awareness of this reasoning process is entry into consciousness (see philosopher Ned Block). The mind can be classified into two parts that are useful as information filters, namely the conscious mind and the subconscious mind. Conscious mind is a tendency to think logically consciously related to reasoning and logic used in everyday life, such as thinking when doing something, thinking about eating when hungry, and so on. Mind consciously as mastery of one's mind is as much as 12%. The subconscious mind is a tendency to think related to emotions and their stored places which subjectively respond to what is conveyed, such as memories, habits, personality, beliefs, and so on. The subconscious mind as the controller of the human body is as much as 88%. Humans as individuals or social beings cannot be separated from the context of their awareness in thinking. Human awareness makes a person able to determine his choice, not just a relationship anymore. In making a choice, patterns of thinking will emerge so that they become the basis for belief in the right, efficient and effective choice. This is what is called the pattern of human thinking. Discussion is one way to exchange ideas related to a problem. The process of thinking in discussions will result in gathering information to solve problems both formally and informally collected from concept ideas, problem solving, to comments. By discussing too, a person is able to convey his arguments or opinions which cannot be separated from thought processes and language. Thought and language are interrelated in solving problems in the discussion process.

Industry is a field or economic activity related to the processing/manufacturing of raw materials or the manufacture of finished goods in factories using skills and labor (English: industrial) and the use of tools in the field of processing agricultural products, and their distribution as the main activity. Therefore, industry is generally known as the next link in the chain of efforts to fulfill (economic) needs related to the earth, namely after agriculture, plantations and mining which are closely related to the land. The position of the industry is increasingly far from the land, which is the basis of the economy, culture and politics. Industry is part of the production process and production process activities in the industry are called industry. Industry can also be interpreted as a collection of various companies that offer the same product. In other words, each product is a substitute for one another because the firm uses the same inputs and faces more or less the same group of suppliers and buyers. The industrial sector is divided into two, namely the goods industry and the service industry. The goods industry is a business of processing raw materials into semi-finished goods or finished goods. This industrial activity produces various types of goods, such as clothing, shoes, cars, motorbikes, fertilizers, and medicines. Meanwhile, the service industry is an economic activity by providing services. For example: transportation services such as buses, trains, flights, and shipping. There are also service companies that help with the production process. For example, banking and warehousing services. There are services that are directly addressed to consumers. Examples include insurance, health, tailors, lawyers, beauty salons and barbers. The industry started with the work of a carpenter or interpreter. After sedentary livelihoods as crop pickers, hunters, and fishermen in ancient times, humans settled down, built houses, and cultivated the land by farming, and gardening and raising livestock.

Their needs are growing, for example to get tools for picking crops, hunting tools, fishing tools, farming tools, gardening, tools for mining something, even tools for war and household tools. The artisans, and the embroiderers as the source of the tools and goods needed. From there, crafts and carpentry began to develop, which produced necessities. In order to become good craftsmen and carpenters, apprentice education patterns were held, and to maintain the quality of handicrafts and carpentry in Europe various guilds were formed (associations of craftsmen and craftsmen as the forerunner of various associations now). Iron and steel mining progressed rapidly in the Middle Ages. Furthermore, the mining of fuels such as coal, oil and gas also developed rapidly. Both of these spurred advances in mechanical technology, starting with the invention of the steam engine which in turn paved the way for the manufacture and trade of goods on a large scale and mass in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. At first, textile factories emerged (Lille, and Manchester) and railroads, then the steel industry (Essen) and shipyards, car factories (Detroit), aluminum factories. From the need for dyeing in textile factories, the chemical and pharmaceutical industries have developed. There was the Industrial Revolution. Since then a wave of industrialization in the form of the establishment of factories for the mass production of goods, the use of labor force, has rapidly swept across the world, colliding with traditional efforts in agriculture (agriculture). Since then, a variety of industry classifications have emerged. Most people assume that industry is just a human economic activity that processes raw materials/raw materials into semi-finished or finished goods. Even though the definition of industry is very broad, this industrial process includes all human activities in a certain field that are productive and commercial in nature.

Metallurgy is a field of materials science and engineering that studies the physical and chemical behavior of metal elements, inter-metallic compounds, and metal alloys called alloys or lacures. Metallurgy is also metal technology, namely the application of science to the production of metals and the engineering of metal components for use in products intended for consumers and manufacturing industries. Metals production includes processing ores to extract their metal contents, and alloying metals, sometimes with non-metallic elements, to produce alloys. Metallurgy differs from craft metalworking, although technical progress in metalworking depends on developments in metallurgical science, just as technical progress in the practice of medicine depends on developments in medical science. Metallurgy is divided into iron-steel metallurgy (black metal science) and non-ferrous-steel metallurgy (multicolored metal science). Iron-steel metallurgy includes methods of processing ferrous elements and making alloys based on iron, while non-ferrous-steel metallurgy includes methods of processing and making alloys based on metals other than iron. Iron-steel production accounts for 95 percent of world metal production. The term "metallurgy" comes from the Ancient Greek word: μεταλλουργός, metallourgós, "metalworker", a combination of μέταλλον, métallon, "metal", and ἔργον, érgon, "work". Originally the word "metallurgy" was a term used in alchemy to refer to the activity of extracting metals from minerals, the suffix -urgy denoting a process, especially a manufacturing process: this metallurgical meaning was discussed in the Encyclopædia Britannica 1797. At the end of the 19th century, The scope of meaning of metallurgy extends to include the more general scientific study of metals, alloys and processes related to them. Metallurgy is the science, art and technology that examines the processing and engineering of minerals and metals.

The scope of metallurgy includes: The history of metallurgy begins with mining product processing technology. The earliest metal used by humans appears to be gold, which can be found freely. Small amounts of gold have been found to have been used in caves in Spain during the Paleolithic period, around 40,000 BC Meteoric silver, copper, lead and iron can also be found free, and allowed limited amounts of metalworking. Egyptian weapons made from meteoric iron around 3000 BC were highly valued as "daggers from the sky". With the knowledge of obtaining copper and tin by heating rocks, and of combining copper and tin to obtain an alloy known as bronze, metallurgical technology began around 3500 BC during the Bronze Age. The extraction of iron from its ores into a workable metal is much more difficult. This process appears to have been created by the Hittites in around 1200 BC, at the start of the Iron Age. The secret of iron extraction and processing was a key factor in the success of the Philistines. Historical developments in ferrous metallurgy can be found in various past cultures and civilizations. It includes the ancient and medieval kingdoms and empires of the Middle and Near East, ancient Egypt and Anatolia (present-day Turkey), Carthage, Greece, ancient Rome, medieval Europe, ancient and medieval China, ancient and medieval India, ancient Japan and middle, and so on. Many metallurgical applications, practices and tools may have been in use in ancient China before Europeans mastered them (such as furnaces, cast iron, steel, etc.). Based on the closeness between metallurgy and mining, initially metallurgical education was born from mining schools such as metallurgical education at the Colorado School of Mines. Extraction metallurgy is the practice of extracting a valuable metal from an ore and refining the extracted raw metal into a pure form.

Einsteinium is a chemical element with the symbol Es and atomic number 99. Einsteinium is a member of the actinide series and is the seventh transuranium element. This element was named in honor of Albert Einstein. Einsteinium was discovered as a component of the debris of the first hydrogen bomb explosion in 1952. Its most common isotope, einsteinium-253 (half-life 20.47 days), is produced artificially from the decay of californium-253 in several high-power nuclear reactors with a total yield of on the order of one milligram per year. The synthesis reactor is followed by a complex process of separating einsteinium-253 from other actinides and their decay products. Other isotopes are synthesized in various laboratories, but in much smaller quantities, by bombarding heavy actinide elements with light ions. Because einsteinium is produced only in small quantities and the short half-life of its most easily produced isotope, there are currently almost no practical applications for the element outside of basic scientific research. Specifically, einsteinium was used to synthesize, for the first time, 17 atoms of the new element delevium in 1955. Einsteinium is a soft, silvery paramagnetic metal. Its chemistry is typical of the late actinides, with the higher +3 oxidation number; the oxidation number +2 is also accessible, especially in solids. Einsteinium-253's high radioactivity produces visible light and rapidly degrades its crystalline metal lattice, with heat released of about 1000 watts per gram. The difficulty in studying its properties is that einsteinium-253 decays into berkelium-249 and then californium-249 at a rate of about 3% per day. The einsteinium isotope with the longest half-life, einsteinium-252 (half-life 471.7 days) would be more suitable for investigations of physical properties, but has proven much more difficult to produce and is only available in small quantities, rather than large amounts.

Einsteinium is the element with the highest atomic number that has been observed in macroscopic quantities in its pure form, and it is the short-lived common isotope of einsteinium-253. Like all synthetic transuranium elements, the isotope einsteinium is highly radioactive and is considered very hazardous to health if ingested. Einsteinium was first identified in December 1952 by Albert Ghiorso and colleagues at the University of California, Berkeley in collaboration with Argonne and Los Alamos National Laboratories, as a result of the Ivy Mike nuclear test. This test took place on November 1, 1952, at Enewetak Atoll in the Pacific Ocean and was the first successful test of a thermonuclear weapon. Preliminary examination of the debris from the explosion has shown the production of a new plutonium isotope, 24494Pu, which can only be formed by the absorption of six neutrons by a uranium-238 nucleus followed by two beta decays. At the time, double neutron absorption was thought to be an extremely rare process, but the identification of 24494Pu shows that many more neutrons can be captured by uranium nuclei, resulting in new elements that are heavier than californium. Ghiorso and co-workers analyzed filter paper that had been flown through blast clouds in airplanes (the same sampling technique that had been used to find 24494Pu). Large amounts of radioactive material were later isolated from the atoll's coral debris, which was then shipped to the U.S. Separation of suspected new elements was carried out in the presence of citric acid/ammonium buffer solution in a weak acid medium (pH ≈ 3.5), using ion exchange at high temperature; less than 200 einsteinium atoms were found in the end. However, element 99 (einsteinium), its 253Es isotope, can be detected via its characteristic high-energy alpha decay at 6.6 MeV.

This province has an area of ​​1,248.3 km² with a population of 496,503 people (2007) with a population density of 402 people/km². Electrostatics is a branch of physics that deals with the force exerted by a static (non-changing/moving) electric field on other charged objects. The history of electricity begins with observing amber or resin material which in Greek means electron, which when the material is rubbed with the skin of a hairy animal can attract light, smooth objects which after sticking to it then repel it. or that was affixed to it, for which reason the object was said to be charged with "awesomeness" or resinious. The same thing happened to glass rubbed with silk, the infection of which made other objects affixed to it charged with "glassyness" or vitrious. 1733, Francois du Fay discovered the fact that in nature there are only two types of charges, namely resinous and vitrious charges, and two objects with the same charge will repel and vice versa two objects will attract if the charges are different. Then Benjamin Franklin (1706) –1790) discovered the fact that the two types of charge are resinious and vitrious when combined they cancel each other out as with positive and negative numbers. Since then resinious charge has been called a negative electric charge and vitrious has been called a positive electric charge. Continuing Michelson and Carlisle's experiments on electrolysis, Michael Faraday (1791–1867) in 1883 proposed the quantization of electric charge into charge units, which was later by Stoney in 1874, which was reinforced by J.J. Thomson in 1897, hypothesized the existence of electric charge-carrying particles which were then called electrons. As a resin, electrons are said to produce a negative electric charge, so the electrons will also be negatively charged. Even though J.C. Maxwell (1831-1879) managed to combine all electrical laws and formulas in the form of four equations which later became known as Maxwell's equations so that all electrical phenomena can always be explained based on or translated from the four equations, in essence the four equations can be combined to become or can be translated from Coulomb's law:″F″=kq1.q2r2{\displaystyle ''F''=k{\dfrac {q1.q2}{r^{2}}}}which states that the force between two electric charges q1 and q2 will proportional to the amount of each electric charge and inversely proportional to the square of the distance (r) between the two electric charges, and depending on the medium in which the two charges are located, which in its formulation is determined by a medium constant k. So Coulomb's law is a fundamental law in electricity, which underlies all electrical laws and formulas, just as the law of 'Newton's initials' in mechanics underlies all mechanical laws and formulas. In the m.k.s unit system, the medium constant k is written as 1/(4 π ε ), so Coulomb's law becomes:″F″=q1.q24πϵr2{\displaystyle ''F''={\dfrac {q1.q2}{4\pi \epsilon r^{2}}}}and ε is called permittivity of the medium. With a positive F it means the force is repulsive and vice versa a negative F means it is attractive.

The existence of an electric charge in a room will cause any electric charge in that room to experience an electrostatic Coulomb force, which is according to Coulomb's law above. Therefore it is said that an electric charge will cause an electric field around it. The electric field is said to be strong if the force on the electric charge in the room with the electric field is large. But the coulomb force is large against many electric charges so that the electric field strength is defined as the force on one unit electric charge. So from Coulomb's law above, the electric field strength by a point electric charge q is: E=q4πϵr2r^{\displaystyle E={\dfrac {q}{4\pi \epsilon r^{2}}}{\hat {r }}} where r is the unit vector of the radial direction from the point charge q . As force is a vector quantity, so is the electric field strength E→{\displaystyle {\vec {E}}} so that the electric field strength by any point electric charge q1, q2, q3, … equals the vector sum of the electric field strengths by each point of electric charge, namely: E→=E→1+E→2+E→3+...{\displaystyle {\vec {E}}={\vec {E}}_{1}+ {\vec {E}}_{2}+{\vec {E}}_{3}+...} The electric field lines of force are not real quantities but an abstraction or wishful thinking or image that states the direction of the electric field in various places in the electric field space, that is, the patterns that express the distribution of electric field directions. The direction of the local electric field, that is, in the direction of the force lines at that place, of course alludes to the lines of force at that place. In essence, every point must be passed by a line of force, so that the lines of force will fill the entire room. But if we draw all the force lines, then the line pattern system of the force will not be visible. Therefore the number of lines of force drawn must be limited, for example as many as the charges that emit them; that is, the number of lines of force drawn, emanating from the point of electric charge q is also just as much as q, so that the pattern of the system of lines of force is visible and has meaning, which except stating the distribution of the direction of the electric field also shows the distribution of the electric field strength where the lines are part the force is dense, the electric field is also dense. For the electric field by a point charge q, according to Coulomb's law, the electric field strength is inversely proportional to the square of the distance.

Viruses are pathogenic microorganisms that can only replicate within cells because they do not have the cellular equipment to reproduce on their own. All forms of life can be infected by viruses, from animals and plants to bacteria and archaea. The term virus is usually used to describe a type of virus that infects eukaryotic cells, while viruses that infect prokaryotic cells (such as bacteria and archaea) are known as bacteriophages. The existence of viruses was first recognized through the scientific writings of Dmitri Ivanovsky in 1892 who described non-bacterial pathogens that infect tobacco plants and the discovery of tobacco mosaic virus by Martinus Beijerinck in 1898. Until 2019, more than 6,000 virus species have been described in detail, of the total millions of types of viruses in the environment. Viruses are found in almost every ecosystem on Earth and are the most numerous biological entities. The study of viruses is known as virology, a subspecialty of microbiology. When infected, the host cell is forced to rapidly produce thousands of identical copies of the original virus. When not inside the cell or in the process of infecting the cell, the virus exists as an independent particle called a virion. A virion consists of two or three parts: (1) genetic material, which is a long molecule of nucleic acid (only DNA or RNA, but not a combination of both) that encodes the protein structure used by the virus; (2) a protein coat called a capsid, which functions to surround and protect the genetic material; and in some viruses there is (3) an outer sheath or envelope made of lipids. The shape of virus particles ranges from simple helical, icosahedral (20-sided shape) to more complex structures. Most virus species have virions that are too small to be seen with a light microscope because they are one-hundredth the size of an ordinary bacterium.

The origins of viruses in the evolutionary history of life are still unclear: some viruses may have evolved from plasmids (pieces of DNA that can move between cells), while others may have evolved from bacteria. In evolution, viruses are important intermediates in horizontal gene transfer, which increases genetic diversity in a manner analogous to sexual reproduction. There is scientific disagreement regarding the status of viruses as living things or as organic structures that interact with living things. As life forms, viruses carry genetic material, reproduce, and evolve through natural selection, although they lack key characteristics of living things, such as cell structure, that are generally considered necessary criteria for life. Because they share some of the criteria of being alive but not all of them, viruses are described as "organisms on the edge of life", and as self-repliers. Viruses spread in many ways. One route of transmission is through disease-carrying organisms known as vectors: for example, viruses are often transmitted from plant to plant by insects that feed on plant sap, such as aphids; and viruses in animals can be carried by blood-sucking insects. The influenza virus is spread by coughing and sneezing. Norovirus and Rotavirus, common causes of viral gastroenteritis, are transmitted by the faecal–oral route, through hand-to-mouth contact or ingestion of food or water. The infectious dose of Norovirus required to produce infection in humans is less than 100 particles. HIV is one of several viruses that are transmitted through sexual intercourse and exposure to blood containing the virus. The variety of host cells that a virus can infect is called the "host range". This range can be narrow, meaning the virus is only capable of infecting a few species, or broad, meaning it is capable of infecting many species.

The ionosphere is the part of the atmosphere that is ionized by solar radiation. This layer plays an important role for the electricity of the atmosphere and forms the boundary in the magnetosphere. Its main function, among the functions it has, is to influence radio propagation to distant places on earth. The ionosphere layer formed as a result of this chemical reaction is also the earth's protective layer from meteor stones originating from outer space because they are pulled by the earth's gravity. In this layer of the ionosphere, meteor rocks burn and decompose. If it is very large in size and does not burn up completely in this ionospheric air layer, it will fall to the surface of the earth which is called a Meteorite. The aurora phenomenon which is also known as the northern lights or southern lights occurs in this layer. Understanding The Thermosphere as an Atmospheric Layer above the mesopouse with an altitude of about 75 km to an altitude of about 650 km. In this layer, the gases will be ionized, therefore this layer is often also called the ionosphere layer. Oxygen molecules will split into atomic oxygen here. The process of breaking down oxygen molecules and other atmospheric gases will produce heat, which will cause an increase in temperature in this layer. The temperature in this layer will increase with increasing altitude. The ionosphere is divided into three more layers, namely: 1. The ozone layer is located between 80 – 150 km with an average of 100 km asl. This layer is where the highest ionization process occurs. This layer is also called the ozone layer. It has the property of reflecting radio waves. The air temperature here ranges from – 70°C to +50°C . 2. Air layer F Located between 150 – 400 km. This layer is also called the appleton air layer. 3. Atomic air layer In this layer, matter is in the form of atoms.

The Celsius scale is a temperature scale designed so that the freezing point of water is at 0 degrees and the boiling point is at 100 degrees at standard atmospheric pressure. The scale gets its name from the astronomer Anders Celsius (1701–1744), who first proposed it in 1742. Because there are one hundred steps between these two reference points, the original term for the system was centigrade (100 parts) or centesimal. In 1948 the name of this system was officially changed to Celsius by the 9th General Conference on Weights and Measures (CR 64), as a tribute to Celsius and to prevent confusion arising from conflicts over the use of the prefix centi- (in Indonesian centi-) as used SI unit of measure. Although the figures for the freezing and boiling times for water remain fairly precise, the original definition is not suitable for use as a formal standard: it relies on the standard definition of atmospheric pressure which itself depends on the definition of temperature. The current official definition of Celsius states that 0.01°C is at the triple point of water and one degree is 1/273.16 of the temperature difference between the triple point of water and absolute zero. This definition ensures that one degree Celsius represents a temperature difference equal to one kelvin. Anders Celsius originally proposed the freezing point to be at 100 degrees and the boiling point at 0 degrees. This was reversed in 1747, at the instigation of Linnaeus, or possibly Daniel Ekström, maker of most of the thermometers used by Celsius. A temperature of −40 degrees has the same value for Celsius and Fahrenheit. Also, a way to convert Celsius to Fahrenheit is to add 40, multiply by the temperature ratio and then subtract 40. In contrast, to convert from Fahrenheit to Celsius we add 40, then divide by the temperature ratio and finally subtract 40.

Erosion (from the Latin erosionem "gnaws") or also called erosion is an event that occurs naturally by the erosion of solids (sediment, soil, rock, and other particles) due to transportation by wind, soil and other materials under the influence of gravity or by living creatures such as animals that make burrows or plant root growth that causes soil cracks in this case is called bio-erosion. Erosion is not the same as weathering due to weather, which is the process of destroying rock minerals by chemical or physical processes, or a combination of both. In general, erosion involves three processes, namely detachment, transformation, and sedimentation. The erosion that occurs can form many interesting natural features such as mountain peaks, valleys and coastlines. Erosion is actually a natural process that is easy to recognize, but in most places it is exacerbated by human activities in poor land use, deforestation, mining, plantation and cultivation activities, construction or development activities that are not well managed and road construction. Soil used to produce agricultural crops is usually subject to much greater erosion than soil with natural vegetation. The conversion of forests into agricultural fields increases erosion, because the strong root structures of forest plants that bind the soil are replaced with weaker root structures of agricultural crops. The impact of erosion is the depletion of the top layer of soil, which will reduce land capability (land degradation). Another consequence of erosion is the decreased ability of the soil to absorb water (infiltration). A decrease in the ability of land to absorb water into the soil layer will increase surface water runoff which will result in flooding in rivers. In addition, soil particles that are transported by surface runoff will eventually settle in rivers (sedimentation), which in turn, due to high sedimentation, will cause siltation of rivers, which will affect the smoothness of shipping lanes.

A certain amount of erosion is actually a natural occurrence, and good for the ecosystem. For example, gravel periodically descends to lower elevations via water transport. Excessive erosion, of course, can cause problems, for example in terms of sedimentation, ecosystem damage and simultaneous loss of water. The amount of erosion depends on various influencing factors including climate, vegetation, soil characteristics, land use, and topography. Climatic factors, including amount and intensity of rain/precipitation, average and range of temperatures, as well as seasonality, wind speed, frequency of storms. Geological factors including sediment type, rock type, porosity and permeability, land slope. Biological factors include the vegetation cover of the land, the creatures that live in the land and land use by humans. In general, with the same ecosystem and vegetation, areas with high rainfall, high frequency of rain, more frequent exposure to wind or storms are more likely to be eroded. sediments with a high content of sand or silt, located in areas with steep slopes, are more easily eroded, as well as areas with weathered or broken rock. the porosity and permeability of sediments or rocks have an impact on the speed of erosion, related to whether or not water seeps easily into the soil. If water moves underground, less surface runoff is formed, reducing surface erosion. Sediments that contain a lot of clay tend to erode more easily than sand or silt. The impact of sodium in the atmosphere on the erodibility of the clay should also be considered. The most variable factor is the amount and type of land cover. In untouched forests, soil minerals are protected by a layer of humus and an organic layer. these two layers protect the soil by dampening the impact of raindrops. the layers along with the litter on the forest floor are porous and easily absorb rainwater.

Andorra (/ænˈdɔːrə/ ( listen), also UK /ænˈdɒrə/; Catalan: ənˈdorə]), officially the Principality of Andorra (Catalan: Principat d'Andorra), also called the Principality of the Valleys of Andorra (Catalan: Principat de les Valls d 'Andorra), is a sealess sovereign micro-state located on the Iberian Peninsula, in the eastern Pyrenees, bordered by France to the north and Spain to the south. Believed to have been founded by Charlemagne, Andorra was ruled by the Count of Urgell until 988, when Andorra was handed over to the Diocese of Urgell. The present principality was established by a treaty of 1278. Andorra is known as a principality because it is a diarchy headed by two princes: the Catholic Diocese of Urgell in Catalonia, Spain, and the President of France. This luxurious country is famous for its tourism sector and duty-free status. Andorra is part of the Catalan countries. Andorra is the 6th smallest country in Europe, has an area of ​​468 square kilometers and a population of approximately 77,006. The people of Andorra are an ethnic group of Romans who are originally of Catalan descent. Andorra is the 16th smallest country in the world by area and the 11th smallest in the world by population. Its seat of government, Andorra la Vella, is the highest major city in Europe, at 1,023 meters above sea level. The official language of the country is Catalan, but Spanish, Portuguese and French are also commonly spoken. Andorra is visited by approximately 10.2 million tourists annually. Andorra is not a member of the European Union, but the euro is its official currency. Andorra has been a member of the United Nations since 1993. In 2013, Andorra achieved the highest life expectancy in the world, namely 81 years, according to the Global Burden of Disease Study. The origins of the word Andorra are unknown, although several hypotheses have been proposed.

The oldest derivative of the word Andorra is that of the Greek historian Polibius (History III, 35, 1) who describes Andosins, an Iberian Pre-Roman, historically located in the valleys of Andorra and encountering the Carthaginian army on his way to the Pyrenees during the Punic Wars. The word Andosini or Andosins (Ἀνδοσίνοι) is probably derived from the Basque handia meaning "big" or "giant". Andorra's toponymy shows evidence of the Basque language in that region. Another theory suggests that the word Andorra may have come from an old Anorra word which includes the Basque word ur (water). Another theory suggests that Andorra may derive from the Arabic al-durra, which means "forest" (الدرة). When the Arabs and Moors conquered the Iberian Peninsula, the valleys of the High Pyrenees which were covered by large tracts of forest, and most of the areas not managed by the Muslims, because of the geographical difficulties that existed, earned this title. Other theories suggest that the term Andorra is derived from the Navarra-Aragonese andurrial, meaning "land covered with thickets". Folk etymology holds that Charlemagne had named this region in reference to the biblical valley around Canaan, namely Endor (where the Midianites were defeated), a name which had been given by his heir and son, Louis the Pious after defeating the Moors in the "valleys of wild valley of Hell". Tradition holds that Charlemagne granted a charter to the people of Andorra in exchange for their war against the Moors. The lordship of the area passed to the local Urgell prince and eventually to the bishop of the Urgell diocese. In the 11th century, there was a dispute between the bishop and his northern French neighbor over Andorra. In 1278, the conflict was resolved by the signing of the parage, which stipulated that sovereignty of Andorra be held between the French count of Foix (whose office eventually passed to the French head of state) and the bishop of La Seu d'Urgell, in Catalonia, Spain.

Tokelau is a territory of New Zealand in the South Pacific Ocean that is made up of three tropical coral atolls. The area is sometimes called by its colonial name the Union Islands. Tokelau was first settled by Polynesian emigrants who came from a neighboring island group. Tokelau was established as a British protectorate in 1889, became part of the British Colony of the Gilbert & Ellice Islands in 1916, before coming under New Zealand administration in 1925. Today Tokelau still has the status of a territory of New Zealand under the Tokelau Act 1948. The defense sector is the responsibility of the mother country. Like Niue and the Cook Islands, the people of Tokelau are drafting a constitution and developing institutions and patterns of self-government to form free association with New Zealand. The head of state for Tokelau is Queen Elizabeth II, represented by Administrator Neil Walter. The position of head of government is held by Pio Tuia who chairs the Faipule Council, consisting of a cabinet of three elected leaders from each atoll. The monarchy is hereditary, administrators are appointed by New Zealand's Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the head of government is selected from among the members of the Faipule Council for a one-year term. On November 11, 2004, Tokelau and New Zealand took steps to form an agreement that would change Tokelau's status from a territory of New Zealand to a territory of free association with New Zealand. In addition to drafting the agreement, a UN-sponsored act ("act of self-determination") needs to be enacted. Tokelau consists of three small islands in the South Pacific Ocean that are halfway between Hawaii and New Zealand, in the Pacific typhoon chain. Tokelau does not have a port or wharf. Coral atolls make up the three islands, namely Atafu (formerly Duke of York Group), Nukunonu (formerly Duke of Clarence Group), and Fakaofo (or Bowditch) Island.

The total land area is 10.8 km2. The fourth island that does not belong to Tokelau although geographically part of the Tokelau group is Swains Island, part of American Samoa since 1935. The Tokelau government's revenue of €410,000 per year does not cover expenses of around €2.3 million. The deficit was subsidized by a New Zealand aid fund. Tokelau's exports of €80,000 included stamps, copra and handicrafts. Meanwhile, imported products worth €245,000 were in the form of food, building materials and fuel. Local industry consists of small businesses such as copra production, timber, handicrafts, stamps, coins and fisheries. The agriculture and livestock sector produces coconuts, copra, keluak fruit, papayas and bananas, pigs, poultry and goats. Tokelau is inhabited by around 1,500 ethnic Polynesian people spread over three villages. They speak Tokelauan and English. Isolation and lack of resources seriously slows down economic development and drives the agricultural sector into a corner which can only meet the subsistence level of farmers and their families. The lack of natural resources and high population density have been the driving factors for emigration to New Zealand, as a result the population growth rate has decreased by 0.9% per year. On the island of Atafu, all residents are members of the Congregational Christian Church of Samoa; in Nukunonu, all are Roman Catholics; in Fakaofo, there are both religious sects with the majority being the Congregational Christian Church. The overall proportion of religions in Tokelau is: Congregational Christian Church 70%, Roman Catholic 28%, others 2%. Tungsten, also known as tungsten, is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol W and atomic number 74. The term tungsten comes from the Swedish tung sten, meaning heavy stone. Its name in Swedish is volfram, but to differentiate it from scheelit, it is given the alternative name tungsten in Swedish. Natural tungsten is found on earth almost always as a chemical compound. It is a rare metal that is hard at standard conditions when not combined. It was identified as a new element in 1781, and first isolated in 1783. Important tungsten ores include wolframite and scheelite. Its free elemental resistance is remarkable, especially the fact that it has the highest melting point of all the elements discovered. It melts at 3,422°C (6,192°F). Its high density is up to 19.3 times that of water, comparable to uranium and gold, and higher (about 1.7 times) than lead. Polycrystalline tungsten is a brittle and hard material, making it difficult to work with. However, pure single-crystalline tungsten is more ductile, and can be cut using a hard steel saw. Many tungsten alloys have a variety of applications, including incandescent lamp filaments, X-ray tubes (both as filaments and targets), electrodes in WIG welding, superalloys, vacuum tubes, and radiation shielding. The hardness and high density of tungsten provide it with military applications in penetrating projectiles. Tungsten compounds are also often used as industrial catalysts. Tungsten is the only metal of the third transition series known to occur in biomolecules, which is used by several species of bacteria and archaea. It is the heaviest element known to be essential for living organisms. Tungsten interferes with molybdenum and copper metabolism and is mildly toxic to animal life.

In its raw form, tungsten is a hard gray metal that is often brittle and difficult to work with. When made very pure, tungsten retains its hardness (which exceeds that of most steels), and becomes malleable enough to be easily machined. It is processed by forging, drawing, or extrusion. Tungsten objects are also commonly formed by sintering. Of all the metals in its pure form, tungsten has the highest melting point (3,422°C (6,192°F)), lowest vapor pressure (at temperatures above 1,650°C (3,000°F)) and highest tensile strength. Although carbon remains solid at higher temperatures than tungsten, it sublimes at atmospheric pressure rather than melting, and so has no melting point. Tungsten has the lowest coefficient of thermal expansion of any pure metal. The low thermal expansion and high melting point and tensile strength of tungsten stem from the strong covalent bonds formed between the tungsten atoms by the 5d electrons. Alloying small amounts of tungsten with steel greatly increases its toughness. Tungsten exists in two main crystalline forms: α and β. The first form has a body-centered cubic structure and is a more stable form. The β-phase structure is called cubic A15; it is metastable, but may coexist with the α phase under ambient conditions due to synthesis or non-equilibrium stabilization by impurities. In contrast to the α phase which crystallizes in isometric grains, the β form exhibits a columnar stature. The α phase has one third the electrical resistivity and a much lower TC superconducting transition temperature than the β phase: ca. 0.015 K vs 1-4 K; mixing the two phases allows obtaining intermediate TC values. The TC value can also be increased by alloying tungsten with other metals (eg 7.9 K for W-Tc). Such tungsten alloys are sometimes used in low temperature superconducting circuits.

Japan (Japanese: 日本国, Nihonkoku or Nipponkoku) is a unitary state with a parliamentary system in the form of a constitutional monarchy and also an island nation in East Asia. It is located on the western tip of the Pacific Ocean, east of the Sea of ​​Japan, and is adjacent to China, South Korea and Russia. The northernmost islands are in the Okhotsk Sea and the southernmost region is a group of small islands in the East China Sea, to be precise south of Okinawa which is across from Taiwan. Japan consists of 6,852 islands and makes it an archipelago. The main islands from north to south are Hokkaido, Honshu (the largest island), Shikoku, and Kyushu. About 97% of Japan's land area is on the four largest islands. Most of Japan's islands are mountainous, and some of them are volcanic. The highest mountain in Japan is Mount Fuji which is a volcano. The population of Japan amounted to 128 million people, and are at the stage of the 10th national populated the most in the world. Tokyo is the de facto is capital city of Japan, and is positioned as a prefecture. Tokyo Road is a reference to Tokyo and some of the cities which are in the prefecture around him. As the largest metropolitan area in the world, Tokyo Raya has a population of more than 30 million people, making it the most populous city in the world. According to Japanese mythology, the Empire of Japan was founded by emperor Jimmu in the 7th century BC. Emperor Jimmu started the chain of Japanese monarchies that has not been broken to this day. However, throughout its history most of the time actual power was in the hands of shoguns, samurai, daimyō and entering modern times, in the hands of prime ministers. According to the Japanese constitution of 1947, Japan is a unitary constitutional monarchy under the leadership of the Japanese emperor and the Japanese parliament.

As an advanced country in the economic field, Japan has the second largest gross domestic product after the United States, and is in the top three in terms of purchasing power balance. Japan is a member of the United Nations, G8, Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, and Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation. Japan has sufficient military strength complete with modern defense systems such as AEGIS and a large fleet of destroyers. In foreign trade, Japan is ranked the 4th largest exporting country and the 6th largest importing country in the world. As a developed country, Japan's population has a high standard of living (ranked 8th in the list of countries according to the human development index) and the highest life expectancy in the world according to UN estimates. In the field of technology, Japan is advanced in telecommunications, machinery and robotics. Japan is called Nippon or Nihon in Japanese. Both of these words are written with the same kanji, which is 日本 (literally: origin of the sun). The term Nippon is often used in official affairs, including the country's name on Japanese money, postage stamps, and international sporting events. Meanwhile, the term Nihon is used in informal matters such as everyday speech. The words Nippon and Nihon mean "country/land of the rising sun". This name is mentioned in the correspondence between the Empire of Japan and the Sui dynasty in China, and refers to Japan's position east of mainland China. Before Japan had relations with China, this country was known as Yamato (大和). In China during the Three Kingdoms period, Japan was called the country of Wa (倭). In the Chinese dialect of Shanghai, which is a dialect of Wu, the Chinese character 日本 is read as Zeppen (zəʔpən]). In the Wu dialect, the character 日 is unofficially read as niʔ] while officially reads as zəʔ].

Authoritarianism is a form of social organization characterized by the surrender of power. This contrasts with individualism and democracy. In politics, an authoritarian government is one in which political power is concentrated in a leader. Authoritarianism is also commonly referred to as authoritarian political ideology, which is a form of government characterized by an emphasis on power only on certain states or individuals, regardless of individual degrees of freedom. Authoritarianism differs from totalitarianism in the social and economic institutions it takes place, which are not under government control. This system is usually opposed to democracy, so that in general the power of government is obtained without democratic elections. The term authoritarianism comes from English, authoritarian. The word authoritarian itself comes from the English word authority, which is actually a derivative of the Latin word auctoritas. This word means influence, power, prestige, authority. With that authority, people can influence people's opinions, thoughts, ideas, and behavior, both individually and in groups. Authoritarianism is an understanding or position that adheres to authority, power and authority, which includes a way of life and action. Followers of authoritarianism will hold on to power as a reference for life. He will use authority as a basis for thinking. When dealing with other people and responding to their problems, they will ask their position (as what) in institutions and organizations. In discussing the matter, he will not question the nature and importance of it, but has the right to intervene and take care of the matter in question. However, this only applies to him. For other people, authoritarian people will limit a person's work, namely for that person to work according to existing procedures and rules. If that person does not understand and does not carry out his duties properly, he will be considered wrong. Authoritarian adherents only know one kind of communication, namely one direction.

Two-way communication, mutual discussion and response, and a democratic model with the possibility of differences and disagreements verbally or conceptually will be understood, but difficult to internalize. Communication that is free and open, originating from various directions and directed to all directions will be foreign to him, because this style of communication does not fit into his frame of mind. Therefore, one-way communication is a mainstay for this person in carrying out their duties. In carrying out their duties both in conveying ideas, thoughts and messages, authoritarian people only know one form of communication, namely instructions. The terms he is familiar with are limited to directions, instructions, advice, orders, coaching, so that forms of communication that are simply informing the case (informative) are considered sufficient. Persuasive forms of communication to convince are considered time-consuming and inefficient. If in communication authoritarian people only know communication in the form of instructions, in acting they like to play with power. What is meant by playing power is imposing power by paralyzing people, using threats, and trivializing matters. Authoritarian people will also play on the feelings of their subordinates by deliberately making them wrong and ashamed. In other words, instead of starting from the nature and interests of cases, the circumstances and abilities of people, as well as the existing situations and conditions, in acting authoritarianism will focus on the power it has. Based on research by political experts, Syed Mohd Aizuddin Tuan Sembak (UTM), Juan Linz, and Paul C. Sondrol from the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs, the differences in authoritarian and totalitarian (dictator) characteristics can be seen in the chart as follows: Power is an important factor in life. With good and proper use of power, many things can be accomplished and various achievements achieved.

Chocolate or Chocolate (English: Chocolate) is the designation for processed food or drinks made from cocoa beans (Theobroma cacao). Chocolate was first consumed by the inhabitants of ancient Mesoamerica as a drink, although it was believed that chocolate could only be consumed by royalty. Chocolate is generally given as a gift or gifts on birthdays and holidays. With its unique shape, pattern and taste, chocolate is often used as an expression of gratitude, sympathy or attention and even as a declaration of love. Chocolate has also become one of the most popular flavors in the world. Apart from being consumed most commonly in the form of chocolate bars, chocolate is also an ingredient in warm and cold drinks. Chocolate is produced from cocoa (Theobroma cacao) which is thought to have originally grown in the northern Amazon region to Central America. Maybe as far as Chiapas, the southernmost part of Mexico. The Olmec people took advantage of the trees and, possibly, made "chocolate" along the coast of the gulf in southern Mexico. The earliest documentation of chocolate is found on its use at a chocolate processing site in Puerto Escondido, Honduras around 1100 -1400 years BC. The residue obtained from these processing tanks indicates that initially the use of cocoa was not only intended for making drinks, but the white membrane found on cocoa beans was more likely to be used as a source of sugar for alcoholic beverages. Chocolate residue found on pottery used by the ancient Mayans in Río Azul, Northern Guatemala, indicates that the Mayans drank chocolate around 400 BC. The first civilization to inhabit the Meso-America area knew the "kakawa" tree whose fruit was consumed as a xocolātl drink which means bitter drink. According to them, this drink needs to be consumed every day, for whatever reason.

However, it seems that chocolate is also a symbol of prosperity. How to present it was not arbitrary. By holding the vessel of this liquid at chest level and pouring it into another vessel on the ground, the skilled server can create a thick froth, part of which makes the drink so valuable. This foam is actually produced by cocoa fat (cocoa butter) but sometimes additional foam is also added. Meso-Americans seem to have important habits of drinking and eating mush containing chocolate. The seeds of the cacao tree are themselves very bitter and must be fermented for the taste to be obtained. After baking and powdering the result is chocolate or cocoa. It is estimated that the Mayan habit of drinking chocolate began around 450 BC - 500 BC. It is said that the consumption of chocolate is considered as an important status symbol in those days. The Mayans consumed chocolate in the form of a frothy liquid sprinkled with red pepper, vanilla or other spices. Xocoatl drink is also believed to prevent fatigue, a belief that may be due to the theobromine content in it. When the classical Mayan civilization collapsed (around 900) and was replaced by the Toltecs, cocoa beans became a major Meso-American commodity. During the time of the Aztec Empire (until about 1500 BC) the area that includes present-day Mexico City was known as the Meso-America area most rich in cocoa beans. For the Aztecs cocoa beans were "food of the gods" (theobroma, from Greek). Usually cocoa beans are used in religious ceremonies and as gifts. Chocolate also became a luxury item during the Colombian-Meso American period, in their cultures, namely the Mayans, Toltecs, and Aztecs, cocoa beans (cacao beans) were often used as currency. For example, the Aztec Indians used a calculation system where one turkey chicken cost one hundred cocoa beans and one avocado cost three cocoa beans.

Reformism is the belief that incremental change through and within existing institutions, can definitely change the economic system and the fundamental political structure of society. This hypothesis about social change grows out of resistance to revolutionary socialism, which argues that revolution is necessary for fundamental structural changes to occur. Reformism must be distinguished from pragmatic reform: reformism is the view that an accumulation of reforms can lead to the formation of a socio-economic system that is completely different from current forms of capitalism and democracy, whereas pragmatic reform represents an effort to maintain the status quo against fundamental and structural changes. There are two kinds of reformism. The former have no desire to bring socialism or fundamental economic changes to society and are used to resist structural change. The second is based on the opinion that while reform is not socialism itself, it can help unite its supporters for the cause of the revolution by popularizing socialism among the working class. The debate over the ability of social democratic reformism to lead the socialist transformation of society has been going on for a century. Reformism was criticized for being paradoxical: trying to overcome the existing capitalist economic system, but also trying to improve the conditions of capitalism so that it actually made capitalism look more acceptable to society. According to Rosa Luxemburg, under reformism, "(capitalism) is not overthrown, but on the contrary will be strengthened by the development of social reforms." In a similar vein, Stan Parker of the Socialist Party of Great Britain argued that reformism was a transfer of power away from the socialists and limited, because they had to obey the logic of capitalism. French social theorist Andre Gorz criticized reformism by advocating a third alternative to reformism and social revolution which he called "non-reformist reforms". "Non-reformist reforms" are reforms that specifically focus on structural changes to capitalism, as opposed to reforms to improve living conditions within capitalism, or sustain it through economic intervention.

In 1875 the German Social Democratic Party (SDP) adopted the Gotha Program which proposed "everything that lawfully serves" for the work towards a "socialist society" and was criticized by Karl Marx as requiring a communist revolution. One of the SDP congress delegates, Eduard Bernstein, expanded his concept by proposing evolutionary socialism. Bernstein was an advocate of social democracy in Germany. Reformism became an immediate target of criticism of revolutionary socialism, with Rosa Luxemburg condemning Bernstein's Evolutionary Socialism in 1900 in her essay Reform or Revolution?. When Luxemburg died in the German Revolution, the reformists began to confront the Bolsheviks and their satellite communist party for the support of the intelligentsia and the working class. In 1959, the Godesberg Program (adopted at a party convention in the West German capital Bad Godesberg) marked the shift of the German Social Democratic Party (SDP) from a Marxist program to end capitalism, to a reformist one focused on social reform. After Joseph Stalin consolidated power in the Soviet Union, the Comintern launched a campaign against the Reformist movement by denouncing them as "social fascists". According to The God that Failed by Arthur Koestler, a former member of the German Communist Party, the largest communist party in Western Europe in the period between World War I and World War II, the communists, in alliance with the Soviet Union, continued to consider the German Social Democratic Party "social fascist" became the real enemy in Germany, even after the Nazi Party came to power. In modern times, reformists are seen as center-left. Some social democratic parties such as the NDP in Canada and the Social Democratic Party of Germany are still considered reformists.notes needed] The term was used for elements within the British Labor Party in the 1950s, and later for the right-wing party.

An ion is an atom or molecule that has a non-zero total electric charge (the total number of electrons is not the same as the total number of protons). Cations are positively charged ions, while anions are negatively charged ions. Therefore, a cation molecule has a hydrogen proton without an electron, whereas an anion has an extra electron. Because of their opposite electrical charges, cations and anions are attracted to each other and easily form ionic compounds. Ions containing only one atom are called monatomic ions or atomic ions, while those containing two or more atoms form molecular ions or polyatomic ions. In the case of physical ionization in a medium, such as a gas, "ion pairs" are created by collisions of ions, where each pair formed contains a free electron and a positive ion. Ions are also created through chemical interactions, for example dissolving a salt in a liquid, or alternatively, passing a direct current through a conducting solution dissolves the anode via ionization. The word ion comes from the Greek: ἰόν, ion, "is going", the verb being forms from the Greek: ἰέναι, ienai, "goes". The term was introduced by the English physicist and chemist Michael Faraday in 1834 to describe an unknown species that travels from one electrode to another via an aqueous medium. Faraday did not know the nature of these species, but he did know that when a metal dissolves into and enters the solution at one electrode, a new metal arises from the solution at the other electrode; the substance has moved through the solution in a current. It carries matter from one place to another. Faraday also introduced the words anion for a negatively charged ion, and a cation for a positively charged ion.

In Faraday nomenclature, cations are so named because they are attracted to the cathode in a galvanic device and anions are so named because they are attracted to the anode. Svante Arrhenius proposed his explanation, in his 1884 dissertation, that in fact solid crystalline salts dissociate into pairs of charged particles when dissolved. This dissertation earned Arrhenius the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1903. Arrhenius' explanation was that in forming a solution, the salt dissociates into Faraday ions. Arrhenius proposed that ions were formed even in the absence of an electric current. Ions in their gaseous state are highly reactive and will quickly interact with ions with opposite charges to produce neutral molecules or ionic salts. Ions are also produced in the liquid or solid state when salts interact with a solvent (eg, water) to produce "solvated ions", which are more stable. The ions move away from each other to interact with the liquid for reasons that involve changes in energy and entropy. These stabilized species are more common in low temperature environments. A common example is the ions found in seawater, which come from dissolved salts. All ions have a charge, which means that, like other charged objects, they: Electrons, due to their small mass and large space-occupying properties, are considered matter waves. It determines the entire size of atoms and molecules that have electrons. Anions (negatively charged ions) are larger than the parent molecule or atom, because the excess electrons repel each other thereby increasing the physical size of the ion, and its size is determined by its electron cloud. Thus, in general, cations are smaller than their parent atoms or molecules because the size of their electron cloud is also smaller. The hydrogen cation has no electrons at all, so it only has a single proton - much smaller than the hydrogen atom.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health science Oceanography (a combination of the Greek words ὠκεανός meaning "ocean" and γράφω meaning "to write"), also called oceanology or marine science, is the branch of Earth science that studies the oceans or oceans. This science covers a wide range of topics such as marine organisms and ecosystem dynamics; ocean currents, waves, and geophysical fluid dynamics; plate tectonics and the geology of the seafloor, bathymetry, and the chemical and physical flows of various substances in the oceans and their boundaries. These diverse topics reflect the wide variety of disciplines that oceanographers combine to deepen their knowledge of the world's oceans and understand the processes within them, namely astronomy, biology, chemistry, climatology, geography, geology, hydrology, meteorology, and physics. Paleoceanography studies the history of the oceans in terms of their geological history. Humans first learned about the waves and currents of the seas and oceans in prehistoric times. Observations of the tides were recorded by Aristotle and Strabo. Early exploration of the ocean was only for cartography and limited to the surface and animals caught by fishermen, even though at that time measurements of the depth of the sea using tin had already been carried out. Although it was Juan Ponce de León in 1513 who first identified the existence of the Gulf Stream which was well known to sailors, it was Benjamin Franklin who made the first scientific study of this current and gave it the name "Gulf Stream". Franklin measured the temperature of the water on several of his voyages across the Atlantic and correctly explained the cause of the Gulf Stream. Franklin and Timothy Folger published the first maps of the Gulf Stream in 1769-1770. When Louis Antoine de Bougainville (sailing between 1766 and 1769) and James Cook (sailing from 1768 to 1779) undertook their explorations of the South Pacific, information about the ocean itself formed part of their reports.

James Rennell wrote the first scientific test book of the currents in the Atlantic and Indian oceans in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. Sir James Clark Ross made the first modern deep-sea echo in 1840, and Charles Darwin published scientific work on reefs and atoll formation as a result of the Second Voyage of HMS Beagle in 1831-6. Robert FitzRoy published four volumes of reports on the Beagle's three voyages. In 1841–1842, Edward Forbes undertook dredging in the Aegean Sea which resulted in marine ecological discoveries. The first superintendent of the United States Naval Observatory (1842–1861), Matthew Fontaine Maury spent his time studying marine meteorology, navigation, and charting strong winds and currents. His 1855 book, Physical Geography of the Sea, was one of the first comprehensive research works on oceanography. Many countries send the results of oceanographic research to Maury at the Naval Observatory, where he and colleagues assess the information and disseminate the results around the world. The steep valley beyond the continental shelf was discovered in 1849. The first successful laying of a transatlantic telegraph cable in August 1858 confirmed the existence of a mid-oceanic ridge or underwater "telegraph plateau". After the mid-19th century, scientists began to process new information about terrestrial botany and zoology. In 1871, on the recommendation of the Royal Society of London, the British government funded an expedition to explore the world's oceans and carry out scientific investigations. With the help of these funds, Charles Wyville Thompson and Sir John Murray of Scotland launched the Challenger Expedition (1872–1876). The results are published in 50 volumes covering aspects of biology, physics and geology. 4,417 new species discovered. Other European and American nations also sent scientific expeditions, including private individuals and institutions.

Nālānda is the name of an ancient monastery and center of learning in India. The name Nālānda comes from Sanskrit and means giver of knowledge, (possibly from nalam, a lotus flower, a symbol of knowledge and da, to give). A Chinese monk, Xuanzang, who had made a pilgrimage to the place, gave several versions of the explanation regarding the naming of Nālandā. Nalanda is located about 55 miles southeast of Patna City, and was the center of Buddhist education from 427 to 1197 AD under the rule of the Pala Kingdom. Nālanda was identified by Alexander Cunningham with Baragaon Village. The Buddha is mentioned several times spending the night at Nalanda. According to the Kevatta Sutta, during the time of Gautama Buddha Nālandā had become a place of influence and prosperity. There is a record in the Samyutta Nikaya, regarding the city having experienced several times of famine. Sāriputta, a disciple of the Buddha, was born and died at Nālandā. Nālandā is also the home of Sonnadinnā. Mahavira is mentioned several times as staying at Nalanda. It is also said that Mahavisa attained Moksha at Pavapuri, which is located at Nalanda. King Asoka (250 BC) is said to have built a temple there. According to Tibetan sources, Nagarjuna taught there. According to historical data, Nalanda University was founded in 450 AD under the orders of several Gupta kings, most notably Kumaragupta. Nalanda was one of the world's first residential universities. In its heyday, the university accommodated more than 10,000 students and 2,000 teachers. This university is considered a masterpiece of architecture. Nalanda has eight separate gated gardens and ten temples, along with several meditation halls and classes. The library is located in a nine story building where many books are written here.

The subjects taught at Nalanda University cover all fields of study, and have attracted students and scholars from Korea, Japan, China, Tibet, Indonesia, Persia and Turkey. A number of teachings that are now considered Vajrayana teachings have their roots in traditions and teachings at Nalanda (late 9th to 12th centuries). Other schools of Buddhism, such as the Mahayana school, also originate from this university. Theravada tradition is also taught at Nalanda University, but Theravada teachings were not developed further at Nalanda. Due to the loss of influence of Buddhism in India in the 12th century, the university went into decline. In 1193, Nalanda University finally fell into ruins after being destroyed by a Muslim army under the command of Bakhtiyar Khalji; this event is considered to be the final end of the destruction of Buddhism in India. It is also said that Khalji asked where the Koran was at Nalanda University before destroying the university. When the Tibetan translator Chag Lotsawa visited the university in 1235, it was already in a state of disrepair, but still survived a small group of monks. Several ruined buildings have survived, near the Surya Mandir, a Hindu temple. The re-excavated ruins have an arena area of ​​150,000 m2, compared to Xuanzang's accounts of the area of ​​Nalanda, it is estimated that nearly 90% of the university has not been excavated. Nālandā is now no longer occupied. The nearest population center is in a village called Bargaon. In 1951, a center for modern Theravada education was founded nearby by Bhikkhu Jagdish Kashyap, named Nava Nalanda Mahavihara. The Nalanda Museum houses a number of manuscripts and displays some excavated historical items. On December 9, 2006, the New York Times reported on plans detailing the $1 billion redevelopment of Nalanda University near the ancient site.

Psychotherapy is a psychological service performed by experts to patients who need psychological self-healing. Experts in the field of psychotherapy are psychologists and counselors. Psychotherapy is a form of clinical intervention. The type of disease that can be treated by psychotherapy is a mental disorder. Treatment is carried out in psychotherapy only related to thoughts, feelings and behavior. Psychotherapy is one of the main clinical treatment methods for people with depression. The term psychotherapy comes from the Ancient Greek, namely psyche (soul) and therapeia (to treat, treat, heal). In the Big Indonesian Dictionary, psychotherapy is defined as "a method of treatment by using the influence (inner power) of a doctor on the soul (spiritual) of the sufferer, by not using drugs, but by using the method of suggestion, advice, entertainment, hypnosis, and so on". Psychotherapy is different from counseling in terms of its goals. The purpose of counseling is more limited when compared to psychotherapy. Counseling only aims to influence a person's development momentarily by involving oneself. The result achieved from counseling is the return of the function of a person according to his role. Psychotherapy has a bigger purpose because it results not only in changing the fundamental structure of personality in the present, but also for the future. So, psychotherapy has three goals at once, namely therapy, adjustment and remediation. Psychotherapy and guidance and counseling are both methods of intervention. Another difference between psychotherapy and counseling is in terms of the level of problems of the patient and the reasons for applying it. Psychotherapy mostly only deals with problems that are classified as serious problems. Psychotherapy and counseling have similarities in terms of demand because both are only done at the request of the patient. While guidance can be done without any request from the patient. The merger between counseling and psychotherapy began with the formation of the Australian Counseling and Psychotherapy Federation in 1998.

However, the Australian Federation of Counseling and Psychotherapy still recognizes that there is a difference between counseling and psychotherapy. Then in England there was a tendency from counselors that they were also psychotherapists. Accordingly, in 2000, the British Association for Counseling changed the name of its organization to the British Association for Counseling and Psychotherapy. Psychiatric psychotherapy is a type of holistic therapy that aims to restore the self-confidence of the patient. Another goal of psychiatric psychotherapy is to improve ego function in patients. Transpersonal psychotherapy aims to increase the transcendence of mind awareness so that it can make it explore consciousness. The result achieved from transpersonal psychotherapy is transpersonal awareness which results in true self-disclosure. Transpersonal psychotherapy techniques include meditation and prayer. Psychoanalysis is a technique used to provide a description of psychological qualities and their changes. Psychoanalysis is applied in psychotherapy to determine a person's personality. The person who first pioneered psychoanalysis was Sigmund Freud. Clinical treatment in psychoanalysis includes acts of hypnosis, catharsis, free association, and dream analysis. Logotherapy is a psychotherapeutic technique created by Viktor Frankl. The basic principle of logotherapy is meaning which is further divided into three types. The principle begins by providing the view that life always has meaning even in the most deplorable conditions. The second principle is the view that the purpose of life is to find meaning in life itself. The third principle is that humans have the freedom to interpret every action they take and experience even though it has tribulations. In the science of mental health, prayer and remembrance are types of psychiatric therapy. Its level is higher than common psychotherapeutic techniques. Prayer and remembrance can speed up the healing process. This acceleration is the result of the values ​​contained in prayer and remembrance, namely hope and self-confidence.

Reductionism can be defined as (a) an approach to understanding the nature of complex things by reducing them to the interactions of their parts, or making things simpler or more basic or (b) a philosophical position that complex systems is nothing but the amalgamation of its components, and such a statement is reducible to a statement of individual elements. This can be said as an object, phenomenon, explanation, theory, and understanding. Reductionism clearly describes a fixed perspective from causality. In a reductionist framework, phenomena can be explained entirely in terms of relationships among other more fundamental phenomena, which are called epiphenomena. There is often the implication that epiphenomenon use causal intermediaries in the underlying phenomena that explain them. Reductionism does not preclude the existence of what are commonly called emergent phenomena, but it does imply the ability to understand these phenomena more fully in terms of the processes by which they are formed. This reductionist understanding is quite different from that usually implied by the term emergence, which specifically means that what arises is more than the sum of the processes by which it arises. Religious reductionism in general tries to explain religion by mingling it with certain causes of non-religious views. Some examples of reductionistic explanations for the existence of religion: that religion is reducible to human concepts of right and wrong, that religion is essentially a primitive attempt at controlling our environment, and that religion is a way of explaining the existence of the physical world. Anthropologists Edward Burnett Tylor and James George Frazer make use of some of the religious reductionist arguments.
