Sigmund Freud had the idea that religion was nothing more than an illusion, or even a mental illness, and Marxists saw religion as the "breath of the oppressed", providing only the "illusory happiness of the people," both of which were influential reductionist views of religion.

There is a certain degree of reductionism in the social sciences, which often try to explain entire areas of social activity as mere subfields of their own. For example, Marxist economists often try to explain politics as a sub-ordination of economics, and sociologists sometimes see economics and politics as mere sub-fields of society. Theoretical reduction is the process by which one theory absorbs another theory. For example, Kepler's laws of planetary motion and Galileo's theories of motion in terrestrial bodies were both reduced to Newton's theories of mechanics, since all the explanatory power of the old theory was contained in the latter. Furthermore, reduction is considered a more useful theory because Newton's theory of mechanics is a more general theory, it explains more events than Kepler's or Galileo's Theories. Therefore, the theory of reductionism is the reduction of an explanation or theory to another theory, that is what is meant by the absorption of an idea about specific things into another idea. Methodological reductionism is a position that is at best scientific strategy in an attempt to simplify explanations to the smallest possible entities. Thus, methodological reductionism would insist that an atomic explanation of the boiling point of a substance is better than a chemical explanation, and that an explanation of even smaller particles would be even better. Therefore, methodological reductionism is the position that all scientific theories can or must be reduced to a single super theory through a process of theoretical reduction. Ontological reductionism is the belief that reality consists of a minimum amount of some kind of entity or substance. This explanation is generally metaphysical and is the most common form of monism, in effect claiming that all objects, properties and events are reducible to a single substance.

The Federal Republic of Brazil or Federal Republic of Brazil (Portuguese: República Federativa do Brasil, Latin: Respublica Foederativa Brasiliae) is the largest country by area and population (204.5 million in 2017) in South America. This country is the easternmost country on the South American Continent and is bordered by the Andes Mountains and the Atlantic Ocean. The name Brasil is taken from the name Brasil Wood, a local type of wood. Brazil is home to extensive agriculture and tropical rain forests. A former colony of Portugal, Brazil's official language is Portuguese. In addition, Brazil is also the largest coffee producer in the world for the last 150 years. Brazil won its independence from the Portuguese on September 7, 1822. This country, located in central and eastern South America, was a Portuguese colony since 1494. In 1889, Brazil's government system changed from a monarchy to a republic. Brazil is bounded by the sea on the east, namely the Atlantic Ocean. The countries that share land borders with Brazil are Uruguay, Argentina, Paraguay, Bolivia, Peru, Colombia, Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname and the French Guiana département; all countries in South America except Ecuador and Chile. In the north of Brazil there is the Amazon Forest and it opens up to the south with hills and small mountains. The south is the center of Brazil's population and agriculture. Several mountains are located on the coast of the Atlantic Ocean which reaches 2,900 meters with the highest peak Pico da Neblina as high as 2,994 m. The rivers in Brazil include the Amazon, Paraná, and Iguaçu where there is the Iguaçu Falls. Brazil's climate is tropical because it is located on the equator with little variation. In the south, the climate is more temperate, but occasionally snows. Rainfall is very high in the Amazon area while drier areas can be found in the northeast.

Important cities in Brazil include Brasília, São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. Most of Brazil is made up of plateaus and mountains. The largest plateau is the Brazilian plateau (in the east). To the east are the mountains of Brazil. In the center are the Mato Grosso plateau and the southern part is the Panama plateau. The 1988 constitution gives the federal government enormous powers. The President of Brazil wields a great deal of executive powers such as appointing the cabinet, and as the head of state and government. The president and vice president are elected simultaneously in general elections every 4 years. Its National Congress (Congresso Nacional) is a bicameral body (two-chamber parliament) consisting of the Federal Senate (Senado Federal) and the Câmara dos Deputados which consist of 81 and 513 seats with different terms of office, respectively. Brazil is composed of 26 states (estado) and 1 federal district (distrito federal): Brazil is the largest national economy in Latin America, the world's eighth largest economy at market exchange rates and seventh largest at purchasing power parity (PPP), according to the Monetary Fund International and World Bank. Brazil has a mixed economy with abundant natural resources. After rapid growth in previous decades, the country entered an ongoing recession in 2014 amid political corruption scandals and nationwide protests. Currently GDP (PPP) per capita of $15,153 in 2014 places Brazil in 77th position according to IMF data. Active in the agricultural, mining, manufacturing and service sectors Brazil has a workforce of over one 107 million (ranked 6th worldwide) and an unemployment of 6.2% (ranked 64th worldwide). Brazil covers the largest part of northern, central and eastern South America and is directly bordered by the countries on this continent except Chile and Ecuador.

Fasting or saum is the voluntary act of abstaining from food, drink, or both, bad deeds and from anything that breaks the fast for a certain period of time. Absolute fasting is usually defined as abstaining from all food and drink for a specified period, usually one day (24 hours), or several days. Another fast, restricting certain foods or substances. Fasting practices can hinder sexual and other activities as well as food. Fasting, often done in the context of performing worship, is also carried out outside the obligation of worship to improve the quality of the spiritual life of the person who does it. This kind of thing is often found in ascetics or monks. The essence of the intent and purpose of fasting is self-restraint from a desire to achieve a goal. Therefore, fasting can be defined as an effort to restrain yourself from a forbidden desire to achieve a goal. Fasting is often done in the context of performing worship in a religion or an obligation that must be carried out by humans according to their religious beliefs. Based on several reading sources, it turns out that fasting is practiced by several religions in the world. Even though the methods are different, the essence of the intent and purpose of fasting is self-restraint from a desire to achieve a goal. In Judaism Fasting for Jews means complete abstinence from food and drink, including water. Tooth brushing is forbidden on the holy fasts of Yom Kippur and Tisha B'Av, but is allowed on the fasts of the holidays. Jews who practice fasting up to six days in one year. With the exception of Yom Kippur, fasting is not permitted on the Sabbath, because the pillars of keeping the Sabbath are according to the Bible (gospel) prescribed and supersede later rabbinical institutionalized fasting days.

Yom Kippur is the only pillar which is prescribed in the Torah. In Christianity in general, Christian Fasting Teachings The point is repentance, fighting worldly desires, the desires of the flesh which is meant by the meaning of flesh in the Christian sense that flesh is the man himself because humans have flesh, so Christians often mention humans in certain words as flesh so meaning the desire of the flesh, namely the desire of man himself, and also teaches fasting so as much as possible not to tell or be known to fellow fasting or non-fasting fellows including keeping secret what day he will start fasting, disguising his body so as not to be seen fasting from people other people even their own beliefs, that's why Christian Fasting in General many of whose existence is not known by non-Christian beliefs and the public media. In some Christian denominations, only the implementation and procedures are different, the essence and goals are the same. For Orthodox Christians, fasting is a very important form of spiritual discipline, because it is often mentioned in the Old and New Testaments and has a close connection with Orthodox Christian theology regarding the synergy between the body (Greek: Soma) and soul (Greek: Pneuma). ). In addition, for Orthodox Christians, fasting is not aimed at suffering, but rather aims to protect oneself from all forms of greed, gluttony, greed, as well as bad thoughts, words and deeds. In the Orthodox Christian tradition, fasting is accompanied by other forms of benevolence such as giving and praying more. It is even stated that if fasting is carried out without this form of virtue, the fast will be in vain. Fasting Rules There are several fasting rules that Orthodox Christians must follow, namely: However, there are some waivers for not fasting for children who don't understand what fasting is, very old people, nursing mothers, those who are physically weak, are sick which if fasting will exacerbate the disease and endanger the life.

The heart (Latin: cor) is a cavity, a hollow muscular organ that pumps blood through the blood vessels by repeated rhythmic contractions. Blood supplies oxygen and nutrients to the body, also helps remove metabolic wastes. The term cardiac means related to the heart, from the Greek cardia for heart. The heart is one of the human organs that plays a role in the circulatory system, located in the chest cavity slightly to the left. In humans, mammals, and birds, the heart is divided into four segments: the right and left upper atrium; and right and left lower ventricles. In general, the right atrium and ventricle are called the right heart, and the rest are called the left heart. Fish have only two segments, an atrium and a ventricle, while reptiles have three. In a healthy heart, blood flows in one direction through the blood vessels. There is a sac that protects the heart, the pericardium, which also contains a small amount of fluid. The heart wall is composed of three layers: epicardium, myocardium, and endocardium. The heart pumps blood through two circulatory systems. Blood originating from the greater circulatory system contains little oxygen and enters the right atrium through the superior and inferior vena cava to the right ventricle. From here the blood is pumped to the lungs, where it picks up oxygen and leaves carbon dioxide. Oxygenated blood returns to the left atrium, passes through the left ventricle and is pumped to the rest of the body via the aorta—where oxygen is used and metabolized to carbon dioxide. In addition, blood also carries nutrients from the liver to various organs of the body, while carrying waste products to the liver and kidneys. Normally, the amount of blood pumped to the lungs equals the amount of blood pumped throughout the body.

Veins pump blood toward the heart and carry blood rich in carbon dioxide - except for the pulmonary and digestive system veins. Arteries carry blood away from the heart, carry oxygen apart from the pulmonary arteries. Long distance from the heart makes veins have less pressure than arteries. When resting, the heart beats approximately 72 times per minute. Physical exercise usually raises the amount, but the amount slows down over time, which is good for the heart. Cardiovascular disease was a common cause of death in 2008, accounting for 30% of people's deaths. Followed by coronary artery disease and stroke. The main causes are: smoking, obesity, lack of exercise, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, diabetes, and others. The diagnosis of cardiovascular disease is often made with a stethoscope, ECG or ultrasound. Specialists who focus on heart disease are called cardiologists, although other specialists are needed to treat them. The heart is a single muscle composed of layers of endothelium. The heart is located in the thoracic cavity, behind the sternum. The heart structure turns downward and slightly to the left. Its mass is approximately 300 grams, the size of a fist. The heart is almost completely enveloped by the lungs, but is covered by a double membrane called the pericardium, which is attached to the diaphragm. The first layer attaches very tightly to the heart, while the outer layer is more loose and watery, to avoid friction between the organs in the body that occurs due to the heart's constant pumping motion. The heart is kept in place by blood vessels that cover flat areas of the heart, such as the base and sides. The two lines of division (formed of muscle) in the outer layers of the heart indicate where the dividing walls between the atria and the chambers of the heart are.

Hippasos of Metapontum was a Pythagorean philosopher. He belongs to the class of philosophers of the Old Pythagorean school, that is, before the school of the Pythagorean school in Kroton was closed in the 5th century BC. Several other philosophers belonging to the Old Pythagorean school were Cercops, Petron, Brontinus, Kalliphon, Democedes, and Parmeniscus. There are no surviving written works of any of these philosophers, including Hippasus. When the Pythagorean school split into two groups, akusmatikoi and mathematikoi, Hippasos became the leader of the mathematikoi group. The akusmatikoi group saw the need to strictly obey all the rules of the Pythagorean school, while the mathematikoi group prioritized teaching science, especially physics. Hippasos hails from the city of Metapontum. Since he was a member of the Pythagorean school, it meant that he had also lived in Kroton. He lived and worked in the 5th century BC, that is, before the Pythagorean school was closed. Apart from that, it is also known that he lived at the same time as Philolaos, so it is estimated that he worked around 470 BC. According to information from Aristotle, Hippasos was of the view that fire was the basic principle of everything. This view is similar to the philosophical views of Herakleitos. However, W.K.C Guthrie said that Hippasos' view of fire was not like Herakleitos' meaning because in the Pythagorean view, fire had a special position. According to the testimony of Diogenes Laertius, Hippasos argued that the universe (cosmos) reaches the fullness of all its changes at certain periods. This view represents the Pythagorean doctrine of the continuously repeating cycles of history. From the testimony of Claudianus Mamertus, it is also known that Hippasos viewed the soul and body as separate from one another. The soul lives on when the body dies. This view is typical of the Pythagorean school.

Apathy is one of the attitudes of someone who surrenders and withdraws in the face of a situation. People who behave apathetic tend not to care about their emotional, social or even physical nature of life. The word apathy comes from the Greek word "pathos", which means emotion or passion. The cause of apathy is a lack of emotion and passion in life which results in a condition of indifference, lack of passion or emotion and insensitivity to the point of affecting everyday social life. In the medical world, apathy is a condition that afflicts individuals with the characteristic of moral dullness and seems to be insensitive to the pain they suffer, causing the sufferer to be lazy to think and move to do something. Apathy is often considered a syndrome or a collection of symptoms. What often appears is unproductive behavior in carrying out daily activities, lack of motivation to achieve desires or goals, not caring about the goals that have been planned to be achieved, loss of desire to pay attention or care for oneself, the desire to participate in various social activities is very low or tends to not at all, does not have a good emotional response to good news or bad news, has difficulty showing any form of feeling, whether happy, angry, or angry. In addition, people who are apathetic are less likely to produce any creativity or work. This happens because the ego in itself is very dominant so that it will not experience life development and will no longer have competitiveness. There are three types of apathy. First, emotional apathy with the characteristics of people who lack positive emotions and negative emotions. Second, apathy with the characteristics of people who lack initiative to start something with encouragement from themselves.

Third, general apathy with the characteristics of people who lack emotional response and motivation, and do not want to be involved in social relationships. Apart from that, there is also what is called bystander apathy which has the characteristic of not being interested in phenomena at all or not caring about other people who really need a helping hand or help. Next is what is called compassion fatigue, which is emotional exhaustion from feeling compassion, so there is no longer a sense of caring for other people. Apathy can be detrimental to oneself or those around it. First, the resulting impact is a lack of social control caused by an attitude of not caring or not being interested in things at all. Second, apathetic people and those around them tend to have difficulty developing, due to a lack of awareness or concern for themselves, others, and their surroundings. Third, there is the potential for individualism in a society so that it strengthens everyone without caring about others. Fourth, apathy can potentially cause enormous problems, such as disputes or divisions between communities and becomes a latent danger that can threaten the fragility of unity. Several potential therapies, such as cognitive stimulation therapy or electrotherapy cranial stimulation are urgently needed to treat chronic apathy. Steps to overcome apathy include pushing yourself to socialize and spend a lot of time with colleagues in an association, doing anything you really like, such as watching concerts or movies with loved ones, taking courses or art therapy classes (music, fine arts). , dance), try to do sports activities regularly, reward yourself after completing planned activities, get enough sleep every night, join the support of apathetic people who want to change to be a better person.

Kindergarten Raudatul athfal Elementary school play group Madrasah ibtidaiyah Package A study group Junior high school Madrasah tsanawiyah , which awards academic degrees in a variety of fields. A university provides undergraduate and postgraduate education. The word university comes from the Latin university magistrorum et scholarium, which means "community of teachers and academics". The university's long-standing predecessors existed in Asia and Africa, but the modern university system has its roots in Medieval universities in Europe, which were created in Italy and are essentially rooted in Christian schools for clergy during the High Middle Ages. The original Latin word, university, generally means "people associated with an agency, society, company, community, group of workers, corporation, etc." With the development of urban life, as well as the emergence of workers' groups in the Middle Ages, the term's meaning later developed into "an association of students and teachers with collective legal rights usually agreed to in a pact issued by the prince or the lord of their city". Like other working groups, the university at that time had its own rules and was free to determine the qualifications of its own members. In modern times, the meaning of the word has changed to "an institution of higher learning that offers instruction in non-vocational fields and usually has the power to award degrees". An important concept that distinguishes universities from others is the concept of academic freedom. The first document that provides evidence of this is a document from the University of Bologna, namely an academic treaty entitled Constitutio Habita which came out in 1158 or 1155.

This document guarantees the right of way for a scientist who is traveling on behalf of education. Today, this document is claimed to be the origin of the concept of "academic freedom". This is now known internationally. On 18 September 1988, 430 university rectors signed the Magna Charta Universitatum, a document marking the 900th anniversary of the founding of the University of Bologna. The number of universities that are signatories to the Magna Charta Universitatum continues to grow from around the world. According to the Encyclopedia Britannica, the ancestors of universities were in Asia and Africa and existed earlier than medieval universities in Europe. Some consider Al Quaraouiyine University founded in Morocco by Fatima al Fihri in 859 to be the oldest degree-granting university in the world. There are some similarities between the early universities established in the area around the Mediterranean Sea and madrasas in Islam. The difference is that madrasas are usually smaller and those who award titles are usually the teachers in the madrasa itself and not the madrasah itself. Historians such as Arnold H. Green and Hossein Nasr argue that as early as the 10th century, there were several Islamic madrasas that were turned into universities. However, other historians such as George Makdisi, Toby Huff and Norman Daniel argue that the European-style university has nothing in common with anything that existed in the medieval Islamic world. There are other scientists who argue that the university concept is originally from Europe, both in history and in characteristics. Darleen Pryds questions this and points out that the various European madrasas and universities in the Mediterranean Sea area share similar characteristics, namely that they both received funding from the nobility and were created to supply local bureaucrats loyal to the government's agenda.

Postmodernism (or postmodernism, postmodernism, post-mo) is a late 20th century movement in art, architecture, and criticism, which continues modernism. Included in postmodernism are skeptical interpretations of culture, literature, art, philosophy, history, economics, architecture, fiction, and literary criticism. Postmodernism is often associated with deconstruction and poststructuralism because its use as a term gained significant popularity at the same time as poststructuralism, namely in the twentieth century. Postmodernism is an understanding that developed after the modern era with its modernism. Postmodernism is not a single understanding or a theory, but rather an umbrella for various scattered theories and it is difficult to find a single common ground. Many figures give the meaning of postmodernism as a continuation of modernism. But the continuation became very mixed. For Lyotard and Geldner, postmodernism is a complete break from modernism. For Derrida, Foucault and Baudrillard, postmodernism is a radical form of modernity which eventually "turns itself off" because of the difficulty of homogenizing various theories. For David Graffin, postmodernism is a correction of some aspects of modernism. In addition, for Giddens, postmodernism is a form of modernism that has become self-aware and has become wise. Finally, for Habermas, postmodernism is an unfinished stage of modernism. Based on the origin of the word, postmodernism, comes from English which means understanding (-ism) which developed after (post) modern. The term first appeared in 1930 in art by Federico de Onis to indicate a reaction from modernism. Then in the field of History by Toyn Bee in his book Study of History in 1947. After that it developed in other fields and carried out criticism of modernism in its own fields. Postmodernism is distinguished from postmodernity. If postmodernism refers more to the concept of thinking, postmodernity refers more to the situation and social order of information technology products, globalization, fragmentation of lifestyles, excessive consumerism, deregulation of financial markets and public facilities, the obsolescence of the state and nation, and the exploration of traditional inspirations.

Astrology refers to any system of knowledge for understanding, and interpreting about reality and human existence, based on the positions and relative motions of various celestial bodies, especially the sun, moon, planets, and lunar nodes as seen at the time and place of birth or other events studied. For many astrologers, the relationship need not be causal. Common forms of astrology include Western Astrology, Chinese Astrology, Jyotish (Vedic Astrology) and Kabbalistic Astrology. Even more unusual is Horary Astrology. Most western astrologers base their work on the tropical zodiac, but western and Jyotish astrologers use the sideral zodiac. Astrology is not completely the same as astronomy. Astronomy is often confused with astrology, and vice versa. Because many scientists consider that astrology does not follow the scientific method, most of them generally reject astrology to be an astronomical science and simply classify it as a pseudoscience. Astrology was once deeply connected with astronomy, and the clear differences between the two were discovered back in the time of Galileo. He was the first to use the scientific method to test objective statements about the sky. Astronomy is meant to understand the physical workings of the universe. This is especially interesting and relevant in astrology. The main focus of most forms of astrology is on unproven correlations between the physical movements of the celestial bodies, and various human affairs, such as world events, events in the personal psyche of people, and innate personality traits. Other astrologers extend this correlation to unrelated geological phenomena to human activities, such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. Many prominent figures in the ancient history of Western astronomy, including Tycho Brahe, Johannes Kepler, and Galileo himself, also lived by their attempts to practice astrology for the wealthy aristocrats.

Isaac Newton is sometimes mentioned as having an interest in astrology, but the proposed evidence does not hold up to check it. Not a single word was recorded in Newton's hand that said the subject, and the book in his possession contained references to astrology primarily concerned with alchemy. There are some biological phenomena that coordinate with the movements of the heavens (eg circadian rhythms, see Chronobiology). This neither proves nor disproves astrological claims, but suggests influences which are wholly incomprehensible. Attempts by scientists to prove the influence of astrology have yielded negative or inconclusive results, for disputed reasons. Scientists would say astrology has no basis in fact, and therefore cannot be proven. Astrologers will say scientists have poorly designed studies because they don't understand astrology enough. Astrological concepts permeate many societies, and persist despite vigorous attempts by scientists to discredit them. This is proven by the fact that influenza was so named because doctors once believed it to be caused by adverse planetary and special influences. Astrology can also be seen as a system of cultural symbolism because it talks about thoughts and figures in Western culture. It has traces in the Alchemical and Hermetic traditions which were very influential until the 17th century. Only through understanding the astrological system to analyze human behavior can much Western thought and literature until the Enlightenment be fully understood. Many modern thinkers, especially Carl Jung, have acknowledged the descriptive powers of thought without necessarily subscribing to its predictive claims. Astrology has long been a part of cultural and religious customs in many parts of the world. Many of the indigenous tribes believe and practice this, which are well-known as Chinese astrology, Hinduism, etc.

Ecofeminism is an understanding of the relationship between women and the universe, especially in the powerlessness and injustice of treatment to both. The term ecofeminism was first introduced in 1974 by Françoise d'Eaubonne. In its application, ecofeminism applies a caring ethic to realize social justice ecologically, prioritizes the value of femininity and opposes patriarchal culture. In 1968, Paul Ehrlich published his book The Population Bomb. This book discusses the damage to the earth as a result of too much human population. The solution offered by him is to stop sexual reproduction. Françoise d'Eaubonne later criticized the book in his book Le Féminisme ou La Mort. He explained that women were not given the right to regulate their reproduction and the patriarchal system wanted reproduction to continue. Within its limitations, women can still achieve emancipation by opposing the patriarchal system through abortion and contraception. The book Le Féminism ou La Mort, written in 1974, introduced the term "ecofeminism" for the first time. Afterwards, this book discusses preventing the destruction of the earth by social movements led by women. In this case, the eco-feminism movement is protecting the earth by making it better by returning it to its original state. Ecofeminism makes social reality as the impact of social processes in society. Society is a human product with the unique fact that humans are also a product of society. Social interaction between humans in a society will develop into the interaction of society and its environment. Ecofeminism stipulates that cooperation, caring, love and tolerance are ways to preserve nature where humans live. This relationship then forms human ethics towards environmental management and creates human gender equality in relation to the universe.

Ecofeminism ontologically views humans and the universe as something that exists and is interconnected. Humans are a unit that cannot possibly live apart from other creatures and their environment and need each other. Human existence is the result of the existence of the universe and vice versa. The relationship between the two is described as a family consisting of members who do not oppress each other, but support each other. Ecofeminism makes admiration the main activity to gain knowledge in a feminist way. Through awe, social reality about the universe can be known. Knowledge based on awe then leads to positive environmental development. Ecofeminism applies human friendship with nature as a basis for taking action. Femininity becomes the main principle in every action. In its implementation, matriarchal culture is prioritized so that every action taken is always based on an emotional connection. The ecofeminism movement originated from criticism of liberalist feminism and socialist feminism, this criticism was first made by Susan Gordon in her book entitled The Prisoner of Men's Dream. He explained that feminism has become the destroyer of the world and has made women an imitation of men in a patriarchal system. Susan and other social activists have the idea that women and men don't have to be the same, but that the quality of life for both should be the same. These shared qualities must then change the world for the better without causing harm. Ecofeminist activists then began to criticize patriarchal culture and capitalism. Apart from that, they also criticize the culture of production and reproduction in relation to the dangers from the development of industrial technology and women's safety. Ecofeminism is based on an ethic of caring that exists because of the nature of women. Ecofeminism explains the powerlessness of women and global environmental damage in terms of social and cultural structures.

Henotheism is an understanding that only one god reigns in the world without denying the existence of other gods. Henotheism is also understood as a religious stage that lies between polytheism and monotheism. The religious stage in question is the stage of changing beliefs from the belief that there are many gods in power (polytheism) to the belief that there is only one god in power (monotheism). Henotheism has a synonym, namely monolatrism. In relation to worship or worship, henotheism is seen as a worship that temporally it is carried out against one god who is considered powerful. However, the god who is considered powerful absorbs other gods. Henotheism has simply been understood as an understanding that one god is powerful, but still acknowledges the existence of other gods. However, there are many perspective on the meaning of henotheism. One of them is the point of view that sees that henotheism is an understanding which states that there is one god who rules in this world. However, the ruler in one place is different from the ruler in another place. There is a point of view that sees that henotheism is an understanding huh ng states that there is only one god who rules in the world, but that god only exists at certain times. At other times, other gods will rule. Initially, the term henotheism was used to refer to the belief systems in Egypt and Israel. Egypt and Israel displayed belief systems based on one god. The question that arises is how to see the differences in these belief systems. This question demands an answer that is based on careful consideration. The term henotheism is an attempt to embrace differences from these belief systems. In the academic world, this term appears in discussions of religions.

Shahadat (Arabic: ٱلشَّهَادَة, translit. al-syahādah‎  audio (help·info)) is the basis and foundation of the five pillars of Islam, as well as the spirit, core and foundation of all Islamic teachings. Reciting two sentences of shahadat is the first condition for someone to become a Muslim. The creed is divided into two parts, namely the creed of monotheism and the creed of apostleship. The Creed contains the value of setting a mission which is part of the principle of personal resilience. Statements in the creed can be invalidated by certain practices. This type of practice can take the form of words, actions, or beliefs that raise doubts about the creed itself. Shahadat comes from the Arabic word shahida (شهد) which means "he has witnessed". That sentence in Islamic law is a statement of faith as well as an acknowledgment of the oneness of God (Allah) and Muhammad as His Messenger. Syahadat is also called Syahadatain because it consists of 2 sentences (In Arabic Syahadatain means 2 sentences Syahadat). The first sentence is the shahadah at-tawhid, and the second sentence is the shahadah ar-rasul. The two sentences of the shahadat are: If the two sentences of the shahadat are combined, then it will read: Shia Islam may also include a third sentence namely: Which will then read as: A Muslim only believes in Allah as the only God and there is no other god but Allah. Allah is God in the sense of something that is the motivation or purpose of a person. By pledging the first sentence, a Muslim establishes himself to make only Allah as his goal, motivation, and way of life. By pledging this sentence, a Muslim strengthens himself to believe in the teachings of God delivered through a 'Messenger of God,' Muhammad. The sentence Laa Ilaaha Illallah actually contains two meanings, namely the meaning of rejection and objection to all forms of worship (both gods and goddesses) other than God, and the meaning of affirming that the title of God, Ilah, Deva or worship belongs only to God.

Based on this verse, then learning the meaning of the confession of monotheism is obligatory and must take precedence over other pillars of Islam. In addition, the Prophet also stated: "Whoever says Laa Ilaaha Illallah sincerely will enter heaven." What is meant by sincerity here is to understand, practice and preach the sentence before others, because it contains the monotheism through which God created the world. The Messenger of Allah (Muhammad) lived for 13 years in Makkah and invited people with his words "Say Laa Ilaaha Illallah" then the disbelievers replied "Worship one worshiper, we never heard such a thing from our parents". The Quraish tribe in the time of the prophet understood the meaning of the sentence very well, and whoever uttered it would not invoke/pray to other than Allah. reference needed] A pledge is a statement by a Muslim about his belief. When a person utters the shahadah sentence, then he has an obligation to uphold and fight for what he pledged. Shahadat also means oath. A person who swears, means that he is ready to accept any consequences and risks in practicing his oath. A Muslim must be prepared and responsible in the upholding of Islam and the enforcement of Islamic teachings. Creed also means promise. That is, every Muslim is a person who surrenders to God and pledges loyalty to listen and obey in all circumstances to all the commands of God and all the messages delivered by God through the messenger of Muhammad. Confession also means testimony. This means that every Muslim is a witness to the statement of pledges, oaths and promises he made. In this case, it is his testimony to the oneness of God and to the apostleship of Prophet Muhammad. The condition of shahadat is something that does not exist, so what it requires is null and void.

P-channel impoverishment N-channel enrichment The metal–oxide–semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET) is a type of field-effect transistor. MOSFETs include channels of N-type and P-type semiconductor materials, and are called NMOSFETs or PMOSFETs (also commonly nMOS, pMOS). It is the most common transistor in both digital and analog circuits, but the bipolar junction transistor was at one time more common. MOSFETs were invented by Mohamed M. Atalla and Dawon Kahng at Bell Labs in 1959, and were first introduced in June 1960. These devices are the foundational building blocks of modern electronics, and are the most widely produced electronic devices in history, with a number of approx. approximately 13 sextillion (1.3×1022) MOSFETs were produced between 1960 and 2018. MOSFETs are the dominant semiconductor devices in digital or analog integrated circuits (ICs), and are common power devices. MOSFETs are miniaturized and mass-produced solid state transistors for various forms of applications, revolutionizing the electronics industry and world economy, and critical to the digital revolution, the silicon age and the information age. The miniaturization of MOSFETs has driven the rapid development of electronic semiconductor technology since the 1960s, and made possible high-density ICs such as memory chips and microprocessors. The word 'metal' in the current name is actually a misnomer because the former metal-oxide layer of the gate material has now often been replaced with a layer of polysilicon (polycrystalline silicon). Previously aluminum was used as a gate material until the 1980s when polysilicon began to dominate with its ability to form self-adjusting gates. However, metal gates are now being used again because it is difficult to increase the operating speed of transistors without metal gates. An IGFET is a related device, a more general term meaning an isolated-gate field-effect transistor, and is nearly identical to a MOSFET, although it can refer to any FET with a non-oxide gate insulator.

Some use IGFETs when referring to devices with polysilicon gates, but most still call them MOSFETs. The basic principle of the field-effect transistor (FET) was first proposed by the Austrian-Hungarian physicist Julius Edgar Lilienfeld in 1926, when he was filling out the first patent for an isolated-gate field-effect transistor (IGFET). Over the next two years he explained various FET structures. In the MOS configuration aluminum is represented by M, aluminum oxide is represented by O, while copper sulphide is used as a semiconductor. However, he was unable to build a practical working FET device. The FET concept was later developed in theory by German engineer Oskar Heil in the 1930s and American physicist William Shockley in the 1940s. No practically working FETs were built at that time, and none of the early FET proposals involved thermally oxidizing silicon. Semiconductor companies initially focused on bipolar junction transistors (BJTs) in the early years of the semiconductor industry. However, junction transistors are relatively thick devices and difficult to mass produce, limiting their use to BJTs. In theory, FETs could be an alternative to junction transistors, but researchers have been unable to build practical FETs, mainly due to the surface state barrier preventing external electric fields from entering into the material. By the 1950s, researchers had mostly stopped trying the FET concept, and instead focused on BJT technology. In 1955, Carl Frosch and Lincoln Derrick accidentally coated the surface of a silicon wafer with a layer of silicon dioxide. They showed that the oxide layer prevented certain probes from entering the silicon wafer, while allowing others to enter. In doing so, they discovered the passivation effect of the oxidation of the semiconductor surface. Their next work was demonstrating how to etch tiny cracks in the oxide layer to spread the rivet over a specific part of the silicon wafer.

The territory of Guam (Guahan in the Chamorro language) is an island in the western Pacific Ocean and also an organized unincorporated territory of the United States of America. Its capital is Hagatna, which was formerly called Agana. The majority of Guam's economy comes from the tourism sector (90% of tourists come from Japan) and the United States Army base. As one of the US territories closest to the International Date Line, Guam is nicknamed "The Place Where America Begins", thus the phrase becoming the island's territorial watchword. Guam is a prime example of the harmful effects of an invasive species: a venomous but harmless brown tree snake (Boiga irregularis) secretly boarded a US troop transport ship at the end of World War II. The ship departed from the Philippines bound for Guam. On Guam, the snake killed nearly the entire bird population on the island that was snake-free. The snake has no natural predators on Guam; today, Guam has one of the highest snake densities in the world (2,000 snakes/km²). Guam was once a Spanish colony which later fell into the hands of the United States in 1898. During World War 2, Guam became one of the first islands to be invaded by the Japanese and its inhabitants were tortured. Guam was successfully liberated by the United States on July 21, 1944 and is celebrated with great fanfare every year. Guam became widely known in 2017 when there was a crisis between the United States and North Korea. North Korea then threatened to attack Guam with ballistic missiles carrying nuclear bombs. Guam is the closest US territory to North Korea, making it easy for its missiles to reach. The crisis was finally resolved peacefully without spilling blood.

Guam, along with the Mariana Islands, were the first islands inhabited by humans in Remote Oceania. It also happened to be the first and longest ocean crossing of the Austronesian peoples, and separated from the later Polynesian settlement of the rest of Outer Oceania. They were first settled around 1500 to 1400 BC by migrants who departed from the Philippines. This was followed by a second migration from the Carolina Islands in the first millennium AD, and a third migration from Island Southeast Asia (probably the Philippines or eastern Indonesia) in 900 AD. These native settlers of Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands evolved into the Chamoru people, historically known as Chamorros after first contact with the Spaniards. :16 The ancient Chamoru people had four classes: chamorri (tribal chief), matua (upper class), achaot (middle class), and mana'chang (lower class). :20–21 matua are located in coastal villages, meaning they have the best access to fishing grounds, whereas mana'chang is located inland. Matua and mana'chang rarely communicated, and matua often used achaot as an intermediary. There are also "makåhna" or "kakahna", shamans with supernatural powers and "'suruhånu" or "suruhåna", healers who use various types of plants and natural materials to make medicine. Belief in an ancient Chamorus spirit called "Taotao mo'na" still survives as a remnant of pre-European culture. It is believed that the "suruhånu" or "suruhåna" are the only ones who can safely harvest plants and other natural materials from their homes or "hålomtåno" without incurring the wrath of the "Taotao mo'na." Their society is organized according to matrilineal clans. :21 The Chamoru people built a colonnade of megalithic pillars called latte stone on which they built their homes. Latte stones are stone pillars found only in the Mariana Islands; they are the latest development in Pre-Contact Chamoru society.

Goguryeo was an ancient kingdom occupying the territory of Manchuria and the northern part of the Korean Peninsula. Goguryeo is included in the Three Kingdoms of Korea along with the Kingdoms of Baekje and Silla and is the largest kingdom. Goguryeo was founded in 37 BC and ended in 668 AD. According to the Samguk Sagi, a prince of the East Buyeo kingdom named Jumong fled after a power struggle with other princes of the kingdom, and he founded a kingdom called Goguryeo in 37 BC in a place called Jolbon Buyeo. It is thought to be located in the middle of the Yalu and Tung-chia river valleys on the border of North Korea and Manchuria. Some historians believe that Goguryeo may have been founded earlier, namely in the 2nd century BC. In the ancient Chinese history book Han Shu, the word Goguryeo in Chinese characters (高句麗) was first written in 113 BC when it was a small country under the control of the Xuantu district. In the records of the Ancient Book of Tang, it is stated that Emperor Taizong of the Tang Dynasty mentioned that the history of Goguryeo was close to 900 years. In 75 BC, a tribal group called the Yemaek, thought to be an indigenous element of Goguryeo's population, made an attack on Xuantu District from the west of the Yalu River valley. However, written evidence from Tang historical books, the Samguk Sagi, Nihon Shoki and so on tends to favor 37 BC or mid-1st century BC for the founding of Goguryeo. Evidence from archaeological remains may support the existence of the Yemaek people in the 2nd century BC, but there is no direct evidence to explain whether they called their group Goguryeo people. The first mention of the word Goguryeo as a group associated with the Yemaek tribe can be found in references in Han Shu which tell of the Goguryeo rebellion in AD 12, when they broke away from Xuantu influence.

It was also around this time that Goguryeo leaders began changing his title to that of the Chinese leader, "wang" (King; 王). At its establishment, Goguryeo's citizens were probably a combination of Buyeos and Yemaek people. The Chinese chronicle San Guo Zhi mentions in the section entitled Notes on the Barbarians of the East, that the Buyeo and Yemaek peoples are ethnically related and speak the same language. The earliest mention of the word Jumong is recorded in an inscription on the Inscription of King Gwanggaeto the Great which was erected in the 4th century AD. Jumong's name can be read: 朱蒙 (Jumong), 鄒牟 (Chumo), or 仲牟 (Jungmo). The Stele states that Jumong was the first emperor and ancestor of Goguryeo and he was the son of the king of Buyeo and a daughter of the river deity Habaek. The Samguk Sagi and Samguk Yusa paints additional detail and names Jumong's mother as Yuhwa. Jumong's real father is Hae Mosu who is called the mighty man or prince of heaven. The Samguk Sagi writes that Hae Mosu was a sky god. So the King of Buyeo gave Yuhwa shelter and appointed Jumong as his son, then prince. That said, Jumong was very talented, especially in archery and horse riding, which made the crown prince jealous. The crown prince plans to kill Jumong and when he learns of this plan Jumong flees from the palace. Korean inscriptions and historical sources contradict each other about the origins of Jumong. The Stele says he came from North Buyeo and the Samguk Sagi and Samguk Yusa say he came from East Buyeo. Jumong arrives at the Jolbon Buyeo confederation and marries the daughter of its lord king. In the end he founded Goguryeo with a few followers from Buyeo. Jumong's family name was Hae (解), the name of the leader of Buyeo.

Calculus (Latin: calculus, meaning "little stone", to count) is a branch of mathematics that includes limits, derivatives, integrals, and infinite series. Calculus is the study of change, just as geometry studies shapes and algebra studies operations and their application to solving equations. Calculus has wide applications in science, economics, and engineering; and can solve various problems that cannot be solved with elementary algebra. Calculus has two main branches, differential calculus and integral calculus which are interconnected through the fundamental theorem of calculus. Examples of other branches of calculus are propositional calculus, calculus of variations, lambda calculus, and process calculus. Calculus lesson is a gateway to other higher mathematics lessons, which specifically study functions and limits, which are generally called mathematical analysis. The history of the development of calculus can be traced to several periods of time, namely ancient times, medieval times, and modern times. In the period of antiquity, some ideas about integral calculus had emerged, but they were not well developed and systematic. Calculations of volume and area which are the main functions of integral calculus can be traced back to the Egyptian Moscow Papyri (c. 1800 BC). On these papyri, the Egyptians were able to calculate the volume of a truncated pyramid. Archimedes took this idea further and created a heuristic that resembles integral calculus. In medieval times, the Indian mathematician Aryabhata used the concept of small infinity in 499 and expressed astronomical problems in the form of elementary differential equations. This equation then led Bhāskara II in the 12th century to develop an initial form of the derivative that represented an infinitesimal change and explained an earlier form of "Rolle's Theorem". Around 1000, the Iraqi mathematician Ibn al-Haytham (Alhazen) was the first to derive a formula for calculating the product of the fourth power, and by using mathematical induction, he developed a method for deriving the general formula for the product of the power of the integral which was so important to the development of integral calculus .

In the 12th century, the Persian Sharaf al-Din al-Tusi discovered the derivative of cubic functions, an important result in differential calculus. In the 14th century, Madhava, together with mathematicians-astronomers from the Kerala school of astronomy and mathematics, described a special case of the Taylor series, which is described in the text of the Yuktibhasa. In modern times, independent discoveries were made in early 17th century Japan by mathematicians such as Seki Kowa. In Europe, mathematicians such as John Wallis and Isaac Barrow made breakthroughs in calculus. James Gregory proved a special case of the fundamental theorem of calculus in 1668. Leibniz and Newton pushed these ideas together as a unit and the two scientists are considered separate discoverers of calculus at about the same time. Newton applied general calculus to physics while Leibniz developed the calculus notations that are widely used today. When Newton and Leibniz published their results for the first time, there was controversy among mathematicians as to which was more deserving of credit for their work. Newton submitted his work first, but it was Leibniz who published it first. Newton accused Leibniz of stealing his ideas from unpublished notes, which Newton often lent to members of the Royal Society. A detailed examination shows that the two worked independently, with Leibniz starting from the integral and Newton from the derivative. Today, both Newton and Leibniz are credited with developing calculus independently. It was Leibniz who gave the name to this branch of mathematics as calculus, while Newton named it "The science of fluxions". Since then, many mathematicians have contributed to the further development of calculus. One of the most complete early works on finite and infinitesimal analysis was written in 1748 by Maria Gaetana Agnesi.

SilicaSilicic oxideSilicon(IV) oxideCrystalline silicaPure Silica Germanium dioxideTin dioxideLead dioxide Silicon sulfide Silicon dioxide, also known as silica (from Latin silex) or silicic acid, is an oxide of silicon with the chemical formula SiO2. Silica is most often found in nature as sand or quartz, as well as in the cell walls of diatoms. Silica is produced in several forms including fused quartz, crystals, silica gel (or pyrogenic silica, trademarks Aerosil or Cab-O-Sil), colloidal silica, silica gel, and airgel. Silica is used primarily in the production of glass for windows, drinking glasses, beverage bottles, and many other uses. The majority of optical fiber for telecommunications is also made of silica. It is the main raw material for many ceramic whiteware such as pottery, ceramics, porcelain, as well as the Portland cement industry. Silica is a common additive in food production, where it is used primarily as a flow agent in powdered foods, or to absorb water in hygroscopic applications. It is the main component of diatomaceous earth which has many uses ranging from filtration to insect control. It is also a major component of rice husk ash which is used, for example, in the manufacture of filtration and cement. Silica thin films grown on silicon wafers via the thermal oxidation method can be very useful in microelectronics, where they act as electrical insulators with high chemical stability. In electrical applications, it can insulate silicon, store charges, block current, and even act as a controlled pathway to limit current flow. A silica-based airgel used in the Stardust spacecraft to collect extraterrestrial particles. Silica is also used in the extraction of DNA and RNA because of its ability to bind to nucleic acids under the presence of chaotropes. As hydrophobic silica is used as a defoamer component. In its hydrated form, it is used in toothpaste as a tough abrasive to remove dental plaque.

In its capacity as a flame retardant material, it is useful in fiber form as a high temperature thermal protection fabric. In cosmetics, it is useful for its light-diffusing and natural absorbent properties. Colloidal silica is used as a grape juice age and fines. In pharmaceutical products, silica aids the flow of powders when tablets are formed. Finally, it is used as a thermal enhancement compound in the ground source heat pump industry. The tetrahedral structure of silica units (SiO4), the most ideal basic building block of glass. In most silicates, the Si atom shows tetrahedral coordination, with 4 oxygen atoms surrounding a central Si atom. The most common example is seen in the form of SiO2 silica quartz crystals. In each of the most thermodynamically stable crystalline forms of silica, on average, all 4 of the nodes (or oxygen atoms) of the SiO4 tetra hedra are shared with other atoms, yielding the net chemical formula: SiO2. For example, in the alpha-quartz unit cell, the share the tetrahedral centers all 4 of its corner O atoms, the 2 faces – the tetrahedrons share centered 2 of their corner O atoms, and the 4 edges share the centered terahedra of only one of their O atoms with the other SiO4 tetrahedral. This makes for a net average of 12 out of 24 total nodes that a portion of the SiO4 7 tetra hedra are considered as part of the unit cell for silica. SiO2 has a number of different crystalline forms (polymorphs) in addition to amorphous forms. With the exception of stishovite and fibrous silica, all crystal forms involve tetrahedral SiO4 units connected by shared vectors in different arrangements. Silicon – oxygen bond length varies between different crystal forms, for example in α – quartz the bond length is 161 pm, whereas in α – tridymite it is in the 154 – 171 pm range.

Hydrocarbons are compounds made up of the elements carbon (C) and hydrogen (H). All hydrocarbons have a carbon chain and hydrogen atoms attached to it. The term is also used to mean aliphatic hydrocarbons. For example, methane (swamp gas) is a hydrocarbon with one carbon atom and four hydrogen atoms: CH4. Meanwhile, ethane is a hydrocarbon (more specifically, an alkane) consisting of two carbon atoms united by a single bond, each holding three carbon atoms: C2H6 and propane are hydrocarbons having three C atoms (C3H8) and so on with the structural formula CnH2 ·n+2 (where n is the number of carbon/hydrogen atoms). Hydrocarbons can be grouped based on the nomenclature of organic compounds as follows: Hydrocarbons can be in the form of gases (for example methane and propane), liquids (for example hexane and benzene), waxes or low boiling point solids (for example paraffin wax and naphthalene) or polymers (for example polyethylene, polypropylene). and polystyrene). Because the molecular structures are different, the empirical formulas of the hydrocarbons are also different: the number of hydrocarbons bonded to alkenes and alkynes must be less because the carbon atoms are double bonded. The ability of hydrocarbons to bond with themselves is known as catenation, and this allows them to form more complex compounds, such as cyclohexane or arenes such as benzene. This ability is obtained because the characteristics of the bonds between carbon atoms are non-polar. In accordance with the valence bond theory, carbon atoms must comply with the "4-hydrogen" rule which states the maximum number of atoms that can bond with carbon, because carbon has 4 valence electrons. Judging from the valence electrons, carbon has 4 electrons which can form covalent bonds or dative bonds. Hydrocarbons are hydrophobic and belong to lipids.

Several hydrocarbons are abundant in the solar system. Lakes filled with liquid methane and ethane have been found on Titan, Saturn's largest moon, as revealed by the Cassini-Huygens Mission. There are 3 types of hydrocarbon reactions, namely: Substitution reactions only apply to saturated hydrocarbons (carbon bonded to 1 double/alkane). In the reaction below, an alkane reacts with a molecule of chlorine. One of the chlorine atoms replaces the hydrogen atom. This reaction forms hydrochloric acid as well as a hydrocarbon with one chlorine atom. Reacts to CCl4 (carbon tetrachloride). Reacts to C2Cl6 (hexachloroethane). Addition reactions occur in alkenes and alkynes. In this reaction, a halogen molecule breaks the double bond in the alkene or the triple bond in the alkyne and forms a new bond. The common characteristics of hydrocarbons are that they produce steam, carbon dioxide, and heat during combustion, and oxygen is required for the combustion reactions to take place. The following is an example of a methane combustion reaction: If the air is poor in oxygen gas, carbon monoxide (CO) and water will be formed: Another example, the propane combustion reaction: The combustion reaction of hydrocarbons is an exothermic chemical reaction. Hydrocarbons are one of the most important sources of energy on earth. Its main use is as a fuel source. In solid form, hydrocarbons are one of the asphalt-forming compositions. Hydrocarbons have also been used in the past to make chlorofluorocarbons, a substance used as a propellant in mosquito spray. Currently, chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) are no longer used because they have an adverse effect on the ozone layer. Methane and ethane are gases at room temperature and are not easily liquefied under pressure alone. Propane is easier to liquefy, and is usually sold in canisters in liquid form. Butane is very easy to liquefy, so it is safer and often used in cigarette lighters.

Types of relationship Widows Widows Widows Family Cohabitation Monogamy Single marriage Boyfriend Boyfriend Girlfriend Marriage Polygamy Siblings Best friend Concubine Husband Mistress Events in relationship Love Kissing Affection Courtship Friendship Marriage · Affair · Divorce · Courtship · Courtship · Intercourse · Adultery Khulu (Arabic: خلع) etymologically means “to let go”. Khulu (Khul/Khul') is mutual divorce, a divorce made because of the will of the wife to release the marriage bond by giving a ransom of iwald (compensation) requested by the owner of the contract, namely the husband. request for divorce/or divorce requested by the wife to her husband by giving money or otherwise to the husband, so that he divorces her. And, in other words, Khulu is a divorce that the wife buys from her husband because there are some things the husband does that don't please his wife. As for the pattern for khulu's words conveyed by a husband to his wife, "I am divorcing you with Rp. 2,000,000,000 (Two billion Rupiah)". The wife then replied "I accept it". If the words are like this, then the wife must give Rp. 2,000,000,000 (Two billion Rupiah) as a ransom to the owner of the contract, namely the husband. Meanwhile, if the wife has asked the husband about the number of khulu, then the wife only needs to return the dowry as much as she had previously received, note: The wife has asked the husband directly sacredly and witnessed by the wife's and husband's family. Khulu is permissible if both are worried about not being able to carry out Allah's rules.

The mole (symbol: mole; English and French: mole) is the base unit for the amount of substance in the International System of Units (SI). After being redefined in 2019, the definition of the unit mole, as stated in the ninth edition of the SI Brochure, is as follows. The mole, which is symbolized by the mole, is the SI unit of amount of substance. One mole contains exactly 6.02214076×1023 elementary entities. This number, called Avogadro's number, is the fixed numerical value of Avogadro's constant NA when expressed in units of mol−1. The amount of substance, denoted by n, in a system is a measure of the amount of a given elementary entity. Elementary entities can be atoms, molecules, ions, electrons, other particles, or a particular group of particles. Previously, this unit was defined as the amount of chemical substance that contained a representative number of particles (now called elementary entities), such as atoms, molecules, ions, electrons, or photons, which was equivalent to the number of atoms in 12 grams of carbon-12 (12C), the isotope carbon with a definitive standard atomic weight of 12. This number was also previously expressed as Avogadro's number. Before being precisely defined in the redefinition, the Avogrado number was considered to be "approximately" to 6.022140857×1023 mol−1. The mole is widely used in chemistry as a convenient way of expressing the amounts of reactants and products in a chemical reaction. For example, the equation 2 H2 + O2 → 2 H2O means that 2 moles of dihydrogen (H2) and 1 mole of dioxygen (O2) react to form 2 moles of water (H2O). The mole is also used to express the number of atoms, ions or other elementary entities in a sample of a given substance. The concentration of a solution is commonly expressed as molarity, which is defined as the number of moles of solute per liter of solution. The number of molecules per mole is known as Avogadro's number, and is defined as the mass of one mole of a substance, expressed in grams, that is equal to the average relative molecular mass of the substance.

For example, the average relative molecular mass of natural water is about 18.015; then one mole of water has a mass of about 18.015 grams. The term gram-molecule was once used for the same concept. The term gram-atom has been used for related but different concepts, namely the quantification of a substance containing as many atoms as Avogadro's number, whether in the form of isolated or discrete molecules. Therefore, for example, 1 mol of MgBr2 is 1 gram-molecule of MgBr2 but 3 gram-atoms of MgBr2. In honor of this unit, some chemists celebrate October 23, which is referred to on the scale of 1023 in Avogadro's number, as "Mole Day". Some also did the same on February 6 and June 2, referring to 6.02 of Avogadro's fix. As of 2011 update], the mole is defined by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures as the amount of substance of a system that contains the same number of elementary particles (e.g. atoms, molecules, ions, electrons, photons) as there are atoms in 0.012 kilograms of carbon-12 (12C), isotope of carbon with a standard atomic weight of 12. Thus, by this definition, one mole of pure 12C has a mass of exactly 12 g. Also from this definition, X moles of any substance will contain the same number of molecules as X moles of any other substance (although their masses may differ). The mass per mole of a substance is called the molar mass. Since the atomic mass unit (amu) is defined as 1/12 of the atomic mass of 12C, the molar mass of a substance, measured in grams per mole, is numerically equal to its average atomic or molecular mass measured in amu. The number of elementary particles in a sample of a substance is technically called the (chemical) amount. Therefore, the mole is a convenient unit for this physical quantity.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union  (light blue) Egypt (Arabic: مصر‎; Translit: Maṣr) official name of the Arab Republic of Egypt (Arabic: جمهوريّة مصر العربيّة; Translit: Gomhoreyet Maṣr el-ʿArabeyya) is a country that is mostly located in Africa. Egypt is also the first country in the world to recognize Indonesian Sovereignty on August 17, 1945. With an area of ​​approximately 997,739 km² Egypt includes the Sinai Peninsula (considered as part of West Asia) while most of its territory is located in North Africa. Egypt is bordered by Libya to the west, Sudan to the south, the Palestinian Gaza Strip and Israel to the northeast. Its borders with water are through the Mediterranean Sea to the north and the Red Sea to the east. The majority of Egypt's population live on the banks of the Nile River (about 40,000 km²). Most of the land is part of the sparsely inhabited Sahara desert. The majority of Egypt's population adheres to Islam while the rest adheres to Kubti Christianity. Egypt is famous for its ancient civilization and some of the grandest ancient monuments in the world, such as the Pyramids of Giza, the Temple of Karnak, the Valley of the Kings and the Temple of Ramses. In Luxor, a city in the south, there are approximately 65% ​​of ancient artefacts worldwide. Today, Egypt is widely recognized as a major cultural and political center in the Arab region and the Middle East. The name Egypt in Indonesian, comes from the Arabic term Miṣr (IPA: mi̠sˤr] or Egyptian Arabic pronunciation: mesˤɾ]; Arabic: مِصر‎) is the classical Arabic of the Koran and is the official name of Egypt, while Maṣr (IPA: mɑsˤɾ]; Egyptian Arabic: مَصر) is the local pronunciation of the Egyptian Arabic dialect. The name is of Semitic origin, directly related to Egyptian names in other Semitic languages, such as Hebrew מִצְרַיִם (Mitzráyim).

The oldest known reference to the Egyptian name, recorded in Akkadian 𒆳 𒈪 𒄑 𒊒 KURmi-iṣ-ru miṣru, is related to the term miṣru/miṣirru/miṣaru, meaning "border" or "outskirts". Egypt is one of the oldest countries in the world. It is over 5000 years old. The native Egyptians are nomadic tribes from the Sahara Desert, Africa. For three thousand years Egypt was ruled by Pharaohs from dynasty to dynasty, of which there were 30 dynasties, of which 140 Pharaohs ruled from year to year. Ancient Egypt is divided into 3 eras, Old Kingdom, Middle Kingdom and New Kingdom. After the New Kingdom era, the Ancient Egyptian Empire collapsed and was controlled by outsiders, namely the Romans (by The Great Alexander), Arabs, Turks (by the Ottoman Empire). There are many relics from the ancient Egyptian empire, for example there are the Giza Pyramids at Giza, the Sphinx (Giza), the Valley of the Kings, the Red Pyramid, the Sakkara Pyramids, the City of Memphis (ancient Egyptian city). The Byzantines were able to establish control in the country after a brief Persian invasion in the early 7th century, until 639-42, when Egypt was invaded and conquered by the Caliphs by the Muslim Arabs. When they defeated the Byzantine army in Egypt, the Arabs brought Sunni Islam there. At the beginning of the period, the Egyptians began to assimilate their faith into traditional beliefs and practices, which led to the various Sufi orders thriving to the present day. These rites survived from the Kubti Alexandrian Orthodox Church. Muslim rulers appointed by the Islamic caliphate remained in control of Egypt for the next six centuries, with Cairo as the center of the caliphate under the Fatimids. With the end of the Kurdish Ayyubid dynasty, the Mamluks, a Turko-Circassian military caste, took control in AD 1250. In the late 13th century, Egypt connected the Red Sea, India, Malaya, and the Indian Ocean.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union    (green) Moldova, or officially the Republic of Moldova (Romanian: Republica Moldova), is a country located between Romania and Ukraine, in Eastern Europe. Moldova has no access to either the coast or the sea. In ancient times, Moldova was part of Dacia, which fell to the Romans. Most of Moldova was part of the medieval Principality of Moldavia. The eastern part of the principality was annexed by the Russian Empire in 1812 and this area became known as Bessarabia. On the dissolution of the Russian Empire in 1917, the Moldavian Democratic Republic was founded, which united with Greater Romania in 1918. In 1940, Bessarabia was occupied by the Soviet Union, and divided between the Ukrainian SSR and the Moldovan SSR. With the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, Moldova declared independence. The country is a parliamentary democracy, with a president as head of state and a prime minister as head of government. Moldova is a member of the UN, WTO, OSCE, GUAM, CIS, BSEC and other international organizations. Moldova is now seeking to join the European Union. About ¼ of Moldova's population still lives on less than $2 per day. During the Neolithic period, the territory of Moldova was the center of the Cucuteni-Trypillia civilization. This civilization that lasted from 5500 to 2750 BC was familiar with agriculture, animal husbandry, hunting and pottery. In the classical era, the Dacians inhabited Moldova. Between the 1st and 7th centuries, it was ruled by the Roman Empire. Situated on the route between Asia and Europe, the territory of modern Moldova was attacked successively by Goths, Huns, Avars, Magyars, Pechenegs, Cumans, and Mongols. In 1359, the Principality of Moldavia was founded.

The principality became one of the tribute payers to the Ottoman Empire with rights of internal autonomy in 1538. Under the 1812 Treaty of Bucharest, the Ottomans ceded the eastern region of Moldavia (known as Bessarabia) to the Ottoman Empire. The western part of Moldavia (which was not part of modern Moldova) remained an autonomous principality, and in 1859 together with Wallachia formed the Kingdom of Romania. After the Russian Revolution of 1917, the Moldavian Democratic Republic was proclaimed. Subsequently, the republic united with Greater Romania in 1918. On June 28, 1940, during World War II, Romania received an ultimatum from the Soviet Union. Romania was forced to cede Bessarabia and North Bukovina to the Soviets to avoid war. By the Soviets, the area was later divided between the Ukrainian SSR and the Moldovan SSR. In 1991, the Soviet Union collapsed, and Moldova declared independence on August 27, 1991. In September 1990, a separatist government was established in Transnistria (a region of Moldova). After the 1992 war, Transnistria became de facto independent, but no member of the United Nations recognized its independence. Moldova is a country located in Eastern Europe. The position of Moldova is at coordinates 45°28' - 48°28' north and from 26°40' - 30°06' east. The country of Moldova is 33,843 km² in area, with a land area of ​​33,371 km² and 472 km² in water area. Most of Moldova is located between two rivers, the Dniester and Prut. The western border of Moldova is formed by the Prut river, while the main river in the east is the Dniester which flows from north to south. This country has no access to the sea even though it is located close to the Black Sea. Most of Moldova is hilly, but the elevation never exceeds 430 m (1,411 ft). The highest peak in Moldova is Bălăneşti Hill.

Paraguay (Spanish: República del Paraguay, Guarani: Tetã Paraguái) is a landlocked country in South America on both sides of the Paraguay River. Paraguay is bordered by Argentina to the south and southwest, by Brazil to the northeast and east, and by Bolivia to the northwest. The country is nicknamed "The Heart of South America". Indigenous people, the Guarani, lived in Paraguay for approximately 1,000 years before being conquered by the Spanish in the 16th century. Asunción is the capital and largest city of Paraguay. The population of Paraguay is predominantly ethnic Mestizo with more than 95% of the total population of Paraguay. The official languages ​​there are Guarani, the local language, and Spanish. The Spanish language exists because Paraguay was once colonized by Spain. Per the 2009 census, the population of Paraguay is estimated to be 6.5 million people concentrated in the southeastern part of Paraguay. The capital city of Asunción is home to nearly a third of the total population of Paraguay. The country's name means "water that flows into the ocean", derived from the Guaraní words: pará ("ocean"), gua ("to/from"), and y ("water", "river" or "lake"). There is no final conclusion about the original name "Paraguay". The most common are various estimates, including: Native Americans have inhabited this area for thousands of years. These pre-Columbian peoples in what is now Paraguay were seminomadic tribes at the time of the Spanish discovery. They are famous for their fighting traditions. These indigenous tribes are divided into five groups based on their language family. Tribes of different language families often fight over resources and territory. These tribes are further divided into groups based on the language they speak, which is a branch of the existing language family. In all, there are 17 ethnic groups remaining with distinct languages.

The People's Republic of China (simplified Chinese: 中华人民共和国; traditional Chinese: 中華人民共和國; pinyin: Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó; literally: 'People's Republic of China', abbreviated PRC) or commonly known as China or China is a country located in East Asia whose capital city is Beijing. This country has the largest population in the world (about 1.4 billion people, the majority of whom are Han people) and a land area of ​​9.59 million square kilometers, making it the 3rd largest country in the world. The country was founded in 1949 after the end of the Chinese Civil War, and since then has been governed by a 1-party system by a single party, namely the Communist Party of the People's Republic of China/China (CCP). Although often seen as a communist state, much of the republic's economy has been privatized since the 1980s. However, the government still controls the economy politically, especially with state-owned companies and the banking sector. Politically, it remains a one-party government. Mainland China is a term used to refer to areas under the rule of the People's Republic of China/China, excluding Hong Kong, Macau, and while the Republic of China/Taiwan refers to other entities that once ruled Mainland China from 1912 until its expulsion in the Civil War. China to Formosa Island and surrounding islands in 1949. However, the Republic of China/Taiwan managed to survive and retain the rest of its territory to this day. Currently the Republic of China/Taiwan only governs the island of Formosa and the surrounding islands. The People's Republic of China/China claims territory belonging to the Republic of China/Taiwan but does not govern it, while the Republic of China/Taiwan claims sovereignty over all of mainland China which is currently controlled by the People's Republic of China/China. China's government from ancient times until today's split has had the world's largest and most complex economy for over two thousand years and dozens of dynasties of the Chinese Empire, along with several highs and lows.

Since the introduction of economic reforms in 1978 by President Deng Xiaoping, the People's Republic of China/China has become the country with the fastest growing economy in the world. As of 2013, this country is the second largest economy in the world based on total nominal GDP and PPP, as well as being the largest exporter and importer in the world. The People's Republic of China/China is a nuclear-weapon country and has the world's largest active army, with the world's second largest military spending. The People's Republic of China/China became a member of the United Nations in 1971, where it replaced and expelled the Republic of China/Taiwan as a permanent member of the UN Security Council. The People's Republic of China/China is also a member of various other organizations such as WTO, APEC, BRICS, Shanghai Cooperation Organization, BCIM and G-20. The People's Republic of China/China is a great power in Asia, and a potential super-state according to some observers. After World War II, the Chinese Civil War between the Chinese Communist Party and the Kuomintang Nationalist Party ended in 1949 with the communists taking control of Mainland China and then establishing the People's Republic of China/China. Meanwhile, the Kuomintang withdrew to the island of Formosa and continued to rule the Republic of China and some of the surrounding islands that were successfully defended. On October 1, 1949, Mao Zedong proclaimed the People's Republic of China and established a communist state, but did not try to completely annihilate the Republic of China. Proponents of Maoism say that under Mao, the unity and sovereignty of the People's Republic of China were ensured for the first time in decades, and there were developments in infrastructure, industry, health, and education, which they believed had helped raise people's living standards. They also believe that campaigns such as the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution are important in accelerating the development of the People's Republic of China and purifying their culture.

Plutonium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Pu and atomic number 94. It is a rare radioactive transuranium element and is an actinide metal with a silvery-white appearance. When exposed to air, it tarnishes due to the formation of plutonium(IV) oxide covering the metal surface. This element basically has six allotropes and four oxidation states. It reacts with carbon, halogens, nitrogen and silicon. When exposed to humidity, it forms oxides and hydrides with a volume of 70% larger and becomes a spontaneously igniting powder. It is also a radiological poison that can accumulate in the bone marrow.
