Because of these properties, the handling of plutonium is quite hazardous, although the overall toxicity of the metal is sometimes exaggerated. The most important isotope of plutonium is plutonium-239 which has a half-life of 24,100 years. Plutonium-239 is fissile, that is, it can split apart when bombarded by thermal neutrons, releasing more energy, gamma radiation, and neutrons. Therefore, it can maintain the nuclear chain reaction after reaching critical mass. These properties allow plutonium to be used as a nuclear weapon and used in several nuclear reactors. The most stable isotope of plutonium is plutonium-244, with a half-life of about 80 million years. This half-life is long enough to be found naturally in small quantities. Plutonium-238 has a half-life of 88 years and emits alpha particles. It is the heat source in radioisotope thermoelectric generators (used in some spacecraft). Plutonium-240 has a high spontaneous fission rate which will increase the level of background neutrons in the sample. The presence of Pu-240 will limit the power and weapon potential of a sample. It is also used as a benchmark for determining plutonium grades: weapons grade (< 7%), fuel grade (7–19%), and reactor grade (> 19%).

Pu-238 can be synthesized by bombarding uranium-238 with deuterons, while Pu-239 can be synthesized by bombarding uranium-238 with neutrons. Element 94 was first synthesized by a group of scientists led by Glenn T. Seaborg and Edwin McMillan at the University of California, Berkeley in 1940. McMillan later named the new element plutonium (after Pluto). The discovery of plutonium later became a key part of the Manhattan Project to develop the atomic bomb during World War II. The first nuclear test, "Trinity" (July 1945), and the second atomic bomb ("Fat Man") used to destroy the city of Nagasaki (August 1945) had a Pu-239 core. Like many other metals, plutonium has a shiny silver appearance. However, when exposed to air, plutonium(IV) oxide forms rapidly and turns the metal a dull gray. In addition, yellow and olive green have also been reported. At room temperature, plutonium exists in its alpha allotopic form. This allotropic form is the most common form and has the hardness level of cast iron, except when it is alloyed with other metals and makes it soft and can be easily deformed. Unlike most metals, plutonium is not a very good conductor of heat and electricity. It has a low melting point (640°C) and a very high boiling point (3.327°C). Alpha particle emission, which is the release of high-energy helium nuclei, is the most common form of radiation emitted by plutonium. The heat released during the release and deceleration of these alpha particles makes softball-sized plutonium feel warm to the touch, whereas for plutonium's larger mass, it can boil a liter of water in a matter of minutes (which varies depending on the isotope composition).

Types of relationship Widows Widows Widows Family Cohabitation Monogamy Single marriage Boyfriend Boyfriend Girlfriend Marriage Polygamy Siblings Best friend Concubine Husband Mistress Events in relationship Love Kissing Affection Courtship Friendship Marriage · Affair · Divorce · Courtship ·Majesty · Intercourse · Adultery Concubine is a practice in society in the form of an extramarital relationship between a woman (called a concubine) and a man for certain reasons. The most common reasons are usually due to differences in social status, race, and religion. In addition, concubinage occurs because there is a prohibition in society to have more than one wife. The practice of keeping a concubine or harem is a form of concubinage. Concubinage was a common practice during colonial times. The relationship that occurs is between landlords and women from among the natives or slaves who become their subordinates. This was made possible due to the lack of availability of women from equal social circles in the colonial lands. During the Dutch East Indies period, concubinage gave birth to a class of society which was later called Indos in the 19th and 20th centuries. In ancient China, a successful man usually had several concubines. One example is the documents that frequently record that the Emperor of China took in thousands of concubines. The treatment of concubines varied greatly, depending on the social status of the man or the attitude of the wife. The position of a concubine is usually lower than that of the original wife of a man. A concubine could have children as heirs, but the social status of those children was usually lower than that of the "original" children.

Adultery (non-standard form: adultery) is an act of sexual intercourse between a man and a woman who are not bound by marriage or marriage. In general, adultery is not only when a human has had sexual intercourse, but all sexual activities that can damage human dignity are categorized as adultery. Buddhism does not prohibit sex outside of marriage although adultery committed on a married person is considered a sexual offence. Buddhist precepts condemn fornication and monasticism. However, sexual activity between lay people is left to their discretion as long as it is not a sexual offense such as adultery of a married person (affection): sexual intercourse between two people is not in itself considered a sexual offence. In Islam, the perpetrators of adultery are divided into two, namely muhsan adulterers and muhsan ghairu. Muhshan adulterers are adulterers who already have a legal partner or are married (affairs), while ghairu muhsan adulterers are perpetrators who have never been married and do not have a legal partner (fornication). Narrated in the hadith: "There was a man who came to the Prophet Muhammad. When he was in the mosque. The man called the Messenger of Allah and said, "O Messenger of Allah, I have committed adultery, but I regret it." he repeated this four times. After the Messenger of Allah heard the statement that had been repeated four times, he called him and said, "Are you crazy?" ", replied the man. The Prophet asked again, "Are you a good person?" "Yes. ", he replied. Then, the Messenger of Allah said again, "Take this man and immediately stoned by you all." Based on Islamic law, adultery is one of the major sins. In Islam, sexual activities by married men/women with a man/woman who is not their legal husband/wife, including adultery.

In the Qur'an, it is said that all Muslims believe that adultery is a major sin and forbidden by God. About adultery in the Qur'an it is mentioned in the verses: "...and do not approach adultery, indeed adultery is an abominable act and a bad way." "The woman who commits adultery and the man who commits adultery, then flog each one of them a hundred times, and do not show mercy to them prevent you from (practicing) the religion of God, if you believe in God and the Last Day, and let (the execution of) their punishment witnessed by a group of believers." The law according to Islam for adulterers is as follows: The above law is based on the hadith: Take it from me! Take it from me! Truly God has given them a way. A boy who commits adultery with a girl is beaten a hundred times and exiled for one year. And those who are married commit adultery shall be beaten a hundred times and stoned." The law of the status of children of adultery in the Islamic view is as follows: In the Hebrew Bible and the Old Testament in the Christian Bible it is clearly written in the Ten Commandments of God given directly by God to the nation of Israel in Mount Sinai: "Do not commit adultery." Further explanation and punishment were given: "If a man commits adultery with another man's wife, that is, commits adultery with the wife of his fellow human being, both men and women who commit adultery must be put to death." There also another meaning of adultery that is strongly warned by God, which is adultery against the relationship of the people of Israel with God. This adultery is in the form of worshiping gods or gods other than the God of Israel. "When you take their daughters as wives -your son and those daughters will commit adultery by following their god, then they will also seduce the son of a you want men to commit adultery by following their god."

Rhein (German: Rhein, French: Rhin, Dutch: Rijn) is one of the longest rivers in Europe with a length of 1,230 km. Its name comes from the word "renos", which means "high current"). Together with the Danube it formed much of the northern frontier of the Roman Empire and has since been an important navigable waterway, influencing trade in the interior. The Rhine originates in the Alps in the Swiss region of Graubünden, where its 2 tributaries were originally called the Vorderrhein and the Hinterrhein. The Vorderrhein (Forward Rhine) leaves Lake Tuma near the Oberalp pass and passes through the Ruinaulta (Great Swiss Cliff). The Hinterrhein (back Rhine) starts from the Paradise Glacier near the Rheinquellhorn on the southern border of Switzerland. The two tributaries meet near Reichenau, remaining at Graubunden. As it leaves Graubuenden, the River Rhine flows north to form the border with Liechtenstein and then Austria, and then empties into Lake Constance. The Rhine then appears again, flows west, mainly on the border between Switzerland and Germany, falls at the Rhein falls, followed by the Aar which is more than 2 times its volume of water, and then turns north at Basel and forms the southern part of the border between Germany and France in the broad valley, before entering sheer Germany. With more than 1,000 km, the Rhine is the longest river especially Germany. It is here that the Rhine meets a number of its main tributaries, such as the Neckar, Main and Moselle. Between Bingen and Bonn, the River Rhine flows through the Rhine Valley, a formation created by erosion, which occurred at about the same rate as uplift in the area, leaving the river at approximately its original level, and the surrounding land was uplifted.

This gorge is rapidly rising, and is a section of the river known for its castle and numerous vineyards. Although many industries can be found along the Rhine to Switzerland, it is in the Ruhr area that the bulk is concentrated, with all streams — mainly of which the Ruhr itself — flows into the River Rhine, adding to it while still being polluted. The River Rhine bends west into the Netherlands, where it joins the Meuse to form a large delta. Across the border into the Netherlands, the Rhine widens, but then divides into 3 main tributaries: IJssel, Waal and Nederrijn. From here things got more complicated, as the name "Rhine" soon coincided with the main stream of water. Most of the Rhine's waters flow further west past the Waal River and then past the Nieuwe Waterweg and, joining the Meuse, past Hollands Diep and the mouth of the Haringvliet into the North Sea. A branch of the IJssel River carries its share of water northward into the IJsselmeer where the Nederrijn River flows west parallel to the Waal River. However, past Wijk bij Duurstede this stream changed its name and became Lek. Flowing further west joins the main stream again into the Nieuwe Waterweg. The name "Rhine" is from here used only for the smaller streamlines that together form the main river Rhein in Roman times. Although they still use that name, this stream does not carry water from the Rhine, but is used to flow through the surrounding land and polders. From Wijk bij Duurstede, the oldest northern branch of the River Rhine is called Kromme Rijn ("Rhine Bend") and via Utrecht, first Leidse Rijn ("Leiden Rhein") and then Oude Rijn ("Ancient Rhine").

Glasses are thin lenses for the eyes to normalize and sharpen vision (some are framed and some are not). Now, apart from being a visual aid, glasses have also become a style complement and a special tool for enjoying entertainment such as special three-dimensional glasses. The history of glasses first started with Nero, a Roman emperor, who reigned from 54 to 68 AD. Nero always used a concave gemstone to read and watch shows, although it is not known for certain whether Nero had problems with his eyesight. The Chinese may have been the first to use glasses like the glasses that are commonly used today. Usually the glasses are made of very large oval lenses made of rock crystal and tortoise shell frames. In order to hold onto the glass, the Chinese used two weighted wires to attach to their ears or lenses to hats or hooks to their temples. For the Chinese at that time, glasses were only used as a lucky charm or a tool to make them look cooler and more dignified, so that sometimes they just wore their glasses without lenses. Glasses became known in Europe in the 13th century. But unlike the Chinese, Europeans use glasses to help their vision. The glasses worn are still similar to the glasses of the Chinese people, which are made of rock crystal or transparent stones. The first glasses used by Europeans were magnifying glasses held in one hand. After that, a double glass lens is used, which is given a handle so that it can be attached to the ear. Then, the handle was removed and replaced with a ribbon or rope so that it could be tied to the head.

For some time, people wore eyeglasses, which are glasses which a pin-like device pinned up the nose. Eventually, over time, the idea arose to use hardened twisted wires to act as handles in the ears. The lenses used to correct vision are said to have been used by Abbas Ibn Firnas in the ninth century. Abbas Ibn Firnas found a way to produce very clear lenses. This lens is formed and sharpened into a round stone that can be used for reading, so it is known as a reading stone. At the end of the thirteenth century, it was finally discovered that using glass as a lens was much better than using transparent stone. This is based on the results of research by a British scientist and historian named Sir Joseph Needham. His research shows that glasses were invented 1000 years ago in China and spread throughout the world at the time of Marco Polo's arrival in 1270. This was also mentioned by Marco Polo in his book. Although it is not known for certain, people believe that it was the glazier who initiated this. In 1784, Benjamin Franklin, an American scientist, succeeded in inventing bifocal glasses, namely glasses that can be used to see both for long distances and near distances. Sunglasses are glasses that have dark (usually black) lenses. The purpose of making these glasses is to protect the eyes from glare to ultraviolet (UV) light. Sunglasses are used in addition to protecting the eyes from light, are also often used for reasons of style. Sunglasses are also often used by the blind for aesthetic reasons so that people don't have to see their eyes. These sunglasses were first used in the 12th century or possibly earlier in China.

Zeni (Dutch: genie; English: combat engineer, pioneer, or sapper) is a military unit that performs military engineering tasks to support ground troop combat operations. Combat engineers perform a variety of military engineering, tunnel warfare, mine warfare and construction and demolition tasks inside and outside the combat zone. Engineers facilitate the mobility of friendly troops and hinder enemy movements. Engineers also worked to ensure friendly troop survival, constructing battle positions, fortifications, and roads. They carry out demolition missions and clear minefields manually or through the use of special vehicles. Typical engineering troop missions include constructing and breaching trenches, tank traps, and other obstacles and fortifications; barrier placement and bunker construction; route and reconnaissance permits; construction or demolition of bridges and roads; placing and clearing landmines; and joint force breakthrough. Usually, the engineers are also trained as gunners and, when necessary, serve as temporary infantry. Engineers are the oldest military corps in Indonesia which was formed on October 15, 1945. Army Engineers are the engineers part of the military forces whose main task is to carry out engineering and military engineering. His duties include construction of military infrastructure, especially on the mainland, construction of fortifications, especially military construction and destruction on the battlefield, camouflage or camouflage, and the implementation of combat engineering, especially providing living facilities in the field for troops. During the Dutch East Indies era, there was a royal army during the Dutch East Indies era named Koninklijk Nederlandsch Indische Leger (KNIL) which also had an Engineer Armament unit or Wapen der Genie. This unit itself includes a combat support unit whose job is to help expedite the movement of infantry troops and other movements. The late veteran KNIL colonel, CA Heshusius in Soldaten van der Kompagnie KNIL (1986:61) stated that these weapons were relatively small but technical weapons always participated in every military expedition.

Alcmeon was a philosopher belonging to the Pythagorean School. He was a student of Pythagoras. He was the first philosopher of the school to publish works in the natural sciences. Apart from being a philosopher, he is also known as a doctor. He worked extensively in medicine as well as in the natural sciences. He is also known as the first physiologist. Alkmeon comes from Kroton, Southern Italy. Kroton is the city where Pythagoras lived and became famous. He lived and worked at the beginning of the 5th century BC. He was much younger than Pythagoras. In the introduction to his book, he dedicated the book to three philosophers of the Pythagorean school, namely Brotinus, Leo, and Bathyllus. The difference between humans and animals according to Alkmeon is in the human ability to understand (understanding). Animals have the ability to feel (sensation). Likewise humans have this ability. However, humans have the ability to understand, while animals do not. According to Alkmeon, human health depended on the balance between the forces in the body. They are wet and dry, cold and hot, bitter and sweet, and so on. If one of these forces becomes dominant and dominates one of them, then that's where disease arises. In this theory, the influence of the Pythagorean school on the principle of balance is illustrated. The Alcmeons declared that all sensory perception, whether human or animal, is centered in the brain. Therefore, if the brain doesn't function anymore, humans can't do anything anymore. Regarding the human soul, he stated that the soul is eternal. Because it is eternal, the soul will continue to move. Unlike the soul, the human body will vanish. Alcmeon declared the sun to be a flat disk. Then he stated that these objects animate or have a soul.

Siddhartha Gautama (also known as Sakyamuni and The Buddha) was a South Asian ascetic and spiritual teacher who lived in the second half of the first millennium BC. He is the founder of Buddhism and is revered by Buddhists as a fully enlightened being who teaches the path to Nirvana (literally "disappearance or extinction"), freedom from ignorance, craving, rebirth and suffering. According to Buddhist tradition, the Buddha was born in Lumbini in what is now Nepal, to noble parents from the Shakya clan, but left his family to live as a wandering ascetic. Leading a life of begging, austerities, and meditation, he attained enlightenment in Bodh Gaya. The Buddha then traveled through the lower Ganges, teaching and establishing a monastic order. He taught the middle way between sensual indulgence and severe asceticism, a training of the mind that includes ethical training and meditative practices such as effort, mindfulness, and jhanas. He died in Kushinagar, attaining parinirvana. The Buddha has since been venerated by many faiths and communities throughout Asia. Several centuries after the Buddha's death, his teachings were compiled by the Buddhist community in the Vinaya, his code for monastic practice, and the Suttas, texts based on his sermons. It was passed down in a Central Indo-Aryan dialect through oral tradition. Later generations compiled additional texts, such as the systematic treatise known as the "Abhidharma", a biography of the Buddha, collections of stories about his past lives known as the Jataka tales, and additional discourses, namely the Mahayana sutras. Prince Siddhartha was born in 623 BC in Lumbini Park, when Queen Maha Maya stood holding a sal tree branch. At the moment he was born, two small currents fell from the sky, one cold while the other warm.

The current washed over Siddhartha's body. Siddhartha was born in a clean and spotless state, stood straight and could immediately take a step towards the north, and the place he stepped on was overgrown with lotus flowers. By hermits under the leadership of Asita Kaladewala, it was predicted that the Prince would one day become a Chakrawartin (World Maharaja) or would become a Buddha. Only the hermit Kondañña had firmly predicted that the Prince would become the Buddha in the future. Hearing this prediction, His Majesty became worried, because if the Prince became Buddha, no one would inherit the throne of his kingdom. By the King's question, the ascetics explained that the Prince should not see four kinds of events. If not, he will become a hermit and later become a Buddha. The four kinds of events were: From childhood it was seen that the Prince was a smart and very clever child, always served by young and beautiful maids and maids in a magnificent and beautiful palace. At the age of 7 years, Prince Siddhartha had 3 lotus flower ponds, namely: At the age of 7 Prince Siddhartha had studied various sciences. Prince Siddhartha mastered all subjects well. At the age of 16, Prince Siddhartha married Princess Yasodhara, whom he married after winning various contests. And when he was 16 years old, the Prince had three Palaces, namely: The ascetic Asita's words made King Suddhodana restless day and night, for fear that his only son would leave the palace and become an ascetic, wandering without a place to live. For this reason, His Majesty chose many servants to care for Prince Siddhartha, so that his only son could enjoy worldly life. All forms of suffering tried to be removed from Prince Siddhartha's life, such as illness, old age, and death, so that the Prince only knew worldly pleasures.

Postcolonialism or postcolonial studies is an academic discipline with an intellectual discourse method that studies, explains, and evaluates the cultural heritage of colonialism and imperialism and the human impact of colonization of a country and settlements of immigrants aimed at exploiting the indigenous people and their land. Derived from postmodernism, postcolonial studies analyze the politics of knowledge (creation, control, and dissemination) by studying the functional relations of social and political power that enable colonialism and neocolonialism to survive—a matter of depiction of the colonizer and the colonized (social, political, cultural). As a genre of contemporary history, postcolonialism questions and reinvents modes of cultural perception—the way of seeing and being seen. In anthropology, postcolonialism studies human relations in colonial countries and subaltern societies exploited by colonial governments. In critical theory, postcolonialism describes, explains, and describes the ideology and praxis of neocolonialism by taking examples from the humanities—history and political science, Marxist philosophy and theory, sociology, anthropology, and human geography; film, religion, and theology; feminism, linguistics, and postcolonial literature, with an anti-colonial genre that tells stories of subaltern conquests during the colonial period. As an epistemology (study of knowledge, its nature, and its validity), ethics (moral philosophy), and politics (civic citizenship), the field of postcolonialism deals with the politics of knowledge—an issue that includes the postcolonial identity of a nation experiencing decolonization that stems from: (i) creation cultural knowledge about the colonized nation by the colonial nation; and (ii) how Western cultural knowledge was used to subjugate non-European nations to become colonies of the European mother country imposed after the initial attack through the cultural identities of "colonizer" and "colonized". Decolonized nations have postcolonial identities derived from cultural interactions with various identities (culture, nation, ethnicity) and social relations of sex, class, and caste; determined by the gender and race of the colonized; and racism embedded in the structure of colonial society.

Alabama (/ˌæləˈbæmə/) is a United States state located in the southern part of the mainland. Alabama is directly bordered by Tennessee to the north, Georgia to the east, Florida and the Gulf of Mexico to the south, and Mississippi to the west. The 22nd-order state to join the Union, Alabama joined the Confederate States of America in 1861. After the Civil War, Alabama returned to the union in 1868. Alabama is also nicknamed Yellowhammer State, after the state bird. Alabama is also known as the "Heart of Dixie" and the "Cotton State". The state tree is the long leaf pine, and the state flower is the camellia. The capital city of Alabama is Montgomery. The city with the largest population is Birmingham, which has long been the most developed city. The largest city on the mainland is Huntsville. The oldest city is Mobile, founded by French colonists in 1702 as the capital of French Louisiana. The Greater Birmingham metropolitan area is the most populous urban area in Alabama. Alabama's name is taken from the Alabama River and the state comes from the Alabama people, a Muskogean-speaking tribe whose members live just below the confluence of the Coosa and Tallapoosa rivers in the upper reaches of the river. The spelling of the word "Alabama" varies widely among historical sources. The first usage appears in three accounts of Hernando de Soto's 1540 expedition: Garcilaso de la Vega uses Alibamo, while Ksatria Elvas and Rodrigo Ranjel write Alibamu and Limamu, respectively, in a transliteration of the term. As early as 1702, the French called the tribe Alibamon, with French maps identifying the river as the Riviere des Alibamons. Other spellings of the name include Alibamu, Alibamu, Alabamo, Albama, Alebamon, Alibama, Alibamou, Alabamu, Allibamou. The state has many place names derived from Native American origins.

Parliament is a legislature, especially in countries whose system of government is based on the Westminster system of the United Kingdom. The English term is of Anglo-Norman origin and dates back to the 14th century, derived from the French Parliament of the 11th century, from "parler", meaning "to speak". This meaning evolved over time, originally referring to any discussion, conversation, or negotiation through various types of deliberative or judicial groups, often summoned by a king. In the 15th century, in England, it specifically meant the legislature. The legislature called parliament is administered by a government with a parliamentary system in which the executive is constitutionally responsible to the parliament. This can be compared to a presidential system where the legislature cannot elect or fire the head of government and conversely the executive cannot dissolve parliament. Several countries developed semi-presidential systems which combined a powerful President and an executive who was responsible to parliament. Parliaments can consist of several chambers or assemblies, and are usually unicameral or bicameral although there are more complex models. A Prime Minister (PM) is almost always a party leader who has a majority position in the lower house of parliament, but only holds that office for as long as parliament trusts him. If members of the lower house lose confidence for any reason, then they can file a vote of no confidence and force the PM to resign. This can be very dangerous for the stability of the government if the number of voting positions is relatively balanced. Since ancient times, when society was tribal, there was a village council or chief whose decisions were judged by village elders. This is called tribalism. Some scholars argue that in ancient Mesopotamia there was a primitive democratic government in which kings were judged by a council.

The same has been said of ancient India, where some form of deliberative assembly existed, and therefore some form of democracy. However, this claim was not accepted by most ulama, who saw these forms of government as oligarchy. Ancient Athens is the cradle of democracy. The Athenian Assembly (ἐκκλησία, ekklesia) was the most important institution, and every citizen could take part in the discussions. However, Athenian democracy was not representative, but more direct, and therefore the ekklesia differed from the parliamentary system. The Roman Republic had a legislative assembly, which had the final say on the election of judges, the passing of new laws, the execution of capital punishment, declarations of war and peace, and the creation (or dissolution) of alliances. The Roman Senate controlled money, administration, and foreign policy details. Some Muslim scholars argue that the Islamic shura (a method of decision-making in an Islamic society) is analogous to parliament. However, others have highlighted what they consider to be fundamental differences between the shura system and the parliamentary system. The unicameral system (only one assembly of the legislature directly representing the people) became popular from the end of the XVIII century and the beginning of the XIX century. Initially the upper house was intended as the last defense of the power of the king and the nobles because they were directly or indirectly related to the king. Now the upper house in general is no longer a representative of the aristocratic class (upper class), but representatives from the states because in general those who use a two-chamber system are the union states. Advantages of the two-chamber system: Disadvantages of the two-chamber system: Examples of countries using the two-chamber system: Early Contemporary

In chemistry, a metal (Greek: μέταλλον, metallon; English: metal) is a material (an element, compound, or alloy) that is normally hard, opaque, lustrous, and has good electrical and thermal conductivity. Metals are generally malleable—that is, they can be hammered or pressed permanently into shape without chipping or cracking—as well as fusible (can be melted down) and ductile (can be stretched to form fine wires). About 91 of the 118 elements in the periodic table are metals; the rest are non-metals or metalloids. Some elements exhibit both metallic and non-metallic properties. Astrophysicists use the term "metal" to collectively describe all the elements other than hydrogen and helium, the two simplest elements, in a star. The star fuses smaller atoms, mostly composed of hydrogen and helium, to create larger atoms during its lifetime. In that sense, the metallicity of an object is the proportion of matter that makes up all of the heavier chemical elements, not just the traditional metals. Many elements and compounds that are not normally classified as metals become metals at high pressure; it forms as a metallic allotropy of a nonmetal. Atoms of metallic substances are usually arranged in one of three common crystal structures, namely body-centered cubic (bcc), face-centered cubic (fcc), and hexagonal close-pack (hcp). In bcc, each atom is located at the center of the cube surrounded by other atoms. In fcc and hcp, each atom is surrounded by twelve other atoms, but the arrangement of the layers is different. Some metals adopt different structures, depending on temperature. Metal atoms easily lose their outer shell electrons, resulting in a cloud of free flowing electrons in their dense nature arrangement. This causes the ability of metals to easily conduct heat and electricity.

If this flow of electrons occurs, the solid characteristics of the metal are produced by the electrostatic interactions between the individual atoms and the electron cloud. This type of bond is called a metallic bond. Metals tend to form cations through electron loss mechanisms, reacting with oxygen in the air to form oxides over various time scales (iron rusts after years, while potassium burns in seconds. Examples: Transition metals (such as iron, copper, zinc, and nickel) ) are slower to oxidize because they form a passivation layer of the oxide that protects the interior of the metal. Others, such as palladium, platinum and gold, do not react at all with the atmosphere. Some metals form a barrier oxide layer on their surface that cannot be penetrated further by molecules oxygen, thereby retaining its luster and conductivity for decades (such as aluminum, magnesium, some steels, and titanium).Metal oxides are generally basic, as opposed to nonmetals, which are acidic.Exceptions are oxides with very high oxidation states such as CrO , Mn, and OsO, which reacted very hopelessly m. Painting, anodising or plating the metal are all good ways to prevent corrosion. However, the more reactive metal in the electrochemical series must be chosen for the coating, especially if the coating flakes are chosen. Water and the two metals form an electrochemical cell, and if the coating is less reactive than the coated substance, the coating has actually promoted corrosion. Metals generally have high electrical conductivity, high thermal conductivity, and high density. They are generally flexible and tough, deforming under pressure without splitting. In terms of its optical properties, metals are shiny and lustrous. Sheet metal under a few micrometers thick looks opaque, but the gold foil lets in a green glow. Although most metals have a higher density than most nonmetals, there is a wide range of variation in their densities.

Kusbini (January 1, 1910 – February 28, 1991) was a legendary figure in the 1930 - 1955 era of keroncong music, along with Annie Landouw, Gesang, S. Abdoellah, Miss Roekiah, etc. He was born in Kemlagi Village, Mojokerto, East Java. During the "Eternal Keroncong" era (1920 - 1960), he was a prominent Indonesian singer and composer. In the era around 1937 - 1942, he was active in singing and playing keroncong music with Annie Landouw, S. Abdoellah, Gesang. During the Dutch East Indies era, he rewrote (transcripts) the kroncong songs Telomoyo, Moresko, Nina Bobo, etc. However, he also wrote the song Kr. Ancient. In 1945–1952, he composed songs of struggle with C. Simanjuntak, Ismail Marzuki, L. Manik, etc. In 1950, he then worked at P&K Yogyakarta for music affairs. He is also a founding figure of SMINDO 1954 (Government-owned Yogyakarta Indonesian Music School—which later became AMI and ISI Yogyakarta). In addition, he founded SOSI (School of Indonesian Art) which is now being cared for and continued by his children. His song "For You Country" is a mandatory struggle song that he composed in 1942 and was designated as the national anthem in 1960. The beginning of the creation of the song began when Kusbini met Bung Karno who asked him about the idea of ​​creating a struggle song and at that time Kusbini immediately agreed. . Kusbini interpreted "Country" as the State (Neg), he deliberately concealed the message of this struggle because Japan did not like anything related to the struggle for independence. Before being officially announced, the song underwent several verse changes and then Ibu Sud sang it for the first time through Hoso Kanri Kyoku. In 1978, Kusbini was sued by J. Semadi who claimed to be the composer of the song Padamu Negeri.

Strontium is a chemical element in the periodic table having the symbol Sr and atomic number 38. An alkaline earth metal, strontium is a silver-white or yellowish soft metallic element that is highly reactive chemically. the metal forms a dark oxide layer when exposed to air. Strontium has similar physical and chemical properties to its two vertical neighbors in the periodic table, calcium and barium. It occurs naturally in the minerals Celestine, strontianite, and putnisite, and is mined in most of the first two of these. While natural strontium is stable, the synthetic isotope 90Sr is radioactive and is one of the most dangerous components of nuclear fallout, as strontium is absorbed by the body in a similar way to calcium. Stable natural strontium, on the other hand, is not harmful to health. Both strontium and strontianite are named after Strontian, a village in Scotland near which the mineral was discovered in 1790 by Adair Crawford and William Cruickshank; it was identified as a new element in the next year's red-red flame test color. Strontium was first isolated as a metal in 1808 by Humphry Davy using the then newly discovered process of electrolysis. The production of sugar from beet sugar in the 19th century was the largest application of strontium (see Strontian process). At the peak of television cathode-ray tube production, as much as 75 percent of the strontium consumption in the United States went into faceplate glass. With the move away from the cathode ray tube to other display methods, strontium consumption has dropped dramatically. CHARACTERISTICS Strontium is a divalent silvery metal with a pale yellow color whose properties are largely intermediate between and similar to those of its calcium group neighbors and barium. It is softer than calcium and harder than barium. Its melting (777°C) and boiling points (1655°C) points are lower than that of calcium (842°C and 1757°C respectively); barium continues this trend decreasing in its melting point (727°C), but not in its boiling point (2170°C).

The density of strontium (2.64 g/cm3) is similar to that of calcium (1.54 g/cm3) and barium (3.594 g/cm3). Three allotropes of metallic strontium exist, with transition points at 235 and 540 °C. The standard electrode potential for the Sr2+/Sr pair is -2.89 V, about the middle between those of the Ca2+/Ca (-2.84 V) and Ba2+/Ba (-2.92 V) pairs, and close to those of the neighboring alkali metals. Strontium is intermediate between calcium and barium reactivity towards water, with which it reacts on contact to produce strontium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. Metal strontium burns in air to produce both strontium oxide and strontium nitride, but because it does not react with nitrogen below 380 °C, at room temperature, it forms only the oxide spontaneously. In addition to the simple oxide SrO, peroxide SrO2 can be prepared by the direct oxidation of strontium metal under high oxygen pressure, and there is some evidence for the yellow superoxide Sr(O2)2. Strontium hydroxide, Sr(OH)2, is a strong base, although it is not as strong as hydroxide of barium or alkali metals. Because of the large size of the heavy block elements, including strontium, a wide variety of coordination numbers are known, from 2, 3, or 4 to 22 or 24 in SrCd11 and SrZn13. The large sizes of strontium and barium play an important role in stabilizing strontium complexes with polydentate macrocyclic ligands such as crown ethers: for example, while 18-crown-6 forms relatively weak complexes with calcium and alkali metals, strontium and barium complexes are much stronger. Organostrontium compounds contain one or more strontium-carbon bonds. They have been reported as intermediates in Barbier-type reactions.

West is one of the four cardinal directions on a compass that are opposite East. The sun and moon set in the west. The word west is an absorption word from Sanskrit: Bharata, (Hindi: Bharat, भारत) which refers to the original name of India. In the past, traders from India who also spread Buddhist and Hindu religions and culture in Indonesia called themselves "coming from the West (Bharat)", so the direction of their arrival was called "west" by the Malay people. , west, is a Germanic word passed into several Romance languages ​​(ouest in French, oest in Catalan, ovest in Italian, oeste in Spanish and Portuguese). The word comes from the Indo-European root *wes which is reduced from *wes-pero 'night' which is related to hesperos from Ancient Greek and vesper 'night; west' from Latin. To go west using a compass for navigation (in a place where magnetic north is the same direction as true north) we need to set the bearing or azimuth of 270°. West is the direction opposite the Earth's rotation on its axis, and therefore is the general direction in which the Sun appears to move and eventually set. This is not the case on the planet Venus, which rotates in the opposite direction from Earth (retrograde rotation). To an observer on the surface of Venus, the Sun will rise in the west and set in the east even though clouds on Venus prevent observing the Sun from the planet's surface. On a map with north at the top, west is on the left. Moving continuously westward is moving with latitude. Due to the direction of Earth's rotation, the prevailing winds in many places in the middle latitudes (i.e. between 35 and 65 degrees latitude) originate in the west, which are known as westerlies.

Abiogenesis (pronounced ˌeɪbaɪ.ɵˈdʒɛnɨsɪs] AY-by-oh-JEN-ə-siss) or biopoiesis is the study of how biological life could arise from inorganic matter through natural processes. In particular, the term usually refers to the process by which life on Earth arose. Abiogenesis is thought to have occurred during the early Eoarchean period, or about 4 to 3.5 billion years ago. Most of the amino acids, which are often dubbed "the building blocks of life", were successfully synthesized in the Miller-Urey experiment and in other experiments that simulated early Earth conditions. Other important biochemicals such as nucleotides and saccharides can occur in a similar way. In all organisms, these biochemicals are organized into more complex molecules, such as proteins, polysaccharides, and nucleic acids. The three molecules are essential for the functioning of life and are present in all organisms. The formation of these macromolecules is mediated by nucleic acids and enzymes, which are synthesized through protein-catalyzed biochemical pathways. Which organic molecules appeared first and how they formed the first organisms is still being debated. The first life to appear on Earth is thought to have been single-celled prokaryotes that may have evolved from protobionts (organic molecules surrounded by a membrane-like structure). The oldest recorded microbial fossils date back 3.5 billion years, about a billion years after the formation of Earth. By 2.4 billion years ago, isotope ratios of carbon, iron, and sulfur indicated the influence of life on mineral and inorganic sediments and molecular markers indicated the occurrence of photosynthesis. Modern abiogenesis (which was first coined by Oparin and Haldane in the 1920s) is different from classical abiogenesis, aka spontaneous generation. One of the most basic differences is that modern abiogenesis is an explanation of the origins of life phenomena while classical abiogenesis expressed by Aristotle explains how certain animals/plants (appear) routinely appear without going through reproduction.

Another difference is in terms of mechanism: modern abiogenesis is based on modern biochemical knowledge while classical abiogenesis is based on classical concepts such as the material principle (η υλικη αρχη/hê hylikê arkhê), the principle of movement (η κινουσα αρχη/hê kinousa arkhê) and the spirit principle (ψιχικης αρχης/psykhikês arkhês). The disprovability of classical abiogenesis is no longer controversial among professional biologists, while modern abiogenesis is an active area of ​​research (the most widely accepted hypothesis today is the RNA-World Hypothesis). Generatio Spontanea aka classical abiogenesis was first thoroughly formulated by Aristotle. In his book, Historia Animalium, Aristotle states: "Now there is one characteristic of animals which turns out to be the same as that of plants. For some plants are produced by plant seeds, while other plants arise independently from the formation of an elemental principle resembling a seed; and plants of this second kind too some absorb nutrients from the soil and some grow inside other plants as described in my treaty on Botany. So there are also animals that are born from a parent animal of the same kind, while others grow spontaneously and not from creatures of the same type." and gives an example in the book: "Eels are not produced through intercourse, nor are they oviparous. Never have any eel caught that has sperm or egg fluids; it has never been found that eels have ducts or oviparous ducts. In fact, all types of living things bleed it is neither produced by intercourse nor by laying eggs. This is absolutely made clear by the following: in certain swamps, after all the water is removed and the mud is drained, the eels reappear after rains." Until the 19th century many scientists as well as the ancient Greeks believed that living matter could spontaneously arise from nonliving matter – a process called spontaneous generation.

Species or type is a taxonomic rank used in biological classification to refer to one or several groups of living organisms (populations) that are similar and can fertilize one another in their group (gene sharing) so as to produce fertile offspring (fertile). . A number of groups within a species may not fertilize each other due to geographical barriers but if they are met and mated they can produce fertile offspring. If two different species fertilize each other, they will face the problem of biological inhibition; if it produces healthy offspring, these offspring are usually sterile or sterile. In some cases, this definition is not met, so that the problem of defining the species arises. In these cases, the parameters often used to define species differ, such as DNA similarity, morphology, or ecological niche. Furthermore, the emergence of certain distinctive features can divide species into smaller taxa, such as subspecies. Species that are hypothesized to have a common ancestor are placed in a single genus. Species similarity is assessed based on a comparison of physical attributes and if available, their DNA sequences. All species (except viruses) are given a name in two parts, called the "binomial name", or simply "binomial". The first part of the binomial is the generic name, which is the genus of the species. The second part is called the specific name (a term used only in zoology) or the specific epithet (a term used in botany, which can also be used in zoology). For example, the Boa constrictor is one of four species in the genus Boa. Genus names start with a capital letter, while specific epithets do not. Binomials are italicized when printed and underlined when handwritten. Species, when referred to in scientific names, abbreviated as sp.

(Example Phalaenopsis sp.—means "a kind of Phalaenopsis", shortened by spp. in the plural). A usable definition of the word "species" and reliable methods for identifying specific species are important for stating and testing biological theories and measuring biodiversity, although other taxonomic levels, such as family (tribe), can also be used. considered in larger-scale studies. Extinct species are known only from fossils where it is usually difficult to determine the exact taxonomic level, so higher taxonomic levels, such as family, are often used for fossil-based studies. In animal taxonomy there is one taxon level under species: subspecies (abbreviated as ssp. (but usually not written in the animal's scientific name). In plant, fungal, and bacterial taxonomy there are other taxa under subspecies: varieties, subvarieties, and forms. Total the total non-bacterial and non-archaean species in the world has been estimated at 8.7 million, with previous estimates ranging from two to one hundred million.Most modern textbooks use Ernst Mayr's 1942 definition, known as The Concept of Biological Species as a basis for discussion more on the definition of a species. This is also called the concept of reproduction or isolation. Mayr defines a species as a group of natural populations that are actually or potentially interbreeding, reproductively isolated from other such groups. Scientists have argued that this definition is a consequence of the effects of sexual reproduction on the dynamics of natural selection. The use of the adjective "berpo tension" by Mayr has been a subject of debate; some interpretations exclude unusual or artificial matings that occur only in captivity, or which involve animals that are capable of mating but usually do not do so in the wild. In the earliest works of science, a species was simply an individual organism representing a group of similar or nearly identical organisms.

Tripiṭaka (Pali: Tipiṭaka; Sanskrit: Tripiṭaka) is the term used by Buddhism to describe their various canonical texts. In accordance with the meaning of the term, Tripiṭaka originally meant "three baskets" or "three groups" of teachings: Sūtra Piṭaka (Sanskrit; Pali: Sutta Pitaka), Vinaya Piṭaka (Sanskrit & Pali) and Abhidharma Piṭaka (Sanskrit; Pali: Abhidhamma Piṭaka ). The Sutta Pitaka contains Buddhist discourses for 45 years expounding the Dharma totaling 84,000 suttas. The Vinaya Pitaka contains Bhikkhu/ni rules, while the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the philosophy and metaphysics of Buddhism. A few weeks after the Buddha's death (483 BC) an old, undisciplined monk named Subhaddha said: "Don't be sad, friends, don't weep, now we are free from the Great Ascetic who will no longer tell us what is appropriate to do and what to do. no, that made our lives miserable, but now we can do whatever we like and not do what we don't like" (Vinaya Pitaka II,284). Thera Maha Kassapa upon hearing these words decided to convene a great Council (Council) at Rajagaha. With the help of King Ajatasattu of Magadha, 500 Arahants gathered at the Sattapanni Cave near Rajagaha to collect the teachings of the Buddha that had been preached so far and arrange them in a systematic way. Venerable Ananda, the Buddha's closest disciple, had the honor of repeating the Buddha's discourses and Venerable Upali recited the Vinaya (rules). It was in this First Great Assembly that all the teachings that are now known as the Tipitaka (Pali) Scriptures were collected. Those who follow the teachings of the Buddha as mentioned in the Tipitaka (Pali) Scriptures are called the Preservers for the Purity of the Teachings as the last words of the Buddha: "Take Dhamma and Vinaya as a lamp and protector for yourself".

At first the Tipitaka (Pali) was passed down orally from one generation to the next. A century later there was a group of monks who wanted to change the Vinaya. Faced with this endeavor, monks who wanted to defend the Dhamma - Vinaya as handed down by Lord Buddha Gotama organized the Second Great Council with the assistance of King Kalasoka at Vesali, where the contents of the Tipitaka (Pali) Scriptures were recited by 700 Arahants. This group of monks who adhered to the purity of the Dhamma - Vinaya called themselves the Sthaviravada, who would later be called Theravada. Meanwhile, a group of monks who wanted to change the Vinaya called themselves the Mahasanghika, which later developed into the Mahayana school. Thus, a century after the death of the Buddha Gotama, Buddhism split into the two major schools of Theravada and Mahayana. The Third Great Council was held in Pattaliputta (Patna) in the third century after the Buddha's death (249 BC) under Emperor Asoka Wardhana. This emperor embraced Buddhism and with his influence helped spread the Dhamma throughout the empire. At that time, thousands of impostors (smugglers of dark teachings) entered the Sangha with the intention of propagating their own teachings to mislead the people. To put an end to this situation, the Emperor convened a Great Assembly and purged the Sangha of interlopers and planned to send Dhamma Ambassadors to other countries. In this Third Great Assembly 100 Arahants repeated their recitation of the Tipitaka (Pali) for nine months. It is from the starting point of this Community that Buddhism can spread to all corners of the world and avoid disappearing from the land of its origin. The Fourth Great Council was held at Aluvihara (Sri Lanka) under the patronage of King Vattamani Abhaya at the beginning of the sixth century after the death of the Buddha (83 BC).

TDK Corporation (Japanese: TDK株式会社, Hepburn: TDK Kabushiki-gaisha) is a Japanese multinational corporation that manufactures electronic materials, electronic components, and data storage media and recordings. The company's motto is "contributing to culture and industry through creativity". "TDK" stands for Tokyo Denki Kagaku Kōgyō K.K. The company is listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and is a component of the Nikkei 225 and TOPIX indices. TDK was founded in Tokyo, Japan, on December 7, 1935 to produce an iron-based magnetic material, namely ferrite, which was recently invented by Yogoro Kato and Takeshi Takei. In 1952 and 1957, the company began producing magnetic tape, and then began producing compact cassette tapes in 1966. TDK produced a wide variety of optical and magnetic media, including a number of videocassette formats as well as blank CD-R and recordable DVD discs, to a business recordings were sold to Imation in 2007. TDK produced five million ferrite cores during 1945, which were primarily used to reduce the volume and weight of radios used by the Imperial Japanese military. In 1965, the company expanded into the United States, opening an office in New York City, and expanded into Europe in 1970, opening an office in Frankfurt, West Germany. In the 1980s, TDK developed a multilayer technology for producing chip capacitors and inductors used in computers, laptops, smartphones, and other electronic devices. In 1986, TDK acquired SAE Magnetics and introduced high-density recording heads. In the 1990s, TDK's mass storage division produced commutator-less direct-current electric motors, magnetoresistance (MR) heads, and thin-film heads.

Since 1997, TDK has slowly stopped producing cassettes. Initially stopped producing MA-X and AR (Acoustic Response), then stopped producing AD (Acoustic Dynamic) and SA-X in 2001 and 2002 respectively, then stopped producing MA (Metal Alloy) in 2004. Production of SA (Super Avilyn) and D (Dynamic) were discontinued in 2011. Even this company shifted to new media. In 2004, TDK became the first media producer to join the company developing post-DVD BD technology. TDK also owned a semiconductor division in California for about a decade, but it was sold in 2005. In late 2007, Imation acquired the sales and marketing operations of TDK's recording media, including flash media, optical media, magnetic tape, and accessories. , priced at $300 million. The acquisition includes a license to use the "TDK Life on Record" brand on data storage and audio products for 25 years. In September 2015, Imation announced that it had agreed to terminate the license and would stop selling TDK products by the end of 2015. Since the 2000s, TDK has focused on the development, manufacture, and sale of electronic components, HDD heads and suspensions, and power supply. Starting in 2005, TDK acquired a number of electronic device manufacturers, including passive component developers, sensor manufacturers, and power supply manufacturers. Since acquiring the companies, TDK has begun producing a wide range of sensors, actuators and power electronics components, including multi-axis MEMS motion tracking devices and MEMS microphones from InvenSense, point-of-load DC-DC converters from Faraday Semi, and time of flight sensors. MEMS-based ultrasonics from Chirp Microsystems for use in consumer electronics, AR/VR, robots, drones, IoT, automotive and industrial.

Marapu is an indigenous religion of the archipelago that is adhered to by the people on the island of Sumba and is also the name of an organization of adherents of the faith which was registered in 1982. More than half of the population of Sumba adheres to this belief. This religion has a belief in the worship of ancestors and ancestors. Followers of the Marapu religion believe that life in this world is only temporary and that after the end of time they will live eternally in the spirit world, namely in the Marapu heaven known as Prai Marapu. Marapu religious ceremonies such as death ceremonies and so on are always accompanied by the slaughter of animals such as buffalo and horses as sacrifices. This has become a hereditary tradition that continues to be maintained on the island of Sumba. The Sumbanese believe that the spirits of their ancestors attend burial ceremonies and therefore animals are offered to them. Animal spirits for the spirits of ancestors and the flesh or corpses of animals eaten by living people. As with other ceremonies, Kebamoto, 2015] and Marapu are highly defended by most Sumba people. This religion is a belief system based on the worship of ancestral spirits. In the Sumba language, the ancestral spirits are called Marapu which means "the lord" or "the exalted one". That is why the religion they profess is also called Marapu. In Marapu religious beliefs, the spirit is placed as the most important component because it is this spirit that must return to Mawulu Tau-Majii Tau. The spirit of a dead person will become an inhabitant of Parai Marapu (land of spirits, heaven) and be glorified as Marapu if during his life on earth he fulfills all the nuku-hara (laws and procedures) set by the ancestors.

According to belief, there are two kinds of spirits, namely hamangu (soul, spirit) and ndiawa or ndewa (holy spirit, god). Hamangu is the human spirit during his lifetime which becomes his core and source of strength. It is thanks to the hamangu that humans can think, feel and act. Hamangu will grow stronger in the growth of life, and become weak when humans are sick and old. Hamangu who has left the human body will become a spirit with its own personality and is called ndiawa''. Ndiawa also exists in all living things, including animals and plants, which later become the inhabitants of Parai Marapu too. Marapu are imagined as noble beings who have thoughts, feelings, and personalities like humans, but with superior intelligence and qualities. They can be both male and female as well as in pairs as husband and wife. Their descendants inhabit the earth and are considered the ancestors who became the forerunners of kabihu-kabihu. Hierarchically, the Marapu can be divided into two groups, namely Marapu and Marapu Ratu. Marapu are ancestral spirits who are deified and are considered to be the forerunners of a kabihu (extended family, clan), while Marapu Ratu is a marapu who is considered to have descended from the sky and is the ancestor of the other marapu, so it is a marapu who has the highest position. Each kabihu has its own marapu which is worshiped so that all their prayers and wishes are conveyed to the Supreme Creator. The marapu are celebrated and worshiped in homes, especially in big houses or centers called uma bokulu or uma bungguru (fellowship house). Inside the house was conducted religious ceremonies involving the interests of all citizens kabihu, eg birth ceremonies, marriage, death, planting, harvest and so on. Although there are many Marapu who are worshiped and are often asked for help, the main purpose of the worship ceremony is not solely to the spirits of the ancestors themselves, but to Mawulu Tau-Majii Tau (Creator and Maker of Humans) or God Almighty.

London (English: -/ˈlʌndən/ ( listen)) is the capital city of England and the United Kingdom, and is the largest metropolitan area in the United Kingdom.note 1] Located along the River Thames, London has been a major settlement for two millennia since its founding by the Romans in the 1st century under the name Londinium. The center of old London, the City of London, has largely retained its medieval boundaries. Since the 19th century, the name London has also been used to refer to the metropolis that developed around this center. The conurbation of these urban areas eventually formed the London Region and the administrative area of ​​Greater London. This area is governed and supervised by the mayor of London and the London Assembly who are elected by general election. London is a leading global city that excels in the arts, business, education, entertainment, fashion, finance, healthcare, media, professional services, research and development, tourism and transport. London, together with New York City, is a leading financial center in the world, and is the city with the fifth largest GDP in the world, or the highest in Europe. This city is said to be the cultural center of the world. London is also the most visited city, and is listed as the city with the busiest airport in the world based on international passenger traffic. London's 43 universities form the largest concentration of higher education in Europe. In 2012, London became the first city to host the modern Summer Olympics three times. London is made up of diverse peoples and cultures with more than 300 languages ​​spoken by various ethnicities. In March 2011, London had a population of 8,174,100, or about 12.5% ​​of the UK's population as a whole.

This makes London the largest city in the European Union by population. The Greater London urban area is also the second largest urban area (after Paris) in the European Union with a population of 8,278,251 people, while the London metropolitan area is the largest in the European Union with an estimated population of 12 to 14 million people. Previously, London was also the city with the largest population in the world in the period 1831-1925. London has four World Heritage Sites, namely: the Tower of London; Kew Botanical Gardens; a complex of historic sites consisting of the Palace of Westminster, Westminster Abbey and St. Margaret; and the historic settlement of Greenwich (where the Royal Observatory marks the prime meridian, 0° longitude, and GMT). Other famous London landmarks include Buckingham Palace, London Eye, St Paul's Cathedral, Piccadilly Circus, Tower Bridge, Wembley Stadium, London Bridge and Trafalgar Square. London is also home to numerous museums, galleries, libraries, sporting events and other cultural institutions, including the British Museum, National Maritime Museum, British Library, National Gallery, Tate Modern, Wimbledon and 40 West End Theatres. The London Underground is the oldest underground rail network in the world, and the second largest after the Shanghai Metro. The origin of the name London is not certain. It is a very ancient name and can be found in sources dating from the early 2nd century. London's name is recorded around 121 AD as Londinium which was given by the rulers of Roman Britain. The earliest explanation for London's origins, although this explanation is currently ignored, is provided by Geoffrey of Monmouth in Historia Regum Britanniae. There it is explained that the name London was coined by King Lud who supposedly conquered this city and named it Kaerlud.

Dr. ing. h.c. F. Porsche AG, better known as Porsche AG (German pronunciation: ˈpɔʁʃə] ( listen)), is a German automaker specializing in the production of sports cars, SUVs and sedans. Porsche AG is headquartered in Stuttgart, and is a subsidiary of Volkswagen AG, which is also a subsidiary of Porsche Automobil Holding SE. Porsche production cars include the Porsche 911, Porsche Boxster, Porsche Cayman, Porsche Panamera, Porsche Cayenne, Porsche Macan, and Porsche 918. Austrian engineer, Ferdinand Porsche founded "Dr. Ing. h. c. F. Porsche GmbH" in Austria in 1931 , and then moved its headquarters to downtown Stuttgart. Initially, the company was engaged in car development and engineering consulting, and did not assemble cars under its own name. One of the company's first assignments, came from the German government who wanted to produce people's car nicknamed "Volkswagen". This company later produced the Volkswagen Beetle, which is one of the most successful car designs in history. The Porsche 64 which was developed in 1939 also uses many components from the Beetle. During World War II, Volkswagen production shifted to military versions, called the Kübelwagen, and the Schwimmwagen. Porsche was also appointed to develop the Panzer VI Tiger(P) heavy tank design but lost to Henschel & Son's design. However, this design was later used by Porsche to design the tank destroyer, Elefant. Porsche also developed the Panzer VIII Maus tank in the late war period. At the end of World War II in 1945, the Volkswagen factory at KdF-Stadt fell to the British. Ferdinand also lost his Director position, and Ivan Hirst, a Major in the British Army, was assigned to lead Porsche.

On December 15, 1945, Ferdinand was jailed, and his son, Ferry Porsche, decided to build his own car, as he could not find one that suited his taste. He also had to lead the company until his father was released in August 1947. Porsche's first car was the Porsche 356 which was assembled in Gmünd, Austria. This car then began to be mass produced by Porsche Konstruktionen GesmbH, which was founded by Ferry and Louise Piëch. After being taken over by his father in 1950, Porsche also appointed Reutter Karosserie, to manufacture the car frame. In 1952, Porsche also built a new factory near the Reutter Karosserie factory. In the post-war period, many auto parts were not available, so the Porsche 356 used many components from the Volkswagen Beetle, such as for the transmission and suspension. Later, however, these parts began to be produced by Porsche themselves. The car body was also specially designed by Erwin Komenda, who also designed the Beetle car body. In 1964, after winning quite a number of racing championships, Porsche launched the Porsche 911, as a replacement for the Porsche 365. The Porsche 911 is currently Porsche's most famous product, and is very successful in various racing events. The Porsche 911 is also still being produced today. In 1972, Porsche's business form changed from its initial one. Kommanditgesellschaft (KG), became Aktiengesellschaft (AG), because Ferry Porsche believes that this company has grown far from being just a family company, after he learned from the founder of Honda, Soichiro Honda, who applied the philosophy of no family members in the company. at the company). This also led to the creation of a Board of Directors with members from outside the Porsche family, and a Supervisory Board made up of members of the Porsche family.

Tai or faeces or in crude language it is called feces, feces, or excrement is a waste product of the digestive tract that is excreted through the anus or cloaca. In humans, the process of defecation can occur (depending on the individual and conditions) between once every one or two days to several times a day. Hardening of feces can cause an increase in the time and a decrease in the frequency of defecation between discharge or disposal, which is called constipation or constipation. And conversely, if the hardening of feces is disturbed, it causes a decrease in the time and an increase in the frequency of defecation, which is called diarrhea or diarrhea. The characteristic odor of feces is caused by bacterial activity. The bacteria produce compounds such as indole, skatole, and thiols (compounds containing sulfur), as well as hydrogen sulfide gas. Food intake in the form of spices can add to the distinctive smell of tai. There are also several commercial products on the market that can reduce the smell of excrement. Frequency of bowel movements Depending on the individual and their condition, humans may have several bowel movements a day, every other day, or once every two or three days. Extensive hardening of the stool that disrupts this routine for several days or more is called constipation. The appearance of human feces varies according to diet and health. Usually it is semi-solid, with a slime layer. The combination of bile and bilirubin, which comes from dead red blood cells, gives stool its characteristic brown color. After meconium, the first stool is excreted, the newborn's stool contains only bile, which gives it a yellow-green color. Breast-fed babies secrete a soft, pale yellowish substance that does not smell bad; but once the baby begins to eat, and the body begins to excrete bilirubin from the dead red blood cells, this matter acquires the familiar brown color.

In chemistry, protonation is the addition of a proton (H+) to an atom, molecule, or ion, producing a conjugate acid. Examples include: Protonation is the process of adding a hydrogen cation (H+ ion) to a compound, generally a nucleophile, because H+ ions are electrophiles. Protonation is a very basic chemical reaction and is a step in many catalytic and stoichiometric processes. Some ions and molecules can undergo more than one protonation and be labeled as polybasic, which is common with many biological macromolecules. Protonation and deprotonation (removal of protons) occur in most acid-base reactions; they are the essence of most theories of acid-base reactions. A Brønsted–Lowry acid is defined as a chemical substance that protonates another substance. Upon protonation of the substrate, the mass and charge of the species increase by one unit each, making it an important step in several analytical procedures such as electron burst mass spectrometry. The protonation and deprotonation of a molecule or ion can change many other chemical properties, not just mass and charge, such as changes in their hydrophilicity, reduction potential, and optical properties. Protonation is sometimes fast, partly due to the fast mobility of protons in many solvents. The rate of protonation is closely related to the acidity of the protonating species: protonation by a weak acid is slower than protonation of the same base by a strong acid. The rates of protonation and deprotonation can be very slow when protonation triggers significant structural changes. Protonation is usually reversible, and the structure and binding of the conjugate base usually do not change with respect to protonation. In some cases, however, protonation leads to isomerization, for example a cis-alkene can be converted to a trans-alkene using a certain amount of a catalytic protonating agent. Many enzymes, such as serine hydrolases, operate by mechanisms that involve alternating protonation of substrates.
