Iddah (Arabic: masa عدة; "waiting time") in Islam is a period in which a woman who has been divorced by her husband, either because his husband died or because he was divorced while his husband was alive, to wait and refrain from marrying a man other. Her goal is to maintain her husband's blood relationship. It is feared that a woman will become pregnant when she is about to remarry, so that her child will become the son of the man she married. Except for women who are 35 years and over and cannot get pregnant anymore, these women do not have an iddah period. A woman who is in her iddah period is called a mu'taddah. Iddah itself is divided into 2, namely women whose husbands have died (mutawaffa 'anha) and women who have not been left by their husbands (ghair mutawaffa 'anha). Iddah is required to ascertain whether the woman's uterus is pregnant or not, this is the reason why a woman has to wait within a predetermined period. If she marries during the iddah period, while we don't know whether the woman is pregnant or not and it turns out she is pregnant, a question will arise "Who is the father of this child?" and when the child is born, it is called "a child of doubt", that is, a child whose father is not clear and if the child is a woman then she is illegitimate, because she was not married off by her guardian. Iddah is obligatory for a wife who is divorced by her husband. As has been explained that a woman is pregnant or not. This iddah obligation can also be seen based on the words of the Prophet Muhammad to Fatimah bint Qais: "Be at the house of Ibn Ummi Maktum". A woman who is in her iddah period is still the responsibility of her husband, not the responsibility of the blood or blood family of the woman, unless separated by the blood or blood family of the wife.

Alkaloids are a class of nitrogenous base compounds that are mostly heterocyclic and occur in plants (but this does not exclude compounds of animal origin). Amino acids, peptides, proteins, nucleotides, nucleic acids, amino sugars and antibiotics are not usually classified as alkaloids. And with the same principle, neutral compounds that are biogenetically related to alkaloids are included in this group. Alkaloids are usually classified according to the similarity of their molecular origins (precursors), based on the metabolic pathway used to form the molecule. If the biosynthesis of an alkaloid is unknown, alkaloids are classified according to the name of the compound, including the name of the compound that does not contain nitrogen (because the molecular structure is present in the final product. for example: opium alkaloids are sometimes called "phenanthrenes"), or according to the name of the plant or animal in which the compound is isolated. If after the alkaloids have been studied, the classification of an alkaloid is changed according to the results of the study, usually taking the name of the biologically important amine that is prominent in the process of its synthesis. Alkaloids are produced by many organisms, ranging from bacteria, fungi (mushrooms), plants and animals. Coarse extraction is usually easily accomplished by acid-base extraction techniques. The bitter or bitter taste that the tongue feels can be caused by alkaloids. One example of an alkaloid plant Archived 2014-11-01 at the Wayback Machine. is papaya which is a producer of papain. The term "alkaloid" (meaning "alkaline-like", because it is considered alkaline) was first used by Carl Friedrich Wilhelm Meissner (1819), a pharmacist from Halle (Germany) to refer to various compounds obtained from plant extraction which were alkaline (at the time it is well known, for example, morphine, striknina, and solanine). Until now there are about 10,000 compounds classified as alkaloids with very diverse structures, so that until now there are no clear boundaries for them.

The European Space Agency ( pronunciation (help·info)) (ESA; French: Agence spatiale européenne, ASE; German: Europäische Weltraumorganisation) is an intergovernmental organization with 22 member countries dedicated to space exploration activities. Founded in 1975, ESA is currently headquartered in Paris and employs approximately 2,200 staff worldwide as of 2018. In 2020, ESA received an annual budget of €6.68 billion (~US$7.43 billion). The ESA's spaceflight program includes manned spaceflight (mainly through participation in the International Space Station program); launch and operation of unmanned exploratory missions to other planets and the Moon; earth observation, science, and telecommunication activities; designing launch vehicles; and operate their main spaceport—the Guyana Space Center in Kourou, French Guiana. Europe's main launch vehicle, Ariane 5, is operated via Arianespace. The agency is also working with NASA to manufacture the Orion spacecraft service module that will fly with the Space Launch System. The facilities owned by this space agency are spread across the following space centers: Other national ESA As of 2015, ESA is an intergovernmental organization with 22 member countries. Member countries participate to varying degrees in mandatory (25% of total spending in 2008) and optional space programs (75% of total spending in 2008). The 2008 budget amounted to € 3.0 billion the 2009 budget to € 3.6 billion. The total budget amounted to around € 3.7 billion in 2010, € 3.99 billion in 2011, € 4.02 billion in 2012, € 4.28 billion in 2013, € 4.10 billion in 2014 and € 4.33 billion in 2015. English and French are the official languages ​​of the ESA.

In addition, official documents are also provided in German and documents regarding Spacelab are also provided in Italian. If deemed appropriate, the agency may carry out correspondence in any language of the member country. Currently the only member state of the association is Slovenia. Previously, Austria, Norway and Finland were members of the association before all of these countries joined the ESA as full members. Since January 1, 1979, Canada has special status as an ESA Cooperating Country. Pursuant to this agreement, the Canadian Space Agency takes part in the deliberative and decision-making bodies of the ESA as well as in the programs and activities of the ESA. Canadian companies can bid and accept contracts to work on a program. ESA has a fleet of launch vehicles that have different target markets. ESA's fleet consists of three main rocket designs: Ariane 5, Soyuz-2 and Vega. The rocket launch was carried out by Arianespace, which produced Ariane 5 with CNES at the Guiana Space Center. Because many communications satellites have equatorial orbits, rockets launching from French Guiana are capable of carrying a heavier payload into space than rockets launching from higher latitudes. In addition, an equatorial launch gives the spacecraft an extra 'boost' of almost 500 m/s due to the higher rotational speed of the earth at the equator compared to near the poles of the earth where the rotational speed is close to zero. The Ariane 5 rocket is ESA's primary launch vehicle. This rocket has been in service since 1997, replacing the Ariane 4. There are two variants of the Ariane 5 rocket in operation today. The strongest and most frequently used version, the Ariane 5 ECA, is capable of transporting two communications satellites weighing up to 10 tons to the GTO.

The egg is an organic vessel containing a zygote in which the embryo develops until it can survive on its own, at which time the animal hatches. Eggs are produced from the fertilization of the egg cell. Most arthropods, vertebrates (excluding currently living mammals), and molluscs lay eggs, although some, such as scorpions, do not lay eggs. Reptile eggs, bird eggs, and monotreme eggs are laid outside the water and surrounded by a protective shell, either flexible or inflexible. Eggs laid on land or in nests are usually kept in a warm, favorable temperature range while the embryos grow. When the embryo is sufficiently developed, it hatches, that is, comes out of the eggshell. Some embryos have temporary egg teeth which they use to crack, damage, or peel off the shell or covering of the egg. The largest recorded egg came from a whale shark and measured 30 cm × 14 cm × 9 cm (11.8 inches × 5.5 inches × 3.5 inches). Whale shark eggs usually hatch inside the mother. Weighing 1.5 kg (3.3 lb) and up to 17.8 cm × 14 cm (7.0 in × 5.5 in), the ostrich egg is the largest egg of any living bird, although the elephant bird which has been became extinct and some non-avian dinosaurs had larger eggs. The bee hummingbird produces the smallest known bird egg, which weighs half a gram (about 0.02 oz). Some of the eggs laid by reptiles and most fish, amphibians, insects and other invertebrates can be even smaller. Reproductive structures similar to eggs in other kingdoms are called "spores", or in spermatophytes "seeds", or in gametophytes "egg cells". This biology-related article is a stub.

Fiqh (Arabic: فقه, translit. fiqh‎ fɪqh]) is Islamic jurisprudence. Fiqh is defined as human understanding of worship practices based on Sharia, which is mentioned in the Qur'an and Sunnah (practices exemplified by the Islamic prophet Muhammad and his companions). Fiqh became the foundation of Sharia through the interpretation (ijtihad) of the Qur'an and Sunnah by scholars and implemented into a fatwa of scholars. Therefore, sharia is considered unchanging and perfect by Muslims, while jurisprudence can be changed at any time. Fiqh is related to the observance of rituals, morals, and social norms in Islam as well as the political system. In the modern era, there are four sects in Sunni, plus two or three sects in Shia. People who master the science of jurisprudence are called faqīh (plural fuqaha). In general, jurisprudence means knowledge of Islamic laws based on its sources. Descending the sources of Islamic law requires the method of ijtihad performed by a mujtahid to obtain a more detailed understanding related to Islamic laws. A faqīh must see and understand deeply all the problems and not be satisfied with the written meaning only, and a person who only understands the law without knowing the essence of the law does not meet the requirements as a faqīh. The study of jurisprudence is generally divided into uṣūl al-fiqh (methods of interpretation and analysis of jurisprudence sources); as well as furūʿ al-fiqh (branches of fiqh with that foundation). Furūʿ al-fiqh is the fruit of uṣūl al-fiqh. Hukm (plural form aḥkām) is a decision made for a specific case. Some jurists divide 4 main discussions, namely; rubu' worship, rubu' mu'amalat, rubu munakahat, and rubu crime. However, some other jurists divide the discussion of jurisprudence into two aspects only, namely ru'bu ibadat and ru'bu mu'amalat. Fiqh fiqh literally means a correct understanding of what is expected.

The following hadith uses the word fiqh according to the meaning of the language. “Whoever Allah wills to be good, Allah will make him religious. I am only the one who distributes while Allah is the one who gives. And this people will always stand on God's commands, they will not be harmed because of people who disagree with them until God's decision comes. Fiqh is the mashdar of chapter فقِهَ يفقَهُ faqiha - yafqahu, which means "understanding". فقُهَ faquha (with qaf having the vowel dhammah) means that fiqh becomes its nature. فقَهَ faqaha (with fathah) means understanding before others. In terms, fiqh means معرفة بالأحكام الشرعية العملية بأدلتها التفصيلية "knowledge of practical Shari'a laws based on detailed arguments." What is meant by معرفة "knowledge" includes exact science and conjecture. Some of the Shari'a laws are known with certainty from convincing evidence and some are known presumptuously. The issues of ijtihad which are the subject of differences of opinion among scholars are a matter of conjecture because if it is known with certainty, then there will definitely be no difference of opinion. What is meant by الأحكام الشرعية "shari'a laws" are as obligatory and unlawful. Fiqh does not address the laws of logic, such as "all is greater than some," nor the laws of nature, such as the falling of dew at the end of a clear summer night. What is meant by العملية "practical (law)," fiqh does not discuss matters of belief. The teachings of faith are discussed in the science of aqidah. Scholars call it الفقه الأكبر al-fiqh al-akbar “the great Jurisprudence.” Therefore, the hadith of the Prophet "Whoever Allah wills to be good, Allah permits him to religion" includes the science of jurisprudence and the science of aqidah. What is meant by بأدلتها التفصيلية "based on detailed arguments" is an argument that is directly related to a practice.

Pantheism is the belief that the universe is a manifestation of a god, or that everything is an immanent all-embracing god, god or goddess. Pantheistic beliefs do not recognize the existence of a specific personal god, whether anthropomorphic or not. However, pantheism is characterized by various doctrines in terms of the relationship between reality and divinity. The concept of pantheistic has existed for thousands of years, and pantheistic elements have been recognized in various religious traditions. The term pantheism was coined by the mathematician Joseph Raphson in 1697, and since then has been used to describe the beliefs of various people and organizations. Pantheism was popularized in Western culture as a theological and philosophical view based on the book by 17th century philosopher Baruch Spinoza, "Ethics". The pantheistic attitude was also shared by the philosopher and cosmologist Giordano Bruno in the 16th century. Pantheistic ideas are found in the religions of South and East Asia (especially Sikhism, Hinduism, Sanamahism, Confucianism, and Taoism) and in Sufism (Sufism) within Islam. The term pantheism comes from the Greek words pan (meaning "all, everything") and theos (meaning "god, divine"). The first known combination of this etymological explanation appears in Latin, in Joseph Raphson's 1697 book, "De Spatio Reali seu Ente Infinito". In the book, he refers to the "pantheism" views of Spinoza and other thinkers. There are many definitions of pantheism. Some scholars consider it a theological and philosophical position about God. :p.8 Pantheism is the view that everything is part of God who is immanent and includes everything. All forms of reality can then be considered as part of that Being, or identical with Him. Some argue that pantheism is a non-religious philosophical position.

For them, pantheism is the view that the Universe (in the sense of the totality of all existence) and God are the same thing. The idea of ​​pantheism can be found in the ancient Greek religious theology of Orphism, that pan (everything) was made to have much in common with the creator god Phanes (symbolizing the universe), and with Zeus. Pantheistic tendencies were also present in some early Gnostic groups, with pantheistic thought appearing throughout the Middle Ages. Pantheist views were also part of the work of Johannes Scotus Eriugena, De divisione naturae, in the 9th century and mystical beliefs as expressed by Amalric of Bena (11th – 12th century) and Eckhart (12th – 13th century) .:pp. 620–621 The Catholic Church has long considered pantheistic views to be heretical. Giordano Bruno, an Italian monk who propagated the teachings of a transcendent and infinite God, died at a burning stake in 1600 by the Roman Inquisition. Since then, he has been known as a renowned pantheist and martyr of science. In the West, pantheism was formalized as a separate theology and philosophy based on the work of the 17th century philosopher Baruch Spinoza. :p.7 Spinoza was a Dutch philosopher of Portuguese descent who was raised in the Sephardi Jewish community in Amsterdam. He developed highly controversial ideas regarding the authenticity of the Hebrew Bible and the nature of the Divine. As a result, he was expelled from Jewish society at the age of 23, when the local synagogue issued a herem against him. A number of his books were published posthumously, and soon they were included in the Catholic Church's Index of Prohibited Books. The importance of Spinoza's work was only recognized over the years, by laying the groundwork for the 18th century Enlightenment and modern biblical criticism, including modern conceptions of the self and the universe. In his posthumously published Ethics, "Spinoza wrote the last undisputed masterpiece of the Latin language, and a pure conception of medieval philosophy that ultimately turned against them and destroyed them."

Anaxagoras is one of the philosophers from the school of pluralism. Another philosopher belonging to this school was Empedocles. Anaxagoras, like Empedocles, taught that the reality of the universe is derived from many principles. Anaxagoras was a contemporary of Empedocles as well as of early atomist philosophers, such as Leucippus and Democritus. Anaxagoras is known to have authored one book in prose. However, only a few fragments of the first part have survived. Anaxagoras (500-428 BC) was born in the city of Clazomenai, Ionia, Asia Minor, around 500 BC. In 480 BC, Anaxagoras left his hometown and settled in Athens. He lived in Athens for about 50 years. Thus Anaxagoras became the first philosopher to work in Athens, which would later become the center of Greek philosophy. In Athens Anaxagoras befriended Pericles, a well-known politician in Athens. In addition, it is also said that Euripides, the famous playwright of Greek literature, was a student of Anaxagoras. When Pericles was old, his enemies succeeded in slandering Anaxagoras with apostasy and Anaxagoras was threatened with death. It seems that Anaxagoras was slandered because he considered the sun and moon not to be gods but purely material things. With Pericles' help, he was released from prison and fled to the city of Lampsacus. Anaxagoras is said to have died there at the age of 72. Anaxagoras, like Empedocles, stated that the basic principles that make up the universe are not single, but they differ in number. Empedocles stated that there are only 4 substances that are the principles of the universe, while Anaxagoras stated that the number of these principles is infinite. These substances he called "seeds" (spermata). According to Anaxagoras, every thing, in fact all the realities in the universe, are composed of a mixture which contains all the seeds in a certain amount.

The human senses cannot perceive all the seeds in an object, but only the dominant seeds. For example, if a person sees gold, then he can immediately recognize it as gold, because the dominant seed in the object is the gold seed. However, in reality, in addition to gold seeds, the thing also has copper, silver, iron, etc. seeds. It's just that all those seeds are not dominant so they are not captured by human senses. The argument that Anaxagoras shows is through the human body. In the human body there are various elements, such as flesh, nails, blood, hair, and so on. How can hair and nails grow, when humans do not eat hair or nails? The solution given by Anaxagoras is because in the food there are seeds of hair, nails, meat, and all other elements. If Empedocles states that there are two principles that cause changes from basic substances, namely "love" and "hate", then Anaxagoras states that there is only one principle that causes changes from those seeds, namely nous. Nous means "spirit" or "ratio". It is not mixed with the seeds and separated from all things, but becomes the principle that regulates everything. It is still a matter of debate whether the nous he means is material or not, because Anaxagoras said that nous is the most refined and purest element of everything that exists. However, it is clear that Anaxagoras was the first philosopher to establish the independence of spirit or ratio over all substances or matter. Anaxagoras' teaching about the universe is similar to the first philosophers from Ionia, especially Anaximenes. Anaxagoras thinks that the bodies of the universe consist of rocks that glow due to the high speed of the whirlwind that moves them.

Interpretation according to language is an explanation or description, as can be understood from the Quran S. Al-Furqan: 33. Interpreted utterances mean firm and clear utterances. In interpreting the Koran, there is the way of Ibn Taimiyyah which is quoted by Buya Hamka in his Tafsir al-Azhar. First verse by verse, if in doubt about the meaning of a verse, connect it with other verses. Buya Hamka took the example of Surah Thaha verse 67 and detailed it with Surat al-A'raf verse 116 so that mujmal (or general) verses are detailed with other mufashshal (or detailed) verses. After that, the verse is interpreted with the Sunnah, then with the interpretation of the Companions. If both are not found, then tabiin's opinion is used - and even then it must be filtered first, looking for which one is closest to the Quran and Sunnah. According to Buya Hamka in Tafsir al-Azhar, in interpreting the Koran, the main thing is to be based on the Sunnah, namely all the words (aqwal) and deeds (af'al) of the Prophet and the actions of other people —namely RA's companions — which were approved by him. That's why one should not interpret the Quran against the Sunnah. Because of that, people who interpret the Koran with legal verses are not guided by the Sunnah of the Prophet, so he is not guided by the Shari'a. Cannot be based on his own will. According to him, this is an exception for Quranic texts that do not need interpretation, because they are very clear, but meet ahad hadiths which are not well-known hadiths, while their contents contradict clear texts from the Quran. Apart from that, there is also an interpretation with reason, which according to Zamakhsyari scholars there is nothing wrong with interpreting with common sense. Interpreting in this way was also followed by Al-Ghazali, according to whom the existence of different interpretations between tabiin and companions was also an indication of interpretation by ra'yi or thought.

Because of that, according to him, interpreting the Koran cannot be purely rational, nor can it only rely on naqal or argument alone. For this reason, al-Qashthalani, the scholar who taught Shahih Bukhari, stated that it is permissible to interpret the Koran in a new way, provided that it conforms to the provisions of the Arabic language, and does not contradict the basic principles of religious teachings. Therefore, he mentions 4 conditions so that interpretation with reason is accepted: Interpretation in root comes from the word ف-س-ر (fa-sa-ra) or فَسَّرَ (fassara) which means بَيَنَ bayana (explains), and وضَّحَ waddhaha (explains ). In terms of terms, there are two definitions: According to terms, the notion of interpretation is the science that studies the contents of Allah's book revealed to the prophet ﷺ, along with an explanation of its meaning and wisdom. Some commentators argue that interpretation is the science that discusses the Koran al-Karim from the perspective of understanding God's intentions according to human ability. In simpler terms, interpretation is expressed as an explanation of something desired by the word. Interpretation can be divided into three types: Historical interpretation is often also referred to as naql interpretation or ma'tsur interpretation. This type of interpretation can be interpreted by interpreting verses of the Koran with other appropriate verses of the Koran, or interpreting verses of the Koran with texts from as-Sunnah. Because one of the functions of as-Sunnah is to interpret the Koran. Tafsir dirayah is also called bi ra'yi interpretation. Dirayah interpretation is by way of ijtihad which is based on valid arguments, pure and precise principles. Tafsir dirayah is not interpreting the Koran based on mere conscience or will, because this is prohibited based on the words of the prophet: "Anyone who deliberately lies on my behalf must be willing to put himself in hell, and anyone who interprets the Koran 'yunya (reason) then he should be willing to put himself in hell." (HR.

In physics, energy or also called power is a physical property of an object, it can be transferred through fundamental interactions, which can be changed in form but cannot be created or destroyed. The joule is the SI unit for energy, taken from the amount exerted on an object (through mechanical work) by moving it 1 meter with a force of 1 newton. Work and heat are 2 examples of processes or mechanisms that can transfer large amounts of energy. The second law of thermodynamics limits the amount of work that can be gained through the heating process—some of it is lost as wasted heat. The maximum amount that can be used for work is called available energy. Systems such as machines and living things need available energy, not just any energy. Mechanical energy and other forms of energy can be transferred directly to thermal energy without any restrictions. There are various forms of energy, but all of these types of energy must meet various conditions such as being able to be converted to other forms of energy, obeying the law of conservation of energy, and causing changes in the object of mass that is subjected to that energy. Common forms of energy include kinetic energy from moving objects, radiant energy from light and electromagnetic radiation, potential energy stored in an object due to its position such as gravitational fields, electric fields or magnetic fields, and heat energy which is composed of microscopic potential and kinetic energy. of the random particle motions. Some specific forms of potential energy are elastic energy caused by the elongation or deformation of solid objects and chemical energy such as the release of heat when fuel burns. Any object that has mass when at rest has rest mass or equal to rest energy, although this is not explained in the everyday phenomena of classical physics.

According to the mass-energy balance, all forms of energy require mass. For example, adding 25 kilowatt-hours (90 megajoules) of energy to an object increases its mass by 1 microgram; if there is a balance that is so sensitive then this increase in mass can be seen. The sun converts nuclear potential energy into other forms of energy; its total mass will change when energy is released around it, especially in the form of radiant energy. Although energy can change form, the law of the conservation of energy states that the total energy of a system changes only when energy is transferred into or out of the system. This means that it is impossible to create or destroy energy. The total energy of a system can be calculated by adding up all forms of energy in the system. Examples of energy transfer and transformation are the generation of electricity, chemical reactions, or raising objects. Living organisms also need available energy to stay alive; humans for example, need energy from food along with oxygen to metabolize it. Civilization needs a supply of energy for various activities; Energy sources such as fossil fuels are an important topic in economics and politics. Earth's climate and ecosystems are also powered by radiant energy obtained from the sun (as well as geothermal energy obtained from within the earth. The word energy comes from the Ancient Greek: ἐνέργεια, translit. energeia, lit. 'activity, operation', which probably first appeared in the work of Aristotle in the 4th century BC.In contrast to the modern definition, energeia is a very broad, qualitative philosophical concept.In the late 17th century, Gottfried Leibniz proposed the Latin idea: vis viva, or lifestyle, defined as the multiplication of the mass of an object by the square of its velocity; he believed that the total vis viva was conserved. To account for the deceleration due to friction, Leibniz theorized that thermal energy consisted of the random motion of the parts that make up matter, although in the end this would take more than a century to complete. generally accepted.

The liver or liver (Ancient Greek: ἡπαρ 'hēpar') or liver (Dutch: lever; English: liver) is the "largest" gland in the human body. The liver is located in the abdominal cavity on the right, just below the diaphragm. The liver is also included as a means of excretion because it helps kidney function by breaking down several toxic compounds and produces ammonia, urea and uric acid by utilizing nitrogen from amino acids. Solving process by a toxic compound called liver detoxification process. The liver lobes are made up of parenchymal cells as well as non-parenchymal cells. Parenchymal cells in the liver, called hepatocytes, occupy about 80% of the volume of the liver and perform the main functions of the liver. As much as 40% of liver cells are in the sinusoidal lobes. Hepatocytes are endodermal cells that are continuously stimulated by mesenchymal tissue during the embryonic period until they develop into parenchymal cells. During this period, there was an increase in albumin mRNA transcription as a stimulant of proliferation and differentiation of endodermal cells into hepatocytes. The lobe lumen is formed from the SEC and is occupied by 3 other types of cells, such as Kupffer cells, Ito cells, intrahepatic lymphocytes such as pit cells. Non-parenchymal cells occupy about 6.5% by volume of the liver and produce a variety of substances that control many of the functions of the hepatocyte. Filtration is a function of the sinusoidal lumen-lobes which separate the hepatocyte surface from the blood, SEC has a very large endocytotic capacity with various ligands such as glycoproteins, immune complexes, transferrin and ceruloplasmin. "SEC" also functions as an antigen presenter cell that provides MHC I and MHC II expression for T cells. The secretion that occurs includes various cytokines, eicosanoids such as prostanoids and leukotrienes, endothelin-1, nitrogen monoxide and several ECM components. Ito cells are in the perisinusoidal tissue, which are cells with many fat vesicles in the cytoplasm that bind to SEC very strongly to provide a double layer in the sinusoidal lobe lumen.

When the liver is normal, Ito cells store vitamin A to control the flexibility of the extracellular matrix formed by SEC, which is also the flexibility of the lumen of the sinusoids. Kupffer cells are located in intranusoidal tissue, are macrophages with astonishing endocytic and phagocytic capabilities. Kupffer cells daily interact with materials of gastrointestinal origin containing bacterial solutions, and prevent the activation of the toxic effects of these compounds into the liver. Exposure to high bacterial solutions, especially exposure to LPS, causes Kupffer cells to secrete various cytokines that trigger inflammatory processes and can cause liver injury. Secretions include reactive oxygen species, eicosanoids, nitrogen monoxide, carbon monoxide, TNF-α, IL-10, as a response from the innate immune system in the primary infection phase. Pit cells are lymphocytes with large granules, like NK cells that live in the liver. Pit cells can induce instantaneous death in tumor cells without relying on antigen expression on major histocompatibility complexes. Pit cell activity can be increased by interferon-γ stimulation. In addition, there are still several cells in the liver, including: Apart from hepatocytes and non-parenchymal cells, there are other types of cells in the liver, namely intra-hepatic cells which are often called oval cells, and ductular hepatocytes. Liver regeneration after partial hepatectomy generally does not involve intra-hepatic progenitor cells and extra-hepatic (hemopoietic) stem cells, and depends only on hepatocyte proliferation. However, under conditions when hepatocyte proliferation is inhibited or delayed, oval cells in the periportal area will experience proliferation and differentiation into mature hepatocytes. Oval cells are a differentiated form of progenitor cells located in the portal and periportal areas, or Hering's canals, and are only found when the liver is injured.

Albigensis (Per. )Hussite (Boh. )Lollard (Ing. )Waldensis (Per./Ita./Jer.) Anabaptist Anglicanism (English)Calvinism (Switzerland)Lutheranism (Jer. )Reformed Socinianism (Pol. )Zwinglianism (Swiss. ) Amish (Ame. )Baptist (Ing. )Congregational Mennonite (Bel./Swi./Ame./Kan. )Methodism (Ing. )Pietism Presbyterianism (Scot./Ame. )Puritanism (Ing. )Evangelical Universalism Pentecostal Revivalism Movement The Restoration Adventist Lutheran Churches are churches based on the teachings of Martin Luther, a reformed church figure in the 16th century who criticized the teachings and practices of the Church at that time. Martin Luther's distinctive teachings which are often also recognized as the distinctive features of the Reformation teachings are summed up in three solas, namely sola fide, sola gratia, and sola scriptura, which mean "only faith", "only grace", and "only Scripture". That is, Luther stated that human salvation is only obtained through faith in the work of God's grace that He did through Jesus Christ, as witnessed by the Scriptures. (Ephesians 2:8-9 For by grace you are saved through faith; it is not the result of your efforts, but God's gift, it is not the result of your works: let no one boast) Luther opposed the practice of abuse of indulgences (abolition of temporary punishment due to sin) in at that time. Luther stated that humans are saved not because of their good deeds or deeds, but solely because of God's grace. This is based on Paul's words in the Epistle to the Romans: "But God shows His love toward us, in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us." (Romans 5:8) The Lutheran Church recognizes two sacraments: Baptism and Holy Communion. The Lutheran Catechism teaches that baptism is an act of God, based on the word and promise of Christ; so that both babies and adults are served. The Lutheran Church believes that the bread and wine in the communion are actually the body and blood of Christ which were given to Christians to eat and drink, which were commanded by Christ himself.

Many Lutherans have preserved a liturgical approach to the Eucharist. Holy Communion (or the Lord's Supper) is seen as the central act of Christian worship. The Lutheran Church believes that the bread and wine in the communion are present with the body and blood of Jesus, rather than replacing or merely representing His body and blood. They confess in the Apology of the Augsburg Confession: Several Protestant reformers, notably Andreas Karlstadt, Huldrych Zwingli and John Calvin supported the removal of religious images by basing their opinions on the prohibition of worshiping idols and the sculptural imagery of God in the Decalogue (The Ten Commandments). As a result, statues and images were vandalized in spontaneous individual attacks and unauthorized iconoclastic riots. However, in many cases religious images were graciously removed by the civil authorities in the recently reformed European cities and territories. Unlike other Protestant Churches, Lutheran Churches are generally not so against the use of religious imagery. This is due to Martin Luther's own statement that Christians should be free to use images as long as they do not worship them instead of God. Apart from HKBP (Huria Kristen Batak Protestant), Lutheran churches in Indonesia are generally spread out in North Sumatra, namely the former RMG (Rheinische Missions-Gesselschaft) mission service area. These churches are GKPI (Indonesian Protestant Christian Church), GKPS (Simalungun Protestant Christian Church), GKPA (Angkola Protestant Christian Church), GKPPD (Pakpak-Dairi Protestant Christian Church), HKI (Indonesian Christian Huria), GPKB (Pakpak-Dairi Christian Church). Batak Christians), GKLI (Indonesian Lutheran Church), GPP (Protestant Fellowship Church), GKR (Rejang Christian Church), GLIpermanently disabled link] (Indonesian Lutheran Church) GLI is a member of the WELS Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod and CELC (Confessional Evangelical Lutheran Conference ). The churches in Nias and the Mentawai Islands are also classified as Lutheran churches, namely BNKP (Banua Niha Keriso Protestant), AMIN (Angowulua Christian Indonesian Christian Nias), ONKP (Orahua Niha Keriso Protestant), BKPN (Banua Keriso Protestant Nias), and GKPM (Mentawai Protestant Christian Church).

Anarchism is a political philosophy that advocates a society without a state or is often defined as a voluntary, self-governing institution. But some authors have defined more specific institutions based on non-hierarchical free association. Anarchism adheres to the concept that states become undesirable, unnecessary, or harmful. While anti-statism is central to this thinking, it also opposes authority or hierarchical organization in the exercise of its relations with human beings, and so is not limited to state systems. Specifically in the economic, political and administrative sectors, anarchy means coordination and management, without bureaucratic rule which is broadly defined as the superior party in the economic, political and administrative realm (both in the public and private spheres). Anarchism comes from the root word "anarchy" with the suffix -ism. The word anarchy is an absorption word from anarchy (English) or anarchie (Dutch/German/French), which comes from the Greek word, anarchos/anarchein. This is a word formed a- (not/without/nil/negation) which is inserted /n/ with archos/archein (government/power or party that exercises control and authority - coercively, repressively, including slavery and tyranny); thus, anarchos/anarchein means "without government" or "management and coordination without a relationship of commanding and being ruled, controlling and being ruled, headed and being led, controlling and being controlled, and so on". The form of the word "anarchist" means a person who believes in and adheres to anarchy, while the ending -ism itself means understanding/teaching/ideology. Anarchism is a political theory that aims to create a society without hierarchies (whether political, economic or social). Anarchists try to maintain that anarchy, the absence of rules, is a form that can be implemented in a social system and can create individual freedom and social togetherness. Anarchists see that the ultimate goal of freedom and togetherness is a mutually beneficial cooperation with one another.

Or, in Bakunin's famous writing: Historically, anarchists in their various movements have often used violence as a method that is quite effective in fighting for their ideas, such as the anarchists who were involved in the Nihilist group in Tzar-era Russia, Leon Czolgosz, the N17 group in Greece. The slogan of the Spanish anarchists, Durruti's followers, reads: This statement is full of the use of violence in a method of movement. The use of violence in applying the concept of anarchism is closely related to the propaganda method by the deed, namely the method of movement by using direct action (real actions) as the path taken, which also means legalizing destruction, violence, and attacks. As long as it is aimed at attacking capitalism or the state. However, not a few also of the anarchists who disagree to make violence a way that must be taken. In his book What is Communist Anarchist, anarchist thinker Alexander Berkman writes: From various disagreements among anarchists in defining an idea of ​​violence as a method, violence is still not an exclusive idea belonging to anarchism, so anarchism cannot be connoted as violence, such as the meaning of anarchism which is widely quoted by various media in Indonesia which means as an act of violence. However, violence is a natural human behavior pattern that can be done by anyone from any background. Anarchism as an idea which in its development has also become a philosophy which also has quite interesting developments and dynamics. Marxism in its development after Marx and Engels developed into 3 major world ideological powers that relied on Marx's thoughts. The three ideologies are: (1) Communism, which was later developed by Lenin to become the ideology of Marxism-Leninism which is currently the mainstay of the majority of world communists; (2) Democratic Socialism, which was first developed by Eduard Bernstein and developed in Germany and then developed into a socialist with European characteristics; (3) Neomarxism and the New Left Movement, which developed around 1965-1975 in universities in Europe.

Helium is a chemical element in the periodic table having the symbol He and atomic number 2. Helium is a colourless, odorless, tasteless, non-toxic, almost inert, monatomic gas, and is the first element in the noble gas group in the periodic table. The boiling and melting points of this gas are the lowest among all the elements. Helium exists only as a gas except under very extreme conditions. Extreme conditions are also required to create small amounts of helium compounds, all of which are unstable at standard temperature and pressure. Helium has a second rare stable isotope called helium-3. Properties of helium-4 variety fluids; helium I and helium II; is important for researchers studying quantum mechanics (particularly in the phenomenon of superfluidity) and for those looking for the effects of the near absolute zero temperature that matter has (such as superconductivity). Helium is the second most abundant and second lightest element in the universe, accounting for 24% of the total elemental mass of the universe and 12 times the total mass of the other heavy elements. The same abundance of helium can also be found on the Sun and Jupiter. This is due to the high nuclear binding energy (per nucleon) of helium-4 compared to the other three chemical elements after helium. The binding energy of helium-4 is also responsible for the abundance of helium-4 as a product of nuclear fusion and radioactive decay. Most of the helium in the universe is helium-4, which is believed to have been formed during the Big Bang. Some new helium is also formed through the nuclear fusion of hydrogen in the cosmic stars. The name "helium" comes from the name of the Greek sun god Helios. In 1868, the French astronomer Pierre Jules César Janssen first detected helium as a hint of unknown yellow spectral lines coming from the light of a solar eclipse.

Formally, the discovery of the element was made by two Swedish chemists Per Teodor Cleve and Nils Abraham Langlet who discovered helium gas escaping from kleveit uranium ore. In 1903, large deposits of helium were discovered in natural gas fields in the United States, which until now were the largest sources of helium gas. Helium is used in cryogenics, deep-sea breathing systems, cooling superconducting magnets, "helium dating", inflating balloons, lifting airships and as a shielding gas for industrial uses (such as "arc welding") and growing silicon wafers). Inhaling small amounts of this gas will cause a temporary change in the quality of a person's voice. On Earth, this gas is quite rare (0.00052% by volume of the atmosphere). Most of the helium that we find on Earth is formed from the radioactive decay of the heavy elements (thorium and uranium) as alpha particles with helium-4 nuclei. This radiogenic helium is trapped in natural gas at a concentration as high as 7% by volume, from which it can be extracted commercially using a low temperature separation process called fractional distillation. Evidence for the presence of helium was first observed on August 18, 1868 in the form of a bright yellow spectral line with a wavelength of 587.49 nanometers originating from the spectrum of the Sun's chromosphere. This spectral line was detected by the French astronomer Jules Janssen during a total solar eclipse in Guntur, India. This spectral line was first assumed to be sodium. On 20 October of the same year, British astronomer Norman Lockyer also observed the same yellow line in the solar spectrum, which he later named the Fraunhofer line D3 because it is adjacent to the known sodium lines D1 and D2. He concluded that the existence of these lines was caused by an element in the Sun that was unknown on Earth.

Corruption is all that has a connection with actions that are threatened with sanctions as stipulated in Law no. 31 of 1999 concerning the Eradication of Criminal Acts of Corruption and Law no. 20 of 2001 concerning amendments to Law no. 31 of 1999 concerning the Eradication of Corruption Crimes. And Supreme Court Regulation Number 1 of 2020. Rasuah or stealing (Latin: corruptio from the verb corrumpere which means rotten, unlawful, shaking, twisting, bribing, stealing, stealing) is an act of public officials, both politicians and civil servants, as well other parties involved in the act who unfairly and illegally abuse the trust of the public and society empowered to them to gain unilateral benefits. In a broad sense, corruption or political corruption is the abuse of official office for personal gain. All forms of government/government are prone to corruption in practice. The severity of corruption varies, from the lightest in the form of using influence and support to give and receive help, to serious corruption that is formalized, and so on. The tipping point of corruption is kleptocracy, which literally means government by thieves, where there is no pretense of being honest. Corruption that appears in the political and bureaucratic fields can be trivial or serious, organized or not. While corruption often facilitates criminal activities such as drug trafficking, money laundering, and prostitution, it is not limited to these areas. In order to study this problem and make a solution, it is very important to distinguish between corruption and crime. Depending on the country or jurisdiction, there are differences between what is considered corruption or not. For example, funding for General Elections for political parties is legal in one place but not legal in another.

Perceptions of the international and national community (the majority of businessmen and government) regarding the level of corruption in a country, the level of corruption is mainly associated with matters of business licenses, taxes, winners of government procurement of goods and services through the tender process of the Goods/Services Procurement Work Unit, customs, illegal levies and payment processes for project terms, Finance and Banking, Oil and Gas, BUMN and BUMD, APBN and APBD Management, State and Regional Asset Management Institutions, Mining, Public Service Agencies, Regional Public Service Agencies. Supporters of the emergence of corruption are as follows: Convicts with imprisonment for a minimum of 1 (one) year and a maximum of 5 (five) years and a minimum fine of IDR 50,000,000.00 (fifty million rupiah) and a maximum of IDR 250,000,000 .00 (Two hundred and fifty million rupiah) each person who: The Supreme Court (MA) Regulation is related to criminal penalties for corruptors called corruptors, contained in MA Regulation (Perma) Number 1 of 2020, which serves as a guide for judges to impose prison sentences accused of corruption. Enacted since July 24 2020, this regulation specifically regulates as a guideline for judges so that there is disparity in practices against corruptors in Indonesia, the categorization of corruptors' sentences based on the amount of money taken (Article 6) and the level of guilt (Article 7). Penalties based on the Corruption Law Article 2 paragraph (1) which reads: "Any person who unlawfully commits an act of enriching himself or another person or a corporation that can harm the state's finances or the country's economy, shall be punished with imprisonment for life or imprisonment for a minimum of four (4) years and a maximum of 20 years and a fine of a minimum of Rp. 200 million and a maximum of Rp. unlimited".

Happiness or joy is a state of mind or feeling characterized by adequacy to intense pleasure, love, contentment, enjoyment, or joy. Being grateful and being sincere is one way to make life feel calmer and happier. Various approaches to philosophy, religion, psychology, and biology have been used to define happiness and determine its sources. Philosophers and religious thinkers have often defined happiness in terms of a good life and not simply as an emotion. This definition was used to translate eudaimonia (Greek: εὐδαιμονία) and is still used in goodness theory. Although direct measurement of happiness levels remains a challenge, several researchers have developed tools to do so, for example with The Oxford Happiness Questionnaire. Researchers have also identified several factors related to happiness: social relationships and interactions, marital status, employment, health, democratic freedoms, optimism, religious involvement, income, receiving gifts and closeness to other happy people. Happiness has many different definitions and is subject to debate in its meaning and usage. This word is widely used in relation to two factors, namely: influencing feelings and emotions, such as pleasure or excitement, and an assessment of the quality of life. In its use can include both of these factors. Assessment of well-being can include what is being felt at the moment (emotions, moods, satisfaction with life and feelings). A female professor named Sonja Lyubomirsky has described happiness as a positive experience, joy, contentment, or state, combined with feelings that one's life is good, meaningful and valuable. Eudaimonia is a Greek term that has been variously translated as happiness, well-being, prosperity, and blessing. Benton added, happiness does not require things to be perfect.

Even the pursuit of perfection in life can actually make people feel less happy. Unfortunately, if humans are too focused on pursuing something external, long-term benefits to happiness cannot be obtained. “We can actually hurt our sense of happiness, because we will always want more and never really satisfied," added Benton. As a solution to help us feel happier overall, the researchers suggest 5 things that can be done, including: The simpler a person's need for happiness, the more likely that person is to be happy This type of happiness can be difficult for anyone to maintain due to its inconsistent nature, which is why it is so difficult for people to be happy in life: Anyone who constantly compares their life to others will never be happy. It is difficult to be satisfied with everyday life when constantly looking at it through a hard lens other people's pages. Comparisons that foster dissatisfaction always look at those who have more and achieve higher levels of success (upward social comparison) but seldom compare with those who may not have or do as much (downward social comparison). People who are unable to see or take responsibility for the ways they are contributing to conflict in their lives, often suffer in relationships, especially close ones where challenges are unavoidable. These people feel that something happened to them, and have no awareness of how they might have triggered or triggered a situation that made them feel unhappy. In their world, it seems that everything is someone else's fault. Yes, it is true that in a relationship conflict, one person's actions and words may have greater consequences than others, but it is a rare situation when one person is completely innocent.

The second or second (symbol: s, abbreviated as "d" or "sec" in everyday use; English: second, French: seconde) is the base unit of time in the International System of Units (SI). After being redefined in 2019, the definition of the second unit, as stated in the ninth edition of the SI Brochure, is as follows. The second, symbolized by s, is the SI unit of time. This unit is defined by obtaining a fixed numerical value from the cesium frequency ∆νCs, the hyperfine transition frequency in the ground state of non-perturbating cesium-133 atoms, which is 9,192,631,770 when expressed in Hz units that are proportional to s−1. In most common usage, a second is 1/60 of a minute, and 1/3600 of an hour. At first, the term second (second) in English was known as second minute (second minute), which means a small part of one hour. The first part is known as the prime minute, which is the same as the minute as it is known today. The magnitude of this division is fixed at 1/60, that is, there are 60 minutes in an hour and 60 seconds in a minute. This may be due to the influence of the Babylonians, who used a system of calculations based on Sexagesimal (base 60). The term hour itself was discovered by the Egyptians in the earth's rotation as 1/24 of the sun's time. This makes a second as 1/86,400 of solar time. In 1956, the International Committee on Measures and Scales, under a mandate given by the tenth General Conference on Measures and Scales (Conférence Générale des Poids et Mesures, CGPM) in 1954, defined the seconds in the period of the Earth's revolution around the sun in epochs. , because at that time it was realized that the rotation of the earth on its axis was not uniform enough to be used as a standard of time.

The motion of the earth was described in Newcomb's Tables of the Sun, which gave a formula for the motion of the sun during the 1900 epoch based on astronomical observations made during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Thus the second is defined as this definition ratified by the Eleventh General Conference on Weights and Measures in 1960. The reference to 1900 does not imply this is the epoch of the solar day which contains 86,400 seconds. Rather it is the epoch of the tropical year which contains 31,556,925.9747 seconds of Ephemeris Time. Ephemeris Time (ET) has been defined as a measure of time that gives the apparent position of a celestial object according to Newton's theory of dynamical motion. With the creation of atomic clocks, the use of atomic clocks was determined as the basis for defining seconds, no longer with the rotation of the earth. As a result of several years' work, two astronomers at the United States Naval Observatory (USNO) and two astronomers at the National Physical Laboratory (Teddington, England) determined the relationship of the hyperfine transition frequency of the cesium atom and the ephemeris second. Using a common-view measurement method based on signals received from radio station WWV, they determined the orbital motion of the moon around the earth, from which the apparent motion of the sun can be inferred, in atomic hour units of time. As a result, in 1967, the General Conference on Weights and Measures defined the second of atomic time in the International System of Units (SI) as the ground state defined in the absence (zero) of the magnetic field. The defined second is the ephemeris second. The definition of second was further refined at the BIPM meeting to include the sentence. In practice, this meant that the realization of a high-fidelity second had to compensate for the effects of the surrounding radiation to try to extrapolate to the value of seconds as mentioned above.

In biology, the cell is the simplest collection of matter that can live and is the building block of all living things. Cells are capable of carrying out all life activities and most of the chemical reactions to sustain life take place within cells. Most living things are composed of a single cell, or are called unicellular organisms, such as bacteria and amoeba. Other living things, including plants, animals and humans, are multicellular organisms consisting of many specialized cell types with different functions. The human body, for example, is composed of more than 1013 cells. However, the whole body of all organisms originates as a result of the division of a single cell. For example, the body of a bacterium originates from the division of its parent bacterial cell, while the body of a mouse originates from the division of its fertilized parent egg. The cells in a multicellular organism would not last long if each were to stand alone. Similar cells are grouped into tissues, which form organs and then organ systems that make up the body of the organism. For example, cardiac muscle cells form cardiac muscle tissue in the heart organ, which is part of the circulatory organ system in the human body. Meanwhile, the cell itself is composed of components called organelles. The smallest cell known to man is the Mycoplasma bacterium with a diameter of 0.0001 to 0.001 mm, while one of the single cells that can be seen with the naked eye is an unfertilized chicken egg. However, most cells are between 1 and 100 µm (0.001–0.1 mm) in diameter and can only be seen with a microscope. The discovery and early study of cells progressed parallel to the invention and refinement of the microscope in the 17th century. Robert Hooke first described and named cells in 1665 when he observed a slice of cork (oak bark) under a microscope with a magnification of 30 times.

However, the theory of the cell as the unit of life was only formulated nearly two centuries later by Matthias Schleiden and Theodor Schwann. Furthermore, cells are studied in a branch of biology called cell biology. The compound microscope with two lenses was invented in the late 16th century and further developed in the Netherlands, Italy and England. Until the mid-17th century, microscopes had the ability to magnify images up to 30 times. British scientist Robert Hooke then designed a compound microscope that had its own light source making it easier to use. He examined thin slices of cork through a microscope and described the microscopic structure of cork as "porous like a honeycomb but irregular pores" in a paper published in 1665. Hooke called the pores cells because they resemble cells (chambers). minor) in a monastery or prison. What Hooke actually saw were the empty cell walls surrounding the dead cells in the cork that came from the bark of an oak tree. He also observed that in green plants there are cells filled with fluid. At the same time in the Netherlands, Antony van Leeuwenhoek, a cloth merchant, invented his own mono-lens microscope and used it to observe various things. He was able to see red blood cells, spermatozoids, single-celled yeasts, protozoa, and even bacteria. In 1673 he began sending letters detailing his activities to the Royal Society, which published them. In one of his letters, Leeuwenhoek described something moving in the saliva which he observed under a microscope. He called it diertjen or dierken (Dutch: 'little animal', translated as animalcule in English by the Royal Society), which is believed to be a bacterium by modern scientists.

Politics (Greek: Πολιτικά, Politiká; Arabic: سياسة, siyasah), which means from, for, or relating to citizens), is the process of formation in society which, among other things, takes the form of decision-making processes, especially within the state. This definition is an attempt to combine different definitions regarding the nature of political positions known in political science. It can be used positively in the context of compromising and non-violent political solutions, or descriptively as the art or science of government, but it also often carries negative connotations. The concept has been defined in a variety of ways, and different approaches have fundamentally different views on whether it should be used broadly or limitedly, empirically or normatively, and whether conflict or cooperation is more important for that. Various methods are used in politics, including promoting one's own political views among people, negotiating with other political subjects, making laws, and using internal and external force, including war against enemies. Politics is exercised at various social levels, from clans or tribes in traditional societies, through modern local governments, companies and institutions to sovereign states, to the international level. Various methods are used in politics, including promoting one's own political views among people, negotiating with other political subjects, making laws, and using internal and external force, including war against enemies. Politics is exercised at various social levels, from clans or tribes in traditional societies, through modern local governments, companies and institutions to sovereign states, to the international level. In modern nation states, people often form political parties to represent their ideas. Party members often agree to take the same position on many issues and agree to support equal welfare under unequal laws and leaders.

General elections are usually competitions between various parties. A political system is a framework that defines acceptable political methods in a society. The history of political thought can be traced back to ancient times, with such seminal works as Plato's Republic and Aristotle's Politics in the West, and the political manuscripts of Confucius and Chanakya's Arthashastra in the East. Politics (from the Greek: ,politika, 'city affairs') is a set of activities related to group decision-making, or other forms of individual power relations, distribution of water resources and status. The branch of social science that studies politics and government is referred to as political science. Politics is the interaction between the government and society in the framework of the process of making and implementing binding decisions about the common good of the people who live in a certain area. (Ramlan surbakti 1999:1) In addition, politics can also be viewed from different perspectives, namely: In the context of understanding politics, it is necessary to understand several keys, including: legitimacy, political system, political behavior, political participation, political process, and also no less important to know the ins and outs of political parties. ¹'"And there is also Aristotle making a classification of the form of government. The criteria or basis for the assessment used are: 1. The number of people in power (sitting in government) who have morals. 2. The way and interests in running the government are required to side with the interests of the welfare of the community. Regarding the number of people who have the morals to run or hold the reins of government, there are three types of division, namely: Each of the three types of division is classified between a good (positive) form and a bad (negative) form. So that there are seven forms of government in total. The good or bad things of a government, in terms of ways and interests of leaders who occupy positions of power in running the government.

Camelus bactrianus Camelus dromedarius Camelus ferus Camelus divaliarus Camels are two species of even-toed hoofed animals from the genus Camelus (one single-humped - Camelus dromedarius, another double-humped - Camelus bactrianus) that live found in dry and desert regions of Asia and North Africa. The average life expectancy of a camel is between 30 and 50 years. Domestication of camels by humans has started since approximately 5,000 years ago. The use of camels, among others, for milk (which has a higher nutritional value than cow's milk) and meat, and also used as working animals. There are 3 species of camels that still exist: As is known, camels live in the desert which has a temperature range that can kill the majority of living things. In addition, they were able not to eat or drink for several days. There are many things that make them able to adapt. One of them is the hump. Many people think their humps store water, but they don't. The camel's hump stores a special fat, which at some point can be converted into water with the help of oxygen from respiration. One gram of fat in the camel's hump can be converted into one gram of water. Another extraordinary adaptability is, its respiratory system leaves very little traces of water vapor. Water vapor that comes out of the lungs is reabsorbed by the body through special cells found in the inner nose, forming crystals and one day it can be taken. The camel's body can survive up to 41 degrees Celsius. More than that, the camel started sweating. Evaporation from the sweat that occurs only on his skin, not on his hair. With this efficient cooling method, camels are able to conserve quite a lot of water.

Tardigrades (known as water bears) are part of the superphylum Ecdysozoa. Tardigrades are very small and live in water with eight legs. Tardigrada was first described by Eprhaim Goeze in 1773. The name Tardigrada means "slow walker" given by Spallanzani (1777). The adult tardigrade body length is 1.5 mm, the smallest is 0.1 mm, the larvae are 0.05 mm. Tardigrada can be found in all parts of the world, from the peaks of the Himalayas to the bottom of the oceans, and from the poles to the equator. The most favored place in the algae. On the beach, land or in the water you can find these mini animals. The most interesting thing about this animal is the ability to adapt in a very extreme environment. Tardigrades can survive in a frozen environment (0°C) to high temperatures (151°C). It can even withstand radiation of 570,000 Rad, 1,000 times higher than the amount of radiation in which other living things can survive. Therefore, tardigrades are known as animals that are polyextremophiles. With this ability, tardigrades are living things that can survive a nuclear war or other extreme natural disasters. Even tardigrades can live for 10-100 years in dry conditions, even the record for tardigrades surviving in dry conditions the longest is 120 years. Unfortunately, after a few minutes of restation and movement, the animal died. Another unique ability of tardigrades is that they can survive in a state of empty outer space. In one study in September 2007, tardigrades could live for as long as 10 days in outer space. Tardigrades, which fly using the FOTON-M3 spacecraft by the European Space Agency, can survive in a vacuum, are exposed to cosmic rays, and can even withstand solar UV radiation 1000 times higher than radiation on the earth's surface, and these animals also have knife-sharp teeth hidden in its tubular mouth.

The Three General Patterns or Three Universal Patterns (Pali: Tilakkhaṇa; Sanskrit: Trilakṣaṇa) often used by the Theravada school, known as the Three Noble Truths by the Mahayana school, are the Buddhist concept of the general characteristics of existential reality as absorbed by perception. According to the Buddhist tradition all things or phenomena that exist in existence other than Nirvana are ruled by three general characteristics, namely: impermanence, suffering, and selflessness (or non-self). Because of this, the longing for or attachment to something -both outwardly and psychologically (or ideologically) - will eventually show up and bring misery. In the Mahayana school, these characteristics are often called Dharma Seals, while in the Theravada tradition they are called Tilakkhana or the Three General Patterns (or the Three Noble Truths; or often known as the Three Patterns of Life). In Buddhist philosophy, the Buddha concluded that everything in the physical world (Pali: Rupa) plus all the phenomena of the soul (Pali: Nama) is characterized by these 3 general characteristics. All visible and invisible forms and views are an assembly of " Nama-Rupa" (physio-psycho phenomenology). The existence of this "Nam-Rupa" realm is a result of perceptual absorption (Pali: sañña) which in turn is brought about by conditioning (Pali: sankhara). Conditioning in turn is the need to make clarity in ignorance, while ignorance (Pali: Avija) itself results from birth or re-existence. Since all things in the last instance are based on perception, all things contain these Three General Features because their basis is conditioning which originates in ignorance. It is often mentioned Fourth Dharma Seal: By bringing the three (or four) seals to experience moment by moment through mindful concentration, ki ta would be said to acquire wisdom – the third step of the three higher trainings – the way out of samsara.

So we can identify that, according to the sutras, the recipe or formula for leaving samsara is obtained by changing the perspective of looking at the world. All phenomena (things and experiences) are fickle, unsteady, and impermanent. Everything we can experience through our mind is made up of components, and depends on the right side of the conditions for its existence. Everything is in continuous change without ceasing, and thus conditions and things are constantly changing. Things are constantly standing; gets, and stops for; Becomes. There's nothing that doesn't end. The important value here is that the symptoms arise and stop according to complex conditions and not according to our attitude and imagination. As long as we have limited our ability to effect change to our environment and attachments, experience tells us that our weak effort is no guarantee that the results of our efforts will be to our liking. More often than not that, the results we get are lower than the results we expect. In the Mahayana tradition, an emphasis is added: one should constantly meditate on the impermanence and transitory nature of structures and phenomena, but one must be on guard against extending this understanding to the realm of Nirvana, where impermanence has no effect. In such a view, the true nature of reality becomes free from the taint of double-mindedness, and is therefore not labeled as 'the one' or 'the other' (i.e. 'eternal' or 'impermanent'). Dzongsar Jamyang Khyentse Rinpoche insists in the four seals of the Mahayana tradition, Nirvana must be seen as "beyond ardor". Further, he states that "In many philosophies or beliefs, the end result is something that you can hold onto and hold on to. The end result is the only thing that is truly real.

Redox is a term that describes changes in the oxidation number (oxidation state) of atoms in a chemical reaction. This can be a simple redox process such as the oxidation of carbon to give carbon dioxide, or the reduction of carbon by hydrogen to give methane (CH4), or it can be a complex process such as the oxidation of sugar in the human body through a complicated sequence of electron transfers. The term redox comes from two concepts, namely reduction and oxidation. It can be explained easily as follows: While it is quite appropriate for use in many purposes, the above explanation is not exactly correct. Oxidation and reduction precisely refer to changes in oxidation number because the actual transfer of electrons will not always occur. So oxidation is better defined as an increase in oxidation number, and reduction as a decrease in oxidation number. In practice, the transfer of electrons will always change oxidation number, but there are many reactions that are classified as "redox" even though there is no transfer of electrons in the reaction (eg those involving covalent bonds). Non-redox reactions that do not involve a change in formal charge are known as metathesis reactions. ReductionOxidant + e– ⟶ Product(Electrons gained; oxidation number decreases)OxidationReductant ⟶ Product + e–(Electrons lost; oxidation number increases) Substances which have the ability to oxidize other compounds are said to be oxidative and are known as oxidizing agents or oxidizing agents. The oxidizing agent removes electrons from other compounds, thereby reducing itself. Because it "accepts" electrons, it is also known as an electron acceptor. Oxidizing agents are usually compounds that have elements with a high oxidation number (such as H, MnO, CrO3, Cr, OsO4) or compounds that are highly electronegative, so they can gain one or two more electrons by oxidizing a compound ( such as oxygen, fluorine, chlorine, and bromine).

Compounds that have the ability to reduce other compounds are said to be reductive and are known as reducing agents or reducing agents. The reducing agent gives up its electrons to another compound, so that it itself is oxidized. Because it "donates" electrons, it is also called an electron donor. Compounds that are reducing agents vary widely. Metal elements such as Li, Na, Mg, Fe, Zn, and Al can be used as reducing agents. These metals will give their electrons easily. Another type of reducing agent is the hydride transfer reagents, eg NaBH4 and LiAlH4), these reagents are used widely in organic chemistry, especially in the reduction of carbonyl compounds to alcohols. Another useful reduction method involves gaseous hydrogen (H2) over a palladium, platinum, or nickel catalyst. This catalytic reduction is primarily used in the reduction of carbon-carbon double or triple bonds. An easy way to look at redox processes is, the reducing agent transfers its electrons to the oxidizing agent. So in a reaction, the reducing agent loses electrons and is oxidized, and the oxidizing agent gains electrons and is reduced. The oxidizing and reducing pairs involved in a reaction are known as redox pairs. One example of a redox reaction is that between hydrogen and fluorine: We can write this whole reaction as two half reactions: an oxidation reaction and a reduction reaction. Analyzing each half reaction will make the overall chemical process clearer. Since there is no change in total charge during a redox reaction, the number of electrons in excess in the oxidation reaction must equal the number consumed in the reduction reaction. Elements, even in molecular form, often have an oxidation number of zero. In the above reaction, hydrogen is oxidized from an oxidation state of 0 to +1, while fluorine is reduced from an oxidation state of 0 to -1. When oxidation and reduction reactions are combined, the electrons involved reduce each other: And the ions combine to form hydrogen fluoride: Redox occurs in a single replacement reaction or substitution reaction.

Bahrain (/bɑːˈreɪn/ ( listen); Arabic: البحرين‎  al-Baḥrayn), officially the Kingdom of Bahrain (Arabic: مملكة البحرين‎  Mamlakat al-Baḥrayn) is a small Arab state in the form of a monarchy on the Persian Gulf. Bahrain is in a group of islands between the Qatar Peninsula and the northeast coast of Saudi Arabia. Bahrain is an island country located off the west coast of the Persian Gulf in the Middle East. Bahrain is a small archipelago centered on Bahrain Island, which is Bahrain's largest island. The country is only about 23 km (14 mi) east of Saudi Arabia, which is connected by the King Fahd Bridge. The Qatar peninsula is also relatively close, only about 50 km (31 mi) southeast of the Gulf of Bahrain. Iran is 200 km (124 mi) north across the Persian Gulf. The population in 2010 was 1,234,567, including 666,172 foreign nationals. The country's area reaches 780 km2 In size, Bahrain is the third smallest country in Asia after the Maldives and Singapore. Bahrain is the site of ancient Dilmun. Bahrain has been famous since ancient times for its pearl fishing, which continued into the 19th century. Bahrain is one of the regions that first embraced Islam (ad 628). According to Arab stories, Bahrain was ruled by the Portuguese in 1521, which was recaptured in 1602 by Shah Abbas I of the Safavi Empire under the Persian Empire. In 1783, the Bani Utbah controlled Bahrain from Nasr Al-Madhkur and were continued by the Al Khalifa Family, with Ahmed al Fateh as the first judge of Bahrain. In the late 1800s by successive treaties with the United Kingdom, Bahrain became a British protected area. In 1971, Bahrain declared its independence. A former country, Bahrain was declared a kingdom in 2002.

In 2011, the country experienced regional Arab-inspired protests. Bahrain is the first oil-sending country in the Persian Gulf. Since the late 20th century Bahrain started investing in the banking and tourism sectors. Several large-scale financial institutions are based in Manama, which is the capital of this country. Bahrain has a high level of Human Development Index and is recognized by the World Bank as a high-income country. Its area is almost equivalent to the area of ​​DKI Jakarta. Bahrain has been occupied by humans since pre-historic times. Its strategic location on the Persian Gulf has influenced the Assyrians, Babylonians, Greeks, Persians, and most recently the Arabs (the inhabitants of which later became Muslim). Bahrain in ancient times was known as Dilmun, Tylos (the Greek name), Awal, even Mishmahig when under the rule of the Persian Sultanate. The islands of Bahrain which are located in the south center of the Persian Gulf have attracted invaders throughout history. Bahrain in Arabic means "Two Seas". This refers to the fact that this island has two different sources of water, fresh water that emerges from the ground and salt water that surrounds it. As a strategic island that lies between East and West, fertile soil, and abundant fresh water, and a place for divers looking for pearls have made Bahrain the center of the longest settlement. For 2300 years, Bahrain was the center of world trade between Mesopotamia (now Iraq) and the Indus Valley (now a region of India). It is the Delmon civilization that has close ties to the Sumerian Civilization in the 3rd century BC. Bahrain became part of Babylon around 600 BC. Historical records show that Bahrain is known by various nicknames, including the "Pearl of the Persian Gulf".

A child broadly means something smaller, someone who is immature, or an object that is "under" by another object. However, this meaning includes things that vary according to the scientific discipline. In the field of biology, children are generally living things that have not yet reached the mature or mature stage. The term "kids" is primarily used for animals that are not yet ready to mate, but can also be used in some plants to refer to small trees growing on tubers or large clumps of vegetation. In the field of psychology, a child is a male or female human who has not yet reached the stage of maturity physically and mentally, or at least has not reached puberty. Children are categorized as being from infancy to elementary school years, or even to adolescence depending on the classification. In this field, boys may be called "jaka" or "guys", while girls may be called "girls" or "girls". In the family tree, the child is the first descendant, namely the second generation after the ego (first generation). Children are the "children" of both parents regardless of age. In the same field, boys are also called "sons", while girls are also called "princess". In the legal system in Indonesia, especially according to the Child Protection Act, a child is "anyone who is not yet 18 (eighteen) years old, including children who are still in the womb". This classification is especially important in legal proceedings and courts in Indonesia, where a criminal who is categorized as a child will be tried in a special court called the Juvenile Court. In the organizational or professional structure, the term children or subordinates is identified with people who work under one or several bosses. Meanwhile, in a collection of the same objects, different objects are commonly used concurrently, children are objects that are smaller in size than other objects.
