Ya Tuhan, berkatilah bangsa Hongaria Dengan rahmat dan kasih-Mu Lindungilah ia dengan naungan-Mu Dari menatan musuh-musuhnya Semoga kesengsaraan ini sirna Seiring begjalannya waktu Penderitaan bangsa ini Adalah karena dosa pada masa lalu dan masa depan

Rope is a collection of linear layers, threads or strands of rope that are twisted or braided together in order to combine them into a larger, stronger shape. Rope has tensile strength so it can be used for dragging and lifting, but is too flexible to provide compressive strength. Rope is thicker and stronger than similarly constructed cables, lines, ropes, and threads. Rope can be constructed from any length, thread, fibrous material, but is generally made from natural fibers or certain synthetic fibers. Synthetic fiber ropes are significantly stronger than their natural fiber counterparts, but they also have certain disadvantages, including slippage. Common natural fibers for manila rope are hemp, linen, cotton, coir, straw, and sisal. Synthetic fibers used for rope manufacture include polypropylene, nylon, polyester (eg PET, LCP, HDPE, Vectran), polyethylene (eg Dyneema and Spectra), aramid (eg Twaron, Technora and Kevlar) and acrylics (eg Dralon). Some ropes are made from a mixture of several fibers or use co-polymer fibers. The rope can also be made of metal. Ropes have been constructed from other fibrous materials such as silk, wool, and hair, but they are not generally available. Rayon is a regenerated fiber used to make decorative ropes. Rope activity has been introduced for centuries. Ropes are usually used for various kinds of daily needs, such as for pulling, lifting, climbing, hunting and so on. As far back as 4000 BC, the ancient Egyptians were making rope from animal hair, grass or leather. Meanwhile, the Chinese themselves began to make rope from hemp fiber. The manufacture of rope then spread to Asia and Europe. In the late 1700s, rope making was already using a machine.

Mongolia (Mongolian: Монгол Улс, Mongolian Uls) is a unitary state with a semi-presidential system with a constitutional republic and also a landlocked country in East Asia. The country is bordered by Russia to the north and China to the south. Mongolia was the center of the Mongol Empire in the 13th century but was ruled by the Qing dynasty from the late 17th century until an independent government was formed with the help of the Soviet Union in 1921. However, Mongolia's independence was not recognized by China until 1949. After the communists took control of mainland China , China finally recognized the independence of Mongolia. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Mongolia embraced democracy. With an area comparable to that of Alaska, most of Mongolia is arid, mostly grassland with mountains to the west and north and the Gobi Desert to the south. The majority of the population are ethnic Mongolians who adhere to Tibetan Buddhism with a nomadic life. With an area of ​​1,564,116 km2 (603,909 sq mi), Mongolia is the 19th largest country in the world (after Iran and before Peru). The geography of the country is the Gobi Desert in the south and the cold mountainous region in the north. Much of Mongolia also consists of steppes. The highest point in Mongolia is Khüiten Hill in Tavan bogd at 4,374 m (14,350 ft). Most of the country experiences hot summers and very cold winters (January averages −30°C (−22°F)). Ulaanbaatar, the nation's capital, is the nation's capital with the lowest average temperature in the world. Mongolia was famous in the 13th century under Genghis Khan for conquering various kingdoms in Eurasia. After the death of Genghis Khan, Mongolia was divided into several powerful states and split in the 14th century.

Alaska (/əˈlæskə/ ( listen)) is a state of the United States located in the Western United States in the far northwest of North America. Alaska is a US semi-exclave bordered by land with the Canadian territories of the Province of British Columbia and the Yukon Territory to the east and by sea with the Russian territory in the Chukotka Autonomous Okrug to the west, just across the Bering Strait. To the north of Alaska are the Chukchi and Beaufort Seas of the Arctic Ocean, while the Pacific Ocean lies to the south and southwest. By area, Alaska is the largest US state. Alaska is the 7th largest subnational division in the world. This state is the third least populated and the most sparsely populated in the United States. But Alaska is by far the most populous region north of the Americas' 60th parallel, with a population of 736,081 in 2020—more than four times the population of Northern Canada and Greenland combined. About half of Alaska's total population lives in the Anchorage metropolitan area. The state capital is Juneau, the second largest city in the US by area, even larger than the states of Rhode Island and Delaware. The former capital of Alaska, Sitka, is the largest city in the US by area. Alaska has been home to various indigenous peoples for thousands of years; it is widely believed that this area served as the entry point for the early settlement of North America via the Bering land bridge. The Russian Empire was the first to actively colonize the area since the 18th century, eventually establishing Russian America, which spans most of today's states. The cost and difficulty of maintaining possession of this distant Alaska prompted the Russian Empire to sell it to the US in 1867 for US$7.2 million (equivalent to $140 million in 2021), or about Rp.70,500/km².

Alaska underwent several administrative changes before being organized as a territory on May 11, 1912. Alaska was recognized as the 49th state of the US on January 3, 1959. Despite being one of the states with the smallest economy in the US, Alaska's per capita income is among the highest, due to the diversified sector dominated by fisheries, natural gas, and oil, all of which are abundant. United States Armed Forces bases and tourism are also an important part of Alaska's economy; more than half of the state's territory is federally owned public land, including many national forests, national parks, and wildlife reserves. Native Alaskans are proportionately the highest of all the US states, at over 15 percent. 20 native Alaskan languages ​​are still spoken and Native Alaskans have considerable influence in local and state politics. The name "Alaska" (Russian: Аля́ска, pronounced: Alyáska) was introduced during colonial Russia when the name was used to refer to the Alaska Peninsula. "Alaska" comes from the Aleut idiom, "alaxsxaq", which means "land" or more literally, "the object towards which the sea acts". This region is also known as "Alyeska", "the great land", an Aleut word with the same root origin. Many indigenous peoples occupied Alaska for thousands of years before the arrival of European peoples to the area. Linguistic and DNA studies conducted here have provided evidence for the settlement of North America via the Bering land bridge. In the Upward Sun Riverside in the Tanana Valley in Alaska, the remains of a six-week-old baby were found. The baby's DNA suggests it belonged to a genetically separate population from other native groups that existed elsewhere in the New World in the late Pleistocene.

Djibouti, officially the Republic of Djibouti (French: République de Djibouti, Arabic: جمهورية جيبوتي‎), is a country located in East Africa on the Gulf of Aden, the entrance to the Mediterranean Sea. Merdeka on 27 June 1977. Formerly known as Land of French Somalia or Afar and Assa then changed to Djibouti. It is neighbors with Ethiopia to the south and Somalia to the southeast. This country, which has an area equivalent to Donggala Regency, is important for Ethiopia because 60% of its exports pass through this country. The Republic of Djibouti became independent on 27 June 1977. Djibouti is a successor to French Somaliland (later called the French Territory of the Afar and Issas), which was created in the first half of the 19th century as a result of French interests in the Horn of Africa. However, the history of the Djibouti is recorded in the poetry and songs of its nomadic people, dating back thousands of years to a time when the Djibouti traded leather and spices in ancient Egypt, India, and China. Through close contact with the Arabian peninsula for more than 1,000 years, the Somali and Afar peoples of this region became one of the African peoples who converted to Islam. Djibouti is a Muslim country that regularly takes part in Islamic as well as Arab meetings. Djibouti is a republic since its independence from France in 1977, and held legislative and presidential elections in 1981. The country maintains a separation of powers: legislative, executive and judicial. Djibouti is divided into 6 regions: The economy in Djibouti is mostly supported by port services and land leasing for the headquarters of foreign troops. In order to improve its economy, the Government of Djibouti has set 2035 as the year of achieving their target of becoming trade and logistics links in Africa. For this reason, the Djibouti government has set a 5-year development plan starting from 2015 to 2019 under the name Strategy of Accelerated Growth and Promotion of Employment (SCAPE).

Various development plans in the economic sector in SCAPE up to 2019 are: 1. Achieving a 10% annual gross domestic product (GDP) growth. Reducing the number of unemployed up to 38% of the total population.3. Reduce the number of people living below the poverty line by up to 20% of the total population.4. Realizing the position of Djibouti as a regional relationship.5. Aligning the basic level education system and holding various vocational training/education so that available human resources can meet workforce needs. 6. Guarantee the availability of health services nationally and reduce the number of deaths during childbirth to 15%, newborn deaths to 25%; and under five mortality to only 30%. Reducing gender inequality.8. Increasing people's access to clean water through seawater distillation projects, connecting water pipes from Ethiopia and drilling springs in the northern region so that access to clean water reaches 85% of the total population.9. Reducing the number of slum settlements (target 0%) through the provision of decent housing for underprivileged people. Increasing awareness and resilience of the population against the effects of global climate change. To diversify the profession into sectors that have not been taken seriously, namely tourism and modern marine fisheries. GDP growth in Djibouti is expected to stabilize at 6-8% in the long term, taking into account that large investment projects such as the construction of deep sea ports, railways and resources are already functioning and generating revenue for the government. on foreign loans in completing various infrastructure development projects, including in this case the construction of a railroad from Ethiopia and the construction of various deep sea ports. The amount of foreign loans which reached 90.70% (2017) of GDP has raised concerns from the IMF and therefore the Government of Djibouti was advised to rearrange their foreign borrowing strategy.

Comets are celestial bodies that revolve around the sun in elliptical, parabolic or hyperbolic orbits. The term "comet" comes from the Greek, cometes (κομήτης) which means "long hair". Another term is a comet which is imprecise because comets are not stars at all. The Javanese call it a cubeb latitude because it has a 'steamed' or dusty tail. Besides that, the tail also resembles a dried cubeb. Comets are formed from ice and dust. Comets consist of a collection of dust and gas that freezes when they are far from the Sun. When they approach the Sun, some of the comet constituents evaporate to form a gas head and tail. Comets also surround the Sun, so they are included in the solar system. Comets are incandescent gases with orbits The "tail" of a comet can reach millions of km. Some comets travel farther in space than planets. Some comets take thousands of years to complete one orbit around the Sun. Comets can be seen when they are far from the sun, the part that is first seen is the comet core. Comets are celestial bodies similar to asteroids, but composed almost entirely of frozen gas (carbon dioxide, methane, water) and dust. Comets are often also called comets. Comets have orbits or trajectories that are ellipses, more oval and longer than planetary orbits. Comets are celestial bodies like layers of rock that appear to have light due to the friction of atoms in the air. For centuries, the appearance of a comet was believed to be a sign of impending catastrophe. The appearance of a comet and occasionally its movement is recorded accurately. Babylonian and Chinese astronomers believed that comets were objects circulating in space like planets.

The Greeks thought that comets were an atmospheric phenomenon, a kind of water vapor that comes from the surface of the Earth. This view was widely accepted until the 16th century, when Tycho Brahe presented his view that a comet was not only a natural phenomenon, but was believed to be a celestial body farther from the earth than the moon. A century later, Isaac Newton devised a method for calculating the orbit of a comet based on its observable path in space. Newton determined that the comet that appeared in December 1680 followed a very elongated parabolic orbit. Edmond Halley, a scientist who lived a contemporary of Newton, found that the orbits of the comets that had appeared in 1531, 1607, and 1682 were nearly identical. This discovery led to the conclusion that the three sightings involved the same comet. He then predicted that the comet would appear again in 1758. Unfortunately, he was not old enough to be able to witness the truth of his prediction. The sighting of this comet-which was later named Halley's comet-in fact has been recorded 20 times since 239 BC. Its last appearance was in 1985-1986. Newly discovered comets are usually named according to the year they were discovered plus a letter indicating the order in which the comet appeared in the year it was discovered. When the date when a comet reaches perihelion is observable, the comet is immediately named according to the digits of the current calendar year followed by Roman numerals indicating the chronological order of its passage at perihelion that year (eg, 1882 II). Some comets are named after their discoverers, for example Halley's comet; also comet Hale-Bopp named after the two amateur astronomers who reported sightings on the same night in 1995.

Peat is a type of soil formed from the accumulation of half-decayed plant remains; Therefore, the organic matter content is high. The soil which mainly forms in these wetlands is known in English as peat; and peatlands in various parts of the world are known by various names such as bog, moor, muskeg, pocosin, mire, and others. The term peat itself is absorbed from the regional language of Banjar. As an organic material, peat can be used as an energy source. The volume of peat worldwide is estimated at 4 trillion m³, which covers an area of ​​approximately 3 million km² or about 2% of the world's land area, and contains an energy potential of approximately 8 billion terajoules. Peat deposits are scattered in many parts of the world, especially in Russia, Belarus, Ukraine, Ireland, Finland, Estonia, Scotland, Poland, northern Germany, the Netherlands, Scandinavia, and in North America, especially in Canada, Michigan, Minnesota, the Everglades in Florida , and in the Sacramento-San Joaquin River delta in California. The peat content in the southern hemisphere is less, because the land area is narrower; however peat can be found in New Zealand, Kerguelen, southern Patagonia/Tierra del Fuego and the Falkland Islands. About 60% of the world's wetlands are peat; and about 7% of those peatlands have been cleared and utilized for agricultural and forestry purposes. When conditions are right, peat can turn into a type of coal over a period of geological time. Peat forms when decaying plant parts are inhibited, usually in swampy areas, due to high acidity or anaerobic conditions in local waters. It is not surprising that most of the peat soil is composed of flakes and pieces of plant remains, leaves, twigs, bark, even large logs, which have not completely decomposed.

Sometimes it is also found, because the absence of oxygen inhibits decomposition, remains of dead animals and insects that are also preserved in layers of peat. Commonly in the world, referred to as peat if the organic matter content in the soil exceeds 30%; however, peat swamp forests in Indonesia generally contain more than 65% and are more than 50cm deep. Soil with an organic matter content between 35–65% is also commonly called muck. The addition of peat layers and the degree of decomposition (humification) mainly depend on the composition of the peat and the intensity of inundation. Peat that forms in very wet conditions decomposes less, and thus accumulates relatively quickly, compared to peat that forms on drier lands. These properties allow climatologists to use peat as an indicator of climate change in the past. Likewise, through an analysis of the composition of peat, especially the type and amount of organic matter constituents, archaeologists can reconstruct an ecological picture of ancient times. Under the right conditions, peat is also an early stage of coal formation. Recent bog peat, formed in the high latitudes at the end of the last Ice Age, about 9,000 years ago. This peat is still growing in thickness at a rate of about a few millimeters a year. But the world's peat is believed to have begun to form no less than 360 million years ago; and now stores about 550 Gt of carbon. Peat is soft and easy to press. When pressed, the water content in the peat can be forced out. When dried, peat can be used as a fuel source of energy. Peat is an important root material in countries where the tree is scarce such as Ireland and Scotland, traditionally used for cooking and household heating.

Chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is a poultry that is usually kept for its meat, eggs and feathers. Domestic chickens are direct descendants of a subspecies of jungle fowl known as the red jungle fowl (Gallus gallus) or bangkiwa chicken (bankiva fowl). All chickens are theropods like tyrannosaurs. Cross-breeding between chicken breeds has produced hundreds of superior lines or pure lines with various functions; the most common are broiler chickens (to be cut) and laying hens (to take the eggs). The common chicken can also be crossed with its close relative, the green jungle fowl, which produces a barren hybrid whose male is known as the bekisar chicken. Chicken supplies two sources of protein in food: chicken meat and eggs. The traditional view of poultry farming on the domestication of this species is set out in the Encyclopædia Britannica (2007): "Humans first domesticated chickens of Indian origin for cockfighting purposes in Asia, Africa and Europe. No special attention was paid to egg or meat production. Domesticated chickens originated from the domestication of the red jungle fowl (bangkiwa chicken, Gallus gallus) which lives in India.However, molecular testing suggests the possibility of germplasm contribution from G. sonneratii, because the red jungle fowl does not have the characteristic yellow color of the skin which is one of the characteristics of domesticated chickens. Chickens show morphological differences between the two sexes (sexual dimorphism). Roosters (jago) are more attractive, are larger in size, have long spurs, have a larger comb, and have long, dangling tail feathers. Hens (baboons) are relatively small, small in size , short or barely visible bristles, small comb, and short tail feathers.Regarding sex in i is regulated by the hormone system. If there is a disturbance in the physiological function of the body, the hen can change sex to become a male because adult chickens still have ovotestis which are dormant and can be active at any time.

Journalists, reporters or journalists (English: journalist) are people who carry out journalistic work and/or journalistic tasks on a regular basis, or in another definition, journalists can be said to be people whose job is to search for and compile news for publication, both print media, electronic media, as well as online media. someone who does journalistic work, journalistic activities on a regular basis or someone who regularly writes news (in the form of reports) and his writings are published regularly. This report can then be published in mass media, such as newspapers, television, radio, magazines, documentary films, and the internet, online cyber media. Journalists look for their sources to write about in their report editors; and their editors are expected to write the most objective and unbiased reports in the service of society. The term journalist just appeared in Indonesia after the influence of communication science tended to be oriented to the United States. This term then has an impact on the naming of journalistic positions. For example, "editor" becomes "editor." When the Alliance of Independent Journalists was founded, there was awareness about the term journalist. According to this alliance, journalism is a profession or the name of someone whose work is related to the contents of the mass media. Journalists include columnists, freelance writers, photographers, and editorial graphic designers. However, in reference to its use, the term journalist refers more to the definition of a journalist. Meanwhile, journalists, in the definition of the Indonesian Journalists Association, relate to writing activities, which include seeking data (research, coverage, verification) to complete their reports. Journalists are required to be objective, this is different from columnists who can express their subjectivity. In the early 19th century, journalist meant someone who wrote for journals, like Charles Dickens early in his career. In the last century this has meant being a writer for newspapers as well as magazines.

The Bible is texts, or religious books written at different times and by different authors in different locations. Jews and Christians (Christians) view the books of the Bible as the result of divine inspiration, and as an authoritative record of the relationship between God and humans. These texts include historical accounts focused on theology, hymns, prayers, proverbs, parables, letters (epistola), exhortations, essays, poetry, and prophecies. Canonical Bibles vary depending on tradition or group; a number of Bible canons have evolved, with overlapping and divergent content. The Christian Old Testament overlaps with the Hebrew Bible and Greek Septuagint; The Hebrew Bible is known in Judaism as the Tanakh. The New Testament is a collection of writings by early Christians, believed to be many of them disciples of Jesus Christ, written in first-century Koine Greek. These early Christian Greek writings consist of various narratives, letters, and apocalyptic writings. Among Christian denominations there is some difference of opinion regarding the content of the canon, especially in the Apocrypha, that is, a number of works which are viewed with varying degrees of reverence. Different Christian circles approach the Bible differently. Roman Catholic, Anglican, and Eastern Orthodox Christians emphasize the harmony and importance of the Bible and sacred tradition, while Protestant Christians focus on the concept of sola scriptura, or just the Bible. This concept arose during the Protestant Reformation, and many Protestant denominations continue to support the use of the Bible as the sole source of Christian teaching to this day. With an estimated total sales of over 5 billion copies, the Bible is widely considered the best-selling book of all time. It is estimated that its annual sales are 100 million copies, and it has had a major impact on literature and history, especially in the Western world.

The Gutenberg Bible was the first book to be mass printed, and the first to be printed using a mobile type press. The English word Bible is derived from the Latin biblia, from the same word in medieval Latin and Late Latin and from the Koine Greek word τὰ βιβλία ta biblia "the books" (singular βιβλίον biblion). The medieval Latin word biblia is short for biblia sacra "scriptures", whereas biblia in Greek and Late Latin is the gender-neutral plural (gen. bibliorum). It was gradually assumed as a singular feminine noun (biblia, gen. bibliae) in medieval Latin, and was later absorbed as a singular form in the vernacular languages ​​of Western Europe. The Latin phrase biblia sacra "holy books" translating the Greek phrase τὰ βιβλία τὰ ἅγια ta biblia ta hagia, "the holy books". The word βιβλίον itself literally means "paper" or "scroll" and became used as a common word for "book" or "book". The word is a shortened form of βύβλος byblos, "Egyptian papyrus", possibly so named after the Phoenician seaport—namely Byblos (also known as Gebal)—from where the Egyptian papyri were exported to Greece. The Greek phrase ta biblia (literally "small papyrus books") is "an expression used by Hellenistic Jews to describe their holy books (Septuagint). Christian use of the term can be traced to AD 223. An academic Bible scholar F.F. Bruce notes that John Chrysostom was apparently the first writer (in his Homily on Matthew, delivered between 386 and 388) to use the Greek phrase ta biblia ("the books") to describe the Old and New Testaments together.

Nutmeg (Myristica fragrans) is a plant in the form of a tree originating from the Banda Islands, Maluku. Due to its high value as a spice, nutmeg fruit and seeds have been important trade commodities since Roman times. Nutmeg is mentioned in Pliny's encyclopedia "The Old One". Since the time of European exploration, nutmeg has spread widely in other tropical regions such as Mauritius and the Caribbean (Grenada). The term nutmeg is also used for traded nutmeg. This plant has two houses (dioecious) so that it is known as male and female trees. The leaves are slender elliptical. The fruit is oval in shape like a lemon, yellow in color, fleshy and has a distinctive aroma because it contains essential oils in the flesh. When ripe, the skin and flesh of the fruit open and the seeds will appear wrapped in red mace. One fruit produces one brown seed. Utilization of nutmeg can be in the form of seeds, coated seeds (arillus), and fruit flesh. In trade, coated nutmeg is called mace, or in English it is called mace, in pharmaceutical terms it is called myristicae arillus or macis). The flesh of the nutmeg is called myristicae fructus cortex. The nutmeg plant is a plant that takes a long time to grow until it is harvested. The first harvest takes place 7 to 9 years after the trees are planted and reaches maximum production capacity after 25 years. The growth can reach 20m and its age can reach hundreds of years. Before being marketed, the seeds are dried in the sun to dry after being separated from the mace. This drying takes six to eight weeks. The inside of the bean will shrink in this process and you will hear a sound when the bean is shaken. The seed shell will crack and the inside of the seed is sold as nutmeg. Nutmeg contains 7-14% essential oil. Nutmeg powder is used as a flavoring for bread or cakes, puddings, sauces, vegetables, and refreshing drinks (such as eggnog).

The oil is also used as a mixture of perfume or soap. In addition, this plant is also rich in benefits, including nutmeg which consists of the skin can be used as an additional ingredient for mosquito repellents; the meat, which contains a lot of nutrients, can be used as the basic material for making various types of food and drinks such as sweets, syrups and candies; the seeds and mace are often used as the main ingredients for making essential oils; Likewise with the leaves, but the flesh of the fruit is often used as raw material for essential oils. Nutmeg plants in general can grow in areas with an altitude of around 0-700 meters above sea level with a relatively high need for rainfall, namely 2000-3500 mm/year and humidity of around 50-80%. This plant can usually grow to a tree height of 5-15 meters or can even reach 30 meters. Nutmeg is suitable for growing at temperatures around 20-30oC with the soil structure where it grows has a fairly large range, from dense to sandy soil and has an acidity degree of 5.5 – 7. In nurseries, nutmeg plants are usually watered every 1-2 times a day. if there is no rain at all accompanied by weeding of the surrounding weeds and also soil loosening treatment. Plant fertilizers such as manure, compost, or inorganic fertilizers such as urea are also added every 3 months. Harvesting nutmeg can be done 3 times a year, namely at the beginning of the rainy season which gives the best quality nutmeg yields, then in the middle of the rainy season when the number of ready-to-harvest nutmeg is usually the highest among other periods, then the amount of nutmeg ready for harvest decreases and can be harvested at the end of the rainy season. Nutmeg plants are spread in regions or countries that have tropical climates including Guangdong and Yunnan in China, Taiwan, Malaysia, Grenada in the Caribbean Islands, Kerala in India, Sri Lanka and South Africa, especially also in their country of origin, namely Indonesia.

Charles the Great (French: Charlemagne; German: Karl der Große; Latin: Carolus Magnus, Karolus Magnus; English: Charles the Great, Italian: Carlo Magno) (742 or 747 – 28 January 814), was a tribal king Frank from 768 to 814 and Lombard from 774 to 814. He was crowned Imperator Augustus in Rome on Christmas Day 800 by Pope Leo III, and is therefore considered to be the founder of the Holy Roman Empire (under the title Charles I). The achievements and progress he created have made him considered the founding father of France and Germany and even the founding father of Europe. Through a series of wars and conquests, he expanded his realm to include most of Western Europe. In fact, he was the first emperor in the West since the collapse of the Roman Empire. The name Karolus is taken from the name of his grandfather, Karl Martell, a warrior who repelled Muslim troops from French territory. In English and French, he is known as Charles. Meanwhile, he is also known as Carolus in Latin. Because of his accomplishments, the name Charles was adopted as a substitute for "king" in various European languages, including Polish: król, Ukrainian: король (korol'), Czech: král, Slovak: kráľ, Hungarian: király, Lithuanian: : karalius, Latvian: karalis, Russian: король, Macedonian: крал, Bulgarian: крал, Serbo-Croatian: краљ/kralj, Turkish: kral. This adaptation is similar to the name Caesars which is also used in place of the word "king", such as kaiser and tsar (or czar). Charles the Great, grandson of Charles Martell, the heroic savior of Europe, ended the era of barbarian nations in Europe by becoming the first Western Emperor to be recognized by the Pope and a Christian since the time of the barbarian Odoaker in 476.

Many of the peoples of Western Europe who since the fall of the Western Roman Empire did not have a supreme government were more or less reunited under Charles the Great. With the existence of unity, wars became rare and the people under the reign of Charles I could focus on other things such as education, culture, religion and finances. When he began his reign in 768, Charles co-reigned with his younger brother Charles. Charles got the western and northern territories bordering the Atlantic ocean, and Karloman got the eastern and southern territories. However, they do not get along with one another. Their tensions led to fears of war breaking out between them, which only ended with Charles' death on December 4, 771. In 771, after Charles had inherited his younger brother's territories, he began three decades of subjection. He pushed the borders of his kingdom eastward and eventually he ruled Burgundy, most of Italy, Alamania, Bavaria and Thuringia. In the north he controlled Saxony and Frisia. To the east of the two areas, he created areas with special military organizations called markers. These areas stretch from the Baltic Sea to the Adriatic. For the first time, most of Europe enjoyed stable leadership. Until Christmas 800, Charles held the title of king of the Franks. On that holy day, Pope Leo III crowned him emperor of the Holy Roman empire, and once again it appeared that Western Europe had an emperor who followed in the footsteps of Constantine the Great. From then on he became known as Carolus Magnus, "Carol the Great". Certainly Charles the Great took seriously the idea that he had become a Christian emperor, because all of his letters read: "Carolus, by the grace of God, Emperor of the Romans".

Fitness is the body's ability to adjust to the physical load it receives from carrying out daily activities. Fitness is a need that a person needs to fulfill in order to be able to carry out daily activities properly without experiencing health problems and excessive fatigue. Health-related components of fitness include muscle strength, muscular endurance, aerobic endurance, and flexibility. As well as components of physical fitness related to skills including coordination, agility, movement speed, muscle explosiveness, and balance. The components of physical fitness are determining factors for the degree of condition of each individual. fitness training is important for every individual to maintain their physical condition so that they are able to carry out activities from day to day, fitness training is related to physical activities such as running, cycling, swimming and other physical activities, for humans in general to be able to maintain their physical condition or minimal fitness Do 30 minutes of exercise each day, outside of your daily activities or routine. recommended exercises such as jogging, cycling, swimming, gymnastics, etc. Physical fitness has been proven to be able to maintain blood pressure in the body. Being active and doing regular physical exercise can increase the strength of the heart as the main organ that plays a role in regulating systolic and diastolic blood pressure. Blood pressure in the body will increase when humans are actively moving and will return to normal when they stop doing activities. This cardiovascular process will occur more easily if humans regularly carry out physical activity. Several studies have found a link between increased physical activity and reduced inflammation. Physical activity can promote short-term responses to inflammation and long-term anti-inflammatory effects. Physical activity can boost the immune system. This effect depends on hormone concentrations (such as reproductive hormones, metabolic hormones, and growth hormones), body temperature, blood flow, hydration, and body position.

Prodikos is a philosopher who is classified as a sophist. He lived a contemporary of Socrates. He is best known for his philosophy teaching in ethics and linguistics. His famous ethical teaching is conveyed through a myth about Hercules. Prodikos comes from the island of Keos which is located in the Aegean Sea. It lived around the 5th century BC, and became known in 430 BC. It is known that he was younger than Protagoras. He once had students sent by Socrates, so it can be concluded that he was on good terms with Socrates. Prodikos is a lecturer in ethics as well as on other public issues. He also carried out the duties of ambassador of Athens. Prodikos is also known to teach rhetoric and oration techniques to many rich young men, so he gets a high fee. Due to his philosophical views which rejected Greek religion, Prodikos had to deal with the local government in Athens. Prodikos adheres to a pessimistic view of life. Death is seen as a way to escape from the hardships of human life. The fear of death is contrary to human common sense. According to Prodikos, religion is a human invention. In the beginning, humans worshiped natural forces as gods, such as the sun, moon, rivers, lakes, trees, and so on. An example is the worship of the Nile in Egypt. In the next stage, people who find certain skills are worshiped as gods. These skills include agriculture, wine growing, and iron processing. Examples of this stage are the Greek gods Demeter, Dionysos, and Hephaistos, all of whom were associated with certain skills. The prayers that humans make are seen as excessive. Prodikos is famous for his linguistic thinking. He places great emphasis on the correct understanding of words, even for synonymous words.

Uranium is a chemical element in the periodic table having the symbol U and atomic number 92. It is a silvery-white radioactive metal included in the actinide series in the periodic table. Uranium has 92 protons and 92 electrons, with 6 valence electrons. The uranium nucleus binds 141 to 146 neutrons, so there are 6 uranium isotopes. The most common isotopes are uranium-238 (146 neutrons) and uranium-235 (143 neutrons). All uranium isotopes are unstable and weakly radioactive. Uranium has the second heaviest atomic weight (after plutonium) of all the chemical elements that can be found naturally. Uranium is about 70% more dense than lead, but it is not as dense as gold or tungsten. Uranium can be found naturally in low concentrations (a few parts per million (ppm)) in soil, rocks, and water. Uranium that can be found naturally is uranium-238 (99.2739–99.2752%), uranium-235 (0.7198–0.7202%), and traces of uranium-234 (0.0050–0.0059%) . Uranium decays slowly by emitting alpha particles. The half-life of uranium-238 is about 4.47 billion years, while that of uranium-235 is 704 million years. Therefore, uranium can be used to determine the age of the Earth. Uranium-235 is the only naturally occurring isotope of a chemical element that is fissile (i.e. it can sustain the chain reaction in nuclear fission), whereas uranium-238 can be fissile using fast neutrons. In addition, uranium-238 can also be transmuted into fissile plutonium-239 in nuclear reactors. Another uranium isotope that is also fissile is uranium-233, which can be produced from thorium. Here are some facts about uranium: Subcritical chunks of naturally enriched uranium and plutonium feel warm to the touch, due to the heat energy released when they spontaneously fission.

Phosphorus is a chemical element with the symbol P and atomic number 15. Elemental phosphorus exists in two main forms, white phosphorus and red phosphorus, but because it is so reactive, it is never found as a free element on Earth. It has a concentration in the Earth's crust of about one gram per kilogram (compared to about 0.06 grams of copper). In minerals, phosphorus generally occurs as phosphate. Elemental phosphorus was first isolated as white phosphorus in 1669. White phosphorus gives off a faint glow when exposed to oxygen – hence its name from Greek mythology, Φωσφόρος (phosphoros) meaning 'bringer of light' (Latin Lucifer), referring to the "Morning Star", planet Venus. The term phosphorescence, meaning glow after illumination, derives from this property of phosphorescence, although the word has been used for the different physical processes that produce light. The glow of phosphorus is caused by the oxidation of white (but not red) phosphorus — a process now called chemiluminescence. Along with nitrogen, arsenic, antimony, and bismuth, phosphorus is classified as a pnictogen. Phosphorus is an element essential for sustaining life, largely through phosphate, a compound containing the phosphate ion, PO43−. Phosphates are components of DNA, RNA, ATP, and phospholipids, complex compounds that are fundamental to cells. Elemental phosphorus was first isolated from human urine, and bone ash was an important initial source of phosphate. Phosphate mines contain fossils because phosphate is present in fossilized deposits of animal remains and excrement. Low phosphate levels are an important threshold for growth in some aquatic systems. Most of the phosphorus compounds mined are consumed as fertilizer. Phosphate is needed to replace the phosphorus that plants excrete from the soil, and its annual demand is increasing almost twice as fast as the human population is growing.

Other applications include organophosphate compounds in detergents, pesticides, and nerve agents. This element was discovered by Hannig Brand in 1669 in Hamburg, Germany. He found this element by 'distilling' urine through a process of evaporation and after he evaporated 50 buckets of urine, he found the element he wanted. Its name comes from the Greek word Phosphoros, Φωσφόρος (but phosphorus is Latin) which means 'bringer of light' because of its unique glow-in-the dark. and now the findings have been highly developed and very useful for mankind. In general phosphorus forms a white, sticky solid which has an unpleasant odor but when pure is colorless and transparent. This nonmetal is insoluble in water, but soluble in carbon disulfide. Pure phosphorus ignites spontaneously in air to form phosphorus pentoxide. Phosphorus can exist in four or more allotropic forms: white (or yellow), red, and black (or purple). The most common are red and white phosphorus, both grouped into four atoms in a tetrahedral shape. White phosphorus burns when in contact with air and can turn red phosphorus when exposed to heat or light. White phosphorus can also exist in alpha and beta states separated by a transition temperature of -3.8°C. Red phosphorus is relatively more stable and sublimes at 170°C at 1 atm vapor pressure, but burns on impact or friction. The allotrope of black phosphorus has a graphite-like structure – the atoms are arranged in hexagonal layers that conduct electricity. Phosphorus is often also called phosphorus. But phosphorus refers to substances that can emit light because they experience phosphorescence. Phosphorus can give off light under certain circumstances, but this phenomenon is not phosphorescence, but chemiluminescence.

The anus, rectum, or buttock (Latin: anus) is an opening from the rectum to the outside of the body. The human anus is located in the middle of the buttocks, posterior to the peritoneum. The opening and closing of the anus is regulated by the sphincter muscles. There are two anal sphincter muscles (inner and outer). This muscle helps hold stool during defecation. One of the sphincter muscles is a smooth muscle that works without command, while the other is a skeletal muscle. Faeces are removed from the body through the process of defecation which is the main function of the anus. The anus is often regarded as a taboo part by various social groups. Reference is needed] It is a canal about 4 cm long which is surrounded by the anal sphincter. The upper part is covered by the rectal glandular mucosa. The function of the anal canal is to act as a link between the rectum and the outside of the body so that feces can be expelled. Is a room about 12 to 15 cm long that is between the end of the large intestine (after the sigmoid/descending colon) and ends at the anus. The function of the rectum is to temporarily store feces, tell the brain to defecate immediately, and help push feces during bowel movements. When the rectum is full of feces, the rectum will expand and the nervous system will send impulses (stimulation) to the brain so that the urge to defecate arises. Is a ring of striated muscle that surrounds the anal canal with a circumference of 2.5 to 4 cm. This internal anal sphincter is related to the external anal sphincter although they are quite separated. It is about 5 mm thick. The function of the internal anal sphincter is to regulate the passage of feces during defecation. Is an elliptical striated muscle fiber and attached to the wall of the anus.

About 8 to 10 cm long. The function of the external anal sphincter is to open and close the anal canal. Is the line that divides between the two-thirds (top) and the third (bottom) of the anus. The function of this line is very important because the top and bottom of the pectinate line have many differences. For example, if a hemorrhoid occurs above the pectinate line, that type of hemorrhoid is called a painless internal hemorrhoid. Whereas if it is below, it is called external hemorrhoids and is painful. The embryological origin is also different, the upper part is from the endoderm, while the lower part is from the ectoderm. Are a number of vertical folds produced by the mucous membrane and muscle tissue at the top of the anus. The function of the anal column is as a barrier to the anal wall. When the rectum is full, the pressure increases inside and forces the walls of the anal canal. This coercion causes feces to enter the anal canal. Expenditures are regulated by the sphincter muscles. To prevent diseases of the anus and in order to live a healthy life, humans always clean the anus after defecation. Usually the anus is cleaned by rinsing with water or toilet paper. jmpl|260px| Female (left) and male (right) anus. During puberty, the hormone testosterone has an impact on several parts of the male body (around 13-14 years), such as the growth of pubic hair around the anus. Pubic hair will grow around the anus in adolescents aged 18 years... Cleanliness is an important factor for the health of the area around the anus. Washing it with soap and water will keep the anus clean. Harsh soaps or cleaning with abrasive toilet paper can irritate the skin around the tonsils and can itch. Penetration of the anus with a penis or other object can irritate the inside of the anus.

Politics (Greek: Πολιτικά, Politiká; Arabic: سياسة, siyasah), which means from, for, or relating to citizens), is the process of formation in society which, among other things, takes the form of decision-making processes, especially within the state. This definition is an attempt to combine different definitions regarding the nature of political positions known in political science. It can be used positively in the context of compromising and non-violent political solutions, or descriptively as the art or science of government, but it also often carries negative connotations. The concept has been defined in a variety of ways, and different approaches have fundamentally different views on whether it should be used broadly or limitedly, empirically or normatively, and whether conflict or cooperation is more important for that. Various methods are used in politics, including promoting one's own political views among people, negotiating with other political subjects, making laws, and using internal and external force, including war against enemies. Politics is exercised at various social levels, from clans or tribes in traditional societies, through modern local governments, companies and institutions to sovereign states, to the international level. Various methods are used in politics, including promoting one's own political views among people, negotiating with other political subjects, making laws, and using internal and external force, including war against enemies. Politics is exercised at various social levels, from clans or tribes in traditional societies, through modern local governments, companies and institutions to sovereign states, to the international level. In modern nation states, people often form political parties to represent their ideas. Party members often agree to take the same position on many issues and agree to support equal welfare under unequal laws and leaders.

General elections are usually competitions between various parties. A political system is a framework that defines acceptable political methods in a society. The history of political thought can be traced back to ancient times, with such seminal works as Plato's Republic and Aristotle's Politics in the West, and the political manuscripts of Confucius and Chanakya's Arthashastra in the East. Politics (from the Greek: ,politika, 'city affairs') is a set of activities related to group decision-making, or other forms of individual power relations, distribution of water resources and status. The branch of social science that studies politics and government is referred to as political science. Politics is the interaction between the government and society in the framework of the process of making and implementing binding decisions about the common good of the people who live in a certain area. (Ramlan surbakti 1999:1) In addition, politics can also be viewed from different perspectives, namely: In the context of understanding politics, it is necessary to understand several keys, including: legitimacy, political system, political behavior, political participation, political process, and also no less important to know the ins and outs of political parties. ¹'"And there is also Aristotle making a classification of the form of government. The criteria or basis for the assessment used are: 1. The number of people in power (sitting in government) who have morals. 2. The way and interests in running the government are required to side with the interests of the welfare of the community. Regarding the number of people who have the morals to run or hold the reins of government, there are three types of division, namely: Each of the three types of division is classified between a good (positive) form and a bad (negative) form. So that there are seven forms of government in total. The good or bad things of a government, in terms of ways and interests of leaders who occupy positions of power in running the government.

Culture is a way of life that develops and is owned by a person or group of people and is passed down from generation to generation but not hereditary. Meanwhile, culture comes from Sanskrit, namely buddhayah, which is the plural form of buddhi (mind or reason), defined as matters relating to the mind and human reason. Another form of the word culture is culture which comes from the Latin cultura. Culture is a way of life that develops and is shared by a group of people, and is passed down from generation to generation. Culture is made up of many complex elements, including religious and political systems, customs, languages, tools, clothing, buildings, and works of art. Language, like culture, is an inseparable part of human beings so that many people tend to think that it is genetically inherited. One can communicate with people of different cultures and adjust for the differences between them, thus proving that culture can be learned. Culture is a whole way of life. Culture is complex, abstract, and broad. Many aspects of culture also determine communicative behavior. These socio-cultural elements are scattered and include many human social activities. Some of the reasons why people experience difficulties when communicating with people from other cultures are seen in the definition of culture: Culture is a complex set of values ​​polarized by an image that bears a view of its own privileges. This "coercive image" takes different forms in various cultures such as "crude individualism" in America, "individual harmony with nature" in Japan, and "collective obedience" in China. -its members with guidelines regarding proper behavior and defines a world of meaning and logical value that its most humble members can borrow to gain a sense of dignity and affinity with their lives.

Thus, it is culture that provides a coherent framework for organizing one's activities and enabling it to predict the behavior of others. Culture is very closely related to society. Anthropologists Melville J. Herskovits and Bronisław Malinowski argue that everything contained in society is determined by the culture that belongs to the community itself. The term for that opinion is cultural-determinism. Herskovits views culture as something that is passed down from one generation to another, which is then referred to as superorganic. Meanwhile, according to Andreas Eppink, culture contains the entire notion of social values, social norms, knowledge, as well as all social, religious, and other structures, in addition to all intellectual and artistic statements that characterize a society. According to Edward Burnett Tylor, culture is that complex whole which includes knowledge, belief, art, morals, law, customs, and any other capabilities acquired by a person as a member of society. Selo Soemardjan and Soelaiman Soemardi stated that culture is a means of creation, taste and creation of society. Meanwhile, M. Selamet Riyadi, culture is a form of love from our ancestors which is passed on to all their descendants, and according to Koentjaraningrat, culture is the entire system of ideas and actions created by humans in the context of social life that humans possess by learning. From these various definitions, it can be concluded that culture is something that will affect the level of knowledge and includes a system of ideas or ideas contained in the human mind so that in everyday life, culture is abstract. Meanwhile, cultural embodiments are objects created by humans as cultured beings, in the form of behavior, and objects that are real, for example behavior patterns, language, tools of life, social organization, religion, art, and so on. others, all of which are intended to help humans in carrying out social life.

Museums are permanent, non-profit institutions, serving public needs, with an open nature, by carrying out efforts to collect, conserve, research, communicate, and exhibit real objects to the public for study, education, and enjoyment. Because of that it can become material for study by academics, documentation of the peculiarities of certain societies, or documentation and imaginative thinking in the future. Since 1977, 18 May has been celebrated as International Museum Day. The existence of a museum is very important because it has the responsibility and function to preserve, foster, as well as develop community culture, both tangible and intangible. Through messages that are arranged through displays and exhibition spaces, museums in Indonesia function as a means of communication and bridges that can trigger awareness and knowledge in society. The existence of museums in Indonesia is very important considering that museums do not only have a function as a protector of cultural heritage objects, but also as a place for forming ideology, discipline, and developing knowledge for the public. This is also confirmed in the ICOM code of ethics, “Museums have an important task of developing an educational role and attracting wider audiences from the community, locality, or group it serves. Interaction with the supporting community and the guidance and promotion of the heritage it supports is an integral part of the education that must be carried out by museums. Etymologically, the museum comes from the Greek word, Μουσεῖον or mouseion, which actually refers to the name of the temple for the nine goddess Muses, the children of Zeus who symbolize science and art. Another building that is known to be related to the history of the museum is part of the library complex built specifically for arts and sciences, especially philosophy and research in Alexandria by Ptolemy I Soter in 280 BC.

Museums develop along with the development of science and humans increasingly need authentic evidence regarding cultural historical records. In Indonesia, the first museum built was the Radya Pustaka Museum. Apart from that, it is also known as the Elephant Museum which is known as the most complete collection in Indonesia, the Puppet Museum, Persada Soekarno, the Textile Museum and the Indonesian National Gallery which specifically presents collections of Indonesian modern art. Initially, museums began as places to store collections belonging to wealthy individuals, families or institutions. The objects kept are usually works of art and rare objects, or collections of natural objects and archaeological artefacts. There are several museums in the world, including: Museums vary in type, from large institutions covering many categories, to small institutions that focus on a particular subject, location, or person. In addition there are universal museums whose collections represent the world and usually collections include art, science, history and natural history. The type and size of the museum is reflected in the collection. A museum usually has a core collection which is the most important object in its field. The categories of these museums include: Archaeological museum is a museum that specializes in displaying archaeological artifacts. Many archaeological museums are open museums (open air museums). In Indonesia, an example of an archaeological museum is the Trowulan Museum in Trowulan, East Java. An art museum, better known as an art gallery, is a room for exhibitions of art objects, ranging from the visual arts, including paintings, drawings and sculptures. Some other examples are ceramic art, metal art and furniture. An example of this art museum in Europe is the Merbach-Cabinet in Basel, which was originally a private collection sold to the Basel city government in 1661, and became a public museum from 1671.

Vajrayana or sometimes written Wajrayana, is a Buddhist teaching which in Indonesia is more commonly known as Tantra or Tantrayana. But many other terms are also used, such as: mantrayana, secret mantra teaching, esoteric Buddhism. Vajrayana is a teaching that developed from Mahayana Buddhism, and differs in practice, not philosophy. In Vajrayana teachings, meditation practice is often preceded by a short mantra recitation and visualization. The term "Vajrayana" comes from the word vajra which in Sanskrit means 'thunder' or 'diamond'. Vajra symbolizes diamond as the hardest element on Earth, so the term Vajrayana can mean "Indestructible and changeless Vehicle". The philosophy of Buddhism can be divided into two: Hinayana/Pratimokshayana (one of which is Theravada) and Mahayana. Hinayana emphasizes attainment as an Arahant, whereas Mahayana emphasizes attainment as a Bodhisattva. Tantrayana which is part of Mahayana is also often known by the name of the Bodhisattva path. Hinayana can be divided into Vaibhashika and Sautrantika. Whereas Mahayana is divided into Cittamatra and Madhyamika. This Madhyamaka consists of Rangtong (which includes Sautrantika and Prasangika) and Shentong (Yogacara-Madhyamaka). These four Buddhist philosophies (Vaibhasika, Sautrantika, Cittamatra, and Madhyamika) have existed since the time of Gautama Buddha, arising from the different beliefs, different levels of understanding, different attainments, and realizations of the Buddha's disciples. Vaibhasika and Sautrantika teachings are widely found in Thailand, Burma, Sri Lanka and Cambodia. This Cittamatra teaching can be found in China, Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Tibet and its surroundings. The Shentongpa Main Teachings are part of the Madyamika teachings, which believe that self-nature is not simply empty, because self-nature is Buddha-nature, which has all the qualities Buddha.

"śūnyatā sarvadriṣṭīṇām proktā niḥsaraṇam jinaiḥyeṣām tu śūnyatādṛṣṭtis tan asādhyan babhāṣire" "The Conquerors say that (realization of) Sunyata eliminates all views. Everything that holds onto Sunyata views is said to be incurable." - Nagarjuna, Mūlamadhyamakakārikā 13.8 Holding onto the Sunyata view is wrong view that does not yet understand voidness. Among all wrong views, Nagarjuna stated that this one view is beyond treatment. Because this teaching of Sunyata is so profound, it should not be seen as simply 'empty'. Initially, the Madhyamika teachings were widely found in the Himalayas, such as in Tibet, Nepal, Bhutan, Sikkim, but now they exist in various Asian countries and in Western countries. The Vajrayana teachings in general in various countries are better known as the teachings of Tibetan Buddhism, which is part of the Mahayana and was taught directly by Sakyamuni Buddha which is very suitable for practice by householders, people who live alone (not married), or people who decide to marry. lived as a monk in the Vajrayana monastery. In several countries (especially in Asia), there are many assumptions that Vajrayana is a mystical teaching, full of occult. This is actually not true. In Vajrayana, there are many methods of practice. Indeed, there are many Vajrayana practitioners who have extraordinary abilities, but this is not something mystical. This is actually a by-product of the practice, and it should be ignored. As the Buddha said, what can save us at the time of death is the Dharma, not the powers we have. Often this acquired ability becomes a hindrance in achieving our ultimate goal, which is attaining enlightenment. The by-product of this ability (siddhi) will often increase our arrogance (me-ness), which we actually have to get rid of, and is not something to be proud of.

The Young Stone Age or Neolithic is a phase or level of culture in prehistoric times which has characteristics in the form of cultural elements, such as sharpened stone tools, settled agriculture, animal husbandry, and pottery making. This phase began around the 10th millennium BC. Humans are thought to have started to really switch to a sedentary lifestyle, around 8000 BC, at which time, the ice age had completely melted away. This makes the soil more fertile, so it can be used for farming. The first towns were built, for example Jericho, which at this time grew into a 10 hectare village. Jericho is the first city with houses built of clay, and also the first city with the oldest known evidence of city defense (the evidence being watchtowers). In the Middle East, goats were raised, and wheat was planted. Due to the melting of all the ice, the sea level rose, so the land bridges in Siberia were closed. This isolated immigrants from Siberia. The end time of this age varies, depending on the region. Some isolated tribes are still experiencing the Neolithic era, even today. The Neolithic or New Stone Age began when humans started sharpening and polishing some of their stone tools after chipping them. The New Stone Age began less than ten thousand years ago. Maps of Europe in this period show outlines much the same as maps today. Great Britain and Ireland are currently separated from the European continent by the shallow waters of the North Sea, English Channel and Irish Sea. Due to the sinking of the Mediterranean region, Spain and Italy are no longer connected to North Africa by a land bridge. The plants that thrived in the colder paleolithic epoch made room for temperate animals, and vast forests began to cover what had previously been treeless prairies. Woolly rhinoceros, woolly mammoths, and cave bears became extinct; sheep and wildebeest fled to the Arctic latitudes, while hippos, elephants and other large mammals found their way to the tropics.

Animals associated with Neolithic humans are familiar species, except for the moose, wild boar and European bison. However, it is not yet known what Paleolithic humans were like, may have become extinct, may have followed the receding ice sheets and reindeer drift northeast into Siberia and the Arctic; or they may have stayed in their old locations and mingled with the neolithic people who invaded them. These new arrivals apparently originated in western Asia and northern Africa, and slowly spread throughout Europe. Neolithic humans belong to the White Race group. Their blood runs in the veins of modern European humans, who are their main descendants. Knowledge of the Neolithic Age derives, not only from things buried in the ground in Paleolithic caves, but also from remains found near or on the ground or in mounds and burial sites. Along the Baltic coast lie mounds of bone and shell, which suggest it was once an ancient human habitation. This “Kitchen Midden” is sometimes a thousand feet long, and two to three hundred feet wide, and ten feet high. Stone, bone, and wood tools, together with pottery shards and other human-made items were found in this "Kitchen Midderı". The Swiss have the remains of the lake's inhabitants, who, for protection from their enemies, lived above The lake in their hut was supported by stakes driving into the bottom of the lake. The huts are gone, but the mud around the pillars of the hut contains thousands of objects, including animal bones, seeds of various plants and fruits, tools, scraps cloth, pottery shards, household utensils and a bit of furniture.

The word "catholic" (καθολικός, katolikos; Latin: catholicus) comes from the Greek phrase καθόλου (katolou), meaning "sarwa gentlemen", "in its entirety", or "am", a compound word κατά (word), meaning " subject", and the word ὅλος (holos), which means "sarwa". The term "Catholic" (with a capital k) was first used in the early 2nd century as a designation for the whole of Christendom. In the realm of ecclesiology, this term has a long history and is used with various meanings. In Indonesia, this word can mean "matters of Catholic Christianity" or "matters of the historic teachings and practices of the Western Church". note 1] This word is used by many Christians as a designation for the Universal Church or all those who believe in Jesus Christ regardless of denomination, and is also used in a narrower sense as a designation for catholicism, which includes several historic churches with the same core beliefs. Catholicos, the title of supreme leader in a number of Eastern Churches, also comes from the same root. This term is already attached to the name of the largest Christian community in the world, namely the Catholic Church. The three main branches of Christianity in the East, namely the Eastern Orthodox Church, the Oriental Orthodox Church and the Persian Church, have always called themselves Catholic, according to the apostolic tradition and the Nicene Creed. Anglican, Lutheran, and some Methodist congregations believe that their churches are also "Catholic", in the sense of being a continuation of the First worldwide Church founded by Christ's apostles. Nevertheless, each Church interprets the term "Catholic Church" differently. For example, both the Catholic Church, the Eastern Orthodox Church, the Oriental Orthodox Church and the Persian Church assert that their denominations are continuations of the worldwide Primal Church, while all other denominations are mere fragments of it. The beliefs that characterize Catholicism, namely the beliefs of the majority of Christians who call themselves "Catholics", include episcopalism, namely glorifying bishops as the highest clergy in Christianity, and acceptance of the Nicene Creed in 381.

Catholicism is also considered as one of the four characteristics of the Church, as stated in one of the points of the Nikea creed which reads "I believe in one, holy, catholic and apostolic Church." In the Middle Ages and in modern times, there was a shift in the meaning of the terms Western Catholic and Eastern Catholic. Before the East-West Schism of 1054, these two terms only meant different areas, because there was only one Catholicism, which included both Latin-speaking Christians in the West and Greek-speaking Christians in the East. After the East-West Schism, the meaning of these terms became more complicated, and gave rise to several parallel but contradictory grammars. The forerunner to the term catholic is the word katolikos, the Greek adjective meaning "universe". Directly from the original language, or via Late Latin, the term catholic entered many other languages, and became the basis for the formation of various theological terms such as catholicism (Late Latin: catholicismus) and catholicism (Late Latin: catholicitas). The term "catholicism" is an abstract noun formed from the adjective "catholic". Its Modern Greek equivalent is καθολικισμός (katolikismos), which usually refers to the Catholic Church. The terms "catholic", "catholicism" and "catholicity" are closely related to the use of the term "Catholic Church". The oldest evidence of the use of this term is the Epistle to the Smyrna of Saint Ignatius, Bishop of Antioch, written around 108 and addressed to Christians in the city of Smyrna. In this letter, Saint Ignatius urges Christians to remain closely united with their bishop, in a sentence that reads "it would be good if wherever the bishop was present, the congregation was also present, so that just as wherever Jesus Christ was present, the Church was present too. Catholic."

P-channel impoverishment N-channel enrichment The metal–oxide–semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET) is a type of field-effect transistor. MOSFETs include channels of N-type and P-type semiconductor materials, and are called NMOSFETs or PMOSFETs (also commonly nMOS, pMOS). It is the most common transistor in both digital and analog circuits, but the bipolar junction transistor was at one time more common. MOSFETs were invented by Mohamed M. Atalla and Dawon Kahng at Bell Labs in 1959, and were first introduced in June 1960. These devices are the foundational building blocks of modern electronics, and are the most widely produced electronic devices in history, with a number of approx. approximately 13 sextillion (1.3×1022) MOSFETs were produced between 1960 and 2018. MOSFETs are the dominant semiconductor devices in digital or analog integrated circuits (ICs), and are common power devices. MOSFETs are miniaturized and mass-produced solid state transistors for various forms of applications, revolutionizing the electronics industry and world economy, and critical to the digital revolution, the silicon age and the information age. The miniaturization of MOSFETs has driven the rapid development of electronic semiconductor technology since the 1960s, and made possible high-density ICs such as memory chips and microprocessors. The word 'metal' in the current name is actually a misnomer because the former metal-oxide layer of the gate material has now often been replaced with a layer of polysilicon (polycrystalline silicon). Previously aluminum was used as a gate material until the 1980s when polysilicon began to dominate with its ability to form self-adjusting gates. However, metal gates are now being used again because it is difficult to increase the operating speed of transistors without metal gates. An IGFET is a related device, a more general term meaning an isolated-gate field-effect transistor, and is nearly identical to a MOSFET, although it can refer to any FET with a non-oxide gate insulator.

Some use IGFETs when referring to devices with polysilicon gates, but most still call them MOSFETs. The basic principle of the field-effect transistor (FET) was first proposed by the Austrian-Hungarian physicist Julius Edgar Lilienfeld in 1926, when he was filling out the first patent for an isolated-gate field-effect transistor (IGFET). Over the next two years he explained various FET structures. In the MOS configuration aluminum is represented by M, aluminum oxide is represented by O, while copper sulphide is used as a semiconductor. However, he was unable to build a practical working FET device. The FET concept was later developed in theory by German engineer Oskar Heil in the 1930s and American physicist William Shockley in the 1940s. No practically working FETs were built at that time, and none of the early FET proposals involved thermally oxidizing silicon. Semiconductor companies initially focused on bipolar junction transistors (BJTs) in the early years of the semiconductor industry. However, junction transistors are relatively thick devices and difficult to mass produce, limiting their use to BJTs. In theory, FETs could be an alternative to junction transistors, but researchers have been unable to build practical FETs, mainly due to the surface state barrier preventing external electric fields from entering into the material. By the 1950s, researchers had mostly stopped trying the FET concept, and instead focused on BJT technology. In 1955, Carl Frosch and Lincoln Derrick accidentally coated the surface of a silicon wafer with a layer of silicon dioxide. They showed that the oxide layer prevented certain probes from entering the silicon wafer, while allowing others to enter. In doing so, they discovered the passivation effect of the oxidation of the semiconductor surface. Their next work was demonstrating how to etch tiny cracks in the oxide layer to spread the rivet over a specific part of the silicon wafer.

Nudity is a state when humans are not wearing clothes. Wearing clothes exclusively is a human characteristic. The amount of clothing worn depends on functional considerations (such as the need for warmth or protection from the elements) and social considerations. In some situations a minimum amount of clothing or clothing is not socially acceptable at all, while in others clothing is much more desirable. Modern social norms regarding nudity vary widely, reflecting cultural ambiguity towards the body and sexuality, and different conceptions of what constitutes public versus private space. While most societies require appropriate clothing in most situations, others recognize non-sexual nudity as appropriate for some recreational and social activities, and value nudity in performances and media as representing positive values. Some societies and groups continue to reject nudity not only in public but also in private. Norms are codified to varying degrees by laws that define appropriate dress and indecent exposure. The loss of body hair is one of the physical characteristics that marks the biological evolution of modern humans from their hominid ancestors. Adaptations related to baldness have contributed to increased brain size, bipedalism, and variations in human skin color. While estimates vary, for at least 90,000 years anatomically modern humans did not wear clothing, a discovery that was part of the transition from not only being anatomically but also behaviorally modern. As societies developed from hunter-gatherers to agrarian ones, clothing and other body adornments were part of a cultural evolution as individuals and groups became distinguished by status, class, and individual identity. The habit of wearing new clothes begins with civilization. Throughout most of history until the early modern era, people did not dress in public out of necessity or convenience either when engaging in strenuous activities, including labor and athletics; or while bathing or swimming.

Such functional nudity occurs in groups that are not always segregated by sex. In the colonial era, Christian and Muslim cultures were more common among tropical indigenous peoples who wore clothes for decorative or ceremonial purposes but were often naked, and had no concept of shame about their bodies. Additionally, the warm climate and way of life is conducive to functional nudity. Cultural differences continue as some previously colonized societies retain or reaffirm their traditional practices in everyday life or for special occasions celebrating their heritage. Traditional dress can include nudity, or bare-chested women and men. Societies such as those in Japan and Finland maintain traditions of communal nudity which provide an alternative to sexualization based on the use of baths and saunas. In general, social norms relating to nudity for men differ from those for women. It was only in the 17th century in Europe that women's breasts became part of the body that had to be covered in public. Only in the modern era has child nudity been portrayed as innocent. Individuals may knowingly violate norms relating to nudity; those without power could use nudity as a form of protest, and those with power could force nudity on others as a form of punishment. The encounters of indigenous African, American and Oceanian cultures with Europeans had a significant influence on both cultures. Western ambivalence can be expressed in responding to native nudity as a sign of the rampant sexuality or innocence that preceded the Fall.
