Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health Sciences Microbiology is a branch of biology that studies microorganisms. The objects of study are usually all (living) creatures that need to be seen with a microscope, especially bacteria, fungi, microscopic algae, protozoa, and archaea. Viruses are often included even though they are not fully considered as living things. Microbiology began with the invention of the microscope and became a very important field in biology after Louis Pasteur was able to explain the wine fermentation process and make the rabies vaccine. : biochemistry. Today's application of microbiology enters various fields and cannot be separated from other branches because it is also needed in the fields of pharmacy, medicine, agriculture, nutrition, chemical engineering, even to astrobiology and archeology. Robert Hooke (1635-1703) was an English mathematician, natural historian, and microscopy expert. In his famous book, Micrographia (1665), Hooke illustrates the structure of the fruiting bodies of a type of mold. This was the first published description of a microorganism. The first person to see bacteria was Antonie van Leeuwenhoek (1632-1723), a Dutch amateur microscope maker. In 1684, Antonie van Leeuwenhoek used a very small microscope of his own making to observe various microorganisms in natural materials. The microscope Leeuwenhoek used at that time was a single, biconvex-shaped magnifying glass with the specimen placed between the small aperture corners of a metal holder. The instrument was held close to the eye and the object on the other side of the lens was adjusted to achieve focus. With that tool, Leewenhoek obtained the appropriate contrast between the floating bacteria and the background so that they could be seen and distinguished clearly.

He discovered bacteria in 1676 while studying pepper-water infusion. Van Leeuwenhoek reported his findings in a letter to the Royal Society of London, which was published in English in 1684. Van Leewenhoek's illustrations of the microorganisms he found were known as "wee animalcules". In the following years, many other observations confirmed van Leeuwenhoek's, but progress in understanding the properties and benefits of microorganisms was slow until the next 150 years. Only in the 19th century, namely after the production of microscopes increased rapidly, did humanity's curiosity about microorganisms begin to develop again. Louis Pasteur is widely known for succeeding in subverting the theory of Spontaneous Generation, living organisms just happened. Pasteur's experiments using sterilized broth and goose neck flask proved the presence of microorganisms. Since the 16th century, it has been known that there is a disease-causing agent that can transmit disease. After its discovery, it was believed that the microorganism was the agent in question, but there has never been any proof. Robert Koch (1842-1910), a German physician, was the first to discover the concept of the relationship between infectious diseases and microorganisms by including experimental evidence. The concept proposed by Koch became known as Koch's Postulates and is now the gold standard for the determination of infectious diseases. General microbiology refers to non-medical aspects of microbiology. Two giants known in this era are Beijerinck and Winogradsky. The two initiated aspects of environmental microbiology. Martinus Beijerinck (1851-1931) was a Dutch professor who contributed greatly to enrichment culture techniques. In this technique, microorganisms are isolated from nature and grown in the laboratory by manipulating their nutrients and incubation conditions. Using this technique, Beijerinck was able to isolate pure cultures of various soil and water microorganisms for the first time.

Rhein (German: Rhein, French: Rhin, Dutch: Rijn) is one of the longest rivers in Europe with a length of 1,230 km. Its name comes from the word "renos", which means "high current"). Together with the Danube it formed much of the northern frontier of the Roman Empire and has since been an important navigable waterway, influencing trade in the interior. The Rhine originates in the Alps in the Swiss region of Graubünden, where its 2 tributaries were originally called the Vorderrhein and the Hinterrhein. The Vorderrhein (Forward Rhine) leaves Lake Tuma near the Oberalp pass and passes through the Ruinaulta (Great Swiss Cliff). The Hinterrhein (back Rhine) starts from the Paradise Glacier near the Rheinquellhorn on the southern border of Switzerland. The two tributaries meet near Reichenau, remaining at Graubunden. As it leaves Graubuenden, the River Rhine flows north to form the border with Liechtenstein and then Austria, and then empties into Lake Constance. The Rhine then appears again, flows west, mainly on the border between Switzerland and Germany, falls at the Rhein falls, followed by the Aar which is more than 2 times its volume of water, and then turns north at Basel and forms the southern part of the border between Germany and France in the broad valley, before entering sheer Germany. With more than 1,000 km, the Rhine is the longest river especially Germany. It is here that the Rhine meets a number of its main tributaries, such as the Neckar, Main and Moselle. Between Bingen and Bonn, the River Rhine flows through the Rhine Valley, a formation created by erosion, which occurred at about the same rate as uplift in the area, leaving the river at approximately its original level, and the surrounding land was uplifted.

This gorge is rapidly rising, and is a section of the river known for its castle and numerous vineyards. Although many industries can be found along the Rhine to Switzerland, it is in the Ruhr area that the bulk is concentrated, with all streams — mainly of which the Ruhr itself — flows into the River Rhine, adding to it while still being polluted. The River Rhine bends west into the Netherlands, where it joins the Meuse to form a large delta. Across the border into the Netherlands, the Rhine widens, but then divides into 3 main tributaries: IJssel, Waal and Nederrijn. From here things got more complicated, as the name "Rhine" soon coincided with the main stream of water. Most of the Rhine's waters flow further west past the Waal River and then past the Nieuwe Waterweg and, joining the Meuse, past Hollands Diep and the mouth of the Haringvliet into the North Sea. A branch of the IJssel River carries its share of water northward into the IJsselmeer where the Nederrijn River flows west parallel to the Waal River. However, past Wijk bij Duurstede this stream changed its name and became Lek. Flowing further west joins the main stream again into the Nieuwe Waterweg. The name "Rhine" is from here used only for the smaller streamlines that together form the main river Rhein in Roman times. Although they still use that name, this stream does not carry water from the Rhine, but is used to flow through the surrounding land and polders. From Wijk bij Duurstede, the oldest northern branch of the River Rhine is called Kromme Rijn ("Rhine Bend") and via Utrecht, first Leidse Rijn ("Leiden Rhein") and then Oude Rijn ("Ancient Rhine").

Mogadishu (Somali: Muqdisho) is a city in East Africa. Mogadishu is the largest city and the nominal capital of Somalia's temporary authority. Uniquely, Somalia has not had a de facto government for more than a decade. Its population is 2,450,000 (est. 2004). The city is also known as Hamarnote 1] by the people of Somalia. As the financial and commercial center of Somalia, its main industries are textiles and food. Roads in Mogadishu connect it to other cities as well as the countries of Kenya and Ethiopia. Air transportation services are still limited. Mogadishu is located at coordinates 2°02′ N 45°21′ E permanently disabled link]. Mogadishu was discovered by ethnic Arab Muslim settlers in the 10th century, according to Ross E. Dunn (The Adventures of Ibn Battuta). According to Dunn's description, Mogadishu and other Muslim settlements in East Africa seem "similar to medieval America, a fertile land of golden opportunity and a place of refuge from drought, famine, overpopulation, and wars that engulfed the homeland." Most immigrants are classified as rich and they come from the Arabian Peninsula. Their marriage with the natives resulted in a beneficial relationship from an economic point of view. Mogadishu is located at the northern tip of the East African City-state. Islamic teachings spread throughout Somalia. When Ibn Batuta visited Mogadishu in 1330, he was amazed at the abundance of food and murmured that someone there "had as much food as our party, and they were very fat." The origin of the name "Mogadishu" is obscure; one story claims the name as the ethnic Somali version of the Arabic term "maqad shah" (imperial seat of the shah), another claims it as the Somali version of the Swahili term "mwyu ma" (last northern city).

Historic buildings in Mogadishu include the Fakr ad-Din Mosque (1269) and the Garesa Palace, built in the late 19th century for the residence of the local administrator of the sultan of Zanzibar which is now a museum and library. In 1871 Mogadishu was occupied by the sultan of Zanzibar, who leased it to Italy in 1892. In 1905 Italy bought the city, renamed it Mogadiscio, and made it the capital of the colony of Italian Somaliland. During World War II Mogadishu was controlled by British troops based in Kenya. During the protracted civil war that has plagued Somalia since the 1970s, rebel forces took control of Mogadishu in 1990. Heavy fighting between clan-based rebel factions destroyed large parts of Mogadishu in 1991-1992. Peacekeepers served there from 1992-1995. On October 3, 1993, the United States carried out a mission to capture two of the men of a militant leader named Mohamed Farrah Aidid, although this mission was successful, this mission claimed many lives. During the Battle of Mogadishu, 19 US troops were killed and several others injured, but Somali casualties are estimated at between 500-1,000 militants and civilians killed and 3,000-4,000 wounded. This incident later became the main theme of the novel Black Hawk Down: A Story of Modern War and the film Black Hawk Down (2001). Mogadishu is the internationally recognized capital of Somalia's Transitional National Government. Parliament sessions are held overseas (Nairobi). Conditions in the southern part of Mogadishu are calmer and more modern. In contrast, the northern part of the city was ruled by militant clans. Some of them have formed their own territories and claim independence from the country. Despite being surrounded by many problems, Mogadishu has recovered from an economic standpoint. Free trade without a de facto government in power means no taxes so doing business there is relatively cheap.

Cergy is a commune in the northwestern suburbs of Paris, France. Located 27.8 km (17.3 mi) from the center of Paris, in the "new town" Cergy-Pontoise, formed in the 1960s, which is the central and most populous commune. Although Pontoise is the official prefecture (capital) of the Val-d'Oise département, the buildings and administration of the prefecture, as well as the departmental council (conseil général), are located within the commune of Cergy, which is designated as the de facto capital of Val-d'Oise. The sous-préfecture building and administration, located within the commune of Pontoise. The name Cergy comes from the Middle Latin Sergiacum, meaning "residence of Sergius", a Gallo-Roman landlord. Cergy is the capital of two cantons: When Cergy was elected the center of the "new town", it was just a village. The commune had 2,895 inhabitants in 1968. It grew rapidly, passing 10,000 inhabitants in the mid-1970s and 20,000 in the early 1980s. In that decade it has grown tremendously, since the city passed 48,000 inhabitants in 1990. The increase continued, but slowly, to reach 54,500 inhabitants in 2004 estimate. However, on 1 January 2000, the commune lost some of its territory (area 0.03 km² with 1999 62 people) to be given to the commune of Courtimanche. The number of official censuses has been revised starting from the official number of 1999 54,781 people to 54,719 people (improved) and the land area from 11.68 km² to 11.65 km² (improved). Port Cergy is a marina on the Oise River at 9 p.m. It has housing and recreational boats as well as a sailing school. This marina can accommodate 103 vessels ranging from 5 to 22m in length. The northern section is used for restaurants and shops which have been built around a small basin. Ham is a small village south of Cergy. The village was once part of the Sergentery and then the commune of Neuville-sur-Oise but is now part of the commune of Cergy.

The Kingdom of Morocco (Berber: ⵜⴰⴳⵍⴷⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵎⵓⵔⴰⴽⵓⵛ Tageldit-N-Murakusy ; Arabic: المملكة المغربية Al-Mamlakatu-L-Maghribiya) is a country that has a very long coastline on the Atlantic Ocean. Geographically, it has an area consisting mostly of deserts and rugged mountains. Morocco is one of only three countries (with Spain and France) that have coastlines on the Atlantic Ocean as well as on the Mediterranean Sea. The Arabic names al-Mamlakah al-Maghribiyah (Arabic: المملكة المغربية, meaning "Western Kingdom") and Al-Maghrib (Arabic: المغرب, meaning "West") are often used as alternative names. Morocco has a population of over 33,800,000 and an area of ​​446,550 km (172,410 sq mi). The capital is Rabat and the largest city is Casablanca. Other major cities are Marrakesh, Tangier, Tetouan, Salé, Fes, Agadir, Meknes, Oujda, Kenitra and Nador. Morocco has a different history from its neighboring countries. Where Moroccan culture is a mixture of Arab, European and Berber cultures. Morocco claims the Western Sahara region as one of its Southern Provinces. Morocco annexed the territory in 1975, leading to a guerrilla war with indigenous troops until a ceasefire in 1991. The peace process has so far failed to break the political deadlock. Morocco is a constitutional monarchy with an elected parliament. The King of Morocco wields broad executive and legislative powers, especially in military, foreign policy and religious affairs. Executive power is exercised by the government, while legislative power is held by the government and two parliamentary institutions, the People's Representative Council and the Assembly of Councilors. The king can issue decrees called dadars which have the force of law. He can also dissolve parliament after consulting with the Prime Minister and the President of the Constitutional Court. The official and majority religion in Morocco is Islam, and the official languages ​​are Arabic and Berber.

Moroccan Arabic, referred to as Darija, and French are also widely spoken. Morocco is an influential member of the Arab League. The country has the fifth largest economy in Africa. The history of human habitation in Morocco stretches back to the Lower Paleolithic, with the earliest being known as Jebel Irhoud. Much later Morocco was part of the Iberomaurusian culture, including the Taforalt. It goes from the founding of Mauretania and other ancient Berber kingdoms, to the founding of the state of Morocco by the Idrisid dynasty followed by other Islamic dynasties, to the colonial period and independence. Archaeological evidence has shown that the area was inhabited by hominids at least 400,000 years ago. Records of Moroccan history begin with the Phoenician colonization of the Moroccan coast between the 8th and 6th centuries BC, although the area was inhabited by indigenous Berbers for some two thousand years before that. In the 5th century BC, the city-state of Carthage expanded its hegemony over the coastal areas. They remained there until the end of the 3rd century BC, while the interior was ruled by a native king. Indigenous Berber kings ruled the region from the 3rd century BC to 40 AD, when it was annexed to the Roman Empire. In the mid-5th century AD, it was overrun by the Vandals, before being rediscovered by the Byzantine Empire in the 6th century. The region was conquered by the Muslims in the early 8th century AD, but broke away from the Umayyad Caliphate after the Berber Revolt of 740. Half a century later, the state of Morocco was founded by the Idrisid dynasty. Under the Almoravid and Almohad dynasties, Morocco dominated the Maghreb and Muslim Spain. The Saadi dynasty ruled the country from 1549 to 1659, followed by the Alaou people from 1667 onwards, who have since become the ruling dynasty of Morocco.

Physicist is a scientist who conducts research in physics. Physicists study various physical phenomena in various branches of physics from sub-atomic particles to the behavior of matter in the universe as a whole (cosmology). The general and broad study of nature, natural philosophy, split into several fields in the 19th century, when the modern form of science emerged. New terms emerged such as "biologist" and "biologist", "physicist" and "physicist", "chemist" and "chemist", and others. The term "physicist" was coined by the English philosopher, as well as priest, and historian of science William Whewell in 1840, to denote the cultivator of physics in his book entitled The Philosophy of the Inductive Sciences in 1840. The highest award given to physicists is the Nobel Prize in Physics. This award has been awarded since 1901 by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. The following gallery displays figures who played an important role in the development of physics Nicolaus Copernicus (1473 - 1543) Galileo Galilei (1564 - 1642) Johannes Kepler (1571—1630) Evangelista Torricelli (1608 - 1647) Blaise Pascal (1623 - 1662) Christiaan Huygens (1629 - 1695) Robert Hooke (1635 - 1703) Sir Isaac Newton (1642 - 1727) Henry Cavendish (1731 - 1810) Charles-Augustin de Coulomb (1736 - 1806) Alessandro Volta (1745 - 1827) Thomas Young (1773 - 1829) Hans Christian Ørsted (1777 – 1851) André-Marie Ampère (1777 - 1836) Joseph von Fraunhofer, (1787 - 1826) Georg Ohm (1789 - 1854) Christian Doppler (1803 - 1853) James Prescott Joule (1818 - 1889) William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin (1824 - 1907) James Clerk Maxwell (1831-1879) Ernst Mach (1838 - 1916) Ludwig Boltzmann (1844 - 1906) Wilhelm Röntgen (1845 - 1923) Henri Becquerel (1852 - 1908) Hendrik Lorentz (1853 - 1928 ) J. J. Thomson (1856 - 1940) Nikola Tesla (1856 - 1943) Heinrich Hertz (1857 - 1894) Max Planck (1858 - 1947) Pi ether Zeeman (1865 - 1943) Marie Curie (1867 - 1934) Robert Andrews Millikan (1868 - 1953) Ernest Rutherford (1871 - 1937) Lise Meitner (1878 - 1968) Albert Einstein (1879 - 1955) Niels Bohr (1885 - 1962) Erwin Schrödinger (1887-1961) Edwin Hubble (1889 - 1953) Louis de Broglie (1892 - 1987) Wolfgang Pauli (1900 - 1958) Werner Heisenberg (1901 - 1976) Enrico Fermi (1901 - 1954) Paul Dirac (1902 - 1984) John Bardeen (1908 – 1991) John Wheeler (1911 - 2008) Richard Feynman (1918 - 1988) Stephen Hawking (1942 - 2018)

A galaxy is a massive, gravitationally bound system consisting of stars (with all their manifestations, including neutron stars and black holes), interstellar medium gas and dust, and dark matter – an important but poorly understood component. The word galaxy comes from the Greek galaxias (γαλαξίας), meaning "like milk," which refers to the Milky Way galaxy (English: Milky Way). Typical galaxies range from dwarfs with as few as ten million (107) stars up to giants with one trillion (1014) stars, all orbiting the galaxy's center of mass. The sun is one of the stars in the Milky Way galaxy; the solar system includes the earth and all objects orbiting the Sun. Each galaxy has a different number of star systems and star clusters, as well as different types of interstellar clouds. Between these galaxies is scattered the interstellar medium of gas, dust and cosmic rays. Supermassive black holes are at the center of most galaxies. It is thought that these supermassive black holes are the main cause of the active galactic nuclei found in some galaxies. The Milky Way galaxy is known to have at least one supermassive black hole. Historically galaxies have been grouped based on their visible form or commonly called visual morphology. A common form is the elliptical galaxy, which has an elliptical light profile. Spiral galaxies are disk-shaped galaxies with curved, dust-filled galactic arms. Galaxies with irregular or unusual shapes are called irregular galaxies and are usually caused by disturbances due to the gravitational pull of neighboring galaxies. Such interactions between nearby galaxies can cause mergers, which sometimes increase the rate of star formation to produce galaxies with rapidly forming stars.

There may be over 170 billion (1.7 × 1011) galaxies in the observable universe. Most are 1000 to 100,000 parsecs in diameter and are usually separated by distances of several million parsecs (or megaparsecs). Intergalactic space is filled with a thin gas with a mass density of less than one atom per cubic meter. Most galaxies are organized into a hierarchy of sets called groups and clusters, which in turn form larger sets called giant clusters. On the largest scale these associations are generally arranged in layers and strands surrounded by a vast void. Although not yet fully understood, dark matter likely makes up about 90% of the mass of most galaxies. Observational data suggests supermassive black holes may exist at the centers of many (if not all) galaxies. The word galaxy comes from the Greek term for our galaxy, galaxias (γαλαξίας) or kyklos galaktikos (κύκλος γαλακτικός). Meaning "something resembling milk" and "milk circle" respectively, due to their appearance in space as faint white bands. In Greek mythology, Zeus placed his human-born son, the infant Heracles, at Hera's breast while she was sleeping so that the baby drank her milk and became immortal. Hera woke up while nursing and then realized she was nursing an unknown baby: she pushed away the baby and a jet of her milk sprayed the night sky, producing the faint band of light known as the Milky Way. When William Herschel compiled his "nebula catalog" in 1786, he used the term "spiral nebula" for certain objects such as object M31. It would later be realized that the object was actually a collection of stars, and the term "island universe" was used to refer to such an object.

Prokaryotes are living things that do not have a cell nucleus membrane (= karyon), while eukaryotes have a cell nucleus membrane. All prokaryotes are unicellular, except for myxobacteria which become multicellular at some stage of their biological life cycle. The word prokaryota'' comes from the Greek πρό- (pro-) "before" + καρυόν (karyon) "nut or seed". Prokaryotes are divided into two domains: Bacteria and Archaea. Archaea have only been recognized as a domain since 1990. Archaea were initially thought to only live in uncomfortable conditions, such as extreme temperatures, pH, and radiation, but later Archaea were also found in various habitats. Eukaryotes have a nucleus which contains DNA, whereas prokaryotes do not have a nucleus and their genetic material is not in a membrane. Because of the great structural and genetic differences between the two, in 1977 Carl Woese split the prokaryotes into Bacteria and Archaea (formerly Eubacteria and Archaebacteria), by proposing a three-domain system consisting of Eukaryotes (or "Eukarya"), Bacteria, and Archaea, the revision of the two kingdom system. The genome of prokaryotes resides in a DNA/protein complex in the cytosol, called the nucleoid, which lacks a nuclear membrane. Prokaryotes generally do not have cell membrane compartments such as mitochondria and chloroplasts so that oxidative phosphorylation and photosynthesis occur along the plasma membrane. However, prokaryotes have an internal structure, such as a cytoskeleton, and specifically the order Planctomycetes bacteria have a membrane around the nucleoid and have cell membrane organelles. Prokaryotes also contain only one loop of stable chromosomal DNA stored in the nucleoid, whereas DNA in eukaryotes is found in tightly packed and organized chromosomes. Although some eukaryotes have satellite DNA structures called plasmids, plasmids are usually identical to prokaryotes, and many important genes in prokaryotes are stored in plasmids.

Prokaryotes have a ratio of surface area to content so they have a higher metabolic rate, a higher growth rate and automatically a shorter breeding duration than eukaryotes. On the other hand, prokaryote cells are usually smaller than eukaryotes. In common, eukaryotes and prokaryotes both contain large RNA/protein structures, called ribosomes, which produce proteins. Bacteria and archaea reproduce asexually, ie mostly by binary fission or budding. Genetic exchange and recombination can occur, but this is horizontal gene transfer and not replication, ie it involves DNA being transferred between two cells, as is the case with bacterial conjugation. Recent research has shown that all prokaryotes have a more primitive cytoskeleton than that of eukaryotes. Despite the homology of actin and tubulin (MreB and FtsZ) the helix components of the flagella, named flagellin, are one of the most important bacterial cytoskeletal proteins as providers of the structural background of chemotaxis, the basic cell physiological response of bacteria. At least some prokaryotes also contain intracellular structures, namely primitive organelles. Membrane organelles (or intercellular membranes) are present in some prokaryotes such as vacuoles and membrane systems used specifically for metabolism, such as photosynthesis or chemolithotrophy. Some species also contain protein-enclosed microcompartments that serve specific physiological roles (eg, carboxysomes or air vacuoles). Most prokaryotes are 1 µm to 10 µm in size, but can vary in size from 0.2 µm to 750 µm (Thiomargarita namibiensis). The following is the cell structure of prokaryotes: flagella, cell membrane, cell wall (except the genus Mycoplasma), cytoplasm, ribosomes, nucleoid, glycocalyx, inclusions. The following are the 4 basic forms of prokaryotes: Prokaryotes live in almost all environments on earth as long as there is water.

An ion is an atom or molecule that has a non-zero total electric charge (the total number of electrons is not the same as the total number of protons). Cations are positively charged ions, while anions are negatively charged ions. Therefore, a cation molecule has a hydrogen proton without an electron, whereas an anion has an extra electron. Because of their opposite electrical charges, cations and anions are attracted to each other and easily form ionic compounds. Ions containing only one atom are called monatomic ions or atomic ions, while those containing two or more atoms form molecular ions or polyatomic ions. In the case of physical ionization in a medium, such as a gas, "ion pairs" are created by collisions of ions, where each pair formed contains a free electron and a positive ion. Ions are also created through chemical interactions, for example dissolving a salt in a liquid, or alternatively, passing a direct current through a conducting solution dissolves the anode via ionization. The word ion comes from the Greek: ἰόν, ion, "is going", the verb being forms from the Greek: ἰέναι, ienai, "goes". The term was introduced by the English physicist and chemist Michael Faraday in 1834 to describe an unknown species that travels from one electrode to another via an aqueous medium. Faraday did not know the nature of these species, but he did know that when a metal dissolves into and enters the solution at one electrode, a new metal arises from the solution at the other electrode; the substance has moved through the solution in a current. It carries matter from one place to another. Faraday also introduced the words anion for a negatively charged ion, and a cation for a positively charged ion.

In Faraday nomenclature, cations are so named because they are attracted to the cathode in a galvanic device and anions are so named because they are attracted to the anode. Svante Arrhenius proposed his explanation, in his 1884 dissertation, that in fact solid crystalline salts dissociate into pairs of charged particles when dissolved. This dissertation earned Arrhenius the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1903. Arrhenius' explanation was that in forming a solution, the salt dissociates into Faraday ions. Arrhenius proposed that ions were formed even in the absence of an electric current. Ions in their gaseous state are highly reactive and will quickly interact with ions with opposite charges to produce neutral molecules or ionic salts. Ions are also produced in the liquid or solid state when salts interact with a solvent (eg, water) to produce "solvated ions", which are more stable. The ions move away from each other to interact with the liquid for reasons that involve changes in energy and entropy. These stabilized species are more common in low temperature environments. A common example is the ions found in seawater, which come from dissolved salts. All ions have a charge, which means that, like other charged objects, they: Electrons, due to their small mass and large space-occupying properties, are considered matter waves. It determines the entire size of atoms and molecules that have electrons. Anions (negatively charged ions) are larger than the parent molecule or atom, because the excess electrons repel each other thereby increasing the physical size of the ion, and its size is determined by its electron cloud. Thus, in general, cations are smaller than their parent atoms or molecules because the size of their electron cloud is also smaller. The hydrogen cation has no electrons at all, so it only has a single proton - much smaller than the hydrogen atom.

Togo (/ˈtoʊɡoʊ/ ( listen)), officially the Republic of Togo (French: République togolaise) is a country in West Africa, bordered by Ghana to the west, Benin to the east and Burkina Faso to the north. To the south, Togo has the coast of the small Gulf of Guinea, where Togo's capital, Lomé is located. Togo is a German Protectorate territory declared in 1884 as Togoland. But after World War I, power over Togo was transferred to France. In 1960, French Togoland achieved its independence and changed the country's name to Togo. Togo is located in West Africa and is a small sub-Saharan country. Togo is bordered by the Gulf of Benin to the south, Ghana to the west, Benin to the east and Burkina Faso to the north. In the northern part of Greater Urisia the land is mostly savanna, in contrast to the hilly part of central Togo. To the south of Togo is mostly a large expanse that reaches the coast consisting of lagoons and marshes. Its land area is 21,927 mi2, with a density of 232 people/mi2. Togo is divided into 5 regions: Togo's economy is a lower middle class economy. Sources of state revenue are dominated by fisheries, mining, forest products, plantations and agriculture. Residents in the northern region of the country tend to work as farmers and miners, while 80% of the population in the southern part of the country work as fishermen. About 43% of Togolese are still living in poverty and almost 28% of citizens of this country cannot go to school. Togo's main exports are agricultural products such as wood, rice, tubers, as well as mining products, such as nickel, tin and others.
