– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Georgia (საქართველო, Sakartvelo; IPA: sɑkʰɑrtʰvɛlɔ] ( listen)) is a country in West Asia. This former republic in the Soviet Union is bordered by Russia to the north, Turkey and Armenia to the south, and Azerbaijan to the southeast. The Black Sea is located in the west of this country. Georgia has an area of ​​69,700 km² (26,911 sq mi), a population of 3.75 million (excluding Abkhazia and South Ossetia, territories occupied by Russia). In classical times, several independent kingdoms were established in what is today Georgia. The kingdoms of Colchis and Iberia adopted Christianity in the early fourth century. The kingdom of Georgia reached its political and economic peak under King David IV and Queen Tamar in the 11th and 12th centuries. It was later invaded by larger kingdoms such as the Mongolian Empire, the Ottoman Empire, and Iranian dynasties. In the late 18th century, the Kingdom of Kartli-Kakheti formed an alliance with the Russian Empire, resulting in the area being annexed by Russia in 1801, confirmed by the Treaty of Gulistan with the Qajar dynasty. When the Russian Revolution took place in 1917, Georgia gained independence and became the first republic to be formed under German and British protection, before being invaded again in 1921 and merging into the Soviet Union as the Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic. Since the creation of the modern Republic of Georgia in April 1991, Georgia has suffered from civil and economic crises during the 1990s. This lasted until the Rose Revolution in 2003, when Georgia decided to follow a pro-Western foreign policy and declared European and Euro-Atlantic integration its top priority. This would lead to a deteriorating relationship between Russia and Georgia, and trigger the Russo-Georgian War in 2008.

Georgia is a member of the European Assembly and the Organization for Democracy and Economic Development GUAM. There are two de-facto independent territories in Georgia, namely Abkhazia and South Ossetia, which received limited international recognition after the Russo-Georgian War. Due to its mountainous terrain, climbing is a prominent sport in Georgia and is of great value in the promotion and growth of the country's economy. Similar sports such as snowboarding or alpine skiing are also quite popular. Georgia is located in the South Caucasus with an area of ​​67,900 km (26,911 sq mi) with mountainous terrain. The Likhi Mountains divide the country into western and eastern parts. Historically, the western part of Georgia is known as Colchis, while the eastern part is known as Iberia. Due to its complex topography, the northern regions of Georgia (such as Svaneti) are isolated from the rest of the country. Major cities in Georgia include: Georgia is divided into 53 provinces, 11 cities and 2 autonomous republics: The old flag of Georgia was used from 1991 to 25 January 2004, it was also used from 1918 to 1921. The old coat of arms was used from 1918 to 1921 and since 1991 to 2004. Georgians are random Ethnic groups in Georgia about 86.8 percent are Ethnic Georgians of 3,713,804 population (2014 Census). n 1] Other ethnic groups include Abkhazians, Armenians, Assyrians, Azerbaijanis, Greeks, Jews, Kists, Ossetians, Russians, Ukrainians, Yazidis and others.n 1] Georgian Jews are one of the oldest Jewish communities in the world. In the past there were also many Germans in Georgia, but were deported back to Germany during World War II. Main religions (2014) Georgia is one of the countries that has officially adopted Christianity as the state religion after Armenia. The country has Eastern Orthodox Christianity as its official religion with a percentage of 83.4%.

The euro (Exchange rate: €, Code: EUR) is the currency used in 19 member states of the European Union. In terms of currency, this currency began to be used on January 1, 1999, but physically it was only used on January 1, 2002. Euro banknotes everywhere have the same appearance and picture, but the reverse side of the coins varies in each country. The coins of each country are marked with the identity symbol of each EU member state in the Eurozone (Eurozone). The euro is the second largest reserve currency as well as the second most traded currency in the world after the United States dollar. As of December 2019, with over €1.3 trillion in circulation, the euro has one of the highest combined values ​​of notes and coins in circulation in the world. In July 2012, the euro fell below US$1.21 for the first time in two years, following worries over Greece's debt and Spain's troubled banking sector. The euro is divided into 100 cents (also referred to as euro cents, especially when to distinguish it from other currencies, and referred to as the common side of all penny coins). In the legislative act of the Community, the plurals euro and cent are spelled without the s, as opposed to normal English usage. Otherwise, the normal English plural is used, with many local variations such as centime in French. Coins issued in denominations of €2, €1, 50c, 20c, 10c, 5c, 2c and 1c. To avoid using the two smallest coins, some cash transactions are rounded to the nearest five cents in the Netherlands and Ireland (by agreement of both parties) and in Finland (by law). This practice is discouraged by the commission, as is the practice of certain shops refusing to accept high-value euro notes.

The design of the euro banknote has a common design on both sides. The design was created by Austrian designer, Robert Kalina. Notes are issued in €500, €200, €100, €50, €20, €10 and €5. Each banknote has its own color and is dedicated to an artistic period of European architecture. The front of the banknote has a window or gate while the back has a bridge, symbolizing the relationship between the states within the union and with the future. While the design is supposed to be without any identifiable characteristics, early designs by Robert Kalina were of certain bridges, including the Rialto and Pont de Neuilly, and were later made more general; the final designs still bore a very close resemblance to their specific prototypes; so they're not really generic. The monuments look similar enough to the different national monuments to please everyone. The special euro currency symbol (€) was devised after a public survey narrowed down the ten original proposals to two. The European Commission then chose a design by Belgian designer Alain Billiet. Of this symbol, the Commission stated: The inspiration for the symbol € itself comes from the Greek epsilon (Є) – referring to the cradle of European civilization – and the first letters of the word Europe, crossed by two parallel lines to 'denote' the stability of the euro. There are 19 member countries of the European Union that use the Euro as currency. The area where this currency is used is known as the Eurozone. The first 11 countries started using it in early 1999. Greece became the 12th user since early 2001. From 1 January 2007 Slovenia joined. Cyprus and Malta joined on 1 January 2008. Slovakia, which joined on 1 January 2009 and Estonia on 1 January 2011.

Hyphae (Latin: hypha, plural hyphae) or fungal threads are tubular fungal structures formed from the growth of spores or conidia. Collections of hyphae can form masses known as mycelum (mycelium, plural mycelia). Hyphae can be easily seen with the eye when they have formed mycelium. The umbrella-shaped structure commonly known to people as a mushroom is nothing but a reproductive organ known as a carpus or fruiting body, which appears only intermittently. Hyphae contain protoplasm surrounded by a strong wall. The hyphal cell wall thickness at the tip or apical is about 125-250nm. In most fungi there is a dividing wall on the hyphae. The dividing wall on the hyphae is called a septum (septum, plural septa). Hyphae that have a septum and have a single nucleus are called monocytic. Hyphae that do not have a septum and have many nuclei are called coenocytic. Hyphal growth occurs at the apical or end of the hyphae. Hyphae length is not fixed but hyphal diameter is constant, ranging from 2--30µm, depending on the species and growing conditions. Each part or piece of hyphae is capable of growing to form new hyphae. Based on its function, hyphae are divided into two, namely vegetative hyphae and reproductive hyphae. The part of the hyphae that functions to take in nutrients is called the vegetative hyphae. Vegetative hyphae grow into the substrate or fall on the substrate. Hyphae that function for reproduction are called reproductive hyphae or fertile hyphae or aerial hyphae. Reproductive hyphae are attached to the mycelium on the surface of the substrate. Reproductive hyphae can be sporangiphores, conidiophores or fruiting bodies. For fungi, hyphae have more or less a role like roots and leaves in plants at once. Hyphae grow to spread throughout the body or all parts of the organism. The fine shape of the hyphae expands the contact surface with the substrate (food object).

in Europe  (gray) The Republic of Azerbaijan (Azeri: Azərbaycan Respublikası) is a country in the Caucasus at the crossroads of Europe and West Asia. It is bordered by Russia to the north, Georgia and Armenia to the west, and Iran to the south. Nakhichevan Autonomous Republic (an exclave belonging to Azerbaijan) is bordered by Armenia to the north, Iran to the south, and Turkey to the west. Azerbaijan is a secular country and has been a member of the Council of Europe since 2001. The majority of the population is Shia and of western Turkic descent, known as Azerbaijanis, or Azeris for short. The country is officially a democracy, but with strong regulatory authority. Azerbaijan is also a member state of the OIC. Now, in terms of history, the designation of the term Azerbaijan has varied from its historical geographical designation and this has led to some political discussions. There are several hypotheses regarding the origin of the name "Azerbaijan." The most common theory is that Azerbaijan was eponymously named after Atropates, satrap (governor) of the Iranian Medes, who controlled an area found in modern Iranian Azarbaijan called Atropatene. It is believed that the name Atropates is derived from an Old Persian root meaning "protected by fire." There is also another opinion that this term is a thin Turkicification of Azarbaijan, an Arabicized version of the original Persian name Âzarâbâdagân, composed of âzar+âbadag+ân (âzar=api; âbâdag=processed area; ân=plural ending); that traditionally the word means "land of eternal fire" or "land of fire", which may imply Zoroastrianism's fire temple in this country. Some Azeri historians think that the name is composed of 4 Azerbaijani elements: az+er+bay+can, meaning "land of the brave Az" or "an elevated place for the wealthy and noble." Azerbaijan is also poetically called Odlar Yurdu ("Land of Fire (Eternal)").

The earliest historical inhabitants of the area now known as Azerbaijan were Caucasian Albanians, a people speaking the languages ​​of the Caucasus who appeared in this area before the large contingent that finally invaded the Caucasus. Historically Azerbaijan has been protected by various nations, including Persians, Greeks, Romans, Armenians, Arabs, Turks, Mongols and Russians. The first kingdom to appear in the present-day Republic of Azerbaijan was Mannae in the 9th century BC, lasting until 616 BC when it became part of the Median Empire, which then became part of the Persian Empire in 549 AD. The satrapies of Atropatene and Caucasian Albania were founded in the 4th century BC and included more or less the territory of the national state of Azerbaijan and the southern part of present-day Dagestan. Islam spread quickly in Azerbaijan following the futuhats of the 7th–8th centuries. After the power of the Arab Caliphate waned, several semi-independent states were formed, the Shirvanshah sultanate being one of them. In the 11th century, the conquering Seljuk Turks became the dominant power in Azerbaijan and laid the foundations of today's Azerbaijani ethnicity. In the 13-14th centuries, this country was attacked by the Mongol-Tatars. Azerbaijan was part of the Safavid Persian Empire during the 15–18th centuries. It also experienced a brief period of aristocratic divisions in the mid-18th to early 19th centuries, and consisted of independent khans. Following the Persian-Russian War between the Qajar Persian Sultanate, such as Ganja, Guba, Baku and other independent khans, and the Russian Empire, Azerbaijan was annexed by Russia through the Treaties of Gulistan in 1813, and the Treaty of Turkmenchay in 1828, and several earlier treaties between tsars Russia and the khans ended in the first decade of the 19th century. In 1873, oil ("black gold") was discovered in the city of Baku, the future capital of Azerbaijan. From the beginning of the 20th century almost half of the world's oil reserves were refined in Baku.

In Buddhism, Nirvana (Sanskrit: निर्वाण nirvāṇa; Pali: nibbāna; Chinese: 涅槃; pinyin: nièpán) is the culmination of the Buddhist quest for freedom from samsara, the cycle of death and rebirth. Siddartha Gautama, the Buddha, described Buddhism as a raft which, having floated down a river, would allow its passengers to reach nirvana. In a deeper sense, Nibbana is the highest bliss, a state of extraordinary eternal bliss. [citation needed] The bliss of Nibbana cannot be experienced by indulging the senses, but by calming them. Nibbana is not a place. Nibbana is not an absence or extinction. Nibbana is not a heaven. There are no suitable words to describe this Nibbana. Nibbana can be realized by eliminating greed (lobha), hatred (dosa) and delusion (moha). citation needed] In the Udana VIII:3, Nibbana is explained by the Buddha as follows: Further in the Milinda Panha Book it is also explained about Nibbana through The conversation between the Bhikkhu Nagasena and King Milinda goes as follows: So it can be concluded that Nibbana is not a place or realm of existence, but a state free from all defilements which are the cause of the sufferings of birth, old age, disease, death, pain, lamentation and despair. despair, namely Greed (Lobha), Hatred (Sin), and Ignorance (Moha). Nibbana can be attained while still alive (Sa-upadisesa Nibbana) and when you die (An-upadisesa Nibbana). When Prince Siddhartha attained Perfect Enlightenment and became Samma Sambuddha, then at that time He experienced Sa-upadisesa Nibbana. When Buddha Gotama died at the age of 80 in Kusinara, he attained An-upadisesa Nibbana or Parinibbana. The way to attain Nibbana is to practice the Noble Eightfold Path for yourself, namely: Hinduism also uses nirvana as a synonym for their thoughts on Moksha, and nirvana is spoken of in several Hindu tantric writings as well as the Bhagawad Gita.

Capitalism is a mode of production that aims to achieve the maximum profit with the smallest production costs. Minimization of production costs is achieved by reducing workers' wages. Capitalism is carried out by an agency or individual outside the government. Thus, the government cannot intervene in the market to obtain mutual benefits, but government intervention is carried out on a large scale for personal interests. The perpetrators of capitalism are called Capital. Capitalism does not actually have a universal definition that can be widely accepted. Some experts define capitalism as a system that began to apply in Europe in the 16th to 19th centuries, namely during the development of European commercial banking where a group of individuals or groups could act as a certain entity that could own or trade in property. personal assets, especially capital goods, such as land and people for the process of changing from capital goods to finished goods. To obtain these capitals, capitalists must obtain raw materials and machinery first, then laborers who act as machine operators in order to obtain value from the raw materials processed. Capitalism has a long history, namely since the discovery of a trading system carried out by the private sector. In Europe, this is known as the guild as the forerunner of capitalism. Currently, capitalism is not only seen as a way of life that wants profit. The merging of capitalism with socialism without any modifications makes capitalism more malleable than it was two or three centuries ago. The term capitalism, in its modern sense, is often associated with Karl Marx. In his magnum opus Das Kapital, Marx wrote about the "capitalist mode of production" using the method of understanding now known as Marxism. However, while Marx rarely used the term "capitalism", it is used twice in the more political interpretations of his work, notably written by collaborator Friedrich Engels.

In the 20th century apologists for the capitalist system often replaced long term capitalism with phrases such as free enterprise and private enterprise and replaced it with rent capitalists and investors as a reaction to the negative connotations associated with capitalism. Governments dominated trade for centuries, which created economic inequality. These thinkers began to think that the bourgeoisie, which in the previous era began to play an important role in the state-dominated trade economy or better known as mercantilism, should start trading and production to support the pattern of people's lives. Some of these experts include: Adam Smith is a classical capitalist economic figure who criticized the mercantilism system which he considered less supportive of the people's economy. He criticizes the psyocrats who think land is the most important thing in the pattern of production. The production movement must move according to the concept of MCM (Capital-Commodity-Money), which is something that will not stop because money will turn into capital again and will rotate again when invested. Adam Smith views that there is a hidden power that will regulate the market (invisible hand), so the market must have laissez-faire or freedom from government intervention. The government only serves as a supervisor of all the work done by its people. Critics of capitalism associate it with social inequality and the unequal distribution of wealth and power; tendencies to market monopoly or oligopoly (and government by oligarchs), imperialism, counter-revolutionary wars and various forms of economic and cultural exploitation; materialism, repression of workers and trade unionists, social alienation, economic inequality, unemployment, and economic instability. Private property rights have also been linked to the tragedy of the anticommons. Notable critics of capitalism have included: socialists, anarchists, communists, national socialists, social democrats, technocrats, various types of conservatives, Luddites, Narodniks, Shakers, and several other types of nationalists.

Industrialization is a process of socio-economic change that changes the livelihood system of an agrarian society into an industrial society. Industrialization can also be interpreted as a situation in which society focuses on the economy which includes increasingly diverse jobs (specialization), higher salaries and income. Industrialization is part of the modernization process in which social change and economic development are closely related to technological innovation. again refers to morals, emotions, habits or traditions). According to the researchers there are factors that become a reference for industrial modernization and company development. Starting from a political and legal environment that is favorable for the world of industry and commerce, it can also be with diverse and abundant natural resources, as well as human resources that tend to be low in cost, have the ability and can adapt to their jobs. The first country to industrialize was England during the industrial revolution in the 18th century. By the end of the 20th century, countries in East Asia had become the part of the world that had done the most industrialization. According to Jean Fourastie's classification, an economy consists of 3 parts. The first part consists of commodity production (agriculture, animal husbandry, exploitation of mineral resources). The second part is the process of producing goods for sale and the third part is the service industry. The industrialization process is based on the expansion of the second part whose economic activities are dominated by the activities of the first part. The first Industrial Revolution took place in the mid-18th to early 19th centuries in Western Europe, North America, starting for the first time in England. fossil energy) and the construction of canals, railroads to electricity poles.

Hippias was a philosopher who belonged to the class of sophists. Besides philosophy, he also mastered expertise in other fields, such as mathematics, astronomy, rhetoric, music, mythology, and history. In addition, he also has great services in the field of geometry. Hippias is spoken of by Plato in two of his works, Hippias Major and Hippias Minor. Hippias came from the city of Elis but worked in Athens. Hippias lived around the 5th century AD and became known around 430 AD. He was a contemporary of Socrates. Just like Prodikos and Gorgias, Hippias also became an ambassador from Elis to other cities, such as Sparta and Athens. He once gave a lecture at Olympia which was followed by questions and answers. Hippias has a haughty personality and always looks neat. He gave teachings to his students in terms of rhetoric so that they would not lose in debates. In addition, he also developed a system to increase human memory. Like many other sophists, Hippias was devoted to the question, "What determines human behavior? Customs and laws (nomos) or human nature?" He replied that human nature is the basis for human behavior and the structure of society. The argument given by Hippias was regarding laws that had to be amended and corrected many times. Therefore, the law is not the final norm to determine good and evil, even the law can degrade human nature. For example, the law classifies people into the categories of slaves and free people. This is contrary to the principle of equality of all human beings. Based on Xenophon's narrative, Hippias also held the doctrine of natural law. Worship of deities and respect for parents are seen as examples. These two things are common in all countries so that they are seen as natural law.

Part of the series Atheism Antitheism Atheism and religion Strong and weak atheism Implicit and explicit atheism History of atheism Arguments from design Demographics Criticism of Atheist Figures State atheism Discrimination Atheist or Atheism is a philosophical view that believes in the non-existence of God and gods or the rejection of theism accompanied by claim. In its broadest sense, it is the belief that there is no god or God in existence. The term atheism comes from the Greek ἄθεος (átheos), which is pejoratively used to refer to anyone whose beliefs conflict with the established religion/belief in their environment. With the spread of free thought, scientific skepticism, and criticism of religion, the term atheist began to be specified to refer to those who did not believe in god. The first self-proclaimed "atheist" appeared in the 18th century. Today, about 2.3% of the world's population identify as atheists, while 11.9% identify as nontheists. About 65% of Japan's population identify as atheists, agnostics, or people with no religion; and about 48% in Russia. The percentage of such communities in the European Union ranges from 6% (Italy) to 85% (Sweden). Many atheists are skeptical of the existence of paranormal phenomena due to a lack of empirical evidence. Others provide arguments with philosophical, social, or historical grounds. In Western culture, atheists are often seen as irreligious. Some schools of Buddhism never mention the term 'God' in various ritual ceremonies, but in Buddhism the concept of divinity in question uses the term Nirvana. Therefore this religion is often called an atheistic religion. Although many who define themselves as atheists lean toward secular philosophies such as humanism, rationalism, and naturalism, there is no specific ideology or behavior that all atheists espouse.

In Ancient Greece, the adjective atheos (ἄθεος, from the prefix ἀ- + θεός "god") meant "godless". The word began to refer to the intentional and active rejection of god in the 5th century BC, with the definition of "cutting off from god/gods" or "rejecting god/gods". Modern translations of the classical texts sometimes render atheos as "atheistic". As an abstract noun, there is also ἀθεότης (atheotēs), which means "atheism". Cicero transliterated the Greek word into Latin atheos. This term was often used in debates between the early Christians and followers of the Ancient Greek (Hellenic) religion, in which each side referred to the other as atheists pejoratively. Atheism was first used to refer to "separate belief" in the late 18th century in Europe, primarily referring to the disbelief in a monotheistic God. In the 20th century, globalization broadened the definition of this term to refer to "non-belief in all gods", although it is still common to refer to atheism as "monotheism". Recently, there has been a push within certain philosophical groups to redefine atheism as the "absence of belief in gods/goddesses", rather than atheism as a belief in itself. This definition is very popular among the atheist community, although its use is still very limited. Authors differ in defining and classifying atheism, namely whether atheism is a belief in itself or simply the absence of belief, and whether atheism requires conscious and explicit rejection. Various categories have been proposed to try to distinguish the different forms of atheism. Some of the ambiguity and controversy involved in defining atheism lies in the difficulty of reaching a consensus on defining words such as god and god. Plurality in the concept of divinity and gods causes different thoughts on the application of the word atheism.

Government is an organization that has the authority to regulate communities in a certain area, which is generally the state. There are several definitions of government systems. Similarly, there are various types of governments in the world. In its broad associative definition, government generally consists of the legislature, the executive, and the judiciary. The government is a means for enforcing organizational policies, as well as a mechanism for determining policies. Every government has some kind of constitution, which is a statement of the principles and philosophy of its government. While all types of organizations have governance, the term government is often used more specifically to refer to the approximately 200 independent national governments and their subordinate organizations. Throughout history, the most common forms of government have included monarchy, aristocracy, timocracy, oligarchy, democracy, theocracy and tyranny. A key aspect of the philosophy of any government is how political power is acquired — the two main forms of which are elections and hereditary succession. The origin and development of the phenomenon of human government is not known with certainty; however, history records the formation of early governments. Around 5,000 years ago, several small city-states appeared. In the third to second millennium BC, several of these city-states developed into larger fiefdoms: Sumer, Ancient Egypt, the Indus Valley Civilization, and the Yellow River Civilization. Development of agricultural projects and water control is a catalyst for the development of government. Sometimes, a chief is chosen by various rituals or tests of strength to rule the tribe, sometimes involving a group of older people as the council. Humans' ability to precisely learn and communicate abstract information allows humans to act more effectively in farming, which in turn continues to increase population densities. Historian David Christian explains how this resulted in states with laws and governments.

Beginning in the late 17th century, a republican form of government grew. The Great Revolution in England, the United States Revolution, and the French Revolution contributed to the growth of representative government. The Soviet Union was the first major country to have a communist government. Since the fall of the Berlin Wall, more and more countries have adopted liberal democracy as their form of government. In the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, there was a significant increase in the size and scale of government at the national level, including corporate governance and the development of the welfare state. In political science, making a typology or taxonomy of political entities has long been a goal because the typology of political systems is not clear. This is especially important in comparative politics (a field within political science) and international relations. Like all categories of forms of government, the boundaries of government classification can be fluid or unclear. On the surface, all governments have an official or ideal form. The United States is a constitutional republic, while the former Soviet Union is a socialist republic. But self-identification is not objective and, as political scientists Kopstein and Lichbach say, defining regimes can be tricky. For example, the French philosopher Voltaire argued that "the Holy Roman Empire is neither Empire nor Roman nor Holy". Identifying a form of government is also difficult because many political systems originate from socio-economic movements which are then brought into government by parties calling themselves from these movements; all with competing political ideologies. Experience with ruling movements and the strong ties they may have to certain forms of government, may cause them to be considered a form of government itself. Other complications include general disagreement or deliberate "distortion or bias" of the technical definitions of political ideology and related forms of government due to the nature of politics in the modern era.

Semarang (Javanese: Hanacaraka:ꦯꦼꦩꦫꦁ​, Pegon: سماراڠ) is the capital city of Central Java Province, Indonesia which is also the center of government and economy of Central Java Province, Indonesia. This city is the fifth largest metropolitan city in Indonesia after Jakarta, Surabaya, Bandung, Medan and Semarang. As one of the developing cities in Java Island, Semarang City has a population of around 1.6 million people. The Semarang mega-urban area which is part of the Kedungsepur metropolitan area (Kendal, Demak, Ungaran, Semarang Regency, Salatiga City, Semarang City and Purwodadi, Grobogan Regency) has a population of 7.3 million people, as well as being the fourth most populous metropolitan area on the island of Java. after Jabodetabek (Jakarta), Gerbangkertosusilo (Surabaya), and Bandung Raya. In recent years, the significant development of Semarang has also been marked by the emergence of several skyscrapers scattered throughout the city and the arrangement of the city by the construction of pedestrian-friendly places. This regional development shows the strategic role of Semarang City in the wheels of the national economy. The city of Semarang is led by the mayor Dr. Hendrar Prihadi, S.E, M.M and deputy mayor Ir. Hj. Hevearita Gunaryanti Rahayu M.Sos. This city is located about 558 km east of Jakarta, or 312 km west of Surabaya, or 621 km southwest of Banjarmasin (by air). Semarang is bordered by the Java Sea to the north, Demak Regency to the east, Semarang Regency to the south, and Kendal Regency to the west. The city of Semarang has an administrative area of ​​373.70 square km, and is the largest municipal administration in Java Island. Etymologically, the name "Semarang" comes from the word "sem", which means "tamarind/tamarind tree", and the word "arang", which means "rare", which are combined to become "tamarind which is rare". The naming of "Semarang" began when Ki Ageng Pandanaran I came to an island called Pulau Tirang (near the port of Bergota) and saw tamarind trees that rarely grew close together.

The naming of the city of Semarang had changed during the colonial era of the Dutch East Indies to become "Samarang". The city of Semarang was one of three important port centers (Jakarta and Surabaya) for the Dutch East Indies as a supplier of crops from the interior of Java. Like other big cities, the city of Semarang recognizes a city area division system which consists of: Central Semarang or Central Semarang, East Semarang, South Semarang, West Semarang and North Semarang. The territorial division of this city stems from the division of the sub-resident areas by the Dutch East Indies Government at the same level as the sub-districts. However, at present, the division of the city area is different from the administrative division of the sub-district area. Although this division of the city is rarely used within the Semarang City Government. However, this city division is used to make it easier to explain a location according to its location to the center of Semarang. This division of the city is also used by several agencies within the City of Semarang to facilitate the reach of services, such as PLN and PDAM. The administrative boundaries of Semarang City include: Semarang City is one of the important cities located on the north coast of Java and serves as the main hub connecting Jakarta-Surabaya and cities in the southern interior of Java (Surakarta and Yogyakarta). The city of Semarang has a height from 2 meters below sea level to 340 meters above sea level with a slope of 0%–45%. Semarang City is a city that has unique topographical conditions in the form of narrow lowland areas and hilly areas that extend from the west to the east side of Semarang City. The lowland area in Semarang City is very narrow. The low-lying areas in the western region of Semarang City are only 4 kilometers wide from the coastline, while in the eastern region of Semarang City the low-lying areas are widening up to 11 kilometers from the coastline.

Agriculture is the activity of utilizing biological resources by humans to produce food, industrial raw materials or energy sources, as well as to manage their environment. The activities of utilizing biological resources that are included in agriculture are commonly understood by people as cultivating plants or cultivating crops and rearing livestock, although its scope can also be in the form of using microorganisms and bioenzymes in the processing of advanced products, such as making cheese and tempeh, or simply extraction, such as catching fish or forest exploitation. The largest part of the world's population makes a living in fields within the scope of agriculture, but agriculture only contributes 4% of world GDP. The agricultural sciences group examines agriculture with the support of supporting sciences. Because agriculture is always bound by space and time, supporting sciences, such as soil science, meteorology, agricultural engineering, biochemistry, and statistics are also studied in agriculture. Farming is a core part of agriculture because it involves a set of activities carried out in cultivation. "Farmers" is a term for those who carry out farming businesses, for example "tobacco farmers" or "fish farmers". Those cultivating livestock are specifically referred to as breeders. Agriculture in a broad sense includes all activities involving the use of living things (including plants, animals and microbes) for the benefit of humans. In a narrow sense, agriculture is defined as plant cultivation activities. Agricultural businesses are given special names for certain farming business subjects. Forestry is farming with plant subjects (usually trees) and cultivated on semi-wild or wild land (forest). Livestock use is subject to dry land animals (particularly all vertebrates except fish and amphibians) or insects (eg bees). The fishery has the subject of aquatic animals (including amphibians and all non-aquatic vertebrates). An agricultural business can involve these various subjects together for reasons of efficiency and increased profits.

Consideration of environmental sustainability results in aspects of natural resource conservation also being part of agricultural business. All agricultural businesses are basically economic activities, so they require the same basic knowledge of business location management, selection of seeds/seedlings, cultivation methods, yield collection, product distribution, product processing and packaging, and marketing. If a farmer looks at all of these aspects with consideration of efficiency to achieve maximum profit then he does intensive farming. Agricultural business viewed in this way is known as agribusiness. Programs and policies that direct agricultural businesses to this perspective are known as intensification. Because industrial agriculture has always applied intensive farming, the two are often confused. The side of industrial agriculture that pays attention to its environment is sustainable agriculture. Sustainable agriculture, also known as its variations such as organic farming or permaculture, incorporates aspects of the sustainability of the carrying capacity of the land as well as the environment and local knowledge as important factors in calculating its efficiency. As a result, sustainable agriculture usually yields lower yields than industrial agriculture. Modern agriculture today usually employs some components of both poles of the agricultural "ideology" mentioned above. In addition to these two, there are also known forms of extensive farming (low input agriculture) which in the most extreme and traditional forms will take the form of subsistence farming, which is only carried out without business motives and solely to meet one's own needs or that of the community. As a business, agriculture has two important characteristics: it always involves large volumes of goods and the production process has a relatively high risk. These two characteristics arise because agriculture involves living things in one or several stages and requires space for these activities and a certain period of time in the production process. Some modern forms of agriculture (eg algae cultivation, hydroponics) have reduced these characteristics but most of the world's agricultural endeavors still do.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health Sciences Physics (an absorption from Dutch: fysica, from Greek: φυσικός, translit. fysikós meaning "natural" or Greek: φύσις, translit. fýsis meaning "nature"; Latin: Physica; Arabic: فيزياء, translit. fīziyāʾ‎) is a science or natural science that studies matter and its motion and behavior in space and time, along with related concepts such as energy and force. As one of the most basic sciences, the main goal of physics is to understand how the universe works. a] People or scientists who are experts in physics are called physicists or physicists. Physics is one of the oldest academic disciplines, perhaps the oldest through which astronomy is included. For more than two millennia, physics was part of the Natural Sciences along with chemistry, biology, and certain branches of mathematics, but with the advent of the scientific revolution in the 17th century, natural science developed as a research program of its own. others, such as biophysics and quantum chemistry, and their physical boundaries are not clearly defined. New knowledge in physics is sometimes used to explain the underlying mechanics of other sciences as well as to pave the way for other research areas such as mathematics and philosophy. Physics also makes an important contribution to the development of technology that develops from theoretical thinking. For example, further understanding of electromagnetism or nuclear physics has led directly to the development of new products that have dramatically shaped modern society, such as televisions, computers, household appliances, and nuclear weapons; advances in thermodynamics led to the development of industrialization, and advances in mechanics inspired the development of calculus. Astronomy is the oldest natural science. The oldest recorded civilizations date back to around 3000 BC, such as the Sumerians, Ancient Egypt, and the Indus Valley Civilization.

All of them have predictive knowledge and a basic understanding of the movements of the moon, sun and stars. Stars and planets are sometimes used as targets of worship, they believe that it is their God. Despite the often unscientific explanations for this phenomenon and the lack of evidence available, these early observations became the basis for later astronomy. According to Asger Aaboe, the beginnings of Western astronomy can be found in Mesopotamia, and all Western endeavors in the exact sciences date back to late Babylon. Egyptian astronomers left monuments showing knowledge of the constellations and the motions of the celestial bodies, while the Greek poet Homer described various celestial bodies in his Iliad and Odyssey; later Greek astronomers gave the names, which are still used today, to most of the constellations visible from the northern hemisphere. Natural philosophy originated in Greece in the Archaic period, (650 BCE – 480 BCE), when pre-Socratic philosophers such as Thales rejected non-naturalistic explanations for natural phenomena and argued that every event had a natural cause. They proposed ideas that were proven by reason and observation, and many of their hypotheses proved successful in experiments; for example, atomism was finally confirmed 2,000 years after it was first proposed by Leucippus and his student Democritus. Islamic scholars had inherited Aristotelian physics from the Greeks and during the Golden Age of Islam increasingly advanced, placing observation and a priori thinking as their focus, developing early forms of the scientific method. The most important discoveries were in the field of optics and sight, resulting from the work of many scientists such as Ibn Sahl, Al-Kindi, Ibn al-Haytham, Al-Farisi and Avicenna. The most important work is The Book of Optics (also known as Kitāb al-Manāẓir), written by Ibn Al-Haitham, in which he was not only the first to reject the ancient Greek idea of ​​vision, but also gave a new theory.

Africa is the second largest continent in the world and the second most populous after Asia. With an area of ​​30,224,050 km² including adjacent islands, Africa covers 20.3% of the total land area of ​​the Earth. With 800 million people in 54 countries, this continent is home to one seventh of the world's population. With a population of 1.3 billion people as of 2018, this continent accounts for around 16% of the world's human population. The continent is surrounded by the Mediterranean Sea to the north, the Isthmus of Suez and the Red Sea to the northeast, the Indian Ocean to the southeast and the Atlantic Ocean to the west. This continent includes Madagascar and various islands. The continent also contains 54 fully recognized sovereign states, nine territories and two de facto independent states with limited or no recognition. The majority of the continent and its countries are in the Northern Hemisphere, with most and most of the countries in the Southern Hemisphere. Africa's average population is the youngest of all continents; the median age in 2012 was 19.7, when the worldwide average was 30.4. Algeria is the largest country in Africa by area, and Nigeria is the country with the largest population. Africa, especially central East Africa, is widely accepted as the origin of humans and the Hominidae (great ape) clade, as evidenced by the discoveries of the earliest hominids and their and later ancestors dating back approximately 7 million years, including Sahelanthropus tchadensis, Australopithecus africanus, A. afarensis, Homo erectus, H. habilis and H. ergaster - The earliest Homo sapiens (modern humans), discovered in Ethiopia, around 200,000 years ago. Africa straddles the equator and includes many climatic regions; it is the only continent that extends from the northern temperate zone to the southern temperate zone.

Africa hosts a great diversity of human ethnicities, cultures, and languages. At the end of the 19th century, European countries colonized almost all of Africa; most countries in Africa emerged from the decolonization process in the 20th century. African countries work together through the formation of the African Union, which is headquartered in Addis Ababa. The word Africa comes from the Latin, Africa terra — "land of Afri" (plural of "Afer") — to denote the northern part of the continent, currently part of Tunisia, seat of the Roman province of Africa. The origin of the word Afer may be from Phoenician, 'afar meaning dust; or from the Afridi tribe, who inhabited the northern part of the continent near Carthage; or from the Greek aphrike meaning without cold; or from the Latin aprica means bright. Africa is the earliest human habitation, from this continent humans then spread to other continents. Africa is the place where the ape evolutionary line diverged from that of the protohumans seven million years ago. Africa was the only continent where human ancestors lived until about two million years ago, when Homo erectus expanded beyond Africa into Europe and Asia. More than 1.5 million years later, the populations of the three continents followed different evolutions so that they became distinct species. Those in Europe became Neanderthals, those in Asia remained Homo erectus, but those in Africa evolved into Homo sapiens. Africa is the largest of the three continents in the southern hemisphere of the Earth and the second largest of all continents after Asia. It has an area of ​​approximately 30,244,050 km2 (11,677,240 sq mi) including the surrounding islands, covers 20.3% of the total land area on earth and is inhabited by more than 800 million people, or about one seventh of the human population on earth.

Israel (IPA: ɪsra.ɛl]; Hebrew: מדינת ישראל, translit. Medinat Yisrā'el‎; Arabic: الدولة إسرائيل, translit. al-Dawlat Isrā'īl‎) is a country in West Asia surrounded by the Mediterranean Sea. , Lebanon, Syria, Palestine, Jordan, Egypt. In addition, it is also surrounded by two Palestinian National Authority areas: the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. With a population of 7.5 million, Israel is the only Jewish state in the world. In addition, there are also several other ethnic minority groups, including Arabs with Israeli citizenship, along with other religious groups such as Muslims, Christians, Druze, Samaritans and others. The founding of the modern state of Israel has its roots in the concept of the Land of Israel (Eretz Yisrael), a concept central to Judaism since ancient times, which was also the territorial center of the ancient Kingdom of Judah. After World War I, the League of Nations approved making the British Mandate of Palestine "the land of the Jewish people". In 1947, the United Nations approved the Partition of Palestine into two states, namely one Jewish state and one Arab state. On May 14, 1948, Israel proclaimed its independence and this was immediately followed by wars with the surrounding Arab countries who rejected this partition plan. Israel then won this war and confirmed its independence. As a result of this war, Israel also managed to expand the boundaries of its territory to exceed the boundaries determined by the Palestinian Partition Plan. Since then, Israel has been in constant conflict with neighboring Arab countries, causing wars and violence that continue to this day. Since the beginning of the formation of the State of Israel, the boundaries of the state of Israel and Israel's right to exist have been contested by many parties, especially by Arab countries and Palestinian refugees. Israel has signed peace agreements with Egypt and Jordan, but peace efforts between Palestine and Israel have so far been unsuccessful.

Israel is a democracy with a parliamentary system of government and universal suffrage. The Prime Minister of Israel serves as head of government and the Knesset serves as Israel's legislature. In terms of gross domestic product, the country's economy ranks 44th in the world. Israel has the highest rankings on the Human Development Index, press freedom, and economic competitiveness compared to neighboring Arab countries. For more than three thousand years, the name "Israel" had both a general and religious meaning as either the Land of Israel or the entire Jewish state. According to the Bible, Jacob was named Israel after his successful struggle with an angel of God. According to archaeological artifact finds, the name "Israel" (other than as a personal name) is the earliest known mention of the Merneptah inscription in ancient Egypt (circa late 13th century BC). In this inscription the name "Israel" itself refers to a group of people who come from a certain land. The modern state of Israel is called Medinat Yisrael, which means "State of Israel". In addition, other names were suggested, including Eretz Israel ("Land of Israel"), Zion, and Judea, but all were rejected. In English, Israeli citizens/people are referred to as Israelis. The term was chosen by the Israeli government at the start of its independence. This was officially announced by the Israeli Foreign Minister at the time, Moshe Sharett. This area is also known as the Holy Land, which is sacred to all Abrahamic religions including Judaism, Christianity, Islam and the Bahá'í faith. Prior to Israel's 1948 Declaration of Independence, this entire area was known by various other names, including Southern Syria, Palestinian Syria, Kingdom of Jerusalem, Province of Iudaea, Coele-Syria, Retjenu, Canaan and, in particular, Palestine.
