Ideas or ideas (from the Greek ἰδέα idea "form, pattern," from the root ἰδεῖν idein, "to see") in philosophy usually refer to a mental representation of an object. Ideas can also be abstract concepts that do not represent mental pictures. According to the Big Indonesian Dictionary, an idea is defined as a design that is arranged in the mind; or a feeling that completely envelops the mind. Ideas, like ideas, have the meaning of the result of thought. In general, an idea is something that results from thoughts, proposals, wishes, and hopes which are then conveyed or heard. It can also be defined as a conception that exists in the mind as a result of mental understanding, awareness, or activity. The ideas in the study of Greek philosophy and Islamic philosophy involve a complete picture of the imagination, which immediately passes away. For example: the idea of ​​a spoon comes to mind as a whole spoon. As long as the idea has not been implanted into a concept with real words or pictures, then the idea will only remain in the mind. Ideas will produce concepts as the basis of all kinds of knowledge, including science and philosophy. Today, many people think of an idea as a kind of intellectual property, like a copyright or patent. The word 'idea' comes from the Greek ἰδέα idea "form, pattern," from the root ἰδεῖν idein, "to see". In the Big Indonesian Dictionary, 'idea' is defined as an idea or thought. Plato expressed his views on the theory of ideas before it was known as idealism. Ideas according to Plato are not bound by time and place, therefore ideas are not creatures. Plato prioritizes ideas as a non-sensuous nature or something that is intangible, and also Plato says that truth comes from material, the material is only the truth which lies the essential truth in the idea, in other Plato's words stated that there is something that exists, with In other words Plato said there are two elements, namely physical and spiritual.

For this reason, the idea is defined as the essence of something, because with the idea that is the origin of the physical form. Rene Descartes said that "ideas are models of thought". An idea is understood as the way it is perceived, as it originates from the mind or is a form of manifestation of the mind. He expressed his assumption that the human self has a set of ideas. If it is explained that the essence or nature of the mind is thinking, then the idea is a way of thinking that represents an object for the mind. Descartes grouped ideas into three types, namely innate ideas, adventitious ideas, and factitious ideas. The goal is to convey ideas in the form of evidence data, reasoning results, and other thoughts in order to convince listeners or readers about the truth, or conclusions of the speaker. The ideas conveyed are also intended to be able to solve problems or as solutions or ways to overcome problems. The ideas conveyed are objective and reasonable and are often also known as opinions. Innate ideas in philosophy are ideas thought to be born in the human mind, different from those received or compiled from experience. Innate ideas encompass at least certain ideas (e.g., ideas about God, immensity, substance of thought), because no satisfactory empirical origin of them can be understood. Adventitious ideas are ideas that come from outside, from objects, and outside the mind. This goes against the innate idea. Descartes' form of the ontological argument about God is built on the idea of ​​adventitious ideas. Artificial ideas are artificial ideas whose contents are derived from the contents of other ideas, no doubt included in the category of non-primary ideas or ideas that originate from the objective reality of some other ideas. Factors that serve as benchmarks for conveying ideas can be grouped into several parts, namely 1) The ideas put forward are related to the problem, 2) The ideas put forward accelerate understanding of the problem, find causes and solve problems, 3) The ideas put forward do not repeat ideas that have been communicated by other participants, 4) Ideas submitted are supported by factors, examples, illustrations, comparisons or testimonies, 5) Language that expresses thoughts with the correct words and sentences, 6) Actions, expressions, tone, stress, and intonation used can clarify thoughts conveyed, and 7) Expressing ideas in a polite and unemotional manner.

Homeostasis is an automatic process and mechanism carried out by living things to maintain constant conditions so that their bodies can function normally, despite changes in the environment inside or outside the body. This constant state includes variables, such as body temperature and body fluid balance, which are maintained within predetermined limits (which are called homeostatic ranges). Examples of other variables are the pH of the extracellular fluid, the concentrations of sodium, potassium, and calcium ions, and blood sugar levels. These things need to be maintained even though the environment, diet, and body activities are constantly changing. Each of these variables is controlled by one or several mechanisms that together sustain life. When things are in optimal conditions, homeostasis appears as a natural resistance to change. Balanced conditions are maintained and regulated by many mechanisms. All mechanisms that control homeostasis have at least three interdependent components, namely receptors, control centers, and effectors, each of which is present for each regulated variable. Receptors are sensing components that monitor and respond to changes in the environment, both external and internal. Receptors include temperature receptors and mechanical receptors. Control centers such as the respiratory center and the renin-angiotensin system. The effector is the target that is acted upon so that changes are returned to their normal state. The concept of regulation of the internal environment was explained by the French physiologist Claude Bernard in 1849, while the word homeostasis was coined by Walter Bradford Cannon in 1926. In 1932, Joseph Barcroft, a British physiologist, said that the higher functions of the brain require the most internal environment. stable. For Barcroft, homeostasis is not only regulated by the brain, but also serves the brain. Homeostasis is an almost exclusively biological term, referring to the concept explained by Bernard and Cannon, regarding the constant internal environment in which the body's cells live and survive.

The term cybernetics is applied to control systems such as thermostats, which function as mechanisms to maintain homeostasis, but are often defined much more broadly than the biological term homeostasis. The word homeostasis itself incorporates new Latin words from Ancient Greek: ὅμοιος homoios, "similar" and στάσις stasis, "to remain still", which results in the compound word "remaining the same". Metabolic processes in all organisms can only occur in a very specific physical and chemical environment. Conditions vary from organism to organism and depend on whether chemical processes take place inside the cells or in the interstitial fluid that bathes the cells. The best known mechanisms of homeostasis in mammals are regulators that keep the composition of the extracellular fluid (or "internal environment") constant, especially with respect to temperature, pH, osmolality, and concentrations of sodium, potassium, glucose, carbon dioxide, and oxygen. There are many other homeostatic mechanisms that regulate various aspects of physiology in the body. When the level of a variable is higher or lower than required, each of these conditions is often preceded by hyper- and hypo-, such as hyperthermia and hypothermia or hypertension and hypotension. If an entity is controlled through homeostasis, that does not imply that its values ​​must be strictly stable to maintain health. Core body temperature, for example, is regulated by homeostatic mechanisms by temperature sensors, one of which is the hypothalamus in the brain. However, the set point of a regulator is reset regularly. For example, core body temperature in humans varies throughout the day (influenced by circadian rhythms), with the lowest temperature occurring at night and the highest in the afternoon. Normal temperature also varies due to the menstrual cycle. The temperature regulator set point is reset during infection to produce fever. Organisms are able to adapt to various conditions, such as changes in temperature or oxygen levels at a certain altitude, through the acclimatization process.

Senegal (/ˌsɛnɪˈɡɔːl, -ˈɡɑːl/ ( listen); French: Sénégal; Wolof: Senegaal), officially the Republic of Senegal (French: République du Sénégal ʁepyblik dy seneɡal]), is a country south of the Senegal River in West Africa . The country is bordered by the Atlantic Ocean to the west, Mauritania to the north, Mali to the east, and Guinea and Guinea Bissau to the south. The Gambia is an enclave within the territory of Senegal. The 300 km long Gambia River flows in Gambia. Cape Verde is located 560 km from the coast of Senegal. The capital city of Senegal is Dakar. The name "Senegal" comes from the Wolof word "Sunuu Gaal", which means "Our Boat". Senegal has a land area of ​​nearly 197,000 square kilometers and has a population of approximately 15 million people. Senegal's climate is that of the Sahel, but it also experiences monsoons. Senegal has a population of over 13.5 million, about 42 percent of whom live in rural areas. Density in this area varies from about 77 inhabitants per square kilometer in the west-central region to 2 per square kilometer in the east. In the mid-15th century, the Portuguese landed on the coast of Senegal, followed by traders representing other countries, including France. Various European powers—Portugal, Holland, and England—compete for trade in this area from the 15th century onward. In 1677, the French took control of what had become a minor point of departure in the Atlantic slave trade—the island of Gorée next to modern Dakar, used as a base for buying slaves. European missionaries introduced Christianity to Senegal and Casamance in the 19th century. It was only in the 1850s that the French began expanding into the Senegalese mainland after they abolished slavery and began promoting abolitionist doctrine, adding native kingdoms such as the Waalo, Cayor, Baol, and Wolof Empires.

The French colonies progressively invaded and took over all the principalities except Sine and Saloum under Governor Louis Faidherbe. Senegal's resistance to French expansion and the imprisonment of the slave trade that benefited them was led in part by Lat-Dior, Damel of Cayor, and Maad a Sinig Kumba Ndoffene Famak Joof, king of Sine, resulting in the Battle of Logandème. On 4 April 1959 Senegal and French Sudan merged to form the Federation of Mali, which became fully independent on 20 June 1960, as a result of the independence and transfer of powers agreement signed with France on 4 April 1960. Senegal was divided into 14 regions, each each administered by a Regional Council which is elected based on population size at the Arrondissement level. The country is further subdivided by 45 Departments, 113 Arrondissements (both of which have no administrative function). Regional capitals share names with their respective regions: Senegal has a population of over 13.5 million, about 42 percent of whom live in rural areas. Density in this area varies from about 77 inhabitants per square kilometer in the west-central region to 2 per square kilometer in the east. Senegal has various ethnic groups and, as in most West African countries, several languages ​​are spoken. Wolof are the largest ethnic group in Senegal at 43 percent; Fula and Toucouleur (also known as Halpulaar'en, literally "Pulaar-speakers") (24%) are the second largest group, followed by Serer (14.7%), followed by groups like Jola (4%), Mandinka (3%), Maures (or Naarkajors), Soninke, Bassari and many smaller communities (9%). About 50,000 Europeans (mostly from France) and Lebanese and a smaller portion from Mauritania and Morocco live in Senegal, mainly in towns and some retirees living in resort towns around Mbour.

Berlin (/bərˈlɪn/; German pronunciation: bɛɐ̯ˈliːn] ( listen)) was the capital of the Federal Republic of Germany since 1994. Previously the eastern part of the city was the capital of the German Democratic Republic from 1949 - 1990 and the capital of the united Germany from 1871 - 1945. The city (2007) had a population of around 3.3 million, making it the largest city in Germany and the second largest city in the European Union after London. Located in northeastern Germany and fed by the River Spree, the city is the center of the Berlin-Brandenburg Metropolitan Area, which has a population of around 4.5 million people from more than 180 countries. About a third of the city consists of forests and city parks, as well as lakes and rivers. First documented in the 13th century, Berlin was the capital of the Kingdom of Prussia (1701–1918), the German Empire (1871–1918), the Weimar Republic (1919–33) and Nazi Germany (1933–45). Berlin in the 1920s was the third largest municipality in the world. After World War II, the city split into East Berlin-the capital of East Germany and West Berlin, an exclav (surrounded by the Berlin Wall in 1961-1989) of the federal state of the Federal Republic of Germany. After German reunification in 1990, the city again became the national capital of Germany and is home to 147 embassies of foreign countries. Besides being a city, Berlin is also one of 16 German states, which acts as the center of European Union political activities, as well as being the busiest metropolis in Europe. The city is also used as a traffic center for economic, cultural, educational, political and scientific activities in Germany. The city's economy is based on high-tech industries and the service sector, plus several creative industry sectors, media and convention arenas.

Berlin is also a major hub for rail and air transport in Europe and a popular tourist destination. There are various kinds of industries in this city: information technology, medicine, biotechnology, electronics, renewable energy, and others. Several institutions such as universities, research institutes, theaters, and museums are located in this city. The city's many historic sites have made it popular as a location for international film productions. This city is also known to have a good quality of life for its residents. The football club based in this city is Hertha BSC Berlin. At the end of World War I in 1918, the Weimar Republic was proclaimed in this city. In 1920, the Greater Berlin Act merged the suburbs, rural areas, and settlements around Berlin to expand the city area. The new city area included Spandau and Charlottenburg in the west. After this expansion, Berlin had a population of around four million. During the Weimar era, Berlin became the center of a cultural transformation, known as the Roaring Twenties. On January 30, 1933, Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party came to power. The regulations made by the Nazis effectively damaged Berlin's Jewish community, which numbered about 160,000 in 1933 (one third of the number of Jews in Germany at the time). The Jewish population was reduced to just 80,000 as a result of the 1933-1939 migration. After Kristallnacht in 1938, thousands of the city's Jews were imprisoned in the Sachsenhausen concentration camp and starting in 1943, were sent to death camps such as the Auschwitz concentration camp. During World War II, most of the city was destroyed in the Battle of Berlin. Hundreds of thousands of people died as a result of this battle, an estimated 125,000 civilians died. After the end of World War II in Europe in 1945, Berlin received large numbers of refugees from the eastern provinces.

A semiconductor is a material with an electrical conductivity that is in between that of an electrical insulator and an electrical conductor. Semiconductor materials consist of 4 valence electrons. The types of semiconductor materials commonly used are carbon, germanium, and silicon. Based on the type of doping, semiconductor materials are divided into two types, namely type P and type N. A semiconductor acts as an electrical insulator if it is not given an electric current in a certain way and with a certain amount of electric current. However, at temperatures, electric currents, procedures and certain work requirements, semiconductors function as conductors, for example as current amplifiers, voltage amplifiers and power amplifiers. To use a semiconductor so that it can function, you must know the specifications and characteristics of the semiconductor, if it does not meet the operating requirements it will not function and be damaged. Semiconductors are very useful in electronics, because their conductance can be varied by injecting other materials (often called electron donors). Semiconductors are used in a variety of semiconductor devices. The electrical properties of a material, including semiconductors, can be described using an energy band diagram. The energy band diagram explains that from a group of atoms that are neatly arranged to form a certain crystal structure, there are only a number of energy levels that can be occupied by electrons. The electrons will occupy the lower energy level first. The last band filled with electrons is called the valence band. The number of energy levels after the valence band is called the conduction band. The distance between the lowest energy level in the conduction band and the highest energy level in the valence band is called the bandgap. In silicon, this band gap is 1.1 eV. Semiconductor materials consisting of the same elements are called intrinsic semiconductors. This intrinsic semiconductor has certain electrical properties at a certain temperature, for example the number of charge carriers.

In application, we want to manipulate the number of charge carriers in a way other than changing the temperature, for example by doping the intrinsic semiconductor. Doped intrinsic semiconductors are called extrinsic semiconductors. Doped intrinsic semiconductors are called extrinsic semiconductors. Extrinsic semiconductors can be distinguished based on the group of doping atoms. P-type semiconductors are semiconductors with very few electrons. The material for making P-type semiconductors is a mixture of germanium atoms and indium atoms or other atoms that have 3 valence electrons, e.g., boron, aluminum, gallium. The P-type semiconductor is positively charged because indium has fewer electrons than germanium. The N-type semiconductor is a semiconductor with a large number of electrons. The material for making N-type semiconductors is a mixture of germanium atoms and arsenic atoms or other atoms that have 5 valence electrons, e.g. phosphorus, arsenic, antimony. The N-type semiconductor is negatively charged because arsenic has more electrons than germanium. The electric current strength in semiconductor materials cannot be known precisely through Ohm's law. The application of Ohm's law only applies to electric circuits that have an electric current that is always directly proportional to the value of the working voltage. On the other hand, semiconductor materials do not always have an electric current that is a linear function of the applied voltage. The electric current that flows through the semiconductor material can experience a linear function, a quadratic function or a cubic function with respect to the working voltage value. In semiconductor materials the Hall effect applies which determines the electric current density expressed in charge per unit volume. The value of electric voltage on a semiconductor material is determined by the concentration of electric charges carried into the electric material.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Science Health Science Police is a law enforcement in Indonesia, security and public order. The role of the police within the court environment is as an investigator. In his duties he seeks money with, statements from various sources, both the testimony of witnesses and the testimony of expert witnesses. The role of the police in society is to guard public order by taking action against lawbreakers (gambling, theft, narcotics, immorality, separatism, terrorism, traffic violations, etc.). Sometimes these institutions are militaristic (Military Police, Carabinieri) and paramilitary (POLRI, SWAT, GIGN, GENDARMERIES). As in Indonesia, after the Indonesian National Police (Polri) was released from ABRI, the POLRI organization was included in the official paramilitary category of the police, because the status of POLRI members in the Police Act is not part of the PNS. POLRI as the parent organization of the state police is not allowed to vote in elections. POLRI is neutral, cannot participate in politics and may not participate in giving voting rights in elections. The Polri organization was founded on July 1, 1946 as a successor to the spirit of the Bhayangkara Troop. Before Polri was established, there was already a special police force (tokubetsu keisatsutai) which had taken part in the struggle for independence. The special police force was formed by the Japanese government in 1943 as an organizational vessel for indigenous police. During the war Independence 1945, Members of the Special Police fought against the Dutch and disarmed the Japanese soldiers who had surrendered in Surabaya, The special police were led by Police Inspector I Muhammad Jasin. In 1946 the Special Police throughout Indonesia were merged with the POLRI in 1946 to become a national police force. The Royal Age Police, Referring to the first founder of the Majapahit empire Raden Wijaya formed a security force called Bhayangkara which was tasked with protecting the King, Bhayangkara was formed from 1293 AD to 1580 AD during the Portuguese pioneer era who was the first in terms of offshore exploration, established a kingdom the first colonialist of a global scope, with possessions in Africa, Asia, and South America, it became a world economic, political, and military power.

During the Dutch colonial era, the formation of security forces was initiated by troops also taken from indigenous people to guard the assets and wealth of Europeans in the Dutch East Indies at that time. In 1817 a number of European citizens in Java recruited 78 natives to maintain their security. During the Japanese occupation, this divided the territory of the Indonesian police into Javanese, Sumatran and Madura police, which were based in Jakarta. The eastern Indonesian regional police are based in Makassar and the Kalimantan police are based in Banjarmasin. Period 1945-1950, not long after Japan surrendered unconditionally to the Allies, the Japanese military government dissolved the map and Gyu-Gun, while the special police remained on duty, including when Soekarno and Hatta proclaimed Indonesian independence in 1945. Officially the police became the Indonesian police independent. During the 1950-1959 period, with the formation of a unitary state on August 17, 1950 and the enactment of the 1950 Constitution which adhered to a parliamentary system, the position of R.S. Soekanto is responsible to the prime minister/president. The Old Order era with the Pressiden Decree July 5, 1959, after the failure, the Constituent Assembly, Indonesia returned to the 1945 Constitution, but in practice it deviated from the 1945 Constitution. The first position of minister (late Ir. Juanda) was replaced with the title First Minister, the National Police still brought to the First Minister until the issuance of Presidential Decree No. 153/1959, dated 10 July where the Head of the State Police was given the position of State Minister ex-officio. During the New Order era, due to the bitter experience of the G 30 S PKI Betrayal Suppression incident which reflected the lack of integrity between ABRI elements, to increase the integrity of ABRI (TNI), 1967 with Presidential Decree No. 132/1967 dated 24 August 1967 stipulated the main organizational and procedural points in the field of defense and security which stated that ABRI was part of the organization of the Hamkam department including the Army, Navy, Air Force and AK, each of which was led by a commander in chief and was responsible for the implementation duties and obligations to Menhamkam/Army Commander.

Synesthesia is a perceptual phenomenon in which stimulation of one sensory or cognitive pathway leads to involuntary experiences in a second sensory or cognitive pathway, giving rise to multiple concurrent perceptions of a single sensory response. People who have this kind of perception are called synesthetes. Synesthetic perceptual awareness varies from person to person. One of the most common forms of synesthesia, known as grapheme-color synesthesia or color-graphemic synesthesia, is where letters or numbers appear to have a particular color perception. In spatial sequence, or number synesthesia, various numbers, months of the year, or days of the week give rise to the perception of a particular location in space (for example, 1980 may feel "farther" than 1990), or may appear as a three-dimensional map (clockwise or counterclockwise). Synthetic associations can occur in any combination and involve any number of sensory or cognitive pathways. Little is known about how synesthesia develops. It has been suggested that synesthesia develops during childhood when children are intensively involved with abstract concepts for the first time. This hypothesis is called the semantic vacuum hypothesis—which explains why the most common forms of synesthesia are synesthesia of grapheme colors, spatial sequences, and number shapes. Because these things are usually the first abstract concepts that children's education systems have to learn. The definition of synesthesia itself is rather vague and difficult to define accurately. The first recorded case of synesthesia was attributed to University of Oxford academic and philosopher John Locke. In 1690, he made a report on a blind man who said that he thought he saw crimson when he heard the sound of a trumpet. However, there is disagreement as to whether Locke was describing an actual instance of synesthesia or simply using a metaphor.

Polysaccharides are carbohydrates that have long polymers composed of hundreds to thousands of monosaccharides. The chemical bond chains of polysaccharides are linked by long and branched glycosidic bonds with similar and multiple molecular arrangements. Types of polysaccharides with straight structures, namely amylose and cellulose, while in the form of branched chains, namely amylopectin and glycogen. Based on their chemical structure, polysaccharides are divided into homopolysaccharides, heteropolysaccharides and compound polysaccharides. Polysaccharides are colorless and tasteless amorphous solids. The main use of polysaccharides is to provide texture, thickness, taste, stability, gelation, and resistance to foodstuffs. Polysaccharides naturally found in plants and muramic acid in bacterial cell walls. Polysaccharides are composed only of carbon (C), hydrogen (H) and oxygen (O) atoms. Examples of polysaccharides are starch, glycogen, agarose, and cellulose. Some complex polysaccharides can also have additional atoms such as nitrogen, such as pectin, chitin and lignin. Polysaccharides include the most common compound found on earth (cellulose) and supply the energy and activity for life on it. Polysaccharides have a large molecular size so it is easy to find variations in them. This variation can often be seen through its physical properties. According to the structure, known straight and branched polysaccharides. The more branches a molecule has, the more sticky the polysaccharide tends to be. According to its function, polysaccharides in plants are generally divided into reserve polysaccharides and constituent polysaccharides. Reserve polysaccharides function as reserves supplying energy (in the form of sugar) needed by cells, through enzymatic hydrolysis. reference needed] Composition polysaccharides are the building blocks of cells or tissues need reference]. The constituent polysaccharides are usually difficult to decompose biologically and require strong acids to break their molecular bonds. In contrast, reserve polysaccharides are easily biodegradable.

Common polysaccharides are named based on the monomers that make them up. Polysaccharides composed of glucose are called glucans, while those of mannose are called mannans. Starch is a polysaccharide contained in roots, tubers, seeds, stems, and fruit flesh in plants. The main property of starch is that it is insoluble in cold water. In addition, starch can absorb slowly until it swells and shrinks back to its initial state when it is dried. Conversely, starch that is immersed in boiling water will experience gelatinization, namely swelling until it breaks, disintegrates and forms a paste. Glycogen is a storage polysaccharide in the animal body. reference needed] Glycogen is similar in structure to amylopectin, but has more branching. reference needed] Humans and other vertebrates store glycogen in liver cells and muscle cells. reference needed] Glycogen in cells will hydrolyze when there is an increase in demand for sugar in the body. references needed] It's just that the energy produced is not much so it cannot be relied upon as an energy source in the long term. references needed] Dextran is a polysaccharide in bacteria and yeast consisting of poly-D-hlucose alpha chains 1-6 , which has alpha 1-3 branches and some have alpha 1-2 or alpha 1-4 branches. citation needed] Plaque on the tooth surface caused by bacteria is known to be dextran rich. citation needed] Dextran has also been produced chemically to produce synthetic dextran . Inulin is a natural polysaccharide found in plants as fructan fibers. The sugar in inulin cannot be digested by the human digestive system, but is used as dietary fiber. Inulin can be found in more than 36,000 plant species in the form of carbohydrate reserves. In plants, inulin is used as an energy reserve. The parts of the plant that have inulin are roots, rhizomes or fruit.

Abdullah bin Abdul Mutthalib bin Hasyim bin Abdu Manaf bin Qushay bin Kilab bin Murrah bin Ka'ab bin Lu'ay bin Ghalib bin Fihr bin Malik bin An-Nadhr bin Kinanah bin Khuzaimah bin Mudrikah bin Ilyas bin Mudhar bin Nizar bin Ma'ad bin Adnan bin Ismail bin Ibrahim Muhammadd] (Arabic: محمد‎; born in Mecca, 570-died in Medina, June 8, 632) was a prophet and the last messenger for Muslims. Muhammad began the spread of Islamic teachings to all mankind and inherited the sole rule of Islam. Muhammad both upheld the teachings of monotheism to confirm God as the previous prophets and apostles had brought. Muhammad was born in 570 AD in Mecca, his father's name was Abdullah and his mother's name was Aminah. Muhammad's father died when Muhammad was 6 months old in his mother's womb, and his mother died when Muhammad was 6 years old. As a baby he was nursed by his nursing mother, Halimatus Sa'diyah. After being orphaned, Muhammad was raised under the care of his grandfather Abdul Muttalib until he was 8 years old, then Muhammad was cared for by his uncle Abu Talib for almost 40 years. As a teenager, Muhammad worked as a merchant. Muhammad sometimes secludes himself in a cave for nights to meditate and pray. It is narrated that at the age of 40, Muhammad was visited by the Angel Gabriel and received his first revelation from God. Three years after the first revelation, Muhammad began preaching openly, expressing the oneness of God in the form of surrender through Islam as the true religion and abandoning all worshipers other than God. Muhammad received revelations gradually until his death. The practices or practices of Muhammad are narrated in the hadith, referred to by Muslims as a source of Islamic law along with the Quran. Muhammad and his early followers encountered various forms of resistance and torture from several Meccan tribes.

As the persecution continued, Muhammad allowed some of his followers to emigrate to Habsyah, before Muhammad embarked on a missionary migration to Medina in 622. The event of the hijra marked the beginning of the calendar of the Islamic Hijri calendar. In Medina, Muhammad united the tribes under the Medina Charter. After eight years of resisting the attacks of the Meccan tribes, Muhammad gathered 10,000 Muslims to lay siege to Mecca. The attack met with little resistance and Muhammad managed to take the city with little bloodshed. This event is known as Fathul Makkah. He destroys idols. In 632, a few months after returning to Medina after undergoing the Hajj Wada, Muhammad fell ill and eventually died. Muhammad left the Arabian Peninsula united under a single Islamic government and had largely accepted Islam. Muhammad (محمد; pronounced mʊħɑmmæd] ( listen)) is the isim maf'ul (passive adjective) form of the word حمَّد "praise a lot", which is an affirmation of the three-letter root ح-م-د ḥ-m-d which is the opposite the word is ذم "reproach", so muhammad means "the much praised". In addition, in one verse of the Qur'an, Muhammad is called by the name "Ahmad" (أحمد), which also means "praiseworthy" in Arabic. Before the prophetic period, Muhammad received two titles from the Quraysh tribe (the largest tribe in Mecca which is also the tribe of Muhammad), namely Al-Amiin which means "one who can be trusted" and As-Saadiq which means "the right one". After the prophetic period his companions called him by the title of Rasulullah Allāh (رسول الله), then added the sentence Shalallaahu 'Alayhi Wasallam (صلى الله عليه و سلم), which means "may Allah give him happiness and safety"; often abbreviated as "S.A.W" or "SAW" ) after his name. e] Muhammad also earned the nickname Abu al-Qasim which means "Father of Qasim", because Muhammad once had a son named Qasim, but he died before reaching adulthood.

Lithium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Li and atomic number 3. The term comes from the Greek: λίθος lithos, meaning "stone". It is a silvery-white soft alkali metal. Under standard conditions, it is the lightest metal as well as the lightest solid element. Like all alkali metals, lithium is highly reactive and flammable, and is stored in mineral oil. When cut open inside, it revealed a metallic sheen, but the damp air stained it quickly to a dull silvery-gray, then formed black spots. Lithium never occurs as a free element in nature, but only as compounds (usually ionic), such as the mineral pegmatite, which was once the main source of lithium. It is present in seawater and is usually obtained from saltwater, because of its solubility as an ion. Lithium metal is isolated electrolytically from a mixture of lithium chloride and potassium chloride. Lithium atomic nuclei vibrate at instability, because the two stable lithium isotopes found in nature have the lowest bond energies per nucleon of all stable nuclides. Lithium is less abundant in the solar system than any of the 25 elements of the first 32 chemical elements despite its very light nucleus, due to its relative nuclear instability: this is an exception to the trend that the heavier the nucleus, the less abundant it is. For this reason, lithium has important uses in nuclear physics. The transmutation of lithium atoms into helium in 1932 was the first man-made nuclear reaction, and lithium-6 deuteride served as a fusion fuel in the thermonuclear weapons on display. Lithium and its compounds have several industrial applications, including heat-resistant glass and ceramics, lithium greases, flux additives for the production of iron, steel and aluminum, lithium batteries, and lithium-ion batteries.

This use consumes more than three quarters of lithium production. The main sources of dietary lithium are grains and vegetables; in some areas, drinking water also contains significant amounts. Humans take in varying amounts, depending on location and diet. Lithium has been detected in human organs and fetal tissues since the late 19th century, sparking speculation about its specific function. After another century, experimental evidence was obtained. In studies from the 1970s–1990s, mice and goats on low-lithium diets had higher mortality, as well as reproductive and behavioral abnormalities. In humans there are no defined lithium deficiency diseases, but low lithium intake from the water supply is associated with increased suicide, homicide and arrest rates for drug use and other crimes. The high lithium content in the early embryo suggests an important role during fetal development. The biochemical mechanisms of lithium action appear to be multifactorial and correlated with the functions of several enzymes, hormones and vitamins, as well as growth and transformation factors. The evidence currently seems insufficient to accept lithium as essential; The temporary RDA for 70 kg adults is suggested to be 1,000 µg/day. Lithium salts have been shown to be useful as mood medications in the treatment of bipolar disorder in humans. Like the other alkali metals, lithium has a single valence electron which is easily released to form cations. Therefore, lithium is a good conductor of heat and electricity and is highly reactive, although it is the least reactive of the alkali metals. Lithium's low reactivity is due to the proximity of its valence electrons to its nucleus (the remaining two electrons are in the 1s orbital, which is much lower in energy, and do not participate in chemical bonds).

Makkaha], officially Makkah al-Mukarramah (Arabic: مكة المكرمة, translit. Makkat al-Mukarramah, lit. 'Makkah, the Glorious City'), is one of Islam's holiest cities and the capital of Makkah Province, Saudi Arabia. The city is located 70 km (43 mi) inland from Jeddah on the Red Sea, in a small valley 277 m (909 ft) above sea level. The last recorded population was 1,578,722 in 2015. The estimated metro population in 2020 is 2.042 million, making Makkah the third most populous city in the kingdom. Pilgrims who arrive are three times the number of local residents during the Hajj every month of Zulhijah. Mecca is the birthplace of Muhammad. Hira Cave which is located above Jabal an-Nur is in the city of Makkah and the cave is the location where Muslims believe that the Qur'an was first revealed to Muhammad. Visiting Mecca for the Hajj is an obligation for able Muslims (fulfillment of the pillars of Islam). The Grand Mosque is home to the Kaaba—believed by Muslims to have been built by Ibrahim and Isma'il—which is one of Islam's holiest sites and a benchmark for the direction of prayer for Muslims (qibla), which reinforces the meaning of the city of Makkah to Muslims. Muslim rulers, both from within and from around the region, have long tried to seize the city of Mecca and keep the city under their control. Thus, like much of the Hijaz region, the city underwent various regime changes which owe its rich history. The city was eventually captured in the conquest of the Hijaz by the Saudis led by Ibn Saud and his allies in 1925. Since then, Mecca has seen a tremendous expansion in size and infrastructure with newer modern buildings such as the Abraj Al Bait Towers, the fourth tallest building in the world. and the third largest based on the floor area that towers over the Grand Mosque.

The Saudi government also carried out the destruction of several historical buildings and archaeological sites, such as the Ajyad Fort. Non-Muslims are strictly prohibited from entering Makkah. Muslims from all over the world visit the city of Makkah, not only for the Hajj and Umrah pilgrimages, but also as tourists to visit the region's landmarks, such as the Aisyah Mosque and sites visited by Hajj and Umrah pilgrims. Makkah is now home to two of the most expensive buildings in the world, the US$100 billion Grand Mosque and the US$15 billion Abraj Al Bait Towers complex. The city of Makkah is located about 600 km south of the city of Medina, approximately 200 km northeast of the city of Jeddah. This city is a dry valley, surrounded by barren coral mountains with the Kaaba building as its center. Thus, in the past this city was prone to flooding during the rainy season before the Saudi Arabian government finally repaired this city and renovated this city. Like most cities in Saudi Arabia, this city has a desert climate. The length of the west to east valley is about 3 km, while the north to south valley is about 1.5 km. The city is surrounded by several mountains, including Mount Abu Qubais in the east, Mount Abi Badidah (Kudai) and Mount Khundamah in the south, Mount Al Falj, Mount Qaiqa'an, Mount Hindi, Mount Lu'lu and Mount Kada (the highest mountain). ) in the north. In the past, there were only three roads that could be passed to enter Makkah. Namely the northern gap at the foot of Al Falh mountain, the western gap to the Red Sea and the southern gap to Yemen. The development of the city of Mecca is inseparable from the existence of the Prophet Ismail and Hajar as the first inhabitants of this city who were placed by the Prophet Abraham at the behest of Allah.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Croatia (officially: Republic of Croatia, Croatian: Republica Hrvatska (help·info)), is a Balkan country at the crossroads of Central Europe and Southeastern Europe, and also is a crescent-shaped country. The country is bordered by Slovenia to the northwest, Hungary to the northeast, Serbia to the east, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro to the southeast, and shares a maritime border with Italy to the west and southwest. Historically, the country was a republic for the Federal Socialist Republic of Yugoslavia. The country broke away and gained independence in 1991 and was a candidate member of the European Union, the United Nations, the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe, the Council of Europe, and a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council for the period 2008-2009. The country is also a member of the European Union and NATO. Croatia officially joined NATO in April 2009, so that there were two former member countries of the Federal Socialist Republic of Yugoslavia that joined the military alliance, namely Croatia and Slovenia. In addition, Croatia is also a member of the Union for the Mediterranean after its founding in 2008. The area that is now known as Croatia since the prehistoric period has been inhabited since the Stone Age. Neanderthal fossils dating from the Middle Paleolithic era, have been found in northern Croatia, with the best-known site at Krapina. Remains of several Neolithic and Chalcolithic cultures have been found throughout the country. The largest proportion of these sites are in the river valleys of northern Croatia, and the most significant culturally visible are Starčevo, Vučedol and Hvar. The Metal Civilization left traces of the early civilizations of the Halstatt culture (early Illyrians) and the La Tène culture (Celts).

Both areas were mostly settled by Liburnians and Illyrians, and Greek colonies were founded on the islands of Vis (by Dionysius I of Syracuse) and Hvar in 9 in what is now Croatia as part of the Roman Empire. The Roman emperor Diocletian built a grand palace in Split where he retired from politics in 305. During the late 5th century, the minor Roman Emperor Julius Nepos ruled Diocletian's kingdom from the palace before he died in 480. Early history of Croatia ends with the Avar invasion in mid-7th century and the destruction of almost the entire city of Rome. The Romanians fled towards the coastal cities and islands, where they could better strategize and defend strategic points. The city of Dubrovnik today was founded by survivors of Epidaurum. The Croats arrived at today are what Croats were in the seventh century. They are arranged in two dukedoms; in the dukes of Pannonian Croatia in the north and of the dukes of the Croatian coast in the south. For the most part, the Christianization of the settled Croats ended in the 9th century. These two dukes became Frankish vassals in the late 8th century, and finally became independent in the following century. The first ruler of Croatia recognized by the pope was duke Branimir, whom Pope John VIII called dux Croatorum ("king of the Croats") in 879. During the early 10th century. Pannonian Croats were surpassed by the Magyars, who were then defeated by duke Tomislav of the Croatian coast who administered to unite with the 2 duchies, and was crowned in 925 as first king of the kingdom of Croatia. The importance of this was later confirmed by Byzantium which had given the king's crown to Stjepan Držislav the pope's crown and the king's crown to Zvonimir.

Carbon (from the Latin: carbo "charcoal") or carbonaceous substance is a chemical element with the symbol C and atomic number 6. It is a nonmetal and is tetravalent—its atoms make four electrons available to form covalent chemical bonds. It is in group 14 of the periodic table. Carbon only makes up about 0.025 percent of the Earth's crust. Three isotopes occur naturally, 12C and 13C are stable nuclides, while 14C is a radionuclide, decaying with a half-life of about 5,730 years. Carbon is one of the few elements that has been known since ancient times. Carbon is the 15th most abundant element in the Earth's crust, and the fourth most abundant element in the universe by mass after hydrogen, helium and oxygen. The abundance of carbon, its unique diversity of organic compounds, and its unusual ability to form polymers at temperatures normally encountered on Earth, allow it to function as a common element of all known life. It is the second most abundant element in the human body by mass (about 18.5%) after oxygen. Carbon atoms can bond together in a variety of ways, producing various allotropes of carbon. The most well-known allotropes of carbon include graphite, diamond, amorphous carbon and fullerene. The physical properties of carbon vary greatly with its allotropic form. For example, graphite is opaque and black whereas diamond is highly transparent. Graphite is soft enough to scratch on paper (hence the name from the Greek verb "γράφειν" meaning "to write"), while diamond is the hardest known naturally occurring material. Graphite is a good conductor of electricity while diamond has a low electrical conductivity. Under normal conditions, diamond, carbon nanotubes and graphene have the highest thermal conductivities of any known material.

All allotropes of carbon are solids under normal conditions, with graphite being the most thermodynamically stable form at standard temperature and pressure. They are all chemically resistant and require high temperatures to react even with oxygen. The most common oxidation number of carbon in inorganic compounds is +4, whereas +2 is found in carbon monoxide and transition metal carbonyl complexes. The largest sources of inorganic carbon are limestone, dolomite and carbon dioxide, but significant amounts occur in organic deposits, namely coal, peat, oil and methane clathrate. Carbon forms a very large number of compounds, more than any other element, with almost ten million compounds described to date, but these are only a fraction of the number of compounds that are theoretically possible under standard conditions. For this reason, carbon is often referred to as the "king of all elements". Allotropes of carbon include graphite, one of the softest known substances, and diamond, the hardest naturally occurring substance. It readily bonds with other small atoms, including other carbon atoms, and is capable of forming several stable covalent bonds with suitable multivalent atoms. Carbon is known to form nearly ten million compounds, the most of all chemical compounds. Carbon also has the highest sublimation point of all the elements. At atmospheric pressure it has no melting point, because its triple point is at 108 ± 02 megapascals (1,066 ± 20 atm; 15,660 ± 290 psi) and 4,600 ± 300 K (4,330 ± 300 °C; 7,820 ± 540 °F), so it sublimes at about 3,900 K (3,630°C; 6,560°F). Graphite is much more reactive than diamond under standard conditions, although it is more thermodynamically stable, because its delocalized pi system is much more vulnerable to attack.

Chemistry Astronomy Earth science Health science Anatomy (from the Ancient Greek anatomḗ 'surgery' and anatémnō 'to cut') is the branch of biology that studies the structures of living bodies. The term anatomy is used for the study of the structure of the human and animal bodies, while the structure of plants is studied in plant anatomy. Anatomy has been studied since prehistoric times. Anatomy and physiology, which study the structure and function of organisms and their parts respectively, are natural partners of related disciplines, and the two are often studied together. Human anatomy is one of the essential basic sciences applied in medicine. The discipline of anatomy is broadly divided into macroscopic and microscopic anatomy. Macroscopic anatomy, or gross anatomy, is the examination of body parts using unaided vision. Macroscopic anatomy also includes superficial anatomy. Microscopic anatomy involves the use of optical instruments to study tissue, which is known as histology, and also in the study of cells. Historically, anatomy has experienced a progressive development of the understanding of the structure and function of the human body. The methods used have improved dramatically, from examining animals by cadaveric and carcass dissection to medical imaging techniques developed in the 20th century, such as X-rays, ultrasonography, and magnetic resonance imaging. Derived from Ancient Greek ἀνατομία anatomía, from ἀνατομή anatomḗ 'dissection' (from ἀνατέμνω anatémnō 'I cut, open' from ἀνά aná 'up', and ἀνατέμνω témnō 'I cut'), anatomy is the scientific study of the structure of organisms, including organ systems, organs, and tissues. Anatomy includes the appearance and position of the various parts of the body, the materials they are made of, their location, and their relationship to other parts. Anatomy is quite different from physiology and biochemistry, each of which deals with the functions of these parts and the chemical processes involved.

For example, an anatomist is concerned with the shape, size, position, structure, blood supply, and innervation of an organ such as the liver; while a physiologist is interested in the production of bile, the role of the liver in nutrition, and the regulation of bodily functions. The discipline of anatomy can be subdivided into several branches, including macroscopic anatomy and microscopic anatomy. Macroscopic anatomy is the study of structures large enough to be seen with the naked eye, and also includes surface or superficial anatomy, the study of the external characteristics of the body. Microscopic anatomy is the study of body structure on a microscopic scale, along with histology (the study of tissues) and embryology (the study of organisms in prenatal conditions). Anatomy can be studied using both invasive and noninvasive methods with the aim of obtaining information about the structure and organization of organs and organ systems. Methods used include dissection, in which the body is opened and the organs studied, and endoscopy, in which instruments equipped with a video camera are inserted through small incisions on the surface of the body and used to explore internal organs and other structures. Angiography using X-rays or magnetic resonance angiography is a method for visualizing blood vessels. The term "anatomy" is usually used to refer to human anatomy. However, substantially the same structures and tissues are found throughout the animal kingdom and the term also includes the anatomy of other animals. The term zootomy is also sometimes used to specifically refer to the anatomy of nonhuman animals. Plant structures and tissues have different properties and are studied in plant anatomy. All vertebrates have a similar basic body cross-section and at some point in their lives (mostly at the embryonic stage), they share the main chordate characteristics, namely, the notochord which is a rigid rod; hollow neuronal tube dorsally and filled with neural material; pharyngeal arches; and a tail behind the anus.

Ruterfordium is a chemical element in the periodic table having the symbol Rf and atomic number 104. It is a highly radioactive synthetic element whose most stable isotope is 265Rf with a half-life of about 13 hours. This name is taken from the name of the scientist Ernst Rutherford. Later this element was not used for anything and little was known about it. Ruterfordium was the first transactinide element and is thought to have chemical properties similar to hafnium. Ruterfordium (named in honor of Lord Rutherford of Nelson) was first reported as synthesized in 1964 at the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research in Dubna (Soviet Union). Researchers there bombarded 242Pu with 22Ne ions with MeV accelerated from 113 to 115 and stated that they detected traces of nuclear fusion in a special type of glass with a microscope that indicated the presence of the new element. In 1969 researchers from the University of California, Berkeley synthesized the element by subjecting 249Cf and 12C to high energy collisions. The UC group also stated that they were unable to reproduce the earliest synthesis by Soviet scientists. This gave rise to controversy over the naming of elements; Since the Soviets claimed that it was first detected in Dubna, Dubnium (Db) was proposed, like Kurchatovium and the symbol Ku for the 104th element, in honor of Igor Vasilevich Kurchatov (1903–1960), former head of Soviet nuclear research. The Americans, however, proposed Rutherfordium (symbol Rf) for the new element in honor of Ernest Rutherford, the famous nuclear physicist from New Zealand. The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) adopted Unnilquadium (symbol Unq) as the systematic element name, provisionally, derived from from the Latin name for the numbers 1, 0, and 4. But in 1997 they broke the dispute and adopted the current name. This chemistry-related article is a stub.

Gross domestic product (GDP) or in English gross domestic product (GDP) is the market value of all goods and services produced by a country in a certain period. GDP is one method for calculating national income. This technique is used most often. Gross Domestic Product is defined as the total value of all goods and services produced in the region in a certain period of time (usually per year). GDP differs from gross national product in that it includes factor income from abroad working in the country. So that GDP calculates the total production of a country without taking into account whether the production is carried out using domestic factors of production or not. On the other hand, GNP pays attention to the origin of the production factors used. Nominal GDP refers to the value of GDP without regard to the effect of prices. Meanwhile, real GDP ←(or called GDP at constant prices)→ corrects the nominal GDP figure by including the effect of prices. GDP can be calculated using two approaches, namely the expenditure approach and the income approach. The general formula for GDP using the expenditure approach is: Where consumption is expenditure made by households, investment by the business sector, government spending by the government, and exports and imports involving the foreign sector. While the income approach calculates the income received by factors of production, where rent is the income of the owner of a fixed factor of production such as land, wages for labor, interest for owners of capital, and profits for entrepreneurs. In theory, GDP with the expenditure and income approach should produce the same figure. However, because in practice it is difficult to calculate GDP using the income approach, the expenditure approach is often used. The GDP of different countries can be compared by exchanging its value in local currency according to: The relative ratings of countries can differ greatly from one method to another.

Nomads or wanderers, are various communities of people who choose to live moving from one place to another in the desert or winter areas, rather than settling in one place. People who move from place to place but not in the desert or winter areas are known as gypsies. Many cultures have traditionally lived a nomadic life, but this traditional nomadic custom is on the wane in industrialized countries. Some of the things that cause humans to live by moving from place to place of residence are due to the changing seasons, in addition to obtaining the materials needed by these nomadic groups. Nomadic habits exist in the Arabian peninsula, Africa, inland tribes in Indonesia who intend to find land for food sources, livestock, game, farming, and so on. In the past, nomadic peoples were often referred to as 'nomads' who crossed the land without a certain pattern with the aim of obtaining resources that were spread unequally over a wide area. Migration is their distinct cultural identity as a land management strategy for sustainable use and conservation. The origins of the word 'nomad' are from the Greek nemein or nomos which means 'to go to the steppe'. The culprit is defined as a member of a nation who travels from one place to another to find fresh pastures for animals and has no permanent residence. While etymologically the term nomad is related to pastoralism, the term has acquired a broader meaning for a variety of nomadic lives, ranging from hunter-gatherers to other itinerant communities whose ways of life are nomadic. Nomadic peoples represent the most diverse group in the world; they usually live in remote areas such as deserts, steppes, tundra, and forests.

There are three kinds of nomadic life, namely as hunter-gatherers, pastoral nomads, and peripatetic nomads. Gathering was the longest-lasting survival method in human history, and practitioners moved with the seasons for wild plants and game. Hunting was the dominant way of life occurring during the development of the agricultural era around 8000 years ago. Currently, for some nomadic groups, migration is an economic, social and cultural value that is very important to them. Nomadic hunter-gatherer groups include the Australian Aboriginal Spinifex (or Pila Nguru) people; the Hadza group in Tanzania; the Ogiek people of Kenya called 'Bushmen' (San, Sho, Basarwa, !Kung or Khwe) from southern Africa; the Jarawa, Onge, and Sentinel peoples of the Andaman Islands in India; The Batek or Bateq and Penan tribes in the rainforests of Peninsular Malaysia; The Aka, Efe, and Mbuti people (also known as the Pygmies) of Central Africa; some Inuit groups in the Arctic who still rely on hunting and fishing; the Nukak people (Nukak-Makú) in Colombia; and the Pirahã people of Brazil. Apart from the grasslands, the Hunter-gatherer group also included nomads who made their living from marine resources. They are; the Alacaluf or Kawésqar people in South America, the Orang Laut group in the Malay Peninsula, the Moken in the Andaman Sea, the Bede (Beday) in Bangladesh, and the Vezo people in Madagascar. Herders raise livestock and move to other places with their livestock, so as not to deplete a grazing area beyond repair, as a livelihood plan for their survival. They are involved in grazing production as the main activity and set aside other livelihood activities and move seasonally.

Monaco /ˈmɒnəkoʊ/ ( listen), officially the Principality of Monaco (French: Principauté de Monaco (French pronunciation: prɛ̃.si.po.te.d(ə).mɔ.na'ko]), Monaco dialect: Prinçipatu de Mu̍negu, Ligurian: Prinçipato de Mónego, Italian: Principato di Monaco, Occitan: Principat de Mónegue) is a sovereign city-state, located on the Côte d'Azur in Western Europe. Bordered by France on three sides, and bordered on one side by the Mediterranean Sea, its center is about 16 km (9.9 mi) from Italy, and only 13 km (8.1 mi) northeast of Nice, France. Monaco has an area of ​​2.02 km² and a population of 37,550 (2016), this makes Monaco the second smallest and most populous country in the world. Monaco has a land border of only 44 km (27 mi), and a coastline of 41 km (25 mi), and a width that varies between 17 km (11 mi) and 349 meters (382 yards). The highest point of the country is a narrow pass called the Chemin des Révoires on the slopes of the Mont Agel mountain, in the Les Révoires district, which is 161 meters (528 feet) above sea level. Monaco's most populous Quartier is Monte Carlo, and the most populous Ward is Larvotto/Bas Moulins. Monaco is famous for its land reclamation, which has increased its size by about 20%. The land reclamation project that currently covers, expanded the Fontvieille district by approximately 008 km2 (3.1 sq mi) or 8 ha (19.8 acres). Monaco is a principality governed by a constitutional monarchy, with Prince Albert II as head of state. Even though Prince Albert II is a constitutional monarch, he still wields immense political power. The House of Grimaldi has ruled Monaco, with brief interruptions, since 1297. The official language is French, but Monégasque, Italian, and English are widely spoken and widely understood. note 1] State sovereignty was formally recognized in the Franco-Monegasque Treaty (1861), by Monaco became a full voting member of the United Nations in 1993, after much political wrangling.

Despite Monaco's independence and separate foreign policy, defense is the responsibility of France. Nonetheless, Monaco retains two military units, numbering 263 men, the Corps des Sapeurs-Pompiers, and the Compagnie des Carabiniers du Prince. Monaco's economic development was boosted in the late 19th century by railroads to France, and the opening of its first casino, Monte Carlo. Since then, its comfortable climate, beautiful scenery, and gambling facilities have made Monaco world famous as a tourist, and recreational center for the rich and famous. However, in recent years Monaco has become a major banking center holding more than €100 billion worth of funds, and has successfully attempted to diversify its economy into small, high value added and non-polluting services and industries. Monaco's name comes from around the 6th century BC Greek colony of Phocaia. Refers to the Ligurian Monoikos, from the Greek "μόνοικος", "one house", from "μόνος" (monos) "alone" + "οἶκος" (oikos) "house", which bears the sense that good people settle in "one residence” or “living apart” from other people. According to an ancient myth, Hercules passed through the area of ​​Monaco and drove away the previous gods. As a result, a temple was built there, that of Hercules Monoikos. Since the only temple in this area was the "House" of Hercules, the city was called Monoikos. After a grant of land from Emperor Henry VI in 1191, Monaco was re-founded in 1215 as a colony of Genoa. Monaco was first ruled by the House of Grimaldi in 1297, when Francesco Grimaldi, known as "Il Malizia" (translated from Italian as either "the dangerous one" or "the cunning one"), and his men captured the rampart protecting the Rock of Monaco and dressed as a Franciscan friar- a Monaco in Italian, although this is a coincidence since the area was already known by this name.

The United States Aeronautics and Space Administration (English: National Aeronautics and Space Administration; abbreviated NASA /ˈnæsə/) is the independent agency of the United States Federal Government responsible for the civilian space program, as well as aeronautical and space research. note 1] NASA was founded in in 1958, replaced the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA). The new agency has a distinct civilian orientation, encouraging peaceful applications in space science. Since its founding, most of US space exploration has been led by NASA, including the moon landing (Apollo) missions, the Skylab space station, and later the Space Shuttle. NASA supports the International Space Station and oversees the development of the Orion space probe, the Space Launch System, and the Commercial Crew. The agency is also responsible for the Launch Services Program, which provides oversight of launch operations and countdown management for unmanned NASA launches. NASA science is focused on better understanding Earth through the Earth Observing System; advancing heliophysics through the efforts of the Science Mission Directorate's Heliophysics Research Program; explore the entire Solar System on unmanned space missions such as New Horizons; and researching astrophysical topics, such as the Big Bang, through the Great Observatories Program and related programs. Since 2011, NASA has had a strategic purpose: President Eisenhower founded NASA in 1958 for the purpose of placing the needs of civil society ahead of the military, and serving as a peacekeeping program in space science. The National Aeronautics and Space Act was passed on July 29, 1958, replacing the previous organization, the National Aeronautics Advisory Committee. The agency officially became operational on October 1, 1958. Various nebulae observed from the NASA 1 space telescope Ceres Pluto Hardware comparison Apollo, Gemini, and Mercurynote 2] Hubble Space Telescope, astronomical observatory in Earth orbit since 1990.

Positivism Functionalism Antipositivism Conflict theory Structuralism Symbolic interaction Intermediate distance Mathematical Critical theory Socialization Quantitative structures and agents Computational Qualitative Ethnography religion culture economic demographics law science science internet industry social networking gender crime class class family health cities environmental education knowledge deviance social psychology medical mobility politics race & ethnicity rationalization secularization stratification Journals Publishing Outlines List of sociologists Indexes in sociology, anthropology, archeology, history, philosophy, and linguistics , structuralism is a general theory of culture and a methodology that implies that elements of human culture must be understood through their relationship to a wider system. It works to uncover the structures that underlie all that humans do, think, feel, and feel. Or, as philosopher Simon Blackburn summarizes it, structuralism is "the belief that the phenomena of human life are not understood except through their interrelationships. These relationships constitute structure, and behind local variations in phenomena that appear on the surface are constant laws of abstract culture". Structuralism in Europe developed in the early 1900s, in the field of structural linguistics from Ferdinand de Saussure to the subsequent Prague, Moscow and Copenhagen schools of linguistics. In the late 1950s and early 60s, when structural linguistics faced serious challenges from the likes of Noam Chomsky and thus waned in importance, an array of scholars in the humanities borrowed Saussure's concepts for use in their respective fields of study. French anthropologist Claude Levi-Strauss is said to be the first scientist, sparking widespread interest in Structuralism. The structuralist model of reasoning has been applied in a variety of fields, including anthropology, sociology, psychology, literary criticism, economics and architecture.

The most prominent thinkers associated with structuralism include Levi-Strauss, linguist Roman Jakobson, and psychoanalyst Jacques Lacan. As an intellectual movement, structuralism was originally considered to be the heir to existentialism. However, in the 1960s, many of the basic tenets of structuralism came under attack from a new wave of intellectuals especially from France such as the philosopher and historian Michel Foucault, the philosopher and social commentator Jacques Derrida, the Marxist philosopher Louis Althusser, and the literary critic Roland Barthes. Although elements of their work are always related to structuralism and informed by it, these theories are generally referred to as post-structuralist. In the 1970s, structuralism was criticized for rigidity and ahistorism. Despite this, many proponents of structuralism, such as Lacan, continue to assert influence on continental philosophy and many of the basic assumptions of some structuralist critics are that post-structuralists are a continuation of structuralism. Structuralism's goal is to seek the deepest structure of reality that appears chaotic and varied on the surface scientifically (objectively, strictly and remotely). These characteristics can be seen in its structure: 1966 was described by Francois Dosse in his book Histoire du Structuralism as the year when structuralism emerged in Europe, especially in France. The development of structuralism in 1967-1978 is described as a period of spreading the ideas of structuralism and enlightenment about the concept of structuralism and its role in science. The characteristics of structuralism is the focus on the description of the actual state of the object through investigation, disclosure of character, properties related to a thing through education. These characteristics can be seen from several things; hierarchies, components or elements, there are methods, clear theoretical models and clear distinctions. Structuralism experts opposed existentialism and phenomenology which they considered too individualistic and unscientific. One of the well-known is Maurice Merleau-Ponty's views against the phenomenology and existentialism of the human body.

Archaea or Archaea is a domain of single-celled microorganisms. Archaea are classified as prokaryotes, a group of microbes that lack a cell nucleus and membrane-bound organelles. Originally, archaea were classified as bacteria and given the name archaebacteria (in the kingdom Archaebacteria), but this classification is no longer used. Archaic cells have unique properties that separate archaea from the other two domains of life, namely Bacteria and Eukaryota. Archaea are further divided into several phyla. Classification is difficult because the majority of archaea have not been isolated in the laboratory and their gene sequences have only been detected from samples taken from the environment. Archaea and bacteria are generally similar in size and shape, although some archaea have very odd shapes, for example the flat, square cells like Haloquadratum walsbyi. Despite the morphological similarities between archaea and bacteria, archaea share genes and several metabolic pathways that are more similar to those of eukaryotes, especially the enzymes involved in transcription and translation. One unique aspect of archaea biochemistry is the dependence of archaea on the ether lipids in their cell membranes. Archaea use more energy sources than eukaryotes, which range from organic compounds such as sugars, ammonia, metal ions, or even hydrogen gas. The salt-tolerant archaea (Haloarchaea) use sunlight as an energy source, while other archaea species fix carbon; however, unlike plants and cyanobacteria, no archaea do both ways. Archaea reproduce asexually by binary fission, fragmentation, or budding. Unlike bacteria and eukaryotes, no archaea species are known to form endospores. The first archaea observed were extremophiles living in extreme environments, such as hot springs and salt lakes, with no other organisms.

The increasing capabilities of molecular detection tools have made it possible to find archaea in almost any habitat, including land, oceans and swamps. They are abundant in the oceans, and archaea in the form of plankton are probably one of the most abundant groups of organisms on the planet. Archaea played a major role in life on Earth. They are part of the microbiota for all organisms. As the human microbiota, archaea play an important role in the large intestine, oral cavity and skin. Their morphological, metabolic and geographical diversity allows them to have a wide range of ecological roles, for example in carbon fixation in the carbon cycle, roles in the nitrogen cycle, cycling of organic compounds, and maintaining symbiotic communities and microbial syntrophy. There are no clear examples of archaea that are pathogenic or parasitic. In contrast, archaea are often mutualists or commensals, for example the methanogens that live in the digestive tracts of humans and ruminants, where they live in large numbers and aid digestion. Methanogens are used in biogas production and sewage treatment. Meanwhile, enzymes from extremophile archaea which can withstand high temperatures and organic solvents are utilized in biotechnology. For most of the 20th century, prokaryotes were considered as a single group of organisms and classified based on their biochemical, morphological, and metabolic properties. Microbiologists try to classify microorganisms based on the structure of their cell walls, shape, and the substances they ingest. In 1965, Linus Pauling and Emile Zuckerkandl proposed using gene sequences in various prokaryotes to work out their relationships to one another. This approach, known as phylogenetics, is the main method used today. Archaea (then only known methanogens) were first classified as a separate group of bacteria on a phylogenetic tree based on their ribosomal RNA (rRNA) gene sequence by Carl Woese and George E. Fox in 1977.

Chuuk—formerly Truk, Ruk, Hogoleu, Torres, Ugulat, and Lugulus—is one of the states of the Federated States of Micronesia, along with Kosrae, Pohnpei, and Yap. Chuuk is the most populous state in Micronesia, with a population of nearly 50,000. Geographically, Chuuk is also part of the Caroline Islands group. The name Chuuk means 'mountains' in the Chuuk language, one of the Austronesian languages ​​spoken there. This group of islands was known as Truk (a mispronounced Ruk), until 1990. The state will hold an independence referendum in 2022. Chuuk is the state with the highest population in the federation of Micronesia. In the 2000 population census, the population of Chuuk was 53,595, compared to Pohnpei's 34,486, Yap's 11,241 and Kosrae's 7,686. The majority of Chuuk residents are Christians of various denominations, from Roman Catholics to various Protestant churches that originated with United States missionaries. An estimated 60 percent of Chuuk residents are Catholic and 40 percent Protestant. Other religious groups with small followings include the Baptists, Assemblies of God Church, Salvation Army, Seventh-day Adventist Church, Jehovah's Witnesses, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons) and Baha'is. Even though the Chuuk are a predominantly Christian society, the traditional belief in the possession of the spirits of the dead still exists. These spirits are thought to possess women and originate from family conflicts. The spirit (sootupw) speaks through women, conveys messages from other realms, and usually admonishes other family members to be kinder to one another. Possession of this spirit generally appears during times of grief, marked by the emotions of love/sadness (ttong), loss (leetiipeta), and suffering (riaffou) experienced by those who leave and those who are left behind.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark gray)– in the African Union  (light blue) Tanzania, officially the United Republic of Tanzania (Swahili: Jamhuri ya Muungano wa Tanzania, English: United Republic of Tanzania) is a country located in East Africa , has a tropical climate, formerly known as Tanganyika, because in Tanzania there is a very famous lake, namely Lake Tanganyika. Bordered by many countries, including: Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Zambia, Malawi and Mozambique. Tanzania has the highest mountain in Africa, namely Mount Kilimanjaro (5,985 m) and a very beautiful wildlife park which is visited by many tourists, both domestic and foreign. There are 3 (three) major islands in Tanzania, namely Zanzibar (famous for cloves and its Islamic leaders and scholars), Pemba Island and Mafia Island. Tanzania may be one of the oldest known inhabited places in the world. The scientific consensus is on the place of human origins in the Great Rift Valley, which dominates the landscape of much of East Africa. Northern Tanzania's Olduvai Gorge has provided rich evidence of the area's prehistory, including the fossilized remains of some of humanity's earliest ancestors. Interior Tanzania's great diversity of cultures and languages ​​is due to various historical migrations from elsewhere in the region. In some cases, migrant groups split, leading to different cultural developments. In other cases, various groups merged, creating new cultural identities and languages. Most Tanzanians are aware of the traditional cultural and historical origins of the ethnic community with which they identify. The interior nations traded with the coastal communities, which in turn traded with all the countries bordering the Indian Ocean. Long standing patterns of political organization, economic production, and trade were disrupted due to the increasing violence of the Arab-led slave and ivory trade in the 18th and 19th centuries.

Bagamoyo on the coast and town of Zanzibar was a major port that served the slave market for the majority of slave labor in the Arab world. Both societies, already deeply stressed by the violence of the slave trade, came under further pressure after European explorers (mostly military, some missionaries) paved the way for European conquest (first by semi-private European companies, then by European nations). from the mid-19th century to the early 20th century. Coastal and island Tanzania was organized into city-states about 1,500 years ago. The Swahili city-state traded with interior peoples and peoples from the Indian Ocean and beyond (including China). Many traders from trading partner countries (mainly from mainland Africa, the Arab world, Persia and India) established themselves in coastal and island communities, which became cosmopolitan in taste. The Portuguese navigator Vasco da Gama explored the East African coast in 1498 in trip to India. In 1506, the Portuguese claimed the entire coast. This control was nominal however, as the Portuguese did not complete the area (except for a few forts) or explore the interior. Instead, they fiercely enforced their monopoly on Indian Ocean trade, denying the Swahili city-state their primary means of existence. The Portuguese also demanded tribute, bombarded and looted people who refused to pay protection money. Coastal peoples rose up against the Portuguese in the late 1700s. The resistance was aided by one of their main trading partners, the Omani Arabs. In the early 19th century the Portuguese were forced off the north African coast of the Ruvuma River and the Omanis moved in. Based in Zanzibar, the Sultanate of Oman maintained close trade and diplomatic relations with the major trading powers, including the United States in 1837. They also maintained close relations with several the interior states with whom they were partners in the ivory and slave trade.

Coordinates: 9°00′N 38°42′E﻿ / ﻿9°N 38.7°E﻿ / 9; 38.7 The Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia (Ityop'iya, Amharic: ኢትዮጵያ), or Habsyi, is a country located on the continent of Africa. The country is bordered by Eritrea to the north, Djibouti to the northeast, Somalia to the east, Kenya to the south, South Sudan to the west, and Sudan to the northwest. Ethiopia has one of the most complete histories as an independent nation on the African continent. Being the oldest country in the world, the Ethiopian region is also one of the oldest civilizations in the world.
