The first Ethiopian government was formed around 980 BC and started converting to Christianity in the 4th century AD. This country is quite unique compared to other African countries in that it was never colonized during the Scramble for Africa and remained independent until 1936 when Italian troops took control of the country . British and Ethiopian troops defeated Italian forces in 1941 and Ethiopia regained sovereignty after signing the British-Ethiopian Treaty in December 1944. Ethiopia was formerly called Abyssinia. Today Ethiopia is a republic and takes an active part in international cooperation activities. Its capital Addis Ababa is the administrative center of the African Union. Ethiopia still uses the Julian calendar, so this country will open a series of celebrations in welcoming the third millennium based on the calendar. This country in the Horn of Africa uses the Julian calendar which is about 7 years behind compared to the Gregorian calendar which is more commonly used around the world. The name "Ethiopia" is said to have come from "Ityopp'is", the name of a descendant of Ham, the founder of the city of Aksum. The old name "Abbesinia" or "Habsyah" comes from the Habesha tribal group, the people who inhabited the Ethiopian region since 3000 BC.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Bulgaria (Bulgarian: България, officially Republika Bŭlgariya (Република България), romanized Republika Bŭlgariya,), is a country in Southeastern Europe. Bulgaria is bordered by five countries: Romania to the north (mostly along the Danube), Serbia and the Republic of Macedonia to the west, and Greece and Turkey to the south. The Black Sea borders this country on the east. With an area of ​​110,994 km², Bulgaria is the 16th largest country in Europe. Several mountainous areas limit its landscape, the most famous of which are the Balkan Mountains and the Rodopi Mountains, as well as the Rila Mountains, which contain the highest peak in the Balkan region, namely the Musala Peak. On the other hand, the Danube Plain in the north and the Upper Thracian Plain in the south are the lowest points as well as the most fertile areas in Bulgaria. The 378 km long Black Sea coast covers the entire eastern border of the country. Bulgaria's administrative center and largest city is Sofia. The forerunner of the unified Bulgarian state and nation dates back to the 7th century AD. All of Bulgaria's successive political entities preserved the traditions (in terms of ethnicity, language and alphabet) of the First Bulgarian Empire (681–1018), which at that time covered most of the Balkans and was actually the center of Slavic culture in the Middle Ages. decline of the Second Bulgarian Empire (1185–1396/1422), Bulgarian territory came under the rule of the Ottoman Empire for five centuries. The Russo-Turkish War of 1877–1878 led to the establishment of the "third Bulgarian state" as a constitutional monarchy in 1878, which gained full sovereignty in 1908. In 1945, after World War II, it became a communist country and was part of the Eastern Bloc until the political changes in Eastern Europe in 1989/1990, when the Bulgarian Communist Party allowed multiparty elections and Bulgaria underwent a period of transition to democracy and free market capitalism with mixed results.

Bulgaria functions as a parliamentary democracy within a unitary constitutional republic. As a member of the European Union, NATO, the United Nations, the European Council, the WTO, and a founding country of the OSCE and the Organization for Black Sea Cooperation, Bulgaria has a Human Development Index of 0.743, ranking 58th in the world in 2010. Prehistoric cultures on the mainland Bulgaria includes the neolithic Hamangia and Vinča culture (6th to 3rd centuries BC), the chalcolithic Varna culture (5th century BC; see also Varna Necropolis), and the Bronze Age Ezero culture. The Karanovo culture serves as a measuring stick for the wider Balkan prehistory. The Thracians, one of the three main ancestral groups of modern Bulgaria, lived apart into several tribes until King Teres unified most of them in about 500 BC in the Kingdom of Odris. They were actually conquered by Alexander the Great and later by the Roman Empire. After migrating from their own lands, the easternmost South Slavs occupied the territory of modern Bulgaria in the 6th century and were assimilated or Greekized as Traco-Romans. In fact the Bulgar elite united them into the First Bulgarian Empire. In the 9th century, the Bulgars and Slavs assimilated each other. Asparukh, heir to the Old Great Bulgarian khan Kubrat, emigrated with some Bulgar tribes to the lower watersheds of the Danube, Dniester, and Dnieper (also known as Ongal) after his father's country was conquered by the Khazars. He conquered Moesia and Little Sitia (Dobrogea) from the Byzantine Empire, expanding his new kingdom towards the Balkan Peninsula. A peace treaty with Byzantium in 681 and the establishment of the Bulgarian capital, Pliska, south of the Danube River marked the beginning of the First Bulgarian Empire, a state founded by the Bulgars, uniting the seven tribes of the South Slavs.

A river (also known as a river; English: river) is a large surface water flow and has an elongated shape that flows continuously from upstream (source) to downstream (estuary). The river is a place where water flows by gravity to a lower place. The direction of the river flow is in accordance with the nature of the water from a high place to a low place. Rivers originate from mountains or highlands to lakes or oceans. One type of river that lies underground, is referred to as an "underground river". For example underground rivers in Hang Soon Dong Cave in Vietnam, underground rivers in Yucatan in Mexico, underground rivers in Pindul Caves in Indonesia. In some cases, a river simply flows into the ground before finding another body of water. Via rivers is the usual way for rainwater that falls on land to flow into the sea or large reservoirs such as lakes. The river consists of several parts, starting from springs that flow into tributaries. Several tributaries will join to form the main river. Streams of water are usually adjacent to the channel with the bottom and cliffs on the left and right. The end of the river where the river meets the sea is known as the river mouth. Rivers are one part of the hydrological cycle. Water in rivers generally collects from precipitation, such as rain, dew, springs, underground runoff, and in certain countries it also comes from melting ice/snow. Apart from water, rivers also carry sediment and pollutants. The biggest use of a river is for agricultural irrigation, raw material for drinking water, as a drainage channel for rainwater and waste water, in fact it has the potential to be used as a river tourism object.

In Indonesia, there are currently 5,950 watersheds (DAS). According to the amount of water: According to genetics: According to the source of water: Rivers are often controlled or controlled so that they are more beneficial or reduce their negative impact on human activities. River management is a continuous activity, as rivers tend to repeat man-made modifications. Channels that are dredged will become shallower again, sluice mechanisms will deteriorate over time, levees and dams are very likely to experience catastrophic seepage or failure as a result. The gains sought in river management often "break even" when compared to the socio-economic costs incurred in mitigating the adverse effects of the management concerned. For example, in some parts of the developing world, rivers have been confined in canals so that flat floodplains can be cleared and developed. Floods can inundate this development pattern so that it requires high costs, and often results in loss of life. Many rivers are now increasingly being developed as a vehicle for habitat conservation, because rivers are important for various aquatic plants, migratory and sedentary fish, and pond cultivation, birds and several types of mammals. Exploitation in the Big Indonesian Dictionary means "exploitation; utilization; utilization for one's own benefit"; "suction"; "extortion (human labor)". Exploitation in English (exploitation) means "the politics of arbitrary or excessive use of a subject, only for economic interests solely without considering a sense of decency, justice, and welfare compensation." Overexploitation occurs when resources are consumed at an unsustainable level. It's not just terrestrial ecosystems that are subject to overexploitation. Aquatic ecosystems such as seas, rivers, lakes and other bodies of water can experience something similar. Exploitation of aquatic resources can be in the form of overfishing of marine organisms.

Electrolysis is the decomposition of an electrolyte by an electric current in an electrolytic cell. A chemical reaction will occur if an electric current is passed through the electrolyte solution, i.e. electrical energy (electric current) is converted into chemical energy (redox reaction). The three main characteristics are: The electrode which receives electrons from an external electric current source is called the cathode, while the electrode which sends electrons back to the external electric current source is called the anode. The cathode is where the reduction reaction occurs where the electrode is negative (-) and the anode is where the oxidation reaction occurs where the electrode is positive (+). In the early 19th century, Michael Faraday investigated the relationship between the amount of electricity flowing in a cell and the chemical quantity changed at the electrodes during electrolysis. He summarized his observations in two laws in 1833. C (Coulomb) is a unit of electric charge, and 1 C is the charge produced when a current of 1 A (Ampere) flows for 1 second. The fundamental constant of electricity is the Faraday constant, F = 9.65 x 104 C, which is defined as the quantity of electricity carried by 1 mole of electrons. It is possible to calculate the mole quantity of a chemical change caused by the constant flow of an electric current for a certain period of time. Electrical conduction through an electrolyte solution can be thought of as a flow of electrons. So, if electrons can flow in an electrolyte solution, it means that electricity can flow in that solution. Electrons come from the cathode pole or negative pole. Meanwhile, the anode releases positive ions and forms a precipitate on the cathode metal. In the solution, the process decomposes: CuSO4 → Cu2+ + SO42- Cu2+ ions will move towards the cathode plate, while SO42- ions will go to the anode plate. Over time, this cathode chip will appear precipitate and there will be a change in mass.

This mass can be calculated in the following way: G = a . I . t Where: G = amount of Cu copper deposits (grams) a = chemical electrical tare (gr/ampere.hour) I = electric current strength (amperes) t = duration of current flowing (hours) For copper a value = 1.186 gr/ampere .hours, since G is known, current I can be obtained by: I = G/at Electrolytic cells are widely used in the gas manufacturing industry, for example in the production of oxygen gas, hydrogen gas, or chlorine gas. To produce oxygen and hydrogen gas, you can use electrolyte solutions from group I A cations, (K+, Na+), group II A, (Ca2+, Mg2+), Al3+, Mn2+, and oxygen-containing anions (SO42-, CO32-, NO3 -, PO43-, ClO4-) with Pt or carbon electrodes. Electrolysis reactions that produce gas, for example electrolysis of Na2SO4 solutions using carbon electrodes. The reaction that occurs: Na2SO4(aq) → 2 Na+(aq) + SO42-(aq) Cathode (C): 2 H2O(l) + 2e- → 2 OH-(aq) + H2(g) Anode (C): 2 H2O(l) → 4 H+(aq) + O2(g) + 4e- Because at the cathode and anode what reacts is water, the longer it takes the water less so it needs to be added. Keep in mind that even though what reacts is water, it does not mean that the electrolyte Na2SO4 is not needed. This electrolyte is useful as a conductor of electric current. Plating a metal gold, silver, or nickel, aims to cover metal that looks less good or covers metal that rusts easily. These metals are plated with other metals that are better in appearance and durability to prevent them from rusting. For example, motor vehicle engines made of steel are generally coated with chromium to prevent corrosion. Some household items are also plated with silver to make them last longer and look better.

Climate is the habit and character of the weather that occurs in a place or area. The time period used as a reference for determining the average climate is 30 years. The constituent elements of climate are the same as the weather. The formation of climate in a place is influenced by the location of latitude, slope, altitude, distance from the waters, and conditions of sea water currents. Each region has a different climate. The type of climate in each region is strongly influenced by latitude. The characteristics of global climate patterns are studied through climatology. Climate is also based on weather characteristics that consider rain, temperature, and wind or evaporation conditions. Based on the latitude, the climate on the surface of the Earth can be divided into polar climate, temperate climate, subtropical climate, tropical climate and equatorial climate. Climate can also be distinguished based on regional conditions, namely continental climate, maritime climate, tundra climate, and mountain climate. Climatic conditions are controlled mainly by the atmosphere which is influenced by environmental factors. The types of environmental factors that affect the atmosphere are the shape of the earth, the earth's cover, and the position of air mixing in the atmosphere. The atmosphere influences the weather which then forms climate. The emergence of the term Climate cannot be separated from Paleoclimatology. Paleoclimatology is the study of ancient climates. Since direct observations of climate were not available prior to the 19th century, paleoclimate is inferred from proxy climate variables that include non-biotic evidence such as deposits found in lake bottoms and ice cores, and biotic evidence such as tree rings and coral. Climate models are mathematical models of past, present and future climates. Climate change can occur in a long and short span of time from various factors; warming recently discussed in global warming. Global warming produces redistribution.

For example, “a 3 °C change in mean annual temperature corresponds to an isotherm shift of about 300–400 km in latitude (in the temperate zone) or 500 m in elevation. or to the highlands to avoid the adverse effects of this natural phenomenon". General map of global temperature in simple warm and cold differential. Same but in three levels of temperature differential. Climate (from the English word derived from the Ancient Greek word "klima", meaning inclination) is usually defined as the average weather over a long period. The standard average period is 30 years, but other periods may be used depending on the purpose. Climate also includes statistics other than averages, such as the magnitude of daily or year-to-year variations. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) 2001 defined climate as follows: Climate in the narrow sense is usually defined as "average weather," or more precisely, as a statistical description in terms of the averages and variability of relevant quantities over periods ranging from months to months. -months to thousands or millions of years. The classic period is 30 years, as defined by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). The most frequently used surface variable quantities are temperature, precipitation, and wind. Climate in a broader sense is the state, including a statistical description, of the climate system. The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) defines "normal" climate as a "point of reference" used by climatologists to compare current climate developments with past or what is considered 'normal'. A normal climate is defined as the arithmetic mean of the climatic elements (eg temperature) over a 30 year period. The 30 year period is used because it is long enough to filter out anomalous variations between anomalies, but also short enough to be able to show longer climate developments.

Pentecost (from Greek: Πεντηκοστή ἡμέρα], Pentēkostē hēmera], "fiftieth day"), or White Sunday is a Christian holiday commemorating the outpouring of the Holy Spirit on the apostles in Jerusalem, which occurred 50 days after the resurrection of Jesus Christ . On the day of Pentecost, the Holy Spirit was poured out according to what Jesus promised after his ascension to heaven. According to the Bible, Jesus' disciples succeeded in converting three thousand souls on that day and this is what is called the birth of the early church (Source: the book of Acts of the Apostles chapter 2). Previously Pentecost was a major Jewish religious holiday called Shavuot or the great harvest festival. On the last night before Jesus Christ was arrested and then crucified, He told His disciples about the coming of the Holy Spirit as a promise of inclusion. The goal: After Jesus rose from the dead, He said again about this: Shortly before Jesus ascended to heaven, He said once again: When the day of Pentecost (Jewish) came, all the believers gathered in one place. Suddenly there came from heaven a sound like the rushing of a violent wind that filled the whole house where they were sitting; and behold to them tongues like flames of fire scattered and alighted on each of them. So filled them with the Holy Spirit, and they began to speak in other tongues, just as the Spirit gave them to speak. At that time in Jerusalem dwelt devout Jews from all nations under heaven. When the sound came down, a crowd gathered. They were confused because they each heard the apostles speak in their own language. They were all astonished and amazed and said, "Are not all these who are speaking Galileans?

How is it possible that each of us hears them speaking in our own language, which is the language we use in our native land: we are Parthians, Medes, Elamites, inhabitants of Mesopotamia, Judea and Cappadocia, Pontus and Asia, Phrygia and Pamphylia, Egypt and the regions of Libya near Cyrene, immigrants from Rome, both Jews and Jews, Cretans and Arabs, we hear them speaking in our own language about the great works of God." They were all astonished and greatly perplexed, saying one to another: "What does this mean?" But others sneered: "They are drunk with sweet wine." Then Peter arose and stood with the eleven apostles, and with a loud voice he said to them: "You Jews and all you who live in Jerusalem, know and heed these words of mine. These people are not drunk as you think, because it is only nine o'clock in the morning, but that is what God said through the prophet Yoël: O people of Israel, listen to these words: What I mean is Jesus of Nazareth, a man who has determined by God and revealed to you by the powers and miracles and signs performed by God through His mediation in your midst, as you know. 23 He whom God delivered according to His purpose and plan, you have crucified and you killed by the hands of disobedient nations. 24 But God resurrected him by releasing him from the agony of death, because it was impossible for him to remain in the power of death. Brethren, I can speak frankly to you about David, the father of our nation. He died and was buried, and his tomb is still with us to this day.

Pompeii is an ancient Roman city that has been in ruins near the city of Naples and is now in the Campania region, Italy. Pompeii was destroyed by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD. Ash from the eruption of Mount Vesuvius buried the city of Pompeii with everything in it several feet deep causing the city to disappear for 1,600 years before being rediscovered by accident. Since then excavations of the city have provided an incredibly detailed view of city life at the height of the Roman Empire. Currently the city of Pompeii is one of the UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Pompeii is located at coordinates 40°45′00″N 14°29′10″E﻿ / ﻿40.75000°N 14.48611°E﻿ / 40.75000; 14.48611, southeast of the city of Naples, close to the modern city of Pompeii. This city stands on a location formed by lava flows to the north on the lower reaches of the Sarno River (in ancient times it was called "Sarnus"). Today it is some distance inland, but it used to be an area close to the coast. In the first century C.E., Pompeii was just one of many cities located at the foot of Mount Vesuvius. This region is quite large in number of people who become prosperous because of the fertile agricultural area. Several small town groups around Pompeii such as Herculaneum also suffered damage or destruction by the eruption of Vesuvius. The city of Pompeii was founded around the 6th century BC by the Osci or Oscan people, a group of people in central Italy. At that time, the city was already used as a safe harbor by Greek and Phoenician sailors. When the Etruscans threatened attack, the city of Pompeii allied with the Greeks who then controlled the Gulf of Naples. In the 5th century BC the people of Samnium occupied it (along with all the cities of Campania).

These new rulers imposed their architecture and enlarged the city area. It is also believed that during the occupation of the people of Samnium, Rome briefly reconquered Pompeii, but this theory has not been proven. Pompeii took part in the wars started by the cities of Campania against Rome, but in 89 BC the city was besieged by Sulla. Although Social League troops led by Lucius Cluentius assisted against Rome, in 80 BC Pompeii was forced to surrender after the conquest of Nola. Pompeii then became a Roman colony with the name: Colonia Cornelia Veneria Pompeianorum. The city was an important route for goods arriving by sea and had to be sent to Rome or Southern Italy which lay along the nearby Via Appia. In AD 62, a great earthquake destroyed Pompeii along with many other cities in Campania. Sometime between 62 AD and the great eruption of Vesuvius in 79 AD, the city was rebuilt, perhaps more magnificent in terms of buildings and works of art than before. The inhabitants of Pompeii, like those who live in the area today, have long been accustomed to slight tremors, but on February 5, 62 there was a great earthquake which caused considerable damage around the bay and in particular to Pompeii. Some of the damage was still not repaired when the volcano erupted. Archived 2012-01-21 on the Wayback Machine.. However, this may be a tectonic earthquake rather than an earthquake caused by rising magma contained within the volcano. Archived 2006-03-25 at the Wayback Machine.. Another earthquake, much milder, occurred at 64; this event is recorded by Suetonius in his biography of Nero, in De Vita Caesarum, and by Tacitus in Book XV of the Annales as it occurred while Nero was in Naples and was performing for the first time on a public stage.

Archaea or Archaea is a domain of single-celled microorganisms. Archaea are classified as prokaryotes, a group of microbes that lack a cell nucleus and membrane-bound organelles. Originally, archaea were classified as bacteria and given the name archaebacteria (in the kingdom Archaebacteria), but this classification is no longer used. Archaic cells have unique properties that separate archaea from the other two domains of life, namely Bacteria and Eukaryota. Archaea are further divided into several phyla. Classification is difficult because the majority of archaea have not been isolated in the laboratory and their gene sequences have only been detected from samples taken from the environment. Archaea and bacteria are generally similar in size and shape, although some archaea have very odd shapes, for example the flat, square cells like Haloquadratum walsbyi. Despite the morphological similarities between archaea and bacteria, archaea share genes and several metabolic pathways that are more similar to those of eukaryotes, especially the enzymes involved in transcription and translation. One unique aspect of archaea biochemistry is the dependence of archaea on the ether lipids in their cell membranes. Archaea use more energy sources than eukaryotes, which range from organic compounds such as sugars, ammonia, metal ions, or even hydrogen gas. The salt-tolerant archaea (Haloarchaea) use sunlight as an energy source, while other archaea species fix carbon; however, unlike plants and cyanobacteria, no archaea do both ways. Archaea reproduce asexually by binary fission, fragmentation, or budding. Unlike bacteria and eukaryotes, no archaea species are known to form endospores. The first archaea observed were extremophiles living in extreme environments, such as hot springs and salt lakes, with no other organisms.

The increasing capabilities of molecular detection tools have made it possible to find archaea in almost any habitat, including land, oceans and swamps. They are abundant in the oceans, and archaea in the form of plankton are probably one of the most abundant groups of organisms on the planet. Archaea played a major role in life on Earth. They are part of the microbiota for all organisms. As the human microbiota, archaea play an important role in the large intestine, oral cavity and skin. Their morphological, metabolic and geographical diversity allows them to have a wide range of ecological roles, for example in carbon fixation in the carbon cycle, roles in the nitrogen cycle, cycling of organic compounds, and maintaining symbiotic communities and microbial syntrophy. There are no clear examples of archaea that are pathogenic or parasitic. In contrast, archaea are often mutualists or commensals, for example the methanogens that live in the digestive tracts of humans and ruminants, where they live in large numbers and aid digestion. Methanogens are used in biogas production and sewage treatment. Meanwhile, enzymes from extremophile archaea which can withstand high temperatures and organic solvents are utilized in biotechnology. For most of the 20th century, prokaryotes were considered as a single group of organisms and classified based on their biochemical, morphological, and metabolic properties. Microbiologists try to classify microorganisms based on the structure of their cell walls, shape, and the substances they ingest. In 1965, Linus Pauling and Emile Zuckerkandl proposed using gene sequences in various prokaryotes to work out their relationships to one another. This approach, known as phylogenetics, is the main method used today. Archaea (then only known methanogens) were first classified as a separate group of bacteria on a phylogenetic tree based on their ribosomal RNA (rRNA) gene sequence by Carl Woese and George E. Fox in 1977.

Sariputta (Pali:Sāriputta; Sanskrit:शारिपुत्र Śāriputra) was one of the two chief disciples of the Buddha. He became an Arahant known for his wisdom and is described in the Theravada tradition as one of the Buddha's important disciples. Sariputta belonged to a Brahmin family and was already embarking on a spiritual life when he encountered the teachings of the Buddha. Close friend of Sariputta (Pāli: Mahāmoggallāna; Sanskrit: Mahāmaudgalyāyana), a wandering ascetic. On the same day, they renounced the world and became disciples of the skeptical Sañjaya Belaṭṭhaputta, before converting to Buddhism. After hearing the teachings of the Buddha through a monk named Assaji (Sanskrit: Asvajit), Sariputta followed the Buddha and became a follower of his teachings. The two are often depicted together with the Buddha, and the interaction between Sariputta and Mahamoggallana (who was famous for his supernatural powers in the early days of Buddhism) On an incident illustrated by anecdote, it is recorded that Sariputta was staying with Mahamoggallana at Kapotakandara. Sariputta was sitting in meditation in the open air with his head freshly shaved. Just then Sariputta was hit on the head by an evil spirit. Mahamoggallana saw this with his 'god-eye' (a psychic-like skill often possessed by Buddhist monks, the power is called Dibachakkuñana ), and failed to warn Sariputta. The blow was quite hard, but at the time it is said that, "Sariputta was absorbed in his meditation of attainment; as a result he was not injured at all." With the approval of the Buddha, Sariputta frequently preached and on several occasions even himself assumed leadership roles - whether as a trained guide and role model, as a kind and caring friend, as protector of the welfare of his monks, or as guardian. Faithful teachings of the Buddha. It was this role that earned him the nickname "The Commander of the Dhamma" (Dhammasenāpati).

However, the Buddha also rebuked Sariputta when he did not fully explain the Dhamma to a prince, or when he allowed a new group of monks to become too noisy. However, Sariputta was one of his most revered disciples. On one occasion the Buddha referred to him as a true spiritual child and as co-leader at the turning of the Dhamma wheel. After me, O monks, Sariputta is the one who turns the noble wheel of the Dhamma, even though I have turned it first. According to the Tipitaka, Sariputta died (Parinibbana) during the full moon of the month Kattika, which according to the solar calendar falls from October to November. Cunda, as a servant, took Sariputta's bowl and robe and departed for Savatthi to Anathapindikia's Jeta's Grove. On arriving there, he went to meet Ananda and brought him the news of Sariputta's death. Ananda who was sad, broke this news to the Buddha who remained in a peaceful state. Seeing Ananda's condition, the Buddha said: The Buddha's ode to his Chief Disciple: To him who, steady in patience like the earth, completely overcome by his mind, who is loving, kind, peaceful, and steady like the earth - now reverence is paid to the parinibbana Sariputta! He who was like a casteless youth with a simple mind, entered the city and walked his way slowly, from house to house with a begging bowl in his hand, like this Sariputta - now homage is paid to the parinibbana Sariputta! One who being in a city or wilderness, harming no one, (living) life like a bull with its horns cut off, like this was Sariputta, who had won self-mastery — now homage is paid to Sariputta who has passed away!

Types of relationship Widows Widows Widows Family Cohabitation Monogamy Single marriage Boyfriend Boyfriend Girlfriend Marriage Polygamy Siblings Best friend Concubine Husband Mistress Events in relationship Love Kissing Affection Courtship Friendship Marriage · Affair · Divorce · Courtship ·Majesty · Intercourse · Adultery Marriage is the process of binding a sacred promise between a man and a woman. A noble and sacred worship. Marriage should not be done carelessly because this is the longest form of worship and can be maintained until death do us part. This ceremony of binding the marriage vows is celebrated or carried out by one male recipient of the holy sacred and one woman with the intention of formalizing the marriage bond according to Islamic religious norms, legal norms, and social norms. Wedding ceremonies have many varieties and variations according to ethnic, religious, customary, cultural and social class traditions. The use of certain customs or rules is sometimes related to certain religious rules or laws. Marriage is a handover contract between a man and a woman with the aim of mutually satisfying each other and to form a sakinah household ark and a prosperous society. The legal validation of a marriage usually occurs when the written document that records the marriage is signed. The wedding ceremony itself is usually an event that is held to carry out ceremonies based on applicable customs, and an opportunity to celebrate with friends and family. The woman and the man who are getting married are called the bride and groom, and after the ceremony is over, they are called husband and wife in marriage. Marriage is a noun form of the word marriage; the word comes from the Arabic word nikkah (Arabic: النكاح ‎) which means marriage agreement; Next, the word comes from another word in Arabic, namely the word nikah (Arabic: نكاح) which means intercourse.

Based on Article 6 of Law no. 1/1974 concerning marriage, the conditions for getting married are things that must be met if you are going to get married. These conditions are: For those who are Muslim, marriage must be present (Article 14 Compilation of Islamic Law (KHI): In mid-2014, a student and 4 alumni of the Faculty of Law, University of Indonesia filed a lawsuit against the Marriage Law to the Constitutional Court, specifically Article 2 paragraph 1 of Law No. 1/1974 which reads: "Marriage is legal, if it is carried out according to the laws of each religion and belief" which precludes/complicates the occurrence of interfaith marriages.On June 18, 2015, the Constitutional Court rejected the entire lawsuit by state considerations play a role in providing guidelines to ensure legal certainty of living together in marriage ties, religion determines the validity of marriage, while the law determines the legality of administration carried out by the state Marriage in Islam in Islam is human nature and is a worship for a Muslim to perfect his faith and his religion.By getting married, someone who has carried the mandate of the greatest responsibility within himself towards the family that he will guide and nurture towards the path of truth. Marriage has the greatest benefit over other social interests. These social interests are maintaining the continuity of the human race, continuing offspring, increasing sustenance, maintaining honor, maintaining public safety from all kinds of diseases that can endanger human life and maintaining peace of mind. Marriage has a very noble purpose, namely to form a happy, eternal family based on Belief in the One and Only God. This is in accordance with the formulation contained in Law Number 1 of 1974 article 1 that: "Marriage is a physical and spiritual bond between a woman and a man as husband and wife with the aim of forming a happy and eternal family (household) based on the Supreme God. Almighty."

Photosynthesis is a biochemical process of forming carbohydrates from inorganic materials carried out by plants, especially plants that contain a green substance, namely chlorophyll. Apart from those containing green leaf substances, there are also living things that photosynthesize, namely algae, and several types of bacteria that use nutrients, carbon dioxide and water and need the help of sunlight energy. Almost all living things depend on the energy produced in the process of photosynthesis. As a result of photosynthesis is essential for life on earth. Photosynthesis is also credited with producing most of the oxygen contained in the earth's atmosphere. Organisms that produce energy through photosynthesis (photos means light) are referred to as phototrophs. Photosynthesis is one way of assimilation of carbon because in photosynthesis free carbon from CO2 is bound (fixed) into sugar as an energy storage molecule. Another way organisms take to assimilate carbon is through chemosynthesis, which is carried out by a number of sulfur bacteria. Although there are still steps in photosynthesis that are not understood, the general equation of photosynthesis has been known since the 1800's. In the early 1600s, a physician and chemist, Jan van Helmont, a Flanders (now part of Belgium), conducted experiments to find out what factors caused plant mass to increase over time. From his research, Helmont concluded that the mass of plants increases only because of the provision of water. However, in 1727, the English botanist Stephen Hales hypothesized that something other than water must be at play. He suggested that most plant food comes from the atmosphere and light involved in certain processes. At that time it was not known that air contained different gaseous elements. In 1771, Joseph Priestley, an English chemist and clergyman, discovered that when he covered a burning candle with an overturned jar, the flame would go out before the candle burned out.

He later discovered that if he placed a mouse in an overturned jar with a candle, the mouse would suffocate. From the two experiments, Priestley concluded that the candle flame had "corrupted" the air in the jar and caused the death of the mice. He then showed that the air that had been "damaged" by the wax could be "restored" by plants. He also showed that rats can survive in closed jars as long as there are plants inside. In 1778, Jan Ingenhousz, Austrian royal physician, repeated Priestley's experiments. He showed that sunlight affects plants so that they can "restore" "damaged" air. He also found that plants also 'polluted the air' in the dark so he then suggested that plants should be removed from homes at night to prevent possible poisoning of the occupants. Finally in 1782, Jean Senebier, a French priest, showed that the air that was "restored" and "damaged" was carbon dioxide absorbed by plants in photosynthesis. It wasn't long before Theodore de Saussure was able to demonstrate a link between Stephen Hale's hypothesis and air "recovery" experiments. He found that the increase in plant mass was due not only to the absorption of carbon dioxide, but also to the provision of water. It was through this series of experiments that the experts finally succeeded in describing the general equation of photosynthesis which produces food (such as glucose). The process of photosynthesis cannot take place in every cell, but only in cells that contain photosynthetic pigments. Cells that do not have photosynthetic pigments are unable to carry out the process of photosynthesis. In Jan Ingenhousz's experiment, it can be seen that light intensity affects the rate of photosynthesis in plants. This can happen because of the difference in energy produced by each spectrum of light. In addition to these energy differences, another factor that is differentiating is the ability of leaves to absorb these different light spectrums.

Siam (Thai: สยาม) is the old state of Thailand including its vassal states namely Cambodia, Lanna, Laos, Pegu & a small part of Malaysia. This kingdom was formed by the Phra Ruang dynasty and lasted until 1932. Initially the kingdom was ruled by the Khmer Empire until 1238 it gained independence from Khmer rule. When Ram Khamhaeng the Great, son of Sri Indraditya ruled over the Kingdom of Sukhothai it had to be in contact with the Mongol Empire. After Ramkhamhaeng's death led to the decline of Sukhothai and the rise of the Ayutthaya Kingdom. Ayutthaya was at war with Sukhothai. Ayutthaya conquered many cities, such as Angkor, Sukhothai, Tambralinga. Ayutthaya then went to war with Lanna then Burma (Toungoo Dynasty) until the Burmese attacked Ayutthaya. In Thonburi (Modern near Bangkok) Phraya Taksin as King of Thonburi. King Taksin attacked Lanna and the other kingdoms to reunite into Siam. Funan, Chenla, Khmer Kingdom, Isan & most of Southern Thailand except Sriwijaya, Khmer, Lavo, Vimayapura city under Jayavarman VII Conquer Chao Phraya Basin, northern Thailand also controlled by Jayavarman VII. His death caused many kingdoms to become independent from the Khmer including Sukhothai, lanna & Phayao. During the time of Ayutthaya Borommaracha II launched an offensive to destroy Angkor. Thailand gradually became an independent city-state from the Khmer Empire. It is said that Sukhothai was founded as a sovereign, powerful kingdom led by Pho Khun Sri Indraditya in 1238. A feature of the so-called classical Thai politics that historians call father ruling children existed at this time. Everyone could bring their problems to the king directly; there is a bell in front of the palace for this purpose. The city briefly dominated the area under King Ramkhamhaeng, who founded the Thai script, but after his death in 1365 it fell into decline and became subject to another Thai kingdom, the Ayutthaya Kingdom, under the Chao Phraya region.

Another kingdom that claimed coexistence with Sukhothai was the northern state of Lanna, centered on Chiangmai. Raja Phya Mangrai was the founder. This state arose in the same period as Sukhothai. Obviously Lanna became a closed ally of Sukhothai. When the Ayutthaya Kingdom had emerged and expanded its influence from the Chao Phraya valley, Sukhothai was finally subdued. Fierce fighting between Lanna and Ayutthaya has been going on and on. Chiangmai was finally subdued, becoming the territory of Ayutthaya. Lanna's independent history ended in 1558, when it finally fell to the Burmese; thereafter it was dominated by Burma until the late 18th century. Local leaders rise up against the Burmese with the help of the Thonburi king Raja Taksin. The 'Northern Union-City' later became a vassal to the kingdoms of Thonburi and Bangkok. In the early twentieth century they were annexed and became part of modern Siam, or Thailand. The Ayutthaya kingdom was located on a small inlet, surrounded by three rivers. Due to its pre-eminent location, Ayutthaya quickly became a powerful political and economic empire. Various names ranging from 'Ayothaya', derived from Ayodhya, India's holy city, 'Krung Thep', 'Phra Nakorn' and 'Dvaravati'. The first ruler of the Kingdom of Ayutthaya, King Ramathibodi I, made two important contributions to Thai history: the establishment and spread of Theravada Buddhism as the official religion - to distinguish his kingdom from the neighboring Hindu Khmer Empire and the compilation of the Dharmashastra, a code of law based on Hindu sources and traditional Thai customs . The Dharmashastra remained a tool of Thai law until the late 19th century. But Ayutthaya was hampered by internal fighting. The Ayutthaya tradition became the model for the next period dynasty, the Bangkok Chakri Dynasty. Starting with the Portuguese in the 16th century, Ayutthaya, known to Europeans as the "Kingdom of Siam", had some contact with the West. It became one of the most prosperous empires in East Asia.

in ASEAN (dark gray) – Legend] The Kingdom of Cambodia (Khmer: ព្រះរាជាណាចក្រកម្ពុជា, French: Royaume du Cambodge) is a constitutional monarchy in Southeast Asia. It is the successor to the Khmer Empire that once ruled the entire Indochina Peninsula between the 11th and 14th centuries. Cambodia is bordered by Thailand to the west, Laos to the north, Vietnam to the east, and the Gulf of Thailand to the south. The Mekong River and Tonle Sap Lake run through the country. Prior to its independence, the Unitary State of the Republic of Indonesia helped Cambodia a lot. War tactics books written by Indonesian military officers are widely used by the Cambodian military. Therefore, prospective officers in the Cambodian military are required to study and be able to speak Indonesian. The development of Cambodian civilization occurred in the 1st century AD. During the 3rd, 4th and 5th centuries AD, the Funan and Chenla states united to establish the Cambodian region. These countries have close ties with China and India. The power of these two countries collapsed when the Khmer Empire was built and ruled in the 9th to 13th centuries. The Khmer Empire survived into the 15th century. The capital of the Khmer Empire was located at Angkor, an area built during the heyday of the Khmer. Angkor Wat, which was also built around this time, became a symbol of Khmer rule. In 1432, the Khmer were overrun by the Thai Kingdom. The Khmer Royal Council moved the capital from Angkor to Lovek, where the Empire gained great advantage because Lovek was a port city. The Khmer defense of Lovek was eventually overrun by the Thais and Vietnamese, and also resulted in the loss of most of the Khmer territory. This event occurred in 1594. Over the next 3 centuries, the Khmer were ruled by the Kings of Thailand and Vietnam in turn.

In 1863, King Norodom, who was appointed by the Thais, sought refuge with the French. In 1867, King Norodom signed an agreement with the French which gave him control over the provinces of Battambang and Siem Reap which became part of Thailand. Eventually, these two areas were granted to Cambodia in 1906 in a border treaty by France and Thailand. Cambodia was made a Protectorate by the French from 1863 to 1953, as part of the Indochina Colony. After the Japanese occupation in the 1940s, Cambodia finally won its independence from France on November 9, 1953. Cambodia became a constitutional kingdom under the leadership of King Norodom Sihanouk. During the Vietnam War in the 1960s, the Kingdom of Cambodia chose to be neutral. This was not allowed by military officials, namely General Lon Nol and Prince Sirik Matak who formed a pro-US alliance to remove Norodom Sihanouk from power. From Beijing, Norodom Sihanouk decided to ally with the Khmer Rouge hordes, aiming to reclaim his throne which had been usurped by Lon Nol. This is what sparked a civil war in Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge finally took control of the area in 1975, and changed the format of the Kingdom into a Democratic Republic of Cambodia led by Pol Pot. They quickly moved urban people to rural areas to work on collective farms. This new government wanted agricultural output similar to what happened in the 11th century. They rejected Western medicine which resulted in starvation of the Cambodian people and no medicine at all in Cambodia. In November 1978, Vietnam invaded Cambodia's Democratic Republic to stop the genocide that was taking place in Cambodia. Finally, in 1989, peace was worked out between the two warring parties in Paris.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union  (light blue) Tunisia (Arabic: تونس, translit. Tūnis‎  Tūnis; Berber language: ⵜⵓⵏⴻⵙ; French: Tunisie), with the official name of the Republic of Tunisia (Arabic : الجمهورية التونسية‎  al-Jumhūrīya at-Tūnisīya; Berber: ⵜⴰⴳⴷⵓⴷⴰ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵏⴻⵙ; French: République Tunisienne) is the northernmost country in Africa, with an area of ​​165,000 square kilometers (64,000 square miles). Ras ben Sakka, is the northernmost point of the African continent located in this country. Its territory is bordered by Algeria to the west, Libya to the southeast, and the Mediterranean Sea to the north and east. The population of Tunisia is estimated at just under 10.8 million in 2013. The name Tunisia comes from its capital city, Tunis, which is located on the northeastern coast of Tunisia. Geographically, Tunisia is located at the eastern end of the Atlas Mountains and the northern part of the Sahara desert. With a coastline of 1300&bsp;km facing the Mediterranean Sea. 40% of the land is part of the Sahara desert and the rest is fertile land. Tunisia is the only democratic country in the Arab World. It has a high human development index. It has an association agreement with the European Union and is a member of La Francophonie, Union for the Mediterranean, Union of the Arab Maghrib, Arab League, OIC, Arab Free Trade, United Sahel-Saharan Community, African Union, Non-Aligned Movement, and the G-77 Group . In ancient times, Tunisia was mainly inhabited by Berber tribes. Phoenician migrations began in the 12th century BC; This migration was led by Carthage. A rival of Greece which was nearly destroyed by the Roman Empire in the Second Punic War, Carthage was finally defeated by the Romans in the Battle of Carthage in 149 BC. The Roman Empire introduced Christianity and architectural art, including the El Djem amphitheater.

Tunisia was conquered by the Arabs in the first Hijri century, followed by the Ottoman Empire in 1534. The Ottoman Empire ruled over Tunisia for more than three hundred years. The French conquest of Tunisia occurred in 1881. Tunisia became independent in 1957 as a republic founded by Habib Burquibah. In 2011, there was the Tunisian Revolution which resulted in the overthrow of President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali. Tunisia gained independence from France in 1956 with Habib Burquibah as Prime Minister. A year later, Tunisia was declared a republic, with Bourguiba as its first President. The Tunisian revolution was an intensive campaign of civil resistance caused by high levels of unemployment, food inflation, corruption, lack of freedom of speech and other political liberties and poor living conditions. Trade unions were cited as an integral part of the demonstrations. The catalyst for the mass demonstrations was the death of Mohamed Bouazizi, a 26-year-old Tunisian street vendor, who set himself on fire on 17 December 2010 to protest the confiscation of his merchandise and the humiliation inflicted on him by a city official. Anger and violence escalated after Bouazizi's death on 4 January 2011, which eventually prompted President Zainal Abidin bin Ali to resign and flee the country on 14 January 2011 after 23 years in power. Tunisia is located on the Mediterranean coast of North Africa, midway between the Atlantic Ocean and the Nile Delta. The country is bordered by Algeria to the west and southwest and Libya to the southeast. Tunisia is located between latitudes 30° and 38°N, and longitudes 7° and 12°E. Despite its relatively small size, Tunisia has great environmental diversity due to its north to south distance.

Part of the Template series:Buddhist Mahāyāna (derived from Sanskrit: महायान, Mahāyāna which literally means 'Great Vehicle') is one of the two main schools of Buddhism and is a dividing term for the philosophy and teachings of the Buddha. Mahāyāna, who was born in India, is used in three main senses: Although the origins of Mahāyāna date back to Gautama Buddha, historians have concluded that Mahāyāna originated in India in the 1st century, or 1st century BC. According to historians, Mahayana became a major movement in Buddhism in India in the 5th century, from that time Mahayana texts began to appear in inscriptions in India. Prior to the 11th century (when Mahayana was still in India), the Mahayana Sutras were still in the process of being refined. Therefore, multiple silks of the same silk may appear. These translations are not considered by historians to form Mahayana history. In the course of its history, Mahāyāna spread throughout East Asia. Countries that adhere to Mahayana teachings today are China, Japan, Korea and Vietnam and adherents of Tibetan Buddhism (the Himalayan ethnicity resulting from the Chinese invasion of Tibet). The current schools of Mahāyāna Buddhism are "Pure Land", Zen, Nichiren, Singon, Tibetan and Tendai. The last three have schools of both Mahāyāna and Vajrayana teachings. Buddha was born in the 6th century BC. After attaining Perfect Enlightenment at the age of 35 to Mahaparinibbana at the age of 80, He spent his whole life preaching and spreading his teachings. For 44 years, he meditated, taught and preached day and night, sleeping only 2 hours a day. The Buddha spoke to all kinds of people: kings and princes, brahmins, farmers, beggars, learned men and common people.

Buddha did not teach all castes even those outside caste or without caste. His teachings are tailored to the experience, level of understanding and mental capacity of his listeners. What he taught is called the Buddha Vacana. At that time it was not known as Theravada or Mahāyāna. After the formation of the Sangha assembly of Bhiku and Bhikuni, the Buddha laid down certain disciplinary rules called the Vinaya as guidelines for the community. All of his teachings are called Dhamma, including discourses, sutras, sermons to monks, nuns and ordinary people. Three months after Buddha Mahaparinibbana, his closest followers held a assembly at Rajagaha. Maha Kassapa, the most respected and elder of the monks, presided over the assembly. Also present were two disciples who were especially skilled in two teachings – Dhamma and Vinaya (discipline, ethics). One was Ananda, the closest friend and follower of the Buddha for 25 years. Gifted with an extraordinary memory, Ananda was able to repeat what the Buddha had said. Another was Upali who memorized all the Vinaya rules. Only these two teachings - the Dhamma and the Vinaya - were recited at the First Council. Although there is no disagreement about the Dhamma (excluding the Abhidhamma), there is some discussion about the Vinaya rules. Before the Buddha's parinibbana, he told Ananda that if the Sangha wanted to correct or change some baseless rules, they could do so. But at that time, Ananda was so grieved over the imminent death of the Buddha that he did not ask the Buddha which of the rules he was referring to. Since the members of the assembly could not agree on what was meant by the non-fundamental rules, Maha Kassapa finally decreed that the rules laid down by the Buddha were not changed and no new rules were added.

Power is the authority obtained by a person or group to exercise that authority in accordance with the authority given, authority may not be exercised beyond the authority obtained or the ability of a person or group to influence the behavior of other people or groups according to the wishes of the perpetrator (Miriam Budiardjo, 2002 ) or Power is the ability to influence other parties to think and behave in accordance with the will that influences (Ramlan Surbakti, 1992). In general speech, power can mean class power, king power, state official power. So it is not wrong to say that power is the ability to influence other parties according to the will of those in power. Robert Mac Iver said that Power is the ability to control the behavior of others either directly by giving orders or indirectly by using all available tools and methods. Power usually takes the form of a relationship, someone who rules and someone who is ruled. Humans act as subjects as well as objects of power. For example the President, he makes laws (subject of power) but also has to submit to laws (object of power). is the ability bestowed by God to individuals as the highest power holders who can influence and change the minds of other people or groups to take an action desired by the power holders seriously and or not because of coercion either physically or mentally. But in power, not all those in power have authority, because authority is special. The nature of power Position Power is power that is already owned by someone in an organization. The nature of this power usually exists in someone who has a position in an organization. In this case, the position in question, such as chairman or board of directors.

If someone already has the position of chairman, then he already has the authority to organize and direct his subordinates. For someone who already has power in an organization, but cannot carry out the responsibilities properly, it is likely that the organization he leads will find it difficult to develop. Therefore, someone who has a position in an organization should have broad insight so that the organization he leads does not experience setbacks. One way to broaden your horizons is to read books. Is the nature or character of someone who is arrogant, selfish, and apathetic in influencing other people or groups to take the action desired by the holder of power by coercion or pressure, both physically and mentally. Usually these negative power holders do not have intellectual intelligence and good emotional, they only think short in making decisions without doing sharp thinking in taking an action, even they themselves sometimes cannot carry out all the orders they order to people or groups who are under their power because of the limited thinking power. . and usually power with a negative character is only looking for personal or group benefits above that power. because they do not have any ability or capital other than the power to produce anything, and those holders of negative power usually won't last long because they won't get the full support of their people. In a democratic country, where power is in the hands of the people, the path to power other than through the bureaucratic route is usually taken through the path of political parties. Political parties try to win constituents during the election period. Political parties then send candidate members to represent their parties in the legislature.

Genomics is a branch of biology that studies the genome of an organism or virus. Genomics can be said to be a branch of genetics when viewed historically, although in genomics many methods are used that come from other branches of biology, such as bioinformatics and molecular biology. Genomics is impossible to stand as a branch of science without the help of bioinformatics because the object of study is very large (sequences of nitrogenous bases) and requires complex data management. Included in the study is the structure, organization and function. The object of study is DNA as a whole (nuclear/nuclear DNA, cpDNA, and mtDNA) or parts ("genes"). RNA as genetic material or DNA made from RNA (cDNA) is also the object of genomic studies. From the Greek gene, "gene" (gamma, epsilon, nu, epsilon) meaning "to become, make, create, give birth to", and the following variants: genealogy, genesis, genetics, genic, genomere, genotype, genus etc. While the word genome (from the German Genome, attributed to Hans Winkler) was used in English as early as 1926, the term genomics was coined by Tom Roderick, a geneticist at the Jackson Laboratory (Bar Harbor, Maine), over a beer at a meeting held in Maryland on mapping the human genome in 1986. Following Rosalind Franklin's confirmation of the helical structure of DNA, James D. Watson and Francis Crick published the structure of DNA in 1953 and Fred Sanger's publication of Amino acid insulin sequences in 1955, nucleic acid sequencing became a major target early molecular biologist. In 1964, Robert W. Holley and colleagues published the first nucleic acid sequence ever determined, the ribonucleotide sequence of alanine transfer RNA. Expanding on this work, Marshall Nirenberg and Philip Leder revealed the triplet nature of the genetic code and were able to determine the sequence of 54 out of 64 codons in their experiments.

In 1972, Walter Fiers and his team at the University of Ghent Molecular Biology Laboratory (Ghent, Belgium) were the first to determine a gene sequence: the gene for the bacteriophage coat protein MS2. Fiers' group expanded on their MS2 coat protein work, determining the complete nucleotide sequence of the MS2-RNA bacteriophage (whose genome encodes only four genes in 3569 base pairs bp]) and Simian virus 40 in 1976 and 1978, respectively. In addition to work on insulin's amino acid sequence, Frederick Sanger and his colleagues played a key role in the development of DNA sequencing techniques that enabled the establishment of comprehensive genome sequencing projects. In 1975, he and Alan Coulson published a sequencing procedure using radiolabelled DNA polymerases which he called the Plus and Minus technique. This involves two closely related methods that produce short oligonucleotides with a defined 3' termini. It can be fractionated by electrophoresis on a polyacrylamide gel (called polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis) and visualized using autoradiography. This procedure can sequence up to 80 nucleotides in one go and is a huge improvement, but still very laborious. Nevertheless, in 1977 his group was able to sequence most of the 5,386 nucleotides of the 17X174 single-stranded bacteriophage, completing a fully sequenced DNA-based genome. Improvements to the Plus and Minus methods resulted in the chain termination, or Sanger method, which forms the basis of the most widely used technique of DNA sequencing, genome mapping, data storage, and bioinformatics analysis in research 25 years later. In the same year Walter Gilbert and Allan Maxam of Harvard University independently developed the Maxam–Gilbert method (also known as the chemical method) of DNA sequencing, which involves preferential cleavage of DNA at known bases, a less efficient method.

Algebra (from Arabic الجبر "al-jabr" meaning "collection of broken parts") is one part of the broad field of mathematics, along with number theory, geometry and analysis. In its most general form, algebra is the study of mathematical symbols and the rules for manipulating these symbols; algebra is the unifying thread of almost all areas of mathematics. In addition, algebra includes everything from solving basic equations to studying abstractions such as groups, rings, and fields. The more basic parts of algebra are called elementary algebra, while the more abstract parts of algebra are called abstract algebra or modern algebra. Elementary algebra is generally considered essential for any study of mathematics, science, or engineering, as well as applications in medicine and economics. Abstract algebra is a major topic in advanced mathematics, studied primarily by professionals and mathematicians. Elementary algebra differs from arithmetic in its use of abstraction, such as using letters to represent unknown numbers or being allowed to take multiple values. For example, in x+2=5{\displaystyle x+2=5} the letter x{\displaystyle x} is unknown, but the law of inversion can be used to find the value: x=3{\displaystyle x=3}. In E = mc2, the letters E{\displaystyle E} and m{\displaystyle m} are variables, and the letter c{\displaystyle c} is a constant, the speed of light in a vacuum. Algebra provides a method for solving equations and expressing formulas that is easier (for those who understand the concept) than the conventional method of writing everything down in words. The word algebra is also used in more specific cases. A special type of mathematical object in abstract algebra is called "algebra", this word is used, for example, in the expressions linear algebra and topological algebra. A mathematician who does research in algebra is called an algebraist, English: Algebraist.

The word algebra comes from the Arabic الجبر (al-jabr literally means "reassembling the broken parts") this term is taken from the title of the book Al Kitaab al muhtasar fii hisaab al jabr wa'l muqabaala by the Persian mathematician and astronomer Al-Khwarizmi. This vocabulary entered the English language during the fifteenth century, either from Spanish, Italian, or Medieval Latin. Algebra was originally called the surgical procedure for setting a bone fracture or dislocation. Its mathematical meaning was first recorded in the 16th century. The word "algebra" has several meanings in mathematics, as a single word or with qualifications. Algebra begins with the same calculations as arithmetic, with letters used to represent numbers. This allows proof of the properties to be true regardless of the numbers involved. For example, in the quadratic equation a,b,c{\displaystyle a,b,c} can be any number (except that a{\displaystyle a} cannot be 0{\displaystyle 0}), and the quadratic formula can be used for with quickly and easily find the values ​​of the unknown quantity x{\displaystyle x} and satisfy the equation. The quadratic formula is used to represent the equation, and then find all the solutions to the equation. Historically, and in teaching today, the study of algebra begins by solving equations such as the quadratic equation above. Then come more general questions, such as "does the equation have a solution?", "how many solutions does the equation have?", "what can be said about the nature of the solution?". These questions sparked ideas about shape, structure and symmetry. The structural properties of these non-numeric objects are then abstracted to define algebraic structures such as groups, rings, and fields. Prior to the 16th century, mathematics was divided into two subfields, arithmetic and geometry. Although some methods, which were developed much earlier, may be considered today as algebra, the emergence of algebra and, soon after, infinitesimal calculus as a subfield of mathematics is only from the 16th or 17th century.

Decomposers or decomposers are organisms that eat dead organisms and waste products from other organisms. Decomposers help cycle nutrients back into the rest of the ecosystem. Decomposers make soil rich by adding organic compounds with it. Substances such as carbon, water and nitrogen are returned to the ecosystem through the action of decomposers. Examples of decomposers include insects, earthworms, bacteria, fungi, maggots, lactobacteria, cockroaches, yeast, slugs, mosses, and actinomycetes. In general, the types of decomposers are classified into 4 groups, namely: Decomposers are organisms that feed on dead organisms and the waste products of other organisms. Decomposers help cycle nutrients back into the rest of the ecosystem. You could say the role of decomposers is very important in the balance of natural ecosystems. Decomposers or decomposers will always exist in every type of ecosystem that exists, whether in grasslands, in forests, in deserts, at the poles, even in the oceans. The role of decomposers is indeed important in the sustainability of ecosystems on land and in the sea. Organisms that are dead will then be directly broken down by decomposers and then returned to the soil into nutrients or inorganic substances that are essential for growth. Decomposition of organisms by decomposers will produce carbon dioxide gas which is very useful in the process of plant photosynthesis. Decomposers also make the soil have a lot of additional organic compounds. Substances such as carbon, water and nitrogen are returned to the ecosystem through decomposer activity. Several biological fertilizers and decomposers have the ability to improve soil, neutralize harmful compounds and accelerate the decomposition of remaining chemical fertilizers and organic matter in the soil. Increase the effectiveness of absorption of chemical fertilizers. Accelerate the growth and development of plants and increase yields. These products contain useful microorganisms.

Semipelagianism is a Christian theological and soteriological idea of ​​salvation; the means by which man and God are restored to a right relationship. Semipelagianism is contrary to the previous teachings of Pelagianism, in which humans are seen as the only thing that affects their own salvation, which has been rejected and seen as heresy. Semipelagianism in its original form developed as a compromise between Pelagianism and the teachings of the Church Fathers such as Saint Augustine, who taught that humans cannot come to God without grace or mercy from God. In the view of Semipelagianism, it is therefore necessary to distinguish between the initial stages of faith and the development of faith; where the second half stage — growing in faith — is the work of God, while faith in the initial stage is an act of free will and grace only comes into play afterward. The Catholic Church condemns semipelagianism, but insists that from its earliest stages faith involved an act of free will; where the initiative comes from God but requires the cooperation of man through his free will. :2008 After the fall of man into sin, (nature) man is no longer healthy, but weak; he fell ill, but did not die. Therefore, man must act, so that he can receive salvation. However, humans have weaknesses and limitations, so humans need outside help, namely God's grace. Nevertheless, humans must desire it and whoever wishes it will obtain salvation. The salvation referred to here is a result of cooperation between God and man. The term "Semipelagianism", a term coined in the 16th century, has been used as an accusation in theological disputes over salvation, divine grace, and free will.

Theologians also use it retrospectively to refer to the original formulation, a usage long considered inappropriate, ambiguous and unfair. In this context, a more historically accurate term is Massilianism - referring to the city of Marseilles - with which some of its supporters are associated. Pelagianism is a teaching that says that humans have the ability to seek God in and of themselves apart from all actions of God or the Holy Spirit, and therefore salvation is only a human endeavor. This doctrine is taken from the name of Pelagius, an English monk who was accused of developing this doctrine (in his own letters he seems to claim that humans do not do good apart from grace or mercy, only, all humans have free will as a gift from God); its teachings were opposed, in particular, by Augustine of Hippo and declared a heresy by Pope Zosimus in 418. Pelagianism denied the existence of original sin, teaching that man is in himself and by nature capable of choosing what is good. Semipelagian thought teaches that humans do not have an unlimited ability, but humans and God can work together to a certain degree in this effort of salvation: humans can (without the help of grace) take the first step to come to God, then God increases and maintains that faith. , then complete His work of salvation. This teaching differs from the traditional patristic (age of the Church Fathers) doctrine of synergism (synergeia), in which the process of salvation is cooperation between God and man from beginning to end. The term "Semipelagianism" was unknown in ancient times, appearing for the first time only in the last quarter of the 16th century. This term is used in connection with Luis de Molina's doctrine of grace.

Jordan (Arabic: اَلأُرْدُن‎; Al-'Urdun), formally the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan (اَلمَمْلَكَة اَلأُرْدُنِيَّة اَلهَاشِمِيَّة; Al-Mamlaka al-Urduniyya al-Hashemiyya) is a kingdom in the West Bank of the Jordan River. The country is bordered by Saudi Arabia to the east and southeast, Iraq to the northeast, Syria to the north, and Israel and Palestine to the west, sharing control of the Dead Sea. Jordan's only port is at the southwest end of the Gulf of Aqaba, parts of which are also controlled by Israel, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. More than half of Jordan is covered by the Arabian Desert. However, the western part of Jordan is forested and arable land. Jordan is part of the Fertile Crescent. The capital and seat of government is Amman. Jordan was founded in 1921, and recognized by the League of Nations as a state under a British mandate in 1922 known as the Emirate of Transjordan. In 1946, Jordan joined the United Nations as an independent state, officially known as the "Hashimid Kingdom of Jordan". In ancient times, the region that is now Jordan was the heart of an ancient civilization that benefited from its geographical position in the Fertile Crescent region that included Babylon and Canaan. Later, Jordan became home to several ancient kingdoms including: The Kingdoms of Edom, Moab, Ammon, and the prominent Nabathic kingdom: Petra. However, across different historical eras, parts of the country came under the control of neighboring powers, such as Ancient Egypt during its wars with Babylon and the Hittites; and at various times by the Israelites who were taken during the Babylonian captivity, and then defeated by the Moabites as recorded in the Moabite Stone. Furthermore, and because of its strategic location in the middle of the ancient world, Jordan was also under the control of the ancient Greek, Persian, Roman and later empires of the Byzantines.

Still, the Nabataeans established an independent kingdom covering most of modern Jordan and adjacent areas, for several centuries, before being finally conquered by the Roman Empire. However, apart from Petra, the Romans maintained the prosperity of most of the ancient cities in Jordan which enjoyed a sort of city-state autonomy under the umbrella of the alliance of the Decapolis. With the decline of the Roman Empire, Jordan came under the control of the Arab kingdom of Ghassan. In the 7th century, and because of its proximity to Damascus, Jordan became one of the important domains for the Arab-Islamic Caliphate and thereby also secured several centuries of stability and prosperity, which allowed the current Islamic Arab identity to emerge. In the 11th century, Jordan witnessed a phase of instability, as it became one of the core zones of the Crusades which ended in defeat by the Ayyubid dynasty. Jordan also suffered from the Mongol attacks which were blocked by the Mamluks. In 1516, Jordan became part of the Ottoman Empire and remained in this state until 1918, when the Great Arab Rebel Army took over, and secured modern Jordan with the help and support of local Jordanian tribes. As a witness to Jordan's rich history, the Nabeth civilization left behind many great archaeological sites in Petra, which is considered one of the New Seven Wonders of the World and has been recognized by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) as a World Heritage Site. Apart from Petra, other civilizations also left their archaeological traces in Jordan such as Hellenistic and Roman through ruins in the cities of the Decapolis: Jerash, Umm Qais, Amman, Kapitolias (Beit Ras), Rafana, Pella, and Irbid and the Byzantine site Umm ar- Rasas (a World Heritage Site). The Islamic-Arabic Caliphate also left a unique architectural imprint that manifested itself in desert palaces including Qasr Mshatta, Qasr al Hallabat, and Qasr Amra which were recognized as World Heritage Sites; in addition to the castles of Ajloun and Al Karak which combines the era of the Crusades, the Ayyubid Dynasty, and the Mamluks.

Cynicism or Cynicism (Greek: κυνισμός) in its original form is an ideology adhered to by the Cynic school (Greek: Κυνικοί, Latin: Cynic), a Greek philosophical school that has no ideals and always considers others worse; therefore he is cynic or cynical. They emphasize that true happiness is independence from randomness or flux. So the Cynics rejected the happiness of wealth, strength, health, and prestige. As a school of philosophy, Cynicism is primarily how its adherents live and behave (even Diogenes of Sinope, who presents Cynicism as a philosophy, shows the debate whether Cynicism is a philosophy or a way of life). This school was never a formal school of philosophy; also, has never owned, and can never own, a physical school of philosophy; nor can it ever have a philosophical doctrine. But philosophers at that time believed that Cynicism contained a kind of philosophical project, Plato called this school "crazy Socrates". Words such as cynicism, cynicism, have a negative connotation (peioratif) for moodiness, pessimism, doubt, belittlement; contempt for the opinions of others; unsure of ideals and humanity. Cynicism is also considered as a belief that humans are self-centered, hypocritical, insincere, and only good to themselves. The Cynic school of philosophy was first founded by Antisthenes who lived in 445-365 BC, who was a loyal follower of Socrates. Antisthenes in language and logic is emphatically not cynical; and the direct association between Diogenes and Anthisthenes is chronologically problematic. Another well-known cynic is Diogenes of Sinope, who lived in a vat., according to Cicero's life records (Cic. Tusc. V.92) Diogenes is thought to have been born and died approx. 412/403-324-321 BC, originating from from the Black Sea.

His father, called Herecias, was in charge of the money making shop; he is exiled; and he spent the rest of his life in Athens and Corinth. The relationship between Antithesnes and Diogenes is not very clear, based on reconstructions that many historians believe, Diogenes and his father were accused of tampering with the currency which led to Diogenes' exile, and this event occurred after the death of Antisthesnes. The exile was the catalyst for the most dramatic change in his life. This assumption confirms that there is no relationship between the two. The history that seems most believable is his meeting with Alexander the Great. One day Diogenes was sunbathing when Alexander the Great, eager to see this great philosopher, approached him and asked if there was anything he could do for him, Diogenes replied, "Get away from my light!", for Alexander was blocking the sunlight. Diogenes' life is indeed very surprising, he lives in a wine pot which is often called a bath, eats and drinks very simply, drinks from cold mountain water, does not drink wine, does not eat legumes, does not wear shoes, only wears two layers of clothing. in winter without robes. He got his belongings from stealing, farming and begging. He exhibited all activities in public: eating, drinking, urinating, defecating, masturbating, and sexual intercourse, especially in the agora, a sacred place outside the confines of worldly activity. In essence, he was nicknamed doggish because of his shameless behavior. Diogenesis had a successor named Crates. Crates was from Boeoti, from Thebes, which rejected its prosperity, and joined the Cynic school. He seemed even happier than Diogenes; according to some reports, every Athenian house was open to him, and he was even regarded by them as a household god. Surprisingly, Crates lived his life by being married to Hipparchia, which seemed to contradict the anti-establishment principle of Diogenetic Cynicism, he even made ends meet by working as a weave.

Anthracene is a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) with the molecular formula C14H10, consisting of three benzene nuclei. It is a component of coal tar. Anthracene is used in the production of alizarin red dye and other dyes. Anthracene is colorless but emits a blue fluorescence (400–500 nm peak) under ultraviolet light. Coal tar, which contains about 1.5% anthracene, is the main source of this material. Common impurities are phenanthrene and carbazole. The classic laboratory method for the preparation of anthracene is the cyclodehydration of o-methyl- or o-methylene-diarylketone known as the Elbs reaction. Anthracena is also present in the interstellar medium. More than 20% of the carbon in the universe can be associated with PAHs, including anthracenes. Anthracene undergoes photochemical dimerization under the influence of UV light: The dimeric compounds, called dianthracenes (or sometimes parantracenes), are linked via new carbon-carbon bond pairs, resulting in a +4] cycloaddition. It can be reverted to anthracene thermally or by UV radiation below 300 nm. Substituted anthracene derivatives have similar properties. The reaction is affected in the presence of oxygen. Reduction of anthracene with alkali metals gives the dark colored anion salt radical M+anthracene]- (M = Li, Na, K). Hydrogenation yields 9,10-dihydroanthracene, while retaining its ring-ring aromaticity. The chemical oxidation is rapid, producing anthraquinone, C14H8O2 (see below), for example, using hydrogen peroxide and vanadil acetylacetonate. Anthracene also reacts with dienophile singlet oxygen in the +2]-cycladdition reaction (Diels-Alder reaction): Anthracene is converted primarily to anthraquinone, a dye precursor. Anthracene, a wide band gap organic semiconductor is used as a scintillator in high energy photon, electron and alpha particle detectors. Plastics, such as polyvinyl toluene, can be filled with anthracene to produce plastic scintillators used for radiotherapy dosimetry.

Ashoka the Great (also Ashoka, Aśoka, pronounced Asyoka) was the ruler of the Maurya Gupta Empire from 273 BC to 232 BC. A Buddhist, Asoka ruled most of the Indian subcontinent, from what is now Afghanistan to Bangladesh and as far south as Mysore. The name "Asoka" means 'without sorrow' in Sanskrit (a – without, soka – sorrow). Asoka was the first ruler of Ancient Bharata (India), after the illustrious Mahabharata rulers, to unite this vast territory under his empire, which even exceeded the boundaries of the sovereign territory of present-day India. The British writer H. G.
