Wells wrote of Ashoka: "In the history of the world, there have been thousands of kings and emperors who called themselves 'Their Highnesses', 'Their Royal Highnesses' and 'Their Royal Highnesses' and so on. They shone for a brief period, and then quickly disappeared. However, Asoka still shines and shines brilliantly like a brilliant star even today" (Originally in English: "In the history of the world there have been thousands of kings and emperors who called themselves 'Their Highnesses', 'Their Majesties' and 'Their Exalted Majesties' and so on. They shone for a brief moment, and as quickly disappeared. But Ashoka shines and shines brightly like a bright star, even unto this day"). Asoka was the son of maharaja Maurya, maharaja Bindusara from a concubine of rather low rank and named subhadrangi who was eventually called Dharma because he followed the path of righteousness. Ashoka had several brothers and only one younger brother, Drupadh. Because of his exemplary intelligence and ability for war, he is said to have been the favorite grandson of his grandfather, maharaja Chandragupta Maurya.

So as the legend says, when Chandragupta Maurya left his kingdom to live as a Jain, he threw away his sword. Ashoka finds the sword and keeps it. So while he developed into a consummate accomplished warrior and a shrewd statesman, Asoka commanded several Mauryan army regiments. His growing popularity throughout the empire made his older brothers jealous as they feared he could be chosen by Bindusara to become the next emperor. Her brother is the oldest, Susima prince, crown prince of the first, to persuade Bindusara to send Asoka to deal with a rebellion in the town of Taxila, in the northwestern province of Sindhu, where the prince Susima was governor. Taxila is an area that is volatile because the population is the Greek-Indian people who like to fight and also because the government of his older brother, Prince Susima, is chaotic. Therefore, in this area many formed militias security screw. Asoka agreed and left for the area which was being hit by the turmoil. So when the news that Asoka is coming to visit them with his troops, he was greeted with respect by the rebel militia and insurgency could be ended without bloodshed. (This province later rebelled again when Asoka ruled, but was then crushed with an iron fist). Asoka's success made his brothers more and more anxious about his intention to become the next emperor, so Susima's instigations towards Bindusara made him throw Ashoka away. Ashoka then goes to Kalinga and hides his identity. There he meets a fisherwoman named Kaurwaki, and he falls in love. Newly discovered inscriptions indicate that she was to become a second or third consort consort. In the meantime, there is a rebellion again, this time in Ujjayani (Ujjain). Maharaja Bindusara invites Asoka back after being exiled for two years.

Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (English: Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation or abbreviated as APEC) is an economic forum of 21 countries in the Pacific Rim which aims to strengthen economic growth, strengthen communities and promote free trade throughout the Asia-Pacific region. APEC was founded in 1989 in response to the growing economic interdependence of Asia-Pacific countries and the emergence of other trading blocs in other parts of the world; fear of Japan dominating economic activity in the Asia-Pacific region, and of establishing new markets for agricultural products and raw materials outside Europe. Headquartered in Singapore, APEC is recognized as the oldest forum and highest level multilateral bloc in the Asia-Pacific region, and exerts significant global influence. The annual APEC Economic Leaders' Meeting is attended by the heads of government of all APEC member countries except for Taiwan (which is represented by a ministerial-level official named Chinese Taipei as chief economist). The location of these meetings rotates annually among member countries, and as a tradition, which is followed by almost all meetings, every head of government attending wears the traditional dress of the host country. APEC has three official observers: the Secretariat of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council and the Secretariat of the Pacific Islands Forum. In January 1989, Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke proposed establishing more effective economic cooperation for the Asia-Pacific region. This culminated in the first APEC meeting in the Australian capital, Canberra, chaired by Australian Foreign Minister Gareth Evans. The meeting was attended by ministers from 12 countries, and culminated in a commitment to hold annual meetings for the future in Singapore and South Korea. Countries from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) opposed the initial proposal, and instead proposed an East Asian Economic Caucus that excluded non-Asian countries such as the United States, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

This proposal was opposed by countries in the Americas, and was sharply criticized by Japan and the United States. The first meeting of APEC Economic Leaders was held in 1993 when United States President Bill Clinton, after discussions with Australian Prime Minister Paul Keating, invited the heads of government of member countries to attend a meeting on Blake Island. Clinton hopes that this will continue the stalled Uruguay Round negotiations. During the meeting, several leaders called for the continued reduction of trade and investment barriers, and envisioned a vision of a community in the Asia-Pacific region that can promote prosperity through cooperation. Finally, a central APEC Secretariat was established in Singapore to coordinate the activities of the organization. At the 1994 meeting in Bogor, Indonesia, APEC leaders adopted the Bogor Goals (Indonesian: Bogor Goals) aimed at encouraging open trade and investment in the Asia-Pacific starting in 2010 for industrialized economies and 2020 for developing economies. In 1995, APEC established a business advisory body called the APEC Business Advisory Council (ABAC), which consists of three business executives from each member country. In April 2001, APEC, in collaboration with five other international organizations (Eurostat, IEA, OLADE, OPEC and UNSD) launched the Joint Oil Data Exercise, which in 2005 became the Joint Organization Data Initiative (JODI). The APEC Summit is held annually in member countries. The first meeting of the APEC organization was held in Canberra, Australia in 1989. APEC produced the "Bogor Declaration" at the 1994 Summit in Bogor which aimed to reduce customs duties to zero and five percent in the Asia Pacific environment for developed countries no later than 2010 and for developing countries no later than 2020.

Confucianism is an official belief and is recognized in Indonesia along with 5 other beliefs. Confucianism is considered a religion that emerged as a result of the political situation in Indonesia during the New Order era. It is common for Confucianism to have its meaning and essence obscured as a philosophy or way of life. Confucius considered himself a transmitter of cultural values ​​inherited from the Xia (c. 2070–1600 BC), Shang (c. 1600–1046 BC) and Western Zhou (c. 1046–771 BC) dynasties. Confucianism was suppressed during the legalist and autocratic Qin dynasty (221–206 BC), but persisted. During the Han dynasty (206 BC–220 AD), the Confucian approach ruled out the Huang–Lao "proto-Taoist" as the official ideology, while the emperors mixed the two with realist Legalist techniques. Confucianism appears in the form of religion in several countries such as Korea, Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong and China. In Chinese, Confucianism is often referred to as Kongjiao (孔教) or Rujiao (儒教). Confucianism as a religious institution in Indonesia implements the following. The Year of the Confucian Prophet's New Year falls on December 22. February 4th turn of winter to spring. So Chinese New Year is not a spring celebration. The estimated date of the 1st Chinese New Year, the span of time is 15 days ahead and 15 days back from the 4th of February. Every 4 or 5 years there is a 13th month, to fulfill it so that the calculation does not change. Needs to be explained] In this era The New Order, the Soeharto government prohibited all forms of activities that smelled of Chinese culture and traditions in Indonesia. This has caused many adherents of Chinese traditional beliefs to have no status as adherents of one of the 5 recognized religions. To avoid political problems (accused of being atheists and communists), adherents of these beliefs are then required to embrace one of the recognized religions, the majority being followers of Buddhism, Islam, Catholicism, or Christianity.

The pagoda, which is a place of worship for traditional Chinese beliefs, was also forced to change its name and become a monastery which is a place of worship for Buddhism. After the New Order, adherents of traditional Chinese beliefs began to regain recognition of their identity since the leadership of President KH. Abdurrahman Wahid (Gus Dur) through Law No. 1/Pn.Ps/1965 which states that the religions with many adherents in Indonesia include Islam, Protestant Christianity, Catholicism, Hinduism, Buddhism and Confucianism. Confucian teachings in Chinese, the original term is Rujiao (儒教), which means the belief of people who are meek, educated and virtuous. Confucius was not the creator of this belief, but he only perfected the belief that existed long before his birth, as he said: "I am not the creator, but I like these ancient teachings." Although people sometimes think that Confucianism is a philosophical teaching to improve morale and maintain human ethics, actually if someone wants to understand Confucianism correctly and completely, then he will know that in Confucianism there are also rituals that must be carried out by its adherents. Confucianism also teaches about how the relationship between humans or called "Ren Dao" and how we make a relationship with the creator of the universe (Tian Dao) which is called "Tian" or "Shang Di". This philosophical teaching was founded by Confucius who was born in 551 BC under the name Chiang Tsai who was then 17 years old. He was known for the spread of new sciences when he was 32 years old, Confucius wrote many moral, historical, literary and philosophical books which were widely followed by adherents of this teaching. He died in 479 BC. Confucius did not prevent the Chinese from worshiping sacred things and guardians but only those that were worthy of worship, not worshiping sacred objects or guardians that were not worthy of worship. What was important in his teaching was that every human being should strive to improve morals.

Celtic is the term for a number of ancient Central European tribes in the past who maintained a culture and language belonging to the Celtic language subgroup. Today, the term Celtic is also used to describe some of the inhabitants of the British Isles, the Brittany region of France, and the Galician region of Spain who retain some of the original Celtic features, particularly of their language. However, in the past they were not considered related to the Celts by outsiders. The term 'Celtic' comes from the name of the Ancient Greeks. In written references to the Celtic people, Hecataeus of Greece in 517 BC refers to them as Keltoi. However, European historical literature before the 19th century never mentions "Celtic" or "Celtic". The mention of the present comes from archaeological findings which show the migration of Celtic people from Gaul and Belgium to the British Isles, such as Atrebates, Menapii, and Parisi, and played a role in the formation of the Celtic population. A clear feature of the Celts is that they are either spoken or descended from speakers of one of the Celtic languages. The territories of Wales, the Isle of Ireland, Scotland, Cornwall, the Isle of Man and Brittany are called "the land of the Celts" because their inhabitants speak languages ​​belonging to the Celtic languages. Other European regions associated with the Celts are Galicia in Spain, and Devon, Cumbria and Northumbria in England. Another feature, especially for archaeological studies, is the prehistoric European people who carry a culture that is considered to have originated from the Hallstatt culture and the La Tene culture. Modern DNA studies have shown that most of the islanders of present-day Britain are of Celtic descent, particularly Old Brythonic, although no Celtic languages ​​survive in British territory. Likewise in Scotland, Gaelic is limited to the north and west.

Types of relationship Widows Widows Widows Family Cohabitation Monogamy Single marriage Boyfriend Boyfriend Girlfriend Marriage Polygamy Siblings Best friend Concubine Husband Mistress Events in relationship Love Kissing Affection Courtship Friendship Marriage · Affair · Divorce · Courtship ·Majesty · Intercourse · Adultery Intercourse or sexual intercourse means in principle the act of intercourse performed by a human being, but in a broader sense it also refers to other acts that are related to or replace the act of intercourse, so it is more rather than simply referring to the meeting between male and female genitalia. Intercourse may be preceded by fondling which causes arousal in the partner, causes the penis to experience an erection, and natural lubrication of the vagina. To initiate intercourse, the erect penis is inserted into the vagina and one partner or both partners move their thighs to make the penis move back and forth in the vagina and produce friction, without fully extending the penis. Thus, they stimulate themselves and their partners until orgasm and ejaculation are obtained. Penile penetration is also known as "intromission" or by the Latin name "immissio penis". The term "penetration" is used to describe the condition when the male genitalia is inserted into the vagina. This is not always a mandatory ritual to achieve pleasure and enjoyment in sex. Sexual activity without penetration is usually carried out by teenagers by masturbating so that sperm is released. Copulation is the basic method of human reproduction. During ejaculation, which is commonly accompanied by orgasm in men, a series of muscle contractions occur which send semen containing the male gametes known as sperm cells or spermatozoa into the vaginal space.

A chemical element is a species of atoms that have the same number of protons in their atomic nuclei (that is, the same atomic number, or Z). A total of 118 elements have been identified, of which 94 occur naturally on Earth. While the remaining 24, is a synthetic element. There are 80 elements that have at least one stable isotope and 38 elements that are radionuclides which, over time, decay into other elements. Iron is the most abundant constituent of the earth (by mass), while oxygen is the most abundant in the earth's crust. Chemical elements make up the ordinary matter in the universe. However, astronomical observations suggest that ordinary observable matter makes up only 4% of the matter in the universe: the rest is dark matter (73%); its composition is unknown, but it is not composed of any chemical elements. This mysterious energy is likely accelerating the inflation of the Universe. The two lightest elements, hydrogen and helium, were formed mostly in the Big Bang and are the most common elements in the universe. The next three elements (lithium, beryllium, and boron) were formed mostly by cosmic ray spallation, and are therefore rarer than the heavier elements. The formation of elements with between 6 and 26 protons occurs and continues in main sequence stars through stellar nucleosynthesis. The high abundance of oxygen, silicon and iron on Earth reflects their abundant production in these stars. Elements with more than 26 protons form via supernova nucleosynthesis within supernovae, which, when they explode, scatter these elements as supernova remnants far into space, which coalesce with planets when they form. The term "element" (or "element") is used for atoms with a certain number of protons (regardless of whether they are ionized or chemically bonded, e.g. hydrogen in water) or for chemically pure substances containing a single element (e.g. hydrogen gas).

For the second meaning, the terms "elementary substances" and "simple substances" have been proposed, but they do not gain wide acceptance in the English chemical literature, while in some other languages ​​their equivalents are widely used (e.g. French: corps simple, Russian: простое вещество). A single element can form many substances that differ in structure; they are called allotropes of elements. When different elements combine chemically, with atoms held together by chemical bonds, they form chemical compounds. Only a few elements are found uncombined as pure minerals. Such naturally occurring elements include copper, silver, gold, carbon (as coal, graphite, or diamond), and sulphur. All elements, except for very inert ones such as the noble gases and noble metals, are normally found on earth in their combined chemical forms, as chemical compounds. While about 32 chemical elements exist on Earth in natural uncombined forms, the vast majority exist as mixtures. For example, atmospheric air mixes primarily with nitrogen, oxygen, and argon, while the naturally occurring solid elements occur in metal alloys, such as iron and nickel. The history of the discovery and use of elements began with primitive human societies who discovered natural elements such as carbon, sulfur, copper and gold. Later civilizations extracted the elements copper, tin, lead and iron from their ores through smelting, using coal. Alchemists and chemists successively identified many more; all naturally occurring elements were known by 1950. The properties of the chemical elements are summarized in the periodic table, which arranges the elements according to increasing atomic number in rows ("periods") that are repeated ("periodically") chemical properties and the physics of its columns ("classes"). Apart from the unstable radioactive elements with short half-lives, all elements are available industrially, most of which are of low impurity Cat 1].

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the Crimean Peninsula  (green) Russia, with the official name referred to as the Russian Federation (Russian: Росси́йская Федера́ция, Rossíyskaya Federátsiya) is a federal state with a semi-presidential system with a constitutional republic in east of Europe and north of Asia from northwest to southeast. The country shares land borders with Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland (both share borders with Kaliningrad Oblast), Belarus, Ukraine, Georgia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, China, Mongolia and North Korea. And also this country has sea borders with Japan in the Sea of ​​Okhotsk and the US state of Alaska in the Bering Strait. With an area of ​​17,125,191 km², Russia is the largest country in the world. Its territory covers one-eighth of the earth's land area, its population ranks ninth in the world with a total of around 147,190,000 people (2021). Covering the whole of North Asia and parts of eastern Europe, Russia has 11 time zones and its territory consists of various types of environments and soils. The history of this country begins with the East Slavs who existed in Europe between the 3rd and 8th centuries BC. Founded and ruled by elite Varangian troops and their descendants, the medieval state of Kievan Rus' emerged around the 9th century. In 988 they adopted Orthodox Christianity from the Byzantine Empire, beginning the Byzantine and Slavic (Gopnik) culture that defines Russian culture to this day. Kievan Rus eventually disintegrated into small states, part of their land was later captured by the Mongols and became a colony of the Golden Horde in the 13th century. The Grand Duchy of Moscow gradually reunited and became independent from the Golden Horde, and was able to return to dominate the cultural and political heritage of Kievan Rus'. In the 18th century, this country grew tremendously through conquest, annexation and exploration to become the Russian Empire which is the third largest empire in history, extending from Poland in Europe to Alaska in North America which was a former Russian territory.

After the Russian Revolution, the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic became the main and largest part of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the first country in the world to have a socialist state constitution. The Soviet Union played a defensive role in the Allied victory in World War II, and later emerged as a superpower against the United States during the Cold War. The Soviet era saw the most significant technological achievements of the 20th century, including the world's first man-made satellite and the launch of the first man in space. By the end of 1990, the Soviet Union had the world's second largest economy, the world's largest military power, and the largest stockpile of weapons of mass destruction. After the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, 15 independent republics split. As the largest country, the most populous, and the most economically developed, the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic changed its name to the Russian Federation and continued the legal status and successor state of the Soviet Union. Currently the country is a semi-presidential republic. The Russian economy is ranked the 12th largest by nominal GDP and the sixth largest by purchasing power balances in 2015. Russia's energy and mineral resources are the world's largest, making it the world's leading oil producer and natural gas producer. The country is one of five known nuclear weapons states and has the largest stockpile of weapons of mass destruction in the world. Russia is a major country and a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, also a member of the G20, European Council, Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), The World Trade Organization (WTO), a principal member of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), the Collective Security Treaty Organization (CSTO) and one of the five members of the Eurasian Economic Union, along with Armenia, Belarus, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan.

Industry is a field or economic activity related to the processing/manufacturing of raw materials or the manufacture of finished goods in factories using skills and labor (English: industrial) and the use of tools in the field of processing agricultural products, and their distribution as the main activity. Therefore, industry is generally known as the next link in the chain of efforts to fulfill (economic) needs related to the earth, namely after agriculture, plantations and mining which are closely related to the land. The position of the industry is increasingly far from the land, which is the basis of the economy, culture and politics. Industry is part of the production process and production process activities in the industry are called industry. Industry can also be interpreted as a collection of various companies that offer the same product. In other words, each product is a substitute for one another because the firm uses the same inputs and faces more or less the same group of suppliers and buyers. The industrial sector is divided into two, namely the goods industry and the service industry. The goods industry is a business of processing raw materials into semi-finished goods or finished goods. This industrial activity produces various types of goods, such as clothing, shoes, cars, motorbikes, fertilizers, and medicines. Meanwhile, the service industry is an economic activity by providing services. For example: transportation services such as buses, trains, flights, and shipping. There are also service companies that help with the production process. For example, banking and warehousing services. There are services that are directly addressed to consumers. Examples include insurance, health, tailors, lawyers, beauty salons and barbers. The industry started with the work of a carpenter or interpreter. After sedentary livelihoods as crop pickers, hunters, and fishermen in ancient times, humans settled down, built houses, and cultivated the land by farming, and gardening and raising livestock.

Their needs are growing, for example to get tools for picking crops, hunting tools, fishing tools, farming tools, gardening, tools for mining something, even tools for war and household tools. The artisans, and the embroiderers as the source of the tools and goods needed. From there, crafts and carpentry began to develop, which produced necessities. In order to become good craftsmen and carpenters, apprentice education patterns were held, and to maintain the quality of handicrafts and carpentry in Europe various guilds were formed (associations of craftsmen and craftsmen as the forerunner of various associations now). Iron and steel mining progressed rapidly in the Middle Ages. Furthermore, the mining of fuels such as coal, oil and gas also developed rapidly. Both of these spurred advances in mechanical technology, starting with the invention of the steam engine which in turn paved the way for the manufacture and trade of goods on a large scale and mass in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. At first, textile factories emerged (Lille, and Manchester) and railroads, then the steel industry (Essen) and shipyards, car factories (Detroit), aluminum factories. From the need for dyeing in textile factories, the chemical and pharmaceutical industries have developed. There was the Industrial Revolution. Since then a wave of industrialization in the form of the establishment of factories for the mass production of goods, the use of labor force, has rapidly swept across the world, colliding with traditional efforts in agriculture (agriculture). Since then, a variety of industry classifications have emerged. Most people assume that industry is just a human economic activity that processes raw materials/raw materials into semi-finished or finished goods. Even though the definition of industry is very broad, this industrial process includes all human activities in a certain field that are productive and commercial in nature.

The Republic of Chile (Spanish: República de Chile), sometimes spelled Chile, Chile, Cili, or Chili, is a sovereign state in the Americas, located in the southeastern part of South America, with the capital and seat of government in the City of Santiago. n 1] Chile is usually grouped into three zones. The first zone, called continental Chile, or mainland Chile, is a narrow strip on the west coast of the South Cone, most of which stretches from the southeastern coast of the Pacific Ocean to the Andes, between 17º29'57" S and 56º32' S, 4,270 km long. Maximum width reaches 445 km at 52º21' S to the Strait of Magellan, minimum width is 90 km at 31º37' S between Punta Amolanas and Paso de la Casa de Piedra, and the average width is 175 km. Chile is bordered on land by Peru to the north, Bolivia and Argentina to the east, a total length of 6,339 km, and to the south by the Drake Strait. Together with Ecuador, Chile is a country in South America that does not have a land border with Brazil. The second zone is called the Chile insular (Chilean archipelago), in the form of a group of islands volcanic areas in the southern Pacific Ocean, namely the Juan Fernández Islands and the Desventuradas Islands which are part of South America, as well as Isla Salas y Gómez and Easter Island which are geographically rafis is located in Polynesia. The third zone is the Chilean Antarctic Territory, a zone covering 1,250,257.6 km² in Antarctica, between 53°W and 90°W that Chile claims as part of its sovereign territory, its southern border with the South Pole. This claim was suspended in accordance with the Antarctic Treaty System, to which Chile is a party, whereas non-participation in this treaty system would require Chile to relinquish its claim.

Due to its location on the Americas, Oceania and Antarctica; Chile describes itself as a 'country of three continents'. In addition, Chile also holds exclusive rights, claims to varying degrees and sovereignty over a maritime area, which is called the Chilean Sea. This maritime area consists of four parts: the territorial sea (120,827 km²), the contiguous zone (131,669 km²), the exclusive economic zone (3,681,989 km²), and the corresponding continental shelf (145,194 km²), which also forms part of the territory of Chile. Chile has a coastline of 6,435 km, while its Pacific coastline is 78,563.2 km long. The climate in Chile varies, ranging from the world's driest desert climate (Atacama Desert) in the north, through the Mediterranean climate in the center, to a rainy temperate climate in the south. Based on its land area, Chile is included in the category of the 38th largest country in the world, which is roughly the same size as the island of Borneo. The northern desert contains abundant mineral wealth, especially copper. The country's relatively narrow central region dominates in terms of population and agricultural resources, and was the cultural and political center from which Chile expanded in the late 19th century, when it absorbed both the north and south. Southern Chile is rich in forests and grasslands, and there are several volcanoes and lakes. The south coast is a maze of fiords, inlets, canals, winding peninsulas and island systems. Prior to the arrival of the Spanish in the 16th century, northern Chile was under the rule of the Inca Empire, while the indigenous Mapuche people inhabited central and southern Chile. Chile declared independence from Spain on February 12, 1818. In the War in the Pacific (1879–1883), Chile defeated Peru and Bolivia and won northern territory.

Construction or development is an activity of building facilities and infrastructure. In addition, construction can also be interpreted as a building or infrastructure unit in one or several areas. Construction is also an activity to build facilities and infrastructure in a field of architecture or civil engineering. A construction is also known as a building or infrastructure unit in an area or in several areas. In summary, construction is defined as the object of the whole building (an) consisting of structural parts. For example, the construction of a building structure is the overall shape/build of the building structure. other examples: highway construction, bridge construction, ship construction, and others. Construction can also be defined as the arrangement (model, layout) of a building (bridges, houses, etc.). Even though construction is known as one job, in reality construction is a unit of activity consisting of several other different jobs. In general, construction activities are supervised by project managers, design engineers, or project architects. These people work in offices, while field supervision is usually left to foremen (projects who supervise construction workers, carpenters, and other builders to complete the "physical" construction). For the successful execution of a construction project, effective planning is essential. This is related to the design and implementation of infrastructure that takes into account the impact on the environment/AMDAL, the method for determining the amount of costs required/budget, accompanied by a good planning schedule, work environment safety, availability of building materials, logistics, public discomfort related to those caused by delays in the preparation of tenders and bids, etc. Here are some types of construction that you should know, namely: Settlement construction is construction that takes into account future spatial planning. This future time range is around 20 years since construction started.

Wiktionary's English edition opened for the first time on December 12, 2002 as a follow-up to Daniel Alston's proposal. On March 29, 2004, Wiktionary in other language editions, namely French and Polish, was opened. Since then, Wiktionary has opened editions in other languages. At first, Wiktionary was based on a temporary URL until finally on May 1, 2004 it was moved to wiktionary.org. Wiktionary is made for: Unlike most dictionaries which are monolingual or bilingual, Wiktionary is a multilingual and international dictionary, which means it aims to cover every word of all known languages ​​and do so in multiple languages. For example, the English edition of Wiktionary contains entries from multiple languages, but is written in English. The Indonesian edition of Wiktionary can also have the same articles as the English edition, but the articles are written in Indonesian. For example, entries with lowercase i and uppercase I are the same. On this page you can search for the meaning of a lemma or entry in Indonesian. If you would like to contribute an entry, this would be greatly appreciated. Below is a partial list of Indonesian words in alphabetical order: - It should be emphasized here that the words contained in this word list are words from the Indonesian vocabulary. So we beg you, do not include the names of figures, countries and other things here. This glossary was created for articles that do not have a link page so they don't become orphaned articles. It should also be emphasized here that you don't just take other people's work rights that are protected under the copyright law. Please always provide sources of information whenever possible!

Pharmacist (apt.) is a professional title for someone who has taken the pharmacist profession education and took the pharmacist's oath of office. Before pursuing a pharmacist professional education, one must first take a bachelor of pharmacy education to obtain an academic degree of bachelor of science (S.Sc.) or bachelor of pharmacy (S.Farm.) which are generally taken within four years. After that, then a bachelor can continue his professional pharmacist education (apt.) which is generally achieved within one year. So, the total time it takes someone to become a pharmacist is five years. The concept of this education is similar to what someone goes through to become a doctor, where after obtaining a bachelor's degree in medicine (S.Ked. ), they must continue their education for young doctors or co-assistant to obtain a doctor's degree (dr.). In clinical practice, pharmacists act as supervisors over prescriptions issued by doctors. As a profession that studies medicines in depth, starting from how they are made to how these drugs give certain reactions to the body, pharmacists actively review, correct, and provide input to doctors and other medical teams in providing therapy to patients. In carrying out the practice of pharmacy, pharmacists wear ivory white coats. This is different from doctors who wear bone-white coats while practicing medicine. In Indonesia, only pharmacists and doctors wear formal attire, such as suits. The terms pharmacist and apothecary originate from the physician Claudius Galenus of Pergamum (129–199) who is commonly known as Galen. He named the place where he examined patients latron and the place where Galen stored medicines apotheca, which literally means warehouse. In 1240, the state of the Kingdom of Sicily passed laws for the first time separating the professions of physicians and pharmacists.

Doctors can only examine patients and write prescriptions, but pharmacists make medicines and hand them over to patients. The World Health Organization (WHO) at a meeting in Vancouver 1997 used the term 7 Star Pharmacist to state the roles and responsibilities of a qualified pharmacist. In 1999, listed in Annex 7, this world body issued Good Pharmacy Practice In Community And Hospital Pharmacy Settings. Pharmacists in Indonesia join a professional pharmacist organization called the Indonesian Pharmacist Association (IAI). Pharmacists in Indonesia are often perceived by the public as someone who works in a pharmacy. However, in fact the scope of work of pharmacists is not only in pharmacies, but can also work in the public sector – such as the Ministry of Health (Kemenkes), the Food and Drug Supervisory Agency (BPOM), the Indonesian Institute of Sciences (LIPI) – or the private sector – such as companies pharmacy. Before pursuing pharmacist education in Indonesia, prospective students will be asked to choose a concentration that is the focus of pharmacist knowledge. Generally concentrations to choose from include Industrial Pharmacy, and Clinical and Community Pharmacy. Pharmacists with a concentration in Industrial Pharmacy will be well-suited to work in the pharmaceutical industry in various fields such as regulatory affairs, quality assurance, quality assurance, production, distribution, and others. Meanwhile, pharmacists with a concentration in Clinical and Community Pharmacy will be right to work in pharmacies, hospitals, and others. Even though there is this kind of clustering, so far it is not prohibited for a pharmacist with an Industrial Pharmacy concentration to work in a clinical environment or vice versa. In pharmacist lectures, there is a pharmacist professional work practice (PKPA) which is an opportunity for pharmacist students to undergo internships in various pharmaceutical fields, so that they will get an overview and readiness in the world of work in the pharmaceutical field later.

The Paleozoic (or Palaeozoic) (/ˌ p eɪ l i ə z oʊ ɪ k, ˌ p æ - /; from Greek palaios (παλαιός), "old" meaning "primeval life" is the beginning of three geological eras of the Phanerozoic era, beginning from 541 to 252.17 million years ago. This era is the longest of the Phanerozoic eras, and is divided into six geological periods the Cambrian, Ordovician, Silurian, Devonian, Carboniferous, and Permian. The Paleozoic comes after the Neoproterozoic Era of the Proterozoic, and is followed by The Mesozoic Era.The Paleozoic was a time of dramatic changes in geology, climate, and evolution.The Cambrian period saw the most rapid and extensive diversification of life in Earth's history, known as the Cambrian explosion, in which the first modern phyla appeared.Fish, arthropods, amphibians, reptiles, and synapsids all evolved in the Paleozoic era.Life started in the sea but eventually migrated to land, and during the late Paleozoic, the earth was dominated by various organic forms me. Gigantic plantations of primitive plantations covered the continent, many of which later formed coal seams stretching from Europe to eastern America. Towards the end of the era, large and advanced reptiles became dominant and the first modern plants (conifers) appeared. The Paleozoic era ended with the largest mass extinction in Earth's history, the Permian-Triassic extinction event. The effects of this catastrophe were so devastating that it took life on land 30 million years, into the Mesozoic era, to recover. The recovery of life in the sea is thought to be much faster. In North America, the era began with deep sedimentary basins along the east, southeast, and west sides of the continent, while the interior (called the interior landmass) was dry land. As the era progressed, the coastal seas periodically eroded parts of the interior landmass, leaving behind deposits of sediment that marked their "attacks".

Early in the era, an open area of ​​the Precambrian (called the shield), rock in central Canada eroded, supplying sediment to the basin from the interior landmass. Beginning in the Ordovician Period, occasional mountains formed in the eastern Appalachian region and continued for the remainder of the era, bringing in new sediments. Sediments scoured from the Acadia Mountains, filled the western Appalachian basin and formed the famous coal marshes of the Carboniferous Period. In North America, the term Carbonifera is rarely used. Instead, time is divided between the Mississippian and Pennsylvania periods because of differences in the sedimentary rocks deposited during those eras. The Mississippian period is characterized by limey sediment deposited in shallow seas, usually with many crinoidal fossils, such as in the Burlington Formation. Whereas the Pennsylvania period is generally characterized by terrestrial sediments such as sand, shale and most importantly: coal. Most of the oil and gas can be obtained from the sediments of Pennsylvania. Whereas in places where this has been moved, such as in the uplands of the Ozarks, there is usually no oil. Paleoclimatological studies and evidence of glaciers suggest that Central Africa was most likely in the polar regions at the start of the Paleozoic. At the start of the Paleozoic, the continents of Gondwanaland were already forming or are currently forming. In the mid-Paleozoic, North America and Europe collided producing the Acadian-Caledonian uplifts, and the eastern Australia subduction zone was uplifted. In the late Paleozoic, the collision of the continents formed the supercontinent Pangaea and produced many major mountain chains, including the Appalachian, Ural, and Tasmanian mountains. There are six periods of the Paleozoic era: Cambrian, Ordovician, Silurian, Devonian, Carboniferous and Permian. The Cambrian Period lasted from 541 to 485 million years ago and is the first period of the Paleozoic era. The Cambrian sparked an explosion in the evolution of life in an event known as the Cambrian Explosion, in which the greatest number of living things evolved in Earth's history in a single period.

Turkmenistan (Turkmenistan: Türkmenistan), also known as Turkmenistan (Russian: Туркмения). Until 1990, Turkmenistan was still part of the Soviet Union's constitution, which was called the Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic. Turkmenistan is located in Central Asia and is bordered by Iran to the south, Afghanistan to the southeast, Uzbekistan to the north, Kazakhstan to the northwest and the Caspian Sea to the west. Most of its territory is a stretch of the Karakum desert. The country has the fifth largest natural gas reserves in the world. Currently, Turkmenistan operates a single-party political system. This system is considered not to meet the basic principles of democracy. Since its independence from the Soviet Union, Turkmenistan was led by Saparmurat Niyazov and even called himself Turkmenbashi (Turkmenistan: Türkmenbaşy, which means "Leader of all Turkmens"). In 2022, he died and was replaced by Serdar Berdimuhamedow who was appointed by the Turkmenistan State Security Council through the general election on 11 February 2007. The Turkmenistan region has long been known to many people in history. Many troops from various kingdoms were sent to this region, in order to get a more prosperous region. This region has long been known primarily by the various Persian empires. The history of this region begins when the Achaemenid Emperor (the first ancient Empire of Persia) conquered this region and divided it into three regions, Margiana, Khwarezmia, Parthia. Alexander the Great conquered the region in the IV century BC on his way to Central Asia, and it was during this time that the Silk Road was established as the main trade route connecting Asia and the Mediterranean Basin. Several centuries later, the Persian Parthian Empire founded and established its capital at Nisa (UNESCO World Heritage Site in Turkmenistan), which today is about 18 km to the southwest of Ashgabat.

After the fall of the Parthian empire, the region was frequently occupied by various Iranian empires for several centuries. In the VII century AD, the Arabs conquered this area and at the same time introduced Islam and also Middle Eastern culture. Turkmenistan became widely known when the caliph Ma'mun Ar-Rashid of the Abbasid dynasty moved the capital of the Greater Khorasan kingdom to Merw (UNESCO World Heritage Site in Turkmenistan). In the mid-11th century the Seljuk Turkic Empire concentrated its territorial power in Turkmenistan in an attempt to expand its empire into Khorasan. In the mid-XII century, the power of the Seljuk Turkish Empire fell, which was defeated by Genghis Khan, who at that time succeeded in seizing power in the eastern region of the Caspian Sea in the context of his journey to the west. Seven centuries later, the Turkmens live under the rule of various empires and wars between tribes. Around the XVII and XIX centuries AD, power in Turkmenistan was contested by the Persian Empire, the Khiva Khanate, the Emirs of Bukhara, and the rulers of Afghanistan. During this time, the spiritual leader of the Turkmens, Magtymguly Pyragy was noted for his efforts to maintain freedom and autonomy for his people. At that time, vast areas of Central Asia, including Turkmenistan, were uncharted and barely known to Europeans and the Western World. The competition for control of the territory between the British Empire and the Russian Tsarist Empire was marked by the Great Games. Throughout their conquest of Central Asia, the Russians were met with the stiffest resistance by the Turkmens. However, by 1894 Russia had gained influence in Turkmenistan and incorporated it into its empire. Based on the Anglo-Russian Treaty of 1907, the war between the Russian Empire and the British Empire in Central Asia ended.

Mature age ·Censorship,Circumcision ·Infidelity Pornography,Childcare,Children pornography,Child prostitution,Inbreeding,Prostitution Pedophilia,Rape (Statutory rape,Rape by husband)Sexting,Sexual abuse of children,Sexual slavery,Sexual harassment, Zoophilia Sodomy is a legal term used in referring to sexual acts " unnatural", which depending on the jurisdiction may consist of oral or anal sex or any form of contact of non-sex organs with the genitals, whether committed heterosexually, homosexually, or between humans and animals. This term comes from the Latin: peccatum Sodomiticum, or "Sin of Sodom." This act is associated with the story of the depravity of the city of Sodom in the Bible story. In the Book of Genesis (chapters 18-20), God saw the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah as places of great evil and sin, and He wanted to find out whether this sin was true before He decided to destroy this city and all its inhabitants. Two angels (disguised as humans) were sent to investigate the city of Sodom. After arriving in the city at night, the angel was invited - then asked by Lut to spend the night and take refuge in his house. Summary:The men of the city of Sodom desire that Lot give up the two men so they can "know him". (In the Bible, the term "know" sometimes refers to the sexual act.) Lot refused to give them up, and (going out) offered his two daughters. The offer was refused, and after the men of Sodom pushed Lut and pushed him, the two angels pulled Lut and locked the door. They brought blindness to the men of the city, so that everyone in the house would be safe. Even when they were blind, the men of Sodom kept trying to enter Lut's house until they were exhausted.

In science and engineering, the notation of parts per set of pseudo units is used to describe small values ​​of various dimensionless quantities, such as mole fraction or mass fraction. Since these fractions are measures of quantity per quantity, they are pure numbers with no units of measurement associated. Commonly used are parts per million (ppm, 10−6), parts per billion (ppb, 10−9), parts per trillion (ppt, 10−12) and parts per quadrillion (ppq, 10−15). This notation is not part of the International Unit (SI) system and its meaning is ambiguous. The per part notation is often used to describe dilute solutions in chemistry, for example, the relative abundances of dissolved minerals or pollutants in water. The quantity "1 ppm" may be used for the mass fraction if the water-borne pollutant is present in one millionth of a gram per gram of sample solution. When dealing with aqueous solutions, it is usually assumed that the density of water is 1.00 g/mL. Therefore, it is customary to equate 1 kilogram of water with 1 liter of water. Consequently, 1 ppm corresponds to 1 mg/L and 1 ppb corresponds to 1 µg/L. Similarly, the per part notation is also used in physics and engineering to express the values ​​of various proportional phenomena. For example, a special metal alloy can expand 1.2 micrometers per meter of length for every degree Celsius and this would be expressed as "α = 1.2 ppm/°C". The per part notation is also used to indicate change, stability, or uncertainty in a measurement. For example, the accuracy of a ground survey distance measurement when using a laser rangefinder may be 1 millimeter per kilometer of distance; this can be expressed as "Accuracy = 1 ppm." The per part notation is all dimensionless quantities: in mathematical expressions, the units of measurement always cancel.

In fractions like "2 nanometers per meter" (2 nm/m = 2 nano = 2 × 10−9 = 2 ppb = 2 × 0.000000001), the quotient is a pure number coefficient with a positive value less than or equal to 1 When the per part notation, including the percent (%) symbol, is used in ordinary prose (as opposed to mathematical expressions), they are still pure number dimensionless quantities. However, they generally take the literal meaning of "parts per" of comparative ratio (eg "2 ppb" would generally be interpreted as "two parts in a billion parts"). The per part notation can be expressed in the same unit of measure. For example, the expansion coefficient of a certain brass alloy, α = 18.7 ppm/°C, can be expressed as 18.7 (μm/m)/°C, or as 18.7 (μin/in)/°C; a numeric value representing the relative proportions does not change with the application of different units of length. Similarly, metering pumps that inject chemicals into the main process line at a proportional flow rate Qp = 125 ppm, do so at rates that can be expressed in various volumetric units, including 125 μL/L, 125 μgal/gal, 125 cm3/m3, etc. In nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, the chemical shift is usually expressed in ppm. It represents the difference in frequency measured in parts per million of the reference frequency. The reference frequency depends on the magnetic field of the instrument and the element being measured. Usually expressed in MHz. Typical chemical shifts are rarely more than a few hundred Hz from a reference frequency, so chemical shifts are easily expressed in ppm (Hz/MHz). The per part notation gives a dimensionless quantity that is independent of the strength of the instrument field. Although the International Bureau of Measures and Scales (an international standards organization also known by its French initials, BIPM) recognizes the use of the per part notation, it is not officially part of the International Units (SI) system.

Radioactive decay (also known as nuclear decay or radioactivity) is the ability of unstable atomic nuclei to become stable through emission of radiation. This ability involves the process of splitting unstable atomic nuclei resulting in a loss of energy (in the form of mass in silence) by emitting radiation, such as alpha particles (helium nuclei), beta particles (electrons or positrons) with neutrinos and gamma rays. Materials containing unstable nuclei are considered radioactive. Decay occurs in a parent nucleus and results in a daughter nucleus. Radioactive decay is a "random" (stochastic) process in which, according to quantum theory, it is impossible to predict when an atom will decay, no matter how long the atom has existed. However, for a collection of atoms, the predicted decay rate can be characterized by a decay constant or half-life. This forms the basis for radiometric measurements. The half-life of a radioactive atom has no limit, spanning 55 magnitude levels, from almost spontaneously beginning to far exceeding the age of the universe. The international (SI) unit for measuring radioactive decay is the becquerel (Bq) after the French physicist Henri Becquerel. If a radioactive material produces 1 decay event every 1 second, then the material is said to have an activity of 1 Bq. Because normally a sample of radioactive material contains many atoms, 1 becquerel will appear to be a low level of activity; The units commonly used are on the order of gigabecquerel. In addition, another unit used to measure radioactive decay is the curie (Ci). This unit is based on the amount of radiation produced by one gram of radium. One curie (Ci) is equivalent to 3.7 × 1010 Bq. The neutrons and protons that make up the atomic nucleus, seen like other particles, are governed by several interactions.

The strong nuclear force, which is not observable at the macroscopic scale, is the strongest force at the subatomic scale. Coulomb's law or electrostatic force also has a significant role in this measure. The weak nuclear force has little effect on this interaction. The gravitational force also has little effect on the nuclear process. Changes in the arrangement of particles and or changes in the type of particles cause complex interactions between these forces. This interaction can then lead to a release of energy. This is because the stability of the nucleus is limited when it undergoes transformation. This event might be described like the sand towers we build on the beach: even though the friction that occurs between the sands is able to support the tower's height, the tower is unstable, given its low potential energy. Therefore, a "disruption" is needed that can change the tower to a higher level of entropy. The disturbance causes the system to produce energy which is then distributed to all parts resulting in a collapse. The collapse of this tower then becomes an analogy of the decay process. The tower collapse (decay) requires a certain activation energy. Disturbances that occur in the tower come from outside the system, either in the form of being kicked or shifted by the hand. In the case of nuclear decay, the activation energy comes from quantum fluctuations. The nucleus, like a tower, is unstable, so it continues to stabilize itself by trying to get as close to the ground state as possible. Some nuclear reactions involve an external source of energy, in the form of "collisions" with external particles, for example. However, such a reaction is not considered decay. Reactions like this will usually be included in nuclear fission/nuclear fusion. Radioactivity was first discovered in 1896 by French scientist Henri Becquerel while working with phosphorescent materials.

Premise is a term used in the basis of thinking to draw conclusions. Premise is a word that comes from the Latin preamissus which means advanced. The premise is a series of sentences used in logic to make a conclusion. The term premise is often found in learning mathematical logic. In addition, the premise is an assumption that is considered true as the basis for drawing conclusions, the results can be used as a theoretical basis for thinking. Therefore, the premise can be used as an assumption in the logic of thinking. The premise is a way to reach a conclusion through arguments. The premise is the main part of logical thinking, which has the goal of accepting, rejecting, or confirming an argument that is true or false. Based on the form the premise is divided into two. First, the major premise is a statement or result of thought in the form of a general statement and an outline. The result of the statement from the major premise is often used as a grand theory. Second, the minor premise is a specific description or statement of a thought. The result of the minor premise is usually referred to as the middle range theory. The results of thinking can be drawn into conclusions if produced scientifically. The method must be generated based on the premises collected. The premise can be a statement, evidence, theory, or data that can guarantee a conclusion. In the world there are many leaders who state theories for something that is scientific in nature. The journey of ideas to be accepted by many people requires very broad generalization concepts, as well as filtering out facts. Therefore we need a benchmark technique of thinking or called a premise. The theoretical basis is prepared using relevant and valid theories. Presentation of premises can help to develop a fundamental frame of mind to lead ideas towards solving problems.

Oceania is a term that refers to a geographical or geopolitical area consisting of a number of islands located in and around the Pacific Ocean. Oceania is the region on Earth (often considered a continent) with the smallest land area and the second smallest population after Antarctica. In a narrow sense (based on French explorer Jules Dumont d'Urville in 1831), Oceania includes Polynesia (including New Zealand), Melanesia (including Papua New Guinea) and Micronesia. Meanwhile, in a broad sense, Oceania also includes Australia and Maritime Southeast Asia which also includes the Malay Peninsula. However, sometimes Hong Kong, the Korean Peninsula, Japan, Taiwan, the Aleutian Islands, Sakhalin Island, the peninsula in northeastern Russia, and the Alaska Peninsula are also considered in the Oceania group. Most of Oceania is made up of small island nations. Australia is the only country that is both an island and is still being debated between islands and continents, while Papua New Guinea, Malaysia and Timor Leste are countries that have land and sea borders, both of which share a border with Indonesia. The countries of Oceania have independence under different terms from their colonial powers, and enjoy constitutional provisions which vary according to their circumstances. Australia, for example, is a country within the British Commonwealth, thus recognizing King Charles III as their King, while French Polynesia is a pays d'outre-mer ("overseas country") of France. Ecologically, Oceania is one of the world's eight terrestrial ecological zones. The Oceania ecological zone includes Polynesia except New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, New Caledonia, Fiji, the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu which are classified as the Australasia and Southeast Asia Maritime ecological zones including the Malay Peninsula and Micronesia which are classified as the Asian ecological zone.

Mucoromycotina:Endogonales MucoralesMortierellalesKickxellomycotina:AsellarialesKickxellalesDimargaritalesHarpellalesEntomophthoromycotina:Entomophthoromycotina:EntomophthoralesZoopagomycotina:Zoopagales Zygomycota (pronounced zi-go-mi-ko-ta) is a fungus characterized by hyphae that are not insulated (aseptae) under normal/vegetative conditions. This fungus is coenocytic (multinucleated cells) and can form temporary dormant structures called zygospores. In the old classification, Zygomycota was put together with Mastigomycota into the class Phycomycetes ("algae fungi") based on these characteristics, but it turned out that both of them were later known to show many different characteristics, such as places to live and the number of flagella at the zoospora stage so that they were placed separately. Zygomycota has about 600 species. Most are land organisms that live in the soil or on decaying plants and animals. Fungi in the division Zygomycota can produce spores. Some examples of fungi that are included in the division Zygomycota are: Members of this class mostly live on land and in the soil or in the decaying parts of plants and animals. Fungal reproduction in this class is sexual reproduction by gametangiogamy of two mutually compatible hyphae by producing zygospores, while asexual reproduction is carried out by forming flagellated spores in the form of sporangiospores or conidia. Zygomycota has senocytic hyphae, namely hyphae that contain many nuclei and do not have transverse partitions, so hyphae are in the form of a smooth tube containing protoplasts with many nuclei. Like other fungi, zygomycota produce cell walls containing chitin, they grow as mycelia or threads called hyphae. There are three types of hyphae, namely stolons (hyphae that form a network on the surface of the substrate and connect two groups of sporangia), rhizoids (hyphae that penetrate the substrate to absorb food), and sporangiophores (hyphae that grow upright on the surface of the substrate and have globular sporangia at the ends). ends). Mushrooms in this class are referred to as the highest fungi compared to the Ascomycota and Basidiomycota classes.

In chemistry, methylation denotes the addition (addition) of a methyl group to a substrate, or the replacement (substitution) of an atom (or group) by a methyl group. Methylation is a form of alkylation, with a methyl group instead of a long carbon chain replacing a hydrogen atom. These terms are commonly used in chemistry, biochemistry, soil science, and biological sciences. In biological systems, methylation is catalyzed by enzymes; Such methylation can be involved in heavy metal modification, gene expression regulation, protein function regulation, and RNA processing. In vitro methylation of tissue samples is also one method to reduce stained histological artifacts. The opposite of methylation is called demethylation. In biological systems, methylation is achieved by enzymes; Methylation can modify heavy metals, regulate gene expression, RNA processing and protein function. This has been recognized as a key process underlying epigenetics. Methanogenesis, the process that produces methane, is the result of a series of methylation reactions. These reactions are influenced by a series of enzymes harbored by the anaerobic microbial family. Various phenols undergo O-methylation to produce anisole derivatives. This process, catalyzed by enzymes such as cafeoyl-CoA O-methyltransferase, is a key reaction in the biosynthesis of lignol, the precursor to lignin, the main structural component of plants. Plants produce flavonoids and isoflavones by methylation at hydroxyl groups, i.e. methoxy bonds. This 5-O-methylation affects the solubility of flavonoids in water. Examples are 5-O-methylgenistein, 5-O-methylmyricetin or 5-O-methylquercetin, also known as azaleatine. Methionine synthase regenerates methionine (Met) from homocysteine ​​(Hcy). The overall reaction converts 5-methyltetrahydrofolate (N5-MeTHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF) while transferring the methyl group to Hcy to form Met. Methionine synthase can be both cobalamin dependent and cobalamin independent: plants have both, animals depend on the methylcobalamin-dependent form. In the methylcobalamin-dependent enzyme form, the reaction proceeds in two steps in the ping-pong reaction.

The enzyme is initially primed to a reactive state by transfer of a methyl group from N5-MeTHF to Co(I) in the enzyme-bound cobalamin (Cob), forming methyl-cobalamin (Me-Cob) which now contains Me-Co(III) and activating the enzyme. Then, Hcy coordinates with enzyme-bound zinc to form a reactive thiolate which reacts with Me-Cob. The activated methyl group is transferred from Me-Cob to Hcy thiolate, which regenerates Co(I) in Cob, and Met is released from the enzyme. Biomethylation is a pathway for converting some heavy elements into more mobile or lethal derivatives that can enter the food chain. Biomethylation of arsenic compounds begins with the formation of methanarsonate. Thus, the trivalent inorganic compound arsenic is methylated to give methanarsonate. S-adenosylmethionine is a methyl donor. Methanarsonate is the precursor to dimethylarsonate, again by a reduction cycle (to methylarsonic acid) followed by a second methylation. Related pathways apply to methylmercury biosynthesis. The term methylation in organic chemistry refers to the alkylation process used to describe delivery of a CH3 group. Methylation is generally carried out using an electrophilic methyl source such as iodomethane, dimethyl sulfate, dimethyl carbonate, or tetramethylammonium chloride. Less common but more potent (and more dangerous) methylating reagents include methyl triflate, diazomethane, and methyl fluorosulfonate. All of these reagents react via nucleophilic SN2 substitution. For example, a carboxylate can be methylated in oxygen to give a methyl ester; an alkoxide salt RO− may also be methylated to give an ether, ROCH3; or the ketone enolate can be methylated on the carbon to give a new ketone. Purdie methylation is specific for methylation at oxygen on carbohydrates using iodomethane and silver oxide. The Eschweiler–Clarke reaction is a method for methylation of amines. This method avoids the risk of quaternization, which occurs when amines are methylated with methyl halides.

The lion (Sanskrit: Siṃha, or its scientific name Panthera leo) is an animal species from the felidae family or cat family. Lions are on the continent of Africa and part of India. Lions are animals that live in groups. Usually consists of one male & many females. This group guards its territory. Lions live between 10 and 15 years in the wild, but in captivity it is possible to be more than 20 years. The younger lion will usurp the leadership from the older lion. Most younger lions will eat the cubs of the previous leader. The female lion is much more active in hunting, while the male lion is more relaxed in waiting and asking for rations from the prey of the females. Male lions are believed to be superior and mighty compared to other big cats, but the lion's weakness is that they cannot climb trees as well as other big cats. Male lions grow thick fur around the nape, this is more beneficial for protecting the nape, especially in free fights between big cats which tend to pounce on the nape to immobilize their enemies. Other big cats, such as cheetahs and leopards, are much smaller than lions. Even though they come from the same family as tigers, lions don't like water. Unlike the tiger who likes water. In the past, lions lived throughout Africa, Europe, the Middle East and the Indian subcontinent. But now the lion's habitat is only in a small part of the Indian subcontinent and Africa. It happened because of poaching aiming to get the skin. Based on archaeological findings from the pictures on the walls, around 15,000 years ago it was estimated to have lived in Europe, and 5,000 years ago to have existed in Greece.

The male lion is 260-330 cm long, and the female lion is 240–270 cm. Male tail length 70–105 cm, female 60–100 cm. Length from toe to shoulder for males 80–123 cm, females 75–110 cm. The weight of an adult male lion is around 150 kg–250 kg, while that of a female lion is around 120–185 kg. The weight of newborn lion cubs is around 1.2 kg to 2.1 kg. The lion's habitat is on the prairie. This animal is classified as nocturnal, in a day 20 hours lying on rocks or under a shady tree. Each group consists of 1–6 males, 4–15 females. The territory of one group is between 20–400 km2. If the food runs out, the lioness looks for food all day while expanding her territory. The task of the male lion is to protect the female from the male lions of other groups, and guard the territory. When occupying another group's territory, the male that takes possession of another group will kill the lion cubs that are in the captured group. The running speed of a male lion is 58 km/hour. It feeds on meat, usually preying on large mammals weighing around 50–500 kg. In addition, lions also prey on small animals such as birds, reptiles and insects. Lions usually hunt at night, but if they are in long grass that can cover their bodies they can hunt during the day. Usually, lionesses who hunt and hunted are monopolized by male lions. During the mating season, one copulation time is 20 seconds, a day can mate 50 times. Gestation period is 98–120 days and pregnant females leave the group temporarily. Once giving birth will give birth to 1-6 tails. Feeding time is 7–10 months. For 1 week, baby lions can not see. After 3 weeks I was able to walk.

Graphene (English: Graphene) is an allotrope of carbon in the form of a thin flat sheet where each carbon atom has sp2 bonds and is tightly packed in a crystal lattice like a honeycomb. It can be seen as an atomic scale web consisting of carbon atoms and their bonds. The name graphene comes from GRAPHITE + -ENE; Graphite itself consists of many graphene sheets stacked together. In 2010, Andre K. Geim and Konstantin Novoselov won the Nobel Prize in chemistry for their work on developing 2-dimensional graphene. The carbon-carbon bonds in graphene are about 0.142 nm. Graphene is the basic element of carbon allotropes, including graphite, carbon nanotubes, and fullerene. Graphene can also be considered as a very large aromatic molecule, which is a group of flat polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon compounds. In 2004 a research group from the Massachusetts institute of technology led by Andre K. Geim and Konstantin Novoselov discovered a semiconductor material called "Graphene". This material, which is an allotrope of carbon, has a thickness of only one atom and is stronger than steel, namely carbon arranged sideways in a lattice resembling a honeycomb (Section 6) and is estimated to be the thinnest semiconductor material in the world. Single layers of graphite earlier (circa 1910s) were grown epitaxially over other materials and are commonly called "epitaxial graphene". Epitaxial graphene contains a one-atom thick hexagonal layer with sp2 bonds between the carbon atoms. In the process of growing graphene crystals, charge transfer occurs from the substrate to epitaxial graphene, and in some cases hybridization of the d orbitals of the substrate atoms with the pi orbitals of graphene occurs, which significantly changes the electronic structure of graphene.

Perfect graphene consists exclusively of hexagonal cells, pentagonal and heptagonal cells are defective cells. If there are isolated pentagonal cells, the plane will contract to a conical shape. The insertion of 12 pentagons will form a fullerene. Similarly, the insertion of isolated heptagon cells causes the sheet to become saddle-shaped. The controlled addition of pentagons and heptagones allows the formation of various complex shapes, for example carbon nanobuds. A single-walled carbon nanotube can be thought of as a graphene cylinder whose fraction has a hemispherical cap (involving 6 pentagons) at each end. It has been considered that small fragments of graphene sheets are produced (along with other flakes) when graphite is rubbed off, for example when drawing lines with a pencil. However, physicists from the University of Manchester and the Institute for Microelectronics Technology, Chernogolovka, Russia were the first to isolate and study graphene (rather than polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons) in 2004. In addition to publications in the scientific journal Science, they also define graphene as Graphene is a name that assigned to a single layer of carbon atoms compacted in a benzene ring structure, and is widely used to describe the properties of many carbon-based materials, including graphite, large fullerene, nanotubes, etc. (For example, carbon nanotubes are usually thought of as graphene sheets rolled into a nanometer-sized cylinder (geometry) | cylinder). Planar graphene itself has been thought to not exist in the free state, being unstable due to the formation of curved structures such as soot, fullerene, and nanotubes. Graphene is by far the most expensive material on Earth, with a sample that could be placed in a human hair costing over $1,000 (Equal to Rp.14,061,891) (April 2008).

Chemistry Astronomy Earth Sciences Health sciences Meteorology or weather science is a branch of atmospheric science that includes atmospheric chemistry and atmospheric physics, with the main focus being on the science of weather forecasting. Studies in this field have been carried out for thousands of years although significant progress was made only in the 18th century. In the 19th century, a major breakthrough occurred after coordinated observations were made across countries. After the development of computers in the mid-20th century, weather forecasting became possible. Meteorological phenomena are weather activities that can be observed and explained by the science of meteorology. These activities are tied to variables in the Earth's atmosphere, such as temperature, air pressure, water vapor, and the interaction gradients of each variable and how they change over time. Spatial differences are studied to determine how weather systems form locally, regionally, and globally and their impacts. Meteorology, climatology, atmospheric physics and atmospheric chemistry are subdisciplines of atmospheric science. Meteorology and hydrology form the interdisciplinary field of hydrometeorology. Meteorology has many applications in various fields, such as military, energy production, transportation, agriculture, and construction. The word "meteorology" comes from the ancient Greek words, metéōros "majestic; high (in the sky)" (from μετα- meta- "above" and ἐωρ eōr "raised") and -λογία -logia "-(o)logy" "knowledge". Weather forecasting is the application of science and technology to predict future atmospheric conditions at a location. Humans have been trying to predict the weather informally since thousands of years ago and formally since the 19th century. Weather forecasts are made by collecting quantitative data about the current state of the atmosphere using scientific understanding of atmospheric processes to project how the atmosphere is changing. In the past, weather forecasting relied heavily on changes in air pressure, current weather conditions, and sky conditions, weather modeling is now used to determine future conditions.

A nebula (from the Latin for "fog"; plural: nebulae or nebulæ, with ligature) is an interstellar cloud of dust, gas, and plasma. Originally nebula was the general name given to all expansive astronomical objects, including galaxies outside the Milky Way (some examples of the old usage survive; for example, the Andromeda Galaxy is sometimes referred to as the Andromeda Nebula). Nebulas are made of many things (and of different kinds). Most nebulae form as emission nebulae. Emission nebulae containing ionized gases are called Region H II. Nebulae like this form when a newly formed star ionizes the gas around it, creating an emission nebula. Examples of Region H II are the Orion Nebula and NGC 604. There are also nebulae formed from Supernova and Nova explosions. The nebula that formed from the supernova is called the Supernova Remnant. An example of a supernova remnant is the Crab Nebula. And the nebula formed from the results of the nova is called the remnants of a nova (Nova Remnant). An example of a nova remnant is GK Persei (otherwise known as Nova Persei 1901). Nebulae are often also formed from stars like the Sun as they are on their way to death, the White dwarf stage. This nebula is known as a planetary nebula. This nebula is formed when a star like the Sun runs out of fuel. This causes the star to continue to grow until finally it blows its stellar wind on a large scale, causing it to lose its mass. The stellar wind then forms a Planetary Nebula and the star becomes a White Dwarf. There are interstellar cloud structures formed from Star Jets, but they usually do not have the status of a Nebula, but can be considered a nebula. It's called the Herbig-haro Object.

Starbucks Corporation is an American coffee company and global coffeehouse chain headquartered in Seattle, Washington. Starbucks is the world's largest coffeehouse company, with 20,336 stores in 61 countries, including 13,123 in the United States, 1,299 in Canada, 977 in Japan, 793 in the United Kingdom, 732 in China, 473 in South Korea, 363 in Mexico, 282 in Taiwan, 204 in the Philippines, 164 in Thailand and 326 in Indonesia. Starbucks sells hot and cold drinks, coffee beans, salads, hot and cold sandwiches, sweet pastries, snacks, and items such as cups and tumblers. Through its Starbucks Entertainment division and the Hear Music brand, the company also markets books, music and films. Many of the company's products are seasonal or specific to the area where the shop is located. Starbucks ice cream and coffee are also sold in the grocery store. Since its founding in 1971 in Seattle as a local roaster and retailer of coffee beans, Starbucks has expanded rapidly. In the 1990s, Starbucks opened a new store every weekday, a step that was continued into the 2000s. The first stores outside the United States or Canada opened in the mid-1990s, and their overseas stores represent one-third of Starbucks stores worldwide. The company plans to open 900 new stores outside the United States in 2009, and has closed 300 stores in the United States since 2008. The first Starbucks store was opened in Seattle, Washington, on March 30, 1971 by three partners: English teacher Jerry Baldwin, history teacher Zev Siegl, and writer Gordon Bowker. The three were inspired by coffee roasting entrepreneur Alfred Peet, whom they knew personally, to sell high-quality coffee beans and equipment.

Originally, the company was intended to be named Pequod after the hunting ship Moby-Dick, but this name was rejected by several co-founders. The company was eventually named after the Pequod's first mate, Starbuck. From 1971–1976, the first Starbucks store opened at 2000 Western Avenue, then relocated to 1912 Pike Place. This company only sells roasted coffee and does not sell coffee drinks. During their first years in operation, they purchased green coffee beans from Peet's, then began buying directly from coffee growers. In 1984, the original owners of Starbucks, led by Jerry Baldwin, acquired Peet's. During the 1980s, total sales of coffee in the United States declined, but sales of specialty coffee increased, forming 10% of the market share in 1989, compared to 3% in in 1983. By 1986, the company had 6 stores in Seattle and had begun selling espresso coffee. In 1987, the original owners sold Starbucks to Howard Schultz who rebranded part of his Il Giornale coffee shops as Starbucks and quickly expanded operations. That same year, Starbucks opened its first stores outside of Seattle in Waterfront Station, Vancouver, British Columbia, and Chicago, Illinois. By 1989 there were 46 stores across the Northwest and Midwest and Starbucks was roasting more than 2,000,000 pounds (910,000 kg) of coffee annually. At the time of its initial public offering in June 1992, Starbucks had 140 stores and revenues of $73.5 million, up from $1.3 million in 1987. The market value was $271 million. The company sold 12% of the company's stock and raised $25 million which would help it increase the number of stores over the next two years. In September 1992, the share price rose 70% to 100 times the previous year's earnings per share.

Steam is the droplets of liquid matter (for example water) in the air (mist) that condenses. In meteorology, visibility (English: visibility) is defined as "the farthest distance at which an object can still be seen clearly". Far or near visibility is determined by how many particles are above the air, the more particles, the shorter the visibility. These particles can be water droplets, dust particles, etc. In English terms, fog (fog) is a cloud that is on the surface of the ground which contains millions of very small water droplets. Fog consists of water droplets, but under certain conditions it can be accompanied by ice crystals. In general, fog is defined as a condition with visibility less than 200 m, and dense fog is a condition with visibility less than 50 m. At sea, the understanding is different. Fog is a condition with a visibility of less than 1000 m, and dense fog is a condition with a visibility of less than 200 m.
