In the English sense, Fog and Mist are both formed by very small water droplets that gather in the air. The difference between the two is in the density of the water droplets. Fog is thicker than mist, because fog contains more water droplets. In a fog, water vapor near the ground condenses and becomes a cloud. This is usually formed because the cold makes water vapor condense and the humidity level is close to 100%. There are several types of fog: Formed by the advection of wet air over a cooler surface. Sometimes the formation of advection fog is strengthened by the cooling of the earth's surface caused by the earth's radiation at night.

Australia, officially the Commonwealth of Australia (English: Commonwealth of Australia), is a country in the southern hemisphere consisting of the mainland of the Australian continent, the Island of Tasmania, and various smaller islands in the Indian Ocean, and the Pacific Ocean. its neighbors are Indonesia, Timor Leste, and Papua New Guinea to the north; Solomon Islands, Vanuatu and New Caledonia in the northeast; and New Zealand in the southeast. Approximately 40,000 years before European settlement in the late 18th century, Australia was settled by Aborigines, who spoke one of 250 language groups. In 1606, European immigrants who came to the Australian continent were Dutch people. However, at the end of the 18th century, the British occupied this continent, and made it a dumping ground for criminals. In the mid-19th century, gold mines were discovered in Australia so that the continent was busy with immigrants. Since then, they have fought for independence to govern Australia on their own, free from British control. Until recently, Australia was part of the British Commonwealth. After being discovered by Dutch explorers in 1606, the eastern half of Australia was recognized as British possession in 1770, and occupation began with the establishment of a penal colony of New South Wales, formally established on 7 February 1788 (although formal ownership was declared only on 26 January 1788). The population grew statically over several decades, and by 1850 most of the continent had been explored, after which five more self-governing Crown Colonies were established. On January 1, 1901, these five colonies became a federation, and the Commonwealth of Australia was created. Since federation, Australia has maintained a stable liberal democratic political system, and is part of a commonwealth realm.

It has a population of 22 million people, of which nearly 60% is centralized or located near the centers of government of the states on the mainland; namely Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide. The nation's capital is Canberra, in the Australian Capital Territory. Nearly 56% of Australia's population lives in Victoria or New South Wales, and nearly 77% live on the east coast of the mainland. As a prosperous developed country, Australia is the 13th largest economy in the world. Australia ranks highly in many comparisons of international performance such as development, quality of life, health care, life expectancy, general education, economic freedom, and protection of civil liberties and political rights. Australia is a member of the United Nations, G-20 major economies, Commonwealth of Nations, ANZUS, AUKUS, Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, Pacific Islands Forum, and World Trade Organization. Latin means south. This country has been colloquially known as Oz since the early 20th century. C 2] Aussie is a colloquial term for "the Australian people/nation". Legends about Terra Australis—a "foreign land in the South"—date from Roman times, and are commonplace in medieval geography, although they are not based on any documented continental knowledge. A subsequent European discovery, the names for the vast landmass of Australia are often referred to as the famous Terra Australis. The earliest documented use of the word Australia in English was in 1625 in "A note of Australia del Espíritu Santo, written by Master Hakluyt", and published by Samuel Purchas in Hakluytus Posthumus, a corruption of the original Spanish name Austrialia del Espíritu Santo for an island in Vanuatu. The Dutch adjective form Australische was used in a Dutch book in Batavia (Jakarta) in 1638, referring to the recently discovered lands to the south.

Taxonomy (from the Greek τάξις taxis meaning "grouping" and νόμος nomos meaning "rules") is the science of grouping things according to certain things. Originally, taxonomy referred only to the categorization of living things. However, in a broader and more general sense, taxonomy can also refer to the categorization of objects or concepts, as well as the principles that underlie this categorization. Many taxonomies have a hierarchical structure, but this is not a requirement. The taxonomy uses a unit known as a taxon (plural: taxa). Higher taxa are more general, while lower taxa are more specific. Taxonomy is different from menonomy, which deals with the categorization of parts of the whole. In biology, taxonomy is also a separate branch of science that studies the classification or systematics of living things. The system used is a two-name nomenclature, known as the binomial nomenclature proposed by Carl von Linne (Latin: Carolus Linnaeus), a Swedish naturalist. He introduced seven hierarchies (levels) to classify living things. The seven hierarchies (which are called taxons) successively from the highest level (general) to the lowest (specific) are: In binomial nomenclature, the name of a species is sufficient only to mention the surname (always starting with a capital letter) and the type designator (always starting with in lowercase) in italics (printed upright if the main text is italicized) or written in underlined. This rule should not be confusing because surnames cannot be the same for other higher taxa levels. Further development of knowledge forced the creation of a new taxon among the six existing ones (using the prefixes 'super-' and 'sub-'). In the branch of soil science (pedology), soil taxonomy is made based on a number of variables that characterize the state of a soil type.

Sultan (Arabic: سلطان, sulṭān) is a title in the Muslim world used to refer to various positions throughout its historical usage. But more often than not, sultan is used to refer to the head of a Muslim monarch who rules over an Islamic state. In modern times, the title sultan is often equated with caliph, although there are some fundamental differences between the two titles. Khalifah is a title for the leader of all Muslims (regardless of being a leader hierarchically or simply symbolically), while the sultan is the ruler of a Muslim country, so he is not the leader of the Muslims who are in his territory. The two titles are often equated, perhaps because the Ottoman rulers held the titles caliph and sultan simultaneously for around four centuries, blurring the boundaries of the roles of the two positions. The sultan is also often equated with the king (ملك, malik). Although both refer to the head of the monarchy, the sultan has Islamic religious connotations in it so that they cannot be completely equated. In international usage, sultan is usually not translated as 'king' in various local languages, but is absorbed as is. Although often identified with a man who is the head of a Muslim monarchy in a Muslim country, the sultan has also been officially used by a woman who is the head of a Muslim monarchy, even though linguistically, the sultan has a female form, namely sultanah. In the Ottoman Empire, sultan was also used not only for the head of state, but also for his relatives, with the man bearing the title before the name and the woman behind the name. Originally, sultan was a noun meaning "strength", "authority", or "leadership", derived from the verb sulṭah (سلطة) meaning "authority" or "power". The sultan's territory was called the sultanate (سلطنة, salṭanah).

In Hebrew, shilton or shaltan (Hebrew: שלטן) means "region of power" or "regime". The female form of the title sultan is sultanah and can be used to refer to a female sultan or the wife of a male sultan. The title of sultan was first given by Caliph Al-Mu'tashim (ruled 833 - 842) from the Abbasid Dynasty to a Turkish Muslim commander named Asynas at-Turki. As a sultan, Asynas at-Turki had great power, but he remained subordinate and subservient to the Caliph al-Mu'tashim. In this period, the sultan played the role of an amir, which is equivalent to the governor and caliph as the head of state and government of a large empire. In its course, the caliphate's political power dwindled and the sultan de facto became independent. Even so, these sultans still acknowledge submission to the caliph symbolically. After Baghdad was destroyed by the Mongol attack in 1258, the political power of the caliph disappeared so that the caliph after this only acted as a leader of the Muslim community completely symbolic, and more in a religious context than a government like the previous period. With such a situation, each sultan officially became the highest leader in his respective territory. Thus, the sultan can be equated with a king or emperor. This situation continued after the caliphate was dissolved in 1924. Currently, the sovereign countries whose head of state bears the title of sultan are Oman and Brunei Darussalam. In addition to being used by rulers from sovereign countries such as the Ottoman and Mamluk Sultanates, sultan is also used for the head of a monarchy whose country is officially subordinate to another country. In eastern Sumatra (the territory of Indonesia before the Dutch colonization), leaders from the Deli Sultanate and the Asahan Sultanate also held the title of sultan, but at the beginning of their establishment, the two countries were under the authority of the Sultanate of Aceh Darussalam.

Bhutan is a small country in South Asia in the form of a Kingdom and is known as the Land of the Thunder Dragon. Its territory is sandwiched between India and China. The country's local name is Druk Yul, which means "Dragon Country". The dragon symbol can be found on the national flag and coat of arms. The government, which was run by absolute monarchy, ended when a new constitution and the election of a prime minister were implemented. King Jigme Singye Wangchuck, who had ruled since 1972, announced he would hold elections in 2008, as well as abdicate. The announcement was made in front of 8,000 yak herders, monks, farmers and rural students on December 18, 2005. The announcement was circulated via the Kuensel daily. Earlier, the king introduced a draft constitution and declared retirement at the age of 65. On this idea, some people disagreed because they were worried that corruption, collusion and nepotism would occur, but in 2006 the king resigned and was replaced by his son. 'Bhutan' may be derived from the Sanskrit word 'Bhu-Uttan भू-उत्थान' which means 'High Land'. In another theory of Sanskritization, 'Bhots-ant भोट-अन्त' means 'tip of Tibet' or 'south of Tibet'. But some Bhutanese call their country 'Druk Yul' and its people 'Drukpa'. The Dzongkha (and Tibetan) name for this land is 'Druk Yul' (Land of the Thunder Dragon). Because of the serenity and virginity of this land and scenery, today Bhutan is sometimes called the last Shangri-La. Historically, Bhutan was known by many names, such as 'Lho Mon' (Southern Land of Darkness), 'Lho Tsendenjong' (Southern Land of Sandalwood), 'Lhomen Khazhi' (Southern Land of Four Destinations), and 'Lho Men Jong' (The Land of Medicinal Plants from the South). Tools, weapons, and stone remains prove that Bhutan was inhabited as early as 2000 BC. Historians have theorized that the state of Lhomon (literally, "southern darkness"), or Monyul ("Dark Land", a reference to the Monpa, the indigenous people of Bhutan) existed between 500 BC and 600 AD. The name Lhomon Tsendenjong (Land of Sandalwood), and Lhomon Khashi, or Southern Mon (land of 4 destinations) have been found in ancient Bhutanese and Tibetan chronicles.

The earliest written account in Bhutan is the passing of the Buddhist holy figure Padmasambhava (also called Guru Rinpoche) in the 8th century. Bhutan's early history is obscure, as most records were destroyed after a fire at Punakha, the ancient capital in 1827. From the 10th century, Bhutan's political development was heavily influenced by its religious history. Various sub-sects of Buddhism arose which were patronized by various Mongolian and Tibetan overlords. After the collapse of the Mongols in the 14th century, these sub-sects vied with each other for supremacy in the political and religious landscape, eventually leading to the rise of the sub-sect Drukpa in the late 16th century. Until the 17th century, Bhutan existed as warring fiefdoms until it was unified by the Tibetan lama and military leader Shabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. To defend his country from occasional Tibetan encroachments, Namgyal built a network of impregnable dzongs (fortresses), and promulgated codes of laws that helped bring local kings under centralized control. Many of those dzongs still exist. After Namgyal's death in 1651, Bhutan fell into anarchy. Taking advantage of the confusion, the Tibetans invaded Bhutan in 1710, and returned in 1730 with the help of the Mongols. Both attacks were thwarted, and an armistice was signed in 1759. In the 18th century, Bhutan attacked and occupied the Kingdom of Cooch Behar in the south. In 1772, Cooch Behar enlisted the British East India Company which assisted them in expelling the Bhutanese, and then in attacking Bhutan itself in 1774. A peace treaty was signed in which Bhutan agreed to withdraw from its borders before 1730. However, the peace was strained, and border fighting with England lasted for the next hundreds of years.

In the sociology of religion, a sect is generally a religious or political group that broke away from a larger group, usually because of disagreements over doctrinal issues. Historically, its usage in Christian religious circles has carried derogatory connotations and usually refers to a movement that adheres to beliefs or teachings that are heretical and which often deviate from orthodox teachings and practices. In the Indian context, sect refers to an organized tradition. The word sect comes from the Latin term secta (from sequi, to follow), which means (1) a course or course of life, (2) a code of conduct or basic principles, (3) a school of philosophy or doctrine. Sectarius or sectilis also refers to cutting, but this meaning, contrary to popular opinion, is not related to the etymology of the word. Sectator is a leader or staunch believer. citation needed] Sectarianism is sometimes defined in the sociology of religion as a worldview that emphasizes the unique legitimacy of believers' creeds and practices and that increases tensions with the wider society through their actions building on these practices. -practice that defines its dividing line. Conversely, a religious or political cult also has high tension with the surrounding community, but its beliefs are within the context of that society's context, even though it is new and innovative. While cults are able to impose their norms and ideas on their members, sects usually do not have "members" with strict obligations, but only followers, sympathizers, supporters, or adherents. Mass-based socialist, social-democratic, workers' and communist parties often had their origins in utopian sects, and thus also produced many sects, which broke away from their mass parties. In particular the communist parties from 1919 underwent various schisms, some of which can be called sects of the parentage.

One of the main factors that seems to produce political sects is the strict adherence to a doctrine or idea after its time has passed, or after it has lost any discernible relevance to changing realities. British sociologist Roy Wallis has suggested that sects are characterized by "epistemological authoritarianism": sects have an authoritative locus that can legitimize a heresy. According to Wallis, "sects claim to have a unique and privileged access to truth or salvation and "their staunch adherents usually regard everything outside the boundaries of their collectivity as 'erroneous.'" He contrasts this with cults which he describes as having the hallmark of "epistemological individualism." This means that "a cult has no clear locus of supreme authority outside its individual members." Axel Michaels, an indologist, writes in his book on Hinduism that in the Indian context the word "sect does not denote any schism or an isolated community, but rather an organized tradition, usually founded by a founder who engages in ascetic practices." And according to Michaels, "The Indian sects do not focus on heresy, for there is no center or center demanding make this impossible. Instead, the focus is on adherents and adherents." In European languages ​​other than English the equivalent word for 'sect', such as "sect", "secta", "sect", or "sect", is used to refer to a religious sect. or dangerous politics, in the same sense that people in English-speaking countries use the word cult.In Latin America, this word is often used to refer to any non-Roman Catholic religious group, no matter how large it is, often with the same negative connotations that the English word 'cult' has.

Engineers or technicians (also known as engineers) are people who work in the engineering field, in other words engineers are people who use scientific knowledge to solve practical problems using technology. In Indonesia during the Dutch East Indies colonial administration, the term engineer was used as an academic title (Dutch: ingenieur) for a bachelor in engineering who graduated from a university (openly used by university graduates in the fields of agriculture, forestry, fisheries, sometimes even used by fields of applied science, etc.). However, after the emergence of the Bachelor of Engineering (S.T.) academic title, the title of Engineer (Ir.) is no longer used by tertiary institutions as an academic degree but as a professional title stipulated by the Regulation of the Minister of Education and Culture of the Republic of Indonesia Number 154 of 2014 concerning the Cluster of Science and Technology As well as College Graduate Degrees. The title of Engineer (Ir.) was upgraded to a professional title like the professional titles of doctors (dr.), dentists (drg. ), midwives (Bd.) nurses (Ns. ), pharmacists (Apt. ), accountants (Akt. ), and psychologist (Psi.). In other words, currently not all college graduates with ST degrees are immediately entitled to be called Engineers. Engineer profession is regulated by Law no. 11 of 2014 concerning Engineering states that an engineer is someone who has a professional degree in engineering. To obtain the title of Professional Engineer, one must graduate from the Professional Engineer Program. Requirements to be able to take part in the Engineer Professional Program as referred to in paragraph (1) include: a. bachelor of engineering or applied bachelor of engineering, both domestic and foreign universities graduates who have been equalized; or b. bachelor of education in engineering or bachelor of science which is equivalent to bachelor of engineering or applied bachelor of engineering through an equalization program.

JavaJavanese CultureJavanese Religion in Indonesia Kejawen (Pangestu • Travel • Sapta Darma • Subud • Sumarah • others) Hinduism in Java Buddhism in IndonesiaSanghyang Adi BuddhaAshin Jinarakkhita Spread of Islam in IndonesiaSantriAbanganWali SangaNahdlatul UlamaMuhammadiyah Christianity in IndonesiaMissionary of the Word of AllahGanjur Confucianism Church in the New Order eraConfucianism in the era The Sumarah Reform is one of the ways/methods (of the various ways that exist in the Archipelago) to achieve inner and outer peace, by prostration of surrender in totality to God Almighty/meditation which originally came from Java. This practice is based on developing sensitivity and acceptance through relaxing the body, feelings and mind. The goal is to create space within oneself, mind and solitude, which is needed to achieve a state of serenity to realize one's identity. Sumarah was formed by a man named Raden Ngabei Soekinohartono (Kino) who lived in Wirobrajan, Yogyakarta. One night, on September 8, 1935 he received a revelation in the form of light, and a dialogue took place which the members of the Sumarah Association believed was God Almighty, which contained teachings from Sumarah. From that revelation, Kino began to slowly spread his teachings to those closest to him since 1935. He didn't have the courage to openly build this group because he could be taken away by the Dutch. After the Dutch finally left the country, Kino and some of his followers began to spread their teachings outside of Yogyakarta. It should be noted here that the Sumarah Association develops according to and follows God's guidance or instructions. Until now, there are 7,200 adherents from Sumarah and are spread in many places on the island of Java, especially Madiun and Central Java, such as Semarang. In foreign countries there are already several foreign nationals, in several countries who learn the sumarah method and hold regular meetings to practice prostration.

There are no special rituals performed by Sumarah adherents in worship. If Muslims pray and Christians go to church, then Sumarah adherents will prostrate together in a studio which is used as a place of worship and also meet with adherents who are more closed to themselves. Worship taught in Sumarah is only prostration. However, there are several levels of prostrations performed by followers. The higher the kebatinan level, the easier it will be to get a blank mind which is the way to communicate with God Almighty. Sumarah did not have a book, but the management of the Sumarah Association created a guide containing Kino's thoughts and the elaboration of his revelations. Although it is a sect similar to religion, followers of Sumarah do not want to call this sect a religion. This is done because there are also adherents of Sumarah who are followers of the religion and continue to carry out the two worship services together without any conflict, because in essence sumarah is surrender completely to God. Most of the adherents who still have that religion are interested in worship and also how to get closer to God from Sumarah. Finally, they participate in worship by prostrating and then emptying their minds so they can reach the highest point of spirituality. It needs to be explained and emphasized here that Sumarah is one of the manifestations of the Indonesian Human Divinity Culture, especially Java. So that according to the constitution and applicable laws and regulations, sumarah, like various streams of adherents of belief in God Almighty, is nationally fostered, supervised and is an organization under the Ministry of Education and Culture of the Republic of Indonesia. In Sumarah, there is no known da'wah which is done frontally to recruit members.

Christianitynote 1] is a monotheistic Abrahamic religion based on the life history and teachings of Jesus Christ, which is the essence of this religion. Christianity is the largest religion in the world, with more than 2.5 billion adherents, or around 2.6 billion people or nearly a third of the world's population, who are called "Christians". note 2] Christians believe that Jesus is the Son of God and The Savior of mankind who came as the Messiah as prophesied in the Old Testament Bible. Christian theology is embodied in confessions such as the Confessions of the Apostles and the Confessions of Nicea. These confessions of faith contain statements that Jesus suffered, died, was buried, descended to hell, and rose from the dead, to give eternal life to anyone who believes in him and relies on him to obtain forgiveness for the sins they have committed. These confessions also state that Jesus physically ascended into heaven, where he reigns with God the Father in the fellowship of the Holy Spirit, and that he will return one day to judge the living and the dead, and grant eternal life to his followers. . His incarnation, ministry, crucifixion, and resurrection are often called "gospels", which means "good news". , and the Gospel of John—considered canonical (valid) and made part of the Christian Bible. Christianity is an Abrahamic religion that began as a sect of Second Temple-era Judaism in the middle of the first century of our Common Era. This sect originated in Judea, then spread rapidly to Europe, Syria, Mesopotamia, Anatolia, Transcaucasia, Egypt, Ethiopia and India, and by the end of the 4th century had become the official religion of the Roman Empire.

After the Age of Discovery, Christianity also spread to the Americas, Australasia, Sub-Saharan Africa, and to all corners of the world through missionary work and colonialism. Christianity has played a major role in the formation of Western World Civilization. Throughout its history, Christianity has experienced schisms and theological disputes that have given rise to various churches and denominations. The three largest branches of Christianity in the world are the Catholic Church, the Eastern Orthodox Church, and the major Protestant Christian denominations. The Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church broke off from each other in the East–West Schism in 1054, while Protestant Christians emerged during the 16th century reformation as a breakaway from the Catholic Church. Early Christians who were Jewish by nationality called themselves followers of the way (Greek: τῆς ὁδοῦ, tês hodoû), possibly referring to the passage of Isaiah 40:3, "prepare in the desert the way for the Lord." note 4] Based on the text of the Acts of the Apostles 11:26, the term "Christians" (Greek: Χρῑστῐᾱνός, Krīstiānós) means "followers of Christ", referring to Jesus' disciples, and was first used in the city of Antioch by non-Jews. The term "Christianity" (Greek: Χρῑστῐᾱνισμός, Krīstiānismós) was first used by Ignatius of Antioch in his letters written around 100 AD. There are many different interpretations and views regarding the Bible and the Sacred Traditions which are the foundation of Christianity. Irreconcilable theological differences, as well as a lack of agreement on the main points of the Christian faith, have caused Catholic, Orthodox and Protestant Christians to often not recognize people from certain Christian denominations as fellow Christians. The summary of the doctrinal declarations or expressions of Christian religious beliefs is called the shahada (from the Arabic: الشهادة‎‎, asy-syahadah, which means "testimony") or the credo (from the Latin credo, which means "I believe"); Protestant Christians in Indonesia usually use the term "confession of faith" (a translation of the typical Protestant term in Latin, confessio fidei).

The Republic of Malta, commonly known as Malta, is an island nation in Southern Europe. Malta is located approximately 80 km (50 mi) south of Italy, 284 km (176 mi) east of Tunisia and 333 km (207 mi) north of Libya. Malta, which has an area of ​​only 316 km2 (122 sq mi) and a population of around 450,000, makes it one of the world's smallest and most densely populated countries. Malta is located in the middle of the Mediterranean Sea and consists of five islands, three of which are inhabited, namely Malta, Gozo and Comino. The country's capital city, Valletta, with an area of ​​about 08 km2 (3.1 sq mi), is the smallest capital city in the European Union. Malta has one national language, Maltese, and English as the official language. Malta's strategic location in the middle of the Mediterranean Sea has made Malta important in history. Malta has been used as a naval base, and a series of powers such as Phoenician, Carthaginian, Greek, Roman, Byzantine, Moorish, Norman, Sicilian, Spanish, Order of Saint John, French and English have ruled Malta. In 1942, King George VI of England presented Malta with the Cross of Saint George for that country's bravery during World War II. St George's cross is a symbol that appears on the Maltese national flag. Under the Malta Independence Act passed by the British Parliament in 1964, Malta gained independence from the United Kingdom as a state of the Commonwealth of Nations, which was officially known from 1964 to 1974 as the State of Malta, with Queen Elizabeth II as head of state. . Malta became a republic in 1974 and although Malta is no longer a member of the Commonwealth of Nations, it is still a member of the Commonwealth of Nations.

Malta became a member of the United Nations in 1964, and became a member of the European Union in 2004. In 2008, Malta was included in the Eurozone. Malta has a long history of Christian heritage and the Archdiocese of Malta was declared one of the apostolic succession, because according to the Acts of the Apostles, the Apostle Paul was shipwrecked in "Melita", which the people said was Malta. The official religion in Malta is Catholicism. Malta is renowned as a popular tourist destination especially for Europeans, with a warm climate, various recreational areas and historical and architectural monuments. Some of the famous monuments are three UNESCO World Heritage Sites: Hypogeum Ħal Saflieni, Valletta and seven megalithic temples, some of which are the oldest freestanding structures in the world. Since 1993, Malta has been divided into 68 city councils (local councils), most of the population of Malta is of Italian and Libyan descent, 93.9% (2018) of the total population of Malta adheres to the Roman Catholic Church. The origin of the term Maltese is unclear and modern variations of the word are taken from Maltese. The most common etymology is that the word Maltese comes from the Greek word μέλι, meli, 'honey'. The ancient Greeks named the island Μελίτη (Melitē) which means 'sweet honey', probably because Malta produces its unique honey from a unique species of bee that lives on the island. The Romans later called the island Melita, which can be seen as a Latinization of the Greek word Μελίτη or as an adaptation of the Greek Doric dialect pronunciation of the same word Μελίτη. Other conjectures suggest that the term Malta derives from the Phoenician maleth, a 'sanctuary' or 'harbor' which refers to Malta's many bays. Several other etymologies appear in classical literature, with the term Malta appearing in its present tense in Antoine's Itineraries (Itin.

Parmenides was a philosopher from the Elea School. The meaning of the name Parmenides is "Stable steadfastness", or "Stable appearance". Within the Elean School, Parmenides is the most famous figure. His philosophical thinking was in conflict with Herakleitos because he held that everything "that is" does not change. Parmenides wrote his philosophy in poetic form. There are hundreds of lines of Parmenides' poems that are still preserved today. Parmenides' poem consists of a foreword and two parts. The two sections are respectively entitled "The Way of Truth" and "The Way of Opinion". The preface and the "Way of Truth" are stored in full, namely 111 verses. The second section, "The Way of Knowledge", contains only 42 verses. Parmenides was born in 540 BC and died in 470 BC. He comes from the city of Elea, Southern Italy. He comes from a wealthy and respectable family in Elea. Parmenides also drafted a constitution for Elea. He was a student of Xenophanes, but did not share his teacher's views. Xenophanes' influence on Parmenides was only in the use of poetry in conveying his philosophy. Apart from that, he was also heavily influenced by Ameinias, a member of the Pythagorean school. According to Plato's testimony, Parmenides once visited Socrates in Athens with Zeno, his student. At that time, Socrates was still young while Parmenides was 65 years old. The main essence of the "Way of Truth" is the belief that "only 'that which is' exists". Parmenides does not define what is meant by "that which is", but mentions its properties. According to Parmenides, "that which is" is all-encompassing, does not move places, does not change, and is not destroyed. In addition, "that which is" is also unshakable and undeniable. According to Parmenides, "that which is" is an undeniable truth. If someone denies it, then he will fall into contradiction.

This can be explained through the supposition given by Parmenides. First, one could say that "that which is" does not exist. Second, one could say that "that which is" and "that which is not" exists together. Both of these assumptions are impossible. The first supposition is impossible, because "which is not" cannot be thought of and cannot be spoken of. "That which is not" cannot be thought of and spoken of. The second supposition is the view of Herakleitos. This supposition is also impossible, because the second supposition accepts the first supposition, that "that which is not there" exists, even though the first supposition proves impossible. Thus, the conclusion is "That which is not there" does not exist, so that only "what is" can be said to exist. To better understand Parmenides' thought, the following example can be used. Let's say someone says "God doesn't exist!" Here, God whose existence people deny actually exists, that is to say, he must be accepted as "the one who exists". This is because if that person says "God doesn't exist", then that person has already thought of a concept about God. Only after that, the concept of God that that person thought was refuted by himself by stating "God does not exist". Thus, God as that person thinks "exists" even if only in his own mind. Meanwhile, the rejection of something, surely presupposes that something "exists" so that "that which does not exist" is not possible. Because "that which is" can always be said and thought, in fact Parmenides equates "that which is" with thinking or reason. After arguing about "that which is" as truth, Parmenides also stated the consequences: Parmenides' thought opened a new chapter in the history of Greek philosophy. It can be said that he was the founder of metaphysics, the branch of philosophy which investigates "that which is".

Sugar is a simple carbohydrate which is a source of energy and the main trade commodity. Most traded sugar is in the form of solid sucrose crystals. Sugar is used to change the taste to sweet and the state of food or drink. Simple sugars, such as glucose (which is produced from sucrose by enzyme or acid hydrolysis), store energy for use by cells. Sugar as sucrose is obtained from sap, sugar cane, sugar beet, or palm sugar. However, there are other minor sources of sugar, such as coconut. Other sources of sweeteners, such as dahlia tubers, grapes, or corn kernels, also produce some sweeteners but are not composed of sucrose as the main component. The process to produce sugar includes an extraction (squeezing) step followed by purification through distillation (refining). The biggest sugar producing countries are countries with warm climates such as Australia, Brazil and Thailand. The Dutch East Indies (now Indonesia) was once the world's main sugar producer in the 1930s, but was soon eclipsed by a new, more efficient sugar industry. In 2001/2002 sugar produced in developing countries was twice as much as sugar produced in developed countries. The biggest sugar producers are Latin America, Caribbean countries, and East Asian countries. Unlike beet sugar, which is produced in cooler climates such as Northwestern and Eastern Europe, northern Japan, and some areas of the United States, the beet-growing season ends with harvest in September. Harvesting and processing continues into March in some cases. The length of time for harvesting and processing is influenced by the availability of plants and the weather. Harvested beets can be stored for further processing, but frozen beets can no longer be processed. The biggest importer of sugar is the European Union (EU).

Agricultural regulations in the EU stipulate maximum quotas of production from each member according to demand, supply and price. Part of this sugar is "quota" sugar from the levees industry, the rest is "quota c" sugar which is sold at market prices without subsidies. These subsidies and high import taxes make it difficult for other countries to export to EU countries, or compete with them on world markets. The United States charges high sugar prices to support manufacturers, this has a side effect however, many consumers are switching to corn syrup (beverage makers) or moving out of the country (candy makers) The sugar market is also being hit by cheap glucose syrup prices. This syrup is produced from corn (maizena). By combining it with artificial sweeteners, drink makers can produce goods at very low prices. Since ancient times, sources of sugar in Indonesia have been coconut or palm flower liquid (sap), as well as sugarcane juice. Sugarcane is a native plant from the archipelago, especially in the eastern part. When the Dutch started to open colonies in Java, monoculture sugarcane gardens were opened by landlords in the 17th century, first around Batavia, then expanding eastwards. The heyday of sugarcane plantations was reached in the early 1930s, with 179 processing plants and the production of three million tonnes of sugar per year. The decline in sugar prices due to the economic crisis eroded this industry and by the end of the decade there were only 35 factories left with a production of 500 thousand tons of sugar per year. The situation recovered somewhat before the Pacific War, with 93 mills and a production of 1.5 million tons. After World War II, 30 active factories remained. The 1950s saw renewed activity so that Indonesia became a net exporter.

The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (English: North Atlantic Treaty Organization, NATO; French: Organization du traité de l'Atlantique nord, OTAN) or also known as the North Atlantic Defense Organization, is a military alliance organization between many countries consisting of 2 countries. in North America, 29 European countries, and 1 Eurasian country which aims for common security which was established in 1949, as a form of support for the North Atlantic Agreement which was signed in Washington, DC on April 4, 1949. NATO initially aimed to suppress the influence of communist ideology of the Soviet Union and its allies, namely the Warsaw Pact during the Cold War era. The main article of the agreement is Article V, which reads: This article applies if a member of the Warsaw Pact launches an attack on the European allies of the United Nations, this will be considered as an attack on all members (including the United States itself), which has the largest military power in the world. alliance and thereby can provide the greatest retaliatory action. But fears of a possible attack from Western Europe did not materialize. This article was only used for the first time in history on September 12, 2001, as a response to the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks on the US that occurred the day before. But since the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact and the breakup of the Soviet Union, they formed a successor organization to the Warsaw Pact, namely to compensate for NATO named CSTO or its abbreviation, namely the Collective Security Treaty Organization (English: Collective Security Treaty Organization), which was joined by several former Soviet Union fractional states and several former vassal state of the Warsaw Pact Organization. On March 4, 1947, the Treaty of Dunkirk was signed by France and Britain as the Treaty of Alliance and Mutual Assistance in the event of a possible attack by Germany or the Soviet Union following World War II.

In 1948, this alliance was expanded to include the Benelux countries, in the form of the Western Union, also known as the Brussels Treaty Organization (BTO), which was established under the Brussels Agreement signed by the United Kingdom, France, and the Benelux members. Talks for a new military alliance, which could also include North America, resulted in the signing of the North Atlantic Treaty on April 4, 1949 by the member states of the Western Union plus the United States, Canada, Portugal, Italy, Norway, Denmark, and Iceland. In 1952, the post of Secretary General of NATO was established as the head of a civilian organization. That year was also the first major NATO maritime exercise, Exercise Mainbrace and the accession of Greece and Turkey to the organization. Following the London and Paris Conferences, West Germany was allowed to rearm militarily, when they joined NATO in May 1955, which in turn, was a major factor in the formation of the Soviet-dominated Warsaw Pact, which defined the two opposing sides of the Cold War. In 1982, newly democratic Spain joined the alliance. The 1989 revolutions in Europe caused NATO to reevaluate its strategic goals, nature, tasks and focus on the continent. In October 1990, East Germany became part of the Federal Republic of Germany, and in November 1990, the alliance signed the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe (CFE) in Paris with the Soviet Union. The treaty mandated specific continent-wide military reductions, which continued after the collapse of the Warsaw Pact in February 1991 and the collapse of the Soviet Union in December of the same year, eliminating NATO's main de facto enemy. This marked the beginning of the withdrawal of military personnel and equipment in Europe. The CFE agreement allowed signatories to phase out 52,000 pieces of conventional weaponry in the next sixteen years, and allowed military spending by European NATO members to decline by 28% from 1990 to 2015.

–  in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union   (light blue) Seychelles or Seiselensa (/seɪˈʃɛlz/ ( listen) say-SHELZ; French: sɛʃɛl]), Officially the Republic of Seychelles (French: République des Seychelles; Creole: Republic of Sesel), is an island nation that includes an archipelago of 115 islands in the Indian Ocean in the Indian Ocean, about 1,600 km east of the African mainland, and northeast of Madagascar. The neighboring countries and territories are Mauritius and Reunion to the south, Comoros and Mayotte to the southwest, and the Maldives to the northeast. Seychelles, with an estimated population of 86,525, has the smallest population in Africa. Seychelles is part of the Mascarene Islands along with Mauritius, and Reunion. Austronesian sailors and Arab traders were the first to visit the Seychelles. The earliest recorded sighting by a European was in 1502 by the Portuguese sailor Vasco da Gama, passing through Amirantes. A transit point for trade between Africa and Asia, the islands were occasionally used by pirates until the French began to take control from 1756 when Captain Nicholas Morphey laid the stone of ownership. The islands are named after Jean Moreau de Séchelles, King Louis XV's finance minister. The British took control of the islands between 1794 and 1810. Jean Baptiste Quéau de Quincy, French administrator for the Seychelles during the years of war with Britain, refused to offer resistance when armed enemy warships arrived. Instead, he successfully negotiated a capitulation status to Britain which gave the settlers a privileged position of neutrality. Great Britain finally assumed full control upon the surrender of Mauritius in 1810, formalized in 1814 in the Treaty of Paris. Seychelles became a separate crown colony from Mauritius in 1903. Elections were held in 1966 and 1970.

Independence was granted in 1976 as a republic. In 1977, a coup overthrew the republic's first president, James Mancham, who was replaced by France Albert René, a politician of French descent. An island nation, Seychelles is located northeast of Madagascar and about 1,600 km (994 mi) east of Kenya. The number of islands in the Seychelles is often referred to as 115 but the Constitution of the Republic of Seychelles lists 155 islands. The islands according to the constitution are divided into various groups as follows. There are 42 granite islands, in order of size: Mahé, Praslin, Silhouette Island, La Digue, Curieuse, Felicite, Frégate, Ste-Anne, North, Cerf, Marianne, Grand Sœur, Thérèse, Aride, Conception, Petite Sœur, Cousin, Cousine , Long, Récif, Round (Praslin), Anonyme, Mamelles, Moyenne, Île aux Vaches Marines, L'Islette, Beacon (Île Sèche), Cachée, Cocos, Round (Mahé), L'Ilot Frégate, Booby, Chauve Souris ( Mahé), Chauve Souris (Praslin), Île La Fouche, Hodoul, L'Ilot, Rat, Souris, St. Pierre (Praslin), Zavé, Harrison Rocks (Grand Rocher). There are two coral sand cays to the north of the granite: Denis and Bird. There are two atolls south of the granite: Coëtivy and Platte. There are 29 atolls in the Amirantes group, west of the granitics: Desroches, Poivre Atoll (consisting of three islands-Poivre, Florentin and South Island), Alphonse, D'Arros, St Joseph Atoll (consisting of 14 islands-St Joseph. Île aux Fouquets, Resources, Petit Carcassaye, Grand Carcassaye, Benjamin, Bancs Ferrari, Chiens, Pelicans, Vars, Île Paulus, Banc de Sable, Banc aux Cocos and Île aux Poules), Marie Louise, Desnoeufs, Bank of Africa (which consists of two African islands Bank and South Island), Rémire, St François, Boudeuse, Etoile, Bijoutier. There are 13 atolls in the Farquhar Group, south-southwest of the Amirantes: Farquhar Atoll (which consists of 10 islands-Bancs de Sable Déposés Île aux Goëlettes Lapins Île du Milieu North Manaha South Manaha Central Manaha North Island and South Island), Providence Atoll (consisting of two islands-Providence and Bancs Providence) and St. Pierre.

D.? belgicus (Newberry) 1873D. denisoni (Kulczycki) 1957D. marsaisi Lehmann, 1956D. magnificus (Hussakof & Bryant) 1919D. missouriensis (Branson) 1914D. newberryi (Clarke) 1885D. amblyodoratus Carr & Hlavin, 2010 Dunkleosteus meaning 'one dunkle bone' in honor of its discoverer, Dr. David Dunkle from the United States, is one of the largest placoderms of all time and one of the strongest carnivorous fish in the world. Dunkleosteus originated in the United States in Devonian times and lived in temperate and deep waters rich in prey such as amphibians, crustaceans, molluscs and even other fish. Dunkleosteus is one of the largest predatory fish on Earth. They can grow to around 5-9 meters in length and weigh 4-6 tonnes, larger than the Great White Sharks from South Africa and Australia which are now recognized as the largest predatory fish. This size was large for the fish of its time, even Dunkleosteus was the largest animal of its time. This fish has bones similar to sharks, but there is a shield of bone plates that cover and protect the head up to part of the back, gills and chest. This shield makes Dunkleosteus difficult to attack on vital parts. Its eyes are protected by circular bony ridges and what is most striking is that this fish has no teeth. In its place were several sharp bone blades like a very sharp axe, which would interlock when the mouth was closed. The blades of these bones sharpen each other when they are adrift, keeping them sharp and never dull. Dunkleosteus is described as a brutal predator who attacked almost anything smaller than his body. This fish goes not too fast because it is heavy-but strong. It can open its jaws by pulling back, causing a powerful suction force that pulls objects in front of it, then cuts the prey's body in half with the bony blade in its mouth.

Nigeria, officially the Federal Republic of Nigeria is a sovereign country in West Africa bordered by Benin to the west, Chad and Cameroon to the east and Niger to the north. The south coast of the country is on the Gulf of Guinea in the Atlantic Ocean. Nigeria is a country in the form of a federal republic consisting of 36 states, as well as the Federal Capital Territory which is the location of the national capital of Abuja. On Christmas Day, 25 December 2011, Nigeria was rocked by a bloody incident. As many as 40 people were killed by a bomb that hit a church near the Nigerian capital, Abuja, including one perpetrator and three policemen. The bomb exploded just before Christmas. The militant group led by Boko Haram said it was responsible for the incident. Nigeria is divided into 36 states and one Federal Capital Territory, which is further divided into 774 Local Government Areas. The multiplicity of states, of which only three are independent, reflects the country's tumultuous history and the difficulty of managing with heterogeneous national entities at the government level. State: Federal Capital Territory: Abuja <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;<div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px ;line-height:0;<div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0; Religion in Nigeria (2018) Around 51.7% of Nigerians are Muslim and 43.5% are Christian With Christian denominations: Protestant (35%), Catholic (7.5%), Eastern Orthodox (1%) With Schools of Islam: Sunni (41.2%), Shia (9.2%), Ahmadiyya (1.3%) Nigerians provide free education supported by the government, but attendance is not mandatory at some levels, and for certain groups, such as migrants and the disabled, secondary school attendance rates are 32 percent for males and 27 percent for females.

The Republic of Ecuador is a country in northwestern South America, bordered by Colombia to the north, Peru to the east and south, and the Pacific Ocean to the west. This country also includes the Galapagos Islands in the Pacific, about 965 km west of the mainland. Ecuador is located on the equator (Ecuador is Spanish for "equator") and has an area of ​​272,045 km². The country is also one of only two countries in South America that do not share a border with Brazil, besides Chile. Quito is the capital city of Ecuador. The Republic of Ecuador was one of three countries that emerged from the fall of Gran Colombia in 1830 (the others being Colombia and Venezuela). The country of Ecuador of origin was part of the Inca Empire in the 15th century. Atahualpa the son of the Inka government named Huayna Capac was born in Quito. But he did not receive government power from the Inca government. Huascar, on the other hand, was born in Cusco, which was the capital of the Inca Empire. The Inca Empire was divided into 2 parts, namely Atahualpa with Quito as its capital and Huascar with Cusco as its capital. Then a Spanish sailor named Francisco Pizarro arrived in the Inca Empire and civil war began. Atahualpa agreed to accept Spanish help against Huascar onwards. Through trickery, the Spanish gained control of the port in Cajamarca, and captured Atahualpa during the Battle of Cajamarca and held him ransom and demanded a sum of gold for his release. While still in custody, Atahualpa planned the assassination of his older brother Huascar in Cusco. Then Spain succeeded in taking control of the Inca Empire. The Spanish army had paid for all the cannon of the Incan Empire army and a colony was built as a center of government located in Peru. All natives were forced to become forced laborers for this landlord of Spanish descent.

In 1563, Quito had representatives in Spain and parts of Peru appointed Governor/Wuzurai. Its capital is in the present-day city of Lima. Nearly 300 years of Spanish colonization, Quito had a population of 10,000 and in 1822 Ecuador joined Simón Bolívar to form the Greater Republic of Colombia. Then Ecuador split in 1830. In the 19th century Gabriel Garcia Moreno formed this country in 1860 with the help of the Roman Catholic Church. In the late 1800s demand for cocoa suddenly increased worldwide and became Ecuador's main export, inviting many inhabitants from the highlands to the coast to become workers on the fields of these Spanish landlords. The 1895 revolution led by Eloy Alfaro reduced government power . A military usurpation took effect in 1925. The 1930s and 1940s were ruled by José María Velasco Ibarra. Between 1904 and 1942, Ecuador lost territory in a series of conflicts with its neighbours. In 1941 a territorial conflict started between Ecuador and Peru. In July 1941, 11,681 Peruvian soldiers fought an Ecuadorian army of 5,300 men in the south. On July 5, 1941 the Peruvian army crossed the Zarumilla River in Ecuador. On July 23, 1941, the Peruvian army once again crossed the Zarumilla River and entered El Oro territory. Then control the Loja area. Peru sealed the Port of Guayaquil and sealed supplies to Ecuador's troops. Under pressure from the United States and several Latin American countries, Peru and Ecuador signed the Rio Protocol on January 29, 1942 in an effort to deal with the Axis Powers during the Second World War. Several territories have been ceded to Peru. See Paquisha Incident and Cenepa War. In the 1960s foreign workers built the oil industry in the Cuadorian Amazon region. The Andean community laid an oil pipeline from the east to the port and made Ecuador the second largest oil producer in South America. In the 1960s the military junta staged a power struggle.

Male or male is a term for the human sex which is equivalent to male for animals. Males have reproductive organs such as the testicles and penis, and are capable of producing gamete cells called sperm cells. Secondary sex characteristics that are unique to humans such as the appearance of the Adam's apple and facial hair (such as a mustache and beard). The term "male" is generally used for people of all ages. The general term for adults of the male sex is called a man. Meanwhile, the terms for children who are male are called "boys", "boys", or "jaka". A more polite greeting or address for respected or older men is "father", or other greetings according to the local language of each region. The opposite sex of a man is a woman. Men have various sexual characteristics that distinguish them from women. The male genital organs which are part of the reproductive system consist of the penis, testicles, vas deferens and other spermatic cords, as well as the prostate gland. The male reproductive system functions primarily to produce and ejaculate semen which contains sperm. Sperm that are ejaculated during intercourse then enter the female genital organs. In contrast to women, most male genitals protrude from the body, although some are hidden inside the body, for example the prostate gland. Secondary sex characteristics that generally appear in postpubertal males are the appearance of an Adam's apple on the neck and thick hair on the face, arms, legs, and around the genitals. Humans of the male sex generally have a sex chromosome 46/XY. Many men do not have any of the male physiological characteristics mentioned above, and a small number of people who are identified as "male" have genetic sexual abnormalities, for example abnormalities in their sex chromosomes, hormonal disorders, or genetic diseases others (such as androgen insensitivity syndrome); or have a disorder that makes it intersex.

Philosophy (from the Greek word φιλοσοφία,philosophy, meaning "love of wisdom" ) is the study of general and fundamental questions, such as questions of existence, reason, values, reason, and language. This term is probably first used by Pythagoras (c. 570–495SM). The methods used in philosophy include asking questions, critical discussion, dialectics, and systematic presentations. Classical philosophical questions include: Is it possible to know everything and prove it? What's the most real? Philosophers also ask more practical and concrete questions such as: Is there a best way to live? Is it better to be fair or unfair (if one can get away with it)? Do humans have free will? Historically, philosophy encompasses the core of all knowledge. From the time of Ancient Greek philosophers such as Aristotle until the 19th century, natural philosophy encompassed astronomy, medicine, and physics. For example, Newton's Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy in 1687 is later classified as a physics book. In the 19th century, the development of modern university research ushered in professionalized and specialized academic philosophy and other disciplines. In the modern era, several investigations that were traditionally part of philosophy have become separate academic disciplines, some of which are psychology, sociology, linguistics, and economics. Other investigations closely related to art, science, politics and several other fields remained part of philosophy. For example, is beauty objective or subjective? Are there many scientific methods or is there only one? Is political utopia a hopeful dream or a vain delusion? The main sub-fields of academic philosophy include metaphysics (dealing with the nature of reality and being), epistemology (concerning "the origins and fields of knowledge and] ... their limits and validity" ), ethics, aesthetics, political philosophy, logic, philosophy of science , and the history of western philosophy.

Since the 20th century, professional philosophers have contributed to society primarily as professors, researchers, and writers. However, many of those who study philosophy in undergraduate or postgraduate programs contribute to the fields of law, journalism, politics, religion, science, business and various arts and entertainment activities. The word philosophy or philosophy in Indonesian is an absorption word from Arabic: فلسفة‎, which is also taken from Greek; Φιλοσοφία philosophia. In this language, this word is a compound word, and comes from the words (philia = friendship, love, etc.) and (sophia = wisdom, س** ایرانی citation needed], so its literal meaning is a "lover of wisdom". which is taken from the Dutch language is also known in Indonesia. This last form is more similar to the original. In Indonesian a person who studies philosophy is called a "philosopher". knowledge. In this sense, philosophy is closely related to religion, mathematics, natural science, education, and politics. "Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy", Newton's work in 1687 was classified in the 2000s as a physics book; he used the term "philosophy nature" because the term was used to cover disciplines later associated with science such as astronomy, medicine, and physics. In classical times, Philosophy t is traditionally divided into three main branches: This division is not obsolete but has changed. Natural philosophy has divided into various natural sciences, especially astronomy, physics, chemistry, biology, and cosmology. Moral philosophy has given birth to the social sciences, but still includes value theory (including aesthetics, ethics, political philosophy, etc.). Metaphysical philosophy has given birth to formal sciences such as logic, mathematics and philosophy of science, but still includes epistemology, cosmology and others.

Praseodymium is a chemical element with the symbol Pr and atomic number 59. It is the third member in the lanthanide series and is considered one of the rare earth metals. It is a soft, silvery, malleable and ductile metal, valued for its magnetic, electrical, chemical, and optical properties. It is too reactive to be found in its native form, and pure praseodymium metal slowly develops a green oxide layer when exposed to air. Praseodymium always occurs naturally along with other rare earth metals. It is the sixth most abundant rare earth element and the fourth most abundant lanthanide, making up 9.1 parts per million of the Earth's crust, an abundance similar to boron. In 1841, Swedish chemist Carl Gustav Mosander extracted a rare earth oxide residue he called didymium from a residue he called "lantana", which in turn separated from cerium salts. In 1885, Austrian chemist Baron Carl Auer von Welsbach separated didymium into two elements giving salts of different colors, which he named praseodymium and neodymium. The name praseodymium comes from the Ancient Greek πράσινος (prasinos), meaning 'green lilac', and δίδυμος (didymos) 'twin'. Like most rare earth elements, praseodymium most readily forms an oxidation number of +3, which is the only stable state in aqueous solution, although an oxidation number of +4 is known in some solid compounds and, uniquely among the lanthanides, an oxidation number of +5 can be reached in matrix isolation conditions. Oxidation numbers 0, +1, and +2 are rare. Aqueous praseodymium ions are yellowish-green in color, and similarly, praseodymium gives various yellow-green tones when it is placed in glass. The many uses of praseodymium in industry involve its ability to filter out yellow light from light sources.

Praseodymium is the third member of the lanthanide series, and also a member of the rare earth metals. In the periodic table, it appears among the other lanthanides, namely to the left of cerium and to the right of neodymium, and above the actinide protactinium. It is a ductile metal with a hardness comparable to silver. Its 59 electrons are arranged in the Xe]4f36s2 configuration; Theoretically, the five outermost electrons can act as valence electrons, but their use requires extreme conditions and typically, praseodymium releases only three or occasionally four electrons in its compounds. Like most of the other metals in the lanthanide series, praseodymium usually only uses three electrons as valence electrons, because after that the remaining 4f electrons are too tightly bound: this is because the 4f orbital penetrates most of the xenon's inert electrons into its core, followed by 5d and 6s, and this increases with higher ionic charge. However, praseodymium can continue to lose its fourth and sometimes even fifth valence electron because it arrives very early in the lanthanide series, where the nuclear charge is still low enough and the energy of the 4f subshell is high enough to allow further loss of valence electrons. Thus, similar to the other early trivalent lanthanides, praseodymium has a crystal structure of double hexagon solid arrangement at room temperature. At about 560 °C, it transitions to a face-centered cubic structure, and a body-centered cubic structure appears just before its melting point, 935 °C. Praseodymium, like all the other lanthanides (except lanthanum, ytterbium, and lutetium, which lack an unpaired 4f electron), is paramagnetic at room temperature. Unlike some other rare earth metals, which exhibit antiferromagnetism or ferromagnetism at low temperatures, praseodymium is paramagnetic at all temperatures above 1 K. Praseodymium has only one stable and naturally occurring isotope, 141Pr.

Capra depressa Linnaeus, 1758Capra mambrica Linnaeus, 1758 Domestic goat (Capra aegagrus hircus) is a goat subspecies that is kept or domesticated from wild goats in Southwest Asia and Eastern Europe. Goats are members of the Bovidae family and are related to sheep because they both belong to the Caprinae sub-family. There are more than 300 different types of goats. Goats are one of the longest-lived species, for milk, meat, fur and skin, worldwide. In 2011, the worldwide population of goats was 924 million according to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. Goats are medium-sized ruminants. Livestock goat (Capra aegagrus hircus) is a subspecies of wild goat that is naturally distributed in Southwest Asia (the "fertile crescent" and Turkey) and Europe. Both male and female wild goats have a pair of horns, but the male goat's horns are larger. Generally, goats have a beard, a convex forehead, a slightly upturned tail, and mostly straight, coarse hair. The body length of wild goats, excluding the tail, is 1.3 meters - 1.4 meters, while the tail is 12 centimeters - 15 centimeters. The female goat weighs 50 kilograms - 55 kilograms, while the male goat can reach 120 kilograms. Wild goats range from Spain eastward to India, and from India northward to Mongolia and Siberia. Its preferred habitat is rocky mountainous areas. Goats have been cultivated by humans approximately 8000 to 9000 years ago. Usually, goats live in groups of 5 to 20 individuals. In his wanderings looking for food, this group of goats is led by the oldest female goat. While the male goats play a role in keeping the herd safe.

Active time looking for food day or night. Its main food is grass and leaves. Goats are different from sheep. Goats are the earliest animals bred by humans. Recent genetic analyzes confirm archeological evidence that the desert goat Bezoar of Zagros is thought to be the origin of nearly all domesticated goats today. Neolithic farmers began herding wild goats primarily for easy access to milk and meat, as well as dung used as fuel, bones, hair and additives for clothing, buildings and tools. Remains of cattle goats dating back 10,000 years have been found in Ganj Dareh, Iran. Goat skeletons can be found in traces of archaeological research at Jericho, Choga Mami Djeitun and Çayönü, proving that goat farming in West Asia existed between 8000 and 9000 years ago. Studies of the DNA evidence postulate 10,000 years ago as the year livestock first appeared. Historically, goat skins were used as containers for water and liquor in the journey and transportation of traded liquor. Goat skin is also used to make parchment. Goats are seen as small livestock compared to large animals such as cows, camels and horses, but larger than micro livestock such as chickens, ducks, rabbits, guinea pigs and bees. Each type of goat has a certain body weight, ranging from 300 pounds (136 kg) for large male goats such as Boers, or 45 to 60 pounds (20–27 kg) for small female goats. Each type can have a variety of sizes due to strain or hereditary abnormalities. Some of the smallest species are miniature breeds such as the African Pygmies which are only 16 to 23 inches (41.5–58.5 cm) at shoulder size at maturity.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark grey)– in the African Union  (light blue) The Kingdom of Eswatini (formerly the Kingdom of Swaziland) is a small, coastless country in southern Africa and is located between South Africa to the west and Mozambique to the east . Artifacts showing human activity dating back to the early Stone Age, around 200,000 years ago, have been found in Eswatini. Prehistoric painting Rock art dating from c. 27,000 years ago, up to the 19th century, it can be found in various places across the country. The region's earliest known inhabitants were the hunter-gatherer Khoisan. They were largely replaced by the Nguni during the great Bantu migration. These people originate from the Great Lakes region of eastern and central Africa. Evidence of agriculture and the use of iron date from around the 4th century. People who speak the ancestral Sotho language and the present-day Nguni language began to settle no later than the 11th century. Swazi settlers, who came to be known as "Ngwane" (or "bakaNgwane") before entering Eswatini, had settled on the banks of the Pongola River. Prior to that, they settled in the Tembe River area near Maputo, in present-day Mozambique. Continuing conflict with the Ndwandwe people pushed them further north, with Ngwane III establishing his capital at Shiselweni in the foothills of the Mhlosheni. Under Sobhuza I, the Ngwane people finally established their capital at Zombodze in the heart of present-day Eswatini. In this process, they conquered and amalgamated the country's long-standing clans known to the Swazis as "Emakhandzambili" (those who were discovered at the front). Eswatini got its name from the king then named Mswati II.

KaNgwane, named for Ngwane III, is an alternative name for Eswatini, the family name whose royal house remains Nkhosi Dlamini. Nkhosi literally means "king". Mswati II was the largest of the warring kings of Eswatini, and he expanded the country's territory to double its current size. The Emakhandzambili clan was originally incorporated into the kingdom with broad autonomy, often including the granting of special rituals and political status. However, their degree of autonomy was drastically limited by Mswati, who attacked and subdued some of them in the 1850s. With his powers, Mswati greatly reduced the influence of "Emakhandzambili" while incorporating more people into his empire either through conquest or by providing them with protection. These people who arrived later became known to the Swazi people as Emafikamuva. The Swazi state autonomy was influenced by British and Dutch rule in southern Africa in the 19th and early 20th centuries. In 1881, the British government signed a convention recognizing the independence of the Swazis, even though the Scramble for Africa was taking place at the time. This independence was also recognized in the London Convention of 1884. Between 1875 and his death in 1889, King Mbandzeni created a complex pattern of land ownership by granting Europeans many concessions. These included grants and leases for farming and grazing. The concessions covered most of the Mbandzeni kingdom, but most of it reserved for the king his rights as sovereign and did not allow the holders to encroach on the rights of the Swazi living in the land. In 1890, after Mbandzeni's death, the Swaziland Convention created a Court of Appeal to decide disputes over controversial land and mineral rights and other concessions. Swaziland was granted triumviral administration in 1890, representing Britain, the Dutch republic, and the Swazi people.

Ethanol, also known as ethyl alcohol, pure alcohol, absolute alcohol, or alcohol, is a volatile, flammable, colorless liquid and is the alcohol most commonly used in everyday life. This compound is a psychoactive drug and can be found in alcoholic beverages and modern thermometers. Ethanol is one of the oldest recreational drugs. Ethanol is included in the single-chain alcohol, with the chemical formula C2H5OH and the empirical formula C2H6O. Ethanol is a constitutional isomer of dimethyl ether. Ethanol is often shortened to EtOH, where "Et" stands for the ethyl group (C2H5). The fermentation of sugar into ethanol is one of the earliest organic reactions ever carried out by humans. The intoxicating effects of ethanol consumption have also been known for a long time. In modern times, ethanol intended for industrial use is often produced from ethylene. Ethanol is widely used as a solvent for various chemicals intended for human consumption and use. Examples include perfumes, flavourings, food coloring and pharmaceuticals. In chemistry, ethanol is an important solvent as well as a feed stock for the synthesis of other chemical compounds. In its history, ethanol has long been used as a fuel. Ethanol has been used by humans since prehistoric times as an intoxicant in alcoholic beverages. Residues found on ceramic remains dating back 9000 years from northern China indicate that alcoholic beverages were used by prehistoric humans from the Neolithic period. Ethanol and alcohol form an azeotropic solution. Therefore purification of ethanol containing water by means of ordinary distillation is only capable of producing ethanol with a purity of 96%. Pure (absolute) ethanol was produced for the first time in 1796 by Johan Tobias Lowitz by filtering the distilled alcohol through charcoal.

Lavoisier described that ethanol is a compound formed from carbon, hydrogen and oxygen. In 1808 Saussure succeeded in determining the chemical formula for ethanol. Fifty years later (1858), Couper published the chemical formula for ethanol. Thus ethanol is one of the chemical compounds whose chemical formula was first discovered. Ethanol was first made synthetically in 1826 independently by Henry Hennel of Great Britain and S.G. Sérullas from France. In 1828, Michael Faraday succeeded in making ethanol from the acid-catalyzed hydration of ethylene. This process is similar to the modern industrial ethanol synthesis process. Ethanol has been used as a lamp fuel in the United States since 1840, but taxes imposed on industrial alcohol during the American Civil War made its use uneconomical. This tax was abolished in 1906, and since 1908 Ford Model T automobiles could be run on ethanol. However, with Prohibition of Alcoholic Beverages in the 1920s, ethanol fuel sellers were accused of conspiring with producers of illegal spirits, and ethanol fuel was abandoned until the late 20th century. Ethanol is a colorless volatile liquid with a characteristic odor. It burns smokelessly with a blue flame that is sometimes invisible in ordinary light. The physical properties of ethanol are mainly influenced by the presence of hydroxyl groups and the shortness of the ethanol carbon chains. The hydroxyl groups can participate in hydrogen bonds, making them liquid and more difficult to evaporate than other organic compounds of the same molecular mass. Ethanol is a versatile solvent, soluble in water and other organic solvents, including acetic acid, acetone, benzene, carbon tetrachloride, chloroform, diethyl ether, ethylene glycol, glycerol, nitromethane, pyridine, and toluene.

Arianism is a non-trinitarian Christology doctrine that holds that Jesus Christ is the Son of God, begotten by God the Father, and is different from God the Father to the point of being inferior to God, and that the Son of God is also God the Son but not as eternal as God the Father. Arian theology was first thought to originate from Arius (ca. 256–336 AD), a presbyter in the city of Alexandria, Egypt. The term Arians comes from the name Arius, and (just like the term Christians) is not a term they use to refer to themselves, but a term from outsiders. The teachings of Arius and his supporters regarding the nature of the Trinity and the nature of Christ are in fact contrary to the theological views held by Homoousian Christians. The Arian concept of Christ is based on the belief that the Son of God does not always exist, but is begotten in time by God the Father, and therefore Jesus is not as eternal as God the Father. A dispute occurred between the two interpretations (Arianism and Homoousianism) which were both based on the orthodox theology of the time, each trying to solve its theological dilemma. Thus, from the beginning these two equally orthodox interpretations deliberately provoked conflict in order to attract the attention of experts and formulate new orthodox teachings. Homoousianism was officially confirmed as the correct interpretation by the first two Ecumenical Councils. The First Council of Nicaea in 325 declared Arianism a heresy. All major sects in Christianity today consider Arianism to be heterodox and heretical. According to Everett Ferguson, "Most Christians do not really understand the doctrines of the Trinity and do not understand the issues at stake." In the first regional Synod of Tire in 335, Arius was found innocent. Constantine the Great was baptized by an Arianist bishop, Eusebius of Nicomedia.

After the deaths of Arius and Constantine, Arius was again anathematized and declared a heretic at the first Council of Constantinople in 381. Emperors Constantius II (337–361) and Emperor Valens (364–378) were either Arianists or Semi-Arians, as were The first king of Italy, Odoacer (433?–493), and the Lombards until the 7th century. The term Arianism is also used as a designation for 4th century anti-Trinitarian theological teachings, which regard Jesus Christ—the Son of God, the Logos—as a begotten being (similar to the teachings of Arianism and Anomoeanism) or as an uncreated being. nor was it created as other creatures were created (as was the case with Semi-Arianism). Arius had been a student of Lucian of Antioch at Lucian's private school at Antioch, and from him he inherited a modified form of Paul's teaching of Samosata. He taught that God the Father and God the Son did not co-exist in eternity from the beginning. The Arians taught that the Logos (Word) was a divine being created by God the Father before the creation of the world, making him the instrument through which all things were created, and that the Son of God was subordinate to God the Father. A verse from the Book of Proverbs is also used by them as a reference: "The LORD has created me as the beginning of His work, as His first work long ago" (Proverbs 8:22). Therefore, the Son is considered more as the first and most perfect creature of God's creation, and is made "God" solely with the permission and power of the Father. The controversy surrounding Arianism arose in the late 3rd century and lasted most of the 4th century. It involved most members of the church—from parishioners, priests, and monks, to bishops, emperors, members of the Roman imperial family. Two Roman emperors, Constantius II and Valens, were either Arians or Semi-Arians, as were the warlords of the Goths, Vandals and Lombards (Lombards), both before and after the fall of the Western Roman Empire.

Afghanistan (Pashtun and Dari: افغانستان, Afghanistan), officially the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan is a country located in South and Central Asia. The country is directly bordered by Pakistan to the east and south, Iran to the west, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan to the north, Tajikistan and China to the northeast. Its area covers 652,000 km² (252,000 sq mi), making it the 41st largest country in the world. Afghanistan has a population of about 31.4 million as of 2020, with a population that includes the Pashtun, Tajik, Hazara and Uzbek ethnic groups. Kabul is the capital and largest city of Afghanistan. Humans have settled in Afghanistan since the Middle Old Stone Age (Paleolithic). Location's proximity to the silk routes linked the country with Europe and other parts of Asia. Throughout the centuries, Afghanistan has been home to many peoples and has been the goal of numerous military campaigns, notably those of Alexander the Great, Mauryans, Muslim Arabs, Mongol Empires, British, Russian Empires, Soviet Union, and the United States. Afghanistan is also the place where the Kushan, White Hun, Samanid, Safarid, Ghaznavid, Gurid, Khilji, Mughal, Hotaki, Durrani and others dynasties have risen to form great empires. The political history of the modern state of Afghanistan begins with the rule of the Hotaki and Durrani Empires in the 18th Century. In the late 19th Century, Afghanistan became a buffer state between the Russian Empire and the British Empire. After the Third Afghan War in 1919, King Amannullah tried to modernize Afghanistan, but failed to do so. Afghanistan became a peaceful country during the forty year reign of Zahir Shah. In the 1970s, a series of coups or forced coups followed by a series of civil wars devastated large parts of Afghanistan. These events began when the country was made a socialist state under the influence of the Soviet Union during the Soviet-Afghan War.

After the Soviet troops left Afghanistan, the country became an Islamic state with the Peshawar Agreement, but most of its territory has been controlled by the Taliban fighters who ruled the country for almost five years by strictly enforcing Islamic Sharia. Since the September 11, 2001 attacks on America, when the Taliban were forced out of Afghanistan by a coalition led. NATO's largest terrorist organization for hiding the whereabouts of the great fighter Osama bin Laden (Founder of Al Qaeda). Afghan politics was replaced with a pro-Western government elected through a democratic process. In 2021, after 20 years of war, US President Joe Biden has decided to withdraw all US troops from Afghanistan. This decision gave room for the Taliban to immediately attack and seize Afghanistan's territories from the control of the central government. After taking control of other provinces, the Taliban managed to enter Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, on August 15, 2021.
