Afghanistan then became an Islamic country that established Islam as the official religion and law. The name Afghanistan comes from the word Afghanistan. The Pashtuns or the largest ethnic group in Afghanistan appear to have started using the term Afghan as a name for themselves from the Islamic period onward. According to W.K. Frazier Tyler, M.C. Gillet, and several other scholars, "The word Afghanistan first appears in history in al-Hudud Alam in 982 AD." There are many views, regarding the origin of the name Afghanistan. Most of them are purely speculative and presumptive as can be seen below: Excavations of a prehistoric site by Louis Dupree and several others have shown that humans lived in what is now Afghanistan at least ± 50,000 years ago, and that agricultural peoples in that area including the oldest in the world.

Arsenic, arsenic, or arsenicum is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol As and atomic number 33. It is a notoriously toxic metalloid material and has three allotropic forms; yellow, black, and gray. Arsenic and arsenic compounds are used as pesticides, herbicides, insecticides and in various alloys. Arsenic has chemical characteristics similar to Phosphorus, and can often be used as a substitute in various biochemical reactions and is also toxic. When heated, arsenic rapidly oxidizes to arsenic oxide, which smells like garlic. Arsenic and some arsenic compounds can also directly sublimate, changing from a solid to a gas without first becoming a liquid. Arsenic is found in two solid forms which are yellow and metallic in color, with specific gravity of 1.97 and 5.73. The word arsenic is borrowed from the Persian زرنيخ Zarnik which means "yellow orpiment". Zarnik is borrowed in Greek as arsenicone. Arsenic has been known and used in Persia and in many other places since ancient times. It was often used to kill, and the symptoms of arsenic poisoning were difficult to explain, until the invention of the Marsh test, a sensitive chemical test for the presence of arsenic. Because it is often used by rulers to get rid of their opponents and because of its extraordinary killing power and difficulty to detect, arsenic is called the Poison of kings, and King of all poisons. In the Bronze Age, arsenic was often used in bronze, which made the alloy harder. Warangan, which is often used as a coating material for keris surfaces, contains the main ingredient arsenic. Arsen evokes the prestige of the keris by emphasizing the contrast on the prestige. In addition, arsenic also increases the lethality of the stabbing weapon. Albertus Magnus is credited with being the first to discover how to isolate this element in 1250.

In 1649 Johan Schroeder published 2 methods of preparing arsenic. The alchemical symbol for arsenic is shown on the right. During Queen Victoria's time in Great Britain, arsenic was mixed with vinegar and lime and eaten by women to improve the appearance of their faces, making their skin lighter to show that they were not working in the fields. Arsenic was also rubbed on women's faces and arms to whiten their skin. However this is highly discouraged now. Some places on earth contain arsenic high enough to seep into groundwater. WHO sets the highest safe threshold for arsenic in groundwater at 50 ppb (parts per billion). Most of the areas with the highest arsenic content are alluvial areas which are river silt deposits and soils rich in organic matter. It is estimated that around 57 million people drink groundwater contaminated with excess arsenic, making it potentially toxic. Arsenic in groundwater is naturally occurring, and is released from sediments into groundwater due to the absence of oxygen in the subsurface layer. This groundwater began to be used after a number of western NGOs researched large well water programs in the late 20th century, but failed to find the presence of arsenic in the groundwater. It is considered to be the worst mass poisoning in history and possibly the worst environmental disaster in history. In Bangladesh there is an epidemic of mass poisoning caused by arsenic. Many other countries in Asia, such as Vietnam, Cambodia, Indonesia and Tibet, are thought to have similar geological environments conducive to producing groundwater containing high levels of arsenic. Plants grown on soil containing arsenic can be absorbed by plants and leave residues in agricultural produce.

Feudalism is a structure of delegation of sociopolitical power (social politics) that is run among the nobility/monarchy to control the various territories they claim through cooperation with local leaders as partners. In the original sense, this structure was embedded by historians in the political system in Europe in the Middle Ages, which placed knights and other noble classes (vassals) as rulers of certain areas or rights (called fiefs or, in Latin, feodum) appointed by monarchy (usually a king or lord). The term feudalism itself has been used since the 17th century and was never used by the actors themselves. Since the 1960s, historians have broadened the use of this term to include aspects of the social life of land workers on land controlled by landlords, giving rise to the term "feudal society". Because the use of the term feudalism has increasingly had a negative connotation, its critics now consider this term not helpful in clarifying the situation and are advised not to use it without clear qualifications. In everyday language use in Indonesia, this word is often used to refer to behaviors similar to those of tyrannical rulers, such as 'old-fashioned', 'always wanting to be respected', or 'holding on to old values ​​that have been many abandoned'. The ninth century in western Europe was a period of turmoil. Charlemagne had for some time created the integration of society that was the result of the invading Germanic peoples, and had united the warring tribes under a centralized government. But Charles magne's empire, as we have learned, did not last long. This empire broke up into several separate kingdoms. Charlemagne's successors in France, Germany, and Italy enjoyed little authority. They rule, but do not rule. During this dark age it was absolutely impossible for a king to rule strictly.

Hammurabi (Akkadian, from Ammu "paternal brother", and Rāpi "a healer"); was the sixth king of the first Babylonian dynasty (r. 1792-1750 B.C.), and he may also have been Amraphel, king of Sinoar according to the Bible (Genesis 14:1). Hammurabi led his armies against Akkadia, Elam, Larsa, Mari and Summeria, bringing the Babylonian Empire almost as large as the ancient Egyptian Empire under the Pharaoh Menes, who had unified Egypt over a thousand years earlier. Although Hammurabi fought many wars conquering other kingdoms, he is more famous because during his reign the first recorded official code (written law) in the world was created, which is known as the Hammurabi Charter (Codex Hammurabi). In 1901, archaeologists discovered the charter while excavating under the ruins of the former ancient city of Susa, Babylon. Hammurabi's charter is engraved on a flattened piece of rock in cuneiform. There are 282 laws in total in the Charter, but 32 of them are fragmented and difficult to read. It contains arrangements for certain criminal acts and their rewards. Some examples of its contents include: Currently, Hammurabi's Charter has been kept and exhibited for the general public at the Louvre Museum in Paris, France. Hammurabi besides being a king, was also a religious leader of the Babylonian people. Thus, Hammurabi's Charter was an official rule enforced by Babylonian society and government. It is thought that in the past the published laws were made into charters (in the form of inscriptions) and shown to the general public for approval. So laws are not made by the government solely to suit its own opinion. In this sense, Hammurabi's Charter can be considered a precursor to the formal legal system as it currently applies to modern society.

Sarawak, popularly known as Bumi Kenyalang (/səˈrɑːwɒk/; Indonesian: saˈrawaʔ]) is a de facto sovereign country that became independent on 22 July 1963, and de jure is also one of the states (now a constituent country) in Malaysia. This state has autonomy in administration, immigration, and judiciary that is different from the states in Peninsular Malaysia. Sarawak is located in the Northwest of Borneo and is bordered by the State of Sabah in the Northeast, West Kalimantan Province, East Kalimantan Province, and North Kalimantan Province in the South, and also meets Brunei in the Northeast. The capital, Kuching, is the economic center of Sarawak State. Sarawak and the seat of the Sarawak state government. Other cities in Sarawak include Miri, Sibu and Bintulu. According to the 2015 census of Malaysia, the state's population is 2,636,000 people. Sarawak has an equatorial climate with tropical rainforests and diverse species of animals and plants. The state has several important cave systems in Gunung Mulu National Park. The Rajang River is the longest river in Malaysia; The Bakun Dam, one of the largest dams in Southeast Asia, is located in one of its tributaries. Mount Murud is the highest point in Sarawak. The earliest human settlement in Sarawak dates back 40,000 years in the Niah Caves. According to whom?] The area had trading links with China in the 8th to 13th centuries AD. The area came under the influence of the Bruneian Empire in the 16th century. The state was ruled by the Brooke family in the 19th and 20th centuries. During World War II, the state was occupied by the Japanese for three years before being created as a British Crown Colony in 1946.

On July 22, 1963, Sarawak achieved self-rule by the British. After that, Sarawak became one of the founding members of the Federation of Malaysia (founded on 16 September 1963) together with North Borneo (Sabah), Singapore (left in 1965), and Federation of Malaysia (Peninsula Malaysia). However, the federation was opposed by Indonesia, and led to the Indonesia–Malaysia Confrontation for three years. The state also experienced a communist rebellion from 1965 to 1968. The area is known for its ethnic, cultural and linguistic diversity. The head of state is the Governor, now known as Yang di-Pertua Negeri, while the head of government is the Chief Minister. The government system follows the Unitary system. The region is divided into districts and administrative divisions. English and Malay are the two official languages ​​in the state; there is no official religion there. The Sarawak State Museum is the oldest museum in Borneo. The area is known for its traditional musical instrument, the sapeh. The World Rainforest Music Festival is one of the premier music events in Borneo. Sarawak has a diversity of natural resources, and its economy is highly export-oriented, especially oil and gas, timber and palm oil. Other industries include manufacturing, energy and tourism. According to the most commonly accepted explanation, the word "Sarawak" comes from the Sarawak Malay language, sarawak, which means antimony. Meanwhile, according to another popular explanation, the word Sarawak is a shortening of four Malay words which are said to have been uttered by Prince Muda Hashim (uncle of the Sultan of Brunei), I surrender to the crew (I leave it to you), when he gave Sarawak to James Brooke in 1841 However, such an explanation is incorrect, as the area was already called Sarawak before Brooke's arrival, and the word "awak" was never in the Sarawak Malay vocabulary prior to the formation of the Malaysian state.

Kyrgyzstan (kir-gi-STAN) is officially the Kyrgyz Republic. Formerly known as Kirghizia, is a landlocked and mountainous country located in Central Asia. Kyrgyzstan is bordered by Kazakhstan to the north, Uzbekistan to the west, Tajikistan to the southwest and China to the east. The capital and largest city is Bishkek. Kyrgyzstan's history spans over 2,000 years. Covers various cultures and kingdoms. Historically Kyrgyzstan was at the crossroads of several major civilizations, namely as part of the Silk Road and other commercial and cultural routes. Kyrgyzstan was under foreign domination and achieved sovereignty as a nation-state after the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991. After independence, Kyrgyzstan has officially become a sovereign country, although ethnic conflicts persist, rebellions, economic problems, transitional governments and political party conflicts. Kyrgyzstan is a member of the Commonwealth of Independent States, Eurasian Economic Union, CSTO, Shanghai Cooperation Organization, Organization of Islamic Cooperation, Turkish Council, TÜRKSOY community and United Nations (UN). Ethnic Kyrgyz make up the majority of the country's 5.7 million people, followed by significant minorities of Uzbeks and Russians. The official language, Kyrgyz, is closely related to other Turkic languages. The majority of the population (64 percent) are non-denominational Muslims. In addition to its Turkic origin, Kyrgyz culture bears elements of Persian, Mongolian and Russian influence. "Kyrgyz" is believed to be derived from the Turkic word "forty", referring to the forty clans of Manas, the legendary heroes who united with the forty regional clans against the Uyghurs. Literally, Kyrgyz means We Are Forty. At that time, in the early 9th century, the Uyghurs dominated parts of Central Asia (including Kyrgyzstan), Mongolia, and parts of Russia and China. The 40 rays of sunshine on the Flag of Kyrgyzstan are a reference to the same forty tribes and the graphic element in the middle of the sun depicts the wooden crown, called bow, of a yurt - a traditional portable dwelling used by nomads in the Central Asian steppes.

The Kyrgyz state achieved its greatest expansion after defeating the Uyghur Khaganate in 840 AD. From the 10th century the Kyrgyz migrated as far as the Tian Shan range and maintained their dominance over this region for around 200 years. By the twelfth century the Kyrgyz power had dwindled to the Altai and the Sayan Mountains as a result of the Mongol expansion. With the emergence of the Mongol Empire in the thirteenth century, Kyrgyz migrated south. The Kyrgyz peaceably became part of the Mongol Empire in 1207. Chinese and Muslim sources from the 7th–12th centuries AD describe the Kyrgyz as red-haired with white skin and blue eyes, which is indicative of ancient Indo-European tribes such as the Slavs. The descent of the Kyrgyz from the original Siberian population is confirmed on the other hand by recent genetic research. Due to processes of migration, conquest, marriage, and assimilation, many of the Kyrgyz people who now inhabit Central and Southwest Asia make them mixed, coming from fragments of various tribes, even though they speak the same language. Issyk Kul Lake was a stopover on the Silk Road, a land route for merchants, traders and other travelers from the East to Europe. the Kyrgyz were invaded in the 17th century by the Oirat Mongols, in the mid-18th century by the Qing dynasty, and in the early 19th century by the Uzbek Khanate of Kokand. At the end of the nineteenth century, the majority part of what is now Kyrgyzstan was ceded to Russia through two treaties between China (later the Qing dynasty) and Russia. The territory, known in Russia as "Kyrgyzians", was formally incorporated into the Russian Empire in 1876. The Russian takeover was met with various rebellions against Tsarist rule, and many Kyrgyz nationals chose to move to the Pamir Mountains and Afghanistan.

Platinum is a chemical element in the periodic table having the symbol Pt and atomic number 78. This gray-white transition metal is dense, malleable, ductile, highly unreactive, and valuable. Its name comes from the Spanish word platinum, which literally translates to "little silver". Platinum is a member of the platinum group elements and is an element in group 10 of the periodic table. It has six naturally occurring isotopes. This metal is one of the rarest elements in the earth's crust with an average abundance of about 5 µg/kg. It occurs in several nickel and copper ores along with several natural deposits, mostly in South Africa, which accounts for 80% of world production. Due to its scarcity in the earth's crust, only a few hundred tons are produced annually, and for its important uses, it is highly valuable and a major precious metal commodity. Platinum is the least reactive metal. Its amazing resistance to corrosion, even at high temperatures, has earned it the title of noble metal. Consequently, platinum is often found as a naturally occurring element. Because it occurs naturally in the alluvial sands of rivers, it was first used by the indigenous people of pre-Columbian South America to make artifacts. European writings refer to the 16th century, but the report of Antonio de Ulloa who published a new metal in Colombia in 1748 became the object of research by scientists. Platinum is used in catalytic converters, laboratory equipment, electrical contacts and electrodes, platinum resistance thermometers, dental equipment, and jewelry. Because it is a heavy metal, platinum has health problems when exposed to its salts, but because of its resistance to corrosion, platinum is not as toxic as some other metals. Compounds containing platinum, such as cisplatin, oxaliplatin and carboplatin, are used in chemotherapy to fight certain types of cancer.

Pure platinum is a silvery-white metal that is lustrous, ductile, and malleable. Platinum is more ductile than gold, silver or copper, making it the most ductile of most pure metals, but less malleable than gold. This metal has excellent resistance to corrosion, is stable at high temperatures and has stable electrical properties. Platinum reacts slowly with oxygen at very high temperatures. This metal reacts violently with fluorine at 500°C (932°F) to form tetrafluoride. The metal is also attacked by chlorine, bromine, iodine and sulfur. Platinum is insoluble in hydrochloric and nitric acids, but dissolves in hot aqua regia to form chloroplatinic acid, H. Its physical properties and chemical stability make it useful for industrial applications. Its resistance to wear and stains makes it suitable for use in jewelry. The most common oxidation states of platinum are +2 and +4. The +1 and +3 oxidation states are less common, and are sometimes stabilized by metallic bonds in bimetallic (or polymetallic) species. As expected, tetracoordinated platinum(II) compounds tend to adopt a 16-electron planar quadrilateral geometry. Although elemental platinum is usually unreactive, it dissolves in hot aqua regia to form chloroplatinic acid (H): As a weak acid, platinum has a great affinity for sulfur, as for dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO); a number of DMSO complexes have been reported and the choice of reaction solvent must be made with great care. Platinum has six naturally occurring isotopes: 190Pt, 192Pt, 194Pt, 195Pt, 196Pt, and 198Pt. The most abundant isotope is 195Pt, composing 33.83% of all platinum. It is the only stable isotope without zero spin; with a spin of ½, the 195Pt satellite peak is frequently observed in 1H and 31P NMR spectroscopy (ie, Pt-phosphine and Pt-alkyl complexes). 190Pt is the least, only 0.01%.

Transnistria, also known as Transdniestria or Trans-Dniester (Russian: Приднестровье, Pridn'estrov'ye; Romanian: Transnistria) officially the Moldavian Republic of Pridnestrovia, is a self-declared state breakaway from Moldova. Transnistria is located between Moldova and Ukraine in Eastern Europe. The name "Transnistria" was inspired by its location east of the Dniester river (Nistru). There are only three countries that recognize the sovereignty of Transnistria, which is unique in that these countries also have limited recognition status, namely Abkhazia, Artsakh, and South Ossetia. The origins of this region can be traced to the Moldovan Soviet Socialist Republic, which was formed in 1924 within the territory of the Ukrainian SSR. During World War II, the Soviet Union took part of the dissolved Moldovan SSR, and Bessarabia from the Kingdom of Romania to form the Moldovan Soviet Socialist Republic in 1940. The territory's current history begins in 1990, during the dissolution of the Soviet Union, when the Moldavian Pridnestrovian SSR was founded with the hope that it would remain within the Soviet Union if Moldova sought unification with Romania or independence, the latter occurring in August 1991. Shortly thereafter, military conflict between the two sides began in March 1992 and ended with an armistice in July of that year. As part of the armistice agreement, the three parties (Russia, Moldova, Transnistria) Joint Control Commission oversees security arrangements in the demilitarized zone, which comprises 20 areas on both sides of the river. Despite the armistice held, the territory's political status remains unresolved: Transnistria is an unrecognized but de facto independent presidential republic with its own government, parliament, military, police, postal system, currency, and license plates. Its authorities have adopted a constitution, flag, anthem and coat of arms.

Following the 2005 agreement between Moldova and Ukraine, all Transnistrian companies wishing to export goods through the Ukrainian border had to be registered with the Moldovan authorities. This agreement was implemented after the European Union Border Assistance Mission for Moldova and Ukraine (EUBAM) entered into force in 2005. Most Transnistrians have Moldovan citizenship, but many also have Russian, Romanian or Ukrainian citizenship. The main ethnic groups are Russians, Moldovans, Romanians and Ukrainians. Transnistria, along with Abkhazia, South Ossetia and Artsakh, is a post-Soviet frozen conflict zone. These four partially recognized countries maintain friendly relations with each other and form a community for democracy and the rights of nations. This region can also be referred to in English as Trans-Dniester or Transdniestria. These names are adapted from the Romanian colloquial name of the region, Transnistria, which means beyond the Dniester River. For the first time, the term Transnistria was used in relation to eastern Moldova in the slogan for the election of a deputy and member of the Moldovan Popular Front, Leonida Lari, in 1989: Let my hands be bloody up to the elbows, but I will drive out invaders, aliens and mankurts over the Dniester. I will drive them out of Transnistria. And you, Romanians, are the real owners of this long-suffering land. You will get their house, their apartment, along with their furniture. We will make them speak Romanian, respecting our language, our culture! Moldovan government documents refer to the region as stînga Nistrului in Moldovan (full name, Unitățile Administrativ-Teritoriale din stînga Nistrului) meaning "left bank of the Dniester" or "left bank Administrative-Territorial Unit of the Dniester". According to the Transnistrian authorities, the name of the state is the Moldavian Republic of Pridnestrovia (Russian: естровская Молдавская Республика, ПМР, Pridnestrovskaya Moldavskaya Respublika; Romanian: Republica Moldovenească Nistreană, RMN).

Satellite is an object orbiting another object with a certain period of revolution and rotation. There are two types of satellites namely natural satellites and artificial satellites. The remainder of this article will revolve around artificial satellites. The first man-made satellite was Sputnik 1, launched by the Soviets on October 4, 1957, and starting the Russian Sputnik Program, with Sergei Korolev as chief design officer and Kerim Kerimov as assistant. This launch sparked a space race between the Soviets and Americans. Sputnik 1 helps identify the density of the upper atmosphere by measuring changes in its orbit and providing data on the distribution of radio signals in the ionosphere. Because the satellite's body is filled with high-pressure nitrogen, Sputnik 1 also provided the first opportunity for meteorite detection, because the loss of internal pressure caused by meteoroid penetration can be seen in the temperature data it transmits to Earth. Sputnik 2 was launched on November 3, 1957 and carried the first living creature into orbit, a dog named Laika. In May, 1946, Project Rand issued a preliminary design for an experimental world-circling spacecraft, stating that, "a satellite vehicle containing the appropriate instrumentation can be expected to be a powerful scientific tool for the twentieth century". America has been thinking about launching orbiting satellites since 1946 under the Bureau of Aeronautics of the United States Navy (Bureau of Aeronautics of the United States Navy). The US Air Force's Project RAND eventually issued the above report, but did not suggest that the satellite had potential as a military weapon; however, they regard it as a tool of science, politics, and propaganda. In 1954, the US Secretary of Defense stated, "I am not aware of any American satellite programs."

On July 29, 1955, the White House announced that the United States would want to launch a satellite in the spring of 1958. This became known as Project Vanguard. On July 31, the Soviets announced that they would launch a satellite in the fall of 1957. Following pressure from the American Rocket Society, the National Science Foundation, and the International Geophysical Year, interest in the armed forces increased and in early 1955 the U.S. Air Force and Navy worked on Project Orbiter, which used the Jupiter C probe to launch satellites. The project was a success, and Explorer 1 became America's first satellite on January 31, 1958. In June 1961, three and a half years after Sputnik 1's launch, the U.S. Air Force made use of facilities from the United States Space Surveillance Network. to catalog a total of 115 satellites orbiting the earth. The largest man-made satellite currently orbiting the earth is the International Space Station. A satellite is an object in space that rotates following the earth's rotation. Satellites can be distinguished based on their shape and uses, such as: weather satellites, communication satellites, science and technology satellites and military satellites. To be able to operate the satellite is launched into orbit with the help of a rocket. Developed countries such as the United States, Russia, France and recently China, already have stations to launch satellites into orbit. There are three kinds of satellite positions in their orbits, namely, all satellite movements are monitored from the earth or better known as control stations. The way the satellite works is by way of uplink and downlink. Uplink is the transmission sent from the earth to the satellite, while downlink is the transmission from the satellite to the earth station.

Anaximenes was a philosopher who came from the City of Miletos, just like Thales and Anaximanders. Anaximenes was a contemporary of the two philosophers, although he was younger than Anaximander. He is mentioned in the Western philosophical tradition, along with Thales and Anaximander, as a member of the Miletus School. Anaximenes was a friend, student, and successor of Anaximander. Like the other two Miletus philosophers, he spoke of natural philosophy, that is, what is the basic principle (arche) of all things. Anaximenes believed that air was the origin of the world. This is because it is air that pervades all of nature and air is also the basis of life for humans, which is very necessary for breathing. For him soul is air, fire is diluted air, and air when condensed becomes water; if it is compacted again it becomes soil and finally becomes stone. About his life history, not much is known. Anaximenes rose to fame around 545 BC, while the year of his death is estimated to be around 528/526 BC. He is known to be younger than Anaximander. He wrote one book and from that book only one fragment is still preserved today. One of the difficulties in accepting Anaximander's philosophy of metaphysical to apeiron is how to explain the interplay between the metaphysical and the physical. For this reason, Anaximenes no longer saw something metaphysical as the basic principle of everything, but returned to a physical substance, namely air. Unlike water, which is not found in fire (Thales thought), air is a substance that is present in all things, whether water, fire, humans, or everything else. Therefore, Anaximenes argued that air is the basic principle of all things. Air is the substance that causes all things to exist, have appeared, or will appear as some other form.

These changes proceed according to the principle of "condensation and rarefaction." When air increases in density, wind, water, earth, and then rock appear. On the other hand, when air is diluted, fire appears. This condensation and dilution encompasses all natural occurrences, as water can turn into ice and vapor, and how all other substances are formed from the combination of air changes.The formation of the universe according to Anaximenes is from the condensation and dilution of air which forms water, earth, rock, and etc. The earth, according to Anaximenes, is flat, broad, and thin, almost like a table. The earth is said to be suspended in the air as a leaf is suspended in the air. Heavenly bodies such as the moon, stars, and sun are also suspended in the air and revolve around the earth. These celestial bodies are fire in the sky, which appears due to the moist breath of earth. Stars do not produce heat because they are far from Earth. When the stars, moon, and sun are not visible at night, it is because they hide behind high parts of the earth as they orbit the earth. Then clouds, rain, snow, and other natural phenomena occur due to air compaction. The human soul is seen as just a collection of air. The proof, humans need to breathe to survive. The soul is what controls the body and keeps everything in the human body moving as it should. Because it is useful for maintaining the continuity of the soul and body. Here, Anaximenes posits the similarities between the human body and the universe based on the same basic unitary principle, namely air. The theme of the body as a microcosm (small universe) which reflects the universe as a macrocosm is a theme that will often be discussed in Greek Philosophy.

Marxism is an ideology based on the views of Karl Marx. Initially, Marx compiled a major theory related to the economic system, social system, and political system. Followers of this theory are referred to as Marxists. Marxism includes dialectical materialism and historical materialism and their application to social life. Marxism is the basis of the theory of modern communism. This theory is contained in the book The Communist Manifesto written by Marx and Friedrich Engels. Marxism is a form of Marx's protest against capitalism. He considers that capital collects money at the expense of the proletariat. The condition of the proletariat is very sad because they are forced to work long hours with minimum wages, while the results of their work are only enjoyed by the capitalists. Many proletarians have to live in the suburbs and slums. Marx argued that this problem arose because of "private ownership" and control over wealth which was dominated by the rich. In order to prosper the proletariat, Marx believes that the understanding of capitalism needs to be replaced with the understanding of communism. If this condition continues, according to Marx, the proletariat will rebel and demand justice. This is the basis of marxism. Marxism is a system of thought that combines three intellectual traditions which were still highly developed at that time, namely German philosophy, French political theory, and English economics. Marxism cannot simply be categorized as "philosophy" like other philosophies, because it contains a major philosophical dimension and even exerts a tremendous influence on many subsequent philosophical thoughts. That is why it is impossible to ignore it in the history of modern philosophy. In putting forward this theory, Marx was heavily influenced by Hegel. Even today, Marxists still use Hegel's terminology. It would be a good idea to mention here one by one the ideas of Hegelianism which are also an important content of Marxism: From these ten similarities, an increasingly complex material quantity can turn into a new quality.

The Precambrian (or Pre-Cambrian, also sometimes abbreviated as pꞒ, or Cryptozoic) is the earliest part of Earth's history, dating back to the present-day Phanerozoic Eon. The name precambrian comes from the time span that occurred before the Cambrian, the first geological period of the Phanerozoic Eon. The name Cambrian comes from Cambria which is the Latin name for the area of ​​Wales where parts of this period were first studied. The Precambrian time span makes up nearly 88% of the Earth's total geological time. The Precambrian is an informal unit of geological time, which is divided into three eons (Hadean, Archean, Proterozoic). This division of the period stretches from the formation of the earth, which is about 4.6 billion years ago (Ga) to the beginning of the Cambrian period, which is about 542 million years ago (Ma), when living things with hard shells first appeared. The movement of the Earth's tectonic plates causes the formation and breakdown of continents and land masses over time. This movement sometimes forms supercontinents which are the largest or all of the largest and most contributing groups of existing terrestrial masses. Vaalbara was the first known supercontinent, which formed 3.636 billion years ago from a collection of proto-continents. Vaalbara went through a split some 2.845–2.803 Ga ago. Then, the Kenorland supercontinent formed around 2.72 Ga ago and then split apart at 2.45–2.1 Ga into proto-craton proto-continents called Laurentia, Baltica, Yilgarn Craton and Kalahari. The Colombian supercontinent, or Nuna, formed about 2.1–1.8 billion years ago and broke up about 1.3–1.2 billion years ago. The supercontinent Rodinia is thought to have formed around 1300–900 Ma, it accounted for most of Earth's land mass and continents and then split into eight continents around 750–600 million years ago.

Fluorine is a chemical element with the symbol F and atomic number 9. It is the lightest of the halogens and occurs under standard conditions as a very toxic pale yellow diatomic gas. As the most electronegative element, it is highly reactive, as it reacts with all other elements except argon, neon and helium. Among all the elements, fluorine ranks 24th in universal abundance and 13th in terrestrial abundance. Fluorite, the principal mineral source of the fluorine which gives the element its name, was first described in 1529; because it was added to a metal ore to lower its melting point in order to make smelting easier, the Latin verb fluo meaning 'to flow' gave the mineral its name. Proposed as an element in 1810, fluorine proved difficult and dangerous to separate from its compounds, and several early researchers died or suffered injuries as a result of their experiments. It wasn't until 1886 that the French chemist Henri Moissan isolated elemental fluorine using low-temperature electrolysis, a process still used for modern production. Industrial production of fluorine gas for uranium enrichment, its greatest application, began during the Manhattan Project in World War II. Due to the high cost of purifying pure fluorine, most commercial applications use fluorine compounds, with about half of the fluorite mined being used in steelmaking. The remaining fluorite is converted to corrosive hydrogen fluoride on its way to various organic fluorides, or to cryolite, which plays a key role in aluminum refining. Molecules containing carbon–fluorine bonds often have very high chemical and thermal stability; their main uses are as refrigerants, insulating electrical and cookware, and PTFE (Teflon). Drugs such as atorvastatin and fluoxetine contain C−F bonds.

Fluoride ions from dissolved fluoride salts inhibit cavities, and are therefore used in toothpaste and water fluoridation. Global fluorochemical sales total over US$69 billion annually. Fluorocarbon gases are generally a greenhouse gas with a global warming potential 100 to 23,500 times that of carbon dioxide, and SF6 has the highest global warming potential of any known substance. Organofluorine compounds often persist in the environment because of the strength of the carbon–fluorine bond. has no known metabolic role in mammals; some plants and sea sponges synthesize organofluorine toxins (most commonly monofluoroacetate) that help prevent predation. The fluorine atom has nine electrons, one fewer than neon, and the electron configuration is 1s22s22p5: two electrons in the inner shell that are filled and seven in the outer shell that require one more to be filled. The outer electrons are ineffective at shielding the core, and experience a high effective nuclear charge of 9 − 2 = 7; this affects the physical properties of the fluorine atom. The first ionization energy of fluorine is the third highest of all the elements, behind helium and neon, which complicates the removal of electrons from the neutral fluorine atom. It also has a high electron affinity, second only to chlorine, and tends to gain electrons to be isoelectronic with the noble gases neon; it has the highest electronegativity of any element. The fluorine atom has a small covalent radius, about 60 picometers, similar to that of its neighbors in the same period, oxygen and neon. note 1] The bond energy of difluorine is much lower than that of Cl2 or Br2 and is similar to that of a peroxide bond that is easily cleaved; this, together with high electronegativity, leads to easy fluorine dissociation, high reactivity, and strong bonding with nonfluorine atoms.

Babylon (Greek: Βαβυλωνία, Babylon), full Babylonian Empire or Babylonian State, was an ancient Akkadian-speaking state and cultural region located in central southern Mesopotamia (now Iraq and Syria). In 1894 B.C.E., the Amorites established a small sovereign state that also included the administrative city of Babylon. During the time of the Akkadian Empire (2335–2154 BC), Babylon was just a small city in one of its tributaries. This situation changed during the time of the Old Babylonian Empire. Babylon During Hammurabi's reign, Babylon was enlarged and made the capital. Throughout and after Hammurabi's reign, Babylonia was called "Land of the Akkadians" (Akkadian: Māt Akkadī) in memory of the former glory of the Akkadian Empire. In the Christian Bible and the Hebrew Bible/Tanakh, the two countries of Babylon and the capital city of Babylon are referred to as Babylon, or simply the Land of Babylon. The term "Babylon" (Hebrew: בָּבֶל‎ Bavel, Tib. בָּבֶל Bāḇel; Syriac: Hirjik Bāwēl, Aramaic: בבל Bāḇel; Arabic: بَابِل‎ Bābil) is interpreted in Genesis as "confusion", from the verb bilbél (בלבל, "toss about"). Babylonia was often involved in rivalry with the Assyrian Empire in the north and the Elamite Kingdom in the east. Although it did not last long, Babylon became a major power in the Mesopotamia region after Hammurabi (acting ca. 1792–1752 BC according to the Intermediate Chronology or ca. 1696–1654 BC according to the Short Chronology) a new empire, following in the footsteps of the glorious Akkadian Empire, the New Sumerian Empire , and the Old Assyrian Empire. Not long after Hammurabi died, the Babylonian Empire went into decline and returned to being a small kingdom. Like Assyria, the Babylonian Empire preserved written Akkadian (the language of the native peoples) for official affairs, although the founding kings were Amorites who spoke a Northwest Semitic language and the successor kings were Kasi speakers of one of the isolated language.

The Babylonian Empire also preserved the Sumerian language for religious matters (as well as the Assyrian Empire), although Sumerian was no longer the spoken language at the time the Babylonian Empire was founded, having been completely replaced by Akkadian. The customs of the Akkadians and the Sumerians from ancient times became a major element in Babylonian and Assyrian culture. The Babylonian region remained a major center of culture, even after the Babylonian Empire was colonized by other countries. The oldest written record mentioning the existence of the city of Babylon is a clay tablet from the reign of King Sargon the Great (2334–2279 BC) around the 23rd century BC. At that time Babylon was only a city of religion and culture, not yet a big city, let alone an independent city-state. The city of Babylon was then subject to the Akkadian Empire, a state that united all Akkadian and Sumerian-speaking peoples under one government. After the fall of the Akkadian Empire, southern Mesopotamia was under the control of the Gutians decades before the founding of the New Sumerian Empire, which ruled over all of Mesopotamia (except for the northern region of Assyria), including the city of Babylon. The history of Mesopotamia has been going on for a long time before Babylon was born. The Sumerian civilization emerged in the area around 3500 BC, while Akkadian-speaking societies emerged in the 30th century BC.[citation needed] In the 3rd millennium BC, an intimate cultural symbiosis developed between Sumerian and Akkadian speakers, which includes the expansion of bilingualism. The influence of the Sumerian language on Akkadian and vice versa is evident in all aspects, from the massive absorption of vocabulary, to the combination of syntax, morphology, and phonology. This fact has led scholars to call the Sumerian and Akkadian languages ​​in the 3rd millennium a sprachbund.

Nutrients or nutrients are organic substances needed by organisms for the normal function of body systems, growth, and maintenance of health. Research in the field of nutrition studies the relationship between food and drink on health and disease, especially in determining the optimal diet. In the past, research on nutrition was limited to preventing malnutrition and determining basic nutritional requirements (standards) in living things. This figure for basic nutritional needs is known internationally as the Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA). Along with scientific developments in the medical and molecular biology fields, medical evidence shows that RDA is not sufficient to maintain optimal body function and prevent or help treat chronic diseases. Medical evidence shows that the root of many chronic diseases is oxidative stress caused by an excess of free radicals in the body. The use of nutrients at an optimal level, known as Optimal Daily Allowance (ODA), is proven to be able to prevent and treat oxidative stress thereby helping to prevent chronic diseases. This optimal level can be achieved if the amount and composition of nutrients used are appropriate. In disease management, the use of nutrition as a complementary medicine can help the effectiveness of treatment and at the same time overcome the side effects of treatment. Therefore, nutrition / nutrition is closely related to optimal health and increased quality of life. The results of measuring can be done with the method of anthropometry. While the science of nutrition is the study of the relationship of food and drink to the health of the human body so that it does not experience nutritional disorders, where nutritional disorders themselves are diseases caused by a lack of certain vitamin substances that cause our bodies to experience nutritional disorders. The first nutritional disorder to be discovered was scorbut in 1497 or more popularly known as sprue.

At that time Vasco da Gama on his voyage to Indonesia had lost more than half of his crew who died from this disease. Referrals are needed] It was only at the beginning of the 20th century that medical experts were able to confirm that this disease was caused by a lack of vitamin C. At this time most of the population Indonesia is experiencing a nutritional surplus rather than a nutritional deficiency. In 2007 the mortality rate due to non-infectious diseases reached 59.5 percent or clearly exceeded the mortality rate due to infectious diseases. In 2015, the Ministry of Health launched the "G4 G1 L5" program or a maximum of 4 tablespoons of sugar (50 grams), 1 teaspoon of salt (5 grams) and 5 tablespoons of oil (67 grams). Nutrition Science (Nutrience Science) is the study of everything about food in relation to optimal health / body. Unfortunately, today's food can be said to have very little nutrition. approximately 1 month in the distribution process causes the nutritional content in the fruit to also decrease. The slogan 4 Healthy 5 Perfect was coined by Prof. Poorwo Soedarmo, known as the father of Indonesian nutrition in 1950. This slogan refers to the "Basic Four" slogan from America. The "Basic Four" were created in the 1940s to discourage the American diet which tended to be high in fat, high in sugar, and lacking in fiber. The composition of 4 healthy 5 perfect is as follows: 1. Staple Foods 2. Side dishes 3. Vegetables 4. Fruits 5. Milk At the world food conference held by FAO in 1992 in Rome and Geneva, among other things, it was determined that all developing countries which originally used a slogan similar to "Basic Four" changed to "Nutrition Guide for Balanced Diet".

The province (non-standard form: province) is the basis for formulating regional spatial planning policies and strategies for the province. A province is a territorial unit, often used as the name of an administrative administrative area under the territory of a state or state. The word is a borrowed word from the Dutch "provincie" of Latin origin and was first used in the Ancient Roman Empire, which was the main territorial and administrative unit of the Roman Empire's territorial possessions outside of Italy. They divided their territory into several "provinciae" (second in rank to the empire for territories outside of Italy). A province is almost always an administrative division within a state. The term province has been adopted by many countries. In some countries without actual provinces, "province" is a metaphorical term meaning "outside the capital". The word province comes from the Latin word "provincia" (singular; provinciae for plural), which means territory. It is likely composed of the words "pro" (in front of or on behalf of) and "vincia" (connected) or "vincere" (to win or control). Thus, a provincia was a territorial area controlled by a Roman official on behalf of his own government. In Indonesia, the government system mostly adopts the Dutch, so that the naming of the provinces is also taken from the Dutch language which actually comes from Latin as explained above. Based on the Big Indonesian Dictionary, the correct writing is "Provinsi", not "Provinsi". In France, the term "en province" still tends to mean "outside the Paris area". Equals in Peru ("en provincias", "outside Lima"), Mexico ("la provincia", "regions outside Mexico City"), Romania ("în provincie", "outside Bucharest"), Poland ("prowincjonalny", "regional"), Bulgarian ("в провинцията", "v provintsiyata", "in the regions"; "провинциален", "provintsialen", "regional") and the Philippines ("taga-probinsiya", "outside Metro Manila", sa probinsiya, "in the areas").

Likewise in Australia "provincial" refers to the part of the state outside the state capital. In Italian, "in provincia" generally means "outside the largest regional capitals" (such as Rome, Milan, Naples, etc.). Canada's constituent areas are also called provinces. At the time of the confederation, only the United Province of Canada/Province of Canada were called provinces, although the Provinces of Lower Canada and Upper Canada had existed previously. Other colonies began using the name "province" after they became constituent provinces of the Canadian Confederation. In Indonesia, it tends to originate from the customary era which entrenched the Islamic legal system from the 7th century Hijriyah, while during the colonial era from 1808 AD European culture entered the archipelago, but the original Indonesian culture of this system has been maintained by the native Indonesian people (society) until now. Rahman Syamsuddin's introductory book, the existence of customs regulations has existed since ancient times, namely the pre-Hindu animism era, customary law experts argue that customs at that time were used as guidelines by Malay people. This proves that Indonesia has its own cultural history. Indonesian culture is very different from western culture because there are differences in experience, from belief systems, religion, notions of time and spatial relationships. Moreover, in Indonesia itself there are many different cultures. This also makes Indonesia a country that is rich in cultural diversity, and because of this it is an attractive country. In this section, Indonesia socializes some of the do's and don'ts for westerners now so they can participate successfully and efficiently in Indonesian society. Not all political entities at the level below the state are called "provinces". In Arab countries, the level of government below the state is called muhafazah, usually translated as governorship.

Judaism or Judaism is an Abrahamic, monotheistic, and ethnic religion composed of the collective religious, cultural, and legal traditions and civilization of the Jewish people. It has its roots as an organized religion in the Middle East during the Bronze Age. Some scholars argue that modern Judaism evolved from Yahwism, the religion of ancient Israel and Judah, in the late 6th century B.C., and is thus considered one of the oldest monotheistic religions. Judaism is considered by Jewish religionists as an expression of the covenant that God made with the Israelites, their ancestors. It includes many texts, practices, theological positions, and forms of organization. The Torah, as it is commonly understood by Jews, is part of a larger text known as the "Tanakh". The "Tanakh" is also known to secular religious scholars as the Hebrew Bible, and to Christians as the "Old Testament". The additional oral tradition of the Torah is represented by later texts such as the Midrash and Talmud. The Hebrew word "torah" can mean "teaching," "law," or "instruction," although "Torah" can also be used as an umbrella term referring to any Jewish text that expands on or elaborates on the original Five Books of Moses. Representing the core of the Jewish spiritual and religious tradition, the Torah is both a term and a set of teachings that explicitly positions itself as encompassing at least seventy, and potentially an infinite number of aspects and interpretations. Judaism's texts, traditions, and values ​​greatly influenced later Abrahamic religions, including Christianity and Islam. Hebraism, like Hellenism, played an important role in the formation of Western civilization through its impact as a core background element of Early Christianity. Within Judaism, there are various religious movements, most of which arose from Rabbinic Judaism, which maintain that God revealed His law and commandments to Moses at Mount Sinai in the form of the Written and Oral Torah.

Historically, all or part of these statements were opposed by various groups such as the Sadducees and Hellenistic Judaism during the Second Temple period; the Karaites during the early and late medieval periods; and among segments of modern non-Orthodox denominations. Some branches of modern Judaism such as Humanistic Judaism can be considered secular or nontheistic. Today, the largest Jewish religious movements are Orthodox Judaism (Haredi Judaism and Modern Orthodox Judaism), Conservative Judaism, and Reform Judaism. The main source of differences between these groups is their approach to halakha (Jewish law), the authority of rabbinical traditions, and the significance of the State of Israel. Orthodox Judaism maintains that the Torah and halakha are of divine origin, eternal and unchangeable, and that they must be strictly followed. Conservative and Reform Judaism are more liberal, with Conservative Judaism generally promoting a more traditionalist interpretation of Judaism's terms than Reform Judaism. The typical Reformation position was that halakha should be seen as a set of general guidelines rather than as a set of restrictions and obligations that all Jews had to adhere to. Historically, special courts enforced halakha; today, this court still exists but the practice of Judaism is largely voluntary. Authority in theological and legal matters rests not with any one person or organization, but with the sacred and rabbinical texts and the scholars who interpret them. Jews are an ethnoreligious group including those born Jewish (or "ethnic Jews"), as well as those who have converted to Judaism. In 2019, the world's Jewish population is estimated at around 14.7 million, or about 0.19% of the total world population. About 46.9% of all Jews live in Israel and another 38.8% live in the United States and Canada, with the majority of the remainder living in Europe, and other minority groups scattered throughout Latin America, Asia, Africa, and Australia.

The state is an organization of sovereign power with a governance system that enforces order over people in a certain area. The state is also a region that has a system or rules that apply to all individuals in the region, and stands independently. The primary requirement for a state is to have people, have territory, and have a sovereign government. While the secondary requirement is to get recognition from other countries. The largest country in the world is Russia, while the largest population is China. The newest country is South Sudan which just gained its independence in 2011. There are two forms of state known in the world today, namely unitary and union (federation). A unitary state is a form of state in which the supreme power resides in the central government. Hierarchically, a unitary state is a single-composed state, which means that there are no states within the state. The unitary state is again divided into two, namely the system of centralization and decentralization. In a centralized system, all matters are regulated by the central government. Regions are tasked with carrying out orders from the center without being given authority. Whereas in decentralization, the regions are given the authority to manage their own household affairs (autonomy rights) according to the needs and regulations which are also regulated by the central government. Characteristics of a unitary state: Examples of unitary states are Great Britain, France, Indonesia and the Maldives. A union state (federation) is a form of state in which there are several states called states. There are countries that are a merger or the result of division of parts. In the United States, there are two types of government, namely the federal government and state government. The federal government usually manages the common affairs of all member states such as international relations, defence, currency, and communications.

A diamond or diamond (Dutch: briljant) is a valuable mineral object which is chemically a crystalline form, or allotrope, of carbon. Diamond is known for having special physical properties, especially its hardness factor which can reach the highest level of the Mohs hardness scale (10) and its ability to disperse light. These properties make diamond used in jewelry and various industrial applications. Diamonds are primarily mined in central and southern Africa, although significant diamond deposits have also been found in Canada, Russia, Brazil and Australia. About 130 million "carat" (26,000 kg) of diamonds are mined annually, which amounts to approximately US$9 billion. In addition, almost four times the weight of diamond is made in the lab as synthetic diamond which has a Mohs 11 hardness scale, which can only be made in a laboratory. Diamonds are mainly mined from volcanic pipes, where the diamond content comes from materials expelled from the Earth because the pressure and temperature are suitable for the formation of diamonds. In Indonesia, diamonds have long been mined in the Martapura area, South Kalimantan. Diamonds are found from within the bowels of the earth which are excavated either manually or by mechanization. Now most of the diamond miners have used mechanization, namely with a vacuum machine to suck up the excavated soil. Soil that is sucked up with water, is sorted through a screen. With his skills, the miner can distinguish ordinary stones, sand or diamonds. The newly obtained diamond is called "galuh" in the Martapura area. Galuh is still a raw diamond. To make it ready to use, diamonds must first be polished. Most people polish diamonds using traditional tools. This geology-related article is a stub.

The Republic of Cameroon is a unitary republic in central, and western Africa. It is bordered by Nigeria to the west, Chad to the northeast, the Central African Republic to the east, and the Republic of the Congo, Gabon and Equatorial Guinea to the south. Cameroon's coast is located on the Bay of Bonny, part of the Gulf of Guinea, and the Atlantic Ocean. The country is called "Africa in miniature" because of its diverse geology and culture. The area has beaches, deserts, mountains, rainforests, and savannas. The highest point is Mount Cameroon in the southwest, and the largest cities are Douala, Yaoundé and Garoua. Cameroon has more than 200 ethnic groups and languages. The country is also known for its distinctive style of music, particularly makossa and bikutsi, and for its national football team. English, and French are official languages. The early inhabitants of this area were the Sao culture around Lake Chad, and the Baka people in the southeast. Portuguese explorers reached its shores in the 15th century, and named the area Rio dos Camarões ("River of Prawns"), from which the name "Cameroon" arose. Fula tribal armies established the Adamawa Emirate in the north in the 19th century, and various ethnic groups in the west, and northwest established chiefdoms, and fondoms. Cameroon became a colony of the German Empire in 1884. After World War I, the territory was divided between France and Britain as a League of Nations mandate. The Union des Populations du Cameroun political party fought for independence but was outlawed in the 1950s. This party fought the French until 1971. In 1960, French Cameroon became independent as the Republic of Cameroon with president Ahmadou Ahidjo. The southern parts of British Cameroon merged in 1961 to form the Federated Republic of Cameroon. The country was later named the Unitary Republic of Cameroon in 1972, and the Republic of Cameroon in 1984.

Compared to other African countries, Cameroon is relatively stable. This made possible the development of agriculture, roads, railways, and the petroleum and timber industries. Yet many Cameroonians live in poverty as farmers. Power is held by president Paul Biya, and his party the Cameroon People's Democratic Movement, and corruption is entrenched. The Anglophone community is feeling increasingly alienated from government, and Anglophone politicians are calling for decentralization or even secession. The area now known as Cameroon was first settled in the Neolithic age. The longest-standing residents are Pygmy groups such as the Baka. The Sao culture emerged near Lake Chad around 500 AD, and was replaced by the kingdom of Kanem, and then the kingdom of Bornu. Various kingdoms, fondoms, and chiefdoms also appeared in the west. Seafarers from Portugal reached the coast of Cameroon in 1472. They saw an abundance of prawns, and crabs in the river Wouri, and named it Rio dos Camarões (river of prawns), from which the word "Cameroon" was derived. After that, European traders and missionaries came to Cameroon and entered the interior. In the early 19th century, Modibo Adama led an army of Fula tribes in a jihad in the north against non-Muslims, and founded the Adamawa Emirate. These people who fled from the Fulani army then settled in various areas. The German Empire colonized Cameroon starting in 1884, and moved inland. They started a project to improve the infrastructure with the slavery system. With the defeat of Germany in World War II, Cameroon became a League of Nations mandate territory, and was divided into the French Cameroun area, and the British Cameroons area in 1919. France then merged Cameroun's economy with the French economy, and improved infrastructure with investment, skilled labour, and slavery. The British ruled their area from neighboring Nigeria.

The name calorie is used for two units of energy. Although this unit is part of the metric system, its use in the International System of Units has been replaced by the joule. One small calorie is about 4.2 joules (so one large calorie is about 4.2 kilojoules). The factor used to convert calories to joules at a given temperature is equivalent to the specific heat capacity of water expressed in joules per kelvin per gram or per kilogram. The exact conversion factor depends on the definition adopted. Despite its unofficial status, the large calorie is still widely used as a unit of food energy. The small calorie is also often used for measurement in chemistry, although the values ​​involved are usually recorded in kilocalories. The calorie was first defined by Nicolas Clément in 1824 as a unit of heat energy, and entered French and English dictionaries between 1841 and 1867. The term calor comes from the Latin calor meaning "heat". The energy required to raise the temperature of water of a given mass by 1°C depends on the atmospheric pressure and initial temperature. Therefore, there are several different definitions of calories. Pressure is usually taken at standard atmospheric pressure (101.325 kPa). The increase in temperature can be expressed as one kelvin, which is equal to a one degree Celsius increase. ≈ 0.003964 BTU≈ 1,163 × 10−6 kWh≈ 2,611 × 1019 EV ≈ 0.003985 BTU≈ 0.001168 KWH≈ 2,624 × 1022 EV ≈ 0.0039671 BTU≈ 0.011626 KWH≈ 2,6124 × 1023 EV ≈ 0.003964 BTU≈ 0.001162 KWH≈ 2,610 × 1022 EV ≈ 0.003971 BTU≈ 0.00116 KWH≈ 2.62 × 1022 EV ≈ 0.0039683 BTU≈ 0.011630 KWH≈ 2,6132 × 1023 EV ≈ 0 0 .0039683 BTU≈ 0.011630 kWh≈ 2.6132×1023 eV The calorie was first defined specifically for the measurement of energy in the form of heat, especially in calorimetry experiments.

In the context of nutrition, the kilojoule (kJ) is the international unit for food energy, although the kilocalorie is still commonly used. In this context confusion often arises. The term calorie is very often used for something that should be kilocalories of nutritional energy. Sometimes, in one case to break up the confusion, it's written slightly to Calories (with an uppercase "K") simply to try to differentiate, though this is not universal, and not widely understood. To facilitate comparison, specific energy or energy density values ​​are often given, for example "calories per serving" or "kilocalories per 100 g". Nutritional or intake requirements are often expressed in calories per day. In other scientific contexts, the term calorie almost always refers to a small calorie. Although not an SI unit, it is still used in chemistry. For example, the energy released in a chemical reaction per mole of reactant is often expressed in kilocalories per mole. Generally, this use is due more to its convenience for laboratory calculations of reactions, especially in aqueous solutions: the volume of a reactant dissolved in water to form a solution, with a concentration expressed in moles per liter (1 liter equals 1 kg), will cause a change in temperature in degrees Celsius for the total solvent volume of water, and this quantity (volume, molar concentration, and temperature change) can then be used to calculate the energy per mole. It is also sometimes used to express energy quantities related to reaction energies, such as the enthalpy of formation and the size of activation barrier. However, its use has been superseded by the SI unit, the joule, and some of its multiples such as the kilojoule. In the past, bomb calorimeters were used to determine the energy content of food by burning a sample and measuring the change in temperature in the surrounding water. Currently, this method is not commonly used in the United States and has been replaced by calculating the energy content indirectly from the sum of the energy provided by energy-containing food nutrients (such as protein, carbohydrates, and fats), the Modified Atwater system.

A calorimeter is a tool used to measure the amount of heat (heat) involved in a chemical change or reaction. A bomb calorimeter is a tool used to measure the amount of heat (calorie value) released in complete combustion (in excess O2) of a compound, food, fuel. A number of samples are placed in an oxygenated tube immersed in a heat-absorbing medium (calorimeter), and the sample is ignited by an electric flame from a metal wire attached to the tube. An example of a bomb calorimeter is a food calorimeter. A food calorimeter is a tool for determining the calorific value of carbohydrate, protein or fat food substances. This tool consists of a glass tube with a height of approximately 19 cm and a diameter of approximately 7.5 cm. The base is curved upwards to form an enclosure. The lid is closed with a rubber stopper with a hole in the middle. The top of the glass tube is covered with a circular ebonite plate. Inside the glass tube was a stirrer, the handle of which pierced the ebonite lid, as well as a copper spiral tube. The lower end of the spiral pipe passed through the rubber stopper on the stopper and the upper end through the central ebonite cap. In the ebonite lid there is another hole, where to insert a thermometer into the glass tube. The glass tube was placed on top of an asbestos chip and held in place by 3 pieces. The chip is a square with a side of approximately 9.5 cm. Under the piece of asbestos there is a power cable that will be connected to a power source when used. On top of the asbestos was an aluminum cup. Above the cup hung a nickel wire that connected to the electrical wires under the asbestos chip.

ImmigrationIllegal immigrationCitizenshipNaturalizationLeave to RemainStateless AlienIllegal ImmigrantsPeople without a stateMigrant workersAdministrative detaineesPolitical prisonersRefugeesCitizensNative nationalsDual citizensNaturalized citizensImmigration lawIllegal immigrationNationalismCitizenship lawNativism (politics)Nativism is an ideology that creates and maintains the sovereignty of a nation by realizing a concept of shared identity for a group of people who have goals or ideals the same ideals in realizing the interests of the nation. Including nationalism is the desire to defend the nation, both from the internal and external realms. The nationalists consider the nation is based on some "political legitimacy". Derived from the theory of romanticism, namely "cultural identity", liberalism debate which considers political correctness is sourced from the will of the people, or a combination of both theories. Ties of nationalism grow in society when the mindset begins to decline. This bond occurs when humans begin to live together in a certain area and do not move from there. At that time, the instinct of self-defence played a very important role and encouraged them to defend their country, where they lived and depended. From this the embryo of the growth of this bond, which in fact is weak and of low quality. This bond can also be seen in the animal world when there is a threat of foreign parties wanting to attack or conquer a habitat. However, if the atmosphere is safe from enemy attacks and the enemy is driven from the country, this power will vanish. In modern times, nationalism refers to political and military practices based on ethnic and religious nationalism, as stated above. Political scientists usually concentrate their investigations on extreme nationalisms such as Nazism, exile and so on. Nationalism can highlight itself as part of a state ideology or popular (non-state) movement based on the opinions of citizens, ethnicity, culture, religion and ideology. These categories are usually related and most nationalist theories mix some or all of these elements.

Civic nationalism (or civic nationalism) is a type of nationalism in which the state derives political correctness from the active inclusion of its people, the "will of the people"; "political representative". This theory was originally built by Jean-Jacques Rousseau and became writing materials. Among his well-known writings is a book entitled Du Contract Sociale (or in Indonesian "About the Social Contract"). Ethnic nationalism is a type of nationalism in which the state derives political correctness from the original culture or ethnicity of a people. Built by Johann Gottfried von Herder, who introduced the concept of Volk (German for "people"). Romantic nationalism (also called organic nationalism, identity nationalism) is a continuation of ethnic nationalism in which the state derives political correctness by nature ("organic") the result of nation or race; in the spirit of romanticism. Romantic nationalism is dependent on the embodiment of ethnic culture that adheres to romantic ideals; the story of tradition that has been designed for the concept of romantic nationalism. For example, Herder's "Brothers Grimm" is a collection of stories related to ethnic Germans. Cultural Nationalism is a type of nationalism in which the state derives political correctness from shared culture rather than "hereditary traits" such as skin color, race and so on. The best example is the Chinese people who think that the state is based on culture. The racial element has been reversed where the Manchus and other minority races are still considered as Chinese citizens. The willingness of the Qing dynasty to adopt Chinese customs testifies to the integrity of Chinese culture. In fact, many Taiwanese people consider themselves Chinese nationalists because of their cultural similarities but reject the PRC because the PRC government has communist views. State nationalism is a variation of civic nationalism, always combined with ethnic nationalism. Nationalistic feelings are so strong that they are given priority over universal rights and freedoms.

Urine, urine, urine, or urine is the remaining fluid excreted by the kidneys which will then be excreted from the body through the urinary tract in the urination process. Urine excretion is needed to remove residual molecules in the blood that are filtered by the kidneys and to maintain body fluid homeostasis. However, there are also several species that use urine as a means of olfactory communication. Urine is filtered in the kidneys, carried through the ureters to the bladder, and finally excreted out of the body through the urethra. Urine consists of water with dissolved materials in the form of metabolic waste (such as urea), dissolved salts, and organic matter. The fluids and materials that make up urine come from the blood or interstitial fluid. The composition of the urine changes during the reabsorption process when molecules important to the body, eg glucose, are reabsorbed into the body via carrier molecules. The remaining fluid contains high levels of urea and various excess or potentially toxic compounds that will be excreted from the body. The material contained in urine can be identified through urinalysis. Urea contained in urine can be a good source of nitrogen for plants and can be used to accelerate compost formation. Diabetes is a disease that can be detected through urine. The urine of a person with diabetes will contain sugar that will not be found in the urine of a healthy person. The main function of urine is to remove waste substances such as poisons or drugs from the body. It is generally accepted that urine is a "dirty" substance. This is related to the possibility that the urine comes from an infected kidney or urinary tract, so that the urine will also contain bacteria. However, if the urine comes from healthy kidneys and urinary tract, medically speaking, urine is actually quite sterile and most of the odor produced comes from urea.

Indigenous people (also known as natives or indigenous people) are people who are descended from the original inhabitants of a place, and have built their culture in that place with original (indigenous) status as an ethnic group who are not immigrants from other areas. Examples of indigenous peoples include: the Indians in the United States, the Maori in New Zealand, the aboriginal people in Australia, and the Ainu in Japan. Indigenous people are autochthonous (attached to a place), while groups of overseas people from certain ethnic groups—who have long left their ancestral lands—are called diaspora, for example the Chinese in Indonesia, the Javanese in Suriname, the Japanese in America, and the Jews in Indonesia. Russia. In some countries, indigenous groups are divided into several ethnic groups. For example, in China (China), there are dozens of ethnic groups; the largest number is the Han (漢) who are native Chinese with a percentage of 91.51% of the total Chinese population (since 2010). Although there are 56 registered ethnic groups recognized by the government, not all are indigenous to China; some minorities are from Russia, Korea, and Tajikistan. In Indonesia there are hundreds of ethnic groups that do not come from outside the Archipelago, which are called Indigenous-Nusantara; the majority are Javanese with a total of more than 95 million people or around nearly 100 million people, followed by the Sundanese, Malay, Batak, and Madurese. During the Dutch colonial period, "Natives" was used as a Malay term for the Inlanders, a group of the Dutch East Indies population who were the original tribes of the Indonesian Archipelago. Therefore, Indonesians of Chinese, Indian, Arab descent (all included in one group, Vreemde Oosterlingen or "Foreign Easterners"), Europeans, or mixed (Indos) are often grouped as "non-indigenous" even though they have been born several generations in Indonesia.

Aristotle (Greek: 'Aριστοτέλης Aristotleēs), (384 BC – 322 BC) was a Greek philosopher who became the teacher of Alexander the Great. He became a student of Plato while in Athens. Aristotle studied from Plato for 20 years. During his life, he wrote about philosophy and other sciences, namely physics, politics, ethics, biology and psychology. Aristotle divided philosophy into four issues, namely logic, physics, metaphysics and practical knowledge. Analysis of philosophy is done using a syllogism. Aristotle's thoughts regarding logic which utilize the deductive method are used as the basis for formal logic. Aristotle also believed that the existence of science was intended to support human life. Aristotle was born in a small town called Stagira in 384 BC. The city is part of the Kalkidiki peninsula. Aristotle's upbringing was carried out by his family in Atarneus, Anatolia. This condition was caused by his father dying at a young age during a trial in Pella, Central Macedonia. His father's occupation was as a physicist. At first, Aristotle was a student of Plato. But he later rejected some of Plato's thoughts and started his own philosophical thought. Aristotle founded an educational and research center called the Lyceum. Through this place, he conveyed his thoughts which then influenced the thinking of other philosophers, theologians or scientists. Aristotle lived in an environment that supported cultural and intellectual creativity. During his lifetime, the city-states of Greece were divided by the defeat of Athens by Sparta in the Peloponnesian War in 404 BC. The long-running conflict between the Greek city-states ended when Philip II of Macedon conquered these countries and founded the Macedonian Empire. Aristotle lived under the reign of Philip II of Macedon's son, Alexander the Great. During this time, he became a student of Plato who wrote many dialogues.

Aristotle developed his own philosophical system at this time. Aristotle believed that abstractions form categories that can be applied to objects of thought. Aristotle considered that human thought transcends the three types of abstractions that make up philosophy, namely physics, mathematics and metaphysics. Man transcends physics when he begins to think while making observations. During thinking, the human mind escapes from observations that use the senses to feel everything that can be felt by its existence. General knowledge is then known from particular and real things. Physics knowledge is then formed through abstract knowledge and human reason. Furthermore, the abstraction of mathematics enables humans to understand invisible matter. Reason detaches itself from everything that can be understood. All the material characteristics of this abstraction then produce science. Meanwhile, the abstraction of metaphysics appears after humans do abstraction of physics. In the third abstraction, humans have been able to think about the reality of all matter along with its origins and purposes for its formation. Aristotle considers this abstraction to be the first philosophy. Aristotle used the term "first philosophy" instead of metaphysics because according to him all philosophy was derived from this abstraction. The first philosophy in Aristotle's view can be interpreted into two senses. The first is as science which is the first principle. While the second is a science that discusses existence as an existence along with the characteristics of objects. Aristotle argued that the method of discovering new knowledge and truth is divided into two. First, the inductive method and the second is the deductive method. The inductive method aims to conclude specific things into a general conclusion. Meanwhile, the deductive method only concludes the truth of two things that are certain and undoubted. The nature of the deductive method is to conclude from something that is general to be specific.

Sodium is a chemical element in the periodic table that has the symbol Na and atomic number 11. It is a soft, silvery-white, and highly reactive metal. Sodium is an alkali metal, in group 1 of the periodic table, because it has one electron in its outer shell which it easily donates, creating a positively charged atom—the Na+ cation. The only stable isotope is 23Na. The free metal does not occur in nature, but must be prepared from its compounds. Sodium is the sixth most abundant element in the Earth's crust, and occurs in many minerals such as feldspar, sodalite and halite (rock salt, NaCl). Many sodium salts are highly soluble in water: sodium ions have been leached by the action of water from Earth's minerals over thousands of years, and thus sodium and chlorine are the most common dissolved elements occurring in the oceans (by weight). Sodium was first isolated by Humphry Davy in 1807 by electrolysis of sodium hydroxide. Among many other useful sodium compounds, sodium hydroxide (lye) is used in soap making, and sodium chloride (table salt) is a deicing agent and nutrient for animals including humans. Sodium is an essential element for all animals and some plants. Sodium ions are the main cation in the extracellular fluid (ECF) and therefore a major contributor to ECF osmotic pressure and ECF compartment volume. Loss of water from the ECF compartment increases sodium concentration, a condition called hypernatremia. Isotonic loss of water and sodium from the ECF compartment reduces the size of that compartment in a condition called ECF hypovolemia.
