By means of a sodium-potassium pump, a living human cell pumps three sodium ions out of the cell instead of the two potassium ions it pumps in; comparing the concentrations of ions across the cell membrane, from inside to outside, potassium is about 40:1, and sodium, about 1:10.

In nerve cells, electrical charges cross the cell membrane enabling the transmission of a nerve impulse—an action potential—when the charges are dissipated; sodium plays an important role in that activity. Sodium at standard temperature and pressure is a silvery soft metal which reacts with oxygen in air to form grayish-white sodium oxide unless immersed in oil or inert gas, which are the usual storage conditions. Sodium metal can be easily cut with a knife and is a good conductor of electricity and heat, having only one electron in its valence shell, resulting in weak metallic bonds and free electrons, which carry energy. Due to its low atomic mass and long atomic radius, sodium is the 3rd lowest density metallic element of all metals and one of only three metals that can float in water, the other two being lithium and potassium. The melting (98°C) and boiling (883°C) points of sodium are lower than those of lithium but higher than those of the heavier alkali metals (potassium, rubidium and cesium), following periodic trends down the group from top to bottom. This property changes dramatically with increasing pressure: at 1.5 Mbar, the color changes from silvery to black; at 1.9 Mbar it becomes transparent with a red tint; and at 3 Mbar, sodium is a clear, transparent solid. All of these high pressure allotropes are insulators and electrids. In a flame test, sodium and its compounds produce a yellow color because sodium's excited 3s electrons emit photons as they return from 3p to 3s; the wavelength of this photon is on the D line of about 589.3 nm. spin–orbit interactions involving electrons in the 3p orbitals split the D line into two, at 589.0 and 589.6 nm; the hyperfine structure involving both orbitals causes more lines.

– in Europe  (green & gray)– in the European Union  (green) Hungary (Hungarian: Magyarország) is a landlocked country in central Europe. The country lies in the Carpathian Basin and is bordered by Austria to the west, Slovakia to the north, Ukraine to the east, Romania to the southeast, Croatia and Serbia to the south, Slovenia to the southwest. In the local language, the country is known as Magyarország which means "Magyar region". Hungary forms the Visegrád group with Poland, Slovakia and the Czech Republic. The largest city and capital is Budapest. Hungary is also a member of NATO, the European Union, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, and the Schengen Agreement. The official language is Hungarian, which is the most widely spoken non-Indo-European language in Europe. After centuries of occupation by Celts, Romans, Huns, Slavs, Gepids and Avars, the kingdom of Hungary was formed in the late 9th century by the great Hungarian prince Arpad. His grandson Stephen I rose to power in AD 1000, turning it into a Christian kingdom. The Kingdom of Hungary lasted for 946 years and at times became the cultural center of the Western world. After the Battle of Mohács and occupation by the Ottoman Empire (1541-1699), Hungary became part of the Habsburg Empire, which later formed part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. The current state boundaries are based on the Treaty of Trianon (1920) after World War I. The country lost over 71% of its territory, 58% of its population and 32% of ethnic Hungary. On the Axis side, Hungary also suffered heavy losses in World War II. During more than four decades of communist rule (1947-1989), the country came under worldwide scrutiny for the 1956 Revolution and the opening of its borders with Austria in 1989, previously closed by the Iron Curtain, which precipitated the collapse of the Eastern Bloc.

On October 23, 1989, Hungary again became a democratic parliamentary republic, and is now a developing country. Hungary is also famous as a popular tourist destination by attracting 10.2 million visitors in one year (2011). The country is home to the world's largest heated cave and second largest thermal lake (Lake Héviz), Central Europe's largest lake (Lake Balaton), and Europe's largest natural meadow (Hortobágyi). In the time of the Roman Empire, the Romans called the region Pannonia (west from the Danube river). After Rome fell under the migration of Germanic tribes and pressure from the Carpians, the Migration Period continued to bring many invaders. First came the Huns, who built a powerful empire under Attila. The name "Hungary" is probably influenced by the Huns, although it is also possible that it derives from the name of a 7th century Turkic alliance called Onogur. After Hun rule waned, other Germanic tribes, namely the Lombards and Gepids ruled in Pannonia for about 100 years. It was also during this time that Slavic tribes began to migrate south. In the 560s, they were replaced by the Avars who would rule the land for more than two centuries. The French under Charlemagne from the west and the Bulgars from the southeast finally managed to overthrow the Avars in the early 9th century. Soon, the Franks withdrew, and the Great Slavonic kingdom of Moravia and the Principality of Balaton controlled most of Pannonia until the end of the century. Finally, the Magyars migrated to Hungary in the late 9th century. Tradition holds that the Magyars (Hungary) were founded by Árpád, who led the Magyars to the Pannonian plains after 895.

Ribosomes are small and dense organelles found in cells and serve as a site for protein synthesis. Ribosomes are present in the cytoplasm and attached to the ER membrane during the process of protein synthesis. If the process of protein synthesis does not take place, the ribosome will form a small sub-unit and a large sub-unit. Ribosomes are also the cell components that make proteins from all amino acids. Ribosomes are about 20 nm in diameter and consist of 65% ribosomal RNA and 35% ribosomal protein. Cells with high rates of protein synthesis have many ribosomes, for example human liver cells have several million ribosomes. Ribosomes are composed of various types of proteins and a number of RNA molecules. Ribosomes are composed of RNA and protein. Ribosome ARN consists of Ribosome ARN (ARNr), but when undergoing protein synthesis other ARNs are involved, such as Ambassador ARN (ARNd) and Transfer ARN (ARNt) attached to ribosomes. ARNd functions as a transmitter of genetic information about proteins that must be synthesized, while ARNt functions to provide the types of amino acids that will be processed into proteins. Based on the composition of prokaryotic and eukaryotic bodies, the arrangement of ribosomes consists of large subunits and small subunits. In prokaryotes, the small subunit has a sedimentation coefficient of 30S (Svedberg unit), while the large subunit is 50S. However, when combined the sedimentation coefficient becomes 70S. In eukaryotic bodies, the small subunit has a sedimentation coefficient of 40S, while the large subunit is 60S. However, as a unit, eukaryotic bodies have a sedimentation coefficient of 80S. 50S 5S 23S 31 Kinds 60S 5S 5,8S 28S 49 Kinds Ribosomes can also translate mrNA to form proteins using the amino acids carried by tRNA during the translation process.

The Javanese-Sundanese religion (current name — Sunda Wiwitan aka Sunda Wiwitan Madrais) is a belief system of a number of people spread across the Cigugur District, Kuningan, West Java. This religion is also known as Karuhun Urang Way (tradition of ancestors), Sundanese Wiwitan religion, Madrais teachings or Cigugur religion. The Javanese-Sundanese religion (ADS), which was established around 1925 in Cigugur, is one of the local religions as well as a growing indigenous community in West Java. This is because ADS, besides believing in and defending the teachings of its predecessor, Kyai Madrais, also tries to preserve the traditional heritage of their ancestors. As a local religious minority group, ADS often experience obstacles and threats in the form of state bans and discriminatory actions from the majority official religion group which makes this community increasingly marginalized and pressured politically and culturally. In religious life, Kelurahan Cigugur is an area whose inhabitants embrace various religions. This is evidenced from population data which shows the number of religious adherents in the Cigugur Village consists of various religions, namely 4,075 Muslims, 2,620 Catholics, 195 Protestants, 176 believers, 12 Buddhists, and 6 Hindus. Residents in Cigugur are diverse, plural in nature, even within a family there is a diversity of religions, the religions of parents and children are different. The diversity of religions embraced by residents in Cigugur does not cause relations between adherents of different religions to be tenuous and rigid. The attitude of tolerance and mutual respect between them actually looks harmonious. Harmonious relations, evidenced by the existence of cooperation and mutual cooperation between religious communities in the construction of various houses of worship in Cigugur. Al-Hidayah Mosque which was founded on January 1, 2005.

This mosque was built in an area where the majority of its citizens are Catholics, but they are trying to help build a mosque to make it easier for the Muslim community to worship. The founder of Madrais is Prince Sadewa Alibasa Kusuma Wijaya Ningrat, who is known as Prince Madrais or Kyai Madrais. Madrais is the son of Prince Alibasa (the ninth Prince of Gebang) from his marriage to R. Kastewi, the fifth descendant of Tumenggung Jayadipura Susukan. When he was born his name was Prince Sadewa Alibasa who in the family tree is called Prince Surya Nata or Prince Kusuma Adiningrat. Madrais was born in Susukan Ciawi Gebang in 1822. Then in 1825 he was entrusted to Ki Sastra Wedana, a Kuwu in Cigugur with the hope that one day he would be able to continue the struggle of his ancestors against the invaders. To trick the Kompeni, it was willed that the child be recognized as the child of Ki Sastra Wadana. It was later discovered that he was not the son of Ki Sastra Wadana, but the son of R. Kastewi from Susukan Ciawigebang, whose father was not explained. At the age of 10, Prince Kusuma Adiningrat worked for Kuwu Sagarahiang as a buffalo herder known as Taswan. When he was leaving Sagarahiang, he advised his friends that his real name was Madrais (short for Mohamad Rais), son of Ki Sastra Wadana from Cigugur. Around 1840 Prince Kusuma Adinigrat returned to Cigugur and from time to time he traveled around West Java. Until finally he returned to Cigugur and founded peguron / pesantren and taught Islam. He is popularly called by the name of Kyai Madrais. The name Kyai Madrais is also well known in the Heubel Isuk and Ciwedus Islamic Boarding Schools (Gebang area) as an intelligent and influential person. Apart from teaching Islam, he also conveyed the teachings of religions in order to find common points in Belief in the One and Only God.

– in Africa  (light blue & dark gray)– in the African Union  (light blue) The Republic of Kenya (Swahili: Jamhuri yes Kenya, English: Republic of Kenya) is a country located in the East African region. The capital and largest city of Kenya is Nairobi, while the oldest city, the second largest and the first capital is Mombasa. The country is bordered by Somalia to the east, the Indian Ocean to the southeast, Tanzania to the south, Uganda to the west, South Sudan to the northwest and Ethiopia to the north. Geography, climate, and population vary widely. From the cold snow-capped mountain peaks (Batian, Nelion, and Lenana Peaks on Mount Kenya) with its vast surrounding forests, wildlife, and fertile agricultural areas to the temperate climates of the west, the rift valley regions, and dry and semi-arid regions. -Arid less fertile and absolute deserts (Chalbi Desert and Nyiri Desert) can be found in Kenya. With an area of ​​580,367 square kilometers (224,081 sq mi), Kenya is the 48th largest country in the world by area. With a population of over 47.6 million at the 2019 census, Kenya is the 29th most populous country in the world. In 2020, Kenya is the third largest economy in sub-Saharan Africa after Nigeria and South Africa. Many animal fossil discoveries by Paleontologists in Kenya. About 200 Cretaceous dinosaur fossils have been excavated at several sites. Among them are giant crocodile fossils that come from the Mesozoic Age, and are estimated to be around 200 million years old. The fossils were discovered by researchers from the University of Utah and the National Museum of Kenya in August 2004 in Lokitaung Gorge, near Lake Turkana.

The discovery at Lake Turkana that hominids such as Homo habilis (1.8 and 2.5 million years ago) and Homo erectus (1.8 million to 350,000 years ago) may have been direct descendants of modern Homo sapiens and lived in Kenya during the Pleistocene. . In 1984 a discovery by renowned paleonthropologists Richard Leakey and Kamoya Kimeu unearthed the bones of a Turkana boy who was a Homo erectus from 1.6 million years ago. The earliest research into hominids was carried out by Louis Leakey and Mary Leakey, who were responsible for early archaeological research at Olorgesailie and Hyrax Hill. Subsequent work was done by Glynn Isaac. North Africans moved to Kenya around 2000 BC. Arab traders began visiting the Kenyan coast in the early first century. As Kenya's proximity to the Arabian Peninsula invited colonization, Arab and Persian settlements developed along the coast in the 8th century. In the early millennium, Nilotic and Bantu peoples began to move into the area, and still make up three-quarters of Kenya's population. Several centuries before the colonization of white people/Europeans, Kenya was part of the eastern part of the African continent which was routinely used by Arabs to find slaves who could be sold in markets. Initially these slave seekers came from Arabia, but later they also came from Zanzibar (like Tippu Tip). The Ameru people descended from slaves who had fled from Arab lands around 1700. Swahili, a Bantu language that uses many Arabic words, developed into the lingua franca of trade in many circles. The Portuguese were the first Europeans to explore Kenya, Vasco da Gama visited Mombasa in 1498.

The Republic of Barbados is an island nation located on the border of the Caribbean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. Summarizing one of the islands of the Lesser Antilles, Barbados is located in the eastern part of the group. Barbados is known for its tourism industry and is known as the Little England or 'Little England' of the Caribbean. This is due to the strong British influence on this island. The island of Barbados is located 2,585 km southeast of Miami, United States of America and 860 km from Caracas, Venezuela. The original inhabitants of this island are the Arawak tribe. The tribe was later driven out by the Caribbean Indians in the early 14th century. In the early 15th century Spanish conquistadors arrived in Barbados and had taken the Caribbean tribes as slaves. As a result, the rest of these clans have moved to adjacent islands. Portuguese explorer Pedro a Campos had stopped on this island in 1536 during his journey to Brazil. He had named this island Los Barbados ('those who bear the beard'), probably after seeing the island's 'fig' tree, which had long hanging roots hanging down like a beard. Barbados was uninhabited when the English came to settle in 1627. Captain John Powell landed on Barbados in 1625 and declared this deserted island a British colony. Two years later, his brother Captain Henry Powell landed with 80 sailors and 10 slaves. The group had founded the first European settlement at Jamestown, on the West coast and now known as Holetown. By the end of 1628 the population of the colony had grown to 2,000 people. After a few years, colonists have cleared a lot of wilderness and planted tobacco and cotton. In the 1640s they replanted these fields with sugarcane. Their fields were the largest sugarcane fields in the Caribbean, and the production of sugar brought in a very good profit for the growers and smokers of Barbados.

Due to the high demand for sugar, the slaves were brought from the African continent and worked in the existing sugar plantations until 1834 when the slavery system was abolished. But the economy of Barbados still depends on sugar, "rum" and "molasses" until the 20th century. In 1639, the settlers on this island formed a Legislative Assembly, which was the second parliament established in the British colony after Bermuda. All this time the people of Barbados were loyal to the King and after King Charles I was beheaded in 1649, Oliver Cromwell, the Prime Minister of Great Britain sent his army to Barbados to get their recognition. His army arrived in 1651 and a year later the 'Articles of Capitulation' were signed, which were the basis of the "Charter of Barbados". This charter guarantees the government of Barbados headed by a governor, independent representation, and freedom from taxation without local authority. When the King system was restored in 1660, this Charter gave more freedom to the people here. Racial discrimination is rampant on this island. Although the slavery system was abolished in 1834, there were still many slaves who were more comfortable living on the plantations. Blacks who refused to be slaves, were forced to live in wild settlements. When the economy fell (known as (The Great Depression) in the 1930s, unemployment increased, and living conditions became more and more acute until chaos broke out in these islands. To overcome political instability, the British had to give in to the black reformers and involve they into the country's political process. One of them was, Grantley Adams, who 1 decade later was appointed as the first Prime Minister. Barbados achieved self-governing status in 1961 and achieved independence in 1966.

Philolaos is a philosopher belonging to the Pythagorean School. Apart from being a philosopher, he is also known as a doctor and also a writer. He was the first philosopher of the Pythagorean School to issue a written work. His name is mentioned in collections of medical theory as early as the 5th century BC. In addition, there is information about him from a papyrus found in the British Museum. There are only a few fragments of his writings that are still preserved today. One of his famous works is "About Nature" (On Nature). Philolaos was from Croton. He was born around 470 BC. After the Pythagorean school in Kroton was destroyed and its members scattered, he left and settled in Thebes. Then he left again and settled in Targentum. The two students of Socrates who accompanied him in his last moments were also known as students of Philolaos. Philolaos states that there are two principles in all that exists. These two principles he called "the finite" and "the infinite." Although different, the two are united by "order". Thus, everything comes from different elements that are united by this "order". In addition, everything that exists can also be identified by numbers. The reason is that if everything that exists is finite, then it can be separated from one another. If something can be separated, it means that something can always be counted. Therefore, everything "limited" that humans know will always be able to be calculated. Regarding the universe, Philolaos argues that the first thing that came into "order" was the so-called "fire furnace". This "furnace" is located at the center of the universe. Thus, the universe is seen as a unit. Existence begins at the center, the "furnace," and expands in all directions.

Speech is an expression of thoughts in the form of words addressed to the crowd to express congratulations, welcome guests, commemorate certain holidays, and various other forms of activity. In essence, speech includes the art of monologue in speaking skills. Speech is two-way, that is, the speaker must pay attention to the other person even though the speaker dominates the conversation. The interlocutor must listen to the messages conveyed by the speaker in the form of words (verbal) or not words (non-verbal) so that what is conveyed can be received and understood perfectly. Speeches are usually delivered by leaders or people who are considered important to provide direction or advice to their listeners, because the function of speeches is to provide information, advice, motivation, warnings, and knowledge. In order for the speech to be delivered to be well received by the audience, the utterances or sentences must be properly and neatly arranged according to the rules of the language in force. Sentences that are arranged sequentially and systematically so that they are pleasant to listen to and can give a positive impression to those who listen. Broadly speaking, the structure of a speech consists of: This method is a method in which the person delivering the speech reads the speech text that has been prepared beforehand. The manuscript is compiled, then read in full from the beginning to the end of the speech. This speech method is commonly used in delivering formal and official speeches, such as state speeches, government remarks, or reports from official institutions. This method does not need to carry a script or other text because the speaker memorizes the entire contents of the speech. Speech texts are also prepared beforehand, but they are not brought before the public. Speeches with this method are commonly used among students or novice public orators. Among students, the speech memorizing method is intended for the learning process.

The memorization method is also applied in various speech contests. The advantage is that it is fluent if you really memorize it, there's nothing wrong if you really memorize it, and the speaker's eyes can see the listener. The weakness is that the speaker tends to speak quickly without understanding, cannot adjust to the situation and listener's reaction, and if he forgets his speech fails miserably. Impromptu is a method of delivering a speech without preparing a script, small notes, or memorizing it beforehand. The delivery is impromptu. The speaker directly spoke according to what he knew and crossed his mind. This method can only be conveyed by people who have high flying hours as orators. He is accustomed and professional in conveying his thoughts in public. The advantage is that the presentation of speech material feels fresher and more interesting. The weakness is that the speech is not smooth and chaotic for novice speakers and the possibility of failing to convey the contents of the speech properly is quite large. Outlining the Outline The speaker prepares the main points of the speech and then arranges them in the form of a speech outline. In addition, the speaker also makes special notes needed in the speech. In speeches the framework is developed directly and the notes are reviewed when needed. Giving a speech by outlining this framework is highly recommended because of its flexibility. The speaker is guided by the outline of the speech he has created. Thus, the contents of the speech can be delivered coherently and nothing is forgotten. Meanwhile, the speaker is free to look at the listener to build inner contact. The speaker is also free to adjust his speech according to the situation and listener's reaction. If the outline and notes can be memorized, the speaker can appear without carrying a piece of paper. This is of course even better because the speaker can concentrate more on improving the quality of his speech to make it more interesting. The advantages of this speech method are that the main contents of the speech are not forgotten, the delivery of the contents of the speech is coherent, the possibility of mistakes is small, and it is communicative.

Bipolar junction transistor or bipolar junction transistor (English: Bipolar junction transistor or abbreviated BJT or Bipolar transistor) is a type of transistor. It is a three-channel device made of doped semiconductor material. Dipole is so named because its operation includes both electrons and electron holes, as opposed to polar transistors such as FETs which use only one of the carriers. Although a small proportion of the transistor current are majority carriers, nearly all of the transistor current is due to the minority carriers, so a BJT is classified as a minority-carrier device. The NPN transistor can be thought of as two diodes backed by a single anode. In normal use, the emitter-base p-n junction is forward biased and the base-collector junction is reverse biased. In an NPN transistor, for example, if a positive voltage is applied across the base-emitter junction, the balance between the heat-generated carriers and the repelling electric field in the depletion region becomes unbalanced, allowing heat-disturbed electrons to enter the base region. These electrons wander (or scatter) through the base from an area of ​​high concentration near the emitter to a low concentration near the collector. The electrons in the base are called minority carriers because the base is doped to be p-type which makes the holes the majority carriers in the base. The base area of ​​the transistor must be made thin, so that the carriers can propagate through it more quickly than the minority carriers age in the semiconductor to reduce the number of carriers combining. back before reaching the collector-base junction. To ensure this, the thickness of the base is made much lower than the scattering length of the electrons. The collector-base junction is reverse biased, so very little injection of electrons occurs from the collector to the base, but electrons spreading through the base towards the collector are swept towards the collector by the field at the collector-base junction. The collector-emitter current can be viewed as being controlled by the base-emitter current (current control) or the base-emitter voltage (voltage control).

This view deals with the current-voltage relationship of the base-emitter junction, which is simply the usual exponential current-voltage curve of a p-n junction diode. The physical explanation for the collector current is the sum of the minority charge carriers in the base region. A detailed model of transistor behavior, the Gummel–Poon model, calculates the distribution of these charges explicitly to describe transistor behavior more precisely. This view of charge-control simply handles the phototransistor, where the minority carriers in the base region are generated by absorption of photons, and handles dynamic shutdown or recovery time, which depend on charge recombination in the base region. However, because base charge is not a signal that can be measured in the line, current and voltage control views are commonly used in circuit design and analysis. In analog circuit design, current control views are often used because they are nearly linear. The collector current is approximately βF{\displaystyle \beta _{F}} times the base current. Some basic circuits can be designed by assuming that the base-emitter voltage is approximately constant, and that the collector current is beta times the base current. However, to accurately and reliably design BJT circuits, a voltage-control model (eg the Ebers–Moll model) is required. The voltage-controlled model requires the exponential function to be considered, but if this is linearized, the transistor can be modeled as a transconductance, as in the Ebers–Moll model, the design for circuits such as the differential amplifier becomes a linear problem, so the voltage-control view is often preferred. For translinear circuits, where the exponential I–V curve is the key to operation, the transistor is usually modeled as voltage controlled with a transconductance proportional to the collector current. A dipole transistor experiences some characteristic delay when it is turned on and off. Almost all transistors, especially power transistors, suffer from a long base shelf life which limits the operating frequency and switching speed.

Sarawak, popularly known as Bumi Kenyalang (/səˈrɑːwɒk/; Indonesian: saˈrawaʔ]) is a de facto sovereign country that became independent on 22 July 1963, and de jure is also one of the states (now a constituent country) in Malaysia. This state has autonomy in administration, immigration, and judiciary that is different from the states in Peninsular Malaysia. Sarawak is located in the Northwest of Borneo and is bordered by the State of Sabah in the Northeast, West Kalimantan Province, East Kalimantan Province, and North Kalimantan Province in the South, and also meets Brunei in the Northeast. The capital, Kuching, is the economic center of Sarawak State. Sarawak and the seat of the Sarawak state government. Other cities in Sarawak include Miri, Sibu and Bintulu. According to the 2015 census of Malaysia, the state's population is 2,636,000 people. Sarawak has an equatorial climate with tropical rainforests and diverse species of animals and plants. The state has several important cave systems in Gunung Mulu National Park. The Rajang River is the longest river in Malaysia; The Bakun Dam, one of the largest dams in Southeast Asia, is located in one of its tributaries. Mount Murud is the highest point in Sarawak. The earliest human settlement in Sarawak dates back 40,000 years in the Niah Caves. According to whom?] The area had trading links with China in the 8th to 13th centuries AD. The area came under the influence of the Bruneian Empire in the 16th century. The state was ruled by the Brooke family in the 19th and 20th centuries. During World War II, the state was occupied by the Japanese for three years before being created as a British Crown Colony in 1946.

On July 22, 1963, Sarawak achieved self-rule by the British. After that, Sarawak became one of the founding members of the Federation of Malaysia (founded on 16 September 1963) together with North Borneo (Sabah), Singapore (left in 1965), and Federation of Malaysia (Peninsula Malaysia). However, the federation was opposed by Indonesia, and led to the Indonesia–Malaysia Confrontation for three years. The state also experienced a communist rebellion from 1965 to 1968. The area is known for its ethnic, cultural and linguistic diversity. The head of state is the Governor, now known as Yang di-Pertua Negeri, while the head of government is the Chief Minister. The government system follows the Unitary system. The region is divided into districts and administrative divisions. English and Malay are the two official languages ​​in the state; there is no official religion there. The Sarawak State Museum is the oldest museum in Borneo. The area is known for its traditional musical instrument, the sapeh. The World Rainforest Music Festival is one of the premier music events in Borneo. Sarawak has a diversity of natural resources, and its economy is highly export-oriented, especially oil and gas, timber and palm oil. Other industries include manufacturing, energy and tourism. According to the most commonly accepted explanation, the word "Sarawak" comes from the Sarawak Malay language, sarawak, which means antimony. Meanwhile, according to another popular explanation, the word Sarawak is a shortening of four Malay words which are said to have been uttered by Prince Muda Hashim (uncle of the Sultan of Brunei), I surrender to the crew (I leave it to you), when he gave Sarawak to James Brooke in 1841 However, such an explanation is incorrect, as the area was already called Sarawak before Brooke's arrival, and the word "awak" was never in the Sarawak Malay vocabulary prior to the formation of the Malaysian state.

Bangkok, officially known as Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Thai: กรุงเทพมหานคร, กรุงเทพมหานคร (help·info)) or Krung Thep (กรุงเทพฯ), is the capital and largest city of Thailand. The city is located on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River, near the Gulf of Thailand. Bangkok is one of the fastest growing cities, with a dynamic economy and progressive society in Southeast Asia. The city is developing into a regional hub that can rival Singapore and Hong Kong, but it still suffers from infrastructure and social problems as a result of its rapid development. Bangkok has long been a gateway for foreign investors seeking new markets in Asia. The city is also noted as one of the cities in the world with the fastest rate of adding skyscrapers. Rich in cultural sites make Bangkok one of the most popular tourist destinations in the world. Bangkok Province is bordered by six other provinces: Nonthaburi, Pathum Thani, Chachoengsao, Samut Prakan, Samut Sakhon and Nakhon Pathom. The city of Bangkok (บางกอก (help·info)) was a small trading center and port on the West bank of the Chao Phraya river serving the Ayuthhaya Kingdom, the founders of modern Thailand which flourished from 1350 to 1767. It is believed that the name Bangkok comes from Bang Makok, Bang the Central Thai name for a town or village located on a riverbank, and Makok (มะกอก) is the Thai name for Spondias pinnata, Spondias mombin or Elaeocarpus hygrophilus (a plant that produces fruit like olives), or Bang Koh, Koh means "island", referring to an area carved by rivers and canals. After the fall of Ayutthaya to the Burmese Empire in 1767, the new king, King Taksin established a new capital city, Thonburi, in what is now Bangkok.

When Taksin's reign ended in 1782, Buddhist King Yodfa Chulaloke rebuilt the capital on the east side of the river and gave it the ceremonial name Krung Thep Mahanakhon Amon Rattanakosin Mahinthara Yuthaya Mahadilok Phop Noppharat Ratchathani Burirom Udomratchaniwet Mahasathan Amon Piman Awatan Sathit Sakkathattiya Witsanukam Prasit and then shortened to its now official name, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon. However, the new city also received the name Bangkok, which continues to be used by foreigners to refer to the entire area of ​​the city and is the official name in English, while in Thai the name Bangkok still refers only to the old city on the west bank of the river. The city has since been extensively modernized and underwent many changes, including the introduction of transportation and infrastructure during the reigns of Kings Mongkut and King Chulalongkorn, and quickly became the center of the Thai economy. Nama lengkap sangat resmi Kota Bangkok (nama pemberian) yang diberikan oleh Raja Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke, dan kemudian diralat oleh Raja Mongkut, adalah: Krung Thep Mah̄ā Nakhon Amon Rạttanakos̄inth Mah̄intharāyuṭthayā Mah̄ādilok P̣hoph Noppharạt Rātchaṭhānī Būrīrom Udom Rātchaniwet Mah̄ās̄at̄hān Amon Phimān Awatān S̄at̄hit S̄ạkkathạttiya Wits̄ʹaṇukampras̄ithṭha]กรุงเทพมหานคร อมรรัตนโกสินทร์ มหิน ทรายุธยา มหาดิลกภพ นพรัตน ราชธานี บูรีรมย์ อุดมราชนิเวศน์ มหาสถาน อมรพิมาน อวตาร สถิต สถิต วิษณุกรรม ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ ประสิทธิ์ immovable, the Great Capital of the World Endowed with Nine Precious Gems, the City of Happiness, full of immense Royal Palaces resembling Heaven where the reigns are the reincarnations of the Gods, a City bestowed by Indra and built by Vishwakarma". Local schools teach children the city's full name, although few can explain its meaning because many of the words are ancient and are now obsolete in spoken language, nor are they known to most people.

Manichaeism is also known as Manichaeism. The founder of this school is Mani. Maniism or Manichaeism (in Modern Persian آیین مانی Āyin e Māni; Chinese: 摩尼教; pinyin: Móní Jiào) was a dualistic religious school based on Maniic teachings. The main character of this school is Manichaeus, he was born in the village of Mardinu, in the Nahr desert of Kuta, South Babylon on April 14, 216. Iran's greatest gnostic, originated in Sassanid Persia. Although many of the original manuscripts of the founding prophet, Mani (Syriac, ���������, c. AD 210–276) have been lost, a number of translations and text fragments have survived. Manicism arose between the 3rd and 7th centuries, and at its heyday was one of the most widespread religions in the world. The churches and scriptures of Mani existed as far east as China and as far west as the Roman Empire. Manicism simply disappeared before the 16th century in southern China. The original six holy books of Manicism, in Syriac Aramaic, were translated into other languages ​​to help spread the religion. As it spread eastward, Mani's writings were published in Middle Persian, Parthian, Sogdian, and Uyghur and Chinese. As they spread westward, they were translated into Greek, Coptic, and Latin. The spread and success of Manicism was seen as a threat to other religions, and continued to be suppressed in Christian, Zoroastrian, Buddhist, and Islamic areas.

Bayer AG (/ˈbeɪ.ər, ˈbaɪ.ər/; German: ˈbaɪɐ]) is a German multinational pharmaceutical and life sciences company. Bayer is one of the largest pharmaceutical companies in the world. Headquartered in Leverkusen, Bayer's business areas include human and veterinary pharmaceuticals; retail health care products; agricultural chemicals, seeds, and biotechnology products. The company's shares are a component of the Euro Stoxx 50 stock market index. Werner Baumann has been Bayer's CEO since 2016. Founded in Barmen in 1863 as a dyes manufacturer, Bayer's first and most famous product was aspirin. In 1898, Bayer registered the name heroin as a trademark for its drug diacetylmorphine, then marketed it as a cough suppressant and non-addictive substitute for morphine until 1910. Bayer also introduced phenobarbital; prontosil, the first widely used antibiotic that won the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1939; Cipro antibiotics (ciprofloxacin); and the Yaz birth control pill (drospirenone). In 1925, Bayer was one of six chemical companies that combined to form IG Farben, the world's largest pharmaceutical and medical device company. The Allied Control Council confiscated IG Farben after World War II,a] because of his role in the Nazi war effort and involvement in the Holocaust, which included the use of forced labor from concentration camps and the purchase of humans for purposes of hazardous medical testing. In 1951, IG Farben was returned to its original form, which was split into six companies, and then split again into three companies, namely BASF, Bayer and Hoechst. Bayer played a key role in the Wirtschaftswunder in post-war West Germany, allowing it to quickly return to being the largest pharmaceutical and chemical company in the world.

In 2006, the company acquired Schering. In 2014, the company acquired Merck & Co.'s retail business, with brands such as Claritin, Coppertone and Dr. School's. In 2018, Bayer acquired Monsanto for $63 billion. Bayer CropScience develops transgenic crops and pesticides. Bayer AG was founded as a dyes manufacturer in 1863 in Barmen (later part of Wuppertal), Germany, by Friedrich Bayer and his partner, Johann Friedrich Weskott, a colorist. Friedrich Bayer is in charge of commercial activities. Fuhsin and aniline were initially the company's most important products. [citation needed] The headquarters and most of Bayer's factories were then moved from Barmen to the larger grounds of Elberfeld in 1866. Friedrich Bayer (1851–1920), son of Bayer's founder, was a chemist and joined the company in 1873. After Friedrich Bayer died in 1880, the company was registered as a legal entity under the name Farbenfabriken vorm. Friedr. Bayern & Co, also known as Elberfelder Farbenfabriken. citation needed] This company later moved from Elberfeld to Wiesdorf on the Rhine and occupied land owned by alizarin producer Leverkus and Sons. A new city called Leverkusen was founded there in 1930 and is the location of Bayer AG's head office to this day. The company logo, the Bayer cross, was introduced in 1904, and features the two words BAYER written vertically and horizontally, sharing a Y and surrounded by a circle. The bright version of the logo has become one of the icons at Leverkusen. Bayer's first major product was acetylsalicylic acid—first described by the French chemist Charles Frederic Gerhardt in 1853—as a modification of salicylic acid or salicin, a traditional ingredient found in papaya from the willow plant.

In general, poisons are solid, liquid, or gaseous substances, which can interfere with the life processes of an organism's cells. Toxic substances can enter the body through oral (mouth) and topical (body surface) routes. In relation to biology, a poison is a substance that causes injury, illness, and death to an organism, usually by chemical reaction or other activity on a molecular scale. The father of Toxicology, Paracelsus, stated that: Everything is poison and nothing is without poison. Only the dose that makes something non-toxic (Dose sola facit venenum). The term poison is synonymous with the word toxin and can, but has a different definition from one to another. The word "toxin" is defined as a toxin produced from a biological process, or often referred to as a biotoxin. Meanwhile, it can be defined as a liquid containing poison secreted or produced by animals during the process of self-defense or attacking other animals with bites or stings. The terms toxic, toxic, and venomous are also comparable words when used to describe the nature or effects of a poison. However, there are still slight differences in the three words. Toxic is used for anything that can be fatal or dangerous when put in a certain amount to living things. Meanwhile, toxic states the nature or effect of the toxin, and venomous refers to venom-producing animals. In a medical forensic book written by JL Casper, poisons are classified into 5 groups, namely: 1. Irritant poisons, namely poisons that cause irritation and inflammation. Examples are mineral acids, toxic fungi, and arsenic preparations. 2. The poison that causes hyperemia, is a narcotic poison, which has been shown to be fatal to the brain, lungs and heart. For example opium, tobacco, konium, dogitalis, etc.

3. Toxins that paralyze the nerves, by poisoning the blood, the central nervous organs can be paralyzed and cause fatal consequences such as sudden death. Examples are hydrocyanic acid, zinc cyanide, and chloroform. 4. The poison that causes marasmus is usually chronic and can be fatal to health slowly. Examples include white bismuth, lead smoke, mercury and arsenic. 5. Poisons that cause infections (septic poisons), can be food poisons which in certain circumstances cause Pyaemia (or pyemia) and typhoid fever in livestock. The early history of poison is closely associated with myths and beliefs. In 2500 BC, the Sumerians are known to have worshiped a poison goddess called Gula. In Greek mythology, there are several references to poison, among them the story of Medea, the granddaughter of Helios (the sun god). Medea wanted to kill her stepson Theseus with poisoned wine. However, this attempt was thwarted by Aegeus, Medea's husband. The oldest writings on poisons were found in Egypt and dated to around 3000 BC and documents on research into poisonous plants by Menes, king of Egypt. In Greek history, poison was used as a death sentence which was called State Poison. One of the philosophers who was executed in this way was Socrates. During the reign of the Roman empire, poisoning at dinner, especially among the upper class, became commonplace. This was one way to get rid of family members you didn't like, as Nero had done. Around 246 BC, China developed a drama called the Chou Ritual, in which there was a ritual of burning 5 kinds of poison. Entering the Middle Ages, in 8 AD, poisons developed because Arab chemists managed to turn arsenic into a tasteless and odorless powder so that the detection of poison was difficult to detect.
